                                               Books by the Author

1. The Race of Grace—introductory book in which performance-related themes (such as perseverance) are
    considered essential for rewards in heaven. Entrance into heaven, in contrast, is regarded as free. A strong
    defense of unconditional security derived from believers being given to Jesus is a particular strength of this
    book.
2. Is Heaven a Gift or a Reward?—while some assert that heaven is a reward in some sense, this book maintains
    that regarding heaven itself as a gift is best.
3. Breaking the Rocking Horse—introductory book regarding the distinction between having eternal life as a gift
    versus obtaining it as a reward. An overview of the outer darkness and an exegetical treatment of the parable of
    the soils are this book’s primary strengths.
4. Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity—a more comprehensive discussion regarding perseverance (and
    other performance-related themes) as being needed for rewards in heaven rather than for entrance into heaven.
    This book provides both introductory material and advanced treatments.
5. Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep—a rejection of the notion that profession of salvation is proven genuine by
    the way a person lives. This book focuses on the parable of the sheep and the goats and shows the inadequacy
    of conditional security in interpreting this parable.
6. Sheep and Goats—an advanced discussion of the parable of the sheep and goats that evaluates four
    interpretations that are compatible with unconditional security.
7. Sealed and Secure—a thorough defense of a popular argument for unconditional security that also defends the
    premise of unconditional promises.
8. Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection—an advanced defense of unconditional security which affirms that
    believers can fall from grace but not fall from perfection.
9. Salvation—a study of how the verb save (sozo) and the noun salvation (soteria) are used in the NT. A
    comprehensive chart of NT usage is provided.
10. Believe—an aspectual defense of unconditional security that examines how the verb believe is used in the
    Gospel of John. A comprehensive chart of metaphors for believe in the Gospel of John is provided also.
11. Carnal Corinth—an affirmation of the categorical existence of carnal Christians within the Corinthian epistles.
12. John in Living Color—a color-colored translation and reference manual of the Gospel of John that focuses on
    the grammatical and aspectual indications of unconditional security.
13. Dad, can I be sure I am saved?—an intermediate discussion of assurance.
14. Trichotomy—an advanced holistic dichotomous discussion of trichotomy with an integration of nikology.
15. Ordo Salutis—a Free Grace order of salvation.
16. Soteric and Mistholic Faith—an advanced discussion of the nature of faith.
17. Karpology—a discussion of the soteriological implications of singular versus plural fruit.
18. Predestination and the Open View—a discussion of predestination that focus on free will and the book of life
    from an open view.
19. Logic Tables and Diagrams—illustrations of logic with scriptural implications pertaining primarily to the
    soteriological and misthological arenas.
20. Drawing and Appointment—an examination of Calvinistic claims regarding drawing and appointment as found
    principally in Jn 6:44 and Acts 13:48.
21. The Outer Darkness—a magnum opus that ties together the author’s arguments for unconditional security and
    conditional rewards.

            See UnconditionalSecurity.org for the release status of these and other books by the author.

                                                         Introduction
        Although the biblical term outer darkness only occurs three times in Scripture (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30), it is
a subject of considerable significance in the ongoing debate between Lordship Salvationists (LS) and Free Grace
Salvationists (FG).* This debate has spilled over into the Calvinistic fountainhead from which Lordship Salvation
(LS) tends to spring. Leading writers from the Free Grace (FG) perspective—such as Hodges, Dillow, and
Stanley—tend to advocate understanding the outer darkness as part of a larger sphere of teaching concerning the
doctrine of rewards, while most Lordship Salvationists contend that it deals with salvation from hell.
        At the same time, variations offered by minority positions within the FG camp have not received significant
interaction from those advocating the more standardized position reflected by the FG writers above. Additionally,
the history of the interpretation of these passages pertaining to the outer darkness has not always been adequately
brought into the discussion. As a result, those advocating the soteriological† interpretation of the outer darkness
have assumed wrongly that the interpretation which connects it with rewards is a novel invention that has been
introduced by Hodges and others within FG as a reaction against LS. Thankfully, with the contribution of Faust’s
book The Rod, the historical backdrop of the topic is now coming into sharper focus. Yet, the minority perspective
that Faust and other likeminded individuals bring to the deliberation may cause some readers to shrink back from
fully considering the plausibility of interpreting the outer darkness in terms of rewards.
        This present study will outline the interpretive background of the outer darkness and interact with both the
LS and FG interpretations of the outer darkness. Further, in order to present the various options for interpreting the
outer darkness, it will interact with both the majority and minority FG positions. Hopefully, this interaction will
spark further dialogue between those advocating the majority and minority interpretations in the FG camp so that
they can benefit from one another, or to put it in biblical terminology, so that iron can sharpen iron (Prov 27:17).
One too often gets the impression that these two competing FG perspectives are ships passing in the night with
little communication between them. However, interaction will be necessary in order to evaluate the strengths and
weaknesses of both positions and, as a result, benefit from the distinctive FG nuances. Although the present work
will interact critically with some of Faust’s conclusions, nevertheless, his seeking to open up the lines of
communication between these positions by challenging the majority FG position is appreciated. Without a doubt,
the majority FG position needs to be challenged, not only by those inside the FG Camp such as Faust, but by those
outside it as well so that the FG hermeneutical sword may be sharpened to a keen edge by such interaction.
        The need for a sharp misthological sword is illustrated by an incident related by Carl Johnson in which a
well-known minister traveled a great distance to attend a prophecy conference in order to find the answer to one
question: Is the message of the outer darkness and the attendant teaching about weeping applicable to Christians at

*
  Lordship Salvationists are those who maintain that some form or degree of surrender to Christ as Lord of one’s life is biblically
necessary for salvation from eternal damnation. Actually, from an exclusively logical and biblical standpoint, those (such as myself)
who are opposed to today’s so-called Lordship Salvation affirm that the only way to be saved from hell is to submit to the Lordship of
Christ in terms of believing in Christ for eternal life. The Lord has commanded that we believe in Him for eternal life. Therefore, to
believe in the Lord Jesus for eternal life is to submit to the His lordship in terms of what is necessary for eternal life. Genuine
Lordship Salvationists correctly insist that one must submit to the Lord’s will as it pertains to having eternal life by believing in Jesus
(rather than one’s performance) for eternal life.
         As a theological term, however, the designation Lordship Salvation has come to be associated with those who condition
salvation from eternal damnation on one’s performance (or at least on one’s intent to change one’s performance). They frequently will
be referred to as pseudo Lordship Salvationists in this book because they refuse to submit to what the Lord actually demands for this
type of salvation—simple faith. Because of the popular association of the term Lordship Salvationists with these false advocates of
Lordship Salvation, however, unless noted otherwise, the popular association will be adopted by default so that the unqualified term
Lordship Salvation will be understood herein in the popular (rather than biblical sense) as denoting performance-based salvation.
         Free Grace Salvationists are those who insist that the biblical requirement for salvation from eternal damnation is that one
simply believes in the Lord Jesus for eternal life. This understanding is exemplified by the Grace Evangelical Society (GES) motto:
Faith Alone in Christ Alone. From their perspective, unconditional security is guaranteed upon the recognition that the free gift of
eternal life is offered freely to one who simply believes in Jesus Christ for eternal life.
†
  The general reader is probably familiar with the word theology, which is based on a combination of two biblical Greek words: theos
(God) and logos (teaching). Thus, theology refers to biblical teaching about God. In similar fashion, soteriology is based on two
biblical Greek words, soteria (salvation) and logos (teaching), and correspondingly refers to biblical teaching about salvation.
Although the biblical concept of salvation includes many dimensions other than deliverance from hell, it is this aspect of salvation to
which writers frequently refer when they use the word soteriology. Thus, salvation from hell (or more specifically, from eternal
damnation in the Lake of Fire) will be referred to as soteriological salvation or eternal salvation. Although such terminology is
somewhat ambiguous, this popular usage will be used in this book (unless indicated otherwise). Thus, a soteriological interpretation of
a passage would treat the passage as dealing with eternal salvation from the Lake of Fire.
Page 2                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
the Judgment Seat of Christ? This minister was having a miserable time trying to counteract the carnality and
complacency evident in his church among those who believed in eternal security. As he stated at the conference,

         I know I need a message from God to arouse my unfaithful members. To tell them of a limited
         reward in Heaven means nothing to them. To get into Heaven is all they desire. I need a message,
         brethren, with teeth in it.2

        The answer provided herein has teeth in it. My anticipation is that those reading the present work already
will have been exposed to material advocating a reconsideration of the doctrine of rewards written at a more
popular level. Wilkinson’s introductory work A Life God Rewards and Wilkin’s slightly more comprehensive work
The Road to Reward provide a good starting point for the layperson, as does Alcorn’s book The Law of Rewards.
Of course, with the new edition of the masterful work by Hodges Grace in Eclipse: A Study on Eternal Rewards,
now back into print, it certainly can be hoped that the laity will be exposed to sound fundamentals concerning this
neglected doctrine, especially since Hodges’ book deals with negative rewards at an introductory level.3 Alcorn’s
popular book Heaven will also be helpful in illustrating some of the positive rewards found in the present work.
Indeed, the present work might be seen as a counterbalance to this popular positive presentation in that Alcorn’s
exclusively positive outlook in Heaven seems to nullify the importance of his book on rewards. The present study
will show the outworking of rewards in heaven.
        In any event, such introductory works hopefully have whetted the believer’s appetite for a more thorough
explanation. Consequently, much of this present discussion will be set forth in a somewhat academic style in order
to accommodate a treatment of some of the more intricate details of the subject. Nevertheless, the general reader is
also encouraged to participate in this inquiry. And to aid the layperson in following along, a running glossary will
be provided in the footnotes, and a number of illustrations in the form of diagrams and charts have been supplied to
summarize, picture, or validate key points. Additionally, some of the more technical material will be allocated to
the appendices and endnotes. Further, practical descriptions of the material will be interwoven in the argumentation
to give the reader an interlude between some of the more in-depth discussion. The general reader would be well-
advised to read the footnotes, especially the glossary items, but may opt to gloss over the endnotes.
        Those wishing a more detailed interaction may refer to the endnotes and appendices in volume two. The
endnotes are listed in continuous sequence rather than chapter sequence in order to facilitate quick reference for
those who wish to peruse the technical material quickly. To reduce the number of endnotes, lexical entries
generally will be referenced within the text, particularly since such words easily may be looked up in a Greek
dictionary. Cross-references to the main body of the book and to the most pertinent sections of the appendices also
are supplied in the footnotes. Such cross-references must be limited to the most significant items, but a variety of
indexes at the conclusion of the present work, with pages ranked in terms of importance (as bold, normal, italic),
and a thorough table of contents at the beginning will aid those who wish to use this book as a reference manual in
evaluating and researching the material in more detail. References to the author’s other books supplied in the
footnotes will be lacking page numbers, but the indexes of those books will suffice for referencing the information.
This procedure will be necessary in that a number of those books have not yet been released and will be useful in
helping the reader quickly discern material contained in the present book from that of the author’s other books.
        Unfortunately, the pursuit of sound doctrine has come to be considered distasteful by our laity today. Wells
decries the fact that there no longer appears to be any place for theology in the church.4 The heartbreaking accuracy
of his insight is especially true concerning the doctrine of the outer darkness and the related truths that it represents.
These powerful parabolic accounts of the outer darkness are large picture windows providing comprehensive views
into vital areas of doctrine that have the power to reform us in thought and in action. These word pictures are much
too important to be limited to academic interests—these doctrines are intensely practical.
        What are we to tell our family members and friends who used to follow Christ but who no longer do so? Are
we to tell them that they have lost their salvation? Will we pass judgment on them as having never been saved to
start with? Will we advise them to ask Jesus into their heart again, even though this solution to their sin problem
did not work the first time? Answers to these questions are needed urgently, not only for encouraging others, but
also in dealing with temptation and unfaithfulness in our own lives. Are we to combat temptation with a fear of
hell? If so, then we cannot really be sure that we will be saved from hell. Not only is faithfulness at stake, but the
different responses to these questions necessarily involve competing understandings of the gospel itself. And the
Bible places a curse on those who fail to present the correct form of the gospel (Gal 1:8-9). In running away from
unfaithfulness, we do not want to run into a curse.
        The Great Commission commands us to make disciples, not mere converts. One of the greatest resources
that the biblical writers constantly use to encourage faithfulness and submission to the Lordship of Christ is the
Introduction                                                                                                                      Page 3
doctrine of eternal rewards. Jesus uses rewards, both positive and negative, to encourage believers to submit to His
Lordship. The outer darkness is part of the imagery that the Lord repeatedly uses to encourage full-fledged
discipleship on the part of those who already have trusted in Him as their Savior. If we want wholehearted devotion
to the Lordship of Christ in our churches, then we must employ the same images and doctrines in our pulpits. We
must follow the example of Jesus.
        Regrettably, most examinations of eschatology practically ignore the most important part of eschatology—
misthology (the doctrine of rewards).* A proper understanding of eschatology† is necessary in order to interpret
many misthological passages accurately. And vice versa, a proper understanding of misthology is crucial for
understanding not only eschatology but also soteriology (the doctrine of salvation). Consequently, the study of
eschatology is necessary for an accurate perception of soteriology, since the study of both doctrines is connected
inseparably with the study of misthology. In other words, one cannot have a proper grasp of salvation if one does
not understand rewards and what happens after a person dies. Conversely, one cannot understand rewards and what
happens after one’s death if one does not understand salvation. The length of this present book is due to the
endeavor to show the harmonious orchestration of these biblical truths.
        A well-grounded misthology, however, is not only made indispensable by these doctrines concerning the
past and the future, an industrial strength misthology is also urgently needed in order to encourage and motivate the
believer facing everyday pressures and temptations. This doctrine is a biblical antidote for laziness and
discouragement among the Christian ranks. It is strong medicine, but like any medicine it must be taken in order to
effect a cure. It does no good as long as it is confined to the bottle. Similarly, this doctrine will do no good as long
as it is bottled up in the Bible by neglect. The purpose of this present work is to dispense this medication by
examining those aspects of misthology that are most often passed over. Misthologists do not wish to dilute this
medicine, but neither can we allow it to be soured by well-meaning practitioners who make it more potent than
what is intended by the biblical writers; otherwise, the biblical doctrine of rewards will be so distasteful that many
needy patients may refuse to swallow it. At the same time, any sugarcoating must be considered biblically
impermissible. Some have put far too much sugar in this misthological medicine, even to the point of dilution and
thereby impeding its full-strength absorption.
        Most misthological examinations of the biblical text focus on the positive aspects of rewards. When biblical
rewards are mentioned from the pulpit in passing, the first (and sometimes only) thing that comes to the minds of
many Christians is the positive component of this teaching—namely that Christians get rewards and crowns in
heaven. Such a shallow perception of the wealth of biblical material concerning this edification results in a dilution
that robs the doctrine of rewards of almost all of its force. If the scriptural message is simply that all Christians get
rewards in heaven, then the way they live makes little real difference. A believer can afford to snooze through life
and ignore the biblical alarm ringing the wakeup call. As a result, the popular presentation of this instruction from
pulpits often results in a misunderstanding of the Bible that inoculates believers from experiencing the undiluted
power of God’s Word to encourage their hearts. This current examination, in contrast, will probe more deeply into
the negative aspects of this doctrine in order to combat the infectious disillusionment that currently exists. In doing
so, it will be necessary to deal with the various opinions concerning this area of misthology rather than to give just
one position and ignore the rest.
        When upgrading software, software manuals typically give the more experienced users (who are simply
upgrading their current version of the software) the opportunity to skip to the What’s New section. I will provide
my fellow FG misthologists that courtesy here as well. Understandably, the more advanced reader who is well-
acquainted with eschatological and misthological writings and who would like to advance to the new material in
this present work might be tempted to skip over the next section, as it is intended to give the general reader a crash
course in these matters. If this be the case, I would advise the advanced reader to read the next chapter carefully
and then skim over the remaining chapters of Part 1, before resuming a more critical reading in Part 2.


*
  Misthology is a coined term derived from the Greek words misthos (reward) and logos (teaching) and refers to the doctrine of
temporal and eternal rewards but will be used primarily in reference to eternal rewards, i.e., eschatological rewards. Some writers
prefer to use the word teleology and its derivatives to denote eschatological rewards. This usage is based on teleo (end) in
Rev 20:3,5,7 referring to the final consummation. But teleology would appear to be better suited to describe the doctrine of the end
time rather than a limited aspect of that period (e.g., rewards). But we already employ eschatology to describe the doctrine of the end
of time. Also, the occurrences in Rev 20:3,5,7 refer to the end of the millennium, to Satan, and to the lost. Thus, teleology is an
inferior designation for the doctrine of eschatological rewards, since eschatological rewards include the millennium and the saved and
are limited to a particular aspect of the end of time. For an expanded theological definition of misthology, see endnote 28.
†
  The word eschatology is derived from the Greek word, eschatos (last), and refers to the doctrine of the last days, i.e. the end of time,
and thus to the millennial and eternal states.
Page 4                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
      The next chapter is foundational, however, and provides a new acronym. It should be digested fully before
proceeding to the new material. This is not to say that there is nothing new under the sun in the remaining chapters
of Part 1—only that refinements there are not supercritical to those already thoroughly familiar with these
concepts. Nevertheless, there is an intricate discussion of the out-resurrection in Part 1 that even the more
advanced user should find engaging.

                                              Chapter 1.
                                 Parabolic and Eschatological Options
                                                          Introduction
        Before proceeding to discuss the interpretations and implications of the outer darkness, stating and
defending the presuppositions being employed in this endeavor will be necessary. Interpreting Scripture without
assuming certain presuppositions is simply not possible. Since the outer darkness is an eschatological doctrine,
understanding where it fits on the eschatological map is most desirable. The fundamental validity of the
progressive nature of revelation will be assumed: Subsequent Scripture tends to clarify what was said previously.
Consequently, later statements that clarify the matter should interpret statements that were unclear in an earlier
period.
        The phrase outer darkness occurs only three times in Scripture, and each of the three occurrences is found in
the gospel of Matthew (8:12; 22:13; 25:30). It is found in passages concerning the Table of the Kingdom, Parable
of the Marriage Feast, and Parable of the Talents. These passages will be considered in reverse order, since one
generally anticipates in progressive revelation that clarity will increase in subsequent revelations to the extent that
the last passage concerning the subject is probably the clearest one of all. Since it is hermeneutically* desirable to
interpret unclear passages in light of clearer passages, the last passage may at times provide a very fruitful point to
begin the hermeneutical inquiry. Anticipating the key role that the Parable of the Talents will assume, its twin
Lukan passage (the Parable of the Minas) will be analyzed briefly as well.
        At the same time, a preliminary decision must be made as to whether to interpret the parables in light of the
details found within those parables or to interpret (or even disregard) the details on the basis of the reputed central
meaning of the parable. Gordon Olson, in his book Beyond Calvinism and Arminianism: An Inductive Mediate
Theology of Salvation, calls for an inductive approach to biblical interpretation, especially when dealing with
doctrines pertaining to salvation. To a degree, the present work takes a similar approach, even when interpreting
parables. A loose reading of the text to get the big idea and then grinding or ignoring the details as to make them fit
the initial impression is an unsuitable methodology. The details are the beacons to the central point of the parable.
Yet if the details are ignored, one runs the risk of running aground on the rocks of premature conclusions.

Parables

                                               Deductive Approach
       Admittedly, this procedure is open to criticism. Basically, two different approaches to interpreting parables
are available—one deductive and the other inductive. A deductive approach takes the central truth of the parable
and then interprets (or ignores) the details on the basis of the central truth, whereas an inductive approach uses the
details to help determine the central truth and then seeks to determine what additional truth may be conveyed by
the details. Keathley† takes a deductive approach, and in doing so, he objects to the methodology that will be
adopted herein concerning the role of details in interpreting parables in general and in understanding the outer
darkness in particular. According to Keathley,

             The first thing to understand about parables is that you can’t make them ‘walk on all fours.’
        Every detail doesn’t necessarily correspond to some eschatological event. Parables typically have one
        main idea that answers some question or problem given in the preceding context. So, little details like
        the one where the guy is at the banquet don’t necessarily mean that he made it into heaven and then
        was removed. This is just rejection imagery.

             The second thing to understand is that Matthew’s eschatology was not as well developed as ours
        or even as well developed as Paul’s or John’s. Matthew is writing about the events of a Jewish

*
  Hermeneutics refers to the scientific art of biblical interpretation. As a science, it has rules which should be followed in performing
an exegesis of the text. These rules are helpful in providing boundaries and limiting options when interpreting the text. But the
application of these rules cannot be mechanically applied in such a way as to make one’s deductions a foregone conclusion so as to
rule out either the subjective necessity of weighing the various probabilities by one’s God-given powers of reason or the need of
depending upon the Spirit’s insights, discernment, and wisdom conveyed to the interpreter through spiritual disposition, perception,
and intuition.
†
  All references to Keathley will be to Keathley IV unless noted otherwise.
Page 8                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
          audience who is looking for the Messiah who will set up the kingdom told about in the Old
          Testament. They have no concept of a millennium or church age. So as we study the passages in
          question, remember who was hearing these parables and witnessing the miracles and what they
          would have understood Jesus to be saying.5

                                                Inductive Approach
        Really? Is it reasonable to accept the premise that one’s interpretation of the parables must be limited to the
understanding of those who initially heard the parables? Keathley’s own presuppositions and hermeneutical grid
leave several questions unanswered. Is cutting off the legs of a parable the best way to prevent it from “walking on
all fours”? Could the audience not even recognize a basic difference between the present and future aspects of the
kingdom? Even if the audience was slow or unwilling to accept this teaching, does this mean that Jesus made no
differentiation between the present and future aspects of the kingdom because He respected the hard heartedness of
His listeners? Were His listeners completely ignorant of the OT teaching that God would judge His people? Even if
they were, does this mean that Jesus shared their ignorance of future events such as the millennium? Did Jesus
limit His parabolic teaching to what His listeners would easily comprehend? If we accept Jesus’ answer to this
latter question, as recorded by Matthew himself (13:10-53), then we will have to acknowledge that neither Jesus
nor Matthew intend for the proper understanding of the parables in general, nor of the outer darkness in particular,
to be limited in the manner that Keathley suggests.*
        When one considers how often the gospel writers state that the masses and even Jesus’ own disciples did
not understand Jesus’ words, much less His parables, it is almost barbaric for Keathley to insist that we must
reject the later refinements and clarifications provided for us in Scripture and limit our understanding of Jesus’
teaching to the perceptiveness of those who originally heard them. Why must we accept Keathley’s assumption
that Jesus’ original hearers understood Him? The biblical witness is manifold that the initial hearers, even the
disciples, frequently did not understand Jesus’ instruction (Mt 13:10-19 15:16-17; 16:9,11; Mk 4:12-13; 7:18;
8:17, 8:21; 9:32; Lk 2:50; 8:10, 9:45; Jn 3:10; 8:43; 10:6; 11:11-14; 12:16; 13:7; 16:25; 20:9). In addition to these
passages, which state this lack of perception explicitly, in other passages it is equally apparent that Jesus Himself
did not necessarily expect His words to be understood initially (Jn 2:19-22). In fact, Jesus explicitly states that
some of these things He did and spoke would not be understood until later (Jn 13:7). His disciples were even
prevented from understanding some of His plainest statements. “But they did not understand this statement, and it
was concealed from them so that they might not perceive it” (Lk 9:45). To adopt the limited understanding and
misunderstandings of the original hearers (that Keathley wants to impose upon us) is to invite the accusation that
we do not understand what is being said any better than the original hearers did.
          11
            And He was saying to them, “To you has been given the mystery of the kingdom of God; but those
          who are outside get everything in parables, 12 in order that while seeing, they may see and not
          perceive; and while hearing, they may hear and not understand lest they return and be forgiven.
          (Mk 4:11-12)

       If we limit our understanding of the parables to how Jesus’ original listeners heard them, then we will not
see nor perceive the meaning that Jesus intends within them. Jesus did not intend for the masses to understand His
parables fully.6 In trying to so limit our understanding of the parables, Keathley makes a methodological error that
seeks to strip the parable of its mystery. The fact that these parables are a mystery means that Jesus is teaching
truths that previously were unknown in the OT and intertestamental period but now are being revealed by Him.
The new aspect being presented in this parable concerning the sower (Mk 4:1-20) is the interim nature of the
kingdom. In later parables, such as those concerning the outer darkness, Jesus deals with service in this interadvent
kingdom. Jesus’ anticipation of this church age is indicated by the Matthean references to the church. The attempt
by Keathley (and Pagenkemper) to limit our understanding to the past (OT and intertestamental periods) and to the
present understanding of the original hearers fails to deal adequately with the possibility that Jesus intends to
present new material for a new age—the church age. Matthew is the only gospel writer who speaks directly of the
church, and he does so in two places (Mt 16:18; 18:17). Both of these statements are recorded in the sequence of
the narration before two of the three passages dealing with the outer darkness. In other words, the majority of the
material concerning the outer darkness was presented after the doctrine of the church already had been introduced.


*
    See Illegitimate Totality Equivalence, 434; Levels of Detail, 935.
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                              Page 9
                                                                                                                       *
        Even more importantly, the cryptic nature of the parables is acknowledged by all three synoptic writers. In
their respective contexts concerning the mysterious form of the kingdom and the obscure nature of the parables,
they each proceed to demonstrate that Jesus explained the meaning of the parables and of the kingdom to His
disciples by means of the details. Matthew also depicts Jesus as explaining the parable of the tares in this same
section. Huber thus wisely adopts the same methodology used by Jesus in explaining the parables. In his thesis on
the outer darkness, Huber states that the central truth of the parable is to be found by examining the details: “Jesus
Himself interpreted the details of his parables….Jesus uses the inductive method, not the deductive method…In
fact Jesus never gives the main point or central truth of the parable but leaves the reader to figure it out from the
details.”7 Huber cites a thesis by McClymont in defense of this position, noting that in the parable of the sower and
the parable of the tares “Jesus interpreted sixty-seven percent of the details” and used the details to “convey
additional information.”8 Moreover, these details were capable of recognizable historical fulfillment.†
        Once upon a time, Keathley’s main-idea mentality that decries interpreting parables by means of details was
in scholarly vogue. France notes this passing fad of asserting that “a parable has only a single point and that all the
rest is mere narrative scenery, which must not be ‘allegorized’ to determine what each detail means,” but he points
out that modern scholarship has increasing recognized that “the way the story is constructed demands that the
detail be noticed, and to interpret those details individually is not arbitrary ‘allegorization’ but a responsible
recognition of the way Jesus constructed the story.”9 Turner concurs that many scholars used to “argue that Jesus’s
parables, unlike allegories, have only one main point. But this narrow approach seems contrary to Jesus own
interpretations of his parables.”10
        From the onset a choice must be made as to which methodology is best for interpreting the outer darkness.
One can use Keathley’s archaic deductive method, which takes the central truth of the parable and then interprets
the details on the basis of the central truth and basically ignores the “little details,” as he calls them.‡ Or one can
follow Huber’s inductive method and determine what the central truth is from the details and what additional truth
is being conveyed by the particulars. The latter course is the most prudent. Hodges emphatically refers to this
additional truth as deeper truth:

            At a deeper level, the parables reveal subtle differences. At this deeper level, they distinguish
       between two groups of people….
            Needless to say, Jesus did not necessarily expect all these details to be obvious when the
       disciples first heard the parables. The general truth was obvious. They should not allow
       misconduct or spiritual neglect to leave them unprepared for His coming. But our Lord also knew that
       the parables would become part of Matthew’s inspired Gospel. When that happened, they could be
       prayerfully studied and more deeply understood.
            The words of our Lord Jesus Christ always reward deeper study. Like all inspired truth, His
       words always have unanticipated depth. That is emphatically true here.11

       This approach pours hours upon hours in study over every jot and tittle of the text and would dare suggest
that Jesus, as recorded in Matthew, indicates that this is the way Scripture should be approached (Mt 5:18). If
inspiration applies to the jot and tittles (and it does), then are we not to assume that interpretation should as well? I
am emphatically in favor of the inductive approach. However, this is not to say that the two approaches are
mutually exclusive or that inductive analysis is always superior to deductive logic.

                                              Adductive Approach
       A personal illustration may help clarify the difference and necessity of both methods. In an independent
research class, the present author presented a paper that defended the doctrine of inerrancy, arguing that preference
concerning this doctrine must be given to deductive logic and supplemented with inductive logic. Inerrantists
frequently start with the clear deductive statements contained within the Bible (in which it teaches its own
trustworthiness) and proceed from there to demonstrate its integrity. They accept the doctrine of inerrancy because
the Bible teaches it. From this premise of trustworthiness, they then seek to interpret the phenomena (facts) of
Scripture in a harmonious fashion.
*
  The first three gospels of the NT are called synoptic gospels because they describe Jesus’ earthly ministry from a similar point of
view. They naturally share many accounts in common. For example, all three contain the Parable of the Sower and record that Jesus
privately explained the meaning of the parable to His disciples by interpreting the details of the parable.
†
  See Futurism, 310.
‡
  Also see Symbolic and Parabolic Versus Doctrinal Material, 574.
Page 10                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
         Those who reject inerrancy are more inclined to prefer an inductive approach in which they start by
examining the facts presented in the Bible, noting apparent contradictions, and then finish by concluding that the
claims of the Bible concerning its own trustworthiness must be modified within the parameters of their findings to
allow for inaccuracies. They deny inerrancy on the basis of problems they find within the text. In response, it may
be noted that some inerrantists have implemented inductive arguments for verbal inspiration, and some inerrantists
have advocated using an integrated approach that combines the deductive and inductive methods into an adductive
one.12 This latter method was the one the present author used in his paper. Deductive statements and logic were
used with supplementation from inductive analysis. Preference was given to deductive logic because of clear
statements within the Bible affirming its own truthfulness, such as, “Thy word is truth” (Ps 119:60; Jn 17:17).
         Nevertheless, such perspicuity is not manifested in the parables. Jesus does not make clear statements as to
the central truth of the parables. On the contrary, the biblical writers themselves teach that Jesus uses parables to
conceal rather than reveal the truth (Mt 13:10-13,34-35). To be sure, liberals (such as Jeremias) have challenged
this assessment and have rejected the veracity of Scripture in doing so.13 Conservatives who attempt to embrace
such liberal advocacy of a supposed central truth that dispels the details will have to give an account for how they
are able to eat the liberal hermeneutical cake without partaking of the liberal hermeneutical batter that went into the
production of such a liberal conclusion. To say the least, conservatives should show considerable caution before
crawling into hermeneutical bed with such liberal presuppositions. Liberals have found it necessary to jettison
veracity in order to argue for central-truth parabolic perspicuity. Can conservatives who crawl into bed with
liberals in order to give birth to a central-truth-perspicuity actually claim, with logically consistency, not to have
sacrificed their views on inerrancy in the process? When the liberal premise is rejected, the liberal conclusion runs
in reverse. So how can one be consistent in advocating inerrancy if one adopts the liberal perspective? If the
biblical statement as to the obscurity of the parabolic material is treated as authentic and if the veracity of parabolic
details is admitted, then the most straightforward deduction is that the truth of the parables is hidden within the
inerrant details of the parables. If the details are ignored, the parables are interpreted in ignorance. Based on the
biblical teaching concerning the nature of the parables, it is fundamentally wrong to start with a supposed central
truth. Deductive logic itself, based on the biblical statements as to the intent and nature of the parables, demands
that deductive logic not be used as the premise for interpreting the details of the parables!
         Yet the usefulness of deductive logic for parabolic interpretation is not limited to this observation. The
primary reason the inductive approach was abandoned by parabolic interpreters (in favor of the deductive method)
was to avoid the allegorical excesses that can come from seeking to find too much information in the parabolic
details. The need for deductive logic to aid in interpreting the parables is a valid inference. Thus, an adductive
approach is best. An initial inductive examination of the details should be used to induce the general teaching and
time period being referred by the parable. This inductive information should then be confined within the
parameters of deductive logic to avoid allegorical excess. Concerning parables at least, Gordon Olson’s
presupposition that priority must be given to details is an exegetical necessity. At the same time, even he
acknowledges that deductive logic is useful for “confirming and testing the results of our induction or filling in the
gaps where the inductive data is missing or incomplete.”14 Therefore, my adductive approach closely resembles his
“synthetic, deductive methodology,” in which primacy is given to inductive details.15
         For example, if it is induced from the contextual details that those outside the city in Rev 22:15 are lost and
if it is induced from the details in Matthew’s parabolic account that those in the darkness outside are saved, then it
would be deduced that being outside New Jerusalem in Rev 22:15 is not the same thing as being outside in the
darkness in the Matthean parables. If one induces from the details of the black darkness in Jude 1:13 that this
Judean darkness refers to the confinement of the lost and if one induces from the details of the Matthean outer
darkness that the Matthean darkness refers to the confinement of the saved, then one would deduce that the black
darkness is not the same thing as the outer darkness. If we determine that the parables place the events of the outer
darkness at the time of the bema* or deals with rewards for believers, we would then be able to deduce that there
are certain things to which the outer darkness can and cannot refer.16 I will start with an inductive analysis of the
details and then deductively limit the possible meaning of those details. Doing so will spare us from allegorically
jumping to the conclusion that since words such as darkness or outside are used in two different passages, they

*
  Bema is a transliteration of the Greek word used in 2Cor 5:10 for the Judgment Seat of Christ and is used as abbreviation for the
judgment of believers. The unqualified use of Bema will be understood in the typical dispensational manner as referring to the
Christian Bema—the judgment of church-age believers following the rapture. Jewish Bema will refer to a similar judgment of Jewish
believers following the tribulation. Gentile Bema (also known as the Judgment of the Sheep and the Goats) will be used for the
judgment of Gentile believers following the tribulation (after the Jewish Bema). Unbelievers are judged 1000 years after the
tribulation at the Great White Throne (thronos) judgment of Rev 20:11.
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                Page 11
necessarily refer to the same thing. The assumption should not be made that just because two different parables
describe a judgment that they are necessarily describing the same judgment. Those judgments may occur at
different time periods and deal with different groups of people.

Eschatology
        The first part of this study will set forth an eschatological framework that will make possible a misthological
examination of the Sermon on the Mount Olivet, which is the context of the primary passage for the outer
darkness. Doing so will allow the general reader to differentiate between different time periods of judgment. This
procedure also will demonstrate the bond between eschatology and misthology. A proper understanding of
eschatology is necessary for a suitable understanding of many misthological passages. Misthological passages in
turn provide one of the most powerful biblical incentives for holy living. In order to enter the biblical gold mine of
misthology, proper mining tools are essential. And one of the most effective mining tools for misthology is a firm
grasp of eschatology. Let us proceed to the future and find out why the way we live today is so crucially important
for our future. Glimpses of our potential future have tremendous power to affect our performance in the present.
This truth is seen in movies such as Back to the Future, It’s a Wonderful Life, and in the classic visiting of
Ebenezer Scrooge by the Ghost of Christmas Future. The way we live today and the choices we make now will
profoundly and permanently affect our future. Christians are not immune to this truth. Believers need to be shown
this fact, not by a time machine, nor an angel, nor a ghost, but by their pastor.
        Our hermeneutical procedure will be to interpret the more difficult misthological passages in light of the
easier eschatological ones. In other words, the goal is to use clear passages to help interpret unclear passages.
Answering four questions will provide us with a compass that will help prevent us from getting lost in the woods as
we proceed. (1) Does Jesus come before or after the millennium? (2) Is His second coming in one or two stages?
(3) Does Jesus come before, during, or after the tribulation? (4) Does Jesus come for all believers? In answering
the above questions, surveying the four, different, basic understandings of the millennium will be necessary.*

                                                 Amillennial View
       Amillennialists (“a” means “no”) believe that there is no future millennial kingdom on earth. They believe
that the church age, the tribulational period, and millennial kingdom are all occurring now in the present time. The
millennial kingdom is currently happening in its full form and refers to either Christ’s rule in heaven or in the
church. The second coming is after the present millennial kingdom, which is now going on in its spiritual form.
When Christ comes, the church is raptured (gathered up) into the sky to meet Him and then the church does a U-
turn and returns with Christ to earth. Thus, from the amillennial perspective, the rapture happens at the same time
as the second coming of Christ.

                                               Postmillennial View
       Postmillennialists (“post” means “after”) also believe that Christ comes after the millennium. However,
they believe that the millennium is still future. The millennial kingdom will be an utopian state on earth brought
about by the church. The church age and the tribulational period occur in the present age, but the millennial
kingdom occurs in the future after the present church age and tribulation. The second coming is after the future
earthly millennium. The major difference between the amillennial and the postmillennial positions is that
amillennialists view the millennium as present while postmillennialists view it as future.

                                                Premillennial View
        Premillennialists (“pre” means “before”) believe that Christ comes before the millennium starts.
Premillennialists differ among themselves, though, as to whether they believe that Jesus will return for the church
before, during, or after the tribulation. These three alternatives are denoted by three question marks in Illustration
3. A premillennial perspective will be developed herein, but for now I will leave the matter unsettled and simply
remark that the church age is the one we are currently in and is followed by the future tribulational period, which in
turn is followed by the future millennial kingdom. Thus, the second coming is before the future earthly millennial
kingdom.
                                          Illustration 3. Premillennial View

                                                Panmillennial View
       Panmillennialists do not know what to believe. (“Pan” is used herein to mean “unsure.”) They believe that it
is too difficult to decide which of the other three millennial options is correct, so they throw in the towel with the
attitude, “Whatever will be will be, the future is not ours to see. It will all pan out in the end.” Panmillennialism is
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                 Page 13
thus a popular colloquial designation based on the everyday expression pan out. If I were to picture their position,
it would simply be one big question mark. This singular question mark would be different from the three little
question marks above shown for premillennialism. In the premillennial view, there may be a question as to when
Christ will come in relation to the tribulation, but there is no question as to when Christ will come in relation to the
millennium. He definitely will return before the millennium. There will be a resurrection of believers before the
millennium and a corresponding judgment at the Judgment Seat of Christ (JSC) to determine what rewards
believers should receive. The end of the millennium will be followed by a general resurrection and a judgment of
the rest of the dead at the Great White Throne (GWT) in which the lost will be thrown into the Lake of Fire. This
primitive, undeveloped form of premillennialism is known as chiliasm. Those holding this position today are called
historic (or covenant) premillennialists.
                                   Illustration 4. Basic Premillennialism (Chiliasm)




        Many think that what the Bible says about the future is so hopelessly complex that it is impossible to come
to any firm conviction concerning the amillennial, postmillennial, and premillennial positions and remove the
question marks. Granted, complexities are involved. But this does not mean that it is impossible to come to some
definite conclusions concerning the millennium. We do not have to know everything in order to know anything.17
Basic presuppositions are possible. In fact, a fundamental conclusion concerning the millennium is derivable from
one primary passage of Scripture.
       Although the kingdom of God is alluded to many times in the Bible, its duration is spelled out in only one
passage—Rev 20:2-7. This passage is decisive. Even though premillennialism is not based on this one passage, this
passage nevertheless conclusively demonstrates the premillennial position as the correct option. In the space of six
verses, the time (duration) of the kingdom is spelled out six times as being 1000 years. Not only does this passage
give us the time of its duration, it also tells us the time of its beginning.
       In the opening chapter of Clouse’s book The Meaning of the Millennium, which presents the various
millennial positions by their proponents and opponents, Ladd’s argument for the (historic) premillennial position is
likewise based primarily on Rev 20:4-6, and he justifies making this focused argument by pointing out that the
millennial doctrine must be based primarily on the NT rather than the OT.18 This procedure is reasonable since in
progressive revelation, clarity increases as the revelation progresses, and it is hermeneutically necessary to base our
understanding of unclear passages on the teaching of clear passages. Revelation is the last book of the Bible and is
dedicated to the subject of eschatology. Therefore, it is not surprising that it is in this book that the teaching about
the millennium reaches its apex. Consequently, the overview of eschatology herein will be gleaned from an
examination of this decisive material from Revelation in the next chapter.

                                        Soteriological Eschatology
      In the parables of the outer darkness, soteriology and eschatology merge. Only by dealing with fundamental
material in these areas can we hope to derive a cohesive theology and accurately understand and apply its
Page 14                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
principles. Throughout the course of this book, a mediating position will be sought between the two prevailing
well-known soteriological points of view known as Arminianism and Calvinism.* The need for a mediating
position will become increasingly apparent as this study unfolds. Still, a brief overview will be helpful to introduce
the reader to these positions and to demonstrate the need for a mediating position and the fundamental role
eschatology may play in developing one’s soteriology.

Augustine
        Many would trace the birth of Calvinism to Augustine’s doctrine of predestination and its corollary
doctrines, as Vance documents in his chapter: “The Origin of Calvinism.”19 Thus, Augustine is sometimes dubbed
as the true father of Calvinism. Anderson provides sufficient citations to demonstrate that Augustine’s Calvinism
may in turn be traced in large part to a change in his eschatology.20
        The early church fathers were chiliasts who believed in a literal return and reign of Christ on earth that
would last for a literal thousand years. Their views were based on a literal interpretation of Rev 20:1-6, which
describes this event with the Greek word chilioi (thousand). The Latin word for thousand is millennium, which is
the popular designation used today. Thus, the earlier church fathers were chiliasts (to use the Greek term) or
millennialists (to use the corresponding Latin term). Since the early Greek fathers believed in a literal interpretation
of what is now called the millennium, they would be properly termed premillennialists, since only premillennialists
affirm this literal understanding. Further, the belief by the early church fathers in the imminent return of Christ
would also require that they be regarded as pretribulationalists. If the rapture is imminent, it must be
pretribulational.
        A scriptural assessment of the accuracy of their position will be provided subsequently. For now it suffices
to note that the early church fathers were pretribulational premillennialists until about A.D. 400, with the exception
of Origen of Alexandria, who departed from the literal interpretation with an allegorical hermeneutic in its place.
Vance states the standard opinion, which is that Augustine adopted this allegorical approach from Origen.
Alternatively, Anderson gives evidence that it was typology instead of allegory that resulted in Augustine’s
abandoning the literal interpretation of a physical millennium. In either case, the end result is the same.21 Augustine
deserted the literal premillennial position of the early church, which he originally held, for a spiritualized
amillennial arrangement in its place.
        As a Latin father, Augustine’s deficiency in Greek is well known in that he misunderstood the nature of the
Greek word for justify (dikaioo) in Romans. He thought it was referring to being made righteous rather than being
declared righteous; he thus took it as denoting imparted righteousness rather than imputed righteousness. As a
result, Augustine failed to make a clear distinction between forensic justification (i.e. imputed legal righteousness)
and practical sanctification (i.e. imparted behavioral righteousness). Surprisingly, Augustine legitimately may be
considered the founder of both Catholicism and Calvinism.

Birth of Calvinism
       The genius of the Reformation was to make a clear distinction between justification and sanctification.
Under Luther’s leadership, the Reformation experienced its soteriological rebirth with a repudiation rather than
recovery of Augustinianism on this particular matter. Luther rejected Augustine’s merger of justification and
sanctification. Unfortunately, this soteriological distinction of the Reformation between legal and practical
righteousness was soon lost when Calvin brought the Augustinian infusion of justification back into sanctification.
The semi-transformation of the Reformation back to soteriological Catholicism mirrors a similar alteration that had
been experienced by Augustine hundreds of years previously. When Augustine abandoned his premillennial
approach for an amillennial one instead, he naturally jettisoned his millennial understanding of salvation. For this

*
  Arminianism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that God contingently determines that those who persevere will be
chosen (i.e., elected) for heaven. Perseverance is the basis for election. The free will of the believer is emphasized. Reaching heaven is
conditioned on the believer’s perseverance in Arminianism. The Arminian order of conditions and result is: perseverance, then
election, then heaven. Calvinism is a branch of conditional security which teaches that God sovereignly determines (i.e., elects) who
will persevere and thus make it to heaven. Election is the basis for perseverance. The sovereignty of God is emphasized. The elect
persevere because they are unconditionally predetermined by God to persevere so that they might reach heaven. Calvinists sometimes
like to present themselves as advocates of unconditional security, but actually Calvinism is a failed attempt to enjoin unconditional
security with conditional security. The Calvinist might assert that the believer is unconditionally assured of reaching heaven, but what
a Calvinist actually means with such an articulation is that the believer is unconditionally assured of persevering and thereby reaching
heaven. Reaching heaven is conditioned on the believer’s perseverance within Calvinism. The Calvinistic order of conditions and
result is: election, then perseverance, then heaven.
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                                Page 15
reason, Anderson is able to trace the birth of Calvinism back to Augustine’s alteration concerning the nature of
salvation in Mt 24:13. This verse became Augustine’s hermeneutical skeleton key: “But the one who endures to the
end, he shall be saved” (Mt 24:13). This verse no longer could be taken as promising millennial salvation to those
who endured to the end of the tribulation in Augustine’s new interpretation.
        Because of his new spiritual understanding of the millennium, Augustine no longer could maintain that the
one who endures to the end of the tribulation would be saved physically from it and allowed to enter the literal,
physical, millennial kingdom on earth. He no longer took the end as referring to the end of the age but rather the
end of one’s life and concluded that 24:13 must be describing spiritual salvation rather than physical salvation. The
result was that he came to conclude that only the elect* would be given the gift of perseverance and thus be saved
in the end. According to this view, the elect will persevere, and only those who persevere are the elect. Regrettably,
in Augustinianism the only way you can know if you are one of the elect is by persevering.22 Certainty of salvation
thus becomes an impossibility until one reaches the point of death. Sanctification proves election and justification.
By such a merger, amillennial Augustine created a soteriological Frankenstein.

Calvin
        The Reformation originally was marked by a revival of the Greek language and a distinction between
forensic justification and progressive sanctification, and thus between imputed righteousness and imparted
righteousness. This doctrinal distinction was based on a revival of the original understanding of the Greek word for
justification and was passed on from Melanchthon to Luther and in the beginning was held by Calvin in the first
edition of his Institutes. But in response to being charged with preaching antinomian licentiousness by the
Catholics,† Calvin reverted to the Augustinian union of justification and sanctification with his doctrine of election
and loss of assurance. Calvin became a Calvinist.23 That is, his modification led to the system of theology which
now bears his name. His new view was that God elected those whom He would cause to believe and persevere and
limited salvation to them. Thus, under this system of thought, the one who does not persevere (and who is cast into
the outer darkness) must be presumed lost. In this theological framework, the outer darkness naturally is equated
with eternal damnation in hell. Unsurprisingly, Calvinists today reject the salvation of the ones thrown into the
outer darkness. Their hermeneutical grid requires this assessment as a foregone conclusion.
        Calvinists share this perspective with their Catholic brethren. Both Catholicism and Calvinism were fathered
by Augustine. Calvinists attempt to distant themselves from their Romanist cousins by claiming that in Calvin’s
theological development Augustine’s soteriology triumphed over his ecclesiology, that is, his doctrine of salvation
is claimed to have prevailed over his doctrine of the church. As Anderson demonstrates, however, the Augustinian
connection of Calvinism with Catholicism runs much deeper than the ecclesiastical surface. Calvin was
Augustine’s spiritual progeny who did much soteriologically to convert the Reformation back to Romanism. His
conversion back to Catholicism is being followed today by many of his followers on their way back to Rome: no
justification without sanctification, no salvation without works.

*
  Elect refers to those chosen by God to reach heaven in Arminianism and Calvinism. Biblically, the term may be used much more
comprehensively than what is suggested by these two schools of thought, however.
†
  As will be explained in more comprehensive detail later, antinomian is derived from anti+nomos (anti-law) and refers to those who
are against the law. They are also known as libertarians, those liberated from the law. Legalists love to charge non-legalists with being
antinomians (i.e. teachers of lawlessness).

Arminius
       The major school of thought standing in opposition to Calvinism is derived from Arminius, who studied
under Beza (who was Calvin’s successor) at Geneva (the very school that Calvin founded). Arminius was by and
large a Calvinist, with one major exception. The crux of his original disagreement was over the doctrine of election
and can be boiled down to two questions: (1) Do we believe because God elected us? Or (2) did God elect us
because we believe?24 In contrast to Calvin, Arminius opted for an affirmative response to the second question. He
believed that election was based on foreknowledge, so God did not predetermine who would believe. In the course
of this investigation, concerning the fate of those cast into the outer darkness, coming to grips with this issue of
predestination and providing a suitable working model will be necessary. But for now, laying the groundwork by
summarizing these two opposing systems of thought suffices.

Calvinism’s TULIP
      Calvinism is the teaching of Calvin and his followers and has been expressed in a five-point acronym known
as TULIP:

        Total Depravity—means total inability. Man is totally unable to believe the gospel unless God acts upon
him with irresistible grace in regeneration. Regeneration, at least in its incipient form, must precede belief. God
regenerates man so that man may believe in accordance with his new nature. *
        Unconditional Election—means that God unconditionally elects who will believe and be saved. Man is not
elected because he believes. Rather, he believes because he is elected. God predetermines who will believe and be
saved. God’s intention was never to save the nonelect. Election is selection. God pre-selects who will believe and
causes them to believe. No one else can genuinely believe the gospel. No one else will persevere in saving faith. †
No one else can be saved.
        Limited Atonement—means that the benefits of the atonement are extended only to the elect. In summary,
Christ died only for the elect, not for the nonelect. God limited the benefits of Christ’s death to the elect. God never
had any true intention of making salvation possible for everyone.
        Irresistible Grace—means that God irresistibly causes the elect to become regenerate so that the elect will
believe. As a result, regeneration precedes faith. A person needs to be born again so that he or she may believe.
Faith is a gift from God that the elect do not have the power to refuse.
        Perseverance of the Saints—means that saints who persevere are preserved and thus are saved. Only those
who persevere are preserved. Preservation does not apply to those who do not persevere. Only those who persevere
in faith and faithfulness will reach heaven. Those who are elected to salvation from eternal damnation persevere as
a result. Thus, perseverance of the saints is not to be confused with eternal security of the saints. Only the elect
persevere, and they persevere because they are predestined to persevere. From the perspective of unconditional
election, this model teaches OSAS (once saved always saved). However, from the perspective of conditionality,
this model teaches NOSAS (not once saved always saved). This form of NOSAS affirms that one hypothetically
may lose one’s regeneration and cease to be saved if one does not persevere.

Historical Clarification
      A point of historical clarification is necessary, at this point, between Augustinianism and Calvinism on the
matter of irresistible grace and persevering grace. As Anderson elucidates, “The grace referenced in Augustine
which is irresistible is not the grace of regeneration, which he believed was bestowed at water baptism, nor the
grace of an efficacious call, rather the grace (gift) of perseverance.”25 In other words, irresistible grace, in the
Augustinian headwaters from which Calvinism would later flow, originally did not refer to regeneration but to
perseverance. Yet in Calvinism, irresistible grace was made to include regeneration. Most importantly, retention of

initial faith is sufficient for salvation from eternal damnation. Insecuritists, in contrast, teach that initial faith is insufficient and must
be followed by perseverance in faith in order to qualify for heaven.

regeneration was conditioned on perseverance. This basic premise regarding retention of regeneration is still
maintained today by Arminians and Calvinists.

Arminianism’s PEARS
       Arminianism is the teaching of Arminius and his followers and may be arranged in opposition to the
Calvinistic TULIP:
       Total Depravity—means man is incapable of doing anything truly good without God. Nevertheless, even
though faith is good and pleases God, it is not a gift from God. Nor does God have to regenerate a person before he
can have faith.
       Conditional Election—means God has elected to save those who believe and persevere in faith. Election is
conditioned on foreseen faith, but since believers who fail to persevere in faith till the end will fail to be saved in
the end, election is also conditioned faithfulness.
       Unlimited Atonement—means Christ died for everyone and made salvation available to all who believe in
Him. The atonement is not limited to the elect.
       Resistible Grace—means man is incapable of doing anything truly good without God’s grace, but God’s
grace can be resisted.
       Perseverance of the Saints—means that saints who persevere are preserved and are thus saved. Only those
who persevere will be saved. Preservation does not apply to those who do not persevere. Only those who persevere
are the elect; they are the elect because they persevere.

        This Arminian arrangement is better expressed positively, however, by the five-point Arminian acronym
known as the PEARS:26
        Prevenient Grace—means that God’s preparatory grace by which He takes the prerequisite step of
providing mankind with the pragmatic ability to search for Him and find Him in saving faith.†
        Election on Condition—means that God has conditionally elected all mankind to salvation. However, God
has only predestined that those who of their own freed will respond in faith to this offer of salvation and persevere
in this faith will be saved. Predestination is thus conditioned on persevering faith.
        Atonement for All—means that the atonement is sufficiently available for all mankind, and its
efficaciousness is only limited by their response.
        Resistible Grace—means that God’s prevenient grace may be resisted so that it does not result in salvation.
        Salvation through Perseverance—means that God’s grace is not only resistible; it is also reversible.
Believers may irremediably fall from the state of saving grace if they fail to persevere. Those who persevere are
elected to salvation from eternal damnation as a result. Believers must persevere in order to be saved in the end.
This doctrine is also popularly known as NOSAS, which stands for not once saved always saved. This form of
NOSAS affirms that one actually may lose one’s regeneration and cease to be saved if one does not persevere.




*

  Prevenient Grace (proper) is the orthodox view of divine-human synergism in which God initiates a pre-regenerative enablement
that makes it possible for a lost person to respond cooperatively in saving faith to the gospel and thereby experience regeneration (in
the form of impartation of eternal life to one’s spirit). This form of grace, therefore, logically precedes the regeneration of one’s spirit
in sequence, efficiently restores the lost person’s ability to respond positively to God by breaking the initial and normative bondage of
the enslaved human will to sin so that one no longer has to respond negatively to God, supernaturally prevents one’s fallen will from
making a positive free response to God impossible, sufficiently arouses the lost soul at the hearing of the gospel so that one can either
resist the gospel call and stay asleep in unbelief or allow oneself to become fully awakened by the call to believe, partially opens one’s
eyes to the truth of the gospel so that one may either close one’s eyes in disbelief or allow one’s eyes to be opened in saving faith,
directly restores free agency so that the constitutional free agent who is practically bound by sin pragmatically now becomes the freed
agent who may respond freely, instrumentally exerts resistible persuasional force upon the intellect through the explicit gospel that
will be successful unless resisted, and internally creates a desire and ability in one’s soul to respond positively to the gospel.

       Although the Arminian acronym is much more attractive than its Calvinistic counterpart, and is thus
pictured as the wife of Frankenstein, it is nevertheless a fiendish friend in that it hisses in soteriological agreement
that salvation from eternal damnation is conditioned on one’s perseverance. The Calvinistic Frankenstein is uglier,
but no more deadlier, than the soteriology espoused by its spouse.* The alternative, to be demonstrated below,
should not be regarded as the son of Frankenstein for the simple reason that, in comparing Scripture to Scripture, it
comes to a different conclusion on this most crucial issue.
                                              Illustration 7. What’s Your Carrot?




        In Arminianism and Calvinism, it makes little difference as to whether you dangle a gift or a crown in front
of believers to keep them running on the performance treadmill. From the joint perspective of both soteriologies,
believers get the gift and crown as a result of perseverance. So both results could be pictured as dangling from the
string in front of the performance treadmill. Obviously, if both outcomes are conditioned on overcoming, then both
are conditioned on performance. Since the crown is a reward based on works, then it must be concluded that the
gift is also based on works—if the gift is given for the same reason. Both of these soteriologies would base the
final realization of one’s salvation from eternal damnation on one’s perseverance. So both the gift and crown are
lifted up as being at stake in front of the Arminian-Calvinistic performance treadmill.

Marrowism
       In contrast, Marrowism† differentiates between a gift and a reward. A salvation based on endurance would
be a remittance rather than a present. Since those who endure to the end (in passages such as 2Tim 2:12 and
Rev 2:26) are promised rulership as a result, a salvation based on perseverance must be understood as salvation
from loss of rulership rather than from hell. Consequently, Marrowism would lift up the crown of life rather than
the gift of life as the prize to be won by perseverance.‡ Salvation from eternal damnation is a gift; salvation from
loss of reward is a reward. In FG theology, it is argued that the NT lifts up future rewards, such as crowns, as
proper incentives for holy living. On the other hand, to base one’s procurement of the free gift of eternal life on
one’s perseverance is exceedingly improper. A free gift is not earned.


*
  For interaction with Perkins, see Eternal Security, 702.
†
  Marrowism is the present author’s coined term for describing his mediating non-Calvinistic Free Grace theology, which is

may be considered a modern-day Marrowist. The present book is an explanation of Marrowism as the present author has come to
refine and define it. As used by the author, Marrowism refers to a defense of unconditional security consisting of soteriological and
misthological consistency. Marrowism is summarized by the acronym GRAPE:

Marrowism’s GRAPE
      Makidon has written articles pointing out the historical connection between the contemporary mediating FG
movement and that of Sandemanianism (and the earlier Marrow Controversy, a designation derived from the title
of Edward Fisher’s book, The Marrow of Modern Divinity).27
