        Sandeman was a pioneer in the NT restoration movement. Consequently, his seeking to restore NT practices
such as foot washing, communal property, and the Lord’s Supper are sometimes made the focus of attention.
However, his endeavor to restore such practices is not what is being extolled in FG theology (although observing
the Lord’s Supper rather than the Lord’s Cracker certainly would seem preferable). Rather, Makidon and the
present author applaud Sandeman’s more valuable contribution in the restoration of NT doctrine. Specifically, by
insisting that saving faith be considered a passive persuasion which results in preservation, Sandeman is an early
prototype of the return to NT soteriology found in contemporary FG theology. To focus our attention on this
positive theological aspect of his contribution (rather than on pragmatic or dogmatic deviations), I will implement a
fresh title for this prospective that goes back to the earlier theological movement which was the impetus for his
work. Correspondingly, the perspective being refined today by the modern FG movement will be labeled herein as
Marrowism.28 The acronym PROPER has been suggested by Andrew for the contemporary expression of this
movement.29 GRAPE is the acronym proposed herein as descriptive of the distinctive aspects of FG theology. Like
the acronym for the other two camps, this Marrowistic acronym will be limited to five letters—GRAPE.

                                                GRAPE Acronym
       Gift is Free—means that the gift of eternal life is offered as a free gift and must be passively received as
such. This free grace affirmation is made in contradistinction to the forced grace view of TULIP and the forfeitable
grace view of PEARS. In contradiction to these opposing systems, this gift is not conditioned on one’s
performance for either its reception or retention.
       Rewards are Earned—means that the distinction between unmerited gifts and merited rewards must not be
blurred. Advocates from both TULIP and PEARS attempt to conflate the two terms—gift and reward—by
introducing rewards of grace terminology or by calling rewards gifts or gifts rewards. In GRAPE, however, a
reward is not a gift, and a gift is not a reward.
       Absolute Assurance—means that personal assurance of one’s salvation from eternal damnation is the
essence of saving faith. Unlike TULIP, in which present assurance is impossible, and in contradistinction to
PEARS, in which future assurance is impossible, GRAPE logically results in the full assurance of one’s eternal
salvation regardless of one’s perseverance or performance. In distinction to some within FG, however, the position
taken herein is that absolute assurance is a natural rather than necessary component of saving faith.
       Passive Persuasion—means that faith is passive persuasion, not an active commitment. Although an
accommodating three-element view of faith is permissible, faith is still not volitional. Unlike those in LS who
require that one commit oneself to Christ in order to receive the free gift of eternal life, or some of those in FG who
believe that one must actively and volitionally entrust one’s eternal destiny to Christ, the passive perspective taken
herein is that saving faith is simple trust in Christ alone for eternal life.
       Eternal Security—means that the person who trusts in Christ alone for eternal life immediately and eternally
thereafter has eternal life and cannot experience eternal damnation. This doctrine of eternal security is known
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                                Page 21
popularly as OSAS (once saved always saved) and is consistently and emphatically affirmed by GRAPE, in
contrast to the conditional denunciation this doctrine receives in TULIP and PEARS. The affirmation of eternal
security (E) is placed strategically at the end of the GRAPE acronym in order to contrast the most distinctive aspect
of Marrowistic theology from the other two acronyms. Unlike Arminianism and Calvinism, Marrowism
emphatically does not condition salvation from hell on the believer’s perseverance. GRAPE affirms true eternal
security, not some Arminian or Calvinistic imitation of security. Marrowistic eternal security is unconditional
security.

                                           A GRAPE Is Not a PEAR
       Many Arminians love to point their fingers at advocates of eternal security and call them Calvinists. But
consistent Calvinists actually reject eternal security. Some Calvinists are just as prone to point their fingers at
advocates of eternal security and call them Arminians. Again, this is a false accusation. Arminians reject eternal
security. TULIP advocates should not point their fingers at GRAPE and call it, “PEARS.” A pear is not a grape.
True eternal security is the heartthrob of GRAPE. Marrowism must therefore be distinguished from Arminianism
and Calvinism and be located as a separate soteriological category between PEARS and TULIP.*

                                               Misthological Merit
       The differentiation between a gift and a reward, which is so vital to GRAPE, frequently is obscured by
PEARS and TUPLIP, and even by older forms of FG that retain much of TULIP.† The need for a pure GRAPE-
flavored FG perspective that is not distorted by TULIP-colored glasses is acute.

Rewards of Grace
        In PEARS, the retention of the gift of eternal life is conditioned on the believer’s postconversional
performance. Matters are even worse in TULIP. Those who reject the notion of merit in positive rewards generally
employ the argument that they are rewards of grace, not of merit. According to Gerig, “even the rewards earned
are totally a result of God’s grace since all successful labor for Christ is accomplished by Christ working in and
through us.”30 This affirmation would be right at home in the monergistic, flowery fields of TULIP.‡ Yet in the
earlier edition of this dictionary, Cleveland takes the opposing position:

        Salvation is a gift (Eph. 2:8-9) whereas rewards are earned (1 Cor. 3:14)….
             Various types of service merit rewards…Rewards can be lost (Rev. 2:10; II John 8). Then too it
        is possible to be busy in the Lord’s service and receive no rewards at all (I Cor. 3:15; 9:27).31

       This distinction between a gift and a reward and the acknowledgment that rewards are earned and
consequently merited is splendid GRAPE theology. The affirmation that a believer may lose rewards without
soteriologically losing salvation is certainly not compatible with Wesleyan PEARS, and the fact that believers may
even “receive no rewards at all” is certainly not suitable for the Calvinistic TULIP. Cleveland’s stance is
compatible with GRAPE. Still, Cleveland should have been more consistent or at least clarified when he said, “In
present-day usage a reward is a gift given in recognition for some service rendered, either good or evil.”32 He
cites 1Kgs 13:7 as a case in point: “Then the king said to the man of God, ‘Come home with me and refresh
yourself, and I will give you a reward.’” What is given is a reward according to this translation. Is that truly what it
is?

  See Illustration 97. OSAS—Whose is It?, 268.

  See Reward = Gift?, 162.

    Monergism means to work alone and refers to the sovereign work of God in which He is the necessary and sufficient cause in
regenerating the elect without dependency on their freewill synergistic cooperation. Although broader than Calvinism, this view is
associated typically with Calvinism. Since synergism also affirms that regeneration is the work of God alone, the crux of the dispute
between monergism and synergism narrows down to the fact that Calvinistic monergism places regeneration before faith so that it can
attribute initial faith exclusively to God’s work apart from freewill synergistic cooperation. In terms of salvation apart from works,
however, this Calvinistic emphasis on saving faith being produced monergistically by God is largely beside the point. Since Calvinism
conditions final salvation on the believer’s synergistic perseverance in faith, Calvinists are synergists in relation to final salvation.
Because Calvinism simultaneously teaches that the elect are unconditionally elected to final salvation apart from their cooperation,
Calvinists have an irreconcilable tension created by their making perseverance conditioned on their cooperation. As a result, some
Calvinists will even try to make perseverance a monergistic result.
Page 22                                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
        Contextual Merit
        The Greek in 1Kgs 13:7 actually reads doma (typically translated as gift), not misthos (typically translated as
reward). A similar case occurs in Jer 40:5 where the NAS translates doron as gift, but the KJV renders it as
reward. What is happening is that the context is leading some translators to suspect that the gift is not really a gift,
as such, but a reward instead—an earned gift is a merited reward! Although a doma is generally considered a gift,
this does not mean that it cannot be translated as reward if warranted by the context. This does not mean, however,
that a gift is a reward. Just as the English word benefit can refer to something that is merited or unmerited
depending on the context, so one might suggest the same possibility for its Greek counterpart without jumping to
the faulty conclusion that it must refer to an unmerited-merit or a gift-reward. Unfortunately, it would seem that
some dictionaries also have a hard time telling the difference between a reward and a gift. Unger’s dictionary
illustrates this lack of clarity: “A principal point of contention between the Roman Catholics and Protestants
concerns the basis of reward. Roman Catholics hold that reward is based on the actual merit of the good works
of believers, whereas many Protestants regard rewards as wholly of grace.”33
        Unger rejects any association of merit with rewards.* Yet in this same entry he acknowledges, “Rewards are
offered by God to a believer on the basis of faithful service rendered after salvation….Salvation is a free
gift…while rewards are earned by works.”34 How much clearer could it be that rewards entail merit? Since
rewards are earned by our synergistic effort,† rewards are based on our relative merit. Paul says that if something is
earned by works, then it is a reward that is owed rather than a gift that is bestowed (Rom 4:4). In short, rewards are
merited; gifts are not. This is standard GRAPE theology. But Unger slips and falls over the concept of biblical
merit. Regrettably, such confusion occurs with redundant frequency in TULIP. Schwertley, in sympathy with
Calvin’s comments, criticizes Gerstner’s attempt to address this problem:

             Gerstner argues that the issue of merit in heaven for good works done on earth is not a
        problem for the Protestant at all, for these good works have nothing to do with earning salvation;
        they all occur after justification. These faith-works are necessary to prove the genuineness of a
        Christian’s faith, but they have nothing to do with earning heaven.35

        Schwertley is appalled both by Gerstner’s affirmation that rewards are merited and by Gerstner’s
denunciation of Augustine’s contradiction within Gerstner’s confession: “I confess my own and Augustine’s past
error in using the oxymoron: ‘rewards of grace.’”36 In contrast to Schwertley, misthologists applaud Gerstner and
likewise reject the notion that rewards of grace means that rewards are not based on merit. Nevertheless, Gerstner
fails to break completely free of the TUPLIP framework and thus necessarily makes entrance into heaven an “issue
of merit.” In Calvinism “faith-works are necessary,” as Grestner acknowledges, to reach heaven. Making these
works necessary as proof does nothing to offset the charge of works-righteousness. Final justification (in relation
to heaven versus hell) remains conditioned on works in this proveitistic mindset.‡ In proveitism, the verdict is
based on works rather than rendered apart from works. By further acknowledging that these works involve merit,
Grestner inadvertently teaches that heaven is merited. A solution is readily available—jettison TULIP. Gerstner’s


*
  Greek dictionaries seem to do a better job at acknowledging merit. See Lexical Merit, 73.
†
  Synergism is derived from the Greek verb sunergeo and means to work together with someone else to accomplish a common goal.
God provides energization via spiritual stimulation by which believers are encouraged to do God’s will. Through God’s enabling
grace, God works synergistically in cooperation with the believer’s free will in making it possible for believers to perform good works
such as persevering in faith and goods works. While it is true that God likewise works cooperatively together with the free will of the
lost in enabling them to come to saving faith, it must be remembered that saving faith is not a work. Thus, saving faith is not a
synergistic response. The synergistic activities through which a person comes to saving faith are only synergistic preconditions to the
non-synergistic response of saving faith. Since saving faith is the singular condition for regeneration and since saving faith is not a
work, regeneration is exclusively the work of God. Regeneration is produced monergistically by God, independently of any
cooperative work performed by man. Saving faith does not cause regeneration, is not a work, and is merely the condition for
regeneration. Therefore, God’s working in cooperation with a believer’s free response of faith to save the believer at the point of
regeneration is not a synergistic activity since the believer is not contributing any work at that point but is only responding with a
passive punctiliar persuasion. Although synergism presupposes libertarian freedom on the part of the believer (in that God performs
regeneration in cooperation with the believer’s free response of saving faith), synergism should not be confused (as is frequently done)
with libertarianism because saving faith is not a work. Synergism is more than libertarian free human cooperation with God.
Synergism is free human cooperation with God in the mutual performance of work.

  Proveitistic is a coined term referring to the Calvinistic perspective in which fruit is viewed as necessary proof of salvation: If you do
not have this fruit, then you were never saved to start with. Perseverance is necessary to prove that you are saved and to enter heaven.
Good works are a soteric necessity in proveitistic theology.

acknowledgment of merit is readily defensible in GRAPE but not in TULIP. His affirmation of misthological merit
results in a soteriological inconsistency within TULIP.

       Intrinsic Merit
       In opposition to PEARS and TULIP, the Marrowistic acronym teaches that good works are not necessary to
reach heaven. Rewards in heaven are merited; entrance into heaven is not merited. Gerstner needs GRAPE
theology in order to avoid making salvation from hell something one earns. Yet as badly as Gerstner needs
GRAPE, Schwertley needs it even more. He wants to retain the oxymoron rewards of grace and attempts to do so
by noting, “Strictly speaking, merit denotes a work that because of its own intrinsic value justly requires a reward
or payment.”37
       One verse that Schwertley cites in defense of his assessment is Lk 17:10, but his argument about intrinsic
value attacks a strawman. Intrinsic value, independent of enabling grace, is not the issue. Furthermore, Marrowists
concur that we cannot put God into our debt by human initiative. Jesus indicates as much when He says, “So you
too, when you do all the things which are commanded you, say, ‘We are unworthy slaves; we have done only that
which we ought to have done.’” God would not be obligated to reward us unless He first chose graciously to assign
such value to our work. Our works do not have independent inherent value. Apart from God’s initiatory and
enabling grace, our works would have no value. However, this fails to prove that God cannot graciously indebt
Himself to us and ascribe relative value to the derivative merit in our work.* Alcorn correctly and astutely deduces,
“He rewards us by grace but also in justice—a just God does not reward unless it is not only gracious but right for
him to do so.”38 Jesus affirms this as being the case: “You too go into the vineyard, and whatever is right I will
give you” (Mt 20:4).

Unworthy of Reward
       BKC wrongly and simply surmises: “They should not expect special praise for doing things they were
supposed to do. A servant does not get special praise from his master for doing his job.” These servants describe
themselves as “unworthy (achreioi, ‘good for nothing,’ used elsewhere only in Matt. 25:30)” (emphasis
original).39 Even so, as BKC notes, the only other occasion where this word for unworthy occurs in the NT is in
Mt 25:30. This time it is Jesus who uses this word to rebuke a servant as being worthless. In that context, those
slaves who served their master received special praise and were given rulership. Graciously, they are considered
worthy of such praise and rulership by their master. In contrast to those faithful slaves who are praised, the
unworthy slave who did not serve was thrown into the outer darkness. The implication is that the two slaves were
regarded as worthy of honor, while the third slave was considered unworthy.
       Merit or demerit determined whether the servants received praise or the outer darkness. Their reward was
not based on grace independent of their works (or on works independent of grace for that matter). Rewards,
whether positive or negative, are merited. The slave thrown into the outer darkness merited the outer darkness. Just
as the outer darkness is a demerit, so praise is a positive merit. To be sure, as servants we do not intrinsically
deserve the praise or rulership we get, as if we could ever hope to take the initiative in putting God in our debt.
God was not under obligation to make it possible for us to earn rewards. Nevertheless, having decided to place
Himself under obligation to reward us, it must be deduced that God graciously rewards us, but not independently of
our relative merit. Calvinists need GRAPE to adequately deal with relative merit.

No Grace
     Calvinists are not the only ones who need GRAPE. Consider Lenski’s lame Lutheran lather:†

        Let no false claims of merit enter our minds….

             But when he so rewards, this is altogether and absolutely due to his abounding grace and

       right and justice. (Italics his.)40

        Oh really? No rewarded merit? Marrowists could be just as crude in claiming that the servant in this parable
gets no grace (charis)! After all, the text explicitly denies that grace is given to the servant who serves: “He does
not hold out grace to the slave because he did the things which were commanded, does he?” (Lk 17:9; TM) Are we
to conclude that Jesus is denying grace to the serving servant? Hardly! Rather than teaching rewards of grace, this
parable denies both rewards and grace—if we follow Lenski’s line of reasoning. A better response can be found in
the GRAPE refinery. Dillow’s discussion of “Rewards and Merit,” along with his treatment of this parable (and
that of the laborers in the vineyard), is a commendable discussion of merit from the FG perspective.41

Relative Merit
       God has not sovereignly decided to irresistibly cause certain believers to work harder than other believers so
that He can give these special believers greater gifts independently of their freewill response to Him or regardless
of their work for Him. Rewards are based on works. Rewards are earned. In comparing the use of the word
unprofitable in Lk 17:10 and Mt 25:30, the conclusion that should be reached is that the opportunity to earn
rewards is unmerited, but the rewards themselves are merited. The technical term for this type of merit as used
herein is condign merit.* The servants entrusted with the talents did not deserve this stewardship. Yet being
entrusted with this stewardship enabled them to serve their master. Just so, we do not deserve God’s enabling
grace, but God has obligated Himself to us by virtue of His promises to reward us on the basis of our relative merit
if we respond positively to His enablement. Schwertley himself practically acknowledges as much:

             The Protestant doctrine that the heavenly rewards that God gives Christians for good works
       are gifts of grace does not mean that believers are not valid secondary moral agents; nor does it
       mean that believers do not actively cooperate in their sanctification; nor does it mean that there is
       not a direct correlation between the good works done on earth and the rewards given in heaven. God
       is just and not arbitrary in bestowing these rewards. The point that needs to be emphasized is that
       these rewards are based on God’s promise, a promise which flows from God’s grace and mercy. God
       is obligated to give these rewards only because He of His own good pleasure decided to set up a
       system of rewards for good deeds upon earth. The whole idea of merit implies an obligation on
       God that apart from His own promise is simply not there. God does not owe man anything. Good
       deeds apart from grace merit nothing.42

       Of course, it is by virtue of God’s gracious promises that God obligates Himself! We do not earn initial
grace or the promises which flow from that initial grace. Such astounding inconsistency on Schwertley’s part in
calling a reward a gift could be avoided easily by allowing God graciously to ascribe relative, resultant merit to our
deeds. Good deeds done in active, synergistic cooperation with God’s gracious enablement and in response to the
misthological opportunity that God graciously provides for us can indeed merit a tremendous benefit. Apparently,
the distinction between dependent versus independent merit never crossed Schwertley’s mind, or such an
admission of his part may simply be unavailable to those locked into TULIP.

*
 Condign merit is performance that incurs reward because Christ won these rewards for us and contingently obligated Himself to us
by promising these rewards to us on the basis of our derivative moral merit. Although the opportunity to earn the reward is not
merited, the reward is merited. In short, condign merit points to the obligatory nature of the reward. Quantitatively, every reward
is merited. Solely on the basis of God’s gracious initiative, He makes it possible for us to earn rewards through His enabling grace:
       merit -reward .
grace-grace
        Congruent merit is performance that results in rewards that graciously, yet proportionally, outweigh any effort that we may
have put into our character development or any improvement actually made in our character as a result of that effort. In short,
congruent merit points to the excessiveness of the reward. Qualitatively, the scope of the reward far exceeds what we deserve. As
an expression of God’s grace, although all rewards are based on merit, God rewards our works with greater benefits than we deserve
so that Marrowistic congruent merit is: merit-gracious
                                                  w o r kreward
                                                          s    .
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                Page 25
Faith Works
       TULIP actually has no room for merit or reward because one entails the other. Since the “P” in TULIP and
the “S” in PEARS make postsalvation works necessary to reach heaven, both systems must admit that entrance into
heaven is meritorious—if the works they deem necessary to enter heaven are meritorious. For this reason, neither
TULIP nor PEARS have any genuine room for meritorious rewards in their acronyms. Both systems have a terrible
time trying to make allowances for meritorious rewards in their theology.

       Fleshly Works
       MacArthur, for example, criticizes Hodges for regarding “postsalvation works as meritorious.”43 According
to MacArthur’s Faith Works: “No one who properly interprets Scripture would ever propose that human effort or
fleshly works can be meritorious—worthy of honor or reward from God” (italics his).44 Actually, however,
fleshly works are not the issue. GRAPE does not affirm that God is going to reward fleshly works with heavenly
rewards. MacArthur’s objection to fleshly works is just a red herring that he uses to distract from the fact that he is
denying that human effort, synergistically energized by the Holy Spirit, is honorable and rewardable.

        Honor
        The real issue is whether human beings can merit honor or reward from God by means of their God-enabled
response to God. Let us consider honor according to Jesus: “If anyone serves Me, the Father will honor him”
(Jn 12:26). This honor comes from the Father, is conditioned on human service, and is thus a reward for human
effort. By denying that humans can be worthy of honor from God, MacArthur in effect is rebuking Jesus. The Lord
indicates rather clearly that those who serve Him will be considered worthy of Him (Mt 10:37-38) and that those
who walk worthy of Him now (Eph 4:1; Col 1:10; 1Thess 2:12) will be considered worthy to walk with Him in
white later (Rev 3:4). What gives MacArthur the right to claim otherwise?

       God’s Favor
       MacArthur’s entire book rests on his mistaken premise: “A crucial point must be made here. The works
described in Hebrews 11 are faith works. These are not fleshly efforts to earn God’s favor. The works described
here are in no sense meritorious” (emphasis his).45 MacArthur has tried to move the discussion of merit from
human effort to purely fleshly effort. However, no one is arguing that fleshly effort will please God. The point of
contention is whether human beings are capable of doing things that result in rewards by responding cooperatively
to the energizing power of the Holy Spirit. Surely, human beings can do things that result in rewards from God by
responding in cooperation to the Spirit’s energization. These things rightly would be considered works since
rewards are based on works. Can believers perform good works and be rewarded by God for doing so? Certainly.
       MacArthur tries to overturn the overwhelming biblical evidence that rewards are based on works by
claiming that they are based on faith instead:

       Why does God reward those who seek him? Because of their works? No…God rewards only those
       with faith…Instead of trying to earn favor with God, faith pursues God himself….Far from making
       faith a human work, this definition [of faith as seeking God] emphasizes that faith is the abandonment
       of seeking to please God through works.46

       On the contrary, according to Peter, favor with God is conditioned on our human performance: “If when you
do what is right and suffer for it you patiently endure it, this finds favor with God” (1Pet 2:20). If you want to seek
favor with God, then you better be prepared to do good (agathopoieo) works and suffer and endure in doing so.
According to Jesus, we are to do good (agathopoieo) works so that we can have a great reward (Lk 6:35). The
biblical harmony is easily discerned.
                                             Illustration 9. God’s Favor
           1. That which comes as a result of doing good works is a reward.
           2. God’s favor can come as a result of doing good works.
           3. God’s favor can be a reward for doing good works.
Page 26                                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
       Favor is actually a translation of charis, which is Greek for grace. God’s grace is often earned.* While
saving grace is unearned, many forms of grace certainly are earned as a reward. Finding God’s favor certainly falls
within the reward spectrum.† After all, God “is a rewarder of those who seek Him” (Heb 11:6)! MacArthur is
refuted by the very verse to which he appeals. Those who find God’s favor as a result of seeking Him find a
reward. Such favor is a reward. MacArthur asserts that we “get no credit” for the good works we do since they are
works of God’s grace.47 Jesus insists otherwise:
        32
          And if you love those who love you, what credit is that to you? For even sinners love those who
       love them. 33 And if you do good to those who do good to you, what credit is that to you? For even
       sinners do the same. 34 And if you lend to those from whom you expect to receive, what credit is that
       to you? Even sinners lend to sinners, in order to receive back the same amount. 35 But love your
       enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return; and your reward will be great.
       (Lk 6:32-35)

      The reward we receive is credit (charis) for the work we perform. BDAG acknowledges that “in these
passages the meaning [of charis] comes close to reward.” Actually, the meaning clearly is reward in the Lukan
passage.

       Human Effort
       As to human effort, the entire context builds to a crescendo of human effort in Heb 11:33-38. These people
were rewarded because they “performed works of righteousness” (ergazomai; 11:33; TM). Naturally, positive
rewards are based on works of righteousness. Specifically, a work is anything we do that results in a reward.‡ For
MacArthur to equate the works these people are performing through faith with saving faith is to teach works-
righteousness§ as the means of getting to heaven. The passage is dealing with rewards (Heb 10:35; 11:6,26). If
MacArthur would just let a reward be a reward, then he would have avoided this dilemma of teaching works-
righteousness as the means of reaching heaven. Works-righteousness (or more literally works of righteousness) are
means of earning rewards, not of entering heaven! But as it is, in confusing misthological faith with soteriological
faith, MacArthur fuses soteriological faith with works-righteousness.

        1. Seeking God results in a reward.
        2. Rewards are always based on works.
        3. Therefore, seeking God is a work.

MacArthur’s definition of faith in this passage as seeking God would lead to the following conclusion:

        1. Faith is seeking God.
        2. Seeking God is a work.
        3. Therefore, such faith is a work.

       Necessity of Works
       In short, faith which seeks God is rewarded and therefore a work. MacArthur fails to make a distinction
between faith that results in a gift versus faith that results in a reward. Therefore, he is at a loss to distinguish
soteric faith from mistholic faith.** Ironically, in his Faith Works, MacArthur objects to considering faith a work!
Even when that faith results in reward! His primary objection is that faith is first and internal, but works are
secondary, external, and performed through faith: “Faith works are a consequence of faith, not a component of

†
  See “Finding Grace” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.

  See “What is Work” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.
§
  Works-righteousness is a derogatory label applied to the teaching which asserts that we are saved from hell on the basis of “works of
righteousness which we have done.” Such a teaching rejects the clear biblical summation which teaches that we are not saved from
hell on the basis of “works of righteousness which we have done” (Tit 3:5). Biblically, by faith we must rest our soteriological
justification on the imputational/legal righteousness of Christ apart from any of our works (Rom 3:28; 4:6). Those trusting in
impartational/practical righteousness instead to get to heaven are wrongly trusting in works-righteousness for a benefit it was never
intended to bestow.

   Soteric is a synonym for soteriological; mistholic is a synonym for misthological.
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                Page 27
faith. As observed earlier, faith is an entirely inward response and therefore is complete before it produces its first
work” (emphasis his).48 Even aside from my response elsewhere, in which I deal with such faulty objections to
misthological faith,* note that MacArthur cannot claim that these works are not meritorious simply because the
faith which results in these works is supposedly nonmeritorious. Faith produces work, and these works (and by his
own admission they are works) are distinct from faith. Regardless as to whether the faith that led to those works is
meritorious, the works themselves are certainly meritorious. Yet in MacArthurian theology these postconversion
works are necessary to reach heaven.49
        According to MacArthur, practical sanctification (i.e., “holy behavior”) is necessary to see God in heaven.
His proof text is Heb 12:14.50 But let us not forget that this verse teaches believers to pursue sanctification. Such a
pursuit requires human effort. To be sure, this effort is energized by the Spirit; nevertheless, the effort remains
human effort. MacArthur, in fact, admits as much: “‘Those who do not purify themselves will not see
Christ’…God’s own holiness thus requires that we persevere. ‘God’s grace insures our persevering—but this does
not make it any less our persevering’” (emphasis original).51 MacArthurian entrance into heaven requires us to
purify ourselves in terms of holy behavior. It is our effort. MacArthur’s statements lead to the conclusion that
MacArthurian entrance into heaven is conditioned on our perseverance.
        In Reformed theology, works are not just evidence of election, they are necessary for glorification: no
works, no heaven. In standard Reformed gab, MacArthur concurs concerning the necessity of perseverance: “God
didn’t save us apart from faith, and He doesn’t keep us apart from faith.”52 In both PEARS and TULIP theology,
your retention of regeneration is conditioned on your perseverance in faith.† Naturally, works play a similar role.
MacArthur quotes Ryle approvingly: “In sanctification our own works are of vast importance.”53 Granted,
Marrowists agree that our works are extremely important in practical sanctification. Where we must emphatically
disagree with MacArthur and Ryle is in their making such works soteriologically necessary to reach heaven.54

        Root-Fruit Fallacy
        MacArthur appeals to Luther’s root-fruit distinction: Faith is the root, and works are the fruit.55 But this
Reformed response refutes itself. Why bother trying to make such a big distinction between root and fruit in LS, so
as to limit work to fruit, and then turn around and say that it does not matter anyway because the fruit is a gift? In
other words, why bother insisting that root ≠ fruit and then insist that the distinction does not really matter anyway
since root = fruit = gift? Why does Reformed theology (RT) logically lead to the conclusion that it is unnecessary
to command believers to do good works (since believers supposedly will do so inevitably like a tree producing
fruit) when the Bible shows that some believers do not work and need to be commanded to work (2Thess 3:11-13)?
Why does Paul find it necessary to pray that believers will bear good fruit in every good work if they are going to
do so automatically anyway (Col 1:10)? Why does RT say that bearing good works is as natural as eating and
sleeping, when Paul considers fruit bearing a learned behavior (Tit 3:14)? Why does RT insist that it is God alone
who monergistically produces the fruit, when the Bible says that it is the tree that produces the fruit? Why does RT
monergistically attribute good works to God, when Jesus attributes these good works to the believer rather than
exclusively to the Father (Mt 5:16)? Why does RT make such a distinction between faith as the root and work as
the fruit and then ascribe them both to God, when Paul ascribes the work of faith to the believer (1Thess 1:3)? Does
this sound like Paul is trying to make a thoroughgoing distinction between fruit and work?
        More importantly, this Reformed differentiation fails to absolve MacArthur of teaching works-righteousness
since he inevitably conditions our entrance into heaven on both our perseverance in faith and our production of
good works. Reformed theology tries to dodge this charge by considering our faith and works as God’s gifts and by
asserting that our works, in particular, are the Spirit’s fruit. Such evasive maneuvers are not persuasive, though, to
those who take the doctrine of rewards seriously, and it does nothing to alleviate the fact that such theology still
conditions soteriological glorification on practical sanctification and thus on works. Salvation from hell is
ultimately based on both our faith and our works in MacArthur’s Faith Works.

                                     Illustration 10. Reformed Faith-Works Are Necessary




        In LS justification is said to be by faith alone, yet works are also said to be necessary for justification.
Frequent appeal is made to James as teaching the full-orbed requirement for the final realization of justification.
After all, James affirms three times that we are justified by works (Jam 2:21,24-25). Since LS believes that this
Jacobean justification is soteriological justification, LS exegetically conditions salvation from hell on one’s works.
MacArthur is being less than candid with his readers when he claims: “Lordship salvation is often caricatured as
teaching people that they must change their lives in order to be saved. But no advocate of lordship theology I know
of has ever taught such a thing.”56
        Far to the contrary, MacArthur teaches such a thing. The proponents of LS deceive themselves into thinking
that they do not teach works-righteousness because they do not teach that unbelievers must change their
performance before they are saved—only after they are saved. In LS, the unbeliever must promise to work (in the
form of commitment and repentance) in order to be saved. Since the promise to work is not actually considered a
work within LS, Lordship Salvationists imagine that this offsets the objection that LS conditions salvation on
postconversion performance. In actuality, however, the promise to behave better is a performance issue and hence
a work.* Nevertheless, that point aside for the moment, MacArthur teaches that good works are necessary for
salvation from eternal damnation. Attempts by LS to make such works the manifestation rather than condition for
soteriological salvation are refuted theologically by LS’s own theological insistence upon the soteriological
necessity of these good works and exegetically by the scriptural emphasis in James and in the fruit passages where
salvation obviously is conditioned on such works. Furthermore, the axe is laid at the root, because of the fruit:
“And the axe is already laid at the root of the trees; every tree therefore that does not bear good fruit is cut down
and thrown into the fire” (Mt 3:10; cp. Lk 3:9). The distinction between fruit and root appears more imagined than
real in the LS interpretation.
        Scripture attributes misthological value both to the root and the fruit. Since both perseverance in faith and
postconversion works are rewardable, they both are meritable. Both the root and fruit of TULIP are poisoned with
works-righteousness since TULIP conditions entrance into heaven on a root and fruit which are biblically
misthological. Moreover, our experience of the Spirit’s fruit is conditioned on our cooperation with the Spirit in
walking by the Spirit (Gal 5:22) rather than quenching the Spirit (1Thess 5:19). Fruit is synergistic. The production
of these spiritual traits requires human effort (spoude, spoudazo, 2Pet 1:5,9).† According to Paul, we are the ones
who bear the fruit (Rom 7:4). We are the ones responsible for our fruit production, and we are to bear “fruit in


*
    See endnote 882.
†
    See “Do your Best” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Chapter 1. Parabolic and Eschatological Options                                                                                 Page 29
every good work” (Col 1:10). Our fruits are even composed, in part, by our finical contributions (Rom 15:28). But
we do not buy heaven, so heaven cannot be conditioned on our fruits.
       More generically, a Christian’s good fruits are composed of good works, but we do not earn heaven, so
heaven is not conditioned on our works. We produce these good fruits/works by abiding in Christ (Jn 15:4-6).
Abiding in Christ, like walking by the Spirit, requires our cooperative effort. The “peaceful fruit of righteousness”
(Heb 12:11) is something that God produces in us by disciplining us as we faithfully submit ourselves to enduring
His discipline. Likewise, from James we find that “the seed whose fruit is righteousness is sown in peace by those
who make peace” (Jam 3:18). We reap what we sow in our lives. Good fruits do not spring up out of nowhere or
from nothing, nor do good fruits spontaneously result from a regenerate nature. The seed of God which results in
our regeneration is sown by God (Jam 1:18). In contrast, the seed whose fruit is righteousness is something we
sow. The seed of the peacemaker is shown by the peacemaker in submitting his or her character development to
the will of God by the power of the Spirit. Marrowists affirm the misthological value of biblical faith-works.*
Tying them soteriologically to justification, as MacArthur does, however, is a deadly perversion of the gospel of
grace.

        Fruitless Fig Tree
        John the Baptist demanded that those Jews who wanted to escape God’s temporal wrath “bear forth fruits
worthy of repentance” (Lk 3:8; NKJ; cp. Mt 3:8). They were responsible for producing the fruits. God has a right
to expect those capable of producing fruits to do so. Capability results in culpability. This truth is pictured
parabolically in the parable of the fig tree (Lk 13:6-9). The purpose of a fruit tree is to produce fruits. Therefore,
the owner of the vineyard had a right to expect the fig tree he planted in his vineyard to bear fruits. He patiently
waited three years. Since fig trees generally are unable to produce fruits until after they are three years old and
since he had been waiting three years for this tree to produce fruits, we may assume this tree was six years old. The
vineyard-keeper implored the owner to wait one more year while he dug a trench around the tree to fertilize it. The
tree was granted one more year. The vineyard-keeper (picturing Christ working through common grace and
prevenient grace) would do everything necessary to enable the fig tree to bear fruits in keeping with its natural
ability.† The fate of the fig tree was left up to the fig tree’s holistic response (roots and all) to this enabling grace.
                                                    Illustration 11. Broad Fruit

        Trees, like people, do not always do what they are supposed to do. Some people, like this parabolic fig tree,
may be pictured as never producing good fruit. Other people, like the historic fig tree which Jesus cursed, may stop
producing good fruit. On this historical occasion, Jesus was hungry and saw a fig tree that was in leaf early that
season (Mt 21:18-19; Mk 11:12-14). Rather than exercise His prerogative of omniscience, He walked to the fig tree
to see if He might find some fruit on it. Fruit was to be expected when leaves were present, and the fruit of fig trees
was something the poor would be expected to eat. The Lord rebuked the tree for failing to fulfill His expectations:
“Let no fruit grow on you ever again (meketi).” Unlike the parabolic fig tree, which never bore any fruit, this
historic fig tree previously had born edible fruit but no longer would be able to do so as a result of the curse placed
on it by Jesus. A nation, a generation, a people, or a person may reach the point where God says, “Your
opportunity to turn aside My judgment is over. Never again will you be able to do anything that will turn aside My
wrath.”* God’s patience has limits.
        The fruit of repentance does not necessarily point to the root of regeneration. Even in the context in which
Jesus teaches that a bad tree cannot produce good fruit, He acknowledges that evil people can do good
(Mt 7:11,18). The lost can bear good fruit in the broad sense of showing moral sensitivity, love, and reform.†
Unbelievers can do things that are relatively good.‡ The fruit of repentance merely points to the root of repentance.
This change in action points to a change in heart, not necessarily to a regenerate heart. The cursing of this fig tree
that formerly bore edible fruit does not show that one can lose the root of regeneration. PEARS is wrong. TULIP is
no better. Many mistakenly think that because they have experienced repentance they have experienced
regeneration. Contrary to proveitism, moral reform flowing from God’s enabling grace does not prove that one has
experienced the root of God’s regenerating grace. One can have repentance without regeneration, and one can have
regeneration without repentance. By equating the two, many are being misled by Reformed theology into thinking
they are going to heaven because they have experienced a moral reform.
        The major problem with LS is that it makes fruit in the broad sense necessary to reach heaven and thus
conditions salvation from the fires of hell on the broad fruit of human performance. The broad-fruit approach to
soteriology leads to the broad-gate destruction. When Jesus speaks of the narrow gate, He narrows fruit down to
saving faith. Do all believers produce good fruit? Yes, in the narrow sense, and broadly speaking in the relative
sense. Nonetheless, my affirmation of this limited fruit bearing is a far cry from the affirmation made within LS
wherein fruit in the broad sense is made necessary to enter heaven. Namely, the Marrowistic counter affirmation is
that all believers produce the narrow fruit of saving faith necessary to enter the narrow gate and escape the
soteriological fire.§

Outcome of Way You Live
        Rosscup is a horrific example of someone locked into the Calvinistic mindset of works-righteousness who
must correspondingly see the Scripture through TULIP-tinted glasses: “The NT is clear that eternal life is a gift, yet
is compatible with this in saying that eternal life as this gift is the fitting blessed outcome of a way of life lived
in faith through grace for the sake of Christ.”57 According to Rosscup, the way you live determines whether you
will receive this gift! Contrary to Rosscup, something that is the outcome of the way you live is not a gift. You do
not earn eternal life as a gift or entrance into heaven as an outcome of your works! Marrowists reject this
performance-based TULIP soteriology in favor of GRAPE. Rosscup provides a blatant example of what
Marrowism is not. In contrast to Rosscup, GRAPE teaches that the gift of eternal life is not the result or outcome of
postconversional performance.
        God can and does graciously obligate Himself to reward us based on our performance. To be sure, Paul asks
in Romans, “Who has first given [prodidomi] to him that it might be paid back to him again?” (11:35) It is
impossible for us to obligate God by our inaugural contribution, but this does not mean it is impossible to obligate
God by our derivative consecration. Those translations, like the NIV, that leave out the word first lead the reader
astray. The preposition before (pro-) suggests that prodidomi should not simply be translated as give (didomi). In
fact, L-N provides this definition for prodidomi: “to give in advance of some other event – ‘to give beforehand, to

give in advance, to give first.’’ More to the point, it suggests the following plausible rendering of this word in this
verse: “Who has ever given God something before God gave something?” No one, obviously.

Derivative Merit
        For example, is it possible for a father graciously to obligate himself to reward his son if his son obeys him?
Certainly. Suppose, the father were to say, “Son, I want you to wash the car this morning and as a reward for doing
so, I’ll buy you a new basketball.” The father does not wash the car for his son, but he provides his son with the
water hose, sponges, bucket, and detergent necessary to wash the car. The son washes the car. Has his father not
obligated himself to buy his son the basketball? Of course he has. The fact that the father wanted to buy his son the
basketball because he loves to play basketball with his son and even wanted to play basketball with him that
afternoon does not change the fact that the father obligated himself to his son. His son probably could anticipate
that his father wanted to shoot some hoops with him, and we may well anticipate that his son was looking forward
to shooting ball with his dad as he was washing his dad’s car. Loving, derivative obligation need not entail a
legalistic relation.
        As to the derivative nature of the obligation, if the father had not first made the offer to his son, then his son
would have had no right to wash the car and expect his father to buy him the basketball as a result. And the
neighbor’s child certainly has no right to sneak into their garage, wash their car, and then demand that the other
boy’s father treat him like his own son by buying him a basketball and playing ball with him. The neighbor’s son
cannot demand grace. Misthological grace is obtained through God’s enabling grace by those who have
experienced God’s soteriological grace and then graciously been given the opportunity to rule with Him.
Marrowists believe in grace—all forms of it.
        The point of passages such as Mt 20:1-16 and Lk 17:10 is to show that the concept of wages due (Rom 4:4)
cannot be used to dispense with the gracious nature of the opportunity given. Gracious obligation antecedes wages
due but is not antithetical to regarding the wages as being due. As believers, we would not have a right to wash one
another’s feet and expect God to give us the opportunity to rule in heaven with Him as our reward unless He had
first graciously opened up the possibility for us to earn such an opportunity. He must first provide us with the
opportunity to earn such a reward and make it contingent on our service to one another.* Unbelievers, for example,
cannot perform this service and demand to receive the same result that God’s children are granted for performing
the same work. The unmerited opportunity to earn misthological grace is only offered to those who freely have
received soteriological grace. God graciously has obligated Himself to reward His children with co-rulership if
they perform the appropriate service. God has not obligated Himself to reward the devil’s children with the same
privilege even if they perform the same work. God’s children who work hard to be rewarded in heaven will not be
treated the same as the devil’s children who work hard to enter heaven.

                                                    Conclusion
       Arminians believe you must endure in order to keep eternal life and be one of the elect. Calvinists believe
that (1) if you are one of the elect, then you will endure, and (2) conversely if you do not endure, then you never
really had eternal life and were never one of the elect. Regardless of which route taken (TULIP or PEARS), the
same conclusion is derived: endurance will determine whether entrance into heaven is attained. In either system,
since you cannot know in advance that you will endure to the end of your life, you cannot be certain that you will
reach heaven until the end of your life. Even at the end of one’s life, a considerable nagging uncertainty about the
quality of endurance may remain so that the absolute assurance of entrance into heaven is not obtained.
       Both TULIP and PEARS claim to believe in salvation by grace; however, in reality, the best they can do
within the confines of their own systems is maintain that salvation is initially by grace but ultimately by grace and
works. The fact that we are called upon to perform these works prevents these works from being considered a gift.
Perseverance in good works is not accomplished without effort on our part. A passive victorious Christian life is a
misnomer. We must be active. Our Christian life is not one of passive receptivity. We are not to be spiritual couch
potatoes waiting for God to give us the victory. We must work if we are to persevere in good works (Tit 3:14).
These works are not a gift. We are actively involved in the production of these good works. Since both the
Arminian and Calvinistic positions logically teach salvation by works (and rob a believer of absolute assurance),
neither system is acceptable to GRAPE theology. In GRAPE one can have absolute assurance regardless of one’s
works. In the other two theologies, one only can have contingent assurance based on one’s works.

 My treatment of biblical texts supporting the concept of co-rulership will commence with discussion of Illustration 22. Triad
Description of Overcoming Rulers, 51.

        In an online review of Dillow’s mediating position, Reagan responds with shock, calling Dillow a hyper-
Calvinist because Dillow rejects the traditional Calvinistic view. Actually, Dillow is at most a modified FG
Calvinist, who has drunk enough GRAPE theology to liberate a believer’s soteriological salvation from the
believer’s perseverance. Perseverance is required to escape the outer darkness, but not to escape hell. This
modification brings Dillow under Reagan’s reproach. Like Reagan, I will reject Calvinistic predestination in the
pages to come. Unlike Reagan, I will also reject the rest of the Calvinistic soteriological scheme as expressed in
TULIP. I will not retain the Calvinistic “P” (perseverance) to which Reagan, as an Arminian, wishes to cling.
        The present work probably will be seen as anti-Calvinistic by both Arminians and Calvinists alike.
Unfortunately, many of those advocating traditional Arminianism or Calvinism will also certainly label the view
expressed herein as being antinomian for the simple reason that, like Dillow, the present writer does not consider
perseverance a requirement for salvation from hell. Nomians insist on making the way you live a condition for
reaching heaven, so it is understandable that they will call us antinomians.* As an Arminian, Reagan rejects
Calvinism, but he embraces the Calvinistic doctrine of perseverance since, as he himself notes, both Arminianism
and Calvinism condition one’s soteriological escape from hell on one’s perseverance: “The traditional Calvinist
would say that because he failed to persevere, he was never saved in the first place. The traditional Arminian
would say he fell from grace. Both would agree that he went to Hell. So, when you get to the bottom line, the
traditional Calvinist and Arminian both agree.”58
        Both PEARS and TULIP concur in concluding their acronym with the necessity of perseverance in order to
reach heaven. The Arminian “S” (salvation through perseverance) is for all practical purposes equivalent to the
Calvinistic “P” (perseverance) since both require perseverance in order to reach heaven.† Both soteriologies would
interchangeably and simultaneously condition the gift of life and the crown of life on a believer’s performance. In
contrast, Marrowism rejects perseverance-based soteriology and concludes its GRAPE acronym with a strong
affirmation of unconditional security. Rewards, rather than the gift of life, are what are at stake on the performance
treadmill. The necessity of this mediating position should be apparent to those who seriously wish to consider the
necessary implications of believers having been saved, in the sense of being fully and eternally justified, by grace
through faith apart from any form of works. This judicial aspect of salvation already has taken place and been
assured. Consequently, it is not conditioned upon ongoing faith or faithfulness. Of course, many others have
undertaken such a mediating endeavor.
        Four-point Calvinists have rejected only one point of TULIP. Others have rejected more. Some only cling to
one point—eternal security—misguidedly thinking that this is one of the points of Calvinism. In actuality though,
Calvinism does not offer unconditional security to the believer. Calvinists, like Arminians, believe in conditional
security, a security conditioned on one’s perseverance. Those who wish to hold to eternal security are invited to do
so by adopting a GRAPE defense.
        Five-point Calvinists maintain that it is impossible to reject even one point of the TULIP and be consistent.
They insist that one must accept all five points or none at all. Vance, Hunt, Hutson, Bryson, and Anderson (among
others) have accepted the challenge to jettison all five points of TULIP and yet affirm eternal security without any
help or hindrance from TULIP.59 In doing so, they have paved the road for a mediating view. It is time for GRAPE.
The examination in this book of the outer darkness from a GRAPE perspective must necessarily be a point of
contention, since it will involve a pilgrimage to Marrowism through a narrow chasm dividing two opposing camps
that reject eternal security. At the same time, pursuing the implications of such findings provides an opportunity to
take part in a journey that provides a fresh position and motivation for living life the way Christ intends, with a
firm assurance of relationship with Him along the way. Marrowism provides misthological hope for tomorrow and
soteriological confidence for today.



*
  Nomian is a coined expression from the Greek word nomos (law) and refers to legalists who believe that soteriological salvation is
conditioned on performance. Antinomian is derived from anti+nomos (anti-law) and refers to those who are against the law. They are
also known as libertines, those liberated from the law. Legalists love to charge non-legalists with being antinomians (i.e. teachers of
lawlessness). Since Paul was a non-legalist, he was slanderously reported as saying, “Let us do evil that good may come” (Rom 3:8).
This trend still survives today. Some Lordship Salvationists slanderously say that those who teach free grace are teaching that the way
a person lives does not matter. This would only be true if rewards do not matter. Perhaps this is the background for some of the
criticism. Lordship Salvationists can appeal to the popular sentiment that rewards do not matter. For many, the only thing that matters
is heaven versus hell. So if you preach that a primary reason to live a good life is to have rewards in heaven, you have said (from their
mistaken perspective) that the way you live does not matter. Nevertheless, biblical Christianity will remain a balance between
legalistic and libertarian extremes.
