                                            Chapter 2.
                                 Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)
                                                   Introduction
        As outlined in the previous chapter, several eschatological and soteriological interpretive options need to be
settled in order to have a firm grasp on what the Scripture intends to convey through the parabolic material
concerning the outer darkness. This chapter will focus on the eschatological alternatives. Traditional interpretations
are not necessarily the correct ones. As chiliasts, the early church fathers held a premillennial position. Yet
Augustine abandoned that traditional view in favor of an amillennial one. Was he justified in doing so? Whose
tradition should we accept? Guthrie’s “principle that a strong tradition must be allowed to stand unless internal
evidence makes it impossible”60 is certainly not without merit. But which tradition should be adopted—the earliest
or the latest? Even aside from this problem, however, one should not make a pope out of tradition. Fidelity to the
text must take precedence over conformity to tradition. The curse in the book of Revelation, pronounced on those
who take away from the message of Revelation (Rev 22:18-19), would fall upon shoddy exegesis, even if such
exegesis has the support of tradition. Fidelity to tradition must not become infidelity to the text. As seen in
Augustine’s example, a modification in one’s eschatology can have a serious impact on one’s soteriology. We
simply cannot afford to simply skip over eschatology, much less skimp over soteriology, on our way to an accurate
misthology.

Date
        Regarding the date of the book of Revelation, the persecution (apparently from the Roman government)
appears to be past, and the current persecution appears to be attributable more so to conflict with the Jews rather
than with the state. John is concerned about his readers overcoming the false doctrine of the Nicolaitans
(Rev 2:6,15). Guthrie believes the tradition should probably be accepted that the Nicolaitans were followers of
Nicolas (Acts 6:5). Nicolas evidently turned heretical since “it is most unusual for any Christian mentioned in the
New Testament to be associated later in tradition with heresy.”61 The danger John presents is that of genuine
believers succumbing to false doctrine, just as Nicolas had done. After all, the presupposition that John is
concerned about the defection of genuine believers to false doctrine is more reasonable than the assumption that he
is worried about the defection of false believers to false doctrine. That Nicolas was a regenerate believer does not
mean that he, or other genuine believers, could not succumb to false doctrine. For those not blinded by their
theological tradition, the reality of this danger is evident in Rev 2:20 where certain believers had succumbed to the
false teaching of Jezebel.
        John is also much more concerned with the believers in Thyatira overcoming the false doctrine of Jezebel
than he is with any state persecution. Their perseverance is expressed in terms of faith and works (Rev 2:19) rather
than in connection with state persecution and not submitting to emperor worship. If state persecution was a
problem for the church at Sardis, how could it sleep through it (Rev 3:2-3)? The church in Philadelphia was
evidently experiencing state persecution, but the persecution appears to be more directly linked with localized
antagonism caused by the Jews rather than by the emperor (Rev 3:9). Finally, the church at Laodicea was certainly
not being persecuted with poverty, much less imprisonment or martyrdom.
        The future persecution of the whole world, mentioned in 3:10 and described in chapters 6-19, does indeed
reflect a conflict between believers and the state. Nevertheless, this conflict appears to be eschatological and is thus
not helpful in determining the date of writing. In summary, it seems that some of the churches outside of Rome
were experiencing persecution, but not all of them. The persecution was being executed intermittently by some
local state authorities but not by others. The persecution could result in poverty, exile, or death. It seems to have
been instigated by a conflict with Jews over the identity of who is really a Jew (Rev 2:9). This situation is exactly
what would be anticipated after the Curse of the Minim in A.D. 90 in which a rabbinical bull was issued to expel
Christians from the synagogues. From the Jewish perspective, these Christians were claiming to be Jews in order to
avoid persecution, but ethnic Jews did not consider these Christians to be Jews. Christians began to be expelled
from the synagogues, and Rome immediately considered Christianity an illicit religion. The punishment was loss
of all goods, expulsion, and death. Therefore, the authorities were inclined to take these actions against Christians
shortly after A.D. 90 at the local level when the local Jewish synagogues insisted upon it. Consequently, internal
evidence corresponds with the external evidence in indicating that Revelation was written A.D. 95 or 96.
Page 34                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
Purpose and Recipients
        Although there appears to be a division in the epistle at Rev 4:1 into two time periods—present and future—
the recipients of both periods are to be identified as genuine believers who are to have their faith tested by various
trials. The purpose of these various tests is not to determine whether or not their faith is soteriologically genuine
but whether it is misthologically victorious. John primarily had written his gospel with an evangelistic purpose,
promising eternal life to those who would believe in Jesus—faith rather than faithfulness being required. On the
other hand, he principally wrote his three epistles to those who already had believed so that they could have
temporal fellowship with Jesus—faith and faithfulness being the requirements. But he writes his apocalyptic
epistle, Revelation, to those who believe in Jesus, chiefly so that they can have eschatological fellowship with
Jesus—faith and faithfulness being the requirements. He shows that there are certain things that faithful believers
(overcomers) will be able to enjoy doing with Jesus that unfaithful believers (subcomers*) will not be able to
enjoy.
        In a variety of ways, John specifies that the intended recipients of Revelation are genuine believers. In the
opening verse, he says that the letter is to Jesus’ servants (Rev 1:1). At the close, he again repeats this statement
(Rev 22:6). Those in danger of subcoming are those who are genuinely the Lord’s servants (Rev 2:20). Those
interpreters who think that the distinction in chapters 2 and 3 is between false believers and genuine believers have
completely missed John’s intended audience and therefore his intended application. More will be said about this in
the upcoming chapter concerning overcomers. For now note that the warnings, exhortations, and promises make no
sense if they are addressed to false believers. The problem with false believers is not that they used to love Jesus
and do so no more (Rev 2:4). It is not that unbelievers have fallen that is so disturbing (Rev 2:5). The exhortation
to unbelievers most naturally would be a summons to faith rather than to faithfulness (Rev 2:10). The problem is
that genuine believers are failing and falling. Unbelievers need to be exhorted to come, not overcome. Since those
being exhorted in chapters 2 and 3 are being urged to overcome rather than come, it stands to reason that they
already had come to faith in Christ.
        The word used in Rev 21:6 and Rev 22:17 to invite the thirsty to come and freely drink (i.e., believe) is
dorean (MT); it is the same word used by John (4:10) and translated as gift. Although Revelation does contain
these evangelistic appeals to come, it should be noted that they are not addressed to the readership. Unbelievers are
to be exhorted to come without cost, and thus to believe. Overcomers are to exhort unbelievers to come—freely. In
contrast, believers are exhorted in the book of Revelation to overcome by paying the cost. Victory will not come
cheaply, freely, or without cost for the overcomer in either the present or the future.
        Numerous reasons for concluding that the exhortations are addressed to genuine believers are readily
apparent. False believers would not be exhorted to hold fast to what they have (Rev 2:25). False believers cannot
be promised that their names will not be erased from the Book of Life (Rev 3:5). The Lord disciplines His children,
not the devil’s children (Rev 3:19). The word used in Rev 3:19 for discipline is paideuo and is considered by Paul
and the writer of Hebrews to be proof that the recipient of such discipline is a genuine believer (1Cor 11:32;
Heb 12:6-7,10). Paideuo is never used in relation to false believers in the NT.
        John refers to the intended readership as his Christian brothers and fellow partakers in the kingdom
(Rev1:9). Time and time again John emphasizes that the Lord is addressing the churches in chapters 2 and 3. If
there is any confusion as to what John means by churches and you in chapters 2 and 3, it should be cleared up
completely by his opening remarks in chapter 1: “John to the seven churches…Grace to you…from Jesus
Christ…who loves us, and released us from our sins by His blood, and He has made us a kingship, priests to
His God” (Rev 1:4-6; TM). When John addresses his readers as the church or you, he intends for his readership to
understand that he is talking about blood-bought believers who have been redeemed by the blood of the Lamb and
who have been made kings and priests. In short, he is not addressing or talking about false believers. The warnings,
*
 Subcomer is a coined expression adopted herein to describe believers who fail to overcome in the sense described in Revelation. That
is, they are genuine believers who fail to overcome experientially and who consequently are overcome by evil. They succumb (i.e.,
subcome, to use the coined terminology) to the world rather than overcome it (e.g., Rom 12:21; 2Pet 2:20). They are genuine believers
who are considered unfaithful and who thus miss out on the rewards promised to overcomers. For the sake of brevity and parallelism,
the nonelect are referred to as noncomers, the elect as comers, the unfaithful elect as subcomers, and the faithful elect as
overcomers. Comer is a coined expression used to refer to those who come to faith in Christ (e.g., Rev 22:17). Noncomer is a coined
expression used to refer to a nonbeliever, to those who refuse to come to faith in Christ (e.g., Jn 5:40). Overcomer is a coined
expression used to refer to those who overcome. Sometimes the word overcome is used as a statement in Scripture to refer to the
positional victory already received by all believers in the past (e.g., 1Jn 5:4-5). However, sometimes it is used in Scripture as an
exhortation, urging believers to progress on to achieve experiential victory in the present (e.g., Rom 12:21). Finally, it is used
futuristically as a promise of rewards to those few believers who will be victorious in faithfulness until the end, thus urging
experiential victory in the present (e.g., Rev 2:26; 3:4-5).
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                   Page 35
exhortations, and promises of chapters 2 and 3 are addressed to genuine believers. Unbelievers or false believers
are not in view at all in these chapters. Correspondingly, the primary purpose of this apocalyptic epistle is to warn
and exhort regenerate believers to overcome any obstacle Satan may place in their path, either now or in the future.
John’s concern is that these genuine believers be overcomers rather than subcomers.

Literary Analysis

                                                 Broad Outline
       The broad outline of the book is given by John himself in Rev 1:19, as Criswell has well stated:

       I remember some lectures saying that there was a key to the interpretation and meaning of
       Revelation, possessed in ancient times, but that key has been lost and we do not possess it today.…I
       have learned just the opposite…The same key that those first and primitive Christians had in the
       Roman province of Asia to whom the letters were addressed, we have today; because the key is
       written here in the first chapter of the book itself.…God has written His Revelation in three
       divisions—in three parts.62

As Criswell goes on to explain, this three-part key is Rev 1:19 where John is told to write the things (1) he has seen
(eides)—past, (2) the things that are (eisin)—present, and (3) the things that will be (genesthai)—future.

                                     Illustration 12. Basic Outline of Revelation
(1) Ch. 1            Things which you have seen                 Past           Description of Christ
(2) Chs. 2-3         Things which are                           Present        Description of Church
(3) Chs. 4-22        Things which will be                       Future         Description of Judgments
                                            Comparison of 1:19 and 4:1
1:19
     Therefore write
     1) the things which you have seen [in 1:12-16],
     2) and the things which are [chs. 2-3],
     3) and the things which will take place after these things….
         a) 4:1 After these things [after chs. 2-3], I looked, and behold, a door was opened in heaven.
         b) And the first voice which I had heard was like a trumpet speaking with me, saying,
         c) “Come up here, and I will show you the things which will take place [chs. 4-22] after these things
              [after chs. 2-3]” (TM).
                                             Comparison of 1:19 and 1:20
1:19
     Therefore write
     1) the things which you have seen [eides],
         2) and the things which are [eisin],
              3) and the things which will take place after these things.
20
   As for the mystery of the seven stars and the seven golden lampstands,
      1) which you have seen [eides] in My right hand:
          2) the seven stars are [eisin] the angels of the seven churches,
               and the seven lampstands are [eisin] the seven churches. (TM)

       The meaning of the statement in 1:19 is spelled out for and by John in the next verse. Jesus explains in 1:20
what John has seen, using the same Greek verb and same tense that He just used in 1:19 (eides). Jesus also explains
the things that are, by twice using the same Greek verb and tense in v. 20 that He used in v. 19 for are (eisin). The
things which are refers to the churches, as Jesus explains in v. 20, and then Jesus immediately gives two chapters
of warnings and exhortations to the churches.
       In the verse that comes immediately after this address to the churches (4:1), John is taken into heaven and
told that he will now be shown the things that will be (genesthai). Again, the same Greek verb and tense is used in
4:1 as was used in 1:19. The most natural conclusion would be that (1) the vision in ch. 1 composes the things that
he has seen; (2) the addresses to the churches in chs. 2 and 3 compose the things that are; and (3) the visions and
wrath of ch. 4 and following show what will be. This conclusion is made even clearer to John and his readers by
the additional descriptive phrase found in 1:19 and 4:1 concerning the things that will be. The ending of 1:19 is so
Page 36                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
identical with 4:1 that both can be translated exactly the same in English: “The things that must/will take place after
these things”63 (TM).
        The first voice John heard in 1:19 said, “Write then the things you have seen, and the things that are, and the
things that must/will take place after these things.” In 4:1, John refers back to that same occasion referred to in
1:19; the same voice is speaking and saying the same thing on both occasions: “After these things, I looked…and
the first voice that I heard…saying, ‘Come up here, and I will show you the things which will take place after these
things.’” Not only is 4:1a the first occurrence after 1:19 of after these things (meta tauta), the same expression is
used again in 4:1c. Therefore, it must be concluded that the futuristic events of 1:19 are the same as those
introduced in 4:1 and consequently that the events of ch. 4 and following deal with the future. As is stressed three
times in 1:19 and 4:1, the events of ch. 4 must occur after the present time period dealing with the church in chs. 2-
3. In other words, the time of wrath (described in the subsequent chapters of Revelation after chs. 2-3) occurs after
the church age.

                                                 Twenty-four Elders
       This understanding is further supported by the identification of the twenty-four elders as rewarded church-
age overcomers who are in heaven. John’s being caught up to heaven in 4:1 does not, in and of itself, indicate the
rapture. However, it does mark a transition to heaven where John sees believers in heaven who already have been
rewarded with crowns (Rev 4:4). It must, therefore, be concluded that they already have been resurrected, raptured,
and judged at the Judgment Seat of Christ (bema). It is this contextual transition, rather than John’s transference,
that demands that the rapture be located at 4:1. They must have glorified earthly bodies before they can be crowned
as glorified earthly rulers, but they will have to await the millennial kingdom before they can begin to exercise that
earthly rulership.
       A number of indicators point to these twenty-four elders as victorious believers rather than angels. (1) These
elders have golden crowns of victory (stephanos; Rev 4:4,10), which is the same kind of crown promised to
overcomers in 2:10; 3:11 (cf. 2Tim 4:8; Jam 1:12). This is also the same type of crown that Jesus wears as a
victorious Son of man in 14:14 (cf. Heb 2:5-8). Jesus wears this crown as a victorious man, and those who share
His humanity and victory will receive the same crown. Admittedly, stephanos is also worn by others, such as the
antichrist in Revelation. Nevertheless, even in this case the crown is closely associated with the concept of
overcoming: “And a crown [stephanos] was given to him and he went forth overcoming [nikao] and to overcome
[nikao]” (6:2; TM). (2) These elders have thrones, but thrones are only promised to believers, not to angels
(Rev 3:21; 20:4; cf. Mt 19:28; Lk 22:30).* (3) The elders wear the white garments which are promised to
overcoming believers (Rev 3:5,18; 6:11; 7:13-14; 19:7-8,14; cf. Mt 22:8-13; Lk 12:35-48; 22:28-30).† (4) The fact
that they are called elders would indicate that they are humans. Angels are never called elders in the Bible. It
would be strange to have these twenty-four, elderly men representing angels. (5) Angels never praise God with a
harp elsewhere in Scripture. Moreover (6) the identification of the elders as angels in Rev 5:8-10 is problematic at
best. Any positive contribution this text may make as to their actual identity favors the identification of the elders
as overcomers.‡
       The number twenty-four signifies that they refer to all designated in that class. Yet it would be a mistake to
assume that the class referred to is all believers or even all believers of the church age. Rather, on the basis of the
passages cited, the position taken herein is that the elders do not represent all believers; rather, they represent all
resurrected, raptured believers who are judged and found to be overcomers at the Bema.64

                                    Illustration 13. Rapture of Church at Rev 4:1
