  Past           Present Church Age                   Future Tribulation                 Future Millennium
  Ch. 1               Chs. 2-3                            Chs. 4-19                          Chs. 20-22
       The astute reader will recognize that this position concerning the outline rules out the amillennial and
postmillennial positions. A comparison of the above illustration with the previous ones will make this immediately
clear. Further, not only does it leave the premillennial option as the only valid option, it goes a long way toward
arguing for a pretribulational rapture as well. The rapture not only happens before the millennium, it happens
before the tribulation. Although this understanding is hotly contested, it is the most natural conclusion. As will be
demonstrated, the most natural interpretation is preferable in light of other details.

                                                Seals and Bowls
       The next major division in the book is that of the seven seals. Gromacki summarizes his preference for the
dispensationalist position well: “The seventh seal introduces the trumpet series and is explained by it. The seventh
trumpet introduces the vial [bowl] series and is explained by it. Thus the seven vials equal the seventh trumpet and
the seven trumpets are the seventh seal.”65
       Although there are strong similarities between these three series of judgments, they are not recapitulations
of one another since there are distinctive differences between them as well as similarities. For example, the
judgment of the fourth trumpet affects the sun, and the judgment of the fourth bowl affects the sun. Thus, some
interpreters would argue that the trumpets and bowls refer to the same event. However, such cannot be the case
since the trumpet decreases the sun’s intensity while the bowl increases it.66 They have an opposite effect upon the
sun. But there are also further differences as Mounce points out:

      Overly subtle interpretations in the interest of recapitulation overlook the distinct differences between
      the two series. Among the more important are: (1) the trumpet-plagues are partial in their
      effect…while the bowls are universal…and final; (2) the trumpets are to a certain extent a call to
      repentance while the bowls are the pouring out of divine wrath; and (3) man is affected indirectly by
      the first four trumpets but is directly attacked from the outset by the bowls.67
Illustration 14. Chronological Outline of Revelation
                                                       Page 38
                                                       The Outer Darkness
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                            Page 39
Major Interpretive Approaches to the Book
        If the above preliminary observations concerning the outline of the book of Revelation are accepted, they
rule out (1) the preteristic interpretation in which the judgments already have been fulfilled in the fall of Jerusalem
(A.D. 70) or of Rome (A.D. 476). The judgments are eschatological and refer to a period of time after the rapture.
Thus, (2) the historicist view is also ruled out since the judgments do not map out present events from the apostolic
period to the second coming. If there were such a map in the book of Revelation, it would have to be found in
chapters 2 and 3.68 Additionally, (3) the idealist approach loses much of its allegorical force. If these judgments are
futuristic, they may indeed represent literal events and depict a struggle that is largely Jewish in nature.
        The approach of interpreters such as Harrison and Mounce—that the judgments have historical and
eschatological fulfillment—is commendable in that this is often true of prophecy.69 Many prophecies have both
historical and eschatological fulfillment. The desolation of the temple in Jerusalem is a popular case in point. On
the other hand, not all prophecies have historical fulfillment preceding, foreshadowing, or typifying their
eschatological fulfillment. For example, it is readily understood that the prophecy reflected in the parable about the
separation of the sheep from the goats (Mt 25:31-46) does not have multiple fulfillments. Likewise, the temporal
indicators in Revelation and the nature of the judgments should lead one to conclude that these prophecies demand
a singular eschatological fulfillment. As a result, one is left with an exclusively (4) futurist interpretation, that is, a
premillennial position.*
        Further, in view of the broad outline, it is not sufficient to take (a) a historical premillennial interpretation in
which a historicist affirms the futuristic nature of the millennium but denies that the judgments are future. Neither
is (b) the covenantal premillennial position acceptable since it attempts to find the fulfillment of some of the
prophecies in the present rather than the future. The only premillennial position left is (c) dispensational
premillennialism.70 The church, which is mentioned so prominently in chapters 2 and 3, is not mentioned again
until after the judgments on earth have been completed (Rev 22:16). Even more importantly, those who accompany
Christ at the second coming (Rev 19:14) are apparently the overcomers. This return of believers with Christ
presupposes the rapture of the church.71 The overcomers of the church age cannot come out of heaven unless they
are first in heaven. Therefore, the rapture (and Bema) must already have occurred previously. This observation is
compatible only with dispensational premillennialism.
                                   Illustration 15. Return of Church from Heaven in Rev 19:14
                                                    Rapture                                     Return
                                                   of Church                                   of Church




     Past              Present Church Age                         Future Tribulation                      Future Millennium
     Ch. 1                  Chs. 2-3                                  Chs. 4-19                               Chs. 20-22
Millennial Binding (Rev 20:1-3)
      1And I saw an angel coming down from heaven, having the key of the abyss and a great chain in his
      hand. 2And he laid hold of the dragon, the serpent of old, who is the devil and Satan, and bound him
      for a millennium, 3and threw him into the abyss, and shut it and sealed it over him, so that he should
      not deceive the nations any longer, until the millennium was completed; after these things he must be
      released for a short time. (TM)

                                                       I saw
       Walvoord states that the opening expression, “‘I saw’ (cf. Rev 19:11, 17, 19; 20:1, 4, 11, 12) marks the
major steps of the progress of the revelation.”72 He reinforces this remark by noting the significance of what John
saw: “The next phase of the prophetic program is introduced by another vision of an angel.”73 Walvoord references
passages such as 7:2; 8:2; 10:1; 17:1 to illustrate the significance of seeing an angel. Such remarks, however,
overstate the dispensational argument. Revelation 7:2 and 10:1 are the beginning statements of parenthetical

*
    For a discussion of these four options as they relate to the Olivet Discourse, see Four Views of Time, 309.
Page 40                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
                                                                                                 74
sections, which Walvoord already has conceded do not advance the chronological process. For John to say, “I
saw an angel,” does not necessarily indicate chronological progress or the next phase. In the case of 8:2, it does
denote chronological advancement to the next phase of the Revelation, but this is determined by the context.

                                                      Bound
      Although Walvoord overstates his case concerning the opening phrase, he does not overstate the
dispensational case concerning the context of the phrase.

      If God wanted to show that Satan was totally inactive and out of touch with the world, how could He
      have rendered it more specifically than He has done in this passage?…I Peter 5:8 should settle the
      matter beyond dispute.…This passage, instead of saying that Satan is bound and unable to deceive
      the nations, pictures him as a lion which has been loosed…John could not see visually how long
      Satan was to be in the pit nor could he see the purpose…This purpose had to be given to John by
      divine revelation…If the record had given only what he saw without any indication as to the meaning
      of the passage, it might have lent itself to diverse interpretation. But with the vision recorded as it is,
      accompanied by the divine interpretation, expositors are not free to inject their own preconceived
      ideas…there is no other alternative than the premillennial interpretation.75

       Satan has been restricted in certain ways. To say that he has fallen like lightning, been bound like a strong
man, and that the gates of his kingdom cannot prevail does not give the complete picture of the present period. His
removal from heaven to earth (Rev 12:9,12) does not totally restrict him. On the contrary, he is very active on
earth (Rev 2:10; 12:17; 13:14). This picture in 20:1-3 does not show Satan being removed from heaven to earth. It
presupposes this previous removal. The angel has to come down from heaven to earth to bind Satan because Satan
already has been removed from heaven to earth. This time, however, Satan is removed from the earth to the
abyss.
                                     Illustration 16. Double Expulsion of Satan
                                                    Expulsion
                                                     of Satan




                Past     Present                 Future
             Theophany Church Age Tribulation Millennium Eternal State
               Ch. 1    Chs. 2-3  Chs. 4-19     Ch. 20    Chs. 21-22



                                                             Expulsion
                                                              of Satan
                                                        Abyss
       The expulsion of Satan at the beginning of the millennium in ch. 20 is not a recapitulation of the expulsion
of Satan that occurs earlier during the tribulation in ch. 12. There is no need for confusion on this matter if one
simply notes the spatial indicators concerning the abyss (abussos). In Lk 8:31, the demons beg Jesus not to send
them into the abyss. He consents and sets them free upon the earth instead. In Rom 10:7, Paul describes the abyss
as the abode of the dead into which one on earth descends in contrast to heaven into which one on earth ascends
(Rom 10:6). The surface of earth would therefore be the intermediate location between heaven and the abyss.
Contrary to some, the surface of earth is not the abyss. The subterranean nature of the abyss is further confirmed by
Revelation itself. The rest of the NT references to the abyss are from the book of Revelation, two of which occur in
our present passage (20:1-3). In Rev 9:1-2, a fallen star from heaven (presumably Satan) is given the key of the
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                      Page 41
abyss from which he releases his demonic horde which come up out of the abyss to torment those on earth. The
subterranean nature of this prison is thus apparent. In Rev 11:7, the beast ascends up out of the abyss to make war
upon the earth. In Rev 17:8, the beast is noted as the one who ascends up out of the abyss and to go to destruction.
Therefore, the subterranean, terrestrial abyss is to be distinguished from the surface of the earth as well as from the
celestial Lake of Fire.*
                                                Illustration 17. Satan’s Two Step Fall


                                 heaven


                                                        to
                                   Rev 9:1-2
                                  Rev 12:9-12
                                                               earth




                                                                               to
                                                            Rev 20:1-3
                                                                                     abyss
        While it may very well be that Rev 9:1-2 and 12:9-12 are recapitulations of the same event, this expulsion of
Satan from heaven to earth must be distinguished from his subsequent expulsion from earth to the abyss by the
sheer nature of the fact that being cast down from heaven to earth is not the same thing as being cast from the earth
into the subterranean abyss. Moreover, in the first casting Satan is given the key to the abyss so that he may free his
demonic hordes. In the second casting, the angel who binds Satan is the one who has the key of the abyss and locks
Satan himself in the abyss. Clearly, different events are being portrayed.
        The timing of the first expulsion (which is that of Satan from heaven to earth) is at the end of the first half of
the tribulation (Rev 12:6). Up until this point in time, Satan will be busy in heaven accusing believers day and
night (Rev 12:10). Tatford offers this reasonable suggestion as the reason for the exclusion midway through the
tribulation:

               Possibly Satan’s last appearance in the heavenly sphere will be at the judgment seat of Christ
          (2Cor 5:10), to discredit the believer and to report his failings so that, when the process of
          examination has been completed, he will no longer be permitted the same access to heaven and will
          be ejected.76

       This hypothesis accords well with the fact that the Bema will be occurring in heaven after the rapture. Also,
after noting that Satan is cast out of heaven where he had been accusing the brethren, in the very next verse John
records: “They overcame him because of the blood of the Lamb and because of the word of their testimony, and
they did not love their life even to death” (Rev 12:11). One would assume that this verse portrays how one
overcomes Satan’s accusations in the previous verse.
       The courtroom scene in heaven frequently is pictured by advocates of eternal security with Satan as the
prosecuting attorney and Jesus as the defending attorney. Satan reads the list of charges and cites the evidence
against us. Jesus counters by presenting His blood in our defense, and the Father dismisses the case as a result.
Satan loses every case against the believer. It is a wonderful picture of eternal security but probably a very shallow
presentation of what will actually occur. To be sure, I affirm eternal security, and it could be that blood of the Lamb
in 12:11 is picturing the basis of that soteriological security (cp. Rev 1:5). However, it must be noted that the
reason that these believers will successfully overcome Satan (who had been accusing them in the previous verse) is
because they are faithful even to death. It was not merely by their faith in the blood of the Lamb that they will
overcome Satan, but by their faithfulness to the blood of the Lamb. In fact, it is highly probable that the reference
to our overcoming by the blood of the Lamb is referring to our washing our own robes and making them white in
practical sanctification. This is certainly the case in Rev 7:14, which is the only other time this complete phrase is
used within Revelation.†

*
    For similar illustration, see “Heaven to Earth to Abyss” in Predestination and the Open View.
†
    See Rev 21:3—Tabernacle, 552.
Page 42                                                                                                                 The Outer Darkness
       Rather than thinking that Satan is merely (or even attempting) to get the Judge to send the believer to hell (a
case Satan would lose every time), the superior supposition is that Satan actually will be dwelling on the same
subject matter that the Bema will be addressing: whether the believer is qualified to be an overcomer and thus a
millennial ruler. After all, that is the purpose of the JSC. Since the text is clear that Satan will be in heaven
accusing believers at the time they are being judged before the JSC regarding this matter, it is reasonable to
propose that he will be making his case against us on the matter at hand. It would be rather strange to think that the
devil will be wasting his time on a matter which is not even being considered and which he cannot possibly win
(regarding our soteriological possession of eternal life) when he could be investing his time in a matter where he
will be able to win many cases dealing with the loss of reward. Those believers who overcome Satan’s
misthological accusations in heaven must overcome him by the way they live on earth. He is our adversary, and the
only way we can become rulers is to overcome this adversary by the blood of the Lamb, the word of our testimony,
and by loving the Lord more than our own lives.* This sequence of events regarding Satan’s expulsion confirms the
premillennial position. I suspect that he will be allowed to attend the judgment and function as our accuser at the
JSC, but he will be excluded from the heavenly city when it is time for the wedding ceremony (for those who are
found faithful) that takes place during the second half of the tribulation.†

Millennial Rulership (Rev 20:4-6)
       Revelation 20:4 is the longest verse in the book of Revelation. It, along with verses 5 and 6, describes the
millennial resurrections and rulership. They are the key verses in this exegesis. Thus, the translation is broken up
into descriptive elements that encompass the description of the rulership, the requirements of the rulership, and the
resurrection for rulership.

                                                    Translation
                                                   Description of Rulership
             4
               And I saw thrones, and they sat upon them, and judgment was given to them.
                                                 Requirements for Rulership
        And I saw the souls of (1) those who had been beheaded because of their testimony for Jesus and for
        the word of God, and (2) who had not worshiped the beast or his image, and (3) had not received his
        mark on their forehead or on their hand,
                                           Premillennial Resurrection for Rulership
        and they were resurrected and ruled with Christ throughout the millennium.‡ 5This is the first
        resurrection. 6Blessed and holy is the one who has a portion in the first resurrection; the second death
        has no power over such ones; but they will be priests of God and of Christ and will rule with Him
        throughout the millennium. (TM) 77

                                                    Resurrection
        Pride of place in the discussion of this passage between premillennialists, postmillennialists, and
amillennialists in determining the nature of the millennium is normally given to the word ezesan (come to life). Yet
John uses two Greek words for resurrection: ezesan and anastasis. His first two references to the resurrection,
which include his footnote, use the word ezesan. His second two references use the word anastasis. He makes it
clear that he is using these two synonyms interchangeably: ezesan “is” anastasis (v. 5).
        The most natural reading would be that there is a literal resurrection from the dead before the millennium
and another after it. This reading, which is the most instinctive one, would destroy both the postmillennial and
amillennial positions. Therefore, postmillennialists and amillennialists seek to demonstrate through contextual and
verbal analysis that the most natural reading is not the one which should be accepted. Such a procedure should not
be overly criticized. First impressions are not always correct, so it is prudent to interact with the claims of those
holding alternative millennial positions and see if the premillennial understanding of the passage is superior.

*
  See Illustration 22. Triad Description of Overcoming Rulers, 51.
†
  See Illustration 129. The Wedding, 361.
‡
  “The rest of the dead were not resurrected until after the millennium.” Footnote his (i.e. John’s). This parenthetical remark is
referred to subsequently as the Johannine footnote or aside in reference to Rev 20:4-6. Translations normally cite it within the text.
Indeed, it is part of the text; nevertheless, it is part of the text just as the footnotes and endnotes of this present book are part of the text
of this book. See Johannine Asides in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John. It is a parenthetical
remark which John himself makes. Also see John in Living Color.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                     Page 43
        In The Meaning of the Millennium, Boettner (a postmillennialist) says that the amillennial exegesis of
Rev 20:1-6 by Hoekema adequately represents his postmillennial position as well.78 Consequently, in this regard,
evaluating the exegesis of Ladd (a premillennialist) versus Hoekema (an amillennialist) on this passage should
suffice, since Boettner has acknowledged that Hoekema’s amillennial exegesis is in essential agreement with his
own postmillennial position. The same thing is true in Three Views on the Millennium and Beyond. This time the
postmillennial co-author is Gentry, but he also offers an amillennial interpretation of millennium in Rev 20:1-6. He
is rightly taken to task by both other writers for doing so. Strimple (the amillennialist co-author) points out that if
Gentry admits that Rev 20:1-6, the only text in the Bible which uses the word millennium, is referring to “the entire
era between Christ’s first and second coming,” then Gentry has no basis upon which to build his distinction
between the current millennium “conditions that prevail now” from a supposed future one of postmillennialism.
“The reader searches in vain for even one biblical text that explicitly sets forth the postmillennial vision” (emphasis
his).79 Blaising (the premillennial co-author) responds similarly:

       Gentry has a “Millennium,” but he doesn’t call it a millennium…He follows a traditional amillennial
       interpretation of relating Revelation 20:1-6 to the interadvent age. However, this leaves him without
       any textual basis for a period in the future of the interadvent age…by taking an amillennial
       interpretation of Revelation 20, he has eliminated what older postmillennialists believed was their
       anchor text. (Emphasis his.)80

       Since Rev 20:1-6 is the anchor text (without which postmillennialism falls apart) and since even leading
postmillennial representatives adopt an amillennial understanding of this key text, it will suffice for present
purposes to demonstrate that the premillennial understanding of this text is superior to that of amillennialism.
Exegesis of this text will, thereby, demonstrate the superiority of premillennialism to both alternatives as advanced
by their popular advocates. Fighting a two-front war is unnecessary when the decisive battle is being waged by a
united opposition. Both amillennialists and leading postmillennialists present a unified and singular perspective in
taking the millennium as referring to the interadvent age in this crucial text. If it can be shown that this age is
future, then both contentions fall with a single blow.

Ezesan
        Both Ladd and Hoekema agree that ezesan (come to life) “must mean the same thing both times it is used”
in the passage.81 The key question is, Does ezesan refer to a physical or spiritual coming to life? Hoekema’s
assessment is that ezesan refers to a spiritual resurrection—a “transition from physical death to life in heaven.”
Hoekema’s arguments are as follows. (1) In distinction to the resurrection described in Rev 20:4-6, the
resurrection described in 20:11-13 is a physical resurrection. Consequently, the resurrection described in 20:4-6
must be another type of resurrection—a spiritual resurrection. (2) Although ezesan refers to physical resurrection in
2:8, it does not in 13:14. (3) Other forms of the verb ezesan in 7:2 and 15:7 refer to spiritual life rather than
physical life.82
        Ladd acknowledges that ezesan and its verbal forms can be used to denote spiritual life, and both
interpreters acknowledge that the context must decide what kind of life is meant. Although one of Ladd’s initial
points concerning Jn 5:25-29 applies to the typical amillennial understanding, rather than to the peculiar
amillennial understanding of Hoekema, the second point Ladd makes applies equally well to Hoekema. Ladd’s
decisive argument concerning Jn 5:25-29 is that ezesan is used to describe those who are spiritually dead as
coming to spiritual life and those who are physically dead as coming to physical life. Thus, ezesan is never used
to describe those who are physically dead as coming to spiritual life. He points out that ezesan is never used in the
NT to describe life after death apart from physical resurrection. In other words, there really is no such thing as a
spiritual resurrection from the dead, such resurrections are physical.
        Ladd’s argument is superior and decisive. In the case of Rev 20:4-6, the context (Rev 20:12-13) and text
(Rev 20:4-5) both specify that the type of life being described is life after death.83 Without exception in the NT,
this would mean a physical resurrection. For this reason, Hoekema’s appeals to Rev 7:2; 13:14; and 15:7 are
entirely beside the point. Revelation 7:2 and 15:7 are not talking about the dead. And if Hoekema is correct that the
wound was not really mortal in 13:3, then 13:14 is not talking about life after death either. Therefore, since the life
being described in 20:4-6 is concerning the dead (i.e., life after death), there is every reason to believe that what is
being described is a physical resurrection and no reason to think otherwise. Not one of Hoekema’s arguments
carries any force since this passage is concerning the dead. In conclusion, the very use of the word ezesan in 20:4-6
to describe what happens to the dead proves that the resurrection involved is physical.
Page 44                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
Anastasis
       Not only does the word ezesan prove the physical nature of the resurrection beyond any reasonable doubt,
but the fact that this ezesan (come to life) is specifically stated by John to be a resurrection does so as well. This
Greek word for resurrection is anastasis. It is used about forty times in the NT and almost always refers to
physical resurrection. (The only possible exception is Lk 2:34.) But like ezesan, there are no exceptions to
anastasis meaning physical resurrection when used in reference to the dead. Blaising likewise surmises that
anastasis “always refers to the elimination of the condition of physical death through bodily resurrection,” and
Lk 2:34 is not actually applicable since “it has no reference to death” (emphasis his).84

Achri
       A third word forms the third argument for understanding the passage as describing physical resurrections—
the word achri (until) in the Johannine footnote. The clear implication of this word until is that after the
millennium the same thing that happened to believers before the millennium will happen to unbelievers after the
millennium. Thus, if Hoekema is correct in arguing for a spiritual resurrection in v. 4 (i.e., a transition from
physical death to spiritual life in heaven), he would have to argue in v. 5 that it means the same thing, that at the
end of the millennium unbelievers will have a spiritual resurrection (i.e., a transition from physical death to
spiritual life in heaven). However, this universalistic conclusion is obviously in error as 20:11-13 illustrates.
Therefore, rather than describing a so-called spiritual resurrection before and after the millennium, the passage
must be describing a physical resurrection before and after the millennium. It is impossible on the basis of 20:11-
13 to conclude that everyone will have a spiritual resurrection, which is what Hoekema’s view concerning 20:4-6
would require. On the contrary, everyone who died will have a physical resurrection.

                                        Illustration 18. Physical Resurrection




                                                    ezesan
                                                 (come to life)




                                                   physical
                                                 resurrection


                          anastasis                                              achri
                        (resurrection)                                           (until)




       In summary, the expression come to life is somewhat ambiguous; it may or may not refer to a resurrection.
The context determines the meaning, and in this case it clearly refers to a resurrection. Both ezesan and anastasis,
pictured above, always refer to a physical resurrection when used in relation to the dead. And this resurrection by
its very nature refers to a bodily resurrection. One resurrection occurs before the millennium and is called the first
one. The second resurrection occurs after the millennium. The sequence in vv. 4-5 is thus: resurrection then
millennium. The other word pictured above, achri (until), is used to recall the fact that the same thing that happens
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                       Page 45
to believers before the millennium will happen to unbelievers after the millennium. Until must be referring to a
physical resurrection both before and after the millennium. Since a physical resurrection clearly occurs before the
millennium, the premillennial position should be accepted because it is the only one of the millennial positions that
affirms a premillennial resurrection.
       This is not to say that premillennialism is built upon one so-called obscure passage. Gentry’s complaint,
citing Blevins, about this passage being made “the tail that wags the dog” is ludicrous. 85 Gentry’s problem is that
he does not even have a dog in the fight. Contrary to Gentry, due consideration to the progressive nature of
revelation would lead one to anticipate that the clearest teaching about the millennium would be in the last biblical
book dealing with the subject of eschatology. Revelation 20:4-6 is not the only argument for the premillennial
position; however, the premillennial position is the only option according to 20:4-6.

                                                      Rulership
        Not only do the three words concerning the resurrection demonstrate the necessity of the premillennial
position, the five words used to describe the rulership of those who are resurrected also indicate a premillennial
resurrection: blessed, holy, thrones, rule, and portion. In fact, Seiss’ argument for the premillennial position rests
primarily on this concept of rulership rather than that of resurrection. According to Rev 20:6 they will reign with
Christ. When does Christ reign? Jesus specifically taught when this would happen: “When the Son of Man will sit
on His glorious throne, you also will sit upon twelve thrones” (Mt 19:28). This authority is received “when the
Chief Shepherd appears” (1Pet 5:4) at the “revelation of Jesus” (1Pet 1:7). This authority will not be exercised until
“in the future”—apparently on the day of His appearing (2Tim 4:8). They receive this reward “at the resurrection
of the righteous” (Lk 14:14). His rule is described in Rev 19:15 as ruling the nations with a rod of iron
(cf. Rev 12:5). His saints will exercise this vengeance, punishment, and judgment with Him (Ps 149:5-9; 1Cor 6:2;
Rev 2:26-27; 3:21). They will not exercise this rulership without first being bodily resurrected,86 and they cannot
exercise eschatological rulership during the millennium if they are not resurrected before the millennium. Thus, the
amillennial and postmillennial positions are ruled out by the futuristic nature of this co-rulership.
        Seiss’ understanding and use of misthology in this passage is commendable but limited. Rulership is
contingent, of course, on the contested position that Christ’s rulership is future. Yet if our co-rulership with Christ
lies in the future, then the fact that this millennial rulership is future is established. Also, if it is a literal earthly
rulership, then its futurist nature is a given.

                        Illustration 19. Premillennial Return for Millennial Rule in Rev 20:4-6
                                                                                    Return
                                                                                    to Rule




  Past            Present Church Age                     Future Tribulation                   Future Millennium
  Ch. 1                Chs. 2-3                              Chs. 4-19                            Chs. 20-22

Blessed
        The reference to blessing in Rev 20:6 is a misthological and millennial blessing, just as it is in Mt 5:3-11.
The millennial blessing of Mt 5:3-11 does not apply to all believers but only to those believers who are poor in
spirit, who are gentle, who are pure in heart, who endure persecution, etc. These so-called Beatitudes, from the
Latin word for blessed, are not be attitudes. These Beatitudes are not merely telling us to have positive attitudes for
the mere sake of avoiding negative attitudes. Jesus is not giving a homily on the virtues of positive thinking. He is
giving solid, tangible reasons for such an attitude. He is promising future rewards. Jesus concludes this list of
blessings in Mt 5:12 by saying, “Rejoice, and be glad, for your reward in heaven is great.” (Also see Mt 24:46-
47.) The reason to be glad or happy is because of your reward. This reward will be in heaven so it is futuristic. But
it will also involve the earth, so it will be millennial. When Jesus says, “Blessed are the gentle, for they shall inherit
the earth” (Mt 5:5), He is not merely saying, “Be happy.” He is saying that believers who are gentle actually will
get something for being gentle—rulership of this planet! YLT is on the right track when it translates Mt 5:10 as,
“Happy [are] those persecuted for righteousness’ sake—because theirs is the reign of the heavens.” The reign (i.e.,
Page 46                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
rulership) of heaven belongs to them, and it will be exercised over this entire planet. NLT rightly translates Mt 5:5
as saying, “The whole earth will belong to them.” There is more to this argument, however, than simply picking
out translations that suite one’s preferences. Thus, the present book will accumulate evidence substantiating the
understanding of Mt 5:3,10 as saying, “The kingship of heaven belongs to them” (TM).*
        The Greek word for inherit in Mt 5:5 is kleronomeo, which BDAG defines as to come into possession of.
Therefore, to inherit something means to own it, to have authority over it.† When Jesus says in Mt 5:10, “Blessed
are those who have been persecuted for the sake of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven,” He is not
merely promising them that they will enter the kingdom. Rather, it will be theirs. The kingdom of heaven will
belong to them. Entrance into the kingdom is by faith, not by works. Entrance is not conditioned on enduring
persecution. Shockingly, Blomberg deduces otherwise:

          The final Matthean beatitude promises a great reward in heaven to those who endure persecution
          (Matt 5:12), but this text simply repeats the theme of v. 10 in which the blessing for endurance is
          “the kingdom of heaven.” The “great reward” of v. 12 must therefore refer to the kingdom itself
          rather than some special status within it. (Emphasis his.)87

       Blomberg dispenses with doctrine of rewards so that he can make heaven itself the reward: “The reward
should be thought of as heaven itself and not some particular status in the life to come.”88 Not surprisingly,
Blomberg appeals to works as necessary evidence that believers must have and yet claims: “This is in no way to
argue for works-righteousness.”89 He notes in Mt 5:3 that the righteousness in view in this (immediate) Matthean
context is “moral uprightness” that characterizes the disciple’s “life-style.”90 According to Blomberg, believers
must enter heaven as a reward and will only do so if they have lived a morally righteous life. Logically, they must
be people whose personal righteousness meets the test. Like the Pharisees of old, they must “trust in themselves
that they are righteous” (Lk 18:9) in order to enter the kingdom. Blomberg is trying to turn Christians into modern-
day Pharisees. But these are the type of people that Jesus excludes from heaven. Having to trust in oneself for
righteousness is self-righteousness. Considering it God-enabled righteousness makes no difference. The Pharisees
of old did the same thing in their prayers: “God thank Thee that I am not like other people” (Lk 18:11). They gave
thanks to God for their moral righteousness. They are like the Christian who says, “There go I but for the grace of
God.” Being dependent on God’s grace to live morally good lives and giving thanks to God for His grace in living
such lives is good. What is bad is depending on such righteousness to get one into heaven. Christians are supposed
to depend on Jesus for imputed righteousness rather than on their personal righteousness to qualify them for
entrance into heaven. Modern-day Pharisees within Christian circles twist Phil 4:13 to mean, “I can work my way
to heaven through Christ who strengthens me.” Perish the thought because such a thought leads to hell rather than
to heaven. God-enabled legalism is still legalism.
       Contrary to his claim otherwise, Blomberg is advocating self-righteousness as a necessary means for
entering heaven. A rebuttal is simple: What is theirs, as a result of enduring persecution, is not entrance into the
kingdom, but the kingdom itself. That is what Jesus says after all: The kingdom is theirs. Basic entrance into the
kingdom already has been granted at the moment of faith and the new birth (Jn 3:3-5). Jesus goes beyond
promising faithful believers entrance into the kingdom by promising them that the kingdom will be theirs; that is, it
will belong to them. He is promising them that they will be able to run the place. The kingship will be theirs
because they will be the kings in the kingdom. They will be the ones sitting on the thrones exercising rulership. By
enduring to the end of their lives, they will attain a rulership at the end of the age. The futuristic nature of this
individualistic rulership thus would be doubly indicated. This inheritance is not referring to current corporate
rulership by the church in the present.
       As one might expect, the background for Jesus’ promise of inheriting the earth may be found in the OT. In
Ps 37, the Greek OT (hereafter LXX) uses the verbal form kleronomeo (inherit), its nominal form inheritance
(kleronomia), and its compound form (katakleronomeo) to affirm the misthological and eternal nature of this
inheritance: “Those that wait upon the Lord, they shall inherit the earth” (Ps 37:9; KJV).91 “The meek shall inherit
the earth” (Ps 37:11; KJV). “The Lord knows the days of the blameless; and their inheritance will be forever”
(Ps 37:18). “For such as be blessed of him shall inherit the earth” (Ps 37:22). “The righteous will inherit the land,
and dwell in it forever” (Ps 37:29). “Wait on the Lord, and keep His way, and He shall exalt thee to inherit the
land” (Ps 37:34). Because this inheritance is conditioned upon waiting upon the Lord, keeping His way, and upon
*
  For preliminary lexical information for kingship, see Present—Future, 54; also see Misthological Entrance, 571.
†
  See Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom, 60. For response to objections, see discussion surrounding Objection to Misthological
Inheritance, 251. Also see discussion of inheritance regarding 1Pet 1:4 in the author’s book Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                           Page 47
being blameless and righteous, the misthological nature of this inheritance is obvious from the OT background.
This reward is based on works and results in one having the special status of being a kingdom ruler.
        That the misthological nature of this exaltation includes rulership also comes across from the OT. In each of
these above verses from Ps 37, the Hebrew verb for inherit is yaresh. Interestingly, in Judges 18:7 this Hebrew
word is translated into Greek as kleronomos by the LXX. English translations render it as ruler (NAS, NKJ),
hereditary ruler (TNK), magistrate (KJV, RWB, WEB), possessing authority (ASV, DBY, JPS), conqueror
(NET), and heir (LXE). In summary, the heir is ruler. Although ruler is not the normal manner in which heir is
translated, this rendition is within its semantic range as shown here.
        In any event, the one who owns the land rules the land does he not? Presumably, the misthological
inheritance would thus entail millennial rulership. In fact, Is 60:21 implies as much. Here, in discussion of the
millennium, the promise is: “Then all your people will be righteous; they will inherit (Heb. yaresh, Gr.
kleronomeo) the land forever.” These righteous heirs are promised: “Foreigners will build up your walls, and their
kings will minister to you….so that men may bring to you the wealth of the nations, with their kings led in
procession….You will also suck the milk of nations, and will suck the breast of kings” (Is 60:10,11,16). “And
strangers will stand and pasture your flocks, and foreigners will be your farmers and your vinedressers” (Is 61:6).
Part of their inheritance was to be served by kings! These faithful Jewish believers will rule Gentile kings. This
millennial rulership/inheritance is to last forever.
        A second reference to inheriting occurs in this context from Isaiah, and it has a double entry regarding
inheriting. “Thus shall they inherit [kleronomeo] the land a second time, and everlasting joy shall be upon their
head” (Is 61:7; LXE). The phrase second time is better rendered as it is in the NAS as double portion: “Instead of
your shame you will have [inherit] a double portion, and instead of humiliation they will shout for joy over their
portion. Therefore they will possess [inherit] a double portion in their land, everlasting joy will be theirs.” They
are doubly promised that they will inherit a double portion in the Hebrew text. (In the OT the firstborn, as the
firstborn heir, received a double portion which entailed rulership.)* According to Isaiah, their heirship/rulership
will be so glorious that the kings of earth will bring the riches of the earth to them in service to them. This is the
background for the promise made in Rev 21:24-26 concerning the kings of the earth, which is yet another context
that associates this blessing of having servant kings with the inheritance: “He who overcomes shall inherit these
things” (Rev 21:7).† In both Isaiah and Revelation, this millennial blessing is used to introduce the eternal state of
affairs. The joy of inheriting this millennial rulership will be everlasting.
        All seven pronouncements of blessing (makarios) throughout Revelation are misthological and millennial
blessings that denote future rewards promised exclusively to those believers who endure by overcoming (Rev 1:3;
14:13; 16:15; 19:9; 20:6; 22:7,14). In Rev 1:3 and 22:7, the blessing is limited to those who heed and keep the
exhortations of the book, which are exhortations to overcome. The temporal reference in Rev 14:13 indicates that
this particular promise is a pronouncement of blessing on martyrs who die during the tribulation and subsequently
are rewarded for their faithfulness. They are blessed because their works follow with them; that is, they will be
judged and rewarded on basis of the way they have lived. This blessing is futuristic, not a blessing experienced
here and now. This eschatological blessing necessarily entails an eschatological millennium, not a millennium that
is currently in process.
        In Rev 19:9 the blessing is limited to those believers who are invited to participate in the marriage supper.
The supper is a millennial activity in the kingdom, not the kingdom itself. All believers will be in the kingdom, but
only those believers who actually get to participate in this activity within the kingdom will experience this marital
blessing. The blessing in Rev 16:15 is not for all believers. This blessing is not for everyone who previously had a
garment, but only for those believers who keep their garments. If you lose the garment, you lose the blessing.
Moreover, the blessing in Rev 22:14 is limited to those believers who keep their garments white by the washing of
practical sanctification. Blessed are those believers who overcome the world by keeping their lives pure from the
pollution of the world for they will inherit the earth and exercise rulership over it.

Holy
       The reference to holy in 20:6 should be compared with the practical sanctification of Rev 19:8 and
Rev 22:11. Not all saints (hagion) are holy (hagios) in this passage.92 To be sure, one may anticipate the questions
that will be raised in response to this statement. Does not the NT describe all believers as saints? Would not the

*
  Portion denotes rulership in the context of Revelation as well. For brief treatment, see Millennial Thrones, 49. For extended
discussion, see The Portion of the First Resurrection, 71.
†
  See Kings, 652.
Page 48                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
designation of saints be a positional term? Are not all saints thus holy? By way of response, the popular definition
may be acknowledged in which saints means sanctified ones. It can be used in absolute terms to refer to all
believers who are positionally righteous. Alternatively, it can also be used in relative terms to refer to believers
who are practically righteous, that is, to those believers who are submitting to practical sanctification. Thus, it may
be limited to positional saints who are also practical saints.
       Some translations bring out the definitional aspect of this meaning of saints more clearly than others: “Here
is a call for the endurance of the saints, those who keep the commandments of God and their faith in Jesus”
(Rev 14:12; ESV). Here saints are defined as (or limited to) those who keep the faith and the commandments.
Alternatively, an expanded translation might make it even clearer: “Here is the perseverance of the saints, that is,
those who keep the commandments of God and their faith in Jesus” (TM). The saints, in this verse, are those who
persevere in faith and faithfulness. Or it could be stated that the saints in view are those who persevere in faith and
faithfulness. Likewise, in 19:8 the saints in view are those who clothe themselves in practical righteousness. These
verses are not talking about all saints/believers but only about those saints/believers who are persevering in
holiness and who are clothing themselves with holiness, which results in misthological holiness.
        The NAS correctly renders the imperative of Rev 22:11 as, “Let the one who is holy [hagios], still keep
himself holy [hagiazo, verbal form of hagios].” The imperative mood argues against this verb being taken as a
divine passive. It is an exhortation for the believer to keep himself holy, not a promise that he will be kept holy by
God. The passive voice of this verb can be used interchangeably with its middle voice. The only other time this
verb occurs in this identical form is in Mt 6:9. However, the Lukan parallel uses the middle voice (Lk 11:2), and
both verses are translated the same: “Holy be Thy name,” a request meaning, “Keep Your name holy.” Thus, the
verb in Rev 22:11 is an imperative meaning, “Keep himself holy.” They are to keep themselves holy just as the
Bride is to dress herself in holiness (Rev 19:8). Those who are holy (Rev 19:8; 20:6; 22:11) are those who make
and keep themselves holy by the washing of practical sanctification. This is a practical rather than a positional
holiness. It is experiential. Those who are positionally holy are being called upon to demonstrate this positional
holiness practically in their experience.
       This usage is similar to where Peter addresses believers, “Like the Holy One who called you, become
(ginomai) holy yourselves also in all your behavior” (1Pet 1:15; TM). Here, Peter uses an imperative (with middle
voice) to tell believers to become holy in their behavior. He is calling for a behavioral holiness, an experiential
holiness. Yet in the very next verse, many translations have Peter saying, “You will be (eimi; CT) holy, for I am
holy” (1Pet 1:16).* Unfortunately, some English readers may think this is a promise. However, as the previous
verse indicates, it is a command, not a promise. When a parent tells his child, “You will do your homework,” the
child understands that the parent is issuing a command rather than making a promise. The MT in fact uses an
imperatival form of ginomai in verse 16 with corresponding middle voice: “Become holy.”
       Even if the CT reading of eimi is adopted, this form of the verb in Greek may be understood as either an
indicative or an imperative. Moreover, even those commentators who prefer the indicative mood frequently point
out that it has the force of an imperative. Many translations render 1Pet 1:16 as: “Be holy, for I am holy.” Since the
verb may be an imperative in form or understood as an imperative in function, even if it is indicative in form, the
second translation is preferable. It is imperative in function even if it is indicative in form. Alternately, perhaps,
one could compromise and translate it as: “You are to be holy, for I am holy.”
       In any case, the verb is contextually futuristic, and Peter is calling on his Christian readers to become
(ginomai) something they are not yet—holy. Or at the very least, he is urging them to progress to a level of
experiential holiness that they have not yet obtained. However, in the next chapter the translations readily
acknowledge that Peter confirms that his readers are holy: “You are…a holy nation” (1Pet 2:9). So there is a sense
in which his readers are already holy and another sense in which they are not yet holy. Peter is urging his readers to
become more fully in practice what they already are in position. Be what you are—holy. Will the Christian readers
be found to have lived holy lives when their lives are assessed at the future judgment? The fact that this holiness is
commanded rather than promised leaves the matter unsettled. Each reader must answer that question for him or
herself by the life that he or she lives.
       Those pronounced holy in Rev 20:6 are those who have responded affirmatively and as a result are being set
aside (i.e., sanctified) to serve God in the experience of rulership. Both their rulership and holiness are experiential,
not merely positional. For this reason, these overcomers are blessed. This holiness is more than sinless perfection
in the afterlife. All believers will be holy in that sense of the word. All believers will experience perfect


*
    GGBB considers this a future indicative used as a command and thus an example of an imperatival future.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                                          Page 49
                  *
sanctification. The holiness in this apocalyptic context, though, is tied to a misthological blessing and is therefore
a blessing pronounced on the basis of practical sanctification. They have been judged to be experientially holy and
blessed as a result. Such pronouncement presupposes judgment, a proleptic judgment that occurs before the
millennium begins. Again, this pronouncement of blessedness and holiness is futuristic and premillennial, and
argues for a physical, premillennial resurrection.

Millennial Thrones
       A difference of opinion exits as to how many groups John is referring to in Rev 20:4-6: one, two, or three
groups. Grammatically, those who sit on the thrones potentially could be the souls (psuche). Nonetheless, such a
position is doubtful syntactically and is ruled out contextually. These souls are to be identified with those souls in
Rev 6:9, and thus most likely refer to the disembodied martyrs of the tribulational period. They are pictured as
under the alter and not on thrones in Rev 6:9 because they have not yet received their resurrected bodies.
                                                    Illustration 20. Elder’s Throne




                                                                 elder



       In contrast, only one group is mentioned earlier in Revelation as sitting on these heavenly thrones—the
twenty-four elders (Rev 4:4; 11:16). That the twenty-four elders are crowned and are on thrones in heaven does not
mean that they are ruling yet. The argument that the rule is exercised by them in heaven during the intermediate
state on the basis of passages such as Mt 5:12 is superficial. The context specifies in Mt 5:5 that this heavenly
reward will be exercised on earth. The phrase in heaven, in Mt 5:12, refers to its eschatological location rather
than its spatial location. This phrase pinpoints it in a futuristic location on the eschatological map; it will be
exercised in the future on earth. Such rewards are stored up in heaven now (cp. Mt 6:1,20) to be exercised on earth
then. No exercise of rewards exits during the intermediate state. The OT and NT saints are seen waiting in heaven
during the intermediate state to receive their yet their future reward (Rev 11:18). They are not ruling in heaven but
waiting to exercise their heavenly reward on earth.
       The twenty-four elders will exercise their rule on earth during the millennium (Rev 5:10). The text states
in 5:10 that they will reign on the earth. The tense of the verb is futuristic, not present. They will reign then; they
are not reigning now. As will be demonstrated subsequently (and as Huber already has explained previously), the
results of the Bema are not executed until after the millennial banquet has started (cf. Mt 22:13).93 The book of
Revelation never pictures any angel on a throne. This privilege of sitting on the throne is limited to overcomers
(Rev 3:21). And regardless of the preferred reading in Rev 5:9-10, the text makes it clear that it is blood-bought
*
  Sanctification is commonly broken up into three designations. Positional sanctification refers to our sinless position in Christ—to
who we are in Christ. Practical sanctification refers to our present experience in Christ—how we live in Christ. Although we do not
achieve sinless perfection in the present life, it would be technically correct to say that our present experience in Christ is sinless. That
is, anything in our present experience that is not sinless is outside of our experience in Christ. Sin is part of our life, but not a part of
our life in Christ. The question then is, “How much of our life is lived inside Christ and how much is lived outside Christ?”
Nevertheless, this level of precision is not necessary for our present discussion. It is sufficient to say that practical sanctification refers
to our present experience—whether we live a godly life, not to whether we live a sinless life. Perfect sanctification refers to our future
experience in Christ when we will be fully in practice what we are in position. We will be what we are—sinless.
Page 50                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
people rather than angels who will be exercising this rule (cp. Heb 2:5). Additionally, there is every reason to agree
with Walvoord: “The most probable interpretation is that they are the twenty-four elders who are said to reign on
earth (Rev 5:10).”94 The ones who will be doing the reigning are the twenty-four elders: blood-bought believers
who overcome.* They do not represent angels who abdicate their thrones to overcomers by casting their crowns at
Jesus feet in Rev 4:10 since they still retain those thrones in 11:16.
       This being the case, there are at least two groups of enthroned overcomers. The group sitting on the thrones
during the tribulation represents resurrected overcomers of the church age (i.e., the twenty-four elders). As
Pentecost repeatedly points out, they are the saints of the church age, not angels or OT saints. They already will
have received their resurrected bodies at the time of the rapture and are thus able to take their seats on thrones
during the tribulation as they await the end of the tribulation so that they can exercise their earthly rulership from
those thrones at the conclusion of the tribulation. The other group of overcomers who are enthroned at the
beginning of the millennium represents the saints of the tribulational period and of the OT period who are
resurrected at the conclusion of the tribulation. They are not raised until the end of the tribulation.95 The
disembodied souls beneath the altar are martyred overcomers of the tribulational period. They are not resurrected
until the millennium. They are given white garments during the tribulation while they await the opportunity to
exercise judgment, but they do not assume their position on their thrones until they are raised (Rev 6:9-11; 20:4-6).
Both groups are declared by Rev 20:6 to be blessed and holy. This is an affirmation of the misthological blessing
and the practical holiness that are true only of believers who experientially overcome.
                                        Illustration 21. Overcomer’s Throne




                                            overcomer



       There could possibly be a third group. Sometimes the argument is made that the second and who in
Rev 20:4 introduces a separate group.† Nevertheless, more likely it introduces a phrase that further describes the
martyrs and thus gives a total of three requirements for being an overcomer in the tribulation and to
overcome Satan’s misthological accusations at the Bema.‡ The verse gives three requirements, not three groups.
This position coincides very well with the earlier Johannine definition of a tribulational overcomer: “They
overcame him (1) because of the blood of the Lamb and (2) because of the word of their testimony, and (3) they
did not love their life even when facing death” (Rev 12:11; TM).

        To be an overcomer in the sense of the word described in Revelation requires more than mere faith, more
than merely being a regenerate believer. One must not only be redeemed by the blood of the Lamb, bearing public
testimony to that redemption and be willing to shed one’s blood for the Lamb is also necessary if that is what is
required to maintain that testimony. Being saved from the penalty of sin by the blood of the Lamb is not enough.
We must also appropriate the power of His blood to overcome the power of sin and the pressure of this beastly
world if we want to rule over the world to come. The victory of these martyrs in heaven is associated in Rev 15:2
with their response to the beast’s number. For these reasons, the arguments of commentators such as Lang, Govett,
and Tatford that there are three groups are not convincing. Of course, the fact that the martyrs are singled out for
special distinction does not mean that other overcomers will not rule. John already has made it quite clear that all
overcomers will rule. Those believers who live before the tribulation and overcome in that time period are not
excluded from rulership. Nor are those overcomers who live till the end of the tribulation excluded. Overcomers in
the latter group will not have worshiped the beast or have taken his mark and will “not [have] loved their life [i.e.,
soul] even when facing death,” even though they are not martyred.
        Tribulational overcomers, as Johnson notes, “may or may not actually suffer physical death for Christ, but
they have (like John) so identified themselves with the slain Lamb that they have in effect already offered up their
lives.”96 John had recorded Jesus’ teaching concerning this matter earlier as well: “He who loves his life [i.e., soul]
loses it; and he who hates his life [i.e., soul] in this world shall keep it” (Jn 12:25). Literal martyrdom is not
necessarily required to be an overcomer and receive such rewards. Even those believers who metaphorically take
up their cross and follow Jesus will save their lives (i.e., their souls) in terms of rulership, whether that cross
involves literal or figurative death. Their lives will demonstrate a love for their Lord rather than for their own lives
(Lk 9:23-26). If the synoptic parallels were combined for this passage, something like the following would be the
result:

             When He had called the people to Himself, with His disciples also, then He said to them all (and
        to His disciples in particular), “If anyone desires to come after Me, let him deny himself, and take up
        his cross daily, and follow Me. For whoever desires to save his soul will lose it, but whoever loses
        his soul for My sake will save it. For what does it profit a man if he gains the whole world, and
        destroys himself, that is, loses his own soul? Or what will a man give in exchange for his soul? For
        whoever is ashamed of Me and My words, the Son of Man will be ashamed of him when He comes
        in His own glory, and in His Father’s, and of the holy angels. For the Son of Man will come in the
        glory of His Father with His angels, and then He will reward each according to his works.”
        (Composite of Mt 16:24-27, Mk 8:34-38, and Luke 9:23-26; TM)

       The personal and misthological profit that Jesus promises—primarily to His disciples (see Mt) as a result of
daily (see Lk) taking up one’s cross and following after Him in discipleship—is the reward (see Mt) which is
explicitly identified as the salvation of one’s soul.* That is, one’s earthly life will be saved from loss of reward at
the JSC and will result in the person (who faithfully exerted this effort) receiving misthological profit (opheleo)†
rather than misthological shame.‡ In addition to clarifying that this is a daily sacrifice, Luke also specifies that the
action being stressed is that we carry our own cross in the subsequent parallel (Lk 14:27). Granted, the purpose of
a cross is death, but the point Jesus is emphasizing is not our passive death (cp. 2Cor 4:11; Gal 2:20) but our active
commitment to such death (cp. Rom 8:13). Luke further emphasizes that we must count the cost (Lk 14:28) of such
discipleship if we are to be able to achieve the eschatological objective. Of course, our salvation from damnation
was accomplished by Christ’s cross and cost Christ His life. Our salvation from eternal damnation cost us nothing.
These passages, therefore, are not discussing such salvation accomplished by Christ’s cross. Instead, they picture a

*
  For a distinction between salvation of the soul and spirit, see endnote 186. For salvation of one’s life/soul, see 1Pet 1:5 and Lk 9:56
in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
†
  See Personal Profit Basis for Loving Others,, 747; Misthological Profit for Serving Others, 747.
‡
  See Misthological Shame, 672.
Page 52                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
salvation that cost our lives and that is accomplished by our own cross and daily sacrifice. This salvation is a
reward, as Matthew clarifies both here and in the parallel in Mt 10:37-42. Thus, the salvation of the soul in these
contexts is a misthological issue. Even a Calvinist like MacDonald admits, “The expression ‘save your souls’ never
means to save from hell.”97 Understanding that we are bearing our cross in order to be rewarded with a crown is
vital. We dare not try to earn the gift of eternal life. Christians following after Christ on the performance treadmill
are seeking a crown rather than a gift.
                                                 Illustration 23. Cross for a Crown




       Many will come to (i.e., believe in) Jesus for spiritual life but fail to come after Christ for soulical life. In the
Lukan parallel, the contrast between the two is implicit: “If anyone comes to Me, and does not hate his own father
and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be My disciple.
Whoever does not carry his own cross and come after Me cannot be My disciple” (Lk 14:26-27). Many who come
to saving faith in Christ will fail to come after Christ in saving discipleship. They will be saved from the Lake of
Fire but not from the forfeiture of one’s earthly life (i.e., soul) in terms of heavenly rewards.98 They will have the
free gift of eternal life but fail to reap the costly reward of misthological life.* The throne is promised to faithful
followers of Christ, not to mere believers in Christ (Mt 19:27-28; Lk 22:28-30).
       Those future believers who stay awake morally and metaphorically and who live till the end of the
tribulation and the beginning of the millennium will be blessed misthologically. They will not lose out on the
opportunity to rule during the millennium just because they did not literally lose their lives. Those who stay awake
and live through the tribulation are pronounced blessed, as are those who die during the tribulation (Rev 14:13;
16:15).
       Love is a crucial element. Paul clearly affirms the necessity of performing one’s works out of love in order
to be counted worthy of reward (1Cor 13:3). John teaches the same misthological truth. It takes faith, faithfulness,
and a correctly focused love to be an overcomer within John’s apocalypse. The church at Ephesus was the first of
the seven churches addressed in chs. 2-3. It was commended for its work and perseverance. Yet John notes that
they have failed to achieve overcomer status because they had left their first love (Rev 2:1-7). An apocalyptic
overcomer is a believer who perseveres in faith, faithfulness, and love—regardless of the cost.
       To summarize, the souls that John sees are those martyred during the tribulation who had cried out for
vindication in Rev 6:9-11. They are overcomers who were martyred (Rev 12:11) for refusing to worship the beast
or take His mark (Rev 13:15). They are in the intermediate state (as souls) waiting for their glorified resurrected
body. These souls are worthy to be clothed in white garments for three reasons according to 20:4—because of their

*
    See “Misthological Life” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                    Page 53
martyrdom, refusing to worship the beast, and refusing to take the mark of the beast. Those overcomers who live
till the end of the tribulation also will have these garments. White garments are not given to subcomers within the
book of Revelation. White garments are given only to overcomers who are correspondingly worthy to wear them
because they have paid the price necessary to become an overcomer and have washed their own robes in practical
sanctification. They are thus rewarded with rulership (Rev 3:4-5,18; 4:4; 7:13-14). This rewarded rulership
necessarily requires that it be located in the future after the Bema differentiation.
        These tribulational overcomers are martyred during the tribulation but do not exercise their rulership during
the tribulation. They do not exercise their rulership in the intermediate state. Their rulership is not exercised until
after they are resurrected and they receive their resurrection bodies in Rev 20:4-6. They do not exercise their
rulership until judgment is given to them to co-rule with Christ throughout the millennium (and thus after they take
their thrones).

          They were resurrected and ruled with Christ throughout the millennium….6 Blessed and holy is the
          one who has a portion in the first resurrection; the second death has no power over such ones; but
          they will be priests of God and of Christ and will rule with Him throughout the millennium.
          (Rev 20:4-6; TM)

       The fact that they take their thrones before the millennium demonstrates that they are resurrected before the
millennium. The premillennial option is the only one that is viable since rulership is not exercised in the
intermediate state. Overcomers must return to earth and receive their glorified bodies before they can rule the
world.
       Concerning these verses, Zeller assumes that having no portion in the kingdom means to be excluded from
the kingdom.99 In doing so, he fails to note that portion in is equated with rule with. Portion denotes rulership. To
be excluded from such a portion is to be excluded from rulership of the kingdom, not from the kingdom itself.
Further, since rulership is merited and since portion (meros) is an inheritance motif, the verse confirms what Zeller
denies: This inheritance is a misthological blessing conditioned on the believer’s performance. This blessing is
only conferred upon faithful believers. As a result, broadly speaking, there will be two types of resurrected
believers in the millennial kingdom: the have’s and the have-not’s. There will be those who have thrones and those
who do not.

Rule

       Past
       The verb used in connection with the rulership exercised by the overcoming martyrs in Rev 20:4 is basileuo
(to rule or to be a ruler or king). This is the same word also used in 5:10 concerning the twenty-four elders.
Resurrected overcomers of both the church age and the tribulational period will have a part (portion) in the
rulership. However, a chronological progression of thought occurs in Revelation concerning the rulership. In 1:6 it
reads, “He has made us priestly kings” (TM). Overcomers will be priests on their thrones as He is “a priest on His
throne” (Zech 6:13). The imagery of our sharing this priestly throne goes back to the OT:
          6
           But you will be called the priests of the Lord; You will be spoken of as ministers of our God. You
          will eat the wealth of nations, and in their riches you will boast. 7 Instead of your shame you will
          have [i.e., inherit] a double portion, and instead of humiliation they will shout for joy over their
          portion. Therefore they will possess a double portion in their land. Everlasting joy will be theirs.
          (Is 61:6-7)

       As noted previously, these priestly rulers will inherit a double portion, which is an inheritance that belongs
to the firstborn entailing rulership.* More explicitly, they are called royal priests even in Ex 19:6. The
misthological realization of these promises is limited to overcomers. All believers are already kings and queens
positionally and potentially, but in the future only overcomers will retain that status misthologically and be able to
exercise that position fully. What they are now in position, they will then be in practice. The authority that
believers can exercise now on earth as God’s full-grown sons in spiritual warfare is but a dim shadow of the
authority that they will be able to wield as overcomers over the nations of earth during the future millennium.

*
    See Blessed, 45.
Page 54                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
       Present—Future
       Revelation 5:10 picks up with this present description and moves to the future. He has “made us priestly
kings to our God, and we will rule upon the earth” (TM). The Textus Receptus (TR) reads us in 5:10, and this
reading is the most conclusive in favor of the interpretation adopted herein. Even so, adoption of this reading is not
required due to the identification of the elders as overcomers on other bases.*
                                    Illustration 24. Textual Options for Rev 5:8-10
                           NAS                                                           NKJ
8
  And when He had taken the book, the four living creatures 8 Now when He had taken the scroll, the four living
and the twenty-four elders fell down before the Lamb, creatures and the twenty-four elders fell down before the

tongue and people and nation. 10 And Thou hast made them Out of every tribe and tongue and people and nation,
