CT= Critical Text                                MT = Majority Text                          TR = Textus Receptus

        Constable prefers to think of the elders as angels, so the reading on the left correspondingly would be
suitable for his interpretation. Still, his observation about the harps seems quite at odds with his preference: “While
the four living creatures and 24 elders prostrated themselves in worship, only the elders had harps (lyres) and
bowls. They used the harps to praise God in song (Ps. 33:2; 98:5).” In a footnote to this statement, he states that the
reason he confidently can assert that only the elders have the harps and bowls is because “this is clear in the Greek
text from the gender of kekastos, translated ‘having.’” Yet in the very next footnote he continues: “This is the only
place in Scripture where angels praise God with harps.”100
        In counterpoint, if the elders represent human overcomers, as seems to be the case, then this text is
harmonious with the rest of Scripture in that angels never praise God with harps. Human beings are always the
ones who praise God in this manner in the rest of Scripture. If the neutral reading on the left is adopted, then the
most that can be said in defense of Constable’s preference for identifying the elders as angels is that it is possible to
interpret the elders as angels who are singing about someone else other than themselves. If this is the case, then
these angels are singing about redeemed men who overcome and who will thus rule. Yet even the word men is not
supplied by the Greek text for those translations following the Greek text on the left. The reading on the left is
neutral in that it neither positively affirms or negatively denies that the elders are in fact angels or men. Granted the
CT reading on the left is consistent in its neutrality; however, I still would submit that the previous positive
arguments in defense of identifying the elders as overcomers carry more weight than this neutral CT reading on the
left, especially in light of the fluctuation in textual tradition.
        The TR on the right is equally consistent in its positive identification of the elders as human overcomers as
the CT is in its neutrality concerning their identity. So if the reading on the right is chosen, it positively contributes
to my previous identification of the elders as human overcomers. My preference will be for the textual tradition on
the right, not merely because it is in harmony with my theological assessment but because the MT is inconsistent in
which approach to take. According to the MT, those singing and praising God are doing so in recognition of the
fact that they themselves are redeemed: “You were slain and have redeemed us” (Rev 5:9). But this is a song that
the angels cannot sing! Angels have not been redeemed and hence cannot sing a song of their personal redemption.
If the MT reading on the right concerning v. 9 is accepted, then the rest of the reading on the right follows much
more intuitively than that on the left. Therefore, since the TR is supported by the MT in v. 9, since the reading of
the TR is much more internally consistent than that of the MT, and since the reading of the TR is more
theologically consistent than the neutral reading of the CT, the TR textual tradition concerning the identity of the
elders will be adopted.
        The Greek grammar would also allow the possibility that the masculine participles for having and saying are
referring exclusively to the twenty-four elders who are also masculine in Greek (as opposed to the four living



*
    See Twenty-four Elders, 36.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                      Page 55
creatures which are neuter). For textual, theological, and grammatical reasons, I will insert this clarification
parenthetically into the NKJ above:
       8
         Now when He had taken the scroll, the four living creatures and the twenty-four elders fell down
       before the Lamb, each of the elders having a harp, and golden bowls full of incense, which are the
       prayers of the saints. 9 And the elders sang a new song, saying: “You are worthy to take the scroll,
       and to open its seals; for You were slain, and have redeemed us to God by Your blood Out of every
       tribe and tongue and people and nation, 10 and have made us kings and priests to our God; and we
       shall reign on the earth.” (Rev 5:8-10).

       As to other potential ambiguities, the CT, MT, and TR agree that the Greek text uses the future tense of the
verb for reign (basileuo), so I certainly will proceed with this understanding as my premise. Granted, some Greek
texts use a present tense, but Mounce points out that “it seems unlikely that John is here referring to a present
spiritual reign of believers,” and even if the verb (basileuo) is present tense, it would be a futuristic present used to
impart assurance.101 So the tense of the verb as expressed in the CT, MT, and TR strongly supports the thesis
herein that the elders represent overcomers of the church age who will sing of their redemption, royal status, and
future reign. Even those manuscripts which say otherwise are not detrimental to such an interpretation.
       The Greek verb that they use to sing of being redeemed (agorazo) is used subsequently of another redeemed
group in Rev 14:3-4. This subsequent group, the hundred and forty-four thousand (hereafter simply called the
144,000), are the only ones who can sing the new song. From the earlier context, I would identify them as the
Jewish evangelists of the tribulation period (Rev 7:4-8). The rest of that previous chapter (i.e., Rev 7:9-17)
immediately goes on to describe a vast number of overcomers—evidently won by their ministry. One would
anticipate that the 144,000 themselves would be numbered among those overcomers. The latter context would
certainly suggest that they are overcomers as well (Rev 14:4-5).
       Accordingly, the elders are redeemed overcomers from the church age, and the 144,000 are a special group
of overcomers during the tribulational period. In both cases, the only ones who can sing these particular songs are
redeemed overcomers. The text concerning the 144,000 explicitly affirms, “And they sang a new song before the
throne and before the four living creatures and the elders; and no one could learn the song except the one hundred
and forty-four thousand who had been purchased from the earth” (Rev 14:3). While it may be assumed that
everyone in heaven, human and angelic alike, will have songs which they can sing in praise to God, certain songs
can only be sung by those believers who overcome. Equally apparent, not every group of overcomers will have the
same song. Obviously, only overcomers can personally offer praise to God for enabling them to overcome and for
rewarding them with rulership as a result of overcoming. Therefore, not surprisingly, in the only two places in
which the phrase new song occurs in the NT (Rev 5:9; 14:3), only overcomers will be doing the singing.

       Kings or Kingdom
       Some question exists concerning what is the best wording in 1:6 and 5:10—kings or a kingdom. The KJV
and NKJ read kings while the other translations, such as the NAS, typically read kingdom. “He has made us to be a
kingdom [basileia, CT, MT], priests to His God” (Rev 1:6). “And Thou hast made them to be a kingdom [basileia,
CT] and priests to our God; and they will reign [basileuo] upon the earth” (Rev 5:10). This difference is also
reflected in the Greek manuscripts. The critical and majority texts read kingdom in 1:6. However, in 5:10, CT reads
kingdom while both majority texts (MT) and TR read kings. The NKJ follows the wording of the KJV and reads
kings. Although kings reads much better, kingdom may very well be correct from a textual criticism point of view
in recording the actual Greek word used as basileia. However, while it may be conceded that those translations
following the CT might possibly be on a firmer footing in terms of textual tradition, regarding them as superior in
terms of actual translation is contextually questionable.
       Admittedly, basileia is normally translated as kingdom. Obviously, however, believers are not made a
kingdom in the sense of being made a territory. For this reason, BDAG (1.a) lists Rev 1:6 and 5:10 in the section
were basileia means kingship. He has made us a kingdom, that is, a kingship of kings—one kingdom ruled over by
many kings, not many kingdoms ruled over by many kings. His kingdom is one kingdom subjected to the rulership
of many kings. He is the King of kings. Consequently, the translation of kings by the KJV and NKJ is preferable to
the translation of kingdom, since the rendering of kings does a better job of bringing out the meaning of basileia in
the context of 1:6 and 5:10. It is evident from the context of 5:10 that basileia is used here to refer to the rulers of
the kingdom; it does not refer to its subjects. Commentators commonly recognize this fact. In fact, Pentecost
quotes Ladd at length in agreement concerning this very important matter:
Page 56                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
                The primary meaning of the New Testament word for kingdom, basileia, is “reign” rather than
          “realm” or “people.” A great deal of attention in recent years has been devoted by critical scholars to
          this subject, and there is practically unanimous agreement that “regal power, authority” is more basic
          to basileia than “realm” or “people.”…
                …Here the basileia is clearly neither the domain nor the subjects, but the authority to rule as
          king in the given domain over its people (Luke 19:11-27).
                The same use is found in Revelation 17:12. “And the ten horns that thou sawest are ten kings,
          who have received no basileia as yet; but they receive authority as kings, with the beast for one
          hour.” Clearly, basileia is a redeemed people; but they constitute the basileia not because they are
          subjects of the king, but because they share his regal power: “and they reign upon the earth.”102

       Translators should bring this truth out since it is so commonly recognized by those studying the original
language. This would be easy to do in English since basileia can just as well be translated kingship as kingdom.
The KJV and NKJ have shown sensitivity to the context by rendering it as kings. Other translations would do well
to demonstrate similar sensitivity to both the context and the Greek text by rendering it as kingship.*
       Overcomers constitute the kingdom because they constitute the kingship. They constitute the rulership
because they exercise the authority as rulers. Therefore, even if basileia (kingdom) is the preferred textual reading,
it means practically the same thing as basileus (king) in this context. The only difference is that basileia refers to
rulers of one kingdom—many kings over one kingdom. Thus, a better way to translate basileia would be rulership
or kingship. Or in these particular contexts, basileia would be well translated, “A rulership of rulers (i.e., a
kingdom of kings)” meaning co-rulers (cf. 2Tim 2:12) over one kingdom. But since we are not only kings, but
priests in these contexts, the best translation is, “A rulership of priests” or “priestly kings.”
       Overcomers already have the title priestly rulers. In the future they also will have the full function of
priestly rulers. In Rev 5:10, a transition is made from what believers are positionally in the present to what they
will be experientially in the future. Ideally, all believers will be ruling priests. They certainly should be. Albeit, as
the Scripture makes clear, what ideally should take place is not what actually takes place. Only obedient believers
will obtain the rulership that God ideally intended for all believers. Our experience of future rulership is
conditioned upon our obedience (cf. Ex 19:5-6; Rev 2:26-27; 3:21). This regal millennial title is applied to us
already (cf. 1Pet 2:9; Rev 1:6; 5:10). This rulership is already ours potentially and positionally, but the only way it
will become ours experientially during and beyond the future millennium is if we obey presently.

       Royal Priesthood
       In 1Pet 2:9 for example, Peter says, “But you are [to be] a chosen race, a royal [basileios] priesthood, a
holy nation.” He applies this title to these believers provisionally, that is, providing they meet the requirement for
its future realization. As Chumney correctly notes, the OT background stresses the contingent nature of this
promise: “If you will indeed obey My voice and keep My covenant, then you will be…to Me a royal [basileios]
priesthood and a holy nation” (Ex 19:5-6; TM).103 The full experience and exercise of our position as ruling
priests is contingent on our present performance and must await the future for its full manifestation.
       The copula to be in 1Pet 2:9 is suggested by its related NT counterparts in Revelation: “He has made us to
be a kingdom, priests to His God” (Rev 1:6; NAS). “You have made them to be a kingdom and priests to our God
(Rev 5:9; NAU). The unrealized tension is evident, even in those translations that fail to use the copula. The NKJ,
for example, omits it, as indicated by the following blank:

          God has “made us _______ kings and priests to our God; and we shall reign on the earth” (Rev 5:9).

How, however, can we already be kings if our reign is yet future? An already-not-yet tension is apparent.
Consequently, those translations that implement the copula in the Johannine texts are to be preferred.
Unfortunately, English translations fail to note this tension in the Petrine affirmation of the kingly priests and
characteristically translate the verse as: “You are a chosen generation, a royal priesthood.” Parenthetically inserting
to be would be much better: “You are (to be) a chosen generation, a royal priesthood.” In this way, the OT and NT
tension would be preserved.104
       On a related note, according to some translations of Heb 1:14, angels render “service for the sake of those
who are to inherit salvation” (e.g., ESV). Such translations are commendable because the possibility (rather than

*
    For further discussion of kingship, see Misthological Entrance, 571.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                      Page 57
certainty) of realizing the inheritance is acknowledged as being affirmed. Some translations, however, gloss over
the potentiality and treat the inheritance as an assured result so that all believers “will inherit.” To the contrary, the
current ministry by angels to potential heirs does not assure that those potential heirs will qualify misthologically
for the inheritance: are to inherit ≠ will inherit. Those translations that use are to are preferable, especially if the
infinitive is understood to express potential.
        Translations universally seem to miss the potentiality in 1Pet 2:9 though. Even worse, many translations
render the last affirmation with a phrase that might seem soteric. Believers are said to be: God’s own possession
(ASV, ERV, ESV, NAS), God’s very own possession (NLT), God’s own people (NRS, RSV), a purchased people
(DRA), people who belong to God (GWN, NIB, NIV), and a redeemed congregation (MRD). “Surely believers are
not potentially redeemed!” the uninformed reader of MRD will exclaim. In response to such potential exclamation,
note that just a few verses earlier Peter affirmed that believers already have been redeemed (1Pet 1:18). Believers
already are fully, permanently, and unconditionally redeemed. MRD correctly translates lutroo as redeemed in
1Pet 1:18. However, Peter uses a different word (peripoiesis) for possession in 2:9. MRD misses Peter’s intent
when it translates both words the same.
        The best commentary on 1Pet 2:9 is the OT background that Peter is using, namely Ex 19:5. In my quotation
of this verse above, I elliptically skipped over this part of the verse in order to focus on the royal priesthood. The
NJK well renders the OT part pertaining to the possession as: “If you will indeed obey My voice and keep My
covenant, then you shall be a special treasure [Heb. segullah, Gr. periousios] to Me above all people” (Ex 19:5; cp.
Mal 3:16-18). In deference to the lexical and syntactical background, observe that being God’s special possession
is conditioned on the believer’s performance. Granted, all believers are trophies of God’s grace. Some trophies,
though, are bigger (i.e., more special) than others. Accordingly, the NKJ does well lexically to render the
corresponding NT phrase as: “His own special people” (1Pet 2:9). Justice to the OT syntax yields the following
conclusion: Believers are to be God’s special treasure; faithful believers will be. While all believers may equally be
trophies of God’s redeeming grace, faithful believers are additionally trophies of God’s sanctifying grace.
Misthologically speaking, only faithful believers are golden trophies—royal trophies. God’s trophy case has plenty
of room for all His trophies, but some trophies are more glorious than others.
                                 Illustration 25. Some Trophies are Better than Others




       Paul uses a similar illustration: “Now in a large house there are not only gold and silver vessels, but also
vessels of wood and of earthenware, and some to honor and some to dishonor. Therefore, if a man cleanses
himself from these things, he will be a vessel for honor, sanctified, useful to the Master, prepared for every good
Page 58                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
work” (2Tim 2:20-21). In Illustration 25, the small wooden trophy on the left (depicting a believer standing idly)
represents God’s redeeming grace. Sanctifying grace, in contrast, is pictured by a large golden trophy on the right
with a crowned believer who has just finished winning the race of grace.*
        A popular example of conditional realization for a provisional application occurs in 1Tim 4:10, where Paul
says that Christ is the “Savior of all men [provisionally], especially of believers [applicably].” Christ provides
salvation for all, but that salvation is only actually applied to those who accept it. The provision is for all, but the
application is limited to believers. Or as Badger relates: “God’s design and intention for Christ’s death was not to
save all men, but indeed to provide a sufficient sacrifice that would accommodate the salvation of any man upon
the fulfillment of a single condition” (emphasis his).105 Some experiences, though, are offered contingently to
believers, such as the royalty mentioned above.
        An eschatological transition exists in John’s writing between what it means to be an overcomer in the
present and what it means to be an overcomer in the future. In his first epistle, John repeatedly talks about believers
being overcomers and sinless.106 In his eschatological epistle, he talks about believers being overcomers and
priests. To summarize his teaching in both epistles, all Christians are already overcomers positionally and
ontologically in 1 John.† In like manner, they already are positionally priestly-rulers in Revelation. As believers we
are all overcomers in this sense, since it only takes a momentary response of faith. But John also calls upon us to
overcome in the full and ultimate sense. He exhorts us to act on faith. A singular, passive response of faith is all
that is necessary to save us from the Lake of Fire, but an active working faith is required to save our portion in the
rulership of heaven. We must actively appropriate what is ours positionally in order for it to become ours
experientially. The positional rulership that we exercise over demons in spiritual warfare does not guarantee the
eschatological rulership that we may exercise over the nations during the future millennium.
                                   Illustration 26. Transitional Rulership in Revelation

                 1:6                                      5:10                                        20:6
               Present                             Present—Future                                    Future
              Potential                         Positional—Prophetical                             Prophetical
              Already                              Already—Not Yet                                   Not Yet
     has made us kings
     has made us kings…                            we will reign
                                                   we will reign                   and we will be priests
        Future
        Revelation 20:6 makes a complete transition to the future period: “They will be priests of God and of Christ
and will reign with Him for a thousand years.” This text is clearly dealing exclusively with the future form of the
rule. A chronological progression occurs in the transition from (1) the positional priesthood and kingship of 1:6 to
(2) the positional and prophetic priesthood and kingship of 5:10 and then to (3) the experiential priesthood and
rulership in 20:6. In contrast to 1:6 and 5:10, which says that we are (to be) priests, 20:6 says that we will be
priests.
        Obviously, we are not yet the priestly kings in the sense that we will be at that future time. Likewise, there is
a sense in which all believers are overcomers and yet another sense in which they are not. In the future, we will
actually and fully exercise the authority that corresponds to the title which we already have. Overcomers in the
experiential sense of the word will become ruling priests at that time. They will become in experience what they
are now in position. Even so, the futuristic nature of the millennial period does not exhaust the progression of
basileuo. According to 22:5, this rule will be eternal. Those servants (believers) who serve Him now will serve
Him then (Rev 22:3) by ruling for eternity (Rev 22:5). His servants in 22:3 are those who serve Him now by
heeding the words of His book (22:7,9). Contextually, it should not be assumed that all His servants will serve Him


*
 See The Race of Grace for discussion as to why believers are better described as trophies, rather than gifts, of God’s grace.
†
 For a discussion of ontology, see Co-Life, 89. For an application to Johannine themes, see Appendix 4. Johannine Anamartetology,
769. To summarize, all believers are overcomers in terms of being rather than in terms of acting. That is, they are new beings in
Christ who have a new sinless nature even if they fail to act like new beings. They are overcomers in fact even if they are not
overcomers in practice.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                  Page 59
in the capacity mentioned in 22:5 or that 22:3 refers to all believers. It refers to those believers who heed His
words—to experiential overcomers.107

Portion
        Lang believes that only overcomers will participate in the first resurrection of Rev 20:6 and the
corresponding resurrection of Lk 20:35 and Phil 3:11.108 He calls this first resurrection the out-resurrection based
on the latter of these three passages. Indeed, on the basis of what has been seen thus far, it is necessary to agree
with him that only overcomers will have the type of portion (meros) in the resurrection to which John is referring.
The question is, however, “What does John mean by portion?” For Lang, to have a portion in the resurrection
simply means to be resurrected. An alternative is possible. To have a portion in the resurrection could mean to be
resurrected for rulership. Indeed, Rev 20:6 itself suggest this very definition: “Blessed and holy is the one who has
a portion in the first resurrection…they will be priests of God and of Christ and will rule with Him throughout the
millennium” (TM). Following a different line of thought, Sweigart comes to the same conclusion: “The idea of
‘life’ or ‘resurrection to life’ means ‘to enthrone a vassal’ or to ‘grant a vassal dominion.’”109 If portion denotes
resurrection for rulership, as seems to be the case, then John is not denying that subcomers will be raised. He only
denies that subcomers will be raised for rulership. This preliminary anticipation is attractive since 20:6 itself
explicitly links having a portion in this premillennial resurrection with rulership.
                                       Illustration 27. Portion of the Portion



                                               r rected
                                          Resu

                                                     r tion
                                                  Po




        Those who have a portion in the resurrection will only be a portion of the portion who are resurrected. That
is, this portion will only be one subgroup of the larger group of those who are resurrected at this point. Not
everyone will be resurrected at this time. Only a portion of those who are still dead at the beginning of the
millennium will be resurrected. (The general resurrection does not occur until later in the chapter, explicitly after
the millennium.) Believers from the OT and tribulational eras will be raised at this time and given transformed
bodies. This will be necessary because they will need transformed bodies in order to exercise their rulership in the
kingdom. Believers from the NT period already will have received immortal bodies at the rapture. In terms of the
above illustration, all sheep, (i.e., all believers) whether morally black or white who have not been previously
resurrected will be resurrected at this time. The goats (i.e., the lost) will not be resurrected until after the
millennium. But the black sheep, (i.e., the subcomers) will not share in the portion of the white sheep (i.e., the
overcomers).
Page 60                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
        The next chapter will be devoted to a more thorough investigation of what this word portion means, because
of its importance in understanding 20:6 and its potential relationship to the outer darkness. For now continuing
with an overview of Revelation chapter 20 will suffice because in this very context John precedes to demonstrate
implicitly in the next paragraph that not all those who enter the kingdom will do so in glorified bodies. Hence, it
may be deduced that having a portion in the kingdom means more than simply entering it. Therefore, rather than
interpreting rest to mean everyone but the martyred believers (so that unfaithful believers would not be resurrected
until after the millennium), it seems preferable to take rest simply to mean that everyone not resurrected before the
millennium will be resurrected after the millennium (so that unfaithful tribulational believers are not excluded from
being resurrected before the millennium).

Millennial Rebellion (Rev 20:7-10)
      7And when the millennium is completed, Satan will be released from his prison, 8and will come out
      to deceive the nations which are in the four corners of the earth, Gog and Magog, to gather them
      together for the battle; their number is like the sand of the seashore. 9And they came up on the broad
      plain of the earth and surrounded the camp of the saints and the beloved city, and fire came down
      from heaven and devoured them. 10And the devil who deceived them was thrown into the lake of fire
      and brimstone, where the beast and the false prophet are also; and they will be tormented day and
      night forever and ever. (TM)

       This passage presents a problem for the premillennial position. Where do these nations come from?
Walvoord is mistaken in suggesting that those who rebel in the battle of Gog and Magog may plausibly be the
rulers and the people under them.110 The millennial rulers will be the premillennial overcomers! John already has
indicated in the context immediately preceding this passage that those who have a portion in the first resurrection
will be the millennial rulers. These overcoming saints do not fight against the camp of the saints!

                                    Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom
       The typical dispensational solution is to suggest that those overcomers (and their children) who endure until
the end of the tribulation will enter the millennium in flesh and blood bodies. As a result of enduring the
tribulation, they will be saved (i.e., delivered) from the tribulation and allowed to enter the millennial kingdom in
physical bodies capable of sexual reproduction. Although they will have exceedingly long life spans, they will all
probably die during the millennium. Still, they will be fruitful and multiply and fill the earth. Therefore, during the
1000 years that follow their entrance into the millennial kingdom, they and their children will repopulate the
planet. Their descendants will compose these nations.
       This standard dispensational solution is unacceptable, however. Overcomers who endure until the end of the
tribulation will inherit the kingdom. They cannot possibly enter the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies because,
according to Paul, perishable flesh and blood bodies cannot inherit the kingdom (1Cor 15:50). To inherit the
millennial kingdom, and thus to rule in the millennial kingdom, one must have a glorified body. Those believers
who are physically alive at the end of the tribulation must enter the millennium in glorified bodies in order to
exercise their millennial rule.
       The most reasonable hypothesis is that both tribulational overcomers and their children will receive glorified
bodies at the second coming just as believers did at the first coming.* If I am correct in my assessment that the
children of overcomers as well as their parents will receive glorified bodies, then this leaves subcomers and their
children (and children of the lost who are below the age of accountability) as composing the group who will enter
the millennial kingdom in flesh and blood bodies and produce the offspring that eventually will rebel against the
Lord at the conclusion of the millennium. This assessment would make the rebellion easier to understand. Carnal
believers will give birth to generations that swell with a number of unbelieving and unfaithful offspring.
       As to the reference to the first and second coming in relation to the tribulation, the coming of Jesus in the
rapture† can be called the first coming, since a second coming follows the tribulation. Of course, this does not
mean that Jesus had not come previously in His incarnation. Similarly, the fact that the resurrection preceding the
millennium is called the first one in relation to the millennium does not mean that there was not a previous

*
  See What about the children?, 65.
†
  Rapture refers to the coming of Jesus Christ for the church as described in 1Thess 4:17 (harpazo). Although the word revelation
(apokalupsis) is used of both stages of the second coming, it generally will be used herein, as it is used in 2Thess 1:7 (apokalupto), to
refer to the second stage of the second coming, that is, to the second coming itself in distinction to the rapture.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                              Page 61
resurrection associated with the rapture. When John refers to the first resurrection in Rev 20:5-6, he is simply
speaking of the first one in reference to the millennium and in distinction from the latter one that follows the
millennium.*
       The Marrowistic thesis, then, is that 1Cor 15:50 applies to the present and future overcomers regardless of
the stage of the Lord’s coming they experience. In order for raptured overcomes (living during the church age) or
for non-raptured overcomers (who live through the tribulation) to inherit the kingdom, they must receive glorified
bodies. Carnal believers who are alive when the Lord returns after the tribulation do not need to receive glorified
bodies because they merely will be entering the kingdom rather than inheriting it.

       Zeller contends, in contrast, that 1Cor 15:50 only applies to believers of the church age.111 Indeed, he must
limit the application of this verse to church-age believers or admit that entering the kingdom is not equated with
inheriting the kingdom. He appears to have painted himself into a corner in which his theology controls his
exegesis. Obviously, if tribulational believers enter the millennial kingdom without inheriting it, then Zeller’s
contention that entering and inheriting refer to one and the same concept is nullified. Actually, if anyone enters the
millennial kingdom without inheriting it, then the assumption that entering means inheriting is obliterated.
       To be sure, Zeller is not alone in his criticism of Marrowism in that he is criticizing the distinction made by
Hodges between entering and inheriting the kingdom. In 1984, William E. Brown likewise wrote a thesis at Dallas
Theological Seminary challenging Hodges’ distinction. (Hodges was part of the faculty at the time and was even
on the examining committee for that thesis.) As one would expect, Brown’s thesis is a scholarly piece of work,
clearly setting forth its positions with appropriate citations. Ironically, however, in Brown’s discussion of
1Cor 15:50, he quotes Morris: “The blunt statement that flesh and blood cannot participate in the kingdom plainly
excludes all crude ideas of resurrection. It is not this present physical body that Paul envisages as taking its place

*
 For an attractive alternative pretribulational model which does not pose a U-turn, see “No U-Turn” in Predestination and the Open
View.
Page 62                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                          112
in the kingdom” (italics his, bold mine). But Morris is an amillennialist! The dispensational combination of two
groups of people, some in mortal and some in immortal bodies, during the millennial kingdom is regarded as crude
by amillennialists. Therefore, it would stand to reason that Morris would rule out physical bodies from entering the
kingdom. So how will Brown make room for the dispensational necessity of having people enter the
eschatological kingdom in flesh and blood bodies? Will he limit this eschatological kingdom to the eternal
kingdom as opposed to the millennial kingdom? If so, why does Paul say that the transformation of church-age
believers is necessary in order to enter this kingdom? Was Paul unaware that there would be an earthly millennial
kingdom that preceded the eternal state? Surely not. Paul had read the OT had he not?
       To his credit, Brown “admits [through the lips of Schweitzer] that Paul believes in a temporary Messianic
Kingdom which was to precede ‘the age to come.’” Brown also commendably adds, “The inheritance of the
believer must be seen as his future participation in both the Messianic Age and the future eternal bliss with
God.”113 Yet these acknowledgments on the part of Brown, that the inheritance must encompass the future
millennial kingdom, make his conclusion all the more incomprehensible: “The idea here is not that of meriting the
Kingdom but of entering the Kingdom. The interpretation of this passage is that mortal bodies of Christians are
unable to enter into the future Kingdom because of their natural limitations.”114
       This statement might be somewhat understandable coming from an amillennialist, but it is a strange
conclusion for a dispensationalist. According to dispensationalism, there will be those who enter the future
millennial kingdom in flesh and blood bodies, so there is nothing about the natural limitations of those living at the
end of the tribulation to prevent them from entering the future kingdom in their mortal bodies. Their mortality is
readily seen in that many of them will perish at the battle of Gog and Magog. But Brown has made a mess of his
eschatology by conflating entering with inheriting the kingdom in his misthology. It must be admitted by
dispensationalists that there is nothing unnatural about stipulating that mortal bodies are indeed able to enter the
future millennial kingdom, and conversely there is nothing in the natural limitations of those who enter in mortal
bodies that would prevent them from merely entering that kingdom.
       I may likewise postulate that those who live until the end of the millennial kingdom will be able to enter the
eternal kingdom in flesh and blood bodies. If their sin nature is removed from their bodies, they will be able to
enter the eternal state free of sin and death. Their limited transformation will not be as complete as ours because
they will only need to enter the kingdom. Our transformation will be more glorious in that we will inherit the
kingdom rather than merely enter it. Still, that conjectural consideration aside, I will be content at this point to
establish my case based on the necessity of the dispensational concession to procreation in the millennial kingdom
and on the fact that there will be those who enter that kingdom in flesh and blood bodies. The possibility that all
those who enter the millennial kingdom in flesh and blood bodies will retain their sin nature will be considered a
probability.
       Brown’s argument that inherit does not mean merit in 1Cor 15:50 proves nothing. Of course to inherit the
kingdom of God does not mean to merit it in terms of translational equivalency, but this is not the same thing as
saying that merit may not be necessary to inherit it. In other words, that merit may be needed to inherit does not
mean inherit must be translatable as merit. I am not suggesting that the verse be translated as, “Flesh and blood
cannot merit the kingdom of God; nor does the perishable merit the imperishable.” Nevertheless, to inherit it we
must merit it. To inherit something means to possess and own it. Brown himself admits as much in 1Cor 15:50b,
where he says that inherit (kleronomeo) means to acquire or obtain.115 I already have demonstrated my agreement
with that definition.* Brown’s definition is consistent with the misthological position in 1Cor 15:50b. Yet his own
definition reveals an interesting inconsistency in his own position. Why did Brown have to break down in his thesis
and abandon his argument that kleronomeo means enter when he reached 1Cor 15:50b? The answer is obvious. It
makes no sense to translate that part of the verse as saying that the perishable does not enter the imperishable.
Such a statement would be nonsensical. This verse poses a dual difficulty for Brown. His argument breaks down
lexically in 1Cor 15:50b and dispensationally in 1Cor 15:50a. Both halves of this verse invalidate his argument that
to inherit the kingdom means to enter it. These two facets must be distinguished from one another, especially by
dispensationalists.
       This is not to say that dispensationalists are the only ones who recognize that inherit means more than enter.
Far to the contrary, Lenski describes it well:

          To inherit God’s kingdom means much more than merely to receive a place in that kingdom as
          one of its subjects. Already in this life we ourselves are royal…actual kings who reign…and in the

*
    See Blessed, 45.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                                   Page 63
       life to come crowns await us…and a great coronation day when we, the sons of the Kingdom, shall
       have authority over five cities, yea, over ten, and shall sit with the King in his throne…and shall reign
       with him forever…
             When Paul speaks of inheriting the kingdom he places us in the midst of these realities….to
       receive this royal inheritance. Our present physical nature is totally unfit to exercise supreme
       prerogatives that are here implied. A tremendous transformation must take place before our
       inheritance can be completely turned over to us.116

       Lenski, unlike some, has not lost sight of the fact that what we inherit is a kingdom. Doing so necessarily
entails exercising rulership. When we inherit the kingdom, we are not entering it as one of its subjects but coming
into possession of it as one of its kings! When the nobleman went to receive his kingdom in Lk 19:12, he exercised
authority over it. If receiving the kingdom can be used to introduce a parable describing ruling that kingdom, then
certainly nothing is intrinsically wrong with understanding inheriting a kingdom in similar fashion.* That inherit
can actually mean to rule has been demonstrated already, and such meaning makes perfect sense here: “Flesh and
blood cannot rule the kingdom of God; nor does the perishable rule the imperishable” (1Cor 15:50; TM).† In God’s
hierarchy, kings rule; peasants do not. Peasants do not rule over kings. Nor will man rule over the universe as a
peasant. The fact that man is now lower than the angels does not mean that he always will be lower than the angels.
Mankind will only be lower than the angels for a little while (Heb 2:6-7). When overcomers sit with Christ on His
throne, they will be exalted over the angels. To inherit such a position, they must be transformed into creatures
more glorious than angels. Certainly, overcomers must be able see God and live, in contrast to Moses to whom
God said, “You cannot see My face, for no man can see Me and live!”(Ex 33:20) Rulership with God necessitates
transformation; mere entrance into the millennial kingdom does not. To inherit the kingdom must mean more than
merely to enter it.
       The present writer shares Zeller’s conviction that there will be believing adults who enter the millennial
kingdom in flesh and blood bodies. However, Zeller believes that faithful adults of the tribulational period will
enter the kingdom in their natural bodies, and he cites Mt 25:31-34 as teaching that they inherit the kingdom in
physical bodies. He is reading this assumption into the text rather than from the text. That text does not specify that
they inherit the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies. In contrast, I will argue that unfaithful believers of that time
period may enter the kingdom in untransformed bodies. Nevertheless, my position does not stand or fall with this
assessment. As Zeller notes, Wilkin and Dillow are more inclined to limit this type of kingdom entrance to either
believing children or children under the age of accountability. I am not so inclined, but this demonstrates the
flexibility of the FG position. The heart of Zeller’s argument concerning 1Cor 15:50 is from the immediate context
of verses 51-53.
       50
         Now I say this, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God; nor does the
       perishable inherit the imperishable. 51 Behold, I tell you a mystery; we shall not all sleep, but we
       shall all be changed, 52 in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet; for the trumpet
       will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we shall be changed. 53 For this perishable
       must put on the imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality. (1Cor 15:50-53)

       At one end of the spectrum, the argument by Zeller applies verse 50 only to church-age believers because, in
his assessment, the context in verses 51-53 applies only to the saints of the current age. After making this leap in
logic, he then takes another large hop to leapfrog to his conclusion that, since all church-age believers will be
changed, they will all inherit.117 To the first point, one might simply respond that Paul is not limiting the need for
resurrection bodies to inherit the kingdom to the church; rather, he is applying a universal principle to the church.‡

*
  The only way to inherit a kingdom is as a king. One cannot inherit a kingdom without becoming a ruler of that kingdom. Similarly,
the only way to receive a kingdom is as a king. Just as one cannot receive a million dollars without becoming a millionaire, so one
cannot receive a kingdom without becoming a kingdom ruler. Nevertheless, to inherit the kingdom is an even more explicit
affirmation of kingdom rulership than receiving the kingdom in that the references to receiving the kingdom in Mk 10:15 and
Lk 18:17 are problematic and might refer to receiving the message of the kingdom (cp. Mt 13:19) by believing the kingdom message
and thus entail entering the kingdom through faith (cp. Mt 13:20; Mk 4:16; Lk 8:13; Acts 8:14; 11:1; 17:11; 1Thess 1:6; 2:13).
Alternatively, the gospel of the kingdom is certainly not limited to how to enter the kingdom soteriologically but also includes how to
enter it misthologically as well. So even if receiving the kingdom means to receive the message of the kingdom, it might entail
instruction as to how to obtain rulership of that kingdom. See endnote 1122.
†
  See Blessed, 45.
‡
  See Option 3 within “Specificity of Application” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Page 64                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
Tribulational believers also will need to undergo the transformation in order to rule in the millennial kingdom. To
Zeller’s second point, one only need respond that the inheritance necessitates the transformation; the
transformation does not necessitate the inheritance.
        In terms of logical propositions, Paul’s argument might be expressed by saying, if (P) someone inherits the
kingdom, then (Q) he must experience a transformation first (P ⇒ Q). However, it does not necessarily follow that
if (Q) someone experiences a transformation, then (P) that person will inherit the kingdom (Q ⇒ P). In terms of
logical consistency, (P ⇒ Q) ≠ (Q ⇒ P). Logically, one might experience a transformation without inheriting the
kingdom. By assuming (P ⇒ Q) = (Q ⇒ P), Zeller has made a logical error. Nevertheless, I will not limit my
response to Zeller by noting his logical error but will further demonstrate his exegetical error below.
        First, at the other end of the spectrum, Faust, an ultraistic FG advocate, uses a partial rapture argument to
maintain that all in the above passage does not apply indiscriminately to all believers. His position is that this is a
corporate promise that does not necessarily apply unconditionally to all those individuals within the body of Christ.
Supposedly, Paul is implementing a relative all that applies generally rather than an universal all that applies
absolutely. Faust appeals to the fact that this type of approach is necessary when countering universalism.118 A
similar type of argument is invoked by Calvinists in various passages to reject universal atonement. As a result,
some non-Calvinists reject the category of relative all in order to affirm universal atonement. In contrast, although
the present work affirms universal atonement, it does not reject the restricted meaning of all if the context demands
such a restriction. As to Faust, the full-rapture arguments that will be presented subsequently appear to derail his
limitation of all here to mean faithful believers. For example, on the basis of 1Thess 5:9-10, the we of 1Thess 4:16-
17 should be taken as referring to all church-age believers.* Consequently, the rapture being described in the
Corinthian passage would be describing the transformation of all church-age believers, even if they are asleep
morally or physically.
        As to the immediate Corinthian context, which Zeller presumes supports his case, Paul’s concern here is
exactly the opposite of what it was in 1Thess 4:13-18. In the Thessalonian passage, Paul wants to assure his
readership that those who died before the rapture will not miss out on being with the Lord. Believers cannot rule
with the Lord in His kingdom if they are not with the Lord. So being with the Lord is a prerequisite for kingdom
rulership. Being with Him is not the sole condition, but it is certainly indispensable. Paul assures the Thessalonians
that all believers, even those who have died, will be with the Lord in His kingdom and thus will not be excluded
from the possibility of ruling that kingdom—if they qualify.
        From the beginning, Paul had urged them to “walk in a manner worthy of the God who calls you into His
own kingdom and glory” (1Thess 2:12). Obviously, he did not take it for granted that all believers would be worthy
of their kingly calling. In the first chapter of his second epistle to the Thessalonians, Paul says that they are
enduring suffering (v. 4) so that they “may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God” (v. 5), and he prays that
God may count them worthy of their calling (v. 11).† Rulership of the kingdom of God is a reward that believers
(even those who already have died) may enjoy if they are judged to be misthologically worthy. Faithful believers
will be considered worthy to walk with Him in white, sit with Him on His throne, and rule with Him in His
kingdom (2Tim 2:12; Rev 3:4,21). Death will be no obstacle to the fulfillment of this promised rulership. All
believers will be present and accounted for, but only those believers who are counted worthy will achieve the
realization of their dreams as kingdom rulers.
        In 1Cor 15:51-58, Paul assures the believers who may be living when the Lord returns that they will not be
disqualified from such rulership either. Why would living believers need such assurance? Because Paul has just
said, “Flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God” (v. 50). If they cannot rule in the kingdom in flesh and
blood bodies, does this mean that they would be better off dead so that they could be resurrected with glorified
bodies? No. Throughout this chapter Paul has been discussing the importance and necessity of the resurrection and
the resulting transformation that the body of dead believers will experience. Now, as the capstone for the
significance of this transformation, he states that this metamorphosis is essential for rulership in the world to come
because a perishable body cannot inherit an imperishable kingdom. A body still subject to death cannot rule as
victor over a kingdom in which death has been defeated. Those still subject to death are ruled out as being victors
over death (1Cor 15:54-57).‡ Rewards are eternal, and those still subject to death cannot rule eternally. They must
be freed from the limitations that death would impose upon their rulership. On the other hand, although those still
*
  See Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11), 131.
†
  See Illustration 31. Misthological Cognates of Worthiness, 75.
‡
  If a misthological understanding of victory in 1Cor 15:57 is adopted on the basis of 1Cor 15:58, then a misthological understanding
of inherit in 1Cor 15:50 finds further corroboration. (See “1Cor 15:57 and Passive Nikology” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.) But a
misthological understanding of v. 57 is not essential to the misthological understanding of v. 50.
Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                     Page 65
subject to death cannot inherit the kingdom, they can still enter it. Many who enter and live in the millennial
kingdom will die. But none of those who inherit it can die. Paul’s point is not merely that believers will be
changed. It is much stronger: they must be changed, as he explicitly states in v. 53. Why? Because it is impossible
for those in flesh and blood bodies to inherit the kingdom, as Paul already had stipulated in v. 50. This necessity
again indicates the futuristic, and thus millennial nature, of the rulership. It must be one that takes place after those
who are qualified to rule in that kingdom have undergone a physical resurrection so that they may inherit their
regal positions.
        To attempt to make the transformation optional for the inheritance, as Zeller does, is to weaken the force of
Paul’s presentation concerning the necessity of the resurrection. The transformation makes the resurrection
indispensable. If our bodies must be glorified, imperishable, spiritual, and sinless in order to inherit the kingdom
(1Cor 15:42-44,56), then why does Zeller postulate that tribulational believers can inherit the kingdom in sinful,
physical, perishable, non-glorified bodies? Is it not intrinsically flawed for Zeller to picture tribulational
overcomers as inheriting the kingdom, and evidently wearing white robes, while retaining their sin nature? Are we
actually to believe that Zeller’s overcomers procreate and pass their sin nature on to their offspring while wearing
white robes? This distasteful imagery, to which Zeller’s conclusions lead, will be erased by the considerations
provided herein. His view of inheriting is inherently repulsive.
        All believers are qualified by physical transformation to rule, since they will have sinless glorified bodies,
but as Paul pointed out earlier, this is not the only qualification. From the broader context, it must be concluded
that those believers who fail to demonstrate a moral transformation here and now will be excluded from the
inheritance then (1Cor 6:8-10). Paul does not say that all believers automatically will inherit the kingdom in
1Cor 15:50-53. He already has ruled out this possibility in the body of the epistle. And from the much broader
context, one would be inclined to think that, since both believers of the church age and of the tribulation must meet
the same ethical requirement (i.e., overcoming) to share the inheritance of the kingdom, it is reasonable to
conjecture that they must also share the same transformational requirement of resurrected bodies in order to
exercise that rulership.
        To restate the Pauline presentation in terms of logical propositions, if as a result of your regeneration* you
have undergone a (A) moral transformation and (B) an eschatological transformation, then (C) you will inherit the
kingdom (A & B ⇒ C). That both A and B are equally necessary to inherit the kingdom is easily demonstrated
from Paul’s double negations. If you are immoral, you cannot inherit the kingdom (1Cor 6:8-10). If you are mortal,
you cannot inherit the kingdom (1Cor 15:50). Inheriting the kingdom is conditioned upon being both moral and
immortal. If you are moral and immortal, then you will inherit the kingdom. If, despite your regeneration, you are
missing either requirement, then you will not inherit the kingdom. You may enter it, but you will not inherit it.
        In the discussion herein of Rev 6:9, concerning the disembodied spirits under the thrones, the inference was
made that they are under the thrones, rather than on the thrones, because the disembodied spirits need resurrected
bodies so that they may sit on the thrones.† Like the OT believers, the disembodied spirits of the tribulation will be
awaiting their resurrection so that they may rule. You must have a resurrected body in order to rule. Those who
rule are those who have conquered death (1Cor 15:20-28). They are no longer subject to death. Tribulational
overcomers do not enter the millennium in flesh and blood bodies to reproduce and die, as Zeller proposes. They
enter it in translated bodies to rule eternally.

                                             What about the children?
        The above illustration depicts the pretribulational perspective. The rapture will include the young children of
believers. By young I mean those children who have not yet reached the age of accountability. Certainly, we may
conclude that the rapture will include the unborn children of expectant Christian mothers! Rapture is not abortion.
Christian mothers will not have to abort their children and leave them behind. One possibility is that pregnant
believers could give birth to their unborn children after the fetus reaches the full term of its pregnancy in heaven. A
second possibility is that their unborn children could receive glorified bodies at the moment of the rapture and then
be cared for in heaven by their believing mothers. One of the most anticipated events in heaven is the joining
together of loved ones who have gone on to be with the Lord. Expectant Christian mothers could experience the
thrill of the rapture and the rapturous joy of giving birth in one-and-the-same moment without any of the pains of
childbirth. If so, these mothers will be joined to their little ones in heaven.


*
    Regeneration is a precondition.
†
    See Millennial Thrones, 49.
Page 66                                                                                                  The Outer Darkness
        A third possibility is that young children, infants, and the unborn could receive mature glorified bodies at
the moment of the rapture. Adam was created as a mature person without going through a stage of immaturity.
Although this latter position has fewer details to work out and is easier to conceive, the opinion taken herein is that
they will pass from infancy to maturity in the due course of time in heaven. The speculation of the present writer is
that all children who die before they reach the age of accountability go to heaven and are raised in heaven. The
blood of Jesus is applied to them provisionally until they are mature enough to express saving faith while in
heaven, at which time His blood is applied to them permanently. In this manner, the potential aspect of Christ’s
atonement may still be affirmed as being provisional to all universally, while at the same time rejecting
universalism since faith is maintained as the conditional component.119
        The Calvinistic presupposition that faith is not a condition for regeneration is rejected. According to the
Calvinistic theory, faith is not really the prerequisite for salvation (or at least not for regeneration) even among
adults, much less for children. Rather election is the true Calvinistic prerequisite. By way of contrast, in my view
children would grow up in heaven and become regenerate when they trust in Christ as their sin bearer and thus
actualize their potential and provisional redemption. Faith would precede regeneration. There certainly would be
no shortage of experienced parents in heaven who would love to volunteer for nursery duty or for foster parenting
in leading these young children to faith in Christ. And it is an understatement of the highest magnitude to say that
the Christian schools in heaven should be quite good. But the postmortem opportunity to believe will be limited to
those who did not mentally reach the age of accountability. The rapture itself will not include all children, only the
children of believers.
        The question naturally will arise about those situations in which only one parent is a believer. The answer
must be speculative. Even so, it would seem evenhanded to assume that unbelieving expectant mothers will not
have their unborn child taken away from them at the rapture even if the father is a believer. Conversely, believing
expectant mothers will not have their unborn child taken away from them at the rapture even if the father is an
unbeliever. In this type of split situation, when the children already have been born but have not reached the age of
accountability, I prefer to trust the graciousness of our Lord. A God who loves the little children certainly will save
them whenever He can without violating His justice.
        Just as the children are included with their parents in receiving glorified bodies at the first coming, it is
sensible to assume that the children are included with their parents in receiving glorified bodies at the second
coming. If we take the events of the exodus as a typological* representation of what happens, then we have a
beautiful picture to illustrate the event. When God called the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt, the Jewish
children left with their parents. The blood of the lamb that was applied to the Jewish doorposts, applied
provisionally to their Jewish children as well. But it did not protect the children of Egypt. Nor did the children of
Egypt leave with the Israelites at the exodus. The Israelites took their own children with them and only their
children. There is little reason to believe that the rapture will include the children of unbelievers. The Egyptian
children stayed behind. Likewise, when it came time for the flood, Noah and his family entered the ark. He did not
take his neighbor’s children aboard. When it was time for Sodom and Gomorrah to be judged, Lot and his family
were the only ones removed. They did not take the children of unbelievers with them. One reason for believing in
Jesus is so that one’s children will not be left behind to go through the tribulation. When it comes time for the
exodus of believers from this planet, my typological hypothesis is that their children (and only their children) leave
with them.
        Assuming a similar correlation between what happens to the children of believers at the first and second
coming, neither overcomers nor their children will enter the kingdom in non-glorified, flesh and blood bodies.
Overcomers must enter the kingdom as its rulers and thus assume glorified bodies in order to exercise their
inheritance of this future kingdom. As will be confirmed in the subsequent discussion, there will be subcomers who
live until the end of the tribulation who, although they will not subcome to the mark or worship of the beast, will
not manifest the love necessary to be an overcomer. These subcomers and their children will enter the kingdom and
repopulate the planet. Since the age of accountability also would apply to the children of unbelievers, their children
also will enter the millennial kingdom. The descendants of these three groups will compose the rebellious nations
one thousand years later.120 (1) Subcomers, (2) the children of subcomers, and (3) the children of unbelievers will
all enter the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies, reproduce, and pass their sin nature on to their children.
        All those still living in flesh and blood bodies at the end of the tribulation thus will have sin natures since
they are in non-glorified bodies that are subject to death. This assessment correlates well with the OT information

events illustrate NT truths. The blood of the lamb in the OT is a picture of the shed blood of Jesus in the NT, etc.

that there will be children born during the millennial kingdom and that death still will occur as well (Is 65:20-23;
Jer 30:20; 31:29-30; Eze 47:22; Zech 8:5; 10:7-9).121 Although death and birth will coexist in the millennial
kingdom, life expectancy will increase greatly and infant mortality will be nonexistent, as confirmed in the passage
from Isaiah. Therefore, the population at the end of a very prosperous thousand years could very well far exceed
the population that we currently have today.

       To summarize in terms of the above illustration, multiple groups will enter the millennial kingdom: some in
physical bodies, some in transformed bodies. Those entering the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies (that can
procreate) are represented with the gray arrows. In contrast, those who are entering the kingdom in transformed
bodies are represented by the black arrows. Correspondingly, church-age believers who are returning from the
clouds, where they will have been with Jesus after the rapture and judged at the JSC, will include subcomers and
overcomers. Raptured children will be treated as overcomers. Since the kingdom will belong to such children
(Mt 19:14), they will have positions of authority (cp. Mt 5:3,10).* Kingdoms only belong to kings. So these
children will possess the kingdom as low ranking kings. After all, the only way to inherit a kingdom is as a king.
Mature overcomers will rule the kingdom as high-ranking kings.
       This explains the top arrow, and the bottom arrow is to be understood similarly. Just as the NT believers
were resurrected at the beginning of the tribulation, so OT believers will be resurrected at the conclusion of the

Page 68                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
tribulation. An OT believer like David will be judged and found to be an overcomer, whereas Saul would be a non-
ruling subcomer. Since children will have positions of rulership, David’s child who died in childbirth (2Sam 12:18-
23) will have long since grown to adulthood in heaven and, along with David, will occupy a position of rulership in
the millennial kingdom.
         The retrieval of everyone who lives through the tribulation to stand either before the Jewish Bema or the
Gentile Sheep and Goat Judgment in their physical bodies will result in overcomers and their children entering the
kingdom in transformed bodies no longer subject to death. Two things are required to inherit the kingdom: morality
and immortality. Just as 1 + 2 = 3, so you must have both (1) morality and (2) immortality in order to have (3) an
inheritance. Regeneration is a nonmeritorious precondition for these two subsequent co-conditions.* As concurrent
conditions, morality and immortality are both necessary, and the inheritance is conditioned on both of these
requirements. Morality is certainly a meritorious co-condition. The inheritance is a reward since it is conditioned
on morality. To inherit a kingdom denotes rulership as is illustratable by substituting the word rule in place of
inherit in the first and second half of 1Cor 15:50.
         The unregenerate will be excluded from inheriting the kingdom since they will not have met the two co-
conditions. Furthermore, they will be excluded from entering the kingdom because they will not have met the
singular condition for kingdom entrance—regeneration (Jn 3:3-5). The singular condition for kingdom entrance
(i.e., regeneration) will be the precondition for the two conditions to rule in the millennial kingdom (i.e., morality
and immortality).
         Although unregenerate adults will be sent to hell since they lack eternal life, their children will be permitted
to enter the kingdom in mortal bodies. The requirement that one be regenerate in order to enter the millennial
kingdom will not be applied to those who have not reached the age of accountability. They will not be held
accountable for not having met that requirement. This is why the children of unbelievers will be permitted to enter
the kingdom in physical bodies even though their parents are not allowed to enter and are sent to hell.
         Adult subcomers and their children will also enter the kingdom in mortal bodies. Although these subcomers
will be judged at the end of the tribulation and found to have lived immorally, they will be allowed to enter the
kingdom because they will have met the requirement for such entrance—new birth.122 Therefore, three groups of
people will enter the kingdom in mortal bodies and consequently will be able to reproduce: subcomers, their
children, and the children of the lost. Since they enter the kingdom without inheriting it, entering the kingdom is
not the same thing as inheriting it. At the end of the tribulation, many of the descendents (of those who will have
entered the kingdom without inheriting it) will compose the nations that rebel against the saints in the battle of Gog
and Magog. At least some of these rebels will be found not to have eternal life at the Great White Throne Judgment
which immediately follows.

Millennial Conclusion (Rev 20:11-15)
      11And I saw a Great White Throne and Him who sat upon it, from whose presence earth and heaven
      fled away, and no place was found for them. 12And I saw the dead, the great and the small, standing
      before the throne, and books were opened; and another book was opened, which is the Book of Life;
      and the dead were judged from the things which were written in the books, according to their works.
      13And the sea gave up the dead which were in it, and death and Hades gave up the dead which were
      in them; and they were judged, every one of them according to their works. 14And death and Hades
      were thrown into the lake of fire. This is the second death, the lake of fire. 15And if anyone’s name
      was not found written in the Book of Life, then he was thrown into the lake of fire. (TM)

                                                 Great White Throne
        At the conclusion of the millennium there will be a resurrection of those not previously raised. This is the
third resurrection overall; it is the second in relation to the millennium, to which John referred to in his footnote in
20:5. This resurrection evidently will include the lost as well as those believers who died during the millennium.
Although this opinion goes counter to popular dispensational position, even Wilkin concedes:

            Of course it is hypothetically possible that people who come to faith in Jesus during the
       Millennium will also be judged at the Great White Throne Judgment. If so, the purpose of their
       judgment would be to determine their degree of reward on the new earth in the eternal
