Chapter 2. Millennial Options (Rev 20:1-15)                                                                     Page 69
          kingdom….There is no indication in Scripture of when millennial believers will be judged.
          Revelation 20:15…may imply that others are being judged there. Or it may simply mean that others
          will be present, such as church-age believers who serve witness.123

        In a more recent book, Wilkin acknowledges that church-age believers will probably be present at the GWT
as witnesses and millennial believers will possibly be judged at it.124 In my assessment, the latter is just as
probable, if not more so, than the former. Of course, church-age believers will not be judged at the GWT nor will
their names be sought in the Book of Life at this time. They were judged at the JSC. But the implication in 20:15 is
that a soteriological determination will occur at the GWT for those being judged at that time, as to which of those
being judged then go to heaven versus hell, with some going to either location. Some of those being judged
according their works will go to hell, while some of those being judged according to their works will go to heaven.
The purpose of judgment is to render to each person according to their works, not to determine who goes to heaven
or hell, however. The soteriological dimension is merely an aside. Unbelievers and believers not previously judged
will stand before the GWT. As Lang states, “The form of the statement can really mean nothing less than that some
names are found in that book…were it said of a great crowd at a railway barrier that if anyone was found not to
have a ticket he was not allowed to pass, the unquestionable force would be that some had tickets” (emphasis
his).125
        Similarly, both the believers and unbelievers appear together before the Lord in the same judgment scene at
the separation of the sheep from the goats, which is associated with the first millennial resurrection (Mt 25:31-46).
Evidently, John is indicating that believers and unbelievers will also appear together before the judgment throne at
the second millennial resurrection as well. However, in the judgment (of the sheep and the goats) before the
millennium, they were separated on the basis of what they were before they were judged on the basis of what they
did. Accordingly, it is likely that unbelievers and believers will be separated from one another after the millennium
at the judgment of the GWT on the basis of what they have (eternal life, denoted by their name in the Book of Life)
before they are dealt with on the basis of what they have done. Although both groups will appear before this throne
of judgment, it may be that only unbelievers will have their works evaluated at this time. Possibly, those believers
who appear before the GWT may have their works evaluated subsequently in an undisclosed scene. Then again,
probably not. Most likely, both groups will be judged according to their works at this time (from the Books of
Works), but the determination as to who goes to heaven versus hell will not be based on this judgment but on the
presence or absence of their names in the Book of Life. Judgment is always based on works. Even if unbelievers
and millennial believers are both judged at this judgment, the separation of the lost from the saved is not based on
the judgment. Marrowists pose a separation of those who have eternal life from those who do not have eternal life
based exclusively on whether their name is in the Book of Life. The adjudication, in contrast, will be based
exclusively on their works.*

                                     Preliminary Remarks on Book of Life
       In any case, the present writer agrees with Lang, and therefore with Faust, that “the wording of verse 15
would be unnecessary unless there will be people found written in the book of life that rise from the underworld”
(emphasis his).126 However, in attempting to explain the Book of Life, Faust has a handicap in trying to maintain
the KJV reading of Rev 22:19. Like the present author, Faust entertains several theories. One is that the Book of
Life in Rev 3:5 and 22:16 is the misthological book of millennial life from which the unworthy believer’s name
may be erased.127 If so, then that status is forfeitable like the crown of life (Rev 3:11). Faust consequently is left
with two basic options. The Book of Life in Rev 20:12,15 is either (1) the same book and those believers who have
their name erased may be restored subsequently after temporary punishment in the Lake of Fire (so supposedly
Mt 18:34 and 1Cor 3:15), or this book is (2) the soteriological book of eternal life.
       The first option (i.e. the temporary misthological erasing of the names) is similar to that of Fuller (except for
the addition of the Lake of Fire possibility) to be discussed and dismissed subsequently.† But Faust’s position is
even more dubious than that of Fuller’s in that Faust’s position requires the implausibility of restoration after the
punishment, as well as the second death of those who cannot experience spiritual death. As to Faust’s second
option, which is soteriological erasing, the casting into the Lake of Fire in Rev 20:15 is at the conclusion of the
millennial age rather than at its beginning. This positioning is contradictory to Faust’s own view of a millennial
limitation of the punishment. Moreover, this erasing and casting is at the beginning of the eternal state, which

*
    See discussion pertaining to sequence of books in Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep.
†
    See Believers who lose Rewards, 492.
Page 70                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
indicates that this will be the permanent state of affairs for eternity. Consequently, Faust’s latter option may be
ruled out without further interaction.

                                                         Exposition
        Ideally, all men and women should believe the gospel. The purchase price of the blood of Jesus already has
been paid for all human beings without exception. Even so, the transaction is completed only on behalf of those
who appropriate the significance of the blood on their behalf. Thus, ideally all blood-paid-for human beings should
believe, but unfortunately what ideally should happen is not what actually happens. They are blood-paid-for but not
blood-bought. This provisional atoning transaction has not yet been completed for those who have not appropriated
its reality. Similarly, all blood-bought believers should rule, but regrettably many will fail to rule on the earth.
Jesus literally has been seated at the right hand of the Father in heaven in a position of rulership (Eph 1:20-21).
Believers have been seated positionally with Him at the right hand of the Father in positions of rulership (Eph 2:6).
Nevertheless, what we are positionally must be appropriated to become ours experientially. For example, to
achieve victory over Satan, our unbound foe, and to exercise our authority over him in spiritual warfare, we must
appropriate (i.e., claim by faith) our position of authority in Christ. This authority is ours positionally and
potentially, but it is not ours automatically. We must appropriate it. We have died, been buried, been resurrected,
and are seated with Christ, and as such, have victory over sin, self, the world, and the devil. Still, in order to
experience this positional truth, we must appropriate it. Just as the present experience of this positional rulership is
neither automatic nor guaranteed, so also our future experience of this positional rulership is not guaranteed. That
which is currently positional, like that which is potential and provisional, may be conditional for its experiential
realization and application.*
        The defeat of our enemy is certain, but our experience of victory is not. He is not bound now, but neither are
we. We can fight. We can take up the shield of faith. Faith is the victory that overcomes the world and its current
ruler. Faith is the victory that will restore rightful rulers upon the earth. Let us take up our shield of faith and fight
the good fight by standing firm in our faith. Rulership of this planet is at stake.

                                                         Conclusion
        The outer darkness is a part of eschatology and thus needs to be located correctly within one’s larger
eschatological frame of reference. In this chapter I have examined the principal text regarding the millennium and
stated my reasons for preferring a premillennial position. The traditional dating of Revelation is confirmed by
internal indications and makes a preteristic and idealistic understanding of Revelation highly improbable.† With
promises of the futuristic realization of their contingent, literal, millennial kingship on this planet as priestly-rulers
at stake, the book was written to encourage believers to overcome experientially. The location of the rapture at the
beginning of Rev 4, and thus at the beginning of the tribulation, renders the dispensational pretribulational
millennial position as the most acceptable hermeneutical scaffold from which to build one’s interpretation.
        An examination of the key words involved leads to the conclusion that a physical resurrection will occur
before and after the millennium, which again confirms the futuristic impression of the millennial inheritance. This
eschatological understanding is reinforced misthologically by the nature of the rulership to be enjoyed by those
believers who have overcome experientially. This rulership awaits the future manifestation of Christ in His earthly
kingdom. The nature of this rulership requires that those who exercise it have glorified bodies animated by the
Spirit rather than fleshly bodies animated by blood. The rulers of this future kingdom will not inherit their portion
in flesh and blood bodies but rather in glorified bodies associated with the future, physical resurrection. The nature
of this portion will be further examined in the next chapter.

                                         Chapter 3.
                             The Portion of the First Resurrection
                                                  Introduction
       As noted previously concerning portion, Lang’s position is that only overcomers will experience the first
resurrection (at the end of the tribulation) and subcomers will be involved in the second resurrection after the
millennium.* Thus, he believes that, although subcomers will not enter the millennial kingdom, these unfaithful
believers will enter the eternal kingdom. His argument is that Rev 20:6 and Lk 20:35 teach that only overcomers
will be worthy of what is called the out-resurrection in Phil 3:11. Moreover, Heb 11:35 may also be added to his
list of passages that teach a misthological resurrection. To these four primary passages, one might also add
secondary passages such as Mt 13:43,49; 25:46; Lk 14:14; and Jn 5:28-29.
       Lang’s position accordingly has wider scriptural support than just three passages. Still, this admission does
not suggest a concession to Lang’s claim to a partial rapture or a partial resurrection, nor does this rejection of
Lang’s partial rapture necessitate agreement with all rebuttals of Lang’s position concerning the resurrection. A
number of primary questions must be addressed. What does John mean by portion? Does portion simply mean to
experience the resurrection, or does it refer to a special experience in the resurrection? What does the out-
resurrection of Phil 3:11 (and related passages) have to do with the first resurrection? Does the out-resurrection
have any correlation with the outer darkness?

                                      Overview of Out-Resurrection
        Both Wilkin and Lang are Marrowists, so I am examining refinements within the soteriological and
misthological parameters of the GRAPE hermeneutic. Even though both of these writers are from the same
theological camp, variations and different understandings concerning specific verses are natural and provide an
opportunity for the sword sharpening interaction among friends mentioned earlier. Wilkin counters Lang’s view
concerning Lk 20:35 by arguing that all believers are counted worthy in Christ. Furthermore, Wilkin believes that
Phil 3:11 refers to a spiritual resurrection, that is, to a temporal reward of Christlike character to be gained in the
present life. Respectfully, I will challenge Wilkin’s assessment and contend that the older misthological view,
which Wilkin had at one time shared with Lang, is still superior.128 An affirmation of eschatological reward best
fits the contexts of both passages.
        This is not to say that Wilkin has abandoned the eschatological view of a misthological resurrection in
general. To the contrary, he still acknowledges that Phil 3:14 and Heb 11:35 refer to eschatological rewards, that is,
to the reward of a special status in the future physical resurrection. Granted, Wilkin is correct that Paul teaches a
spiritual resurrection in Rom 6:4,11-13; 8:10-17. This spiritual resurrection, however, is something that is already
positionally true of all believers in the book of Romans. It is past, not future. It was given, not earned. One may
further concede to Wilkin that Paul calls upon believers to appropriate the reality of their spiritual resurrection, so
there is some tension between the already and not yet. Even so, the tension can be expressed adequately by the
exhortation to be what you are. You have been resurrected and are spiritually alive, so live accordingly. Obviously,
the exhortation is based on the fact that believers already have experienced the spiritual resurrection. This spiritual
resurrection is past, not future. Yet the eschatological out-resurrection, which will be the subject of study in this
chapter, in contrast, is future, not past or present.
        Wilkin is also accurate that Phil 3:10 is referring to experiencing the power of this spiritual resurrection in
the here-and-now. However, to use the phraseology of one hymnist, Wilkin fails to make the transition to the
futuristic sweet by-and-by in Phil 3:11. Paul wants to experience the power of his spiritual resurrection in Phil 3:10
so that he may earn the out-resurrection in the future. Two different resurrections are in view. Paul should not be
misunderstood as saying in Phil 3:11-12 that he had not yet achieved a Christlike character or spiritual maturity!
Certainly he already had achieved Christian character and assumes that many of his readers have done so as well
(Phil 3:15).
        Moreover, Paul uses different words in Romans for our present spiritual resurrection when he says that we
have been raised (egeiro) from the dead and made alive (zao) from the dead. The latter verb zao is the root of the
verb ezesan, which was discussed earlier.† In that discussion, it was shown that Ladd acknowledges that this word
can be used in passages such as Eph 2:1-6 to refer to a spiritual resurrection (i.e., coming to spiritual life).

*
    See Portion, 59.
†
    See Ezesan, 43.
Page 72                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
Contrastively, the word Paul uses in Phil 3:11 is exanastasis, a derivative of anastasis, which refers to physical
resurrection, not spiritual resurrection.* Since exanastasis refers to a subgroup of anastasis, it should also be taken
as referring to a physical resurrection rather than a spiritual resurrection. The out-resurrection is a physical
selection of certain people who already will have experienced a physical resurrection.
                                              Illustration 30. Out = Subgroup




       In contrast to both Lang and Wilkin, Dillow believes that only some believers will be worthy and that what
is being referred to is “a special class of resurrection.” He takes the same position concerning Phil 3:11.129 The
position of Dillow, yet another GRAPE writer, is superior. The normal word for resurrection is anastasis
(resurrection from among the dead), whereas here Paul uses exanastasis (resurrection out from among the
resurrected ones). As will be further explained below, although all believers will experience the resurrection, only
some will be worthy of it (Lk 20:35).† These worthy believers (overcomers) will obtain a better resurrection than
other believers (Heb 11:35). A contrast between resurrection and better resurrection occurs in Heb 11:35.
Unfaithful believers are not mentioned in Rev 20:6 because they are not in view; it does not serve John’s
contrasting of the extremes to mention the in-betweens. This present discussion of out-resurrection is not only
pertinent to the study of resurrection in Rev 20:6; it is also important in understanding the misthological role of
portion/inheritance in this verse and why the partial rapture theory is eschatologically unnecessary. Its implications
for the outer darkness and what it means to be outside the city must take such concepts into consideration. Thus, an
examination of each passage is warranted.

                                        The Out-Resurrection in Lk 20:34-36
      The first primary reference to special status in the resurrection is found in the gospel of Luke, where Jesus
promises:
          34
            And Jesus said to them, “The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage, 35 but those who are
          considered worthy to attain to that age and the resurrection from the dead, neither marry, nor are
          given in marriage; 36 for neither can they die anymore, for they are like angels, and are sons of God,
          being sons of the resurrection.” (Lk 20:34-36)

*
    See Anastasis, 44.
†
    See Misthological Worthiness, 73.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                             Page 73

       Wilkin rejects Lang’s misthological interpretation of this passage stating, “No one is worthy to enter God’s
Kingdom on the basis of his own works and merit….Are you worthy to go to heaven? Not on the basis of your
feeble, flawed, and unfinished works.” Thus, Wilkin rejects a misthological understanding of this Lukan passage in
favor of a soteriological one because of the word worthy (kataxioo). This Greek word is found in only three places
in the NT (Lk 20:35; Acts 5:41; 2Thess 1:5). One would think that Wilkin would consider the latter verse a
particularly strong parallel since it refers to being worthy of the kingdom—the very concept Wilkin is addressing.
       4
        Therefore, we ourselves speak proudly of you among the churches of God for your perseverance and
       faith in the midst of all your persecutions and afflictions which you endure. 5 This is a plain
       indication of God’s righteous judgment so that you may be considered worthy of the kingdom of
       God, for which indeed you are suffering (2Thess 1:4-5).

Lexical Merit
       Yet concerning this Thessalonian passage, Wilkin (GNTC) has no problem acknowledging a misthological
interpretation and declaring that being worthy of the kingdom is dealing with rulership in the kingdom. Certainly
he is correct. After all, a worthiness based on endurance is merited. Paul explicitly says that the Thessalonians are
enduring so that they may be worthy of the kingdom.* Now although some Calvinists and non-Calvinists (such as
Lenski cited earlier) may shriek at the mention of merit, I am simply stating a lexical fact.† As mentioned above,
the Greek word for being considered worthy in both Lk 20:35 and 2Thess 1:5 is kataxioo. It is a compound form of
axioo. Both verbs mean: “To consider something of a comparable merit or worth – ‘to regard as worthy of, to
consider as meriting’” (L-N 65.18). These verbs also have cognates which have the same meaning, thus entailing
merit.‡ Once, while discussing this matter with an Augustinian fan who claimed that merit was foreign to the Bible,
I simply went through BDAG and pointed out a variety of words that denote the possibility of positive, relative,
human merit in the Greek NT.130 But one should not have to dig through lexicons to prove something that is so
contextually obvious. Since Wilkin is a proponent of GRAPE, he should have no theological obstacles preventing
him from acknowledging misthological merit in Lk 20:35. So why does he not do so?

Misthological Worthiness
       Why does Wilkin regard being worthy in 2Thess 1:5 as misthological and in Lk 20:35 as soteriological? I do
not charge Wilkin with being completely inconsistent in this matter since he again states concerning 2Thess 1:4-5
that, whatever being counted worthy of the kingdom means, “it certainly is not talking about being counted worthy
of entering the kingdom; the only condition of that is belief in Christ” (emphasis his).131 At least, while correctly
maintaining the misthological nature of this verse, Wilkin is consistent in denying that basic entrance into the
kingdom is a misthological idea. Yet in a splendid discussion of 2Pet 1:10-11, Wilkin acknowledges that entrance
into the kingdom in that passage is a misthological concept.132 “As long as you practice these things, you will never
stumble; for in this way the entrance into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ will be
abundantly supplied to you” (2Pet 1:10-11). This abundant entrance into the kingdom is based on your practice as
a believer and is thus merited.
       Undoubtedly, Wilkin is accurate that soteriological entrance into the kingdom is unmerited. Still, as he
himself has acknowledged, the Bible also teaches a misthological entrance which is merited. The Greek verb for
being considered worthy (kataxioo) in Lk 20:35 certainly leads one to suspect that misthological entrance is in
view. Additionally, the word translated attain (tugchano) in Lk 20:35 could just as easily be translated achieve.
One need only consult attain in an English dictionary for confirmation: attain can mean to gain through effort. So
when an English translation or a Greek-to-English lexicon gives attain as a possible meaning, one also has to be
sensitive to the semantic range of the English word which the Greek dictionary supplies and allow the Greek
context to determine which meaning is intended.
       Returning now to the Greek text, although tugchano may simply mean to experience, it could just as easily
mean to earn or be rewarded. The context in Greek (as in English) determines the meaning of the word.
Accordingly, tugchano in Heb 11:35 should be translated as saying that they endured torture so that they might
earn, that is, be rewarded with a better resurrection (Heb 11:35). In the immediate context, BBE appropriately

*
  See Experience, 174; Misthological Worthiness = Misthological Glory, 426.
†
  See Misthological Merit, 21.
‡
  See Illustration 31. Misthological Cognates of Worthiness, 75.
Page 74                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
translates the compound cognate epitugchano as got their reward (Heb 11:33). The resurrection is a reward in
these contexts. Lexical considerations for the Lukan phrase, especially for worthy (kataxioo), cause me to opt for
the contextually decisive parallel in Hebrews as being applicable to Jesus’ statement in Luke. BBE is, therefore,
correct to render the phrase considered worthy to attain (kataxioo tugchano) in this neutral Lukan context as given
the reward (Lk 20:35), specifically, of the world to come (cp. Heb 2:5). My preferred translation would be: “Those
who are considered misthologically worthy of that world and the resurrection out from the dead, neither marry, nor
are given in marriage” (TM).
        The world to come, as well as the out-resurrection, will be their reward.* Although the phrase out from the
dead limits this resurrection to believers, partial rapturists are in error in arguing that this resurrection itself is the
reward. Granted, this phrase could be translated as referring to “those who are considered worthy of that world and
to be rewarded with [tugchano] the resurrection out from the dead.”† This grammatical possibility allows the
partial rapturists to make a case for limiting the experience of the resurrection to those considered worthy of it.
They limit this resurrection to faithful believers.
        I contend instead that all believers will experience this resurrection out from the dead.‡ But not all believers
are considered worthy of the experience. The reward is to be considered worthy of the experience. Unworthy
believers will unworthily experience this resurrection out from the dead. Worthy believers will worthily experience
it misthologically, which is equivalent to saying that overcomers will experience the out-resurrection that is limited
to worthy believers. For example, all believers will experience the kingdom, but not all believers will be considered
worthy of this experience (2Thess 1:5). Those considered misthologically worthy of this experience will
experience it as kings. No one is soteriologically worthy on the basis of their performance to experience such
benefits. Thankfully, soteriological benefits are not based on one’s performance; misthological benefits though are
based on one’s performance. Our performance only allows us to be considered misthologically worthy.
        The partial rapture theory also has several logistical problems. How can the resurrection be limited to
worthy believers before the Bema occurs? The JSC must occur to determine who is worthy. Since the rapture
occurs before the JSC, all believers must be resurrected to stand before the JSC (cp. 2Cor 5:10). So no believer will
be left behind at the rapture. The angels will gather all those who have eternal life to stand before the Bema. All
believers must be raptured and stand before the Bema so that it may be determined which of them were
misthologically worthy of the experience. Secondly, partial rapturists have a problem explaining how unworthy
believers experience negative consequences at the Bema without having been raptured to stand before the Bema.
This second problem can be alleviated in part by arguing that all unworthy believers die during the tribulation.
Even then, an awkward arrangement would have to be made to have these unresurrected believers appear before
the Bema (even though scriptural order appears to be resurrection then judgment) or to wait and have these
believers unworthily resurrected some time later, such as at the end of the tribulation, and then stand before the
Bema (after the Bema judgment which by most accounts would be over).
        As noted above, Wilkin was reluctant to embrace the misthological nature of the resurrection in Luke
because of Lang’s misthological assertions that only overcomers will participate in the premillennial resurrection
and be worthy to enter the millennial kingdom. In Lang’s view, unfaithful believers will miss out on the
millennium. Faust likewise uses this misthological foil to advance the ultra-misthological GRAPE view, in which
some believers are excluded from the millennial kingdom. Accordingly, he would take this passage as indicating
that only some believers experience this type of resurrection which enables them to enter the millennial kingdom as
a reward.133 The logic for ultraistic misthological exclusion from the kingdom is rather straightforward since the
text is discussing believers who are worthy to achieve the resurrection from the dead in that (millennial) age. Yet
does this admission necessarily require agreement with Faust that basic entrance is limited to faithful believers?
        The initial impression at least is that the answer is negative. Being worthy of the resurrection refers to
something over and above simply experiencing the resurrection. Likewise, being worthy of the kingdom in
2Thess 1:5 refers to something more than simply entering the kingdom. Being worthy of our calling, as in
2Thess 1:11 for example, refers to more than just being called.
        At a Labor Day service in which the author was speaking on the topic of laborers being worthy of their
wages, he tied the following chart in with a message Larry Burkett had given on the importance of Christian
employers paying their employees in a biblical manner that would be conducive to a winsome testimony. After all,
just as laborers are worthy (axios) of their wages (1Tim 5:18), so believers are to labor to be worthy of Christ. The
chart thus ties together various Greek cognates for worthiness with illustrations from the Bible as to what the word
*
  See Illustration 42. Parallelism of Lk 20:35 and Phil 3:11, 96.
†
  See The Out-Resurrection in Heb 11:35, 76.
‡
  See Illustration 44. Two Options for Out-Resurrection, 98.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                             Page 75
worthy means. It means that one’s conduct determines whether or not one is entitled to the benefit. Workers are
worthy of their wages. Christians who live obediently are walking worthily of various benefits: the Lord, the
gospel, His calling, the kingdom, and glory. Obedient believers will be counted worthy of their calling and walk
with the Lord in white. The only way to be worthy of misthologically walking with the Lord in the future is to walk
in a manner worthy of it now in the present—worthiness by works.
                                Illustration 31. Misthological Cognates of Worthiness




       All Christians are called, but this does not mean that they currently are walking in a manner worthy of that
calling (Eph 4:1; 1Thess 2:12) or that they necessarily will be considered misthologically worthy of their calling in
the future (2Thess 1:11). Likewise, it may be concluded that not all believers “walk in a manner worthy of the God
who calls” them “into His own kingdom and glory” (1Thess 2:12) or that they walk in a “manner worthy of the
Lord” (Col 1:10). Not all believers are “worthy of Christ” (Mt 10:37-38); nevertheless, the implication of such
passages is that those who heed the injunctions will be worthy. To be worthy (axios) of Christ is to “deserve to
belong Him” (BDAG 2.a) on the basis of relative “merit” (L-N 65:17).* Obviously, I am not talking about worthy
to belong to Him soteriologically. Rather, those who are worthy of misthological association with the Lord will sit
with Him on His throne as his regal cohorts.
       To simply be called (i.e., invited) in Mt 22:8 does not mean to be worthy of the invitation. The Greek word
here is kaleo. Yet there are a number of passages in the above chart where this verb or its cognate klesis (calling)


*
    See Lexical Merit, 73.
Page 76                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                                                     *
presents the possibility of being worthy of one’s calling. The prodigal son’s assessment that he was no longer
worthy (Lk 15:19,21) to be called a son indicates that previously he was worthy of that title and that his righteous
brother who stayed home and worked was still worthy of that title. To be sure, his father ran forth and embraced
his wayward son when he returned home, but this does not mean that this reckless son was worthy of his father’s
actions or of the title son. Although this prodigal was graciously embraced and called son, the point remains that
there were lasting misthological repercussions that came about as a result of the prodigal son no longer being
misthologically worthy of the title which he was graciously given. Although he was still a son and still allowed to
retain that title on the basis of sheer grace, he was no longer worthy of that title. And this unworthiness cost him his
inheritance.† The inheritance which he had squandered on riotous living was gone permanently.
        Likewise, not all those who are resurrected are worthy of that resurrection. Those who are not worthy of the
resurrection may still experience it but fail to receive the inheritance to which they otherwise would have been
entitled if they had been faithful. In the Markan parallel, Jesus simply remarks, “For when they rise from the dead,
they neither marry nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven” (Mk 12:25; cp. Mt 22:30). No mention
is made of being worthy of the resurrection. Indeed, this limited citation in the context would suggest that this
angelic likeness in the resurrection is applicable to all who experience it, not only to those who are worthy of it.
From the fuller Lukan account, it may be observed that if (A) you are resurrected and (B) worthy, then you are
(C) immortal, (D) unmarried (E) sons of God (A & B ⇒ C & D & E). However, from Matthew and Mark one may
deduce that if (A) you are resurrected, then (D) you are unmarried (A ⇒ D). Being unmarried in the resurrection is
not conditioned on worthiness. No believer who experiences the resurrection will be married. This subsidiary part
of the Lukan statement is not conditioned on personal worthiness.
        Noting the unconditional nature of this matrimonial component of Jesus’ statement for all who participate in
the resurrection, however, does not completely nullify Faust’s point that entrance is misthologically conditioned on
faithfulness. He easily could contend that the other aspects of the resurrection specified in Lk 20:36 are
misthological elements limited to those who are worthy of the resurrection. To be worthy of the resurrection, in this
case, would move beyond merely participating in it to having a misthological part in it. Granted, this is indeed the
case concerning being a mature son of God who is entitled to an inheritance and to the title son of God in the
resurrection. Although Faust may go further and say that the other portions of the statement in 20:36 (such as the
affirmation that they cannot die anymore) are misthological aspects of the resurrection, linking the remainder with
the general participation in the resurrection experienced by all believers is preferable for reasons which must be
considered beyond the present context in the ensuing discussion. As a result, a mediating position between Wilkin
and Faust on this matter will be advisable.

                                        The Out-Resurrection in Heb 11:35
       Wilkin acknowledges that Heb 11:35 is teaching a misthological resurrection. Yet in doing so, he already
has conceded that attain (tugchano), which is the same word used in Lk 20:35, can be used to describe a
misthological resurrection as something with which one is rewarded. Both verses are using the word
misthologically. “Those who are considered misthologically [tugchano] worthy of that world and the resurrection
from the dead, neither marry, nor are given in marriage” (Lk 20:35; TM). “Women received back their dead by
resurrection; and others were tortured, not accepting their release, in order that they might be rewarded with
[tugchano] a better resurrection” (Heb 11:35; TM). This better resurrection is attained and achieved (i.e., gained
through effort). This misthological resurrection is earned by enduring torture. This type of resurrection is a reward.
By enduring, they achieve a resurrection better than what they would have if they had not endured. They are not
trying to earn a better resurrection than unbelievers. They already are assured by saving grace that they will have a
resurrection better than unbelievers because of their simple faith in the Promised Redeemer. A soteriological
resurrection is not earned. Rather, these believers, who already are assured of a better resurrection than will be
experienced by unbelievers, are attempting to merit a resurrection that will be better for them as faithful believers.
       Therefore, they are seeking to experience a resurrection that will be better for them as believers than if they
had not endured and achieved this type of resurrection. This means, of course, that those believers who do endure
will achieve a better resurrection than those believers who do not endure. Naturally, all believers will have a
resurrection better than the lost. Although the resurrection itself is unearned, the attainment of a better resurrection
is based on the believer’s performance. The clear implication is that a plain resurrection is not earned. All believers
will participate in the resurrection itself (i.e., in the plain physical aspect of the resurrection), but some believers

*
    See Misthological Call, 299.
†
    See “Repent Now” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                Page 77
will be better off as a result of the resurrection than other believers. All believers will experience the resurrection,
but not all believers will have the same experience in the resurrection. Consequently, although Lang is correct in
that the Scripture teaches a misthological resurrection, he is mistaken in assuming that the resurrection itself is a
reward.

Sons of God
       Since Wilkin’s treatment of Heb 11:35 implicitly acknowledges that the Scripture teaches a misthological
resurrection that may be attained (i.e., earned), additional terms in Lk 20:35-36 will now be examined. The two
phrases sons of God and sons of the kingdom in Lk 20:36 are part of a more general biblical teaching concerning
sons. The word son (huios) can be used in contrast to being an illegitimate child (nothos). “But if you are without
discipline, of which all have become partakers, then you are illegitimate children and not sons” (Heb 12:8). If
someone is an illegitimate child, he is physically a son but not legally an heir. Illegitimate children were not legally
entitled to the inheritance.*

      On the other hand, the word son (huios) can also be used in conjunction with the word child (teknon) to
make a contrast between being a child entitled to a partial inheritance versus a full inheritance.
          14
            For all who are being led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God. 15 For you have not received
          a spirit of slavery leading to fear again, but you have received a spirit of adoption as sons by which
          we cry out, “Abba! Father!” 16 The Spirit Himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of
          God, 17 and if children, then heirs also: on the one hand, heirs of God, but on the other hand, co-
          heirs with Christ if indeed we co-suffer with Him in order that we also may be co-glorified with Him.
          (Rom 8:14-17; TM)


*
    See “Illegitimate Children” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Page 78                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
                                                                                                     134
        Dillow points out the implications and justification for this type of translation. The men…de construction
in Rom 8:17 is translatable as on the one hand…on the other hand. It can also be translated as to be sure…but (or
simply but in cases where the other readings are awkward), that is, “to be sure heirs of God, but joint-heirs with
Christ if indeed we co-suffer with Him.” Both Greek grammars and lexicons note the legitimacy of this translation
of men…de. So in v. 17 a contrast is being made between being a simple heir, on the one hand, versus being a co-
heir, on the other hand.
        Dillow has stated that this construction is always contrastive in the book of Romans. On the other hand,
Ventilato cites Kelly in defense of his counter claim that this verse is neither conditional nor contrastive. In fact, he
quotes Rom 6:11 as somehow supposedly proving that being dead to sin is not being contrasted with being alive in
Christ. To the contrary, surely this text is indeed disjunctive rather than conjunctive. We are not merely dead and
alive. We are alive in contrast to being dead. However, even if one plays Kelly’s semantic word game and calls it
distinctive rather than disjunctive, this construction is making a distinction between being dead and alive in
Rom 6:11 and between those who are heirs and those who are co-heirs in Rom 8:17. Further, even Ventilato’s
quote of Kelly admits that the rendition of on the one hand and on the other is suitable for this construction.
Correspondingly, I will render these first class conditions in Rom 8:17 simply as: “On the one hand, if you are
children of God, then you are heirs; on the other hand, if you co-suffer with Christ in order that you also may be
co-glorified with Christ, then you are co-heirs with Christ” (TM). Now considering the fact that these expressions
are indeed grammatically conditional, Ventilato will have to present a very evasive argument indeed to deny that
the statements are not theologically conditional as well. In contrast, Marrowists will build their theology on the
grammar.135
        Ventilato interjects a parenthetical since after the second if to express his belief that all believers will
successfully suffer with Christ.136 Hopefully, he has done so because these two conditional statements in Rom 8:17
are first class conditions rather than because he merely has imported his Calvinistic theology into the text. The
present book would acknowledge that rendering a first class condition as since is permissible if contextually
justifiable.* Hence, for the sake of argument, Ventilato’s rendition of since will be adopted for the moment. He also
emphatically inserts the present tense are from Rom 8:16 into the latter part of 8:17.137 For sake of argument, this
modification will also be made part of the translation: “On the one hand, you are heirs since you are children of
God; on the other hand, you are co-heirs with Christ since you co-suffer with Christ in order that you also may be
co-glorified with Christ” (TM).
        According to Ventilato, it is an absurd perversion to take the first statement as unconditionally referring to
something that is true of all believers on the basis of grace and the second statement as conditionally true of some
believers on the basis of works. But why are we expected to concur with Ventilato’s assessment? The alleged
nature of this so-called absurdity is certainly not due to a logical or grammatical problem. Apparently, Ventilato
means that it is a theological absurdity since such a position would not correlate with his Calvinistic
presuppositions. In defense, he cites a Calvinistic proof text (Phil 1:29). This proof text will be dealt with
subsequently and shown to be unsupportive of his Calvinistic argument.† But for now, in passing, let it be noted
that even if faith and perseverance in suffering were given irresistibly to the elect, then this only makes Rom 8:17b
applicable to all believers. It does not detract from the fact that the reason believers are co-heirs is because they co-
suffer. Heirship is conditioned on being a child of God, and co-heirship is conditioned on suffering for God. One is
based on what you are, while the other is based on what you do. The latter part of the verse is still conditioned on
performance. Ventilato claims that such performance is not a voluntary reaction but one that a believer involuntary
exercises automatically.‡ Even if this were true, his contention does nothing to remove the conditional nature of
Paul’s statement.138 A first class conditional sentence is still conditional even if rendered by since.§ In either case,
the reason they are regarded as co-heirs is because of their suffering with Christ. Their co-suffering makes them
co-heirs; it is not their co-heirship which makes them co-sufferers. This particular group of believers had a
victorious faith that allowed Paul to express confidence regarding its future outcome (Rom 1:8; 15:14; 16:9). So
even if Paul optimistically is expressing confidence concerning their future status based on their present
performance (as he does in several places elsewhere**), it is still a confidence that is expressed as a condition.

*
  See Conditional Sentences, 87.
†
  See Gift of Faith ≠ Act of Faith, 205; Phil 1:28-29, 211; Phil 1:29, 848.
‡
  Even if Calvinism were correct in regarding perseverance in faith an involuntary response to irresistible grace, it must be noted that
Calvinism makes this response a condition for reaching heaven and thus teaches conditional security in doing so. See Calvinistic
Conditional Security, 272.

   See “Calvinistic Objections” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                        Page 79
                                                                                                                    *
        The context conditions our hope of attaining this future glory on our perseverance (Rom 8:25). Paul does
not regard this perseverance as automatic. On the contrary, he warns his brethren that if they do not live right, they
will die (Rom 8:13). The idea that all brethren will persevere in a life of holiness is not contextually derived. Far to
the contrary, the believer’s present, temporal, spiritual experience may be one of death. And this experiential death
may result in premature death. Further, in this same epistle Paul warns of the danger of destroying another
believer’s faith (Rom 14:15). For that matter, he uses the same men…de construction in Rom 11:22 to say:
“Behold then the kindness and severity of God. On the one hand, God showed severity to those who fell, but on the
other hand, if you persevere in His kindness, then God will continue to show kindness to you—otherwise you also
will be cut off” (TM). Believers can be cut off from God’s misthological kindness. Perseverance is the condition,
and we are not automatons. We are not robots, or puppets on the Calvinistic string, from which God has removed
our free will and predetermined our responses so as to make them involuntary.† Instead, exhortations to persevere
are addressed to our volitions in hopes of eliciting a voluntary response. Whether we are cut off is determined by
whether we persevere; whether we persevere is not determined by whether we are cut off. The conditional nature of
the statement is expressed by the syntax and context.
        As to Ventilato’s argument that believers are already co-heirs in Rom 8:17, he mistakenly thinks that this
proves that coheirship cannot be denoting future rewards. In counterpoint, the realization of this co-heirship awaits
the future. Although believers who suffer for Christ in the present may be described in the present as co-heirs in
anticipation of that future event, their realization of that future event is conditioned on their present continuance in
suffering for Christ. If they fail to continue to suffer, then they forfeit their status as co-heirs. They can be cut off
from the misthological kindness and co-glory to which they would otherwise be entitled. Just as Esau sold his
birthright and forfeited the inheritance to which he previously was entitled, so faithful believers can forfeit the
misthological aspect of their inheritance to which they presently are entitled.‡ Persevering believers are the ones
whom Jesus warns, “Hold fast what you have, in order that no one [will] take your crown” (Rev 3:11). As a result
of their present perseverance, they were entitled to crowns. Nonetheless, just as they could forfeit that entitlement
to crowns, so we may forfeit our title as co-heirs if we fail to persevere. Co-heirship with Christ is conditioned on
present suffering with Christ.
        Paul teaches an equivalent truth in 2Tim 2:12. “If we endure, then we will also co-rule with Him” (TM). Co-
rule is a future tense verb. This future experience is conditioned on present endurance. Yes, all of God’s children
will have an inheritance within the kingdom and unconditionally enter the kingdom. All believers are heirs of God
(Gal 4:7). So when the question is posed, “What use is it to be an heir of God if you end up in the outer darkness?”
the response would begin with noting that this basic designation as an unconditional child of God guarantees
believers that they will be in the kingdom rather than in hell. This is a significant benefit indeed! Yet only those
believers who demonstrate their love for the Lord by the way they live are heirs of the kingdom (Jam 2:5). Only
those who practice righteousness will inherit the kingdom itself (cf. Mt 25:34; 1Cor 6:9-10; Gal 5:21). This latter
inheritance is a misthological inheritance conditioned on how well one does in practical sanctification. Only
overcomers are sons in this sense of the word. “He who overcomes shall inherit these things, and I will be his God
and he will be My son” (Rev 21:7).§ Certain things are only inherited by overcomers due to their status as mature
sons. Immature children will not inherit these things.
        In Rom 8:14 Paul says that only those believers who are led by the Spirit are sons of God, in the sense that
he is describing in this passage. He makes it very clear in Gal 5:16-26 that he does not assume that all believers are
led by the Spirit. Not being under the law experientially is conditioned on being led by the Spirit (Gal 5:18). No
believer is legally (i.e., positionally) under the law. Yet many believers are experientially under the law (Gal 5:4).
Both Rom 8:14 and Gal 5:18 are describing the experiential results of following the Spirit’s leading. Those
Christians who follow the Spirit’s leadership are mature sons of God who embody the character of their heavenly
Father in terms of their practice. Some believers walk by the Spirit, but other believers do not. Paul acknowledges
that some believers may grieve or quench the Spirit instead of following His leading (Eph 4:30; 1Thess 5:19). Not
all believers are sons of God in the sense Paul is using the term in Rom 8:14-17. In this passage, he is contrasting
being a child and heir of God with being a Spirit-led son and co-heir with Jesus.

        Now it is true that in Gal 4:7 Paul says that all believers are sons and heirs: “Therefore you are no longer a
slave, but a son; and if a son, then an heir through God.” Although the Bible teaches that it is possible to forfeit our
active inheritance; it appears that this passage is talking about our passive inheritance,139 which cannot be
forfeited (cf. Gal 3:29; 4:30).* Our soteriological status as sons cannot be forfeited, but our misthological status as
sons may indeed be lost.† Even so, it must be remembered that in this context (Gal 4:1-5) Paul is contrasting being
a son with being a slave. He warns these believers that they may fail to inherit the kingdom (Gal 5:21). As is
usually the case, the context determines how the author wishes his words to be understood. In Rom 8 Paul makes a
misthological contrast between being a child of God and a son of God. In Gal 4:1-5, on the other hand, the contrast
is between being a son versus a slave. Two different contrasts and two different points correspondingly are being
made. In this Galatian context, the designation son (at least perhaps in part) is a soteriological term in contrast to
slave. Nevertheless, Paul still warns these sons that they may fail to inherit the kingdom. Even this soteriological
contrast is not without its misthological dimension as well.‡
        Sons of God may either be used soteriologically (Gal 3:26) or misthologically (Rom 8:14,19) in Paul’s
writings.140 However, the only time that it is used is in the gospels, other than Lk 20:36, is where Jesus says,
“Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God” (Mt 5:9). In this passage the term is
misthological and associated with a misthological blessing that is dependent on one’s behavior; it is merited.
Another passage in that same context provides a very close (and collaborating) parallel:
        44
          But I say to you, love your enemies, and pray for those who persecute you 45 in order that you may
        be sons of your Father who is in heaven; for He causes His sun to rise on the evil and the good, and
        sends rain on the righteous and the unrighteous. 46 For if you love those who love you, what reward
        have you? Do not even the tax-gatherers do the same? (Mt 5:44-46)

       The word translated be (ginomai) also could be translated as become. You are to love your enemies so that
you may become sons of God (and be so regarded at the JSC). Regardless of whether the verb is translated as be or
become, sonship is clearly a misthological concept in this passage. In the Lukan parallel, Jesus uses a different
verb: “But love your enemies, and do good, and lend, expecting nothing in return; and your reward will be (eimi
future tense) great, and you will be (eimi future tense) sons of the Most High; for He Himself is (eimi present tense)
kind to ungrateful and evil men” (Lk 6:35). Since the futuristic tense of what we can be and receive is contrasted
with the present tense concerning what God already is, Luke apparently is using the future tense to reflect the same
potentiality as is Matthew with his subjunctive use of ginomai. These gospel writers are telling us, in similar
accounts, how we can become behaviorally like our Father and become entitled misthologically to the title sons of
God and to the corresponding rewards that go with that title to those who legitimately bear it.
       The word for reward that both Matthew and Luke use is misthos—the very word from which the term
misthology is derived. In both of these Matthean passages, in order to be a son, you must be a son in terms of your
behavior and thus son in terms of your deeds. A son in deed is truly a son indeed and entitled to a full inheritance
as such.141 Misthological sonship is indeed based on works. Since Jesus uses this expression in a misthological
sense in these passages, one would be inclined to suspect that this is the case in Lk 20:36 as well.

Sons of the Kingdom
       The other similar expression to sons of the resurrection in Lk 20:36 is the Matthean phrase sons of the
kingdom, which only occurs twice, once soteriologically (Mt 13:38) and once misthologically (Mt 8:12). To
summarize, since the resurrection in Lk 20:35-36 is based on personal worthiness and is associated with terms that
are possibly misthological (and in some cases very probably misthological), this passage is best considered to be
misthological. Since the word Jesus uses for resurrection always refers to a physical resurrection rather than a
spiritual resurrection, it should be interpreted as doing so here as well. This is not a spiritual resurrection and thus

*
  Passive inheritance is sometimes restricted to a soteriological entrance into the kingdom. Apparently, all believers have an
inheritance within the kingdom. For example, all believers will inherit a certain degree of glory as God’s children (Rom 8:21,30).
Thus, it must be remembered that soteriological entrance entails more than just getting into the kingdom. Although being an heir
through God (Gal 4:7) may amount to no more than being saved through fire (1Cor 3:15), even believers who enter the kingdom in
this manner will not only be in the kingdom but also will have certain rights which cannot be forfeited as well, such as being glorified
as God’s child. Active inheritance refers to a misthological entrance into the kingdom in which the mature child of God is recognized
as His mature son and receives the honor of being co-glorified with Jesus as His co-heir and co-ruler of the kingdom.
†
  See “Two Types of Sons” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
‡
  See “Son of a bondwoman” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                                      Page 81
not a soteriological resurrection. This resurrection is futuristic, physical, and misthological. The resurrection itself
will not be the reward, but the resurrection will be the occasion for the reward. These faithful sons will be rewarded
at the time of the resurrection by being given rulership over the earth. Or to restate the summary in a positive way
in terms of the interaction with the above writers, Lang and Faust are correct that the resurrection is physical and
misthological, Wilkin is correct that it is not a partial rapture, and Dillow appropriately combines these
perspectives into a harmonious whole.

                                            The Out-Resurrection in Phil 3:11
       Paul’s statement in Phil 3:11 is paralleled in the immediate context by similar statements. Breaking the
translation of this passage up into three time-related categories (in terms of when the benefit is to be experienced)
demonstrates this parallelism more readily. The chart is to be read just like reading a book (from left to right and
then down to the next line) in order to follow the numerical sequence that is noted parenthetically.
