Phil 3:7
      But whatever things were gain to me, those things I have counted as loss for the sake of Christ.

     This first statement (#1) refers to Paul’s past gains (kerdos) or accomplishments as a Pharisee in Phil 3:5-6.
He now proceeds to explain what for Christ’s sake means both temporally and eternally.

Phil 3:8a
      More than that, I count all things to be loss in view of the surpassing value of knowing Christ Jesus
      my Lord.

      He not only views his past as loss, but anything and everything in his present is regarded as worthless
compared to the value of knowing Christ. This level of knowing Christ moves beyond merely knowing Him as
Savior to knowing Him experientially as Lord. This contextually intimate-mature knowledge (gnosis) can only be
achieved by submission to the Lordship of Christ. Jesus also had taught that this level of intimacy with Him is
Page 82                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
conditioned on faithful discipleship: “He who has My commandments and keeps them, he it is who loves Me; and
he who loves Me shall be loved by My Father, and I will love him, and will disclose Myself to him” (Jn 14:21).
Such intimacy with Jesus is conditioned on keeping His commandments and thus is merited. Paul first draws our
attention to the value of this temporal reward in statement #2 above.

Phil 3:8b
      For whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and count them but rubbish in order that I may gain
      Christ.

        Next, Paul makes a transition in verse 8 from a present experience of Christ (described as knowing Him,
above in #2) to a future experience of Christ (described as gaining Him, here in #5). The word gain (kerdos) in
verse 7 is a nominal derivative of the verb for gain (kerdaino) in verse 8. This word denotes gain in terms of profit
and loss. For example, it is the same verb that Jesus uses in Mk 8:36. “For what does it profit a man to gain the
whole world, and lose his life?” (TM) The bottom line is that a life lived for earthly pursuits will amount to nothing
in terms of heavenly rewards. There will be no profit, and thus no reward, in heaven for earthly pursuits. But what
heavenly reward has so captivated Paul’s desire in this passage?
        The verb gain (kerdaino) can also be rendered win, as it is in the KJV. Christ is the prize to be won, as Paul
will further go on to indicate in Phil 3:14. Christ is the focus of Paul’s temporal and eternal desires. The reward
Paul wants is Christ, both now and in the future. Those who say they have no interest in rewards have, in contrast
to Paul, unwittingly said that they have no interest in Christ. The greatest thing about co-rulership with Christ is
that it is with Christ. The prize of co-rulership with Christ makes intimate association with Christ Himself the
reward to be won or lost. My Reward by Paul Baloche is a great misthological song that has the following chorus:

                                                 Jesus You are my reward
                                                 To hear Your voice on that day
                                                 Is all I’m living for.
                                                 Jesus You are my reward
                                                 To see Your face on that day
                                                 Is all I’m living for.

       The present author would have no problem picturing Paul the apostle singing this song, especially in
association with the present passage. However, the wording might need a little fine-tuning:

                                                 Jesus You are my reward
                                                 To hear Your voice of praise
                                                 Is all I’m living for.
                                                 Jesus You are my reward
                                                 To see Your smiling face
                                                 Is all I’m living for.

       All believers will hear Jesus voice and see His face, but only obedient believers will hear His praise and see
His smile. The rhyme may not work quite as well in this modification, and perhaps that was the reason for the
original selection, but the theology would be a little better expressed with this clarification. Regardless, the stanza
captures this misthology nicely:

                               I want to hear You say the words to me, “Well done.”
                               I want to hear You say, “Good and faithful servant.”
                               I want to hear You say, “I’ve prepared a place for you.”*

Phil 3:9
      And may be found in Him, not having a righteousness of my own derived from the Law, but that
      which is through faith in Christ, the righteousness which comes from God on the basis of faith.

*
    The prepared place is the misthological bridal chamber. See Many Mansions Prepared for You, 602.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                                  Page 83
       Statement #6 (verse 9) could be regarded as either present or future or both. In any case, the meaning is the
same. Paul is referring to being declared righteous (i.e., justified) on the basis of faith alone. This is the alien,
imputed righteousness that he discusses in Romans 3 and the first half of chapter 4 of that epistle. It refers to being
declared or found legally righteous. This is also known as positional righteousness as opposed to practical
righteousness. Such righteousness is dependent upon one’s legal position of being in Him, that is, in Christ. Such
righteousness is not dependent upon one’s practice or behavior.*

Phil 3:10
      That I may know Him, and the power of His resurrection and the fellowship of His sufferings, being
      conformed to His death.
                                              Illustration 34. Gnosis-Epignosis Spiral




       After all these years, Paul still has knowing Christ as his highest goal. One might have expected Paul to use
epiginosko (for mature knowledge). Instead, he simply uses ginosko (for experiential knowledge). Christ has said
that eternal life consists of knowing Him (Jn 17:3). The opening chapter of that same gospel says that the lost
world did not know Him (Jn 1:10). The word used on each of these occasions for know is ginosko, the same word
used of Adam knowing his wife so that she became pregnant as a result (Gen 4:1). All believers know Christ as
Savior, but only mature believers truly know (ginosko) Him as Lord. Even a little child knows his parents, but as
the child grows up and matures and experiences his parent’s love and discipline, he comes to know his parents at a
much fuller and deeper level. As he faces the challenges and difficulties of life and learns from his parents how to
deal with problems, the character of his parents is instilled in him. He moves from merely being his parents’ child
physically and legally to being their child experientially and practically in terms of his behavior. In like manner, as

*
 Positional righteousness is righteousness that is imputed to us legally as a gift. To be considered positionally righteous, one must at
some point in his or her life come to faith in Christ. This aspect of righteous is punctiliar in condition and permanent in its
bestowment. Practical righteousness, in contrast, is righteousness that is imparted to us experientially as we walk by faith. To be
considered practically righteous, a believer must be subsequently faithful. This aspect of righteousness, in contrast, is linear both in its
condition and bestowment.
Page 84                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
we experience the sufferings associated with following Christ’s example, we appropriate the reality of our co-
death, co-burial, and co-resurrection through dependence upon the Lord. We submit to His Lordship so that we
may experience the power of His resurrected life as He lives through us right here and now. These elemental truths
are fundamental to the doctrine of the victorious Christian life discussed by Paul in Romans 6-8. This practical
righteousness is definitely dependent upon one’s behavior.
       Some have likened this experience to what happens to a child progressing through school. When the student
moves from the elementary grades to middle school, the knowledge of the latter comparatively seems to be mature
knowledge. Soon, however, this mature knowledge simply will be considered an elementary knowledge compared
to what the child will be learning in junior high school. That mature knowledge will in turn become immature
knowledge compared to high school. Even then, what is learned in the classroom begins to make its way into the
student’s life. So it is with biblical studies. What was once considered an advanced understanding regarding
rewards (such as the salvation of the soul, the outer darkness, or the out-resurrection) gives way to an ever
expanding understanding of even the material that previously was thought to have been mastered. Even beyond
that head-knowledge, what is learned becomes an empowerment for how one lives. Head knowledge becomes
heart knowledge, so to speak. The gnosis of yesterday becomes the epignosis of today and the gnosis of tomorrow.

Phil 3:11
      In order that I may attain to the resurrection from the dead.

        The temporal reason that submission to the Lordship of Christ is so vitally important was given by Paul in
the previous verse: to know Christ and the power of His resurrected life. Paul wants to experience this type of life
before the resurrection. He desires it in the here-and-now before he dies. Unfortunately, some advocates of the
victorious Christian life stop here and make the experience of the victorious Christian life the primary or ultimate
reason for making Christ the Lord of one’s life, and thus for passing from being a carnal Christian to becoming a
spiritual Christian. In contrast, Paul goes on in verse 11 to give the ultimate reason for the victorious Christian life.
The reason that he wants the type of life described in Phil 3:10 is so that he can achieve the result laid out in
Phil 3:11.
        The word translated resurrection is exanastasis. This is the Greek word anastasis (resurrection) used in
Rev 20:6 with the Greek prefix out (ex i.e. ek) added to it. This compound noun literally means out-resurrection
and would be better translated as such since Paul has chosen this word rather than the normal word for resurrection.
English translations unfortunately render this word as if it were the normal designation for resurrection. The
translation, though, should indicate to the English reader that Paul is using a different word, the specific meaning
of which must be determined by its context. Granted, its basic meaning is derived from the base component
anastasis, which is the normal word for resurrection (anastasis) that Paul used above in verse 10 to say that Christ
was raised from the dead. It does not refer to a spiritual resurrection; it refers to a physical resurrection. Christ was
physically raised from the dead. That past physical reality is the basis for our present spiritual victory (v. 10). This
present spiritual victory is the requirement for our future physical reality—the out-resurrection (v. 11). But what
type of physical resurrection is in view in verse 11, and why does Paul use a word that is found nowhere else in the
NT to indicate this particular characteristic of our physical resurrection? What aspect of this physical resurrection
is Paul drawing to our attention by the use of this prefix?
        If the out-resurrection refers to the { soteriological resurrection of the righteous, then this soteriological
resurrection is dependent upon enduring sufferings (v. 10) and is a prize to be won (vv. 8,14). However,
soteriological righteousness by works is ruled out in the present context (v. 9). Thus, this resurrection by works
cannot refer to a soteriological resurrection by faith apart from works. This resurrection cannot refer to a
soteriological distinction between the lost and the saved. Some dispensationalists say that it refers to a | partial
resurrection and thus the rapture. However, if it refers to the rapture, then it must also be affirmed that it is a
partial rapture since it is merited. Thus, at this juncture, we are left with two valid possibilities. It could refer to a }
partial rapture, in which case the resurrection/rapture itself is regarded as a misthological experience. Or it could
refer to a ~ misthological experience that occurs at the time of the resurrection/rapture. Since we know from
Paul’s writings that all believers will appear at the Judgment Seat of Christ following the rapture (e.g., 2Cor 5:10),
the latter option is the only valid alternative. Affirmation of this interpretation of Paul’s perspective is also found in
such Pauline passages as 2Tim 2:11-12a, where he says,
       11
            It is a trustworthy statement:
            For if we have died with Him, we will also live with Him;
       12
            If we endure, we will also reign with Him. (TM)
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                Page 85


        All Christians have died positionally with Christ: “Now if we have died with Christ, we believe that we shall
also live with Him” (Rom 6:8). This guarantees that they will live with Him at the time of the resurrection: “For if
we have become united with Him in the likeness of His death, certainly we shall be also in the likeness of His
resurrection” (Rom 6:5). The word for resurrection is again anastasis. Paul assures us that since all believers have
died positionally with Christ in the past, all believers will live eschatologically with Him in the future at the time of
the physical resurrection. To be sure, this co-life with Christ has temporal implications as well, which Paul states in
Rom 6:10-13.
        Our experience of this resurrected life begins at regeneration and should have profound effects on our
earthly experience. Nevertheless, the temporal effects of this life do not exhaust its meaning. Eschatological
consequences are also envisioned. Further, our temporal experience of this life in no way determines whether we
will experience the soteriological dimension of this life in the future. This soteric dimension is conditioned in vv. 5
and 8 upon our having died with Him in the past, not upon our living for Him in the present. Paul summarizes this
for us in a nutshell: “For you have died and your life is hidden with Christ in God. When Christ, who is our life, is
revealed, then you also will be revealed with Him in glory” (Col 3:3-4). All believers will live with Christ in glory
at the time of the resurrection simply because they positionally have died with Him. This soteriological assurance
is to provide the basis for our misthological performance. Unfortunately, many Lordship Salvationists put the
proverbial cart before the horse.
                             Illustration 35. Soteriological Performance-Based Assurance




       In contrast to LS, Paul bases his exhortations for our present experience on the assurance of our past and
future union with Christ in His resurrection. The assurance of our co-resurrection with Christ positionally in the
past and eschatologically in the future is the basis for our co-life with Him in the present. Unfortunately, many
throw Paul’s theology into reverse and make our co-life with Christ in the present the basis of the assurance of our
co-resurrection with Christ positionally in the past and eschatologically in the future. In other words, many say that
the way you live determines whether you have been saved and whether you will be saved from eternal damnation.
This soteriological salvation-by-works is completely backwards. According to Paul, the fact that you have been
saved in the past and will be saved in the future should determine the way you live in the present. Your past and
future should determine your performance in the present. However, just because you should have this deterministic
response does not mean that you necessarily will. It is not a mechanical response. For that matter, your
performance in the present does not determine your unmerited category in the past or future.
Page 86                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                          Illustration 36. Out-Resurrection as a Balance

                                                            e ri e n




                                                    exp


                                                                       ce
                                                 ontolo
                                                                 gical




        Consider the illustration of a high-wire aerialist. In the initial stages, when first learning how to walk a high
wire, the wire is very low. The aerialist practices walking back and forth between the stands on the cable. Both the
stands and the cable are very secure. Of course, the aerialist falls occasionally, but the safety net prevents life-
threatening injury. His or her coach is there to remind the aerialist of the trustworthiness of the stands and cable.
The fall of the aerialist cannot be blamed on the equipment; the aerialist simply needs more experience. As he or
she becomes more experienced, the stands and wire are raised as the aerialist gradually leaves the immature level
for a mature height. A balancing beam makes the walk much easier; aerialists even learn how to do incredible feats
with the aid of the beam.
        All believers start out the Christian life in an immature carnal stage. They should be taught that they have
been raised with Christ, are raised with Christ, and will be raised with Christ. They are to face the difficulties of
life in submission to the Lordship of Christ with confidence in their past, present, and future union with their Lord.
They can have confidence that they have been raise with Christ positionally in the past, that they are ontologically
new creatures in Christ in the present,* and that they will be raised to live with Christ in the future. As a wise

*
  Ontology will be discussed more thoroughly momentarily (see Co-Life, 89). For now, let it be summarized that Christians should not
doubt that they have become new creatures in Christ even if they live like old creatures. The ontological change of regeneration is an
internal transformation that results in one becoming alive spiritually. This life is imparted to the believer’s spirit. Whether or not that
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                               Page 87
coach, Paul instills this confidence in his young converts and radiates this confidence himself. Assurance helps
performance.
        What kind of coach would tell his apprentice, “You cannot be sure about the second stand or the cable. The
second stand is liable to fall or the cable may break.” Yet this is precisely what many do, who throw Paul’s
theology in reverse. They are saying that you cannot be sure that the cable will hold. It might break. You might
lose eternal life. The new life which you received from God might be snuffed out. You cannot be sure you will
make it to heaven. You might forfeit your salvation from hell. You might cease to be a new creature in Christ.
Your performance will determine whether the cable breaks or whether the second stand falls, so you better perform
well or you will end up in hell. This type of theology is Arminian. At least many in the Arminian camp would
acknowledge that you can be sure that you have been raised with Christ positionally since you have trusted in
Christ as your Savior. You can be certain that this positional truth applies to you personally. You can also know
that you are a child of God, born of God, and have the life of God. But since Arminians reject eternal security, they
are left with temporal and eternal insecurity as to whether they will perform well enough to make it to heaven.
Their first stand, the positional one, may be stable, but their eschatological stand wobbles.
        Although this perverse, reverse theology is bad, another is even worse. Imagine the coach saying, “You
cannot be sure about the first stand nor the second stand nor the cable. Neither stand may even exist and the cable
may not even really be there.” These theologians, called Calvinists, teach that you cannot be certain that you have
been born again. Your performance will determine whether you were ever a genuine believer to start with. They
theoretically believe in a perseverance-based eternal security but deny that even they can be certain of their own
personal security. Although some within their camp hypothetically believe in some form of eternal security, they
realistically believe the Bible teaches personal insecurity. If you are Calvinistically consistent, you cannot be
entirely certain that you are a child of God or that you will reach heaven. Ultimately, these matters will be
determined by your performance—specifically by your perseverance.
        Paul’s theology stands in bold relief to both of these contemporary systems of thought. Unfortunately, many
laymen who have been conditioned to read the NT through the theological lens of either of the above theologies
might not readily pick up on the confidence that is the foundation for Paul’s statements. After all, in Romans 6:5
and 6:8 quoted previously, Paul says that we will be raised with Him and live with Him if we have died with Him.
Now, although these verses effectively rule out an Arminian perspective, the Calvinist may respond that Paul
brings the genuineness of his readers’ salvation into question, since they cannot be absolutely certain that they are
saved and thus cannot know for certain that they have been crucified with Christ in the past or will be raised with
Him in the future.

                                             Conditional Sentences
       Those familiar with Greek will already be aware that these statements by Paul are first class conditional
sentences. As a result, some commentators, such as Witmer, would say that the first class condition should be
translated since not if “because the statement is assumed to be true and is true.”142 On the other hand, Wallace
argues that “the first class condition should never be translated since,”143 even when the statement being made is
believed by the one making it (GGBB).144 Both perspectives have legitimate points. Paul says that his readers have
died with Christ (and are thus genuine believers). For those who believe in inerrancy, this means that absolute
assurance is possible, and today’s Calvinistic disbelief in absolute assurance must be rejected. Paul states that his
readers are justified. Since what he is writing is Scripture, they could not doubt their salvation without doubting
Scripture. To doubt the genuineness of their justification would be to doubt the Scripture itself. They were saved.
Neither Paul nor they (nor God for that matter) had any doubt about it. Neither should we. Witmer wants to convey
this certainty to the English reader with the translation of since due to the Greek grammar and context. So the
thought would be: “We will be raised with Him and live with Him since we have died with Him.”
       The Greek language can express if in multiple ways (e.g., four types of conditional sentences). Witmer
desires to clarify this distinction for the English readers. In contrast, one of Wallace’s arguments as to why we
should never use since is because the Greek language has other ways of saying since. Had Paul simply wished to
say since, he could have chosen a Greek word for since rather than use a first class condition that may or may not
be understood as since. This too is a valid position. Even so, the two positions are not irreconcilable.



change is manifested externally in a believer’s life does not change the fact that inward reality has taken place if a person has trusted
in Christ alone for eternal life. Assurance (or what Paul would call reckoning) of this inward reality is the basis from which one
overcomes carnality. To say that one must overcome carnality in order to have assurance is to put the chart before the horse.
Page 88                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
        Paul uses a conditional structure to remind his readers that there is one and only one condition to participate
in the resurrection. If we have died with Christ, then we will live with Christ. Paul does not use the if to cast doubt
on his own salvation or that of his readers but to point out that the one and only requirement to live with Christ is to
have died with Christ. Since Paul and his readers had died with Christ, they could be absolutely certain that they
would live with Christ. In this context, if does mean since. Either way we translate it, we lose something of the
Greek. The translation of since fails to notify the English reader that a condition is involved and that there are
multiple ways of saying since. The translation of if fails to alert the English reader that there is no uncertainty
involved and that there are multiple ways of saying if.
        Imagine a son coming to his father and saying, “I have finished my homework; may I go to the ball game?”
And his father responds, “If you have finished your homework, you may go the ball game.” Is the father
questioning his son’s honesty, or is he simply reminding his son that the one condition he had made for his son to
attend the game was that he finish his homework? It probably depends on the father and the son! Sensitivity to the
context of this father-son relationship would be necessary to be certain which sense is understood. The Greek
language helps clarify which is the case. The latter part of the illustration is the one that applies here. The father
just as easily could have said, “Since you have finished your homework, you may go to the game.” Flexibility is
permissible in English and Greek. Translating it as since or if is contextually permissible. The English reader must
be sensitive to the translation and context to realize that since may indicate a condition and if does not necessarily
indicate uncertainty.

                                                Co-Death
       The following Pauline conditional statements concerning co-death with Christ resulting in co-life with
Christ are illustrative (TM):
                                 Illustration 37. Co-Life is Conditioned on Co-Death
      1) “If we have become united with Him in the likeness of His death, then certainly we will also be
         in the likeness of His resurrection” (Rom 6:5).
      2) “If we have died with Christ, then we believe that we shall also live with Him” (Rom 6:8).
      3) “If you have died with Christ to the elementary principles of the world, then why, as if you
         were living in the world, do you submit yourself to worldly regulations” (Col 2:20).
      4) “If we have died with Him, then we will also live with Him” (2Tim 2:11b).

        If one were inclined to think that in any of these cases the readers might not be genuine believers (and that
as a result Paul is casting doubt on whether they have died with Christ), then surely it would be in #3, where Paul
addresses the Colossians, “If you have died with Christ.” They are not living like they have died with Christ. Their
experience does not match their position. Yet it is to these very believers that Paul proceeds to say just a few verses
later, “For you have died and your life is hidden with Christ in God” (Col 3:3). Paul does not base their assurance
on their performance. Quite the contrary! He urges them to base their performance on their assurance! The thought
is, “Since you have died with Christ, live like it.” If means since in Col 2:20.
        All believers have died with Christ. Does Paul mean to insinuate in Rom 6:5 that his readers may not have
been crucified with Christ, since he has used a conditional sentence? No. In the very next verse, he goes on to
affirm that the reason they should live for Christ is because they have died with Christ. This is typical of his
approach.
                                         Illustration 38. Co-Death is Assured
      1) “Knowing this, that our old self was crucified with Him, that our body of sin might be done
         away with, that we should no longer be slaves to sin” (Rom 6:6). All believers have died with
         Christ, and Paul expresses no doubt that he and his intended readers are believers.
      2) All believers can say with Paul, “I have been crucified with Christ” (Gal 2:20).
      3) They can say it and know it is true, as Paul goes on to explain: “Now those who belong to
         Christ Jesus have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires” (Gal 5:24).
      4) “For you have died and your life is hidden with Christ in God” (Col 3:3).

                                                Co-Resurrection
       Affirmation of our co-crucifixion is paralleled by Paul’s affirmation of our co-resurrection. Paul exhorts the
believers, “If then you have been raised up with Christ, keep seeking the things above” (Col 3:1). Does this mean
that he doubts that they might have been raised up? Not at all. Just a few verses earlier he affirmed their co-
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                               Page 89
resurrection, “You were also raised up with Him through faith in the working of God” (Col 2:12). The positional
aspect of this co-resurrection is brought out in Eph 2:6, where Paul says that God “raised us up with Him and
seated us with Him in the heavenly places, in Christ Jesus.” Once again, the exhortation to these Colossian
believers is based on an affirmation. You have been raised so have a heavenly mindset. Performance is to be based
on position. Position is not based on performance. Our relationship with God is not dependent on our walk with
God. Rather, our walk with God is dependent on our relationship with God and should reflect that relationship.
       For example, a man and woman may act like they are married when in fact they are not. Or a man and
woman may act like they are not married when in fact they are. The way they act does not determine whether they
are married. But whether or not they are married should determine the way they act. Paul’s point is that your
relationship with the world has been severed by co-death with Christ, so stop flirting with the world. You are
married to Christ now. You have been co-raised and joined to Christ (Rom 7:4) so be faithful to Christ. Neither
your flirting nor faithfulness determines whether you have a relationship with Christ. Instead, your relationship
should determine your performance.
                                            Illustration 39. Daisy Theology




        Paul does not teach his converts to act married so that they can know they are married. Rather, they are to
act like they are married because they know they are married (actually betrothed) to Christ. Your performance is to
be based on your assurance. Modern Calvinistic teaching is quite different. According to it, you are to act like you
are a Christian so that you can know you are a Christian. To the degree you act like you are a Christian, you can
know you are a Christian. Proveitism is a rather strange theology. This TULIP doctrine of assurance really amounts
to what Wilkin would call daisy theology: “You go through your whole life with what I call daisy theology. ‘He
loves me, He loves me not. He loves me, He loves me not.’ And you hope you end your life on ‘He loves me’
cause you don’t know.”145 This was well expressed in a GES comic strip series by Mike Sanderson.146
        You pretend to be something you may not be (i.e., saved, loved, elect), in hope that you may prove to be
what you cannot know for sure that you are (i.e., saved, loved, elect). But it would seem to be very difficult to be
faithful to a relationship that you cannot even be sure exists. Certainty of relationship would tend to inspire
faithfulness to that relationship. Certainty of our soteriological co-resurrection tends to inspire living by the power
of that resurrection. It is better to accept Paul’s theology and psychology. Be what you are because you are certain
of what you are—a new creature in Christ. This is but one reason that GRAPE writers stress the availability of
absolute assurance. Doubt caused by mind games over the mythical differences between head and heart faith
should be dispelled by (1) the biblical synonymity that exists between the two (in that mind and heart are used
interchangeably) and (2) the fact that faith on the part of those who are saved is ascribed as a function of both the
mind and heart.147

                                                    Co-Life
      Having life is a natural corollary of having been raised with Christ, and Paul assures his readers that they
have been made alive together with Christ (Eph 2:5; Col 2:13). They have new life as a result of regeneration and
Page 90                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
consequently are new creatures: “Therefore if any man is in Christ, he is a new creature” (2Cor 5:17). This
transformation moves beyond being new creatures positionally to being new creatures ontologically. Our physical
birth resulted in a physical being and nature; our spiritual birth results in a spiritual being and nature. Through the
power of God’s word, we were created human beings with physical life. Likewise, through the power of God’s
word in the gospel, we are created spiritual beings with spiritual life the moment we believe. Every believer is in
Christ; every believer is a new creature. These statements are absolute. You are either in Christ, or you are not.
You are either a new creature, or you are not.
        Regrettably, being a new creature in Christ had not resulted in the appropriate experiential change in the
lives of the Corinthian believers to whom Paul wrote 2Cor 5:17. We know this is true, not only from the broad
context but also from the immediate context. Paul begs these new creatures to be reconciled to God, to become in
practice what they are in position legally and what they are by new birth ontologically (2Cor 5:20).* Nevertheless,
they are in fact new creatures (i.e., new creations) in Christ ontologically even though they are failing to
demonstrate this change experientially. Faust is correct to say that 2Cor 5:17 “refers to position and provision; it is
not absolute in regard to practice.”148 All believers are new creatures positionally and provisionally and can be new
creatures practically. But the experiential manifestation of this new reality is ours, providing we meet the
contextual condition necessary for the practical reconciliation. Our new birth results in something real, even if we
fail to allow it to make a real change in our behavior. Our experience should be based on the reality of our new
birth. The converse is not true: The reality of our new birth should not be based on our experience.
        To illustrate the potential disparity between being a new creature ontologically versus experientially,
suppose that your wife were to call you from work to let you know that her car battery is dead and that the car is
sitting in her parking lot at work. You tell her that if you have time you will replace the battery before she gets off
work. And you inform her that if you do so, you will call her and let her know. Otherwise, she is to go catch a ride
home with someone else. On your lunch break you go and replace the battery and call your wife, leaving a message
on her cell phone to let her know that you replaced the battery. But she fails to check her messages on her cell
phone and assumes that you were unable to take care of the battery. So she catches a ride home with a friend.
Although the car now has a new battery (and might thus be said to have undergone an ontological change so that its
internal nature has been changed from one of death to life), it has not undergone an experiential change and is still
sitting just as motionless as ever in her parking lot at work. Its internal chemical transformation has not been
transferred into living motion.
        Or suppose that you take to heart the popular advice given for older men to have their prostate checked and
then take supplements that will raise your testosterone level back to normal levels in order to lose weight. After a
few months of taking such supplements, your testosterone levels do increase, but you do not complement it with
moderation in diet and exercise. So you lose no weight. You fail to experience the external change that you were
hoping for although you have undergone the internal hormonal transformation that you were trying to achieve.
Your internal transformation fails to show itself in your external appearance because you do not take the necessary
auxiliary actions. Just as internal chemical or hormonal changes do not necessarily demonstrate themselves in the
desired external results, so an internal spiritual transformation of a believer into a new creature may not
demonstrate itself in the desired behavior.
        All believers have undergone the internal transformation of the new birth and are unconditionally
guaranteed that they have life and will live with Christ even if they do not undergo a moral transformation. We
have been raised; we are raised; we will be raised. The logical connection in Paul’s thought is that resurrection
with Christ in the past guarantees life with Him now and in the future. Paul assures his readers that he and they will
be raised with Jesus (1Cor 6:14; 2Cor 4:14). And as shown in the conditional statements above, our resurrection
with Christ in the future is conditioned solely upon our death with Him in the past.
                                          Illustration 40. Co-Resurrection is Assured
1. If you ever believed in Christ, then you have died with Christ.†
2. If you have died with Christ, then you will be raised with Christ.‡
3. Therefore, if you ever believed in Christ, then you will be raised with Christ.

       Some mistakenly think that the promise of life with Christ in heaven is conditioned on the way a believer
lives on earth. To the contrary, Paul conditions life with Christ on whether one died with Christ, not on whether
*
  See my book, Carnal Corinth.
†
  See Illustration 38. Co-Death is Assured, 88.
‡
  See Illustration 37. Co-Life is Conditioned on Co-Death, 88.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                               Page 91
one lives for Christ. Paul assures us that having life with the Lord in the future is conditioned solely on our having
died with Christ in the past. And he repeatedly affirms that all believers have died with Him. The way we live
should be based on the reality of the co-death with Christ, but the way we live does not determine if we have
undergone this death. Consequently, Paul assures believers that they will live with Christ in the future even if they
do not live for Him in the present.
       This acknowledgment by Paul that all believers have died with Christ also nullifies the claim that a believer
must persevere in the faith in order to make it to heaven. If one has ever believed in Christ, then he or she has died
with Christ and, therefore, is assured of being raised with Christ and of living with Christ. The question is not, “Did
they stay dead?” (They did, but that is beside the point.) The real question is, “Did they die?” All believers have
died with Christ. The mistaken argument that a believer ceases to be dead with Christ when that believer ceases to
believe in Christ must concede that this former believer had died with Christ and, by virtue of that fact, was
unconditionally promised life with Christ in the future. We do not have to continue to believe in the present in
order to have died with Christ in the past. Therefore, if we have ever believed, then we have died with Christ and
our resurrection with Christ is unconditionally guaranteed. Punctiliar faith* results in unconditional security.

                                        Necessity of the Out-Resurrection
        Nevertheless, as Paul notes in 2Tim 2:11-12a, the fact that all believers will live with Christ does not
guarantee that all believers will rule with Christ. Ruling with Christ requires enduring suffering. The reason that
Paul wants to experience Christ’s suffering in Phil 3:10 is not because he is a masochist. Rather, he wants to attain
the out-resurrection, which is rulership with Christ in verse 11. Returning briefly to the imagery of the high-wire
performer, the out-resurrection enables him to walk back and forth between the positional and eschatological
aspects of his union with Christ in the past and future as he experiences the ontological reality of this union in the
present. Certainly, there is a thrill in walking with Christ. Indeed, some in the victorious Christian life camp say
that we should walk that wire just for the thrill of it. Paul, however, does not share that attitude. The temporal thrill
is part of it, but the eschatological paycheck is also a valid part of Paul’s motivation. We would not think it strange
that a high wire aerialist not only enjoys the performance but also looks forward to the paycheck afterward. Nor
should we consider Paul ungrateful because he misthologically desires the out-resurrection.
        Paul’s example should be followed in imploring carnal believers to leave their worldly infancy and in order
to move on to spiritual maturity. Temporal motivations are very important to the carnal Christian; thus, temporal
rewards are important. But temporal rewards must be bolstered by eternal rewards. Let us take a carnal look at
temporal rewards, so that we can see them through the carnal eyes of carnal believers. What do you get if you obey
the Lord? Persecution (2Tim 3:12). What do you get if you disobey the Lord? Punishment (Heb 10:29). Whether or
not you live for the Lord, bad things are going to happen to you. The Bible also teaches that the Lord temporally
blesses the righteous and the unrighteous (Mt 5:45). From a purely carnal perspective that focuses exclusively on
the present, the best thing you can do is live your life for the here and now and not be too good or too bad. A carnal
believer might conclude that it is best to not be good enough to get persecuted by the devil and not be bad enough
to come under punishment by God. After all, carnal believers may conclude that since they are saved from hell and
since heaven is going to be basically the same for everyone, those poor fools who suffer for Jesus are to be most
pitied.
        Quite frankly, if this carnal presupposition were correct, then Paul probably would agree with the carnal
conclusion. In 1Cor 15:19, Paul says that if nonbelievers were correct that there is no resurrection and no hope of
heaven, then believers are the most pitiful group of people on the planet. If the lost were correct that our hope in
Christ is limited to this life, then it would appear that, according to Paul, we should “eat and drink, for tomorrow
we die” (1Cor 15:32). If such were the case, we should live for the here and now and for the simple temporal
pleasures of life. Temporal rewards are obviously not sufficient to motivate Paul to live for the Lord in Phil 3:7-15.
Although temporal rewards are certainly benefits, eschatological rewards were undeniably the driving force in
Paul’s life.

*
  Punctiliar faith may be represented by a dot [z] as opposed to linear faith which would be denoted by a line or arrow [£]. The
analogy of a camera taking a snapshot as opposed to a video camera taking a motion picture is often used to convey the difference
between punctiliar and linear action respectively. (See discussion and illustration of internal aoristic aspect in Believe: An Aspectual
and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.) Since regeneration is a punctiliar event that happens the very moment one
comes to saving faith, soteric faith must be punctiliar. Regeneration is not a process and therefore cannot be conditioned on
continuation in faith. Those who reject unconditional security assert that retention of regeneration is conditioned on continuation in
faith. The present book, in contrast, affirms unconditional security and therefore limits saving faith to a punctiliar condition that
irrevocably results in regeneration as a punctiliar event.
Page 92                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
        In contrast to Paul, a seminary professor that the present writer once had said that our temporal experience
as believers should be sufficient to motivate us to live for the Lord regardless of eternal rewards. However, in
attempting to attribute interest in rewards to carnal motivation, the professor was unknowingly claiming to be more
spiritual than Paul. The apostle frequently acknowledges that he is motivated by eschatological rewards. Indeed,
the implication of 1Cor 15:19 is that if there are no future rewards, then faithful believers are fools. (Paul was no
Sadducee!) The attempt to limit one’s perspective to the blessings of this life is a carnal endeavor, not a spiritual
demeanor. If carnal believers are correct that there is no real treasure in heaven, then faithful believers are fools to
lay up treasure in heaven. Our hope in Christ, whether it is soteriological or misthological, must not be limited to
this life; otherwise, one is a pitiful fool to live for Christ.149 The Marrowistic contention is that we are not fools to
live for Christ because the victorious Christian life will result in the crown of life in the future. Our hope in Christ
is futuristic concerning things not seen in the here and now (Rom 8:24). He is no fool who gives up earthly
pleasure to pursue heavenly treasure.

                                         Misthological Hope and Glory
        Paul not only believes in a soteriological hope in Christ, he also believes in a misthological hope as well:
“We exult in hope of the glory of God. And not only this, but we also exult in our tribulations, knowing that
tribulation brings about perseverance; and perseverance, proven character; and proven character, hope” (Rom 5:2-
4). The reason Paul exults in hope in the midst of his tribulations is because these tribulations bring him hope, not a
soteriological hope of entering heaven, but a misthological hope of the glory of God. Our soteriological hope of
entering heaven is not dependent upon our enduring tribulations, but our misthological hope of being co-glorified
with Jesus is most certainly dependent upon our response to our tribulations.
        According to Paul, we will be “co-heirs with Christ if indeed we co-suffer with Him in order that we may be
co-glorified with Him” (Rom 8:17b; TM). In the very next verse, Paul immediately proceeds to link this glory with
the sufferings we endure: “For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared
with the glory that is to be revealed to us” (Rom 8:18). Paul insists that we should set our minds on glory as an
eternal reward gained by perseverance rather than set our minds on temporal pursuits. “For momentary, light
affliction is producing for us an eternal weight of glory far beyond all comparison, while we look not at the things
which are seen, but at the things which are not seen; for the things which are seen are temporal, but the things
which are not seen are eternal” (2Cor 4:17-18).150 Paul promotes an eternal perspective over against a temporal
one. The reason he eagerly awaits this hope with perseverance (Rom 8:25; 12:12) is because it is through
perseverance that we obtain this hope (Rom 15:4).
        Not surprisingly, Paul misthologically associates this hope with a crown: “For who is our hope or joy or
crown of exultation? Is it not even you, in the presence of our Lord Jesus at His coming? For you are our glory and
joy” (1Thess 2:19-20). Our hope, joy, crown, exultation, and glory are not only dependent upon our own
perseverance, they are also dependent upon the perseverance of those whom we evangelize and disciple.151 The
glory of living with Christ in the kingdom is promised unconditionally to all believers. The co-glory of ruling with
Him is conditioned on co-suffering with Him. Paul wants to know the fellowship of Christ’s suffering, that is,
share in Christ’s suffering, so that he may have a co-share in Christ’s ruling.
        The biblical affirmation of misthological glory is found in a number of passages: Rom 2:7,10; 5:2; 8:17-18;
2Cor 4:17; Eph 5:17; Phil 2:16; 1Thess 2:12,20; 2Thess 2:14; 2Tim 2:10; Heb 2:7,9-10; 1Pet 1:7-8; 1Pet 5:4,10.
Examples of misthological hope are also ample, in a number of passages to be discussed subsequently (Acts 26:6-
8; Rom 5:2,4; 8:24-25; 15:4; Phil 1:20; 3:11; Col 1:5,23; 1Thess 2:19; 5:8; Tit 1:2; 3:7; Heb 6:11,18-19;
1Pet 1:3).152

                                               Preliminary Findings
        As has just been demonstrated in the conditional statements concerning co-death in the past and co-
resurrection in the future, living with Christ in glory is not conditioned on merit. Our position in Christ guarantees
that we will live with Christ in His glorious kingdom. Since we have died with Christ positionally, we will live
with Him eschatologically at the time of the resurrection. Yet whether we will rule with Him in His kingdom is
merited by our endurance in the face of present sufferings. These facts argue against a partial resurrection of
believers and thus against a partial rapture. All believers have died with Christ, and since this is the only condition
to live with Him and be resurrected, all believers will be raptured.
        This observation also gives preliminary indications that all believers will be in the eschatological kingdom,
since they will all participate in the same physical resurrection. An ultraistic misthological interpretation that
teaches that all believers will not be raptured or that all believers will not live with Christ in the kingdom is
consequently rendered intrinsically unlikely. Nor would it be possible to take an ultraistic misthological view that
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                 Page 93
all believers will be in the eternal kingdom but only some believers will be in the millennial kingdom. The
resurrection takes place before the millennium. It is a resurrection of all believers and results in all believers living
with Christ. Thus, although the misthological aspect of the out-resurrection must be acknowledged, it should not be
overdone to the point of assuming that only those believers who participate in the out-resurrection will be in the
eternal or millennial kingdom. Rather, if the outer darkness is a misthological concept (as will be demonstrated), its
relationship to the doctrine of the out-resurrection would not be one of exclusion from living with Christ in the
kingdom. Misthological exclusion from the out-resurrection indeed may indicate inclusion in the outer darkness,
but it would not result in exclusion from the kingdom. The preliminary deduction would be that if the outer
darkness is a misthological concept, it does not indicate exclusion from the millennial kingdom. It would seem to
be a limitation within the kingdom after the resurrection.

Phil 3:12
      12
         Not that I have already obtained it, or have already become perfect, but I press on in order that I
      may lay hold of that for which also I was laid hold of by Christ Jesus.

        Of course, Paul has not achieved sinless perfection in Phil 3:12, but that is not his point. Sinless perfection is
not something you have to strive to obtain. Perfect sanctification (i.e., sinless perfection) will be the experience of
all believers at death or at the rapture, whichever comes first. Sinless perfection will not be experienced until then.
This is not the type of perfection that Paul is trying to earn in either the present or future. Nor is he saying that he
has failed to reach Christian maturity or the Christlike character of verse 10. The it of verse 12 refers to the future
experience of verse 11, not to the present experience of verse 10.
        The verb for lay hold in verses 12 and 13 is katalambano. The NAS translates this verb as win in 1Cor 9:24:
“Do you not know that those who run in a race all run, but only one receives the prize? Run in such a way that you
may win.” The word for prize (brabeion) is also the same word Paul uses in Phil 3:14 (the only two places he uses
this word). Paul clarifies in 1Cor 9:24-27 that the misthological prize (brabeion) he wants to win is associated with
a crown (stephanos).
        In the athletic games of Paul’s time, winners were awarded a prize purse (brabeion), and the winners of the
Olympian games also received a crown (stephanos). The prizes might include golden spears, shields, or cups, and a
golden pass to the games that you won. This pass would entitle you to sit in the royal box at the games with the
highest ruler. Although the laurel wreath itself awarded at the Olympian games may not seem that significant to us
now, it was the highest sought-after distinction in that society. The indirect rewards associated with it were
significant.
        The victor’s native city would honor their hometown hero significantly. To start with, when their native
Olympian champion returned home, they would tear down a place in the city wall through which he could have a
special entrance into the city. Banquets would be held in his honor and songs composed as well to commemorate
his victory. His local city would practically idolize him. He would also receive exemption from taxation for the rest
of his life, and the education of his children was provided for at public expense. His home city likewise may vote
to provide him with significant sums of money and even make him a general. And he was also given other special
privileges, such as a place of honor at banquets and a high position in the City Council. The Olympian crown was
thus considered the pinnacle of temporal happiness.
        Paul wants to win the corresponding eschatological crown and the prize that went along with it. He also
acknowledges that he has not already earned it. To win this prize one must not only run the race well, one must
finish well. What Paul is saying in Phil 3:12 is that he has not already taken hold of the trophy (i.e., the out-
resurrection). Christ won him so that he could win the prize. The purpose for which Christ won Paul was to make
Paul a winner.
        The use of the passive voice for perfect (teleioo) in Phil 3:12 does not rule out this understanding.
According to FB, the passive tense of this verb may refer to dying and “finishing one’s earthly course of life
successfully” as in Lk 13:32. In this passage, Jesus says that when He dies He “will be perfected.” Obviously,
Jesus is not saying that He will not achieve sinless perfection until He dies! The NAS translates Jesus as saying, “I
reach my goal.” The RSV renders it as, “I finish my course.” This is the type of perfection that Paul is referring to
in this passage. “I press on toward the goal to win the prize” (Phil 3:14; TM). Paul had not yet been perfected in the
sense of reaching the goalpost—the out-resurrection. In football a forty-yard run is great. Still, you do not stop at
the ten-yard line and sit down! You take it all the way into the end zone. In Phil 3:12, Paul simply is
acknowledging that he has not yet won the out-resurrection because he has not yet finished the race, but he runs on
in order to do so. Merely enduring suffering is not enough; one must endure it to the end in order to win.
Page 94                                                                                                   The Outer Darkness
       The word for perfect (teleioo) is synonymous with the one he uses in 2Tim 4:7-8 (teleo). “I have fought the
good fight, I have finished the course, I have kept the faith; in the future there is laid up for me the crown of
righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous Judge, will award to me on that day; and not only to me, but also to all
who have loved His appearing.” Paul utters these words at the end of the race. He is now to be killed for his faith,
and he has run and finished the race as a winner. He is pressing on for misthological perfection.

Phil 3:13-14
      13
         Brethren, I do not regard myself as having laid hold of it yet; but one thing I do: forgetting what
      lies behind and reaching forward to what lies ahead, 14 I press on toward the goal for the prize of the
      upward call of God in Christ Jesus.

      This passage and 1Cor 9:24-27 not only have verbal parallels but are strong conceptual parallels as well and
should be used to clarify what Paul means, since he is dealing with the same topic.
