       Some of the words are identical; some are synonymous. The only place that kerdaino (win) is found in
Paul’s writings is in Phil 3:8 and 1Cor 9:19-22. The KJV is fully justified as translating this word as win in these
related contexts. Christ is the prize to be won in Phil 3:8. Just as in the Corinthian passage Paul refers to winning
the lost to Christ, in the Philippian passage he refers to winning Christ Himself. The other word for win
(katalambano) is the same in both passages, and BDAG lists win as one of its meanings in Phil 3:12-13.
       The words for run can be used synonymously. For example, the dioko of Phil 3:12,14 is translated as run by
the NAS in Lk 17:23. As already noted, the word for prize (brabeion) is the same in both passages and found only
in these passages (i.e., 1Cor 9:24; Phil 3:14). In 1Cor 9:24-25 Paul specifies that the prize is an eternal crown. This
is the victor’s crown (stephanos), which he also declares to have won in 2Tim 4:7-8 because he has finished the
course.* This crown was received in the Olympic games. He also uses this same terminology about finishing the
race in Phil 3:12. One would anticipate a similar meaning in Phil 3:14. Paul continues to use terms associated with
the Olympic games in this verse: goal and upward call. Sweigart points out that the goal “was the mark on the
racetrack at the finishing post to which an athlete directs his eye. This prize is a result of the upward call of
God….Here is a reference to the command ‘come up here’ that was spoken by the judge at the games when the
victor was crowned.”153
       This interpretation is readily found among the commentators and is superior to other options considered
therein; although, a number of those alternate options would still lead to the misthological conclusion being
derived herein. Paul urges Timothy to pursue, that is, run after (dioko), godly behavior so that Timothy may
likewise lay hold of or take hold of (epilambano) eternal life (1Tim 6:11-12). Thus, Paul is using the combination
of dioko with both katalambano and epilambano to paint a word picture of running to win a prize that may be
firmly grasped. Paul is telling Timothy to run and fight in order to win eternal life as his future acquisition. As
Thayer (TY) correctly notes, in this context it must mean “to struggle to obtain eternal life.” If Timothy is to obtain
eternal life in the future, then he must exert the necessary effort to do so in the present. Then Paul proceeds to tell
Timothy that rich believers will have to be rich in good works in order lay hold of or take hold of (epilambano)
eternal life in the future (1Tim 6:18-19). So although the literal meaning of both katalambano and epilambano may
be translated identically and literally as lay hold of (see NAS for Lk 23:26; Phil 3:12), the NJB translation of win
the eternal life in 1Tim 6:12 is attractive in view of the contextual imagery and cross-reference equivalency to Phil

*
    See also Stephanos, 852; Illustration 311. Run for the Brabeion and Stephanos, 872.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                Page 95
3:12. This synonym may be translated win. Timothy is to lay hold of eternal life in the future by winning the race
and winning the war.
       This future misthological nature of eternal life as a reward is not to be confused with the free gift of eternal
life, which believers already have received in the past and which guarantees their soteriological future (Jn 5:24).
Believers already have received eternal life as a gift. Since this aspect of eternal life is a gift, it is unearned and
cannot be lost. The NLT does a grave injustice to the text when it translates 1Tim 6:12 as, “Hold tightly to the
eternal life that God has given you.” This sloppy paraphrase gives the false impression that Paul is exhorting
Timothy to hold on to the gift of eternal life that God already has given him in the past lest he lose it in the present.
This Arminian misrepresentation, in which regeneration is lost, is refuted by the fact that Timothy has not yet laid
hold of eternal life in the manner in which Paul is describing it. He is not talking about eternal life in terms of
regeneration. We already have life in that capacity; we do not await it in the future. The NLT correctly translated
1Tim 6:19, however, as taking hold of eternal life in “the future.” Clearly, in Phil 3:12 and 1Tim 6:12, Paul is also
talking about attaining a future glory, not retaining a gift that we already have received in the past. The gift of
eternal life cannot be forfeited once it is received. It and its benefactor hold on to us whether or not we hold on to it
or to Him (Jn 10:28). Paul is not talking about holding on to something we already have received but about laying
hold of something set before us in the future. You do not run to win the right to lay hold on something you already
possess.
       The rich athletic terminology, however, does not exhaust the metaphorical imagery being presented by Paul.
Indeed, the facet that Sweigart emphasizes is the inheritance motif.154 The verbs for attain to in Phil 3:11 and lay
hold of in verses 12 and 13 provide the basis for this association. The expression attain to is katantao eis, which as
BDAG (2b) notes, can be used as “a technical term for the inheritance that comes to an heir.” Indeed, Paul uses this
terminology in Eph 4:13, “until we all attain to [reach the inheritance corresponding to] the unity of the faith, and
to the knowledge of the Son of God, to a mature man.” The word for mature (teleios) is again a word that brings to
mind the previous discussion about the Pauline distinction between the inheritance of mature sons versus immature
children.* More importantly, Paul’s usage of attain to (katantao eis) in Phil 3:11 is reminiscent of his statement in
Acts 26:7, within an interesting context.
          6
           And now I am standing trial for the hope of the promise made by God to our fathers; 7 for [eis] the
          promise which our twelve tribes hope to inherit [katantao], as they earnestly serve God night and
          day. And for this hope, O King, I am being accused by Jews. 8 Why is it considered incredible among
          you people if God does raise the dead? (Acts 26:6-8; TM)

What Paul hopes to attain is a hope related to the inheritance. He hopes to inherit the promise. Paul goes on to say
in Phil 3:12 that the reason Christ converted (won) him was so that he could win others, not merely to faith but to
the inheritance.
          16
            For this purpose I have appeared to you, to appoint you a minister and a witness…18 to open their
          eyes so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the dominion of Satan to God, in order
          that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who have been sanctified
          by faith in Me. (Acts 26:16-18).

The expression attain to (katantao eis) in Phil 3:11 (which BDAG noted is a technical term for inheritance) is
associated conceptually with Acts 26:7 and associated contextually with inheritance in 26:18. This expression is
also used in connection with resurrection. Furthermore, katantao is used in conjunction with eis as a hope in
Acts 26:7. In Phil 3:11 it is also a hope, but the NAS does not bring this fact out as clearly as other translations.
       The expression in order that (ei pos) in verse 11 typically is translated as if by any means, if somehow, or if
possible. It is found in four passages in the NT (Acts 27:12; Rom 1:10; 11:14; Phil 3:11). Commentators are
divided on the best way to understand it. Does it express doubt, humility, or expectation? Hope combines all these
elements into one. Further, ei pos is connected with katantao eis in Phil 3:11, which in turn is strongly identified
with hope in Acts 26:6-7. The expression (ei pos) combines uncertainty with expectation and could thus be well
rendered as in hope. Thus Paul is saying, “In hope that I may inherit the resurrection from the dead” (Phil 3:11;
TM). He cannot be absolutely certain that he will inherit the resurrection since doing so is conditioned on his
performance. There is room for doubt and genuine humility. At the same time, his performance can give him a

*
    See Sons of God, 77.
Page 96                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
confident expectation of doing well at the JSC and thus achieving this misthological experience. Thus, these
passages describe a misthological hope.
       The verb for lay hold of (katalambano), as already noted, can be translated win in view of the athletic
imagery. However, BDAG (1.a) also states that it means “come into possession of an inheritance.’ Quite possibly,
Paul intends this dual connotation. For this reason, a preferable translation, which brings out both aspects, might be
rendered as follows:
          11
            In hope that I may inherit the out-resurrection out from the dead. 12 Not that I have already won it,
          or have already become perfect, but I press on in order that I may win that for which I also was won
          by Christ Jesus. (Phil 3:11-12; TM)

       The inheritance is won. Paul’s words in Acts 26, as recorded by his traveling companion, Luke, provide a
strong reinforcement for the dual possibility of an inheritance that is won. Another Lukan parallel lends
confirmation that this is indeed the case. The closest verbal parallels to this phrase in Phil 3:11 are Lk 20:35 (of
believers) and Acts 4:2 (of Christ). Of these two, Lk 20:35 is the closest conceptual parallel since it deals with the
resurrection of believers.155
                                     Illustration 42. Parallelism of Lk 20:35 and Phil 3:11

    Lk 20:35               The                                 resurrection                   out from the dead
                           Hn                                   anastasis                       hn ek nekros
    Phil 3:11              The                out              resurrection                   out from the dead
                           Hn                 ek+               anastasis                       hn ek nekros
       These two passages are two of only a handful of passages in the NT that teach a misthological resurrection
and are thus very strong conceptual parallels.156 They also have each other as their closest verbal parallels in the
NT. And they were written by two very good friends. The examination of Luke’s passage already undertaken led to
the conclusion that the sons of the kingdom who are considered worthy of achieving the resurrection are those
believers who inherit it.* Certainly, there are sufficient grounds for concluding that the same is true here in Paul’s
writings as well.
         Lenski cautions against drawing “fanciful” interpretations “on the basis of evk” and assumes that Paul “uses
the double compound from the dead because this is not identical with Christ’s resurrection.”157 Granted, building
too much on the double repetition of ek would be ill-advised. Nevertheless, the preceding discussion has not been
based on a mere assumption concerning this repetition, nor, for that matter, is it dependent on taking the
preposition ek as a prefix denoting a misthological resurrection. On the contrary, the other three passages
concerning the misthological resurrection do not contain this prefix, and yet they must be understood
misthologically from the context. The ek prefix supports the misthological conclusion, but the misthological
position is not dependent on the prefix for its conclusion. Likewise, the context determines the meaning of the
compound usage of ek in this passage.
       Discussion of this dual compound has been delayed until now to demonstrate that the misthological
understanding of the passage is not based on the compound. Rather, the reverse is true. The misthological
understanding of the compound is based on a proper understanding of the passage. A fanciful interpretation that
simply takes the prepositions as presuppositions would be highly questionable. At the same time, simplistically
ignoring the prepositions is just as excessive in the opposite direction. Lenski’s explanation for the prepositions is
hardly convincing in light of the context. The prepositions help to convey Paul’s thought in this passage.
       Kent accurately points out that a spiritual or moral resurrection is highly unlikely due to the double use of
the compound.

          There is little NT warrant for such a use of anastasis or its cognate (the only time in the NT that
          anastasis does not refer to physical resurrection is in Luke 2:34, a highly figurative passage). The
          majority view regards the word as denoting physical resurrection, however, on the basis of its
          cognate, and from the sense of “from the dead,” which follows.158

*
    See The Out-Resurrection in Lk 20:34-36, 72.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                  Page 97


       The word Paul uses in Phil 3:11 for resurrection, exanastasis, is a compound of ek+anastasis. This
compound is a cognate of anastasis and should likewise be understood as referring to a physical resurrection.
Further support for this conclusion is found in the fact that this preposition is repeated immediately in the phrase
from the dead. As was stated previously, there are no exceptions to anastasis meaning physical resurrection when
used in reference to the dead. Thus, this double compound links the concepts together in such a way as to provide
two reasons for interpreting this as a reference to a physical resurrection. Even so, Kent’s observations do not stop
here: “Usage of the preposition ek (‘out of’) twice in the expression strongly suggests a partial resurrection “out
from” other dead ones. Hence Paul must be thinking not in terms of a general resurrection of righteous and wicked,
but of believers only (cf. Rev 20:4-15).”159
       Muller makes a similar point. Paul is referring to a resurrection from the dead (ek nekron), not of the dead
(ton nekron). Had Paul simply meant the general resurrection of the dead he could have easily have said so.
Instead, he chose to use the preposition ek to say from the dead, which as Muller surmises “always denotes,
wherever it is used, the resurrection of the righteous, the resurrection to life and glory, which will not be the case
with all the dead.” “Paul does not refer to the general resurrection of all the dead but definitely to the resurrection
in glory in which only believers will share.”160 Stated differently, of the forty-four times ek nekron is used in the
NT, it never refers to a general resurrection of the dead. This combination is used frequently of an individual being
raised from the dead. The phrase is never used of the lost.
       There is nothing fanciful about Kent or Muller’s interpretation. The preposition ek in out from the dead
refers to the physical resurrection of believers. Context and cross-references also collaborate that the double
compound expression, out-resurrection out from the dead, refers to a special misthological experience of a
subgroup of faithful believers, otherwise known as overcomers.

   Illustration 43. Out-Resurrection
      of Some Believers                             It is like having a large box of raisins and reaching into it with a
                                                   spoon and only taking out some of the raisins from the box. You do
                                                   not empty the whole contents of the box on your bowl of cereal.161
                                                   Paul is speaking of a spoonful of believers from the box of
                                                   resurrected believers so to speak. The resurrection of all believers is
                                                   the box of raisins from which the relative spoonful of victorious
                                                   overcomers will be taken via the out-resurrection. The plumpest,
                                                   juiciest raisins are selected out of the box.
                                                           Having laid the foundation for this elementary understanding,
                                                   now is the appropriate time for what might be considered by some
                                                   to be a fanciful exegesis concerning ek, but in reality it is nothing
                                                   more than a historical-grammatical conclusion. The question is,
                                                   “Does Paul intend for his readers to understand the entire double
                                                   compound (out-resurrection out from the dead) as referring only to
                                                   overcomers, as I have assumed thus far?” (See Option A below.) Or
                                                   does he intend for the first use of ek to refer to overcomers and the
                                                   second reference to ek to refer to subcomers? (See Option B below.)
                                                   Dillow, Chitwood, and Whipple apparently take the first option, but
                                                   it is difficult to be certain due to the brief nature of their
                                                   discussion.162 In support of Option A, it could be pointed out that the
                                                   entire phrase is misthological in its Lukan parallel. On the other
                                                   hand, Luke (20:35) does use the word worthy to help clarify that
                                                   what is being referred to is a second misthological subgroup of
                                                   believers. Paul may be using the double ek in much the same way.
                                                   Neighbour takes Option B, and it appears that Dodson also accepts
                                                   Neighbour’s position.163
Page 98                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
                                   Illustration 44. Two Options for Out-Resurrection
                              Option A.                                           Option B.




        Commentators such as Kent and Muller concur that the expression out from the dead refers to all believers
and only believers; thus, it is used to refer to a subgroup, that is, to the believing dead as a subgroup of all the dead.
Accordingly, since Paul is using this second ek to refer to a subgroup, it is not too far-fetched to suppose that he
intends to use the first ek in the same fashion, and thus to refer to a subgroup rather than to the same group. If the
first ek is used in the same manner as the second one, then it could not possibly refer to the same group. It would
have to refer to a subgroup of that group, or more specifically, to a subgroup of that subgroup (pictured in Option
B). Thus, if ek were pictured as the functional equivalent of the mathematical subgroup symbol, it would be:

                          out-resurrection ⊂ resurrection of believers ⊂ resurrection of dead

       Paul uses ek to perform the same function (i.e., to denote a subgroup) rather than to refer to the same group.
To conclude that ek in out from the dead refers to all believers (as opposed to a general resurrection of all people)
is contextually reasonable. In the same fashion, the ek in out-resurrection refers to a subgroup of those believers.
Paul runs to win in hope of inheriting the misthological out-resurrection out from the group of believers who
simply experience the physical resurrection. This second option (i.e., Option B) is preferable because Paul teaches
elsewhere that all believers have been, are, and will be raised with Christ. As shown above, all believers have been
raised positionally, all believers are raised ontologically, and all believers will be raised eschatologically.*
       This same phrase is implemented by Paul in 1Cor 15:20 to say that Christ has been raised from the dead (ek
nekron) as the firstfruit of all believers. Christ being raised from the dead results in the resurrection (anastasis) of
all believers when Christ returns (1Cor 15:20-23). A partial rapture is ruled out, and the expression out from the
dead is applied explicitly to all believers in Christ—to them and them alone. Faust misconstrues the passage by
seeking to limit the resurrection in 1Cor 15:23 to worthy Christians rather than all believers. He posits the
resurrection of unworthy believers a thousand years later in 1Cor 15:24.164
       As a dispensationalist, I certainly will agree with Faust that a thousand year gap occurs between the
resurrections in this passage. Also, I could agree with him (as well as with amillennialists, such as Strimple, and
dispensationalists, such as Constable) that this is a relative all in 1Cor 15:22. Consequently, one could adopt
Strimple’s position: “There is no reference to a general resurrection in verse 22.”165 One could further extend this
observation, in agreement with both amillennialists and some dispensationalists, to note that the context is dealing
with the resurrection of all believers, and only believers. Accordingly, WBC remarks, “This chapter contemplates
the resurrection of believers only.”
       However, Faust’s limitation of those who belong to Christ (TM) in 1Cor 15:23 to mean only worthy
believers is exceptionally difficult to give any credibility without any contextual conditionality. The only other
time this phrase hoi tou Christou occurs is in Gal 5:24, where Paul says, “Now those who belong to Christ Jesus
have crucified the flesh with its passions and desires.” All believers belong to Christ and have died positionally

*
    See Phil 3:11, 84.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                           Page 99
with Him. Both Gal 5:24 and 1Cor 15:23 would seem to affirm our positional belonging to Christ regardless of our
experience, which is the reverse of what Faust’s position requires. One might restrict the passage to a description of
the resurrection of believers only, but restricting it to describe the resurrection of only worthy believers would not
be a valid option.
        Two competing dispensational views of the passage are left. It either refers to the resurrection of everyone in
1Cor 15:22, with subsequent, sequential delineation as to when everyone will be raised: believers (i.e., those who
belong to Christ) in 1Cor 15:23 and unbelievers later in 1Cor 15:24 (i.e., at the end of the millennium). Or the
passage is referring exclusively to the resurrection of believers (in agreement with amillennialists), in which case it
is silent about the resurrection of the lost. Regardless, contrary to Faust, since all Christians belong to Christ, they
all will be raised with Christ before the kingdom (which they contingently are to inherit) commences.
        Whether this kingdom is the millennial kingdom or the eternal kingdom is a matter of dispute between
amillennialists and dispensationalists. In any event, if the misthological inheritance of the millennial kingdom on
earth is an eternal reward and is the introduction to the eternal kingdom on the New Earth (as is proposed herein),
then there is really little reason to think that Paul necessarily had to make a sharp distinction between the two time
frames of this earthly kingdom in this summary passage.
             21
                 For since by man came death, by Man also came the resurrection of the dead. 22 For as in
        Adam all die, even so in Christ all will be made alive. 23 But each one in his own order: {Christ the
        firstfruits, | afterward (epeita) those who belong to Christ at His coming (Parousia). 24 } Next (eita)
        comes the end (telos), when (otan) He [the Son] delivers the kingdom to God the Father, when
        (otan) He [the Son] ends all rule and all authority and power. 25 For He [the Son] must reign until He
        has put all enemies under His feet. 26The last enemy that will be destroyed is death….28 Now when
        (otan) all things are subjected to Him, then (tote) the Son Himself will also be subject to Him [the
        Father] who put all things under Him, that God may be all in all….
              50
                 Now this I say, brethren, that flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God; nor does
        perishable inherit the imperishable. 51 Behold, I tell you a mystery: We will not all sleep, but we will
        all be changed—52 in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet will
        sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and we will be changed. 53 For this perishable
        must put on the imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality. 54So when (otan) this
        perishable has put on the imperishable, and this mortal has put on immortality, then (tote) the saying
        will come to pass that is written: “Death is swallowed up in victory.” (1Cor 15:21-26,50-54; TM)

        Blaising argues for the alternate dispensational view: “The end must be the resurrection of unbelievers since
at the ‘end’ death is completely abolished”; otherwise, “the resurrection of unbelievers [is] unaccounted for.”166 He
cites an article by Wallis in support.167 To summarize the arguments Wallis employs (in relation to the translation
and chart above), the combination of afterward (epeita)… next (eita) is used earlier in the context to denote a
sequence of events (e.g., 1Cor 15:7). Then end (telos) sequentially subsumes the events described by when (otan)
and then (tote). Since death must be subjected to the Son (as part of His kingdom reign) in the end (telos), before
that kingdom reign is delivered over to the Father, the sequence must be that the Parousia precedes and is not a
part of the end (telos). This sequence of the resurrection of believers first is necessitated by Paul’s teaching that
believers must be judged at the Bema (2Cor 5:10) after the Parousia (before they can inherit the kingdom).
        The turning over of the kingdom rule to the Father necessarily presupposes that the rule will be exercised by
the Son before being handed over to the Father. This presents two options: (1) the kingdom rule that Paul has in
mind either began at Christ’s ascension to the Father’s throne, and is thus currently being exercised by the Son (so
amillennialism), or (2) this kingdom rule is yet future and will commence at the Parousia when the Son returns to
sit on an earthly throne (so premillennialism).
        Wallis’ preference for the second option is due, in part, to the correlation between the Pauline emphasis that
all things must be placed beneath Christ’s feet in this kingdom rule and due, in other part, to the clarification that
the realization in placing them beneath Christ’s feet pertains to the world to come (Heb 2:5) and has not yet taken
place (Heb 2:8). So the fact that God already has placed all things under Christ’s feet in Eph 1:22 does not mean
that it has yet come to pass in the fullness of its earthly realization.
        I might insert parenthetically, in this summation of Wallis’ argumentation, that the distinction between
Christ’s throne and the Father’s throne in Rev 3:21 might also be seen as corroborative evidence that the rulership
that believers share with Christ must await the future millennial rule when Christ is seated on His own throne;
whereas, now He is seated on the Father’s throne. According to Paul, Christ must assume His own throne so that
He can submit that throne to the Father. In other words, the fact that Christ is now currently seated on the Father’s
throne (Eph 1:22) and must have a kingdom that He can turn over to the Father in the future presupposes, in
Pauline thought, that there must be a future transitional kingdom in which the Son will sit on His own throne.
        For such reasons as these, the present work agrees with the dispensational argument by Wallis that the
passage relates sequential resurrections and a future, transitional Messianic kingdom. Why did Paul not specify that
it would last one thousand years? Besides not being germane to his purpose, perhaps one reason Paul did not focus
on the length of the intermission was because he did not know how long the intermission would be. At the time
Paul was writing, the length of either intermission was unknown. It may be that the length of the second
intermission was not known until about forty years later, when the Lord supplied that information to John.
Accordingly, I have filled in the length of that intermission on the chart. As to the first intermission, we will
continue to mark it off on our calendars as we wait for our Lord to return. The intermission of approximately two
thousand years after epeita should causes one to view the amillennialist claim (that there cannot be a one thousand
year transition after eita) with considerable suspicion.
        That said, I am still content to mark Wallis’ assertion of an explicit affirmation of the resurrection of
unbelievers in this passage as questionable. Granted, the emphasis that Paul places on all rule and authority being
put under the Son’s feet harkens back to Ps 8:6 and 110:1. According to Wallis, this means that all who died in
Adam will be made alive in Christ via the resurrection (1Cor 15:22), so this verse is an affirmation of the general
resurrection. After all, Rev 20:5 affirms the resurrection of unbelievers. Nevertheless, it is at this point that Wallis’
argument fails to be entirely persuasive as currently articulated. While his position that a general resurrection is
being explicitly affirmed is plausible, it is difficult to regard it as probable since Wallis does not explain how being
resurrected in Christ does not require one to be soteriologically in (en) Christ. Perhaps if Wallis had augmented his
argument with a discussion of the texts which talk about all things being summed up in Christ (Eph 1:10), or all
things being created in/by (en) Christ (Col 1:16), or all things holding together in Christ (Col 1:17), then this aspect
of his line of reasoning might have been more persuasive. As it is, I simply note the possibility of the argument
made by some dispensationalists such, as Wallis, that Paul is affirming the general resurrection in 1Cor 15:21-22
with an unspecified interval in-between in the following verses. Notwithstanding my hesitancy to embrace this
option fully, the fact that Paul does affirm the resurrection of both the righteous and unrighteous in Acts 24:15 does
lead to an admission that at least an implicit affirmation of the resurrection of unbelievers in the subjection of death
to Christ is certainly within the realms of reasonable possibility.
        Regardless, assuming that Paul is consistent with his usage of those who belong to Christ (hoi tou Christou)
as referring to all believers, which is my position regardless of which dispensational route is taken, then the phrase
from the dead (ek nekros) refers to the unconditional and unmerited resurrection of all believers. Additionally, the
word Paul uses for the resurrection of all believers is anastasis. Thus, anastasis ek nekros would refer to the
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                              Page 101
resurrection of all believers, which is what one would expect from a context dealing with the unconditional
resurrection of believers. Still, in contrast to the Corinthian passage, in the context of Phil 3:11, which deals with a
conditional resurrection, Paul adds an additional ek (denoting an additional subgroup) so that ek+anastasis ek
nekros would refer to a subgroup of believers who experience a misthological resurrection.
                              Illustration 46. Parallelism of 1Cor 15:20-21 and Phil 3:11
  1Cor 15:20-21                       (resurrection          out from the dead)                = all believers
                                        anastasis                 ek nekros
     Phil 3:11            out         (resurrection          out from the dead)               = some believers
                          ek+           anastasis                 ek nekros

      There are actually three possible ways to represent the misthological understanding of Phil 3:11. Option A
below is supported by the parallel in Lk 20:35. Either of the B-Options below are more favorable in view of the
double prepositions. Option B1 might be the best way to represent Phil 3:11 in correlation to parallel texts, which
simply have the phrase out from the dead in common. Option B2 would be best to show its relationship to
1Cor 15:20-21. Each of the expressions are valid and useful depending on which comparison is being made, and
each option is virtually synonymous.
                                 Illustration 47. Three Options for Out-Resurrection
Option A            Out       resurrection out from the dead                                = some believers
Option B1           Out      resurrection (out from the dead)                               = some believers
Option B2           Out     (resurrection out from the dead)                                = some believers




       The out-resurrection is the inheritance to be won. (1) Those believers who win (i.e., who overcome) will
participate in the out-resurrection from the dead and rule with Christ in His kingdom. (2) Those believers who fail
to win (i.e., who subcome) will participate in the resurrection from the dead and live with Christ in His kingdom
and be saved soteriologically from the second death. (3) Those unbelievers who refuse to believe in Christ will
experience the resurrection of the dead and the punishment of the second death.
Page 102                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
Phil 3:15
      15
         Let us therefore, as many as are perfect, have this attitude; and if in anything you have a different
      attitude, God will reveal that also to you.

       Paul uses another play on words, as he has been doing throughout the passage. This time it is with the word
perfect (teleios)—the adjective form of the verb become perfect (teleioo) in Phil 3:12. As was pointed out
concerning that verse, Paul is not dealing with sinless perfection. He is using the imagery of reaching a goal. Both
an intermediate goal and an ultimate goal are in view. Paul already has reached his intermediate goal. He already
has become mature. Paul makes it clear that he expects his Christian converts to progress from being carnal to
spiritual maturity within a reasonably short period of time (1Cor 3:1-3). Paul had made this progression himself
(1Cor 2:15-16). Within a reasonable amount of time, every believer should reach maturity as well (Heb 5:12). The
failure on the part of many believers to reach maturity does not necessarily mean that it is impossible for them to
reach it.
       The doctrine of the victorious Christian life takes as its premise that it is possible to experience victory now,
and thus to be a winner in the present. Indeed, given time to mature, this is a reasonable expectation. Paul urges his
fellow believers who have matured to the point of experiencing this present victory to press on for the ultimate
victory. Temporal victory should whet our appetite for ultimate victory. Victory over the power of sin in our lives
now should cause us to long for our eschatological salvation from the presence of sin in our lives and to see it
stamped out completely in the future. The victory of living for the Lord should inspire us to want to rule with the
Lord. A life of victory should cause us to long for the crown of victory.
       The eschatological dimension to which Paul focuses our attention is the reward of the up-calling and the
receiving of the victor’s crown. To claim to be interested in the victorious Christian life and yet not be interested in
the victor’s crown would seem almost to be a fraudulent claim compared to Paul’s passion. In any case, it would
certainly be a refusal to have the attitude that Paul exhorts us to have toward the crown in this passage. One may
well wonder, if we do not share Paul’s attitude toward the victory in the future, can we really share his experience
of victory in the present? Can we actually reject his attitude and yet realistically expect to share his victory either
temporally or eschatologically? If not, then perhaps one reason there is so little victory today is because there is
such shallow perception of its true significance in the future.
       We should share Paul’s exuberance for the thrill of victory and not underestimate the agony of defeat. Not
all believers will share in the out-resurrection. Some believers will be completely left out of that experience.
Although they will be in the kingdom, they will be excluded from the privileges that come from running the race
well. How does the Scripture describe the fate of those believers who are left out? As will become increasingly
clear, believers basically have two misthological options: the out-resurrection or the outer darkness. The two
teachings not only complement each other; the one logically demands the other. If only some believers are inside,
then other believers must be outside. If only some are winners, then others must be losers. But it stands to reason
that there would be fewer losers if they were shown how thrilling the victory may be and how agonizing the defeat
will be as well.

                                     The Out-Resurrection in Jn 5:29
       Having now dealt with three of the primary passages pertaining to the related topic in Rev 20:6 (concerning
what it means to have a portion in the resurrection), consideration will now be given to a secondary passage. Since
the passage being examined in Revelation is a Johannine passage, one is not surprised to find the same truth in
John’s gospel. This secondary passage, Jn 5:28, is one of the few places in his gospel where John expresses his
eschatology.
       28
         Do not marvel at this; for an hour is coming, in which all who are in the tombs shall hear His voice,
       29
         and shall come forth; those who did the good deeds to a resurrection of life, those who
       committed the evil deeds to a resurrection of judgment. (Jn 5:28-29)

      There are at least five possible interpretations of what John means when he records that those who do good
works will experience the resurrection of life.

(1) Ethical View.
      Arminians and Calvinists tend to agree in their mutual perspective that good Christians go to heaven and
bad Christians go to hell. The believer’s ethical performance determines his or her soteriological destiny. Although
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                             Page 103
this popular theology is dressed in scholastic garb, it is still soteriological garbage. Both theological groups will
claim to believe in salvation by grace apart from works, yet even a casual reading of what they say will reveal that
they do not believe what they say. Contemporary Arminians by-and-large say that how good you are determines
whether you lose the gift of eternal life. Thus, what really determines whether you have eternal life at the time of
the resurrection is the quality of life you live in the present. Calvinists seemingly think that all genuine believers
are relatively good compared to false believers; works determine whether you are genuinely saved. The life you
live now will determine whether you have life then. Ultimately for both groups, your participation in the
resurrection of life, and thus having eternal life, is dependent on the good works you do. Zeller adopts this
interpretation and thus rejects the FG position:

       Hodges’ teaching that a saved person may be characterized as an evil doer is refuted by John 5:29
       which clearly teaches that those who do evil will participate in the resurrection of damnation (the
       second resurrection which is exclusively for the unsaved). This verse mentions only two groups of
       people: 1) those who do good and who have life; 2) those who do evil and who are damned. Hodges
       and Dillow require a third group of those who do evil and are saved, but this verse does not mention
       such.168

        Zeller’s argument is inherently weak since it is based on an argument from silence. In essence he is saying
that since this passage does not mention three possibilities, three possibilities cannot exist. However, the passage
itself does not explicitly deny the possibility of a third group. As a matter of fact, Zeller’s argument is the same
type of argument used by amillennialists. They posit that, since no mention is made of a millennium between the
two resurrections, no millennium exists between the two resurrections. Premillennialists respond that these two
resurrections are telescoped together. Just because the intervening millennium is not mentioned does not prove that
it does not exist. In view of progressive revelation, the amillennial argument from silence is considered very weak
by premillennialists. I appreciate the fact that Zeller has produced some commendable articles on his web site in
defense of premillennialism. In fact, the statement of faith for his church affirms premillennial understanding of
eschatology.169 Yet I wonder if Zeller has fully thought through the fact that his eschatological affirmation refutes
his soteriological objection.
        Zeller would have us believe that any passage dealing with a contrast must include all intervening
possibilities or such intervening possibilities do not exist. Such an approach would severely limit the concept of
contrast. The questionability of such a methodology should be self-evident to a premillennialist. Zeller does not
implement this same approach when affirming premillennialism. His soteriological argument from silence is even
far less persuasive than the amillennial argument from silence in that multiple texts affirm the existence of
unfaithful believers and only one primary text explicitly affirms premillennialism. The fact that Jn 5:28-29 does not
mention the one thousand year gap between the resurrections does not nullify the fact that such a gap may exist.
Likewise, the absence of any reference to a third group of people does not mean that such a group cannot exist. The
following four interpretations are superior alternatives to this soteriological salvation-based-on-works posed by
Arminians, Calvinists, and shortsighted premillennialists. Contrary to what Zeller imagines, neither ethical
performance nor theological perseverance determines salvation from eternal damnation.

(2) Misthological View
        According to Faust, Jn 5:28-29 is describing a misthological resurrection of believers. The resurrection of
the lost is not in view. Of course, this would at least be eschatologically possible in that it could be describing the
resurrection that occurs at the rapture. There would be no need to mention a millennial gap between the two
resurrections because it is a singular resurrection of two groups before the millennium. A pretribulational
resurrection naturally would be limited to believers. If this is correct, then those believers who have lived
righteously experience a resurrection of life, which makes it impossible for them to die again (Lk 20:36).
Conversely, those believers who have committed the evil deeds experience a resurrection of judgment. This
approach makes it possible for Faust to maintain that believers who do not serve the Lord are literally slain, that is,
cut in two (dichotomeo) at the Bema (Mt 24:51; Lk 12:46). This ultraistic understanding of dichotomeo is likewise
within the lexical realm of possibility.
        Contextual considerations, however, make this interpretation very difficult to accept. First, the text is
referring to all who are in the tombs. The burden of proof is on Faust if he wishes to make this a relative all so as
to interpret the text to mean only all believers who are in the tomb. To be sure, it will be demonstrated
Page 104                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
                                                                                                           *
subsequently that Dan 12:2 does indeed describe a premillennial, misthological resurrection. So I do not object to
Faust’s misthological view of the resurrection on a theological basis. Some passages do indeed teach a
misthological resurrection, such as those dealing with the out-resurrection. My objection is more of an exegetical
nature. The Danielic text, for example, says, “Many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth shall awake.” This
is in stark contrast to Jn 5:28-29, which says, “All who are in the tombs…will come forth.” All is more than many.
The contrast between these two texts is even more apparent when one considers that Dan 12:2 is the first OT
mention of eternal life and the twofold resurrection, which are the same themes picked up in this Johannine
passage.
        Second, Jesus had just said, “Truly, truly, I say to you, he who hears My word, and believes Him who sent
Me, has eternal life, and does not come into judgment, but has passed out of death into life” (Jn 5:24). Having
just promised all believers that they would not come into judgment, Jesus proceeds to describe a resurrection of
judgment for those who commit evil deeds. The word for judgment in both verses is krisis. So how can those who
are promised that they will not come into judgment (because they are believers) be resurrected to judgment
(because of their works)? Faust’s position runs aground on the shores of the context. Believers are excluded from
the judgment of Jn 5:29. Furthermore, the promise of life in Jn 5:24 to all believers would seem to assure a
resurrection of life in Jn 5:29. Nevertheless, the present writer is in sympathy with Faust’s misthological view of
the resurrection, albeit it will be necessary to affirm different misthological ramifications below.

(3) Metaphorical View
       If all believers cannot be described as ethically do-gooders, and only those who do good experience the
resurrection of life, then how can it be maintained that those who do good refer to all believers? According to the
metaphorical view, doing good simply refers to believing in Jesus. The passage is using doing good metaphorically
rather than literally or ethically. Anyone who has seriously considered the frequency and variety of the Johannine
metaphors for believe in the Gospel of John (GJ) should be attracted to the plausibility of this interpretation. The
present author’s metaphorical analysis of the GJ turns up numerous times that a word or expression is used
metaphorically for believe within GJ.† Wilkin proposes a metaphorical understanding of doing good in this
particular verse: “The reference to doing good alludes to believing in Jesus and that the reference to doing evil
concerns rejecting Him. This fits the immediate context (cf. 5:24, 39-47). It also harmonizes well with 3:36 and
6:29.”170
       This interpretation is exceedingly attractive. Both of the metaphors in 5:29 (do good/evil) stand or fall
together as metaphors for believe or disbelieve. To his credit, Wilkin is consistent in taking both expressions as
metaphors for believe or disbelieve. However, the only other time this phrase (do evil) occurs in GJ is in 3:20, and
in that text it is not a metaphor for disbelieve. Granted, this does not mean that it could not be a metaphor for
disbelieve in 5:29. Likewise, the fact that doing good is understood literally rather than metaphorically in other
passages (i.e., Jn 6:28; 8:39,41) is not a conclusive counterargument against Wilkin’s position. On the other hand,
the fact that doing good in these other passages is plural rather than singular initially appears detrimental to
Wilkin’s harmonization. Good is plural in 5:29, referring to good things, which the NAS assumes means good
works. Even so, if the nonmeritorious nature of 6:29 is indicated by its singularity, then the meritorious nature of
5:29 is evidenced by its plurality.‡ Nevertheless, if Wilkin’s proposal were adopted, it would be in agreement with
my punctiliar findings concerning the soteriological nature of the metaphors for believe within GJ. Still, due to the
reasons stated herein, and my preference for the fifth interpretation to follow, Wilkin’s position (despite its
consistency with my Johannine metaphorical analysis) has been ranked with a soft negation in the present work
when the fuller NT context is taken into consideration.§

(4) Positional View.
        The next FG view correctly observes that all believers are absolutely and completely good positionally.
Hodges argues that the context (specifically Jn 5:24) shows that all believers have passed from the sphere of
soteriological judgment into soteriological life. Certainly, for a person not to come into judgment, that person must

*
  See Daniel 12:1-3, 533.
†
  See Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis of the Gospel of John. Also see John in Living Color.
‡
  This objection to Wilkin’s proposal is not insurmountable if the plurality only denotes a distributive aspect, which is a strong
possibility. In fact, when interpreting this expression within the limited scope of GJ, I prefer Wilkin’s metaphorical interpretation
over the one I adopt in the present book. See John in Living Color.
§
  See Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis of the Gospel of John.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                         Page 105
be sinless. A believer is absolutely sinless soteriologically. In fact, Hodges could have bolstered his argument by
appealing to 1Jn 3:6-9, where John teaches that all believers are ontologically, positionally, and experientially
sinless.* Any sin in a believer’s experience is outside of his experience in Christ. Instead, Hodges appeals to
Rev 20:4-6, since it is a clear parallel.

             As the text [Jn 5:29] makes clear, there are two resurrections: one to life, the other to judgment.
       Scripture is quite innocent of the concept of one general resurrection and judgment designed to
       distinguish the saved from the lost. For the Apostle John, in particular, no such idea is at all pertinent
       since in Revelation 20 he sharply distinguishes the first and second resurrections and separates them
       by an interval of one thousand years (Rev. 20:5-6). Further, the passages in Revelation related to the
       two resurrections differentiate them in character in precisely the same way as they are differentiated
       in John 5:29. On the one hand, no judgment at all is mentioned in connection with the first
       resurrection but rather the idea of living and reigning with Christ (Rev. 24:4-6). By contrast, the
       second resurrection describes nothing but judgment and its tragic outcome (Rev. 20:11-15).171
       (Emphasis his.)

       The resurrection will be universal; it will include both the saved and the lost. It will also be sequential—the
saved then the lost (also see Acts 24:15). Moreover, it will also be chronological, occurring in two stages (as John
indicates in both Jn 5:28-29 and Rev 20:4-6) with a period of time in-between the two stages. Hodges has well
stated the standard premillennial connection between these two passages. The passage in Jn 5:28-29 is basically
Rev 20:4-15 in a super-condensed version. It is Rev 20:4-15 in a nutshell. Hodges is correct in that both passages
should be interpreted in a similar fashion within this broader NT context.
       On the other hand, the believers being described in Rev 20:4-6 are not only holy positionally, they are also
holy experientially.† The reason they will sit on thrones is not because they merely believed in Jesus, but because
they lived and died for Jesus.‡ Thus, the metaphorical and positional interpretations, although compatible with
Johannine theology, are incompatible with this parallel. These believers are ethically righteous and for this reason
have this type of resurrection in Revelation—a misthological resurrection. Notwithstanding, this admission in no
way indicates agreement with the ethical interpretation or with the partial rapture. Those interpretations are
impossible for other reasons. In summary, three of the four interpretations considered thus far are viable as FG
soteriological alternatives to the ethical LS interpretation that was rejected as soteriologically defective. However,
the FG interpretation to be considered next is superior to these three FG interpretations.

(5) Antithetical view.
        The point of the passage is to contrast opposites. Jesus is making a generalization to contrast the nature,
actions, and destiny of two groups in Jn 5:28-29 that are polar opposites. The antithetical intent is to contrast the
nature and actions of those whose actions manifest their true nature. That there are those within both groups who
mask their true nature is not dealt with in this passage. The affirmation of two poles is not necessarily a denial that
a range occurs between those poles. Just as the mention of two resurrections, without affirmation of a thousand-
year interlude, does not prove that such an interlude does not exist, so the mention of two ethical poles does not
prove the absence of an intermediate range.
       The Matthean passage about the sheep and goats in Mt 25:31-46 is a strong parallel and has been well
interpreted by Dillow.172 The passage is not talking about believers and nonbelievers in mere positional terms.
Their deeds are also taken into consideration. There are neither bad sheep nor good goats in the passage. Even so,
the lack of bad sheep and good goats is not due to their being described positionally. Rather, it is due (in part§) to
the fact that Jesus is contrasting the extremes, but this contrast does not mean that there is no middle ground.

         •    Sheep (= all believers) have eternal life and do not come into judgment (Jn 5:24).
         •    White sheep (= good believers) inherit the kingdom and enter eternal life (= resurrection of life).
         •    Gray goats (= unbelievers) depart into eternal fire and punishment (= resurrection of judgment).

*
  See Appendix 4. Johannine Anamartetology, 769.
†
  See Holy, 47.
‡
  See Millennial Thrones, 49.
§
  As explained in Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep, the purpose of the parable is to portray congruent merit and demerit. Therefore,
the absence of gray sheep or white goats from the parable is to be expected. Their absence in no way proves their nonexistence.
Page 106                                                                                           The Outer Darkness


       What about gray sheep? They are not addressed by this Johannine passage nor by the Matthean parable. Nor
need they be. Their existence is allowed for by the Johannine passage and affirmed by the broader Johannine
context. Likewise, the preceding Matthean Olivet parables deal with gray sheep. Some passages contrast spiritual
believers with carnal believers. Some of these passages do not even mention unbelievers, but that does not mean
that unbelievers do not exist. Likewise, some passages contrast spiritual believers and unbelievers. Carnal believers
are not mentioned in these passages, but that does not mean that carnal believers do not exist. The purpose of a
parable may be to contrast rather than to compare. Thus, when Jesus contrasts good sheep with gray goats, this
contrast, in and of itself, does not disprove that similarities between the sheep and goats might come into
consideration if the purpose of the parable were to deal with such similarities.
                               Illustration 48. Antithetical Contrast of Polar Opposites

             CONTRAST                              Lost                    Carnal                  Spiritual
 Mt 13:24-50                                                                                         
 Mt 18:8-9                                                                                           
 Mt 25:31-46                                                                                         

 1Jn 3:10                                                                                            
 Rev 21:7-8,27                                                                                       
 Rev 22:14-15                                                                                        

        Jesus is simply contrasting the nature, actions, and destiny of believers and unbelievers without going into
detail and without explaining that some believers act like unbelievers and conversely that some unbelievers act like
believers. For example, when a parent tells his little boy that balls are round, this does not mean that the parent
denies that a football is a ball. Rather, the parent is not going into detail concerning the various possible shapes of
all balls. On some occasions, a summary statement is better suited than a detailed explanation.
        This antithetical interpretation incorporates the strength of the ethical position. Practical righteousness is
required. However, the antithetical interpretation does not include the soteriological weakness of the ethical
position in that the antithetical interpretation does not assume that all believers will meet this ethical requirement
or that this ethical requirement is also a soteriological requirement. It is a misthological requirement that only some
believers will meet. In this regard, the antithetical explanation agrees with the second interpretation. In addition,
the antithetical interpretation presupposes the strengths of the third and fourth positions, just as Jn 5:29
presupposes Jn 5:24. Believers (who do good) will be raised before unbelievers (who do evil) are raised. This is not
to say that all believers are relatively better than all unbelievers in terms of their conduct. Rather, as a result of
simply believing in Jesus, all believers are absolutely perfect in terms of their position and will live with Jesus in
the kingdom. Nevertheless, those believers who actually have done well in terms of their behavior will have
abundant life in the kingdom. To use a colloquialism, they will hear the words well done and be well-off in the
kingdom. Moreover, the fifth interpretation agrees with the fourth interpretation in finding Rev 20:6 to be a parallel
passage.
        When interpreted within the broader NT context, this fifth interpretation is superior in light of the Matthean
and Johannine parallels and builds on the strengths of the other interpretations. Consequently, Jn 5:28-29 may be
regarded as another passage teaching a misthological resurrection in which faithful believers will experience the
out-resurrection. Those believers who do good works will experience life in a misthological dimension at the time
of their resurrection because of their good works. According to the NT, eternal life can either be a gift or a reward
depending upon what aspect of that life is in view. In this passage, it is a dimension of life that is experienced by
these believers because they have done well. They are rewarded with life. What that means is explained in
Rev 20:6, which, like Jn 5:28-29, has no reference to subcomers. Overcomers really will be able to live it up in
heaven because they will have the crown of life and access to the tree of life. They will experience heavenly life at
its fullest dimension.
        In Rev 21:7-8,27 and Rev 22:14-15 noncomers are contrasted with overcomers without dealing explicitly
with subcomers. It is not necessary for each passage to deal with each group. Similarly, tribulational subcomers are
not dealt with in Rev 20:6. It may be reasonably assumed that just as church-age believers will all be resurrected at
the same time, so tribulational believers will all be resurrected at the same time. All tribulational believers will be
resurrected at the end of the tribulation but not have the same portion in that resurrection that overcomers have.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                                   Page 107
The passage in Rev 20:6 is dealing with the requirements for rulership, not for resurrection. To be sure,
resurrection is one of the requirements for this rulership. Nevertheless it is an amoral requirement since both the
immoral and moral persons will be resurrected. Morality does not determine whether or not believers will be
resurrected or in which resurrection they will participate. The concern of the passage in Rev 20:6 is to contrast the
morality and corresponding portion of overcomers and noncomers, not to compare the portion of overcomers with
that of subcomers. Participation in the resurrection is not the reward; rather, participation in the rulership is the
reward.

                                             The Out-Resurrection in Rev 20:6
          And I saw the souls of those who had been beheaded because of their testimony for Jesus and for the
          word of God, and who had not worshiped the beast or his image, and had not received his mark on
          their forehead or on their hand, and they were resurrected and ruled with Christ throughout the
          millennium.* 5This is the first resurrection. 6Blessed and holy is the one who has a portion in the first
          resurrection; the second death has no power over such ones; but they will be priests of God and of
          Christ and will rule with Him throughout the millennium. (Rev 20:4b-6; TM)

Three Portions in Revelation
       Rev 20:6 is dealing with the portion of rulers, not that of non-rulers. It describes the fate of overcomers, not
subcomers. The portion of the rulers is explicitly equated with rulership in the millennial kingdom, which of course
presupposes a physical, premillennial resurrection. Resurrection is required for rulership. These souls are
resurrected so that they might rule in the kingdom, which is what it means to have a portion in the first
resurrection. Pertaining to the related well-known topic in misthological circles, the salvation of the soul is pictured
in this passage by the souls coming to life in order to rule. Thus, the salvation of one’s soul would be defined
correspondingly as the coming back to life of the faithful believer’s soul to receive a glorified body by which to
experience life to the fullest extent possible as a ruler in the eschatological state. In short, it is resurrection for
rulership.
       That the portion of only one group is mentioned in this passage does not mean that other groups do not exist
or that they do not have a portion assigned to them. The book of Revelation itself teaches that noncomers
(Rev 21:8), subcomers (Rev 22:19), and overcomers (Rev 20:6) will each have different portions (meros). Three
different groups will have three different portions. That only victorious believers are described in Rev 20:4-6 does
not prove that all believers are victorious. Hodges evidently concurs with this understanding of Rev 20:4-6.

                Even in that grand scene which is described in the Book of Revelation, after our Lord has
          triumphantly returned to reign, we still encounter the theme of heirship. For there the rulers of the
          world to come are described as having a “portion” in the first resurrection. But the Greek word for
          “portion” can signify a “share” in an inheritance, or the inheritance itself.…
                It is, in fact, this very word which the Prodigal Son used when he asked for his inheritance
          ahead of time [Lk 15:12]…One should note also the prominence of the Old Testament word for
          “portion,” to signify an inheritance or a possession [Num 18:20]…The words of the Apostle John,
          therefore, are rich with significance when he writes [Rev 20:4]…Here the theme of merit is
          unmistakable. The faithful martyrs of the Great Tribulation are rewarded with a share in Christ’s
          royal power.…The text [Rev 20:6] need not be construed as saying that certain people simply “take
          part in the first resurrection.…
                What we have here is co-heirship with Christ.…there are those who are especially blessed
          because they have “a portion,” “an inheritance”…an immortality which entails priestly and kingly
          duties. (Emphasis his.)173

       Since this statement is from Hodges’ book Grace in Eclipse, which is dedicated to the theme of rewards and
to demonstrating that not all believers will receive these positive rewards, the broader context of Hodges’ statement
indicates that he takes Rev 20:4,6 as not referring to the rulership exercised by all believers. The logical outcome
of his position would be an antithetical interpretation of this passage. The passage does not refer to all believers,
not even to all believers positionally (which is the primary reason the antithetical interpretation of its background
passage was chosen in Jn 5:28-29). John is actually only referring to rewarded believers—overcomers who obtain
*
    “The rest of the dead were not resurrected until after the millennium.” Footnote his, that is, original to the writer of Revelation.
Page 108                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
the reward of the inheritance, referred to by its synonym portion. In the book of Revelation, passages contrasting
two groups of people do not necessarily prove that there are only two groups of people. The existence of the third
group would be understood from the broader context of the book of Revelation itself.
                                                       Illustration 49. Three Portions


                                                       Portion/Meros
                                                        = Inheritance (Lk 15:12)

                OF LOST                                                         OF SAVED
                    Natural                                      Carnal                     Spiritual
                   (nonelect)                               (unfaithful elect)           (faithful elect)
