                    Rev 21:8                                                                Rev 20:6
                                                               Rev 22:19




        Faust is too premature in his conclusion that since all believers do not have a misthological portion in the
first resurrection, they do not have entrance into the millennial kingdom.174 On the other hand, he is correct that the
portion is limited conditionally to believers who have overcome in terms of their practical sanctification. Even so,
the fact that only overcomers have a portion in the first resurrection simply means that they are the ones who will
have rulership during that time period. Taking part in that resurrection should not be equated with having a
misthological portion in the resurrection. Carnal believers will have a part in the resurrection itself but not have a
part in the portion of that resurrection. They will experience the resurrection but miss their portion/rulership within
it. Just as in the OT some of those who entered the Promised Land failed to realize their portion of the inheritance
in of that land, so some believers will have participation but no portion in the resurrection.*

Portion in Acts 8:21 (meris)
        Peter likewise warns a fellow believer, Simon Magus, of this possibility: “You have no part (meris) or
portion (kleros) in this matter, for your heart is not right before God” (Acts 8:21). Both meris and kleros can be
translated as portion. The first word used in this verse to describe this portion is meris, which is the feminine form
of meros found in Rev 20:6. The combination of this feminine word for portion and this same word for inheritance
in Acts 8:21 is found only one other time in the NT: “Giving thanks to the Father, who has qualified us to have a
portion [meris] in the inheritance [kleros] of the saints in light” (Col 1:12; TM). To have a portion is translated as
to be partakers in the KJV and NKJ. All believers are qualified to run the race and to be partakers of the
inheritance. Nonetheless, the fact that all believers are qualified initially for a portion in the inheritance does not
mean that all believers will be qualified ultimately for the realization of a portion (reward) in the inheritance. Only
those believers who finish the course will partake of the reward. Not all believers will be partakers.175 They may
disqualify themselves from partaking in the reward of this inheritance. The only other time Paul uses this verb for
qualify (hikanoo) is in 2Cor 3:6, where he says that God “made us qualified as servants of a new covenant” (TM).
It is used to denote God making believers sufficient and qualified in the sense of empowered for some activity. In
the preceding verse Paul uses the adjectival and nominal forms to express the same thought: “Not that we are
qualified [hikanos] in ourselves to consider anything as coming from ourselves, but our qualification [hikanotes] is
from God” (2Cor 3:5; TM). Or as the BBE translates it, “Our power comes from God.”


*
    See Illustration 271. Achan’s Lack of Rest, 760.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                               Page 109
        Of course, the fact that God has qualified and thus empowered believers to serve does not unconditionally
guarantee that all believers will serve. For example, all believers have the God-given ability to walk in the light
because God has made them children of light, but this does not prove that all believers necessarily will walk in the
light. Paul exhorts believers by saying, “For you were formerly darkness, but now you are light in the Lord; walk
as children of light” (Eph 5:8). As Paul’s exhortation in this verse indicates, not all believers walk in the light;
otherwise, there would have been no need for the exhortation. A promise would have been made instead of an
exhortation if Paul had wished to assure them that they unconditionally would walk in the light. Believers cannot
blame God for their carnality (i.e., for their failure to walk in the light), nor for their resultant failure to obtain a
portion in the inheritance of the kingdom. God has qualified all believers to walk in the light and to run the race,
and He provides the enablement to do so. But it is up to the believer to appropriate God’s sustaining and enabling
grace and put one foot in front of the other in order to walk in the light.
        Unfortunately, some believers not only stop running, they run the other way. Apparently, Acts 8:21 refers to
a believer who did this very thing and lost his portion in the kingdom.
        9
          Now there was a certain man named Simon, who formerly was practicing magic in the city, and
    astonishing the people of Samaria, claiming to be someone great; 10 and they all, from smallest to greatest,
    were giving attention to him, saying, “This man is what is called the Great Power of God.” 11 And they
    were giving him attention because he had for a long time astonished them with his magic arts. 12 But when
    they believed Philip preaching the good news about the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus
    Christ, they were being baptized, men and women alike. 13 And even Simon himself believed; and after
    being baptized, he continued on with Philip; and as he observed signs and great miracles taking place, he
    was constantly amazed. 14 Now when the apostles in Jerusalem heard that Samaria had received the word
    of God, they sent them Peter and John, 15 who came down and prayed for them, that they might receive the
    Holy Spirit. 16 For He had not yet fallen upon any of them; they had simply been baptized in the name of
    the Lord Jesus. 17 Then they began laying their hands on them, and they were receiving the Holy Spirit. 18
    Now when Simon saw that the Spirit was bestowed through the laying on of the apostles’ hands, he
    offered them money, 19 saying, “Give this authority to me as well, so that everyone on whom I lay my
    hands may receive the Holy Spirit.” 20 But Peter said to him,
         May your silver perish with you, because you thought you could obtain the gift of God with
         money! 21You have no part or portion in this matter, for your heart is not right before God.
         22
            Therefore repent of this wickedness of yours, and pray the Lord that if possible, the intention of
         your heart may be forgiven you. 23 For I see that you are in the gall of bitterness and in the
         bondage of iniquity.
        24
           But Simon answered and said, “Pray to the Lord for me yourselves, so that nothing of what you
    have said may come upon me.” 25 And so, when they had solemnly testified and spoken the word of the
    Lord, they started back to Jerusalem, and were preaching the gospel to many villages of the Samaritans.
    (Acts 8:9-25)

       To Gromacki’s credit, he acknowledges that Simon Magus may have indeed expressed saving faith, but
Gromacki unfortunately expresses doubt and asserts that one cannot be dogmatic about the matter, thinking that
one cannot be certain what Simon believed.176 Not all writers are so hesitant to acknowledge the obvious
implication of the text, however. What Simon believed is defined implicitly in the text as the good news of the
gospel.177 Luke does not distinguish Simon’s faith from that of the other Samaritans; instead, he clearly indicates
that Simon also believed in the same sense by believing the same thing.
       Does Peter exhort Simon to believe? No. Simon already had believed. For that matter, Peter’s exhortation
would make no sense if addressed to an unbeliever. The NT does not exhort unbelievers to clean up their act and
get their heart right in hope that maybe God just might decide to forgive them soteriologically. Rather, the NT
offers assurance of soteriological forgiveness to anyone who simply believes, whether it be a Simon Peter or Simon
Magus. To be sure, the same expression, if possible (ei ara), is used in Acts 17:27 in reference to groping for God
in hopes of finding Him. In that passage, contrastively, doubt is expressed about whether people will seek God, not
whether God would forgive those who seek Him. The present passage, on the other hand, uses this term to express
doubt about whether God will forgive Magus, even if he were to grope after God in repentance. This anomaly is
consistent with the fact that believers may commit sins leading to temporal death, and in such cases God may
refuse to forgive such believers temporally (1Jn 5:16). God may enact the death penalty. Peter already had seen
God do this in the case of Ananias and Sapphira (Acts 5:1-11). God may take believers home prematurely. Peter is
evidently warning Magus that he was in such danger.
Page 110                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
       Pertaining to the present discussion concerning meris, what does Peter mean by no part or portion? Does he
mean that Magus was out of fellowship with God? Peter had heard Jesus say that only believers who cleanse
themselves of their sins will have this portion (meros) with Him (Jn 13:8), and certainly fellowship with God is
conditioned on walking in the light (1Jn 1:7-9). Still, it is difficult to believe that Peter is only warning Magus
about the temporal consequences of his sin. There is no reason to limit part either in Jn 13:8 or in Acts 8:21 to
temporal loss of fellowship. There are very good reasons to believe that it refers to eschatological, and thus
misthological, exclusion as well.

Portion in Jn 13:8 (meros)
        In the upper room, Jesus warns Peter that if Peter will not allow Jesus to cleanse his feet, then Peter will
have no part or portion (meros) with Him (Jn 13:8). Peter already had a bath (a picture of regeneration), but he
needed to have his feet washed (a picture of sanctification). Otherwise, he would fail to be a partaker with Jesus.
The disciples were arguing frequently about which of them would be greatest in the kingdom. One reason that
Jesus washed their feet was to rebuke them of this I-am-better-than-you attitude. If Jesus, who is the greatest, was
willing to serve them, then the matter of who is better than whom is a moot point. In the present, it does not matter
who is greater than whom; the point is that we should serve one another. However, this does not mean that Jesus
was upset with their desire to be great in His kingdom. To the contrary, the very warning that Jesus gives Peter is
that if Peter fails to have clean feet, he will fail to have a misthological part (meros) in the rulership of the
kingdom. Peter’s part (i.e., his portion, share, inheritance) in the kingdom was at stake. Jesus is telling Peter that if
such things are really important to him (and thus if Peter genuinely wants to be important in terms of what portion
he gets in heaven), then he must submit to the foot washing. If Peter had not submitted to the foot washing, then he
certainly would not have been permitted to partake of the Lord’s Supper which followed, which represents
kingdom rulership. Participation in that Supper is conditioned on personal worthiness because it represents the
right to exercise kingdom rulership from Mount Zion.*
        After Jesus washed their feet, the disciples got into another argument in the upper room as to which of them
was best. As usual, they were very concerned about what part they would have with Jesus in His future kingdom.
After all, Jesus promised that if they were faithful, they would be rulers with Him in the kingdom (Lk 22:24-30).
Even in this future kingdom, who was greater than whom would not be a vital matter—if they are faithful—since
they would all be co-rulers in His kingdom. Peter wanted a part with Jesus in the rulership of this kingdom. He
wanted a co-partnership with Him, that is, a co-rulership with Jesus. After all, this is precisely what Jesus promised
Peter, if he would keep his feet clean. The desire to have such a misthological portion is not what Jesus rebukes.
Rather, this portion is the promise He makes. Yet the realization of this misthological participation must await the
future. Now is the time for humble service.

Portion in Acts 8:21 (kleros)
       Likewise, the part described by Peter in Acts 8:21 need not be restricted to a temporal experience. Luke
again records this word portion (kleros) in Acts 26:18, where Paul says that the purpose of his ministry is “to open
their eyes so that they may turn from darkness to light and from the dominion of Satan to God, in order that they
may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who have been sanctified by faith in Me [Jesus].”
This passage is dealing with the same concept as Acts 8:22. Turning from sin (i.e., repentance) is necessary in
order to receive temporal forgiveness and a misthological inheritance. Those who have experienced positional
sanctification must press on to practical sanctification in order to obtain this inheritance.178 The connection
between Acts 26:18 and Phil 3:11 has been demonstrated already.† Thus, the association of this inheritance with
the out-resurrection has been established.
       As noted above, the only other verse in the NT where these two words in Acts 8:21 for part and portion
occur are again on the lips of Paul in Col 1:12, where (as mentioned) that part may be translated partakers. Peter
could very well be warning Magus that he does not have a part or inheritance in this matter. Magus would not be a
partaker nor inheritor of the kingdom. The phrase this matter (to logo ≈ o logos) certainly can be understood
generally as matter, as BDAG points out. Even so, in this same section, concerning the general use in Acts 8:21,
BDAG also states that it refers to “the subject under discussion” (emphasis original; see logos, 1.a.e). What is the
subject under discussion? In verses 14 and 25, the subject (ton logon ≈ o logos) is the word of God that is being
preached. This in turn is defined in verse 12, where Luke says that Philip was preaching the gospel (euaggelizo) of
*
    See The Lord’s Banquet, 561.
†
    See Phil 3:13-14, 94.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                               Page 111
the kingdom! In Mt 24:14 Jesus defines the gospel (euaggelion) of the kingdom as good news that the one who
endures to the end will be saved (Mt 24:13).
        Unfortunately, the popular perception is that the good news of the kingdom refers to going to heaven when
you die. The NT teaching that the gospel of the kingdom encompasses ruling earth when believers are raised has
been practically forgotten. Nevertheless, this is the portion that John refers to in Rev 20:6. Quite likely, Peter refers
the same portion in Acts 8:21. By holding out the possibility of ruling in the kingdom by being faithful, the gospel
of the kingdom advances beyond merely affirming that one enters the kingdom by faith. Just as Ananias and
Sapphira failed (allowing a preoccupation with money to prevent them from obtaining this misthological
experience in the kingdom), Magus might also. In 1Tim 6:9, Paul says that believers who pursue wealth are in
danger of this same destruction (apoleia).
        No doubt in the case of Ananias and Sapphira, a temporal dimension to their destruction was entailed. What
it meant for them to perish is obvious on one level since they died instantly. Still, should one assume that what it
meant to perish was limited to temporal destruction? Will they be co-rulers with Christ? Hardly! By their sin they
destroyed any hope that they might have had of ruling in the kingdom. One should not presume that the destruction
that Peter warned Magus about was limited to the present. Although Peter held immediate chastisement out as a
possibility, Magus did not experience temporal destruction and drop dead. Nor did Magus repent or get his heart
right. Experientially, he remained enslaved to his sinful misperception. Did he perish? Most certainly. Does this
mean that Simon’s silver went to hell? No. Perish (apoleia) refers to the danger of temporal and misthological loss
rather than to the possibility of soteriological destruction in this passage.
        Due to his attitude, Magus had no portion (i.e., no misthological inheritance) in the kingdom of God (cf.
Acts 8:12-13). Simon Magus could not forfeit his entrance into the kingdom, but he could forfeit his portion (i.e.,
the reward of his inheritance) in the kingdom. Due to the context and parallels, Simon’s destruction cannot be
limited to a temporal sphere. Nor, on the basis of history, can one suggest that he repented and thus escaped
destruction. If Ananias and Sapphira are a picture of what it means to fumble the ball, Magus is an example of a
believer who picks the ball up, runs the other way, scores a touchdown for the other team, and then puts on the
Devil’s jersey!
        According to church history, Magus went on to be a prominent leader in Gnostic Christianity. In fact,
according to Irenaeus, we should regard Magus as the very founder of Gnosticism. In Acts, we find the initial
confrontation between Simon Magus and Simon Peter in Samaria. According to some accounts, they meet again
later in Antioch. Peter was sent to confront Magus in Antioch. Simon Magus wanted to pervert liberty (cp.
Gal 5:13), and this is what Peter was sent to Antioch to correct (Gal 2:11). But in confronting the antinomian
teaching of Simon Magus, Simon Peter ran right into the arms of the nomians. These false brethren in Gal 2:4,
wanted to destroy liberty—the liberty preached by Paul—which in their minds was equivalent to that preached by
Simon Magus. They slanderously equated Simon Peter with Simon Magus.
        After being confronted by Peter in Antioch, Magus then went to Rome. (Some speculate that it was Simon
Magus rather than Simon Peter who was the founder of Roman Catholicism in Rome, since Peter did not come to
Rome until much later—if at all.) Nicholas of Antioch, one of the seven deacons in Antioch (Acts 6:5), was
probably Bishop in Samaria and Simon’s successor after Simon left for Rome. According to Irenaeus, the
Nicolaitans (whom John responds against in Revelation) were followers of the “sect of Nicolas,” and Nicolas was
one of the first seven ordained deacons by the apostles (see Date, 33). Hippolytus concurs with Irenaeus in saying
that Nicolas was one of these seven and that Nicolas departed from correct doctrine and caused wide-spread
doctrinal contamination and that he was the forerunner of Hymenaeus and Philetus who also committed apostasy
(2Tim 2:17-18).
        The Nicolaitans introduced sex orgies as an expression of Christian love in their love feasts. This was not
that difficult to do in that society, since sex outside of marriage was accepted completely without any stigma; in
fact, harlot priestesses offered themselves for prostitution in service to the gods. Indeed, prior to marriage, many
well-born girls dedicated themselves to sacred prostitution for a period of time and were honored for doing so.
According to Irenaeus, this wide-spread doctorial and sexual seduction within the Christian community is to be
traced back to Magus. These Gnostic Christians still considered themselves Christians. In their opinion, they
simply had evolved in their understanding of Christianity to a more mature knowledge.*
        Certainly, the above historical sketch is open to debate, but the basic perception is well established that
Magus was a theological maggot. Was Luke wrong in his assessment that even Magus had believed? No. In view
of what Magus turned out to be, it is little wonder that Peter evidently wished that Magus would just drop dead in

*
 See Appendix 5. Gnostic Writings (p. 797) for further interaction with this Gnostic Christian perspective.
Page 112                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
verse 20. Who would want a convert like that! But God does not always deal with His children in this manner,
even with His illegitimate children.* There are black sheep in the family, and certainly they are an embarrassment
to the family. Although some theologians might want to deny that these embarrassments are a part of the family,
the Father claims them as His own and acknowledges that these embarrassments to the family are in fact believers,
just like He does here in black and white concerning Simon.

Four Types of Discipline
       Even though Simon lived through the discipline of verse 20, he did not escape the discipline of verse 21.
Kendall devotes an entire chapter to describing the three ways God disciplines His children: internally, externally,
and terminally. What Kendall means by terminal discipline needs clarification:

          I call it terminal chastening for two reasons. First, because it is something which takes place beyond
          the present age. It takes place on the last day. Secondly, it can justly be called a terminal chastening
          because one’s loss of reward at the judgment seat of Christ will never be regained throughout the
          endless aeons of eternity. In other words, one will spend eternity “rewardless” in heaven. It will be an
          everlasting reminder that one was saved “so as by fire”...the judgment seat of Christ for some will
          mean the ultimate measure of God’s chastening. It will be such for those who simply would not heed
          the previous warnings of God in their lifetime. 179

        To Kendall’s credit, he correctly notes that the ultimate and severest form of God’s discipline is the finale in
which a believer is sentenced to eternal misthological emptiness—no rewards for all eternity. Those in GRAPE,
who fully grasp the significance of the second letter of the acronym, will concur that misthological discipline is far
more severe than temporal discipline. Yet, as to the present discussion, what needs to be underscored is that
Kendall goes on to explain that in some cases God may stop disciplining His children internally and externally and
may wait to deal with them terminally instead.
        Although Kendall’s’ assessment is excellent, his terminology could use refinement. Most people would
probably think of the premature death of Ananias and Sapphira as examples of terminal discipline. They died.
Accordingly, it would be best to add a classification to clarify the distinction. I will use misthological discipline to
refer to what Kendall describes as terminal discipline so that terminal discipline can be used to refer to premature
death as a form of discipline. Of course, not all premature death is an expression of discipline.
                                         Illustration 50. Four Forms of Discipline


                                         Temporal                                             Eschatological

          (1) Internal                   (2) External              (3) Terminal               (4) Misthological
1Sam 24:5; Ps 19:11: Acts        Job 5:17; 33:19; 2Sam 7:14; Acts 5:5; 8:20; 1Cor 5:5; 1Chron 28:9; Mt 8:12; 22:13;

Tit 2:15; 1Jn 3:21               Heb 12:5-11; 1Tim 1:20      1Jn 5:16                  Rev 3:19


                                                                    Hope



        God’s chastisement of His children, therefore, may be clarified as occurring in four possible forms:
(1) internal, (2) external, (3) terminal, or (4) misthological. The first three are temporal (i.e., experienced in time)
and are thus temporary. The last one is eschatological and thus eternal. God initially disciplines every believer
temporally (Heb 12:6-8), and ultimately He will discipline them misthologically (Rev 3:19), but He may cease to
discipline a believer temporally.
*
    See Sons of God, 77.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                            Page 113
       The mildest form of God’s discipline is conviction and instruction through His word and the believer’s
biblically-informed conscience, pictured by the Bible in the above illustration. If believers resist or prove
insensitive to that form of discipline, then God may move to external forms of correction. When the author’s
children were very young, he would keep a little switch or fly swat handy in each room of the house so that he
could render external discipline as necessary, being a firm believer in the proverb: spare the rod, spoil the child.
Biblical discipline is an expression of Fatherly love (Prov 13:24; Heb 12:6). Such discipline can be administered in
various degrees of severity. Some would describe this type of discipline as being taken to God’s woodshed. It may
be experienced as sickness or various degrees and forms of calamity.
       Should God’s children prove to be rebellious when submitted to this form of reproof, God may progress to
terminal discipline by one of two courses of action. He may chastise His children with premature death.
Considering the alternative, in certain cases this might even be considered, at least in part, to be a mercy killing. In
mercy God may kill a disobedient believer before such a believer can do even more damage to his or her
testimony, which in turn would result in an even worse degree of misthological punishment at the JSC. Or God
may decide to allow believers to persist in their error, and swear in His wrath that such believers will not inherit the
misthological throne. From the perspective of eternity, this latter alternative frequently could be much more severe
than premature death. Regardless, since terminal discipline is not limited to premature death, it might more broadly
be defined as the death of hope—misthological hope. There is no longer any hope of ruling with Christ in heaven
in any capacity for those subjected to this form of discipline. As a result, they will be subjected to the maximum
form of chastisement—misthological exclusion from rulership.
       The brilliance of Kendall’s approach is to be found in his recognition that temporal discipline may be
resisted and temporally cease. Believers may persist in sin to such a degree or duration that they become without
discipline (Heb 12:8). Although Magus’ temporal discipline was less severe than that of Ananias and Sapphira, his
misthological discipline will be much worse. God apparently stopped disciplining Simon Magus temporally, but
his misthological discipline will be far worse. Just as there will be degrees of rewards in heaven, there will also be
degrees of discipline (i.e., degrees of punishment in the outer darkness).
       A common objection to the FG position is based on mistaken perceptions concerning discipline. Opponents
to FG theology, such as Zeller, object that believers cannot persist in sin because Gods’ discipline prevents them
from doing so:

       If the sinning believer does not respond in the right way to God’s conviction in the heart, then the
       Father will chasten His child whom He loves (1 Cor. 11:31-32). Maximum chastisement can even
       result in the physical death of the believer (1 Cor. 11:30). As a good human father will not permit his
       child to continue doing wrong, so the Heavenly Father will not permit His child to continue in
       wickedness.180

       Amazingly, such writers make statements that are blatantly self-contradictory and yet fail to see their
inconsistency. Yet how many times do we hear such sentiments expressed from our pulpits! Zeller unwittingly
admits that these believers resisted God’s conviction and His discipline, and they persisted in their practice of sin
right up until the point of their death. These believers did not persevere in a life of holiness. Far from it! Neither
God’s conviction nor His discipline prevented them from persevering in sin. Zeller refutes himself. God did allow
these believers to continue doing wrong until the very end of their lives. But He did not let them continue in
wickedness without suffering the consequences. Such consequences are not confined to this life but will have
tremendous impact in the life to come. Zeller is further mistaken in that terminal discipline is not the ultimate or
maximum expression of God’s chastisement. The final and eternal expression at the Bema will be far more
excruciating, culminating in the outer darkness for God’s rebellious children.
       To be sure, one of the arguments advanced by fellow securitists* in favor of OSAS is that God’s discipline
keeps the believer saved. In fact, Strombeck says, “This chastening [in 1Cor 11:32] is for the purpose of keeping

to be labeled from either perspective since they teach a hybrid: Conditional OSAS. See COSAS, 709. As demonstrated in that

                                                                     181
the saved one from becoming lost” (italics his; bold mine). The other two primary passages used in this regard
are 1Cor 5:5 and Heb 12:8. Kendall, on the other hand, in his book defending OSAS, does not suggest that the
purpose of the discipline is to keep the believer saved from losing regeneration. Yet Kendall does not discount the
importance of the doctrine of chastisement in his defense of eternal security. In his OSAS book, in his chapter
devoted to the forms of discipline discussed above, Kendall states: “Some have regarded 1 Corinthians 5:5 as the
strongest verse in the Bible for once saved always saved and I would not disagree.”182 Neither would I. Assuming
that the purpose of chastisement is to keep us eternally saved is one thing; acknowledging that the result of
chastisement shows that we are eternally saved is quite another and far better.

     In the above chart, the primary interpretive options have been laid out for 1Cor 5:5 and then combined in the
bottom row with my understanding of the complementary passage of 1Cor 11:32. The hina in the former passage is
understood as denoting purpose and commonly translated something along the lines of:

                                       I have decided to deliver such a one to Satan
                                               for (eis) the destruction of his flesh,
                           in order that (hina) his spirit may be saved in the Day of the Lord Jesus.

                                          Arminian View of Discipline
       The Arminian view, charted above, takes a remedial view of the chastisement in 5:5. The wayward believer
within this verse is delivered over to Satan for (eis) the temporal destruction of his flesh for the temporal goal of
the person repenting (and perhaps coming back to faith in Christ if the individual has apostatized) in order that
(hina) he may attain the eschatological goal of soteriological salvation in the Day of the Lord. The believer’s
soteriological salvation consequently is conditioned on his or her response to the discipline. The purpose of the
discipline is that the believers may keep their salvation from eternal damnation or regain it if they have lost it. This
view is compatible with NOSAS.

                                         Reformed View of Discipline
     The Reformed view may take a similar route and say that the person in 1Cor 5:5 was still saved but was
delivered over to Satan for the purpose of premature death before he would progress to the state of apostasy in
order that (hina) he may not lose his salvation. The fear is that the regenerate believer may stop believing and thus

discussion, the above explanation concerning divine versus human perspective is an inadequate means by which to absolve this
Calvinistic tension because the conditions are not just limited to the believer’s perspective. These conditions are genuine from God’s
perspective. Although this conditionality is readily acknowledged by many Calvinists, even those Calvinists who try to avoid this
conclusion fall into making good works a condition to reach heaven. See Retention of Regeneration (p. 274) and its ensuing
discussion. Consequently, Calvinists have a cross-eyed God looking at us as both insecure (because of conditions) and secure (due to
predestination). See Illustration 248. Cross-Eyed Calvinism, 709. And as if that were not bad enough, those Calvinists who attempt to
make human libertarianism compatible with divine determinism fail in that attempt as well. See Illustration 251. Forms of
Determinism, 711.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                         Page 115
forfeit regeneration and its ensuing spiritual salvation from eternal damnation. Thus, the ultimate goal of this
discipline is to keep the believer saved from hell. Strombeck’s articulation would fall into this category. For this
reason, his statement is counterintuitive to his affirmation of the OSAS position. He seeks to combine OSAS with
CS (conditional security). But the conditional security of the Reformed camp is really not compatible with eternal
security of the FG camp.* This Reformed view is compatible, however, with the Arminian NOSAS.

                                       Remedial FG View of Discipline
     The remedial FG view of 5:5 (e.g., Bing) takes the position that the wayward believer is delivered over to
Satan for (eis) the temporal destruction of his flesh for the temporal goal of the person repenting in order that
(hina) he may attain spiritual wellness in the present life. This might call the abundant-life view. The believer has
eternal life, but he needs to repent in order to experience abundant life (Jn 10:10). This view is theologically
permissible but exegetically questionable in that the Day of the Lord Jesus would appear to be eschatological. This
phrase is more readily understood in this epistle to refer to an eschatological salvation to be experienced in the day
of our Lord Jesus Christ and thus at the JSC (cp. 1Cor 1:8; 3:15).

                                      Misthological FG View of Discipline
      The misthological FG view of 5:5 (e.g., Constable) believes that the temporal destruction would prevent
continuance in sin and thus avoid a worse verdict at the Bema in 3:15.183 The salvation of spirit would thus be
synonymous with those passages which describe the salvation of soul—both the salvation of the soul and the spirit
would be interpreted as being misthological. The condemnation for the believer in 11:32 is likewise taken to be
temporal and misthological. This view has seeming theological and exegetical consistency in its favor. The view
itself, however, is untenable in that the salvation of the soul is attained by works—by not dying in a state of failure
as a believer. Misthological inconsistency is a deficiency in this view.

                                Remedial-Misthological FG View of Discipline
      Dwight Hunt (GNTC) has combined the two views above to form an attractive alternative for 1Cor 5:5. The
wayward believer is delivered over to Satan for (eis) the temporal destruction of his flesh for the temporal goal of
the person repenting in order that (hina) he may attain spiritual wellness at the Bema.† Thus, the eschatological
nature of this salvation is correctly recognized. Moreover, this misthological salvation is made properly contingent
upon the believer repenting and thus not dying in a state of misthological failure.184
      Because this composite interpretation successfully circumvents my criticisms of the previous two FG views
leading up to it, I will add a word in its defense. Although my personal inclination is to understand the salvation of
one’s spirit to be a soteriological concern, I must admit, nevertheless, that 1Thess 5:23 provides a collaborating
conceptual parallel for Hunt’s misthological understanding of such salvation. Paul prays that God may sanctify the
believers wholly in order that they may be holistically blameless at the Bema. Specifically, he desires that their
spirit will be misthologically blameless. To have one’s spirit saved from misthological blame would be a
misthological salvation of one’s spirit. Conceptually at least, one may acknowledge the misthological salvation of
spirit. Perhaps one might combine my preference for the spirit denoting a soteriological secure ontological core
with this misthological view by suggesting that Paul desires the misthological salvation of the soteriological core.
A believer’s regenerate spirit will be soteriologically blameless and ontologically sinless, but the misthological
blamelessness of the believer’s spirit will be contingent upon the purity of the believer’s walk. Even those believers
who do not walk in the light will find that they themselves are saved soteriologically (1Cor 3:15) because of their
regenerate spirit, but they will not find that their regenerate spirit is saved misthologically.
      In less technical jargon, Paul desires that this born-again person repent in the present life and thus experience
salvation at the Bema. This believer is already “one spirit” with the Lord (1Cor 6:17). Spiritual birth had resulted in
spiritual union. As a result of this spiritual union, believers already are betrothed to the Lord. Yet to attain the
*
  Allowances might be made for soft-shelled securitists such as Strombeck. See 3D Unconditional Security and RFG3 in endnote 499.
†
  Catholics and some ultraists would pose a remedial-misthological view in which the purpose of the Bema is to purify believers so

See Permanent, not Purgatory, 535. Note carefully that the position being considered above limits the remedial potential of the Bema
to the temporal arena. The punitory Bema is not a purgatory because the purification intended by the Bema is limited to this life.
Therefore, critics of the punitory Bema, such as Hoyt, cannot use an objection against purgatory as a valid argument against the
remedial-misthological purpose of the Bema being entertained above. Believers must allow warnings regarding the punitive nature of
the Bema to accomplish its purifying in the present. By denying the punitive nature of the Bema, Hoyt takes away from the biblical
motivation for present purification. Those taking away from the warnings may find the Bema more punitive than they imagined.
Page 116                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
intended goal of this spiritual union and thus enjoy misthological consummation, they must be pure (2Cor 11:2).
Just as Paul desires for the betrothed to be wed, so he desires for those who are secure soteriologically to be saved
misthologically. Although this misthological understanding of the salvation of one’s spirit is exegetically possible
and conceptually permissible, I will proceed with the assumption that a soteriological understanding is intended in
1Cor 5:5. Doing so will allow me to engage with Arminian and Reformed interpreters on their own turf in the
discussion of this verse.

                                       Soteriological FG View of Discipline
      The soteriological FG view (e.g., Dillow) would agree with the Arminian and Reformed interpretations in
considering the salvation of one’s spirit a soteriological issue in 1Cor 5:5. After all, soteriological salvation is
conditioned on the possession of eternal life in one’s regenerate spirit. Also, the phrase in 5:5 hina sozo (in order
that he may be saved) normally refers (at least inclusively) to the soteriological salvation of the lost: Lk 8:12;
Jn 3:17; 5:34; 12:47; Acts 16:30; 1Cor 9:22; 10:33; 1Thess 2:16. For these reasons, and others expressed by
Dillow, it is probably best to take 1Cor 5:5 as a hina result clause referring to the soteriological salvation of the
spirit.* This is described in 1Cor 3:15 as the person himself being saved, although his life’s work (picturing his
soul) is forfeited. Paul clarifies the result of the JSC by adding, “But [de] he himself will be saved.” Like the result
clause introduced by hina in 5:5, the result clause introduced by de in 3:15 clarifies that the believer himself is
saved from hell; although, his life’s (i.e., soul’s) work goes up in smoke. Even though the soul/life is lost
temporally and misthologically, the spirit is still saved soteriologically. Thus, hina in 1Cor 5:5 would be best
translated as a result clause:

                                          I have decided to deliver such a one to Satan
                                                   for (eis) the destruction of his flesh,
                           with the result that (hina) his spirit will be saved in the Day of the Lord Jesus.

     The soteriological result is guaranteed unconditionally despite the fact that the wayward believer is being
delivered over to Satan for the purpose of premature death. The present writer concurs with Dillow concerning the
soteriological nature of salvation of the spirit in 1Cor 5:5, a text which factors heavily in debates regarding
OSAS.185 The destruction of the flesh is thus understood herein to be temporal, and to Dillow’s credit he likewise
takes the related passage in 1Cor 11:32 as referring to temporal condemnation for the rebellious believer. Taking
both passages jointly as describing temporal destruction and condemnation gives Dillow theological and exegetical
consistency.

                                     Dual: Soteriological-Misthological
     Granted, Dillow’s understanding of 11:32 has hermeneutical consistency in its favor. Nevertheless,
Constable’s preference for misthological condemnation in 11:32 is favorably received herein. These approaches
have been combined in Illustration 51. The hina in 11:32 is consequently charted as using a purpose clause to show
that the goal of temporal judgment is that believers respond rightly to this discipline so that they will not
experience misthological discipline in the form of disinheritance (see Heb 12:8; Constable concurs there also) and
thus may be translated properly as:
                                                    But when we are judged,
                                                  we are disciplined by the Lord
                              in order that (hina) we may not be condemned along with the world.
      The result clause of 5:5 and the purpose clause of 11:32 coalesce in harmony with the clarification in 3:15
(that himself will be saved) to teach that those believers who die prematurely as a result of temporal chastisement
will only have their spirits saved, but their life’s works (and thus their souls) will be condemned misthologically.
Like Dillow, I believe that 1Cor 5:5 shows the soteriological result rather than the purpose of God’s discipline.
Like Kendall, I understand that Heb 12:8 as indicating that some believers are allowed to resist God’s discipline to
the point of becoming without discipline (rather than teaching that God’s discipline always achieves its intended
purpose). Such believers will be disinherited misthologically as a result. They will be dealt with misthologically
when they get home.†

*
    See protracted discussion of Hina Purpose Clause, 259.
†
    For an illustration of misthological discipline which explains this allusion, see “Misthological Forgiveness” in Trichotomy.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                               Page 117
       Consequently, I am not satisfied with simplistic assumptions, even by fellow advocates of eternal security,
when I encounter a text like 1Cor 11:32. God may or may not allow His children to continue in wickedness without
invoking terminal discipline. Just because He uses terminal discipline on certain occasions does not mean that He
must do so on every occasion. Otherwise, a lot more Christians would be dropping dead like Ananias and Sapphira.
A holistic consideration of the texts pertaining to chastisement causes me to reject Zeller’s simplistic presumption
that believers cannot continue in sin. The context itself indicates believers may continue in sin until the end of their
lives. More sophisticated avenues are available to eternal securitists concerning verses like 1Cor 11:32 than the
shortsighted one offered by Zeller.186

Conditional Portion
       Portions (i.e., potential positions in ruling, Rev 20:6) can be lost. Believers can also lose their portion in the
tree of life (Rev 22:19). Obviously, unbelievers do not have a portion in the tree of life to lose. The warning was
given to the intended readers—believers. They already have crowns and clothing positionally and potentially, but
these potential rewards can be lost (Rev 3:11; 16:15). Believers themselves cannot be lost, but their rewards can be
lost (1Cor 3:15). John and Paul are teaching the same misthological truth: Co-heirship with Christ is conditional
and forfeitable. Paul uses the prefix sum (with) to denote conditional co-rulership with Christ in 2Tim 2:12 (rule
with). Not all believers will meet the conditions necessary to rule with Christ. John uses the synonym meta (with)
to denote the same misthological co-participation with Christ in the book of Revelation on multiple occasions: 3:4
(walk with); 3:20 (eat with); 3:21 (sit with); 17:14 (overcome with); 20:4,6 (rule with). The Johannine co-rulership
with Christ in Rev 20:4,6 (meta basileuo) is equivalent to the Pauline co-rulership with Christ in 2Tim 2:12
(sumbasileuo).

       Matthew, Luke, and John show a preference for meta to describe the believer’s conditional and
eschatological co-participation: Mt 8:11 (eat with); Mt 24:51 (portion with); Mt 25:10 (feast with); Lk 12:46
(portion with); Jn 13:8 (portion with). Paul, on the other hand, seems to show a preference for sug, sum, and sun. In
Rom 8:17 Paul uses sug, sum, and sun as prefixes to describe some believers being glorified with Christ; that is,
the co-heirs (sug) will be those believers who co-suffer (sum) and who will be co-glorified (sun) with Jesus.
Page 118                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
Unconditional Portion
        In contrast, Paul uses sun as a stand-alone word in Col 3:4 to describe all believers being glorified with
Christ (also see sum prefix in Phil 3:21). Whereas Paul uses sun in Col 3:4 to say that there is a sense in which all
believers will unconditionally be with Christ in glory, John uses meta in Jn 17:24 to assert the same point. Both
writers teach that certain eschatological aspects of being with Christ are unconditional while other facets are
conditional. They simply use different synonyms to state the same truth. Compare Paul’s interchangeable use of
sun and meta in Col 3:4 and 1Thess 3:13. The Lord will return with all His saints in glory, and they will all be
glorified to some extent. They will at least appear with Him in glory and in glorified bodies. Paul’s use in Eph 5:7
of summetochos (portion with) is similar to the meta meros (portion with) of Mt 24:51 and Lk 12:46. Depending
on the context, sug, sun, sum, and meta can be used synonymously. The context determines whether all believers
are in view. As to Rom 8:29, it is debatable as to whether this conformity to the Son is unconditional or
conditional. Throughout the present discussion I will assume the former but provide my preference for an alternate
approach elsewhere.* Either approach in Rom 8:29 is compatible with GRAPE theology.

Eschatological and Temporal Portion
        Contingent fellowship with Christ (in both the eschatological and temporal arena) is implied by eating with
the Lord in Rev 3:20. Certainly, believers may fail to meet the contextual conditions for this fellowship. Also, in
his first epistle, John made it very clear that believers may fail to experience temporal fellowship with (meta)
Christ if they do not meet the daily conditions of walking in the light and confessing their sins (1Jn 1:6-9). As
noted above, John also pictured this type of ongoing cleansing previously in GJ, where Jesus warned Peter: “If I do
not wash (nipto) you, then you have no portion (meros) with Me” (Jn 13:8; TM).†
        The bath of justification is only needed once, but the washing of sanctification is needed subsequently to be
completely clean: “He who has bathed (louo) needs only to wash (nipto) his feet, but is completely clean”
(Jn 13:10). Those believers who already have had their bath but refuse to wash afterwards have no portion (meros)
with (meta) Jesus. They lose their participation in rulership with Jesus.‡
        Although they cannot forfeit their relationship with the Lord, they do forfeit their fellowship and rulership
with the Lord. John pictures this same truth again in his eschatological epistle and emphasizes that the fellowship
forfeited is not merely temporal but also eschatological. Subcomers do not have the temporal fellowship of dining
with Jesus now, nor will they have the eschatological fellowship of walking, sitting, eating, overcoming, and ruling
with Him in the future.

Three Options Concerning Portion
       Three basic options are available concerning portion/inheritance.§ (1) One can take the position of such
writers as Hodges, Dillow, Dodson, and others that, although the rapture is full, sometimes a misthological
distinction is made between entering the kingdom and inheriting it, between being a believer and an overcomer,
and between participating in the resurrection in any sense versus a special sense. (2) Or one can take the position of
writers such as Brown, Bing, Lopez, and Zeller that the rapture is full and no significant distinctions exist between
entering and inheriting. All believers will have this type of participation. (3) Or one can agree with the partial
rapturists such as Govett and Lang who, like those in option two, do not make a distinction between entering and
inheriting the kingdom.187 According to this partial rapture position, only overcomers are raptured/resurrected
before the millennium and thus have this participation. Option three, the partial rapture position, will be further
examined and rejected subsequently.**

                                                  1Cor 6:8-11
       As for Brown’s analysis in option two, in chapter 4 of his thesis, which deals with the Pauline passages
(such as 1Cor 6:9-10; Gal 5:21; Eph 5:5), even Brown himself acknowledges that regenerate believers may commit
these acts of unrighteousness (adikia). Yet Brown attempts to argue that these believers cannot be called
unrighteous (adikoi).188 Of course, believers cannot be called unrighteous positionally, as Brown argues, but this

does not prove that they cannot be called unrighteous experientially. Brown’s argument is that believers can and do
commit adikia without being characterized as such, even if they continue committing them!189 Brown is followed
in this assessment by Zeller, who argues that the past tense of the verb were in 1Cor 6:11 proves that the
Corinthians are no longer considered unrighteous; although, Zeller acknowledges that they are still considered
carnal (1Cor 3:3).190 Even so, the admission that they are still carnal is, in fact, an admission that they are still
unrighteous in terms of their behavior. Actually, Paul explicitly uses the present tense verb to say that these
believers are actively unrighteous in 1Cor 6:8!
        1
          Does any of you [Corinthian believers], who has a lawsuit against another, dare take it to court
        before the [hoi] unrighteous [articular adikoi] and not before the saints?…8But you [Corinthian
        believers] are being unrighteous [adikeo] and unfair, doing this even to your own brethren. 9 Do you
        not know those who are unrighteous [anarthrous* adikoi] will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do
        not be deceived; neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor effeminate, nor homosexuals,
        10
           or thieves, nor the covetous, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor swindlers, will inherit the kingdom of
        God. 11 And such were some of you; but you were washed, but you were sanctified, but you were
        justified in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ, and in the Spirit of our God.191 (1Cor 6:8-11; TM)

        Brown’s contrast between the saints (hoi hagioi) and the unrighteous (hoi adikoi) in 1Cor 6:1 is not very
impressive in view of the facts. First, not all saints (hagioi) are holy (hagios).† Peter, for example, commands the
saints to be saints; that is, he commands the holy ones to be holy (1Pet 1:16). Likewise, Paul is urging these saints
to be righteous rather than unrighteous in their behavior. Surely Paul is not to be understood as referring to all
saints in this context. Is he teaching that the civil cases should be brought before newly converted children? No.
Even though such children are saints positionally, Paul is not saying that such children should rule over adults in
the church. For that matter, he does not even assume that all Christian adults in the church are qualified to perform
the saintly function he has in mind. He specifies that the type of saint he has in mind for performing such a
function would be a wise Christian (1Cor 6:5). Certainly, the brother just judged by Paul in the preceding chapter,
who was to be expelled from the church (1Cor 5:3-5), would also be excluded from the saints who are qualified to
render judgment in the church. Likewise, the fact that the saints will rule the world and judge angels is not intended
to be applied to all saints. Not all saints will be qualified misthologically to exercise this saintly function (1Cor 6:2-
3). Of course, Paul wants all saints to perform within the boundaries he is laying out, but the problem causing him
to set forth such boundaries in the first place is that these saints are not acting saintly.
        Second, believers commit nominal unrighteousness (adikia; Rom 6:13; 2Tim 2:19; 1Jn 1:9). In the first
parallel passage, Paul enjoins: “Do not go on presenting the members of your body to sin as instruments of
unrighteousness” (Rom 6:13). Paul exhorts believers to stop practicing unrighteousness. In the second parallel, he
likewise urges believers to abstain from unrighteousness because cleansing oneself from such things is how a
believer comes to be classified as a vessel of honor rather than as a dishonorable vessel (2Tim 2:19-21). The
dishonorable vessels in the Lord’s house do not refer to a classification of unbelievers but instead to carnal
believers. The contrast is not between being an unbeliever and a believer because one does not become a believer
by cleansing oneself! Rather, one becomes a sanctified believer (in this sense) by the process of practical
sanctification. After all, if God only sees believers as righteous, then why does John say that believers constantly
need to be cleansed of their unrighteousness in order to maintain fellowship with God in 1Jn 1:9?
        Third, believers are warned not to commit verbal unrighteousness (adikeo; cp. this verbal form in Col 3:25
and 1Cor 6:8 with adjectival form adikia in 1Cor 6:9). In the Colossian parallel, Paul warns that behaving
unrighteously will result in a negative payment where the reward of the inheritance is at stake for the believer
(Col 3:24). Likewise, in the Corinthian passage, Paul warns the unrighteous believers in verse 8 (with an
anarthrous adikoi in verse 9) that those who are behaving unrighteously will not inherit the kingdom. That is, the
lack of the Greek article suggests that Paul is referring to their behavior rather than soteriologically labeling them
as the unrighteous.
        One might have thought that in this discussion (or at least in his web article dedicated to inheriting the
kingdom) Zeller might have at least mentioned the fact that believers are being described as unrighteous in verse
eight. But he does not, and neither does his cohort Ventilato, whom Zeller quotes in support.192 Their argument

*
  Anarthrous is a term of Greek grammar which means that the word in question does not have a Greek article. When the Greek
article for the is missing, the word is said to be anarthrous. If the word had an article, it would be called an articular expression. For
example, the dog is articular in English because, in this instance, the word dog has the English article the in front of it.
†
  See Holy, 47; Illustration 197. The Assumed All, 577; Overcomers, 847.
Page 120                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
collapses in view of the immediate context. They do an injustice to the context in jumping over verse eight in order
to run back to verse one in trying to avoid the conclusion that Paul is warning genuine believers that they may fail
to inherit the kingdom due to their unrighteous behavior.
        To be sure, the unrighteous unbeliever in verse one has no hope of inheriting the kingdom. However, Paul’s
point in verse nine is that no one who is unrighteous in behavior can inherit the kingdom. Consequently,
unbelievers automatically are ruled out since all their righteousness is as filthy rags. Conversely, believers
conditionally are ruled out if their lack of practical righteousness disqualifies them from inheriting the kingdom.
        As to Zeller’s appeal to the tense of 1Cor 6:11, he shows a disregard for the sense of the passage. The fact
that they were sinners by nature does not establish that they are now saints in action. Paul is pointing out the stark
incongruity between their practice and position. This is a common NT technique.* This same contrast between
what believers were positionally and ontologically and what they are practically and experientially is expressed by
Paul elsewhere: “For you were formerly darkness, but now you are light in the Lord; walk as children of light”
(Eph 5:8). Paul urges these very believers to “stop participating in the unfruitful deeds of darkness, but instead
even expose them” (Eph 5:11; TM).† They were darkness; they are light; they walk in darkness. John also
acknowledges that believers may walk in darkness (1Jn 1:6; 2:11); although, they are actually children of light
(Jn 12:36). Believers may fail to be what they are. The fact that they were justified does not prove that they are
acting justly. The fact that they are righteous does not prove that they are living righteously.
        Logically, one would deduce that Paul is not only characterizing these believers as being experientially
unrighteous, but he is also warning these unrighteous believers that they will not inherit the kingdom if they do not
stop practicing unrighteousness. Amazingly, this deduction is lost on Brown, who concludes: “Whether or not
believers can and do commit these sins is not the issue; rather, Paul’s point is that believers should not degrade
themselves to participation in the deeds of those who have no title to the future kingdom.”193 On the contrary, this
is the issue and Paul’s very point! Paul is saying that anyone who degrades himself or herself by participation in
such unrighteous behavior will not inherit the kingdom. Everyone who lives like this, even if they are believers,
will “have no title to the future kingdom,” to use Brown’s words. Having no title to it means that it does not belong
to them. Believers guilty of such behavior may enter the kingdom, but they will not own the place. To be entitled to
enter the kingdom is one thing; to own the title to the kingdom is quite another. If those who commit these sins are
believers, then it is those believers who will not inherit the kingdom!
        One frequently hears 1Cor 6:9-11 used as a proveitistic proof text that believers do not commit such sins
and that those who commit such sins are not believers. This assumption basically ignores the significance of the
wider context of the NT, in which one finds that believers do in fact commit such sins. And such proveitistic proof
texting fails to deal adequately with the fact that the broader context of the Corinthian epistles teaches that these
particular believers were guilty of many of these same sins. But even more objectionable is the blatant disregard of
the immediate context by those who advance such an interpretation. Verse 8 specifies that the unrighteous people,
to whom Paul is addressing the warning, are the Corinthian readers and thus genuine believers.‡ Paul does not
question the genuineness of their conversion; he confirms it and appeals to it in verse 11. Positionally and legally,
they were (1) forgiven, (2) sanctified, and (3) justified—even in regard to these very sins they are now committing.
For this reason, they should stop committing these sins. It is another way of Paul urging, Be what you have become
rather than what you used to be. You are saved so start acting like it!
        So what does Zeller do with the contrast between verses 8 and 9, upon which Dillow bases his entire
argument? Zeller completely ignores it and does not even mention v. 8 in either article in which he pretends to
interact with Dillow’s view!194 This omission is a completely inexcusable in an article that claims to interact with
Dillow’s discussion. Dillow had noted that unbelievers are referred to as the unrighteous (hoi adikoi) in 1Cor 6:1.
However, he also stated that this would be an unlikely antecedent because (1) unrighteous is not a technical term
reserved for the lost (cp. Lk 16:10-11). (2) The verbal form (adikeo) in verse 8 is the closer antecedent, and for this
reason some commentators believe that verse 9 is referring back to the unrighteous behavior of verse 8 rather than
the unrighteous group of verse 1. (3) The grammar itself would suggest that the articular form in verse 1 refers to
the classification of a group as being unrighteous; whereas, the anarthrous form in verse 9 is describing the
character of being unrighteous. In other words, the fact that they act like the lost in their character does not
demonstrate that they are classified with the lost, but it does show that they express the same behavior as the lost.
(4) The warning about not inheriting is addressed to genuine believers.195

       Dillow’s exegesis is sound logically, contextually, and grammatically. The only minor counterpoint I might
acknowledge in deference to those commentators who also see a link with hoi adikoi (the unrighteous) in verse 1 is
to admit that it may not be completely incidental that Paul uses a similar description for the lost and saved in verses
1 and 8. As Dillow already has mentioned, this description shows that those who are saved may express the same
character as those who are lost. The saved still have their old sin nature. So a link between the two verses is not out
of the question. Paul reminds his readers that the unjust judges of the world will not judge the world to come.
Unbelievers will not inherit the kingdom because of their lack of righteousness. Believers need righteousness, both
imputed and imparted, to inherit the kingdom and judge the world. We should not envy or imitate the immoral
behavior of those who will not inherit the kingdom, or we will not inherit the kingdom either. Using a principle of
correlativity, Paul purposefully ties the believer’s potential lack of inheritance together with the definite lack
thereof on the part of unbelievers.* Not all believers will inherit the kingdom. Those believers who live like
unbelievers certainly will not inherit the kingdom.196

        In summary, the articular hoi adikoi (the unrighteous) is used in offsetting parallelism with hoi hagioi (the
righteous; i.e., the saints) to differentiate the lost from the saved as a class. However, within the classification of
the saved, there are those who behave as if they were lost. They are not holy (hagios) in their behavior. Instead,
Paul accuses these believers of behaving unrighteously (adikeo), and he proves that this is the case with his law-
court indictment against them. He then uses an anarthrous adikoi, which is the plural form of unrighteous (adikos),
to link their behavior characteristically with those who will not inherit the kingdom categorically. Believers who
live unrighteously are placing themselves characteristically in the same set (denoted by the ellipse) as those who
categorically will not inherit the kingdom. Yet such believers are not categorized with the lost (denoted by the fact
that they are not in the same box as the lost in the above diagram). Carnal believers do not lose their salvation or
become a part of the articular hoi adikoi. Carnal Christians are in the same ellipse characteristically as the lost, but
not in the same box categorically. Although all saints potentially are qualified to render judgment in the church and
rule the world categorically, only some saints actually are qualified to do so characteristically. Other saints will be
disqualified characteristically. Not all saints will rule.†
