Page 122                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
                                         Corner vs Corner vs Corner
       The standard FG position is thus affirmed herein in regarding the inheritance of the kingdom as a
misthological issue. Accordingly, Paul is warning genuine believers in the Galatian passage about a genuine danger
of not inheriting the kingdom: “I forewarn you just as I have forewarned you that those who practice such things
shall not inherit the kingdom of God” (Gal 5:21). Yet Corner quotes 5:21 and claims that OSAS will deny that it
applies to genuine believers: “Surely OSAS proponents will object and say that Paul wasn’t addressing Christians
in the book of Galatians.”197 But earlier Corner expressed the opposite criticism: “A very common OSAS
misinterpretation of Gal. 6:7-9 is that those verses are related to the judgment and rewards of believers.”198 So
Corner refutes himself with his previous remonstrance. As to his statement that OSAS would deny that the Galatian
warnings are addressed to Christians (which is shown patently to be false by his previous statement), he proceeds
to assert in bold print: “No OSAS teacher could ever issue such a helpful and important warning of ultimate
spiritual danger to Christians that they could still not inherit the kingdom of God, as Paul did in these
verses!” (All emphasis his.)199 What is this allegation by Corner if not a boldface fabrication? Corner claims that
an OSAS teacher could never issue such a warning to believers. On the contrary, I just did. Moreover, I am simply
sounding an alarm which already has been sounded by OSAS forerunners such as Dillow, Kendall, and Hodges
whom Corner criticizes. If Corner has read their writings, and he has, then how can he not realize that he is falsely
maligning the OSAS position?
       Corner continues to rant in boldface print: “Many have been deceived by OSAS teachers! Under their
kind of grace such sins [as those described above in 1Cor 6:9-10] can be committed without any danger of
not inheriting the kingdom of God.” (All emphasis his.)200 What is this misrepresentation by Corner if not a
boldface lie? Much later in his book, Corner turns around and chastises the misthological view of the inheritance:
“This Hodges-Evans-Kendall interpretation of inherit is easily refuted by noticing the overlap between
1Cor. 6:9,10 and Rev. 21:8.” In doing so, Corner shows that he had not spoken truthfully when he previously said
that OSAS denies that there is “any danger of not inheriting.” Corner falsifies his own statement with his own
citations. His quotation of Kendall will suffice to illustrate the point: “It was not salvation, then, but their
inheritance in the kingdom of God that these Christians were in danger of forfeiting. So with the Galatians”
(bold his, italics mine).201 Here, contrary to Corner’s own claims, he cites Kendall as applying the Galatian
warning to genuine believers; moreover, the warning is that they will not inherit the kingdom. By his own citation,
Corner has proven himself guilty of falsely maligning the FG position. Besides his error in logic concerning
Rev 21:8,* Corner has stated falsely (1) that OSAS would not warn believers that they may be in danger of not
inheriting the kingdom and (2) that OSAS advocates would not apply the Galatian warnings to believers.
Unfortunately, Corner not only takes away from the words of his opponents, he also takes away from the words of
Scripture itself when he refuses to acknowledge that the inheritance is a reward.

                                                    Col 3:23-25
       Corner attempts to disassociate disinheritance with rewards or with works by claiming that the
disinheritance is based on sins rather than works and by also claiming that OSAS mistakenly considers everything
believers do a work.202 First, his claim is false that OSAS necessarily considers everything we do a work. The
present work emphatically denies that everything we do is a work. Rather, the present book asserts from Rom 4:4
that a work is anything we do that results in a reward.† Second, Corner is being less than forthcoming in his
attempt to disassociate the inheritance with rewards when he fails to even mention Col 3:23-25 anywhere in his
entire eight-hundred-page book! Paul explicitly says that the inheritance is a reward in this passage. So how can
Corner implicitly deny it? Has he not taken away from the words of Scripture by seeking to suppress the truth
contained in Col 3:23-25? Third, the fact that the inheritance is a reward means that the inheritance is in fact based
on works.

           1. The inheritance is a reward (Col 3:23-25).
           2. Rewards are based on works (Rom 4:4, etc).
           3. Therefore, the inheritance is based on works.

      In equating entrance into heaven with the inheritance, Corner has conditioned entrance into heaven on
works, since the inheritance is based on works. He is teaching a works-based soteriology. Fourth, his false

*
    See Cure for Depression, 697.
†
    See “What is Work” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                            Page 123
dichotomy between sin and works will not work since the disinheritance is based on sinful works. In order to
respond to scholarship that seeks to counter to the misthological interpretation herein, one will have to look
somewhere other than Corner’s corner. So let us return to Brown.
        Brown assumes that verses such as 1Cor 4:8; 1Cor 6:3; 2Tim 2:12; and Rev 20:4-6 teach that “all believers
will reign with Christ in some capacity” in the future millennial kingdom203 and that in Col 3:24 all believers “will
receive the reward of the inheritance.”204 (At least Brown does have this limited interaction with the Colossian
text.) But his appeal to 1Cor 4:8 proves nothing; his presumption that 1Cor 6:3 and Rev 20:4-6 apply to all
believers is unwarranted; and his citation of 2Tim 2:12 contradicts his own position, since the reign is explicitly
limited in this verse to believers who overcome (i.e., endure).
        The best that Brown can do with Col 3:24 is to reduce it to an unmerited possession that the slaves will
receive whether or not they are faithful. Thus, he brushes aside the merit implied by the context and demanded by
the word reward, stating that the slaves will receive the reward in spite of their position as slaves. Of course they
will! Being a slave will not prevent them from receiving the reward. This is clear in Eph 6:8 (another text that is
strangely missing from Corner’s discussion). Even in this Ephesian passage, what is received is repayment:
“Whatever good thing each one does, he will be repaid (komizo) this back by the Lord, whether slave or free”
(TM). It should not be thought that this means that one is only repaid good. On the contrary, the Colossian parallel
clarifies that this is not the case, where Paul warns slaves: “He who does wrong will be repaid (komizo) the wrong
which he has done, and that without partiality” (Col 3:25; TM). This makes Paul’s exhortation comprehensible in
Eph 6:5 that their service to Christ should be rendered “with fear and trembling.” Paul’s point is not merely that
Christian slaves will receive the reward despite their position as slaves. Emphatically to the contrary, they will
receive this indiscriminate payment despite their status as slaves because of their service, and this payback can
either be good or bad:
          23
             Whatever you do, do your work [ergazomai] heartily [lit. from the soul], as for the Lord rather
          than for men; 24 knowing that from the Lord you will receive [apolambano] the reward [antapodosis]
          of the inheritance [kleronomia]. It is the Lord Christ whom you serve. 25 For he who does wrong
          [adikeo] will receive the consequences [komizo] of the wrong which he has done [adikeo], and that
          without partiality. (Col 3:23-25)

       Paul is explicitly teaching these believers that the inheritance is a reward: “Work…for…the reward of the
inheritance.” For that matter, komizo can be translated, just as well, as be rewarded with as can apolambano.*
Those who do wrong will be rewarded with the consequences of the wrong they have done. The inheritance is their
paycheck. Most people would not appreciate it if their employer handed them their paycheck at the end of the
workweek and said, “Here is your gift.” It would come across as an insult, in which the employer was accusing the
employee of having loafed all week and having done nothing to deserve the check. Paul is not picturing God as a
lenient boss who will allow lazy believers to loaf on the job. To the contrary, unrighteous believers can expect
negative consequences if they fail to do right.† The consequences are not inconsequential. The parallelism is
obvious:

           •   The good worker (ergazomai) will receive (apolambano; i.e., be rewarded with) the positive.
           •   The wrongdoer (adikeo) will receive (komizo; i.e., be rewarded with) the negative (adikeo).

       This repetition of adikeo should not fall on deaf ears. Christians who behave unrighteously will not inherit
the kingdom. Paul affirmed this in the Corinthian text above with a combination of adikeo and adikos; here he
repeats the verb (adikeo): “He who is doing unrighteously shall receive what he did unrighteously” (YLT).

Rom 4:4
       There is nothing hard to understand about these sentences in Col 3:23-25. A clear text like this should be
given primacy in understanding other texts pertaining to inheriting the kingdom. The meaning of these Greek
words is certainly easy to illustrate from Paul’s writings: “Now to the one who works [ergazomai], his reward
[misthos] is not reckoned as a gift [charis], but as a debt [opheilema]” (Rom 4:4; TM). If it is a reward, then it is
not a gift. If it is a gift, then it is not a reward. What is given in response to works is regarded as payment of a debt.

*
    Also compare discussion of tugchano in Misthological Worthiness, 73. Also see 1Pet 1:9 in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
†
    Also see Repaid (komizo), 664.
Page 124                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                                                             205
Opheilema can also be translated, just as well, as what is owed. The one who works is owed the payment. The
inheritance of the kingdom is thus a reward that is owed to the worker who meets the qualifications. God has
graciously given us the opportunity to put Him in our debt and earn the inheritance. God did not owe us the
opportunity to work for this inheritance. But having given us the opportunity, He graciously has obligated Himself
to pay us the inheritance as a payment if we qualify on the basis of our works.*

       Dollywood Illustration
       By way of illustration, one year in which my boys were memorizing the Pastoral Epistles, I told them that if
they finished memorizing the epistles and quoted them for the AWANA program before AWANA ended that year
that I would take them to Dollywood amusement park as a reward. They did. As a result, I was obligated to take
them to the park as reward in response to their meritorious work. In this obligation, I indebted myself to my
children. Now suppose, I had said instead, “Boys, I’ll take you Dollywood this fall. All you have to do is just
believe I’ll take you.” And they had said, “Sure dad.” I likewise would still have been obligated to take them. But
in this latter obligation, I would not have indebted myself to my children because they would not have done
anything to deserve the gift. When God offers us a gift and conditions its reception simply on whether we believe,
He is obligated to give us that gift if we believe. Yet He is not indebted to us because we did nothing to deserve the
gift. Conversely, when God offers us a payment if we work, He is obligated to pay us if we work. This latter
obligation of a paycheck is owed to us because of our work; the former obligation of a gift is not.†

       A Debt is Owed
       On the matter of debt and obligation, texts describing sin as a debt are familiar passages (Mt 6:12, 18:27,32;
Col 2:14). However, the word used of debt (opheilema) in Mt 6:12 is the same as that used in Rom 4:4. In fact,
these are the only two verses in which the word occurs in the NT. In one passage, believers are the debtors to God;
in the other, God is the potential debtor to believers. Rewards are always based on debt. Negative rewards are
based on debt we owe God. Positive rewards are based on the debt God owes us. Nevertheless, negative rewards
can also be described as what we earn from God (Rom 6:23). We owe God positive obedience. If we respond with
positive works, we earn a positive reward. If we respond with negative works, we earn a negative reward. God’s
repayment is always a reward based on our works. Our works morally obligate God to either punish us or reward
us. Positive works obligate God because of His promises rather than due to any intrinsic value of the work itself.
God will be faithful to His obligation either positively to reward us or negatively to punish us. God will “repay
everyman according to his works” (Rom 2:6; TM; cp. 1Cor 3:8).
       The thief dying on the cross said, “For we receive [apolambano] the due reward of our deeds” (Lk 23:41;
KJV). John warned, “Watch yourselves, that you might not lose what we have accomplished, but that you may
receive [apolambano] a full reward [misthos]” (2Jn 1:8). What believers receive in these contexts is what they are
due on the basis of their actions. Writing to believers, Paul says, “For we must all appear before the judgment seat
of Christ, that each one may be recompensed [komizo] for his deeds in the body, according to what he has done,
whether good or bad” (2Cor 10:5). Those believers who serve the Lord well will be rewarded with the inheritance
of the kingdom at the Judgment Seat of Christ. Those believers who serve badly will be treated badly as a result.

Syllogistic Summation
        Paul gives no indication that believers can anticipate receiving this positive paycheck if they fail to work for
it. He teaches that this practice-based inheritance deals with rewards in heaven (Col 3:24). Not all believers will
merit this reward. Some will work hard and earn it; others will do wrong and reap wrong as a result. Consequently,
it must be concluded that a believer’s ontological change and legal position in Christ does not necessarily result in
practical sanctification. Soteriological justification does not always result in practical sanctification. A syllogism is
a logical deduction that necessarily follows from two premises. To summarize syllogistically, this deduction may
restate it as follows:

           1. This inheritance is a reward.
           2. Heaven is not a reward.
           3. Therefore, this inheritance is not heaven.


*
    In condign merit, God graciously obligates Himself to reward us via His promise to do so.
†
    See Beggar Illustration, 206.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                            Page 125
       The reason these believers are exhorted to work heartily is because they will be rewarded for doing so. Their
actions will have consequences. This inheritance is a reward they earn based on what they do. It is not a reward
that Christ has earned for them and offers to them freely as a gift. Paul acknowledges twice, in the same verse, that
believers may do wrong (adikeo) in Col 3:25. This is the same verb used by Paul above in 1Cor 6:8. He uses this
verb twice in consecutive verses (1Cor 6:7-8) to warn these believers that if they are doing wrong, the consequence
of their doing wrong will be the failure to “receive the reward of the inheritance.” This is the same warning Paul
gave to other believers (1Cor 6:9; Gal 5:21; Eph 5:5). Lack of personal, practical righteousness on the part of
believers will disqualify them from receiving the inheritance as a reward.
       Brown’s attempt to sweep Col 3:24 under the rug is completely unsuccessful. Paul clearly teaches that the
inheritance is a reward rather than a gift. So how does Zeller deal with this passage in Col 3:23-25, which is so
clearly antithetical to his thesis? He completely ignores it in both of his articles that are supposedly refuting the
GRAPE view of inheriting the kingdom!206 To put it mildly, Zeller appears to be less than straightforward with the
FG misthological evidence offered from the Scripture pertaining to the reward of the inheritance. To teach that the
inheritance is heaven is to make heaven a reward and thus to teach salvation by works. The Scripture teaches that
the inheritance of the kingdom is a reward, not a gift. Closing one’s eyes to the evidence will not make it go away.
The Bible confirms numerous times that God will pay every person according to his or her works. In the citations
within the following illustration, a variety of Greek words that mean pay or works have been translated with
respective consistency. Verses stating that judgment is based on works have also been added.
                                           Illustration 54. Payday Someday
• For the Son of Man is going to come in the glory of His Father with His angels; and will then pay every man
  according to his works (Mt 16:27).

• Who will pay to every man according to his works (Rom 2:6).

• For we [believers] must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may be paid back for his
  works in the body, according to what he has done, whether good or bad. (2Cor 5:10).

• Therefore it is not surprising if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness; whose end
  shall be according to their works. (2Cor 11:15)

• Alexander the coppersmith did me much harm; the Lord will pay him back according to his works
  (2Tim4:14).

• And if you address as Father the One who impartially judges according to each man’s work, conduct
  yourselves in fear during the time of your stay upon earth (1Pet 1:17).

• And I will kill her children with pestilence; and all the churches will know that I am He who searches the minds
  and hearts; and I will pay each one of you [believers] according to your works (Rev 2:23).

• Pay her back even as she has paid, and pay her back double according to her works; in the cup which she has
  mixed, mix twice as much for her (Rev 18:6).

• And I saw the dead, the great and the small, standing before the throne, and books were opened; and another
  book was opened, which is the book of life; and the dead were judged from the things which were written in the
  books, according to their works (Rev 20:12).

• And the sea gave up the dead which were in it, and death and Hades gave up the dead which were in them; and
  they were judged, every one of them according to their works (Rev 20:13).

• Behold, I am coming quickly, and My reward is with Me, to pay every man according to his works
  (Rev 22:12).

      Judgment is always based on works. According to Johnson, “the thought of God judging every person
according to his works is found as many as forty-two times in the Bible.”207 Unfortunately, this has led some
(Calvinists) to conclude that everything we do is a work. They seem to have a picture of us standing before God
Page 126                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
and His reviewing everything we have done—at the very least to determine if what we did was a work. The truth of
the matter, though, is that our works already will have been recorded. God is not going to have to play a motion
picture of our actions in order to determine which actions are rewardable. Non-works are not going to be bothered
with at the judgment. God knows our non-works to be sure, just as He knows the number of hairs on our head. Yet
judgment is not going to deal with our daily hair count nor will there be a tally of how many times we ordered
mustard on our burger.*
        Everyone (unbeliever and believer alike) will be judged on the basis of their works and paid on the basis of
their works. Both will be disqualified on the basis of their works from inheriting the kingdom. Faith plus works are
necessary to qualify for this reward. Therefore, those lacking the necessary works will fail to inherit it whether they
are lost or saved. This is not to say that a morally lost person can inherit the kingdom. Such a person is missing the
necessary prerequisite—faith. Paul is stressing the fact that the inheritance is a reward based on the believer’s
performance. In counter distinction, by trying to turn the reward into a gift and by attempting to deny the obvious,
it is as if Brown is looking Paul in the eye and boldly refuting Paul by saying, “It just isn’t so.” In denying the
distinction between entering and inheriting the kingdom, Brown is forced to deny the distinction between reward
and gift. Nevertheless, Brown’s work is useful in that it shows the logical outcome of rejecting the distinction
between inheriting and entering. In order to avoid such erroneous conclusions (such as those espoused by Brown),
the distinction between inherit and enter must be maintained.
         The kingdom (basileia) is not to be understood as strictly soteriological in nature. Specifically, in the NT
basileia is used in a general sense 50% of the time, in a soteriological sense 18%, and in a misthological sense
32%.† The misthological sense, in which only some believers will possess the kingdom, is displayed in numerous
ways. Inherit is only one of the many words used in this connection. In certain contexts, kingdom and inheritance
(and its synonym portion) must be understood to be a reward to be rendered at the resurrection. The believer will
never come into judgment where the issue is soteriological life versus soteriological death, that is, life in the
kingdom versus eternal death in hell (Jn 5:24). Even so, every believer will be judged as to what portion (position
of authority) he or she may have in the kingdom.

FG Soteriological View
       Surprisingly perhaps, one of the most interesting defenses of the soteriological view of the inheritance in
Col 3:24 that this author has seen has not come from LS but from FG. At the GES chat site, which the author
frequented, a FG advocate defended the soteriological view of the inheritance with two arguments. I will amplify
this FG objection and briefly respond to FG friends who may hold a similar view.

       First Argument
       The first argument that may be used to advance a FG soteriological understanding of Col 3:24 is based on
the future tense of the verb will receive (apolambano). According to this view, the fact that the inheritance is future
indicates that it is a gift. Since we already have received such membership by virtue of our new birth, what is to be
received in the future is likewise a result of our new birth, not our efforts. We are to work out of gratitude for the
inheritance we will receive by virtue of our new birth. The inheritance is a consequence of our new birth rather
than a consequence of our works. Our works are simply a means of expressing our gratitude for what we freely will
receive by virtue of new birth.

       Rebuttal
       My rebuttal to this first soteric argument is to point out that such a perspective simply assumes that
inheritance of the kingdom is equated with membership in that kingdom. Although it may be acknowledged that all
believers freely have soteriological entrance into the kingdom, such entrance should not be equated with
inheritance of the kingdom when that inheritance is conditioned on works, as it is in this passage. That the
inheritance in this verse is the consequence of one’s works is proven by the fact that the outcome is called a
reward/payment (antapodosis) rather than a gift. The receiving of eschatological rewards is properly referred to as
a future event, so the future tense in no way helps a soteriological understanding. The future tense makes sense


*
  For a discussion dealing with what is work in which the author’s mustard illustration is repeatedly featured, see “What is Work” in
Soteric and Mistholic Faith. The author has used this illustration to such an extent in that discussion that it could be considered a code
name for misthologically neutral actions.
†
  See Illustration 273. Classical Pie Chart of Kingdom, 765.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                                  Page 127
when speaking of future rewards. The future aspect is consistent with misthology. Conversely, it makes no sense to
say that we do not yet have a relationship with God or that this relationship is a consequence of our performance.

       Second Argument
       The next FG argument used to advance a soteriological understanding of Col 3:24 is based on understanding
the middle voice of the verb will receive (apolambano) to designate the inheritance as the recovery of something
that has been lost. The lost have lost their relationship with God; this relationship will be restored for believers. Or
it might be argued from the context that the slaves’ masters were withholding the rewards/payment that they, as
masters, should have been paying to their slaves for the services they rendered. So Paul assures these slaves that in
the future such inequities would be rectified. After all, Paul immediately proceeds to tell their believing masters to
give their slaves what is right: “Masters, grant to your slaves justice and fairness, knowing that you too have a
Master in heaven” (Col 4:1). Certainly, the withholding of payment was a problem in Paul’s day: “Behold, the pay
of the laborers who mowed your fields, and which has been withheld by you, cries out against you; and the outcry
of those who did the harvesting has reached the ears of the Lord of Sabaoth” (Jam 5:6).

       Rebuttal
       My initial response to this second soteriological alternative (that of withheld wages) is to note that it actually
refutes the soteriological argument. I have no objection to this second approach in that it accords well with the
misthological understanding of the inheritance. The payment guaranteed by God, despite being a potentially
withheld temporal payment, is based on the slave’s works and thus is not soteriological. To restate the quandary
encountered by the soteriological advocates, my rebuttal of the first argument makes the soteriological alternative
impossible, since a soteriological relationship is not a reward based on works. Second, we already have received a
soteriological relationship with God, but the fact that this restoration (if that is what it is) awaits the future nullifies
the soteriological understanding, since believers already have a soteriological relationship with God. Third, this
alternate soteriological argument contradicts the first soteriological argument. The first argument was that what is
rendered is not based on works. The second alternative takes the premise that the repayment is for services
rendered and is thus based on works. These believing slaves will be repaid because of the works they have done.
These two soteriological arguments nullify one another.

       Middle Voice
       Moreover, the soteriological appeal to the middle voice as indicating the recovery of something lost is
highly suspect in the present passage. Granted, Thayer does put apolambano in the category: “to take again or
back, to recover.” But even this lexicon still acknowledges that it means: “to receive by way of retribution.” I have
no quarrel with this approach, in that it coincides with the contextual considerations pointed out above. Even so,
this recovering-by-retribution would be rewards-by-works and thus a misthological rather than soteriological
interpretation.
       Although one could adopt this lexical understanding of the middle voice and exegetically be consistent with
the points made herein, this recovery understanding is doubtful in this particular verse. BDAG acknowledges that
apolambano could mean recover or get back something previously possessed, but it does not list Col 3:24 under
this semantic range. Rather, BDAG lists this verse under the definition for its entry simply meaning: “To obtain
something from a source, receive.” It further clarifies that this usage is used especially in regard to receiving
wages. BDAG also provides a clarifying example: “They served for wages [misthos]…They said it was only just
that they should receive [apolambano] their wages [misthos] before they departed (Herodotus 8.137.4).”
       In Herodotus, what was received (apolambano) was a wage—a misthos and thus misthological—which
those who served their king had a right to expect to receive. In contrast to these servants in Herodotus, who failed
to receive that to which they were entitled when they served the king, Paul assures these Christian slaves that they
will indeed receive their wages from their King if they serve Him. That which is received is earned as a wage.
Correspondingly, the Liddell-and-Scott (hereafter L&S) definition to receive what is one’s due seems to be the idea
most fitting for Col 3:24, which is again the same definition that encountered for opheilema in Rom 4:4 above.
Those who work will receive this inheritance as what is due as a result of their works. It is not a gift! It is earned.
As to the middle voice itself, I have no problem understanding Paul as saying, “You will earn for yourselves”
(reflexive middle), or “you yourselves will earn” (intensive middle).
Page 128                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
Summary
       The parallel between Col 3:24 and Col 3:25 is obvious. Komizo is used in synonymous parallel with
apolambano in these two verses (receive = repaid). What is received is a payment, not gift. Comparing the twice
repeated usage of adikeo in Col 3:25 with that in 1Cor 6:7-8 is very beneficial. In 1Cor 6:7-8, the unrighteous are
believers, and Paul is warning these believers that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom. Likewise, Paul
urges believing slaves to do right because the righteous will inherit the kingdom as a reward (Col 3:22-25).
                                        Illustration 55. Faith + Works = Reward ≠ Gift




        When my boys were young, I bought them toys that demonstrated the fallacy of trying to make a round peg
fit into a square socket. Some theologians need to go back to the basic building blocks and stop trying to make
salvation apart-from-works fit into salvation-by-works. Conditionalists think that because works are a natural
expression of faith, faith and works can be enjoined to result in the same conclusion so that it is not incompatible to
teach that we ultimately are saved by a faith that expresses itself in works. Multiple fallacies, however, are
embodied by such reasoning.
        First, although it would be natural to assume that all believers will perform some good works, this is not the
point being made.* Paul is not telling the Colossian slaves that if they perform well one day out of the year, they
will be qualified to inherit the kingdom. On the contrary, they must be characterized as working hard on a daily
basis. Hardly working will not qualify for heartily working. Just as sharing one French-fry from one’s happy meal
in James 2 does not qualify one for the misthological salvation discussed there,† so heartily working one day a year
and hardly working the rest of the year will not qualify one for the misthological inheritance here.
        Second, in the Colossian passage works are linked implicitly with faith, but these works result in a reward
rather than a gift. Paul tells these saved slaves to work for the Lord, knowing that they will be rewarded as a result.
But how do they know this to be true? Because they believe Paul’s teaching. They have never seen the Lord render
this reward; nevertheless, they are expected to work for this unseen reward. This knowing comes from believing.208
In this context, Paul implicitly combines believing with working as not being inevitable behavior but rewardable
behavior. For example, I had a weed eater with a round shaft that went into a square sprocket that fit into the round
head of my weed eater. Whenever I took it apart to put more string in it, I had to place the shaft back into the
square sprocket; otherwise, the weed eater would not work. Even so, in the above illustration, the round shaft of
persuasion (i.e., faith) must be placed into the square sprocket of action (i.e., work) to reap a reward as the
conclusion. Those who identify the conclusion as salvation from eternal damnation on the basis of faith plus works
are teaching a damned version of the gospel (Gal 1:6-9).
        Third, it cannot be assumed that just because good works are the natural expression of a believer’s
regenerate nature that such works will be expressed inevitably. Theoretically, some believers may never do
anything that amounts to a good work. Practically, some believers may never do enough good work to qualify for
inheriting the kingdom. Frequently, some believers may stop doing enough good works to qualify for inheriting the
kingdom. To further illustrate, my weed eater eventually stopped working, not because I did not have the shaft in
the sprocket or because I could not crank it, but because the shaft would not turn. I could crank it. The weed eater
itself had internal life in that sense of the word. But the shaft was dead. It would not turn. Some believers are like
that weed eater. They have spiritual life but a dead, non-productive faith.‡ I also had a car like that when I was in
seminary. My car died in the sense of performing any productive work. I could crank my car. It came to life in
turning over the engine and revving up the engine. The engine was fine. The car had internal life, but it would not
move. The transmission was dead. Dead weed eaters and dead cars can wind up in a junk pile even though they
have a running engine. They are good for nothing except to be used as junk. Dead believers likewise wind up in the

*
  See Theory of Misthological Relativity, 687.
†
  See illustration of “Simple Justification by Faith and Works” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
‡
  See illustration of “Three Types of Faith” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection                                                              Page 129
outer darkness. Such believers cannot be thrown into hell since they have eternal/internal life. Yet they cannot
inherit the kingdom because they do not have the performance that qualifies them for exalted service, so they are
good for nothing except for lowly service (cp. Mt 5:13).*
        Fourth, Paul teaches that salvation from eternal damnation from the beginning is apart from works and
continues to be apart from works throughout the interim. According to some translations, such as the NAS,
Eph 2:8-9 uses the past tense for salvation: “For by grace you have been saved through faith; and that not of
yourselves, it is the gift of God; not as a result of works, that no one should boast.” Yet other translations render it
as a present tense: “You are saved” (cp. CSB, DBY, DRA, KJV, MRD, NET, PNT, RWB, TNT, WEB, YLT). The
BBE expresses the present result as: “By grace you have salvation through faith.” Both are correct. The verb sozo
is in the prefect tense meaning that the action has taken place in the past (thus you have been saved) and the result
still continues into the present (thus you still are saved). Such salvation continues to be by faith apart from any
works. You have been saved and still are saved by faith apart from works. Soteriologically to condition either the
reception or retention of such salvation upon works is to teach another kind of salvation.

                                          Out-Resurrection in Lk 14:13-14
        Of the remaining secondary parallels citied initially at the beginning of this chapter,† three out of four
already have been antithetically charted.‡ The description of the resurrection in the parables of (1) the wheat and
tares, (2) the dragnet, and (3) the sheep and goats is correspondingly antithetical. The fourth passage, the Lukan
parallel, provides a fitting conclusion in light of its obvious connection to the discussion above concerning
receiving a paycheck at the time of the resurrection.
        12
          And He also went on to say to the one who had invited Him, “When you give a luncheon or a
        dinner, do not invite your friends or your brothers or your relatives or rich neighbors, lest they also
        invite you in return, and repayment come to you. 13 But when you give a reception, invite the poor,
        the crippled, the lame, the blind, 14 and you will be blessed, since they do not have the means to repay
        you; for you will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous” (Lk 14:12-14).

        This resurrection of the righteous, also known as the resurrection of the just, is the resurrection of all
believers, but only believers. They have been justified by faith. This resurrection occurs at the time of the rapture,
to be discussed in the following chapter. The person whom Jesus is instructing as to how to earn rewards in this
resurrection of believers is the religious leader who had invited Him into his home (Lk 14:1). Jesus is addressing
this one Pharisee (you is singular), not all the lawyers and Pharisees who had been invited to the dinner (Lk 14:3).
The most natural conclusion is that this Pharisee is saved. He is probably a secret believer (cf. Jn 3:1-2; 12:42-43;
19:38). His participation in the resurrection of the just is not conditioned on his practical righteousness in helping
the poor, but his portion (in the sense of repayment) in that resurrection is so conditioned. He will take part in that
resurrection because of his positional righteousness, yet what part he takes in that resurrection will be based on his
practical righteousness. It is a resurrection to life, but it will be abundant life for those repaid (antapodidomi) in
this manner. His performance determines how rich his experience of life will be within the kingdom.
        Perhaps the man was a vocal (rather than genuine) believer, but in view of the Johannine passages cited
above, this seems highly unlikely. Hypothetically, the possibility that the man may have been an unbeliever may be
entertained. If the rich young ruler was lost (which generally is presumed to be the case§), then this may be a
parallel account in which Jesus soteriologically uses misthology. In order to gain rewards in heaven, the rich young
ruler would have to change his attitude about how to earn those rewards. He would have to believe Jesus’ teachings
about rewards. However, in order to believe Jesus’ teachings about rewards in the kingdom, he first would have to
believe what Jesus taught about Himself and about entrance into the kingdom. He would have to accept the fact
that Jesus was not merely a good teacher from God, but God’s Christ who does indeed have the power to forgive
sins and grant eternal life to those who believe Him to be the Christ. The doctrine of rewards can even be used
today to lead unbelievers to faith in Christ. At the core of the human personality resides the question, “What’s in it
for me?” The answer to that question is, “Entrance into heaven if you trust in Jesus as the Christ who gives eternal
life to all who simply trust Him for it, and rulership of this planet if you then follow Him as your Lord.”

*
  See endnote 609.
†
  See Introduction, 71.
‡
  See Illustration 48. Antithetical Contrast of Polar Opposites, 106.
§
  See Sell all to Enter (Mt 19:16-21) in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 130                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       A person who is highly motivated toward prestige in the kingdom has ample reason to trust Jesus for
entrance into that kingdom. As King of that kingdom, Jesus has the right to lay down the law as to what is required
for entrance into His kingdom, as well as the requirements for rewards in that kingdom. For the man to accept what
Jesus tells him about the requirement for rewards in the kingdom and yet reject what Jesus tells him about the
requirement for entrance into the kingdom would be utterly illogical. Logically, Jesus can use this ruler’s desire to
be great in the kingdom as an incentive to trust Him for entrance into the kingdom.
       Even those who do not hold the author’s perspective concerning the rapture or the resurrection should not
find this interpretation too objectionable. For the sake of argument, let us assume momentarily that Jesus is
referring to a general resurrection here in Luke and thus to a joint judgment of both the saved and the lost at the
same time, such as what many people believe happens at the Sheep and Goat Judgment before the millennium and
at the Great White Throne after the millennium. Even so, what determines if one is saved from the Lake of Fire is
not one’s performance but one’s position—who the person is, not what the individual does. The soteriological
question is, “Are you a sheep or a goat?” not, “Are you a bad sheep or a good sheep?”
       Regardless of full agreement concerning eschatology, one still should be able to perceive that this Lukan
Pharisee is encouraged to become a good sheep rather than a bad sheep so that he may be rewarded, not so that he
may escape hell. Otherwise, his salvation from hell would be based on his performance, which is refuted by the
NT. Correspondingly, at the Great White Throne Judgment, the soteriological question is, “Have you received the
free gift of life as attested by having your name in the Book of Life?” not, “What deeds do you have recorded in
the Books of Works?”* Jesus is encouraging the Pharisee to perform good works, not in order to have his name in
the Book of Life, but to have good works recorded in the Books of Works.
       Jesus tells this believing Pharisee that he can expect payment, not from the poor, but from the Lord. Since
this payment is based on works, it is a reward and most definitely not a gift. Brown’s inability to distinguish
between a reward and a gift is an unfortunate malady that affects many interpreters. Others acknowledge the
difference but fail to grasp the importance of misthological teaching. They respond that it is wrong to expect
payment. But if they are right, then Jesus is wrong. Jesus encourages believers to expect payment. Jesus is teaching
this believer that he can expect payment and that the expectation of payment is to be a motivating factor for
showing love toward the poor.†

                                                        Conclusion
       In the previous chapter, it was shown that a physical resurrection of believers occurs before the millennium.
In the present chapter, it has been shown that a subgroup of believers experience an out-resurrection out from this
group of believers. This subgroup will be blessed with rulership of the new order. The writers of the NT do not
take it for granted that all believers automatically or inevitably will achieve a misthological portion in the
resurrection of believers. The participation of believers in that resurrection is assured, but having a portion in it is
dependent on their performance: showing love for the poor, running the race, striving for the prize, living morally
pure lives, being ethically righteous, and enduring hardship. This portion is not merely equated with having an
inheritance within the kingdom (which may be true of all believers), but with inheriting the kingdom itself. Those
believers who inherit the kingdom (inheritors) will be rulers of the kingdom. Even though the out-resurrection
terminology is found only in one passage, this misthological theology concerning a special status at the time of the
resurrection is taught in a variety of passages ranging from those teaching co-heirship or co-rulership to those
promising a misthological resurrection for those who move beyond judicial righteousness to experiential
righteousness.
       Warnings are addressed to genuine believers that they will fail to exercise the heirship associated with
mature son status if they fail to press on to maturity. They cannot misthologically inherit the earth if they cannot
temporally overcome the world. The reasonable anticipation is that there will be losers and winners among
Christians. Some believers will win the prize; some believers will be disqualified and lose out on the privileges
they could have had otherwise. Deductive reasoning leads to the conclusion that believers may be grouped broadly
into two subgroups: overcomers and subcomers. If, as will be demonstrated, the outer darkness involves a similar
misthological division of believers into two groups, then it can be accurately said that Scripture presents the
eternally, unconditionally secure believer with only two basic misthological options at opposite ends of the
misthological spectrum: out-resurrection or outer darkness.


*
    See “Appendix 1” in Breaking the Rocking Horse.
†
    See NT Teaches Rewards as Incentive to Love, 746.
                                            Chapter 4.
                             Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)
                                                       Introduction
        In the study herein of the millennium, it was concluded that the second coming must occur before the
millennium. Thus, the premillennial option is the one that will be used in aiding our hermeneutical endeavor in
interpreting passages pertaining to the eschatological dimensions of the outer darkness. Some preliminary evidence
for a pretribulational position was also noted. Notwithstanding, further consideration of this issue will be prudent,
not only to firmly establish this eschatology as the correct basis for interpreting the context of the outer darkness,
but to interact with implications of the outer darkness as well.
        For example, in the last two chapters considerable evidence was provided for concluding that a physical
resurrection of all believers occurs before the millennium and that a further out-resurrection awaits some of these
believers who are selected out from this general group of resurrected believers. This subgroup is granted rulership
of the kingdom. This leads to the anticipation that those believers who are disqualified for the out-resurrection may
be subjected to the outer darkness instead. Before pursuing a vigorous defense of this assertion, a few other
eschatological details should be discussed first. Although the rationale has been provided for believing that all
believers are resurrected before the millennium, the next major question to be addressed is, “Do believers go
through the great tribulation?”

                                      Four Basic Views of the Tribulation
                                          Illustration 56. Posttribulational Rapture




        Posttribulationalists, pictured above, believe that the rapture will come after the tribulation. In their view,
the church must go through the tribulation and then be raptured to meet the Lord. But what happens after we meet
the Lord in the air? Who does the U-turn, the church or the Lord? Regardless of the position taken, someone does a
U-turn in all the standard eschatological models.* Posttribulationalists believe that the rapture of the church occurs
at the same time as the revelation of Christ; consequently, the church does the U-turn. Like the amillennialists and
postmillennialists (discussed in the chapter dealing with the millennium), posttribulationalists believe that Jesus
comes to take us back to earth. In that case, what is the point of the rapture? Why does the Lord want us to make
a U-turn?


*
 For an attractive alternative pretribulational model which does not pose a U-turn, see “No U-Turn” in Predestination and the Open
View.
Page 132                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                       Illustration 57. Midtribulational Rapture




       Midtribulationalists believe that the rapture will come during (the middle of) the tribulation, as shown
above. Thus, they believe that the church will have to go through the first part of the tribulation. Yet the church
will be removed from earth before the second half of the tribulation, which would be the worst part of the
tribulation. This latter half of the tribulation is what they would consider the great tribulation.
                                       Illustration 58. Pretribulational Rapture




      Pretribulationalists, as represented above, believe that the rapture will occur before the tribulation, so the
church will not have to go through any part of the tribulation. The typical, or at least older, pretribulational view is
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                                         Page 133
that the Lord comes to take us back to heaven. This typical representation is used herein so that comparison can be
made more easily with other standard views. However, a number of pretribulationalists today, including the present
writer, would follow Hodges in modifying that model so that no U-turn is made in the pretribulationalist model.*
Nevertheless, in either model, the Lord does not come all the way to earth, because He is not coming to set up His
millennial kingdom on earth at that time. Instead, He comes to take His saints to their heavenly home.
                                                  Illustration 59. Partial Rapture




       Partial rapturists also believe that the rapture will occur before the tribulation, but they believe that only part
of the church will be raptured. Only faithful believers will be raptured and not go through the tribulation; unfaithful
believers will have to go through at least part of the tribulation. Partial rapturists also believe that a number of
raptures will occur for faithful believers during the tribulation.

                                                            Passages
       Three primary passages of Scripture describe the rapture: Jn 14:1-3; 1Cor 15:50-58; 1Thess 4:13-18. Of
these three, the first passage deals with a promise given by Jesus before He left.

Jn 14:1-3
     1
       Let not your heart be troubled; believe in God, believe also in Me. 2In My Father’s house are many
     dwelling places; if it were not so, I would have told you; for I go to prepare a place for you. 3And if I
     go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you to Myself; that where I am,
     there you may be also.

       In this passage, it is easy to see why the Lord would make the U-turn. He comes to take us back to heaven
with Him (in all standard eschatology models).† In an eschatology course which the author took in seminary, the
professor criticized the pretribulational position as nonsensical since it pictured a U-turn. Evidently, the seminary
professor had not thought through the implications of his own position very thoroughly in that his own position
required a U-turn. There are only two basic options. (1) The Lord comes from heaven to take us back to heaven,
and He makes the U-turn. (2) Or the Lord comes from heaven to take us back to earth, and we do the U-turn.
*
    For an alternative pretribulational model which does not pose a U-turn, see “No U-Turn” in Predestination and the Open View.
†
    For an alternative pretribulational model which does not pose a U-turn, see “No U-Turn” in Predestination and the Open View.
Page 134                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
Certainly, it makes more sense for the Lord to come from heaven and take us from earth in order to take us back to
heaven than it does for the Lord come from heaven to take us from earth only to take us immediately back to earth.
       Further, if the posttribulational view is correct, then how can Jn 14:1-3 have fulfillment? Jesus said that He
was going to prepare a place for us. But where? He explicitly gives the answer to that question by saying that it is
where He is and where His Father dwells. Where is the Father? Heaven. Where is Jesus? Heaven. The point of the
passage is not that Christ will come to dwell with the believer but that the believer will go to dwell with Christ.
Some posttribulationalists claim that this promise by Christ finds its fulfillment when a believer dies. In doing so,
they make the promise of Jn 14:1-3 a funeral promise rather than a promise of Jesus’ coming again.
       In accordance with the nuptial imagery of the passage, however, the groom would come to take the bride
back to his house. The bride does not take the groom to her house.* Jesus is coming to take His Bride back to His
father’s home in heaven. This imagery thus rules out the posttribulational view. Still, contrary to many, it does not
rule out the partial rapture position.† The partial rapture position and midtribulationism must be rejected for other
considerations below.

1Thess 4:13-18
     13
       But we do not want you to be uninformed, brethren, about those who are asleep [refers to their
     bodies not to their souls or to soul sleep], that you may not grieve, as do the rest who have no hope.
     14
        For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who have
     fallen asleep in Jesus. 15For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive, and
     remain until the coming of the Lord, shall not precede those who have fallen asleep. 16For the Lord
     Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and with the trumpet
     of God; and the dead [those asleep] in Christ shall rise first [physical resurrection]. 17Then we who
     are alive and remain shall be caught up [raptured] together with them in the clouds to meet the Lord
     in the air, and thus we shall always be with the Lord. 18Therefore comfort one another with these
     words.

       Even aside from the nuptial imagery of Jn 14:1-3, the timing of the event in Jn 14:1-3 appears to be the
same as that promised by Jesus concerning His return to earth for believers as described in 1Thess 4. If
1Thess 4:13-18 is picturing an event that happens at the end of the tribulation, then Paul’s application of the
passage seems almost to be in error. If the posttribulational position is correct, then should not Paul have been
urging the believers to warn one another with his words, like Jesus did in Mk 13, rather than comfort one another
as he states in 1Thess 4:18? Either Paul has a very strange application in 1Thess 4, or posttribulationalists have a
very strange interpretation of the passage. However, by proceeding past the chapter break between chapters four
and five of 1Thessalonians to consider Paul’s ongoing elucidation concerning the timing of the above event, pre-
tribulationalism will be left standing as the sole winner of the tribulational bout.

1Thess 1:10
        Posttribulationalism, midtribulationalism, and partial tribulationalism move from being improbable to
impossible in light of certain key passages. Pentecost says that there are three passages which “definitely promise
the church a removal before the seventieth week” (i.e., before the tribulation): 1Thess 1:9-10; 5:9; Rev 3:10.209 The
latter passage in Revelation is open to debate, but Hodges demonstrates conclusively that a full pretribulational
rapture must be affirmed on the basis of the Thessalonian passages.210 The first section of this extended teaching on
the rapture, 1Thess 4:13-18, describes the event of the rapture. The second section, 1Thess 5:1-11, describes the
time of the rapture. This division was anticipated in 1Thess 1:10 where, in reference to two future events, Paul
states,

         Wait for His Son from heaven, whom He raised from the dead, that is Jesus, who delivers us from
         the wrath to come.

      The first part of v. 10 describes our current waiting for the future coming of His Son from heaven. The
second part of v. 10 describes our deliverance from the future wrath. The first part of 1Thess 1:10 affirms the
Lord’s return; the second part affirms that the Lord’s coming saves us from the coming wrath. We are to wait for

*
    See Taken, 337.
†
    See Many Mansions Prepared for You, 602.
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                                Page 135
the coming of His Son (in the rapture), which will deliver us from the coming wrath (of the tribulation). A
paraphrase of 1Thess 1:10 would be: “His coming Son will deliver us from His coming wrath.” With this brief
overview of the context, we can now proceed to the text of 1Thess 5:1-11.

1Thess 5:1
     Now as to the times and the epochs, brethren, you have no need of anything to be written to you.

       The expression the times and the epochs may have its source in an earlier reference in Acts 1:7, where Jesus
(as recorded by Paul’s traveling companion, Luke) said that we will not know the times or epochs. Jesus’ statement
concerning the time and the epochs fits well with the doctrine of imminency.* Those who are addressed as you in
this passage in 1Thess 5 are brethren, that is, believers.

1Thess 5:2
     For you yourselves know full well that the day of the Lord will come just like a thief in the night.

       The Day of the Lord is alluded to with the word wrath in 1Thess 1:10 (cp. 5:9) and destruction in 1Thess 5:3
and refers to the beginning of the tribulation. This deduction naturally follows since the analogy of a thief in the
night indicates that the rapture and the beginning of the tribulational wrath will come unexpectedly. This thief in
the night motif is a graphic illustration of the doctrine of imminency.211 It may occur at any moment. No signs
announce its coming. Jesus also uses the same imagery to describe His coming in the rapture—Mt 24:43.
       Admittedly, in considering Mt 24:43 to be a reference to the rapture, the present writer is willing to part with
some of the narrow pretribulational presumptions held by some within his camp. Some passages, which various
pretribulationalists take as referring to the revelation, actually seem to be better understood as references to the
rapture. In making this concession, to what might be regarded as a posttribulational position, it frankly is admitted
herein that there are places where agreement with posttribulationalism rather than with typical pretribulationalism
is necessary. Wholesale rejection of the posttribulational position should not necessarily mean rejection of its
strong points, if these points have greater validity than one’s own particular viewpoint. Posttribulationalists are
correct in that some of the passages that pretribulationalists relate to the revelation really are referring to the
rapture. The more perceptive pretribulational position is to acknowledge these strong points. Indeed, the present
book is certainly not alone in adopting this position. Some pretribulationalists indeed do take Mt 24:13, as well as
other material in the Mount Olivet Discourse as dealing with rapture and church age. Their precedence will be
followed.

1Thess 5:3
     While they are saying, “Peace and safety!” then destruction will come upon them suddenly like the
     birth pang upon a woman with child; and they shall not escape (TM).

       The Day of the Lord will come in a time of peace and safety. The tribulation would not be considered a time
of peace and safety. Such a description better suits the period before the tribulation. Thus, the Day of the Lord will
occur at the conclusion of the present period and mark the beginning of the tribulation. While Jesus spoke of the
beginning of birth pangs plural, Paul uses the articular singular the birth pang to associate the very first such pangs
with the commencement of the Day of the Lord. The destruction referred to is the wrath previously referred to in
1Thess 1:10 and the Day of the Lord in 1Thess 5:2. A transition and contrast occurs between you and they, and thus
between what happens to believers and unbelievers. This destruction will come upon unbelievers, not upon
believers. The sudden unexpected nature of this destruction supports the doctrine of imminency. Whereas Jesus
uses arche (beginning) to call attention to the very first of these birth pangs, Paul use the articular singular to do the
same. The beginning, not midpoint, of the tribulation is marked by both in Mt 24:8-9 and 1Thess 5:3 respectively.
The rapture is imminent and will mark the beginning of the painful tribulation, not just the latter half of it.




*
  The doctrine of imminency refers to the teaching that the Lord can come at any moment. No signs are necessary nor yet to be
fulfilled before He comes in the rapture.

                                             Illustration 60. Day of the Lord Contrast
