                                                                     • Temporal Destruction

1Thess 5:4
     But you, brethren, are not in darkness, that the day should overtake you like a thief.

       The shift is back from them to you. In the rest of the passage, Paul is talking to Christian brethren—to
people who have become children of light by believing in the light. Those addressed in the second person are thus
no longer in the darkness positionally. Jesus also said in Jn 12:36, “Believe in the light, in order that you may
become sons of light.” Believers are of the light ontologically. Such brethren have become children of God, and
thus of the light, by believing in Jesus (cf. Jn 1:12). Unbelievers are not the only ones who are in danger of being
caught unaware by the approaching thief in the night; believers themselves may be caught off guard. The timing of
the rapture will not just be a surprise to unbelievers, but to believers also. Thus, it must be fully imminent, which
would rule out a midtribulational or posttribulational rapture. That both believers and unbelievers (referred to as
others in v. 6) may be caught morally sleeping is denoted in the chart above by having katheudo in both columns.*

1Thess 5:5
     For you are all sons of light and sons of day. We are not of night nor of darkness.

        The verse and passage affirm the regenerate status of the readers. It does not say you may be sons of light;
rather, you are sons of light. There is no question concerning the fact that they are genuine believers. There is no if
here. Paul does not say, “If you are sons.” Moreover, he does not say, “Some of you are sons of God.” He says,
“You all are sons of God.” As v. 5 proves, Paul’s purpose is not to question their soteriological salvation; rather, as
v. 6 indicates, he questions their walk, and thus their practical sanctification.

1Thess 5:6
     So then let us not sleep as others do, but let us be alert and sober.

       Even if the lay reader does not know that the Greek word for sleep is katheudo, this should not hinder him
or her from recognizing that Paul is talking about sleep in ch. 5 in a different way than he did in ch. 4. In ch. 4 it is
clear that sleep refers to physical sleep, that is, to death. Anyone can read 4:13-18 and make this substitution and
see that this is indeed the case:

*
  The negative correlation that exists between the outcome of the unbeliever and believer both being caught morally asleep provides
the basis for the exhortation to believers to be awake morally. The principle of correlativity indicates a point of similarity between the
two groups. If believers are unprepared morally, they too will experience negative consequences. Namely, in this passage, believers
who are asleep morally will fail to obtain the millennial co-glorification salvation that is at stake. See Theory of Correlativity, 911.
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                            Page 137

       13
         But we do not want you to be uninformed, brethren, about those who have fallen asleep [=those
       who died], in order that you may not grieve, as do the rest who have no hope. 14 For if we believe that
       Jesus died and rose again, even so God will bring with Him those who have fallen asleep [=those
       who died] in Jesus. 15For this we say to you by the word of the Lord, that we who are alive and
       remain until the coming of the Lord will not precede those who have fallen asleep [=those who died].
       16
          For the Lord Himself will descend from heaven with a shout, with the voice of the archangel, and
       with the trumpet of God; and the dead [those asleep] in Christ will rise first. 17Then we who are alive
       and remain will be caught up together with them. (1Thess 4:13-18; TM)

        Sleep is contrasted with being alive in 4:13-18. But that is not the case in 5:6. This substitution of die for
sleep in 5:6 would make no sense: “So then let us not die as others do, but let us be sober.” Sleep is not contrasted
with being alive in 5:6 but with being alert. Here, Paul is talking about being morally asleep versus being alert and
sober. The same is true of 5:7-8. The word used for sleep in 5:6 is the same one also used in 5:7,10 (katheudo)—it
refers to moral sleep, not physical sleep—Paul used another word for sleep in 4:13-15 (koimao) to refer to physical
sleep (i.e., death). Paul is concerned that the coming thief will find these believers morally asleep.

1Thess 5:7-8
     7
       For those who sleep do their sleeping at night, and those who get drunk get drunk at night. 8But since
     we are of the day, let us be sober, having put on the breastplate of faith and love, and as a helmet, the
     hope of salvation.

        When Paul says, “Since we are of the day, let us be sober,” he basically is saying, “Since you are saved, live
like it.” Since you are spiritually alive, stay spiritually awake! Put your faith and love into practice. This is what he
means with his triple repetition of let us (vv. 6,8). It is an exhortation, something we should do, not something we
inevitably will do. Likewise, in Eph 5:8 Paul exhorts, “You were formerly darkness, but now you are light in the
Lord; walk as children of light.”
        No question is posed about what you are as believers (light); the question is about the way you walk (as
light). Walvoord is wrong in thinking that the way you walk determines what you are, and consequently that the
way you live determines whether you are saved and will go to heaven. On the contrary, what you are should
determine the way you walk. Walvoord thinks that if you are truly saved, your life inevitably will demonstrate that
fact.212 Not so! Some believers are morally asleep—spiritually lethargic. Otherwise, there would be no need for the
stress on let us or the promise that we will live with Him even if we are asleep (v. 10). Walvoord’s soteriological
perspective, like that of so many others, prevents him from recognizing that this passage is dealing with carnal
versus spiritual Christians. Since the recognition of this fundamental distinction is necessary for a proper
understanding of the eschatology of this passage (and is central for the overall position being advocated),
digression into a discussion of carnality is warranted.

                                                 Carnal Believers
      Paul explicitly says that some believers are carnal. Not only does he so label them, but he also compares
them to the lost and contrasts them with spiritual believers. He calls them carnal brethren.
       14
         But a NATURAL man does not accept the things of the Spirit of God; for they are foolishness to
       him, and he cannot understand them, because they are spiritually appraised. 15But he who
       is SPIRITUAL appraises all things, yet he himself is appraised by no man. 16For who has known the
       mind of the Lord, that he should instruct Him? But we [apostles] have the mind of Christ. 1And I,
       brethren, could not speak to you as to spiritual men, but as to CARNAL men, as to babes in Christ. 2I
       gave you milk to drink, not solid food, for you were not yet able to receive it. Indeed, even now you
       are not yet able, 3for you are still carnal. For since there is jealousy and strife among you, are you not
       carnal, and are you not walking like natural men? (1Cor 2:14-3:3; TM)

       Paul divides humanity here into three categories: natural, carnal, and spiritual. The natural man is the
unbeliever. He is outside the kingdom, and Christ is outside his life. When a person trusts in Christ for eternal life,
Christ comes into that individual’s life and imparts spiritual life. The person is transformed instantaneously and
completely into a new creature—a new creation. As physical birth results in a new life, and then a new being, so
spiritual birth results in a new being. If this new believer is taught how to experience the victorious Christian life,
Page 138                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
he or she may experience the abundant life here and now and, in due time, become spiritual. Unfortunately, a
popular gospel tract, which presents similar circle diagrams as those shown below, gives the lost person the
potentially false impression that it is possible to go from natural to spiritual in an instant. Yet this instant migration
is impossible. Regrettably, that popular gospel tract only presents two options to the lost reader—natural versus
spiritual. To its credit, however, this same organization does provide a second tract that illustrates all three
possibilities. These tracts should be combined so that the true order is presented to the lost person as follows.
                                              Illustration 61. Lost or Saved




       You cannot bypass the carnal stage and go directly to being spiritual any more than you can bypass spiritual
infancy and go directly to spiritual maturity. Experiential knowledge is necessary to move from carnality to
spirituality. Putting what you intellectually know into practice over a period of time is required. Not even Paul
could enable the Corinthian believers to bypass the carnal stage. If they were not able to bypass carnality under
Paul’s tutorage, it is arrogant for us to assume that we can make it possible for those whom we evangelize to
bypass infancy by drawing a few circles. This is not to say such that illustrations are not effective. On the contrary,
they are very helpful, but they must be conveyed with a strong sense of realism and an accurate explanation. If
presented in the logical and biblical order, as in the above illustration, in which the carnal stage is the second one
on the road to becoming spiritual, then these types of diagrams become truly useful.

                                             Inevitability of Carnality
       The author has two sons. The oldest one, Jeremy, learned how to ride his bicycle by using training wheels.
His father was very reluctant to take those training wheels off, remembering the bloody knees of his own childhood
when he himself first learned how to ride. Jeremy’s training wheels were left on until they were literally worn off
the bike, but when the training wheels finally came off, there were no bloody knees. The training had paid off.
Jeremy rode flawlessly and was given a new bike as a result. His old bike was then given to his younger brother,
Jonathan, who had seen his older brother ride for months, using those training wheels. Jonathan had a thorough
understanding of how to ride from watching his older brother. And now that the training wheels had been taken
off, the old bike was instantly his. Did his father tell Jonathan that he could hop on the bike and ride it without
training wheels? Not hardly. Newer and even sturdier training wheels were put on the bike before his youngest son
was allowed to get on it. Although Jonathan had an intellectual understanding of how to ride, he needed time to
translate that knowledge into an experiential understanding. Even though it would have been possible theoretically
for him to ride the bike flawlessly without training wheels, his parents knew that this was not a practical
expectation and took the necessary precaution.
       Similarly, even if a person has been in church all of his life and then becomes a believer, he cannot start off
as a spiritual believer. Although it is a theoretical possibility, it is a practical impossibility, just as someone who
knows how bicycles work and watches others ride them cannot simply hop on one and ride it successfully. It takes
time and training under the tutelage of the Spirit for new believers to make the transition from having self in
control of their lives to having Christ in control of their lives and to bringing their interests under His control. But it
seems that some Lordship Salvationists teach that you must move from natural to spiritual before you can become
carnal, and in doing so they present a false gospel and a logical impossibility.
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                                        Page 139
                                               Escape from Carnality
       Despite the inevitably of carnality, the lost may still be presented with the doctrine of nikology.* An
evangelist will do well to appeal to the lost from multiple directions. Many simultaneous reasons (some of which
are auxiliary) are possible for coming to the Lord. For some a desire to escape hell may be the sole or primary
reason to believe in Jesus for eternal life. For others the desire simply to go to heaven may be reason. They may not
even believe in hell (as a place of eternal suffering). For others a desire to have rewards in heaven may be part of
their motivation. For others a desire to be with their loved ones when they die may play a part. For others they may
be so overwhelmed by the Lord’s love that they want to respond in love to Him by trusting in Him and accepting
His free gift so that they may have a relationship with Him. For others experiencing Christ’s Lordship over their
lives may very well be one reason they come to Christ in saving faith. They may be so tired of the tyranny of sin
that they want the Lord Jesus to straighten out the mess they have made of their lives. For such people, the
Lordship of Christ may be the primary reason they come to faith in Christ for eternal life. How beautiful is His
Lordship! Praise God for the Lordship of Christ!
       28
         Come to Me, all who are weary and heavy-laden, and I will give you rest. 29 Take My yoke upon
       you, and learn from Me, for I am gentle and humble in heart; and you shall find rest for your souls.
       30
          For My yoke is easy, and My load is light (Mt 11:28-30).

        Christ’s invitation to discipleship should be equally appealing to people in both the natural and the carnal
states. Broken lives and marriages can be good reasons to respond to this beautiful invitation. But the lost should
not be given the false impression that trusting in the Lord and submitting to His Lordship will solve all their
problems or result in health and wealth. The yoke is easy; the path is not. Nevertheless, those who respond to the
Lord’s invitation will have His resources and strength to deal with their problems. They will have internal rest
amidst the external conflict. One of the major differences between Lordship Salvationists and Free Grace
Salvationists, at this point, is that Lordship Salvationists insist that subjection to the mastery of Christ is the only
way to come to the Lord. They demand that people submit their lives to the Lordship of Christ Lord regarding their
performance in order to escape hell. However, this confuses the way with the reason. Jesus is the only way to
heaven, but many reasons exist for taking that way. In presenting the Lordship of Christ as one reason to trust in
Christ, it must be stressed emphatically and repeatedly that submission to His Lordship in terms of one’s
performance is not a theological requirement for the free gift of eternal life. Otherwise, the lost will misconstrue
the gospel of grace and think that they must make Christ the Lord of their lives in order to escape hell. But this
deadly distortion of the gospel of grace turns it into a gospel of merit.
        With that warning noted, Whipple’s suggestion that this passage in Mt 11:28-29 is presenting a dual
invitation is not without virtue. The invitation that Jesus gives to come to Him may be parallel to the Johannine
invitations to believe in Jesus (Jn 5:40; 6:37,44,65; 7:37), that is, to come to faith in Christ for eternal life. Thus,
coming to Christ results in soteriological rest, which Whipple describes as the salvation of your spirit. In contrast,
the other aspect of this invitation is to take the yoke of discipleship and find rest for your soul, which is a temporal
rest (that results in a misthological rest).213 This understanding of the text accords well with the synoptic teaching
that the salvation of the soul is based on one’s performance and with the Johannine principle that the regeneration
of one’s spirit, in contrast, is based on simple faith (Jn 3:5-8). Paul later picks up this theme and teaches that a
carnal believer may lose his soul (life) but have his spirit saved (1Cor 5:5). In short, just as Jn 10:10 presents a dual
invitation to life and abundant life, so Mt 11:28-29 offers a dual invitation to rest and rest for our souls.†
        Just as Jesus presents a twofold summons, FG Salvationists may offer the Lordship of Christ as one of the
incentives to come to Jesus, clearly articulating that the only requirement for salvation from eternal damnation is
simply to believe in Jesus for eternal life. For those who are more concerned about the internal subjective hell that
they temporally are going through on earth than the external objective hell that eschatologically awaits them in the
future, let them be offered an invitation to the Lordship of Christ for temporal rest, just as long as they are
emphatically and repeatedly informed that their soteriological rest (i.e., salvation from the Lake of Fire) is not
dependent upon their performance-based submission to the Lordship of Christ.

*
  Nikology is a coined expression derived from nikos (victory) and refers to the doctrine of the victorious Christian life. Nikos is a
cognate of the verb nikao (overcome). Overcomers are those who experience the Lord’s victory. This victory may be soteriological
and positional (and thus limited to legal and ontological realms). Or this victory may be temporal and result in the experience of the
abundant life in the present. Then again, this term may be used eschatologically and thus misthologically refer to receiving the crown
of life and being treated as an overcomer throughout eternity.
†
  The dual invitation also can be described as a positional versus experiential rest (GNTC).
Page 140                                                                                                   The Outer Darkness
         Also, the temporal advantages of the Lordship of Christ should not be overplayed to the point of
misrepresenting the abundant life as a painless life. Although the gift of eternal life is free, the abundant life is not
pain free. The requirement to enter heaven is to believe in Jesus for eternal life. Paul clearly says, “Jesus came into
the world to save sinners.” The single requirement is that they “believe in Him for eternal life” (1Tim 1:15-16).
The main focus in evangelism should be on the free gift of eternal life that guarantees entrance into heaven. Felt
needs may be helpful as additional incentives in bringing inquirers to trust in Christ for eternal life so that they may
also have an abundant life, but these felt needs cannot be substituted for the theological need of the free gift of
eternal life. Those coming to Christ must have a clear realization that it is their fundamental need of eternal life that
is being met by simple faith in Christ.
         The main reason for this focus is the ever-present danger that a person may trust in Jesus for abundant life
(i.e., the fuller temporal expression of eternal life) and yet fail to believe in Him for the gift of eternal life (in terms
of soteriological, eschatological entry). Additionally, evangelists should not confuse the internal subjective rest of
Mt 11:29 with the external objective rest found in the book of Hebrews. The rest believers experience now is but a
pale foreshadowing of the misthological rest they are to experience then. The requirement for both the temporal
rest now and for the misthological rest then remains the same—the yoke of Christ. We submit to the Lordship of
Christ in order to enjoy His nikological rest now on earth and His misthological rest later in heaven, not in order to
enter heaven itself. Soteriological rest is conditioned solely on coming to Christ in faith. Taking up His yoke and
following Him, in contrast, is required for temporal and misthological rest.
                                                Illustration 62. Hall of Shame
OT: Esau, Lot and his wife, Saul, David, Samson, Solomon.
NT: Ananias and Sapphira, Simon Magus, Demas, Hymenaeus, Philetus.
Parables: unsalty salt, unfruitful branches, nonworking workers, unforgiving forgiven.
Epistles: carnal Corinthians, man sleeping with his step-mother, abusers of the Lord’s supper, legalists who have fallen from
grace, the lazy not providing for their parents, apostates, the living dead, thorny ground, insulters of the Spirit of grace, the
overcomed whose last state is worse than the first.
Revelation: nonovercoming overcomers.

       The above list is just suggestive of some of the clear examples of carnality in the Bible, many of whom will
be discussed in the present text, some in considerable detail. Carnality is a widespread reality, not a mere
hypothetical possibility. Thankfully, it does not have to be the end of the story. Surprisingly, at least a couple of
those who have their names enlisted in the Hall of Shame emerged triumphant to have their names listed on the
Hall of Fame in Hebrews as heroes of the faith.

                                                 Reality of Carnality
        Theoretically, it is possible that all believers will press on to maturity and advance from carnality to
maturity regardless of the reason they came to Christ. Realistically and biblically speaking, on the other hand, it is
only a hypothetical possibility. It is also theoretically possible that in next year’s basketball season that no one
playing in the NBA will miss a single jump shot, just as each year it theoretically was possible that Shaquille
O’Neal would make all of his free throws in the upcoming season. After all, they are professionals! Such
expectations would be foolish, however. Likewise, to think that all Christians will mature because they are genuine
believers is delusional. Paul goes on to say that some believers are so carnal that all their works are represented as
going up in smoke at the Bema. They will fail miserably in terms of receiving heavenly rewards. Yet in that same
passage, Paul affirms that such Christians are nevertheless true believers and are saved (1Cor 3:11-15).,
        Lordship Salvationists attempt to counter by superficially appealing to the context of this passage as proving
that all believers are spiritual rather than carnal. Their argument is that since we refers to the Corinthian believers
(1Cor 2:16) and since all believers have the Spirit (1Cor 2:12), all believers are spiritual. Thus, Reisinger appeals
to the context in 1Cor 2:14-15 to argue that there are only two classes of people.214 Combs concurs: “In Paul’s
language, the spiritual man is simply the person who has the Spirit in contrast to the natural man, who does not.”215
Even so, then he goes on to add: “The Corinthians are not thinking and acting like spiritual men, like true
Christians should. Instead their behavior is characterized by carnality—they are ‘carnal.’” So according to
Combs, these Christians are carnal, but they are not carnal Christians “because there is no such category.”216 This
sounds like LS doubletalk.
        According to popular Lordship mentality, there is no such thing as a carnal versus spiritual Christian. There
are only two groups of people—lost and saved. Christ must be your Lord to be your Savior. If He is not your Lord,
then He is not your Savior. As a result, LS argues that if you are carnal, that is, if Christ is not the Lord of your
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                             Page 141
life, then you are lost. You are not a carnal believer; rather, you are an unbeliever. Christ is either Lord of all or not
Lord at all.
        In contrast, FG Salvationists may respond that not all believers are spiritual in the sense being described in
this passage. In the context preceding 1Cor 3:1-3, we refers to Paul and the other members of the apostolic circle
(1Cor 1:1): who preached the gospel (1Cor 1:23), who are able to speak wisdom to the mature (1Cor 2:6ff), and
who are able to claim verbal inspiration (1Cor 2:14). In this context, Paul claims that his thoughts and words are
inspired. Advocates of inerrancy will be acquainted with this understanding of the text.* The Corinthians, in
contrast, are not spiritual (1Cor 3:1); they are not mature (1Cor 3:2). They are not part of the mature group in
1Cor 2:6; and they are not part of the we in 2:6. For that matter, whenever we is contrasted with the readers
throughout the Corinthian epistles, it always refers exclusively to Paul and his fellow workers; it never refers to the
readers.† Contrary to LS claims, a careful examination of we in the immediate and broad context, confirms the FG
distinction between spiritual and carnal believers. The GRAPE understanding of the JSC is being described in
1Cor 3:11-15.
                                                    Illustration 63. Sheep or Goat




*
    See the author’s Carnal Corinth.
†
    See the author’s discussion of exclusive we in Carnal Corinth.
Page 142                                                                                               The Outer Darkness


       In the above diagram, Lordship Salvationists are correct to divide mankind into two groups—lost and saved.
Humanity may indeed be broken up into the two basic divisions. Certain passages, such as Mt 25:31-46, are limited
to this basic outlook. Nevertheless, these are not the only possible designations. Free Grace Salvationists are
equally accurate in further subdividing those who are saved into two subcategories. This FG subdivision is in
harmony with the theology of the immediate text, the context, the broader context, and the wider context of the NT.
Some passages divide humanity into two groups of lost and saved, such as goats versus sheep. You are either a
sheep or a goat, but this does not mean that there are no good sheep versus bad sheep. The NT also describes the
black sheep of the Christian family in the following ways.
                                              Illustration 64. Black Sheep
                                          Carnal Traits of NT Believers
•   asleep                                                    •    friend of the world
•   anxious, worriers, doubters                               •    conformed to the world
•   disobedient                                               •    lost first love
•   dead (nonproductive)                                      •    adulteresses
•   ashamed of Jesus                                          •    cruel, evil, wicked
•   shames Christ                                             •    desires praise of men
•   denies Jesus                                              •    dog, sow
•   deserts Jesus                                             •    double-minded
•   does not abide in Jesus                                   •    proud
•   in bondage to iniquity                                    •    jealous, envious
•   prisoner of sin                                           •    fallen from grace
•   tossed by wind                                            •    foolish
•   enemy of God                                              •    greedy
•   loves the world                                           •    grieves, quenches, insults Spirit

       The first item listed above is that of being morally asleep, because it is the characteristic that Paul is warning
about here in this rapture passage to the Thessalonians (1Thess 5:6-10). The existence of carnal Christians is an
embarrassment to Reformed theology, so much so that the very existence of carnal Christians is often denied.217
Consistently maintaining both this category and Reformed theology is impossible. Contrary to Reformed claims,
the fact that all believers have a carnal, fleshly, sinful nature does not demonstrate that all Christians are carnal or
that carnal Christian is useless as a designation for a certain class of Christians. The designation of carnal
Christian describes the biblical phenomena of believers who walk according to the flesh and is often equated in
Scripture with spiritual infancy, since it is impossible to progress to spiritual maturity while walking according to
the flesh. Although the sin nature in a believer’s body is not eradicated until permanent sanctification in the
hereafter, this is not the point Paul is making in 1Cor 3:1-3. Paul is reprimanding these believers for allowing their
fleshly nature to prevent them from advancing to spiritual maturity.
       Paul does, in fact, make a two-fold classification of believers based on their maturity by acknowledging that
some believers are mature while others are not (e.g., 1Cor 2:6; 14:20; Gal 6:1; Eph 4:13; Phil 3:15; Col 1:28; 4:12).
He labors and prays for believers so that they might become mature. He does not assume that just because they are
believers they will achieve maturity. Nor is Paul alone in recognizing this classification and need. James, John,
Peter, and the writer of Hebrews share similar convictions (Jam 1:4; 2:22; 3:2; 1Jn 2:5; 4:12,17-18; 1Pet 2:1-2;
Heb 5:14; 6:1). The background for their classification and concern is the teaching of Jesus, who likewise teaches
that some believers will progress to maturity while others will not (Mt 5:48; Lk 8:14). Some believers are
dominated by their fleshly sin nature (Rom 7:14-24). Although this classic passage in Romans does, in fact,
describe the sin principle that is present in all believers, it does not, contrary to Reisinger, describe the defeat of all
believers due to this inherent sin nature.218 Rather, this classic passage depicts the experience of carnal believers. It
is one thing to be in a body contaminated by a sin nature and quite another to be dominated by that sin nature.
Carnal believers live and walk according to the flesh (1Cor 3:3; Gal 5:16-21) and therefore are dead in terms of
their spiritual experience (Rom 8:13). Paul urges such believers to grow up by abandoning their fleshly way of life
(Eph 4:14-15; 5:8-10). They are to accomplish this and thus become spiritual by walking in the power of the Spirit
(Eph 4:1,17-5:2,18; Gal 5:16). Spirituality is not an impossibility.
       Another argument advanced by Reisinger against the existence of a class denoted as carnal Christians is
based on the proveitist claim that carnality is evidence that the supposed believer has experienced spurious faith
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                                      Page 143
rather than saving faith. Reisinger cites several passages in support of his proveitistic presupposition that not all
faith in Christ is saving faith and that its saving value is determined by its practical results (Lk 8:13; Jn 2:23-24;
12:42-43; Acts 8:12-22). Conversely, if these passages do in fact describe the genuine believers, as is demonstrated
in the present work (and elsewhere), then Reisinger’s own citations disprove the very point he is trying to make.*
The argument that there will be no such thing as carnal believers to be cast into the outer darkness is demonstrably
false and therefore collapses like a sandcastle against the pounding waves of the misthological understanding of the
outer darkness. Carnal believers can live in moral darkness and be cast into the outer darkness as a result.

1Thess 5:9
     For God has not destined us for wrath, but for obtaining salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ.

        Returning to the primary discussion, concerning the possible outcome for protracted carnality in this
Thessalonian passage, some believers will do the things Paul exhorts them to do in this passage—that is, they will
be sober, meaning they live a life that demonstrates faith, hope, and love—but other believers will not. Some
believers will fail miserably and sleep morally. Otherwise, there would be no need for the exhortation to stay
awake. Nonetheless, even those carnal believers who fail are saved from the wrath of hell. “If any man’s work is
burned up, he shall suffer loss; but he himself shall be saved, yet so as through fire” (1Cor 3:15). Not only will
carnal believers be saved from God’s soteriological wrath, they also will be saved from His tribulational wrath,
which is the point Paul is making here to the Thessalonians.
        1Thess 5:9 gives believers two reasons to be sober and live lives that reflect faith, hope, and love. The
second of these reasons is that God has destined believers for obtaining salvation, described as the hope of
salvation in verse 8. Discussion of what this means will be postponed until treatment of salvation and election
later.† For now, note that the first reason given for staying morally awake is out of gratitude that God has not
destined us for wrath even if we morally are asleep. The wrath of 5:9 (orge) is the same wrath which Paul had
previously mentioned in 1:10 and defined in the immediate context as the Day of the Lord and destruction which
comes like an unannounced thief in the night. It is the wrath of the tribulation. The entire context is talking about
the wrath and destruction of the Day of the Lord (i.e., the tribulation). This passage affirms more than just salvation
from hell.
        To be sure, it might be assumed that Paul assures believers that they will be saved from the wrath (orge) of
hell in Rom 5:9 when he says, “Having now been justified by His blood, we shall be saved from the wrath of God
through Him.” To many, this salvation from the wrath of God would seem to be salvation from eternal damnation.
But even if this were the case in Rom 5:9 (which seems unlikely), it is certainly not the case in 1Thess 5:9. In this
latter passage Paul affirms salvation from the wrath of the tribulation. Using an argument from lesser to greater, it
may nevertheless be inferred that in affirming salvation from the tribulation for all believers, Paul indirectly
affirms salvation from eternal damnation as well.‡ It would make no sense for Paul to affirm that believers will be
saved from the wrath of the tribulation, only to be thrown into hell, when he himself teaches that those believers
who make a poor showing at the Bema will still be saved from hell (1Cor 3:15).
        Rom 8:32 provides an example of a Pauline argument from greater to lesser: “He who did not spare His own
Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how will He not also with Him freely give us all things?” It would not make
sense for God to give us His greatest blessing, in the death of His Son, but refuse to give us lesser blessings.
Likewise, it would make no sense for God to deliver believers from the wrath of the tribulation and then throw
them into the wrath of hell. If God delivers believers from the wrath of the tribulation, as 1Thess 5:9 teaches, then
certainly He will also deliver them from the wrath of hell. Salvation from God’s tribulational wrath implies
salvation from His soteriological wrath as well. But is this deliverance from the tribulation, and thus by implication
from hell, really for all believers? What about those believers who are morally asleep? The fact that it is possible
for a believer to be asleep morally is certainly evident from the exhortation. What would be the point of the
exhortation to stay awake morally if believers could not be asleep morally? Verse 10 addresses this very real
possibility and answers such questions.

1Thess 5:10
     Who died for us, that whether we are awake or asleep, we may live together with Him.

       The words awake (gregoreo) and asleep (katheudo) are the same Greek words for alert (gregoreo) and
asleep (katheudo) used in v. 6 and in Mk 13:34-37 to describe moral preparedness in view of the imminent rapture.
These words are used misthologically to warn believers within Mark:
      34
        It is like a man, away on a journey, who upon leaving his house and putting his slaves in charge,
      assigning to each one his task, also commanded the doorkeeper to stay on the alert. 35Therefore, be
      on the alert—for you do not know when the master of the house is coming, whether in the evening,
      at midnight, at cockcrowing, or in the morning—36lest he come suddenly and find you asleep. 37And
      what I say to you I say to all, “Be on the alert!” (Mk 13:34-37)

       However, Paul uses the words eschatologically in 1Thess 5 to comfort believers. Paul explicitly affirms the
deliverance of all believers from the tribulation, whether they are morally awake or morally asleep, and thus he
implicitly affirms the eternal security of all believers from hell whether they are morally awake or morally asleep.
As a result of the rapture described in 1Thess 4:17, all believers will live with Jesus, as Hodges explains:

      The true force of the phrase “whether we are awake or asleep” is crucial and has been widely
      overlooked by expositors, particularly those of a posttribulational persuasion. Frequently, the
      expression has been construed as a reference to Christians who are alive (“awake”) and to those who
      are dead (“asleep”) at the coming of Christ. But careful examination of the Greek text shows this to
      be impossible. In 4:14, the Greek word used to refer to “sleeping” believers (i.e. dead ones) is the
      Greek verb koimao. However, in 5:10 the verb for sleep is quite different. Here it is the word
      katheudo. The context defines its meaning since it has been used in verses 5 and 6 to describe the
      state of unwatchfulness against which Paul is warning. In the same way, the verb in verse 10 for
      “awake” (gregoreo) has been used in verse 6 to describe the state of alertness that Paul enjoins.
            Unless sound exegetical procedure is to be thrown to the winds, verse 10 cannot be seen as a
      description of living and dead Christians. Rather it refers to watchful and unwatchful believers.219

        In other words, in chapter five Paul is not assuring these believers that whether they are physically dead or
alive, they will be with the Lord. He already had assured them of that in 1Thess 4:13-18. Instead, in 5:1-11 he
assures them that whether they are morally alert or asleep, they will be with the Lord. Paul then makes his
application in v. 11.

1Thess 5:11
     Therefore encourage one another.

       Not surprisingly, this is the same application that Paul used in 4:18, instructing us to comfort (parakaleo)
one another, rather than warn one another, with these words. The same Greek word for comfort is used in both 4:18
and 5:11, and thus the NKJ translates both verses as: “Therefore comfort each other.” In the first section (4:13-18),
Paul assures them that all physically dead believers are with the Lord and that living believers will join them in the
rapture. His exhortation to comfort one another with this teaching is completely understandable. In the second
section (5:1-11), he assures them that all physically alive believers, whether or not they are morally awake, will be
included in the rapture. Again, his application to encourage one another with this teaching makes sense. The two
sections combine to teach that all believers, whether they are physically alive or dead or morally alert or asleep,
will be with the Lord as a result of the rapture. Further, the second section assures them that the rapture would take
place before the Day of the Lord.
       Thus, 1Thess 5:1-11 teaches that the rapture will result in the translation of all believers before the Day of
the Lord. As already noted, the Day of the Lord is called the coming wrath in 1:10 and destruction in 1Thess 5:3.
As a result, this passage clearly rules out the partial rapture and posttribulational positions since the rapture
involves the translation of all believers before the Day of the Lord, which is the time period of destruction in the
coming wrath.
       Since the partial rapture and posttribulational views are nullified by this observation, this leaves two
possibilities: the midtribulational and pretribulational positions. Even at this juncture, however, it may be pointed
out that the above analysis renders the midtribulational and prewrath views highly improbable in that the
Chapter 4. Tribulational Options (1Thess 4:13-5:11)                                                                          Page 145
preliminary indications are that the Day of the Lord and its corresponding wrath commence at the beginning of the
tribulational period. The key question is, “When does the Day of the Lord begin?” Since the rapture marks the
beginning of the Day of the Lord, if we know for sure when the Day of the Lord begins, we know when the rapture
occurs. If the Day of the Lord begins at the beginning of the tribulation period (as maintained herein), then the
pretribulational view is correct.* If the Day of the Lord begins in the middle of the tribulational period, then the
midtribulational view is correct. If the Day of the Lord begins in the middle of the second half of the tribulational
period, then the prewrath view is correct. Paul follows up his first letter to the Thessalonians with a second letter to
the Thessalonians, in which he continues his teaching concerning the Day of the Lord. Therefore, we will proceed
to that discussion in the next chapter.

                                                          Conclusion
       Of the three major passages discussing the tribulation and rapture, the first passage considered (Jn 14:1-3)
does not explicitly state that the rapture comes before the tribulation. Nevertheless, it does indicate that Jesus is
coming from heaven to take believers to the place He is preparing for them. This detail effectively rules out the
posttribulational position, which would have the bride bringing the groom back to her home on earth rather than
the groom bringing His Bride back to His home in heaven. The nuptial imagery rules out this posttribulational
possibility, but it does not render the other alternative rapture positions impossible. For example, if the Bride is not
composed of all believers, then the nuptial imagery of Jn 14:1-3 still leaves the partial rapture position open as a
possibility.
       On the other hand, when Paul’s discussion in 1Thessalonians is considered, clear confirmation as to the
timing of the Lord’s return is provided. It is before the tribulational wrath. The midtribulational option is thus no
longer a valid candidate. The partial position is also obliterated since Paul teaches in this twin, two-part discussion
(anticipated in 1Thess 1:10) that God will save all believers, even those who are asleep morally, from this wrath.
The partial rapture understanding is thus refuted. Moreover, the partial rapture position was flawed intrinsically to
begin with because bridal misthology actually nullifies the partial rapture view. God must come and take all
believers to the Bema so that the Bride of Christ may be chosen from the Body of Christ.† That only part of the
believers will become the Bride does not mean that only some of the believers are raptured. On the contrary, the
Bema, rather than the rapture, is the time for the selection of the Bride from among her countrymen.
       To reiterate, Paul discussed the rapture in the first section (4:13-18) and then the tribulation (i.e., the Day of
the Lord) in the second section (5:1-11). The order of the two sections is rapture then tribulation. This is also the
order that Paul teaches in 1Thess 5:1-11. The rapture comes first, then the tribulation. This sequence rules out the
possibility of a posttribulational rapture. In the second section, Paul also makes explicit what he had made implicit
in the first section: the rapture involves all believers. This explanation, in turn, rules out the possibility of a partial
rapture.
       By way of anticipation, Paul presents an additional detail in the second section concerning the Day of the
Lord that has not yet been implemented fully in deciding which tribulational view is correct, and that is the
doctrine of imminency, which Paul graphically represents with two illustrations in 1Thess 5:2-3. The rapture and
resulting Day of the Lord will come “just like a thief in the night” and “suddenly like birth pangs upon a woman
with child.” Paul explains this aspect of his teaching more thoroughly in his second letter to the Thessalonians,
which will be considered in the next chapter.‡

*
  Technically, the Day of the Lord (DOL) does not necessarily mark the beginning of the tribulation proper (TRIB) since the clock for
the countdown of the tribulational days does not begin until the treaty with Israel is signed (so DOL ≠ TRIB). An unspecified a gap of
time could occur between the DOL and the TRIB (so that TRIB ⊂ DOL). Apparently, Jeffery (pp. 176,189-190) would place Ezekiel’s
battle of Gog and Magog (cp. Eze 38:2; 39:9) during this gap of time (a possibility not entertained by Pentecost, Things, 343-355).
This supernatural victory would help explain why the antichrist would sign a peace treaty with Israel. More likely, however, this battle
takes place after the TRIB starts, probably during the middle of the TRIB. Thus, no substantial amount of time needs to occur between
the DOL and the TRIB. The present work will assume this to be the case (so that DOL ≈ TRIB). However, I would also at least
entertain the theoretical possibility that the rapture could occur on the very day the treaty is signed/ratified, presumably after it is
signed/ratified (in which case DOL = TRIB). One difficulty with this latter proposal, though, is that it would seem to require that the
nature of the signing/ratification not be clearly perceived as marking the beginning of the TRIB until after the rapture takes place.
†
  See Chapter 25. The Bride, 565.
‡
  Since there are those in my own FG camp who argue for a relative all in the Corinthian passage (1Cor 15:50-58), I have not
implemented arguments from this passage in defense of my position concerning the tribulation. Not that this would be impossible; it is
simply unnecessary. Having demonstrated the necessity of my conclusions apart from this Corinthian passage, I will treat this passage
as harmonious with such conclusions. The most natural rendition would be to find 1Cor 15:50-58 as describing the translation and
transformation of all believers at the time of the pretribulational rapture.
Page 146   The Outer Darkness
                                                   Chapter 5.
                                            Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)
                                                          Introduction
       After Paul had written his first epistle to the Thessalonian believers, assuring them of deliverance from the
coming tribulational wrath, someone started giving them false information concerning the second coming. In
response, Paul writes to this church again concerning this same topic in his second epistle. It is ironic how history
sometimes repeats itself. One Sunday, after the present author had preached on what Paul had to say in
1Thessalonians, he received an unsolicited copy of a pamphlet in the mail the next day which taught a partial
rapture theory and claimed that Jesus was coming on October 22 of 1992. Like Paul, the author proceeded to show
his congregation that this was false by proceeding to the information in 2 Thessalonians. Accordingly, having just
devoted this previous chapter of this book to Paul’s argument in 1 Thessalonians, his follow-up treatment in
2 Thessalonians will now be considered.

                                                           Passage

2Thess 2:1-2
     1
       Now we request you, brethren, with regard to the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, and our
     gathering together to Him 2that you may not be quickly shaken from your composure or be disturbed
     either by a spirit or a message or a letter as if from us, to the effect that the Day of the Lord has come.

       The gathering referred to is the rapture when the Lord comes for His church. The Day of the Lord is the
period of wrath (cf. 1Thess 1:10; 5:9), which comes like a thief (cf. 1Thess 5:2) with the destruction that comes
like birth pangs (cf. 1Thess 5:3) and marks the beginning of the coming tribulation.220 This indicates a
pretribulational rapture, but it does not prove it beyond doubt. The question that still remains is, “Can the
midtribulational and prewrath positions also be considered pretribulational in the broad sense of the word?” In
1Thess 5:2, Paul had said that the Day of the Lord will come. Now, in 2Thess 2:2, he is addressing the false
message that the Day of the Lord has come. If either the midtribulational or prewrath positions were correct, then it
would be possible for believers living in the church age to think that the Day of the Lord has come. Paul rules out
this possibility in his second correspondence to the Thessalonians.

2Thess 2:3
     3
       Let no one in any way deceive you, for it will not come unless the apostasy comes first, and the man
     of lawlessness is revealed, the son of destruction.

        Paul had assured these Thessalonian believers of a pretribulational rapture, at least in the broad sense of the
word, in 1Thess 1:10; 5:9. In other words, he had told them that the rapture would occur before the Day of the
Lord. Now someone else was telling these believers that the tribulation already had started. Indeed, as is seen in
2Thess 1:4-7, they were suffering afflictions and tribulations. Paul speaks of their perseverance in spite of their
afflictions. This persecution made it easy for them to believe this false teaching that the tribulation had started. Paul
reassures them that the beginning of the tribulation proper (i.e., the eschatological tribulation) would be marked by
two events—the absence of which proved that it had not yet started.
        The first event that will mark the beginning of the tribulation is the apostasy.221 This is like saying, “Class
will not start until the bell rings,” or “The class begins with the bell.” The second thing that marks the beginning of
the tribulation is the revelation of the man of lawlessness. These two things mark the beginning of the tribulational
period, known as the Day of the Lord. Before the tribulation can start, the apostasy must climax, and the antichrist
must be revealed. Naturally, the apostasy of the church will climax immediately after the rapture, since all true
believers will be removed from the church on earth at that time, leaving only false believers within the church on
earth. Since according to Dan 9:27 the antichrist will ratify a public peace treaty with Israel at the very beginning
of the tribulational period, this ratification of the peace treaty takes place shortly after the rapture.* Apparently,
Paul has this event in mind. If so, then the pretribulational position proper is immediately proven since the rapture

*
    See Illustration 106. Overview of Dan 9:24-27, 303.
Page 148                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
would have to precede the ratification of the peace treaty, which takes place at the very beginning of the
tribulational period. The order of events is:

           1. The rapture.
           2. The immediate climax of apostasy.
           3. Then the revealing of the antichrist in the signing of the peace treaty.

        Walvoord points out another weakness of midtribulationalism that is also very conclusive.222 The OT
references to the Day of the Lord call it the Day of the Lord’s destruction, vengeance, indignation, anger, and
wrath. For example, Is 13:9 confirms, “The Day of the Lord is coming, cruel, with fury and burning anger.”
Zeph 1:14-17 says of that day, “Near is the great Day of the Lord, near and coming very quickly…A day of wrath
is that day.” Apparently, the wrath of that day is imminent. Midtribulationalism puts the commencement of the
wrath at Rev 11:18. The prewrath view puts it at Rev 8:1 and denies that the seals are part of God’s wrath.
        A simple reading of the descriptions of the seals in Rev 6 refutes the notion that these seals are not
describing God’s wrath. That the seals are describing wrath is evident from the events which take place and the fact
that events of the six seals, or at least the events of the sixth seal, are specifically called wrath twice in Rev 6:16-
17, where the people on the earth cry out for the rocks to fall on them and hide them from the wrath of the Lamb,
also referred to as the great day of wrath. That these seals represent God’s wrath is clear in Rev 6:16 since: it
specifically designates it as the wrath of the Lamb; the Lamb is the one breaking the seals (which brings forth the
wrath); and the riders of the four horses of the first four seals are called forth by the four living creatures who are
before the throne of God (cf. Rev 4:6-8).
        The great wrath is specifically referred to in Rev 7:14, before the seventh seal and the trumpets.
Midtribulationalism is consequently in error for saying that the wrath does not begin until Rev 11:18, and the
prewrath view is in error for saying that it does not begin until Rev 8:1. Both views are wrong in denying that the
seals are part of God’s wrath. As a result, the only option left is the premillennial view proper, which understands
the Day of the Lord as starting with the beginning of the tribulation. Paul teaches the Thessalonians that they would
be raptured before the Day of the Lord and the wrath associated with it. Thus, the pretribulational position proper is
the proper pretribulational position. The standard premillennial pretribulational view is correct.* We do not have to
know everything about eschatology to be able to make this assessment. Exegeses of the key passages in Rev 20:4-
6; 1Thess 4:13-5:11; and 2Thess 2:1-3 are sufficient to demonstrate that this position is necessary.
        Paul instructs them that a pretribulational rapture will occur before the revealing of the antichrist which
marks the beginning of the tribulation. He teaches that all believers will be included in this rapture and thus escape
the coming day of wrath—the entire tribulation period. This is why Paul told the Thessalonian church in
2Thess 2:2 not to be disturbed when people told them that the tribulation already had started and in 2Thess 2:3—
not to be disturbed by posttribulationalists or midtribulationalists or partial tribulationalists. His rationale is simple:
The tribulation could not start before the full rapture occurred.† The basis for locating the time of the first stage of
the coming of the Lord mentioned in 2Thess 2:1 has now been demonstrated. Examining the rest of the passage
concerning the second stage of the Lord’s coming in v. 8 will permit the second stage to be pinpointed also.

2Thess 2:4-8
     4
       Who opposes and exalts himself above every so-called god or object of worship, so that he takes his
     seat in the temple of God, displaying himself as being God. 5Do you not remember that while I was
     still with you, I was telling you these things? 6And you know what restrains him now, so that in his
     time he may be revealed. 7For the mystery of lawlessness is already at work; only he who now
     restrains will do so until he is taken out of the way. 8And then that lawless one will be revealed
     whom the Lord will slay with the breath of His mouth and bring to an end by the appearance of His
     coming.

       The sequence is indicated by the word then that begins verse 8. The order is verse 7 then verse 8. Therefore,
the revealing of vv. 2,6,8 is after the removing of the restrainer. Before the antichrist can be revealed, the restrainer
must be removed (taken out of the way). The restrainer is the Holy Spirit as uniquely present in the church. Or as
Hitchcock states: “The restrainer in 2 Thessalonians is not just the Holy Spirit and not just the church. Rather, the

*
    See Illustration 58. Pretribulational , 132.
†
    See Temple, 156.
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                           Page 149
one who holds it back is the restraining influence of God the Holy Spirit, who presently restrains evil through the
church.”223
       Unlike the regenerate believers of the OT time and of the coming tribulational period, church-age believers
actually are sealed with the Holy Spirit and thus permanently indwelt by the Spirit. Presently, the church, which is
constituted by sealed believers, is a hindrance to unchecked evil. The church is the salt of the earth, but once its
preserving influence has been removed, evil will flourish. The church must be removed because it is in the way of
evil. Also, the church must also be removed because it is in the way of God’s wrath. Just as Noah had to enter the
ark before the flood could come and as Lot had to be removed from Sodom before it could be destroyed, so the
church must be removed before God’s wrath can come on the world. The restrainer is referred to in this passage
both in the neuter and masculine, which is the same phenomenon seen elsewhere in reference to the Holy Spirit.224
Paul is teaching that the Holy Spirit as uniquely present in the church must be removed before these things can
occur. The sequence is first the rapture of the church and then the revelation of the lawless one (i.e., the
antichrist). The revelation of Christ (2Thess 1:7) already was described in detail by Paul in his proceeding chapter.

                                            Rewarded Rest at Revelation
       6
          For after all it is only just for God to repay (antapodidomi) with affliction those who afflict you,
       7
         and to repay (antapodidomi) rest to you who are afflicted and to us as well when the Lord Jesus will
       be revealed from heaven with His mighty angels in flaming fire, 8 paying out retribution to those who
       do not know God and to those who do not obey the gospel of our Lord Jesus. 9 And these will pay the
       penalty of eternal destruction, away from the presence of the Lord and from the glory of His power,
       10
          when He comes to be glorified in His saints on that day, and to be marveled at among all who have
       believed—for our testimony to you was believed. (2Thess 1:6-10; TM)

         This second stage of the second coming was described previously in 2Thess 1:6-10. (In 2Thess 2:8 the
appearing of Christ occurs in juxtaposition with the revelation of the antichrist.) This passage in 2Thess 1:6-10 is
reminiscent of the martyrs who cry for God to repay those who had afflicted them in Rev 6:10-11. They were told
to rest (anapauo) a little while longer. Thus, in John’s description of the intermediate state, a restlessness is seen in
their rest. We may more easily sympathize with their restlessness when we consider a subsequent passage in
Revelation dealing with this rest: “Write, ‘Blessed are the dead who die in the Lord from now on!’ ‘Yes,’ says the
Spirit, ‘that they may rest from their labors, for their deeds follow with them’” (Rev 14:13). This rest is not merely
the cessation from one’s works necessary to earn this rest; it also is the accompaniment of one’s works into this
rest.
        This rest is the payment since it is the result of their works. John describes this in picturesque language,
saying that their works accompany them. Paul, on the other hand, simply uses the verb antapodidomi, which means
to repay or reward, to make the same point. He also uses the nominal form of this verb explicitly to refer to the
inheritance as a reward: “Whatever you do, do your work heartily, as for the Lord rather than for men; knowing
that from the Lord you will receive the reward (antapodosis) of the inheritance” (Col 3:24-25). This helps us
understand the restless rest of the martyred saints in Revelation. When we die, we cease laboring to inherit the
kingdom. Whatever work we are going to perform to inherit the kingdom must be done while we are alive on earth.
So in this sense, the martyred saints rested from their labors necessary to be counted worthy of inheriting the
kingdom. For that matter, Paul likewise reminds the Thessalonians that they are suffering to be counted worthy of
the kingdom (2Thess 1:5). Once we die, we have a rest from such laborious suffering. But the promise is not that
we simply will have rest from suffering but that we will have the rest of the inheritance. We are working to earn
the reward of the inheritance. Once we have earned this inheritance, we no longer have to work for it. The martyrs
had earned the inheritance and thus had ceased working for it (and in that sense already had rest), but they had not
yet come into the realization of their rest. They had not yet been given their payment.
        The rest is not only to cease from working to earn one’s payment, it is to be given one’s payment. And they
had not yet been given their recompense. They are eager to receive it. Paul looks beyond the intermediate state to
the complete rest that occurs when the Lord answers the martyrs’ cry and at last executes judgment upon those who
dwell on the earth who had afflicted them. Believers will not experience the rest Paul is describing until the
revelation of Christ, that is, until the millennium. This rest is a reward to be paid at that time. God’s payment for
the afflicters will be affliction; His payment for those who endured affliction will be rest. Since this rest is not
experienced until that time, it is millennial. Since it is a payment, it is misthological.
        Paul uses the Greek verb antapodidomi in v. 6 and leaves the verb unstated in v. 7. Yet it is apparent that the
same verb is to be understood as carrying over to the latter verse. The KJV uses the verb recompense to translate
antapodidomi in v. 6 and merely leaves the verb unstated in v. 7, allowing the reader to fill it in from v. 6. This is
Page 150                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
certainly a superior procedure to other translations that use one verb in v. 6 (such as pay) and then a completely
different verb in v. 7 (such as give). This popular mistranslation gives the false impression that v. 6 is talking about
a payment whereas v. 7 is talking about something given in contrast, such as a gift. A better translation would be to
demonstrate to the English reader what is implicit in the Greek text, namely that the same verb governs both
verses.
                                  Illustration 65. Abbreviated Sentence Diagram of 2Thess 1:6-7

                                      Illustration 66. Abbreviated Flow Chart of 2Thess 1:6-7




       God will repay affliction to the afflicters and rest to the afflicted. The same verb takes both objects.
Certainly, the rest is a reward in this context. In fact, the CSB renders v. 7 as “to reward with rest.” And
commentaries such as the EBC, NIC, and NTC acknowledge that rest is a reward in v. 7. The merited nature of the
rest (anesis) in 2Thess 1:7 leads to equating it with the millennial rest (katapausis) of Heb 3-4. Only believers who
persevere will enter this rest and thus be rewarded with rulership of the millennial kingdom. This rest is to
experience one’s misthological inheritance in the land of Canaan.*
       The rest of Heb 3-4 is more than just entrance into the millennial kingdom; it is rulership of that kingdom.
One can read Heb 3:11-4:11 and note how little sense it makes to substitute heaven for rest. For example, consider
this substitution in the last verse with the realization that the epistle was written to regenerate believers: “Let us
[regenerate believers] therefore be diligent to enter heaven” (4:11). The substitution heaven for rest is
incomprehensible since entrance into heaven is not based on a believer’s diligence. Or if one were to make this
substitution in 4:1, the result would have: “Therefore, let us fear lest, while a promise remains of entering heaven,
any one of you [regenerate believers] should seem to have come short of it.” For those readers of Hebrews who—
like the writer of Hebrews (10:10,14)—believe in unconditional security, this substitution is a desecration of
biblical theology.

*
    See Rest, 526; Illustration 271. Achan’s Lack of Rest, 760.
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                               Page 151
                                                 Sequence
       The Thessalonians already had been instructed by Paul in 1Thess 4 and 5 that the Lord’s coming for them
via the rapture would precede the Lord’s Day of wrath—the Day of the Lord. Consequently, in 2Thess 2 the
following order of events are discernible:

          1. The Lord’s coming in connection with the rapture (vv. 1,7)
          2. commences the Day of the Lord’s wrath (v. 2) and the revelation of the antichrist (vv. 3-6,8),
          3. which in turn is followed by the coming of Christ (v. 8).

When interpreted in light of what Paul already has spelled out in 1Thess 4-5 and 2Thess 1:6-10, the order of events
according to 2Thess 2 is thus:

           1. The rapture occurs first,
           2. next comes the Day of the Lord and the revelation of the antichrist,
           3. and then the revelation of Christ follows.

Therefore, the two-stage nature of the second coming is confirmed in this passage. The coming of the Lord, the
gathering of the church, and the removal of the restrainer are the events that mark the end of the current age. The
apostasy of the church and the revealing of the antichrist mark the beginning of the next age. Christ comes first in
the rapture and then later in the revelation.

Page 152                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                                    Apostasy
       Three additional details in these Thessalonian passages require comment. Determining exactly what is being
referred to by the word apostasy presents a difficulty in 2Thess 2:3. Four interpretations are possible, and any one
of the four interpretations would be consistent with the pretribulational position, so the interpretation chosen does
not detract from the conclusions that already have been attained. If anything, they strengthen the pretribulational
position.

1. Departure from the Earth
       First, the word apostasy (apostasia) could be talking about departure from the earth (i.e., the rapture, cf.
v. 1) or departure from the faith. Because of its improbability, the first view has gained limited support. Apostasia
is more likely referring to departure from the faith, that is, apostasy. Other similar apostasy passages concerning
rejecting the faith or its practical or doctrinal implications should be kept in mind (e.g., 1Kgs 11:4,9; Mt 11:3;
24:10-12,24; Mk 4:17; 13:22; Lk 8:13; Acts 20:29-30; Gal 1:6-7; 5:4; Col 1:23; 1Tim 1:5-6,19; 4:1-3; 5:8,12,15;
6:10; 20-21; 2Tim 1:15; 2:12,14-18; 3:1-5; 4:3-4; 10,16; Tit 1:11,13-14; Heb 2:1; 3:12; 6:4-6; 10:29,35-38; 12:25;
2Pet 2:1-3,21; 3:3-6,17; Jude 1:7-18; Rev 2:20). Yet even assuming that the reference is to apostasy, the verse still
can be interpreted two ways by pretribulationalists, as seen below.

2. Pretribulational Departure from Faith
        Some dispensationalists consider this apostasy a characteristic of “the last days of the church.” Therefore,
they believe that it happens before the tribulation. See, for example, Ryrie’s discussion concerning apostasy.225
“This present-future concept [concerning apostasy] is similar to that of the present-future antichrist. There were
antichrists present in the church in John’s day and still he looked forward to the coming great Antichrist
(I John 2:18).”226 Ryrie’s point is that this view of apostasy does not deny the doctrine of imminency. If this is
what Paul means by apostasy, then Paul simply is saying that the tribulation cannot come unless this age (i.e., the
church age) closes first and then the next age (i.e., the tribulation) begins. This option does not necessarily negate
imminency. Although Paul and the other NT writers affirmed that apostasy would characterize the church before
the Lord returned, a sufficient degree of apostasy has existed from the very beginning so as to allow believers to
think that they are living in the last days. So why does Paul bring up apostasy as being a reason not to worry that
they are not in the day of wrath?
        Perhaps he does so because apostasy is characterized by the teaching of false doctrine, and he wants his
readers to realize that this false teaching that was disturbing them was a part of that false doctrine. There was no
truth to it, as was evident by the absence of the antichrist. Thus, they should not be disturbed by this false teaching
that they were in the tribulation because it was a part of the apostasy that they were to expect in this church age. In
other words, the present-day application of what Paul is telling them is not to be disturbed by the partial rapture
teaching, the midtribulational rapture teaching, the prewrath rapture teaching, or the posttribulational rapture
teaching because these teachings are departures from his teaching concerning the rapture, and believers should
expect to encounter such apostate teaching even now and with increasing frequency. Notwithstanding the
attractiveness of this approach, this interpretation may be ranked as improbable also.

3. Posttribulational Departure from Faith
      The third interpretation is to argue that 2Thess 2:3 refers to apostasy after the rapture. For example, Stanton
says,

       Scripture does not declare that the consummation of apostasy must occur before the rapture. II
       Thessalonians 2:3 speaks of a ‘falling away,’ and the revelation of the Man of Sin, but the Tribulation
       is here in view and not conditions of the Church age. The apostasy in its final form will reach its
       climax only under the Satan-inspired leadership of the antichrist during the great Tribulation.
       (Emphasis his.)227

       Of course, Ryrie’s present-future analogy would apply equally well (or even better) to this position since
John was talking about present day antichrists versus the future tribulational Antichrist. Thomas also believes that
this apostasy in 2Thess 2:3 does not mark the end of the church age but the beginning of the tribulation period. He
even goes beyond merely assigning 2Thess 2:3 to the tribulation by assigning the similar apostasy passages of
Scripture (referred to above in interpretation #1) to this category.228 According to this view, the first thing to
happen in the tribulation period will be tremendous apostasy. This explanation is very appealing because it would
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                                       Page 153
parallel the truth that the first thing that happens in the tribulation period is the revealing of the man of lawlessness.
Certainly, he will attract a large following. Further, one naturally would expect a tremendous apostasy immediately
following the rapture since only false believers will be left behind. This third interpretation, in which apostasy in
2Thess 2:3 is understood as referring to apostasy at the beginning of the tribulation, has much to commend it. As a
matter of fact, tribulational apostasy is what is being described in 2Thess 2:11-12. After talking about the
revelation, coming, and deception by the antichrist in vv. 8-10, in vv. 11-12 Paul immediately goes on to add that
“God will send upon them a deluding influence so that they might believe what is false, in order that they all may
be judged who did not believe.” What they had refused to believe before the rapture, they are incapable of
believing after the rapture. This is one possibility, but there is another.
       When the author first heard about the Left Behind movie, he asked those who saw the movie if the people in
the movie who had heard the gospel and rejected it before the rapture were those who believed it afterwards. When
he was told that they were, he lost interest in going to watch the movie, citing 2Thess 2:9-12 as proof that those
who reject the gospel in the present age will be hardened and not believe it after the rapture. However, after reading
Bible Prophecy by Hitchcock, the author found Hitchcock’s proposal more reasonable and subsequently (and
consequently) watched the movie. Hitchcock believes that this passage refers to the hardening of those who reject
the gospel after the rapture and embrace the Antichrist. Thus, many who reject the gospel before the rapture will
have a second chance to believe after the rapture.229 Those who take the mark of the beast after the tribulation has
commenced are the ones who are doomed.* Thus, additional writers (such as Ice and Zeller) would appear to be on
the right track in arguing that those who reject the truth of the gospel during the tribulation and who take the mark
of the beast as the ones who cannot believe, not those who reject it before the tribulation.230
       If 2Thess 2:9-12 refers to those who take the mark of the beast, as seems probable, one naturally may be
inclined to ask, “Do they take the mark because God hardens them, or does God harden them because they take the
mark?” Regardless, in either case the mark of the beast will be an indication of God’s judicial hardening rather
than sovereign hardening, making it impossible for those who take it in that time period to believe subsequently.†
God will make it impossible for them to believe because they already will have refused to believe. They did not
previously fail to believe because they were hardened sovereignly; rather, they were hardened judicially because
they had refused to believe previously. Pharaoh is the classic example. God told Moses ahead of time that He
would harden Pharaoh’s heart (Ex 4:21; 7:3). Then God strengthened Pharaoh’s heart (Ex 9:12) and finally
hardened his heart (Ex 10:1)—after Pharaoh already had hardened his own heart (Ex 8:15, 32; 9:34).‡
       If it be asked, “Then how could the Thessalonians know that the tribulation had not yet started?’ the answer
would be simple—they were true believers. A genuine believer is someone who believes the genuine gospel. At the
time of the rapture, all genuine believers will depart from earth, leaving only professing believers behind who
never believed the true gospel that salvation from eternal damnation is by faith alone in Christ alone. Since the
Thessalonians knew that they were true believers, they could know that the rapture had not yet taken place.
Understandably, this perspective will be difficult, if not impossible, for many Lordship Salvationists to accept.
Such Lordship Salvationists may be able only to acknowledge absolute assurance of one’s own personal salvation
at a hypothetical intellectual level. Free Grace Salvationists, on the other hand, teach absolute assurance concerning
salvation from hell and are thus in a better position experientially to relate that assurance to this doctrine as well.
       A Christian does not have to wake up each morning wondering if the rapture has happened, if he or she has
been left behind, or if the tribulation already has started. All believers should know beyond a shadow of a doubt
that they are saved since their salvation and the assurance of their salvation is based on the object of their faith, not
on the doubtless persuasion, linear duration, or visible manifestation of their faith. Christ is the object of their faith.
They can know with absolute assurance that they are saved since their faith is in Christ alone. Those who have a
false assurance of salvation, like those described in Mt 7:21-23, are those who base their assurance on what they do
for Christ rather than what Christ has done for them.
       As true believers, since our faith is based exclusively on what Christ has done, we know that our salvation
and our assurance of salvation are genuine. Each morning that we wake up, we know that the rapture has not yet
occurred and that the tribulation has not yet started for one simple reason—we are still here. We know we will be
saved from hell and from the tribulation for the uncomplicated reason that Scripture teaches that everyone who has
