trusted in Christ alone for their salvation will be saved from both. We do not speak presumptuously, merely
credulously. We simply take the Bible at its word in applying its promises of assurance to ourselves. As
Marrowists, we can and should know that we are saved from both the wrath of hell and the tribulation. This is the
logical outcome of GRAPE theology. The Day of the Lord cannot come unless the departure of the true believers
takes place, leaving behind only those people who have never believed the true gospel. The only gospel those left
behind will have ever believed is the false gospel of salvation by faith and works, in spite of numerous biblical
warnings against this accursed gospel. Paul is thus assuring the Thessalonians from the perspective that genuine
believers can have genuine assurance. Those who do not share his presupposition concerning assurance do not
share his perspective concerning the gospel.

4. Dual Departure
       Nevertheless, it would not seem necessary to limit Paul to the third interpretation. Perhaps he had both
options one and three in mind when he wrote 2Thess 2:3. Why could he not use departure to refer to both the
rapture and the special apostasy that marks the tribulation? Contextually, the word could refer to both at the same
time.
                                           Illustration 68. Dual Apostasy




       Paul uses the word revealed in 2Thess 2:3 to refer to the revelation of the antichrist, and he had just used it
in 2Thess 1:7 to refer to the revelation of Christ. Since the word revelation (apokalupto) in 2:3 can be used in
reference to both the Christ and the false Christ, why not assume that the word departure (apostasia) can be used
in reference to both believers and false believers? This combined view appears to be the most compelling
alternative. The beginning of the tribulation will be marked by the exodus of genuine believers from the earth
to heaven and by the exodus of false believers from Christ to antichrist.
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                         Page 155
                                                   Imminency
        Yet another point concerning the rapture and the Day of the Lord is also very conclusive. 1Thess 5:2-4 says
that this day will come just like a thief in the night. Imminency would require that this be at the beginning of the
tribulation. If it be acknowledged that the Lord can come at any moment, then the pretribulational premillennial
view is a logical necessity in order to be biblically consistent. Does the Bible exhort us to expect the Lord to come
at any moment? Most certainly. Stanton develops this point and objections to it quite nicely. He delineates the
biblical exhortations related to imminency around three words: Look (Phil 3:20; Tit 2:13; Heb 9:28), watch
(1Thess 5:6; Rev 3:3?; Mt 24:42; cf. 25:13; Rev 16:15; Lk 12:37; cf. 21:36), and wait (Rom 8:23; 1Cor 1:7;
1Thess 1:10; cf. 2Thess 3:5; Lk 12:36,40; Mt 24:44).231
        Concerning these exhortations, the reason we can “eagerly await Him,” as Heb 9:28 exhorts us to do, is
because He can come at any moment. That is why Paul also exhorts believers in Phil 3:20 to “eagerly wait for”
Christ to return from heaven. James warns Christians: “The Judge is standing right at the door”; His coming “is at
hand”; He can come at any moment (Jam 5:7-9). James says that “the coming of the Lord is at hand,” not a month,
a year, or seven years down the road. James is saying that Christians do not have to look for signs; they should look
for the Judge. They do not have to wait for signs; His coming is already at hand for them. Tit 2:13 tells us that we
should be looking for Christ. We are looking for Christ, not antichrist. This is the Lord’s point in the book of
Revelation. When He comes to the church in temporal judgment during the church age (in Rev 2:5,16; 3:3) or for
the church in misthological judgment at the end of the church age (in Rev 2:25; 3:10-11), His coming will happen
quickly, that is, suddenly (cf. Rev 22:12). No warning or signs occur beforehand. The reason His coming is “about
to” take place (Rev 3:10) is because it is imminent, not immediate.
        These exhortations and warnings should be contrasted with Mt 24:33. The Lord says that the Jews of that
time period should be able to recognize that His coming is “right at the door” when they see “all these things,” that
is, these signs taking place. The Jews in the tribulation will be looking for signs, but Christians in the church age
should be looking for the Lord. This looking for signs by tribulational believers is in sharp contrast with looking
for the Lord by believers in the present period (cf. Mk 13:32-37). For present believers, Jesus teaches that His
coming may be at any time (which would certainly include now). In Mt 24:36-51 the Lord gives even more details
about this aspect of His coming.
        According to Lk 21:31, the leaves on the fig tree indicate the approach of the kingdom, not that of the
tribulation. Thus, the leaves point to the revelation, not to the rapture. Therefore, Mt 24:32-35 continues the
discussion of the Jewish section; it recapitulates it—sums it up using another parable. So Jesus is saying that, when
the Jews in the time of the tribulation see these signs, they should realize that His coming is at hand—there are no
further signs for which to look. In vv. 32-35 His coming is known and expected. However, in v. 36ff it is unknown
and unexpected. By these shifts and contrasts, Jesus is indicating that His coming will have both aspects, which is
what one would expect since it is in two stages. The Mt. Olivet Discourse thus could be expected to deal with
judgments associated with both stages, meaning that the parable concerning the outer darkness in that Discourse
would be describing the judgment of believers who experience the Bema judgment.
        According to Mt 24:36, “But of that day and hour no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, nor the
Son, but the Father alone.” The time is unknown. Unlike the revelation, we cannot use signs to predict the time of
the rapture. The rapture can happen any moment, as pictured in Mt 24:37-38:

       For the coming of the Son of Man will be just like the days of Noah. For as in those days which were
       before the flood they were eating and drinking, they were marrying and giving in marriage, until the
       day that Noah entered the ark.

Jesus is teaching that life will be business as usual; no special signs will mark this stage of His coming. Thus, He is
describing the peace before the rapture, not the tribulation before the revelation. Jesus continues in Mt 24:39, “And
they did not understand until the flood came and took them all away; so shall the coming of the Son of Man be.” In
other words, the rapture is sudden and unexpected. Preachers can preach about the Lord’s coming rapture, just like
Noah preached about the Lord’s coming judgment. Evan so, as with the flood, people in general do not expect the
rapture because they cannot see signs of it coming. Likewise, Mt 24:40-41 pictures the rapture, “Then there shall
be two men in the field; one will be taken/raptured, and one will be left. Two women will be grinding at the mill;
one will be taken/raptured, and one will be left.” The same Greek word for taken (paralambano) is used by Jesus
used to describe the rapture in Jn 14:3. Although the use of the same word from one context to the next is not
Page 156                                                                                                   The Outer Darkness
                              *
conclusive, it is indicative. In the context, Mt 24:42 makes it clear that believers need to “be on the alert” for His
coming now because He may come now. In the same manner, Mt 24:43 informs believers that He will come just
like a thief in the night (cf. 1Thess 5:2-4). And Mt 24:44 warns believers that He will come at a time when even
you (i.e., believers) will not be expecting Him (cf. v. 50). Here comes your judge, Christian. Since the rapture is
imminent, the pretribulational premillennial view is the only option.

                                                          Temple
        The details of the passage in 2Thess 2:1-12 create problems for non-pretribulationalists. For example,
Hoekema is forced to admit that the antichrist is a person who will rise out of the great tribulation, who will be
worshipped, who will perform deceptive miracles, and who will teach deceptive teachings.232 Antichrist will do all
this before Christ comes again! No wonder Hoekema prefers to think of the Parousia† as impending rather than
imminent!233 Apparently, in Hoekema’s view, we may not know when Christ is coming, but we know when He is
not coming. Christ is not coming tonight, not this week, and not even this month! The dilemma does not end here.
If the rise of the antichrist indicates the nearness of the return of Christ, then when the antichrist is revealed, we
will have a sign indicating that Christ is about to return. If that be true, then how can Christ’s return be a surprise?
It cannot be. Hoekema must “look forward to a climactic series of future events associated with the Second
Coming”234 rather than to the second coming itself.
        Archer also, in defending a midtribulational rapture, looks for a series of events. But he is more candid in
thoroughly rejecting an imminent rapture:

       The teaching Paul was rebuking [in 2Thess 2:2] as erroneous was an any-moment Rapture! Some
       were arguing that the Day of Christ, involving the gathering together of all Christian believers to
       Himself, was impending already….We also have a clear denial of the doctrine of the any-moment
       Rapture, for Paul unequivocally denies that the Day of the Lord is at hand (enesteken).235

        Archer’s objection is dependent upon the translational renderings he cites from the KJV and ASV, in which
it is said that the Day of the Lord is at hand. As a result, his whole argument collapses when it is noted that
enesteken is the perfect form of enistemi. This is why a number of translations will render it emphatically in the
past as having already come (NIB, NIV, NJB, NRS) or simply in the past by saying that it has or had come (ESV,
NAS, NKJ, NLT, RSV, RWB). The thought conveyed by the perfect tense is it already had come and consequently
is present. As noted above regarding 2Thess 2:3,‡ some were misleading the Thessalonians by telling them that the
Day of the Lord already had come and that they thus were presently in it—the exact opposite of what Archer
contends. The false teachers were teaching that the Thessalonians were already in the midst of the Day of the Lord.
Therefore, the teaching Paul is refuting is the teaching that the rapture may not come until believers are in the
midst of the tribulation. This effectively identifies the midtribulation position as a form of the false teaching Paul is
rebutting. Paul had taught them that the Day of the Lord would come like a thief in the night (1Thess 5:2).
Therefore, it would commence after the rapture and mark the beginning of the seven year period of the tribulation.
Those who teach that the rapture will be preceded by signs, such as the rebuilding of the temple, are the ones being
contradicted by Paul.
        The prophecy that the antichrist will sit in the temple must be included in this series of events that Paul
gives to the Thessalonians. Since the rapture and Day of the Lord is imminent, it must come before the series of
literal events that mark that action commencement. Old Testament prophecies may have single, double, or multiple
fulfillments, as opposed to multiple meanings (i.e., sensus plenior), depending upon the specific prophecy.236
Daniel’s prophecy about the temple was fulfilled literally in 167 B.C. and A.D. 70. Therefore, the other prophecies
about the temple will be fulfilled literally as well.

       And forces from him [the antichrist] will arise, desecrate the sanctuary fortress [=temple], and do
       away with the regular sacrifice. And they will set up the abomination of desolation. (Dan 11:31)

        Consistency would anticipate that the future and ultimate fulfillment concerning the temple also will be
literal. Therefore, the reference to temple in 2Thess 2:4 should be taken literally. This position best fits Jesus’
prophecy in Mt 24; Mk 13; and Lk 21. This series of events is literal. The antichrist literally will sit in a Jewish
temple after the rapture. Strimple, an amillennialist, objects:

           Since Christ is the true temple, we are to look for no other. When the apostle John is given that
      climactic vision of a new heaven and a new earth, and of “the Holy City, the new Jerusalem, coming

       On the contrary, Hodges observes: “The rebuilt physical Temple referred to in Matthew 24:15 is duly
acknowledged by Jesus when He refers to it as ‘the holy place.’ The validity of the Sabbath law is also implied in
verse 20” (emphasis his).238 Jewish believers at that time will be expected by the Lord literally to subject
themselves to Sabbatical law. This rules out amillennialism since it is a literal temple. The fact that they are under
such law also rules out the preterism of postmillennialism. Jewish believers in A.D. 70 were not subject to the
Jewish law. Yet even more may be gleaned from Hodges’ observations concerning the temple:

            The so-called Second Temple of Judaism, that existed while Jesus was on earth, was doomed to
      destruction (Matthew 24:1-2). In its place would rise, by the work of the Holy Spirit, a new, spiritual
      temple composed not of physical materials, but of believing people (see 1 Peter 2:1-5). As Jesus said
      (Matthew 16:18), He Himself would be the Builder of this new Temple of God!
            Therefore, the removal of the Church from the earth at the beginning of our Lord’s parousia is
      the removal of this spiritual Temple from the earth. (Emphasis his.)239

       Believers individually and corporately are called the temple of God (1Cor 3:16-17; 2Cor 6:16; Eph 2:21).
John specifies that overcomers will be permanent pillars in that temple and associates this temple with the New
Jerusalem, the bridal city, “which comes down out of heaven from My God” (Rev 3:12). As noted from Strimple
above, it comes “down out of heaven from God, prepared as a bride beautifully dressed for her husband.”
Consequently, the temple of eternity future will not only be comprised of the Lord God Almighty and the Lamb but
also of the wife of the Lamb—overcomers who live in the capital city. Presumably, the Jewish temple cannot be
rebuilt until the spiritual temple is removed. Although the Dome of the Rock may be a pragmatic obstacle
preventing the rebuilding of the next and final Jewish temple, it would seem fair to theorize that the presence of the
spiritual temple is the theological obstacle preventing the Jewish temple from being rebuilt. Once the church is
removed via the rapture, the tribulational wrath and building of the Jewish temple may commence.
       Hoekema basically provides two further amillennial objections against regarding this as a literal Jewish
temple.240 (1) Jesus’ prophecy is an example of prophetic foreshortening; thus, when Jesus prophesied the
destruction of Jerusalem followed by the great tribulation and His second coming, Jesus presented events together
which in fulfillment occur far apart; and (2) the destruction of Jerusalem is a type of the end of the age.241

Prophetic Foreshortening
        Prophetic foreshortening and typology are valid ways of understanding prophecy; however, they are not the
only ways, nor do they exclude other hermeneutical options such as multiple fulfillments. Briefly, prophetic
foreshortening refers to the phenomena which occurred when prophets sometimes prophesied events together in
their visions that were separated by many years in their fulfillment. It is often compared to looking at a mountain
range. One can see two peaks that appear together from a distance, but upon closer examination, it becomes
apparent that one peak is a considerable distance behind the other peak, with a valley in-between. For example, the
first and second coming of the Messiah were sometimes presented by the OT prophets as if the two events happen
one right after the other. However, in actual fulfillment, we now know that a considerable period of time occurs
between the comings. When the OT prophets prophesied that the Messiah would suffer and be glorified, they could
not foresee the period of time that would lapse between these two advents. The valley of the church age was
hidden from their sight.
Page 158                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                      Illustration 69. Prophetic Foreshortening




                                                                                Valley

Christ:                                                  Suffering                                   Glory
         The prophets could see the suffering and glorified Christ. They could see details of two separate future
events pertaining to the Christ, but they could not clearly see the gap of time between these two events and thus
that these events would occur in two separate stages. In order to limit sensus plenior (i.e., Scripture having many
meanings) merely to accommodate the possibility of prophetic foreshortening, limiting this phenomenon to time
rather than expanded it to meaning is best (i.e., a references plenior).242 The events were separated in time and
perhaps extent of fulfillment, but they are the same in kind of fulfillment. That is, since Jesus’ first coming was
literal, His second coming must be literal also. The same kind of coming is involved both times—a literal coming.
One cannot take the first coming literally and the second coming spiritually (i.e., figuratively). The two comings
are separate in time not in kind. The prophets could see that the Messiah would be crucified and glorified; the
details of the one event are just as literal as the details of the other event. The mountains represent literal details
pertaining to the corresponding events.
         Assuming that Hoekema is correct that the destruction of the temple is another example of prophetic
foreshortening with multiple fulfillments, the same presupposition should be made concerning literal fulfillment.
Just as the destruction of the temple was literal, its future defilement will be literal. The antichrist will sit in a
literal temple. A literal correspondence exists between the desolation of the temple in A.D. 70 and the future
desolation of the temple in the great tribulation. Prophetic foreshortening refutes, rather than supports, Hoekema’s
position. The first two destructions of the temple were fulfilled literally, and the third will be likewise. Hoekema is
mistaken in taking the third major fulfillment as different in kind from the first two. The Jewish temple will be
literal since 2Thess 2:4 says that the antichrist will take his seat in that temple.
                                       Illustration 70. Temple Foreshortening




 Temple:                                                 167 BC 70 AD                                Trib
      At this point it would be natural to ask, “How can we be certain that the next temple will be the tribulational
temple?” After all, since there are multiple temples, then why could there not be several more built and destroyed
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                             Page 159
before we finally arrive at the one prophesied in the Bible during the tribulation (e.g., Dan 9:27; Mt 24:15;
2Thess 2:4; Rev 11:1-2)? As a follow up to this question, it might also be asked, “Will the tribulational temple be
built before the tribulation, or could they at least start building it before the tribulation?” In response, it may be said
that pattern fulfillment does not necessarily mean that one can have an unlimited number of typological precursory
events, or in this case, an unlimited number of temples. Scripture only prophesies two more temples: the
tribulational temple and the millennial temple (Eze 40-41). Although the argument that the next temple must be
that of the tribulation (and can only be built after the tribulation starts) is established on a theological argument
regarding the spiritual temple, its corroboration from history makes it well nigh certain. On that site today stands
the oldest extant Islamic structure, the Dome of the Rock, where Muslims believe the Prophet Muhammad ascended
to heaven. This shrine was completed between 691 and 692 and is the third holiest site of pilgrimage for Muslims.
The presence of this shrine currently prevents the building of the Jewish temple. It is a pragmatic rather than
strictly prophetic indicator that the rapture must occur before the shrine is destroyed and the temple is built. One
certainly would expect the destruction of that shrine to start a holy war of tribulational proportions. Even if the
temple were to be build beside of the Dome of the Rock, the Muslim reaction would a holy jihad.
        Some use Dan 11:45 as a proof that the temple will be built during the time of the tribulation. But this is
inaccurate. Although Dan 11:36-45 does describe the 70th week, the event described in Dan 11:45 is more properly
identified as the time when the antichrist comes to Jerusalem and erects an image in the temple, which already has
been built. And he puts an end to offering of the Jewish sacrifices in that temple (Dan 12:11). Thus, all that can be
explicitly affirmed is that the temple must already have been built previously, presumably at the beginning of the
tribulation. This correlation of prophetic and pragmatic factors allows one to conclude that the next temple will be
the tribulational temple. For the theological reasons noted above, the anticipation herein is that the destruction of
the shrine and the building of the temple probably will follow the rapture in short order. It will be built at the
beginning of the tribulation, probably under the protection of the antichrist.*

Types
        Hoekema’s supposition that there are many antichrists (e.g., Nero, Stalin, Hitler, etc.) is reasonable. Unlike
the temple situation above, it is sensible to postulate that since Satan does not know when Christ will return, he
must have an antichrist ready in each generation to assume global domination, so there are an unlimited number of
antichrists. Nevertheless, there will be one final, climactic, literal antichrist. Both Antiochus Epiphanes and Titus
were types of the antichrist. Antiochus was the first fulfillment of Daniel’s prophecy concerning the temple; Titus
was the second; and there will be a third major fulfillment. Hoekema is correct on these points. His error lies in
merely linking the prophetic foreshortening and typological correspondence between the desolation of Jerusalem
and the great tribulation. The subject matter includes the temple, not just the tribulation. As Jesus is walking out
of the temple, He tells his disciples that the temple will be destroyed. His disciples ask Him when it would happen.
          1
            And as He was going out of the temple, one of His disciples said to Him, “Teacher, behold what
          wonderful stones and what wonderful buildings!” 2 And Jesus said to him, “Do you see these great
          buildings? Not one stone shall be left upon another which will not be torn down.” 3 And as He was
          sitting on the Mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter and James and John and Andrew were

          understand), then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.…26 And then they will see the

        Jesus informs them about the coming destruction and desolation of the temple. Prophecies about the temple
concern multiple fulfillments (separate in time) concerning the same kind of temple—a literal Jewish temple. Jesus
and Paul teach the same sequence. The desolation of the temple will be followed by the revelation of Jesus in
glory. In short, there will be a literal future desolation of the temple since (1) it fits the context of Jesus’ prophecies
better, (2) it concurs with 2Thess 2:4 that there will be another temple, and (3) the multiple fulfillments of Daniel’s
prophecy, which already have been fulfilled, took place in a literal temple.

Imminency
        How can Christ’s second coming be at any moment since there is no
temple? It cannot be if His second coming is one stage. If His next coming is        Illustration 71. Temple Mount
in one stage, then it cannot be imminent in any real sense of the word. Christ
cannot come at an hour we think not nor like a thief in the night—if His
second coming is in one stage. He is not coming until after the temple is
built, and the antichrist takes his seat in it. Thus, the details of 2Thess 2:1-
12, when combined with the doctrine of imminency (which was made




                                                                                                       io n
                                                                                                                    r ev
implicit in 1Thess 5:2-3), demand that the second coming of Christ be
understood as occurring in two stages. One stage is imminent; the other




                                                                                                    uat
stage is not. The first stage (i.e., the rapture) is imminent and occurs before




                                                                                                                        e la
the signs and details. In this first stage, the church is evacuated from earth
before God’s wrath comes upon those who dwell on the earth. The second




                                                                                                   c


                                                                                                                          ti o n
stage (i.e., the revelation) is after the signs and details, which includes the




                                                                                               eva
desolation of the temple. The evacuation of the church takes place before
the desolation of the temple. The revelation of Christ takes place after the
desolation of the temple. These two aspects of His coming thus are separated
by the events surrounding the temple. We are looking at two different sides
of the same mountain. The mountain is the desolation of the third temple.
On this side of the mountain, we encounter the evacuation of believers via
                                                                                                    desolation
rapture. On the other side, we find the revelation of Christ.
        To summarize 2Thess 2:1-12, after the restrainer is removed by means of the rapture (v. 1), the “first” (v. 3)
things to happen are the climax of the apostasy and the revealing of the antichrist who then must be worshipped,
perform deceptive miracles, teach deceptive doctrines, and “take his seat in the temple of God,” that is, the Jewish
temple (v. 4). All these things take place before the revelation of Christ in v. 8. The antichrist must first be revealed
publicly before Christ is revealed publicly. Paul is saying that the second coming does not happen until after the
tribulation. If the second coming is not in two stages, then we should be looking for antichrist, not Christ. If it is
not in two stages, then we can be certain that Christ is not coming any time soon! Whom do you have your eyes set
upon, Christ or antichrist? Are you looking for Christ or the signs of Christ? Only pretribulationalists can be
consistent with their theological affirmation in answering that they are looking for the return of the Lord rather than
for the appearance of the antichrist.

                                                             Typology
       The legitimacy of types already has been acknowledged in the discussion concerning the temple above.
Walvoord makes appropriate use of types when he says, “It is characteristic of divine dealing to deliver believers
before a divine judgment is inflicted on the world as illustrated in the deliverance of Noah, Lot, Rahab, etc.
(2 Peter 2:5-9).”243 In 2Pet 2:5-9, Peter makes a correlation* between God’s past deliverance of Noah and Lot
before He executed judgment on the world and God’s future wrath in the day of judgment. Jesus uses this same
typology concerning Noah to make the same point in Mt 24:37-41. God’s wrath was not turned loose on the world
in the past until Noah entered the ark; it will not commence in the future until believers are taken out of the way.
And in Lk 17:26-32, Jesus uses both Noah and Lot to illustrate the Day of the Lord, saying that it will be just the
same on that future day of judgment.
        20
           And the Lord said, “The outcry of Sodom and Gomorrah is indeed great, and their sin is
        exceedingly grave.”…23 And Abraham came near and said, “Wilt Thou indeed sweep away the
        righteous with the wicked?”… 25 Far be it from Thee to do such a thing, to slay the righteous with
        the wicked, so that the righteous and the wicked are treated alike. Far be it from Thee! Shall not the
        Judge of all the earth deal justly?”
        1
         Now the two angels came to Sodom in the evening as Lot was sitting in the gate of Sodom…15 the
        angels urged Lot, saying, “Up, take your wife and your two daughters, who are here, lest you be

of correlativity, which would address soteric-mistholic correspondences. See Theory of Correlativity, 911.

       swept away in the punishment of the city.” But he hesitated. So the men seized his hand and the

       and they brought him out, and put him outside the city. 17 And it came about when they had brought

       28
         It was the same as happened in the days of Lot: they were eating, they were drinking, they were
       buying, they were selling, they were planting, they were building; 29 but on the day that Lot went
       out from Sodom it rained fire and brimstone from heaven and destroyed them all. 30 It will be just the
       same on the day that the Son of Man is revealed…. 32 Remember Lot’s wife. 33 Whoever seeks to
       keep his life shall lose it, and whoever loses his life shall preserve it. (Lk 17:28-33)

        We are accustomed to the expression: It cannot start without you. In this case the opposite is true: It cannot
start with you. The angels had to get Lot to safety before the Lord’s judgment could be executed on Sodom and
Gomorrah. The Lord will take believers out of the way before He deals with the world, just as He took Lot out of
the way before He dealt with Sodom and Gomorrah. The Lord will spare all believers, even pathetic ones like Lot,
from the tribulation. The picture concerning Lot provides additional details. Lot’s wife also serves typologically as
an illustration of a believer delivered from the wrath of the tribulation, but who still forfeited her life (soul) since
she was not fit for the kingdom. Although she was not a Sodomite, she looked back longingly to the world she had
left behind. She escaped the wrath but lost her soul-life! So will it be with many Christians!
        For a believer to lose his or her soul-life would mean that his or her capacity to experience pleasure in the
form of heavenly treasure will be forfeited. Such believers will lose their soulical capacity to experience pleasure in
direct proportion to the time and energy they wasted on earth in trying to increase their soulical pleasures at the
expense of their heavenly treasure. * In the case of those believers disqualified for kingdom rulership, they will lose
their souls completely in terms of failing to reap the capacity of experiencing the pleasure of ruling with Christ.
        Immediately following the rapture, all believers (faithful and unfaithful) will appear before the JSC. Some
will lose their soul-lives. The work of their earthly lives will go up in smoke at the Bema resulting in relatively no
rewards for their earthly lives. Their earthly lives will have been a complete waste in terms of heavenly treasure.
The example of Lot’s wife shows that believers cannot afford to look forward and backward. They must set their
eyes on Jesus (Heb 12:2) rather than on the things of the world. Having put our hand to the plow, we are warned by
Jesus about the danger of looking back (Lk 9:62). No one who is looking back is fit for (i.e., worthy of) the
kingdom.† Worthy or not, we will escape the fire and brimstone, even as Lot’s wife did—which pictures salvation
from hell and thus entering the kingdom. But inheriting the kingdom is determined by whether we are fit for
rulership in the kingdom.244 The question is whether we will be counted worthy to rule.

                                                      Partial Rapture
       This above typological overview concerning Noah, Lot, and Lot’s wife points out several things:

            4. the legitimacy of typology in understanding eschatology,
            5. the legitimate use of typology to demonstrate the pretribulational position,
            6. eschatological agreement with Walvoord that the rapture will not be partial,
            7. soteriological disagreement with Walvoord’s proveitism that all true believers will prove that they
               are genuine believers by a life of good works,
            8. misthological disagreement with Walvoord that all true believers are watching for the Lord and
               living lives that demonstrate that they have their eyes fixed on Jesus rather than on the things of this
               world.

  See Persevere for Pleasure, 327; Conclusion, 517. See “Overlapping Functions” in Trichotomy. Also see illustration of the “Loss of

†
  See Misthological Worthiness, 73; Misthological Entrance Expanded, 749; endnote 609.

       For reasons already anticipated, disagreement with Walvoord is necessary concerning a number of
unfavorable judgments he passes upon the partial rapture position in his chapter dealing with this subject.245
Although, like Walvoord, I reject the partial rapture position, I find Walvoord’s soteriological criticism of Govett
and Lang to be unfair and inaccurate and some of his eschatological criticisms of their position to be objectionable.
Walvoord says, concerning Mt 24:40-51, that faithfulness determines who is a true believer.246 I object strongly. If
that were the case, then faithfulness is required to enter heaven, and salvation from hell is determined ultimately by
faith and works. Marrowists cannot agree with Walvoord that faithfulness determines who is a true believer. His
soteriologically-based criticism of the partial rapture position is very much in harmony with Puritanism and falls
short of eschatological sensitivity to the texts. I renounce his Amyraldian Calvinism in favor of Marrowism
instead. Rejecting Walvoord’s eschatological perception concerning the time period involved in this passage and a
number of other passages is also necessary as well. As will be demonstrated subsequently, his identification of the
virgins in Mt 25:1-13 is unacceptable soteriologically.
       As to the point at hand, Walvoord’s analysis of 1Thess 5:6 is defective soteriologically, as already has been
pointed out from its context.* He believes that genuine believers will watch and live lives in keeping with that
watching and thus demonstrate their faith. On the contrary, the very fact that Paul is writing to believers who
already are sons of light, and on that basis urging them to live like sons of light, indicates that Paul does not believe
that believers invariably will live the way they should. Walvoord’s understanding (that being found soteriologically
sinless in Heb 9:28 is a result of eagerly awaiting Christ’s return is unfortunate) in that he considers soteriological
sinlessness a result of eager waiting. But it is not. This type of sinlessness, and thus this passage, should be
understood misthologically.† The same is true of Rev 3:3 and 3:10. These are misthological passages, addressed to
those who are genuine believers, which makes their respective warning and blessing contingent upon perseverance,
and thus upon works. Walvoord’s analysis of James 2 reflects the same typical misunderstanding of the nature of
faith and works. He says, “The evidence of salvation, good works, is pointed to as necessary to salvation (James
2:21-26).”247 But such a statement is equivalent to asserting that good works are necessary for salvation!248 To
make this salvation from eternal damnation is to teach a gospel that Paul calls accursed. As Myers surmises:
“There are three major systems attacking the gospel of grace: Roman Catholic, Reformed, and Arminian.” By
making good works the necessary result of justification, all three systems teach that good “works are necessary in
order to get to heaven.”249 Walvoord’s inconsistent Reformed view is an affront to consistent FG theology.
       Govett and Lang are among the very best writers in the field of misthology. And their soteriological
perspective is far superior to that of many of their critics, such as Walvoord. Chitwood correctly summarizes that
Govett and Lang are sound soteriologically and misthologically but weak in their eschatology:

               What they failed to understand was that God’s future judgment of Christians is not associated
          with the rapture, but occurs at a time beyond the rapture.
               The separation of Christians—the faithful separated from the unfaithful—occurs at the
          Judgment Seat of Christ in heaven alone, not here on earth via a partial or selective removal of
          certain Christians. (Emphasis his.)250

Reward = Gift?
       The reason that Govett’s partial rapture theory is wrong is not because all believers deserve the reward of
being raptured (as Walvoord seems to think), but because the rapture is based on grace—not merit or rewards.
According to Walvoord, “the reward given to believers…is entrance into the millennial kingdom…Their reward
is entrance into the millennial kingdom.”251 Walvoord makes entrance into the kingdom a reward! Yet this is the
position of Govett whom Walvoord criticizes! Walvoord is correct in saying that Govett originated the partial
rapture theory because Govett thought that “participation in the kingdom is conditional and depends on worthy
conduct.”252 Govett believes that entrance is a reward, but Walvoord believes the same thing!
       The only real difference between Govett and Walvoord on this matter is that Govett believes that believers
should have conduct worthy of this reward, and Walvoord believes that they will have conduct worthy of this
reward.‡ In all reality, both men believe the rapture is a reward. In an attempt to evade this admission, Walvoord
concludes that entrance into the millennial kingdom is a part of “salvation provided by grace and is a reward only

*
    See 1Thess 5:7-8, 137.
†
    See Misthological Sinlessness (p. 772) and compare with discussion of blamelessness in Eph 5:27, 585.
‡
    See endnote 246.
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                                        Page 163
                                                        253
in the sense that it is a fruit of faith in Christ.” In other words, according to Walvoord, salvation from eternal
damnation is a reward that is given in response to fruity faith. However, this means that it is earned by faith’s fruit.
Since Walvoord’s position is that works are required for faith to be saving, his position must likewise conclude that
works are required for entrance into the millennial kingdom. His fruity soteriological entrance is faulty.
        Stated more fully, Walvoord’s position is equivalent to saying that saving faith is the only requirement for
entrance into the millennial kingdom, but works are required for saving faith; thus, faith and works are both
required for entrance into the millennial kingdom. Consequently, Walvoord does not really believe that faith is the
only requirement for entrance into the kingdom. As noted above, the only substantial difference between these two
men is that Govett thinks that only some believers have the works necessary to merit this entrance while Walvoord
believes all believers have the works necessary to merit this entrance. Pentecost does no better in his rebuttal of the
partial rapture position than Walvoord. After erroneously charging the partial rapture position with a defective
soteriological understanding, Pentecost then proceeds to blunder by claiming that the partial rapture position
“would make rewards a legal obligation on the part of God, rather than a gracious gift.”254 Pentecost thinks that
rewards are gifts and that the rapture is a reward that is given as a gift to all believers. This is confused nonsense.
Pentecost’s inability to tell the difference between a gift and a reward is based on a false identification of rewards
                                          merit-gracious reward. However, contrary to Pentecost, rewards are not gracious
as gifts. Rewards are gracious: grace-grace         works
gifts! Rewards are based jointly on condign and congruent merit. GRAPE theology avoids Pentecost’s muddled
mistake.* Govett and Lang are better representatives of GRAPE than are Pentecost and Walvoord since the errors
in eschatology by the former pair are not as destructive as the errors in soteriology by the latter pair.

Reward ≠ Gift
        The ability and opportunity to earn rewards is a gift, but the actual earning of the reward itself is a work.
Since the actual earning of the reward is a work, and the actual giving of rewards is based on this work, rewards
themselves are not gifts. Rewards are neither a gift nor a legal obligation based solely on strict merit apart from
any grace whatsoever.† Condign merit is not strict merit. The gracious obligatory nature of rewards in relation to
condign merit does not necessarily imply the legalistic obligatory nature of strict merit. Even apart from such
precise considerations, Pentecost’s criticism is easily shown to be groundless. Grace makes rewards possible, but
saving grace should not be confused with enabling grace. Grace makes works possible, but rewards are not based
solely on the grace that makes the works possible. Rather, rewards are based on the works that are done in response
to such grace. Rewards are based on works—on our active response to God’s grace.
        Rewards are based directly on our works and only indirectly upon the grace that makes such works possible.
For an action to be truly rewardable in heaven, it must be done in dependence on God’s enabling grace by those
who already have experienced God’s saving grace. Nevertheless, the reward is based ultimately on the culminating
action—the performance (i.e., the work)—rather than exclusively on the grace that made such action possible.
Partial rapture advocates frequently have a better understanding of both soteriology and misthology than many of
their critics. As has been demonstrated, many of the criticisms against the partial rapture position are objectionable.
But the weakness of these responses to the partial rapture interpretation does not mean that the partial rapture
position is plausible. Rejection of the partial rapture will follow, but this rejection will not be based on the faulty
soteriological objections so often provided by critics of that position.

Scripture Concerning the Rapture
       In 1Thess 4:16 Paul explicitly says that the rapture will involve the resurrection of the dead in Christ. Since
every believer in Christ is in Christ, Paul is affirming the resurrection of every dead believer at the time of the
rapture, regardless of whether they are faithful to Christ. Since the rapture is to involve the resurrection of every
dead believer, whether they were faithful to Christ, it would seem reasonable to conclude that it also involves the
translation of every living believer, regardless of whether they are faithful to Christ. This is certainly the
implication of the next verse (1Thess 4:17), which teaches that those who are physically “alive and remain” will be
raptured. No exceptions are noted. The implication of 1Thess 4:16-17 is that the rapture involves every dead and
living person in Christ.

*
 See Marrowism’s GRAPE, 20.
†
 Strict merit refers to an equitable exchange between works and their attendant reward. Basically, the reward is the agreed-upon, fair-
payment value for the service performed. The reward is fully merited. No appeal to grace occurs in this view: merit-reward. See
Misthological Merit, 21. As explained therein, condign merit affirms that God graciously obligates Himself to reward us via His
promise to do so. Congruent merit affirms that God graciously rewards us with more than we deserve.
Page 164                                                                                                 The Outer Darkness
        Paul continues this discussion in 1Thess 5 and explicitly teaches that the rapture will be for all believers,
regardless of whether they are faithful to Christ, that is, regardless of whether they morally are awake or asleep.
Paul’s follow-up instruction to the Thessalonians concerning the removal of the restrainer in 2Thess 2:6-8 indicates
that the Holy Spirit as uniquely present in believers will be removed. And this calls for the removal of all believers
since all believers are sealed by the Spirit.
        The typology of Lot and his wife also points to the removal of all believers before the tribulation begins.
The partial rapture position is ruled out implicitly and explicitly by these considerations. That the rapture involves
all living and dead believers in Christ is explicitly affirmed by Paul in 1Cor 15:51-52, where he said, “We shall not
all sleep, but we shall all be changed, in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet; for the trumpet
will sound, and the dead will be raised imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality.” All Christians will
be translated at the same time, and thus all Christians will be involved in the rapture. It is not called the last
trumpet in the sense that there will never be another one. As a matter of fact, there are seven more trumpets yet to
be sounded in the trumpet judgments of Revelation (8:2). Midtribulationalists confuse the seventh trumpet of the
tribulation with the last trumpet for the church. The seventh trumpet of Revelation is the last of that series, but the
one in 1Cor 15:52 is not part of a series. This last trumpet for the church in Corinthians is the one that marks the
conclusion of the church age.
        For example, John repeatedly describes the rapture as taking place on the last day (Jn 6:39-40,44,54;
11:24).255 This is not the last day that will ever occur. Other days will follow in the tribulation and in the
millennium, as well as throughout eternity. The last days (plural) for the church (2Tim 3:1; Heb 1:2) as well as this
last day (singular) for the church in the Johannine passages above are to be distinguished from and followed by the
last days for Israel (Is 2:2; Micah 4:1; Acts 2:17). According to Jesus, the resurrection of all believers of the current
time period marks the conclusion of the present time period. The word last in this sense means last of a period of
time. It is a relative last rather than an absolute last. It is the last day relative to that period of time. The last
trumpet for the church is sounded on the last day for the church. It signifies the close of the church age. There will
be other trumpets and days after these but not for the church. Thus, Jn 6:39-40 is not only one of the strongest
passages in the Bible pertaining to eternal security, but when coupled with 1Cor 15:52, it is also one of the
strongest arguments against a partial rapture. All believers of the church age will be resurrected at the same time.

Time of Judgment
        The partial rapture is also impossible in view of the Bema judgment that all believers will experience
immediately after the rapture. Numerous passages indicate that the judgment of faithful and unfaithful believers at
the Judgment Seat of Christ in heaven occurs at the same time and immediately after the rapture. For example, in
Mt 24:42-51 the slave (whether he be faithful or unfaithful) is judged when his master returns. This pictures the
judgment of faithful and unfaithful believers as happening immediately after the rapture and at the same time. In
the parable of the talents in Mt 25:14-30, the faithful and unfaithful slaves are judged when their master returns.
Both the faithful and unfaithful are judged at the same time. Again, this pictures the judgment of faithful and
unfaithful believers as happening synchronically, immediately after the rapture.
        Luke 14:14 likewise teaches that this payment via judgment is rendered at the time of the resurrection. In the
parable of the minas in Lk 19:12-27, worthy and unworthy slaves are judged at the same time—when their master
returns. This also pictures the judgment of faithful and unfaithful believers as happening at the same time,
immediately after the rapture. In reference to Luke, it may be mentioned concerning Lk 4:5 that if Satan can show
all the kingdoms of the earth in a moment, and if God can rapture and resurrect all believers in a moment (in the
twinkling of an eye), and if God can create this vast universe in six days, then the first few years of the tribulation
will provide more than enough time for Him to judge each and every believer.*
        Paul explicitly teaches in 2Cor 5:10 that all believers are to be judged at the Judgment Seat of Christ. Thus,
the Bema is for all the living and dead in Christ. Paul had earlier pictured this judgment in 1Cor 3:11-15. Since
there will be believers at this judgment who have all their works burned and who correspondingly receive no
reward, it is evident that Walvoord is soteriologically wrong in saying that faithfulness determines who is a true
believer. Here, in 1Cor 3:15, is a believer who is saved who was not faithful or watchful. It is also evident that
Govett and Lang are eschatologically wrong, since this unfaithful believer is judged at the same time as the faithful
believer.


*
 For various views of time theory, see “Five Views of Time” in Predestination and the Open View. For an elastic time bubble for
Bema, see “Relatively Elastic” in Predestination and the Open View.
Chapter 5. Two Stages (2Thess 2:1-8)                                                                                          Page 165
        In this context, Paul refers to the JSC as the Day (1Cor 3:13; ESV), not those days. Similarly, in 2Tim 4:8,
judgment day is called that Day (ESV), not those days. Now, while the Bema certainly will occur over a period of
many days (three and a half years E.S.T. to be exact), Paul can lump all those days into one because all contestants
will be present and accounted for when the award ceremony begins. The race will be completed for all participants.
Every believer to be evaluated, that is, all church-age believers, will be present. Good and bad believers will be
present at the same time. Thus, we speak of Judgment Day, not Judgment Days. Paul is in heaven now, still
awaiting his crown. He did not anticipate receiving it immediately after he died. Rather, he states that crowns for
church-age believers will be awarded on that Day (i.e., the Day of Christ, Phil 2:16). That is the day in which Paul
will be rejoice over the crown he is awarded. Peter concurs on the timing as being when Christ appears (1Pet 5:4),
that is, when Christ comes (1Cor 4:5).*
        James 5:7-9 expresses the timing of the event very vividly, “Be patient, therefore, brethren, until the
coming of the Lord.…strengthen your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is at hand. Do not complain, brethren,
against one another, that you yourselves may not be judged (krino); behold, the Judge (krites) is standing right at
the door.” Since the coming is at hand, it is the rapture. Further, the exhortation based on the coming is addressed
to the brethren, thus to believers. When the Lord comes in the rapture for believers, it will be as Judge (krites) to
judge (krino). The common assumption that the Bema will merely be an awards podium (since it supposedly does
not entail judgment) is thus refuted.† This Jacobean Bema will certainly involve krima (judgment), and severe
krima at that (Jam 3:1).
        Moreover, believers themselves will be judged, not just their works. James is urging them not to be found in
a state of complaining against one another. He associates the judgment of believers with the rapture. Jesus,
likewise, in Rev 22:12 indicates that judgment will be for “every” one, faithful and unfaithful, and that it occurs
when He returns.‡ Of course, this should be understood as being applicable for each and every one of those in their
own respective time periods. When Jesus comes for the church, He will reward everyone in the church age. As just
demonstrated, although the partial rapture position of Govett and Lang must be rejected, not every criticism of their
position must be accepted. Their writings are far too valuable to be set aside and ignored. Their writings must be
read with discernment, but this warning is just as true, and probably much more so, concerning the inconsistencies
of others, especially of some of their soteriological critics. The misthological expertise of partial rapturists should
be appreciated, and regarding the soteriological charges leveled against them, they should be exonerated.
Disagreement with their eschatology need not invoke criticism of their soteriology or failure to appreciate
commendable points in their misthology.

                                                           Conclusion
        As in the previous chapter on Paul’s discussion in 1 Thessalonians, this chapter on 2 Thessalonians finds
that Paul locates the gathering of believers to the Lord before the events of the tribulation take place. The rapture is
not the reward, since it is unearned. Rather, the rest to be repaid to the believer will be subsequent to the
tribulation. This is pictured in the restless, unclothed souls under the throne awaiting their rest/rulership in the
millennial kingdom to follow.
        The apostasy/departure of believers from earth is to be followed by the apostasy/departure of professing
believers (who were left behind as a result of their trusting in some form of their works). Many professing believers
will turn from the worship of Christ to the worship of the antichrist. It is highly ironic that many of those who
reject the partial rapture position (because it conditions participation in the rapture upon works) will themselves be
left behind because they condition their salvation from eternal damnation upon their works. Critics cry foul when

*
  Those days is a common expression for the time of the tribulation on earth (Mt 24:19,29; Mk 13:17,19-20,24; Lk 21:23; Rev 9:6).
Judgment Day, in contrast, is looked upon as a singular event for those being dealt with in that particular period. The day of judgment
for church-age believers would be a separate day of judgment for tribulational believers. Nevertheless, the day for each group would
be viewed singularly. A day of judgment does not share a one-to-one correspondence to the passage of days on earth. A singular day
of judgment might last many corresponding days on earth. Given the Lord’s ability to control time, a singular day in His court might
be a very long time. The judgment of church-age believers might be a singular event in heaven (lasting thousands of years) while only
1260 days pass on earth. The 75 days for the judgment of various other groups at the conclusion of the tribulation will pose no
problem for the Lord of time to complete a thorough judgment (Dan 12:11-12). Each believer will have his or her day in court. While
the watches of those outside the courtroom might have counted off only a millisecond, those inside the courtroom will find it to be a
very meticulous review.
†
  See Punitive Podium, 657.
‡
  Indeed, the Lord is bringing His reward (city) with Him (Rev 22:12). At the rapture, believers literally will be caught up to the chief
local of their heavenly reward—Heavenly Jerusalem. When the Lord returns, He will not only bring crowns from the vault, He will
bring the vault itself.
Page 166                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
partial rapturists point to the necessity of good works, but these critics themselves tend do the same and far worse.
The pot does indeed have a tendency to call the kettle black in such eschatological debates. I decline from taking
the partial rapture position but not because of such potshots.
        The imminent nature of the Lord’s return for His Church necessitates that it occurs before the desolation of
the temple which will occur during the tribulation. Both events must be understood as typologically literal. Pattern
fulfillment requires literal fulfillment. Unfaithful and faithful believers are synchronically raptured and
subsequently and simultaneously judged. This judgment will be based on works and thus congruently render the
results to each believer according to his or her own relative merits. The ability to distinguish between a gift and
reward is thus crucial, and yet this ability escapes some within our own dispensational camp. A notable feature of
GRAPE theology is its ability to clearly differentiate distinctions between gifts and rewards amidst affirmations of
misthological merit and soteriological security.
