                                            Chapter 6.
                                      Eschatological Summary
                                                  Introduction
       Advanced readers were advised that they may read the opening chapter carefully and then skim over the rest
of the material to this point. For those who took advantage of that invitation, a very brief review at this point of
some of the basic terminology will be helpful. Additional details and terminology will be implemented in this
chapter to enable a more in-depth exploration of misthology. When the section entitled Specifics later in this
chapter is reached, it will be readily apparent (in the words of Dorothy) that “we are not in Kansas anymore.”*
       This quick review of some of the basic terminology should also prove useful in solidifying the general
reader’s understanding of the foregoing discussion as well. After this short recap of terminology, we will then
promptly advance beyond the elementary concepts, as we explore the meaning of salvation (soteria) in 1Thess 5:9
and 2Thess 2:13. These verses have been discussed already in their eschatological contexts in the introductory
section, so repeating that analysis will not be necessary here. This methodology will allow us to move on as rapidly
as prudently possible to more intricate misthological concerns in this section. The general reader, or new user (to
speak in the software terms described in the introduction to this book) is cautioned, however, to read the previous
discussion carefully as a necessary introduction if he or she has not already done so. The advanced reader, on the
other hand, is admonished to slow down and read the new material in this section with care. Distinctions between
the salvation of the soul versus that of the spirit, for example, will be well known to advanced readers. But we are
moving far beyond such elementary distinctions at this point. It is time to wade out into the deep end of the pool. If
one wishes to dive into the deeper end of the Scripture, this chapter will provide the springboard to do so after a
concise recapitulation.

                                                      Terms
       The relationships of these definitions are pictured below.256 The BEMA is derived from 2Cor 5:10 and
refers to the Judgment Seat of Christ where all church-age believers will be judged in heaven immediately
following the rapture. The FIRST COMING happens in two stages. The first stage (1a) has happened already;
Jesus came to the earth to save it. In the second stage (1b), He will come to earth to judge it.
                                             Illustration 72. Two Stages




*
    See Specifics, 172.
Page 170                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
         The SECOND COMING happens in two stages also. In the first stage (2a), Jesus returns to the clouds of
earth. This stage is called the rapture. He comes to judge believers. In the second stage (2b), He comes to judge
everyone. Arguments that the second coming cannot be in two stages since it is not clearly depicted as such in the
NT are not impressive. The OT did not clearly depict the first coming in two stages, so why should the NT be
required to clearly depict the second coming in two stages? Additionally, the argument that there is no millennium
between the second coming and the final judgment, since they seem to be depicted at the same time, is very weak.
Who, for example, reading Mk 13 would have thought that there would be a two thousand year period between the
destruction of the temple and the Parousia?
        It is hypercritical, if not hypocritical, for amillennialists to justify their two thousand year period between
the destruction of the temple and the Parousia (which is evident from history) on the basis of prophetic
foreshortening and then to criticize other camps for justifying a one thousand year period between the second
coming and the final judgment (which is evident from the progressive revelation). If a two thousand year gap can
occur between the destruction of the temple and the Second Coming (which one would not have expected), a one
thousand year gap can occur between the Second Coming and the final judgment (which is to be expected based on
the prophecy in Rev 20). The same statements could be made about passages that seem to present both stages of
the second coming as happening at the same time. They can be explained on the basis of prophetic foreshortening
in view of the progressive revelation that gives further details later.
        The RAPTURE of the Church is based on the word rapture (harpazo) derived from caught up in
1Thess 4:17. The Latin Vulgate translates harpazo as rapere, which describes the first stage of the second coming.
Christ will come in the clouds with the first part of the church (i.e., those who have died in Christ, 1Thess 4:14) for
the rest of the church (i.e., those who are alive in Christ, 1Thess 4:17) to take them back to heaven (Jn 14:1-3).* For
this reason, the word church is broken up into two parts in the diagram. It is at this time that those who are alive in
Christ (who have physical bodies) and the dead in Christ (who have spiritual bodies) receive their immortal
(glorified) bodies (1Cor 15:50-58).
        The REVELATION of Christ is based on the word revelation (apokalupto) in 2Thess 1:7 and Lk 17:30;
both verses associate it with fire (pur). It refers to the second stage in which He comes with all the church saints
(1Thess 3:13) all the way to earth, not stopping in the clouds. If for nothing other than the sake of argument, it may
be allowed that some NT passages use this same word group (apokalupsis/apokalupto) to refer to (at least
inclusively of) the first stage also, and in those passages it is most often associated with His glory, which may be
potentially shared with believers (1Cor 1:7; Col 3:4; 1Pet 1:7,13; 4:13—cf. 5:1). But of these texts listed, the only
one that really seems possibly to have the first stage in view is 1Cor 1:7 and that is by no means certain. In any
case, the first stage results in judgment for the church; the second stage results in rest for the church. That the
same word can be used to denote two different stages of the same event is evident from 1Tim 6:14 and 2Tim 1:10,
where both stages of the first coming are described in terms of Christ’s appearing (epiphaneia).
        Hoekema tries to discredit the two-stage position by showing that the same word, coming (parousia), is used
in 2Thess 2:8 to refer to the second stage of the second coming.257 His observation that the same word is used to
refer to both stages of the second coming is correct; however, his argument is false that the usage of the same
terminology for both stages of the second coming proves that only one stage is in view. It is quite possible for Paul
to use the same word for two different but similar events. The context of the word can be relied upon for the
differentiation. Hoekema’s argument concerning the use of the same word in 2Thess 2:8 is built upon a false
premise, as is provable by comparing it with 2Tim 1:10. If Hoekema is correct that the use of the same word (in
this case revealing/epiphaneia) proves that the same event is being referred to, then Christ already has come the
second time! The argument that the same word must be used in the same way regardless of the context is
unsustainable.†
        The DAY OF THE LORD is the time of wrath and fulfillment on earth that begins with the rapture and
would thus include both the tribulational period and millennial kingdom. On the other hand, the DAY OF CHRIST
is the time of blessing in heaven that begins with the rapture, ends with the revelation, and thus includes the Bema
and the marriage. It is referred to as the Day of the Lord Jesus, the Day of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the Day of
Christ in Scripture.
        The MARRIAGE refers to the period in which Christ takes overcomers of the church age as a Bride unto
Himself after the Bema but before the revelation. The present stage is the betrothal, which is taking place now

**
   For an alternative pretribulational model which does not pose a U-turn, see “No U-Turn” in Predestination and the Open View.
†
  For an alternate pretribulational view of the key words that does not pose Christ taking us back to heaven in a U-turn before
completing the second phase of the parousia (and which might therefore be more easily reconciled with Hoekema), see “Apokalupsis,”
“Apokalupto,” and “Epiphaneia” in Predestination and the Open View.
Chapter 6. Eschatological Summary                                                                              Page 171
during the church age. When someone accepts the Lord Jesus as their Savior, they are betrothed to Him
(2Cor 11:2). It is a prenuptial agreement that takes place the moment they believe. Thus, the betrothal (or what
would be called the engagement in our society) chronologically takes place before the Bema in heaven. The second
stage is the marriage, which is future, and pertains to the transfer of the bride to the bridegroom.258 The third stage
is the wedding feast and the consummation of the marriage. Although this feast is often referred to as the marriage
supper, it must be kept in mind that it lasts over a period of time.
       The MARRIAGE SUPPER is held on earth after the revelation. The overcomers of the tribulational period
are guests at the wedding supper/feast. The marriage supper is a picture of the entire millennial age, whether it is
described as a period, rest, or relief. It is called rest in Heb 3-4 and relief in 2Thess 1:7. The supper does not
represent mere entrance into the millennial kingdom. It refers to the joyous and victorious experience of ruling with
Christ in the millennial kingdom.

                                                                Basics
        There are two primary reasons for adopting the premillennial position. The first reason is because the key
passage Rev 20:1-7 teaches it. The key words in the passage (come to life, resurrection, until, throne, rule, and
portion) and the descriptive context in Rev 20:11-13 require the passage to be understood as teaching that there
will be a physical resurrection both before and after the millennium. This rules out postmillennial, amillennial, and
panmillennial views, leaving the premillennial position as the only biblical choice. The second reason for accepting
the premillennial interpretation is because the Bible teaches a pretribulational rapture. As we saw, this principle of
physical resurrection also has application to misthological passages concerning the out-resurrection so that the
resurrection in a passage like Jn 5:29 cannot be simply spiritualized away. There will be a literal distinction
between (1) those raised from the dead, (2) those raised out from among the dead, and (3) those who have a special
portion in the out-resurrection out from among these resurrected ones.*
        In 1Thess 4:13-18, we are to comfort one another with the teaching that the Lord will come and take us back
to heaven, which is the logical implication of His promise to bridal saints in Jn 14:1-3. Although this Johannine
passage may have primary application to victorious believers, Paul reveals that the timing of this event will have
broader application to all believers. All living and dead believers will be involved in this translation to the Father’s
kingdom. In 1Thess 5:1, Paul reminds us that the time of the Lord’s coming, which commences the day of wrath, is
imminent and thus unknown. Even after His resurrection, Jesus reaffirmed this teaching (Acts 1:6-7). When asked,
“Lord, is it at this time You are restoring the kingdom to Israel?” He responded, “It is not for you to know.” In
1Thess 5:2, Paul uses the imagery of the thief in the night to remind his readers of Jesus’ teaching that the time of
His coming for believers will be imminent and unknown. In 1Thess 5:3, he reminds them that the Lord’s coming
will be in a time of relative peace and safety; thus, it must take place before the beginning of the tribulation.
        An obvious change in reference about whom Paul is talking occurs in 1Thess 5:3-4. In verse 3 he is talking
about them. In verse 4 he is talking about you, that is, about believers. He says that all believers are in the light. He
is referring to their position rather than to their walk, as the context of his description demonstrates. Jesus teaches
that the only requirement to be in and of the light is to believe in Him (Jn 12:36,46). Thus, all believers are in and
of the light regardless of whether they walk in the light. John explicitly teaches in 1Jn 1:6-7 that believers may
walk in the light or in the darkness. While your relationship with God is dependent upon whether you are a
believer, rather than on the way you live, your fellowship with God is dependent upon your walk and is thus very
much dependent upon the way you live. Or to use theological terminology, all believers are positionally in the light
and ontologically of the light. They are new creatures in Christ. Their new nature is one of light. However, not all
believers are experientially in the light; not all believers live like new creatures. Or to use Jesus’ imagery in
Mt 5:14-16, all believers are light, but not all believers let their light shine. Some believers hide their light (i.e.,
their true nature) by the way they live. The way you live can either display or hide your true nature. Clearly, if all
believers automatically let their light shine, then Jesus would not have had to urge them to let it shine.
        Likewise, in Eph 5:8 Paul teaches that being a believer, and thus being in the light, does not guarantee that
you are walking in the light. Paul affirms and exhorts, “You were formerly darkness, but now you are light in the
Lord; walk as children of light.” All believers are in the light, but not all believers walk in the light. Otherwise,
Paul would not have had to exhort these believers to walk as children of light. All believers are in the light
positionally, but not all believers walk in the light experientially. Some believers morally participate in the
unfruitful deeds of darkness. Paul’s exhortation in Eph 5:11, urging believers to not participate in the deeds of
darkness, is pointless if believers cannot participate in the darkness. His point is not that the way you walk

*
    See Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection, 71.
Page 172                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
determines whether you are saved. Quite the opposite, he assures his readers in Ephesus that they are saved by faith
for good works (Eph 2:8-10) not by good works. In Eph 5:8 he assures them of their salvation (i.e., of the fact that
they are light and therefore regenerate) regardless of the way they live. He can do so because assurance of salvation
from hell is based on their faith, not on their faithfulness.
       In 1Thess 5:4-6 Paul again assures his readers that they are saved (i.e., they are in and of the light)
regardless of whether they experientially are walking in the light. However, this time, instead of using the word
walk to describe their moral experience, he uses the word awake, meaning to be alert morally and thus to walk in
the light. Some believers morally are awake and sober; some are not. If all believers are awake and sober, then
Paul’s exhortation is pointless. Rather than make Paul’s exhortation purposeless, the obvious implication is that
some believers are morally asleep rather than morally awake.

                                                       Specifics

Majority View
       The agreement of the present work with the minority view, as described by Hodges concerning the
Thessalonian rapture passages, has been noted and demonstrated already.* Edgar also has written a splendid
defense of this position.259 As Edgar explains, the majority opinion believes that the words awake and asleep
simply mean alive or dead in 1Thess 5:10. The preference of the majority in taking these terms physically rather
than morally is primarily reactionary and based on misperceived theological repugnancy rather than on contextual
or lexical inadequacy in the minority constituency. Edgar quotes Hiebert and Bruce to summarize the reaction of
the majority view. Hiebert recoils from the minority view by saying: “It seems inconceivable that after the writers
have been urging the duty of watchfulness they should now present it as a matter of little difference whether
believers are spiritually vigilant or negligent.” Bruce likewise shuns the minority view: “It is ludicrous to suppose
that the writers mean, ‘Whether you live like sons of light or like sons of darkness, it will make little difference:
you will be all right in the end.”260 Edgar also notes that Howard

          considers inconceivable or ludicrous the concept that hope in the certain deliverance at the Lord’s
          coming could motivate believers to moral and spiritual living or belong in an exhortation to do so.
          Howard denies that hope is a factor, stressing the incompatibility of the two. He regards hope as so
          inconsistent with motivation for effective living that he denies that Paul would include “the series of
          ethical injunctions in vv 6 and 8,” if hope motivates.261

Inadequacy of Minority View
       In defense of the minority view, Edgar appeals to 1Jn 3:3 as proof that hope (as a confident expectation of
the Lord’s return) can indeed be motivational for moral purity.262 Even so, this minority response to the criticism
made by the majority view is woefully inadequate. To begin with, not even Hodges (an exemplary advocate of the
minority view) thinks this is what is meant by 1Jn 3:3. Hodges weakens this defense of the minority view from this
verse when he says: “No doubt His anticipated return can have strongly positive spiritual effects. But this is not
what John is likely to mean in this context” (emphasis his).263 Although there is a measure of truth to Edgar’s
defense, his appeal to 1Jn 3:3 fails to take into account that this verse does not necessarily teach that the
anticipation of the Lord’s return automatically has a temporally morally purifying effect on all believers in the
interim.† Quite the contrary, Matthew and Luke show that some believers develop the opposite attitude. Since the
Lord’s coming is delayed, from their carnal perspective, these believers think that they can get away with
irresponsible behavior (Mt 24:48; 25:25-26; Lk 12:45; cp. Mt 25:5). Therefore, Edgar’s defense of the minority
position by means of 1Jn 3:3 is not sustainable.

Synthesis into a Moderate View
       The second passage in this list of believers acting irresponsibly is one of the outer darkness passages, and
the other passages are misthological parallels, which demonstrate that anticipation of the Lord’s return should (not
necessarily will) have a morally purifying effect upon believers in light of the doctrine of rewards and retribution.
For this reason, James urges believers: “Do not complain, brethren, against one another, that you yourselves may

*
    See discussion commencing with 1Thess 1:10, 134.
†
    See 1Jn 3:3, 779.
Chapter 6. Eschatological Summary                                                                              Page 173
not be judged; behold, the Judge is standing right at the door” (Jam 5:9). Expectation of the Lord’s return is linked
with exhortations based on misthological judgment in other passages. The Thessalonian passage is no exception.
However, lack of recognition of this facet of the Thessalonian passage has prevented minority advocates, such as
Edgar, from making a theologically convincing response to the majority criticism.
       The following interaction with the minority position will provide the minority view with a suitable response
to the criticism made by the majority advocates, such as Bruce, Hiebert, and Howard above. It is possible to merge
the lexical and contextual evidence in favor of the minority view (still taking awake and asleep morally in
1Thess 5:10) and satisfactorily address the concerns of the majority outlook by reexamining the lexical and
contextual meaning of the words hope and salvation in 1Thess 5:8-9. In short, if the doctrine of rewards is joined to
the minority view, then this revised minority view is superior to the majority view on all fronts and answers the
legitimate criticism raised by the majority constituents against the minority advocates. Howard’s repeated emphasis
on hope is easily countered by the recognition that the passage is holding out a misthological hope* to believers
and exhorting them to faithfulness in view of the misthological salvation available to them. In short, I will
synthesize the strength of the minority view concerning the tribulation with a misthological response to the
majority criticism concerning the nature of salvation into a moderate view which teaches a full, pretribulational
rapture of all believers coupled with a misthological salvation of watchful believers.

Salvation
       Hodges and Edgar understand the salvation (soteria) in 1Thess 5:9 as salvation from the tribulation. The
minority view takes the salvation being promised here and in 2Thess 2:13 as salvation from the tribulation for all
believers regardless of the way they live.
          8
           But since we are of the day, let us be sober, having put on the breastplate of faith and love, and as a
          helmet, the hope of salvation. 9 For God has not destined us for wrath, but for obtaining salvation
          through our Lord Jesus Christ. (1Thess 5:8-9)
          13
            God has chosen you from the beginning for salvation through sanctification by the Spirit and faith
          in the truth. (2Thess 2:13)

       From the foregoing examination, it is evident that the present author shares the minority perspective that
1Thess 5:9-10 does in fact teach the full, unconditional, pretribulational rapture of all believers whether they are
morally awake or asleep. Even if believers are morally asleep, God has not destined them for the wrath of the
tribulation, so this concurrence demonstrates that deliverance from tribulational wrath is unconditional for all
believers. Their deliverance from this wrath is not contingent on their behavior.
       This understanding of the passage as promising unconditional security from tribulational wrath has not been
based on an analysis of what salvation means in this passage, however. The discussion of what this word means in
this context has been deferred until now.† As will be demonstrated in this chapter, Hodges’ overall interpretation of
the passage does not require restricting salvation simply to mean salvation from tribulational wrath. Although the
passage itself is promising tribulational deliverance to all believers regardless of the way they live, Paul is referring
to a related, yet distinguishable matter, when he uses the word salvation in 1Thess 5:8-9. The misthological
understanding of the word salvation in 1Thess 5:8-9 and 2Thess 2:13 adopted herein is based on the following
considerations and will defend Hodges’ eschatological understanding of the passage against the majority view.
Even so, it will do so by refining Hodges’ argument concerning the usage of the word salvation in this context.
This amelioration will result in a misthological minority defense of the full rapture position.
       The Greek word peripoiesis in 1Thess 5:9 may be translated as: obtain, gain, purchase. Paul’s use of
peripoiesis makes the traditional minority interpretation of salvation very difficult to accept. Hodges evidently
believes that Paul is using the word salvation to restate the message of the passage. However, the alternative
proposal herein is that Paul is using the word salvation to advance beyond the basic message of the passage.
Although the passage is concerned with tribulational deliverance, the context is not limited to this type of salvation.
The position that will be set forth in the ensuing presentation is that Paul is using the word salvation in 1Thess 5:9-
10 to refer to millennial salvation, that is, to co-glorification salvation. Paul’s appeal to these Christians for
Christian morality is not based exclusively upon their gratitude for their unconditional tribulational deliverance.

*
    See Misthological Hope and Glory, 92.
†
    See 1Thess 5:9, 143.
Page 174                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
The majority misgiving concerning the minority position is justified on this point. My response to the majority
charge of ludicrousness is that, in addition to gratitude, Paul also appeals to these believers to live morally pure
lives in order that they might obtain the misthological salvation that is promised only to faithful believers.264 This
salvation, unlike tribulational deliverance, is conditional upon the believer’s moral behavior. Paul expects them to
be pure morally because their salvation is at stake! Of course, this is not salvation from hell or from the tribulation.

Deliverance (1Thess 1:10b)
       1Thess 1:10b (“Jesus…delivers us from the wrath to come”) is referring to tribulational deliverance;
notwithstanding, Paul avoids using the word salvation (soteria) in 1Thess 1:10, using the word deliver (hruomai)
instead. A possible reason for his choice of different words is that he is referring to two different outcomes—
depending on whether one overcomes. Even if believers subcome to moral sleep, they will be delivered from the
wrath of the tribulation. Nevertheless, only by overcoming the temptation to sleep morally can believers obtain the
millennial salvation envisioned.

Tribulational deliverance is free
       Hodges is correct that 1Thess 5:8-10 teaches that the future deliverance from the tribulation is a free gift
when he notes that regardless of the way we live (1) we are of the day; (2) we are not destined for the wrath of the
tribulation; and (3) we will live with Him via the rapture.

Millennial Salvation
       Yet 1Thess 5:8-9 progresses beyond simple tribulational deliverance to millennial salvation with its usage of
the word salvation. This salvation is a futuristic, misthological hope that moves beyond the tribulational
deliverance that is freely given to us independently of the way we live. This millennial salvation is purchased (i.e.,
obtained) by us through our being sober, and thus through our living morally pure lives. This salvation is referring
to co-glorification millennial salvation, not to tribulational escape, of which we already are assured. This salvation
is merited; the deliverance is not. Deliverance from the wrath of the tribulation is promised unconditionally to all
believers, even if they are not awake. In contrast, the millennial co-glorification that follows this deliverance is
conditioned upon being awake.

Obtain

                                                    Experience
        This same word obtain is used by Paul in both 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:14. The verbal and nominal forms
of this word are found in eight NT passages. The verbal form (peripoieomai) occurs in Lk 17:33; Acts 20:28;
1Tim 3:13, and the nominal form (peripoiesis) occurs in Eph 1:14; 1Thess 5:9; 2Thess 2:14; Heb 10:39;
1Pet 2:9.265 The Louw-Nida (L-N) Greek Lexicon gives two different types of meaning for the noun. On the one
hand, it may refer to the “experience of an event or state which has been acquired—‘experience, to experience.’”
In this same category, L-N (90.74) simply translates 1Thess 5:9 as saying that God has called us “for the purpose
of experiencing salvation.” Thus, this Greek word might be construed by some to simply mean experience.
Hodges’ interpretation evidently presupposes this limited range of the word’s meaning. According to this
understanding, all believers will experience salvation from the wrath of the tribulation since this salvation is not
something they have to acquire with effort. Still, even this understanding is open to question because in this same
definition L-N clarifies that it refers to “the experience of an event or state which has been acquired.” If the
believer is the one who actively acquires this experience with effort, then this experience is based on merit. To its
credit, L-N (57.62) does refer to another definition, the one provided below, as an alternative possibility.
        Before addressing this alternate definition, it should be noted that the translation provided above by L-N
(90.74) says that this experience is the “purpose” for which God called us. It is not the guaranteed result.
Grammatically speaking, this is a purpose clause, not a result clause. The result is not guaranteed. God called us
believers for the purpose of our acquiring this salvation, but whether or not we will do so is contingent upon our
ongoing response to His will. The word translated for (eis) can denote either purpose or result. As such, L-N
(89.57) notes that in a similar verse, 2Thess 1:5, eis would mean that you are to endure suffering “for the purpose
of your becoming worthy of the kingdom of God.” In contrast, it says that if eis was a result clause in 2Thess 1:5, it
would mean that as “a result [of enduring suffering] you will be worthy of the kingdom of God” (L-N 89.48).
Either way, the misthological nature of 2Thess 1:5 is apparent in the context of v. 4. Regardless of whether the
verse is taken as denoting purpose or result, it must be misthological since our being worthy of the kingdom is
Chapter 6. Eschatological Summary                                                                               Page 175
dependent on our performance. If L-N is consistent with its terminology, then it would have to conclude that the
purpose for which we are called in 1Thess 5:9 is not a guaranteed result. For advocates of unconditional security,
this prohibits a soteriological understanding of the verse. Likewise, this nullifies the minority view that the verse
guarantees salvation from the tribulation. Deliverance from the tribulation is guaranteed, salvation is not. Thus,
this conditional salvation pertains to something other than deliverance from the tribulation.

                                                         Earn
        The alternative rendering by L-N (57.62) mentioned above brings the meritorious nature of this concept
clearly to the forefront by defining the noun as a possession that “is acquired, presumably with considerable
effort.” L-N (57.61) also defines the verb as meaning “to acquire possession of something, with the probable
component of considerable effort—‘to acquire, to achieve, to win.’” Thus, L-N understands the verbal form in a
manner equivalent to this second definition given for the noun. According to BDAG, the verbal form
(peripoieomai) means to “acquire, obtain, gain for oneself,” and the nominal form (peripoiesis) correspondingly
refers to the “experience of an event of acquisition, gaining, obtaining.” It cites the Thessalonian passages as
examples of this meaning. Likewise, the Thayer’s Greek-English Lexicon (TY) says that verb means to purchase,
and the noun means obtaining and possession. The Friberg (FB) lexicon states that the verb means to “gain or
acquire (for oneself), obtain (1T 3.13); pay the price for, acquire with much effort (AC 20.28).” According to FB,
the noun likewise means, “(1) a preserving for oneself, saving, keeping (HE 10.39); (2) an acquiring for oneself,
obtaining (1TH 5.9); (3) a possessing for oneself, possession (1P 2.9).” The UBS Greek dictionary gives similar
interpretations, saying that it also means to win.
        The translation that L-N (90.74) gave of merely experiencing the event is not even listed as a possibility by
these other lexicons, nor should it be considered a possibility in terms of NT usage. For that matter, L-N (90.74)
notes that it is an experience that is acquired. As to meaning experience, the definitions by L-N and BDAG are
similar. L-N notes that the experience is intended for those who acquire it. BDAG elaborates that it is an
experience that is gained or obtained as an acquisition. I have no problem with understanding it to mean
experience as long as the fuller lexical, grammatical, and contextual understanding is retained. Our salvation in
1Thess 5:9 is won, bought, purchased by us, not given to us as a gift by the Lord. We obtain it and gain it for
ourselves. If we want to experience this salvation, then we will have to earn it. It is to be our purchased
possession,* if we, as believers, will respond positively to God’s call to acquire it. After all, God is calling believers
in this verse, and this Greek word for obtain is never used in the NT to denote receiving something that is
free. Instead, it denotes paying the price necessary to acquire the object in view. We have been called to gain co-
glorification salvation. The verbal and nominal forms of this word mean to gain and keep as a possession by
paying the necessary purchase price, thus to achieve and win by much effort. We have been called to purchase
this salvation. This salvation is something we purchase through our works—through living morally pure lives.

                                                    Active/Passive

Active is most Common
       Summarily, these two different spheres of meaning for the noun (peripoiesis) are delineated by
commentators as the active versus passive sense. The NIV and NIB translate it passively: “For God did not appoint
us to suffer wrath but to receive salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ” (1Thess 5:9). According to this
translation, this salvation is something we passively receive rather than actively obtain. This would accord well
with the traditional view. However, the active understanding is far more predominant among the translations: KJV,
NKJ, ASV, NAS, NAU, RSV, NRS, WEB, DRA, RWB, DBY, YLT, NAB, and NJB. In its active sense, it is
translated as acquire, win, obtain, or gain. BDAG denotes it as having the active meaning in 1Thess 5:9 and
2Thess 2:14 (and Heb 10:39) but a passive meaning in Eph 1:14 and 1Pet 2:9. Morris takes the passages similarly:

          It has a passive sense in Eph 1:14, I Pet. 2:9, in both places being translated “possession.” But while
          it can have such a meaning, it is hard to see how this fits into the present passage. Moreover,
          “acquiring” seems nearer the intrinsic meaning of the word (cf. its use in II Thess. 2:14, “obtaining,”
          and Heb. 10:39, “saving).266



*
    See “Possession” in Sealed and Secure.
Page 176                                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
                                                                                    267
Beyreuther gives an active meaning for all five verses except 1Pet 2:9.  Thus, the translators and lexicographers
favor the active meaning for the noun (particularly in the Thessalonian passages), and this active meaning is the
meaning of the verb, as shown above.

Passive Argument
        To be sure, there are commentators, such as Thomas, who prefer the passive meaning. He notes that Hiebert,
Hendriksen, and Best prefer the active meaning, but he cites Lightfoot in favor of the passive meaning. Thomas
rejects the active meaning because it

        injects human effort into procuring future salvation and emphasizes alert activity. Yet the thought of
        “acquiring one’s own slavation [sic]” conflicts with God’s unconditional appointment of believers
        to salvation. Furthermore, the incompatibility of the word’s usual active meaning of “preservation”
        (or “preserve”) with future salvation is obvious. And in view of the cognate verb peripoieo with its
        technical connotation of divine action in God’s procuring a people for himself, taking peripoiesin
        passively becomes more plausible. Also the antithetical orgen (“wrath”) clearly implies divine
        activity. As Christians have been elected ([1Thess] 1:4), they have also been adopted. For them to be
        possessed by God as his very own is synonymous with the future salvation.268 (Italics his.)

Active Counterargument
        Thomas’ Calvinistic assumption that the verse is describing unconditional election in 1Thess 5:9 will be
contested shortly, which will also bring his appeal to 1Thess 1:4 into question.* He states that it is “obvious” that a
believer’s future salvation could not be based on works. On the contrary, it is far from obvious. His simplistic
misconception will be refuted subsequently.† For now it may be stated that God conditionally has determined that
believers should work so that they can experience a full salvation when they enter His kingdom. Some believers
will fail to achieve this type of salvation and thus will enter heaven by the skin of their teeth, so to speak.
        Aside from these theological considerations, Thomas acts as though the verbal form makes the passive
meaning probable, when in fact the opposite is true. Even the NIV and NIB translate the verb in an active sense in
Lk 17:33 and 1Tim 3:13. Admittedly, the church is described as a purchased possession in Acts 20:28. However,
the sense of verb is misconstrued by Thomas, since the church is not the subject of the verb—it is the object. God
purchased the church. God is the active agent. The verb has an active nuance. The middle voice is to show that God
actively purchased us for Himself.
        The fact that this salvation for believers is contrasted with tribulational wrath for unbelievers in 1Thess 5:9
does not mean that it is soteriological or unconditional. One need only recall what is probably the most famous
verse in the Bible concerning this contrast: “Because you have kept the word of My perseverance, I also will keep
you from the hour of testing, that hour which is about to come upon the whole world, to test those who dwell upon
the earth” (Rev 3:10).‡ In this verse we again encounter the promise of preservation from the tribulational wrath
that will come upon unbelievers. Yet this promise to believers is not soteriological or unconditional. The opposite
is true; it is misthological and conditional. These faithful believers earn this salvation by keeping His word.
        These two verses have much more in common than is commonly recognized. Both verses presume that all
believers will be delivered from the wrath of the tribulation. Both verses promise misthological salvation to faithful
believers who overcome. The difference is that Paul teaches this dual truth explicitly, while John indicates it
implicitly through the use of a litotes.§ Both verses teach the same dual truth. In 1Thess 5:9, Paul teaches that God
unconditionally has determined that all believers would be delivered from the tribulation, and He contingently has
determined that all believers should be faithful so that they may earn a full, millennial, salvation experience. In
Rev 3:10 John likewise uses the fact that all believers will be delivered from the tribulation as a springboard to the
greater promise of a full millennial salvation to those believers who overcome.




*
  See Chapter 7. Election and Predestination, 181.
†
  See Salvation (Mt 24:13), 319.
‡
  This typical punctuation of Rev 3:10 is probably not the best one possible. Nevertheless, the conditional nature of the verse is still
readily defensible. See Partial Rapture in Rev 3:10, 504.

  See Chapter 21. Litotes, 481.
Chapter 6. Eschatological Summary                                                                                   Page 177
                                                        NT Usage
       This active and passive clarification is very clearly demonstrated by Paul’s use of the verb peripoieo in
Acts 20:28, where he said that we are purchased by the blood of Christ. We are a purchased possession. The
purchase price for our justification cost Christ His life. He had to pay the ransom price. In this exchange, Christ is
the active agent, and we are the completely passive object. Our justification salvation cost Christ His life, but our
co-glorification salvation costs us our lives. Likewise, Paul again uses this word and business imagery in Eph 1:14
to say that the Holy Spirit was given to us as the down payment (i.e., the earnest) for our redemption. This is the
payment of a ransom, with the result that we are God’s purchased possession. God is the active agent, and we are
the passive recipients. But this does not mean that man is always the passive agent when this verb is used. Rather,
the one performing the action expressed by the verb is the active agent, and this can be man.
       Paul uses this word in 1Tim 3:13 to say that in order to obtain a high standing, a deacon has to pay the price
of serving well. The subject of the verb, the deacon in this case, is again the one performing action. The verb
denotes action of paying the price. Concerning the usage of peripoieomai and peripoiesis in Lk 17:33 and
Heb 10:39 respectively, dealing with the salvation of the soul-life, Hodges is correct that these passages are
misthological.269 In order to save your soul-life, you must pay the price. This salvation will cost you your soul-life.
       Wilkin has an excellent five part series concerning salvation of the soul, which he appropriately calls, “Soul
Salvation.” In the last article of that series, he deals with soul salvation in 1Pet 1:9. This verse says, “Obtaining as
the outcome of your faith, the salvation of your souls.” The word translated as obtaining in 1Pet 1:9 is komizo.
Wilkin makes a very powerful argument that soul salvation in this verse is misthological.270 He bases his
understanding on the definition given for komizo by BAGD: “This word is one which refers to ‘pay’ or ‘wages’
received for work done.”271 Wilkin then proceeds to demonstrate that this definition is consistent with NT usage
and that the word always means to receive as “wages for something one deserved”; it never refers “to receiving
something undeserved.”272
       Wilkin’s argument is sound,* but it is also the same argument that I have just made at length concerning
peripoiesis in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:14. The salvation obtained in both 1Thesss 5:9 and 1Pet 1:9 is merited. To
be consistent with the NT, Paul, and their own arguments, FG interpreters need to acknowledge that peripoiesis
means to obtain by merit in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:14. It does not refer to receiving a free gift, but to winning
and earning a possession by paying the necessary price. The salvation in these two verses is misthological (not
tribulational or soteriological) since it is merited.

 Parallel with 2Thess 2:14
       Whatever salvation means in 1Thess 5:9, it means the same thing in 2Thess 2:14. These passages are
linguistic and conceptual parallels as can be seen in our translation below.
                                Illustration 73. Parallelism of 1Thess 5:8-11 and 2Thess 2:13-15

                      1Thess 5:8-11                                    2Thess 2:13-15
8                                                               13
  But since we are of the day, let us be sober, having             But we should always give thanks to God for you,

                                              Internal parallelism
      The triple repetition of for (eis) in 2Thess 2:13-14 identifies the salvation as co-glorification with Christ.
The salvation { for which we were chosen and | for which we were called is } for winning co-glory with the
Lord. The reward of co-glorification salvation is in view. That co-glorification with Christ is a reward is certainly
acknowledged by FG interpreters such as Hodges, Wilkin, and others (cf. Rom 8:17). They would also
acknowledge that salvation can be a reward in certain contexts. This should be considered one of those contexts.
*
    See 1Pet 1:9 in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 178                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
We are destined and chosen to earn salvation in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:13, which is defined in 2Thess 2:14 as
earning glory.

                                                External Parallelism
       The parallel of winning salvation in 1Thess 5:9 with winning glory in 2Thess 2:14 emphasizes the fact that
co-glorification salvation is in view.* Or as the NIDNTT says concerning the use of peripoiesis in these two verses,
the salvation obtained in 1Thess 5:9 “is described in terms of” glory in 2Thess 2:14.273 This glory (i.e., this
salvation) is earned, merited, bought, and won. It is not given as a gift; it is given as a reward.

 The Exhortation
       Would this passage effectively encourage believers to stay awake if Paul were simply saying that God has
destined believers for deliverance from the tribulation regardless of whether or not they stay awake? Not really.
The criticism expressed by the majority view has a valid point on this particular aspect of the matter. It sounds like
the exhortations are based on much more than simple gratitude. The fact that this salvation/glory is earned makes
the exhortation comprehensible. Stay awake and stand firm because if you do not, then you will fail to achieve this
salvation that has been promised conditionally.

 Doorkeeper
       Dillow is probably correct when he suggests that Paul had the parable of the doorkeeper (Mk 13:33-37) in
mind in 1Thess 5.274 Be on the alert because only those who are alert will reign with Christ (cf. the parallel in
Mt 24:42-30). Paul’s traveling companion, Luke, also uses this same word for alert (gregoreo) in his gospel
(Lk 12:37).275 We obtain this reign with Christ (this salvation) by remaining alert (1Thess 5:8-9). This salvation of
ruling with Him is greater than merely living with Him. All believers, whether they are alert, will live with Him
(1Thess 5:10). They will always be with Him as a result of the rapture (1Thess 4:17).
       Believers are chosen and called in 2Thess 2:13-15 to obtain glory (v. 14), that is, salvation (v. 13). The
salvation in view is misthological co-glorification salvation, as is proven by the internal and external parallelism
and the use of the word obtain. The word obtain should be understood as meaning to gain through effort. Thus, it
functions as a synonym for tugchano, which was discussed earlier concerning the out-resurrection in Lk 20:35 and
Heb 11:35.† The salvation Paul is exhorting the Thessalonians to achieve is the special status of co-glory with
Christ in the out-resurrection.

Failed Mediation
        Stallard makes a failed attempt at mediation between the majority and minority views. To his credit, unlike
some majority view advocates, he recognizes that deliverance from hell cannot be the subject matter in 1Thess 5:9.
Also, in harmony with the minority view, as a FG writer, he correctly maintains that deliverance from hell is a free
gift not conditioned on performance. At the same time, as a pretribulationalist, he likewise rightly perceives that a
pretribulational, unconditional deliverance from the wrath of the tribulation is being assured for the Thessalonian
believers. Unfortunately, in acquiescence to the majority view, though, he interprets awake and asleep in
1Thess 5:10 to mean physically alive and dead so that this verse “is simply a recap of 4:13-17.”276 His assessment
is self-refuting since he acknowledges that the exhortations to be alert, sober¸ not asleep in 1Thess 5:6 refer to
being alert spiritually and are addressed to these same believers. So despite the fact that the context is using
katheudo to describe being asleep morally, he interprets it to mean asleep physically—a weakness of the majority
view. At the same time, having adopted the minority view’s assurance of unconditional rapture (regardless as to
whether they are awake or asleep), he fails to provide a persuasive rational for the exhortation to be alert—a
weakness of the minority view. He incorporates the weaknesses of the majority view and the weaknesses of the
minority view and strangely thinks that he has made a successful mediation. However, combining their weaknesses
does not make for a strong interpretation.
        Although Stallard takes the minority view of salvation in 1Thess 5:9, in perceiving it to be deliverance from
the tribulation, he acknowledges that this salvation involves practical sanctification when he reaches its twin
passage in 2Thess 2:13. He thinks practical salvation is “part of the salvation package” so that “the entire package
is probably viewed holistically.”277 This interpretation shares the same fallacy in logic as the frequent Calvinistic

*
    For review of obtaining as meaning winning in these passages, see Earn, 175; Active is most Common, 175.
†
    See The Out-Resurrection in Lk 20:34-36, 72; and The Out-Resurrection in Heb 11:35, 76.
Chapter 6. Eschatological Summary                                                                             Page 179
proposal that saving faith is part of the package received by saving faith. Arminians are quick to point out that the
means of receiving the package cannot be part of the package. Such an objection is just as applicable in the present
case. Just as being saved through faith (Eph 2:8-9) cannot make faith (which is the means of receiving this
salvation) part of the salvation being received, so salvation through sanctification (2Thess 2:13) cannot make
sanctification (which is the means of receiving this salvation) part of the salvation being received. Stallard has
committed a classical package fallacy in making practical sanctification part of the salvation being received as well
as the means to receive that same salvation. The means of receiving the package cannot be part of the package.
       The solution is simple: Distinguish the means of receiving the package from the package itself.
Acknowledge that practical sanctification is necessary to receive this salvation and thus correctly identify the
package to be received as a reward to be won, namely, co-glorification salvation. In turn, interpret 1Thess 5:9
similarly. This mediation is the one proposed herein.

Successful Mediation
        In contradistinction to Stallard, the mediation proposed herein enjoins the strengths, rather than weaknesses,
of the majority and minority views to form a consistent synthesis. The formulation of this synthesis involved a
succinct review of the principal eschatological points made in the previous section in favor of a dispensational
hermeneutic, in which the typical arguments in favor of taking a literal resurrection as occurring both before and
after the millennium were noted. Jesus and Paul concur in picturing that the return of the Lord for His Bride in an
imminent rapture, which leads to the conclusion that the rapture will occur for all believers (even those who do not
compose the Bride) before the signs of the tribulation. Thus, an unconditional, pretribulational rapture was
affirmed. Yet bridal saints will have a special portion in the out-resurrection, which is logically consistent with the
exhortation to be morally ready.
                                      Illustration 74. Summation of Moderation
              Majority                                 Moderate                                Minority
          Awake & asleep =                         Awake & asleep =                         Awake & asleep =
        physically alive & dead                morally vigilant or negligent            morally alert or indifferent
     Deliverance from wrath = hell         Deliverance from wrath = tribulation    Deliverance from wrath = tribulation
      Salvation = soteriological                  Salvation = millennial                 Salvation = tribulational
         Hope = soteriological                    Hope = misthological                    Hope = eschatological
              For = result                            For = Purpose                            For = Result
               Obtain =                                  Obtain =                                Obtain =
         passively experience                         Actively Earn                        passively experience
     Through Christ = monergistic              Through Christ = synergistic           Through Christ = monergistic

       The specifics of the pretribulational defense were then examined and the majority view was found to have
discovered an exploitable weakness in Hodges’ presentation of the minority view. The minority position that all
believers will be raptured even if they are morally asleep is incompatible with Paul’s exhortation to be alert
morally. Consequently, an argument was made for a misthologically moderate view of 1Thess 5:9. Although the
context substantiates the minority view, in that deliverance from the tribulation is being promised to all believers,
the majority view is correct in its perception that the salvation is indeed conditioned on watchfulness. Such
salvation, however, must be understood misthologically rather than soteriologically. Thus, the mediating view
adopted herein between the majority position and the minority perception is that no believer is destined for the
tribulational wrath, but only faithful believers will experience millennial salvation in the form of misthological
rulership. This salvation is intended by Paul to be understood misthologically.

                                                   Conclusion
       Paul presents us with twin truths concerning predestination in his discussion of this misthological salvation:
“God has destined us not for wrath but for winning salvation” (1Thess 5:9; TM). On the one hand, God
unconditionally has determined that believers will be delivered from the day of wrath. This deliverance from
tribulational wrath is unconditional since it is not based on the way believers live. Even if believers are morally
asleep, they will be spared this tribulational wrath. By logical extension it may be deduced that if God is going to
deliver them unconditionally from this lesser tribulational wrath, then certainly He likewise will deliver them
unconditionally from the eternal wrath of the Lake of Fire. All believers unconditionally are prohibited by the
blood of Christ from experiencing such wrath. After all, Paul concludes chapter four by saying that all those who
are raptured will always be with the Lord (1Thess 4:17). Thus, it may be inferred from the context and from the
Page 180                                                                                                  The Outer Darkness
logical outcome of Paul’s discussion that all believers unconditionally will live with the Lord as a result of the
rapture (pictured below in Illustration 75 by the vertical assent). Consequently, all believers will enter the
millennial kingdom. However, only those believers who morally are awake and sober will win salvation from the
outer darkness and be allowed to rule in the capital city.* This part of God’s predestination is therefore conditional
upon the way believers live.
                                         Illustration 75. Destined versus Delivered




        The misthological nature of this salvation was validated by a word study of peripoieomai and peripoiesis.
This salvation is earned by the believer’s performance. That such salvation is earned through Christ in no way
invalidates the claim that it is earned and thus misthological. Contrary to Morris (concerning 1Thess 5:9) and
contrary to passive nikology in general, it was shown that we do indeed merit this salvation through active
implementation of Christ’s enabling grace. This victory is synergistic, not a victory that we monergistically win
apart from Christ or that He monergistically wins apart from us. We are in this battle together. Even a strong
emphasis on intermediate means provides no legitimate cause for confusing a gift with a reward. The GRAPE
distinction between a gift and a reward is not nullified by an appeal to intermediate means. The use of intermediate
means does not mean that our response to God somehow becomes a gift from God to us.
        The fidelity of this treatment to Paul’s thought in 1Thess 5:9 was then confirmed with an analysis of his
verbal and conceptual parallel in 2Thess 2:14, where it was shown that we are to win misthological glory. This
interaction with the two verses is not yet complete, however. These verses teach that we are destined and chosen
for these misthological rewards. But if all believers are predestined for such honors, does this mean that all
believers will inevitably achieve such honors? In short, does my mediating response to the majority view mean that
I inadvertently have paved a road back to TULIP and its insistency regarding the perseverance of the saints? Not at
all. Preliminary observations already have noted that believers may be asleep morally. Sleeping morally would not
normally be regarded as persevering Calvinistically. Yet full demonstration of the fallacy of the Calvinistic TULIP
as applied to believers being destined for co-glorification awaits the material to be introduced in the next chapter.
Just because all believers are unconditionally assured of being raptured does not mean that they are unconditionally
assured of misthological salvation. Unfaithful believers will be raptured, but this does not mean that they
necessarily will have the practical righteousness necessary to be saved from the outer darkness.




*
   For further illustration and discussion regarding this city, see Illustration 173. Outside the City, 532; Rev 21:2—City, 542;

                                             Chapter 7.
                                     Election and Predestination
                                                   Introduction
       In the previous chapter, it was concluded that God has not destined believers for tribulational wrath but for
misthological glory. No believer will experience the wrath of the tribulation, but not all believers will achieve
misthological glory. Since both promises have both been predestined by God, it may seem inconsistent to assert
that the first promise (i.e., of deliverance from tribulational wrath) unconditionally applies to all believers, but the
second promise (i.e., of co-glorification salvation) only applies conditionally to faithful believers. After all, God
has destined/chosen believers for both, so why assume that they may only experience one? Resolving this apparent
inconsistency will help solidify the conclusions reached above and pave the way for future implications.
       Has God’s election failed in the case of believers who die in a carnal state and who consequently fail to
achieve the salvation for which God has elected them? Are Arminians correct that God’s election is conditioned on
the believer’s perseverance? Has the Calvinistic position, that God’s election is unconditional, completely been
ruled out? Must election be either conditional or unconditional? Could it not be both? As a systematic misthology,
the present work will seek to provide a cohesive response. Such a response is necessary as evidenced by
Ventilato’s objection to the outer darkness being regarded a misthological concept on the grounds of election:

            Notice too that, according to the inspired words of James 2:5, our inheritance of the kingdom of
       God is based on His election (thus according to grace): for God has “chosen” us to be “heirs of the
       kingdom.” Just as every believer has been chosen out of the world by God in eternity past unto
       salvation (2 Thess. 2:13), likewise has every believer been chosen out by God in eternity past to
       inherit the kingdom of God. (Emphasis his.)278

        I will ignore, for the moment, the apparent weakness in his rejoinder concerning Jam 2:5. This verse is
talking about the poor and would more naturally be considered an example of conditional election—a believer
must be poor in spirit in order to qualify for the inheritance. But aside from Ventilato’s misrepresentation of this
particular text, I will allow that Ventilato has an argument that potentially could be developed as a counter to the
Marrowistic position by those who are more careful in their exegesis and in their articulation of a misthological
counterpoint. Let it be conceded that a potential weakness in Marrowism has gone unnoticed by many Marrowists.
If the outer darkness is a misthological experience for some believers, then it must be explained why or if election
has failed to apply to them. A working hypothesis concerning the integration of the doctrine of election with the
doctrine of misthology must be developed. Election is not limited to the soteriological sphere. This chapter will
serve as an introduction to the topic of election and to some of the raw data to be processed and analyzed in the
following chapters concerning different types of election. At this introductory level, providing classifications of
election and giving a brief synopsis of each passage will suffice.

                                             Definition of Election
       A working definition will be offered that will be based on the biblical data listed in the following chart,
which depicts the Greek verbal, nominal, and adjectival forms of election respectively: eklego, ekloge, eklektos.
When the word election is used in its common sense, it simply means to choose. Common references to election
have not been included in the following chart. Thus, the chart does not include references to the election of the
twelve apostles, since they were simply being chosen for apostleship (e.g., Jn 6:70; 13:18; 15:16,19). According to
Jn 6:70, even Judas was one of the elect. This simply means that he was chosen for apostleship, not necessarily for
salvation. The references included in the following chart are limited to soteriological election, which means to
choose for salvation. Soteriological election, when used in its broad sense, means to choose for salvation, (A) all
three phases of salvation: (J) justification salvation, (S) sanctification salvation, and (C) co-glorification salvation.
Such election guarantees justification salvation and in turn makes sanctification and co-glorification salvation
possible. In its restricted sense, soteriological election exclusively refers to one or two phases of salvation.
       Admittedly, I am not following the lead of my fellow non-Calvinists, such as Vance and Hunt in this matter,
who would refuse to link election with salvation. For example, Hunt stresses:

       In the Bible predestination/election is never unto salvation. To the Calvinist, however,
       predestination/election is always and only unto salvation—a view which is imposed wrongly upon
Page 182                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
          Scripture. In fact, election/predestination is always unto specific blessings that accompany salvation,
          but not to salvation itself. Knowing who would believe the gospel is a valid reason for electing or
          predestinating those persons to certain blessings. But God’s knowledge that He would extend
          Irresistible Grace to certain persons cannot be offered as the reason for doing so. (Emphasis his.) 279

        Although Hunt’s rejection of irresistible grace as the basis for election is well received, his disassociation of
election as a basis for salvation is open to question. A mediating view (between his never and the Calvinistic
always) which affirms that election sometimes deals with salvation should be considered. A comparison of the
chart below concerning election, with a similar chart pertaining to proffered salvation,* reveals an intersection
between election and salvation that cannot be easily ignored. God has destined us for salvation (1Thess 5:9). God
has chosen us for salvation (2Thess 2:13). Only the elect may obtain salvation (2Tim 2:10).
        In contrast to Hunt, who fails to interact with such passages, Forster (who also takes a non-Calvinistic stance
concerning election) acknowledges that this latter passage “shows the link between election and the future
‘salvation’ of those in Christ.”280 In consideration of (1) the link in this passage between election and salvation,
(2) a synonymous election for salvation in 2Thess 2:13, and (3) a synonymous predestination for salvation in
1Thess 5:9, I will allow the Calvinistic association of predestination and election with salvation. Even so, the
adoption of this Calvinistic starting point does not make the overall Calvinistic position a foregone conclusion.
Significant evidence already has been provided that the futuristic salvation obtainable in such passages is co-
glorification salvation rather than simple justification salvation. Therefore, my disagreement with Hunt is more
apparent than real, more semantic than thematic. My analysis will concur with Hunt in affirming that God has not
irresistibly predestined certain individuals to salvation, much less to simple justification salvation. Although I will
enter this labyrinth at a different door and take alternate routes through part of the maze than do some of my fellow
non-Calvinists, I will emerge, nevertheless, at much the same position as do Vance and Hunt in showing that our
destination was not irresistibly predestined in terms of justification or co-glorification.

Chapter 7. Election and Predestination                                                                          Page 183
                                              Overview of Election
        In passages #1-2 (Mt 20:16; 22:14), the adjective for election is used to denote co-glorification salvation in
the Majority Text (hereafter MT).281 Those who are elected in these passages already have believed.
Notwithstanding, election as used in these passages has nothing to do with soteriology strictly speaking; that is, it
has nothing to do with salvation from eternal damnation in hell. Rather, election is used misthologically to denote
being chosen to be at the wedding. The wedding is not the kingdom itself but something within the kingdom.282
The passage concerning the feast parallels the same truth that is taught in Mt 5:5-12, where Jesus promises that the
gentle will inherit the earth. All Christians are not gentle; thus, this promise does not apply to all Christians. In v. 9
Jesus continues His teaching on rewards by promising the kingdom to those who endure persecution for the
kingdom: “Theirs is the kingdom of heaven.” That is, “the kingdom of heaven is theirs,” which means that it
belongs to them. This is why Jesus calls these believers blessed.* Entering heaven is one thing; inheriting or
owning heaven is quite another. Matthew 5:10-12 clearly indicates this mistholic understanding of expression: the
kingdom of heaven is theirs. In continuing His discussion about those persecuted for the kingdom, Jesus promises
them that their reward in heaven will be great. To inherit the kingdom (i.e., for the kingdom to belong to you)
means to have a great reward in heaven. The reward is not heaven itself but something in heaven. If election were
limited to heaven, it would only be necessary to speak of general election versus heavenly election. As noted
above, the word election can be used in its common sense to denote being selected for something. But election also
may be used more specifically to denote being selected for something in relation to heaven—to be selected to enter
heaven and/or inherit heaven. These believers in passages #1-2 are being selected to inherit heaven.
        In contrast to passages #1-2, no compelling reason is readily apparent for restricting the meaning of election
in passages #3-9 (Mt 24:22,24,31; Mk 13:20,22,27) to co-glorification salvation. Rather, all three phases of
salvation are indicated by the A in the chart. The days will have been shortened for all the elect who have believed.
Matthew uses the future tense whereas Mark uses the past tense, indicating the days already had been shortened.
The days of the tribulation will be shortened temporally because Daniel already has shortened them prophetically.
Matthew is looking forward to the temporal shortening while Mark is alluding back to the prophetic shortening.
The tribulation will not continue until all human life is destroyed. Instead, it will be terminated before mankind is
completely wiped out so that there will be elect survivors who live till the end of the tribulation. The shortening of
the days for the sake of the elect indicates that those who are called elect in that time period already have believed
and become elect during the tribulation. Certainly, they will believe before the termination of the tribulation. The
days will be shortened in that temporal time period for those who already will have become believers in that
period. Likewise, the angels are sent to gather all those who already have believed and who thus already have
entered into the temporal experience of their pre-temporal election. Again, those described by the adjective as elect
are pictured as already having believed. The same is true about those elect who are led astray by the antichrist; they
already have believed in Christ and now are being led astray to believe in antichrist.
        In passage #10 (Lk 18:7), the adjective elect certainly is used to describe those who already have believed
and thus entered into the temporal experience of their pre-temporal election. After all, they already have believed in
Christ, and for that reason they cry out to Him (cf. Lk 18:8). However, the question in Lk 18:7 is concerning a
special type of faith. In the parable, this faith is pictured as a faith that keeps on keeping on. It is a persistent,
victorious, living by faith. We know that the Lord will find believers when He returns. For He sends His angels to
collect them. Some of these elect believers will live to the end of the tribulation and be gathered by the angels at
that time. But will Jesus find believers who are enduring victoriously in faith to the end of the tribulation? Those
who are enduring the suffering in faith (i.e., who are living by faith) will be doing the consistent crying out to God
that Jesus describes in Lk 18:7. Those who are not only justified but who are also experiencing sanctification will
be the ones crying out to God.
        In passage #11 (Rom 8:33), Paul focuses his attention on the justification aspect of election, referring to God
as the one who justifies them. Again, the adjectival form of election is used to describe those who already have
believed. Obviously, they would have charges brought against them if they had not yet believed. At the moment of
faith, all charges against them had been dropped, as described in Col 2:13-14.
        In #12-15 (Rom 9:11; 11:5,7,28), Paul uses the nominal form of election, but he apparently advances his
focus from simple justification salvation to co-glorification salvation (which is the intended result of election),
while at the same time maintaining the continuity between the two concepts by insisting that such gracious election
is not of works (9:11; 11:5). Rather, it is an election based on grace. Both the gift of justification salvation and the
opportunity to earn co-glorification salvation are graciously given. Since Paul’s discussion of election in this

*
    See Blessed, 45.
Page 184                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
extended passage, however, is intertwined with references to salvation, more intensive interaction with this text
will be provided elsewhere.* Interestingly, it appears that in passages #13-14 Paul is using the nominal form to
describe those who already have believed. At the time Paul wrote this epistle to the Romans, there was a remnant
of Jews who already had trusted Christ as their Messiah and thus who already had received the eternal life which
the Messiah had promised. In passage #16 (Rom 16:13), Rufus already had believed and temporally entered into
his pre-temporal election.
        In passage #17 (Col 3:12), the elect, who already have believed and thus entered temporally into their pre-
temporal justification, are urged to enter temporally into their pre-temporal sanctification. Thus, the passage is
focused on their sanctification salvation. They already have believed and received justification salvation. In
passage #18 (Eph 1:4), Paul is again referring to those who already have believed as elect/chosen. God has
determined where they would be and what they should be. They would be in Christ—this is a positional truth
concerning justification salvation. They should be holy—this is practical truth concerning sanctification and is
paralleled by Paul’s statement in Eph 2:10. God has determined what we would and should be. We would be His
workmanship, and we should work—so that we can achieve co-glorification salvation and misthological
blamelessness (Col 1:22-23).
        In passage #19 (1Thess 1:4), a group of people is described as elect, and Paul affirms that they know they
are elect. The implication is that you do not have to wait until you die to find out if you are one of the elect. If you
have trusted in Christ alone for salvation from eternal damnation, then you are one of the elect and can know it.
Not only are you one of the elect, you have entered into the first phase of the salvation for which you were
elected—justification. These believers in #19 not only have entered into the initial phase of their salvation, they
also have entered into the second phase of the salvation to which they were elected/selected—practical
sanctification. Their faith is a living faith that works (vv. 3,8).
        In passage #20 (2Tim 2:10), Paul is concerned that those who already have believed will obtain the third
phase of their salvation: co-glorification salvation. He would not be concerned about this type of endurance for
those who have not yet believed. You cannot persevere in the faith until you have first come to the faith. This
passage has a strong parallel in 2Thess 2:13-14. Paul uses synonyms for choosing and obtaining in both passages.
The passages urge those who are chosen (and thus who already have believed) to experience the power of practical
sanctification in enduring so that they can obtain co-glorification salvation.
        In passage #21 (Tit 1:1), Paul is again concerned about the faith of the elect. In all probability, Paul is again
using the adjective elect to refer to those who already have believed. He is concerned about the elect continuing in
faith, not coming to faith. All the elect will come to faith (just as God has foreseen), but not all the elect will live
by faith. Most likely, Paul is concerned that those who already have believed should go on to demonstrate practical
holiness that marks a life of faith. Compare Tit 1:2 with Tit 3:7-8.283 Like salvation, eternal life can be a gift or a
reward depending upon which aspect of eternal life is in view. Paul is talking about inheriting eternal life as a
future misthological hope rather than merely having it as a present possession.
        In passage #22 (Jam 2:5), James is talking about election in a strictly misthological sense. He does not mean
that only the physically poor can inherit the kingdom. For not only can rich believers enter the kingdom, they can
also inherit it (1Tim 6:17-19). Nevertheless, it is difficult for the physically rich to be spiritually rich in faith, since
they are strongly tempted to trust in their riches rather than in God. It is much easier for the physically poor to be
poor in spirit. Thus, the promise made by Jesus in Mt 5:5, to which James refers, applies much more readily to
those who are physically poor.
        In passage #23 (1Pet 1:1), Peter is addressing those who already have believed. In v. 2 he is concerned that,
through the power of the Spirit experienced in practical sanctification, they obey Jesus and experience His
cleansing as a result (cf. 1Jn 1:7). In passage #24 (1Pet 2:9), Peter states that, as the elect, they are God’s
possession. Belonging to God is part of our justification salvation, of course. But Peter emphasizes that they are to
show forth God’s light, which is connected with practical sanctification. At the same time he reminds them of their
regal, misthological function which is to be realized eschatologically and contingently as a result of such
sanctification. Nevertheless, the focus of the passage within this context is concerning the practical ramifications of
their sanctification so that they live as light in this dark world as they abstain from lust and manifest good deeds
before the Gentiles. As a result, salvation is to become a growing experience in victory over the power of sin (1Pet
2:1-2,10-12). Those addressed in passage #25 (2Pet 1:10) are called brethren; they already have believed and come
into the first phase of their salvation. Still, Peter is urging them to experience the third phase of the salvation for


*
    See Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 7. Election and Predestination                                                                       Page 185
which they were called and elected: co-glorification. Election only guarantees the first phase of salvation for
believers. The third phase is not guaranteed but requires our diligence.
       In passages #26-27 (2Jn 1:1,13), John is again using the adjective form of election to describe those who
already have believed. In passage #28 (Rev 17:14), John is referring to those in the future who will overcome the
forces of evil with Jesus. This passage appears to be describing an eschatological battle in which those who already
have qualified to rule, by temporally overcoming with Jesus, are allowed also to overcome eschatologically with
Him (cf. Rev 19:14). All believers will live with Jesus, but not every believer will rule with Jesus. This rulership is
an eschatological reward. Overcoming with Jesus in this passage also appears to be an eschatological reward. Or as
Wilkin surmises,

       It pictures the Second Coming of Christ to vanquish the enemies of God at Armageddon. The King of
       kings is surrounded by a coterie of approved believers…Unfaithful believers are not mentioned. They
       will not be numbered among Jesus’ partners or companions (metochoi, see Hebrews 1:9). This is in
       keeping with the imagery of Psalm 45…Of course, the Lord Jesus will rightly have the superlative
