       experience of joy. Yet His companions will also be given a special measure of gladness forever.284

       The sequence (of calling followed by election) is found in Mt 20:16; 22:14; 2Pet 1:10; and Rev 17:14. As
seen on the chart, these four passages (and only these four passages) have been marked as referring to post-
temporal election. They are all considered to be references to co-glorification salvation, but they are not the only
references to co-glorification salvation.

                                                   Conclusion
       The purpose of this chapter was simply to provide an introduction to some of the primary texts and ideas
associated with election. As such, it focused on three phases of election/predestination. Election may be unto
salvation, but this does not necessarily indicate that election is restricted to a soteriological understanding of
salvation in all such passages. In fact, varying aspects of salvation may be in view. Further, this election may
fluctuate in terms of temporal vantage points. Whether election is conditional must be determined by contextual
factors. In the chapters to follow, it will be demonstrated that the doctrine of predestination provides an inadequate
basis for Ventilato’s opinion that all believers misthologically will inherit the kingdom and thus be spared from the
outer darkness.
Page 186   The Outer Darkness
                                               Chapter 8.
                                         Pre-temporal Election
                                                  Introduction
        Within the overview of the conceptual context just presented in the previous chapter, the details involved
may now be considered. This chapter will deal with that aspect of election that occurred in eternity past. This pre-
temporal election occurred before time (i.e., before temporal reality), as we know it, came to be. The discussion
will include interaction concerning the relationship between foreknowledge, foreordination, and free will. Whether
prevenient grace is necessary will be explored. A Marrowistic affirmation of double predestination will be
maintained.
       Because of the complexity of this aspect of the discussion concerning election, even with some of the more
technical aspects farmed out to the appendices, this will still be a long chapter. But a rather thorough discussion
will be necessary since we are interacting with the Arminian and Calvinistic camps in a theological battlefield with
heavily entrenched positions. After this rather lengthy début of the refinements offered by GRAPE on this
hermeneutical battleground, the two other aspects of predestination (temporal and post-temporal) will be dealt with
briefly within the space of a single, concise chapter before moving to the biblical context surrounding the outer
darkness. Since some believe that predestination prevents a believer from suffering severe misthological
consequences and would use this doctrine to rule out seriously considering the misthological position concerning
the outer darkness (even before examining the Scripture pertaining to it), this objection will be dealt with now so
that the reader may have greater freedom in earnestly examining the subsequent exegesis of the contexts pertaining
to the outer darkness.

                          Temporal Implications of Pre-temporal Election
       The election in Eph 1:4 was made before the foundation of the world. Therefore, this election is pre-
temporal. It was made in eternity past. One camp argues that it predetermines who will be in Christ. Marrowistic
theology certainly could accommodate such a viewpoint with no problem. The us in v. 4 refers to believers. God
has predetermined that believers will be in Christ. But they are not actually put in Christ and sealed in Christ until
the temporal moment they believe (Eph 1:13). The other camp believes that the election refers to a
predetermination made about those who already have entered into Christ by faith. Of course, this presents no
problem for Marrowism either. Every time in the NT someone is described as elect due to their pre-temporal
election, they are being described from this temporal perspective of already having believed. They already have
believed and been put in Christ as a result. They already have entered into the temporal sphere of their pre-
temporal election. Or as Paul affirms about those in Christ in Eph 2:10, they already have become His
workmanship: new creations and new creatures in Christ. Either way one looks at it, this is the election of
believers, not of unbelievers to become believers.
       Not only do Eph 1:4 and 2:10 tell us what the elect would be—His workmanship—they also tell us what the
elect should be—holy workers. The temporal implications of this pre-temporal election must also be considered.

      Just as He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless
      before Him. (Eph 1:4; NAS, 1977)

      Just as He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we would be holy and blameless
      before Him. (Eph 1:4; NAS, 1995)

      For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared
      beforehand, that we should walk in them. (Eph 2:10; NAS, 1977)

      For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared
      beforehand so that we would walk in them. (Eph 2:10; NAS, 1995)

        The NAS has abandoned its previous rendition of should for would. Other translations typically translate
these verses as should. Evidently, the more recent editors of the NAS felt that a stronger rendition was preferable.
One might speculate that in doing so they are advocating a Calvinistic understanding of the Scripture and reading
their theology into the text by assuming that God has predetermined that all believers should not only be holy in
their walk but that they actually would be experientially holy as a result or their predestination.
Page 188                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
        As an unconditional result of God’s irresistible decree, all believers will live holy lives. According to this
perspective, if you do not live a holy life, then you were not predestined to do so; you are not one of the elect. If
you do not walk in the good works, then God has not predestined that you would walk in them. In such a case, you
are not His workmanship; you are not saved. Speaking from this Calvinistic premise, your good works ultimately
will determine whether you are saved. This is one reason that many of those in Calvinism readily will admit that
their system conditions your final salvation on God’s unconditional predestination.
        If this is the understanding of the current editors of the NAS, then it is unfortunate that they have allowed
their Calvinistic theology to color their interpretation. On the other hand, although the newer edition of the NAS
might be interpreted this way, it is not a foregone conclusion that this is the intention of the editors, or at least not
all of them. Although the older translation is clearer, the working model proposed within this present chapter could
accommodate either should or would, as seen in the illustration using the author’s children in the example to
follow.

                                         Working Model of Would & Should
       After allowing my children to start elementary school at Fairview Elementary, when we moved to a
permanent location a short distance away, I predetermined that my children would go to the school district of their
residence and attend Scott’s Creek Elementary rather than continue at Fairview Elementary. I also determined that
my children would do well in their studies at the new school. To his dismay, Jeremy, my older son, was not given
a choice of continuing to go to Fairview. As a child, he had no choice as to which school he would attend; I made
that choice for him. But Jeremy did have a choice as to how well he would do in the new school. There is a limit
as to how far I would push him to perform well. As a parent, my choice as their father that my children would
perform well would be balanced with their choice as to how well they would perform. My fatherly will for them
concerning the school contextually may be divided into two aspects: I determined (1) that they would go to school
and (2) that they would perform well. Likewise, God has determined (1) that we would be in Christ and (2) that we
would be holy in our practice.
       God predetermined that His children would be in Christ—they have no choice about the matter. This is
unconditional election. If you believe in Christ, you have no choice as to whether you are in Christ. He also
predetermined that His children would live holy lives in Christ and walk in good works. As a loving parent, He
will discipline them and encourage them to do well in Christ, but there is a limit as to how hard He will push them.
He will not do away with their free will. He will permit them to fail if they obstinately insist on doing so. Failure
will have its consequences, of course, but they will remain His children and will be dealt with as such. This aspect
of His Fatherly election is conditioned upon the response of His children to His love and discipline.
       Although describing both aspects of the above election as would is permissible, clarifying between the two
aspects by rendering conditional election as should is preferable. The author predetermined which school his
children would go to and that they should do well in school. God has predetermined that His children would be in
Christ and that they should live holy lives in Christ. God sovereignly has determined that believers would go to
heaven. Thus, I am using would as an expression of God’s sovereign, irresistible will. On the other hand, God has
also predetermined that we should be holy and blameless in our temporal walk. Or as stated in the better
translations of Eph 2:10, we should walk in good works. In electing us, God determined what we would be and
what we should be. We should perform good works (this is our moral responsibility), but we may fail to fulfill that
responsibility. Thus, should is being used to express God’s resistible moral will.* The fact that we fail morally does
not mean that God’s election has failed. God’s election has determined what we would be and should be, but God’s
election only guarantees what would be, not what should be. The Scripture says that we should be holy and that we
should walk in good works. That is a far cry from saying that we will be holy and that we will walk in good works.
Our temporal walk is quite often not what it should be. What should be is not necessarily what is.

*
  For further interaction with God’s sovereign will as opposed to His moral will from a more classical format, see the illustrations in
Predestination and the Open View. In grammatical terms, I am entertaining the possibility that Eph 1:4 dualistically refers to a
guaranteed result for believers (in terms of their position), but that it, like Eph 2:10, represents God’s purpose and intention for
believers, not the guaranteed result in terms of their behavior. For further discussion of purpose, result, and purpose-result, see Three
Basic Views of Election (p. 264) and endnote 466. Eph 2:10 is a hina clause plus subjunctive mood. This construction is discussed in
more detail in that chapter as well. If this dualistic approach to Eph 1:4 is too difficult to maintain, the preference would be to drop the
dualism and adopt the position that Paul simply is saying that God misthologically has chosen believers contingently (who are in
Christ positionally) to be holy and blameless before Him. In other words, the election in this verse would be limited to God’s purpose
and intention. The expression in Him tells who He has chosen. The expression pertaining to before Him provides the purpose or reason
for the election.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election          Page 189




                                   Illustration 77. Predestination
Page 190                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       God has unconditionally predestined that the believer’s position would be in Christ, and He has
conditionally predestined that the believer’s practice should be a life of holiness. Those children who respond in a
positive manner to their Father will be co-glorified with Jesus. Those children who respond in a negative manner
will be excluded from being co-heirs with Jesus. God will not violate their free will on this matter. If they choose
to disobey, they will have to pay the misthological consequences in what is described by the Lord as the outer
darkness. This proposed model is thus a balance between the Arminian and Calvinistic views of election. It has
also been anticipated to some extent by Eaton,

       I suspect there is a difference between irresistile [sic] predestination to salvation, and resistible
       predestination to inheritance. My approach then to Rom. 8:28-30 and 9:6-29 is thoroughly—but
       unspeculatively—“Calvinistic.” Yet this does not predetermine the interpretation of predestination to
       inheritance or the interpretation of Eph. 2:10. When it speaks of…the human factor (“that we should
       walk in them”) [it] implies we are not dealing with [a] sheer gracious gift but with human co-
       operation. At this point an “Arminian” exposition is more convincing…There may be “irresistible
       grace” in Eph. 2:8-9, but not in Eph. 2:10—a possibility that has not so far as I know been adequately
       considered.285

       Co-heirship in the kingdom is, as Eaton acknowledges, a resistible aspect of election. Every believer should
be a co-heir with Christ, but not all believers will be co-heirs. In the illustration, the Calvinistically irresistible
portion of predestination is pictured by would {
                                               w . The Arminian’s resistible portion of predestination is pictured by

should { s .


                                                     Foresaw
       Did God forechoose or foresee who would believe? Even some of the best writers within the FG camp
prefer the forechose position and use the Great Pearly Gate illustration. This side of the gate is marked by
Whosoever Will may Come; the other side is marked by Chosen from the Foundation of the World. The tension as
to how we can be chosen irresistibly to believe and yet still be free to believe or disbelieve is left unexplained as a
paradox.286 Moderate Calvinists take this route in order to affirm both the sovereignty of God and free will of man.
But one wonders how they can be so comfortable with this unresolved tension within their view of sovereignty.
Can one truly be comfortable with saying that God can make a man with free will and yet irresistibly predestine all
the decisions that man will make without violating man’s free will, and then claim that this is a mystery that cannot
be understood so there is no use trying to explain it? Would one be content to say that since God is sovereign He
can do absolutely anything?
       Would we likewise say that God can make a round square since He is sovereign and then be content to
respond when challenged by the absurdity of such a notion that it is a mystery and that this is explanation enough?
Can we state that God can make a rock so big that even He cannot lift it and then claim that this must be
mysteriously possible since God is sovereign? The Bible has no trouble affirming that God can do anything but
cannot do everything (Lk 1:37; Tit 1:2). God can do everything that is possible for a holy, loving, almighty God to
do. Yet this does not mean that He can do everything imaginable, much less the unimaginable. One is left to
wonder if the picture of a God who can grant free will to man, while at the same time irresistibly predetermining
man’s actions, is the only picture of God that is capable of existing in the mysterious, imaginary world of
Calvinism. Others within the FG camp prefer the foreknowledge position. Unlike Arminians, these FG writers
believe that God’s prescience-based predestination predetermines the believer’s destination as heaven. This is the
one-way-road of unconditional security.287 Although many Calvinists would be aghast at the audacity of such
simplicity, it is the approach taken herein.
       Although preference will be given to this second position, interaction will be provided with both
possibilities. This difference in perspective is not limited to those in the FG camp, of course. For example, the
reader is encouraged to consider Thiessen’s Systematic Theology for a balanced discussion of both positions.288 In
Shank’s assessment, Thiessen “states a good case for conditional election while contending for the unconditional
security.”289 Marrowists concur. Like many of those in FG, Thiessen evidently sees a need for some type of
mediating position between the Arminian and Calvinistic perspectives on this matter. Fisk provides us with a
chapter full of quotations from moderate Calvinists, such as Thiessen, who likewise advocate a prescience-based
predestination.290 One of the more insightful comments provided by Fisk in that chapter is from Torrey:
“Foreknowledge no more determines man’s actions than afterknowledge. Knowledge is determined by the fact, not
fact by the knowledge.”291 Bryson concurs: “Knowing an event is going to occur (or even allowing for an event to
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 191
occur) is no more the cause of that event occurring than is knowing an event has occurred is the cause of an event
which has occurred.”292
       God loved the world (and all its human inhabitants of the past, present, and future) so much that He sent His
only Son Jesus to die for every human being. God desired and provided salvation from hell for all of lost humanity.
The provision for their forgiveness already has been made; they need only trust Him for eternal life. God in His
omniscience could see the sins of all sinners of all time and laid them on His Son who died for their sins. Even
though He has chosen to save all humanity, as a rule, He honors our free will and allows us to choose to live in hell
with Satan rather than in heaven with Jesus if we so choose to harden our hearts against believing in Christ. This
aspect of God’s election is not irresistible. We should trust in Christ, we can trust in Christ, but that does not
necessarily mean that we will trust in Christ. We should—we have the moral responsibility. We can—God has
given us the ability. But this does not necessarily mean that we will—God does not force us to believe with a
sovereign decree. Those in Illustration 77 who are pictured as going to hell are those who could have and should
have trusted in Christ but were unwilling to do so.293

Hardened Hearts
        The song Whosoever Will May Come is true to the biblical exhortations addressed to all unbelievers (e.g.,
Rev 22:17).294 Jesus also stated that the problem was a lack of willingness. “I would have…but you would not”
(Mt 23:37; TM). This should not be taken to mean that they were unable to believe. They did not believe because
they would not of their own volition (Jn 5:40). They were unable to believe because of their own carnal pursuits
(Jn 5:44). Eventually, some of them reached the point where, for all practical purposes, they could not believe
(Jn 12:39). People may reach an unpardonable state* where they become so hardened (as a result of resisting the
Spirit) that subsequently they can never believe. This is not the natural state of affairs though; it is not the initial
state of the lost. Otherwise, God would not have to harden the heart of the lost who persisted in unbelieving to
prevent them from ever believing (Jn 12:39-40; cp. 2Thess 2:11).
        Yet, strangely, White asserts to the contrary: “The passage [Jn 12:39-40] explains their unbelief as a
fulfillment of prophecy, not as a result of anything the men did themselves.”295 White’s opinion is based on the
fallacy that prophecy is causative. To the contrary, Jesus was not forced to speak in parables (Mt 13:35) or ride on
a donkey (Mt 21:4) in order to fulfill prophecy. Jesus acted of His own free volition to say, “I am thirsty”
(Jn 19:28), in order to fulfill Scripture. Jesus was not forced by His foreknowledge or by prophecy to make this
utterance against His will, nor was His will determined by this prophecy. Prophecy, like prescience, is
noncausative. To be sure, whatever is prophesied to take place will take place. Still, it will not necessarily take
place because it was prophesied in a causal sense. Rather, sometimes a future event simply may be prophesied
because it will take place.† John’s explanation as to why so many rejected Jesus’ public ministry (which is in
John’s conclusion to Jesus’ public ministry) would seem to indicate that their hardening may have been a result of
their rejection of Jesus. In fact, Jn 12:39-30 is a quote of Is 6:9-10. This OT passage is also quoted four more times
in the NT. In the synoptic accounts, it is used to explain why Jesus decided to speak to the multitudes in parables:
          13
             Therefore I speak to them in parables; because while seeing they do not see, and while hearing
          they do not hear, nor do they understand. 14 And in their case the prophecy of Isaiah is being fulfilled,
          which says, “You will keep on hearing, but will not understand; And you will keep on seeing, but
          will not perceive; 15 for the heart of this people has become dull, and with their ears they scarcely
          hear, and they have closed their eyes lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears,
          and understand with their heart and return, and I should heal them.” (Mt 13:13-15)

       The reason Jesus spoke to them in this manner was because they did not understand, and the reason they
did not understand was because they themselves had closed their own eyes to the truth of what Jesus was
saying. Granted, the other two synoptic accounts, Mark (4:12) and Luke (8:10), do not include this phrase: they
have closed their eyes. But why should they or John be required to do so? Are abbreviated quotations
inadmissible? Does the abridged edition make the fuller revelation any less true? Of course not.
       In the context of the parable of the soil, in which this statement is imbedded in both Mark and Luke, it is
made sufficiently clear by each writer that the personal disposition of each person is a significant factor. A person’s
reception to the word, rather than God’s sovereign decree, determines what impact the word will have on the

*
    See Appendix 10. The Unpardonable Sin, 831.
†
    See “Certainty and Necessity” in Predestination and the Open View.
Page 192                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
individual’s heart. What is more, Luke concludes Acts with the fuller form of the quote from Isaiah and includes
the phrase they have closed their eyes. He does so in order to explain why Paul was turning to the Gentiles with the
gospel—because the Jews had rejected it! Moreover, in John’s immediate context, Jesus is imploring the Jewish
people to believe (12:36). Postulating that Jesus is attempting to get them to do something contrary to the Father’s
sovereign decree would be ludicrous! For that matter, John indicates in his quote from Isaiah that it was not
sovereignly impossible for them to believe since he says, “He hardened their heart; lest they see” (John 12:40).
       Obviously, if it were sovereignly impossible for them to believe, hardening them lest they believe would not
have been necessary. Therefore, it was possible for them to believe, but the hardening decreased the likelihood of
this happening. John further clarifies that the hardening was not an absolute: “Nevertheless many even of the rulers
believed” (John 12:42). The hardening was not absolute, eternal, or irresistible, but it was sufficient to explain the
general lack of response to Jesus’ public ministry.
       In contrast to White, not all Calvinists have closed their eyes to what this text is saying. Although
Hendriksen is a Calvinist, he provides an excellent explanation:

                The terrible consequence of hardening ourselves…is here pointed out…But when people, of
          their own accord and after repeated threats and promises, reject him and spurn his messages, then—
          and not until then—he hardens them, in order that those who were not willing to repent may not be
          able to repent.296

        Well said, even if by a Calvinist. It was a temporal hardening. Barnes likewise believes that it merely
reflects “moral inability” and cites Chrysostom in support as saying, “They could not, because they would not.”
Amen. He quotes Augustine to the same effect: “If I be asked why they could not believe, I answer without
hesitation, because they would not: because God foresaw their evil will, and he announced it beforehand by the
prophets.”297 Excellent Arminian theology, even if it is by Augustine! God foresaw, rather than fore-determined,
their response and its corresponding result. White presents us with a false dichotomy when he posits the unbelief as
being a fulfillment of prophecy rather than a result of something they themselves did. It was both.
        In his opening comments, Lenski takes a stance that would be in agreement with White: “It was impossible
for them to believe because of the prophecy spoken by Isaiah.”298 Even so, Lenski’s explanation of why prophecy
made them angry sweeps the ground out from under White: “We have not the antecedent but the subsequent will of
God. This is not a blinding and heardening decree in advance by an absolute will forcing damnation upon men; but
a judicial and punitive decree upon those whose obduracy God infallibly foresees.”299
        Prophecy did not cause them to harden their hearts. Prophecy foresaw them hardening their hearts. To relate
an explanation from Craig pertaining to this concept that will be more fully explained elsewhere: “The word
because here indicates a logical, not a causal, relation, one similar to that expressed in the sentence ‘four is an even
number because it is divisible by two.’”300 If one must speak deterministically, prophecy did not determine what
they would do; rather, it revealed what they would do and what God would do in response.* If one must speak in
terms of sovereignty, then the manner in which Tenney does so should not be objectionable: “Unbelief is the result
of the rejection of light, which act, by the sovereign law of God, gradually makes belief impossible.”301 It was not a
sovereign decree or natural inability which predetermined their response and made it impossible for them to
believe. Instead, the more they violated God’s moral will, the more they morally were hardened.
        The fact that God had to harden their heart to prevent them from believing after their rejecting the gospel
attests to the fact that the gospel itself has the power to draw men to faith in Christ. This verse nullifies, rather than
ratifies, the theory that people totally are incapable of believing the gospel. If total depravity meant total inability to
believe the gospel apart from irresistible drawing, then God would not have to harden them to prevent them from
believing it. You cannot divorce the word of God from the Spirit of God. As the living, powerful, inspired word of
God pulsating with the life-giving power of the Spirit, the gospel has the power to draw and regenerate. Still, as a
general rule, God has decided that those who choose to harden themselves to it will be allowed to do so.

Prevenient Grace

                                                  Provides Ability
       Thiessen explains that prevenient grace is the part of common grace through which God has made it
possible for all the lost to believe: “God, through prevenient grace, provides everyone with the ability to respond to

*
    See “Certainty versus Necessity” and “Prescient Will ≠ Chronological Must” in Predestination and the Open View.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                             Page 193
                           302
him if they so choose.” In this act of grace, God takes the initiative and makes the antecedent step of restoring
“to the sinner the ability to make a favorable response to God (Rom. 2:4; Titus 2:11).”303 Now it is true that this
enabling grace can provide the basis for synergistic effort. For example, concerning Phil 2:12-13 and prevenient
grace, Cox summarizes Wesley’s view as: “Here is a form of synergism understood in the midst of a monergism.
Initially God works and after His work begins, then it is possible for man to cooperate with Him.”304 Or as Harper,
the Wesleyan representative, states it: “Prevenient grace prevents the Fall from being so intensive that even the
ability to respond is lost. The Fall is extensive; that is, no aspect of existence escapes it. Yet because of grace, it is
not so complete in humanity that people lose all ability to recognize and respond to God.”305
        This view of prevenient grace held by Harper (a Wesleyan Arminian*) is met by this rejoinder from Ashby (a
Reformed Arminian†): “Fallen humanity is always responding to God wrongly. It is not like a dense fog settling
over a city in which everyone equally shares….Rather, it is individually directed” (emphasis his).306 In response,
the present book affirms prevenient grace by contending that it is possible for the lost person soteriologically to
seek God. Accordingly, since it is not wrong to seek God, it is wrong to say that the lost always respond to God
wrongly when they respond by seeking God. Nevertheless, all are not drawn equally. Those drawn by natural
revelation are not drawn as strongly as those who hear the special revelation. As Craig wisely notes, although not
all are drawn equally, all are drawn sufficiently, and “many of the unsaved may actually receive greater divine
assistance and drawing than do the saved.”307 Those who hear the gospel are drawn more powerfully than those
who have not heard it. So we need to preach the gospel. But even those who hear the gospel are not drawn with the
same persuasive power by it. Agrippa was, perhaps, only almost persuaded (Acts 26:28). Like the man gripping the
aisle in church to avoid the powerful pull of the Spirit, he refused to be persuaded, whereas some who respond to
the gospel will respond with a simple nudge from the Spirit. Some harden themselves to the Spirit’s drawing, and
some soften themselves to it. Those who soften themselves to it may be expected to become more and more
attracted to it. Conversely, those who harden themselves to it may become harder and harder to reach. We have the
God-given ability to respond to the forces exerted upon us.
        Marrowists also affirm common grace. As a general rule, people have the ability (through common grace) to
live obediently so that they do not have to sin willfully (i.e., knowingly as opposed to unknowingly) in response to
any given temptation. Do they sin willfully out of necessity? No. Culpability for sinning willfully must entail the
ability not to sin willfully. Otherwise, we would have the same degree of culpability for unknown sins as willful
sins. As it is, various types of sin required different types of sacrifices in the OT.
        The necessity of common grace may be deduced from the fact that doing good is counter to our disposition
so that we cannot even do anything that is even relatively good apart from God (Jer 13:23; Rom 3:10-18; 8:7-8).
Although Christians, and we may presume human beings in general, may not be tempted beyond what they are able
to resist initially (1Cor 10:13), those who flirt with the temptation rather than flee from it may find that they have
put themselves in a position where they can no longer resist it. Even though the law shows our inability to live
perfectly (Jam 2:10) and our propensity to live rebelliously (Josh 24:19), it nevertheless reveals us our ability to
live responsibly (Dt 30:11-14). Since the law also makes sacrificial provisions for those who fail to keep its
stipulations, it is reasonable to believe that it recognizes the inevitability of our failing to live up to all its
expectations consistently. To speak analogously, theoretically we could make each free throw in basketball. But
practically speaking, we do not have the ability to make every shot. This lack of ability to perform with flawless
consistency does not alleviate us of the responsibility to try to make every shot during the game since any given
shot is within range of our God-given ability. We cannot make every shot, but we are responsible for trying our
best to make every single shot. Responsibility necessarily entails a sufficient degree of ability so as to result in
culpability.


*
  A Wesleyan Arminian is someone who follows the modifications made by Wesley to Arminianism. Most notably, this view believes
that salvation can be lost by either apostasy or unconfessed sin. Nevertheless, regeneration may be restored by reconversion and
repentance.
†
  A Reformed Arminian is someone who holds the views of Arminius himself and his original followers. It is debated as to whether
Arminius himself actually affirmed that irremediable apostasy actually could take place for those who had experienced saving faith. In
any case, his modern advocates certainly tend to deny OSAS in the case of willful, irremediable apostasy. Basically, it would seem
that Arminius’ position leads to the conclusion that regenerate believers who persevere in the faith until the end of their lives become
elect at that time and are chosen to go to heaven as a result. God predestines those whom He foreknows will persevere in the faith to
reach heaven. If you fail to persevere, you lose your regenerate life and fail to reach final salvation. In Reformed Arminianism, you
are predestined because you persevere. In Reformed theology itself, however, you persevere because you are predestined. Other than
this particular matter, Reformed Arminianism tends to agree with Reformed theology on other issues, such as the penal nature of the
atonement and justification by imputation.
Page 194                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
                                       Semi-Pelagianism Charge is False
        If prevenient grace is broadly meant as God taking the initiative to allow fallen man to make a positive
response to His will, then Marrowists may agree. Further, if it were simply said that prevenient grace makes
synergistic effort possible, we would still agree. But a point of contention would be with Calvinists who claim that
any response to God based on prevenient grace must be synergistic. For example, the Calvinistic claim that saving
grace must be irresistible to avoid being synergistic (and thus avoid being Semi-Pelagian) is false. Marrowists
reject Semi-Pelagianism by affirming that God must take the initiative. Peterson and Williams equate Semi-
Pelagianism with the view that “God helps those who help themselves” (emphasis theirs).308 Man takes the
initiative. In prevenient grace, in contrast, God takes the initiative. God helps those who respond to His help. His
gracious enablement occurs both the antecedently and subsequently to the human response. We further affirm
monergistic soteriology by maintaining that God does all the work in our regeneration, not us (Jn 1:13). We do not
give birth to ourselves. Since our soteriological response is passive acceptance (Jn 1:12), rather than active
commitment, our response is not meritorious. In other words, the type of response must be taken into
consideration.
        The present writer rejects the notion that saving faith itself is volitional, much less a work. The Calvinists
who claim that saving faith is an active commitment are the ones who actually are turning faith into a work and
opening the door to synergistic soteriology. For such Calvinists, the only way salvation could be monergistic is for
God to do everything, including giving us faith through irresistible grace. Yet Paul does not consider salvation by
grace through faith a synergistic response (Rom 4:4-5), nor will it be considered so here. Forster well states that the
passive view of faith refutes this Calvinistic charge: “Paul makes it clear that receiving a free gift is not works, for
works earn whatever is received…receiving a free gift is not a work” (emphasis his).309 After an extended
discussion of synergisms, Anderson comes to the same conclusion: “As Roy Aldrich argued long ago, receiving a
gift can never be construed to be a meritorious work” (emphasis his).310 Or as Aldrich himself states: “A gift from
a good man to a beggar does not cease to be a gift because the beggar stretches forth his hand to receive it.”311
        If faith is a work, then we are not justified by faith, since Paul explicitly says that we are not justified by
works (Rom 3:28; 4:5; Gal 2:16; 2Tim 1:9). However, since Paul with equal clarity confirms that we are justified
by faith (Rom 3:28; 5:1; Gal 2:16), it must be concluded that such faith is not a work. The Calvinistic notion that
such faith must be a gift is rejected because this view is built on the misperception that faith is a work unless it is a
gift. God in His prevenient grace makes faith possible, but He does not irresistibly cause us to believe. The gift is
not faith but salvation.
        The rejoinder sometimes offered by Calvinists, such as Gerstner, is that faith is a nonmeritorious work.
Gerstner wants to import a whole laundry list of works as soteriological requirements. But Marrowists reject the
attempts by Reformed Calvinists and Arminian Campbellites* to import works under a Semi-Pelagian white flag.
No truce will be offered to those seeking to add works as a soteriological requirement. Misthologists affirm, with
Hodges, that all works are meritorious and, therefore, not allowable as a soteriological necessity.312 The faith which
Paul describes is nonmeritorious and, correspondingly, not equatable with any form of works. The true Semi-
Pelagians in this debate are not to be found in the FG camp. Soteriological faith is completely nonmeritorious.
Saving faith is a passive reliance on Christ’s finished work, not an active commitment to work.

                                                Universal Drawing
        That God enables the lost to believe and conditions their salvation on what they believe does not mean that
He has conditioned their salvation on works. In urging the lost to believe, God is not calling on them to do
something they are incapable of doing. No one would come to God apart from God’s drawing him (Jn 6:44). But
this same Greek word for draw (helko) is used by John to say that Jesus draws all men (Jn 12:32). God takes the
initiative and makes faith possible for all men. All are drawn, but not all come. Even so, one need not wait until ch.
12 in John’s narrative to discover the universal nature of this resistible drawing. Just as Jesus says that no one can
come to Him unless the Father draws him (6:44), so He reiterates that no one can come to Him unless it is given to
him by the Father (6:65). But to whom is the drawing given? In the very next verse, many of Jesus’ disciples
withdraw from following Him (Jn 6:66). Evidently, this drawing is not irresistible since some withdraw.
        Likewise, in Heb 10:38-39, it is still possible for believers today to draw back from Jesus and experience
misthological destruction as a result. Neither soteriological or misthological drawing is irresistible. Obviously, one

*
 Campbellites are followers of Alexander Campbell, who started a separatist movement in 1807. Campbellism teaches that water
baptism is essential to soteriological salvation. A split over the use of musical instruments among these followers gave rise to the
Disciples of Christ and later to a more conservative branch called the Church of Christ.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 195
has to be drawn before one can withdraw. The fact that different Greek words are being used for drawing and
withdrawing does not detract from the picture being painted by Scripture. Since the drawing is resistible, it is
universal. Calvinists are not free to suppose irresistible drawing and thereby deduce that it is limited to certain
individuals. John even entertains the unlikely possibility that the twelve might even withdraw from Jesus’ drawing
(Jn 6:67). The drawing refers to opportunity and ability that God gives to all of us to believe. It is the draw of the
gospel call.
        Calvinists are quick to claim that this drawing is irresistible for two primary reasons, based on supposed
meanings for all and draw. Sellers, for instance, states that the all in Jn 12:32 may mean all (races) without
distinction rather than all individuals without exception and that draw may mean to compel or drag.313 In response
to these Calvinistic claims, Gordon Olson appropriately cites BAGD and states: “Note the primary literal meaning
of the verb ‘to draw, to drag’ has reference to physical objects, whereas the figurative usage in reference to the
inner life of a person is appropriately not coercive” (emphasis his).314
        To the Calvinists who would respond that Olson has overstated his case and then offer a retort by pointing
out that this verb is used of people being dragged in several passages (Acts 16:19; 21:30; Jam 2:6), let it be pointed
out that BDAG correctly lists these passages and those of the fish being dragged by the net to shore (Jn 21:6,11) as
examples of moving unwilling objects, but it cites both Jn 6:44 and 12:32 (along with Jer 31:3 and SSol 1:4) in a
separate category, meaning to attract. It means to exert an influence. By the news of His sacrificial death, Jesus
draws us, rather than drags us, to His cross for forgiveness and eternal life. If anything, Olson understates his case.
        Olson makes a concession to the Calvinists concerning the meaning of all in Jn 12:32 and states that the
context (Jn 12:20) may indeed indicate that it is merely affirming that Christ will draw all without distinction, not
all without exception.315 In other words, both Jews and Greeks would be drawn, but this does not establish that
every human being on the planet would be drawn, just every type of person. Olson immediately goes on to show
that there are passages which do, in fact, affirm that Christ died for all in the absolute sense without distinction as
well as without exception (e.g., Lk 19:10; Rom 5:6,18; 2Cor 5:14-15; 1Tim 1:1-6; 4:10; Tit 2:11; Heb 2:9).
        The passage in Rom 5:18 may be taken as a case in point: “So then as through one transgression there
resulted condemnation to all men, even so through one act of righteousness there resulted justification of life to all
men.” Condemnation has, in fact, actually been passed on to all men. But the imputation of justification and the
impartation of eternal life have only potentially been made available to all men. These benefits are provisional for
all, but they are also conditional. We must believe in order to actually be justified and receive eternal life. So for
Calvinists who quip that such Marrowists are picturing Christ as only making a potential atonement or paying a
potential amount, we would respond that provisional means conditional rather than not actual. Christ actually bore
everyone’s sins in order to make a universal atonement contingently available.
        The difference between the two expressions to all men is not one of distinction versus exception. On the
contrary, the justification is as universal as the condemnation. They are both applied to the same group, not to two
different groups or to different types of people. The difference is between what is actual and what is potential.
Overall, Olson provides an excellent discussion in his chapter, For Whom Did Christ Die? In the midst of his
chapter on provisional atonement, Olson rejects Owen’s Calvinistic notion that election, rather than faith, is really
all that is necessary for salvation.
        I concur with Olson, but not, however, for the reason which he himself supplies: “Unbelief is a unique sin,
one which if persisted in will lead to condemnation (Jn. 3:18)….Unbelief must be distinguished from other sins lest
the necessity of faith be totally obviated.”316 Olson’s defective understanding is perhaps the premise from which he
maintains that perseverance in faith is necessary to reach heaven. In any case, Olson’s argument is flawed in
assuming that unbelief could not be included in the atonement without landing one in universalism.
        It is true that persistence in unbelief will result in hell if it prevents one from ever believing the gospel. The
notion that perseverance in faith is necessary to ultimately reach heaven is false, however. Christ died for all sins,
even the sin of unbelief. Yet, like all sins, His death for the sin of unbelief was provisional and conditional. Christ
has provided forgiveness for unbelief, but this forgiveness is conditioned upon belief. When a person believes, that
person is immediately forgiven of all sins: past, present, and future (Col 2:13-14). This forgiveness includes all
past, present, and future forms of unbelief. Even unbelief experienced at the point of conversion in the form of
weak faith is no obstacle to regeneration in my articulation of GRAPE theology.* Unbelief is no exception to the
rule that justification declares us righteous as our final verdict, even if that justification is based on weak punctiliar
faith, as long as that faith is in Christ alone for eternal life. Perseverance in faith is not a soteriological necessity.
For this reason, neither the degree nor duration of one’s faith is a factor to be taken into consideration for assurance

*
    See Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
Page 196                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
                                                                                     *
of salvation. The sole basis of such salvation is the object of one’s faith. Salvation from hell is conditioned on
faith alone in Christ alone for eternal life. Neither the length of our faith nor the magnitude of our faith is the issue.
Saving faith is nonmeritorious.
         Nor do Marrowists need to be too quick in following Olson’s abandonment of Jn 12:32 as an affirmation of
universal drawing, at least not to those who hear the gospel. As the gospel of Christ being lifted up on the cross is
proclaimed, those who hear the message are drawn to Christ without exception and without distinction. All those
who hear it are drawn by it. A draw by the gospel call is exerted even on those who find it repugnant or foolish
(e.g., 1Cor 1:22-24). They may pull away from it, but, in doing so, they evidence that they have been pulled by it.
Just as God calls believers through the gospel of the kingdom to live for Christ (2Thess 2:14), so He calls
unbelievers through the gospel of grace to believe in Christ. Those who hear the gospel are called by it to believe,
even if they incline themselves to disbelieve it instead. The child who hears the dinner bell but refuses to respond
to it has been called by it nonetheless. Likewise, in the context of Jn 6:44, Jesus proceeds in the next verse to
associate the drawing with being taught God’s word (Jn 6:45). If you are taught it, an influence is exerted upon you
to believe it. A universal drawing occurs upon all those who are taught it. Not all those who read it or hear it in turn
believe it. The drawing of Jn 6:44 is associated with the written word of God in 6:45 and is explained in 6:65,
where Jesus said, “No one can come to Me, unless it has been granted him from the Father.” This Spirit-energized
drawing by the word gives the ability and opportunity to believe the word.
         This hearing or reading of the word precedes faith and regeneration. The fact that regeneration is the result
of hearing rather than the basis for it is specified by Jesus: “Truly, truly, I say to you, an hour is coming and now is,
when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God; and those who hear shall live” (Jn 5:25). Life (regeneration)
is conditioned on hearing the word. Note the order of events: the spiritually dead hear then live. The spiritually
dead can hear and come to life as a result. Peter also states, “For you have been born again not of seed which is
perishable but imperishable, that is, through the living and abiding word of God” (1Pet 1:23). The word produces
life. Yet the germination does not occur until hearing the word is enjoined with faith in the word.
         Paul makes it clear in his sequential chain of events that hearing must precede faith (Rom 10:14). The lost
need only believe it, and the very preaching of the gospel provides everyone with opportunity and ability to believe
it. The prerequisite for believing the gospel is simply hearing it (Rom 10:17), not being elected to believe it. Since
the gospel “is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes” (Rom 1:18), the gospel is the channel
through which God draws everyone who hears it. The fact that this opportunity to believe the gospel when it is
initially heard is offered without distinction to both the Jews and Greeks does not prove that it is not offered to
everyone who hears without exception. Although the word is not the only means through which God draws the
lost, it is a necessary means. And if being spiritually dead does not prevent the lost from hearing the word, then it
does not prevent them from believing the word. If the spiritually dead can hear it, then they can believe it—at least
initially.
         “Then why does Jesus warn about the necessity of God’s drawing in Jn 6:44,65 if every time the lost hear
the gospel they are drawn by it?” will be the question naturally raised. Because the heart that rejects it may
eventually be hardened by it so that it is no longer drawn by it. The Father who gives the ability to believe the word
may allow Satan to snatch away that word (Mt 13:19) and, with it, to remove the ability to believe. Or God may
harden that heart Himself (Jn 12:39-40). The fact that some of those who withdrew from Jesus in the context of
Jn 6:65 were believers does not detract from this conclusion since believers also may harden their hearts
(Heb 3:8,15; 4:7). Unbelievers, as well as believers, may lose the ability to believe. Faith is not irresistible. Nor is
faith a gift given immediately and directly by the Spirit in the act of regeneration. Faith is not even really a mediate
gift given indirectly by the Spirit. Rather, the opportunity and ability to believe are made possible by the Spirit
through the mediation of the proclamation of the word which draws men and women to Christ. Although their
opportunity and ability might possibly be described as a gift in certain circumstances, receiving the gift of eternal
life is to be distinguished from being offered the gift of life. Faith itself is not a gift; faith is the means by which we
receive the gift.

                                       Warning of Judicial Hardening
       Jesus warns His listeners not to grumble in Jn 6:44-45, explaining that it would be impossible for them to
believe in Him unless the Father draws them by giving the ability and opportunity to believe in Him. This is not a
statement of emotional detachment, as if Jesus were expressing the Calvinistic outlook that they cannot believe
because they are not elected to believe and, therefore, they are not objects of His love or concern. On the contrary,

*
    More precisely, see GMR in Dad, can I be sure I am saved? For brief comments herein regarding GMR, see page 728.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 197
in this context, the Lord explicitly says that everyone who believes in Him may have eternal life (Jn 6:40). His
warnings do not represent disinterest but the painful concern that those who are grumbling and stumbling over His
words may reach the point where they are no longer drawn by the Father. The Father will not force them to come,
but neither can He be forced to keep making it possible for them to come.
        At the beginning of this discourse, Jesus reminded His audience that His Father had given them manna out
of heaven in the past. The Father gave it to them; He did not force it on them. His drawing and giving are not
forced. Neither Moses nor His Father went out and gathered the manna and force-fed the people of Israel. Jesus
implores the people to work for this food (Jn 6:27): to take advantage of the opportunity before it is too late and the
manna is gone. Judicial hardening is a real danger: “He has blinded their eyes, and He hardened their heart; lest
they see with their eyes, and perceive with their heart, and be converted, and I heal them” (Jn 12:40). Jesus says
that those who in their religious arrogance profess to see when they cannot see “may become blind” (Jn 9:39), that
is, they may become incapable of seeing. Obviously, if the unregenerate are in danger of becoming blind, then they
are not born blind in the sense of being incapable of seeing the light when God shines it in their face. Lack of
regeneration does not, in and of itself, make man incapable of seeing or believing. The lack of responding to the
opportunities presented may eventually result in the lack of ability to respond to any such further opportunities.
        Those who have a desire/willingness to be saved through faith in Christ are capable of being saved through
this means. By all means, let them show willingness to be saved by examining the evidence now. Let them not
delay. This concern is expressed in Jesus’ exhortation. In the closing words of John’s writings, he again reminds us
that whosoever wishes may come: “Let the one who is thirsty come; let the one who wishes take the water of life
without cost.” (Rev 22:17). Thirst precedes coming. The prevenient desire to drink comes before the coming to
drink. The wish to drink is experienced before appropriation of the life-giving fluid. Being spiritually dead does not
prevent them from experiencing spiritual thirst. Similarly, Jesus prays “that the world may believe” (Jn 17:21).
Obviously, as Godet remarks, “It cannot therefore designate a forced conviction…Jesus does not mean to say that
the whole world will believe.”317 What Jesus requests for the world is ability not irresistibility. Earlier in GJ, Jesus
likewise had prayed in order that the Jews may believe (Jn 11:42). Many did, but some did not (Jn 11:45-46). But
Jesus’ prayer (and actions) gave them ability to believe. He made it possible for them to believe. They may if they
would. The lost may believe, but this does not necessarily mean that they will believe.
        Jesus expresses invitations and prayers for all who need to come, to come (Mt 11:28). Such exhortations,
therefore, depict a universal drawing. In fact, Cornelius (Acts 10:1-31) and Lydia (Acts 16:14) responded
positively to this drawing before their regeneration. Their positive response led to their eventual conversion. Even
if Paul’s conversion were to indicate irresistible grace, then Lydia’s conversion, in stark contrast, demonstrates
wooing grace. Through the grace of God, the lost are able to seek, see, and believe. But if they put off believing,
they eventually may find themselves incapable of believing. Failing to respond to the desire and willingness to
believe may harden one’s heart over a period of time, rendering it harder and harder to believe as the desire and
willingness fades and eventually disappears never to be seen again, making it impossible to believe.

                                    Breakdown of a Calvinistic Stronghold
       Perhaps the strongest case for the Calvinistic limitation of the drawing to the elect is to be found in Jn 6:44-
45. Despite Calvinistic claims, the first verse is not really that difficult: “No one can come to Me, unless the Father
who sent Me draws him” (Jn 6:44). God draws everyone through the gospel, but not everyone responds to the
gospel. No one can come to God apart from His taking the initiative in drawing (in the form of prevenient grace).
       Yet when this verse is joined to the second verse, it does appear to limit this drawing to a select group of
people, especially if the OT background is brought into play. “It is written in the prophets, [a] ‘And they shall all
[pantes] be taught of God.’ [b] Everyone [pas] who has heard and learned from the Father, [c] comes to Me”
(Jn 6:45). (Pantes is the plural form of pas.) Jesus presumably alludes to Is 54:13, and perhaps Jer 31:34, as part of
the prophetic background.
       Part of the difficulty in understanding exactly what Jesus means by this citation is that the reference in
Is 54:13 is millennial: “And all your sons will be taught of the Lord; and the well-being of your sons will be great.”
To further compound the problem, the passage in Jer 31:34 is apparently internal and regenerational: “And they
shall not teach again, each man his neighbor and each man his brother, saying, ‘Know the Lord,’ for they shall all
know Me, from the least of them to the greatest of them, declares the lord, for I will forgive their iniquity, and their
sin I will remember no more” (see also Jer 31:33). These texts would appear to be limited to regenerate Jews in the
millennial kingdom. Even so, at the same time they also have application to believers of the present dispensation
(Heb 8:6-13; 10:14-18).
       In fairness to Calvinists, if these words in John are read in isolation from the broader context, then a case
could be made from a simplistic, covenantal reading of the OT background so that when Jesus says, “All will be
Page 198                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
taught” (Jn 6:45a), He is using a relative all that is restricted to those who experience regeneration. If this drawing
is then equated with hearing and learning from the Father in 6:45b, it logically may be deduced that the drawing is
regeneration, which precedes coming to Jesus (Jn 6:45c). Thus, Calvinists propose that regeneration (6:45a) is the
drawing (6:45b) that results in believing (6:45c).
       For example, Boice, a Calvinist, concludes, “The verse applies to God’s children only, not to all men, and it
implies that one must first be a child of God through new birth before one can really understand about Christ and
come to him.”318 In other words, you have to become a child of God through regeneration before you can come to
Christ in faith. Irresistible regeneration precedes and irresistibly produces faith. This faith is saving faith, not
because it is required for regeneration, but because only the saved can have such faith. Or some Calvinists, such as
White, may prefer to say that faith is required for salvation but not for regeneration. Regardless, from the
Calvinistic perspective, saving faith is not required for regeneration; rather, regeneration is required for saving
faith. Your faith is non-saving if it is not preceded by regeneration. That a popular Calvinist preacher like Boice
would take such a view is not surprising. But that a dispensationalist like Chafer would take the same position and
argue that the verse describes Sovereign irresistible election and predestination makes one wonder if he is being
consistent with his eschatology.319 In any case, a dispensationalist need not espouse such Calvinistic soteriology.

Universal/Relative
        The most common way of avoiding the above Calvinistic conclusion is to take the all (pantes) in Jn 6:45a as
universal but the everyone (pas) in 6:45b as restrictive. The thought in this case would be that all are drawn
through Scripture to the Messiah, but only those who respond positively to this drawing will come to faith in the
Messiah.320 Godet finds this a convenient way to circumvent the Calvinistic view but rejects this solution since the
prophecy in Is 54:13 “designates only the members of the Messianic community” (emphasis his).321 Like Boice,
Godet would thus find both all and everyone (two different forms of pas) to be restricted to this group, designated
in Is 54:13 as thy children (KJV). Unlike Boice, Godet does not find the Calvinistic interpretation necessary, seeing
membership in this community to be descriptive of believers. All these future believers will be taught by the Father
and thus infallibly (rather than irresistibly) come to faith in Jesus. Those who do not believe are culpable for their
inability to believe for the simple reason that this teaching was not effective in them because it was rejected by
them.
        Godet’s view has much to commend it, but one need not be quick to dispense with the more common
counterargument to the Calvinistic interpretation mentioned above. Jesus does not include the OT limitation of thy
children in the quotation. Further, His plural reference to prophets is probably not intended to be limited to any one
passage. Peter seems to think in very comprehensive terms: “Of Him all the prophets bear witness that through
His name everyone who believes in Him receives forgiveness of sins” (Acts 10:43). Seven other such references to
all the prophets occur in the gospels and Acts. Additionally, simple plural references to the prophets are numerous.
For example, “These are My words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that all things which are
written about Me in the Law of Moses and the Prophets and the Psalms must be fulfilled” (Lk 24:44). It is not at
all certain that Jesus intended to extract a limitation from any specific OT passage in referencing the citation in the
manner in which He did. In fact, John concludes the preceding chapter with these words: “For if you believed
Moses, you would believe Me; for he wrote of Me. But if you do not believe his writings, how will you believe My
words?” (John 5:46-47) Jesus simply is saying that those who believe the OT will believe in Him. The OT points
us to Christ, and those who yield to its drawing will be drawn infallibly to Christ.*
        Since Is 54:13 and Jer 31:34 are the background passages generally suggested and since they are futuristic in
their intended dispensational fulfillment (even if Jesus has anything beyond the universal appeal expressed in these
passages in mind), it would still seem that an inaugurated realization is the most that one can expect in Jn 6:45. In
the time period in which these verses will find complete fulfillment, a universal realization for the people of Israel
is anticipated. Therefore, the foretaste in Jn 6:45 may leave out any restrictive notion because Jesus is alluding to
the universal reception that the Scripture will have among all Jews who enter the kingdom at the inception of the
millennium. This forms the backdrop for the invitation that He is extending to the entire Jewish nation in the
present discourse. The Scripture, which is universal in its future appeal and reception by the Jewish people, was
only presently being effectively received by those who were willing to hear it and learn from it. Jesus affirms the
efficiency of the Scripture to persuasively draw all those who are willing to respond to it, not the efficiency of
election to irresistibly draw those who are opposed to the Scripture. An universal all followed by a relative all in


*
    See “Temporal Inevitability” in Drawing and Appointment.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                  Page 199
Jn 6:45 is thus not so easily ruled out. In such a case, Jesus is saying that all are called, but only those who are
willing to listen will come to believe.

Relative/Relative
         On the other hand, Godet’s suggestion certainly has merit. A relative all followed by a relative all is
possible and need not be taken in a Calvinistic sense of limiting those who may believe to the Calvinistic elect,
especially considering the fact that John repeatedly uses pas to tell us that whosoever will may come to faith
(Jn 3:15-16; 5:23; 6:40; 11:26; 12:32,46). The most popular non-Calvinistic counter citation in this regard is
Jn 12:32 since all (pas) and draw (helko) are enjoined again in this single verse: “And I, if I am lifted up from the
earth, will draw all men to Myself.” The gospel call draws all. Calvinists may respond by either claiming that the
all is limited to the elect (without any substantial contextual justification for this limitation in 12:32) or by claiming
that the draw in this verse is general, whereas the one in Jn 6:44-45 is effective. In other words, Calvinists will
either restrict the all or the draw. The non-Calvinist, on the other hand, may take the all as universal or relative in
6:45a. If Godet is correct, then it refers to all believers.

Universal Draw through the Gospel Call
         Calvinistic restrictions on all in the present passage are by no means certain. Indeed, in this very context,
Jesus says, “For this is the will of My Father, that everyone [pas] who beholds the Son and believes in Him, may
have eternal life; and I Myself will raise him up on the last day” (Jn 6:40). Simply put, the will of the Father is that
everyone may believe in Jesus and have eternal life as a result. Everyone is best taken to mean everyone. Everyone
may respond to God’s drawing through the Scripture, and everyone who responds in faith will do so because they
have responded to such drawing. The passage is not affirming the irresistibility of the drawing but the universality
of the means (i.e., the Scripture) and the necessity of the agent who does the drawing (i.e., the Father).*
        All believers (i.e., all who believe the gospel) come to faith because they have been drawn to do so by the
gospel. Jesus’ emphasis in Jn 6:45 is on teaching, hearing, and learning as the prerequisites for faith. This verse
does not make election the precondition for faith. Openness to teaching, hearing, and learning from the Scripture
are the requirements for coming to Jesus (i.e., for believing in Him). Just as all future Jews who come to believe in
Jesus will do so because of the Scripture, so Jesus informs those listening to Him that only those Jews who are
allowing the Scripture to fulfill its intended effect will be among the elect. Those who believe in Him do so
because they are responding to the drawing they encounter in the gospel call. Those who do not believe do not do
so because they disobey the gospel call: “However, they did not all obey the gospel, for Isaiah says, ‘Lord, who has
believed our report?’ So then faith comes from hearing, and hearing by the word of Christ” (Rom 10:16-17; TM).
        Like John, Paul teaches that the gospel call draws all without exception, but it may be resisted and result in
judicial hardening (Jn 12:40; Rom 11:7,25). There would be no need for temporal, judicial hardening if total
depravity meant that one is incapable of responding to the gospel call. The gospel call enables all to believe (at
least initially). This is why Satan must take away the words of the gospel that are shown in the hearts of those who
hear it if he hopes to prevent regeneration (Lk 8:12). The gospel has the power to germinate in any heart. The word
of God is powerful and will not return to Him void, that is, without giving those who hear it the opportunity to
respond to it and be saved by it.
        The question is not one of election but of reception. What reception does the Scripture find in your heart?
Are you allowing it to draw you to faith alone in Christ alone, or are you drawing some other conclusion? If you
come to some other conclusion, then you have resisted the drawing of the Father through the Scripture. Rejection
proves that you have rejected the drawing power of the Father expressed through Scripture. This is the drawing
power to which all Jewish believers who enter the kingdom must submit and eventually will submit, as the
prophets have foretold. If there is any reprobation in this passage, then it is self-imposed. God rejects us because
we first reject Him.

                                                     Eph 2:8
      Unfortunately, even some FG writers, such as Dillow, hold to the faith-gift myth, although he at least
embeds it within illumination rather than regeneration.322 Vance is on far firmer ground in completely rejecting this
Reformed fallacy of faith-gift equivalency.323 The primary passage used to support this Calvinistic perception is
Eph 2:8, “For by grace you have been saved through faith; and that not of yourselves, it is the gift of God.” The
whole argument boils down to answering two questions, the first of which is: “To what does the word that (touto)
*
    For a more detailed explanation, see “The Necessity of Drawing (Jn 6:37,44,65)” in Drawing and Appointment.
Page 200                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
refer—to faith, to grace, to the verbal form of salvation (i.e., saved), to the entire concept of salvation by grace, or
to the entire conceptualization of salvation by grace through faith?”
        Vance correctly points out the well-known grammatical improbability of faith being the antecedent and why
the Greek grammars are opposed to such a misunderstanding of the text. The word that (touto) is neuter and
therefore would not modify the words faith or grace (which are feminine). Had Paul meant to refer to either of
these words, he would have used the feminine adjectival form. Even Calvin acknowledged that faith is not the
antecedent, and a number of non-Calvinists have concluded that Calvin did not regard faith as a gift in this verse at
all. White contests their understanding, but his argument is indecisive. It appears that when Calvin was faced with
actually having to exegete the text, he blinked. When having to look the text straight in the eye, he made some
statements that called his theology into question. And this is not the only occasion. I reject the notion that faith is a
gift and believe Calvin did as well, at least in this verse.*
        Wallace notes that this construction most commonly refers to conceptual antecedents in the NT, so this is a
definite possibility.† Even so, the Calvinistic retreat to a conceptual antecedent certainly puts the faith-as-a-gift
view on very questionable ground. Alternately, Wallace also suggests an adverbial usage as a strong likelihood in
this passage.324 If this is the case, then the emphatic focus is on the verb saved. Accordingly, a suitable expanded
translation of the emphatic adverbial usage would be: “For by grace you have been saved through faith; and being
saved especially in this manner is not of yourselves, it is the gift of God.” Either a conceptual or an adverbial
usage is permissible grammatically; either is acceptable theologically. But answering the next question gives
advantage to the adverbial usage.
         The second related question is: “To what does the word gift refer?” The word gift is again neuter (doron).
Again, had Paul meant grace or faith then he easily could have used the feminine nominal form of gift (dorea), just
as he did in Rom 15:15. Faith is, time and time again, presented in Scripture as the means by which the gift of
salvation is received and is, therefore, distinguished from the gift itself. Saving faith is never the gift. Likewise,
grace is the basis by which the gift is offered and is thus not part of the gift. Denying that saving faith is a gift is the
view maintained by FG advocates such as Bing, Hodges, Nebeker, and Sapaugh and is more consistent with
GRAPE than is Dillow’s position.
        Zeller’s identification of salvation as the gift and his rejection of faith as the gift (and syntactical attraction)
are thus appreciated. Even though he is not a FG advocate, his assessment that faith is not the gift is in harmony
with standard FG theology.325 The gift is salvation. But strangely, having denied that faith is the gift, Zeller still
affirms the Calvinistic notion of perseverance in faith (and faithfulness). He is, therefore, susceptible to being
charged with holding a Calvinistic Lordship Salvation view of perseverance on his own website.326 Yet how can
Zeller be so sure that God will produce faith in him subsequently and continually when he has denied the
Calvinistic position that God produces faith in him initially? It would appear that in rejecting the TULI, he should
reject the “P” as well, which normally completes this Calvinistic acronym. The same comment is applicable to
Geisler and Gordon Olson. While some woodsmen may like to keep a rattlesnake’s rattle, there seems little point in
keeping the tail of this theological animal once you have acknowledged that the body keeping it alive is dead.
        Since the nominal neuter form of gift (doron) refers to salvation, it is highly probable that the antecedent for
the adjectival neuter form of that (touto) is likewise used adverbially to refer to saved. Paul is not saying that faith
is part of the gift, much less that faith is the gift. The gift adverbially points to the verb saved. God graciously
offers us salvation, and we receive it through faith. No condition on our part compelled God to offer us salvation.
The offer is an expression of His love and grace, prompted by His goodness, not ours, and prompted by His
benevolence, not our faith or faithfulness. Yet there is a condition for our receiving it—faith. Grace is God’s part;
faith is ours. Through means of our freed response, we receive the gift of salvation by faith. This does not mean
that our appropriation is active or meritorious.
        Faith is the passive persuasion that results from a reflexive volitional action that we exercise on ourselves. It
is contrasted with meritorious works. Our volition is the normative means that we, as free agents, use to come to
the passive persuasion that we are saved as a result of having come to this persuasion. The passive result must be
distinguished from the volitional means of arriving at that result.‡
        For example, to put this in everyday language, listening to the gospel is the means of coming to faith, but
faith itself is not listening to the gospel. If we buy a gospel tape to hear the gospel, that purchase price is not part of
our faith. When we come to believe the gospel in this manner, neither our money we spent nor the tape we bought
is a part of our faith. We were not saved by faith and by buying a tape; we were saved by faith alone. The means
*
  See “Calvin’s Gift in Eph 2:8” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.
†
  A neuter demonstrative adjective (such as that) can modify a phrase.
‡
  See “The Elementary Faith of Demons” in Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 201
                                                              *
employed in coming to faith are not part of saving faith. The fact that we must receive the gift by faith alone
means that any prerequisite steps in coming to faith are not credited to us as part of what is necessary to receive the
gift. The single requirement for receiving the gift is faith. Thus, the giver gets credit for giving the gift; the receiver
gets no meritorious credit for receiving it because whatever means were used in coming to faith are not credited to
the recipient as part of his or her faith. Saving faith is the nonmeritorious, passive, free response to the gospel.
After all, the “P” in GRAPE stands for passive persuasion.

                                                 Forced Grace
      Calvinism, on the other hand, denies that faith is a freewill response. The Canons of Dort are the Holy Grail
from which many in the Reformed camp drink their theology. Article 14 of this document reads as follows:

               Faith is therefore to be considered as the gift of God, not on account of its being offered by
          God to man, to be accepted or rejected at his pleasure, but because it is in reality conferred upon
          him, breathed and infused into him; nor even because God bestows the power or ability to
          believe, and then expects that man should by the exercise of his own free will consent to the
          terms of salvation and actually believe in Christ, but because He who works in man both to will and
          to work, and indeed all things in all, produces both the will to believe and the act of believing also.

        The typical affirmations of RT are seen within this statement: (1) faith is a gift, (2) faith is infused, (3) faith
is not the God-given ability to believe, (4) faith is not an expression of our free will, and (5) God produces faith in
us. In other words, God sovereignly regenerates us and in that act forces us to believe. This so-called gift of faith
really is forced upon us by God’s sovereign, irresistible will. Geisler rightly takes RT to task in Chosen But Free
for teaching forced grace rather than free grace. Lutzer, on the other hand, misleads the reader into thinking that he
believes the reader has free will. In response to the question, “Who made the choice that you should be reborn
spiritually?” he answers, “It was your decision, for no one was ever born again against his will. Anyone who
desires to be born again can be.”327 But then he clarifies that he does not actually believe in free will: “What I once
thought was the result of my will turns out to be the result of God’s will.”328 Then he waffles in his articulation:

          The reason we choose Christ is that God worked in our hearts to bring us to that point of trust.
          The decision that I would be born physically was made entirely without me; the decision that I would
          be reborn in God’s kingdom was made with my consent to be sure, although my exercise of faith was
          God-given.329

        With a disclaimer, he shows that in affirming our so-called consent he does not mean that we really have
