any choice about it: “Those who have the desire to receive the gift of God’s grace do so because that desire has
been implanted there by God. But by nature, we do not seek God. God seeks us.”330 In other words, God
irresistibly works in our hearts to cause us to believe by implanting an irresistible desire within us (without our
consent) to cause us to believe, and then we consent once God has given us this spiritual lobotomy to make us
consent. Or to use Lutzer’s imagery, in irresistibly regenerating us, God gives us a spiritual implant to make us
believe. Once God has made us willing to believe, we are willing to believe. Despite our initial unwillingness to
believe, God irresistibly makes us willing, and then we are willing.
        This appears to be nothing more than theological tautology to camouflage the fact that Calvinists believe in
forced grace rather than free grace. If God were to make us willing before regeneration, then regeneration is not
necessary to make us willing, and the Calvinistic argument for the necessity of irresistible grace would fall to the
wayside. On the other hand, if God regenerates us despite the fact that we are unwilling to be regenerated, then the
result of that regeneration is forced consent. We become nothing but automatons to carry out the will of our new
nature which God gave us against our will in order to make us willing.
         Lutzer then launches into a rebuttal of “decisional regeneration.”331 However, FG theology would agree
wholeheartedly with his rejection of decisional regeneration and his affirmation of persuasional regeneration
instead.332 Regeneration is the result of being persuaded of the truth of the gospel. The FG camp might even agree
that God uses irresistible persuasion on occasion, but FG cannot agree to irresistible grace that bypasses persuasion
as a prerequisite to regeneration. Such grace would not be free grace; it would be forced grace. Thus, a consistent
GRAPE position would reject the notion of irresistible grace that bypasses our response. Faith is not the direct

*
    See Harmonization, 206.
Page 202                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
result of God’s will. Faith does not bypass our agreement to the propositions of the gospel as a necessary condition
for regeneration.
        The Canons of Dort give us no free will in the matter. God opens our mouth and forces His grace down our
throats to make us willing to receive His grace. In RT we have no more decision regarding being reborn spiritually
than we do about being born physically. Lutzer hides his meaning with his roundabout disclaimer as to the logical
sequence of what he is teaching. Lutzer’s sequence really is: In rebirth God makes us willing to consent to new-
birth. The willingness to become regenerate comes after we are regenerate, not before. Free will to do otherwise
does not exist. RT necessitates that saving faith be imparted rather than imputed. Like the five hundred pound
gorilla who says, “If I want your opinion, I’ll wring it out of you,” the Calvinistic God says, “If I want you to have
faith, I’ll infuse it into you.” Or worse yet, God impregnates unbelievers with His seed to make them willing to
love and trust Him.* Although some Calvinists reject the imagery, their theology does seem to express a divine
rape in which Jesus says of the woman He wants to become His Bride, “If I rape her, she will love Me.”333
        From the Calvinistic perception, saving faith is not imputed because it supposedly is infused; nor is
soteriological righteousness imputed because it is reputedly imparted. Those in the Reformed camp are correct to
affirm imputational righteousness and on that basis to reject imparted righteousness as the basis for soteriological
justification. As Lutzer fittingly states: “There is also a righteousness from God, which is given as a gift to sinners.
For us, this is an alien righteousness because it is not part of our nature, nor is it fused into us” (emphasis his).334
This is an accurate summation by Lutzer in which he properly notes that this righteousness is not “fused into us.”
Not surprisingly, the Westminster Confession states it similarly:

          Those whom God effectually calleth He also freely justifieth; not by infusing righteousness into
          them, but by pardoning their sins, and by accounting and accepting their persons as righteous: not for
          anything wrought in them, or done by them, but for Christ’s sake alone: nor by imputing faith itself,
          the act of believing, or any other evangelical obedience, to them as their righteousness; but by
          imputing the obedience and satisfaction of Christ unto them, they receiving and resting on Him
          and His righteousness, by faith: which faith they have not of themselves; it is the gift of God. (WCF
          11:1)

        Calvinists are correct to reject imparted/infused righteousness in contexts describing soteriological
justification. This is biblical.
          3
            For what does the Scripture say? “And Abraham believed God, and it was imputed to him as
          righteousness.” 4 Now to the one who works, his reward is not imputed as grace, but as what is due.
          5
            But to the one who does not work, but believes in Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is
          imputed as righteousness, 6 just as David also speaks of the blessing upon the man to whom God
          imputes righteousness apart from works: 7 “Blessed are those whose lawless deeds have been
          forgiven, and whose sins have been covered. 8 “Blessed is the man whose sin the Lord will not
          impute.” 9 Is this blessing then upon the circumcised, or upon the uncircumcised also? For we say,
          “Faith was imputed to Abraham as righteousness.” 10 Then how was it imputed? While he was
          circumcised, or while he was uncircumcised? Not while he was circumcised, but while he was
          uncircumcised. (Rom 4:3-10; TM).

The Reformed logic, at this point, is straightforward and scriptural:

               1. What is soteriologically imputed is not imparted.
               2. Soteric righteousness is soteriologically imputed.
               3. Therefore, righteousness is not soteriologically imparted.

Yet Paul teaches, in the above text, that both faith and righteousness are imputed. The same verb for impute
(logizomai) is used throughout the passage, and the same form of the verb is used in both verses five and six. In
verse five, faith is imputed; in the next verse, righteousness is imputed. Within the same soteriological context,
Paul affirms that both faith and righteousness are imputed. The conclusion should be obvious:


*
    See Ordo Salutis.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 203
           1. What is soteriologically imputed is not imparted.
           2. Soteric faith is soteriologically imputed.
           3. Therefore, faith is not soteriologically imparted.

        Saving faith is imputed rather than imparted. Our faith in the Promised Redeemer is imputed as
righteousness rather than imparted to us in regeneration. Saving faith is neither infused in us nor imparted to us.
The passage says, “Abraham believed” (Rom 4:3). He did the believing. God did not do it for him. It was “his
faith,” not God’s faith, which was “imputed as righteousness” (v. 5). Faith is our response to God, not His gift to
us. Since God imputes our faith to us as righteousness rather than imparts faith to us in regeneration, faith is not the
imperishable result of regeneration. Even the evasive maneuver by some Calvinists to break regeneration up into
two distinct phases fails to evade the conclusion from this passage: Since soteric faith is imputed, it is not imparted.
Consequently, God’s grace is not irresistible and our faith is not indestructible. Both the Calvinistic doctrines of
irresistible grace and the perseverance of the saints in faith stumble over this simple observation.
        Dort is confused in claiming that faith is infused. The text says that both faith and righteousness are imputed
rather than imparted. Despite the multiple repetitions by Paul that faith is imputed, Westminster says that only
righteousness is imputed, not faith. Yet four times in this context Paul confirms that faith is imputed and only once
that righteousness is imputed. However, Calvinists say that righteousness is imputed and faith is not. Even so, the
Westminster clarification that faith itself is not imputed is technically permissible as long as it is not used to
circumvent the above conclusion that Dort is confused in regarding faith as infused.335

                                                      2Pet 1:1

Lots
        Another passage used to support the Calvinistic opinion that faith is a gift is the Petrine passage: “Simon
Peter, a bond-servant and apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who have received/obtained a faith of the same kind as
ours, by the righteousness of our God and Savior, Jesus Christ” (2Pet 1:1). According to White, “the text describes
the faith these Christians have as something they ‘received’ or ‘were given.’ The Greek term is defined by one
lexical source as ‘what comes to one, always apart from one’s own efforts.’”336 I have chosen to put the emphasis
on White’s word one because this is a rather unique lexicographical entry by FB, which then proceeds to give the
typical lexical entries: “(1) Cast lots (JN 19.24); (2) attain by lot, be appointed by lot, be chosen by lot (LU 1.9);
(3) of what comes by divine will, attain, receive, obtain (2P 1.1).” These are the typical categories one would find
in BAGD/BDAG. But the blurb found in FB to introduce these definitions is missing in other lexicons:
BAGD/BDAG, L-N, LS, TY, UBS, and VGNT. One is left to suspect that perhaps FB has added a Calvinistic
interpretation for its introduction, just as Packer adds a Calvinistic conclusion: “In 2 Pet. 1:1 Peter addresses those
who have obtained faith “through God’s grace-gift, not by personal merit.”337 Evidently we are expected to accept
Packer’s interpretation in good faith even though the verse does not call faith a gift and does say that it is by grace.
        The Calvinistic argument one typically encounters is that since this soteriological faith is received passively,
God must, therefore, give it to us as a gift. Further, since the verb for obtain (lagchano) is an unusual one, meaning
to obtain by lot, it supposedly indicates God’s sovereign choice. God randomly (or mysteriously, to speak
Calvinistically) chose to whom He would give this gift. To be sure, this verb is used of drawing lots (Lk 1:9;
Jn 19:24). Accordingly, in this perspective, if you are one of the lucky ones, then congratulations, you win the
divine lottery—saving faith. Too bad for the losers; they never really had a chance other than blind chance—
certainly no free will. So to obtain by lot is like winning the lottery. If you have a winning number, you win. The
way some commentators describe this passage, you would think it is like drawing names out of a hat in which your
salvation resembles a divine crapshoot. God rolled the dice. Your number came up, and bingo you are a winner.
God decided to give you the gift of faith so that you would not die and go to hell. The role of the dice determines
whether or not you die.
        Roy Aldrich rejects the scholastic facade in which this divine fatalism is wrapped by responding: “Here
Peter states that believers have “obtained” their faith, but he does not say how it was obtained. To use such a verse
to affirm that saving faith is a special gift of God is only to show how desperate the advocates of this theory are for
Scriptural proof.”338 Meisinger gives a little more substance to his criticism of this Calvinism:

       The active voice of “obtain” shows that they were not passive in obtaining faith, as many Calvinists
       maintain, but that they took initiative to obtain faith. Thus, Peter does not here say that God gave to
       them a subjective ability to believe. The benefit they took initiative to obtain was “faith,” in the sense
       [of] the body of sound doctrine taught and written by the apostles. Peter’s readers obtained a great
Page 204                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
       benefit: divine revelation. So it is for you and me. The “faith” or body of sound doctrine we have
       obtained in Scripture is as precious for us as it was for the Apostles….
       … The point is that since Christ is God, He is able to provide the precious faith, or Scripture, for all
       our needs and to give us a full experience of life.339

In a note to this quote, Meisinger adds:

       Many commentators take “faith” to denote a faith God sovereignly gives a sinner thus enabling him
       to believe…Several things work against that interpretation and support taking “faith” to be the Word
       of God: (1) “Obtain” is an active voice, not passive. (2) The emphasis of immediate context on
       “knowledge” (1:2,3), and “promises” (1:4) as the means to living out our life and godliness as God
       intends. Peter’s thrust is on the object-content of our faith, not faith itself. (3) Chapter 3:2 speaks of
       “words” and “commandment” which Peter’s readers share with the apostles (and which have equal
       value for them as for the apostles).

       A number of commentators would concur with Meisinger in taking faith in this passage to refer to an
objective body of truth rather than to a personal subjective ability to trust God. Nevertheless, counterarguments to
this objective interpretation include the following. (1) Obtain is always used in the active voice in the NT, so the
use of the active voice in this passage is not surprising. (2) Certainly, faith can be used to refer to objective truth (as
in Jude 1:3), but an anarthrous usage, such as we have in 2Pet 1:1, would be a less likely reference to the faith.
(3) The only other occurrence of faith in this epistle is found just a few verses later and is subjective (2Pet 1:5).

Subjective Faith
        For the sake of argument, let me concede that Peter is indeed referring to subjective faith, as many
Calvinists are inclined to believe. After all, everywhere else Peter talks about faith in either of his epistles, he is
referring to personal faith rather than objective faith. Further, let us acknowledge that a divine operation occurs
behind their personal experience of faith. Indeed, two verses later Peter says, “His divine power has granted to us
everything pertaining to life and godliness” (2Pet 1:3). Certainly, faith is part of this everything that is granted and
is included in his list of qualities a believer must develop (v. 5) in order to gain an abundant entrance into the
kingdom (1:8-9). Proceeding then from this premise, note that the objective foundation of faith, found in
knowledge and promises (vv. 2-4), makes a victorious faith possible but not automatic. Although everything we
need is divinely given (doreo) in verses 3 and 4, some of these items must be actively applied through diligent
human effort: “Now for this very reason also, applying all diligence, to your faith supply moral virtue” (v. 5; TM).*
Peter is calling for a morally virtuous faith that is obtained by diligent effort. This is not a faith that passively sits
on the shelf.
        God empowers believers (v. 3) so that they can obtain this type of faith by the righteousness which He
makes possible (v. 1). The type of righteousness referred to in this verse is judicial righteousness. Even Calvinists
admit that faith comes before imputed righteousness, so a faith that comes as a result of righteousness, as it is here,
is not to be confused in this context with soteriological faith. (Obviously, soteric faith would come before imputed
righteousness.) The faith mentioned in this verse is available to those who already have been justified by faith. Nor
can the righteousness in this verse be infused righteousness (as if in the form of regeneration) to make faith
possible since in this passage faith is associated with progressive sanctification.
        Since the means by which we obtain this faith is “by (en) the righteousness” which God makes possible to
us, this faith must be that which comes after initial justification and commences sanctification. This faith is
obtained through practical sanctification, and thus as a result of practical righteousness. This faith does not happen
automatically but requires our synergistic participation in casting our lot with the Lord. God imparts His practical
righteousness to believers who are willing to receive it experientially so that they may achieve a misthologically
refined faith. This faith is not given as a gift, but comes as a result of casting the dice, and it takes practical
righteousness to cast those dice. Those previously made soteriologically righteous by faith are here living by a faith
made possible by that righteousness as it progresses into sanctification.

*
  The superior rendition is to translate epichoregeo (supply, add) 2Pet 1:5 in terms of addition. Peter is enjoining believers to add
works to their faith. The end result envisioned in this context is derived by faith plus works. See discussion and illustrations in
Breaking the Rocking Horse or more fully in Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity. The overall thesis being developed herein,
however, is not dependent on this rendition.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 205
Virtuous Faith
         The active understanding of faith in this passage correlates well with the active tense of verse 1. This faith is
not passively received; it is actively obtained. Therefore, deference must be given to those lexicons and translations
that denote the active tense of the verb by rendering it as obtained. The readers are the active agents in obtaining
this faith. This supposedly Calvinistic proof text refutes the Calvinistic notion that faith is passively received as a
gift. It may take a lot of work to come to faith, and then even more work to maintain and develop that faith. If there
are any dice to be rolled, then it is up to the believers to roll them, not God. Even so, doing so is not a game of
chance but a decision to accept God’s will in developing a virtuous faith.
         The underlying reason for Peter’s choice of this verb is not that of chance but of reliance upon God. The
practice of casting lots occurs about twenty times in Scripture. Perhaps the most well-known example is that of
Jonah (1:7). Casting lots (kleros) was a common practice in relying upon God for divine guidance in that day and
time (before a completed canon). Peter himself had even participated in this practice on at least one occasion
(Acts 1:26). And he still thinks in these terms much later as he writes the epistles, speaking of those allotted
(kleros) to the charge of the elders (1Pet 5:3). As believers we have the responsibility to accept our lot in life by
diligently availing ourselves of the imparted righteousness that God makes available to us in developing a morally
virtuous faith.

Gift of Faith ≠ Act of Faith
        To be sure, Paul does state that God has allotted (merizo) different degrees and portions of faith to believers
(Rom 12:3,6). But he uses a different word for allotment, in which God is the active agent, in contrast to this
Petrine passage in which we are the active agents. Spiritual gifts are sovereignly given, not earned. Yet even the
fact that God may give the gift of faith to certain believers does not prove that the exercise of this faith is
sovereignly given. Even this God-given capacity must be actively developed and applied by the believer. We are
responsible for developing and using our spiritual gifts. When God gives certain believers the gift of teaching, for
example, it is understood that God has given them ability to teach. Ryrie’s simple definition is right on target: “A
spiritual gift is a God-given ability for service.”340
        The act of teaching itself, though, is not a gift that is passively received. Teaching is an action that the
believer actively performs. God does not make the teacher teach or the believer believe. What God gives is the
ability. The exercise of the gift is not to be confused with the gift itself. The exercise of the gift is the believer’s
responsibility, not God’s liability. God has given us free will as to whether we will exercise our spiritual gifts.341
Even believers who are given the gift of faith do not necessarily exercise that gift. It is possible to have a spiritual
gift (such as the gift of faith) and fail to exercise that gift. Not all those who have the gift of faith necessarily will
respond in faith. Not every believer who has a greater capacity to trust God will exercise that ability. Some
believers who have the gift of faith may actually prefer on occasion to trust in themselves, or trust their
circumstances, or to worry. Elijah was a man of faith, but he hid in a cave out of fear for his life. Even if Phil 1:29
were talking about giving unbelievers the gift of faith at a soteriological level (which it is not),* it would not
thereby be concluded that God gives them the response of faith. God merely gives the ability and opportunity. A
gift must be appropriated to be experienced. Calvinists who appeal to the spiritual gift of faith to demonstrate that
faith may be given as a gift inadvertently shoot their own argument in the foot. Even when faith is given as a gift,
what is given is the ability (i.e., increased capacity) to believe rather than the response of belief.

Misthological Faith
        Appealing to the gift of faith, as described by Paul, will not help the Calvinistic argument in the present
Petrine passage anyway. If anything, it weakens it. But in even further contrast, Peter is not talking about degrees
of faith which sovereignly are given and passively received (in terms of capacities and abilities); he is discussing
the kind of faith—the quality of faith (isotimos)—that has equal misthological value and actively is attained. This
type of faith is one of the qualities Peter is describing that result in a reward (2Pet 1:8).342 For that reason, it is
called a precious faith (2Pet 1:1; NKJ). It is a misthologically valuable faith—a faith that is rewarded. One may
compare this equally valuable faith (isotimos) with the misthologically valuable faith (timios) or very valuable
faith (polutimos) in 1Pet 1:7.† This equally valuable misthological faith is achieved through divine enablement—
divine power (2Pet 1:3,5). God not only enables unbelievers to believe; He also enables believers to experience a
powerful faith through synergistic cooperation with His endeavors. Believers do so in order that they avail

*
    See Phil 1:28-29, 211.
†
    See illustration of “Refined Misthological Faith” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 206                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
themselves of God’s valuable (timios) promises: “And through this he has given us the hope of great rewards
highly to be valued” (2Pet 1:4; BBE).
        Peter also uses the association of divine power with faith in his first epistle. Through the use of an active
faith that draws on God’s power in the act of daily appropriation (1Pet 1:5), such faith demonstrates itself worthy
(1Pet 1:7) of the misthological salvation of the believer’s soul—if they have a faith of sufficient quality to merit
such salvation (1Pet 1:9).* A meritorious faith must be maintained consistently (1Pet 5:9). This is the type of faith
his readers had (as evidenced in Peter’s fist epistle), and this is the type of faith to which Peter refers in his second
epistle. A fiat act of faith, in which God takes a passive unbeliever and makes him or her a believer to save his or
her spirit from hell (as Calvinists suppose) is far removed from the type of faith that Peter presupposes that his
readers actively have attained in order to save their souls from the outer darkness. Peter is not talking about any
supposed gift of faith given either to unbelievers or believers. He is referring to a living faith that is available to all
believers and which these particular believers had attained. In short, in this passage faith is a personal faith that has
been achieved actively by drawing on God’s divine power in order to obtain an abundant kingdom entrance. Peter
affirms that this type of faith has the same precious misthological value for his readers as it does for him.

        Harmonization
        Of course, Calvinists will object by saying, “What is the difference between soteriological and misthological
faith?” After all, if both are synergistically derivable from cooperation with the Holy Spirit, why is soteriological
faith nonmeritorious?† The answer is not to be found in changing the nature of faith. In both cases, faith is passive
persuasion. Nevertheless, the works that may go into reaching this point of passive saving persuasion, through
availing oneself of God’s intermediate means and enabling Spirit, do not count before God as being part of the
reason He soteriologically grants the gift of eternal life. Such works may be a necessary means for some to come to
saving faith, but they are not part of that faith. The gift is given in response to the faith alone, not in response to the
works that went into coming to the point of faith.‡
        On the other hand, the works necessary for a believer to maintain, develop, and express his or her faith are
misthologically credited by God as part of his or her faith. For this reason, misthological faith accurately may be
called an active faith even though faith itself is passive persuasion. The faith associated with the believer’s activity
is misthologically credited as part of that activity from God’s perspective. And from the believer’s perspective, this
faith (i.e., passive persuasion) is the tool he or she actively uses in volitional reaction as he or she serves God.§

       Application
       By way of application concerning Heb 11:6, if a lost person seeks God, God will reward that lost person
with the opportunity to hear the gospel. However, receiving the gift of eternal life is not a reward since it is
conditioned on punctiliar, passive faith. While in some cases the opportunity to hear the gospel might be a reward,
the reception of eternal life while listening to the gospel is never a reward. The beggar who climbs the hill to reach
the road so that he might receive alms given to the poor has not merited the alms he receives from the rich passing
by any more than the beggar who already was sitting there. Both are poor beggars holding out their hands to
receive something that they have not obligated the passerby to give them. While it might be said that God
graciously has obligated Himself to reward those who soteriologically seek Him with the opportunity to hear the
gospel, it cannot be said that He misthologically has obligated Himself to give them eternal life as a result of
hearing and believing the gospel. This is an unmerited obligation (prompted by His benevolence, independent of
any human response)—to promise eternal life to those who simply believe in His Son for such life.

        Beggar Illustration
        To further illustrate the comments above concerning the beggar, suppose a rich king announced that he
would walk down a certain road on a certain day and give a gold coin to any beggar sitting there willing to receive
it.** Some beggars travel from a great distance to get there in time; some already are sitting along that road, just as

they had been doing every day their entire lives. When that particular day arrives, neither those beggars who
traveled a great distance nor those who already were sitting there by the road deserve the coin. They did nothing to
obligate the king to make an announcement of the free gift. Neither they nor the king consider it a reward. Work
may have been involved in their reaching that location, but it was not work done for the king in order to receive
the gift. It was something they did for themselves in coming to the place where they could receive the gift. They
did nothing for the king that merited this response from the king. The gift was conditioned simply on their being
there ready to receive it. They did not cut hay in the king’s fields or trees in the king’s forest to earn it. They did
nothing in service for the king to receive it. They simply sat there with their cupped hands as he walked by and
dropped the coins in their hands. We may have to do a lot of work to reach the point in our lives where we are
ready to receive eternal life as a free gift. Yet preconditions to our being able to meet the singular condition are not
considered part of the reason the gift is offered or part of the instrumental means by which the gift is received.
Meritorious preconditions, such as those found in Heb 11:6 (when made applicable as a means of coming to faith,
as in Lk 13:24), are to be distinguished from a nonmeritorious condition, which is faith itself.
       It is better for the lost to work diligently by studying the Scripture under the conviction that they do not
deserve eternal life (while trusting God to show them how to receive it undeservingly) than to pass down the road
of life in arrogant satisfaction, refusing to humble themselves like a beggar and receive it. Even so, it will not
accomplish anything to stand out in the fields cutting the king’s hay trying to earn his gift when he has demanded
that we sit like beggars along the road if we want to receive it as a free gift.343
                                   Illustration 78. Soteriological versus Misthological Faith




                                                                                             Works
                                    Faith




        In the figure above, saving faith is not meritorious. It is not a work. Soteriological justification is by faith
apart from works (Rom 3:28), just as it is by grace apart from works (Rom 11:6).* All works are meritorious.
Marrowists acknowledge Paul’s thoroughgoing distinction between a gift and a reward in GRAPE.† The Scripture
repeatedly says that rewards are based on works. Rewards are certainly not limited to works of the law; therefore, it
is futile to try to limit works to works of the law. To be sure, the word works is a polymorphous term capable of
many usages within its semantic range. But this polymorphous affirmation simply means that the word has a
semantic range with contextual limitations. However, in no context would works denote behavior that results in a
gift. Anything truly falling under the works umbrella denotes performance and is thus meritorious in nature. Since
all polymorphous usages of work fall within the realm of performance, and thus have meritorious associations,
saving faith cannot be a work. Soteriological faith cannot be a work in the meritorious sense; hence, it cannot be a
work in any true sense. Therefore, the category pictured by number one above is soteriological faith.
        On the other hand, misthological faith is rewardable and therefore a work in the meritorious sense of the
word. One certainly would anticipate that having one’s faith “proclaimed throughout the whole world” would have
misthological value as well (Rom 1:8; cp. 1Thess 1:8; 3:7). Likewise, it may be anticipated that the dying thief’s
profession of faith, which has been proclaimed throughout the world, will result in this saved thief having rewards
in heaven. Our faith may encourage other believers (Rom 1:12). Since encouraging one another is a rewardable
activity, the faith that serves as the means of that encouragement is rewardable. For faith to have misthological
value in 1Cor 13:2, it must be coupled with love. “Faith working through love” would be rewardable (Gal 5:6).344


*
  For a similar discussion concerning misthological grace, see Fallen From Grace but Not From Perfection.
†
  For a discussion of a similar diagram, see “Faith as an Overlap with Work” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith. For a more technical
interaction with a similar diagram with a suggestion for a children’s object lesson which makes it simple, see the author’s treatment in
Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity.
Page 208                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
        Faith works! Of course it does. Faith not only works; it has works (1Thess 1:3; 2Thess 1:11).345 The
Scripture uses both the verbal and nominal forms of work to affirm the nature of misthological faith. Faith also
serves (Phil 2:17). Misthological faith works and serves. Soteriological faith does not work or serve—it is
diametrically disassociated with works or with being a meritorious response in Scripture. Faith that works is
misthological, not soteriological. To confuse the two, as is commonly done in LS, is to fuse faith with works and to
make faith a work. It results in a false soteriology and misthology.
        There is no reason to assume that standing firm in faith or taking up the shield or breastplate of faith should
not also be regarded as rewardable behavior (1Cor 16:13; Eph 6:16; 1Thess 5:8). The same is true of living by faith
(Gal 2:20; Heb 10:38-39). Timothy is enjoined to take hold of eternal life misthologically by fighting the good
fight of faith (1Tim 6:122). Faith can be a weapon that we wield in winning the crown of life (2Tim 4:7-8). Indeed,
keeping the faith is one of the misthological requirements necessary in verse 7 to win this crown.
        Continuance in faith is rewardable with misthological blamelessness (Col 1:22-23). As such, continuance in
faith is not a soteriological issue and cannot result in soteriological loss of eternal life. The fifth and final point of
GRAPE, eternal security, is thus deductively established by this distinction. Perseverance in faith in the midst of
fiery trials results in being considered misthologically worthy of the kingdom (1Thess 1:4-5). This again indicates
that perseverance in faith is a misthological issue, not a soteriological one. Therefore, the destruction of a
believer’s faith would be a misthological shipwreck rather than a soteriological one (1Tim 1:19). Holding on to
your faith, in this verse, would entail the opposite positive misthological result. Women who continue in faith will
be saved misthologically (1Tim 2:15). The misthological destruction of faith does not destroy its soteriological
foundation (2Tim 2:18-19).
        Faith is the means through which we inherit the misthological promises (Heb 6:12). The entire eleventh
chapter of Hebrews is an ode to misthological faith. We are not only soteriologically saved through faith;
misthological salvation is through faith as well (Jam 2:14-26; 1Pet 1:5,9). In conclusion, misthological salvation,
rather than soteriological salvation, is at stake in regards to one’s continuation in faith. Since postconversion faith
is the means by which we earn rewards, it cannot be made the means by which we retain the gift of eternal life.
Perseverance in faith is a misthological matter and therefore cannot be regarded as a soteriological issue. Eternal
security cannot be conditioned on perseverance in faith.

       Relegation
       The fact that linear, post-regenerational faith is rewarded militates against the Reformed position—whether
Arminian or Calvinistic—that linear faith is a soteriological requirement to reach heaven. Linear faith is
meritorious, and, for that reason, the insistence on the soteriological necessity of linear faith necessarily teaches
salvation by works.
                                       Illustration 79. Linear Faith is Meritorious
           1. Entrance into heaven is not based on rewardable responses to God.
           2. Linear faith is rewardable.
           3. Therefore, entrance into heaven is not based on linear faith.

       The importance of this observation can hardly be overstated. Arminians and Calvinists agree that
perseverance in faith is necessary to reach heaven. However, this cannot be the case, not only because of the tense
and case arguments,* but also because of the meritorious nature of post-regenerational faith. Our retention of the
faith and progression in the faith after we become believers are given misthological status in the Scripture and,
therefore, cannot be soteriological conditions. Our perseverance in the faith, or lack thereof, is rewardable and thus
meritorious and consequently a work. Since our perseverance is a rewardable work, our soteriological salvation is
in no way conditioned upon our perseverance.346
       We will be judged as believers on the basis of our misthological faith at the Bema, even if we stop
believing, because we are classified as believers if we ever responded in soteriological faith to the gospel. What
determines which judgment we appear before—Judgment Seat of Christ or Great White Throne Judgment—is our
soteriological faith, not our misthological faith. We are urged to not throw away our confidence in Christ because it
has a great reward (Heb 10:35). This confidence (i.e., the faith we have in God after we become children of God) is


*
  See “Continue to Believe in Jn 3:36” and “Categorical Retention of Eternal Life” in the author’s Believe: An Aspectual and
Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 209
rewardable and therefore meritorious. Consequently, continuation in faith is a work in the meritorious sense of the
word and, consequently, cannot be a necessary component of our soteriological salvation.
       Continued faith in Christ for someone who already has come to Christ has misthological value and thus
must be relegated to the misthological sphere. To argue that cessation of faith would result in loss of soteriological
life would be to assign a soteriological value to continuous faith. Doing so is foreign to Scripture. In other words,
you cannot lose the free gift of eternal life if you stop believing. A free gift is not conditioned on misthological
responses, but rewards are. To claim that you can lose eternal life by ceasing to believe is to turn the faith
necessary for the possession of that life into a meritorious response, which the Scripture emphatically and
repeatedly denies. Salvation from eternal damnation is not by works! Since post-regenerational faith is a work,
post-regenerational faith has nothing to do with salvation from such soteriological damnation. You cannot lose the
free gift of eternal life by failing to continue in faith, since the Scripture gives misthological value to such faith.
The distinction between soteriological faith and misthological faith is a differentiation that attests to the reality of
eternal security.
       To repeat, those who require perseverance in faith to reach heaven are basing entrance into heaven on a
response to which Scripture assigns misthological value. Such teachers and preachers have transformed entrance
into heaven from something that is soteriologically free into something that is misthologically earned. If
perseverance were indeed necessary to enter heaven, those entering heaven could stand before God and biblically
claim that they deserve to enter heaven because they persevered in faith. Perish the thought!
       If we picture the hypothetical scene posed by evangelists, in which we appear before God and He asks us,
“Why should I let you into My heaven?” the RT response could be, “Because I persevered in faith in Christ for
eternal life.” The argument herein refutes such a response as being legitimate. God would respond to such an
answer by saying, “Entrance into My heaven is not earned by your perseverance in faith. I never knew you. You
did not have to persevere in faith to enter My heaven. Depart from Me into the fire prepared for the devil and his
angels—you who have trusted in your perseverance in faith for the gift of eternal life.”
       We cannot enter heaven with what the Scripture considers meritorious reactions to the free offer of
salvation. Therefore, GRAPE rejects the PEARS and TULIP acronyms as teaching a false gospel of salvation by
works, since both of these systems logically lead to the conclusion that saving faith is a work (by conditioning
entrance into heaven on perseverance in faith). No meritorious value, however, is assigned by Scripture to
punctiliar appropriation by passive faith. This faith is not a work. The sinner cannot stand before God and say, “I
deserve to get into heaven because I believed in Christ.” God never attributed any misthological value to such faith.
The sinner can only say, “Thank You for letting me into heaven because I believed in Christ for eternal life.”
       Christ, the great Savior, not the believer’s great faith, is the object of saving faith. Even a weak, punctiliar
faith will save as long as it was in Christ alone for eternal life. For this reason, believers cannot assign any degree
of merit to the faith by which they enter heaven, and the Scripture attributes no merit to such faith. Unbelievers
need not muster up enough faith (whether in quantity or duration) to make it into heaven. Quite the contrary, they
must come to the place where they cease trying to save themselves by making such misthological responses the
condition for their entrance into heaven.
       By consigning those who fail to persevere in faith to the outer darkness, perseverance is thus recognized in
GRAPE as being a misthological issue dealing with (“R”) rewards rather than dealing with a soteriological
outcome regarding a (“G”) gift. The outer darkness is God’s misthological response to His children who fail to
persevere. Those who make hell God’s soteriological response to those who fail to persevere have transformed a
misthological requirement into a soteriological one. They are trying to get into heaven on the basis of faith and
works—and it simply will not work.

       Fruition
       A question sometimes arises in this regard concerning the contrast between the works of the flesh (Gal 5:19-
21) and the fruit of the Spirit, immediately listed thereafter (Gal 5:22-23). Some assert that fruit of the Spirit is not
a work and thus that faith is not a work since one characteristic of this fruit is faith or faithfulness (pistis). In
connection with the discussion of meritorious faith, a response to this misconception is permissible. Although
translations are split between how to render this character trait in the Pauline list, the translations universally render
this same word as faith in the similar Petrine list (2Pet 1:5). Since rewards are based on works, I am treating this
fruit as a work in applying the misthological title to it. There are two principal sources from which objections
might be brought forth against the mistholic position. First, antagonists may argue that fruit is not a work. “God
Page 210                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
produces the fruit in us,” they claim, “You need simply to quit trying and start trusting—let go and let God.” Since
this theological error by passive nikologists is refuted elsewhere, it need not detract from the present discussion.*
        A more reasonable exegetical challenge to the Marrowistic position would be to require that misthologists
explain how faith can be labeled a work when the context contrasts it with works. My answer would be that the
context considers works of the flesh to be monergistic, autonomous actions done independently of the Spirit, while
the fruit of the Spirit are synergistic responses produced in dependency upon the Spirit as we walk by the Spirit
(Gal 5:16,25). The necessity of cooperative human effort in the production of this fruit is affirmed repeatedly in the
Petrine list of fruit.† Therefore, although works and faith are contextually distinguishable in regard to their source,
they are synonymous in requiring human effort and in resulting in rewards. Since both works and fruit are
rewardable, both are meritorious. Even though there is a sense in which fruit and works can be distinguished, there
is another sense in which they can be equated. As an expression of post-regenerational fruition, fruit is a work in
the sense of being rewardable. It may, therefore, be appropriately said that this faith is a work in the broader sense
of the word, meaning it has meritorious value.
        When James refers to righteousness as a fruit (3:18), he obviously is referring to practical righteousness—
one that would necessarily involve works. In fact, just a few verses earlier, he urged believers to show their good
behavior by their works (3:13). Of course, in the previous chapter (2:22), James had described faith synergistically
working (sunergeo) with a believer’s works (ergon).‡ This faith is active in that it performs works. In 2Pet 1:5-9,
we are rewarded for the fruit we (synergistically) produce/practice. To describe this synergistical production
syllogistically, the summarization can be expressed both negatively and positively.
                                            Illustration 80. Fruit is not a Gift
           1. A gift is not rewarded.
           2. Fruit is rewarded.
           3. Therefore, fruit is not a gift.

This negative affirmation as to what fruit is not can be followed with a positive contribution as to what fruit
actually is.
                                           Illustration 81. Fruit is Meritorious
           1. God only rewards meritorious responses.
           2. Fruit is rewarded.
           3. Therefore, fruit is a meritorious response.

        The reason we are rewarded positively for spiritual fruit we produce is because it is produced synergistically
in dependency upon the Spirit rather than autonomously produced by independent effort. We are rewarded for this
fruit because it incorporates our cooperative work and thus accrues merit to our account. Therefore, fruit is a work
in the meritorious sense of the word. Accordingly, ongoing faith in the life of a believer is a work since it is an
aspect of that misthological fruit. Consequently, those who claim that believers must have ongoing faith to reach
heaven are teaching salvation by works.

Summation
        Keeping one’s faith earns a reward in Heb 10:35. Since entering heaven is not a reward, keeping one’s faith
is not a requirement to enter heaven. Likewise, James says that perseverance results in a crown of life, which must,
therefore, be a reward (1:12). Jesus said that the crown of life is conditioned on maintaining faith/faithfulness
(pistos) until the end (cp. Rev 2:10). Failure in faith is consequently a reward issue, not a salvation-from-hell issue.
Now to be sure, perseverance is a salvation issue in 1Tim 2:15, but this verse is not talking about salvation from
hell: “But women will be saved through childbearing—if they continue in faith, love and holiness with propriety”
(NIV). Salvation from hell is by faith apart from works. Salvation from the outer darkness, on the other hand, is by
perseverance in faith, which is itself a work. Perseverance in faith is a misthological consideration and hence
cannot be made a soteriological condition.

                                                     Heb 12:2
          Looking unto Jesus, the author and finisher of our faith, who for the joy that was set before Him
          endured the cross, despising the shame, and has sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
          (NKJ)

        Strange as it may sound, some advocates of irresistible grace appeal to Heb 12:2 as if were some kind of
irrefutable evidence for their position. Jesus supposedly authors our faith by irresistibly causing us to believe. But
the word translated author only affirms that Jesus is the initiator, originator, founder, or pioneer of our faith. Jesus
no more irresistibly causes us to come to faith than He irresistibly causes us to persevere in faith. Now while the
Calvinist will insist that Jesus does both, it is ridiculous to use this text as a proof text for such a claim since it
occurs in an epistle that is saturated with concern that believers may not persevere in faith. To be sure, the verse
does attribute our coming to faith and finishing in the faith to Jesus’ ministry. However, it does not say that this
ministry is administered irresistibly or monergistically. Rather, according to L-N teleiotes (finisher, ender,
completer, perfecter) means: “One who makes possible the successful completion of something.” Yes, Jesus
makes it possible for us to believe. Certainly, it would be impossible to believe in Jesus if there were no Jesus. So
Jesus is undoubtedly necessary for faith in Jesus. But it takes a stretch of the imagination (and of the biblical text)
to make this mean that Jesus is the guarantor of faith. If one simply were to look at what the writer of Hebrews
affirms concerning teleiology (doctrine of completion), it would be evident that it involves our cooperation (Heb
5:14; 6:1; cp. telos in 3:6,14; 6:11). Neither the words, text, or context support the meaning imposed upon it by
those trying to deduce irresistible grace from it.
        Marrowists have no particular quarrel with those who insist in speaking in terms of causation (so that Jesus
is said to cause our faith), but we merely point out this would not necessarily mean that He does so irresistibly. In
fact, for Calvinists to appeal to this verse in an attempt to persuade others that their faith is irresistibly caused
logically refutes the interpretation being advanced by such advocates. If the impact of this verse were irresistible,
then an attempt to use it to persuade others would be unnecessary. In other words, claiming that Jesus irresistibly
causes such faith is a logical fallacy (as demonstrated by the practical hypocrisy of those using the verse to try to
persuade others to adopt their understanding of faith). This verse fails to convey an irresistible impact because it
was never intended to do so.
        Part of the fallacy of appealing to irresistible causation lies in confusing sufficient and necessary causation.*
Just as the affirmation that faith comes from hearing (Rom 10:17) does not mean that faith irresistibly comes from
hearing, so Jesus’ authoring our faith does not mean that He does so independently of means or that He uses
irresistible means. For instance, concerning this passage Bruce (NIC) believes that Jesus’ perseverance is the
means by which He inspires us to have a persevering faith and thereby the means by which He becomes the
perfecter of our faith. One observation he makes in favor of this conclusion is that the phrase our faith actually has
the definite article the (ho) in front of faith. He provides a grammatical reason for preferring not to translate it as a
possessive.
        As delightful as Bruce’s whole discussion is, Lenski’s concise comment is more insightful: “‘The faith’
(article) is not ‘our faith’ (the article used as the possessive pronoun) but the faith defined in 11:1; hence it is
specific.”347 Grammatically, this is an article of previous reference since it refers to the faith described in the
previous chapter, which was dedicated to portraying the misthological faith resumptively introduced in Heb 11:1.†
Jesus is being described as the author and finisher of our misthological faith. Calvinists miss the point of the
immediate context when they try to make this a discussion of soteriological faith. Moreover, they miss the point of
the broad context when they think this epistle is saying that faith is irresistible. The argument for irresistibility
based on this verse, therefore, is faulty both logically, semantically, and contextually.

          28
            In no way alarmed by your opponents—which is a sign of destruction for them, but of salvation for
          you, and that too, from God. 29 For to you it (Gr. to) has been granted for Christ’s sake, not only to
          (Gr. to) believe in Him, but also to (Gr. to) suffer for His sake.

          Shell gives a very concise description of the Calvinistic interpretation and an interesting response:

                Calvinists often treat this verse [1:29] to mean God granted the Philippian believers the faith to
          believe the Gospel. However, the infinitive “to believe” is compounded with “to suffer,” and God
          tests no man with such suffering, cf. James 1:13. Rather, as C. F. D. Moule's An Idiom-Book of N.T.

          (Emphasis his.)348

Tests
       Shell’s rejection of the Calvinistic position is appreciated but not altogether convincing, at least concerning
the denial that God tests us. Job probably would object to the claim that God does not test believers with suffering.
The appeal to the verb tests (peirazo) in Jam 1:13 perhaps overlooks the noun test in Jam 1:2, which apparently
describes a test that comes from the hand of God.* In any case, it certainly fails to do justice to the fact that the
LXX349 repeatedly uses this verb to affirm that God does indeed actively test His children. “God tested Abraham”
(Gen 22:1). God tested Israel (Ex 15:25; 16:4; 20:20; Dt 13:3; Judges 3:1). David even invites God to test him
(Ps 26:2). In the NT, Paul affirms that God allows us to be tested (1Cor 10:13). Lest it be thought that God merely
passively allows the NT believer to be tested, let it be remembered that the writer of Hebrews uses this verb to
remind us that Abraham was tested (Heb 11:17), which takes us back to the Genesis account in which God was the
active agent performing the test: “God tested Abraham” (Gen 22:1). In fact, Jesus tested Philip (Jn 6:5-6).

Kataphoric
        Additionally, it is quite possible that the expression is grammatically kataphoric rather than simply elliptic.
Wallace considers it kataphoric. The first Greek article (to) “refers to a twofold concept that is to follow,” namely,
(1) to believe in Him and (2) to suffer for Him.350 Similarly, according to Robertson, the first article is explained by
the second two.351 What is given in Phil 1:29 involves two things: faith in Him and suffering for Him. Is suffering a
gift? Muller answers affirmatively, expressing a proveitistic interpretation in which true faith is a gift of God’s
grace and is proved genuine by suffering.352 In other words, God does not give you saving faith apart from
successful suffering. If you do not suffer for Him, then He has not given you saving faith. You will go to hell
unless you successfully endure the suffering. But to claim that the suffering is a gift from God does not blunt the
charge that Calvinism results in salvation by works. This Calvinistic appeal to soteric suffering is none other than
salvation by faith and works, even if it is called salvation by faith that works. Even if the works were a gift, they
become part of the requirement for salvation in the Calvinistic scheme of things, making salvation by faith apart
from works impossible.

Act of Faith
        Aside from the theological problems such a view imposes on the text, it also fails to deal adequately with
the context. Muller correctly notes that what is granted from God in Phil 1:28 is not salvation but perseverance.
The word that (touto) is neuter and cannot refer to either sign or salvation (which are feminine). As Kent also
notes, that takes a conceptual antecedent and refers to “the entire fact that believers have been granted courage
from God to stand firm in their struggles.”353 Unfortunately, Kent likewise considers this perseverance the means
by which the believers demonstrate the reality of their salvation. If you are really saved, then you will persevere.
Conversely, if you do not persevere, then you are not really saved. To really be saved, you must persevere. The
degree of Calvinism expressed in Martin’s comments is even more nauseating. He uses this passage as a
springboard to claim that the acts of faith and suffering are themselves gifts from God that result in the
soteriological salvation of those who endure. He further states, “God is the responsible agent of the whole
situation.” “Overarching both the fury of persecutor and the fidelity of the persecuted is the sovereignty of God.”
Martin insists upon seeing both the fury and the fidelity as expressions of “the sovereign control and purpose of
God.”354
        The overall impression gleaned from such statements is not that God merely passively allows suffering
(which would make the persecutors the responsible agents as a result of their free will). Instead, God is made the
responsible agent who sovereignly causes the persecutors to persecute and the persecuted to persevere. God pulls
the strings, making His puppets jump, not so much as allowing them the freedom to ask, “How high?” Instead of
submissively and voluntarily singing, “Thou art the potter. I am the clay. Mold me and make me after Thine will,
*
    See Appendix 8. Judicial Hardening, 821.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                              Page 213
while I am waiting, yielded and still,” we should theologically affirm, of this Calvinistic potter: “Thou art the
Puppeteer. I am the puppet.” The Calvinistic Potter is free; we are not.355 Logically speaking, with Calvinistic
consistency, the Potter is the Puppeteer.
                                         Illustration 82. Calvinistic Potter is Puppeteer




       In his discussion of divine determinism,* Murphree concurs that this type of determinism results in people
being treated “like marionettes, they only move when God pulls the strings.”356 Like a child in sovereign control of
his toys, forcing them to wage a war of good guys versus bad guys, so God is pictured as sovereignly causing the
forces of good and evil to do battle on a cosmic level. He just has better toys. His toys are more sophisticated and
capable of remote control rather than necessitating attached wires and strings. His toys are like remote controlled
planes and cars. In this case, these are remote controlled action figures in which God controls every action.
Whether pictured by strings or electric signals as His intermediate means, He irresistibly controls His subjects’
actions and reactions without giving them any libertarian freedom to do otherwise.
       After discussing compatibilism,† which tries to reconcile God’s sovereign control with human free will
through various manipulations, Murphree again finds that it denies any true freedom either and therefore opts for

*
  Divine determinism is the viewpoint that everything that happens, including the choices we make, must happen exactly as they do
because the events and circumstances leading up to these actions are the sufficient conditions that God uses to causally determine what
actions will take place. Our choices are governed by the principle of universal causality, according to which everything that happens is
causally determined by a long unbreakable chain of sufficient conditions that cause us to respond in the manner in which we do. In
other words, God made a complex array of dominos to control our actions and affections. And by knocking over the first domino, He
has set in motion a sequence of events over which we have no free will to do or desire otherwise than what God has determined that
we will do and desire.
†
  Compatibilism is an affirmation of divine determinism that believes that hard determinism is compatible with human freedom since
compatibilism defines freedom as the ability to act in accordance with one’s prevailing internal desires rather than being forced
to take a particular course of actions by external control. This viewpoint, also known as soft determinism, actuality is no less
deterministic than hard determinism. In the soft view, our internal desires are causally determined by the external factors leading up to
those desires so that we could not desire to do otherwise. Secondly, we cannot do otherwise than what we desire to do. Stated jointly,
we cannot do otherwise than what we do because we cannot do otherwise than what our external factors have compelled us to want to
do. In other words, God made a complex array of dominos to control our desires and thereby control our actions. By knocking over (or
pulling the rug out from under) the first domino, God has set in motion a sequence of events that causally determines our internal
desires to the point of making us irresistibly respond in the manner in which we (desire to) do. God has remotely controlled our
actions by putting in motion a chain of events that make it impossible for us to do otherwise than what we do. God controls our
internal desires, and our internal desires control us. In short, God controls us by controlling our internal desires. God controls
our character, and our character controls us.
Page 214                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                 *
libertarianism. Simply put, this teaching affirms that by-and-large we pull our own strings. Our actions are self-
determined, so this viewpoint is also known as self-determinism. God causes us. He created us. But we create our
actions. God causes the person, but the person causes the action via means of his or her free will that God has
endowed the individual with as a gift via creation. This is the view of the present writer and has been popularized
by Geisler.
        We cannot take an Adamic copout and say, “The woman made me do it.” We cannot take her copout and
say, “The devil made me do it.” Nor can we make more sophisticated excuses and blame God due to our external
circumstances or our environment and whine, “God, you put that tree there, and that tree was just too great a
temptation.” Nor can we blame God due to our internal desires: “God, You created me with these desires, and my
desires made me do it.” To be sure, Eve had the desire to eat the fruit before she ate the fruit, just as she had eyes to
see it before she picked it (Gen 3:6). But she could not blame God with creating her with human eyes or desires,
nor could she blame her eyes or desires for making her sin. She chose to sin. At the very least, by choosing to listen
to the serpent and looking at the tree, she was responsible for placing herself in a position to where her emotions
overcame her volition, as Murphree explains:

        We can place ourselves in such a vulnerable position to temptation that it becomes virtually
        irresistible. We can become emotionally and psychologically incapacitated, unable to make
        responsible choices. Libertarians make no claim for absolute freedom, only for a measure of
        freedom.357

Misthological Salvation
        Those Calvinistic writers who mistakenly deduce that our acts of endurance (rather than our free will as to
whether we endure) are gifts of God evidently have failed to fully consider some very obvious deductions. A
perseverance-based salvation is a misthological salvation, not a soteriological one.† A salvation conditioned on our
enduring suffering is a salvation by works and results in rewards in heaven rather than entrance into heaven. The
same gospel that proclaims destruction for unbelievers who cause persecution also makes a rich salvation available
to believers who endure persecution. The that (touto) of verse 28 and the it (to) of verse 29 are both linked together
by their neuter gender in referring to the same concept, namely that of believing in Christ and suffering for Him in
order to obtain misthological salvation. God makes believing in Him and suffering for Him possible, not
irresistible. Believers persevere, not in order to escape hell, but in order to rule in heaven—expressing their free
will within the limitations of God’s sovereignty.
         God does not sovereignly cause humanity to endure suffering or to inflict suffering. God sovereignly may
put up the ropes around the boxing arena, set the boundaries, and at times blow the whistle for a pause in the fight,
or limit the type of punches that can be thrown, but He does not press the buttons making the offsetting boxers take
every opposing jab. He has given them a mind of their own. Does not our volition play a part in whether we
successfully suffer for His sake? Paul seems to think so: “And indeed, all who desire to live godly in Christ Jesus
will be persecuted” (2Tim 3:12). The word for desire is thelo (to desire or will). That all believers are willing to
undergo persecution is not a foregone conclusion (2Tim 2:12). The choice is theirs. God does not irresistibly cause
people to believe in Him any more than He irresistibly forces them to suffer for Him. Rather, God graciously

*
  Libertarianism is the true affirmation of human freedom in which prior factors are not seen as sufficient conditions to explain all of
our choices. This does not mean that our actions are uncaused, of course. Rather, they are self-caused. A person’s actions do not cause
themselves; the person himself causes his own action. This viewpoint is synonymous with self-determinism. From the libertarian
perspective, a person must be free to do otherwise than what his or her internal and external factors dictate in order to be morally
responsible for his or her actions. Free agents must be free to determine their own actions. This is not to say that their actions occur in
a vacuum, but free agents sometimes act contrary to their desires, and, in doing so, they can have a dynamic effect upon their desires.
Libertarian freedom is therefore the ability to act contrary to external and internal impulses.
        When the Scripture commands us to “let your character be free from the love of money” (Heb 13:5), it thereby indicates that
we have some control over our character. Not only does our character mold us, but we mold it (Rom 5:4). When the Bible says, “You
shall not desire your neighbor’s house” (Dt 5:21), it is taking libertarian freedom for granted in telling us that we have culpable control
over what we desire. When Paul exhorts believers to “earnestly desire the greater gifts” (1Cor 12:31), he assumes that they are free to
determine their own desires (cp. 1Cor 14:1). In fact, Paul gives believers a course of action which they may follow so that they will
not have to carry out the desires of the flesh (Gal 5:16). They have a choice as to which desires they will obey: those of the flesh
versus those of the Spirit. We choose what desires we will obey. Believers are not slavishly obedient to their strongest desires.
Obviously, Paul is not a compatibilist, much less a hardcore determinist. It is possible, on occasion, to base our actions on our
convictions and principles rather than simply on what we want to do.
†
  See Phil 1:28 in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 215
                                                                                                          *
makes it possible for us to believe and suffer successfully. He does, in fact, give us the opportunity. God not only
gives us the opportunity to believe in the doctrine of rewards at a theoretical level, He also provides us with the
opportunity to earn rewards at the practical level. We can express our faith in Him as rewarder (Heb 11:6) by
striving for those rewards.
        Since God did not have to give us the faith to believe the sun rose yesterday, why conclude that He would
have to give us the faith to believe the Son rose yesteryear? Every good gift is from above (Jam 1:18), whether it
be rain or the ability to believe. This ability has been given by God to the lost and saved. He does not have to give
us faith to believe that it is raining anymore than He has to give us faith to believe that our sins are forgiven. He
can present the evidence persuasively, but faith or lack of faith remains our response to the evidence. Through
common grace, God has made it possible for us to believe both physical as well as metaphysical propositions.
        The only other occurrence of granted (charizomai) in Philippians is in 2:9 and would suggest that what is
given is not necessarily freely given independently of one’s performance (cf. 2:8). More emphatically, in this other
Philippian passage, what is given is a reward based on performance, where the Father graced the Son with an
exalted name because of what the Son did. As will be discussed more fully concerning Gal 3:18, the promise of
rewards is graciously given (charizomai). We do not deserve either the God-given opportunity or ability to earn
rewards. Nevertheless, if we avail ourselves of this opportunity to earn rewards through God’s imparted ability,
then we do in fact merit such rewards.† That which is offered has to be received. It is not irresistibly forced upon
us. What is freely given is the opportunity and ability to earn the reward, not the reward itself. Consequently,
another reason the Calvinistic interpretation of this passage must be rejected is because it misconstrues the nature
of charizomai. This verb does not prove that what is given is a gift, much less an irresistible gift.
        The assessment herein is, therefore, in substantial agreement with that of Shell. The expression is
grammatically kataphoric but theologically elliptic. What is granted to us by God consists of the opportunity and
ability to believe in Him and suffer for Him. Even some Calvinists, such as Martin, acknowledge that what is given
is the privilege and ability to believe in Him. The Calvinistic error comes in making the action of believing and
suffering themselves also part of what is given. Although these capacities are graciously given and enabled, their
exercise is not irresistibly caused. What is given is the opportunity to earn a reward by victorious faith and
suffering. Even though it might be said that the opportunities to believe and suffer are gifts, faith and suffering
themselves are not gifts. What is given is the opportunity and ability to believe and suffer. God graciously gives us
these capabilities. It is not God who suffers for us in this passage, but we who suffer for God. We perform the
action. Likewise, faith is our reaction. The text ascribes both the action and reaction to us.

                                             Universal Enablement
       Although Wilkin appears to adopt a type of Calvinistic forechose position (as reflected in his acceptance of
the Pearly Gate illustration mentioned earlier), he rightly rejects the notion that only those who are predestined are
capable of believing:

          I realize that the elect will believe someday and the non-elect never will. However, there is a
          difference between what someone will do and what they can do. It is possible for anyone with a
          sound mind to trust in Christ. That is why those who do not believe can be said to have rejected Him,
          to have chosen not to receive Him (John 1:11). (Emphasis his.) 358

Hodges also articulates this mediating perspective very well:

          If God condemns men for not believing, and men have no capacity whatsoever to believe, then the
          justice of God is called into question. How can a man be held responsible for what he is incapable of
          doing? On that basis, why could not God cast babies who die in infancy into hell? Why not also the
          mentally impaired? When man’s capacity to believe is totally denied, what is left behind is a horrible,
          even monstrous, conception of God….
                Thus the Bible does not say that man is constitutionally incapable of faith, only that faith cannot
          occur without divine illumination….
                Paul’s statement that “there is none who seeks after God” (Rom 3:11) may seem to contradict
          this, but it doesn’t. This famous text does not say that man cannot seek God! He can and should seek

*
    This faith-suffering is both kataphoric and elliptic.
†
    See Derivative Merit, 31.
Page 216                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
       God (Acts 17:26-27)! But he doesn’t (unprompted by the Spirit) and, therefore, is responsible for not
       doing so.359

       In his antecedent article, Hodges also notes (concerning 2Cor 4:3): “Evidently Satan does not subscribe to
the notion that man is inherently incapable of believing. He would be wasting his time blinding man if man is
already hopelessly blind!”360 A similar deduction can be made from Satan’s activity in Lk 8:12. If it is impossible
for the nonelect to believe, then Satan’s frantic activity to prevent them from believing is hard to explain. Satan’s
action in trying to blind all and God’s initiative in drawing all indicates that predestination is not taken by either
God or Satan as being an irrevocable or irresistible decree fatalistically determining who will or will not believe.
Satan is busy at work trying to prevent salvation from occurring because he knows that it is not God’s
predisposition to act sovereignly in causing the saving faith that results in regeneration. The foreknowledge
position is certainly more intuitive, and the activity by both God and Satan indicate its functionality. At least for
God and Satan, it is a very practical theology— a theology they both put into practice.
       In contrast, the forechose understanding would seem to be irreconcilable with the universal-ability position.
If God has forechosen who will believe, and only they can believe because they have been forechosen to believe,
then God has not really made it possible for everyone to believe. In contrast, if God has forechosen who will
believe, but everyone can believe because God enables them to believe, then their enablement is not based on God
forechoosing them to believe. Universal enablement would seem to preclude God from forechoosing who will
believe. It is more consistent to say that God simply foreknows who will believe, but He has not predestined who
will believe. He leaves this possibility open to all. Enabling grace is not limited to the saved.

                                    Definition of Prevenient Grace
      The statements made by Wilkin and Hodges above are fully compatible with the Arminian insistence on the
necessity of prevenient grace. To give fuller expression to Thiessen’s summation cited earlier, his extended
explanation is now offered:

       Originally man had freedom in two senses of the term: freedom to carry out the dictates of his nature
       and freedom to act contrary to his nature. Man had the ability to sin and the ability not to sin. In the
       fall he lost the ability not to sin; his ability not to sin became inability not to sin (Gen. 6:5; Job 14:14;
       Jer. 13:23; 17:9; Rom 3:10-18; 8:5-8). Now he is free only in the sense that he is able to do as his
       fallen nature suggests. Because man is without any ability or desire to change, God responded by
       prevenient grace. This grace (sometimes considered a part of common or universal grace) restores to
       the sinner the ability to make favorable responses to God (Rom 2:4; Titus 2:11).361

       Both Rom 3:11 considered above and Rom 8:8 to be discussed below are included in the passages that
Thiessen uses to show the necessity of prevenient grace. In an excellent chapter devoted to this topic, Picirilli (a
Reformed Arminian) takes this affirmation of prevenient grace one step further and uses it to affirm and adequately
deal with the lost person’s total inability: “This condition may rightly be called total depravity, in that it pervades
every aspect of man’s being, and total inability, in that it leaves him helpless to perform anything truly good in
God’s sight.”362 This is not to say that there are not those in the FG camp or Arminian camps who would reject the
notion of total inability. However, it would appear that better-informed Arminian and FG advocates would agree
with the Reformed view concerning man’s total inability. Apart from God’s enabling grace, none of us would be
able to believe the gospel. The present work thus agrees with those in the Arminian, Free Grace, and Calvinistic
camps who affirm that certain passages (such as Jn 6:44,65; Rom 3:11; 8:8; cp. Jn 16:8; Acts 16:14) logically
necessitate this doctrinal affirmation of total inability. Prevenient grace is pragmatically rather than constitutionally
necessary for the unbeliever to come to faith. Where the present work disagrees with the Calvinistic doctrine of
total inability is when Calvinists move beyond the affirmation of enabling grace to irresistible grace as the
necessary means of enabling man to believe. The Marrowistic position is that enabling grace is sufficient to enable
man to believe.
       Prevenient grace, also known as enabling or pre-regenerating grace, may be thus defined as the Holy Spirit’s
sufficient (not efficacious) and direct (not immediate) work on the unbeliever’s heart through the intermediate
means of the gospel call (by which the Spirit conveys resistible conviction, illumination, inclination, and
persuasion in the form of influence) that enables the unbeliever to respond in saving faith.
       To briefly unpack this definition, the common grace that is common to all mankind (by which the Spirit
touches the conscience of the lost and enables them to seek God even before they hear the gospel) becomes more
narrowly focused and intensified in the proclamation of the gospel message to enable and influence anyone and
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 217
everyone who hears the gospel to believe it. The Spirit acts persuasively and powerfully but not irresistibly upon
the unregenerate heart in communicating the truth of that message to the unbelieving heart. There is sufficient
persuasion for such persons to become convinced by it if they do not resist this persuasional influence. But it is not
a mechanical cause and effect reaction in which the Spirit causes the unbeliever to believe. Rather it is a personal
influence and response interrelation in which the person himself (i.e., his self) determines his own response.363 The
