influence is efficacious upon the person whose resistance is less than the Spirit’s persistence.
        Paul’s ministry is instructive and illustrative of the Spirit’s operation. Paul was “trying to persuade” people
to believe (Acts 18:4). He was “reasoning and persuading them” (Acts 19:8). Some were persuaded; some were not
(Acts 28:23-24). Some who were not persuaded were almost persuaded (Acts 26:28). But the present author’s
appreciation for Picirilli’s explanation of prevenient grace must stop short of Picirilli’s affirmation that a person
could be persuaded about the truth of the gospel and yet be an unbeliever! The author does not share this point of
view with Picirilli, although admittedly many in the FG camp would. One technical difference between my
approach and that of my FG counterparts on this particular matter revolves around the two-element and three-
element view of faith. Those holding a three-element view of faith (and defining the third element as volitional
assent in entrusting Christ with one’s eternal destiny) would have no problem with Picirilli’s delineation on the
nature of faith.364 Therefore, Picirilli’s assessment of the nature of faith is certainly within the parameters of FG
theology. However, I am specifically limiting my outlook to the Marrowistic view defined herein. Marrowism
espouses a narrower form of FG in which faith explicitly is regarded as passive persuasion. In doing so, I am siding
with Hodges, who might be rightly regarded as the father of the modern expression of Marrowism.
        This is not to say that I agree with Hodges on every detail or that Hodges would agree with me on every
detail. Indeed, I already have modified Hodges’ minority view concerning the tribulation to a moderate view in
response to the criticism being made from the majority camp. In doing so, I have strengthened Hodges’ main point
concerning the tribulation. Moreover, even in the context of the present discussion concerning saving faith, in
contrast to Hodges, the present writer prefers a potential three-element view of faith. It is a modified form of the
three-element view of faith and is pragmatically a two-element view.* This alteration should make the Hodgian
view of faith (as being passive persuasion) even more persuasive.
        The Spirit exerts persuasive pressure on the lost person’s intellect to believe, just as Paul did with Agrippa.
But a lost person such as Agrippa may choose, by means of his volition, to exert a counter-influence upon his own
intellect to think of reasons not to believe and to create intellectual barriers to prevent faith. While the Holy Spirit
and His intermediate agents, such as Paul, are exerting positive persuasive influence, an unholy spirit and the lost
person may be exerting negative persuasional influence. Prevenient grace does not necessarily determine who will
win the battle. It only makes the battle winnable. Prevenient grace means that Agrippa could have believed. He was
not a helpless pawn in the battle. Enabling grace empowered him with the ability to choose. He was therefore
responsible for his reluctance to believe the gospel.
        White asks regarding Col 1:3-4, “Why should we give thanks to God upon hearing of the faith of fellow
believers, if in fact having faith in Christ is something that every person is capable of having without any gracious
enablement by God?”365 This is a good question. One could only wish that Calvinists were content with the
“gracious enablement” answer as provided by Hunt: “We believe that enablement from God is
essential….Enablement implies a responsibility on the part of the one who is being enabled.”366 We also would ask
Calvinists a related question regarding 2Thess 1:4, where Paul this time states: “Therefore, we ourselves speak
proudly of you among the churches of God for your perseverance and faith in the midst of all your persecutions
and afflictions which you endure.” If Paul’s being thankful to God for their faith in Col 1:3-4 means that in some
way (such as through “gracious enablement”) their faith was attributable to God, would not Paul’s being proud of
them for their faith in 2Thess 1:4 mean that in some way (such as cooperative response) their faith was attributable
to themselves? In other words, why should Paul be proud of them for their perseverance in faith if such faith is
monergistically produced by God? White would appear to be trapped by the logic on his own question, when
applied to Col 1:3-4, into admitting that the most reasonable conclusion is that faith is a cooperative response
rather than a monergistic product.




*
    See “The Elementary Faith of Demons” in Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
Page 218                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
                                                         Rom 8:8

Dual Syllogisms
        Paul’s statement in Rom 8:8 was used frequently by White in his debate with Hunt concerning man’s
inability to believe the gospel and for good reason. It does seem to be a rather clear indicator of inability. This
Calvinistic perception is sometimes presented syllogistically along the following lines.
                                           Illustration 83. The Lost Cannot Believe
          1. Those in the flesh cannot please God (Rom 8:7-8).
          2. Coming to God in saving faith pleases God (1Cor 1:21; Heb 11:6).
          3. Therefore, those who are in the flesh cannot come to God in saving faith.

        For the sake of expedience at least, rather than circumvent this syllogism with contextual counterarguments,
this argument will be engaged at face value, particularly since Calvinists also will define spiritual death as the
inability to do anything that pleases God.367 At the same time, a somewhat related syllogism will be considered,
which also explores the relationship between free will and ability:
                                         Illustration 84. God Does Not Have Free Will
          1. Free will is the ability to choose either good or evil.
          2. God cannot choose evil.
          3. Therefore, God does not have free will.

       If this simplistic definition of free will in the second syllogism is accepted, then God does not have free will.
Indeed, in a dialogue the present author had with an Arminian on this matter, the Arminian author actually denied
that God has free will. Another Arminian rejected the second premise and claimed that God can choose sin but will
not do so. Thankfully, not all Arminians would make such strange assertions. Briefly, in defense of the second
premise, the following lexical renderings may be observed.

Lexical Cannot
       On Jam 1:13, BDAG takes a passive view and defines apeirastos as: God cannot be tempted to do evil. L-N
acknowledges this definition as one possibility and suggests God would never want to do what is evil as an active
alternative. The present writer prefers the passive God cannot sin over the active God will not sin. The reason God
will not sin volitionally is because He cannot sin ontologically. Jesus likewise could not be tempted
subjectively/internally (cp. Jam 1:14 and Jn 14:30).
       As to Tit 1:2, translations of apseudes are split between the two views: God cannot lie versus God does not
lie. However, the similar expression in Heb 6:18 uses adunatos, which according to BDAG (2.a) means impossible.
The translations concur. God’s immutability in essence and character makes it impossible for Him to lie.
       Regarding 1Jn 3:9, the present work defends the position that ou dunamai (cannot) means that it is
impossible for believers to sin ontologically in terms of who they really are as a result of regeneration.* This would
seem to be lexically straightforward. Ou dunamai (cannot) is also applicable to God (2Tim 2:13).
       Hence, the minor premise of the second syllogism is accepted herein. God cannot choose evil. But the
double negation of dunamai in Rom 8:7-8 in the first syllogism indicates that unbelievers cannot please God. So
how can unbelievers believe? Does prevenient grace somehow mean that those who are in the flesh can do that
which is otherwise impossible for them to do in this passage? Thiessen has answered affirmatively in the block
quote above.†

Adam’s Free Will
       In his state of innocence, Adam had the God-given ability to choose to sin. But Adam was not free to choose
sin and remain within God’s moral will. So why does Adam’s free will require the ability to sin, but God’s free
will not require the ability to sin? Further, in their futuristic state of perfect sanctification in heaven, believers will
be transformed into Christ’s likeness and will no longer have a sin nature. As a result, in eternity believers will not
be able to sin since they will only be left with a regenerate nature that is incapable of sin. So does this mean that in

*
    See Appendix 4. Johannine Anamartetology, 769.
†
    See Definition of Prevenient Grace, 216.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                             Page 219
heaven believers lose their free will? Some would be content simply to say that believers will not sin rather than
state that they will not be able to sin. But Alcorn is far more perceptive:

            The inability to sin doesn’t inherently violate free will. My inability to be God, an angel, a
       rabbit, or a flower is not a violation of my free will. It’s the simple reality of my nature. The new
       nature that’ll be ours in Heaven—the righteousness of Christ—is a nature that cannot sin, any more
       than a diamond can be soft or blue can be red. God cannot sin, yet no being has greater free choice
       than God does.368

        For lexical reasons presented above and due to texts such as 1Jn 3:2, the position taken herein affirms the
stronger affirmation: Believers will not be able to sin in heaven. After all, can God sin? No. It is ontologically
impossible for God to sin; it goes against His nature. In heaven believers will be experientially sinless, like God,
for the same reason—they share His nature. It will be ontologically impossible for them to sin. Since they will no
longer have a sin nature, the only nature they will have will be their incorruptible regenerate nature that cannot
sin.369
        So back to the original question, “Does their resulting inability to sin mean that believers lose their free
will?” No. Libertarian freedom is the ability to choose between two or more options; sin need not necessarily be
one of those options. Man does not necessarily need the ability to sin in order to love God. But if that is the case,
then why did God give Adam the ability to sin? In my estimation, the ability to sin is necessary for libertarian
freedom unless the free agent is ontologically incapable of sinning. Therefore, God either had to create angels and
men with the ability to sin in order to allow them to have libertarian freedom, or He had to create them with His
nature, making it impossible for them to sin. He chose not to create them with His own immutable nature unless
they chose to share that nature. However, He only shared this option with men, not angels.370
        God has created both men and angels as spiritual beings. Thus, they both share His ability to make moral
choices. However, He will only share the fuller ontological sinless aspect of His spiritual nature, which makes sin
impossible, with those free agents who choose to share this nature. He does not force this aspect on unwilling
creatures. This fuller impartation of His nature is limited to humanity. Since the man or woman who willingly
desires to share God’s nature will more fully share in God’s imparted nature than angels, it is only fitting that
regenerate humanity, as a higher order of spiritual beings, should rule over angels, who are unregenerate sinless
beings. Good angels are merely volitionally sinless. They choose not to sin, but they could choose to sin. Glorified
regenerate humans, however, ontologically are unable to sin and thus more fully share God’s spiritual nature. God
not only chooses not to sin, He cannot choose to sin.

Supreme Motif
       Even so, God’s decision to condition our sharing His immutability on our free will response is certainly due
to more than a desire on His part to exalt our free will. Something much more important than our free will was at
stake. Namely, the reason God gave us free will independent of immutability was so that He might be glorified by
the calamity that we brought upon ourselves when we abused our freedom. By allowing us to put ourselves in
jeopardy, God made it possible for Him to reveal things about us and about Himself that we never would have
known otherwise. God could not redeem angels, but He could redeem us. If the Lord had created us in such a way
that we could never have fallen, then we never would have known what it is like to be picked up.
       Do holy angels love God? Surely they do, as evidenced by their praise, worship, and adoration of God. Yet
from Jesus’ teaching on the relationship between being forgiven and loving, it may be reasonably deduced that
those who have been forgiven an enormous sin debt have a far greater capacity to love God than angels who have
never done anything for which to be forgiven (Lk 7:40-43). Redeemed humanity has a far greater capacity to love
God than unfallen angels. But certainly unfallen angels love God even more than they would have otherwise now
that they have seen what God has done in redeeming humanity. By creating angels and humanity with a free will
(flowing from their mutable nature) which would result in an angelic uprising and human rebellion (followed in
turn by God redeeming humanity), the Lord has revealed more about Himself both to angels and to humanity than
He ever could had He not created angels and men with the possibility of rebelling against Him. It was not to the
praise of the glory of our free will that God created us with the capacity to rebel against Him; rather, it was “to the
praise of the glory of His grace” (Eph 1:6). The reason a good God created a world in which evil was possible was
to glorify His grace in providing saving grace for a lost humanity in order that He might be loved more. He did it
for love: to maximize our love for Him and to demonstrate His love for us. Love was worth the price.
       The Calvinistic dispensationalist might point to God’s glory as the greatest good and extol His sovereignty
as a result, even to the point of adopting a theology that logically makes God the author of sin to the praise of His
Page 220                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
sovereign glory. Christian libertarians, in contrast, defend the liberty of the human will—not because of some
priori regarding philosophical convictions, anthropological optimism, or a love affair with the notion of freedom—
but because they love God. They cannot and will not attribute sin to God or make Him out to be a heartless
monster who causes evil and unconditionally reprobates the lost. The libertarian controlling priori is their
conviction about the good, loving character of God: God is good (Mk 10:18); God is love (1Jn 4:8,16). Roger
Olson devotes a chapter to defending this thesis: “Arminianism begins with God’s goodness and ends by affirming
free will.”371 Classic Arminianism even acknowledges the bondage of the will. Hunt did not entitle his book, What
Free Will is This? but What Love is This? The libertarian concern over free will is not due to an overriding sense of
human dignity. Rather, their driving concern is to defend the dignity of God against those who would malign His
character.
        As to the difference between free will flowing from an mutable versus immutable nature, consideration
might be given to the question, “What is the difference between God breathing in Adam the breath of life (which
herein will be considered a higher order of trichotomy that makes moral free will possible in the case of man)*
versus being born of the Spirit?” That which is born of Spirit is spirit. Man and angels initially were created with
innocent spirits. But a major difference between the innocent spirit and the regenerate spirit is that the regenerate
spirit immutably shares God’s spiritual nature. The trichotomous, regenerate spirit is absolutely incapable of
choosing to sin because sin is ontologically impossible for that which immutably shares God’s sinless nature. If
this proposal is correct, then libertarian free will necessarily requires the ability to sin, unless the free agent is
ontologically incapable of sinning. Such a free agent cannot sin because it would go against his or her immutable
nature. Calvinists will thus respond that fallen man is incapable of believing for the same reason: It is contrary to
fallen nature to submit in faith to God. They will insist that just as the regenerate nature cannot help but believe, so
the unregenerate nature cannot help but disbelieve (Rom 8:7-8).

Total Inability
       This brings the discussion back to the solution proposed in prevenient grace. Prevenient grace provides lost
humanity with the functional rather than ontological ability to believe. The lost person already has the
constitutional ability to believe, but this ability is morally impaired and pragmatically requires divine intervention
to make a morally-acceptable response. In Calvinism, God has to change the sinner’s nature before the sinner can
believe. Thus, regeneration must precede faith. In Arminianism, God only has to restore the ability for the sinner to
act contrary to his or her sin nature. As Thiessen notes above, Adam originally had the ability to act contrary to his
(innocent) nature. He lost this ability in the fall. God restores this ability in prevenient grace, making it possible for
sinners to act contrary to their fallen nature. In making this affirmation, I concur with the Arminian dissatisfaction
of the compatibilism offered by many Calvinists, who try to make God’s sovereign determinism compatible “with
human freedom by redefining ‘freedom’ to mean the freedom to do as one desires.”372 This notion of soft
determinism is incompatible with the view being expressed herein. For the lost person to be free to believe the
gospel, that lost individual must be free to act contrary to his or her rebellious sin nature and the dictates of
circumstantial influences.
       Murray demands that Calvinistic total inability be acknowledged in this passage in Romans, evidently
thinking that this settles the issue:

          Here we have nothing less than the doctrine of total inability of the natural man, that is to say, total
          inability to be well-pleasing to God…
               In the whole passage we have the biblical basis for the doctrines of total depravity and total
          inability….‘Enmity against God’ is nothing other than total depravity and ‘cannot please God’ [is]
          nothing less than total inability. (Emphasis added.)373

       Enough already! Libertarians agree! The lost, in and of themselves, are completely and totally incapable of
responding positively to God. The will of the lost is in bondage to sin. For that matter, believers must likewise live
in dependency upon the Spirit if they hope to please God. The Arminian can insist just as emphatically as the
Calvinist that the lost person is naturally incapable of believing the gospel apart from God’s grace. The preliminary
lexical examination of various forms of cannot above, concerning what God and man cannot do, provided a
foretaste of the discussion to be considered here. This treatment, in turn, will anticipate some of the points to be


*
    See “Scholastic Trichotomy” in Trichotomy.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                  Page 221
                                                                                       *
more fully demonstrated elsewhere concerning the use of dunamai Jn 6:44,65. The semantic range of this word
group for cannot is broader than what was noted briefly above regarding active versus passive readings.

          •    “No one is able [oudeis dunamai] to come to Me unless the Father draws Him” (Jn 6:44; TM).
          •    “No one is able [oudeis dunamai] to come to Me unless it has been given to him by the Father”
               (Jn 6:65; TM).
          •    “The mind set on the flesh is hostile toward God; for it does not subject itself to the law of God, for it is
               not able [oude dunamai]” (Rom 8:7; TM).
          •    “Those who are in the flesh are not able [ou dunamai] to please God” (Rom 8:8; TM).

       Restored Ability
       In contradistinction to some within FG, the present work acknowledges that such verses (at least the first
two) indicate that unbelievers are unable to believe—unless the Father draws them through the intermediate agency
of the Spirit using the intermediate means of the gospel and in doing so gives them the enablement to believe. This
would be a Johannine-based response. The Pauline conceptual counterparts are not actually dealing with the
unbeliever’s inability to respond in saving faith to the gospel. So Paul is not addressing the question: “How is it
possible for the unbeliever to believe?” It is understandable, therefore, that some non-Calvinists simply point out
that the Pauline passage is not addressing this issue and move on. On the other hand, one would assume that Paul
and John would be in agreement on the matter and, thus, that the same answer would suffice for both. For that
matter, one would think that it would be the same answer as provided by Luke concerning Lydia in Acts 16:14.
       In an excellent summation, Wilkin states, “Clearly if He had not opened her heart, whatever that means, she
[Lydia] wouldn’t have been able to believe the Gospel of Christ which Paul preached….she was able to seek God
only because He had been drawing her to Himself” (emphasis added). Wilkin defines opening her heart as
removing the mental block that prevents the lost from perceiving the truth of the gospel. He further acknowledges:
“Yet there is some truth in the Reformed position. God is indeed sovereign. No one comes to Christ unless the
Father draws him (John 6:44).”374 The ability that Adam lost in the fall to respond rightly to God was sufficiently
restored by God in His calling Adam. When Adam heard God walking in the garden, he responded wrongly to
God. He went and hid himself (Gen 3:8). Yet when God called his name, Adam responded rightly, or at least
sufficiently so.

        Through Grace
        Although God’s opening Lydia’s heart is the most popular example in Luke’s writings of God enabling a
person to believe, it is certainly not the only one. Luke states that they “believed through grace” (Acts 18:27).
Whereas the Calvinist would read this as irresistible grace, libertarians would understand this to mean that they
believed through the intermediate means of enabling grace. This phrase for through grace (dia tes charitos) occurs
four times in the NT (Acts 15:11; 18:27; Rom 12:3; Gal 1:15). In none of these references is there a need to
suppose irresistible grace.
        In Gal 1:15, Paul says that he was called through God’s grace. Whereas the Calvinist may be inclined to see
this as an expression of God’s sovereign grace working irresistibly, libertarians would be more inclined to point out
that it was not a sovereign decree from eternity past but a separation and calling from his mother’s womb and thus
a temporal calling. Consequently, agreement with Cole is reasonable: “Like Jeremiah [1:5], Paul is one set apart
and called from his mother’s womb, by the prevenient grace of God.”375
        In Rom 12:3, Paul exhorts the believers through the grace that God had given to him. This would seem most
naturally to refer to imparted ability rather than irresistible grace. God did not force Paul to speak apart from his
cooperation. Rather, God gave Paul the ability to speak. Paul is simply giving glory to God for the office, ability,
and opportunity given to him to allow him to speak in this way. This may certainly be contrasted with the attitude
of Herod.
          21
            And on an appointed day Herod, having put on his royal apparel, took his seat on the rostrum and
          began delivering an address to them. 22 And the people kept crying out, “The voice of a god and not
          of a man!” 23 And immediately an angel of the Lord struck him because he did not give God the
          glory, and he was eaten by worms and died. (Acts 12:21-23).


*
    See “Temporal Inevitability” and “Syntax of Jn 6:44” in Drawing and Appointment.
Page 222                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
But why should a lost man like Herod be expected to give glory to God for his ability to speak? Would it not be
because the lost are also enabled to do what they do through God’s enabling grace? Certainly this would speak of
common grace, not irresistible grace.
       In Acts 18:27, Constable expresses the syntactical probability: “The word order in the Greek text favors the
view that ‘through grace’ modifies ‘believed’ rather than ‘helped.’ The Corinthian Christians had believed the
gospel through the grace of God.”376 Again, the text states that Apollos “helped those who had believed through
grace” (TM). The adverbial phrase through grace could modify either verb: helped or believed. Proximity argues
for the latter.
       This argument from emphatic syntactical location should be kept in mind when consulting Acts 15:11. It is
very strange that the same logic is not followed in this verse, especially since this is the only other place in Acts
where this adverbial phrase occurs: “But through the grace of the Lord Jesus we believed to be saved just as they
also [believed to be saved].” Luke, through recording the words of Peter, emphatically is expressing the same
theology. In Acts 15:11 the adverbial phrase is brought to the front of the sentence to stress that it is through grace
that we believe. Had he put the phrase on the tail end of the sentence, like he did in 18:27, it would have given the
wrong impression that he was merely affirming that we are saved through grace. Although it is true that we are
saved through grace, this is not the point Luke syntactically is making. Rather, he is saying that we believe through
grace, and this believing through grace results in salvation. His location of the phrase in both 15:11 and 18:27
indicates that this is his meaning. Unfortunately, few translators have picked up on this fact, but perhaps a few have
done so (DRA, YLT; Lenski). As mentioned above, Lydia (Acts 16:14) is a Lukan example of this Lukan teaching
that we believe through grace and that apart from such grace we would not be able to believe.

        Functional Ability
        Likewise, it may be surmised that those who are in the flesh in Rom 8:8 are incapable of submitting
themselves to God’s commands, particularly the command to believe in Christ for eternal life. Their ontological
hostility toward God renders them functionally incapable of coming to faith in God. It is impossible for them to
believe unless God intervenes through prevenient grace. Naturally, Calvin rejects this understanding:

       Behold the power of free-will! which the Sophists cannot carry high enough. Doubtless, Paul affirms
       here, in express words, what they openly detest,—that it is impossible for us to render our powers
       subject to the law. They boast that the heart can turn to either side, provide it be aided by the
       influence of the Spirit, and that a free choice of good or evil is in our power, when the Spirit only
       brings help; but it is ours to choose or refuse. They also imagine some good emotions, by which we
       become of ourselves prepared. Paul, on the contrary, declares, that the heart is full of hardness and
       indomitable contumacy, so that it is never moved naturally to undertake the yoke of God. (Emphasis
       added.)377

       Libertarian acknowledgment of biblical total inability is not an endorsement of Calvinistic total inability.
Calvin rejects free will, even if the lost person is supernaturally aided and helped by the Spirit’s influence.
According to Calvin, our will has to be moved irresistibly rather than through natural means. But how is the
supernatural influence of the Holy Spirit limited to natural means? Perhaps Calvin means to rule out intermediate
means. Still, such a denial is not enough since prevenient grace also involves a supernatural intermediate agent—
the Holy Spirit.
       The biblical doctrine of total inability renders the lost person (and the saved person for that matter)
incapable of doing anything that pleases God apart from the Spirit’s enablement. Jesus even says to believers, “The
branch is not able [ou dunamai] unless it abides in the vine…I am the vine, you are the branches….apart from Me
you are not able [ou dunamai] to do anything” (Jn 15:4-5; TM). Believers, of their own free will, may choose
whether to abide in Christ. If they choose not to abide in Christ, then everything they do amounts to nothing. This
phrase ou dunamai is used by Paul of unbelievers and by John of believers. Total inability applies just as much to
the believer as to the unbeliever. Just as regeneration does not necessarily remove the believer’s free will, neither
does lack of regeneration necessarily remove the unbeliever’s free will. The same Spirit who makes it possible for
believers to overcome their inability also makes it possible for unbelievers to likewise overcome their inability.
       For the sake of parallelism, to this point this phraseology has been translated consistently in terms of not
being able, which is certainly a suitable translation. However, the preference herein is to use the terminology of
power, since Paul is really not focusing on soteriological issues but rather on nikological issues—empowerment to
live the Christian life—at least in this particular context in Romans. Just as the carnal believer is powerless to live
the Christian life (Rom 7:14-25), so the natural person certainly does not have the ability to do so. The Law’s
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 223
inability (adunatos) in Rom 8:3 is described as weakness, which may also be translated as powerless. It seems that
practically everyone is familiar with the Greek word for power (dunamis), from which the modern word dynamite
is derived. Dunamis is the noun form of the verb dunamai (to have power). God supplies us with spiritual power
(dunamis) through His Spirit (Eph 3:16). The Holy Spirit empowers us to please God. The Law does not empower
us to please God:
          3
            For what the Law was powerless [adunatos] to do, weak as it was through the flesh, God did:
          sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and as an offering for sin, He condemned sin in
          the flesh….6 For the mind set on the flesh is death, but the mind set on the Spirit is life and peace,
          7
            because the mind set on the flesh is hostile toward God; for it does not subject itself to the law of
          God, for it is powerless [oude dunamai] to do so. 8 So then those who are in the flesh are powerless
          [ou dunamai] to please God. (Rom 8:3-8; TM)

        The lost person does not have this internal power supply. Although the saved person has it internally, he or
she may not necessarily have it experientially. This much is self-evident from the text. That is, the believer may
have this power ontologically but not functionally. But if that is the case, then why could the reverse not be true?
Could not the unbeliever have this empowerment functionally restored but not have it ontologically? Just as Eve
acted contrary to her innocent nature and disbelieved God, so prevenient grace allows the sinners to act contrary to
their fallen nature and believe God. Sinners are responding to the prompting of the Holy Spirit rather than to their
fallen nature when they believe God. The power to please God is not found in one’s flesh but in the power of the
Spirit who provides the prompting.
        To further illustrate the difference between functional and ontological ability, believers are ontologically
incapable of sin.* However, at the prompting of their internal old nature, they may choose to sin, contrary to their
true, new nature. Thus, this disobedience to God is a functional rather than ontological response. When believers
reach heaven, they will no longer have an internal old nature. They will no longer have internal promptings to sin.
Hypothetically, suppose that sometime in the distant future another archangel were to choose to lead another
rebellion against God. Would this Satan II be able to entice glorified saints to follow him. Not hardly. Like Jesus,
such saints would be able to respond, “He has nothing in Me” (Jn 14:30). There would be nothing in the glorified
saint that would resonate with the external pitch of sin. In the similar manner, the Holy Spirit is able to strike a
chord in the sinner’s heart by appealing to the image of God within the sinner. This internal image makes
prevenient grace possible. The Holy Spirit does not need to recreate (i.e., regenerate) the image of God within the
sinner before appealing to the sinner. That image, though dead in terms of separation from God, is still able to hear
God when the Spirit of God comes to walk in what is left of the garden within his or her own heart and call his or
her name.

        Powerless to Please God
        God does not take pleasure in the death of the wicked (Eze 18:23,32; 33:11). Conversely, He does take
pleasure in the prolonging of their life. So even unbelievers can please God in a limited capacity by repenting of
their sins so that God temporally can prolong their lives. It would, therefore, be strange to assert that Paul is saying
in Rom 8:8 that unbelievers can do absolutely nothing that pleases God. There are at least two recourses by which
to harmonize Paul’s syntax and context with such OT texts. If ou dunamai in Rom 8:8 is taken to mean that the lost
do not have the power to please God, then it can be argued that prevenient grace provides them with the power in
terms of functional ability to do what they otherwise could not do: believe in Christ. Through prevenient grace they
are enabled to believe; subsequently, through regenerative grace they receive the power to become children of God
(Jn 1:12). This is certainly within the range of semantic possibilities and certainly fits the context: “Those who are
in the flesh are powerless to please God” (TM). This is the preferred generic response above. On the other hand,
there is another possibility in this particular context.

       Impossible to Please God
       Pleasing God is a matter of life and death, even for the believer in Rom 8:13. Therefore, pleasing God is
dealing with something other than merely becoming a child of God and possessing eternal life in Rom 8:8. Just as
one must first receive the gift of righteousness in order to be in a position that would enable one to reign in life
through Christ (Rom 5:17), so the imputation of righteousness precedes the regeneration of the spirit (Rom 8:10).

*
    See Appendix 4. Johannine Anamartetology, 769.
Page 224                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
Being alive in the spirit is the prerequisite for misthologically experiencing the life of the Spirit. But just because
believers are in the Spirit does not mean that they will please God in terms of meeting the misthological
requirements to experience eternal life misthologically either now or in the future. This misthological participation
in eternal life requires a spiritual mindset that is only possible to those who have the Spirit. Those in the flesh, on
the other hand, cannot do anything that will please God in terms of enabling them to experience eternal life
misthologically.
       To be sure, through the enabling power of the Spirit expressed in common grace, the lost can do things that
will please God in terms of allowing them temporally to experience and extend physical life. Nineveh is a case in
point. The people of Nineveh believed that God was going to judge them, repented, and gained an extension of
their physical lives (Jonah 3:5-6).378 Through the Spirit’s prevenient grace, the lost are also able to do things that
will enable them to come into soteriological possession of eternal life. Cornelius is a case in point. However, the
lost can do nothing at all that will please God in terms of enabling them to experience eternal life misthologically
because such participation in eternal life is dependent upon a spiritual walk and mindset which is only possible to
those who have the Spirit. Paul not only talks about the gift of life (Rom 6:23), but also about the reign of life
(Rom 5:17,21). The lost can do nothing that will enable them to experience eternal life in this misthological
dimension.
                                         Illustration 85. Trapped in a Bubble




       The author had a dog by the name of DJ and was well-pleased by his dog’s enthusiastic greeting when his
master returned home from work. Consequently, his master was well-pleased to bring back scraps of meat or bones
for DJ on occasions when the author and his family had been out to eat at a restaurant. Even so, there was
absolutely nothing that DJ could do that would please his owner in regards to being welcome to go with him and
his family to the restaurant and sit down with them at the table to enjoy a meal! DG is a dog. He is trapped in his
dog flesh. There is nothing he can do to please his owner in terms of being qualified for table fellowship in his
master’s house, much less for table fellowship in a restaurant. Similarly, there is absolutely nothing that those who
are in sinful flesh can do that will enable them to enjoy table fellowship with God their creator in the present or in
the future. Not even prevenient grace can change that fact. There is nothing that the lost can do that will please God
in terms of allowing them to enjoy this quality of life with God. They must first escape from the fleshly bubble by
becoming a new creature in Christ through faith.
       It takes regenerative grace to move one out of the sphere of sinful flesh into the Christological sphere. One
who has experienced regenerative grace is a new creature in Christ. Such a one has been transformed into a child of
God and is no longer in the sphere of sinful flesh. Nevertheless, just because a believer is a child of God does not
necessarily mean that he or she pleases God (1Cor 10:5; Heb 10:38). More than saving faith is necessary to qualify
for the quality of life depicted by table fellowship.* After one has escaped from the fleshly bubble through faith in
Christ, the believer can then start doing things that will please God in terms of qualifying to rule in the kingdom of

*
    See The Lord’s Banquet, 561.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                                 Page 225
God. Even a child of God cannot dine with the swine and expect to be welcome at the family table (Lk 15:15-24).
A choice must be made as to which type of dining experience a believer wants to have. The prodigal son was dead
in terms of table fellowship with his father. This wayward son had to repent in order to experience life at the family
table. Since his repentance preceded his coming to life, it is counter to the Calvinistic picture of regeneration
preceding conversion. He came from the far country before he came to life. He came to himself before he came to
his father. He was drawn to his father, by his memories of his father, before he was returned to life with his father.
Proponents of irresistible grace will have to look elsewhere than this context for a proof text.

                                                        1Cor 2:14
        One of the most popular Calvinistic proof texts using cannot (ou dunamai) to prove total inability is: “But a
natural man does not accept the things of the Spirit of God; for they are foolishness to him, and he cannot
understand them, because they are spiritually appraised” (1Cor 2:14). Non-Calvinistic responses tend to either
show that the context defines the things as (1) the deep things of God (1Cor 2:10), so that what is being denied is
the ability of the lost accurately to understand these deep things, or to assert that what is being denied is (2) the
ability of the lost to accept these things as true. Both assessments are correct, so I will simply combine them. The
lost have the natural ability to understand the necessary components of the gospel. It is a very simple message after
all. However, it is questionable whether they can fully grasp the deeper truths, since a few verses later Paul says
that even carnal believers cannot (oute dunamai) receive/understand the meat of the word (1Cor 3:2; MT). Or as
the writer of Hebrews terms it, they lack experiential knowledge associated with maturity (5:13). Even Peter found
it hard to understand some of Paul’s statements (2Pet 3:16).
        On the other hand, the lost can write commentaries and systematic theologies, so one suspects that more
than mere lack of intellectual perception is being denied. Since it is certain that the lost do not accept the gospel as
true, it is reasonable to extend the teaching of this text deductively to acknowledge that the lost can understand the
gospel (in terms of notitia). But they do not understand how it can be true, so they do not assent to its truth and
accept it as being true (in terms of assensus). Therefore, they do not reflexively trust (fiducia) in the truth of this
message for salvation.* By way of application at least, it may be conceded to the Calvinist that the natural person
cannot accept the truth of the gospel. I concur with White that the lost can completely understand the gospel, but
“the term ‘understand’ should be taken as it is used in this passage: the natural man cannot accept and embrace
spiritual things.”379 Yet in contrast to White, I believe that prevenient grace makes it possible for the natural person
to do something which he is constitutionally able to do but pragmatically unable to do, namely, accept the gospel
as being true. Calvinists believe that it takes irresistible grace to cause the lost to believe. Marrowists believe that it
takes enabling grace to enable the lost to believe.
        The context, nonetheless, is describing the process of inspiration. Paul is claiming verbal inspiration (as
inerrantists correctly point out). His primary concern is to defend the message of his ministry, not to discuss what
is necessary for the natural person to accept his message. Thus, he mentions the natural person’s inability without
specifically addressing what action of the Spirit is necessary to overcome that inability. This passage only affirms
the necessity of ability, and the doctrine of prevenient grace supplies that ability.

Biblical Irresistible Grace
       God was able to foresee those who would trust Christ and has predestined that those who respond positively
to His drawing and who trust in Christ as their Savior would be in Christ. God permits Satan to oppose His efforts
in drawing men to faith. In the tug-of-war going on in the spiritual dimension within the human heart, God allows
Satan to blind as the Holy Spirit seeks to enlighten. Yet God will only go so far in permitting Satan to blind
humanity. God normally does not take away a person’s free will, nor does He usually allow Satan to do so. God
makes it possible for a person to exercise free will in responding to one pull or the other. As a rule, any given
individual is not free from being pulled but enabled by God to respond to either pull. There are limits of course on
a person’s freedom.
       As noted before, libertarianism involves a measure of freedom, not absolute freedom. The NOSAS
argument that OSAS violates libertarianism is thus false. NOSAS falsely charges OSAS with being logically
inconsistent in affirming libertarianism even though OSAS affirms that a believer no longer can choose hell.†
Although libertarian freedom necessarily entails the ability to choose between two or more options, libertarianism

*
  See “Three-element FG View of Faith” in Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
†
  NOSAS insists that if we can come into possession of eternal life by our own free will, then we must be able to forfeit possession of
eternal life by our own free will. This fallacy in logic fails to acknowledge that some results freely entered into cannot be freely exited.
Page 226                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
does not necessarily mean that we can determine what those options are. Adam was not given a choice to be a
Martian or a fish. Just as we have no choice over some matters, some options also involve results over which we
have no freedom of choice. Adam was not free to choose to eat the forbidden fruit and yet choose not to die. God
promised death if Adam ate, so Adam was not free to choose to eat and yet choose not to die. Just as we cannot
choose to cut off our heads and yet choose not to die, Adam could not choose to eat the fruit and not die as a result.
In OSAS we likewise affirm that if a person partakes of the living water by believing in Jesus for eternal life, then
that individual has forfeited his or her option to die since Jesus has promised that such a person will never die or
thirst for spiritual water again (Jn 4:14; 11:26).
        Therefore, OSAS libertarianism simply takes God at His word. Even though a choice is placed before an
individual, as to whether to become a child of God by immutably sharing in God’s nature by receiving eternal life,
one is not given a choice to become a child of God and not immutably share in His life. In other words, just as
Adam could not eat the fruit and subsequently choose not to die, one cannot choose to drink living water and
subsequently choose not to live eternally. Logical consistency rules out the possibility of NOSAS. Once a person
becomes a child of God by sharing in God’s immutable nature, spiritual death becomes ontologically impossible
because one has undergone a transformation in which one immutably shares in a new nature which cannot die.
Logically, since God cannot die, neither can His children (at least not ontologically) since they ontologically share
in His immutable nature.*
        To illustrate, God has so designed the natural transformation of a caterpillar so that it may become a
butterfly, but God has not provided a reverse process whereby a butterfly may become a caterpillar. Likewise, the
fact that God has provided us with an option by which we can undergo a supernatural transformation in which we
pass ontologically and immutably from death into life does not (indeed logically cannot) mean that God must
likewise give us the option to pass in the same manner back into death. Otherwise, the original offer of immutably
passing from death into life by ontologically sharing God’s nature was not a legitimate offer.
        Furthermore, just as the ability to choose between two or more options also does not necessarily entail the
ability to forgo the results of that choice, libertarianism also does not necessarily entail the ability to undo that
choice. The ability to choose one option does not automatically carry with it the ability to go back and undo that
choice and decide to choose the second option instead. For example, the person who chooses to kill herself cannot
turn around later and decide to unkill herself. Some choices have irreversible consequences. Correspondingly, the
freedom to choose heaven by believing in Christ does not necessarily entail the right to subsequently change one’s
mind and choose hell by disbelieving in Christ. To be sure, a person may cease to believe in Christ, but this does
not mean that one forfeits the eternal life which one has come to possess. The option to receive eternal life must
inherently result in the forfeiture of the option to experience death in the manner ruled out by reception of life that
is eternal.
        Adam did not have to continue to eat the fruit in order to die. One bite was sufficient. Just as the eater could
not forgo the consequence of having eaten by ceasing to eat, so the believer cannot undo the consequence of having
taken a drink by ceasing to drink. Just as one bite transformed Adam’s nature, one drink transforms the believer’s
nature. Neither the eater or the drinker has a choice as to whether to forgo the transformation. Likewise, the drinker
of living water has no choice regarding undoing the results of the transformation resulting in the possession of
eternal life since it involves an immutable participation in eternal life at the ontological level.
        On the negative side of limited libertarianism, if a person persists in following Satan, then God may indeed
give such a person over to Satan, allowing Satan eventually to harden such an individual’s heart beyond
remediation.† The unpardonable state is a point of hardening that a person ultimately may reach; it does not
describe an individual’s initial state. A person may forfeit his or her free will to Satan over a period of time. On the
positive side of self-determinism, believers forfeit their right to determine their soteriological future once they
entrust Christ with their future. Once they trust in Christ alone for eternal life, they have no choice as to whether
they are positionally and legally in Christ or will go to heaven. This aspect of God’s election and grace is
absolutely irresistible. Once you trust in Christ alone for eternal life, you eternally have forfeited your ability to
choose hell. You have forfeited your free will concerning overriding your previous response. God’s grace will
irresistibly take you to heaven. Indeed, irresistible grace (when understood in this capacity) is biblical and goes by
the name of unconditional security. Unlike Calvinistic unconditional election (or Calvinistic irresistible grace), the
biblical counterpart does not determine who will believe; rather, it determines that whosoever believes will never
thirst again for spiritual life (Jn 4:14; 6:35).

*
    See “Trichotomous Classification” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
†
    See Appendix 10. The Unpardonable Sin, 831.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                            Page 227
Resistible Grace
       In His love, God desires and provides abundant life and full misthological salvation to all His children. But
the Lord conditions these special experiences with Him on obedience to Him. In His foreknowledge, God foresaw
that not all of His children would choose to obey Him. God determined ahead of time that they should obey Him,
but He does not force them to obey. This aspect of His will is not irresistible. They should obey Him, but this does
not inevitably mean that they will. Those who in the previous illustration* were pictured as going to the outer
darkness were believers who could have and should have lived for Christ, but they were unwilling to do so. Those
of His children who do not obey Him will be with Him in His kingdom, but they will not rule with Him. On the
other hand, God has predetermined that those who do obey Him will rule with Him in heaven.
                                                Illustration 86. Should/Would




        The logical order, then, is that God has predetermined that everyone in the world should believe and has
determined to provide salvation for all of lost humanity. Nevertheless, He could foresee that not all would believe.
But He predestined that those who would believe would be in Christ. These are the ones whom the Bible describes
as elected in Christ before the foundation of the world (Eph 1:4). Their names are also said to be in the Book of
Life from the foundation of the world (Rev 17:8). Election is thus corporate and particular. Each believer is
corporately in Christ, and every believer’s name is personally recorded in the Book of Life. From the very
beginning, God knew there would be believers and unbelievers and determined their corporate and personal fate.
He has conditioned that fate on their response to Him. He determined that those who would respond in faith by
trusting in Christ as their Savior would be placed corporately in Christ and personally have eternal life. He further
determined that those believers who subsequently follow Christ as their Lord in a life of faithfulness would be co-
glorified with Christ in the kingdom.

                                                Double Predestination
       Calvinists who are consistent with their own theological paradigm believe in double predestination: (1) God
unconditionally has predetermined who would believe and thus go to heaven, and (2) God unconditionally has
predetermined who would disbelieve and thus go to hell. They believe that just as there is predestination unto
salvation, there is also predestination unto perdition, otherwise known as reprobation. In Calvinistic terminology,
predestination is composed of two parts: election and reprobation. The former is positive; the latter is negative. I
will not be maintaining this strict technical distinction between election and predestination, choosing rather to use
the terms synonymously at times. Theologically, the legitimacy of Marrowistic double predestination and free will
was acknowledged in Illustration 77. Predestination (p. 189) and thus should be distinguished from the
unconditional double predestination of Calvinism. Marrowism takes a combination of conditional and
unconditional predestination: God has predetermined that those who reject Christ will conditionally go to hell and
that those who believe in Christ will go to heaven unconditionally. God conditionally has predestined to save those
who believe. Their salvation is conditioned on whether they believe. On the other hand, God has predetermined
that once a person believes that individual will unconditionally reach heaven, even if he or she ceases to believe.
Salvation is no longer conditional once the person already has met the single condition of punctiliar faith.

*
    See Illustration 77. Predestination, 189.
Page 228                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
       In objection to double predestination, others point out that the terms for predestination and election are only
used in a positive sense in Scripture and would thus prefer this latter illustration.* Linguistically, they are correct.
The latter illustration is much more positive in that it does not show hell or the outer darkness as being in the scope
of predestination. Linguistically speaking, the second position is correct, and this must be kept in mind when
interpreting the meaning of these words in any particular passage. The words convey a positive implication.
However, logically and conceptually speaking, there is truth in the more negative diagram as well. Although
Rev 20:11-15 does not use the words predestination or election, it is nevertheless quite evident that God already
has decided from the foundation of the world that unbelievers whose names are not in the Book of Life will be
thrown into the Lake of Fire. Theologically speaking, God has predestined these unbelievers to hell (in the sense of
predetermined that they will go to hell), since their names are absent from the Book of Life from the foundation of
the world.† Our conceptual understanding of what predestination means should not be limited to those passages in
which the particular word is found.380 Conceptual parallels must also be incorporated. God foreknows who will
refuse to trust Christ and has predetermined that those who reject Christ will go to hell. The scene described in
Rev 20:11-15 reflects this theological truth.
       The concept of predestination thus would include negative passages such as Rev 20:11-15 and positive
passages like Jn 3:16. Theologically speaking, speaking of God’s foreknowledge and predestination of the lost is
permissible. These concepts logically extend to them. The present discussion is a blend of linguistical and
theological meanings. Linguistically speaking, it cannot be said that God has predestined the lost to hell. Logically
speaking, it could be said that He has indeed predetermined that the lost will go to hell. In order to balance logic
with linguistics, it is best to stress the positive and condition the negative. With these thoughts in mind, the present
model does allow one to speak in terms of a double predestination which includes the lost. What is denied is that
God has predetermined who will believe or who will disbelieve. On the contrary, God predetermined that all
should believe. And He predestined that those who do believe will go to glory in heaven and that those who
disbelieve will go to suffer in hell. Like Forlines, I object to unconditional double predestination, not to conditional
double predestination.381

Amyraldianism
        Since the model employed herein has a limited kinship with the mediating system of Amyraldianism (in
implementing a combination of conditional and unconditional election), a word of explanation and differentiation
is in order. Amyraldianism is derived from the teachings of Moise Amyraut, who in turn further developed the
teachings of his mentor John Cameron.382 His meditating position between Calvinism and Arminianism is
substantially Calvinistic and is often referred to as four-point Calvinism: TULIP – L = TUIP. That is, he
advocated a universal rather than limited atonement. His dual perspective of the atonement might be summarized
as saying that Christ died sufficiently for all but efficiently only for the elect. If this were taken simply to mean that
Christ died universally for everyone (in the sense of making everyone savable) but that the benefits of Christ’s
death are limited imputationally to those who trust in Christ as Savior, then all would be well and good, and I could
concur with the duality of his unlimited and limited atonement. The atonement is unlimited in extent, but limited in
effect. It is limited in its subjective application to those who believe but universal in its objective provision to
unbelievers. However, Amyraut’s view of election is what causes a problem.
        Appreciably, Amyraut perceives a dichotomy in God’s election as unconditional and conditional. He
believes that God conditionally and universally elected to save all who believe, but unfortunately Amyraut chooses
to limit those who would believe to those whom he believes God unconditionally has selected to believe through
irresistible grace. His twofold approach to election and atonement allows him to adopt a universal atonement and
election. But the benefits of the atonement and conditional election are only applicable to those whom God
unconditionally had elected. Therein lies a major difference between his approach and mine. In his model, God
decided to save everyone who expressed saving faith but only chose to give saving faith to an arbitrary few.383
        The alternative model herein likewise advocates a combination of unconditional and conditional election,
but at its core is an Arminian distinction between foreknowledge and predestination, which is in stark contrast to
the irresistible Calvinistic decree found at the bottom of Amyraut’s theological well. His Calvinistic presupposition
is evident in the second half of this Amyraldian summary: (A) God conditionally has decided to soteriologically
save all who believe but (B) unconditionally decided to irresistibly cause certain ones to believe. God forechose
those who would believe.

*
    See Illustration 86. Should/Would, 227.
†
    See The Believer’s Name in Rev 3:5, 490.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                             Page 229
        In contrast, the foreknowledge aspect of the Marrowistic model is evident in the second part of my
statement: (A) God conditionally has decided to soteriologically save all who believe and (B) unconditionally
decided to save those who do believe. God foreknew who would believe. In this Marrowistic model, God
foreknew who would believe and unconditionally has granted them eternal security. Unlike Amyraut’s moderate
Calvinistic approach, the Marrowistic model does not espouse irresistible grace or the other remnants of the
TULIP. All may believe. God has not limited the efficaciousness of the atonement to the elect whom He has
irresistibly chosen to believe. Instead, God has chosen to condition our salvation from hell on our response to the
gospel. Humanity has free will. God does not irresistibly make this choice for humanity. God also has chosen to
condition a believer’s salvation from the outer darkness on the believer’s choice. A believer’s practical
sanctification may be retrogressive rather than progressive.* A believer may fall from grace rather than grow in
grace.† In summary, Amyraldianists are to be commended for recognizing that predestination is a combination of
conditional and unconditional election. But where Marrowism parts company with Amyraldianism on this matter is
that the Marrowistic model is based on foreknowledge rather than forechoice. Thus, the model used herein is a
combination Amyraldian dichotomy and Arminian prescience (Amy-Arm) to yield a defense of eternal security
based on foreseen faith. Of course, the affirmation of Arminian prescience is to be understood as an acceptance of
their distinction between foreknowing and forechoosing and basing the latter on the former. This Marrowistic
model is not Arminian, though, in that it rejects the Arminian perspective that God also choose to condition the
believer’s security on the believer’s foreseen perseverance.

Objections

                                                  Rom 8:29
       A common objection to the foreknowledge position regarding Rom 8:29 points out that the verse does not
say that God foresaw the person’s faith but the person himself. God is the one performing the action in the five
verbs. So foreknowledge is predicated on God’s action rather than our reaction.
          29
            For whom He foreknew, He also predestined to become conformed to the image of His Son, that
          He might be the first-born among many brethren; 30 and whom He predestined, these He also called;
          and whom He called, these He also justified; and whom He justified, these He also glorified. (Rom
          8:29-30)

       Linguistically speaking, Calvinists posit that foreknowledge (proginosko) can refer to God’s active selection
of certain persons for intimate association. On this basis, it is argued that, since foreknowledge can be equated with
God forechoosing the person himself, God forechose the person to believe rather than forechose the person who
believes. But this is an unnecessary inference.
                                            Illustration 87. The Steps of Rom 8:29-30


                                                             5. Glorified


                                                          4. Justified


                                                          3. Called


                                                     2. Predestined


                                                     1. Foreknew

*
    See Retrogressive Sanctification, 674.
†
    See Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Page 230                                                                                           The Outer Darkness


        Who are the ones God foreknows? Those who would believe are the ones who are foreknown. The passage
does not say that God has predestined us to believe but rather to become conformed to the image of His son.
Assuming soteriological motifs are in view, then the affirmation that John makes of all believers is pertinent:
“When He appears, we shall be like Him, because we shall see Him just as He is” (1Jn 3:2). Who will be
transformed into His likeness when they see Him? Believers. Who are those who are justified in the book of
Romans? Believers. God predestines those whom He knows will believe. Five logically sequential and
distinguishable steps are evident in this passage. Foreknowing cannot be equated with forechoosing because each
of these steps logically and contextually are distinguished from one another.
        To continue with this line of inquiry, to whom does the us refer in Eph 1:4? “He chose us in Him before the
foundation of the world.” It refers to those who would believe. The fact that the foreknowledge pertains to whom
rather than what or that does not nullify the discernment that foreknowledge pertains to foreseen faith. Granted, the
text does not state what God foreknew or that He foreknew their faith. Foreknowledge of the person himself or
herself rather than of some event (such as the faith that the person would express) is affirmed. So technically, the
passage simply is affirming that God chose the believer. Although the text does not explicitly state that God
foreknew something about these believers, would it not stand to reason that in foreknowing the person God also
foreknows something about that person—in reality, everything about that person? The person is not just a name in
a hat. God foreknows the person himself or herself—what he or she would be and do. Or as TY relates, Justin
Martyr said that God foreknew those who would believe in Christ.384 God foreknew those who would come to faith
in Christ and accordingly chose them to be in Christ before the foundation of the world so that their names are in
the Book of Life from the foundation of the world.
        This assessment is not only logical, it is also lexical and syntactical. Gordon Olson provides an extended
quotation from Edgar’s study of the syntactical relationship between foreknowledge and pronouns used in
reference to people. Most significantly, Paul says that the Jews foreknew him:

      So then, all Jews know (oida) my manner of life from my youth up, which from the beginning was
      spent among my own nation and at Jerusalem; since they have known (proginosko) about me for a
      long time previously, if they are willing to testify, that I lived as a Pharisee according to the strictest
      sect of our religion. (Acts 26:4-5)

        The word about, used in connection with foreknowledge, is supplied by the NAS translators and rightly so.
It is not impersonal knowledge. The verb indicates more than just knowing a person’s name. As Edgar states, “To
‘foreknow’ a person means to know something about that person beforehand” (emphasis his).385 Nor is it intimate
knowledge. These Jews accusing Paul before the officials are not his buddies! The present tense of foreknow
shows that, although these Jews still have foreknowledge of Paul, they have no intimacy with him. Foreknowledge
is not necessarily intimate knowledge. They foreknew him; that is, for a long time previously they knew that he
lived as a strict Pharisee. The word that (hoti) expresses the content of what they knew about him.
        The assertion by BDAG that proginosko means to choose beforehand in this passage is ludicrous. Paul is
not saying that all Jews chose him, much less that all Jews still choose him! Rather, they retain their prior
knowledge of his manner of life. Paul is certainly not saying that all Jews choose his manner of life for him, either
in the past or present. BDAG would have done much better to have listed this verse under its other lexical heading
of simply meaning to know beforehand or in advance. The same may be said concerning Rom 8:29. The fact that
God foreknew them means that God had prior knowledge about them, specifically about what they would believe.
The verb proginosko does not mean to choose beforehand. Rather, it means to know beforehand. Just as the Jews
foreknowing Paul meant they foreknew something about him, so God foreknowing us means that He foreknows
something about us. He knows that we will believe.

      1. To foreknow someone is to foreknow something about that person.
      2. God foreknew those whom He predestined.
      3. Therefore, God knew something about those whom He predestined.

      God did not randomly, arbitrarily, or mysteriously choose names out of a hat when He predestined a certain
group for glory. There was something about those whom He predestined that logically resulted in Him selecting
them and not others. Their free response of faith logically determined His selection of them. God already had
decided to save those who would believe, but their belief is what put them in the category of those who would be
saved. Although their free, intellectual response of faith chronologically came after His selection, it logically
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 231
predetermined His selection. In terms of logical sequence, individuals predetermine their own predestination.
God predestined us because we believe.*
        The meaning of to choose beforehand is conveyed by other verbs. In Eph 1:4, God chose (eklego) those who
would believe in Christ to be in Christ before the foundation of the world. Believers are the ones whom are
foreknown and forechosen to be in Christ. God has forechosen believers for an intimate relationship, namely a
Father-son relationship. To be sure, since this is a pre-temporal selection, God chose us while we were still
unbelievers. As a result, some postulate that election is of sinners to believe rather than of saints because they have
believed. But again, this assumption is unnecessary. There is no reason to suppose that God’s pre-temporal action
of election must await our temporal response of believing. It could just as well be presumed that His pre-temporal
action is based on His pre-temporal knowledge of those who would believe. Theologically speaking,
foreknowledge can refer to God’s knowledge of who would believe. God foreknows the believer. In turn, God’s
predestination logically could be based on His foreknowledge of who would believe. In terms of logical sequence
at least, foreknowledge comes before predestination.
        Thus, even if (for the sake of argument) the Calvinistic assumption that foreknowledge includes the idea of
forechoosing is granted, foreknowledge is not limited to this meaning—certainly not theologically and probably
not linguistically. In His foreknowledge, God foreknows who will believe and has chosen these believers for an
intimate relationship. So even if we perform a marriage of linguistical data and theological presuppositions to
conclude that foreknowledge includes intimate selection, it still may be postulated that such selection is based on
prior knowledge. Sellers acknowledges that in 2Pet 3:17 foreknowledge means “only advance knowledge”
(emphasis his).386 It does not mean to forechoose. But he then proceeds to argue that in passages where God is the
subject, the word changes meaning and does mean to forechoose. He filters his understanding of the linguistical
data through his theological lens. However, Olson shows the weakness of that approach,

       This is a defective methodology which implies that a verb changes its meaning dependent upon who
       the subject is. Other verbs do not change meaning when God is the subject….Since God uses human
       language to reveal Himself, if word meanings change when used of God, all objective
       communication is lost.387

        In addition to implementing this defective methodological procedure, White also uses a defective
grammatical deduction: “The term foreknow is an active verb. The way it is portrayed in evangelical tradition
would not be something God does but instead would involve God passively taking in knowledge from an outside
source” (emphasis his).388 White simplistically equates the active voice with taking action. This is an
oversimplification. Among other things, the simple active can mean to experience the action. It can refer to actively
experiencing knowledge or emotion for example. It does not necessarily mean to actively cause some outside
action.
        In 2Pet 3:17 just mentioned above, the believer’s active foreknowledge of the Scripture twisting that was
sure to come (3:16) does not cause that distortion nor the destruction of those who would so distort it. Their
foreknowledge, although in the active voice, is not causative. On the other hand, even if it were in the passive, it
would not establish what White imagines. Peter uses it in the passive in 1Pet 1:20 to say that Jesus was “foreknown
before the foundation of the world.” Does this use of the passive voice for God’s foreknowledge mean that the
Father had to look outside of Himself to find out what the Son would do? Not hardly.
        Agreement with White that God does not use a crystal ball or with Craig that God does not actually use a
time telescope does not prevent me from finding such anthropomorphic descriptions useful, and I would not deride
the popular evangelist for using such anthropomorphism, especially since Scripture itself does so in terms of seeing
the future.† Still, in terms of technical accuracy, it would be better to describe the event as God looking within
Himself and thus knowing the future by virtue of His innate knowledge. Jesus’ intuitive knowledge may serve as a
feasible illustration: “And immediately Jesus, aware in His spirit that they were reasoning that way within
themselves, said to them, ‘Why are you reasoning about these things in your hearts?’” (Mk 2:8)
        God is able to look within Himself to find out everything He desires to know innately. I would suggest that
God is able to look without Himself to have an open view experience when He so chooses. However, such matters
are dealt with elsewhere‡ and need not detract from the fact that God’s active knowledge is not causative. White
has overstated his case in appealing to the active tense of this cognitive function. Internal, intellectual awareness is
*
  See Predestination and the Open View.
†
  See Predestination and the Open View.
‡
  See “Foreknowledge is Foresight” in Predestination and the Open View.
Page 232                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
not causative of past, present, or future events. Foreknowledge is not causative, regardless of whether it is active or
passive. Our active knowledge of the past, present, or future does not cause the past, present, or future. For
example, when Paul uses the active tense to say, “I know you will” (Phlm 1:21), his active knowledge does not
cause or force Philemon to do what Paul knows Philemon will do.

                                                     1Pet 1:2
       Sellers appeals to the linguistic evidence in order to rule out the theological possibility of predestination
being based on foreknowledge in his discussion of the nominal form of foreknowledge (prognosis) in 1Pet 1:2.

          In this passage it can be seen “foreknowledge” cannot be merely equated with prescience. Their
          election is not said to be based upon divine foreknowledge of their obedience to the gospel. To the
          contrary, rather than foreknowledge of obedience, it is foreknowledge unto (Greek eivj [eis])
          obedience. They were elect unto obedience to the gospel. (Emphasis his.)389

        Sellers’ position leads to the theological conclusion that God sovereignly decides who will obey the gospel,
which means that God irresistibly predetermines who will become a believer. According to his view then, those
who do not believe do not believe because God did not decide that they would believe. This in effect means that
God decided that they would not believe. They go to hell because God decided not to save them. He decided not to
make it possible for them to believe. Yet this understanding fails on the basis of syntax and context. The KJV
renders 1Pet 1:2 as: “Elect according to (kata) the foreknowledge of God the Father, through sanctification of the
Spirit, unto (eis) obedience and sprinkling of the blood of Jesus Christ.” Does the verse say that we are foreknown
unto obedience? No, it does not. We are elected unto obedience. It is a syntactical fallacy to say that we are
foreknown unto obedience. Rather, we are elected for the purpose of obeying Jesus and being sprinkled with His
blood. This is the goal. Eis (unto; KJV) in this context shows intended result.*
          1
           Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who reside as aliens, dispersed throughout Pontus, Galatia,
          Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia, who are chosen 2 according to the foreknowledge of God the Father,
          by the sanctifying work of the Spirit, so that you may obey Jesus Christ and be sprinkled with His
          blood as a result: May grace and peace be yours in fullest measure. (1Pet 1:1-2; TM)

       As Gordon Olson explains, the syntax shows that election is based upon foreknowledge in this passage.
Election is according to (kata), that is, governed by foreknowledge. Edgar likewise concludes: Foreknowledge is
the ground or reason for the electing.” The verse “refers to believers as those who are elected according to God’s
foreknowledge.”390 Foreknowledge comes first. It is primary.† This primacy is also theologically necessary;
otherwise, you would have God’s essential attribute of omniscience dependent upon His action. In other words,
God would be taking action before He knows what would happen, which Olson likens to picturing God as blindly
throwing darts.391

                                                 Whosoever Will
        The implication of verses such as Jn 3:16-18 and Rev 22:17 is that whosoever will may come.392 Salvation is
provided for everyone—the whole world (Jn 1:29; 4:42; 6:51; 1Tim 2:4-6; 4:10; Tit 2:11; Heb 2:9; 1Jn 2:2; 4:14).
The offer of salvation must include with it the ability to appropriate that offer, that is, to believe. Imagine going to
