the zoo and holding out a banana to a monkey in the cage but holding it just out of his reach. The monkey holds out
his hand, and you hold out yours. But you do not stretch out your arm so that the monkey can take the banana. Can
it really be said that you desire for the monkey to have the banana, or that you legitimately are offering it to him?
Not really. Yet if you reach out your arm far enough to make it possible for the monkey to take it, then a legitimate
offer has been made, even if the monkey refuses. You made it possible for him to have taken it, even if he chose
not to do so.




*
    See “Inheritance of Salvation” (1Pet 1:5) in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
†
    For a more thorough interaction with alternatives, such as Geisler’s simultaneous election, see Predestination and the Open View.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 233
                            Illustration 88. Not Forechosen from a Calvinistic Perspective




        The Calvinistic perspective of foreknowledge bars unbelievers who are not chosen from believing the
gospel. They cannot believe because God never planned for them to believe. They cannot because God would not.
The Calvinist picture is of a God who is not willing to make a realistic offer of salvation to the nonelect. He has
forechosen to not make them a legitimate offer of salvation. God may tantalize them with the offer of salvation.
But He certainly has made certain that they cannot actually receive it.
        White considers this is a false characterization of the Calvinistic position: “While unregenerate men may
know the facts of the gospel, they have no desire to believe in the Lord Jesus Christ and cast themselves solely
upon him?”393 White expands upon this statement: “Those who are condemned never so much as desired to repent,
reveled in their sin, and will stand upon the parapets of hell screaming their hatred of God in eternity to come,
proving the justice of God’s condemnation of them” (emphasis his). And he accuses Hunt of misrepresentation:
“Hunt’s misrepresentation of this reality is meant to convey the idea that the nonelect may desire to repent”
(emphasis his).394
        This counter by White is scripturally unacceptable for multiple reasons. First, as Walls and Dongell
repeatedly point out, in Calvinism the reason that the nonelect do not desire salvation is because God was
unwilling to make them willing. The Calvinistic God did not desire to create a desire within the nonelect. This
Reformed God irresistibly makes the elect willing, so He could have done the same thing for the nonelect—if He
had chosen to do so. Instead, this Calvinistic God refuses to make the nonelect thirsty for the water of life, and this
is the reason they refuse to drink it.
        Second, the Scripture indicates that many of the unregenerate desire to be saved. Will White acknowledge
that the five foolish virgins are elect? After all, they desperately desired to enter the marriage celebration, saying,
“Lord, lord, open up for us” (Mt 25:11)? If he does not acknowledge that they are elect, then how does he explain
their desire to enter? Is it the elect or nonelect who stand before God seeking entrance into the kingdom saying,
“Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in Your name, and in Your name cast out demons, and in Your name perform
many miracles?” (Mt 7:22) If it is the nonelect who are excluded, then to what does White attribute their desire to
enter? Contrary to White, many of the lost desire to be saved now, and most, if not all, will desire to be saved then.
They will not be beating down the bars of hell trying to get into hell! Third, Calvinism teaches that God makes
some of the nonelect just thirsty enough to sip the water of life and taste it so that they think that they are elect
(e.g., Heb 6:4-6), but not thirsty enough to drink it and continue doing so. As a result, these thirsty nonelect sippers
end up going to hell because they did not persevere. And they do not persevere because God did not give them
sufficient thirst to drink and keep on drinking.

Temporary Faith
      What Calvinism is this that White describes for us? Is White trying to conceal the darker side of
Calvinism—temporary faith? In his Institutes, Calvin has this to say about the temporary faith of the nonelect:
Page 234                                                                                             The Outer Darkness


       Hence it is not strange, that by the Apostle a taste of heavenly gifts, and by Christ himself a
       temporary faith, is ascribed to them. Not that they truly perceive the power of spiritual grace and
       the sure light of faith; but the Lord, the better to convict them, and leave them without excuse,
       instills into their minds such a sense of his goodness as can be felt without the Spirit of adoption.395

According to Calvin, the temporary faith ascribed to the nonelect is instilled into them by the Lord so that He can
have even better grounds for condemning them for not having the genuine faith, which He refused to give to them!
By the power of His Holy Spirit, God irresistibly causes the nonelect temporarily to believe in order to deceive
them into thinking they are genuine believers so that He might be better excused for condemning them for not
continuing to believe. God causes them temporarily to believe so that He can then turn around and condemn them
for not continuing to believe. In this way, God gets to condemn them for apostasy.
        If God had not caused them to believe, then He could not condemn them for apostasy because they would
never have believed in the first place and thus would have been unable to commit apostasy in the second place. So
God is pleased Calvinistically to make the nonelect believe so that He can pull the rug out from under them and
convict them for falling into apostasy. Of course, these apostates could not have done otherwise than fall since God
had no intention of enabling them to stand. Yet this poses no problem for Calvinism. The Calvinistic picture of
God is that He causes them to thirst and drink sufficiently so as to sip and believe temporarily, but such faith fails
in the end because God did not intend for it to persevere to the end.
        It would be somewhat analogous to a firefighter going down into a dry well and tying a lifeline around an
injured woman with broken arms and hosting her halfway up out of the well and then cutting the rope so that she
can fall back unto the rocks below so that he can lambaste her for not making it out of the well. In this way, the
firefighter can better berate her: “Hey, I helped her up halfway. I gave her a fighting chance.” Then the firefighter
can turn to the bystanders and say, “It is her fault that she did not persevere in getting out of that well.”
        To be fair to the Calvinistic firefighter, perhaps I should picture the woman as cursing the firefighter from
the pain of the ordeal, as she is pulled up out of the well and screaming at the firefighter to let her die. After all, it
can be a painful ordeal to be pulled up out of a pit with broken bones as one hits the jutting rocks of life that come
at one from all sides. Accordingly, it would be best to keep one’s mouth shut because the Calvinistic God may cut
the rope otherwise. On the other hand, maybe the woman was pleading rather and cursing. Perhaps, she was
begging this Calvinistic firefighter to not cut the rope. But the firefighter did so anyway in order to fill his desire to
tally up the number of apostates.
        Although White may say that the nonelect have no desire to be saved or get out of the well or seek God,
Calvin says otherwise:

       There is the greater reason to fear that sparks of faith, which make their appearance in us, may be
       extinguished; for, although lively faith, which has its roots deeply fixed by the Spirit of regeneration,
       never dies, yet we have seen formerly that many conceive a temporary faith, which immediately
       disappears. Above all, it is too common a disease that, when we are urged by strong necessity, and
       when the Lord himself prompts us by a secret movement of the Spirit, we seek God, but, when
       we have obtained our wishes, ungrateful forgetfulness swallows up that feeling of piety. Thus poverty
       and hunger beget faith, but abundance kills it.396

        Calvin says that the nonelect in this passage “eagerly embrace the Gospel, and shortly afterwards fall off; for
they have not the lively affection that is necessary to give them firmness and perseverance.”397 According to
Kuyper, the closest type of faith to saving faith is temporary faith, “Temporary faith comes nearest, which is
indeed wrought by the Holy Spirit, and affords a taste of the heavenly gifts, but which has not root in itself”
(emphasis his).398 The Holy Spirit causes such unbelievers to think that they are saved. Boettner adds, “Often times
it is impossible for an observer or even the person himself to distinguish these experiences from those of the truly
regenerated.”399 The assurance wrought by the Holy Spirit in the heart of such unbelievers is indiscernible by them
or anyone else as being a soteriologically defective faith. Accordingly, in Calvinistic theology not only may the
lost desire to be saved and trust in Christ; it may be impossible for them or anyone else to tell if the faith they
currently are experiencing is genuine or not. The Holy Spirit temporarily has fooled them into thinking that they
are believers! Calvinism is devastating to the doctrine of assurance.
        For present purposes, it is sufficient to note that the Calvinistic God causes people to seek Him and want to
be saved and gives them sufficient faith to make them think that they are saved and yet withholds saving faith from
them. If anything, the above depiction of the Calvinistic God standing outside the bars withholding the banana is
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                             Page 235
much too mild. More realistically, the fuller horrific form of the Calvinistic formulation would have God electing
to let one of the monkeys out of the cage and feed him the banana in front of the nonelect monkey behind the bars.
Then God throws the banana peel into the cage so that the caged monkey can think he is getting a real banana.
Sadly, the caged monkey only subsequently finds out he only has been given the peel in this sadistic scheme of
events. Evidently, it sadistically pleased God to tantalize and fool the caged monkey into thinking he was
genuinely being offered a real banana.400

Unwilling
        In contrast, the model proposed herein is that God has given a legitimate invitation to each of the lost
without exception. It is possible for everyone to believe. God’s will is for all to come to faith in the gospel
(1Tim 2:4). His will is not for any to perish (Mt 18:14; 2Pet 3:9). The question of willingness is on the part of the
individual, not on the part of God. “O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, who kills the prophets and stones those who are sent
to her! How often I wanted to gather your children together, the way a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and
you were unwilling” (Mt 23:37). “You are unwilling to come to Me, that you may have life” (Jn 5:40). These
plain statements, coupled with the numerous exhortations for the lost to believe the gospel, indicate that it is
possible for the lost to do so.
        White seeks to limit the word Jerusalem to Jewish leaders (who oppose Jesus, Mt 23:13ff) and children to
the general Jewish populace of Jerusalem. His purpose in doing so is to restrict the unwillingness expressed by you
to that of the Jewish leaders and to limit Jesus’ desire to save those over whom He wept to the common people.401
In other words, Jesus purportedly desired to save the common people rather than their Jewish leaders, and the
unwillingness that prevented Him from saving the common people was that of their leaders rather than their own.
However, in the parallel Lukan account, Luke did not see any need to give an indication that there was a limitation
of the rejection to that of the leaders in order to understand Jesus’ meaning (Lk 13:34).
        White’s exegesis is built upon a false dichotomy between the attitude of the people and their leaders toward
Jesus. Matthew clearly shows that the multitudes were persuaded by their leaders to cry out for the crucifixion of
Jesus (Mt 27:20). The general populace shared the unwillingness of their leaders in their rejection of Jesus. “And
all the people answered and said, ‘His blood be on us and on our children!’” (Mt 27:25). The unwillingness to
believe in Jesus was not limited to the leaders (Mt 22:13; Lk 19:14; Jn 1:11; 3:19-20).
        This is an old problem that cannot be so easily divorced from the attitude of the people in general, even in
the OT era: “But My people did not listen to My voice; and Israel did not obey Me (Ps 81:10). As Hunt well points
out, the phrase how often (Mt 23:37) indicates that Jesus

       was referring to the city and all of its inhabitants down through history, not to any certain segment of
       the population….
       …Christ is presenting Himself as the God of Israel who had sent His prophets generation after
       generation to warn the inhabitants of Jerusalem.402

         Additionally, White’s exegesis is built upon a false dichotomy between Jesus’ attitude toward the people in
general and toward their leaders. Contrary, to the leanings in White’s argument, Jesus came to save the lost—
whether they be leaders or laity. The parallel expression not willing (ou thelo) occurs in Jn 5:40. In this Johannine
passage, the Jewish leaders are the ones not willing to believe in Jesus. Yet, in this same context, Jesus indicates
that He desires to save these leaders who are trying to kill Him (Jn 5:19). Jesus tries to persuade these leaders to
believe: “I say these things that you may be saved” (Jn 5:40). The problem was not Jesus’ lack of desire or effort
to save them. On the contrary, Jesus pinpointed the problem: “You are unwilling to come to Me, that you may
have life” (Jn 5:40). The unwilling may be saved if they were willing (thelo, Rev 22:14).
         Aside from its historical background deficiency and its defective dichotomization inadequacies, White’s
approach fails to sustain his theology logically in that, even if his premise were adopted that the unwillingness is
limited to the leaders and Jesus’ willingness to save is limited to the general populace, White is still faced with the
problem of explaining how their unwillingness overcame the will of God. How is it that the unwillingness on the
part of the leaders prevented God from carrying out His will to save the general populace? The biblical explanation
still stands: Their unwillingness is the reason God’s will was not carried out in saving those whom He desired to
save. White has failed to demonstrate his point either logically, contextually, or historically.

Unable
      The Calvinistic counterexamples sometimes used (such as comparing unbelievers to birds with broken
wings who are free to fly but unable to do so) are intended to establish that unbelievers are free to believe but
Page 236                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
powerless to do so. God has to heal their wings—that is, regenerate them, before they can believe. This Calvinistic
perspective perverts the biblical order in which faith must come before regeneration. The Bible does not find it
necessary to present regeneration before faith, nor should it be thought theologically necessary to assert that the
only way that God can enable the lost to believe is to regenerate them beforehand. Nor should foreknowledge be
equated with forechoosing in such a manner as to make it necessary for God irresistibly to choose a person for faith
in order for the person to come to faith. Otherwise, not being forechosen means being denied the opportunity and
ability to believe.
        Since Thiessen prefers a prescient-based predestination, I am not surprised to find myself in agreement with
his distinguishing between permissive and efficient decrees and, in the process, denying that to foreknow means to
predetermine: “God foresaw that sin would enter the universe but he did not efficiently decree it. Surely he can also
foresee how men will act without efficiently decreeing how they will act.”403 But it is perhaps a little more
surprising to hear an almost equivalent concession from Bromiley, as he tries to define and defend foreknowledge
from a Calvinistic stance. On the one hand, Bromiley states:

              God’s foreknowledge stands related to his will and power. What he knows, he does not know
        merely as information. He is no mere spectator. What he foreknows he ordains. He wills it….
              By reason of the totality of will and power in God’s prescience, the “pre” in the word has more
        than temporal meaning….
              Some more dubious differentiations have arisen…Arminius, with a special focus on
        predestination, separated God’s foreknowledge from his foreordination. God foreordains the
        salvation of all those who, freed by his Spirit, trust in Christ, and he foreknows who will make this
        decision and stick to it. On this view neither foreordination nor foreknowledge affects the
        individual decision but at the cost of breaking the chain of Rom. 8:29-30, robbing foreordination of
        its point, and separating the knowledge of God from his will and power.404

      Marrowists certainly share Bromiley’s disdain for the Arminian breaking of the soteriological chain in
Rom 8:29-30 by those who condition eternal security on whether or not one sticks to it.* Aside from the fact that
Calvinists likewise condition a believer’s security on his or her sticking to it (i.e., perseverance),† Marrowists
maintain that no one can come to God apart from the prevenient grace of God in which He draws people to Him
through the power of His Spirit and the gospel. Like Bromiley, we insist on the unbreakable nature of the chain.
                                         Illustration 89. Golden Chain of Rom 8:29-30




      Everyone who is foreknown by God (to believe the gospel call) is predestined by God (to be glorified in
heaven).‡ This chain of events was determined sovereignly by God in eternity past, and nothing can break this


*
  See endnote 1245.
†
  For additional chain illustrations which show that both Perkins and Arminius insert an unwarranted additional link, see Illustration
237. Perkins’ Perversion, 702; Illustration 238. Arminius’ Abrogation, 703.
‡
  The present discussion within the body of this book will assume that the calling in Rom 8:30 is soteriological. There are two ways in
which this may be done. Equate called with the gospel call (i.e., the proclamation of the soteriological message to believe in Christ for
eternal life) or to make it a call to those who already have become believers to simple soteriological glorification. For simplicity’s
sake, and to interact with those who hold the former view, I will assume the validity of the gospel call equation. An attractive
alternative, however, is presented in my book Ordo Salutis. Much of the present discussion in the body of this text, nevertheless, will
still be viable to those who prefer one of the alternatives in that proclamation precedes conversion. So one could make a minor
modification to the present discussion by equating the gospel call with soteriological proclamation and understand the calling of Rom
8:30 to be misthological. Some have speculated that the entire chain of Rom 8:29-30 may be a misthological chain (see endnote 1245).
The present writer does not hold that position. The mediation he prefers is to regard predestined and called as two misthological links
in this otherwise soteriological chain. See “Golden Chain with Two Misthological Links” in Ordo Salutis. All believers have been
predestined contingently to moral conformity to Christ and called to earn conditional misthological profits as a result, but whether or
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                           Page 237
chain of events. In due time, they will hear the gospel call and be justified by faith. All those who put their faith in
Christ alone for eternal life are guaranteed that they will enter into heaven’s glory. Marrowists even further agree
with Bromiley that what God foreknows He pre-wills in this passage, but we would object to equating the two
concepts. Foreknowledge is linguistically and logically distinct from predestination. We would even speculate that
it is supratemporally sequential.* In this context, all whom God foreknows will be justified by faith are predestined
for glory. Every single one of them will respond in faith to the call of the gospel and be justified by faith as a result.

                                                   Efficacious call
        At this point Calvinists try to limit the gospel to the elect and stipulate that only the elect are objects of an
effectual call. The logic would run something like this: (1) only those who are foreknown are predestined; (2) only
those who are predestined are called; (3) only those who are called are justified; and (4) only those who are
justified are glorified. From this line of reasoning, it is deduced that the call is limited to the elect and must
therefore be an effectual call that irresistibly creates faith. And this forced faith then results in justification. Edgar
rejects this line of reasoning:

       God foreknows who will believe. He predestines these, these same individuals he calls, and these
       same individuals he justifies because they believe. All of them believe, not because they receive a
       special “effectual” or “irresistible” call that men in general do not receive, but because they were the
       ones God foreknew would believe.405

        Edgar’s above response is appreciated but in error in the manner in which he articulates it: “All of them
believe…because they were the ones God foreknew would believe.” But foreknowledge is not causative, so Edgar
has misstated the logical relationship. The elect do not believe because God foreknows they will believe. The
reverse is true. God foreknew they would believe because they will believe. God knew they would believe, and in
time, they do believe. Thus, the reason God foreknew that they would believe is because they eventually do
believe. Their free, intellectual response of faith logically determined the Lord’s foreknowledge that they would
believe.† In view of the extended explanation that Edgar provides concerning the definition of foreknowledge (in
which he refutes the notion that foreknowledge is causative or deterministic), his misstatement above was probably
just a slip of the pen, a minor detraction from his otherwise excellent presentation.
        Foreknowledge cannot always be limited to what is predestined. God not only has simple pre-knowledge of
what will happen. He also has pre-knowledge of what could happen, called middle knowledge by some. Choosing
one course of action over another presupposes that the one course of action that could have taken place will not
take place since another course of action has been chosen. For example, God choosing to create Adam on Earth
rather than on Mars means that Adam could not choose to be a Martian. The course of action God has chosen is
but a subset of the possible courses of action that God could have chosen (and limits the choices that we may
make).‡
        Logically, foreknowledge and foreordination cannot be the same. Foreordination is logically a subsequent
subset of foreknowledge. Although they may coincide in this particular text of Rom 8:29-30, this does not mean
that God predestined everything He foreknows in every context. Depending on the context, foreordination ⊆
foreknowledge in extent. As Gordon Olson and Edgar join forces in demonstrating, the lexical data demonstrates
that foreknowledge simply means to know beforehand rather than to choose beforehand.406 To foreknow does not
mean to predestine. Even Rom 8:29-30 proves that this is true. These two links in the chain are just as logically and
sequentially distinct as every other link. Foreknowledge is not causative, as even Bromiley is forced to admit: “We
must not press this to the point of saying that his foreknowledge is the cause of all things. God knows what is
possible as well as actual, but did not cause it. He also knows the devil and sin, but plainly is not their cause.”407
        Correspondingly, on a theological level at least, it could be stipulated that, although God foreknows who
will believe and who will disbelieve, this does not mean that He will cause them to believe or disbelieve. He has
created angels and humans as free moral agents. God did not give Satan the desire to sin. Satan chose this course of
action of his own free volition. Nor did God’s foreknowledge of Satan’s sin cause Satan to sin. Conversely, God’s

not they do so, all believers unconditionally have been guaranteed the soteriological benefits. Therefore, I maintain an unbreakable
soteriological chain and agree with those who use this text as a defense of OSAS.
*
  For discussions of supratemporality in relation to election, see treatments and illustrations throughout Predestination and the Open
View.
†
  See “Key to Foreknowledge” in Predestination and the Open View.
‡
  See “Logical Sequence of Knowledge” in Predestination and the Open View.
Page 238                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
foreknowledge does not force us to believe either. God urges unbelievers to believe and draws them to believe. He
makes it possible for them to believe. He goes yet one step further and enables them to actualize their potential to
believe by opening their hearts to understand the truth of the gospel message, just like He did with Lydia when He
enlightened her to recognize the truth of the gospel (Acts 16:14). Granted, He did so because she had responded
positively to His previous drawing. But again, it must be remembered that this enlightenment is available to all.
Jesus came to enlighten all so that all might believe (Jn 1:7,9).
        Peterson and Williams note that Jn 1:9 was “Wesley’s favorite proof text for universal prevenient grace.”
But they criticize this position as a mistranslation since modern translations are much more inclined to translate the
verse as signifying that Jesus enlightens every man by His coming into the world rather than as indicating that
every man who comes into the world is enlightened. As a result, “‘every man’ does not mean every person, but all
who came in contact with Jesus’ earthly ministry.”408 In making such a response, Peterson and Williams win the
battle but lose the war. Even in this restricted sense, the enlightenment is not limited to the elect. Not everyone who
came in contact with Jesus was one of the elect; nevertheless, they were enlightened. Prevenient grace is not
limited to the elect. Calvinism still loses the main argument by default. Just as the crucifixion draws all who hear of
it (Jn 12:32), even the nonelect, so the incarnation enlightened all who beheld it, even the nonelect. The universal
nature of this enlightenment is thus conceded by this lame Calvinistic rejoinder by Peterson and Williams.
        God’s grace is operating at a perennial level to enlighten all men, and it operates at an effective
soteriological level for those who respond to His initial enlightening. Although Satan is working to blind the hearts
of all, God is working and willing to enlighten all. Effective enlightenment is potential and provisional upon the
conditional appropriation of the shining light (Jn 1:5). The light shines more clearly in the incarnation and in the
cross of the NT, but there was still light in the OT. The universality shown in the NT clarity should be understood
as applying equally in the OT obscurity.
        Just as Satan is drawing all unbelievers to hell, so God is drawing all unbelievers to heaven. By and large
such drawing is not irresistible by either party. Occasionally, God may give a sovereign jerk on the rope that sends
Satan sprawling, just as He did with Saul on the road to Damascus with irresistible persuasion. But even then the
Lord allowed Satan to regain his footing and afflict the new convert and thus oppose him. Paul himself
acknowledges that Satan could have subsequent victory and disqualify him from misthological victory (1Cor 9:27).
Then again, God may give some slack in the rope, allowing judicial hardening in the cases of those who pull with
Satan against God in their effort to reject the salvation that God offers. Still, even on these occasions, the judicial
hardening is frequently not irreversible. God still may refuse to let go of the rope completely and still hold out hope
for the individual. In such cases believers will have to work harder to reach such a lost person. But if enough
believers grab hold of God’s end of the rope and pull in prayer and evangelism, they might find that any slack that
previously had been conceded might be regained.
        More believers need to be tenacious in evangelism. God is not going to do all the work for us. But if His
children start tugging on the rope to covert a lost person in concerted effort, God may find it difficult to resist
pulling a little harder Himself. They may find that He was holding on to the rope just a little longer in hope that
some of His children would join His effort. In His sovereignty, God could have bypassed their effort. But as a
loving Father, who seeks to motivate His children to share His heart for the lost, He is willing to allow Satan to win
many matches if that is what it takes to move His children to win some of the matches. Notwithstanding, in this all-
out spiritual warfare, the unbeliever is ultimately responsible for which direction he or she will be drawn.
Unbelievers can pull with God or against God. God has given them that choice.
        In the present text, the call in Rom 8:29-30 is an efficacious call. But does this require a Calvinistic
explanation in which there are two calls? Is there an ineffectual outer call that God only half-heartedly gives to the
non-elect whereby it is impossible for them to be saved and an effectual irresistible inner call that He extends to the
elect whereby He makes it impossible for them to remain lost? No. The claims of Calvinists, such as Walvoord,
must be rejected: that God gives insufficient grace for all to believe and uses irresistible grace to cause His elect to
believe.409 GRAPE is to be preferred over TULIP or TUIP. What is passively received in response to free grace is a
gift rather than a result of forced grace.
        There is but one gospel call to believe in Christ for the free gift of eternal life. The efficaciousness of this
call is not determined by God but by those who hear it. The passage before us only relates the divine side of the
process. Paul describes the human side of this stair step in Rom 10:14-15.* To combine the two sets of stairs and
present them in logical rather than chronological sequence would yield the following result: (1) only those who
will believe are foreknown to believe; (2) only those who are foreknown to believe are predestined to be

*
    See illustration of “Dual Stair Steps” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                             Page 239
glorified; (3) only those who are predestined to be glorified freely will believe the universal gospel call; (4) only
those who effectually are called are justified soteriologically; and (5) only those who are justified soteriologically
will be glorified soteriologically.
        They are foreknown to believe because they will believe when given the opportunity. In turn, they are
predestined because of their positive response to the gospel call. The call is effectual because they respond in faith.
This same call is ineffectual to those who choose not to respond in faith. Those who believe do so because they are
called (rather than they are called because they believe). One must hear the gospel call before he or she can believe
in the gospel. Nevertheless, what determines whether the call is effective is one’s freewill response to it. This
particular passage is focused only on those who will respond positively to the gospel call. These and only these will
be justified and glorified as a result. These and only these positive responders are foreknown and predestined as a
result. Their response logically determines whether the call is efficacious. God’s predestination of their ultimate
destination is conditioned logically on their self-determination. Namely, they themselves determine their own
destiny by their positive response to the gospel. Chronologically, God predetermines their destination. Logically,
however, they determine their own destination. Or as Olson would state the matter: “The ‘called’ are those who
have responded to the general invitation, and thus, by hindsight, the calling is seen as effectual” (italics his).410
        As the author wrote this line, he foreknew that his wife would like to be taken out to lunch. He had
predetermined that he would do so. He paused from his typing and picked up the phone to call her and invite her to
lunch. She accepted. The call was efficacious. The call was effective because she accepted. It was her freewill
response that made the call effective. The fact that the author foreknew his wife well enough to foreknow her
decision did not mean that she was not free to make a decision. His predetermination to take her to lunch was based
on his foreknowledge of her freewill response. Still, it was her freewill response that ultimately determined that
they would go out for lunch. His predetermination was only effective because of her post-determination.
        Suppose the author had also picked up the phone and called a friend and invited him to join them, and
suppose that friend had declined. In that case, the same call, which was extended to his wife and to his friend,
would have had different results depending on their own choices. Similarly, God has written a letter inviting
everyone to heaven. The fact that He foreknows some will respond positively and negatively does not mean that
He forces them to do so. He has predetermined that those who respond positively will, in fact, reach heaven. The
letter He has written does not make them believe, but it does give them the opportunity to believe. In this passage
of Scripture, God focuses Paul’s attention on those who respond positively. The passage does, in fact, teach an
efficacious call, but it is the reader’s response that determines whether or not it is efficacious. Marrowists affirm a
GRAPE efficacious call rather than a TULIP efficacious call. Our temporal response post-determines whether or
not we are supratemporally predetermined to go to heaven.

                                                  Degrees of Love
        In other words, God wants to save everyone and has done everything necessary to make salvation available
to everyone. White overstates his criticism when he says that the non-Calvinistic view of God’s omnibenevolence
(love) requires that God “does everything in His power to save” a person.411 Actually, Marrowists are quite content
to affirm that God has done everything necessary rather than everything possible. God does not give a Damascus
Road experience to everyone to exert the maximum persuasive (as opposed to coercive) force to save them. It is
doubtful that in the best possible world God could create that it would be possible to do such a thing. Nor would
White be accurate to charge the Marrowistic system of love with necessarily maintaining: “God must love
everyone equally, and try to save each one equally.”412 Not so. God loves each one sufficiently to make each one
savable potentially. God draws each one sufficiently, not equally.
        In Marrowistic theology, unlike Calvinistic theology, God will not force His love on anyone; rather, He
freely offers His love to everyone. In contradistinction to Hunt, Marrowists would more carefully articulate that
God loves everyone sufficiently rather than equally.413 White is accurate in discriminating between kinds and
levels of God’s love and to say, for example, that God loved Jacob more than Esau (Rom 9:13).414 Some contexts
do not evidence any discrimination for God’s love. But whereas the Calvinistic God may be charged with
practicing discrimination in Jn 3:16, and withholding salvation from all but His favorites, Marrowism does not
practice this type of soteriological discrimination. God made it possible for all people to come freely to Christ.
        Yet, once a person of his or her own free will makes a positive response to the gospel call that results in his
or her justification, then God has predetermined that he or she must go to heaven. God’s predestination is logically
conditioned on our response. However, once we respond positively (with the result that we are justified) we are
thereafter unconditionally bound for heaven. Every single one of those who are foreknown are predestined. There
are no exceptions. Every single one of those who are predestined will be called effectively. There are no
exceptions. And so on down the links of the chain one may move. There is no escaping the soteriological security
Page 240                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
of this chain of events. Every single one of those who are called effectively are justified without exception. Every
single one of us who are justified will be glorified. The calling in this passage logically presupposes our positive
response. But given that positive response, the results are inescapably assured. But what makes the calling effective
is not God’s predestination but our response, which God infallibly foreknew in a noncausative manner.

                                                      1Tim 2:4

Relative All
               1
              First of all, then, I urge that entreaties and prayers, petitions and thanksgivings, be made on
       behalf of all (pas) men (anthropos), 2 for kings and all (pas) who are in authority, in order that we
       may lead a tranquil and quiet life in all godliness and dignity. 3 This is good and acceptable in the
       sight of God our Savior, 4 who desires all (pas) men (anthropos) to be saved and to come to the
       knowledge of the truth. 5 For there is one God, and one mediator also between God and men, the
       man Christ Jesus, 6 who gave Himself as a ransom for all (pas), the testimony borne at the proper
       time. (1Tim 2:1-6)

        One common Calvinistic recourse used to evade universal atonement is to claim that all means all without
distinction rather than all without exception in passages that seem to indicate that God desires the salvation of all
people. That is, they argue that the fact that God has decided to save people from every people group does not
mean that God has decided to save every person. White gives a witty illustration in implementing this defense:
“Paul is not instructing Timothy to initiate never-ending prayer meetings where the Ephesian phone book would be
opened and every single person listed would become the object of prayer.”415
        On the other hand, Hunt well illustrates how misleading Scripture would be in its emphasis that Christ died
for the whole world and in its affirmations that whosoever will may come or that all may believe—if Calvinism is
true and all merely means some. Hunt rightly rejects this Calvinistic limitation. Nevertheless, he appears to
overreact when he then goes on to explain: “There may be some context in which such a special meaning would be
implied, but it is difficult to think of an example—nor can we find one in all of Scripture.”416
        The present work, in contrast, would concede the existence of qualified universal terminology in certain
contexts and would not automatically reject this Calvinistic limitation if contextually justifiable. There is such a
thing as a relative all versus an universal all. In fact, White’s phone book illustration is well-taken herein as
showing that all without distinction rather than all without exception is intended in 1Tim 2:1-2. Obviously, Paul
does not mean to pray for every single person on the face of the planet individually by name. Paul wanted the
Ephesians to pray for leaders indiscriminately rather than necessarily universally individually. However, this
admission does little to help White’s position.
        The version of the Calvinistic position that White attempts to defend in this passage is that God shows
discrimination! God is unwilling to save the nonelect according to White’s proposal. God does not even desire that
the nonelect be saved. God makes a distinction based on election. But this train of thought runs contrary to Paul’s
intent. He wants the Ephesians to pray without distinction because God desires and provides salvation without
exception. Paul is not telling us to pray for everyone in the telephone book by name, but neither is he giving us
permission to go through the telephone book and cross out the names of people we do not like! We are to pray for
others without bias, discrimination, or distinction because God offers salvation without bias, discrimination, or
distinction. Paul is not saying that we can restrict our prayers for whomever we like because God supposedly has
restricted His offer of salvation to whomever He pleases! On the contrary, Jesus gave Himself as a ransom for all
indiscriminately. Even granting the Calvinist the conceptual category of a relative all and the exegetical
plausibility of an all without distinction, the evidence still militates against the limitations necessitated by
Calvinism.

Absolute All
       In addition to the two occasions in this passage (1Tim 2:1,4) of the phrase all men (pas anthropos), it also
occurs one other time in the epistle, where it is said that God “is the Savior of all men, especially [malista] of
believers” (1Tim 4:10). Believers (i.e., the elect) are a subset of all men (i.e., believers ⊂ all men). Paul also uses
this same word repeatedly in similar constructions in his writings: “So then, while we have opportunity, let us do
good to all men, and especially to those who are of the household of the faith” (Gal 6:10). We are to do good to
everyone in general and to believers in particular. Believers are a subset of the former and set aside for fuller
application of the good provided. This is the consistent manner in which Paul uses this word. “All the saints greet
you, especially those of Caesar's household” (Phil 4:22). All the believers participated in the greeting, but the latter
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 241
group to an extraordinary degree. “If anyone does not provide for his own, and especially for those of his
household, he has denied the faith” (1Tim 5:8). The latter is singled out as a special subset of the former (cp.
1Tim 5:17; 2Tim 4:13; Tit 1:10; Phlm 1:16). In each case, the latter is a subset of the former.
         Likewise, in 1Tim 4:10, God is Savior of all men in general but of believers in particular. The latter is but a
subset of the former. The expression all men cannot be limited to believers, that is, to the elect. Rather, believers
(i.e., the elect) are a subset of all men (elect ⊂ all men). All men is a larger group of which the elect are but a
smaller subgroup. Since all men is not limited to the elect but comprises a larger group, this expression must
include the nonelect. Consequently, all men would mean all without exception. It is a universal all. Likewise, in
chapter 2 we find the same contrast between God our Savior (v. 3) and all men (v. 4) and Jesus being a ransom for
all (v. 6). God is the actual Savior of believers in contrast to being the potential Savior of all men. Jesus already has
become our Savior, which shows realized potentiality in the case of the believer. But God still desires all men to be
saved, which shows the unrealized potential salvation of all men (in contrast to those who already have been saved
by the subjective application of the objective benefit provided). Jesus is the provisional Savior of all men and the
actual Savior of those who have believed.
         When Christ gave Himself as a ransom for all in 1Tim 2:6, many of those for whom He died had not yet
even been born. Yet, it was at that point in history in which He “bore our sins in His body on the cross” (1Pet 2:24;
cp. Col 2:14). He ransomed us at that point in time by objectively taking care of our sin problem. However, the
application of that provision awaits that future point in time in which we believe in Him. Since Paul’s reference to
all includes future believers, it must be referring to the atonement from an objective and provisional point of view.
Christ provided salvation to all universally and provisionally.
         For such reasons, the indiscriminant usage in 2:4 should be understood to mean all without exception. Christ
provides salvation for all because God desires the salvation of all. We are to pray for all without distinction
because God has made salvation possible to all without exception. Our human inability to name each one
individually should not be imposed on God by Calvinism! What we can only do without distinction (2:1), God can
do without exception (2:4). In seeking to impose a limited atonement on God, it would seem that Calvinists are
trying to limit God’s ability. But why should we allow Calvinists to impose human limitations upon God? That
which human beings can only do without distinction in this passage God can do without exception.
         As a cross-reference affirming God’s universal desire, Gordon Olson points out, concerning Acts 17:30-31,
God’s command that all men everywhere repent “must refer to all without exception since the ‘everywhere’
implies all without distinction.”417 Those, in contrast, who seek to use the classifications in 1Tim 2:1-2 to impose a
limitation on God in 2:3-6 are running cross-grained to the passage and cross-references. Vance voices an
objection to the Calvinistic limitation, stating that whenever the writers of Scripture wanted to specify classes of
people, they did so unambiguously and had Greek words for such designations that they could employ.418 Had Paul
wished to impose a limitation on God’s desire in v. 3, he easily could have said something like all manner or kinds
of men. Yet he did not. The verse frequently quoted in defense of the Calvinistic position is Rev 5:9, which says,
“Thou wast slain, and didst purchase for God with Thy blood men from every tribe and tongue and people and
nation.” The word every refers to every class of people. Still, once again, this classification is not carried over as a
limitation from vv. 1-2 into vv. 4-6. The classification is for the purpose of broadening our prayers, not for limiting
God’s provision. As Guthrie concludes: “The intercession for all men could be justified only on the ground of
God’s willingness to save all.”419

Desire (thelo)
       Other Calvinists, evidently sensing the failure of other compatriots to limit the all in 1Tim 2:4, take a
different approach and seek to limit God’s desire/will (thelo) instead. Sellers states:

       Since thelo is the word for an emotional will or desire, it can be seen that God desires all men to be
       saved….God has not sovereignly willed to save all men. But it is His desire, arising from His
       emotions that all might be saved. God simply does not choose to fulfill all of His desires. (Emphasis
       his.)420

       Sellers’ acknowledgement that 1Tim 2:4 applies to everyone without distinction or exception is thus
appreciated. Nevertheless, is this weakened meaning of desire a realistic possibility from Sellers’ theological
perspective? If you refuse to make it possible for the monkey to have the banana, can it be said that you really
desire for him to have it? The present author has a full-length, solid-glass storm door that can be practically
invisible, as attested by the number of times that he or a family member has collided with it. Suppose at Halloween
that he were to turn on the outside light at this door to indicate his desire to give candy to the trick-or-treaters, but
Page 242                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
he were to leave his storm door locked. Then when the children came to the door, he held out the candy for them to
take it, but he left the glass door shut and locked. Could it really be said that he desired for the children to have the
candy? Not really. The author would have erected an invisible barrier prohibiting them from taking the candy.
Realistically speaking, the Calvinistic position makes foreknowledge an invisible barrier to the lost, preventing
them from believing the gospel. They were not forechosen to believe, so they cannot believe. In contrast, the model
proposed within is that God has turned on the light and opened the door. Even so, He will not go out and drag
people inside; instead, He freely welcomes all who will come inside. His will is that they be saved, and He has
made it possible for them to be saved. God not only desires their salvation emotionally, He has willed it
volitionally. Notwithstanding, He has not willed it irresistibly or sovereignly. He does not force them to believe,
but He has taken the necessary action to make it possible for them to believe.
                                      Illustration 90. Calvinistic Foreknowledge




       Imagine the hall of a prison where all the prisoners are on death row. They all want to be saved from the
penalty of their sin. None of them want to fry in the electric chair. The warden comes by with a master key that can
unlock each door. He unlocks five of the doors, telling the prisoners in those particular cells that they are free to
leave. They are being granted a full pardon. They leave and their lives are spared. To the rest of the prisoners he
says, “I have the same authority and ability to release all of you, and I really desire to set you free.” Then he puts
the key back in his pocket and turns and walks away to let them die. Which one of those remaining prisoners is
going to believe that the warden really wanted to set them free? When he gets back to his office, one of his guards
asks him why he did not set the others free. The warden responds that he had written down only five names before
he entered that hall, and those are the ones he set free. Since he had not forechosen the others, their doors were not
unlocked. When questioned as to why he chose those particular five, he informs the guard that it was not due to
anything the prisoners had done, no merit or demerits on their part. It was simply a choice he had made on his part,
drawing five names out of a hat. He decided to show saving grace to those five and only those five so that it might
be demonstrated that none of them deserved such grace.
       The Calvinistic portrayal of foreknowledge as forechoosing for faith logically results in the mental picture
of those who are not forechosen as being left behind the bars of a prison, incapable of being saved. God foreknew
that He would not make salvation possible to them. To the glory of God’s Calvinistic grace, He does decide to save
a comparatively few people from the lost numbers of humanity. The few He did decide to save were just as
incapable of believing as anyone else. So the choice is not based on any foreseen faith. This Calvinistic perspective
is perhaps theologically permissible to the extent that God did not have to choose to save anybody, and the small
number He is willing to save does, in fact, demonstrate that He is a gracious God. However, it is out of harmony
with the Biblical picture of God, as a God who loves all humanity and who desires salvation for all humanity. The
Marrowistic model proposed herein balances both pictures. To the glory of God’s grace, He graciously has chosen
to save all and has made it possible for all to be saved. He has made the gospel extremely simple so that even a
child can believe it. There is power in the preached word of the gospel that draws all who hear it to the crucified
Christ, making it possible for them to believe in Him. But so that God’s grace may be glorified, He will only save
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                            Page 243
those who are willing to be saved by grace. Those who refuse to be saved by grace and who try to be saved by
performance have rejected the grace that He has offered them.
       There is a sermon illustration that one hears occasionally that describes just such a scene. A governor signed
the pardon for a prisoner. Yet the prisoner refused to accept it. The courts ruled that if he refused to accept it, he
would have to serve his sentence. He chose to serve his sentence. In such a scenario, it is evident that the governor
desired to save the prisoner and made his salvation possible. However, this salvation was not forced on the
prisoner. Whether or not one is forechosen should not be pictured as irresistible bars preventing a person from
believing. God has opened the prison door, but He will not drag the prisoner out. The Lord respects the prisoner’s
free will and leaves that choice up to each individual.
       Using a differentiation between antecedent and consequent will, Ken Keathley explains the dualism in
God’s will this way: “God antecedently desires that all be saved, but he consequently wills that faith is a [the]
condition to salvation.”421 In terms of Jn 3:16, he expresses it in this manner: “God antecedently ‘so loved the
world that he gave his only begotten Son,’ that consequently “whoever believes in Him should [would] not perish
but have everlasting life.”422 Or it might be restated as follows: God unconditionally loves the whole world and
antecedently desires the salvation of each individual, but He contingently has decided only to save those who
believe so that He might be glorified by saving those who “choose Him freely” rather than by saving everyone
universally or indiscriminately. In other words, God consequently determined that our fate would be self-
determined to His honor and glory.423

                                                     2Pet 3:9

Believers
        Sellers wants to limit 2Pet 3:9 “to the believers [addressed in the epistle] or at most to the elect.”424 His
preference is for the former. Sellers contends that when Peter says that God “is patient toward you, not wishing for
any to perish but for all to come to repentance,” what Peter really means is, “God is patient toward you believers,
not wishing for any of you believers to perish but for all of you believers to come to repentance.” Sellers claims
this is an “elliptical construction, in which some word or words which have already been used in a previous part of
a sentence are intended to be understood as occurring in the latter part.”425
        Now to be sure, elliptical constructions are common enough in Greek; however, it would seem intrinsically
unlikely that Peter is limiting the oncoming destruction to unrepentant believers in verse 9 when he has just
mentioned the fire reserved for the “destruction of ungodly men” in verse 8! Certainly, Sellers is correct that the
word you in this epistle refers to believers. But are we to conclude that believers are the only ones who need to
repent? Are believers the only ones in danger of perishing? Is the message of repent-or-perish limited to believers?
Are we to believe that God does not want the lost to repent? No.
        The answers to these questions and to Sellers’ suggestion must clearly be answered in the negative
regardless of what type of destruction is in view.426 Regardless of whether the destruction is physical destruction in
the tribulation or eternal destruction in the Lake of Fire, it cannot be limited to believers. For that matter, if you
refers to believers and perish is limited to tribulational or soteriological wrath, then the any and all do not even
apply to believers at all. Believers are promised unconditional salvation from both the tribulation and Lake of Fire.
They do not need to do anything additionally, like repent, in order to be saved from either calamity. Sellers’
interpretation (that since the you refers to believers the any and all must as well) is not only unlikely—it is
impossible.

Elect
       White takes a similar approach but expands you to include all the elect (which was the option Sellers
refrained from taking, and for good reason). Like Sellers, White claims “that we must decide who the ‘you’ refers
to and use this to limit the ‘any’ and ‘all’ of verse 9.”427 White fails to explain why we must limit the meaning of
any and all to the scope of you. If these words are contrastive rather than explicative, then the entire argument by
either Sellers or White falls apart. For the sake of argument, though, allow this discussion to proceed for the
moment, with assuming the legitimacy of their unproven premise that the one governs the other. Further, despite
the demonstration above to the contrary,* for the sake of discussion, I also momentarily will adopt White’s
mistaken soteriological interpretation of 2Pet 1:1.


*
    See 2Pet 1:1, 203.
Page 244                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
        Accordingly, on the basis of White’s understanding of 2Pet 1:1, the you being referred to in the epistle are
saved believers since Peter specifies that he is writing “to those who have received a faith of the same kind as
ours.” White is correct that the you refers to genuine believers. Marrowists only wish that he and other Calvinists
would be consistent and realize that this same argument destroys their theology in other epistles in which genuine
believers are being warned about the dangers and realities of committing apostasy and falling into prolonged sin.
Still, being content with White’s present concession, I will demonstrate his inconsistency in this particular epistle.
        White presumes that Peter is addressing all the elect in 1:1 so that the you in 3:9 is to be taken as meaning
any and all of the elect. White would have us understand Peter as saying, “God is patient toward you the elect, not
wishing for any of you elect to perish but for all of you elect to come to repentance.” The fallacy of this approach is
easily demonstrated by noting that the audience which Peter is addressing in 1:1 already has received this faith.
They already are saved. They are believers. Peter is not addressing all the elect throughout all time and space but
those among the elect who already have responded in saving faith to the gospel presentation. But White wants to
broaden the intended scope of Peter’s address to include all future believers. This would allow White to include
future believers who have not yet believed. But this jump in logic is unwarranted. The you in this epistle is limited
to actual believers, to those who already have received the faith; it does not include potential believers. Since the
elect being discussed are those who actually have believed, White’s interpretation collapses to that of Sellers’
above (who wisely hesitated to broaden the you to mean all the elect). The you must be restricted to referring to
those who already have come to faith. Yet this reduces White’s argument to that of Sellers’ position which already
has been found unsatisfactory above.

Misthological Believers
        The unlikelihood of the Calvinistic exegesis is rendered even further unlikely if, as argued earlier, Sellers’
premise is rejected that the epistle simply is written to believers in general. It is unlikely that 2Pet 1:1 is describing
soteriological faith; rather, it should be understood as referring to misthological faith. If this misthological
understanding is adopted regarding the nature of their faith in 1:1, then the epistle is being written to beloved
brethren who have advanced to a mature faith. These mature believers are being exhorted misthologically to obtain
the eschatological salvation of their souls (1Pet 1:5,9) as the outcome of successfully enduring the refinement of
their faith (1Pet 1:7-9), resulting in their rich misthological entrance into the kingdom (2Pet 1:11). Peter is writing
to believers who have obtained a misthological status by virtue of their misthological faith. This approach allows
OSAS to respond to Corner, an Arminian, concerning the implicit warnings in this context:
          9
            The Lord is not slow about His promise, as some count slowness, but is patient (makrothumeo)
          toward you, not wishing for any to perish (apollumi) but for all to come to repentance….14 Therefore,
          beloved, since you look for these things, be diligent to be found by Him in peace, [misthologically]
          spotless and blameless, 15 and regard the patience of our Lord to be [misthological] salvation; just as
          also our beloved brother Paul, according to the wisdom given him, wrote to you, 16 as also in all his
          letters, speaking in them of these things, in which are some things hard to understand, which the
          untaught and unstable distort, as they do also the rest of the Scriptures, to their own destruction
          (apoleia). 17 You therefore, beloved, knowing this beforehand, be on your guard lest, being carried
          away by the error of unprincipled men, you fall from your own steadfastness (sterigmos). (2Pet 3:9-
          17).

        Corner objects to OSAS by quoting from the NIV in 3:17 and noting that these unquestionably genuine
believers may fall from their “secure position” (NIV).428 This translation is plausible. Not only do BDAG and LW
both list this type of translation as one of two possible renditions for sterigmos, but even if one were to accept the
more popular translation of steadfastness, there would still be an implicit danger for the believer. The NIV is only
making explicit what the NAS, in context, makes implicit. Corner consequently reasons that our security is
conditional. He is correct in that aspect. Marrowists can fully grant that Corner wins the battle but loses the war.
What is at stake for the believer is misthological security rather than soteriological security. Also using the NIV,
Marrowistic securitists may respond to Corner by pointing out that Peter enjoins these believers: “Make every
effort (spoudazo) to be found spotless, blameless” (2Pet 3:14). Since what is at stake is contingent on their effort,
and thus on their work, what is at risk is the misthological realization of their misthological election (cp. spoudazo
in 2Pet 1:10): “Make every effort to make your calling and election secure” (TM).* Misthological security is at

*
    See “Do your Best” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                             Page 245
stake. Salvation from hell is not by works, so salvation from hell is not in view. Salvation from the outer darkness,
on the other hand, is by works and may, therefore, be within the scope of the misthological destruction that
believers may experience in the loss of their souls.* Moreover, our effort is to be found blameless by Him, not in
Him. The security of our soteriological position in Him is not in question; rather, the security of our misthological
blamelessness before Him is at stake. The salvation and destruction for believers in such passages is misthological
rather than soteriological.
        Peter has just warned his readers in the previous chapter that they would be exploited by false teachers who
successfully would seduce some mature believers among them (who successfully had scaled to temporal heights
that could potentially qualify them for misthological blamelessness) to turn away from his apostolic admonitions
(2:2,21). The danger, therefore, is that if these mature believers fall from this tentatively misthologically secure
position (3:17), their resultant state will be worse temporally and misthologically for them than their initial
immature state. Falling from maturity into apostasy is worse than the carnality of immaturity (2:20), both
temporally and misthologically.†
        God’s desire is not that believers or unbelievers perish and suffer destruction, whether that destruction be
temporal or eschatological, or soteriological or misthological. A soul is a terrible thing to lose. God wants all to
repent and save their lives. The lost need to repent, if that is what is necessary for them to become believers so that
they will not perish soteriologically. Believers also need to repent, if they are living out of God’s will, so that they
will not perish misthologically. The passage (2Pet 3:9-17) certainly addresses the potential Bema peril to believers.
However, 3:9 and 16 are not limited to believers.‡ Thus 3:9 remains an effective counter to Calvinism on multiple
fronts. God’s desire is not limited to the elect, and the elect may fail to persevere.
        Calvinism and Arminianism both crash on these rocky misthological shores. But Marrowism is able to
navigate safely through these waters. God desires the salvation of all people from His tribulational, misthological,
and soteriological destruction and wrath. A soul, any soul, is a terrible thing to waste. God does not desire that any
human soul perish. On the other hand, He has granted us free will and may respond to us, “Have thine own way,”
when we want to run headlong against the warnings in His word to our own peril.

Desire (boulomai)
       Since the Calvinistic attempt to limit any and all to believers, much less to the elect, is fraught with such
difficulties, the alternative Calvinistic course of action is to try to limit the verb boulomai to an irresistible
sovereign decree in contrast to the thelo (desire), as Sellers argued above.§ The word for will/desire in 2Pet 3:9 is
boulomai, which Sellers considers volitional planning in contrast with thelo (which he would take as emotional
desire). That is, according to this interpretation, thelo only represents what God desires; boulomai refers to what
God decides. According to Sellers, the former refers to God’s emotional will, whereas the latter is equated with
God’s sovereign will. God does not give in to His emotional impulse to save everyone. The Calvinistic God only
decides to save those whom He irresistibly elects to save. Yet this sharp dichotomy that Sellers draws between the
words is open to question.
       For the sake of simplicity, this discussion will proceed as if 2Pet 3:9 is dealing with soteriological issues.
After all, if the Calvinistic view cannot even withstand scrutiny on its own terms, then it certainly would falter if
subjected to the misthological understanding above. In any case, if the outcome is not unconditionally or
sovereignly determined, then the outcome could just as easily be misthological as it could be soteriological.
       The NAS translates 2Pet 3:9 as, “The Lord is…not wishing [boulomai] for any to perish but for all to come
to repentance.” And it translates 1Tim 2:4 by saying that God “desires [thelo] all men to be saved.” Thus, it
translates the two words, boulomai and thelo, synonymously as wishing and desires. Evidently the translators did
not see any sharp division between the two words. However, even assuming that Sellers’ distinction is valid, this
does not mean that his conclusion is necessarily correct. The NKJ translates 2Pet 3:9 as, “the Lord is…not willing
that any should perish but that all should come to repentance” (see also KJV). There is no reason to limit God’s
will to save the lost to a mere emotional desire. This verse is not saying that God sovereignly has decided just to
save the elect. It describes what should happen, not what (out of divine necessity) must happen. God’s
soteriological love for the world has expressed itself in concrete action on behalf of the entire world to save it
(Jn 3:16). God’s will is that all should be saved. God’s will is not that all would be saved for the clear-cut reason

*
  As to what it means to lose one’s soul, see Typology, 160.
†
  Compare to Peter’s warning in 2Pet 2:17-22, pictured in Illustration 307. Falling from Path of Righteousness, 862.
‡
  This soteric-mistholic duality of applicability suggests a principle of correlativity. See Theory of Correlativity, 911.
§
  See Desire (thelo), 241.
Page 246                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
that He decided to condition our salvation on our willingness to respond to His warnings. He has willed our
salvation but not to the point of eliminating our free will.
        Another indication of Sellers’ fallacy in trying to limit this verb for God’s will (boulomai) to mean God’s
sovereign, irresistible will can be found in examining its nominal form counsel (boule). To be sure, this noun can
refer to God’s immutable will. In fact, both the verbal and nominal forms of this word occur in this capacity in the
same verse concerning the believer’s inheritance: “Thus God, determining (boulomai) to show more abundantly to
the heirs of promise the immutability of His counsel (boule), confirmed it [i.e., the hope of the inheritance] by an
oath” (Heb 6:17; NKJ). Certainly, this word can refer to God’s sovereign will.
        For example, in Eph 1:11 the unconditional component of the believer’s inheritance is predestined and
guaranteed: “We have obtained an inheritance, having been predestined according to His purpose who works all
things after the counsel (boule) of His will.” This inheritance is guaranteed unconditionally to all believers
(Eph 1:14; NKJ). Dillow justly considers this verse to be proof of eternal security.429 All believers will be trophies
to the glory of God’s grace (Eph 1:12), certainly to the glory of His redeeming grace on the one hand (cp. Eph
1:14), and potentially to the glory of His enabling (energizing) grace on the other (cp. Eph 3:16).* Shank’s
Arminianism may be countered by appealing to the context of the word. Being predestined (proorizo) in both
Rom 8:29-30, Eph 1:5-6, and Eph 1:11-12 unconditionally results in glory for all believers. Hence, one finds
justification for unconditional security.

                                                       Luke 7:30
       Still, does this mean that this word for God’s will (boule) always means that the desired outcome is
guaranteed, as Sellers would have us believe? No. The same word is used in Lk 7:30 where “the Pharisees and the
lawyers rejected God’s purpose (boule) for themselves, not having been baptized by John.” Shank correctly notes
that this proves that God’s will may be rejected.430 Sellers then attempts to counter by posing an alternative
translation that could be rendered as: “The Pharisees and the lawyers rejected for themselves God’s purpose, not
having been baptized by John.” On the basis of this type of translation, Sellers then proceeds to claim: “The
counsel of God was that John should baptize. But these Pharisees and lawyers rejected for themselves that counsel
and so were not baptized. God’s counsel that John should baptize was carried out.”431
       In support, Sellers cites Lenski, a Lutheran commentator. However, this is a rather peculiar citation that
Sellers uses in his defense. Granted, Lenski gives the type of translation that Sellers needs, but Lenski’s
interpretation appears to counteract the very point that Sellers is trying to make. According to Lenski, “This
counsel (boule) is what the will of God fixed and planned; it was exhibited in John and in his work. They made it
void and ineffective…for themselves.”432 In other words, Lenski’s interpretation of Sellers’ translation is evidently
that they resisted God’s will. It was not irresistible. God’s will was not merely that John would baptize but that the
Pharisees should be baptized also. They rejected God’s will. According to Lenski, although God’s plan was
evidently “fixed and planned,” it was apparently not irresistible in this context. Arndt, a fellow Lutheran
commentator, is much more explicit:

                Boule is a strong term, signifying that it was God’s desire and plan to save the Pharisees and
          scribes as well as all other people….God’s saving will, it must be noted, does not work irresistibly; it
          is not a fiat which beats down with sovereign majesty all opposing forces. Man has the terrible power
          to ruin himself.433

        Thus, contrary to Sellers’ Calvinistic opinion of this verse, Vance is fully justified in providing Lk 7:30 as
one of the legitimate and persuasive references demonstrating that humanity can reject God’s will.434 There are
passages of Scripture in which God’s will is irresistible; there are others in which it is not. Context is the decisive
factor. Even so, a word of warning is in order. It was noted above that the immutability of God’s will in Eph 1:11
may be correctly used as an indication of God’s unconditional will for all believers concerning their basic
soteriological inheritance in heaven. However, on the same page in which Dillow uses this defense for eternal
security, he also quotes Heb 6:17 in support as well. Lexically, he is correct. Contextually, he is wrong.

                                                       Heb 6:17
        As pointed out above, Heb 6:17 does indeed confirm that God’s will is immutable in this particular passage.
It is sovereign; it is certain to happen. Lexically, this expression of God’s will cannot be circumvented. However,

*
    See Illustration 25. Some Trophies are Better than Others, 57.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 247
what Dillow failed to note was that in this context it does not unconditionally apply to all believers. This passage,
in contrast to Eph 1:11, is dealing with a misthological inheritance. The context is clear as to the misthological
nature of this inheritance in Hebrews. Dillow quoted the passage from verses 17-20. However, had he started with
verse 11, he might have reached a different conclusion:
          11
             And we desire that each one of you show the same diligence so as to realize the full assurance of
          hope until the end, 12 that you may not be sluggish, but imitators of those who through faith and
          patience inherit the promises. 13 For when God made the promise to Abraham, since He could swear
          by no one greater, He swore by Himself, 14 saying, “I will surely bless you, and I will surely multiply
          you.” 15 And thus, having patiently waited, he obtained the promise. 16 For men swear by one greater
          than themselves, and with them an oath given as confirmation is an end of every dispute. 17 In the
          same way God, desiring even more to show to the heirs of the promise the unchangeableness of His
          purpose, interposed with an oath, 18 in order that by two unchangeable things, in which it is
          impossible for God to lie, we may have strong encouragement, we who have fled for refuge in laying
          hold of the hope set before us. 19 This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, a hope both sure and
          steadfast and one which enters within the veil, 20 where Jesus has entered as a forerunner for us,
          having become a high priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek. (Heb 6:11-20)

       Repeatedly and correctly, Dillow had identified the inheritance in 6:12 as a reward that can be forfeited
since “it can only be obtained by persevering.”435 The combined impact of verse 11-12 is that it takes diligence and
patience to inherit this promise. According to BDAG, patience may also be rendered as endurance in this context.
In Jam 5:7-11, its verbal and nominal forms (makrothumeo and makrothumia) are used synonymously with the
verbal and nominal forms of endurance (hupomeno and hupomone) and is translated as patiently endured by the
KJV in Heb 6:15. The eschatological realization of this misthological promise is conditioned on perseverance in
faith and works.
       The word for obtained in verse 15 is epitugchano, which can either be defined as acquire or experience
according to L-N. In this context, it certainly alludes back to the diligent effort (spoude) referred to in v. 11 so that
L-N may be commended for acknowledging that epitugchano has the sense of acquire in v. 15. The writer of
Hebrews only uses this verb in one other passage: “Who by faith conquered kingdoms, performed acts of
righteousness, obtained promises, shut the mouths of lions” (Heb 11:33). Here again, the Greek word for acquire is
connected with acquiring a promise. Obviously, what is promised is attained through an active faith rather than
through a passive faith. The only two occasions in which the writer of Hebrews uses the expression through faith
(dia pistis) are 6:12 and 11:33. Just as in 11:33 through faith we obtain the promises, so in 6:12 and 15 through
faith we inherit and obtain the promise. What they obtain through faith is a reward, not a gift. Both passages are
picturing misthological faith.
       The significance of the cognate for obtain (tugchano) that occurs two verses later has been discussed
already: “Women received back their dead by resurrection; and others were tortured, not accepting their release, in
order that they might obtain a better resurrection” (Heb 11:35). Unfortunately, although L-N admits that these
cognates can have the same meaning, it preferred to define it as meaning experience in Heb 11:35. But one does
not endure torture in order to merely experience the resurrection that has been promised unconditionally to all
believers! Contextually, the verb is being used misthologically to denote a resurrection that is promised
conditionally to those believers who advance actively beyond passive soteriological faith to exhibit a victorious
