active faith. The verb thus refers to achieving the out-resurrection.*
       In progressing through this context to verse 18, it is readily apparent that this misthological perception of the
inheritance is retained in the imagery of running to take hold of the prize of misthological hope set before us
(Heb 6:18). This imagery is picked up again by the writer of Hebrews later and further developed: “Let us run with
endurance the race that is set before us, fixing our eyes on Jesus, the author and perfecter of faith, who for the joy
set before Him endured the cross” (Heb 12:1-2). In fact, Paul says that the reason God exalted Jesus’ name above
every name was because Jesus humbled Himself by dying on the cross (Phil 2:8-9). Naturally, we will recall the
similar Pauline misthological illustrations of running to win the reward (1Cor 9:24; Phil 3:14; 2Tim 2:5). Likewise,
in the present context of Hebrews, it takes diligent perseverance to earn the promised inheritance. I must agree with
Hodges, rather than with Dillow, that this is a misthological inheritance in Heb 6:17, not a soteriological
inheritance.436 Consequently, it describes the misthological hope of inheriting a full inheritance.

*
    See The Out-Resurrection in Heb 11:35, 76.
Page 248                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
Abrahamic Covenant
        One might suppose that Dillow was thrown off the misthological track concerning the nature of the promise
due to the fact that this covenant is an immutable promise based on the Abrahamic covenant, which is typically
presumed to be unconditional among dispensationalists. But Dillow’s discussion of the Abrahamic Covenant is
highly accurate, concerning which he states: “The condition for receiving the inheritance of the land promised in
the covenant was circumcision and the offering of his son Isaac.” The crosscurrents in these hermeneutical waters
concerning the covenant are difficult to navigate, but overall Dillow has done well. As an example of the
complexity involved, I will interact with Anderson’s charge against Pentecost that Pentecost has muddied the water
with the simplistic contrast between conditional and unconditional covenants.437 To be fair, however, it may be
said in Pentecost’s defense that he does inform the reader that even the Abrahamic Covenant initially was
conditional.438 Further, he and Anderson appear to come to the same conclusion—that it is a future faithful
generation of Jewish believers at the end of the tribulation that will realize the national promises to Abraham
concerning this promise.
        As to the original stipulation, God appeared to Abraham in Ur and established a promissory covenant
relationship with His vassal—Abraham (Acts 7:2-3). The Lord (as Suzerain) gave Abraham a conditional promise:
If you go, I will bless you (Gen 12:1-2). Abraham departed and was then given the land grant when he reached the
Promised Land (Gen 12:7). Thus, this type of covenant is called a covenant of grant. Anderson points out:
“Covenants of grant are conditional upon obedience, but are unconditional after their inauguration (at least for the
initial recipient).”439 God has no problem calling this blessing a reward rather than a gift: “Your reward shall be
very great” (Gen 15:1). The misthological promise in Gen 12:1-2 for future obedience was conditioned on
Abraham’s future submission to God’s Lordship in leaving the land. It was to be a reward. After Abraham obeyed,
he was then unconditionally promised that the land would be given to him and his descendants (Gen 12:7). So one
might concur with Pentecost that it did become unconditional for Abraham at this future point in time:

      Whether God would institute a covenant program with Abraham or not depended upon Abraham’s
      act of obedience in leaving the land. When once this act was accomplished, and Abraham did obey
      God, God instituted an irrevocable, unconditional program. This obedience, which became the basis
      of the institution of the program, is referred to in Genesis 22:18, where the offering of Isaac is just
      one more evidence of Abraham’s attitude toward God.440

Expansion Because of Subsequent Obedience
       It is at this point, however, where Anderson’s criticism of Pentecost is perhaps both at its strongest and
weakest. Anderson’s censure is accurate in that Abraham was promised the land because of his obedience to God
(Gen 22:16-18; 26:5), and David was promised a dynasty because of his service to God (1Kgs 3:6; 9:4;
11:4,6,11,35; 14:8; 15:3).441 So Abraham eventually earned an unconditional guarantee of a reward because of his
subsequent faithfulness. Abraham actually must have secured something extra by his subsequent obedience in
offering up Isaac. Pentecost may be faulted in failing to note that the expansion of the covenant was in fact due to
Abraham’s obedience.
       On the other hand, if Anderson means to imply that this reward could be revoked completely, then he has
overreacted to the causal nature of the subsequent statements. As Pentecost notes, the nature of the covenant made
in Gen 15, in which God alone passed through the cut pieces, ran counter to the current practice of that day and
time and was God’s way of showing that the fulfillment of the covenant rested solely upon Himself. To be sure,
faithfulness on the part of Abraham’s seed would be necessary for the realization of the promise as to which
particular seed would experience the fulfillment (Gen 26:3; 31:3). However, Abraham could be sure that he would
eventually have seed that would fulfill the requirements. God would see to it. But which of Abraham’s seed would
qualify to share this inheritance with Abraham? Anderson’s analysis is well stated:

           Here is the point. Once Abraham or David was given his grant, it could not be taken away. But
      since these grants included promises regarding future generations (seed), and since these grants were
      rewards based on the faithfulness of the initial recipient, how can the blessings (rewards) of the grant
      accrue to future generations if they are unfaithful? The answer is that they cannot.442

Types of Seed
       Abraham would have seed that would qualify, but not all his seed would qualify. Pentecost cites Walvoord
in support of the fact that Abraham had three types of descendants.443
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                            Page 249
                                        Illustration 91. Three Types of Abrahamic Seed




        A person can be a child of Abraham in three different ways. (1) Natural Jewish descendants of Abraham,
who are such through physical birth through Jacob’s lineage, possessed the land in the OT. This refers to those who
are Jewish by birth. (2) Faithful physical descendants of Abraham who manifest his same spirit in trusting and
obeying God will inherit the land during the millennium. This refers to faithful Jews. (3) Spiritual descendants
refers to the Gentiles who believe and who are to be included in the blessing to “all the families of the earth” in
Gen 12:3.* They are considered Abraham’s seed as well and, thus, entitled to the inheritance (Gal 3:29).
        These designations are good insofar as they go, but they fail to deal with all basic contingences. What about
Jews who follow Abraham’s example of faith but who fail to follow his example of faithfulness? Similarly, what
about Gentiles who believe in Christ but fail to live for Christ? Do they get the same benefits as do the faithful? Is
there not a blessing to be had because of faithfulness, as both the writers of Genesis and Hebrews attest? Certainly
there is, but in order to see it, an overview of the Abrahamic covenants will be helpful.
                            Illustration 92. Reiteration and Expansion of Abrahamic Covenants
                                                       Gen 12:2-3
 “And I will make you a great nation, And I will bless you, And make your name great; And so you shall be a
blessing; And I will bless those who bless you, And the one who curses you I will curse. And in you all the
families of the earth shall be blessed.”
                                                      Gen 13:14-17
And the Lord said to Abram, after Lot had separated from him, “Now lift up your eyes and look from the place
where you are, northward and southward and eastward and westward; for all the land which you see, I will give it
to you and to your descendants forever. And I will make your descendants as the dust of the earth; so that if
anyone can number the dust of the earth, then your descendants can also be numbered. Arise, walk about the land
through its length and breadth; for I will give it to you.”
                                                       Gen 15:5-7
And He took him outside and said, “Now look toward the heavens, and count the stars, if you are able to count
them.” And He said to him, “So shall your descendants be.” Then he believed in the Lord; and He reckoned it to
him as righteousness. And He said to him, “I am the Lord who brought you out of Ur of the Chaldeans, to give you
this land to possess it.”
                                                      Gen 22:16-18
By Myself I have sworn, declares the Lord, because you have done this thing, and have not withheld your son,
your only son, indeed I will greatly bless you, and I will greatly multiply your seed as the stars of the heavens, and
as the sand which is on the seashore; and your seed shall possess the gate of their enemies. And in your seed all
the nations of the earth shall be blessed, because you have obeyed My voice.

*
  To clarify the illustration, the circle on the left Natural Seed refers to Jews, and the circle on the right Spiritual Seed refers to
believers. Believing Gentiles would compose part 3 of the circle on the right. Believing Jews would compose part 2 of both circles.
Page 250                                                                                                               The Outer Darkness


        Abraham had been promised early in chapter 12 that if he would leave his homeland God would bless him
by (1) making him a great nation, (2) making his name great, and (3) making him a blessing to all the families of
the earth. Abraham goes, and then God promises him the land that God shows to him (Gen 12:7). Next, in chapter
13, God assures Abraham that it is to be a permanent blessing for him and his descendants and that his descendants
will be innumerable. In chapter 15, God confirms this promise by a vision, in which God graphically demonstrates
that the promise is completely unconditional as far as any future obedience from Abraham is concerned.
Subsequent obedience is not required to obtain the promise. So why did Abraham have to pass the test concerning
Isaac in order to obtain the promise in chapter 22? Why does God explicitly and repeatedly confirm that the reason
He is making this promise in chapter 22 is because Abraham offered up Isaac? How could the promise be due to
this subsequent obedience when God already had indicated to Abraham that the land-promise would not be based
on Abraham’s ensuing compliance to His will? Did God change His mind and decide to condition His promise on
Abraham’s subsequent obedience after all? No.
        In mediation between the positions taken by Anderson and Pentecost, the proposal herein is that the
expansion of the final reiteration moves beyond the previous ones. God expanded the promise because of
Abraham’s obedience.444 Up to this point, God had promised Abraham a great name, great fame, innumerable
descendants, possession of the land, and that he would be the fountainhead for blessings for families throughout the
earth. But after Abraham offered up Isaac, God added two additional items. For one, not only would Abraham be
the source of blessing for families but also for nations.
        Abraham was aware of the Messianic promises of the coming Messiah. Indeed, he already had trusted in the
coming Messiah many years previously for salvation and had righteousness imputed to him as a result. He was thus
already aware that the promise God was giving him in chapter 12 was that the coming Messiah would be his
descendant. Thus, all the peoples of the earth would be capable of receiving a soteriological blessing through him if
they would likewise follow his example of trusting in the Messiah for eternal life, as he already had done many
years before. Abraham realized that God was promising him that the Messianic line would come through him if he
would just go to the land God wanted to show him. He went. As a result of this obedience, Abraham could then
rest assured that the Messiah would be one of his descendants and the source of soteriological salvation for the
entire world. Further, he knew that some of his physical seed would not only follow his spiritual example and trust
in the Messiah, but they would also follow his example of obedience and be qualified to inherit the land. Yet
Abraham also anticipated that additional obedience would bring even greater blessings. He planned to offer up
Isaac with the expectation that he would be blessed by witnessing at least, even if nothing else, the resurrection of
Isaac from the dead (Heb 11:17-19). However, God intervened and gave Abraham an expansion of the previous
blessings as a result of his willingness to offer up Isaac. Not only would the families of the earth be blessed, but
entire nations would be also. The second new part of this expanded covenant was that his descendants would
“possess the gates of their enemies.” Complete national domination of the entire world was now added as a result
of his subsequent submission.

Faithful and Unfaithful Spiritual Seed
       When Paul writes of the soteriological blessings that we as believers have, such as imputational
righteousness and an unconditional inheritance in heaven (e.g., Rom 4:3-5; Eph 1:11,14; Gal 3:29; 4:6-7), and yet
affirms the existence of misthological blessings if we endure, such as the crown of righteousness and a conditional
inheritance of co-glory with Christ (e.g., Rom 8:17; 2Tim 4:8), Paul is in complete agreement with the writer of
Hebrews that a full inheritance is conditioned on subsequent faithfulness. It would be better, then, clearly to
indicate that among Abraham’s spiritual descendants there will be both Jews and Gentiles who are faithful and
unfaithful. The unfaithful Jewish sons of the kingdom are consigned to the outer darkness along with their Gentile
counterparts (Mt 8:12; 25:30). Those who insist that the sons of the kingdom thrown into the outer darkness are
unbelievers because they are merely ethic Jews have failed to take into consideration that unfaithful Jewish
believers are susceptible to this misthological fate and that the foundation for their misthological exclusion was laid
as early as this Abrahamic text. The full inheritance is reserved for faithful sons. Thus, we have five categories for
Abraham’s seed: (1) natural Jews, (2) natural Jewish believers who are (a) unfaithful or (b) faithful; and
(3) spiritual believers who are (a) faithful or (b) unfaithful.*
*
  To further clarify the illustration, the circle on the left Natural Seed refers to Jews, and the circle on the right Spiritual Seed refers to
believers. Believing Gentiles would compose part 3 of the circle on the right. Believing Jews would compose part 2 of both circles.
However, not all believers in parts 2 or 3 are faithful. Faithful Jewish believers are pictured in 2B and faithful Gentile believers are
pictured in 3A. Unfaithful Jewish sons of the kingdom who are thrown into the outer darkness would be pictured by 2A. The sons of
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                              Page 251
                                         Illustration 93. Five Types of Abrahamic Seed




Summation of Abrahamic Promise
       Those who follow Abraham’s example of faith become his spiritual seed and share in the soteriological
promises. And those of Abraham’s spiritual seed who follow his example of faithfulness share in his misthological
blessing. The blessing given in Gen 22:16-18 is an expansion of the original Abrahamic Covenant in that now it is
added that his heirs would possess the gates of their enemies. The ultra-dispensational view that believers of the
church age do not share in the inheritance is false. According to Heb 6:12, we may share in those promises. Yet
pertaining to the present stage of the discussion as it relates to predestination, it will suffice to say that, although
the promise in Heb 6:17 is sovereign and immutable, it is only such for those who meet the contextual conditions
and faithfully endure the trials set before them in order to lay hold of the misthological hope set before them
(Heb 6:18). The implication from Hebrews is that the introduction for misthological realization and exclusion on
the part of Abraham’s spiritual Jewish and Gentile decedents was laid as early as the Abrahamic covenants.

Objection to Misthological Inheritance
        Brown objects to a misthological understanding of the inheritance and appeals to the promise of Rom 4:13
and Gal 3:18 and its context in defense of an exclusively soteriological understanding of the concept.445 “For the
promise to Abraham or to his descendants that he would be heir of the world was not through the Law, but
through the righteousness of faith” (Rom 4:13). “For if the inheritance is based on law, it is no longer based on a
promise; but God has granted it to Abraham by means of a promise” (Gal 3:18). Brown’s argument in a nutshell is
that all believers are Abrahamic heirs (Gal 3:7-9,29; 4:6-7). Heir of the world in Rom 4:13 is taken as a summation
of the Abrahamic Covenant, and the Hebrew word for possess in Gen 22:17 is understood to mean inherit. From
this basis, he concludes that all believers unconditionally are guaranteed this soteriological inheritance. In short,
Brown believes that all believers will inherit the world.

Potential Counterargument
       I could short-circuit his argument by adopting an approach such as that taken by Harrison, who considers
world to mean people in Rom 4:13 rather than land. He suggests this understanding due to its anarthrous usage and


the kingdom thrown into the outer darkness are either 2A and 3B, or just 2A. The present work will entertain either possibility. That is,
the sons of the kingdom thrown into the outer darkness in Mt 8:12 might refer inclusively to unfaithful Gentiles who are spiritual seed
of Abraham or exclusively to unfaithful Jewish believers who are jointly natural-spiritual seed of Abraham.
Page 252                                                                                                        The Outer Darkness
thus claims “that nothing in the section we are considering suggests the thought of dominion” found in Gen 22:17.
Thus, it would be concluded that the dominion concept of Gen 22:17 is not being alluded to in Rom 4:13 and that
Paul is just referring to a soteriological promise.446 Likewise, following Dillow’s lead, I could then argue that these
passages are soteriological rather than misthological, as is demonstrated by their contexts.447
       Rather than evading Brown’s argument in this fashion, I will strengthen his presuppositions instead. In
support of his position, it may be noted from the LXX that the Greek word for possess is indeed inherit
(kleronomeo), which is the verbal form of heir (kleronomos) in Rom 4:13 and inheritance (kleronomia) in
Gal 3:18. The anarthrous construction is certainly not a decisive counterargument since Paul describes inheriting
the kingdom with anarthrous constructions elsewhere (1Cor 6:9-10; Gal 5:21). Further, it is possible for a
misthological promise to be made in soteriological contexts and be built upon their soteriological foundation. I
accept Brown’s premise in this case but consistently reject his conclusion.* This passage, like Mt 5:5, is holding
out the misthological possibility of inheriting the world, but this promise is only offered to believers.

Abraham’s Preexisting Faith
        Certainly, Abraham was a believer before the events recorded in Gen 22 concerning the offering of his son
Isaac. God’s test (Gen 22:1) of Abraham the believer (Gal 3:9) was a test of preexisting faith (Heb 11:17) that
resulted in misthological justification by works (Jam 2:21). The term misthological justification is a
straightforward deduction derivable from the parallel statements from Paul and James concerning Abraham’s
justification. In speaking of Abraham’s soteriological justification by grace, Paul makes a contrast with its
inverse—justification by works. “Now to the one who works, his reward [misthos] is not counted as grace, but as
what is owed” (Rom 4:4; TM). James makes the same point with his rhetorical question: “Was not Abraham our
father justified by works, when he offered up Isaac his son on the altar?” (Jam 2:21)

          1. According to Paul, anything by works is a reward (misthos).
          2. According to James, Abraham was justified by works.
          3. Therefore, Abraham’s justification was a reward (misthos).

        To use the coined derivative of misthos, Abraham received misthological justification when he offered up
Isaac. But he had experienced soteriological justification by grace through faith as a gift many years before. And
Paul is discussing this type of justification in Rom 4:2. James and Paul complement rather than contradict. They
simply are discussing two different types of justification that occurred at two separate times in Abraham’s life.
Soteriological justification precedes misthological justification. God does not wait for believers to demonstrate
their faith in active obedience before He grants soteriological justification. The original promise made to Abraham
in Gen 12:3 was expanded to include worldwide domination (Gen 22:17). God could not offer Abraham an eternal
inheritance based on works in Gen 12:3 if Abraham already had not received eternal life through faith. Neither the
law nor any other form of human performance has the ability to impart life (Gal 3:21). This soteriological life must
be imparted through regeneration, and soteriological righteousness must be imputed through faith. The believer
must legally be made a child who is qualified for the inheritance before the believer has the ability to do any work
that may be credited toward the realization of the potential inheritance. One must become a potential heir of the
misthological promises through saving faith before one can become an actual heir of the misthological promises
through active faith that works.

Misthological Promise on Soteriological Foundation
        This promise in both its original and expanded forms was misthological in nature, but it was built upon a
soteriological foundation; namely, Abraham was a believer who already had believed, as Moses parenthetically
points out at a later point in the narrative (Gen 15:6). The conditional promise of a misthological inheritance is
given to all believers. The fulfillment of the promise is conditioned on their response as believers. All
soteriological believers are qualified to become misthological heirs if they move on from passive faith to active
faith, just as Abraham did. By following Abraham’s example of active faith, the promise is actualized individually
and personally by each believer. Paul’s point in Rom 4:13 is not that all believers are promised unconditionally that
they will be heirs of the world as a result of their passive faith. The realization of the promise was not offered to
Abraham on such basis. Abraham had to leave his home and offer up his son in order to obtain the ultimate
fulfillment of this promise. Nevertheless, the opportunity itself to become heir of the world was not made to

*
    For preceding interaction with Brown’s arguments on the nature of the inheritance, see Three Options Concerning Portion, 118.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 253
Abraham because of his works, but because of his passive faith. And Paul expounds this point in Romans and
pounds away at it in Galatians.
        God has given every believer the opportunity to become an heir of the world, not only to share in
Abraham’s soteriological blessing but also in his misthological blessing as well. God did not grant Abraham this
opportunity because Abraham kept the law or because of his performance or his merit. This opportunity was given
on the basis of sheer grace.* Abraham did nothing to deserve such a commitment from God. Rather, God chose to
obligate Himself in this manner to Abraham for no other reason than the fact that Abraham was a passive believer.
God already had granted Abraham justification by faith, and now He wanted to give him the chance to earn
justification by works. If a father were to offer his son a thousand dollars to mow the lawn, the son would realize
that the possibility of earning such great reward was being offered to him because he is a son. This same promise
would not be given to the neighbor’s kids. Yet the actuation of the promise would require that he actually go
outside and mow the lawn. Obviously, he does not mow the lawn to become his father’s son.†
        The promise is graciously given (charizomai) to Abraham in Gal 3:18 apart from any human performance.
The perspective that we earn such an opportunity is doomed to failure since it misperceives the basis for the offer
as well as the means of achieving what is offered: “If the inheritance is based on law, it is no longer based on a
promise” (Gal 3:18). If believers misunderstand the basis for the promise, then they also can be expected to fail to
appropriate the means to realize the promise. As Paul emphatically states in both Romans and Galatians, the law
can only tell you what to do; it cannot give you the power to do it. You must appropriate the power that God
provides through His Spirit in order to attain the misthological realization of the inheritance. The same God who
gave the promise will also provide the power to fulfill the conditions for that promise. The opportunity to earn
rewards is given graciously. We do not earn the opportunity to earn rewards. But the realization of the opportunity
will indeed be based on our synergistic response to the opportunity. God graciously gives us both the opportunity
and the ability.
        Imagine the legalistic son who thinks that in order to earn the thousand dollars for mowing the lawn, he
must do so independently of his father and must do so in his own strength. The son walks to the store and spends
his last few dollars to buy a pair of scissors so that he can cut the grass. All the while, his father (who made the
promise) has provided a power lawnmower out in the yard with a tank full of gas and the key in the ignition. It is
little wonder that Paul is so exasperated with the Galatians when he, as it were, comes home as the father and finds
them out in the yard with a pair of scissors trying to cut it as a Christian!
        Paul sternly warns them that they have fallen from grace (Gal 5:4) and will never inherit the kingdom by
trying to get the job done in that manner (Gal 5:21). In terms of this analogy, it is as if Paul is exhorting them,

       Put away the scissors and get on the lawnmower seat if you want to earn the thousand dollars. You
       will never finish cutting the yard with a pair of scissors. The grass will grow faster than you are
       cutting it. The same God who made the promise to you in the first place because of your trust in Him
       as your Father will make it possible for you to fulfill your side of the obligation for the misthological
       inheritance if you continue to trust in Him. He wants to be the object of your trust. You can trust Him
       through His Spirit to provide you with the fruit of the Spirit (Gal 5:22-23). Sure, you will still have to
       press the gas pedal, change the gears, and turn the handle (Gal 5:25). But there is no mistaking a pair
       of scissors for a three-blade, riding, power mower.‡

        Another form of legalism is perhaps more prevalent in our day, and certainly not excluded by Paul in
Galatians. Many, if not most, legalists in our current theological climate acknowledge the futility of trying to serve
God in the strength of the flesh. They claim to be living the Christian life out of the power of the Spirit. They
would be pictured as cutting the grass with the riding lawn mower, not merely in order to earn the thousand dollars
but in order to be (remain) a child of God. These legalistic children believe God will throw them into hell if they
fail to cut it. They too have fallen from grace. They have the correct means but wrong motive. Trusting in God-
enabled performance to enter heaven is still salvation by works and rejected by the Bible. Soteriologically,
Abraham was justified by faith apart from works, not by God-enabled works. Abraham’s imputed righteousness in
Rom 4:13 is the soteriological basis for the promise, but the misthological realization of the promise would require
imparted righteousness. Such an assessment accords well with Heb 6:11-17 discussed above, in which the writer
of Hebrews states that Abraham’s realization of the promise was based on his perseverance in faith.
*
  See discussion of condign merit in Relative Merit, 24.
†
  See Derivative Merit, 31.
‡
  Or to use Paul’s analogy. walk by the Spirit.
Page 254                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
        The fourth reason (provided by Eaton for coming to a similar understanding) is that twenty years previously
he held a strictly soteriological view of Romans 4 within the Calvinistic framework when he spent four years
preaching through the epistle of Romans. But in a subsequent struggle with the passage, Eaton could not maintain
this viewpoint and had to adopt a misthological approach for the latter half of the chapter.
        I also experienced a similar situation. I had memorized the epistle of Romans years before and was
accustomed to reviewing it on an ongoing basis and assumed that the soteriological foundation laid in the
beginning of the chapter was pretty much maintained until the end of the chapter. However, years later, even after
having eventually developed the misthological defense for 4:13 above, I was quoting the epistle of Romans again
to myself (while working out on a stair stepper) when it occurred to me that holding on to an exclusively
soteriological view of 4:18,22 would be very difficult. I filed that thought away in the back of my mind where it
probably would have remained and eventually been forgotten except that a friend, Scott Crawford, called up a
couple of days later asking about that very issue. It is good to memorize Scripture so that one can quote it any time
of day or night, and it is good to have friends that the Lord can use to stir one’s memory and challenge your
position. At this friend’s request, I briefly gave him a possible defense of a misthological understanding, assuming
that it would just be an option at best but exegetically unlikely. Upon further reflection, I came to adopt this view
tentatively. Granted, there are those in FG who continue to hold to the soteriological view of these verses. To do
so, they reject Allen Ross’ thesis (see BKC) that Abraham was justified by faith previously.* But I fail to see how
even taking this approach will allow the soteriological view to be maintained consistently.
        One problem is that in Rom 4:22 Paul says, “Therefore (dio) also it was reckoned to him as righteousness”
(Rom 4:22). The statement itself is not the problem. It is certainly soteriological in other contexts (cp. Rom 4:3,6;
Gal 3:6). The difficulty is the logical and temporal sequence in which this affirmation appears in the context, and
the connection is amplified by the context in 4:18. According to this verse, Abraham continued to believe in order
that he might obtain the realization of the promise (Rom 4:18). Rather than become “weak in faith” (4:19) or
“waver in unbelief” (4:20), he “grew strong in faith” (4:20) so that he was “fully persuaded” (4:21). The ultimate
reason his faith was “imputed to him as righteousness” in 4:22 is because it had persevered and matured in faith. If
we want our faith misthologically imputed (logizomai) to us as righteousness in the end, we must persevere like
Abraham. After all, misthological imputation is not a foreign concept to Paul. He uses the verbal form (logizomai)
misthologically in 2Tim 4:16 and the nominal form (logos) misthologically in Phil 4:17. This cognate form for
imputation is also used misthologically on other occasions as well, even in Pauline literature.448
        The faith described in Rom 4:18 appears to be after all hope was gone (humanly speaking) and is thus not
referring to that earlier faith that resulted in his justification by faith. Moreover, in v. 18 Abraham does not believe
soterically in the ultimate coming Messiah (in order to be saved from hell) but in the promise of God concerning
the realization of the promised child that would be born to him personally in order that (eis purpose clause) the
promise would be fulfilled. The implication was that this later faith was necessary for fulfillment of the promise,
and hence there was an implicit condition of linear faith for the fulfillment of misthological righteousness. The
therefore of 4:22 seems to confirm that the reason righteousness was imputed to him at this later point in time was
because he persevered and matured in the faith just described in the preceding verses. An exclusively soteriological
view of what is happening in this passage would lead to a linear soteriological justification. Not only would this
make perseverance in faith soteriologically necessary, but the quality and maturity of this faith (and the works
necessary to maintain and develop it) would become conditions for this soteriological benefit as well. This is
tantamount to soteric justification by works, which is contrary to the thesis Paul is developing.
        An exclusively soteriological perspective is thus difficult to retain. Granted, many in FG would maintain a
soteriological view of imputation in Rom 4:22, with the stipulation that there are no degrees of faith, and therefore
would claim that the imputation was based on simple faith in the preceding verses. At the 2005 GES conference, I
bought Lopez’s commentary on Romans and questioned him about the import of 4:22. Lopez offered two
possibilities concerning the therefore of 4:22: (1) It may be an inclusio that refers back to 4:3 that does not include
the activity or progression from 4:3, or (2) it may only refer back to 4:21. From his theological vantage point, I
would agree that these are admittedly two very good suggestions by Lopez and are internally self-consistent with
the discussion in his commentary. Therein, Lopez provided a reasonable definition of inclusio:

          Paul uses the phrase for obedience to the faith in a symmetrical form in 1:5 and 16:26 that forms an
          inclusio (i.e., a similar word, phrase or clause that begins and ends a literary unit that serves as a


*
    For more detailed interaction with Ross and the OT background and timeline see my book Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 255
          framing device to unite a paragraph, section or book treating the same theme), thus encapsulating
          everything found in Romans.449

       Subsequently, Lopez prescribes a similar function to the conjunction: “Therefore (dio in 2:1) acts as a
connector linking both groups. However, one should not understand therefore to relate primarily to the sins of the
Gentiles described in 1:21-32, but to God’s wrath in 1:18.”450 The first option provided by Lopez is to be
commended for consistency. The second option would also be attractive to those who hold to the degreeless view
of faith, which in fairness to Lopez should probably be regarded as the majority GES position. Correspondingly,
Lopez would reject the translation I used above because of the degreeless view:

          The term fully convinced may not be the best translation since it implies the possibility of varying
          degrees of assurance (99%, 90%, 80%, etc…) in believing the promise initially. This idea, of course,
          is unbiblical, since the Scripture knows of only two options when it comes to believing…either one is
          or is not convinced of the truth.451

Such a statement is consistent with the FG majority position, but one wonders if it is consistent with Lopez’s
admission (made on this same page in his commentary) that Abraham was strengthened in faith in v.20.
Surprisingly, Lopez takes this to

          mean that due to Abraham’s unwavering faith he became stronger….That is, by God’s help
          Abraham became more confident in the fulfillment of the promise that he already believed (cf. v
          21)…
               God perhaps waited…in order to challenge and cause Abraham’s faith to grow….This may be a
          paradigm of how God works with people to strengthen their faith.452

        Although I understand how one who holds a degreeless view of faith might make such statements,* it still
seems highly ironic that on the same page in which Lopez rejects the notion of being fully confident (because in his
assessment there is no such thing as degrees of confidence—one is either confident or one is not) he nevertheless
entertains the possibility of becoming more confident. This admission certainly sounds like a confession to degrees
of confidence and thus to degrees of faith. Concerning Rom 1:11 and 16:25, Lopez likewise acknowledges that the
purpose of the Roman epistle is that “their faith will be strengthened.” Paul wants “to strengthen the faith of the
Roman believers (to live and overcome problems in life).”453 Perhaps Lopez only means that Abraham grew to
trust God more consistently or broadly rather than intently or greatly, or more quantitatively than qualitatively. Yet,
if so, it is difficult to reconcile this degreeless view of Abraham’s faith with Lopez’s articulation concerning the
centurion’s faith:

          Some could object by posing that God could have given the centurion faith. Though probable, this is
          an impossible interpretation for several reasons. First, Christ refers to the degree of the centurion’s
          faith (“great faith”) and not faith itself. Second, since Christ admires the degree of Gentile faith
          above Jewish faith, it only makes sense if that faith came from the centurion and not God. For, why
          would Christ emphasize the centurion’s degree of faith if it came from God?454

        Lopez certainly gives the impression that faith can occur in degrees! In any event, in addition to my counter
to the degreeless view,† I would point out that BDAG translates plerophoreo as fully convinced. This word is
translated in terms of fully in twenty-three out of twenty-five translations that I consulted. Its only other occurrence
in this epistle, in Rom 14:5, also strongly suggests that conviction or persuasion may occur in degrees. But putting
aside this consideration for the moment, even if Paul only means to affirm that Abraham was justified at this point
in the narrative because of his consistency in faith, then Lopez’s second option still falters in that it was Abraham’s
perseverance in faith in v. 21 that resulted in his justification by faith in v. 22.
        Apparently, the parenthetical inclusio argument is the only valid alternative by which Lopez can maintain in
4:18-25 that “Abraham was justified by simple faith” (emphasis his).455 So even if I were to adopt the premise of
my fellow FG friends, the placement of such justification at this point in the context still would be difficult to

*
    See “Absolute Necessity” in Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
†
    See Dad, can I be sure I am really saved?
Page 256                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
defend if the therefore of Rom 4:22 reflects chronological progression. Additionally, the soteriological view of
what occurred at this point in time in Abraham’s life appears to be refuted clearly by Heb 6:11-15, where the
promise, “I will surely bless you, and I will surely multiply you,” is undoubtedly misthological. As Hodges
comments, “In due time his patience was rewarded in that he (lit.) ‘received the promise.’ Since the reference is to
the promise given in Genesis 22:17 after the offering of Isaac, the author may have been thinking of the reception
of the promise itself as the reward.”456
        Hodges also perceives the promise as being misthological, due in part to the chronological sequence, which
is in complete harmony with my assessment. Chapter 11 of Hebrews would also seem to be a treatise on the virtue
of misthological faith: Faith is meritorious therein in that it results in a reward. Abraham dualistically was justified
by faith—soteriologically by simple faith initially and misthologically by a mature faith subsequently. Admittedly,
Lopez would only see soteriological inheritance in Rom 4:13-25, as is demonstrated by his comments on
Rom 4:13. At the same time, though, even he admits that Paul teaches a misthological inheritance in Rom 8:17b.
Since the present work already has engaged Lopez’s soteriological interpretation of the inheritance in 1Cor 6:9-11
(as advanced by Brown and others) and rejected it in favor of the misthological interpretation taken by Hodges,* I
will press on with a misthological preference for the inheritance in Rom 4:13, based on the chronological sequence.
        The position taken herein is in substantial agreement with the conclusion reached by Eaton (and perhaps
anticipated to some degree by Govett).457 Having demonstrated at length that the Galatian problem was that they
trusted in the human ability of fleshly performance, and having noted that the promise to Abraham entailed a
reward and that the believer’s inheritance is to be understood likewise, Eaton goes on to explain in detail:

       The inheritance is not Abraham’s justification, which he already has. The land which God wants to
       give as a gift will be ‘inherited’ in the future. It is natural to ask: what does its actual possession
       depend on?
       …The point seems to be that since God’s oath is irrevocable the land must be given to someone. But
       God did not specify in detail to whom the inheritance would come….Apparently in Scripture
       something which is promised by oath can be lost to one person and fulfilled for someone else….
       Romans 4 begins by emphasizing the starting-point (justification by faith, 4:1-12) then goes on to
       deal with how inheritance is attained (by persistent faith, 4:13-21). Subsequently Paul will introduce
       an “if” (Rom. 8:17). A similar point is made in Gal 3:18,29; 4:1,7,30, where (because of the
       particular controversy at Galatia) the subject matter is largely our standing before God. In a later
       section (5:12-6:18) where the theme is actual godliness, he warns that inheritance can be blocked
       (5:21)….
            In Ro. 4:13,14 Paul expands the land-promises given to Abraham. The fact that land/inheritance
       was so obviously a reward in Genesis makes it likely that this is the view here….“The promise” in
       Ro. 4:13 does not concern justification (since it looks to the new heavens and earth) but it comes
       about through righteousness-by-faith, i.e., it is open only to those who are justified by faith….
            …In 4:13 Paul develops his argument and goes on to make a slightly different point. His point is
       that the goal of salvation, the reward that salvation makes possible, is reached not through law-
       keeping but through the “righteousness of faith” he has already referred to….
            …Abraham was justified at the point mentioned in Genesis 15:6, or even earlier. The
       inheritance is something he will receive later.
            …But it was not by this initial faith that Abraham immediately received the inheritance. He had
       to continue in faith for a long time before his inheritance began to come to him….It was by faith and
       patience that Abraham inherited the promise of Isaac. This is the language of Heb. 6:12….Only
       persistent and ongoing faith brought the birth of Isaac….
            As I understand it, [Rom] 4:13-21 shows that saving faith, when persisted in, becomes
       inheriting faith, without any use of the Mosaic law….The faith that inherits without any use of the
       Mosaic law is none other than the faith that saved us in the first place. The difference between the
       two is simply a matter of persistence!458

       The opportunity to earn a misthological inheritance is a gift. But the actual possession of this inheritance
is a reward conditioned on living by faith. Like Abraham, we believers can become heirs of the world if we

*
  For general discussion, see 1Cor 6:8-11, 118. For response specific to Lopez therein, see endnote 196, and related discussion of
2 Enoch, 474.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                            Page 257
persevere in the faith. Such perseverance is not taken for granted or guaranteed. Yet the reward for such
perseverance has been immutably decreed. To believers who overcome, God has promised an eternal reward.
Rewards are eternal. God will not change His mind about these rewards. He has guaranteed them with an
unchangeable oath. Still, His sovereignty is not expressed in terms of irresistibility in making all believers
persevere. He has not guaranteed our perseverance, only what will happen if we persevere. All believers are
qualified soteriologically as potential misthological heirs, but not all believers will actualize their misthological
potential.
        The soteriological imputation of righteousness in Rom 4:1-8 (apart from works of any type) progresses to
misthological righteousness through a misthologically mature, inheriting faith that has withstood the test of time
and has grown strong as a result. In fact, according to Jesus, it is because of Abraham’s great faith that Abraham
will be a son of the kingdom who rules in the kingdom rather than be thrown into the outer darkness (Mt 8:10-12).
If Abraham had withered in faith rather than grown strong in faith, it is my understanding, per Jesus, that Abraham
himself would have been cast into the outer darkness.*
        Following “in the steps of the faith of our father Abraham” in Rom 8:12 is the footbridge by which Paul
thematically crosses from soteriological imputation to misthological imputation for those believers who follow in
Abraham’s steps. By following Abraham’s example and becoming mature in faith, we too will attain misthological
imputation. James also teaches that Abraham’s misthological justification was conditioned on Abraham’s mature
faith—a faith that had matured because of works (Jam 2:22). Works were the intermediate means by which he
attained a misthological faith. Whereas Paul merely focuses on the immediate means (i.e., misthological faith)
upon which misthological imputation is based in Rom 4:22, James includes the intermediate means (i.e.,
misthological works) as the necessary means to reach a mature, misthological faith that results in misthological
justification (Jam 2:24).
                                               Illustration 94. Footbridge of Faith




*
    See Illustration 146. Matthew’s Kingdom Banquet, 432.
Page 258                                                                                           The Outer Darkness


       Believers already have had righteousness soteriologically imputed to them, but their remains a future
misthological dimension to this imputation (Rom 4:24). “Those who believe in Him who raised Jesus our Lord
from the dead” (Rom 4:24) can walk in newness of life (6:4), experience resurrection power (6:9), present
themselves to God as those righteously alive from the dead (6:13), bear fruit (7:4), experience spiritual vitality
(8:11) and attain practical righteousness as a result.* The purpose in believing that Jesus has risen from the dead is
not merely to obtain alien righteousness soteriologically but to experience righteousness in a living faith that results
in misthological imputation. Therefore, Shank’s findings are appropriate:

             Abraham was “fully persuaded that, what God had promised, he was able also to perform”
        (Rom. 4:21). But the faith which was “imputed to him for righteousness” (v. 22) was not merely the
        persuasion of one grand and holy moment; it was his enduring persuasion. No lesser faith could
        have inherited the promise of God. The enduring faith of Abraham which was reckoned as
        righteousness, and which made him an heir of God, is vividly portrayed in Hebrews 6:11-15, an
        urgent exhortation to believers…who through faith and patience inherit the promises. (Italics his.) 459

      This is a splendid misthological assessment. Unfortunately, Shank did not intend for his statement to be
taken misthologically but soteriologically. For Shank, the final soteriological realization of one’s imputation is
based on the linear condition of “enduring persuasion.” If you stop being persuaded (i.e., you stop believing), then
you lose the gift of eternal life. Locking himself into a soteriological hermeneutic causes Shank to fail to perceive
the misthological dimension to which his brilliant piece of writing would have led him otherwise. Marrowists
concur with the necessity of living faith, but we see it as a misthological rather than soteriological necessity. A
misthological hermeneutic greatly enhances our soteriological understanding of Rom 4 and provides us with
options that were unavailable to Shank, with his strictly soteriological approach to this context.

                                                           Forechose
       Having demonstrated that texts, such as Heb 6:17, do not prove that all believers will persevere and obtain
the promised inheritance as a result, we should also consider a broader objection that could be made conceptually
on the basis of predestination. If God has forechosen who would believe and irresistibly brings them to faith, as
Calvinists suppose, then it could be argued that He irresistibly has predestined their faithfulness also.
Predestination is not limited to our position in Christ. It includes our practice (e.g., Eph 1:4; 2:10; cp. Jn 15:16).
God has predestined our position and our faithfulness. It is little wonder, then, that Calvinists (such as Sellers)
argue for the perseverance of the saints in faith and faithfulness. In fact, Sellers could have asserted this in his
discussion of foreknowledge in 1Pet 1:2.†
        1
         Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who reside as aliens, dispersed throughout Pontus, Galatia,
        Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia, who are chosen 2 according to the foreknowledge of God the Father,
        by the sanctifying work of the Spirit, so that you may obey Jesus Christ and be sprinkled with His
        blood as a result: May grace and peace be yours in fullest measure. (1Pet 1:1-2; TM)

        Commentators frequently assume that practical sanctification is being referred to or included in this verse
and that the obedience is correspondingly ongoing obedience, not just a onetime act of faith. This is the
understanding of the text adopted within the present work.‡ Correspondingly, it could have been asserted by Sellers
that God sovereignly has determined that believers would submit to the process of sanctification by the Spirit and
submit to the Lordship of Christ in a life of ongoing obedience (and thus inherit the kingdom). However, it has
been countered herein that God not only has predestined what we would be but what we should be as well. God has
irresistibly determined that believers will be in Christ. But this does not mean that He irresistibly has determined
that believers will be faithful in Christ. Believers are elected, in accordance with God’s desire for intimate
fellowship made possible by practical sanctification, for obeying Jesus and appropriating the power of His shed
blood on an ongoing basis. This intimacy is the goal of their election, not the inevitable result of their election.


*
  See author’s discussion of practical righteousness in Carnal Corinth.
†
  See 1Pet 1:2, 232.
‡
  See Illustration 76. Election (eklego, ekloge, eklektos), 182.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                            Page 259
                                                     Practice
       The conceptual parallel of Eph 1:4 with 2:10 demonstrates that predestination includes our practice. The
verbal parallel with Col 1:22 shows that it is conditioned on our practice.
      4
        He chose us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless
      before Him. (Eph 1:4)
      22
         Yet He has now reconciled you in His fleshly body through death, in order to present you before
      Him holy and blameless and beyond reproach—23if indeed you continue in the faith firmly
      established and steadfast, and not moved away from the hope of the gospel that you have heard.
      (Col 1:22-23)

       These two Pauline occurrences are the only places in the Greek NT were this identical phrase holy and
blameless is found. (The related phrase in Eph 5:27 should be understood similarly and will be dealt with
subsequently.) Failures in practice show that this aspect of election is resistible, as does the grammatical parallel
with Jn 3:17.
      10
         For we are His workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God prepared
      beforehand, that we should walk in them. (Eph 2:10)
      17
        For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world should be saved
      through Him. (Jn 3:17)

                                            Hina Purpose Clause

NAS Inconsistency
       Both verses use hina (that, in order that, so that) with an aorist subjunctive verb. Interestingly, the NAS
1995 edition (i.e., the NAU) uses might in Jn 3:17 rather than should. So the editors subsequently changed it from
should to might. They chose might rather than would for obvious reasons—to avoid translating it as saying, “The
world would be saved.” Evidently they did not want to convey the false impression that the entire world would be
saved! Yet in Eph 2:10, the subsequent editors convey the false impression that all believers will (i.e., would) walk
in good works. The hina phrase also has been changed by the NAU from should to would in Jn 15:16, giving the
false impression that all believers will produce good fruit; in Rom 6:6, giving the mistaken impression that no
believer will serve sin (if the slavery is experiential rather than positional); and in Eph 5:27, giving the false
impression that all believers are holy and blameless (if it is talking about practical holiness rather than positional
holiness).
       The grammatical structure is the same: hina followed by a subjunctive verb. But this rendition of would was
not feasible in Jn 3:17. Nor is it any more tolerable in the Pauline passage. If this construction is best rendered as
might in Jn 3:17 (so the NAU there), then Eph 2:10 should be translated as: “We might walk in them.” We might,
then again we might not. This translation is perhaps too flippant and may fail to convey the fact that God has taken
action to bring about the intended results (both the salvation of the world and the holiness of believers), and we are
under moral obligation to render these results.

Moral Obligation
       Yet in both editions (i.e., NAS/NAU) Rom 6:4 is translated as might walk. This is a very              ditio
close parallel to Eph 2:10, since Paul uses the same Greek construction (hina with the aorist
                                                                                                            s
                                                                                                      con


                                                                                                                 nal




subjunctive verb) and the same verb, walk (peripateo). English translations render it as should,
may, or might. In this context, should might convey the moral obligation but not convey the divine
enablement as clearly as might. If the intent is to express the thought of enabling grace, might may
be a better translation in such instances. On the other hand, we should walk in this manner because we can so walk
through God’s enabling grace. We should do what we are capable of doing. Moral obligation certainly does not
rule out divine enablement. In fact, it implies it. Divine enablement necessarily results in moral obligation.
       Unlike Calvinists who believe that the lost are under moral obligation to do that which they cannot do, the
more reasonable supposition is that the lost are under moral obligation to trust Christ as their Savior because they
are capable of doing so. All are drawn; all can believe; all should believe. But ability does not translate into
Page 260                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
certainty. They should have believed, but they would not. Or as Jesus states, they are unwilling (Jn 5:40). They
might refuse to meet the stated condition for eternal life, which is to believe. Thus, in Illustration 77.
Predestination, unbelievers are those who should have been saved but who refused to believe. They should have
believed, but they chose hell instead and are designated by an “S.” They have chosen hell in spite of the fact that
God had chosen heaven for them and paid their sin debt for them.
       The saved are under moral obligation to submit to Christ as their Lord. All are exhorted to do so; all should
do so; all are capable of doing so. Nevertheless, many will not do so. Thus, those believers in the illustration
designated by an “S” as going to the outer darkness are those who should have gone on to live for the Lord after
they trusted Him as their Savior, but they refused to submit to the Lordship of Christ.* They rejected God’s moral
will for their own will.
       God’s action of compelling the lost to believe and believers to submit is not irresistible, but it is nevertheless
very forceful. It has to be in order to counteract the demonic influences seeking to blind us and draw us away from
considering God’s will. In cases where irresistible election is involved, would is an acceptable translation. But
where resistible election is in view, should (or may or might) remains the preferred translation. That God has willed
that the entire world should be saved does not mean that the entire world would be saved: should = could ≠
would.460 He has taken action to make salvation possible for everyone in the world in that Christ has died for the
whole world and draws everyone in the world so that they might believe (Jn 12:32). Yet the Lord does not draw
them irresistibly. He has not irresistibly predestined the lost to believe.

Exceptions

                                            Saul on Road to Damascus
        Since God has chosen to condition our justification on our faith and our rewards upon our faithfulness, the
proper deduction is that He has not irresistibly predetermined either response. Granted, Saul’s conversion to
become the apostle Paul is a possible exception to this general rule of thumb. When Christ appeared to him on the
road to Damascus, Saul had little, if any, choice but to believe. Even if this were considered an irresistible draw, in
terms of the gospel call to faith, it was not irresistible grace in terms of regeneration preceding persuasion. After
his conversion, he taught that persuasion (i.e., faith) must precede regeneration (i.e., receiving the Spirit) in
passages such as Gal 3:2-3. Saul was persuaded by overwhelming evidence that Christ was indeed the Messiah,
who had in fact granted eternal life to those believers whom he was now persecuting. This might be termed
irresistible persuasion.
        To be sure, this proposal of irresistible persuasion is conjectural since a counterpoint could be made that
many of those who live during the millennium will rebel against Christ at the end of the millennium. Despite what
would be considered overwhelming evidence, that should irresistibly lead any thinking person to trust in Christ,
many of those living in this future period will fail to see the need to trust in Christ alone for eternal life. Therefore,
it could be argued that there is no such thing as irresistible persuasion—even under the best of circumstances. This
counterproposal has considerable merit, and I do not wish to be dogmatic in entertaining the possibility of God
invoking limited irresistible persuasion. Still, it does seem plausible that those living in this future period will
perhaps think that their suppressed sin nature and resulting practical righteousness and presence in the millennial
kingdom will qualify them as being good enough to enter the eternal kingdom. They may, therefore, fail to trust in
Christ alone for their entrance into the eternal kingdom, just as many in our churches today are deceived into
thinking that their good lives and presence in the church partially qualifies them for entrance into heaven. Then
again, what might be irresistible persuasion to one person might not necessarily be irresistible to another.
        Even in the case of Saul, it cannot be said that the Lord bypassed Saul’s intellect in drawing him to faith.
When a prosecutor seeks to convince a jury with irrefutable evidence to believe in the defendant’s guilt, the
prosecutor does not bypass the jury’s intellect. When the Lord confronted Saul on the road to Damascus and
confronted him with his guilt, the Lord presented Saul with irrefutable evidence beyond any reasonable shadow of
a doubt that Saul was guilty of persecuting the risen Lord.† He did not bypass Saul’s intellect in presenting His
case. Saul immediately realized his guilt when confronted by the evidence. The Lord persuaded rather than forced
Saul to believe. God certainly did not do the believing for Saul.
        In any case, since God’s will (as expressed in this topical presentation of predestination) may be either
resistible or irresistible, it would not be surprising if on certain occasions God has chosen to act irresistibly. God

*
    See Illustration 77. Predestination, 189.
†
    Christ’s ongoing, shared life with the believers meant that in persecuting believers, Saul was persecuting Christ.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 261
can, when He so chooses, act irresistibly. The question naturally will be posed as to why God does not act
irresistibly on all occasions to persuade humanity if He can do so on special occasions. The answer is simple: He
does not have to do so in order to save humanity. The Lord has made salvation possible for all apart from
irresistible persuasion, much less apart from irresistible force. He does not have to drag a person to Him in order to
enable humanity to come to Him. The Lord’s preference is gentle persuasion rather than irresistible persuasion.
This makes the evangelistic efforts of His children a very real factor in whether people will come to faith. If we do
not persist in winning the lost, they will be lost for eternity. The battle is real and the stakes are high. Predestination
does not predetermine who will believe; it merely predetermines what will happen to those who do believe.

                                                  Hearts of Water
        God can move the hearts of kings and world rulers irresistibly when He so desires like “channels of water”
(Prov 21:1). Yet even this passage may be talking about God executing considerable positive influence rather than
irresistible influence, or it may be negatively referring to judicial hardening rather than sovereign hardening. Even
if the middle foreknowledge position is taken (in which God not only foreknows what will happen but what could
happen), and even if the variation of middle foreknowledge is adopted in which God irresistibly can influence us
through our circumstances, this still fails to demonstrate that this is His normal method of operation. Even if it is
acknowledged that the 144,000 are typified by Paul’s type of conversion, such irresistible drawing would be the
exception rather than the rule.
        Certainly God influences people. But this affirmation of common grace is not an unlimited endorsement of
irresistible grace. Irresistible influence does not appear to be His general method of operation. How much less
would predetermination of every act of humanity or every circumstance affecting humanity be considered
scriptural? For example, let us presume that Jesus knew when and how to appear to Thomas in such a way so as to
dispel any doubt that Thomas had, and the Lord chose to appear to him in such a way as to make doubt realistically
impossible (Jn 20:24-28). One could then consider this an exceptional instance in which God chose to act
sovereignly through irresistible influence by means of His middle foreknowledge. At the same time, however, there
were some for whom Jesus’ post-resurrection appearance did not remove all doubt (Mt 28:17). Jesus did not intend
for even His post-resurrection appearances sovereignly to remove all doubt from everyone, not even from those
who already were believers. As a general rule, God does not act sovereignly through intermediate means (such as
burning bushes and blinding lights) to cause us to believe. And it could be argued that He never acts sovereignly
from eternity to cause humanity to disbelieve; rather, in such cases He acts judicially to harden those who already
have hardened themselves.*
        God’s omnibenevolence does not require that He do everything possible to save everyone. Rather, it only
necessitates that He do everything necessary to save everyone. And He has done so objectively in an unlimited
atonement and subjectively through prevenient grace. The Son woos those who are to be His Bride. It is not a
shotgun wedding. God desires a freewill response on the part of those who are to rule with Him in heaven. As to
the blinding-light and burning-bush experiences, in both cases this was prompted by God’s love for His persecuted
people more so than by His love for any one individual. God’s people were praying for deliverance, and God acted
in their behalf. God can restrain evil and promote good on behalf of His people.

                                          Abimelech and Nations
       White’s affirmation of common grace as the means through which God restrains evil is appreciated. On the
basis of Gen 20:6, White states: “God prevented Abimelech from committing an act of sin. If God could keep him
from sinning in this instance, could He not have kept him from sinning in any other given instance? Of course.”
White makes a similar point concerning Ex 34:24, where God even promises to prevent the desire of Israel’s
enemies to sin against her under special circumstances. From these examples, White affirms that God “has a
purpose in what He allows.” I myself have no quarrel with such points and neither does Hunt. Still, it should be
acknowledged that White is making some rather gratuitous assumptions even in these remarks.

Abimelech (Gen 20:6)
       First, concerning Gen 20:6, the means through which God kept Abimelech from sin should be taken into
consideration. The fact of restraining grace is seen easily enough in this verse: “I also kept you from sinning
against Me; therefore I did not let you touch her.” But the means of restraining grace are contextually just as
evident: “But God came to Abimelech in a dream of the night, and said to him, ‘Behold, you are a dead man
*
    See Appendix 8. Judicial Hardening, 821.
Page 262                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is married’” (Gen 20:3). God imparted information to
Abimelech through means of a dream that He was going to kill Abimelech for taking Abraham’s wife.
        Naturally, but not irresistibility, Abimelech’s desire to take Abraham’s wife was diminished, perhaps even
destroyed. The threat of death did more than just dampen his sexual desire. So allow me to agree with White that
God killed Abimelech’s desire to sin. But the interesting point is how God did so—by imparting information. The
Lord did not bypass Abimelech’s mental faculties. Had Abimelech been a fool, he could have gone ahead with his
plans to take Sarah sexually. God did not take away Abimelech’s free will. On the contrary, God’s warning makes
it very clear that God’s intent was to kill Abimelech. Naturally, Abimelech was quite free to continue in his intent
to take Sarah. Of course, God would have been quite content to carry through in His intent to kill Abimelech before
Abimelech was able to carry out his evil intent. Nevertheless, Abimelech was still free to try to keep Sarah as his
own, if he were foolish enough to make such an attempt.
        Abimelech chose the wiser course of action: give Abraham back his wife before God took his life.
Nevertheless, the fact still remains that Abimelech chose this course of action. God did not take away Abimelech’s
power of choice. Abimelech could have chosen to persist in his original intent and could have been killed as a
result. When Pilate was faced with a decision as to whether to crucify Jesus, God gave him a warning through his
wife’s dream: “And while he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent to him, saying, ‘Have nothing to do
with that righteous Man; for last night I suffered greatly in a dream because of Him’” (Mt 27:19). Notwithstanding
this warning, Pilate gave in to the political pressure and had Jesus crucified. One man heeded God’s warning; the
other did not. They were both culpable free agents. The dreams did not fatalistically, or Calvinistically, determine
their response. Oneiric warnings militate against Calvinistic conclusions.
        To be sure, the Calvinist is free to respond that God was taking action to prevent Abimelech from fulfilling
his sexual desire even before that desire was taken away by means of a dream. Again, I have no quarrel with such a
conjecture, although it is only that—a conjecture. Libertarians believe that God works circumstantially through
providential means to accomplish His will sovereignly. In other words, God could have had Abimelech so
preoccupied with other activities that he would not have had time to carry out his sexual desire. But once more, this
circumstantial restriction fails to prove lack of free volition.

Nations (Ex 34:24)
        White appears to be on a little firmer ground in the passage about the nations since it deals directly with
desires: “For I will drive out nations before you and enlarge your borders, and no man shall covet your land when
you go up three times a year to appear before the Lord your God” (Ex 34:24). In connection with the present
discussion of predestination, it may be pointed out that if this passage is merely predictive, then it fails to provide
the support that White seeks to derive from it. Predestination as well as prophecy are both based on prescience.
Additionally, both may relate information concerning the future. Moreover, whether these future events may-
versus-must happen should be determined contextually from the nature of what is being predestined or prophesied.
Just because something will happen does not mean that it must happen.* If God’s statement here in Exodus is
simply declarative rather than determinative, then God is simply providing His people assurance that they will be
safe at that time. If this seems too weak a proposal, then perhaps a little amplification is in order.
        If Israel were to choose to obey God, as they were being exhorted to do, and become a mighty and
prosperous force as a result, then it is conceivable that no neighboring nation would want to try to go in and take
their land on their festive occasions. It is hard to want something when you are aware it will cost you your life, as
Abimelech readily would attest. If the front doors of our refrigerators were shaped and functioned like guillotines,
dieting would be much easier would it not? If it were apparent to Israel’s neighbors that God was blessing Israel
and that Israel would easily destroy anyone who attacked her, it would be understandable that no one would want
to do so. The Doberman pinschers in your yard may lead would-be thieves to desire the property of someone else
rather than your own.
        Despite the weakness of White’s proof text, I will allow him the induction he desires and show that his
deduction still does not necessarily follow. In defense of White’s proposal, it is plausible that in Ex 34:24 God not
only saw what would happen but took responsibility to see to it that it would happen. In other words, it could be
taken as a promise of what will happen as a result of God’s direct intervention in the hearts of men rather than a
mere prophecy of what would circumstantially happen to the hearts of men. However, even granting White this
foothold in the text for the sake of good sportsmanship fails to provide him sufficient leverage by which to scale
the exegetical heights to which he aspires. It is hard to rock climb with a U-Haul tied to one’s back.

*
    See “Key to Foreknowledge” in Predestination and the Open View.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                            Page 263
        Inducements
        The present writer believes, evidently in harmony with White, that God can and does put and take thoughts
and desires in and from the hearts of men. However, God does not bypass interaction with their intellect in doing
so. Yet it would appear that White somehow wants to move beyond this point and deduce that such action on
God’s part violates libertarian free will, at least on such occasions, and somehow indicates that man has no
libertarian free will in the cerebral sphere.461 But where is the logic in such an assumption?

       Confinements
       Even siding with White as to God’s give-and-take method of operation in the hearts of men, there are still
multiple weaknesses in White’s approach. First, let it be noted that White’s opponents advocate both prevenient
and preventative grace. Hunt has no problem affirming that God can act sovereignly to prevent evil, and Geisler
likewise affirms that God’s providential will may be sovereign. Providentially and sovereignly, God will carry out
His plans. God’s circumstantial will may indeed circumscribe our options. God works our circumstances according
to His will so that He can even turn bad into good (Gen 50:20; Rom 8:28). Circumstantially, He can use our
circumstances to limit our options circumscriptively or change the outcome of the intended result of our actions.
       To be sure, White is correct that although God worked the evil that Joseph’s brothers intended for good, this
does not excuse them for the evil “intention of their hearts. We dare not think that Joseph’s brothers were forced
against the desires of their hearts to commit the evil of selling their brother into slavery” (emphasis his).462 But
White’s misdirection only seeks to evade the real issues. (1) Were Joseph’s brothers forced by the desires of their
hearts to commit evil? White’s compatibilism would have to answer yes. (2) Were these internal desires
sovereignly caused by God’s arrangement of external factors? Again yes, compatibilistically speaking. In other
words, God Calvinistically set a series of events in motion that irresistibly caused Joseph’s brother’s to sin. They
could not do otherwise. In short, God irresistibly caused them to sin. The logical conclusion of Calvinism
demonstrates that Calvinism is incompatible with God’s nature in that Calvinism logically pictures God as causing
moral evil so that He work it for good.
       White’s criticism of Hunt and Geisler would appear to be misplaced in that White merely is mouthing
positions as his own with which Hunt and Geisler already would agree. God not only takes action to encourage
good behavior but also to discourage bad behavior. God may act with persuasion or dissuasion in doing so. He can
put thoughts into our hearts or take them out of our hearts in doing so. Satan works similarly. God puts thoughts
into someone’s heart (Neh 7:5); Satan does also (Jn 13:2; Acts 5:3). Satan takes away thoughts from a person’s
heart (Lk 8:12), and so does God, as White notes above. Supernatural influence is a given in Scripture. But it
should not be assumed that such influence is necessarily irresistibly causative.

        Permissive Will
        The primary weakness in White’s argument concerning restraining grace that captures Hunt’s attention is
that White uses the word “allow.” By logical necessity, White cannot be satisfied to say that God merely allows us
to respond.* This would allow us free will. Rather, Calvinism requires that God causes the response that pleases
Him. It would seem, accordingly, that God caused: (1) Satan to fall; (2) Satan to tempt Adam; and (3) Adam to
fall.† Accordingly, Adam did not fall; he was pushed—by God. If God causes everything and does everything
according to His good pleasure, then a logical explanation should be provided by White as to why God is not the
author of sin and as to why our sin does not please God. Simply claiming that lack of free will is not incompatible
with moral responsibility or with God not being the author of sin hardly suffices for a logically satisfying answer.
For this reason, Hunt regards Calvinistic compatibilism to be theological double-talk. And it is difficult to see
