where Hunt is at fault in this assessment of White’s position.
        For God simply to allow us to respond is nothing more than an affirmation of permissive will. It appears that
White is convoluting permissive will with providential will. He is attempting to make providential will universal to
the practical exclusion of permissive will. Instead, I would affirm both and say that God can work providentially in
the above examples when He so chooses and respond permissively on other occasions to allow libertarian free will.
Walls and Dongell alert us to another manner in which Calvinists mislead their readers into thinking that Calvinists
truly affirm God’s permissive will in a way that is compatible with human freedom:



*
    See Permit the Fall?, 715.
†
    See Illustration 252. Calvinistic Dominos, 712.
Page 264                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
         God’s permission, then, is [Calvinistically speaking] simply his choice to allow things to unfold as
         He has already determined they will. This is an odd way to think of permission and a highly
         misleading way of speaking. Calvinists can insist on using the language of permission, but we think
         it’s strained and unnatural.463

        Influence
        Additionally, it may be noted that in imputing and removing thoughts or emotions from our hearts or minds,
neither God nor Satan is bypassing the cerebral sphere of influence. In other words, it is not necessary for God to
regenerate a person in order to exert this type of influence. Nor is it necessary for Satan to inhabit a person’s spirit
in order to inhibit the person’s freewill response with this type of persuasional pressure either.* God does not have
to regenerate a person before He can provide that person with the desire to be saved. Regeneration need not
logically occur before saving faith. God is able to affect and effect desires before regeneration. White has
unwittingly refuted his primary argument in which he maintains that regeneration must occur before faith.
Logically speaking, this is not necessary as he himself has demonstrated.
        His approach to this topic concerning divine influence undercuts his primary argument—that God needs to
act in irresistible manner by regenerating a person without his or her consent in order to elicit a favorable desire or
response from that person. On the contrary, certainly much to his chagrin, White’s argument demonstrates
otherwise. Under the influence of the gospel, those who are dead in sin can respond rightly to God’s call. God can
act indirectly and directly on the unregenerate heart through external and internal means to accomplish His ends
without resorting to regeneration. In giving man free will, God has not necessarily given man free rein. God did not
bypass Paul’s or Moses’ ego (mind, emotion, and will) by regenerating them before bringing them to faith. Satan
does not have to possess a person to blind that person sufficiently from seeing the truth of the gospel. And God
does not have to regenerate a person in order to enlighten that person sufficiently to see the truth of the gospel. The
lost who go to hell will have no one to blame but themselves. The saved who go to the outer darkness will likewise
have no one but themselves to blame as well.

Three Basic Views of Election
      Of course, one’s overall theology will determine to a significant degree whether the election in view is
considered irresistible or resistible. This is to be expected. For example, in Jn 3:15-16 the NAS has changed may
and should to will and would respectively. The newer edition reads,
         15
           That whoever believes will [not may] in Him have eternal life. 16 For God so loved the world, that
         He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall [not should] not perish, but have
         eternal life.

        The resulting impression from this change is that the editors desire to communicate the          dit
                                                                                                      on i

                                                                                                        w
certainty of eternal life. If this is an accurate perception of their intention, then the current              onal
                                                                                                    Unc


author readily admits that he shares this assessment of John’s promises.464 While attending an
Arminian Bible study in college, Jn 3:16 was read, and then the author was asked what he
thought of the verse. Being a firm advocate of eternal security, the author responded that he
understood the verse as teaching that he was going to heaven whether he liked it or not, that he could not go to hell
even if he so desired because he had trusted in Christ for eternal life and therefore eternally had such life. This
answer was equivalent to throwing a theological hand grenade into the center of the room. The explosion was
immediate. The author’s logic was straightforward. He had believed in Jesus and thus had eternal life and would
not perish in hell. For him, Jn 3:16 could just as well be translated, “For God so loved the world, that He gave His
only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him would not perish, but have eternal life.” This is indicated in the
illustration by a “W.”† God has predetermined that all believers would be in Christ and thus unconditionally would
go to heaven. Once they have met the stated condition of belief, they have no choice concerning the stated
outcome. The choice regarding the outcome was God’s and God’s alone. On the other hand, their Arminian logic
was also to the point. They had believed and had eternal life. But even though they “should not perish,” they might
perish if they did not continue in belief or live up to the implications of their belief.


*
    See “Advanced Trichotomous Model” in Trichotomy.
†
    See Illustration 77. Predestination, 189.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 265
        For an example of this type of Arminian perspective, one may turn to a Lutheran such as Lenski who says
that “should not perish” simply means: “God does not want him to perish.” Nevertheless, such believers will perish
if they stop believing.465 Thus, for Lenski the “should not perish” of Jn 3:16 is equivalent to the expression in
2Pet 3:9. Although it is not God’s will (i.e., desire) that any “should perish,” nevertheless many will perish. No one
should perish. The Arminian God does not want anyone to perish, much less believers, but this does not prove that
believers cannot perish any more than it proves that everyone will be saved. The fact that we should not perish
does not prove that we cannot perish. However, this Arminian evasion of the nature of the promise in Jn 3:16
stands or falls with whether or not the text requires continuous faith. I deal thoroughly with this consideration of
the verb tense elsewhere and demonstrate, contrary to Lenski and others, that continuous faith is not required by
this present participle.* For now, I will be content merely with the syntax.
        The hina purpose clause in Jn 3:16 indicates the aim or goal of the action. The goal of God’s action in
giving His Son is that we believe and have eternal life as a result. The stated condition for having eternal life is that
we simply believe. The moment a person meets that stated condition, he or she has the intended result—eternal
life. In this case, should refers to something that happens the very instant that one meets the stated condition of
believing in Jesus. The intended result becomes a guaranteed result (and thus an irresistible result) once the
stated condition has been met. Not only is the temporal result (of having eternal life) immediately guaranteed, but
the eschatological result (of not perishing) must inevitably follow. Those who meet the stated condition will not
perish. Where the purpose is unconditionally guaranteed, the hina purpose clause can be legitimately translated as
would or will. Where the purpose is contextually conditional, should, may, or might is a better translation.466
        Although Lavender loves to overtranslate the subjunctive mood so as to deny guaranteed result and eternal
security,† the fact that should have in this construction is equivalent to has in this context is clear from parallels:

         •    Every believer in Him...should have eternal life (Jn 3:16; TM).
         •    The believer in the Son has eternal life (Jn 3:36; TM).

Once the conditional aspect of the contingency has been met, the subjunctive nature of the mood becomes moot,
and the potentiality becomes certainty, because the fulfillment is now only dependent on God’s veracity.
Lavender’s criticism thus becomes moot. Context underscores that the believer has eternal life, not merely should
have eternal life (see also Jn 5:24; 6:47). Wallace and White are correct on at least this matter: The subjunctive
mood can be just as indicative as the indicative mood once the condition has been met.
       The legitimate component of Lavender’s criticism, however, does not fall on deaf ears in that it is herein
acknowledged that Jn 3:17 is best translated as should: “The world should be saved through Him.” The salvation
is contextually conditioned on whether they believe, and it is not stated that the world has met that condition.467 If
vv. 16 and 17 were combined into one verse, then we would have: “For God did not send the Son into the world to
judge the world, but that anyone in the world who believes in Him will [=would] not perish but be saved instead.”
Salvation is unconditional for believers in this combined verse, since they already have met the condition. Not
perishing is unconditionally guaranteed for believers. But, as it is, v. 17 does not state that the condition has been
met; rather, it should be met. You have to believe in order for the promise to apply to you. There is no excuse for
not believing. After believing, it is inexcusable to claim that you cannot know that you have eternal life.468
       A balance between the Arminian and Calvinistic perspectives is possible. Arminians are correct in that
there are passages that teach a conditional election and are best translated as should (or an equivalent), and
Calvinists are correct in that there are passages that teach an unconditional election and are best translated by
would (or an equivalent).
                                              Illustration 95. Unconditional Election

               PEARS                                    GRAPE                                    TULIP
               (should)                              (would/should)                              (would)
              position                               position                                position
              practice                               practice                                practice
          An all-or-nothing attitude pertaining to Calvinism versus Arminianism is not necessary. The Arminian
*
    See Jn 3:16 in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
†
    See the author’s book, Drawing and Appointment.
Page 266                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
PEARS acronym denies that election unconditionally guarantees a believer’s position or practice. Since neither the
believer’s position or practice is guaranteed in Arminian theology, it is represented as should concerning both
above. Calvinists, on the other hand, insist that election unconditionally guarantees both a believer’s position and
practice. True believers will persevere.* Their TULIP understanding of both the believer’s position and practice are
marked as would above. God predetermined that the elect would have the position and practice corresponding to
their election. The Arminian argument against the security of a believer’s position is extremely weak. Conversely,
the Calvinistic argument that all believers live holy lives is exceedingly weak. GRAPE takes the strengths of both
positions and rejects the weaknesses of both by affirming that Scripture guarantees the believer’s position (marked
as would) but does not guarantee the believer’s practice (marked as should).
        Concerning Eph 1:4, Arminians and Marrowians may agree that the best translation is that the Lord elected
us so that “we should be holy and blameless.” However, for the Arminian this affirmation in reality frequently
means that we must be holy and blameless if we hope to reach heaven. To clarify between the positions and to
indicate how the passage is truly understood by the three camps, the following translations are suitable
representations:

                                                           Arminianism
        He elected us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we must be holy and blameless before Him.

                                                            Marrowism
        He elected us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before Him.

                                                             Calvinism
        He elected us in Him before the foundation of the world, that we will be holy and blameless before Him.

Must, Should, Will
       To further clarify the distinctions between these three approaches, it will be helpful to consider other
popular ramifications of their teaching. Soft Arminians (a.k.a., Reformed Arminians) affirm that believers can
commit apostasy (i.e., fall away from the faith) and in doing so lose eternal life.469 Strong Arminians (i.e.,
Wesleyan Arminians) may go further and say that if a believer continues in the faith but fails to continue in
faithfulness, he or she will lose eternal life. Regardless of the Arminian particulars, Arminians as a whole reject
both the preservation (eternal security) and perseverance (guarantee of general faithfulness) of the saints. The
distinguishing characteristic between Marrowism and Arminianism is that Arminians believe that you must
continue in faith (and quite frequently faithfulness) in order to keep eternal life. GRAPE affirms that although you
should continue in faith and faithfulness, this continuation is not required for eternal salvation but for temporal
and misthological salvation.
       Calvinists not only affirm the preservation of the saints; they also affirm the perseverance of the saints. By
perseverance they mean that anyone who trusts in Christ alone will persevere in faith and faithfulness (i.e., in a life
of holiness and good works). As a result, Calvinists deny that the elect can commit apostasy. Marrowists, by
contrast, while affirming eternal security, maintain by means of GRAPE that, although believers should persevere
and produce a life of good works, believers may fail to do so. Marrowism thus affirms the preservation of the saints
but not the perseverance of the saints.
                                      Illustration 96. Three Major Soteriological Positions

         PEARS                                         GRAPE                                           TULIP
         (must)                                        (should)                                         (will)
     preservation                                  preservation                                 preservation
     perseverance                                  perseverance                                 perseverance


*
  In reality, by making perseverance a requirement to reach heaven, Calvinists teach conditional security. Yet for the purpose of this
present illustration, I am representing Calvinists as they sometimes perceive themselves, that is, as advocates of eternal security. Their
status as advocates of security will be challenged as we proceed.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                              Page 267
        These three competing soteriological positions can be summarized as must, should, and will. The must and
will approaches both teach salvation by works since they maintain that it is impossible to reach heaven apart from a
faith that works. Peterson, a Calvinist, argues that perseverance is a requirement for final salvation (i.e., entrance
into heaven) and quotes O’Brien in support of his contention that will means must: “If it is true that the saints will
persevere to the end, then it is equally true that the saints must persevere to the end.”470 In the end, the Calvinistic
will is equivalent to the Arminian must.
        As Calvinists Peterson and Williams acknowledge: “Arminians and Calvinists agree that professed
Christians must continue to the end in three areas if they are to be saved: believing the gospel, loving Christ and
other believers, and living godly lives.” “It is necessary for professed believers to persevere in love of Christ and
their neighbors if they are finally to be saved.” “Put simply, perseverance in holiness is essential for Christians to
reach heaven.” But they think they offer their readers reassurance when they maintain, “The saints not only must
persevere but will persevere because of God’s grace” (italics theirs). But the conclusion, all the same, is that your
soteriological salvation is conditioned on synergistic cooperation with God in Calvinism: “Scripture clearly and
frequently affirms the obligation of those who profess Christ to continue believing the gospel (Col 1:21-23), loving
God and other Christians (Jn 15:9, 12, 17), and living holy lives (Heb 12:14).”471
        Postconversional works, or more specifically, perseverance in works is required for entrance into heaven in
both systems of thought. Advocates of both of these two extreme positions (Arminianism and Calvinism) teach that
practical holiness and blamelessness, as demonstrated by walking in good works, is necessary to be saved from
hell. Consequently, Calvinism really teaches conditional security. The balanced view, that of the Grace camp,
teaches that entrance into heaven is not dependent on personal holiness, but rewards in heaven are so conditioned.
Thus, the overall perspective of the FG view, as represented in Marrowism, is superior.

Personal Holiness
       This is not to say that all FG interpretations are always preferable to the interpretations offered by the other
camps, however. For example, a FG Salvationist could argue that the holiness referred to in Eph 1:4 is positional
holiness in an attempt to circumvent the LS conclusion that all believers will live holy lives. But the perception that
practical sanctification is in view in this verse is supported by the conceptual parallel of Eph 2:10 and the verbal
parallel of Col 1:22-23. It should thus be acknowledged that the Lordship Salvationists are correct on this particular
point in this specific verse. What is not conceded, however, is that practical sanctification is inevitably guaranteed.
It is not. Rather, we should be holy; we can be holy; we ought to be holy. But this experiential aspect of our
holiness is conditioned upon our decision to obey the exhortations in the second half of the epistle. The pre-
temporal election of Eph 1:4 makes the temporal consequences of that election possible.

Five Views of Eternal Security
       In the book Four Views on Eternal Security, five views of eternal security actually are described. The fifth
view is the FG view, which was denounced by the authors representing the other four views. Unfortunately, no
representative of the FG view (i.e., the Marrowistic option) was given an opportunity to speak. It is ironic that in a
book discussing eternal security, the one group that truly advocates eternal security was not given opportunity to
make a case for this vital doctrine. The closest advocate in the four-views book is Norman Geisler. Much of what
Geisler has to say is very much in harmony with FG theology. Therefore, a good deal of his discussion is very
enjoyable to read. However, his lack of consistency in trying to defend eternal security is attributable primarily to a
fundamental flaw in his Calvinistic premise concerning perseverance. I will expand upon the above discussion to
allow interaction with his deficiency.
       But first, a brief defense for positioning the Marrowistic approach as a mediating position is in order,
particularly since some in the other camps who try to paint FG as an extremist position. Horton is the
representative for strong Calvinism in Four Views on Eternal Security. He denies that eternal security is a
Calvinistic doctrine and attributes the doctrine of eternal security to “Arminian presuppositions concerning grace
and free will.”472 He seeks to disassociate himself from eternal security throughout his discussion. Harper, the
representative for the Strong Arminian position, is startled that Horton tries to deny that eternal security is a
Calvinistic doctrine. Harper claims that Calvin was a powerful proponent of eternal security.473 Such exchanges are
not uncommon between Arminians and Calvinists.
Page 268                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                         Illustration 97. OSAS—Whose is It?




              It’s Yours!                                                      It’s Yours!


                   nians                                                      Calvinis ts
              Ar mi                                OSAS


       The doctrine of eternal security is popularly referred to as once saved always saved (OSAS). But logically,
if Arminians are pointing their finger at the Calvinists and claiming that OSAS is a Calvinistic teaching, and if the
Calvinists are, in turn, pointing their finger back at the Arminians and claiming that OSAS is an Arminian
teaching, then OSAS is best pictured as a mediating position between the two camps. It cannot be pictured as an
extremist position to the left or right when both alternative camps are pointing their fingers at each other and
accusing each other of believing in eternal security. Since they are pointing their fingers at one another and
attributing OSAS to the other, logically OSAS must be located between them. They cannot stand shoulder to
shoulder and point at FG as being a extremist position when they are pointing their fingers at one another and
accusing each other of teaching FG theology. Since FG theology is, at its heart, an argument for the unconditional
security of the one who has come to faith in Christ, those pointing at OSAS are in reality pointing at the FG camp.
                                     Illustration 98. OSAS—Whose bastard is It?




                  It’s our bastard.                              It’s our bastard.




                                                   OSAS
                          Arminians                                  Calvinists


       The same conclusion may be reached even when considering the opinions of Arminians and Calvinists
holding viewpoints that are opposite to the Arminian and Calvinistic criticisms above. Arminians Walls and
Dongell in their co-authored book Why I am not a Calvinist claim that many Arminians hold to OSAS and cite
Norman Geisler as an example. Thus, these Arminians attribute OSAS to the Arminian camp. Yet in the very
section to which they differ the reader for Geisler’s treatment, Geisler identifies himself as a moderate Calvinist, as
opposed to an Arminian, in affirming eternal security.474 Calvinists Peterson and Williams in their co-authored
book Why I am not an Arminian put forth a defense of eternal security that is conditioned on perseverance. These
Calvinists, like many others, act as though eternal security were a Calvinistic doctrine. Yet none of these authors
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 269
would have anything to do with an eternal security that is truly unconditional for the person who has become a
believer. A truly unconditional security would be an anomaly (or worse) for either the Arminians or Calvinists who
are said to affirm it. According to Walls and Dongell, “those who hold to eternal security while rejecting the
middle three points are not truly Calvinists but rather a sort of Calvinist-Arminian hybrid.”475 Calling unconditional
security a hybrid is a polite scholastic way of saying that it is a theological half-breed that one should view in
disgust. Reasoner is more livid: “The modern eternal security teaching is a bastard doctrine which neither true
Calvinists nor Arminians will claim.”476 If Calvinists or Arminians claim unconditional security as their own, it is
only as a bastard child that does not legitimately bear their family name.
       Unlike Calvinism which shuns OSAS and Arminianism which attacks OSAS, Marrowism embraces true
eternal security (i.e., unconditional security) and defends OSAS. Marrowists will gladly accept the backhanded
association of eternal security with the FG camp and take it as a compliment. We believe in the unconditional
security of the person who has become a believer even if such a person does not remain a believer. We do not turn
eternal security into a conditional security that is viable only for those who persevere in the faith. In response to the
question, “To what theological camp does this doctrine of unconditional security legitimately belong?” our
emphatic rejoinder is, “It belongs to us!” In terms of theological consistency and popular association, OSAS is the
doctrine of the FG camp. This theological child, given birth by the Scriptures and orphaned by the theologians, will
find welcome sanctuary in our Marrowistic writings.
       The GES motto is: Faith Alone in Christ Alone. Correspondingly, saving faith may be defined as the belief
that one has eternal life simply as the result of believing in Christ alone for eternal life. Saving faith is to “believe
in Him for eternal life” (1Tim 1:16). As a result of this punctiliar, positive response of faith in Christ, believers
eternally have this life—no matter what. The security of their regeneration is not conditioned on the quantity or the
duration of their faith or faithfulness. Once they have believed in Christ, their security is guaranteed
unconditionally for eternity, even if they do not persevere in faith or faithfulness. Eternal security is the heartthrob
of Marrowistic theology, and thus the Marrowistic GRAPE acronym ends with an “E.” In contrast to the other two
camps who either ostracize or bastardize unconditional security, Marrowism is affirmation of unconditional
security, that is, genuine eternal security.
       Although the present book regards unconditional security to be the essence of what one must believe (in
order to come to saving faith), this book is not so much dedicated to defending eternal security as it is to using it as
a hermeneutical tool to explain Scripture. Even aside from offering observations in defense of OSAS as a
vindication of this premise as a tool to explore Scripture, the occasional arguments offered herein in favor of OSAS
are certainly in harmony with the stated topic of rewards in that any book dedicated to a strong presentation of the
biblical teaching of rewards lends itself quite naturally to a defense of eternal security. In Four Views on Eternal
Security, Geisler constantly uses the doctrine of rewards to defend security. And he is correct in doing so. Biblical
misthology is a natural champion of soteriological security.
       As noted, Geisler takes what he calls a moderate form of Calvinism. And I appreciate the fact that there are
moderate Calvinists who, at least in their minds, defend eternal security. However, moderate Calvinists are
normally described as four point Calvinists, but Geisler would be more accurately described as a one point
Calvinist at best. The only point of the TULIP that he truly affirms is the worst one: (P) the perseverance of the
saints. But even here he modifies the typical Calvinistic position and waters it down only to affirm the
perseverance of the saints in faith, not in faithfulness. He rejects the strong Calvinistic position that we must
persevere in faithfulness. Theologically, Geisler affirms only half of the Calvinistic position concerning
perseverance. Thus, Geisler would be better described as a mild Calvinist rather than a moderate Calvinist.
Theologically speaking, Geisler is a half-point Calvinist. Exegetically, however, he fluctuates between being a
half-point and one-point Calvinist. And this exegetical oscillation, combined with his theological insistence on the
half-point, cripples his consistency considerably. Rejecting the TULIP altogether is better. Geisler’s modifications
(splendidly depicted in his charts) may be expanded to modify the doctrine of perseverance completely so that it
affirms the perseverance of God’s perseverance rather than that of man. God perseveres in our preservation. He
permanently saves the person who comes to faith in Christ so that this person is classified as a believer even if that
believer subsequently should cease to believe. The subsequent classification of a person as a believer is based on
what the believer ontologically and positionally has become rather than what the person phenomenally believes or
does.
       The doctrine of assurance likewise suffers from Geisler’s inconsistent attempt to defend it. On the one hand,
he correctly notes a weakness in the Reformed view: “No one can really be sure he or she is one of the elect unless
he or she remains faithful to the end” (emphasis his).477 Geisler rejects perseverance in faithfulness on the basis of
present assurance. This aspect of his logic is sound. Since you cannot be certain that you will persevere in
faithfulness, you cannot be certain that you are one of the elect—if Calvinism is true. But since present assurance is
Page 270                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
possible, the Calvinistic insistence on perseverance in faith must be false. Present assurance is not conditioned on
perseverance in faith. Splendid logic! Yet Geisler immediately proceeds to presume that the same logic would not
apply to perseverance in faith. Surprisingly, Geisler claims: “All believers can be sure they are saved and will
continue in their faith to the end.”478
       It is amazing that one so gifted in logic as Geisler could be so inconsistent in its application. Believers
cannot be any more certain that they will continue in their faith than they can be certain that they will continue in
their faithfulness. In fact, faith may die long before faithfulness does. Believers can keep going through the
motions of going to church, tithing, and teaching, even though the faith that led them to do these things in the first
place begins to flicker out. The doctrine of perseverance is logically incompatible with the doctrine of present
assurance. Geisler’s insistence on present assurance logically should have resulted in his unequivocal rejection of
the Calvinistic doctrine of perseverance.
       Embarrassingly, Geisler, who is considered an advocate of eternal security, uses Heb 11:1 as his proof text
to support his insistence on perseverance in faith: “The presence of ‘faith’ is ‘evidence’ that one is truly saved.” 479
Gordon Olson holds to a much more consistent form of this mild Calvinism than does Geisler. Still, in an almost
equally embarrassing act concerning Heb 11:1, Olson seeks to divorce faith from assurance so that he can affirm
perseverance (or perhaps just preservation?) in faith for those who lose present assurance.480 Regrettably, Olson
espouses separation of faith from assurance, but commendably Olson at least recognizes that Heb 11:1 contextually
is not talking about saving faith. The passage is not describing soteriological faith but misthological faith. Faith
that perseveres is the faith that gains misthological approval through the confident expectation and assurance that
God will reward those who seek to save their souls (rather than their spirits) by misthologically seeking Him.481
These mild Calvinistic attempts by Geisler and Olson (to hold on to perseverance in faith) are doomed to failure
and inconsistency.
       Geisler affirms that 2Tim 2:13 is a strong affirmation of eternal security, correctly understanding the verse
to teach that even if we are faithless (i.e., unfaithful) God will save us. In other words, he uses it to deny
perseverance in faithfulness and yet says, “Our perseverance is assured by him.”482 This inconsistency is evidently
caused by the Calvinistic propensity to use preservation and perseverance interchangeably. Geisler easily could
have avoided this self-contradiction by using his terms more distinctly. In Chosen but Free, Geisler even goes a
step further in his affirmation of eternal security in 2Tim 2:13 to say, “Even if our faith falters, His faithfulness
does not.”483 In this statement he allows our faltering faithlessness to include lack of faith. Splendid! Yet he cannot
maintain this position for more than one page in his defense of eternal security. On the next page he retreats and
says that true believers endure and continue in the faith and never lose it! He falls for the Calvinistic tense fallacy
of 1Jn 3:9 and claims: “One’s perseverance in avoiding continual sin is a proof of one’s salvation.”484 But how can
he deny perseverance in faithfulness on the one hand and yet affirm that believers will not persevere in sin on the
other? Moreover, how does he affirm assurance of salvation apart from perseverance in faithfulness but claim that
such perseverance is “proof of one’s salvation”?
       Perhaps the most astonishing aspect of his failure to recognize the tense fallacy in 1Jn 3:9 is that he does
recognize and even refutes this misperception concerning the present tense used of believe in the Gospel of John.
Even if ample refutation of these tense fallacies was not provided in my book Believe, I simply could have allowed
Geisler to refute himself. He has an excellent section in which he provides positive citation of FG literature in
arguing that the present tense shows current rather than perpetual action and that continual faith is not necessary for
the reception or retention of eternal life. However, even in the midst of this short but splendid discussion, Geisler
introduces a fatal flaw when he says that continual faith is a “natural manifestation of” salvation (emphasis his).485
A Marrowist might have been willing to agree, or at least allow this statement to go unchallenged, if by natural he
really had meant natural rather than inevitable or necessary. In fact, his discussion of natural versus automatic or
inevitable is very commendable. He prefers natural over inevitable because:

       The word “inevitable”…seems to imply there is no free choice involved, but there is….So, perhaps
       “natural” is a better word, denoting the essential connection without guaranteeing a necessary
       product. For example, love for children comes natural to mothers; however, some mothers abuse
       their children. When this happens, however, they are not doing what comes naturally.486

His analogy is brilliant. Those in FG readily would agree. Hodges, for example, expresses the same sentiment:

           Under the New Covenant this law is inscribed on our hearts (Heb 8:10) and every act of
       obedience is the natural outworking of what we are inwardly….
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 271
                Please don’t misunderstand. Obviously I’m not saying that obedience to the New Covenant law
          is inevitable. But I am saying that it is natural. Of course, there is a significant difference between
          something that is inevitable and something that is natural.487 (Italics his.)

        Unfortunately, however, unlike Hodges, Geisler fails to apply this distinction to his discussion. Geisler
comments, “Only the faith that takes ‘root’ and produces ‘fruit’ (Luke 8:13,15) is true saving faith.” To which he
adds the old adage, “we are not saved by works but by faith that works.” “Good works flow naturally and inevitably
from” justifying faith.488 In making good works inevitable, Geisler appends works as necessary soteriological
baggage to reach heaven. While he admits that justification is by faith, he is conditioning glorification (i.e.,
entrance into heaven) on works. Geisler is being soteriologically inconsistent with himself and with Scripture when
he says that we are saved…by…works.
        If mothers can fail to do that which is natural, then why cannot God’s children fail to do what is natural? Is
Geisler asking us to believe that all children love and obey their parents even though all mothers do not love their
children? Geisler should have retained his perspective in which he acknowledged that both mothers and children
may fail to do what should come naturally. Paul has to exhort mothers to love their children (Tit 2:4) and children
to obey their parents (Eph 6:1). And Jesus warns: “And brother will deliver up brother to death, and a father his
child; and children will rise up against parents, and cause them to be put to death” (Mt 10:21). Neither mothers nor
children necessarily have the affections they naturally should.
        In trying to tone down the conditionality evident in his approach, Geisler approving cites Ryrie that weak,
erratic, invisible fruit would suffice during dormant states in a believer’s life.489 Yet, who reading the proof texts
Geisler cites would ever think that invisible fruit would qualify? Is Jesus referring to invisible fruit in the Parable
of the Sower? Is James saying that invisible fruit qualifies for the salvation he has in mind? Hardly! Geisler wisely
steers away from claiming that fruit is produced automatically. We are not automations. Nevertheless, he still
overstates his case by saying that fruit is produced naturally but acting as though it is produced sufficiently and
visibly to qualify for salvation from hell.
        Good works can be made theologically natural and even inevitable without making them exegetically
necessary to reach heaven.* But Geisler does not adequately or accurately articulate this inevitability. Quite the
contrary, he thinks that non-persevering “faith is not sufficient for salvation”490 and that faith without works does
not save.491 He is not content simply to say that saving faith should naturally express itself in good works and
continue throughout the course of one’s life and leave it at that. He has made good works a soteriological necessity.
        In response to his question as to “whether continual faith in Christ throughout one’s life is a necessary
indication that one is truly saved,” he denies that it is a “necessary condition,” but he makes it a necessary
manifestation.492 This semantic word play does little to conceal the conditional nature of the type of eternal security
offered by Geisler. The logical conclusion of his presentation would be that those who fail to persevere in faith will
go to hell; only those who persevere in faith and produce good works go to heaven. Geisler is a better spokesperson
for the doctrine of perseverance than he is for the doctrine of preservation. In trying to maintain both, he does
justice to neither. He severely cripples his own argument.
        The real question is not: “Do good works naturally accompany regeneration?” Certainly they do. The real
question is: “Do good works necessarily accompany regeneration?” Geisler waffles on this distinction. To make
what is natural a soteriological necessity is exegetically to condition entrance into heaven on this necessity. The
Marrowistic position, in contrast, argues that what is soteriologically natural is misthologically necessary for
rewards (misthos) in heaven rather than for entrance into heaven itself. Viewed from this perspective, Marrowism
does not divorce sanctification from justification. Rather, Marrowists believe that justification makes sanctification
possible and profitable, natural and normal.

Page 272                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
       Strong Arminians (also known as Wesleyan Arminians) and strong Calvinists affirm the necessity of both
perseverance in faith and faithfulness to reach heaven. Mild Arminians (also called Reformed Arminians) and mild
Calvinists (in theory) only affirm the necessity of perseverance in faith to reach heaven. Yet even the mild forms
inevitably make works indirectly necessary to reach heaven.493 In all four of these views, the believer’s security is
conditioned logically on his or her perseverance in faith and/or faithfulness. The only defense of eternal security
that does not condition a believer’s entrance into heaven on the believer’s perseverance is one that does not require
perseverance in either faith or faithfulness in order to reach heaven. This is the theology of the Free Grace camp.
The consistent eternal securitist is, in point of fact, the FG Salvationist. The “E” at the end of GRAPE is placed
strategically at the end of the FG acronym in contradistinction to the endings of the acronyms of the other camps
which end the affirmations of salvation through perseverance.
                              Illustration 100. Acronymic Salvation of Pears and TULIP
                                       P                         T
                                       E                         U
                                       A                         L
                                       R                         I
                                       Salvation through         Perseverance

Calvinistic Conditional Security

                                              Theological Inconsistency
        Both Arminians and Calvinists agree that if a believer does not persevere, then that believer goes to hell. So
both systems of thought teach conditional security. But some Calvinists object to being labeled conditional
securitists. The reason being, they argue, is that since perseverance is guaranteed unconditionally and, in their
system, caused by God, perseverance is not a condition. The logical fallacy of this Calvinistic remonstrance can be
illustrated in a comparison of initial and linear faith. If God unconditionally and irresistibly causing us to believe
means that our faith is not a condition for salvation, then even initial faith is not a condition for salvation within
Calvinism. It would be logically inconsistent within their system to exclude linear faith as a condition just because
God unconditionally guarantees it and yet include initial faith as a requirement despite the fact that God
unconditionally guarantees it.
        If God’s unconditionally guaranteeing the response means that the response is not a condition (which we
must meet for salvation), then the Calvinist must also reject initial faith as a condition for salvation. If guarantee
means unconditional, then faith is not a condition in Calvinism. The underlying problem is that faith is not really a
condition for salvation in Calvinism. The real condition is unconditional election. Given unconditional election,
both initial and linear faith are just irresistible byproducts. Be that as it may, to summarize the conditional necessity
embedded within Calvinism, as articulated by Calvinists, one may ask two questions:

           •    Is the salvation of the elect conditioned on whether they believe?
           •    Is the security of the elect conditioned on whether they persevere?

       Even Calvinists will answer the first question affirmatively. But if God causes the elect to believe, as
Calvinism maintains, and yet conditions their salvation on their faith, then it cannot be objected that perseverance
is a condition for the security of the elect, even though God causes them to persevere. God’s causing them to
believe does not mean that their believing is not a condition, so it cannot be maintained by Calvinists that just
because God causes them to persevere that their perseverance is not a condition. Even by Calvinistic standards, just
because God causes the perseverance, this does not mean that perseverance is not a condition. More consistent
Calvinist acknowledge the conditional security implicit in their system. Having demonstrated that Calvinism
teaches conditional security theologically, a brief illustration will make the same point biblically.

                                            Aspectual Inconsistency

Initial Faith is a condition for salvation
        Believe and be saved (Lk 8:12).
        Believe…and you will be saved (Acts 16:31).
        He who believes in Him will not perish (Jn 3:16).
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                          Page 273
Calminian Perseverance in faith is a condition for salvation
      He who continues to believe in Him will not perish (Jn 3:16).
      He who continues to believe continues to have eternal life (Jn 5:24).
      He who continues to eat and drink continues to have eternal life (Jn 6:54).
      He who continues to eat and drink continues to abide in Me (Jn 6:56).
      The one who endures to the end will be saved (Mt 10:22; Mk 13:13).
      You are saved, if you hold fast (1Cor 15:2).
      Women will be saved…if they continue in faith (1Tim 2:15).
      If we deny Him, He also will deny us (2Tim 2:12).

        Since Calvinists make both initial and continual faith the necessary co-conditions for the same soteriological
result in Jn 3:16, it must be concluded that they teach conditional security. If you do not want to perish in a
Calminian hell, then you must believe and continue to do so.* The same is true of Calvinism and Arminianism. But
Marrowism, on the other hand, does not lump Jn 3:16 into the second category of texts above and would not
translate it as continues to believe. Marrowists reject making linear faith a soteriological requirement. To be sure,
the Bible makes both initial and linear faith a condition for salvation. Therefore, linear faith must be a condition,
but the question is, “For what type of salvation?”
        For the Calvinist, it is necessary to continue to believe in order to reach heaven, so continuous faith is a
soteriological requirement. For the Marrowists, however, it is necessary to continue to believe in order to be saved
from loss of rewards in heaven and thus from the outer darkness. Therefore, Calvinism makes continuous faith a
soteriological necessity, whereas Marrowism makes continuation in faith a misthological necessity. Calvinism
teaches conditional soteriological security. Marrowism, in contrast, teaches unconditional soteriological security
but conditional misthological security. Accordingly, in Marrowism, if you want salvation from the outer darkness,
you must stay true to the faith. In Calvinism, in contrast, if you want to reach heaven, you must stay true to the
faith. Calvinism makes heaven itself a reward.

                                                Salvation by Works
        Although there are splendid writers like Gordon Olson and Geisler who basically reject all of Calvinism
except for perseverance in faith and then try to offer a perseverance-based defense of OSAS, in doing so they retain
the worst part of Calvinism—the part that teaches a false gospel of salvation by works. To make perseverance in
faith a requirement to reach heaven is to teach a false gospel because doing so conditions salvation on linear faith,
which is a meritorious response in Scripture. This is anathema to FG theology, which teaches preservation not
perseverance. FG theology stands out in bright contrast to Shank’s conditional security: “Jesus affirmed that the
condition whereby He perseveres in the saints is that they persevere in Him” (emphasis his).494 Shank has little
problem with Calvinistic election as a condition for the final realization of salvation: “While it is true that the elect
will persevere to the end, that is only half the truth; for it is equally true that they who persevere to the end are the
elect….the elect will persevere, and they who persevere are the elect” (emphasis his).495
        In Arminianism, those who are elect are elected because they persevere. In Calvinism, those who persevere
do so because they are the elect.† In both systems of thought, perseverance is the condition for preservation.
Calvinists try to merge preservation with perseverance: God preserves us in our perseverance. If we do not
persevere, then we are not preserved (i.e., not elected) according to Calvinists.




*
  Calminianism = Calminianism + Arminianism. This term was popularized by Norman Geisler in his endeavor to adopt a mediating
position between Calminianism and Arminianism. Since the acronyms of both positions teach that perseverance is necessary to reach
heaven, a mediating position could be forged by affirming the soteriological necessity of perseverance from the S of PEARS and the P
of TULIP. Because Geisler affirmed this core doctrine of perseverance from a TULIP perspective but rejected the rest of the TULIP in
preference for an approach more in harmony with PEARS, his position may be appropriately described as Calminian (somewhat
analogous to a PEAR+P since he affirms the TULIP form of P). The present work rejects Geisler’s harmonization in favor of a
mediation which teaches that perseverance is necessary for rewards in heaven rather than for salvation from eternal damnation.
Calminianism makes perseverance descriptively necessary for entrance into heaven. Contrary to Calminian claims otherwise, in
making perseverance descriptively necessary, Calminianism also necessarily makes perseverance prescriptively necessary: both
exegetically and logically. (See endnote 499.) Marrowism, in contrast, achieves its mediation by teaching unconditional security from
a non-TULIP perspective.
†
  See Illustration 235. Predestined Perseverance, 701; Illustration 236. Perseverance-Based Predestination, 702.
Page 274                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
                                           Retention of Regeneration
       According to Augustine, the grandfather of Calvinism, the nonelect lose regeneration because they do not
persevere, and the elect retain regeneration because they do persevere. God gives the gift of persevering grace to
the elect but not to the nonelect. God does not give persevering grace to all whom He gives regenerating grace. In
Augustinianism, regeneration can be lost.496 Lutherans have followed Augustine in this understanding, as Davis
notes in his history of the doctrine of perseverance: “Martin Luther shared with the Roman Catholic Church of his
day the belief that the grace of baptismal regeneration and justification could be lost. On these points he was in
agreement with Augustine.”497
       Since Calvinism is indebted to Augustine for its soteriology, it is understandable that many Calvinists
follow Augustine in conditioning retention of regeneration on perseverance. For example, Anderson demonstrates
the same mentality from McKnight, a modern day Calvinist:

           McKnight recognizes these [phenomenological] believers as regenerate, but for him
      regeneration does not necessitate perseverance and is, by his definition, a lifelong process. So, much
      like Augustine, these believers can be regenerated but fall away from the faith and be eternally
      damned.498

       Calvinism, nevertheless, has by and large not followed Augustinianism in affirming the regeneration of the
nonelect. Still, Calvinists generally have retained Augustine’s understanding of the conditional nature concerning
the retention of regeneration, although they may hold it in tension.499 The elect must persevere in order not to lose
eternal life. Perseverance is a necessity, not an option in mainstream Calvinism. Therefore, it would be a
misrepresentation to suppose that Calvinism affirms unconditional security. Reformed exegetes, such as Pink,
acknowledge that in RT the retention of regeneration is conditioned on perseverance.

      The Word of God nowhere teaches that once a man is born again he may give free rein to the lusts of
      the flesh and be as worldly as he pleases, yet still be sure of getting to Heaven. Instead, Scripture
      says, and the words are addressed to believers, "For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die"
      (Rom. 8:13). No, if a man is born again he will desire, purpose and endeavor to live as becometh a
      child of God.
            There has been some deliberation in our mind as to which is the better title for this doctrine: the
      preservation or the perseverance of the saints. At first sight the former [preservation] seems
      preferable, as being more honoring to God, throwing the emphasis on His keeping power. Yet further
      reflection will show that such preferableness is more seeming than real. We prefer the latter
      [perseverance] because rightly understood it [preservation] includes the former [perseverance], while
      at the same time pressing the believer’s responsibility. Moreover, we believe it to be more in accord
      with the general tenor of Scripture. The saints are “kept by the power of God through faith”
      (1 Pet. 1:5). He does not deal with them as unaccountable automatons, but as moral agents, just as
      their natural life is maintained through their use of means and by their avoidance of that which
      is inimical to their wellbeing, so it is with the maintenance and preservation of their spiritual
      lives.
            God preserves His people in this world through their perseverance—their use of means and
      avoidance of what is destructive.500

       Libertarians can appreciate the fact that Pink links moral accountability with the ability not to act
automatically, since libertarians would concur that if our nature automatically determines our actions then we are
not accountable. Moreover, Pink does not try to elude the impact of the warning by making it apply to those who
might potentially be lost. After all, how can Paul threaten those who are spiritually dead with spiritual death? The
spiritually dead are spiritually dead already. They have no spiritual life to lose. Accordingly, Pink understands
Rom 8:13 to warn genuine believers that if you (i.e., a regenerate believer) continue to live according to the flesh,
you will die (i.e., lose your regenerate life). That the warning is addressed to genuine believers is granted herein,
but Pink’s assertion that perseverance is the means by which regeneration is preserved must be rejected.
       According to Pink, preservation is through the means of perseverance. God uses perseverance to preserve
your regeneration. Without perseverance, your regeneration would not be preserved. From his perspective,
regeneration does not guarantee its own self-continuation. On the contrary, perseverance in faith and holiness is the
necessary “means” to retain your regeneration. Preservation is conditioned on perseverance. Pink is insistent that
regeneration is not the power source, not even in part, for perseverance. Perseverance, through God’s enabling
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 275
grace rather than regenerating grace, is the “means” for retaining regeneration. The threat is the means of causing
you to persevere, and perseverance is the means of your retaining your regeneration. That is what Pink means by
means. His double statements concerning “means” above is elaborated in terms of enablement below:

           Enablement for this perseverance is wrought in the saints by God. Their deliverance from a total
      and final falling away is not owing to any power or sufficiency in themselves. Though their moral
      agency be not impaired and though continuance in well doing be required of them, yet their
      enduring unto the end is not to be attributed unto their fidelity nor to the strength of the new
      nature which they received at regeneration. No, Christian perseverance depends wholly and
      entirely on the will and fidelity, the influence and energy of God, working in them both to will and to
      do of His good pleasure.501

The power for perseverance does not come from the believer’s regenerate nature. Therefore, preservation is not
maintained by their regeneration. The extraneous nature of this persevering grace, in relation to the believer’s new
nature, is clearly reasserted by Pink:

           How important it is then that the babe in Christ should be instructed in the ground of Christian
      perseverance, that the foundation on which his eternal security rests is nothing whatever in
      himself but wholly outside.502

Eternal security is not based whatsoever on the regeneration within the person but on the power of God outside the
person that causes that person to persevere. Although it is the regenerate who will persevere in RT, according to
Pink the reason they persevere is not because of their regeneration. Their perseverance is to be attributed to their
election rather than to their regeneration. Pink expounds on Rom 8:13 at length in his chapter, The Spirit
Cleansing. Pink’s exposition calls attention to five points. Each point is addressed below.

           “For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die: but if ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the
      body, ye shall live” (Rom. 8:13). A most solemn and searching verse is this, and one which we
      greatly fear has very little place in present-day preaching. Five things in it claim attention. First, the
      persons addressed. Second, the awful warning here set before them. Third, the duty enjoined upon
      them. Fourth, the efficient Helper provided. Fifth, the promise made.503

Pink’s Five points

       First—Addressees
       Pink is certainly correct concerning the first point: “Those here addressed are regenerated believers,
Christians, as is evident from the whole context: the Apostle denominates them ‘brethren’ (v. 12).” Arminianism,
Marrowism, and Calvinism can agree that the warning is addressed to regenerate believers. Thus, if the passage is
talking about spiritual death, then obviously only those who have spiritual life can be so threatened.

      Second—Awfulness of Warning
      In complete agreement with Arminianism, but in contrast to Marrowism, Pink continues to explain why
regeneration, in and of itself, does not guarantee eternal security in Calvinism:

      “For if ye live after the flesh, ye shall die”—die spiritually, die eternally, for “life” and “death” in
      Romans always signifies far more than natural life and death. Moreover, to restrict “ye shall die” to
      physical dissolution would be quite pointless, for that experience is shared by sinners and saints
      alike….
      … It is by no means limited to the grosser forms of wickedness and crime, but includes as well the
      refinement, morality, and religiousness of the best of men, who yet give God no real place in their
      hearts and lives. And the wages of sin is death….
            …O the madness of men in courting eternal death rather than leave their sinful pleasures and
      live a holy life….Will you, my reader, for a little temporal satisfaction run the hazard of God’s
      eternal wrath? Heed this solemn warning, fellow-Christian: God means what He says, “IF ye live
      after the flesh, ye shall die.” (Bold emphasis mine.)504
Page 276                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
       Pink therefore would agree with Shank as to the recipients and nature of the warning. From his RT
perspective, regarding the warning as a threat of premature death is not an option. Those passages which some
would take as treating believers with premature death actually are treating them with eternal death from this shared
perspective between those in the Reformed and Arminian camps. This passage and those like it warn regenerate
believers of the possibility of eternal death if they live according to the flesh. Loss of regeneration is at stake.
Marrowists would disagree of course. In Marrowism, one’s security is not conditioned on the way one lives.
Marrowists do not believe that one’s retention of regeneration is conditioned on one’s sanctification.

       Third—Duty of Mortification
       According to Pink, the believer has the duty, through the indwelling Holy Spirit, to put to death the deeds of
the flesh in this relentless warfare. Marrowists agree with Pink on the duty of mortification. Regeneration does not
guarantee victory. We must depend upon our Helper who lives within us. Where Marrowism would disagree with
Arminianism, Augustinianism, Catholicism, and Calvinism is in their insistence that failure in regard to
mortification would be a mortal sin which would snuff out regeneration. These latter four isms present regenerate
believers with two soteriological options: mortification of regeneration or mortification of sinful actions. If you do
not kill the flesh, it will kill you—spiritually and eternally. Marrowism, in contrast, does not condition your
continuation of regeneration on your mortification.
       Yet it is surprising that Calvinists at the popular level frequently fail to perceive the point that Calvinistic
scholars such as Pink are making, so it will be worth restating Pink’s position in syllogistic summation:

            1. Perseverance prevents the elect from committing mortal sin.
            2. If the elect were to commit the mortal sin of Rom 8:13, they would forfeit regeneration.
            3. Therefore, perseverance prevents the elect from losing regeneration.

        According to Pink, God’s irresistible electing grace causes the elect to persevere so that they will not lose
their regeneration. Perseverance preserves regeneration. The elect will live relatively holy lives because otherwise
they would forfeit regeneration. God will not allow the elect to forfeit regeneration, so God irresistibly causes them
to persevere. Nevertheless, the fact still remains that the elect must live holy lives, or they will go to hell.
        Calvinists are in general agreement that regeneration cannot be lost. But the questions that must be
addressed are: (1) why can regeneration not be lost in Calvinism, and (2) could regeneration hypothetically be lost
if the elect did not persevere in faith or if they committed some mortal sin. When such questions are answered
forthrightly by Calvinists, it readily becomes apparent that Calvinism retains the mortal-sin perspective of
Catholicism; Calvinism just claims that the elect will not commit mortal sin. Still, hypothetically speaking at least,
if the elect were to commit mortal sin, they would lose regeneration.
        Calvinistically speaking, if believers were not to live holy lives, they would lose regeneration and fail to
achieve final salvation from eternal damnation. This means that perseverance is the condition for retaining
regeneration and for finally achieving unconditional salvation in Calvinism. Perseverance is the means by which
they avoid losing their regenerate nature.* They do not have unconditional security until they reach heaven—if
then. In Arminianism, Calvinism, and Catholicism, the security of the regenerate believer is conditioned on his or
her perseverance.
        Marrowism, though, affirms the unconditional security of the regenerate believer. Once a person is
regenerate, there is nothing more that individual must do in order to stay regenerate. There is no sin, actual or
hypothetical, that a believer could commit that would nullify his or her regeneration.
        The word hypothetical is chosen to underscore the nature of Pink’s argument. This approach should not be
objectionable since some Calvinists teach that warning passages (particularly such as those found in the book of
Hebrews) are the means God uses to cause believers to persevere so that they will not lose their regeneration.
Supposedly, the Lord warns believers what would happen hypothetically if they were to commit apostasy—they
would lose their regeneration according to Calvinism. The Bible is thought to warn believers of this latent danger
as a means of preventing them from committing apostasy since their regeneration is potentially in jeopardy.
Although it is popularly asserted by the proveitistic element within the Calvinistic camp that if a believer were not
to persevere this would merely prove that he or she was not actually regenerate to begin with, nevertheless, it is
simultaneously and hypothetically affirmed within that camp that had the believer been regenerate and failed to

*
  See second quote of Pink below in section Fifth—The Promise, 277. Conditionality is the means by which God causes us to
persevere—with His hypothetical warnings.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 277
persevere that believer would have lost his or her regeneration. Calvinists actually believe in conditionality rather
than mere hypotheticality.
       Hypothetically and Calvinistically speaking, if believers do not persevere, they actually lose their
regeneration. The conditional nature of this discussion is not to be disregarded just because it is hypothetical. On
the contrary, speaking hypothetically is simply a tool by which to underscore the conditionality of the biblical
warning. To the present author’s amazement, in pointing out these excerpts from Pink to a Calvinist who had just
read Pink’s book, the Calvinist failed to perceive (or refused to admit) that Pink conditioned the retention of one’s
regeneration on one’s perseverance! Not only that, but the Calvinist responded that there was nothing hypothetical
or conditional about Pink’s discussion and retorted that there “is no IF about it” (emphasis his). But the
hypothetical nature of Pink’s argument is easily demonstrated deductively:

    1. If the elect live according to the flesh, they will die in the sense of lose their regeneration (Rom 8:13).
    2. The elect cannot lose their regeneration since God will cause them to persevere.
    3. The elect cannot really lose their regeneration or live according to the flesh, so the if only expresses a
       hypothetical possibility for the elect.

       Pink is speaking hypothetically. As to the claim that there is no if, the biblical text itself affirms that there is
indeed an if involved. The first word of the verse in Rom 8:13 is ei (if). For that matter, the if is repeated twice with
equal grammatical possibility for each outcome:

       •    If you are living according to the flesh, you must die;
       •    If by the Spirit you mortify the deeds of the body, you will live.

       In RT the elect will persevere because they must. God will not allow an elect person to do otherwise; since
if He/he were to do otherwise, the elect individual would go to hell. Salvation from eternal damnation and retention
of regeneration is conditioned on perseverance. Kill or be killed would be the thought. If you do not mortify your
flesh, your flesh will mortify you and cause you to lose your regenerate life. In Pink’s theology, the retention of
your regeneration tragically is conditioned on your perseverance.

       Fourth—Helper
       Pink is excellent in his nikology: “Though grace be wrought in the hearts of the regenerate, it is not in their
power to act it: He who implanted it must renew, excite, and marshal it. ‘If ye through the Spirit do mortify’
(Rom. 8:13).”505 His rejection of passive nikology is likewise appreciated: “Yet note well it is not, ‘If the Spirit do
mortify,’ nor even, ‘If the Spirit through you do mortify,’ but, ‘If ye through the Spirit do mortify’! The Christian is
not passive, but active in this work” (all emphasis his).506 The present writer shares Pink’s preference for influence-
response rather than mechanical-causation as the basis for synergistic self-effort:

            The believer is not a cipher in this work. The gracious operations of the Spirit were never
       designed to be a substitute for the Christian’s discharge of his duty. True, His influence is
       indispensable, though it relaxes us not from our individual responsibility…. Is no self-effort required
       to escape the snares of Satan by refusing to walk in those paths which God has forbidden? Is no self-
       effort to be made in breaking away from the evil influence of godless companions? Is no self-effort
       called for to dethrone an unlawful habit? Mortification is a task to which every Christian must
       address himself with prayerful and resolute earnestness. Nevertheless it is a task far transcending our
       feeble powers. (Italics his.)507

       Fifth—The Promise
       When Pink comes to the last of the five points, he articulates the link between mortification and vivification:

             “If ye through the Spirit do mortify the deeds of the body, ye shall live” (Rom.
       8:13)….Mortification and vivification are inseparable: dying to sin and living unto God are
       indissolubly connected: the one cannot be without the other. If we through the Spirit do mortify the
       deeds of the body, then, but only then, we shall “live”—live a life of grace and comfort here, and
       live a life of eternal glory and bliss hereafter. (Italics his.) 508
Page 278                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       The conditional nature of this continual vivification is readily apparent from both the text and from Pink’s
discussion. According to Pink, if we perform this mortification, then, but only then, will we continue to live and
retain eternal life and avoid the eternal death and wrath which Paul warns us against. In conjunction with Pink’s
comments on perseverance, one would have concluded from Pink that God effectively influences the elect through
means of such warnings so that they persevere and thereby avert the loss of regeneration. The danger is real since
regeneration would be lost apart from perseverance. This is the logical conclusion to which Pink’s comments lead
within the context of RT. However, it comes as no surprise that when the time comes for Pink to expound upon the
logical implications of his conditionalism, he tries to soften the insinuations of his own conditionality:

            Some have a difficulty here in that Romans 8:13 conditions “life” upon our performance of the
      duty of mortification. “In the Gospel there are promises of life upon the condition of our obedience.
      The promises are not made to the work, but to the worker, and to the worker not for his work, but for
      Christ’s sake according to his work. As for example, promise of life is made not to the work of
      mortification, but to him that mortifieth the flesh, and that not for his mortification, but because he is
      in Christ, and his mortification is the token or evidence thereof[.] And therefore it must be
      remembered that all promises of the Gospel that mention works include in them reconciliation with
      God in Christ” (W. Perkins, 1604). The conditionality of the promise, then, is neither that of
      causation or uncertainty, but of coherence and connection, or means and end. The Highway of
      Holiness is the only path that leads to Heaven: “He that soweth to the Spirit shall of the Spirit reap
      life everlasting” (Gal. 6:8).509 (Italics his.)

       By Pink’s own analysis, mortification is not merely the evidence of vivification but the necessary means by
which to maintain vivification. A vital connection exists between the two, and that connection is logically
conditional. If mortification were to cease, then vivification would terminate as well. Preservation is therefore
reduced to God’s effectively influencing us so that we continue to meet the linear condition of perseverance as the
necessary means for the ongoing retention of regeneration. In short, according to Pink, if regenerate believers were
to stop mortifying the sins of the flesh, they would lose eternal life.
       Although Pink’s original discussion above was renamed with a more popular title Eternal Security, it is
apparent that his original title more accurately conveys his soteriology: The Doctrine Of The Saints’ Perseverance.
Pink does not believe in unconditional security. Rather, like Shank, he believes in conditional security.
Regeneration, in and of itself, does not give you unconditional protection against loss of regeneration. The
difference between Arminians and Calvinists (such as Pink on this matter) has been stated correctly by Shank
above. In Arminianism, believers who persevere are elected. In Calvinism, believers persevere because they are
elected. In both, perseverance is the condition for retention of regeneration. Neither Arminians nor Calvinists
believe in unconditional security of the regenerate believer who ceases to believe or who fails to mortify his or her
fleshly desires.

       Pink’s Corroboration
       Since I have shared the above quotations with a Calvinist only to have that Calvinist deny the obvious, I will
include a few additional confirmations from Pink’s own pen:

      No matter how excellent a beginning I have made, if I do not continue to press forward I shall be lost.
      Yes, lost, and not merely miss some particular crown or millennial honors as the deluded
      dispensationalists teach. It is persevere or perish: it is final perseverance or perish eternally—there
      is no other alternative. Romans 11:22 makes that unmistakably clear….badness. The evidence that
      we are the recipients of God’s goodness is that we continue in the faith and obedience of the Gospel.
      The end cannot be reached apart from the appointed means.510

Pink is a conditionalist who teaches that if you do not persevere you will perish in hell. The evidence of
regeneration is the conditional means of retaining regeneration. This is standard fare in RT.

Other Reformed Collaborators
      Reformed commentator Murray likewise indicates that retention of regeneration is conditioned on
perseverance, although the elect are assured of perseverance. Regeneration does not assure perseverance; rather,
perseverance assures retention of regeneration:
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                Page 279
       The death referred to [in Rom 8:13] must be understood in its broadest scope and does not stop short
       of death in its ultimate manifestation, eternal separation from God. The doctrine of the security of
       the believer does not obviate this sequence. The only way of avoiding the issue of death is to be
       delivered and desist from the life of the flesh.511

       MacArthur repeatedly states his concurrence with Murray, and quotes Murray at length in regarding
enduring to the end in Mt 24:13 and Mk 13:13 as confirming that we are not saved irrespective of our perseverance
or our continuance in the faith.512 From this Reformed perspective, continuation in faith is the only way you can
keep your regeneration and is the condition for your being kept by Christ:

           Furthermore, Christians are protected through faith. Continued faith in Christ is the instrument
       of God’s sustaining work. God did not save Christians apart from faith, and He does not keep them
       apart from faith.513 (Italics his.)

        If you want God to keep you, you better keep believing. Little wonder, then, that in defending the
Westminster Confession’s view of perseverance, as opposed to OSAS, MacArthur begins by stipulating: “It is
crucial to understand what the biblical doctrine of perseverance does not mean. It does not mean that people who
‘accept Christ’ can then live any way they please without fear of hell.”514 MacArthur appears to be well within the
currents of mainstream Calvinistic thought in affirming that believers should fear hell. After all, in this Calvinistic
theology if believers do not persevere, they will go to hell. Salvation from hell is conditioned on continuation in
faith. Sellers likewise states, “Romans 8:13 does not demonstrate that one can lose his salvation. It does show,
though, that the one who does keep his salvation does so by mortifying the deeds of the flesh through the Holy
Spirit” (italics his).515 Mortification is the means to keeping regeneration.
        Hendriksen concurs with Murray in his exegesis that soteriological death is in view: “The fact to be
emphasized is that the right choice must be made, for where a person will spend eternity is at stake.”516 Matthew
Henry, writing from the same perspective, correspondingly remarks: “If you live after the flesh, you shall die; that
is, die eternally. It is the pleasing, and serving, and gratifying, of the flesh, that are the ruin of souls; that is, the
second death.”517 If you live according to the flesh, you will experience the second death in the Lake of Fire. Your
security is thus conditioned by Calvinists on the way you live. Unlike Marrowists, who would argue for
unconditional security for the regenerate believer, Arminians and Calvinists advocate conditional security, even for
the regenerate believer. Retention of regeneration is at stake in their mutual theological perspective. Regeneration
in and of itself does not assure believers that they will remain regenerate in these two systems of thought.
        Owen likewise conditions the retention of regeneration on one’s practical sanctification. His heading
regarding 1Thess 5:23 is: “Regeneration carried on by Sanctification.”518 He understands this verse as teaching that
your soteriological preservation is conditioned on your practical sanctification. The end result of this whole process
of sanctification is soteriological preservation and soteriological blamelessness. Following Owen’s line of thought,
the Reformed exegete would thus understand this verse as stating: “Now may the God of peace Himself
