[practically] sanctify you entirely; and may your spirit and soul and body be [soteriologically] preserved complete,
without [soteriological] blame at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.” The Marrowist would agree that practical
sanctification is in view but would contend that our soteriological preservation is not conditioned on our practical
sanctification; rather, our misthological status is at stake. But Owen again insists that retention of regeneration is in
jeopardy. Concerning duties required “either by the law or the gospel,” such as “their duty not to sin,” he stipulates:

       And these duties are so far necessary unto the continuation at our justification, as that a justified
       estate cannot consist with the sins and vices that are opposite unto them; so the apostle affirms
       that “if we live after the flesh, we shall die,” Rom.8:13. He that does not carefully avoid falling into
       the fire or water, or other things immediately destructive of life natural, cannot live.519

       Then, as if trying to conceal the obvious implication of his own interpretation (that retention of regeneration
and justification depends on avoiding living after the flesh), Owen immediately proceeds to obfuscate: “But these
are not the things whereon life does depend. Nor have the best of our duties any other respect unto the continuation
of our justification, but only as in them we are preserved from those things which are contrary unto it, and
destructive of it.”520 His discussion merges the continuation of justification with the retention of regeneration as
being conditioned on one’s perseverance in faith. Concerning Heb 10:38-39, he continues:
Page 280                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
      The drawing back to perdition includes the loss of a justified estate, really so or in profession. In
      opposition whereunto the apostle places "believing unto the saving of the soul;" that is, unto the
      continuation of justification unto the end. And herein it is that the “just live by faith;” and the loss
      of this life can only be by unbelief….And this life is by faith in Christ….This, then, is the only
      way, means, and cause, on our part, of the preservation of this life.521

The preservation of our regeneration and justification is accomplished by means of our perseverance in faith. If we
were to not persevere, both regeneration and justification would be lost according to Owen.

Continuation of Justification
        The only type of justification Owen will allow is soteriological justification before God. He conditions this
justification on perseverance.

      The continuation of the justification of Abraham before God is declared to have been by faith only,
      Rom. 4:3; for the instance of his justification, given by the apostle from Gen.15:6, was long after he
      was justified absolutely….All other works and duties of obedience do accompany faith in the
      continuation of our justified estate, as necessary effects and fruits of it, but not as causes, means,
      or conditions, whereon that effect is suspended.522

       According to Owen, Abraham had been justified by faith long before the justification recorded in Gen 15:6
and Rom 4:3. On this matter, the present writer would agree, but in contrast to Owen, the present work argues that
subsequent justification for Abraham was misthological rather than soteriological. Owen, on the other hand,
believes the reason that Abraham was still justified soteriologically at this later point in time was because he still
believed. The continuation of his justification was because of his continuation in faith. According to Owen, good
works and Christian duties are “necessary effects,” meaning Christians cannot reach heaven without these works.
But how can these works be necessary and yet not be means or conditions? Reformed theology has a terrible time
dealing with this question. And Owen is not exempt:

      If this be that which is intended in this position, that the continuation of our justification depends
      on our own obedience and good works, or that our own obedience and good works are the
      condition of the continuation of our justification,—namely, that God does indispensably require
      good works and obedience in all that are justified, so that a justified estate is inconsistent with the
      neglect of them,—it is readily granted, and I shall never contend with any about the way whereby
      they choose to express the conceptions of their minds. But if it be inquired what it is whereby we
      immediately concur in a way of duty unto the continuation of our justified estate,—that is, the pardon
      of our sins and acceptance with God,—we say it is faith alone; for “The just shall live by faith.”

       Owen readily grants “that the continuation of our justification depends on our own obedience and good
works.” And he has no objection to those who would restate this as: “Our own obedience and good works are the
condition of the continuation of our justification.” He only asks that faith be recognized as the immediate means
while works are considered secondary means whereby we meet this condition for continuation of our justification.
Those who claim that Reformed theology teaches unconditional security need to rethink their claim. Not only is
your security conditioned on your perseverance in faith, it is also conditioned on your perseverance in works as the
secondary means. By making works a “necessary effect,” Owen is forced to admit that the good works are a
condition after all.

Reformed Detractors
       To be sure, there are Calvinists, such as Warren, who in contrast to Pink and Owen would assert that the
elect persevere in faith and practice because they are regenerate, and claim that such perseverance is the non-
conditional evidence of their regeneration.523 Regeneration supposedly results in perseverance. Even so, Warren
unwittingly makes the evidence of regeneration the necessary means to retain that regeneration, just as Owen made
them the “necessary effects and fruits of it.” In spite of themselves, even those trying to advocate a non-conditional
variation of Calvinism still teach conditional security (CS). They do not teach NOSAS; nevertheless, they adopt a
conditional form of OSAS. That is, in this Reformed alteration you cannot lose your salvation, but the salvation
which you cannot lose is still conditioned on your sanctification.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                               Page 281
      Reformed theologian Berkhof, like Warren, oscillates concerning the necessity of good works: “They
cannot be regarded as necessary to merit salvation, nor as a means to retain a hold on salvation….At the same
time good works necessarily follow….They are also necessary as required by God, Rom. 7:4; 8:12,13….The
necessity of good works must be maintained.” Apparently, good works are not necessary to retain regeneration
theologically, but at the same time good works are necessary to retain regeneration exegetically (so Rom 8:13).
Good works are necessarily unnecessary theologically but necessarily necessary exegetically. This appears to be
the best one can make of Berkhof’s contradictory comments. One must logically chose between Reformed
theology or exegesis. Holding to both is logically not possible, at least not as articulated by Berkhof. When the
theological rubber meets the exegetical road, one can follow the Calvinistic skid marks right over the cliff and see
where it crashes into teaching a retention of regeneration that is conditioned on perseverance.

Arminian Equalizers
        Marrowists could abbreviate this Reformed form of conditional once saved always saved as COSAS, in
contrast to the unconditional security (US) or unconditional once saved always saved (UOSAS) found in the FG
camp. But rather than pursue such fine distinctions in our terminology, my preference will be to use the popular
designation OSAS to refer to the Marrowistic affirmation of unconditional eternal security (i.e., UOSAS). The
Reformed version of OSAS is just as bad soteriologically and certainly worse logically than NOSAS. The
Calvinistic version of OSAS does not truly advocate OSAS or eternal security since it requires conditional
security.*
        Yet despite the sharp and fundamental difference that exists between COSAS and UOSAS, Corner states
that from “the perspective that [his] book is written” that “the doctrine of eternal security, the perseverance of the
saints or Once Saved Always Saved mean the same thing” (emphasis his).524 Then he has the audacity to claim that
COSAS and UOSAS are only “slightly different.”525 Yet then in a Corner-vs-Corner style, he spends chapter 18 of
his book unwittingly refuting own his statement. They are not slightly different; they are greatly different. As Tony
the Tiger® would shout, the difference between them is, “Grrr-e-a-t!” Corner simply provides us with an example
of an Arminian pointing his finger at the Reformed camp and mistakenly thinking that OSAS is a doctrine that
belongs in the Reformed camp when emphatically it does not!†

Further Corroboration by Pink
      Retuning now to Pink, he continues to express at length what Berkhof failed to maintain in brief:

          When we affirm the final perseverance of every born-again soul we do not mean that saints are not in
          themselves prone to fall away, nor that at regeneration such a work is wrought in them once for all
          that they now have sufficient strength of their own to overcome sin and Satan and that there is no
          likelihood of their spiritual life decaying. So far from it, we hesitate not to declare that the very
          principle of grace (or “new nature”) in the believer considered abstractedly in itself — apart from the
          renewing and sustaining power of God—would assuredly perish under the corruptions of the flesh
          and the assaults of the Devil. No, the preservation of the Christian’s faith and his continuance in
          the path of obedience lies in something entirely external to himself or his state.526

       Like Shank, Pink believes that regeneration is dynamic rather than static and that the regeneration imparted
to the believer would perish apart from the constant renewing by God. In and of themselves, the saints would be
prone to fall away and lose regeneration. The internal work of regeneration would not prevent this apostasy.
Regeneration is not unconditionally “once for all” according to Pink, and those who are regenerate “would
assuredly perish” and lose their regeneration if God did not effectively influence believers so that they infallibly
persevere in faith. At last Pink concludes:

          As His providence is virtually a continual creation, an upholding of all things by His ‘power, [sic]
          without which they would lapse back again into nonentity: so the Christian’s preservation is like a
          continual regeneration, a maintenance of the new creation by the operations of the Spirit and the
          bestowing [of] fresh supplies of grace.527


*
    See COSAS, 709.
†
    See Illustration 97. OSAS—Whose is It?, 268.
Page 282                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
       In Pink’s Calvinism, God preserves you by means of your perseverance so that you maintain your
regeneration as a result of your perseverance. Like the Arminian lamp, if you were to become unplugged from
Christ dynamically, you would lose your regeneration soteriologically.* The external electrical current must
continually flow through you via perseverance for your eternal life not to lapse back into a state of spiritual death.
If perseverance were to cease, so would the regeneration which perseverance maintains.

Conditional by Peterson and Schreiner
       Things are really not that different on the contemporary Calvinistic landscape, just a few more branches on
the same conditional tree. Peterson wrote an article in 1991 in support of Owen’s insistence that there is no
“preservation without perseverance.”528 “The Colossians must persevere ‘in their faith’ if they are to be finally
saved.”529 Peterson concludes: “Perseverance in faith (Col. 1:23; Heb. 3:12; John 15:7), love (15:9, 12, 17), and
holiness (Heb. 12:14; Heb. 3:13; John 15:10, 14) is a condition of final salvation….Professed Christians must
continue to believe…if they are to see the Lord.”530
       Schreiner joined the faculty at Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in 1997 and wrote an article for their
journal the following year entitled: Perseverance and Assurance: A Survey and a Proposal. This set the stage for a
book which he co-authored in 2001, The Race Set Before Us: A Biblical Theology of Perseverance & Assurance.
This was followed in 2002 by two responses in the spring edition of JOTGES. One response was an article-length
review by Wilkin. The other was a paper that had been presented by Ken Keathley at the Evangelical Theological
Society Southwest Regional Meeting. Keathley is a professor at New Orleans Baptist Theological Seminary who
takes issue with Schreiner’s conditional approach. Since these latter two articles are readily accessible online, I will
briefly summarize from Schreiner’s original online journal article. Schreiner rejects the Arminian view that
salvation is lost, and he also rejects the Marrowistic view that rewards are lost. He presents Calvinistic alternatives
instead.
       The first Calvinistic alternative Schreiner proposes is the tests-of-genuineness view. He summarizes that
“perseverance in faith and good works are considered necessary for salvation.”531 In this popular proveitistic
perspective, good works are not the root but the necessary fruit. Those without the fruit show that they never had
the root of saving faith. Retrospective examination of your fruit will determine whether or not you are really saved.
He mistakenly relegates Owen to this category. Perhaps in Owen’s exegesis of certain texts such an expedient is
used, but as demonstrated above, Owen also implements conditional retention of the root. The fruit is necessary to
keep the root. Without the fruit of good works, the root of regeneration would wither and perish. Having
overlooked this aspect of Owen’s theology, Schreiner fails to notice that his own theological position has been
presented already by Owen. In any event, making good fruit necessary to reach heaven is to make good works a
necessity to reach heaven. Granted, such a statement is tautological, but let it not escape notice that this proveitist
approach conditions one’s entrance into heaven on one’s good works.
       According to Schreiner’s second Calvinistic alternative, the hypothetical-loss-of-salvation view, the elect
hypothetically could apostatize, but doing so is actually impossible. Another alternative mentioned by Schreiner is
the irresolvable-tension view, in which the tension between the assurances and threats in Scripture cannot be
resolved in this life (unless, of course, one takes the rewards view, which Schreiner finds unpalatable with his
Calvinism). This tension view is the one he adopts. He reprimands his fellow Calvinists by pointing out that
Col 1:21-23 is prospective (rather than retrospective) in that it deals with the future. Perseverance in faith is the
condition for the future presentation, which he believes is soteriological: “Paul in Colossians 1:21-23, and many
other texts, warns believers that if they do not persist in the faith, they will be damned. Contrary to the tests of
genuineness view, I believe Paul means exactly what he says: ‘If we fall away from Christ, we will face eternal
destruction.’”532
       Nothing new under the sun here. Pink, Owen, and Peterson, among others, already have beat Schreiner to
the punch line. Schreiner continues: “The warnings are prospective. Hebrews warns believers that if they
apostatize, then they will be damned” (emphasis his).533 Of course, believers will never really apostatize in
Schreiner’s estimation. Naturally, one would assume that this means that believers could only hypothetically do so.
But Schreiner already has shown the weakness of this Calvinistic recourse. Thus, he is left without any resource
other than to say that the warnings are unexplainable. Yet he does not find this explanation credible either and at
last presents his means-of-salvation view: “We take seriously the threat that if we commit apostasy, we will be
eternally damned.”534


*
    See “Dynamic Classification” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                             Page 283
       Adhering to the warnings is the means by which salvation is obtained on the final day. Some protest
       that this is works righteousness, but such an objection fails to see that such perseverance is the fruit
       of faith and grounded in God’s sustaining and electing grace. Yes, works are necessary to be
       saved.535

       The final realization of soteriological salvation is conditioned on one’s perseverance. Logically, therefore,
retention of regeneration is Calvinistically conditioned on ongoing fruitfulness. Since initial faith is
nonmeritorious, Schreiner assumes the same would apply to his stipulation of continuation in faith and thereby
make this condition nonmeritorious also. This would seem to require a monergistic view of the believer’s works—
in which God does the work and produces the faith. However, such a view seems to be very much out of sync with
the synergism of Schreiner’s fellow Calvinists. The synergistic nature of this Calvinistic perseverance is readily
apparent in Peterson’s article, in which he quotes Hendriksen’s comments regarding Col 1:23 in support:

       Divine preservation always presupposes human perseverance. Perseverance proves faith’s genuine
       character, and is therefore indispensable to salvation. To be sure, no one can continue in the faith in
       his own strength (John 15:5). The enabling grace of God is needed from start to finish (Phil 2:12,13).
       This, however, does not cancel human responsibility and activity. Yes, activity, continuous,
       sustained, strenuous effort (Heb. 12:14).536 (Emphasis his.)

       Perseverance is soteriologically indispensable in proveitism. Schreiner simply has come to the realization
that proveitism is conditionalism. The tests-of-genuineness view logically leads to the means-of-salvation view.
Final salvation is conditioned on one’s works in proveitism. As to the nature of these works, offsetting Calvinistic
claims regarding the nature of these works (as monergistic versus synergistic) are evidenced within this proveitistic
theology. The present book prefers the synergistic understanding of postconversion works, of course, and contends
that perseverance in faith is a misthological issue. Ongoing faith can merit reward and is therefore impossible to
label as nonmeritorious. The same counter is valid concerning the fruit comprising good works. Such works result
in rewards and are therefore meritorious. Consistent Calvinists, therefore, are teaching synergistic salvation—
salvation by works.
       Nevertheless, for the sake of current interaction with Schreiner’s comments, such objections will be set
aside for the moment. Even if ongoing faith and fruit are not synergistically or cooperatively produced (as
Schreiner maintains), in his proposal retention of regeneration is still conditioned on ongoing faith and faithfulness.
They are, as he admits, the necessary means by which we reach heaven.

       That salvation is at stake is confirmed by Mark 13:13 with the words, “But the one who endures to
       the end will be saved.” Eschatological salvation belongs only to those who persevere in faith until the
       end….their physical preservation is an emblem of the spiritual preservation of the elect. The Lord
       shortens the time of affliction so that the chosen will not apostatize.537

       “If” you fall away, then you will be damned. We need not deny the strength of the apodosis in such
       sentences. If you or I apostatize, we will be damned. So too, if we do not believe in Jesus, we will not
       be saved. We need to beware of reading conditional statements as if they are a reality.538

       The refreshing candor of Schreiner’s analysis is appreciated: The unconditional election of Calvinism results
in conditional retention of regeneration. Where Marrowists differ with Schreiner is that they reject Calvinism and
its conditional retention of regeneration and its unconditional election in favor of the doctrine which Owen,
Peterson, and Schreiner find so loathsome—unconditional security. In Marrowism eternal security is unconditional
security for the person who has come to faith in Christ. Preservation is not conditioned on perseverance.
       Despite subtle differences in the various views, there are really only two alternatives: preservation in the
state of grace versus perseverance in the expression of grace, that is, unconditional security versus conditional
security. To be sure, one occasionally encounters FG Calvinists who seek to limit themselves to the confessional
statements that affirm the believer’s perseverance in the state of grace and who stress the creedal affirmations of
preservation and who seek to tone down the creedal affirmations and implications of perseverance. But they are the
exception rather than the rule and certainly do not represent the mainstream of Calvinistic thought. They are not the
ones likely to be encountered in heated Calvinistic engagements. Rather, to one degree or another, Calvinists in
general affirm that believers will persevere in the expression of grace in terms of faith and faithfulness. Regardless
Page 284                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
of which flavor of Calvinism one may choose from Schreiner’s classifications, perseverance is a condition for
preservation:

       Hypothetical-Loss: faith and faithfulness are actually required.
       Tests-of-Genuineness: faith and faithfulness are implicitly required.
       Irreconcilable-Tension: faith and faithfulness are mysteriously required.
       Means-of-Salvation: faith and faithfulness are explicitly required.

     When it comes to the bottom line, despite his efforts to offer a modification of Schreiner’s conditionalism,
Ken Keathley, in like fashion, still conditions entrance into heaven on perseverance:

            Saving faith perseveres or remains until the day when it gives way to sight. Perseverance should
       be understood as a faith that cannot be annihilated and therefore persists. This persistent faith
       inevitably and eventually exhibits itself in the believer’s life in such a way as to bring glory to
       God. The point of Hebrews 11 is that saving faith manifests itself by the journey of discipleship.
       One may stumble and falter but never leave the trail. Perseverance should be viewed more as a
       promise than a requirement. (Italics his).539

        The discussion has come full circle. Keathley, like Augustine, makes perseverance a gift. For Keathley
perseverance is a promise; for Augustine it is a gift. For both, it is withheld from the nonelect. The promise of this
gift is made only to the elect. But even the elect will not reach heaven apart from perseverance in faith and
discipleship. This Calvinistically makes perseverance an Augustinian gift given only to the elect. The nonelect do
not get to go to heaven because God never promised them the gift of perseverance. The elect get to go to heaven
because God gives them the gift of persevering faith. The elect reach heaven because they persevere; the nonelect
fail to reach heaven because they fail to persevere. The Augustinian tree has many branches, but they are all
attached to the same conditional trunk.

Summation of CS
       Pink and Shank take the same basic approach to security—it is conditional. If you do not persevere, you lose
eternal life. The difference is that Pink believes the elect will persevere; Shank believes that those who persevere
are the elect. Yet both are agreed that only those who meet the condition of perseverance will attain the final
realization of soteriological salvation. Perseverance is thus made an intermediate condition for the final realization
of salvation in both Arminianism and Calvinism. But a security which is conditioned on one’s perseverance (even
though supposedly guaranteed through God’s preservation) is not unconditional. Such security is clearly
conditioned on one’s perseverance. If the only way the regenerate can avoid soteriological death is by not living
according to the flesh in Rom 8:13, as both Arminians and Calvinists affirm, then the salvation of the elect from
loss of eternal life is conditioned on the way they live in both soteriological systems. Regardless of whether one
derives this conditionalism through Arminianism or Calvinism, it is still a conditionalism. Calvinists and
Arminians, whether strong or soft, jointly espouse a soteriologically conditional security, not unconditional eternal
security. Calminianism teaches conditional security (CS).

Affirmation of US
        Marrowism, on the other hand, affirms unconditional security (US) for the regenerate believer. The believer
who fails to persevere in either faith or practice is saved unconditionally from loss of regeneration and thereby
assured of his or her final realization of soteriological salvation. Marrowism stands practically alone in its
affirmation of unconditional security, when compared to Arminianism and mainstream Calvinism. Nevertheless,
the Marrowist does not find any reason to shy away from Rom 8:13 in its full, contextual strength. The regenerate
may die prematurely; they may die soulically (both temporally and misthologically); they may even die spiritually
at the dynamic level, but they retain regenerate life ontologically at the static level.
        From the FG perspective, since in Rom 8:13 life and death are dependent upon the way we live, life and
death do not refer to soteriological truths. Marrowism does not understand Paul as teaching soteriological security
based on works. Our soteriological possession of life is not conditioned on the way we live. It is static in that there
is no fluctuation in our possession of eternal life at the soteric level. However, our experience of life and death is
conditioned on the way we live and is therefore open to dynamic variation. This distinction between possession and
experience, therefore, leads to the conclusion that eternal life has both static and dynamic dimensions. The result of
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 285
sin is death, even for the believer. But the FG interpretation will limit this death to the dynamic experience of such
life.*

       Telolic Results
       Paul has set the stage for this conclusion earlier in the context where he notes that the believer may walk in
newness of life (Rom 6:4). But he also warns of the possibility of a death contingent upon moral obedience
(Rom 6:16). The outcome (telos) of unrighteousness is death (6:21). But in the same verse he presents the positive
parallel: obedience results in (eis) righteousness (6:16). With this potential positive outcome in mind, Paul urges
believers to “present your members as slaves to righteousness, resulting in (eis) sanctification” (6:19). The causal
connection is clear. Moral obedience results in righteousness, and righteousness in turn results in sanctification.
And the outcome (telos) of this practical sanctification is eternal life (6:22).
                                                  Illustration 101. Telolic Links
                    obedience Æ experiential righteousness Æ practical sanctification Æ eternal life

                                   disobedience Æ experiential unrighteousness Æ death

        The misthological nature of this telolic spectrum of eternal life is thus very apparent. Eternal life is the
future reward for practical sanctification. Alternatively, telolic death is the outcome for unrighteous behavior. The
parallelism between telolic life and telolic death as dual possible outcomes for the believer strongly suggests a
misthological view of this telolic death. Telolic death is the absence of telolic life. Therefore, I do not fault
Arminians and Calvinists for finding an eschatological dimension to this death. The broad context suggests this is
indeed the case. Even so, must this misthological death† necessarily entail soteriological loss? Paul anticipates this
question in the next verse with a contrast not only between life and death, but also between soteriological and
misthological bestowments. With life and death for the believer hanging in the contextual balance, Paul reassures
his Christian readers, “The wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord”
(6:23).
        Death, whether soteriological or misthological, is a wage. Eternal life, in contrast, is first and foremost a free
gift. Since it is eternal, once it is received it cannot be lost. The dynamic qualitative force of this life must not be
stressed to the detriment of its static quantitative stability. The durative nature of this life must be maintained at the
static level. Otherwise, it would not be eternal life.‡
        However, Paul’s emphasis in Romans is not on the fundamental nature of this life at the static level. The
other three times Paul uses the full expression eternal life in Romans, he uses it misthologically to describe the
telolic nature of this life. 1 “He will reward eternal life to those who seek for glory and honor and immortality by
persevering in good work (Rom 2:7; TM). Eternal life is a reward for good work. 2 “Grace might reign through
righteousness resulting in (eis) eternal life (Rom 5:21; TM). This verse, which is the last verse of ch. 5, introduces
the same causal link found in ch. 6. Experiential righteousness results in eternal life (6:16-20). 3 And as noted in
6:22, eternal life is the outcome or end result (telos) of practical sanctification. In these three verses, eternal life is
an object that is bestowed as a reward.

       Static Versus Dynamic Life
       However, in Rom 6:23b, Paul no longer is presenting eternal life as a misthological object.540 Rather, in
clear contrast with the concept of reward, he uses an adversative conjunction but (de) to affirm that eternal life is a
free gift. Before eternal life can be pursued as a future reward, it must first be received as a free gift. From Pauline
theology in general, and from the book of Romans in particular, one clearly may assert that a gift is not a reward
since the latter is based on works and the former is not.§ So how is it that eternal life is both a gift and a reward
when a gift is not a reward?
       The answer is simple. There are dual dimensions to eternal life. The various dynamic experiences of this life
are conditioned on works. Yet the basic static possession of eternal life is not conditioned on works. Therefore, it
clearly follows from the definition of gift that the soteric possession of eternal life cannot be conditioned on how

*
  See endnote 1277 for threshold of misthological death.
†
  See Misthological Death Defined, 286.
‡
  See Illustration 258. Quality versus Quantity, 725.
§
  See “What is Work” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.
Page 286                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
we live. Consequently, when Paul warns that those believers who live according to the flesh will die, he cannot be
talking about losing the possession of eternal life. The imputation of righteousness as a free gift (5:17) results in
justification of life (5:18), which is the impartation of eternal life as a free gift.
                                                Illustration 102. Soteric Link
                                imputational righteousness Æ justification Æ eternal life

       Imputational justification makes the impartational regeneration possible.* Since soteriological justification is
by faith apart from works, the soteriological possession of eternal life must likewise be by faith apart from works.
The two go hand in hand. Likewise, the possibility that a believer may be righteous positionally but not
experientially corresponds to the conclusion herein that a believer may have eternal life statically but fail to
experience it dynamically. As Paul said elsewhere, believers who live according to the flesh are dead even while
they live (1Tim 5:6). They are the living dead. Although they have both physical and spiritual life, their experience
is one of death. Eternal life for them is a static possession rather than dynamic experience. They are dead in terms
of their spiritual experience and in terms of their fellowship with God. Death is separation from God who is life.
Yet God gives life at various levels. Such believers are separated from God’s fellowship and empowerment. They
are not experiencing a life of fellowship with God or the dynamic power of God.

        Misthological Death Defined
        Tragically, such believers will also experience misthological death.† Death is the absence of life.
Misthological death therefore would be the absence of misthological life. Just as life can be experienced at multiple
levels, so can death. Those believers who have eternal life at the soteriological level may fail to experience eternal
life temporally at the filial level‡ and eternally at the misthological level. They will not reign in life (Rom 5:17).
They will not share this reign in life. Rather, their temporal and misthological experience will be one of death.
They will be separated from this victorious experience with God as a result of their sin. Carnal believers will have
an impoverished experience both now and in the future.541
        The wages of sin is death—both temporal and misthological in the case of the carnal believer. In contrast to
the wages of sin, the gift and reward of God is eternal life. At the static level, eternal life is a gift; at the dynamic
level, it is a reward (Rom 6:22-23). Our daily experience of salvation from the power of sin can fluctuate.
Relationship is permanent; fellowship is not. Present dynamic salvation should be a growing experience (1Pet 2:2).
Yet it may wither instead. Still, even if it withers to the point of experiential death, the static possession of the
imputation of justification and the impartation of regeneration is retained. Judicial victory over the penalty of sin
has been granted permanently apart from works. The fact that Peter describes being born again as being
accomplished with indestructible seed in 1Pet 1:23 suggests that the life imparted is indestructible.§
        The NT talks about the possibility of believers losing their life, reward, and crown in the future. These
ennoblements are forfeitable and thus may be lost in terms of the believer failing to achieve the intended
consummation. Eternal life may indeed be lost—in terms of dynamic experience and potential. For example,
believers may lose the crown of life and lose access to the tree of life in the future, and they may fail to experience
eternal life in the form of abundant life in the present. This fullness of the dynamic potential of eternal life is
indeed forfeitable. Nevertheless, the loss of this life cannot dip below the soteric threshold.**

       Contextual Analysis
       We are under moral obligation to put to death the deeds of our body (Rom 8:12). Doing so results in life for
our body so that we may live as a son of God in the present and be co-glorified as sons of God in the future. In the
broader context, the death of ch. 8 is illustrated in ch 7. Sin killed Paul (Rom 7:11). How? Did it send him to hell?
No. Paul describes this death as failing to experience the life-giving power of the Spirit in his body. Therefore,
such death is dynamic rather than static. Even in this state of death, Paul’s inner man is pictured as alive (7:22). He
has static life even during his dynamic experience of death. Having life in the inner man corresponds to having life
given to his spirit (8:10). In ch. 7, this static impartation of life to his spirit had failed to result in a dynamic
*
  See “Ordo Salutis—Marrowistic” in Ordo Salutis.
†
  See Illustration 101. Telolic Links, 285. Also see “Misthological Death” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from
the Gospel of John.
‡
  See Illustration 126. Types of Vertical Forgiveness, 348. Also see “Filial Forgiveness” in Trichotomy.
§
  See endnote 140.
**
   See endnote 1277 for threshold of misthological death.
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 287
transformation in his experience. He explicitly identifies his death as occurring in his body (7:24). His inner man
was alive within his body of death. The implication of ch. 7 is that his spirit was alive despite his failure to meet his
moral obligation to put to death the deeds of his body.
       Paul makes this explicit in ch. 8 when he affirms that the spirit is alive even though the body is dead (8:10).
We must not gloss over the affirmation that Paul is making in this verse: “If Christ is in you, though the body is
dead because of sin, yet the spirit is alive because of righteousness.” For the body to be dead in this context
means that it is not experiencing the life-giving power of the Spirit. Paul has just been describing what it
means for the body to be dead in ch. 7. Paul is claiming that even if you as a believer are having a ch. 7
experience, your spirit nevertheless is alive because of righteousness. Experiential righteousness? Not hardly.
His experience as a believer in ch. 7 was one of death. Yet Paul affirms that the believer’s spirit is alive. Why?
Because of righteousness. This must be imputational righteousness. It is not the telolic causal link of righteousness
resulting in eternal life eschatologically.* Rather, it must be the soteric causal connection between justification and
life that Paul alluded to as justification of life in 5:18.† The impartation of eternal life is a free gift. This
imputational righteousness makes impartational regeneration possible. More than that, imputation makes
regeneration retainable.
       Paul is assuring us that even if our body is dead because of sin (i.e., even if we are dynamically dead and
immoral in our practice as described in ch. 7) still our spirit is alive because of righteousness. This is the static
possession of life due to the imputation of righteousness to us as a gift. In other words, Rom 8:10 is 7:7-21 in a
nutshell. Even though your body is experientially dead because of sin, your spirit (i.e., your inner man is
soteriologically alive). As Lopez notes, the if of verse 10 is best translated as since.542 After all, there is no question
as to whether Christ is in someone who is spiritually alive. Paul’s affirmation thus may be stated without any
question that would be implied by if. Since Christ is in you, you spiritually are alive even though you
experientially are dead. This is a strong affirmation of OSAS and rules out soteric death in Rom 8:13. Even
defeated Christians who are failing to experience the life-giving power of the Spirit still have Christ in them and
spiritually are alive as a result.
       Yet rather than leave us in this tragic state of defeat, Paul moves to verse 11 with an adversative conjunction
but (de) to say that this is not the end of the story. The rest of the story is that Christ is ready, willing, and able to
make a dynamic transfusion of life from the static storehouse in our spirits to our mortal bodies (8:11) if we will
meet the necessary moral obligation (8:12-13).543 Merely having Christ in you will result in a live spirit but dead
body. If you want to experience life in your body, you must do more than simply have Christ in you. You must
allow Him to perform a dynamic ongoing transfusion. Therefore, what is at stake if you fail to meet your moral
obligation for such a transfusion is not the death of your spirit but the continued experience of death in your body.
                                        Illustration 103. Transfusion from Static to Dynamic

                                 Ch. 7                                                   Ch. 8




*
    See Illustration 101. Telolic Links, 285.
†
    See Illustration 102. Soteric Link, 286.
Page 288                                                                                           The Outer Darkness


        To restate the facts, even if you are dead bodily and not meeting your moral obligation necessary to
experience life in your mortal body, your spirit nevertheless is alive since Christ is in you (8:10). Paul also
indicates in his conclusion of this section that nothing can separate him from Christ (8:31-39). Although moral
failure will result in mortal calamity, your spirit is not subject to such death since your regenerate spirit has been
made immortal. The context in general and 8:10 in particular render the soteriological interpretation of 8:13 null
and void. Incidentally, the word used by Peter to say that we have been born again of imperishable (aphthartos)
seed is the same word used by Paul when he says that God is immortal (1Tim 1:17). The seed of life, which God
has placed in us, is immortal. We will never perish because our spirit has become immortal by virtue of our new
birth. Christ has taken up static residency within our spirits in that He does not come and go. This spiritual union is
permanent. However, the experience of this reality is dynamic as we submit to the transfusion of life to our bodies.
Yet even if we do not submit, the flow of the transfusion is in one direction. The spirit can impart life to the body,
but the body cannot impart death to the spirit.
                                           Illustration 104. Dynamic Lamp




        What are Marrowists to make of the Calminian lamp in which Arminians and Calvinists join forces to assert
that if the believer becomes unplugged from Christ by failing to persevere in faith the believer loses eternal life?
We respond that eternal life is both dynamic and static. Even if the dynamic expression of that life is put out so that
the static potential is hidden from view by the darkness, the static power is still there, residing just as powerful and
just as available as ever in our spirit. The body of the lamp can become unplugged from the outlet, but this does not
mean that the outlet becomes unplugged from itself. We need to plug into the power available in our spirit through
the Spirit who indwells our spirit. Still, even if we fail to plug into that power source, the Spirit still indwells our
spirit. The light-giving power is still there even though the lamp is not burning. We are not only the lamp, we are
the outlet also. The lamp represents our body. The outlet represents our spirit. Even if we do not have life
dynamically, we still have it statically. Our spirit cannot be unplugged from Christ since His Spirit permanently
resides in our spirit. It is only our bodies that may fail to plug into Christ. But this failure is nothing more than
failing to plug into the life that is available within our spirit and which permanently resides there within our spirit.
        Granted, the response will be made that Paul says in Rom 8:13 that you will die. Rather than saying that
your body will die, he speaks holistically of the entire person as dying. Does this mean that the believer’s spirit will
die also? No. But it does mean that the person himself will experience death, not just his body. When we
experience temporal death, it is as a person, not just as a body. In ch. 7, Paul describes his temporal experience of
death as a person. Despite the fact that his inner man is alive, his experience as a person is death.
        The objection still will be made that Paul says in Rom 8:13 that you will die. If you are presently living
according to the flesh, you are dead. Your bodily experience is already one of death. But rather than say that you
are dead, Paul says that you will die in the future. So Paul must mean that your spirit will die. Otherwise, he would
have said, “You are dead.”
        I counter by noting two matters from the context. One, the statement you will die may just be implementing
a logical future to denote the conditional nature of this death. The conditional aspect is certainly borne out in 8:11
and 8:13b. However, I find no reason to limit this death to the temporal dimension. Marrowists may agree with
Arminians and Calvinists in finding an eschatological dimension to this death since it is juxtaposed in the
Chapter 8. Pre-Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 289
immediate context with eschatological life as a son of God. Moreover, the telolic nature of this death for the
believer already has been established from the broader context. Even so, this does not require a soteriological
understanding of this death.
        Misthological death for the believer will mean that that believer will not be co-glorified as a son of God.
Failure to experience this qualitative degree of life may be considered a form of death. Failure to attain to
misthological life may be regarded as misthological death. Death may be defined as the absence of life. In this
case, it is the absence of misthological life. So the fact that this death is eschatological does not mean that it cannot
be misthological. Nor does its futuristic nature conflict with its personal nature. If we are thrown into the outer
darkness, it is as a person. Our body is not thrown into the outer darkness while our spirit is allowed to roam freely.
The consequences are very real holistically. Believers cast into the outer darkness will weep and gnash their teeth
in response to their misthological death. It will not be merely the believer’s body weeping and gnashing its teeth.
The believer himself or herself will weep and gnash his or her teeth. Since disharmony between the believer’s
spirit and body will no longer exist, this expression of sorrow must be profound indeed. It will not be a case of
rejoicing in spirit while sorrowing in body. Death will hurt—even if it is misthological death.

                                                     Conclusion
        In this chapter spanning over a hundred pages dealing with pre-temporal election, I have demonstrated that
God’s predestination in eternity past does not guarantee that believers will persevere in either faith or faithfulness.
Consequently, the doctrine of predestination does not rule out a misthological interpretation of the outer darkness.
God has not irresistibly determined either our faith or our faithfulness. Instead, He conditionally has determined
that we will believe and will be faithful and has taken action to enable and encourage this response. This contingent
predestination does not override our will. Rather, God implements persuasional influence in seeking to save the
lost from hell and believers from the outer darkness. We have a real choice to make as to how we will respond to
His exhortations. God has, however, irresistibly determined the results of our faith and faithfulness. Punctiliar
saving faith irresistibly results in soteriological salvation, that is, in our being in Christ. Subsequent linear faith and
faithfulness irresistibly result in misthological salvation in the form of rulership with Christ.
        That God foreknows the future does not mean that He sovereignly has predetermined all aspects of the
future. Since He does not take a fatalistic view of His foreknowledge, neither should we take a deterministic view.
Neither He nor we are prisoners of His foreknowledge. Some aspects of God’s election show His intended goal for
believers, but it is up to the believers to fulfill their misthological destiny. Although more technical defenses of this
conclusion have been postponed to the appendices and deferred to other areas of my writings, I have presented
considerable exegetical evidence in favor of a Marrowistic approach to this topic concerning both the free will of
the believer and unbeliever.
        Equating what should happen with what will or would happen has been shown to be a faulty procedure.
Certain parts of God’s predestination are conditional, while other aspects are unconditional for the believer. God
has predetermined that certain events irresistibly would take place, but the same cannot be said of everything that
God has predestined. Although the conclusion is certain as to who will win the game (if one may call it that), the
game is not fixed. Free will is a vibrant reality. God has made it possible for unbelievers to go to either heaven or
hell, depending on their response to His gracious offer to receive the unmerited gift of eternal life. The Lord
likewise has made it possible for believers to experience the outer darkness or co-glorification, pending their free
response to His gracious offer to earn rewards.
        This is not to say that humanity is free to do whatever it wants, whenever it wants, or however it wants. God
has limited human options for example. The type of world in which God has placed us limits our actions. God may
further temporally limit human choices circumstantially and providentially, both externally and internally.
Humanity cannot come to God and escape hell independently of God who graciously gives humankind the internal
ability and external opportunity to do so. In prevenient grace, God universally makes both possible rather than
either universally irresistible. By the same token, believers cannot live for God and escape the outer darkness apart
from God’s enabling grace.
        Faith is not a gift, much less a forced gift, nor is soteriological faith a synergistic response, despite the
emphatic Calvinistic denials to the contrary. Calvinism teaches a synergistic soteriology in that post-regenerational
activity is necessary in the form of perseverance for the Calvinistic believer to reach heaven. Final salvation, in the
ultimate analysis, Calvinistically is conditioned on a believer’s works. It makes no difference if TULIP tries to
label these works as gifts or monergistic results. In either case, it is still salvation by perseverance. Consequently,
both Calvinism and Arminianism come to the same acronymic conclusion: Salvation is by perseverance, not by
faith alone. Marrowism contends, to the contrary, that salvation from eternal damnation is by faith alone, but
Page 290                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
salvation from the outer darkness is by faith that works. Static life guarantees soteric salvation, but dynamic life is
necessary to ensure mistholic salvation.
        This theological perspective of predestination should be comforting and encouraging. God’s will is for the
lost to be saved, and He has taken and is continuing to take the necessary action to make such salvation possible.
Let us pray and witness in cooperation with His efforts and be encouraged that our efforts will be fruitful, since
they are in harmony with His will and work. Let us also be encouraged in living holy lives, knowing that God has
and is taking action to make such holiness possible. He has not left us on our own to try to live up to His
expectations. God has predestined us to be holy experientially by predisposing Himself to do everything necessary
to enable us to live righteously. Although God will not work irresistibly in this regard, He will work powerfully to
this end. We can rely on Him for both our positional and practical righteousness. We can rely on the Lord to save
us from the outer darkness, just as we already have relied on Him to save us from a certain hell. We can cooperate
with Christ’s efforts to save us from shame at the Judgment Seat of Christ, just as we may cooperate with Christ’s
efforts to save the lost from the horror of the Great White Throne Judgment.
                                                       Chapter 9.
                                                    Temporal Election
                                                           Introduction
       The previous chapter dealt with pre-temporal election that was made before the foundation of the world.
This chapter will deal with temporal election that has been made subsequently within the course of time as we
know it. What have believers been elected for and what must they do in order to fulfill their destiny? What should
believers be doing now, and what effect will this have on us in the eschatological future? In answering such
questions, this chapter will cover both temporal and post-temporal election.

                                          Temporal Election in 2Tim 2:10-13
         Paul teaches in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:13 that those who are chosen are believers who have been called
(i.e., invited) to obtain co-glorification.* He also presents this same truth in 2Tim 2:10-13. Chosen in 2Tim 2:10
refers to regenerate believers. Bema salvation is entailed in all three passages.

          For this reason I endure all things for the sake of those who are chosen, that they also may obtain the
          salvation which is in Christ Jesus and with it eternal glory. It is a trustworthy statement:
              • For if we died with Him, we shall also live with Him;
              • If we endure, we shall also reign with Him;
              • If we deny Him, He also will deny us;
              • If we are faithless, He remains faithful.

                                                 Chosen Believers
        Strangely, after acknowledging that the conceptual parallels in the above Thessalonian passages are dealing
with believers who are chosen, Wilkin (GNTC) states that unbelievers are the ones chosen/elect in 2Tim 2:10.
Remarkably, he thinks that these unbelievers are chosen to rule with Christ! Perish the thought! Wilkin recognizes
that this salvation is not soteric but mistholic and consists of ruling with Christ as a result of the Bema. Thus, his
supposing that unbelievers are chosen for this salvation is completely gratuitous. Obviously, Wilkin has misstated
or left out some statements needed to justify such absurd comments. Dillow’s comments below, however, stand out
in bold relief and are supported by my previous assessment that those designated as elect already have believed.†

                While the majority of the commentators understand the “elect” to refer to the unregenerate who
          have not yet believed (but certainly will), there is good reason to understand the term in this context
          [2Tim 2:10] as a virtual synonym for a regenerate saint. First of all, in every usage of the term
          applied to men, in the New Testament it always refers to a justified saint. Conversely, it never refers
          to someone who was elect in eternity past but who has not yet entered into the purpose of their
          election, justification.544

        Those designated as chosen in the NT already have entered into the initial phase of their salvation; chosen
refers to someone who already is justified and regenerate. But it is not limited to the initial phase of their salvation.
It encompasses all three phases of their salvation: justification salvation, sanctification salvation, and co-
glorification salvation. The chosen already have experienced the first phase of their salvation—justification and
regeneration; and they are urged to experience the other two phases as well.
        Paul is concerned for the salvation of the elect. If the word elect is used in the manner it is used consistently
in the rest of the NT, what Paul is saying in 2Tim 2:10 is that he is concerned about the salvation of those who
have not only been elected pre-temporally but who already have entered into that election temporally. They already
have been put in Christ. They already have been justified. For example, in Rom 8:33 Paul uses the word elect to
refer to those who already are justified. Obviously, you could bring a charge against someone who had not yet
believed and who thus had not yet temporally entered into his or her election. Similarly, in Col 3:12 Paul refers to
those who already have believed as the elect. These elect already have experienced the initial phase of salvation

*
    For a quick review, see Illustration 73. Parallelism of 1Thess 5:8-11 and 2Thess 2:13-15, 177.
†
    See Illustration 76. Election (eklego, ekloge, eklektos), 182.
Page 292                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
(regeneration and justification), but Paul is concerned that they may fail to experience the intermediate and
ultimate phases of salvation. In other words, they have experienced justification salvation, but they may fail to
experience sanctification salvation temporally and co-glorification salvation post-temporally.

Apostasy of the elect
        Jesus’ concern is that the elect might be led astray (apoplanao): “For false Christs and false prophets will
arise, and will show signs and wonders, in order, if possible, to lead the elect astray” (Mk 13:22). The possibly of
their being led astray from the faith presumes they first have come to faith. The elect are believers. That genuine
believers are the ones in danger of being misled is also indicated in the initial warning in Mk 13:5, where Jesus
warns, “See to it that no one misleads [planao] you.” The you is identified as genuine believers in Mk 13:3.
        The phrase if possible (ei dunatos) in Mk 13:22 occurs nine times in the Bible (Mt 24:24; 26:39; Mk 9:23;
13:22; 14:35; Lk 14:31; Acts 20:16; Rom 12:18; Gal 4:15). The phrase, in and of itself, does not mean that the
event in question is impossible. For example, in Rom 12:18 Paul says, “If possible, so far as depends upon you, be
at peace with all men.” He evidently considers it possible to be at peace in certain circumstances. Also, in Acts
20:16 Paul hastens to be at Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost—if possible. If it were impossible, there would be no
need to hasten. If possible does not necessarily mean impossible. On the other hand, when Paul says, “if possible,
you would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me” (Gal 4:15), he is describing a sacrifice that was
medically impossible in that day and time. The context determines whether the action in question is possible.
        The context of Mt 24:24 indicates that it will be possible for the antichrist to lead some believers astray. In
Mt 24:4, Jesus warns believers to take heed lest they be led astray. Why warn them against being lead astray if it
were impossible for them to be lead astray. In the next verse (Mt 24:5 and in Mt 24:11), Jesus proceeds to say that
“many” will be led astray (planao). Evidently, Jesus wants to convey the possibility that the elect might be part of
that “many.” The writers of the NT repeatedly use this Greek verb to urge their Christian readers against being led
astray or deceived (e.g., 1Cor 6:9; 15:33; Gal 6:7; Jam 1:16; 1Jn 3:7). James also uses this word and gives explicit
instructions concerning believers who are actually led astray (Jam 5:19). According to Jesus, many of His servants
were led astray to commit fornication (Rev 2:20). Mark (13:22) uses a compound form of this verb to lead astray
(apoplanao), which is a parallel to Mt 24:11. The only other time this compound form is found in the NT is in
1Tim 6:10, where Paul affirms that some believers have been led astray from the faith. Although Satan will find it
impossible to lead all the elect astray, he will find it possible to lead some of the elect astray.
        Robertson oddly thinks that “the implication is that it is not possible” to mislead” the elect (WPNT). Only
the nonelect could be mislead astray. Blomberg takes a more realistic approach: “Believers are not immune to their
attacks, but God will protect them from full-fledged apostasy.” He suggests that the expression “is probably an
ellipsis for the protasis of a fourth-class condition…implying that it is not probable that the elect will be deceived.”
If so, it could be translated as: if it were possible.545 McKay concurs (NSVNT, 165). Both writers suggest the
optative form of eimi. Several translations render it in this manner. Actually, it is much more probable in this
context that the ellipsis is for a first class condition, as indicated by the translation suggested by BDAG: if it is
possible (dunatos, 2a). An ellipsis for the present indicative of eimi is more likely. For one thing, as Wallace notes,
“There are no complete fourth class conditions in the NT” (GGBB, 699). So why think that an incomplete fourth
class condition is more likely than an incomplete first class? Second, by Blomberg’s own admission, even a fourth
class usage in this context leaves the possibility open that the elect will be deceived. Improbable does not mean
impossible. The tension between certainty and probability is addressed by France in this manner: “Even the
‘chosen people’ may not be immune to such deceit, though the addition of ‘if possible’ suggests that they, unlike
the rest of the people in the city, have the spiritual resources to resist it.”546 The elect have the ability to resist
Satan, but Satan has the ability to mislead the elect. When the elect do not sufficiently resist, as they otherwise
could, they will be mislead. A suitable gloss would be: “For false Christs and false prophets will arise and will
show great signs and wonders, so as to mislead, when possible, even the elect.”
        Satan already has had considerable success in leading some of the elect astray in the past, and he will
continue to have some success during the tribulation. What happens to those who are lead astray during the
tribulation? Both Matthew and Mark indirectly answer this question when they record Jesus as saying that the
angels will gather together His elect at the end of the tribulation. No exceptions are made. The implication is that
any elect still living at that time will be gathered—even if they have been led astray. The same thing that will
happen to the unfaithful elect at the beginning of the tribulation will also happen to the unfaithful elect at the end of
the tribulation. They will be gathered by the angels to live with the Lord. The Pauline affirmation that all believers
will be raptured to be with the Lord when He returns in 1Thess 4:17 and 5:9-10 has been examined already. Paul
also indicates the same thing in 2Tim 2:11-13, where he again teaches that all believers will live with the Lord.
Likewise, at the conclusion of the tribulation, all believers will be gathered to the Lord.
Chapter 9. Temporal Election                                                                                    Page 293
Die with Him
       In 2Tim 2:11, Paul is saying that everyone who has died with Christ will live with Him. Who has died with
Christ? According to Paul, all believers have died with Christ (Rom 6:4-8; Col 3:3).* Admittedly, Paul specified
that he had been crucified with Christ in Gal 2:20. But he also affirms that this is true of all believers in Gal 5:24.
Accordingly, the if (ei) of 2Tim 2:11 may be rendered since.† Paul is acknowledging that since believers have died
with Christ, they will live with Him.

Endure with Him
        In 2Tim 2:12a, Paul continues by promising that believers who endure will also reign with Christ. In v. 12b
he teaches that believers who do not endure will be denied the reward of ruling with Christ. In v. 13 he restates the
truth of v. 11 in a different manner by saying that even if believers are unfaithful to Jesus and do not endure, Jesus
is faithful to them because Jesus does not lie. The Lord has promised eternal life to every believer, and He will
keep His promise.
        We can deny Him, and He can deny us, but He cannot deny Himself. As McCoy argues, this is basically the
same as saying, “He cannot do anything that violates His own character or essence.”547 God cannot die since that
would violate His eternal essence. God cannot lie since that would violate His eternal character (Tit 1:2). However,
He can deny believers the reward of ruling with Him, since this does not violate His character. He never promised
rewards to believers in general, only to faithful believers. Yet God cannot deny believers the gift of eternal life and
the right to live with Him in heaven since this would violate His character. He has promised this gift of life (and
life with Him) to all believers. God’s elect can commit apostasy by abandoning Him, but God will never commit
apostasy by abandoning them.
        In summary, concerning 2Tim 2:10-13, those who are described by the adjective elect in v. 10 already have
responded to the efficacious gospel call. They made it efficacious on their behalf by believing it. Those designated
as elect already have believed. In v. 10 Paul is saying that he endures in order that these elect believers may follow
his example of endurance and thus obtain co-glorification salvation, that is, the reward of ruling with Christ (cf.
v. 12a). Living with Christ, though, is not dependent upon our faithfulness but upon His faithfulness. The passage
is very clear concerning the fact that our faithfulness does not determine whether we will live with Christ. What
determines whether we will live with Christ is whether we have died with Christ, not whether we live for Christ.
Thus, in 2Tim 2:10-13 Paul gives a remarkable restatement of the same truth he presented in 1Thess 5:9-10. All
believers will live with the Lord (and thus will be saved from the tribulation), but not all believers will experience
the misthological salvation and glory of ruling with the Lord.

                                  Election in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:13
      Paul’s use of tithemi (to destine) in 1Thess 5:9 and of haipreomai (to choose) in 2Thess 2:13 parallels his
usage of eklego (to elect) in Eph 1:4. With this in mind, the following expanded paraphrases of the Thessalonians
passages are offered:

Expanded Paraphrase of 1Thess 5:8-11
     Christian, through the exercise of faith, hope, and love be morally sober and alert for two reasons:
     out of gratitude that we have been delivered from God’s tribulational wrath, and in order to gain
     millennial salvation, which is the glory of co-ruling with Christ in the millennial kingdom.

Expanded Paraphrase of 2Thess 2:13-15
     God has pre-temporally elected you believers for co-glorification salvation through progressive
     sanctification and a living faith (i.e., living by faith). And it was for this co-glorification salvation that
     He invited you through our gospel so that you may win it. So then, believer, stand firm in your faith.

      Some leaders in the FG movement, like Hodges and Wilkin, contend that the sanctification in 2Thess 2:13
and 1Pet 1:2 is preconversion sanctification that makes faith possible.548 For example, Hodges states:




*
    See Co-Death, 88.
†
    See Conditional Sentences, 87.
Page 294                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
            In my opinion, 2 Thess. 2:13 refers to the truth enunciated somewhat differently in Gal. 1:15.
       The “salvation” here is naturally taken to refer to exactly the same thing as it does in 1 Thess. 5:8-
       10—i.e., deliverance from the wrath of the day of the Lord. The fact that “sanctification” precedes
       “belief of the truth” in [2 Thess] 2:13 puts this passage in the same category as 1 Peter 1:2 as well.
       (Emphasis his.)549

        Temporal Possibility
        In contrast, the position taken herein is that postconversion sanctification is being referred to in these
passages.550 This is the same position taken by Fisk, who quotes Ellicott at length to the effect that sanctification in
this passage is progressive sanctification of believers. Moreover, Ellicott even argues that the salvation in view is
sanctification salvation as well. According to these authors, believers may forfeit this type of salvation if they do
not continue in correct belief because the predestination in this passage is not absolute or irreversible. It is a
conditional predestination. Indeed, the purpose of this predestination may be rejected so that it goes unrealized.
The present book is in substantial agreement with Ellicott on these matters but considers the salvation in view to be
future co-glorification salvation, which may be forfeited by believers (a position which Fisk seems to suggest as
well). In agreement with both writers, it is affirmed that this type of salvation can be forfeited by believers.551
        Further, it may be noted that Fisk rejects Ellicott’s pre-temporal election in this passage in favor of temporal
election. Fisk is joined by Forster, along with others whom Fisk cites, in this preference for temporal election in
this passage. My thesis is quite comfortable with either pre-temporal or temporal election. In defense of the
temporal position, Forster states that it is “very significant” in Phil 4:15-16 that “Paul’s first journey to
Thessalonica is specifically mentioned as the ‘beginning of the gospel.’ Thus when he tells the Thessalonians:
‘God chose you from the beginning’ it would seem obvious that he means the beginning of the gospel.”552
        If this is the case, then Fisk and company are certainly correct in affirming that the passage is clearly not
talking about the predestination of certain unbelievers to become believers. Rather, it refers to the predestination of
those who already have become believers to attain to a future experience of salvation (which in our mutual opinion
may be forfeited but explicitly forfeited misthologically in mine). If this type of understanding of the text is taken,
then the verse is saying that subsequent to their believing the gospel, God chose (i.e., invited) these believers to
attain (misthological) salvation through progressive sanctification and faith. Vance takes a similar temporal
position, although he would say that we are chosen to be in Christ positionally after believing.553 Regardless,
Hodges’ argument concerning the significance of sanctification preceding faith would be nullified because the faith
that resulted in their justification would have occurred beforehand, when they first heard and believed the gospel in
the beginning.
        In other words, if Fisk and Vance are correct, then God temporally chose the Thessalonian believers after
they believed the gospel. Thus, being chosen from the beginning indicates that they already had experienced saving
faith. Paul is now progressing beyond that initial previous experience to progressive sanctification and a living
faith. If temporal election is thus intended, then the temporal order in the passage would be: (1) they believed the
gospel from the beginning; (2) God chose them for misthological salvation after they believed the gospel; and the
means through which God determined they could achieve misthological salvation are (3) progressive sanctification
by the Spirit and (4) persevering faith. If this position is taken, then the requirements for misthological salvation
being presented by Paul in temporal sequence are: soteriological faith, predestination, progressive sanctification,
and misthological faith.
        In support of this understanding of the sequence in 2Thess 2:13, Fisk quotes Drew at length (concerning the
same sequence in 2Pet 1:10), who rightly argues that we are called through the gospel (cp. 2Thess 2:14), and then
after believing the gospel, we are chosen for co-glorification if we are faithful (cp. Rev 17:14).554 After responding
to the gospel call to believe in Jesus, we then are invited by the gospel to rule with Jesus. The means of the calling
is the gospel. The goal of the calling is that these believers may earn glory with Jesus in His kingdom. The
requirement of the calling is that these believers stand firm and hold to the truth embedded in the gospel
(2Thess 2:15). Being called to earn glory by standing firm and holding on in verses 14-15 is the same as being
chosen for salvation through progressive sanctification and ongoing faith in the truth in verse 13. Being called or
chosen is not based on some irresistible or unconditional Calvinistic decree. The exhortations to stand firm and
hold on are imperatival commands, not unconditional futuristic promises. The realization of this invitation is
conditioned on our subsequent faithfulness as believers.
        This conditional view concerning the calling and choosing is also justly advocated by both Wilkin and
Hodges in 2Pet 1:10. And taking a similar approach in 2Thess 2:13 is extremely attractive. The faith Paul has in
mind as a requirement for attaining this misthological salvation is faithfulness. Pistis (faith) can be translated as
faith or faithfulness depending on context. Ongoing faith in the truth is faithfulness to the truth. In fact, this “faith
Chapter 9. Temporal Election                                                                                      Page 295
in the truth” is really a genitive and is translated as such in Phil 1:27, where Paul urges believers to strive “together
for the faith of the gospel.” Whether the phrase is translated as faith in the truth, faith of the truth, or faithfulness to
the truth, the meaning is basically the same in this context.
        Soteriological faith is passive confidence in Christ. Misthological faith, on the other hand, requires active
commitment to Christ. That is to say, a volitional response, although disguisable from faith itself, must necessarily
be added to faith for such faith to result in rewards. A simple, punctiliar, passive response (which faith strictly
speaking is) does not qualify for rewards. Persevering faith, on the other hand, is presumed to result in, be
enlivened by, and kept alive by works. Such faith is rewardable. It is a form of faithfulness. Paul already had
mentioned the persevering faith of the Thessalonians (2Thess 1:4), and now he urges them to continue to believe in
the body of truth they had been taught (2Thess 2:15). This context is not addressing initial soteriological faith,
which they already had experienced (2Thess 1:10). Instead, it deals with the possibility of being shaken in their
faith (2Thess 2:2) and with the need for persevering in faith by the sanctifying power of the Spirit so that they
might stand firm and attain the future, potential glory available to them in the gospel (2Thess 2:13-15).
        To bring these many strands together, it would be best to highlight some of the misthological details from
the context which lead up to the conclusion that 2Thess 1:4 is indeed referring to misthological faith.
            4
             Therefore, we ourselves speak proudly of you among the churches of God for your
       perseverance and faith in the midst of all your persecutions and afflictions which you endure. 5 This
       is a plain indication of God’s righteous judgment so that you may be considered worthy of the
       kingship of God, for which indeed you are suffering….
            11
               To this end also we always pray for you so that our God may count you worthy of the
       calling, and fulfill every desire for goodness and the work of faith with power; 12 in order that the
       name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in Him.…
            13
               But we should always give thanks to God for you, brethren beloved by the Lord, because God
       has chosen you from the beginning for salvation through sanctification by the Spirit and faith in the
       truth. 14 And it was for this He called you through our gospel, for earning the glory of our Lord
       Jesus Christ. (2Thess 1:4-5,11-12; 2:13-14; TM)

        In verse 4 Paul is proud of them for their persevering faith (both words being united by kai under one
article). Certainly, we are to understand this as misthological faith. Paul explains that this type of faith (in
conjunction with persecutions they endure in their suffering) is necessary in order to be considered worthy of the
kingship of God (v. 5). He then proceeds to say that he is constantly praying for them in order that they may be
counted worthy of their calling (v. 11). Obviously, if he has to pray that these regenerate believers will be counted
worthy of their calling, then becoming regenerate has not automatically qualified them as being considered worthy,
nor does being regenerate guarantee that they will inevitably be so qualified in the future. It may, therefore, be
safely concluded that both verses are discussing misthological worthiness. Confirmation comes in the next verse, in
which Paul’s supplication includes the petition that they would abound in the work of faith in order that they may
be glorified in Christ (v. 12). To be sure, this is misthological glorification since it is conditioned on their working
faith and is something for which Paul believes he needs to pray for them rather than promise to them.
        Having described this misthological faith twice in ch. 1, Paul picks back up on it in ch. 2, by noting that God
has chosen them for faith in the truth (assuming in is the way we render the genitive in 2:13). If this is, as it appears
to be, the same postconversional, persevering, working faith described in ch. 1, then there is good reason to think
that God chose them for such faith after they came to saving faith. Since they have come to saving faith, God now
desires that they progress to a productive faith. This temporal sequence is reasonable. Corroboration (that Paul is
picking this theme back up from ch. 1) comes in the next verse, where he again says that God called them to earn
the glory of Christ (2:14). Again, this is parallel to his prayer that they become misthologically worthy of their
misthological calling to misthological glory (1:11-12). The calling that Paul is praying that they will be counted
worthy of in 1:11 is being glorified in Christ in 1:12. Specifically, it is the call to earn the glory of Christ (2:14).
