These misthological strands of misthological worthiness, calling, glory, and faith weave a tight argument for
considering the election in 2:13 to be misthological as well. But this conclusion concerning election is not
inextricably bound to regarding the election as temporal. Even if the election were not temporal, it would still be
misthological in this context.

      Pre-Temporal Preference
      Despite the attractiveness of the above arguments for temporal election by misthological friends and
notwithstanding my own personal preference for temporal election in this passage, in order to be attentive to the
Page 296                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
realization that scholarship is divided as to whether the predestination in 2Thess 2:13 is pre-temporal or temporal, I
will adopt the more difficult interpretation and show that even this more difficult path is by no means detrimental
to the overall misthological thesis. Conscientious exegesis permits adopting a Calvinistic understanding of the text
as referring to pre-temporal predestination. Yet even yielding Calvinists this advantage will not yield the
Calvinistic conclusion. The order of sanctification before faith in 2Thess 2:13 need not be surprising, nor does it
prove preconversion sanctification. The same thing (sanctification by the Spirit) that made faith possible at the time
of conversion also makes faith and faithfulness possible after our conversion.* The Spirit enables unbelievers to
come to faith and enables believers to persist in faith and faithfulness. Additionally, 1Pet 1:2 should be considered
an example of postconversion sanctification.555
       1
        Peter, an apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who reside as aliens, dispersed throughout Pontus, Galatia,
       Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia, who are chosen 2 according to the foreknowledge of God the Father,
       by the sanctifying work of the Spirit, so that you may obey Jesus Christ and be sprinkled with His
       blood as a result: May grace and peace be yours in fullest measure. (1Pet 1:1-2; TM)

        Dillow believes that this passage, as well as the other Petrine examples cited earlier, should not to be limited
to initial election but signify the intended goal of our election.† This goal is to be experientially righteous in the
present life by living an obedient life so that we might achieve the ultimate goal which is co-glorification
salvation.556 The obedience that Peter calls for is not merely the obedience to faith but to faithfulness. For that
matter, it is not necessary even to concede that the initial phase of their obedience to believe is in view at all. As
already pointed out, some FG interpreters evidently believe that God forechooses who will believe so that Peter
may be perceived as saying that God has chosen them to obey by simply believing the gospel. Such FG brethren
would have little trouble accepting the view by Hodges or Wilkin that this is what Peter is describing also.557 Other
FG interpreters, like the present writer, believe that God foresees who will believe rather than forechooses who will
believe. Interpreters who share this perspective would thus be reluctant to find a reference to God choosing who
will believe in this passage.
        Presuppositionless exegesis is impossible. An author needs to be aware of his or her own presuppositions
and compensate for these inclinations by not being satisfied by the slightest evidence that seems to support his or
her own position. For this reason, interaction with those holding different views and alternative presuppositions is
both necessary and healthy. Multiple reasons for taking a particular interpretation are accordingly preferable in
order to counterbalance one’s own disposition. There are three basic FG possibilities concerning what it means to
be chosen to obey in this passage. { It could mean to be chosen to become a believer (so Hodges). | It could
mean to be chosen to become an obedient believer (so the present author). } Or it could be a combination of these
two possibilities and mean to become a believer and then follow in obedience (so Dillow).
        The working model of predestination developed herein would permit either of these interpretations, even
from a foresee presupposition. If Hodges’ approach is adapted to the present model, then it could be argued that
God conditionally has chosen who would believe, and thus whether they believe is dependent on their response.‡ If
Dillow’s view is preferred, then it could be maintained that God conditionally has chosen who would believe and
conditionally has determined that those who do believe will live obediently. Namely, whether they believe and
follow in obedience is dependent upon their response to the Holy Spirit: whether they quench the Spirit or walk by
the Spirit. God’s will is that they believe and follow in sanctification, but it is not His irresistible will. On the other
hand, if the present author’s preference is adopted, then Peter is saying that God conditionally has elected believers
to walk by the Spirit. God’s will is they walk in this manner, but God will not force them to do so. They already
have been sealed by the Spirit, and now they need to be filled by the Spirit. They already have become babes in
Christ, and now they need to grow in Christ (1Pet 2:2). Peter is reminding these believers that the goal of their
election is practical sanctification.
        The rejection of Hodges’ justification limitation herein is thus not based on an incompatible view of
election. It is based on the context in which the salvation in view is not justification salvation, but co-glorification
salvation (1Pet 1:5,9). This salvation is, in turn, dependent on practical sanctification—a fact that is acknowledged
by Hodges himself.558 The rejection of the justification limitation is also based on the broader context of 2Pet 1:10-
11, where the misthological goal of election is in view and is also based on practical sanctification. My preference
is also based on the parallelism with cross-references (e.g., 1Thess 5:9; 2Thess 2:13; Eph 1:4; Col 3:12).
*
  See Illustration 73. Parallelism of 1Thess 5:8-11 and 2Thess 2:13-15, 177.
†
  See 1Pet 1:2, 232.
‡
  This model can also be applied to difficult texts such as Acts 13:48. See Drawing and Appointment.
Chapter 9. Temporal Election                                                                                   Page 297
       Further, it should not be considered unusual that Peter urges those who already have believed in Jesus to
obey Him here in 1Pet 1:2. After all, Paul urges those who already have believed in Jesus to obey Him (Rom 6:16;
2Cor 10:5-6). The writer of Hebrews says that a believer’s co-glorification salvation is dependent upon obeying
Jesus (Heb 5:8-9). The only other time that the writer of Hebrews uses this word for obey (hupakouo) is when he
says, “By faith, Abraham, when he was called, obeyed by going out to a place which he was to receive for an
inheritance” (Heb 11:8). This obedience is certainly misthological. Abraham obeyed by putting feet to his faith in
order to receive a misthological inheritance. Constable acknowledges that the salvation in Heb 5:9 is plausibly
misthological. Hodges is even more to the point and acknowledges that the salvation in Heb 5:9 is in fact a
reference to millennial salvation (i.e., co-glorification salvation)!

                The salvation here referred to…should not be confused with the acquisition of eternal life which
          is conditioned not on obedience but on faith (cf. John 3:16, etc.). Once again the writer had in mind
          final deliverance from and victory over all enemies and the consequent enjoyment of the “glory” of
          the many sons and daughters. This kind of salvation is explicitly contingent on obedience and indeed
          on an obedience modeled after that of Jesus who also suffered.…
                The High Priest has become the “Source” of this kind of salvation experience for those who are
          willing to live obediently.559

        Salvation never refers to simple soteriological salvation anywhere in the entire epistle of Hebrews.*
Certainly Hodges is correct on the misthological nature of eternal salvation in 5:9.† But Hodges’ perceptive
remarks concerning Heb 5:9 above should also be applied to 1Pet 1:2 as well. This kind of salvation, co-
glorification salvation, “should not be confused with the acquisition of eternal life which is conditioned not on
obedience but on faith.” In 1Pet 1:2 believers are being invited to obey the Lord in order to experience the
cleansing power of the blood in the present (cf. 1Jn 1:7) and obtain co-glorification salvation in the future (cf.
1Pet 1:5,9). Likewise, it should be recognized that in 1Thess 5:9-13 and 2Thess 2:13-15 the goal of our
predestination, election, and calling is co-glorification salvation. Thus, although Hodges is correct that 1Thess 5:9
teaches a full pretribulational rapture, this does not mean that the salvation referred to in 5:9 must be a reference to
tribulational salvation. The same would be true of 2Thess 2:13. The word salvation in these two texts refers to co-
glorification salvation, that is, millennial salvation. The passages promise tribulational salvation to all believers and
millennial salvation to some believers.

                                          Election (foresaw/forechose)
       Predestination is based on God’s foreknowledge. “For whom He foreknew [proginosko], He also
predestined [proorizo]” (Rom 8:29). Election also is based on God’s foreknowledge. Believers “are elected/chosen
according to the foreknowledge of God” (1Pet 1:1-2). The Scripture does not specify what it is that God foreknew.
Some believe that it means that God foresaw who would believe and elected them; that is, God chose believers for
salvation. (This is my position as has been explained already.) Others, such as Calvinists, believe that it means that
God forechose who would believe and elected them; that is, God chose them for salvation. Therefore, regardless of
how foreknowledge is understood by these two perspectives, election means to choose for salvation (1Pet 1:5,9).
God has predetermined that those who believe will be saved.
       This simplistic Calvinistic restatement would apparently suffice for Hodges’ view of salvation in 1Thess 5:9
and 2Thess 2:13, since he regards this salvation as unmerited salvation. But this FG interpretation has been found
linguistically, contextually, and logically unacceptable in this chapter and the previous one. The salvation in view
is one that is merited. This would present no problem for Calvinistic Lordship Salvationists. They simply may
respond that God has predetermined that all believers will persevere and thus achieve co-glorification salvation by
God’s enabling grace. However, the weaknesses of this assumption already have been pointed out. Some believers
will die in a carnal stage of development and thus fail to achieve the out-resurrection. This observation leads to the
consideration of a more consistent position for election below, which is a harmonious extension of the logic of my
previous discussion.




*
    See Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
†
    See Aionios, 520.
Page 298                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                                  Post-Temporal Election

Goal of Election
        God’s election not only has determined what we should be temporally; it has also determined what we
should be post-temporally. We should gain the glory of ruling with Christ in heaven. However, what should be is
not necessarily what will be. This has been demonstrated to be the case in 2Thess 2:13-14. Believers were pre-
temporally chosen for the goal of earning co-glorification salvation through practical, that is, temporal
sanctification. Or as stated in 1Thess 5:9, the goal for which God has destined us is to earn co-glorification
salvation. God has predetermined that believers would not experience wrath and should earn glory. Jesus presents
this truth beautifully in two Matthean parables: the Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard and the Parable of the
Wedding Supper.

Misthological Sequence of Election
       According to MT, both of these eschatological parables are followed by the statement, “many are called
[kletos], few are chosen [eklektos]” (Mt 20:16; 22:14). The latter passage is one of the passages concerning the
outer darkness. Both parables deal with Christians who either fail or succeed in preparing for the Lord’s return and
its corresponding Bema. In the parable of the workers in the vineyard, the call (i.e., the invitation) is given
throughout the day to work in the vineyard. That evening, after their work is completed, the choice is made
concerning their wages (misthos—reward). Likewise, in the parable of the wedding feast, the call/invitation is
issued throughout the day to come to the feast. But the poorly dressed man is not chosen to participate even though
he had been invited/called. The election, that is, choosing (eklektos) not only is distinguished from the call (kletos)
but also follows the call.
       Just as resurrection is followed by a possible out-resurrection (ek+anastasis),* so here, in Mt 20:16 and
22:14, call is followed by a possible out-calling (ek+lego). The latter are called out of those who were called
previously. A subsequent, selective, misthological calling out is made of those who previously and misthologically
had been invited. Only some of those believers who universally were invited will actualize the reality to which they
were otherwise entitled by invitation. Only a few believers will obtain the out-calling. The Pauline out-resurrection
appears to be an explicit elucidation of the implicit confirmation by Jesus that there would be a selective realization
of faithful believers from among those believers who already had responded to the initial invitation. This smaller
subset of faithful believers will experience the out-calling.
       The eschatological election in Mt 22:14 follows the temporal call and is thus post-temporal election. Those
believers who are invited (called) to participate in the rewards of heaven will not be chosen (elected, out-called) to
receive those rewards if they have not lived in accordance with their calling. The misthological potential of the
called (kletos) will be realized only by the elected (eklektos). This election is based on merit and deals with rewards
in heaven rather than with entrance into heaven. All believers are called to work, but only faithful believers are
elected to receive the reward for their work. Peter had heard these parables when Jesus originally gave them and
probably had them in mind when he wrote 2Pet 1:10-11.
        10
          Therefore, brethren, be all the more diligent to make certain about His calling and choosing you;
        for as long as you practice these things, you will never stumble; 11 for in this way the entrance into
        the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ will be abundantly supplied to you.†

       In this passage, election (i.e., choosing or out-calling) likewise comes after the call. Therefore, Hodges is
correct to conclude concerning this verse: “Peter’s words do not refer here to a pre-temporal election to eternal
salvation, which by its very nature would proceed the call to salvation.”560 Wilkin elaborates on the importance of
this order:

             It is possible that call and election here refers to God’s calling and electing of people to eternal
        salvation. However, this is unlikely, for if that were the case, the order should be election and call,

*
 See Illustration 42. Parallelism of Lk 20:35 and Phil 3:11, 96.
†
 For reasons being explained here and elsewhere, translations that render 2Pet 1:10 as if it means to make sure you are elect, so as to
imply that Peter is asserting that his intended readership needs to make sure they really are saved, are inferior to the translation: “Make
your calling and election secure.” See “Do Your Best” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection. The soteriological security of
Peter’s readership is assured, but their misthological security is in jeopardy.
Chapter 9. Temporal Election                                                                                 Page 299
       not call and election. Election to eternal salvation occurred in eternity past, long before any person
       was called to eternal salvation….
            Calling does precede election if we are speaking of being chosen to rule with Christ. All
       believers are invited to rule. Yet only some of those will actually be chosen to rule.561

       Although it was not possible to agree with Hodges and Wilkin that the order of sanctification before faith in
2Thess 2:13 proves preconversion sanctification (since the Spirit also enables the believer to believe), the
implications they draw concerning the sequence of election in 2Pet 1:10 are highly probable. The realization of this
election is post-temporal and occurs at the JSC. This election comes after the call and results in a rich entrance into
the kingdom for those believers who live holy lives. The word translated abundantly (plousios) by the NAS in
2Pet 1:11 is translated as rich(ly) by the NAS everywhere else it appears in the NT and has the same meaning
here.562 Some believers will have rich entrance into the kingdom because they will be rich in the kingdom; other
believers will have an impoverished entrance into the kingdom because they will have an impoverished experience
in the kingdom. This is conditional election. All believers are elected to have a rich entrance into the kingdom, but
the realization of such an election is conditioned on their practice.
                                        Illustration 105. Sequence of Election

             { Election                               | Call                               } Election
 Eternity Past                           Present                                 Bema
 Pre-temporal                            Temporal                                Post-temporal
 Election                                Invitation                              Compensation
 All Believers                           All Believers                           Few Believers

        The sequence of this post-temporal election is logical: | call then } election. This misthological election is
based on the believer’s response to the Lord’s invitation to prepare for the supper by living morally pure and holy
lives. The order is not { election then | call. It is not a call based on the unbeliever’s temporal response to the
invitation to believe the gospel to validate his or her pre-temporal election. Peter is not saying, “Make certain you
are a believer and thus one of the elect.” His epistle is addressed to those who are believers. His exhortation is,
“Make certain you are living righteously so that you may be rewarded richly.” Jesus, likewise, is not saying that
many are invited to believe the gospel but few do so. The Lord is not saying that many are invited to believe but
few were elected in eternity past to believe. Rather, He is saying that of the many believers who are now being
invited to earn a rich entrance into the kingdom, only a few will be selected to receive it in the future misthological
judgment. Dillow interprets this passage from a similar perspective:

            To “make [our] calling and election sure” means to guarantee by adding to our faith the
       character qualities of 1:5-7 that our calling and election will achieve their intended aim.…
            The aim of our calling and election appears to be holiness in this life, perseverance in suffering,
       and inheriting a blessing in the life to come.563

       In a footnote to this material, Dillow states that Eph 1:4 should be understood similarly: “He chose us in
Him before the foundation of the world, that we should be holy and blameless before Him.” It refers to practical
rather than positional righteousness. We have been elected to be holy in this life so that we can qualify for the
misthological inheritance in the future. The FG camp can affirm a soteriological election that does not involve
merit. Marrowists not only hypothetically affirm that believers can enter heaven apart from good works; they
affirm the reality of this doctrine by acknowledging that there will be many carnal Christians who will enter heaven
apart from a life of good works. At the same time Marrowists can also affirm a misthological election that requires
merit: Rewards are given in response to a person’s work.

Misthological Call
       The noun Peter uses in 2Pet 1:10 for calling is klesis. It is a cognate of the verb kaleo, which Peter used five
times in his first epistle concerning the calling of believers. “But like the Holy One who called you, be holy
yourselves also in all your behavior” (1Pet 1:15). As has already been noted in Eph 1:4, we were pre-temporally
elected to be holy in our behavior. Peter likewise says that we were called to be holy in our behavior. God invites
us to experience the holiness now for which He already has predestined us. We were elected in eternity past and
invited to share His experience of light so that we might praise Him (1Pet 2:9). We are called to do good works and
Page 300                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
suffer for doing so in order that we might follow Christ’s example (1Pet 2:20-21). “Not returning evil for evil, or
insult for insult, but giving a blessing instead; for you were called for the very purpose that you might inherit a
blessing” (1Pet 3:9). All believers are invited to inherit this blessing but doing so is conditioned on their
performance. The stated purpose of our calling is that we receive a heavenly inheritance. But this is the intended
goal of our calling, not the guaranteed result.564 We are invited to (share) God’s glory, which is implicitly
conditioned on enduring suffering (1Pet 5:9-10).
        Just as Abraham was called misthologically so that he might receive the (articular) Heavenly City for an
inheritance (Heb 11:8-10), so we too are called so that we might become partakers of this heavenly calling
(Heb 3:1) and the (articular) Heavenly City (Heb 13:14). This particular city is a reward inherited by the faithful.
We are called to win the glory of Christ (2Thess 2:14) and the fullness of eternal life as a future reward
(1Tim 6:12).
        Believers have been called/invited to salvation: not just the minimum salvation of entering heaven, but the
maximum salvation of inheriting heaven. But although we have been given that invitation, few Christians actually
will achieve the realization of its potential. Believers are not automatically considered worthy of their calling;
otherwise, Paul would not have to exhort them to walk in a manner worthy of their calling or pray that God would
count them worthy of their calling (Eph 4:1; 1Thess 2:12; 2Thess 1:11). This election (i.e., the realization of the
invitation) for believers is conditioned on their performance. The goal of our calling and election is to inherit the
kingdom. These Petrine passages, in harmony with other NT passages, are presenting believers with a
misthological call to endure suffering in the present so that they may inherit the kingdom in the future.

                                            Conclusions Concerning Election
        The point has now been reached where conclusions may be drawn concerning the three forms of election in
the previous illustration.* First, the verbal form of election (eklego) is always pre-temporal and is used in its broad
sense or in its restricted sense referring to sanctification or co-glorification. Even this pre-temporal verbal form of
election can refer to co-glorification salvation. The synonymous usage in the key passage, 2Thess 2:13, also
demonstrates the fact that pre-temporal election can focus its attention exclusively on the ultimate goal of
salvation—the reward of co-glorification. This pre-temporal selection does not focus its attention on justification
salvation, however. The verbal form of election is not dealing with who goes to heaven versus hell.
        Second, the nominal form of election (ekloge) is used pre-temporally, temporally, and post-temporally.
Even though it is used in all three temporal phases, it is used to refer to sanctification salvation only once; the rest
of the time the primary focus is on co-glorification. The nominal form of election is not focused on heaven versus
hell. In contrast to Calvinists, Peter affirms that the believer may be relatively assured of his or her sanctification
election. Of course, this presupposes absolute assurance of one’s own personal justification election. But one will
have to look to the next category concerning the adjectival form before one finds any focus on justification.
        Third, the adjectival form of election (eklektos) is used temporally and post-temporally, and it is used to
refer to all three phases of salvation. Its focus on justification salvation is minimal, with only one reference having
this focus. Unlike the verbal and nominal forms, though, the adjectival form is never used pre-temporally. It always
refers to someone who already has believed within the respective time frame in which it is used. Thus, when the
Bible uses the adjectival form of elect in the future, it is talking about someone in that future period who already
has believed from the perspective of that period. Likewise, when the Bible uses the adjectival form of elect in the
present, it is describing someone who already has believed. The inverse of this statement is that the adjectival form
of elect is never used to describe someone who has not yet believed within his or her respective time zone. Those
described as elect are those who already have experienced justification.
        The significance of this study on election in relation to this study on eschatology is that it further strengthens
the conclusion that the key eschatological passages in 1Thess 5 and 2Thess 2 not only promise tribulational
salvation to all the elect, these passages also promote the goal of our election (i.e., millennial salvation) as a reward
to the faithful elect. In addition to making this contribution to this study on eschatology, this analysis of election
also will be useful when we deal with the subject of election in the Mount Olivet discourse in the next section,
which is the context for the major passage concerning the outer darkness.




*
    See Illustration 76. Election (eklego, ekloge, eklektos), 182.

                                          Chapter 10.
                                    When Will These Things Be?
                                                  Introduction
       In the first section, the groundwork was laid for examining the outer darkness in its eschatological context.
Therein the basis for taking a pretribulational position was established so that this understanding could be used
legitimately as a skeleton key to help unlock other eschatological passages, such as the present one. Of course, this
procedure is exactly what one should do in light of the sound hermeneutical principle expressed in the analogy of
faith. Unclear passages of Scripture should be interpreted in light of the clearer passages. In the course of
progressive revelation, one generally anticipates that clarity increases progressively and culminates in the last
teaching on the subject matter at hand. This is not to say that other related passages do not make valuable
contributions to the topic, but they certainly will not contradict the clearer revelation subsequently revealed.
       In this section, of the Mount Olivet Discourse will be examined because it provides the context for the
primary passage on the outer darkness. Just the last passage on the millennium is the clearest passage concerning
the millennium and has been used herein to help understand related passages, so this discussion will now turn to
the last passage on the outer darkness, which is also the clearest, in order to analyze it so that it may in turn shed
light on the other two passages concerning the outer darkness. In this first chapter of this section, the timing of the
events surrounding the primary outer darkness passage will be investigated by first considering the OT background
and then the four major views regarding the time period in view.

                                                OT Background
        The first outer darkness passage that will be investigated in this section is that found in the parable of the
talents, which in turn is found in Matthew’s Mount Olivet Discourse. This discourse is the context for the third and,
arguably, most important passage pertaining to the outer darkness. As Jesus (the Jewish Messiah) came out of the
Jewish temple, His Jewish disciples asked Him when the Jewish temple would be destroyed (Mt 24:1-3). The
Jewishness of this section and their question should not be forgotten. Actually, they ask a dual question regarding
when and what: “Tell us, when will these things be, and what will be the sign of Your coming, and of the end of
the age?” (Mt 24:3) When would it occur, and what would be the signs?
        Before delving into the four possibilities that this parable may have in potential relation to time, it will be
prudent to consider the OT specification concerning the fulfillment of that time. This specification should help cut
down on speculation as we proceed.
                                      Illustration 106. Overview of Dan 9:24-27

                Dan 9:25                                    Dan 9:26                      Dan 9:27 *Dan 9:24

                     483 yrs                                      ? yrs                        7 yrs          1000 yrs
      3/5/444 BC               5/30/33 AD                        Current                       Trib             Mill

       The when aspect of the question requires an examination of its principal OT background text concerning the
time element involved (Dan 9:24-27). This passage is the foundational passage for Jesus’ answer concerning when
in Mt 24:15. The typical dispensational view of Dan 9:24-27 will suffice. A basic dispensational breakdown of this
passage is provided in the above chart. In terms of chronological sequence, the order of the above events may also
be displayed as follows:

         Dan 9:25—483 years in fulfillment
           Decree to rebuild city
           Messiah revealed
         Dan 9:26—Within life span of the generation to whom Jesus spoke
           Messiah killed

        * Dan 9:24—During Millennium

        Moving Dan 9:24 to the end of the above chart may seem odd, but it must be remembered that this is a chart
of chronological sequence. Daniel is being told that 70 prophetic weeks must pass before the six millennial
blessings being described in this verse are to be fulfilled during the millennium. Naturally, the events leading up to
the millennium must be fulfilled before the millennium. So the millennial blessings would happen afterward. Thus,
the move in the chart was necessary. Three major periods of time come first, represented by the three circles:  the
time leading up to the coming of the Messiah (69 weeks),  the time of the Messiah’s generation and the ensuing
persecution (unlimited time), and  the time of the tribulation (1 week). This information is represented and
annotated in more detail below. The above representations are brief outlines of the text used in the following
illustration (which implements the NAS except for the NIV in the latter part of v. 27).

        The Jewish people thought in terms of seven. There were seven days in a week. There were seven years
until the Sabbath year. There were seven sevens of years until the Jubilee year. One would anticipate that if seven
sevens refer to years that seventy sevens would as well. The expression seventy weeks literally reads “seventy
sevens.” The sevens could refer to days, weeks, or years. Neither seventy days nor seventy weeks would be enough
time for the six prophecies in Dan 9:24 to occur, so the natural conclusion is that the seventy is referring to years,
just as it did in Dan 9:2. Seventy sevens of years = 70 x 7 = 490 years. Your people, that is, Daniel’s people,
obviously refers to the Jews, and this expression occurs again in Dan 10:14. The Jewish city referred to is
correspondingly Jerusalem, as it is in Dan 9:16,25. The passage is dealing with Jewish history, not world history or
church history. At the end of the seventy sevens (i.e., the 490 years), God will bless the Jews in six ways.
Therefore, these are millennial blessings.
        The events of these seventy sevens (i.e., the 490 years) are then broken up and given with additional details
in the rest of the passage.  In the first section, the decree referred to is the fourth Persian decree concerning the
Jews. The first three decrees were concerning the rebuilding of the temple and offering sacrifices in the temple.
The fourth decree was concerning the actual rebuilding of the city of Jerusalem itself, and Daniel’s prophecy in this
Chapter 10. When Will These Things Be?                                                                          Page 305
section is concerned explicitly with the rebuilding of the city, not merely the temple. The fourth decree was issued
by Artaxerxes Longimanus on March 5, 444 B.C. (see Neh 2:1-8).
       The time period from March 5, 444 B.C., when the fourth decree was issued until Jesus was presented as the
ruler of His messianic kingdom, was to be sixty nine weeks, that is, 483 years. Jesus officially presented Himself as
Messiah in His Triumphant Entry on March 30, 33 A.D. (cf. Zech 9:9). This was supposed to be the day for peace
according to Jesus in Lk 19:42. To summarize, there will be sixty-nine weeks (i.e., 483 years) between the decree
and the presentation of Jesus as the Messiah in the triumphant entry. The Jewish month had 30 days, and the
Jewish year thus had 360 days. Correspondingly, the 483 years would = 483 x 360 days = 173,880 days between
the declaration and the presentation. This part of the prophecy was fulfilled literally and numerically to the very
day. The triumphant entry took place exactly 173,880 days after the decree.
        The three events in this section two, that is, in Dan 9:26, occur after the Triumphant Entry of section one.
The events in this section two also occur before the events in section three. Therefore, the three events of section
two happened to the Jews after the 69 weeks but before the 70th week. The 70th week is not described until the
third section, that is, until Dan 9:27.
       The three events prophesied in section two were that the Messiah would be cut off and have nothing. This
was fulfilled by Jesus being rejected as King, being crucified, and by His kingdom being postponed. The kingdom
over which He was to be prince was not instituted at this time. The second prophecy is that the prince who is to
come, who is identified as the little horn in Dan 7:8, would destroy Jerusalem and its temple. This prophecy, which
was to be fulfilled in-between the crucifixion and the 70th week of section three, was fulfilled by Titus in A.D. 70.
The third prophecy by Gabriel in section two was that “even to the end there will be war.” The three events of
section two were to take place after the 69th week. The death of the Messiah, the destruction of Jerusalem and the
temple, and wars (Jewish sufferings) are to take place after the triumphant entry. These Jewish sufferings will
continue unto and into the 70th week and even until the end of the 70th week.
        Section three begins with the antichrist (i.e., the little horn) making a covenant with the many, that is,
with many of the Jewish people. This covenant evidently will be a covenant of peace with the nation of Israel—a
peace treaty. The antichrist will falsely present himself as Israel’s prince of peace and be accepted as such.
Although a brief period of time (e.g., weeks) may elapse after the rapture before the peace treaty is signed, the
peace treaty is signed at the very beginning of the tribulational week—the seven years. Thus, the clock starts
ticking off the days on the tribulational calendar on the first day the treaty is signed shortly after the rapture. But in
the middle of the seven years (i.e., 3½ years after making the peace treaty with Israel), the antichrist will put an end
to the Levitical sacrificial system. The implication seems to be that the sacrificial system will be restored and
protected by the peace treaty during the tribulation, but the antichrist will revoke the treaty. In addition to stopping
the Levitical expression of worship, the antichrist will require a different type of worship that causes desolation.
This event is described by Jesus in Mt 24:15 and, as already noted, is described by Paul in 2Thess 2:4.
       For the purpose of our study, it is important to note that the time period of 490 years that began with the
decree is concerned with Jewish history. The amount of time in sections one and three is specifically designated.
The amount of time involved in section two not only is not specified, it also is not part of the 70 weeks. This
unspecified amount of time occurs in-between the presentation of the Messiah (on March 30, 33 A.D.) and the
rapture. The rapture happens at the end of section two and before the peace treaty of section three. Since the
amount of time between the end of the 69th week and the beginning of the 70th week is not given, the time of the
rapture is not prophesied. The rapture could happen at any time; it is imminent. Of course, imminency of the
rapture already has been demonstrated on other bases, so this deduction simply confirms what already has been
deduced. The church age, as it is called, occurs in the unspecified amount of time in section two (i.e., after the 69
weeks but before the 70th week).
                                 Illustration 108. Parenthetical Break in the 70 Weeks




                 69 Weeks
from decree until Messiah dies
                                                           (           church age
                                                                                                 )     1 Week
                                                                                                      tribulation
Page 306                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
        A related conclusion should be made concerning the type of fulfillment. Since the first 69 sevens refer to
literal years, the last seven also should be understood as referring to literal years. Therefore, the last week of
section three will cover 7 literal years. This last section is what is called the tribulation. Thus, the tribulation will
take place over a period of seven literal years. Further, since the prophecy concerning the amount of time from
the decree until the presentation of the Christ is to be taken literally as a duration of 483 years, and since the
prophecy concerning the duration of the tribulation literally is 7 years, the prophecy concerning the duration of the
millennium in Rev 20:1-6 should be interpreted literally as 1000 years.
        Now, returning the discussion back to Mt 24:1-3, and recalling the Jewishness of this section, it was as Jesus
came out of the Jewish temple that His Jewish disciples asked when the temple of the Jews would be destroyed.
The when question in Mt 24:3 has been dealt with already, to a limited extent, by examining Jesus’ reference in
Mt 24:15 in regard to its principal background text in Dan 9:24-27. We will now probe more deeply. According to
Dan 9, when will the 70th week (i.e., the seven years of tribulation) start? Dan 9 does not say. Rather, the
beginning of that period is unknown, as is represented by a question mark in the initial Danielic chart above. This
is the same type of answer that Jesus gives in answer to the when question (see Mt 24:36,42,50; 25:13). We cannot
know when the Lord will return and the last week will start. Date setting for the rapture is impossible.

                                                     Lukan Parallel
       Concerning Mt 24:3, Barbieri says that Matthew does not answer the when question, but Luke does in
Lk 21:20.565 His reason for this statement is that he understands Mt 23:38 as Jesus’ prophecy concerning the
destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70. He suggests that Mt 24:15ff does not describe the A.D. 70 destruction of
Jerusalem, but Lk 21:20ff does. But how can this be since these passages are parallel passages of Scripture?

Singular Destruction
       The answer as to how Matthew and Luke can be giving parallel accounts and yet not both be describing the
destruction of Jerusalem is to be found in noting that the prophecy given by Jesus in Mt 23:38 (“Behold, your
house is being left to you desolate!”) is concerning the immediate future. And this prophecy is followed by an
eschatological prophecy in Mt 23:39 concerning the ultimate future, where Jesus says, “You shall not see Me until
you say, ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord.’” Matthew, like Jesus, focuses the answer to the
disciples’ question on the eschatological fulfillment. Indeed, this eschatological fulfillment is where the disciples
focused their question in Mt 24:3. Thus, it is natural that the answer is focused there as well. Gaebelein takes the
same position as Barbieri when he says:

               Had the Lord nothing to say in this discourse [on Mt Olivet] about the great judgment, which
          befell Jerusalem. [sic] He certainly gave a revelation concerning it as well as warnings. But the
          record of this prediction of the fall of Jerusalem under Titus [in A.D. 70] is not at all given in
          Matthew twenty-four, but we find that the Spirit of God has put that in the Gospel of Luke. In Luke
          xxi:20-23 we have the words which predict the siege and fall of Jerusalem in the year 70. The
          prediction is, that after that catastrophe has taken place and they have fallen by the edge of the sword
          and are led away captives, that Jerusalem shall be trodden down by the Gentiles until the times of the
          Gentiles are fulfilled. This happened after the destruction of the City and Jerusalem is still trodden
          down, because the times of the Gentiles have not yet run out. But now turning to the words in
          Matthew we find an entirely different result from the manifestation of the Son of Man in Glory and in
          the clouds of heaven….There is not a word mentioned of their being scattered among the nations, but
          the very opposite is said, “they shall gather together his elect from the four winds from one end of
          heaven to the other.” The predictions in Matthew xxiv:4-44 have nothing whatever to do with the 40
          years which preceded the destruction of Jerusalem, nor with that event in the year 70. 566

       Concerning Mt 24:2, Gaebelein states, “This is a prediction which refers to the destruction of the temple in
the great catastrophe which came upon Jerusalem in the year 70. It is, as stated before, fully given by our Lord in
Luke xxi:20-24.”567

Multiple Desolation
       Jesus deals with the when aspect of their question, to the extent that was possible, in the parallel passages to
the Matthean text. Grassmick believes that the details of these parallel passages mean that both the immediate and
ultimate fulfillments are in view.568 The first fulfillment of Daniel’s prophecy in Dan 11:31-32 concerning the
abomination of desolation was by Antiochus Epiphanes in 167 B.C.* Jesus uses the phrase abomination of
desolation in these parallel passages, however, to refer to future desolation. One phase of this desolation was to be
immediate. Jesus had referred to this immediate phase of the desolation in Mt 23:38. And its immediacy was
*
    See Illustration 70. Temple Foreshortening, p. 158.
Page 308                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
indicated by Dan 9:26. This desolation happens after the death of the Messiah and before the 70th week. But the
second phase of this desolation, which is what Dan 9:27 explicitly refers to, happens in the middle of the 70th
week. This fulfillment is the one also referred to in Dan 12:11. The two earlier fulfillments in 167 B.C. and A.D.
70 foreshadow this final fulfillment. Wessel likewise concludes that the best solution “is to understand the
abomination that causes desolation as having a multiple fulfillment in (1) the Maccabean period, (2) the events of
A.D. 66-70, and (3) the end time.”569
        Most of the reasons for agreeing with these commentators on this particular point can be briefly summarized
by considering the parallel passages. Matthew, Mark, and Luke are presenting the same prophecy by Jesus, but
each one complements the accounts of the other two and highlights particular parts of that prophecy. Matthew and
Mark give basically the same account, and although Luke is giving the same pericope, his focus is different.
Cheney makes a reasonable suggestion that the material in Lk 21:20 was probably spoken first.570 In this section,
Jesus answers the when question, and starts off by saying, as Luke records, “But when you see Jerusalem
surrounded by armies, then recognize that her desolation is at hand.” In doing so, Jesus first describes the
desolation/destruction described by Dan 9:26. This refers to the first phase of the future fulfillment. In this first
sentence, Jesus talks about the desolation/destruction of the city. When will this first phase take place? The answer
is, “When you see the city surrounded by armies.” This took place in the events of A.D. 70.
        Next, Jesus proceeds to the second phase by warning, as Matthew and Mark record, “Therefore when you
see the abomination of desolation which was spoken of through Daniel the prophet, standing in the holy place
(let the reader understand), then let those who are in Judea flee.” In this second sentence, Jesus is talking about the
desolation of the temple itself rather than the city in general. This transition from city to temple corresponds to the
transition from Dan 9:26 to Dan 9:27. Dan 9:26 warns of the destruction of the city and temple. But Dan 9:27
refers exclusively to the temple and even more importantly to the abomination of desolation in the temple. In
Dan 9:26, the temple is destroyed. In Dan 9:27, the temple is not destroyed; rather, the antichrist takes his seat in
the temple and demands that he be worshipped there, as Paul indicates in 2Thess 2:4. The abomination of
desolation that Jesus refers to is, therefore, the same abomination of desolation that Daniel wrote about in 9:27 and
12:11. It refers to the eschatological desolation that takes place in the middle of the seven years of tribulation.
        Jesus continues to discuss the eschatological tribulation in this section in the parallels, referring to it as those
days and great tribulation. But He returns to the subject of the intermediate distress in Lk 21:23b-24a.571 In this
Lukan section in Lk 21:23b-24a, Jesus again returns to talking about the city (Jerusalem) instead of the temple. He
also describes the fate of the Jews as being led captive into all the nations. This is part of the intermediate
fulfillment, not the eschatological fulfillment. This part has been fulfilled. Then Jesus continues to discuss this
intermediate period by saying that Jerusalem would experience Gentile domination. This was certainly the case in
A.D. 70, but it will also be the case in the tribulation. Therefore, this part of the prophecy (in v. 24b) covers the
intermediate period and reaches into the eschatological period. Accordingly, this part of the prophecy brings us
back into the eschatological period where Jesus continues His discussion in Matthew and Mark. And Matthew, in
particular, stresses the fact in Mt 24:27 that the prophesies he is recording, even in this section, are eschatological
by explicitly associating this section with Jesus’ coming.

Parallel Options
        Consequently, the interpretation that would do justice to the integrity of the parallels is to say that when
Jesus spoke this section, He spoke all the material given in the three parallels. The result is that Jesus’ prophecy
covered both the intermediate and final phases of Daniel’s prophecy. However, the three gospel writers select
which part of the material they wish to include in accordance with the time frame upon which they wish to focus
the readers’ attention. Luke includes the material about the desolation of Jerusalem in Lk 21:20 because he wants
to focus our attention on the immediate fulfillment of Jesus’ words concerning the city. For this reason, he also
leaves out the reference to “the abomination of desolation which was spoken through Daniel,” since this Danielic
material deals with the temple and the ultimate fulfillment of Jesus’ words. It may very well be that Jesus spoke
all of the material recorded in Lk 21:20-24 concerning the city before He spoke the material recorded by Matthew
and Mark concerning the temple. Cheney gives this construction in his gospel parallels.572 It is the easiest
reconstruction, and the explicit references in Lk 21:21 to the city make it very tempting.
        On the other hand, the reconstruction advanced in Illustration 109 above is also possible. In either case,
Luke purposefully omits the material that has exclusive eschatological application and purposefully includes the
material that has exclusive intermediate application. Luke either recorded the intermediate material and left out the
eschatological material in this section—see Cheney’s construction—or Luke recorded the intermediate material
and only included eschatological material that had application to the intermediate period, as pictured in Illustration
109. In this latter case, Luke credited his readers with being able to understand the difference between
Chapter 10. When Will These Things Be?                                                                      Page 309
interpretation and application. In either case, Luke selected the material that was suitable to stressing the
intermediate fulfillment.
       The exact opposite is true of Matthew and Mark. They leave out the material that deals with the first phase
of Jesus’ prophecy. They focus the attention of their readers on the eschatological aspect of Jesus’ prophecy. Thus,
as we proceed to examine Matthew’s account of the Mt. Olivet discourse, it should be kept in mind that Matthew
has omitted prophecies concerning the intermediate period and has chosen to focus our attention exclusively on the
eschatological period of Daniel’s prophecy, that is, the 70th week, also known as the seven years of tribulation.
Matthew is quite justified in doing so since this is where Jesus focused His answer. And it is of no surprise that
Jesus focuses His answer on this period since this is where the disciples focus their question.

Multiple Destructions
       In the above discussion, the most cut-and-dried approach was taken, with a singular past destruction of the
temple amidst multiple desolations. Chitwood counters this popular dispensational opinion by relegating this
destruction of the temple to the future tribulation.573 In contrast, Constable takes the popular position described
above that the destruction in Lk 21:20-24 was limited in prophetic outlook to the past destruction in A.D. 70.574
But, like Chitwood, he believes that the destruction in Mt 24:2 must include the future temple: “The fulfillment
was not complete, however. Many of these huge stones still stand on one another today. What Jesus proceeded to
say about the destruction of the temple points farther ahead in history to the destruction of the Tribulation
temple.”575
       Understandably, at this point many readers will simply shrug their shoulders and assume prophetic
foreshortening concerning both the desecration and destruction of the temple, at least in the Olivet Discourse. The
problem posed by this simple solution, however, is that the distinction between these two events is one of the
arguments employed by dispensationalists in rejecting preterism. The temple of Olivet’s tribulation is desecrated
(24:15) rather than destroyed (23:38; 24:2). Therefore, dispensationalists argue that two different time periods must
be in view. I will briefly survey the options and accept the dispensational distinction. At the same time I will
acquiesce to Chitwood and Constable concerning the possibility that Mt 24:2 implicitly may include the
destruction of the future temple. But Chitwood’s location of this destruction in the middle of the tribulation does
not intuitively follow. The dispensational distinction still remains in that the Olivet discourse focuses on the
temple’s desecration rather than destruction during the tribulation. The destruction logically may be deduced as
subsequent to the desecration, not simultaneous with it.

                                                    Four Views of Time
       Bigalke follows Ice’s lead in breaking up the discussion of the potential time frames for the fulfillment of
the Olivet Discourse around the four logical possibilities.576 In regard to time, an event may either be temporally
past, present, future, or atemporally timeless. I already have mentioned these possibilities and indicated my
preference in my analysis of Revelation,* but a brief resumption of that discussion would be well advised as an
introduction to the Olivet Discourse. The passages of this discourse are crucial to understanding the time and
events of Jesus’ coming, since all four of the explicit Matthean references to the Parousia are found within this one
chapter (Mt 24:3,27,37,39).

Preterism
       Not surprisingly, the preterist typically begins his discussion of eschatology with the Olivet Discourse so
that he can link the events associated with Jesus’ return to the past destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70. After all,
preterism is derived from a Latin word that means that the event has gone by and is therefore in the past.
According to preterism, Jesus’ coming in judgment upon the Jews in destroying Jerusalem was a parousia not the
Parousia. It was national rather than universal. Most importantly, it is in the past.
       Sproul is a recent convert to moderate preterism. He rejects radical preterism (in which all prophecies are
regarded as fulfilled) but affirms partial preterism (in which many prophecies are regarded as fulfilled). In this
view, the prophecies of Jesus’ coming in the Olivet Discourse were fulfilled in A.D. 70, and most of the prophecies
of Revelation were also fulfilled in this time frame. After all, the discussion on Olivet and the tribulation of
Revelation cover the same time period, as Bigalke shows in a chart similar to the one below.577


*
    See Major Interpretive Approaches to the Book, 39.
Page 310                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                 Illustration 110. The Tribulation of Mt 24 and Rev 6

                                         Matthew                    Revelation
                                 False Christs     24:5        First Seal      6:2
                                 War               24:6        Second Seal     6:3–4
                                 Famine            24:7        Third Seal      6:5–6
                                 Death             24:6–7      Fourth Seal     6:7–8
                                 Martyrs           24:9–10     Fifth Seal      6:9–11
                                 Earthquake        24:15–20    Sixth Seal      6:12–17

        Of course, the preteristic view requires that the book of Revelation be written before A.D. 70, and thus
during Nero’s reign (A.D. 54-68), which in itself is a very questionable dating and makes preterism extremely
doubtful.* The tribulation described in Revelation is past from the preteristic perspective. According to some
amillennialists, the millennium—if there is ever one on earth—is to be found on earth before Jesus comes again. So
this view is adopted by either postmillennialists or (thoroughgoing) amillennialists (who believe that earth may go
on indefinitely).

Historicism
        Ice points out that a historicist may hold any of the three (pre/post/a) millennial views, but the preterist
cannot adopt the premillennial framework. If you are premillennialist, then preterism is not an option. By Ice’s
definition, “historicism is the view that basically the Church Age and the Tribulation are the same.”578
Correspondingly, if you are a pretribulationalist, then historicism is not an option. As a corollary, if you are a date-
setter, then you are a historicist. If you believe that it is possible to set a date for the time of the Lord’s return or
that the events of the present indicate the time of His return, then you are logically a historicist and cannot hold to
pretribulationalism with logical consistency. Stage-setting is permissible for the pretribulationalist, but date-setting
is not. In Mt 24:3, the disciples ask, “What will be the sign of Your coming and of the end of the age?” The
historicist could respond that the disciples are thinking about the age in which they live. For us living in the present
period, this would be the church age. Christians express this popular sentiment today in the looking for signs of the
times in current events such as earthquakes and wars to indicate the end of the church age in which they are living.
         In addition to denying a truly imminent rapture, other problems associated with this ecclesiastical view of
the age include making the passage devoid of any signs for Jewish believers living during the tribulation, creating
signs for their own age (i.e., the church age) in which there are no signs, and confusing the later days of the Jews
with that of the Christians by taking terminology as being equal even when spoken of different people. But we
should reject this assumption since a day is not necessarily equal to an age and the last days must be
distinguishable for different groups of people. Equality of terminology does not prove indistinguishability of
anthropology. We are dealing with the last days of different groups of people.

Idealism
        The idealist disassociates the discourse with historical fulfillment. After all, earthquakes and wars are
generalizations that do not easily lend themselves to specific historical fulfillment. Thus, the warnings are ageless
and apply to believers living in any age. The fulfillment is timeless; it is atemporal. It does not have temporal
fulfillment. Although this approach is to be commended for finding application to any view, it is void of any real
correlation with interpretation. It has little corresponding reality. In a historical-grammatical hermeneutic, we seek
to base our application on our interpretation. An application void of a solid interpretation is like shooting in the
dark. You cannot see your target, and the chances of hitting it are slim. This idealistic approach should be rejected
as a spiritualization that focuses on application and fails to have any real association with historic realization.

Futurism
       The top contenders in our current day and age for how to understand the time frame are preterism and
futurism. We already have surveyed preterism above. The crucial phrase for the preterist is this generation (genea)
in Mt 24:34 (cf. Mk 13:30; Lk 21:32). Older dispensational interpreters took this to mean that the Jewish race
would not be destroyed. Thomas, a more contemporary dispensationalist, tries to counter preterism by claiming
that Jesus is referring to a type of people: “‘This generation’ is a qualitative expression without chronological or

*
    See Date, 33.
Chapter 10. When Will These Things Be?                                                                         Page 311
                             579
temporal connotations.” Jesus will thus find the same kind of rebels when He returns in His second advent as He
was then encountering during His first advent. Preterists respond that this generation always literally refers to the
current generation in historic texts. Supposedly, this means we must either allegorize the phrase in Mt 24:34 or
literalize the generation by supplying a hermeneutical limitation so that it refers to the generation to which Jesus
spoke, that is, to the generation which crucified Jesus.
        Preterists are inconsistent in demanding a literal generation in 24:34 but a non-literal coming in the clouds in
24:30. As Ice counters, there is another option that allows the futurists to take both the generation and clouds
literally. All one must do is simply recognize that Mt 24:34 is a prophetic rather than a historic text. Consequently,
genea should be understood as referring to the generation living at the time when these things prophetically will
take place. That generation of Jews then living will see all these things take place within their generation. That
generation of Jews, and thus the Israel of that time period, will be rescued from their enemies. Olivet is describing
a rescue operation in this section—the salvation of the elect (24:13,22,31)—rather than the judgment of the elect
during the tribulation.
        As Bigalke demonstrates, this generation in 23:36 and 24:34 refers to two different generations in two
different time periods. Jesus had first predicted the A.D. 70 destruction of Jerusalem in Mt 22:7. The fact that the
Romans burned the city in A.D. 70, just as Jesus had foretold (as one of the so-called little details in His parable),
proves that the little details of Jesus’ parables cannot be ignored. These details are capable of significant, literal,
historical fulfillment. Further, parables are capable of expressing more than one central truth. This pronouncement
concerning the burning of the city is followed by a series of woes and parables concerning the imminent judgment
to fall upon the Jewish nation. The you in Mt 24:15 addresses this future generation, just as you in Dt 30:1-9
addresses a future generation.580 Although Bigalke is certainly correct that it is this future generation who will see
these signs rather than the past or present generation of believers, his limitation of this entire discourse to that
future generation does not necessarily follow. There are sections of this material that have direct application to
believers living in the church age because proper interpretation requires that some of the parables be understood as
being intended directly for church-age believers.

                                                    Conclusion
        The last, futuristic, Danielic week for the generation who will experience the climactic events surrounding
the antichrist is being set side-by-side with the imminent destruction of Jerusalem to be experienced by the
generation who crucified the Christ. Nevertheless, these two different time periods and generations should be
carefully distinguished. The imminent destruction of the temple is distinguishable from the Danielic desecration.
While it may be assumed that the desecration will be followed by destruction, it by no means necessarily follows
that antichrist will be the instrument of that destruction. Christ Himself may destroy the temple of the antichrist.
        To summarize the discussion of the four principal views of the time of fulfillment in terms of the chart in
Illustration 111. Four Possible Relationships to Time, the preteristic view is logically limited to amillennial and
postmillennial schools of thought and to a national fulfillment. The thematic verse for this perspective is Mt 24:34,
in which this generation is taken to be the same generation to which Jesus was speaking. This speculation is
problematic, however, in that it equates the historic generation with the prophetic one and deliteralizes
incompatible components of its theory without contextual justification.
        The historicist, in contrast, may hold a premillennial view. But he or she must still reject the pretribulational
understanding of the rapture since the historicist seeks signs in the present time period. The historical view takes an
ecclesiastical view of the age, assigning it to the present church age.
        The idealist regards the passage as being merely inspirational and void of any real historical fulfillment. The
ideal view shuns historical and millennial realization and therefore is rejected herein. It will not do to spiritualize
the desolation since we already have established that the preferable hermeneutical procedure is to understand all
stages of pattern fulfillment in the same manner in order to limit sensus plenior.*
        This leaves us with futurism as the sole hermeneutical contender for properly interpreting the details of the
passage. The dispensational outline (in which the events are both pretribulational and premillennial) naturally leads
one to suspect that some of the judgments will be pretribulational while others are premillennial. Although the
signs are tribulational, the judgments invoked by the ushering in of this time period may be directly applicable to
those living before the tribulation starts. Two separate judgments would thus be anticipated: the Bema judgment
for those living now, and the judgment of the Gentiles for those who live through the tribulation.

    See Prophetic Foreshortening, 157.
Page 312                                                           The Outer Darkness
           Illustration 111. Four Possible Relationships to Time
                                             Chapter 11.
                                  What Will Be The Sign? (Mt 24:1-35)
                                                          Introduction
        In this chapter, an exegetical investigation of the biblical context itself surrounding the primary passage on
the outer darkness is now ready to commence. Although reasons for adopting a futuristic approach to this passage
have been presented in the foregoing discussion, it should be noted that not all futurists would agree with the
assessment that two periods of judgment are in view. Bigalke, for example (a fellow futurist positively cited above
in connection with the four views of time) contends that only one judgment is in view, which is that depicted by the
sheep and goats. Thus, in the flowchart presented above, he would not have included the Bema in the conclusion.*
        It may, therefore, be taken for granted that some within our own futuristic camp will be skeptical of the
eschatological framework being proposing. Not only that, but some in our own soteriological camp will see the
matter differently. Bigalke, for example, objects to an outline of the Mt. Olivet Discourse that would require a
misthological understanding of the outer darkness. And even worse, he implicitly rejects the misthological
understanding of the outer darkness by equating all four judgments with that of the sheep and goats and regarding
those cast into the outer darkness as unregenerate Gentiles at the conclusion of the tribulation.
        Classifying fellow FG soteriologists who disagree with such fundamental misthological findings is difficult.
At the Chafer site, one finds a FG soteriologist who thinks the outer darkness is a soteriological issue. But the GES
website, in contrast, has a strong history in regarding the outer darkness as a misthological theme, due largely in
part to the writings of Zane Hodges, whose writings can be found at both locations. Moreover, Meisinger, president
of Chafer, conducted a workshop at GES in which he affirmed that the outer darkness in the Olivet Discourse is an
issue dealing with the negative reward of unfaithful believers.581
        Such differences in opinion among those in substantial harmony with the basic components of modern
expression of the FG movement could also be documented from printed sources, but these online resources are
readily available and illustrate the point. In order to have a base point for comparison, the supposition that FG
misthologists agree that the outer darkness is a misthological rather than soteriological issue will be taken as a
given. As noted, some FG soteriologists will find the outer darkness to be a soteriological theme. But it is very
difficult to perceive how they can be considered consistent misthologists (or even consistent FG soteriologists for
that matter) since they fail to differentiate between what would appear to be a clear distinction between a gift and a
reward. Since this demarcation is the hallmark of GRAPE, it will not be the tendency herein to regard those FG
advocates who manifest such fundamental inconsistencies as worthy of the misthological title or GRAPE acronym.
        I do not wish to be prejudicial or discriminatory in making such a comment. But just as other camps (such as
Arminianism and Calvinism) have writers who are more consistent than others in representing the viewpoints
adhered to by that camp, so in the FG camp there are those who waver considerably in terms of their consistency.
Such writers may indeed be generally regarded as FG in their soteriological viewpoint, but I would prefer not to
classify them as Marrowists for reasons to be presented in my discussion on the outer darkness. Perhaps writers
adhering to the blanket principles of Marrowism might be regarded as Marrowists broadly speaking.†
         As I hope to demonstrate to my fellow FG soteriologists, a misthological understanding of the outer
darkness serves as a suitable starting point for contemporary Marrowism. Those in FG who see the matter
differently will hopefully find another method by which to describe themselves adequately. Perhaps they will just
define themselves as FG generically. But for my purposes, I intend for Marrowism and its corresponding GRAPE
acronym to be most fully and consistently used as designations for those in FG who can specifically acknowledge
that the outer darkness is a misthological concept. Even so, I would allow that FG soteriologists who at least
acknowledge that one of the three outer darkness passages is truly misthological legitimately qualify as FG
misthologists and are entitled to the Marrowistic title and GRAPE acronym.‡
        Even this specification will by no means limit all the misthological possibilities within Marrowism, of
course. Bridal misthologists and Gehenna misthologists may face off against one another or even stand shoulder to

*
  See Illustration 111. Four Possible Relationships to Time, 312.
†
  Unfortunately, some allowance must be made to allow Marrowism to be used in both the general capacities since within the course
of this study interaction will be necessary with interpreters who generally would be considered FG misthologist in that they affirm that
the outer darkness is a misthological issue, and yet they will also hold to some soft form of conditional security. Inconsistencies
abound in all camps. Nevertheless, when Marrowism is defined narrowly and implemented consistently, inconsistencies will find little
fertile soil in which to propagate.
‡
  See Modern Interpreters, 453.
Page 314                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
shoulder against those who do not see these items as misthological concepts. Regardless, such interpreters are
herein regarded as Marrowists. Nevertheless, the practical advantage of using the outer darkness as the cardinal
misthological reference point is that this will allow me to classify Marrowists as conservative, moderate, ultraistic,
neo-ultraistic, or neoclassical based on their views of the outer darkness, the kingdom, and Gehenna.
        Granted, the Marrowistic title broadly may be applied to those such as Vance, Hunt, Hutson, and Bryson
who have only distinguished themselves as non-Calvinists by rejecting all five points of the TULIP. Due to their
rejecting TULIP and PEARS, I contingently offer them, and those like them, the GRAPE acronym until such time
as they may reject this association or prove unworthy of it. On a hermeneutical battleground, one needs to be able
to distinguish between friend and foe. Even then, the danger of still being caught in friendly fire is real. To
minimize causalities in terms of misunderstanding from friendly fire (or perhaps not so friendly in some cases), I
offer this clarification.
        Thus, someone like Bigalke legitimately might be considered FG but not GRAPE, at least not in the narrow,
technical sense. Even FG soteriologists like Paul Benware and Philip Evans, who have written very commendable
books dealing with soteriology, misthology, and eschatology, would not be considered Marrowists in the narrow
sense because they reject the outer darkness interpretation in all three passages. Certainly, regarding general
soteriological themes or elementary matters pertaining to rewards, I would interact with them on friendly terms.
But when it comes to matters more closely integrated with a misthological understanding of the outer darkness, by
the sheer nature of the case, dealing with them as misthological foes will be necessary.
        In order to advance GRAPE theology on the hermeneutical front, one must always be vigilant in
distinguishing a gift from a reward. In doing so, this present chapter will examine the futuristic signs of salvation
during the tribulation and use this occasion to show that a reward is not a gift, as we consider the meaning of
salvation in context. As already noted, the nature of salvation in Mt 24:13 is pivotal. Anderson has traced the birth
of Calvinism back to Augustine’s renovation of this verse and the Augustinian implementation of this permutation
as a hermeneutical skeleton key.*
        As a result of Augustine’s typological conversion to a figurative rather than physical millennium, he came to
regard the salvation in this verse as portraying spiritual (rather than physical) deliverance. This led him to conclude
that only the elect would be given the gift of perseverance and consequently be saved. Practical sanctification
proved election and became an indispensable condition for final salvation. Proveitism was born.† A spiritual
millennium required a corresponding spiritual salvation. This reward of physical salvation became synonymous
with the gift of spiritual salvation, resulting in the synergistic soteriology known today as Calvinism. By confusing
a reward with a gift, Augustine was able to bring forth Calvinism amidst its typological embryonic fluid. By calling
their synergistic salvation a gift, Calvinists seek to masquerade as monergists and call the legitimate monergistic
heirs synergists. The true soteriological synergists in this debate will not be Marrowists, since they can
theologically and exegetically tell the difference between a gift and a reward.

                                               The Questions (Mt 24:1-3)
        In analyzing the when question in the previous chapter, preliminary indications have been observed that
Jesus is dealing with the seven years of the tribulation. Now, the second part of the question needs to be examined
as to the signs associated with this period.

The Jewish Section (Mt 24:1-35)

        will these things be, and what will be the sign of Your coming, and of the end of the age?”

†
  Proveitism today asserts that fruit in the form of perseverance is necessary proof of regeneration: If you do not have this fruit, then
you were never regenerate. Originally, however, in its Augustinian form, it would have to be regarded differently, so as to mean: If
you do not have the fruit of perseverance, then you were never elect. Augustine, the original proveitist, allowed the loss of
regeneration. Perseverance requires election, not mere regeneration, as even the nonelect regenerate could produce the fruit associated
with regeneration.

*
  Vv. 15-28 = a more detailed account of the second half of the tribulation, which is described in a less detailed summation in vv.9-14
