Page 316                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                        Illustration 112. Outline of Mt 24:4-31

              First Half                              Second Half                               End
           Beginning (24:4-8)                        Then (24:9-12)                       After (24:13-14)
                                                     When (24:15-28)                      Gather (24:29-31)

Then
       Concerning Mt 24:9, it should be noticed that Jesus says, “Then (tote) they will deliver you to tribulation,
and will kill you, and you will be hated by all nations on account of My name.” In other words, Mt 24:4-8 occurs,
and the next section occurs then, next, afterwards. The then in v. 9 signifies next. As such, the natural assumption
would be that the next time period is in view. This assumption is reinforced by the 18 times this Greek word for
then is used in Mt 24-25. Mt 24:8-9 may be read as, “All these things are merely the beginning of birth pangs.
Next, in this time period, they will deliver you to tribulation.” This word then occurs in v. 14 with the same
meaning. Thus, the later part of v. 14 could be read as, “Next, in this time period, the end will come.” The end will
follow this second phase of the tribulation. So in Mt 24:4-14, we have the beginning of the tribulation, then the
tribulation, and then the end of the tribulation. These temporal markers provide natural hermeneutical landmarks
dividing up the eschatological terrain into the designations shown above: first half, second half, and end.

When
        In contrast, Mt 24:15 does not start off by saying, then (tote); instead it says, when (hotan). It introduces
another section that also has a sequence of events. We understand from the passage in Daniel 9, to which Mt 24:15
refers, that the desolation refers back to the breaking of the peace treaty and the setting up of the abomination in the
temple, which marks the beginning of the second half of the tribulation. Therefore, Mt 24:15ff is referring to events
in the second half of the tribulation.

End
        Mt 24:29 brings us to the end of that tribulation and thus to the end of the sequence of events that Jesus gave
starting with 24:15. Therefore, Mt 24:15-28 covers the second half of the tribulation. In light of these observations,
it is easy to understand how the end of the tribulation comes in 24:14 and then much later in 24:29. The simple
reason is because 24:15-28 refers to the same time period as 24:9-14. After outlining the tribulation in 24:4-14,
Jesus simply goes back and fills in some of the details in 24:15-28 concerning the second half of the tribulation that
He briefly had outlined in 24:9-14. In outlining the second half of the tribulation in 24:9-14, Jesus merely refers to
the second half of this period as tribulation (see v. 9). But in light of the additional details He provides in the
passage (24:15-28), what He is referring to is what He subsequently refers to as the great tribulation (24:21). The
beginning of the tribulation in Mt 24:4-8 is called birth pangs in comparison to the next phase of the tribulation to
which it will give birth in Mt 24:9-28. The general tribulation of the first half of this period gives birth to the great
tribulation of the second half of this period.

                                           The Answer (Mt 24:4-31)

The First Half of the Tribulation (Mt 24:4-8)
       Plurals are used concerning the first half of the tribulation described in 24:4-8. There are (1) Christs (and
with them apostasy), (2) wars (of one nation against another), and (3) famines.

 The Second Half of the Tribulation (Mt 24:9-28)
       Who is the you in v. 15? The answer to this question may be found by asking, “To whom is Jesus talking?”
To Jews. At this time, the treaty of the antichrist will be broken with the Jews. The passage moves from wars
(plural) of one nation against another nation in v. 7 to all nations against one singular nation in v. 9. The second
phase of the tribulation begins in v. 9 when all the nations focus their hatred against one nation—against one
people—the Jews. These nations will wage war against the Jewish people. Likewise, the warning in v. 16 is
directed to people living in Judea, thus to Jews. Further proof (that this passage is talking about what happens to
Jews) is found in other references in the passage: the holy place, thus the Jewish temple in Jerusalem is the focus of
attention (v. 15), the Sabbath (v. 20), false Christs (i.e., false Messiahs), and prophets (v. 24). The passage is
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                           Page 317

talking about Jewish believers during the time of the tribulation, not about Christian believers during the time of
the church. What difference would it make to a Christian if these events happened on a Sabbath (i.e., Saturday)?
None. The warning in v. 20 is pointless to Christians, but it would make a tremendous difference to Jews. The
passage is talking about Jews, not about Christians.

 The End of the Tribulation (Mt 24:29-31)
        The beginning of this next section in vv. 29-31 is marked off by the word after in v. 29. It deals with the
events that occur at the end of the tribulation. The most notable event is the gathering of the elect. As the Lord’s
coming for the elect at the end of the church age resulted in the translation of those living and the resurrection of
those who had died, it is probable that His coming at the end of the tribulation will likewise involve the
resurrection of those who had died during the tribulation and the translation of those believers who are then living.
This assumption presents a problem, however. If it is correct, then the question immediately arises as to who will
be left to populate the millennial kingdom. The typical dispensational answer to this question is that the elect who
endure to the end of the tribulation will be saved in the sense of having their physical lives spared and be able to
enter the millennial kingdom in their physical bodies (see v. 14). These faithful tribulational believers thus will be
granted the eschatological reward of entering the millennial kingdom in their physical bodies. In the jettisoning of
this approach, Augustine changed this salvation from a physical reward into a soteriological gift that was earned by
enduring. And now today, as a result, a host of interpreters cannot recognize that a supposedly earned gift is really
a reward, not a gift. This is not to say that there is no problem with the typical dispensational solution. The problem
with this traditional dispensational line of reasoning has been pointed out already and dealt with.* However, the
Augustinian cure is worse than the dispensational disease.
        Actually, there are two problems with this dispensational solution. The first problem is very minor.
Dispensationalists propose that there is no translation that takes place when the elect are gathered. This, indeed,
may be the case. But after the elect are gathered, according to the parable of the sheep and goats that concludes this
discourse, the elect are judged. This presents the second problem (a major one), already discussed.
        The elect, who have been faithful, are rewarded with the inheritance of the kingdom (see 25:34). But Paul
explicitly states in 1Cor 15:50 that “flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom.” This fact makes it necessary for
us to receive our imperishable bodies in 1Cor 15:50ff. Since “flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom,” and
since the faithful elect will inherit the kingdom, the faithful elect do not enter the kingdom in their flesh and blood
bodies. Rather, they enter the millennial kingdom in their glorified bodies so that they can inherit that kingdom.
Their glorified bodies will be necessary for them to fulfill their ruling function in the kingdom. Since the faithful
elect (who endure to the end) will not enter the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies, they cannot populate the
kingdom. They will not be involved in procreation during the millennium.
        The solution proposed by Dillow is that the children of the faithful elect will enter the millennial kingdom in
their physical bodies and be able to procreate.582 This modification of the typical dispensational proposal is
plausible. Dillow, though, advances even beyond this modified dispensational response and allows, correctly, that
the parable of the Ten Virgins in this discourse (Mt 25:1-13) demonstrates that some of the elect (who live until the
end of the tribulation) will be unfaithful. Given this acknowledgment by Dillow, it would seem more reasonable to
propose that the unfaithful elect (who live until the end of the tribulation) will be gathered just like the faithful
elect. However, the unfaithful elect will merely enter the kingdom, rather than inherit it. It is one thing to inhabit
the kingdom and quite another to inherit it. Since these unfaithful elect do not inherit the kingdom, it is not
necessary for them to receive their glorified bodies at the beginning of the millennium. Therefore, instead of
receiving their glorified bodies at the beginning of the millennium, they may enter the kingdom in their flesh and
blood bodies and procreate. They and their children are not rulers in the kingdom but subjects of the kingdom.
Thus, they repopulate the kingdom and planet.
        In any event, Dillow’s solution and the solution proposed herein are both compatible with the discourse and
allow us to proceed from a Marrowistic dispensational perspective. But the typical dispensational explanation of
Mt 24:13 will not work. The elect (who faithfully endure until the end of the tribulation) will not merely enter the
kingdom. According to Mt 25:34, they will also inherit the kingdom, which means their flesh and blood bodies will
be transformed into glorified bodies (1Cor 15:50) at the very inception of the millennial kingdom.




*
    See Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom, 60.
Page 318                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
                            The Summary of the Tribulation (Mt 24:32-35)

Judge
        Jesus concludes this section with the parable of the fig tree. The Jews living in this period are to look for
something rather than someone. Rather than look for the coming of the Lord, they are to look for fig leaves that
represent all these signs that Jesus has just described. The Lord will not be at the door ready to come until all these
events take place. Contrast this with Jam 5:9, which was written to Christians living in the church age. James uses
the same imagery to illustrate the fact that in this current time period, the Judge is at the door ready to come at any
moment. In contradistinction, Jesus uses this fig-tree-related imagery to illustrate that the Judge will not be ready to
come and will not be at the door until all these things take place. Jesus and James are using the same imagery to
illustrate two different comings of the same Judge. There is one Judge but two different time periods, so His
coming is at two different times. The phase of His coming that Jesus is referring to is His revelation at the end of
the tribulation—the second phase (and thus the continuation) of His coming. James is referring to the first phase of
His coming at the end of the church age—the rapture.

Knowing and Recognizing the Signs of the Times
       Jesus makes it very clear in the conclusion of this section that the time of His coming will be known,
recognized, and indicated by the signs that are seen. In Mt 24:32, in response to the question when, Jesus says that
you are expected to “know” when He will return on the basis of the signs you will see. In Mt 24:33, in response to
the question when, Jesus says that you are expected to “recognize” when He will return on the basis of the signs
you will see. Jesus expects you to be able to know and recognize when He will return if you are living in the time
period in which these signs occur. He does not expect the time of His return to be unknown, if you are living in that
period of time. The time of His coming will be well announced by the signs.

General versus Great Tribulation
        In the first half of the tribulation (Mt 24:4-8), the antichrist will sign the peace treaty with the Jewish nation,
and thus the antichrist will be revealed. It will be a time of general tribulation, false Christs, apostasy, famines,
earthquakes, and wars. This tribulation is intensified in the second half (in Mt 24:9-28) when the peace treaty is
broken and the antichrist is worshipped. It is a time of great tribulation, antichrists, and apostasy. The wars are
now replaced with a war directed at the nation of Israel. But according to Mt 24:14, the gospel of the kingdom
must be preached before the end comes. Accordingly, the preaching of the gospel of the kingdom will also mark
the second half of the tribulation. Then come the signs concerning the end in Mt 24:29-31: the darkening of the
sun, the falling of the stars, the shaking of the heavens, the coming of the Son, the mourning of the earth, the
slaying of the antichrist, and the gathering of the elect. The signs concerning the end are followed by the fig tree
summary in Mt 24:32-35.
        The Lukan parallel to this summary in Mt 24:32-35 is Lk 21:28-32. According to Lk 21:28, those living in
this time period are not instructed to lift up their heads and look for their coming redemption until they first see
these things begin to take place. Even more conclusively, Lk 21:31 states that these things (i.e., the fig leaves)
indicate the approach of the kingdom, not the tribulation. This coming marks the end of the tribulation and the
beginning of the millennial kingdom. Of course, this is additional evidence that the millennium comes after the
tribulation.

Gospel of Kingdom
       On the basis of Mt 24:14, some people think that before the Lord comes again in the rapture, the gospel
must be preached in every nation. This is a mistaken perspective. True, we should preach the gospel in every nation
according to Mt 28:19. But Jesus is not telling us in Mt 24:14 that there is no use to look for His coming until we
preach the gospel in every nation. The time period in 24:14 is the tribulation. Jesus is saying that the Jewish
evangelists will preach the gospel of the kingdom throughout the nations during the tribulation before the kingdom
comes. These Jewish evangelists will be scattered throughout the nations and thus be well suited to this task.
       How does the gospel of the kingdom differ from the gospel we now preach, called the gospel of grace
(Acts 20:24)? In response it may be asked, “What do you have to do to be saved according to the gospel of grace?”
Believe (Acts 16 31; Eph 2:8-9). But if it is asked, “What do you have to do to be saved according to the gospel of
the kingdom in this passage?” the answer is that you must endure (Mt 24:13). In reference to eternal damnation,
there is only one requirement for salvation—having your name in the Book of Life by having eternal life which
you get when you believe. In reference to the kingdom, there are two requirements for salvation—entering the
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                          Page 319

kingdom by believing (Jn 3:5) and inheriting the kingdom by enduring (Mt 24:13). Endurance will be a
requirement for those Jewish believers and their converts in the future period to inherit the kingdom (cf. Mt 25:34).
       The connection between Mt 24:13-14 is very close. He who endures will be saved. This is the gospel of the
kingdom. The this of v. 14 refers back to the statement in v. 13 and the salvation promised there. This gospel of the
kingdom is the gospel of salvation for those who endure to the end of the tribulation.* It will be preached
throughout the whole world during the tribulation. This elementary distinction could have saved believers from so
much eschatological and soteriological error had Augustine recognized it. Not only is amillennialism unnecessary,
idealism is also. We do not need to abuse the interpretation in order to derive reasonable application.

Application
       Certainly, we should make applications of biblical texts whether they deal with the past or the future. For
example, Paul tells us that the things recorded in the OT which happened in the past “happened as examples for us”
in the present (1Cor 10:6). But the Bible is not only a history book; it also tells us about the future. And we could
also say that the things recorded in the Bible which are to happen in the future are also recorded as examples for us
who live in the present. Thus, although Mt 24:13 is concerning the future, it has application to us now.
       Although Jesus’ words in this text are for the elect in the next time period, these exhortations still have
tremendous application and meaning for the elect today. There are believers today going through difficult times
and just wishing that somewhere they could find a word of encouragement that would really mean something and
help them get through it—something more than just a pat on the back with someone saying, “Grin and bear it.”
When things are really tough, persecuted believers might feel like snapping back in response to someone who tells
them to just grin and bear it by exclaiming, “Why should I!” In this study, we will be looking at future, fellow
believers who will go through difficulties that will probably far exceed anything that most of us have to go through
today. To them Jesus gives only one word of encouragement in this entire passage of Mt 24:4-35, and that
encouragement is in Mt 24:13. If you were asked to go through hell on earth and were given only one word of
encouragement from the Lord in this entire passage to help you get through it, you would be thinking, “Make that
word count!” Jesus does, and His words apply to us in the present as well. Jesus promises us salvation if we
endure. Yet to really experience the full encouragement of the promise, we need to know exactly what He means
by salvation.

                                                     Salvation (Mt 24:13)

Types
       Salvation can be divided into two basic categories: physical and spiritual. We see this same division in
Matthew and the rest of the NT. Physical salvation can be further divided into subcategories. It can refer to
salvation from disease for health, from death for life, from danger for safety, or from demons for self-control. It
would be ridiculous to read all references to physical salvation as references to deliverance from demons. It would
be just as ridiculous to read all references to spiritual salvation as dealing with deliverance from hell. Spiritual
salvation is multi-dimensional and can refer to salvation from the penalty of sin for heaven (justification), from the
power of sin for the abundant life (sanctification), or from the sorrow of a wasted life for the joy of rulership in
heaven (co-glorification). Salvation is thus both negative and positive, from something negative for something
positive.
       The following chart and comments are based on the Greek verb and noun for salvation: sozo and soteria
respectively. When a NT writer uses sozo or soteria, he expects his readership to be sensitive to the different types
of salvation that might be intended. He anticipates that they will be able contextually to distinguish between
physical and spiritual salvation. The NT writers further take it for granted that their readership are able to
differentiate as to what aspect of each of these types of salvation they have in mind—at least this is the case where
the writer contextually indicates this degree of specificity. To be sure, the level of specificity will vary with the
context. In an attempt to acknowledge this variability, a “” is used to denote the primary meaning, and an “*” is
used to represent secondary meaning.




*
    See Illustration 272. The Gospel of the Kingdom, 764.

Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                                   Page 321

       Salvation is popularly understood as encompassing justification, sanctification, and glorification. Also,
frequently it is described among theologians as salvation from the penalty, power, and presence of sin in terms of
its past, present, and future ramifications. Therefore, Radmacher’s terminology (of justification salvation,
sanctification salvation, and glorification salvation) is simply another way of expressing a commonly held view of
salvation. These popular designations are theologically useful, but they must not be used so rigidly as to interfere
with proper understanding of the linguistic data. For example, it is well known that sanctification can be used in
certain contexts to refer to any three of these concepts. Thus, sanctification is sometimes broken down into three
similar categories: positional, practical, and perfect sanctification. For that matter, justification can also refer to our
unmerited justification before God that already has been granted, or to merited justification before men in the
present, or to merited justification before God in the future. Consequently, justification can likewise be broken
down into corresponding subcategories.
                           Illustration 114. Types of Salvation, Sanctification, and Justification




                            justification                                             penalty




                            salvation                                                salvation



        sanctification                        glorification           power                            presence




                         positional                                                 positional




                         sanctification                                             justification




        practical                           perfect                 experiential                     misthological




        When studying what the words sanctification or justification mean in any particular context, one must not
limit the meaning of that word to a popular, preconceived notion based on a popular theological term that was
intended to serve as a rule of thumb rather than an absolute regulation. For example, all references to sanctification
in the NT do not refer to what is popularly known as practical sanctification. The theological term sanctification
salvation is not intended to indicate that the word sanctification is always distinguishable in the NT from
justification or glorification. An overlapping of meaning occurs in certain cases. However, broadly speaking, it
may be said that sanctification frequently refers to a believer’s practice and thus to the believer’s present
experience of victory over the power of sin. Justification, in contrast, more frequently refers to our position
independent of our practice. Therefore, although the terms may not be absolutely distinguished in all cases
Page 322                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
regardless of context, they can nevertheless frequently be distinguished. Correspondingly, as long as the distinction
between linguistic meaning and theological categories is kept in mind, such terminology is indeed quite useful.

Glorification Salvation versus Co-Glorification Salvation
        For this reason co-glorification has been used in this present book as an umbrella term for references to
misthological salvation. This is a useful designation since the NT teaches that there will be degrees of glory in
heaven, and glory can properly be considered a reward. As for simple glorification salvation, it has been noted that
there are passages that teach that all believers will receive unmerited soteriological glory in heaven. Hence, it is
theologically permissible to speak of a glorification salvation that all believers will receive as God’s children, in
contrast to co-glorification salvation which will be rewarded only to faithful believers as God’s mature, obedient
sons and daughters.583 The term glorification salvation is thus used theologically in Illustration 114 as a parallel to
the unmerited salvation from the presence of sin when all believers receive glorified bodies. But the chart in
Illustration 113 does not have a separate category for glorification salvation versus co-glorification salvation in
order to represent the linguistic meaning of the word salvation within these theological categories. Linguistically
speaking, when the word salvation (sozo/soteria) is used with the word glory (doxa/doxazo), there are no passages
in the NT where the glory in view is simple, unmerited glory. The passages where glory is used in reference to
salvation refer to merited glory (2Thess 2:13-14; 2Tim 2:10; Heb 2:10; 1Pet 1:5-7; 1:8-11). In terms of
terminology, the linguistical combination of glory and salvation always is associated with merit in the NT. Strictly
speaking, this NT combination always refers to merited glorification salvation and is thus designated as co-
glorification salvation.
        Perhaps Rev 7:10 or 19:1 could be posed as possible examples of unmerited glorification salvation. But are
we actually willing to say that God does not deserve this glory and salvation? Would we not rather conclude that
He deserves glory and salvation, both by virtue of who He is and what He has done? In any case, these verses are
not an example of a believer’s unmerited glorification salvation. The question remains, “Are there any linguistic
examples anywhere in the NT of a believer’s unmerited glorification salvation, and if not, why is it commonly
assumed that this is what is meant by the term salvation?”
        One may respond that Rom 8:24 is an example of the word salvation being contextually associated with
unmerited glory, and it is possible that this verse might possibly provide a linguistic basis for the term glorification
salvation. On the other hand, although the tense of this salvation is apparently past, the scope and emphasis of this
salvation in the context is future.
       17
         And if children, then heirs also: on the one hand, heirs of God, but on the other hand, co-heirs
       with Christ, if indeed we co-suffer with Him in order that we may also be co-glorified with Him. 18
       For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory
       that is to be revealed to us. 19 For the anxious longing of the creation waits eagerly for the revealing
       of the sons of God. 20 For the creation was subjected to futility, not of its own will, but because of
       Him who subjected it, in hope 21 that the creation itself also will be set free from its slavery to
       corruption into the freedom of the glory of the children of God. 22 For we know that the whole
       creation groans and suffers the pains of childbirth together until now. 23 And not only this, but also we
       ourselves, having the first fruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, waiting
       eagerly for our adoption as sons, the redemption of our body. 24 For by this hope we have been
       saved, but hope that is seen is not hope; for why does one also hope for what he sees? 25 But if we
       hope for what we do not see, then with perseverance we eagerly wait for it. (Rom 8:17-25; TM)

       Here is a potential case of unmerited futuristic glory that is the consummation of our salvation. One might
also assume that it includes the idea of being set free from the presence of sin in our corrupt bodies. Hence, it
conceivably might provide a linguistic basis for the simple term glorification salvation. However, in this context it
is not limited to glorification salvation, nor, for that matter, is simple glorification the emphasis. The distinction
between sons of God and children of God is maintained throughout Rom 8, and this includes Rom 8:19, 8:21, and
8:23. The sons will have co-glory with Christ and rule over creation. As we long to be under Christ’s rulership, so
Paul pictures creation’s desire to be under that of His co-rulers. Creation will share the glory of the children in
being set free from the presence of sin. The children share the glory of the new creation. The sons, in contrast,
share the glory of Christ. The latter includes but exceeds the former. The misthological sonship of 8:19 is a subset
of the soteriological status as children in 8:21. The misthological glory of 8:18 is a corresponding subset of the
soteriological glory of 8:21. In describing the glory of the children and the co-glory of the sons, Paul seeks to
motivate us to set our minds on aspiring to the hope of co-glorification. This hope not only includes the hope of the
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                            Page 323

redemption of our bodies from the presence of sin but also exceeds that simple hope to grasp the expectation of
ruling creation and thus to misthological hope.
        Considering that Paul limits his definition of sons in this context to those believers who are led by the Spirit
(8:14) and indicates that these are believers who are putting to death the flesh so that they are experiencing the life-
giving power of the Spirit in their mortal bodies (8:12-13), we are to understand the sons of God in this passage as
being Spirit-led believers who are filled by the Spirit’s energizing power. Therefore, when Paul refers to our spirit
of adoption as sons, he is either (1) referring exclusively to these Spirit-filled believers or (2) he is describing the
potential realization of adoption as sons that lies before all believers if they meet the condition of following the
Spirit’s leading. Regardless, the Spirit is not only currently bearing witness with our spirit that we are children
(8:16) but is also invoking our spirit to cry out in eager, but hopeful, anticipation of this misthological realization.
Nevertheless, the former is probably intended in view of 8:23. The first fruits of the Spirit would not allude to the
experience of defeat on the part of those believers who are failing to appropriate the Spirit’s power but instead to
the resurrected power being experienced by those who are following the Spirit’s leading. These Spirit-filled
believers who are experiencing the fruit of Spirit would be the only ones qualified to the co-inheritance as sons
(8:17b; Gal 5:21-23), and they would be expected eagerly to await the realization of their misthological hope in
8:23.
        The goal and hope of our salvation is co-glorification. But co-glorification requires perseverance; simple
glorification does not. Later, in this same epistle, Paul says that it is “through perseverance and the
encouragement of the Scriptures we might have hope” (Rom 15:4). Here is hope that believers obtain through
perseverance. This hope is based on their performance. Earlier in this epistle he had said, “We exult in hope of the
glory of God. And not only this, but we also exult in our tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces
perseverance; and perseverance, proven character; and proven character, hope” (Rom 5:2-3; TM). Here, as in
Rom 8:25, we have a hope-inspired perseverance. This hope is produced by our perseverance. This confident
expectation of being rewarded with glory from God is a product of our endurance. The salvation in Rom 8:24 is
equated with a hope that is misthological in nature.* Just as hope produces perseverance and perseverance in turn
produces hope, so our hope of being rewarded for persevering inspires us to persevere, and our perseverance in
turn gives us the legitimate basis by which to hope that we will be rewarded.
        Yet just as our perseverance can produce misthological hope, so the testing of our faith can produce
perseverance that results in a misthological crown. The words translated produces perseverance (katergazomai and
hupomone) in Rom 5:4 are also used by James in a parallel passage:
          2
            Consider it all joy, my brethren, when you encounter various trials, 3knowing that the testing of
          your faith produces perseverance. 4 And let perseverance have its perfect result, that you may be
          perfect and complete, lacking in nothing….12 Blessed is a man who perseveres under trial; for once
          he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life, which the Lord has promised to those who
          love Him (Jam 1:1-2,12 TM).

Jesus also teaches us to rejoice when we have to endure such trials:
          11
            Blessed are you when men cast insults at you, and persecute you, and say all kinds of evil against
          you falsely, on account of Me. 12 Rejoice, and be glad, for your reward [misthos] in heaven is great,
          for so they persecuted the prophets who were before you (Mt 5:11-12).

       The Bible does not exhort us to be masochists (i.e., to enjoy suffering or find it pleasurable), but it does
expect us to be misthologists (i.e., to rejoice when suffering because we keep our eyes firmly set on the hope of the
future joy and pleasure we may attain as a reward, as denoted by the word misthos). This hope, if subjective, is a
joyful anticipation of being rewarded with the crown of life and being co-glorified with Christ. If objective, the
hope is the reward itself. It was for the joy set before Him that Jesus endured His cross (Heb 12:2). We likewise are
to take up our cross and follow Him in enduring persecution for the joy objectively set before us.
       The hope Paul refers to in Rom 8:24 is not simply the hope of reaching glory but of obtaining co-glory.
Although this verse might include glorification salvation, its emphasis is on co-glorification salvation. Since there
are at least five references to merited co-glorification salvation, and since even Rom 8:24 is probably another
reference to misthological co-glory, it may be concluded that whenever the Scripture speaks of the believer’s glory

*
    See Misthological Hope, 92.
Page 324                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
and salvation in conjunction with one another, misthological co-glory and misthological salvation are in view. We
are saved by hope because misthological hope inspires us to persevere and thereby have hope of reward.*
        Since the Bible teaches that all believers will be delivered from the presence of sin (cf. Rom 11:26) and
since there are aspects of glory and salvation that are unmerited, it is permissible to speak of glorification
salvation. However, there is no separate category on the chart† in Illustration 113 for glorification salvation
because there is no case in the NT where glorification salvation is exclusively, primarily, or even necessarily in
view. It is unfortunate that such a weakly attested NT usage is the one associated with the popular designation
glorification salvation, as if that is the only kind of glorification salvation taught in the Bible. Quite the contrary,
this simplistic futuristic salvation in terms of unmerited glory is so weakly attested that it needs no independent
category on the chart. There are no cases in the Greek NT where glory (doxa/doxazo) is used in conjunction with
the word salvation (sozo/soteria) to refer exclusively, primarily, or even necessarily to the believer’s unmerited
future experience. There are at least six cases, however, where it refers primarily or even exclusively to the
believer’s merited future experience.
                                             Illustration 115. Four Types of Salvation


       Penalty                             Power                          Presence                              Piracy
        Past                              Present                            Future                             Future




            zFaith                     £Faith + £Works                           zFaith                     £Faith + £Works

         Justification                    Sanctification                     Glorification                    Co-Glorification
          Salvation                         Salvation                         Salvation                          Salvation


       Although the present study finds no linguistic examples of glorification salvation in the NT, theologically
this category is still useful and may be expressed in association with the exegetical categories thus far considered.
(1) Salvation from the penalty of sin is a biblical concept that would be called justification salvation and is
represented by the judge’s judicial gravel. This soteric salvation is conditioned on punctiliar faith. (2) Salvation
from the power of sin is a biblical concept that would be called sanctification salvation and is represented by the
conflict we experience with the sin that resides in our flesh. This experiential victory is conditioned on our linear
postconversional faith and works. (3) Salvation from the presence of sin is a theological construct‡ that we call
glorification salvation when sin is removed from our flesh. This eschatological salvation is conditioned on same
punctiliar faith that we experienced when we first believed and is thus soteriological and unconditional for one who
has experienced saving faith. (4) Salvation from the piracy of sin (so that sin does not rob us of our potential
rewards) is a biblical concept that would be called co-glorification salvation. This mistholic salvation is
*
  See Rom 8:24 in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
†
  See Illustration 113. Primary and Secondary References to Matthean Salvation, 320.
‡
  Since sozo/soteria are not actually used in this reference to salvation from the presence of sin, the affirmation that this category is a
biblical concept must be obtained indirectly through theological deduction rather than directly through exegetical usage. Hence, in
contradistinction to the other three directly attested forms, this form of salvation is called a theological construct.
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                              Page 325

conditioned on our linear postconversional faith and works in which we must persevere during our sojourn on earth
in order to attain the promised rewards.
        I am indebted to my brother, Philip Cauley, for the heading of piracy for the last category. A word of
clarification is probably in order though. Sin steals; faithful servants do not. The faithful servant in Lk 19:24 does
not steal the mina from the unfaithful servant. Yet the unfaithful servant has his mina taken away from him and
given to the faithful servant. Because of his sin (i.e., his unfaithfulness), the unfaithful servant’s opportunity so
serve eschatologically was taken away from him and given to another. Sin, we might say, stole this opportunity
from him. Thus, when Jesus warns that we should be faithful so that no one should take/receive (lambano) our
crown in Rev 3:11, He need not be understood as saying that someone is going to steal your crown if you are
unfaithful. Rather, you will have allowed sin to steal your crown from you so that it is taken away from you and
given to another.
                                          Illustration 116. Spiritual Salvation


                                       st
                                     rsi

                            gre

        To speak in terms of theological categories, after a person trusts in Christ as Savior, he or she should follow
Christ as Lord. That is, having received justification salvation, he or she should progress on to sanctification. But
unlike justification, which is instantaneous, sanctification salvation is to be an ongoing and growing experience.
For this reason, it is frequently referred to as progressive sanctification. We should progress to it, progress in it, and
persist in it so that we ultimately can achieve co-glory with Christ in heaven. Co-glorification is the pinnacle the
one reaches by climbing the mountain of progressive sanctification. Justification makes practical sanctification
possible. Sanctification, in turn, makes co-glorification salvation attainable.
        A favorite passage on the chart (Illustration 113) describing physical salvation is found in Mt 9:20-22. She
thought, “If I just touch His garment, I will get saved.” Jesus said to her, “Your faith has saved you. And at once
the women was saved” (TM.) This particular example of physical salvation is a beautiful example of our spiritual
salvation, that is, justification. Faith is the only requirement, and the salvation experience takes place immediately.
The same Greek word is used for both types of salvation. Depending upon the context, it is translated in terms of
being made well or being saved.
        Augustine’s popular passage concerning spiritual salvation is, of course, found in Mt 24:13: “But the one
who endures to the end, he shall be saved.” Arminians use it to say that Christians must endure to the end of their
lives in order to be saved from hell. Calvinists use it to say that genuine Christians will endure to the end of their
Page 326                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
lives. Which group is correct? The Calvinistic interpretation is wrong for two obvious reasons. The passage does
not say that it is impossible to be misled or fall away; on the contrary, the context indicates that many will be
misled and fall away. Not all believers will endure. Furthermore, the salvation in v. 13 does not guarantee
endurance; rather, it depends on endurance. The verse does not say, contrary to many Calvinists, that if you are
saved, then you will endure. It says the opposite. If you endure, then you will be saved. The salvation in view is
dependent upon endurance. Endurance (perseverance) is not dependent upon salvation. The reverse is true.
Salvation is dependent upon endurance (perseverance). Arminians are correct in that the verse teaches that this
salvation is conditioned on perseverance (and thus by works) and can be lost. This passage is not talking about a
salvation which is by faith alone or that is eternally secure. Does that mean that we can lose our salvation and go to
hell? No!
       Consider these questions. He who endures to the end of what will be saved from what? Who is being talked
about? What kind of salvation is being promised? First, the passage is talking about Jewish believers during the
tribulation, not Christian believers during the church age. Second, the end being discussed is the end of the
tribulation, not the end of their lives (cf. vv. 13 and 14). Verse 14 certainly does not mean that the end of their lives
will come! Third, the salvation being discussed is not salvation from hell but physical salvation (see v. 22). The
verse is saying that Jewish believers who endure until the end of the tribulation will be delivered from that
tribulation.
       Dispensationalists correctly understand these facets. Yet if that is all that the verse means, then it is not
much of a promise. Shank does not consider this much of a promise either, if it is limited to physical salvation. In
response, Sellers criticizes him for rejecting the physical-salvation interpretation, but then he himself likewise
rejects it! The physical salvation interpretation does appear to be a rather meaningless restatement of the obvious,
and the context is concerned about apostasy. Understandably, both of these writers reject the physical-salvation
interpretation in preference for the spiritual-salvation interpretation. As an Arminian, Shank rejects it in favor of
the interpretation that a believer must endure to get to heaven. As a Calvinist, Sellers rejects it in favor of the
interpretation that “the endurance will be evidence of the genuineness of their profession….Those who are not
genuine will not endure the suffering. They will recant in the face of persecution. The rest will endure and will be
saved because of the genuineness of their faith.”584
          This must/will mentality has been discussed already.* Here is just one more example of a Calvinist
standing a verse on its head and claiming that believers will endure because they are saved, when the verse says the
opposite. The verse clearly says that they will be saved because they endure. Despite all denials to the contrary,
both the Arminian and Calvinistic positions ultimately condition one’s final salvation on one’s endurance. Both
camps teach salvation from hell by works. Why not simply acknowledge that the salvation in this passage is
merited and do away with all the theological confusion that results when one tries to avoid this obvious exegetical
conclusion? This salvation is earned and thus cannot be referring to salvation from hell. Both the Arminian and
Calvinistic interpretations of the verse are wrong. This passage may be talking about eschatological salvation, as
both Shank and Sellers claim, but it is not referring to the soteriological aspect of that salvation.
       As pointed out previously, dispensationalists err in assuming that what is being promised is simply that the
faithful elect will have their lives spared in the sense of entering the future millennium in their flesh and blood
bodies. This is ruled out since the elect who faithfully endure the tribulation not only enter the kingdom, they also
inherit the kingdom (cf. Mt 25:34), and they cannot do so in flesh and blood bodies. The salvation in view is much
greater than salvation from physical death. From the context, one would suspect that this salvation is the
inheritance of the kingdom. If it is a millennial salvation that consists of inheriting the millennial kingdom, then it
is a misthological salvation. This interpretation is corroborated by what the rest of the NT promises to those who
endure.

Endurance

                                           Persevere for Salvation
       The word for endure (hupomeno) means to stand one’s ground, suffer, stand firm, persevere. The following
translations of hupomeno will use the latter word to facilitate the discussion between the Arminian and Calvinistic
positions concerning perseverance.† Matthew also uses this word in 10:22: “And you will be hated by all on
account of My name, but it is the one who has persevered to the end who will be saved” (TM). Arminians are

*
    See Must, Should, Will, 266.
†
    See Illustration 96. Three Major Soteriological Positions, 266.
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                           Page 327

correct that the Scripture conditions salvation on perseverance. Contrary to Calvinistic claims, the Scripture does
not say that those who are saved will persevere. Scripture teaches the opposite. Those, and only those, who
persevere will be saved (in the sense intended in this passage). This salvation is by works; it is merited. In
2Tim 2:12 Paul says, “If we persevere, we will also co-rule with Him” (TM). This co-rulership with Jesus was
referred to as salvation by Paul just two verses earlier: “I endure all things for the sake of those who are chosen,
that they also may win the salvation which is in Christ Jesus and with it eternal glory” (2Tim 2:10; TM). Salvation
is the prize to be earned and won. This salvation is comprised of glory and co-rulership. Co-glorification salvation
is in view.

                                           Persevere for Legitimacy
       The writer of Hebrews affirms, “It is for discipline that you persevere. God deals with you as with sons, for
what son is there whom his father does not discipline? But if you are without discipline, of which all have become
partakers, then you are illegitimate children and not sons” (Heb 12:7-8; TM). Illegitimate means that those
believers who do not persevere are God’s spiritual children but lack the legal status of sonship.* Legal entitlement
to one’s misthological inheritance requires two things: spiritual birth and perseverance (having God as your Father
and living like it). There are many believers who have experienced the new birth and have God as their Father but
who refuse to live accordingly. They live like God is not their Father, and when it comes time to inherit the
kingdom, God will treat them like they are not His sons. If they do not treat God as their Father, He will not treat
them as His mature sons. Mature sons rule; immature children do not.

                                             Persevere for Approval
        James says, “Blessed is a man who perseveres under trial; for once he has been approved, he will receive the
crown of life, which the Lord has promised to those who love Him” (Jam 1:12). Once again, the reward for
perseverance is a crown, which denotes rulership. Peter likewise uses synonymous words and states, “For what
glory is there if, when you sin and are harshly treated, you persevere with patience? But if when you do what is
right and suffer for it, you patiently persevere, this finds approval with God” (1Pet 2:20; TM). Glory and
misthological approval from God are the rewards for perseverance. The if clearly points out the conditional nature
of this promise in this context. This approval is going to cost you—no pain, no gain. If you determine to do what is
right, then you may have to suffer for it. If you pay the price of endurance, then you get God’s favor, and this
approval is much more than just a pat on the back. It is a crown for your head, a thrown for your chair, a kingdom
for your rulership. It means to be worthy of being a king or queen in the kingdom (2Thess 1:4-5).

                                        Persevere for Reward
      The writer of Hebrews uses the noun form of endurance (hupomone) in association with the promise of
personal reward and God’s approval.
          35
            Therefore, do not throw away your confidence, which has a great reward. 36 For you have need of
          perseverance, so that when you have done the will of God, you may receive what was
          promised….38 My righteous one will live by faith; and if he draws back, My soul has no pleasure in
          him. 39 But we are not of those who draw back into destruction, but of those who have faith to the
          winning of the soul. (Heb 10:35-39; TM)

       To persevere means to do the will of God on an ongoing basis. It takes more than an act of faith; it takes an
active faith expressed through one’s life. God’s righteous one, that is, God’s child, may either obey or disobey
Him. The passage refers to a reward, not a gift. Not all Christians will receive this reward; some will not endure
and as a result will miss out on this aspect of salvation. What is at stake is a promised reward, not whether one is
considered judicially righteous. Perseverance in the faith is rewarded and thus a work. Since we are not saved by
works, we are not saved, in the soteriological sense, by persevering in the faith.

                                            Persevere for Pleasure
       Soulish pleasure is at stake. Will our lives give God’s soul pleasure? The potential is there. After all, in the
passage God inversely says of the believer who does not persevere, “My soul has no pleasure in him.” God is

*
    See “Illegitimate Children” in Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection.
Page 328                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
Spirit, but according to the passage God also has a soul (i.e., a personality) with the capacity to experience pleasure
or displeasure. He has created us in His image to desire pleasure. Desiring pleasure is not sinful in and of itself.
Hedonism is making pleasure your god. Marrowists do not advocate this sin, of course. But we were created to
desire pleasure, and it can be a very healthy desire. A desire to love and serve God is healthy is it not? This is the
desire to bring pleasure to another. The desire for personal pleasure can also be healthy. God certainly desires
personal pleasure in this passage. The question is, “Where is the focus of our desire?” Is it on the things of this
earth or the things of heaven? Is the focus on the present or the future pleasure? Spiritual Christians live to bring
eternal pleasure to their souls. Soulish Christians live to bring temporal pleasure to their souls. A hypocritical
Christian is someone who pretends not to be really concerned about personal pleasure at all when, in fact, his or her
life demonstrates quite the opposite.
        If we want to win eternal pleasure for our souls, then we must persevere. We must earn this eternal
pleasure.* If we fail to earn it, then we face the temporal and misthological destruction of our souls. Our soul-lives
may be forfeited temporally in premature death (or even worse, in protracted temporal pain), and our opportunity
to experience eternal misthological soulish pleasure may go up in smoke at the JSC. Perseverance is not required
for salvation from hell, but it is required for misthological salvation at the JSC (1Cor 3:11-15).

Gospel of Kingdom as Salvation
       The Lord has saved us from hell for rulership in heaven. But we must endure in order to get this rulership.
Good intentions and a good start are not enough. According to the NT, this message of misthological rulership is
the gospel of the kingdom for us today, and it will be the same gospel of the kingdom for believers in the future:
Endure so that you can earn salvation, that is, rulership in the kingdom. Demonstration of this meaning for gospel
of the kingdom can also be seen in comparing the reference to the gospel of the kingdom in Mt 24:13-14 with the
reference to the kingdom in Mt 25:34.

          •    The one who endures to the end will be saved…this is the gospel of the kingdom.
          •    Come, you are blessed due to your works…inherit the kingdom prepared for you.

        The salvation referred to in v. 13 is the gospel of the kingdom in v. 14. The gospel of the kingdom is the
gospel of inheriting that kingdom. The statement from the parable of the sheep and goats, inherit the kingdom
prepared for you, was given by Jesus to give greater detail concerning the salvation promised in Mt 24:13. The
salvation the Lord promises in both cases is merited by the faithful elect who endure the tribulation. The purpose of
the parable is to give greater detail about what that salvation entailed. Salvation is not only from something (hell),
it also is to be for something (the inheritance of the kingdom). In the Lukan parallel, this salvation is defined by its
cross-reference in Lk 21:36 as the ability “to stand before the son of Man.” All believers will appear before the
Lord, but not all believers will have the misthological strength to stand before Him.†
        Our pre-temporal election was made before the foundation of the world, as Paul says in Eph 1:4. But the
goal of that election is to inherit the kingdom, not merely to enter it. Jesus likewise indicates that the goal of our
pre-temporal election is the inheritance of the kingdom in this discourse when He says in Mt 25:34 that the
inheritance was prepared from the foundation of the world. Some elect will be led astray and fail to endure, but
some elect will be faithful and endure and experience the goal of their pre-temporal election, which is a post-
temporal selection to inherit rulership in the kingdom. This rulership was pre-temporally chosen as the reward for
the faithful. You enter the kingdom by faith, but only those believers who faithfully work to the end will be worthy
to inherit the kingdom, that is, to rule in the kingdom.
        Suppose a rich friend predetermined to give you a check for a $1,000,000 the next time he saw you. He
writes the check out, puts it in his coat pocket, and sets out to find you. Being your friend, he knows where you
are—at the lake fishing. So he goes there. Sure enough, he finds you at the lake, but you have fallen off the pier
into the water and are drowning. You are a poor swimmer, but he is a great swimmer. So he throws his coat off,
jumps in, and pulls you to shore. When you reach shore, he gets his coat, pulls out the check that he already has
written for you, and gives it to you. He only says, “Take this check to the bank and you will have a million
dollars.” He not only saved you from something—the lake—he also saved you for something that he had pre-
chosen for you—the million dollars. He chose that million dollars for you and you for that million dollars before he
saved you from the lake.

*
    See Earn, 175.
†
    See Before (emprosthen), 663.
Chapter 11. What Will Be The Sign?                                                                                                  Page 329

       Yet suppose you are careless with the check and lose it on the way to the bank. Would you not be a fool?
Certainly. However, you would not have forfeited your salvation from the lake. Your friend will not hunt you
down and throw you back in the lake! But you would have lost what you were saved for—the million dollars. In
the same way, Jesus has given you a check (a promissory note already written out on the paper of the Bible) that if
you endure, you will be rich. All you have to do is take this promissory note to the bank of heaven, and you will be
rich for all eternity. Suppose you are careless, though, with the promise and lose it on the way to the bank. You
rightly would be considered a fool. Only a fool would be careless with such a wonderful promise and fail to cash in
on it by failing to endure. Are you enduring for Jesus, or are you a fool? The Lord pre-temporally chose you for the
inheritance and pre-temporally chose the inheritance for you before He saved you from hell. As a believer, you
already have received what you were saved from, deliverance from hell. But are you going to obtain what you
were saved for, rulership in heaven?

                                                                                               *
        The above chart is a brief summary of some of the most pertinent NT data. As seen in this survey, the
misthological understanding of salvation in the Gospel of Matthew is compatible with what is found in the rest of
the NT.† It is congenial with Matthean theology to anticipate that those in the outer darkness may in fact be those
believers who fail to attain a full salvation.
        To recap this discussion of some of the most relevant passages discussed in our previous chapters, the
eschatological salvation in 2Thess 2:13-15 is dependent upon two things: sanctification and faith (2Thess 2:13).
Gaining the glory of the Lord is the result (2Thess 2:14), and it requires endurance, as expressed by the
exhortation to stand firm and hold on (2Thess 2:15). This passage of Scripture is not talking about salvation from
hell; it is talking about salvation for glory. “And it was for this He called you through our gospel, that you may
earn the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ” (2Thess 2:14; TM). This same Greek word for earn (peripoiesis) is found
in 1Thess 5:9. The DRA translates it as purchasing in both verses; the YLT translates it as acquiring. The salvation
we purchase and acquire in 1Thess 5:9 is the glory we purchase and acquire in 2Thess 2:14. Alternatively, the NJB
translates it as win in 2Thess 2:14. The salvation we win is glory. God’s deliverance in 1Thess 5:9 is not merely
from something (tribulational wrath); it is for something, the salvation of millennial glory.
        The same teaching is expressed by Paul again in 2Tim 2:10-13, where he talks about earning a salvation
associated with glory. He says in v. 10 that it was in view of this salvation that he endures in order that others also
may earn this co-glorification salvation if they endure (v. 10). And notice that Paul says we throughout verses 11-
13. He includes himself and the rest of the elect. He is talking about believers. Paul’s salvation and our salvation
are dependent upon endurance. The glory of reigning with Christ in heaven is dependent upon enduring. It is a
reward. Matthean misthology is in harmony with the rest of the NT on this fact.

                                                       Conclusion
       The discourse in Mt 24:1-36 concerning the tribulation naturally divides itself into two halves and a
conclusion (with a double occurrence of then). A more detailed recapitulation is introduced subsequently with
when, which goes back and fills in some of the details pertaining to the last half of the tribulation, and another
recapitulation marked by the word after supplies particulars concerning the end of the tribulation. Those living in
that period of time will have ample signs indicating the sequential fulfillment of the prophesied events leading up
to the Lord’s return. His return will be of no surprise to those eagerly watching the signs.
       During the time period of this tribulation, the gospel of the kingdom will be preached throughout the whole
world. The full realization of this gospel for our personal benefit predicates enduring suffering and is thus
distinguished from the gospel of grace. It is not wrong to seek the salvation which God supplies; it would be wrong
not to seek it. Seeking pleasure is proper in terms of heavenly treasure. To do otherwise would be to reject the
gospel of the kingdom. This gospel of the future kingdom is misthologically applicable to us even today. It is a
misthological salvation that is earned through perseverance and which entails rulership of the millennial kingdom.
Those who endure until the end of the tribulation will be rewarded with rulership of the millennial kingdom which
immediately follows. Overcomers will be millennial rulers.

Salvation” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
                                        Chapter 12.
                          I Wish We'd All Been Ready (Mt 24:36-44)
                                                   Introduction
        Since reasons for adapting the pretribulational interpretation already have been provided, subsequent
interaction will be from this point of view. This means that a choice must be made as to which stage of the second
coming is being referred to in each section. Does it describe the rapture or the revelation? As already demonstrated,
the first section (Mt 24:1-35) describes the revelation. Does the next section continue the description of the
revelation? Many pretribulationalists believe that it does. I will take the opposing position and provide an
eschatological time chart for the entire passage. In the early 1970s, there was a popular song by Larry Norman by
the title I Wish We’d All Been Ready that associated the events of this passage with the rapture along the following
lines:

                                 A man and wife asleep in bed.
                                 She hears a noise and turns her head, he’s gone.
                                 I wish we’d all been ready.
                                 Two men walking up a hill.
                                 One disappears and one’s left standing still.
                                 I wish we’d all been ready.

       The present author used to enjoy singing this song back in those early days when he was in the youth choir.
His conviction still, as an adult, is that this passage does in fact describe the judgment associated with the rapture.
But if so, why is Jesus warning believers to get ready? Some highly respected pretribulationalists have responded
that this song is in error by arguing that those who are taken away are taken away in judgment and by assuming
that the church is not judged. Presumably, the lost are killed in the tribulation and the elect are left behind to enter
the millennial kingdom in physical bodies. This argument is mistaken, of course, in assuming that the church is not
judged. Immediately after the rapture, the church will appear before the JSC. Accordingly, one might wonder if the
church is being taken away to be judged at the Bema and if the lost are being left behind to be judged on earth
during the tribulation. This would present a more mature understanding of the song: I Wish We’d All Been Ready.
All would no longer be taken to mean just the lost.

                                                        Text
       36
         But of that day and hour no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, nor the Son, but the Father
       alone. 37 For the coming of the Son of Man will be just like the days of Noah. 38 For as in those days
       which were before the flood they were eating and drinking, they were marrying and giving in
       marriage, until the day that Noah entered the ark, 39 and they did not understand until the flood came
       and took them all away; so shall the coming of the Son of Man be. 40 Then there shall be two men in
       the field; one will be taken, and one will be left. 41 Two women will be grinding at the mill; one will
       be taken, and one will be left. 42 Therefore be on the alert, for you do not know which day your
       Lord is coming. 43 But be sure of this, that if the head of the house had known at what time of the
       night the thief was coming, he would have been on the alert and would not have allowed his house to
       be broken into. 44 For this reason you be ready too; for the Son of Man is coming at an hour when
       you do not think He will. (Mt 24:36-44)

                                                  Simple Future
       The simplest futuristic breakdown of the Olivet Discourse has the tribulation followed by the Lord coming
in judgment at the conclusion of the tribulation. The church age is completely absent in this prophetic discourse.
Everything is future. I will challenge this simplistic-futuristic view after explaining alternatives. Still, for now, a
simple two-part outline suffices for this simplistic perspective.
                               Illustration 118. Simplistic Futuristic Olivet Chronology
       •    Tribulation of Jews (Mt 24:1-35).
       •    Judgment of Gentiles (Mt 24:36-25:46).
Page 332                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
                                                 Historical Future
        Chitwood seeks to set date-parameters. He believes the fruitless fig tree putting forth its leaves in the parable
of 24:32-35 represents Israel becoming a nation in 1948. Phillips also takes this approach, but he cautions against
date setting since he says we do not know exactly how much time is covered by the elastic term generation.585 This
passage and this type of interpretation is a favorite among modern-day historicists. The generation to which Jesus
refers is supposedly the generation of Christians now living. We can know that the Lord will return soon, within
our generation. Oddly, though, this generation does not necessarily mean forty years.586 An online search will
confirm the popularity of this type of approach, which combines the historical and futuristic viewpoints. According
to advocates of this mindset, the Lord actually knows the day and hour in which He will return. Citing Trench in
support, Chitwood takes the words ei me in Mt 24:36 (cp. Mk 13:32) to mean if not and thus understands it to mean
that if Jesus were not the Father, then He would not know the time of His return. But since Jesus does know the
time of His return, we are supposed to understand that Jesus is asserting that He is the Father (cp. Jn 10:30), so
these verses thus confirm Jesus’ omniscience and deity. For such reasons, Chitwood gives a historical time break at
verses 31/32 that results in an outline that would look like this:
                                 Illustration 119. Historical-Future Olivet Chronology
        •   Tribulation of Jews (Mt 24:1-31).
        •   Judgment of Christians (Mt 24:32-25:30).
        •   Judgment of Gentiles (Mt 25:31-46).587

       I already have found the traditional historical position wanting on other occasions, and this is no exception.
This combination of ei me is readily translated as except rather than if not. No one except the Father knew when
Jesus would return. Jesus did not know when He would return. The historicist interpretation is refuted by the fact
that Jesus did not come within the space of one generation. Jesus should have come in 1988, the year Deal
published his book advocating this type of approach, if there were anything to this position.588 The attempt to
expand the length of the generation from forty to seventy years is hardly convincing. The generation who crucified
Jesus, and to which Jesus referred earlier in connection with the prophesied destruction of Jerusalem, saw the
destruction of their city within the forty year window. The generation that died in the wilderness did so within the
forty year window.
       The historical interpretation has missed its window of opportunity, and the leaves are falling off this popular
hermeneutical tree as it fades into the past. If the historicist position were true, then the church was wrong to look
for Christ to return before 1988! The doctrine of imminency kills this historicist tree, since this particular
permutation of the historical view must deny imminency for past generations. The fig tree of this passage is simply
a pictorial recapitulation of the events of the tribulation that Jesus had just presented. Meisinger correctly believes
the leaves of the tree are the signs that occur within the tribulation and point to the climactic day of the return of
the Lord at the conclusion of the tribulation.589

                                                 Imminent Future
       By merely moving the verse division in the above outline, we are able to fully retain the doctrine of
imminency and yet accommodate the viewpoint that the church age is to be found in the parables as well. In this
outline, we simply do not apply the parable of the fig tree to the church age.
                                 Illustration 120. Imminent Future Olivet Chronology
        •   Tribulation of Jews (Mt 24:1-35).
        •   Judgment of Christians (Mt 24:36-25:30).
        •   Judgment of Gentiles (Mt 25:31-46).

        Although Meisinger (president of Chafer Theological Seminary) is correct to reject the modified historical
position above, his simplistic futuristic inclusion of v. 36 in this pericope of the fig tree is unlikely. Bigalke, also at
the Chafer site, more fully defends this simplistic futuristic view. I will more thoroughly present my reasons for
rejecting this simplistic view as we proceed, but for now I note my agreement with Meisinger that the leaves of the
tree refer to the signs seen by those living during the tribulation, not to those living in the present church age. He is
also correct to state that, in addition to seeing these signs, those living then (i.e., during the tribulation) will be able
Chapter 12. I Wish We’d All Been Ready?(Mt 24:36-44)                                                         Page 333
to calculate the day that Jesus will return with absolute certainty. Splendid. I fully accept and defend this position
below.* Meisinger is also correct in that Jesus says that this day will be unknown to those living now: “Thus when
Jesus says ‘no one knows,’ He refers to people living before the countdown begins. People before the Tribulation
cannot know. Accordingly, before the Tribulation it is impossible to set dates for the Tribulation, or Second
Coming. Such attempts are mere conjectures.”590
        Yet it is at this point one encounters an inconsistency with Chafer’s simplistic futuristic position. The words
“no one knows,” as Meisinger correctly deduces, do not apply to those living then (during the tribulation) but to us
living now (during the church age). Contrary to the simplistic outline, verse 36 cannot possibly be allocated to the
future. It must be relocated and intended for those living now in the present. This admission by Meisinger opens up
the door for the imminent future outline above. Sweigart swings this door wide open with two major arguments.
First, the peri de (but of) used to introduce this section “indicate a change in subject material. The Lord is moving
on to a new topic.”591 In fact, Matthew uses it to introduce a new time period in the remaining two out of three
times he uses the expression (20:6, 27:46). Nevertheless, since it appears to be used in 22:31 to restate a different
aspect of the same subject matter, this part of Sweigart’s argument appears to be merely indicative rather than
conclusive. His second point, however, is stronger: “Note that the phrase ‘day and hour’ in verse 36 forms an
inclusion with ‘day and hour’ in 25:13. That effectively eliminates the idea that the three parable[s in 24:45-25:30]
that follow this discourse pertain only to tribulation Israel.”592
         This powerful argument can be likened to bookends that disjunctively section off the intervening
homogeneous parenthetical material from that coming before and after it. Again, however, I find a flaw in
Sweigart’s argument. In the subsequent flow of the biblical text, he says, “Concepts of ‘delay’ occur in each one of
these three parables [24:45-25:30]. This cannot be accidental. We must be dealing with the interadvent period of
nearly 2000 years.”593 He extends the period of delay to 25:30, which is beyond his second bookend in 25:13
above. Although some of his arguments are rather awkward and need the modification made below, I concur with
his break at 24:36 and note that even Meisinger does so as well, although perhaps unwittingly. They both open the
door to the church age in 24:36. The only question that now remains is how long does that door stay open? How
long does Jesus address those living in the present time period? Bigalke (and I assume Meisinger by association)
tries only to crack the door open and slam it quickly. Sweigart, on the other hand, appears to want to leave the door
open too long. In contrast, I will find it necessary to perceive a revolving door in which the conversation oscillates
around the judgment to be found on both sides of the tribulation.
        Verse 36 should not be included in the pericope concerning the fig tree. So the parable concerning the fig
tree is limited to vv. 32-35. But how far should this discussion of the present time period be extended in the
outline? The imminent future outline above is the view I initially preferred long ago, when I was trying to construct
a time table of this passage. As one can see, I was then in agreement with the argument being advanced by
Sweigart. But there were problems with this approach that led me to seek Hodges’ guidance.
        As the chart below will further demonstrate, I am not the only dispensationalist to struggle with seeking to
discern the time period involved for each part of the Olivet Discourse. Dispensationalists differ among themselves
as to what part of the discourse deals with the rapture versus the revelation.594 Perhaps the most difficult passage to
categorize in this material is Mt 25:1-13. In a personal correspondence with Hodges in 1992, I suggested the
imminent future classification shown above, which is in harmony with Sweigart’s current assessment. But Hodges
suggested an alternative that I eventually found more persuasive.

    See Unexpected, 338.

                                        Modified Imminent Future
       Hodges was in agreement with my initial identification of all the passages except Mt 25:1-13.596 Hodges
maintained that this passage refers to the second phase after the tribulation. This singular modification can be
easily made to the imminent future outline above by just changing the classification of this particular parable
accordingly. If this modification is made, it would result in the following oscillating description of judgments:
Christians being judged before the tribulation and Gentiles afterwards.
                               Illustration 122. Modified Future Olivet Chronology
       •   Tribulation of Jews (Mt 24:1-35).
       •   Judgment of Christians (Mt 24:36-51).
       •   Judgment of Gentiles (Mt 25:1-13).
       •   Judgment of Christians (Mt 25:14-30).
       •   Judgment of Gentiles (Mt 25:31-46).

       The above outline might appropriately be called a modified imminent-future presentation. This outline is
fully satisfactory. But Hodges also had suggested a simple two-part breakdown of the outline.597 Upon further
consideration, I came to accept Hodges’ position but developed it into the more advanced form below. Those who
would like a discussion of these passages from Hodges’ perspective (that is very suitable for a layperson) may see
his booklet Jesus: God’s Prophet.
Chapter 12. I Wish We’d All Been Ready?(Mt 24:36-44)                                                                         Page 335
                                        Illustration 123. Modified Phase Chart of Mt. Olivet



                                                                Phase
                         Part 1: Mt 24:1-44                                                 Part 2: Mt 24:45-25:46
                           what & when                                                               where

                                                                       A. 25:14-30 T       (Christian—Rapture)*
