T = Taken
L = Left Behind
* = Contrast of faithful & unfaithful elect

Order of Description
       If the timetables of either the historical future, or imminent future, or modified imminent future are
accepted, then the Marrowistic position on the outer darkness is a dispensational given. The misthological
interpretation of the outer darkness would be proven from a consistent dispensational point of view. A
dispensationalist, who is logically consistent, would have to acknowledge that the corresponding judgment being
described by the outer darkness is the JSC and must therefore be dealing with born-again believers. In other words,
for those sharing the dispensational eschatology, three out of the four possibilities surveyed above immediately
result in the misthological position, namely the historical future, imminent future, and the modified imminent
future. Even if the alternative simple view were taken, however, it would still not disprove the misthological
assessment, as will be demonstrated from the initial Matthean passage on the outer darkness. But for now, I will
address the simplistic objections to this primary outer darkness passage. The principal arguments in favor of the
simplistic view (which takes Mt 24:36-44 as a reference to the second phase of Jesus’ coming) are as follows.

Posttribulational Chronology
       According to the first argument for simplistic view, since Mt 24:3-35 describes the tribulation, Mt 24:36-44
cannot describe the rapture or one would have a posttribulational view, because the rapture would be after the
tribulation. In response, it may be pointed out that Jesus’ decision to describe the rapture after the tribulation and
revelation does not prove that the rapture happens after the tribulation and revelation. The order of the discussion is
based on the disciples’ question, not on chronology. The disciples were interested in two things: signs and the
destruction of the temple. The second phase of His coming, rather than the rapture of the first phase, is the one
associated with signs and the desolation of the temple, so it is this phase that Jesus describes first.

Lk 17:26-37
      In the second argument for simplistic view, Ryrie argues that Lk 17:26-37 proves that they are taken in
judgment rather than in safety (cf. Lk 17:37).598 Further, support for this view can be drawn from the context (cf.
Mt 24:39). The judgment of the flood came and took them away. Thus, it is argued that those taken away in
Mt 24:40-41 are taken away in judgment rather than in the rapture.* In response, it may be noted concerning
Lk 17:37 that Ryrie overstates his case in his use of this verse. The meaning of Lk 17:37 is rather obscure.
          36
            “Two men will be in the field; one will be taken and the other will be left.” 37 And answering they
          said to Him, “Where, Lord?” And He said to them, “Where the body is, there also will the vultures be
          gathered.” (Lk 17:36-37)

     The same expression is found earlier in Matthew’s account where the saying concerning vultures follows the
comparison of Jesus’ coming to lightning (Mt 24:27-28). Additionally, concerning its obscurity, Marshall lists a
number of positions concerning Lk 17:37 that are adopted by various interpreters:


*
    For further interaction with the typical dispensational view of what it means to be taken, see Mark of the Beast, 362.
Page 336                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
      [1] His coming will be as obvious as lightening. His presence will be clearly indicated, just as the
      presence of carrion is clearly indicated by the gathering of vultures overhead.…[2] Men will no more
      be able to miss seeing the Son of man than vultures can miss seeing carrion.…[3] The son of man
      will appear when the world is ripe for judgment.…[4] judgment will operate whenever it is
      needed…[5] men should avoid being like carrion, waiting to be devoured.…[6] Weiss…thinks that
      the disciples’ question means, “Where do those who are left behind stay?” with the answer being “at
      the scene of judgment”; but this is rather forced…[7] the point is the universality of the separation in
      vs. 34f. This last view seems best for Lk.599

       Although Marshall prefers the last interpretation, the third one appears more attractive. Geldenhuys states it
well, “Where there is spiritual decay judgment will follow.”600 This is very close to what Barbieri says concerning
the same phrase in Mt 24:28, “Where there is spiritual corruption judgment will follow.”601 The position taken
herein concerning Lk 17:37 is that Ryrie is correct in saying that it answers the question of where they will be
taken. Weiss is correct in saying that it answers the question of where they will be left. The commentators are
correct in saying that it indicates judgment. So how is it possible to agree with all of them when they disagree with
each other? Simple. Jesus gave an ambiguous answer to an equivocal question in Lk 17:37. The disciples did not
ask, “Where will they be taken?” To do so would indicate that they at least understood where they would be left.
Nor did the disciples ask, “Where will they be left?” To do so would indicate that they at least understood where
they would be taken. In other words, the disciples did not know enough to ask such a specific question. Instead,
they asked a question regarding both where they would be taken and where they would be left.
       Their ignorance about where is manifest: “Thomas said to Him, ‘Lord, we do not know where You are
going, how do we know the way?’” (Jn 14:5) They did not know where they would be taken. They knew who
would take the elect—the angels. Jesus had just said so in Mt 24:31. But where the elect were to be taken was a
much harder question. How could the angels take them away from earth since the kingdom of heaven was
supposed to be on earth? They knew that their inheritance in the kingdom of heaven was supposed to be on earth
from what Jesus had said in Mt 5:5,10. So where would they be taken if the kingdom of heaven was supposed to be
on earth?
       On the other hand, how could the nonelect be left on earth? The disciples knew that entrance into the
kingdom was limited to believers from what Jesus had said in Jn 3:5. So unbelievers could not be left on earth. The
disciples were completely befuddled, as the simple form of their question indicates. They ask both where will the
two men be taken and where will they be left. Jesus’ answer in Lk 17:37 is judgment. They will be taken to
judgment and left for judgment. Everywhere there is sin, there will be judgment. Everywhere there is spiritual
decay, there will be judgment. That was His answer as to where. The vultures indicate judgment.
       On the way to Jerusalem, and in response to Lk 17:26-36, they had asked Jesus the question about where in
Lk 17:37. In the Mount Olivet Discourse, they have now reached Jerusalem, and Jesus is answering their questions
about what and when. And He concludes this answer in Mt 24:36-41. As Jesus is presenting this same teaching
again (that He had presented a few days earlier), the disciples no doubt are hoping for an answer to their where
question that would be easier to understand than a reference to vultures. And indeed this time Jesus gives them a
glorious answer to their previous where question. As He concludes His answer about what and when, instead of
concluding with the allusion to vultures, as He had done previously (in Luke), this time He gives four parables
instead. These four parables answer the earlier question as to where they would be taken and where they would be
left.
       Ryrie is correct, to a limited extent, that their being taken was connected with judgment. Yet this does not
mean that the passage is describing the revelation. On the contrary, those taken in the rapture are taken to the Bema
for judgment. All four parables are concerned with the judgment that takes place when the Lord returns. Two of the
parables present the judgment of those who are taken in the rapture. Two of the parables present the judgment of
those who are left behind at the rapture. The point of the parables is that whether you are left behind or taken, you
will be judged. And this is the point of Jesus’ answer in Lk 17:37. Therefore, the simple future argument that being
taken away in Mt 24:39 refers to being taken away in regards to judgment rather than in safety does not prove that
the rapture is not in view. In two of the following parables, the rapture is associated with judgment.

Population of Millennial Kingdom
       The third simplistic argument that this passage describes the revelation rather than the rapture is that since
there must be someone left behind to populate the millennial kingdom when the Lord returns at the revelation, it is
Chapter 12. I Wish We’d All Been Ready?(Mt 24:36-44)                                                           Page 337
those who are left behind to populate the kingdom who are in view. The weaknesses of this argument already have
been pointed out.* The kingdom cannot be inherited in flesh and blood bodies.

Imminent Revelation
       The fourth simplistic argument for taking this passage (in Lk 17:36-37) as dealing with the revelation is that
even the revelation will happen at an unknown time since the seven years will be shortened just a bit. Those who
live during the tribulation will not be able to mark the date of the revelation as exactly seven years after the rapture.
Thus, for those in that time period, although the Lord’s coming may not be truly imminent, it will, nonetheless, be
at an unknown time.

                                                   Unknown Time
       The argument that the passage is referring to the revelation is nullified by the earlier response herein that the
NT doctrine of imminency is concerning the rapture, not the revelation. Additionally, the interpretation that the
passage is dealing with the revelation may further be ruled out by considering the specifics of the passage. In
Mt 24:32-35, His coming is known and expected. You can see it coming; there are leaves (all these events of the
tribulation), which indicate the approaching summer (His return). Moreover, Meisinger’s inconsistency concerning
v. 36 has been demonstrated already.† In Mt 24:36ff, there is a shift so that the Lord’s return is unknown and
unexpected. Jesus is telling them that His coming will have both aspects, which is what one would expect since it is
in two stages. Thus, this second section is contrastive with the earlier section, as will be seen in our examination of
vv. 36-44.
       Mt 24:36 says that the time is unknown. Granted, it could be argued that the day and hour is not known
since the second half of the tribulation will be shortened a little bit according to v. 22. Accordingly, it might be
assumed that it will be shortened by a few days, perhaps a few weeks, maybe even a month or two. Even if this
view of the shortening were true (which it is not, as even Meisinger acknowledges), this saying, in and of itself,
would not prove that the passage refers to the revelation. Still, in this context the shortening means more than not
knowing the mere day; it means not to know the time. So even adopting this view of shortening is a self-defeating
basis for taking this passage as a reference to the revelation.

                                                     No Signs
       Mt 24:37-38 shows that life will be business as usual, no special signs to mark this stage of His coming. It is
a time of peace. This peaceful time is comparable to the peace in 1Thess 5:3 that precedes the rapture. This would
not be true of the time preceding the revelation. The tribulation will be anything but a time of peace and business as
usual! These verses depict the time before the tribulation (thus they depict the rapture). Likewise, Mt 24:39 shows
that the judgment is sudden and unexpected. You can preach about it just like Noah did, but people in general do
not expect it because they cannot see signs of it coming. Thus, the first phase of the Lord’s coming is in view.

                                                        Taken
        At one end of the dispensational spectrum, Bigalke believes that “the Olivet Discourse does not refer to the
church age so it does not discuss the timing of the Rapture.”602 Although he is correct that the word used to
describe their being taken (i.e., paralambano) is not always positive, this is an insufficient basis from which to
conclude that paralambano and airo are equivalent in this context.603 As demonstrated above, Sweigart comes to
an opposite assessment.‡ Although the overall force of the argument is in favor of Sweigart’s position, a mediating
position between these two dispensational extremes will be adopted herein in that one of these three major parables
(i.e., 25:1-13) will be considered as not dealing with the church age.
        Mt 24:40-41 pictures the rapture. The word for took away (airo) in judgment in v. 39 is different from the
word used for taken (paralambano) in vv. 40-41. According to John, the Greek word Jesus uses here for taken in
vv. 40-41 is the same word that Jesus uses shortly thereafter to describe the rapture (Jn 14:3). In that eschatological
context, it means to take away to heaven. Sweigart rightly understands it to indicate the rapture in this Matthean
passage as well. Further, he points out a possible connection with the initial Matthean usage of this verb in which
Joseph was told to take Mary as his wife (Mt 1:20). This nuptial taking of a bride by her husband is quite probable

*
  See Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom, 60.
†
  See Imminent Future, 332.
‡
  See Imminent Future,332.
Page 338                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
in Jn 14:3, and Sweigart finds it as likely in Jesus’ reference to not knowing the day or hour in the present
Matthean Olivet context:

         Our Lord was speaking metaphorically using Jewish nuptial imagery. As we have learned previously,
         when a Jewish young man betrothed a bride they did not immediately live together. In fact, the
         bridegroom returned to his father’s house to build a room onto the house where he was to live with
         his bride after the marriage was consummated. Although this is foreign to our culture, the purpose of
         this arrangement was so that the young bride could learn from her mother-in-law how to properly
         care for her new husband. So the groom was responsible for building a new room onto the house.
         However, to prevent the young man from doing a sloppy job because of his desire to be with his
         bride, the son was only allowed to go bring his bride after the father had inspected AND
         APPROVED the new dwelling that the son had prepared. In this sense then only the father knew
         when the bridegroom would go for the bride. (Emphasis his.) 604

When the Lord finishes preparing the rooms in His Father’s mansion for His Bride, His Father will tell Him to go,
take His Bride, and bring her home. Jesus is preparing a room for His Bride right now, awaiting His Father’s
approval to take His Bride, who in turn is composed of those believers who are preparing themselves for His
return.*

                                                         Alert
       Mt 24:42 indicates that we need to be on the alert (gregoreo) for His coming now because He may come
now. It is not merely the coming of the Lord but your Lord about which Jesus is warning these disciples. As was
pointed out concerning verse 3, the word you addresses His disciples. Believers are warned to be on the alert.
Unlike the unbelievers in Mt 7:22, who falsely claim that Jesus is their Lord, Jesus Himself acknowledges those
who legitimately have this relationship with Him are being exhorted to be alert and ready. The Judge and judgment
are coming for believers. Genuine believers are the ones who need to be ready for the coming of their Lord.
       According to Mt 24:43, He will come just like a thief in the night. This is the same imagery that Paul uses in
1Thess 5:2-4 to describe the commencing of the Day of the Lord and thus the rapture. Paul is using the word day in
the phrase Day of the Lord in 1Thess 5:2-4 in association with the rapture. In saying that we will not know when
the Day of the Lord will occur, Paul does not indicate that we might know the week or month or year that it will
occur. Not knowing the day meant not knowing the time. Paul just as easily could have said that the hour of the
Lord would come like a thief in the night, meaning that we will not know the time period.605 More importantly, this
imagery of a thief in the night is the same imagery that Jesus uses in Rev 3:3 to indicate His any-moment coming
in the rapture for the purpose of judging believers. This is exactly the same way it is being used in Mt 24:43—to
denote the rapture of believers and the judgment associated with it. Also, Rev 3:3 says that we will not know the
hour that the rapture takes place. The idea, of course, is not that we will know the day but not know the hour of the
day the rapture will take place. The thought is that we will not know the time period. The similar phrase in
Mt 24:36 and 24:42 should likewise be understood as saying believers will not know the time period. These types
of expressions do not mean that we will merely not know the exact hour or day; rather, we will not even know the
general time frame.606

                                                    Unexpected
       Mt 24:44 says that Jesus will come at a time when even you, that is, believers, will not be expecting Him (cf.
v. 50). This observation destroys the possibility of interpreting this passage as referring to the tribulation and the
revelation. If the time were merely unknown, then it might be possible to argue that the passage is dealing with the
second phase of His coming, since the revelation interpretation of this passage presumes that the elect living during
the tribulation will not know the exact literal day or literal hour when He will come due to the shortening.
However, it is one thing for the time of Jesus’ coming to be unknown; it is an entirely different matter for it to be
completely unexpected!
       It would be very difficult for believers living in the last days of the tribulation not to expect His coming as
the end of the seven years of tribulation draws nigh. On the other hand, it is very difficult for believers today to
expect His coming right now in the present age as time continues to drag by. Perceiving of the second phase of His
coming as being unexpected by tribulational believers is impossible. The unexpected nature of His return on the

*
    See Many Mansions Prepared for You, 602.
Chapter 12. I Wish We’d All Been Ready?(Mt 24:36-44)                                                              Page 339
part of believers must refer to the first phase of His coming for believers and thus the rapture. Notice also that this
unexpected aspect is stressed in Lk 12:40,46. Especially note the use of day and hour in Lk 12:46. It is not only
unknown; it is unexpected. For the day or hour to be unknown in these contexts means that it is unexpected. It
must refer to the first stage of His coming, the rapture.
        This conclusion is in accordance with the previous discussions concerning the future and past tense of the
shortening as described by Matthew and Mark respectively (Mt 24:22; Mk 13:20).* The duration of the
tribulation will be temporally shortened in the future for the sake of the elect because Daniel already has
prophetically shortened it in the past.† As was seen from that objective prophetic foreshortening, the number of
the days until Christ’s official presentation as Messiah was 173,880 days. The precision of this prophecy right
down to the very day is truly remarkable. However, exactitude of this foresight also equally applies to the length of
the tribulation. The same prophecy uses the same terminology of a prophetic week to specify that the tribulation
will last 7 years, that is, 2,520 days (7 x 360 = 2,520). This meticulous computation is confirmed by John as the
length of the tribulation in the book of Revelation.
        Half of the seven-year tribulation would be 3½ years, which is 42 months or 1,260 days. John’s references
to the second half of the tribulation as being 3½ years long (Rev 12:14), 42 months long (Rev 11:2; 13:5), and
1,260 days long (11:3; 12:6) must be doubled, of course, to find the total number of years, months, and days
respectively in the total tribulation. According to John, the tribulation will last 7 years, that is 84 months, or more
precisely 2,520 days. His mathematical calculations are in full agreement with those of Daniel. As Daniel’s
foresight was fulfilled literally down to the very day, so also will be John’s insight. The time of Jesus’ return at the
end of the tribulation has been decreed with pinpoint accuracy. The elect of that time period, that is, believers
living during the tribulation, will be able to mark the exact day when Christ will return.‡ They will be able to
have absolute confidence that if they can just hold out until then, they will be saved, not only from the tribulation
but also for the millennial inheritance. Or course, Satan will know the exact day as well and will be doing
everything he possibly can to exterminate them before the termination of the tribulation. Since the time of the
Lord’s coming in Mt 24:36-44 is unknown, it cannot refer to His coming at the conclusion of the tribulation. It has
to refer to His coming at the commencement of the tribulation. It must be describing the rapture.

                                                 Summary of Phase Chart
        Jesus is referring to both the first and second phases of His coming revelation in the Mount Olivet
Discourse. Part 1 of the chart§ indicates that Jesus answers His disciples’ question from v. 3 in reverse order. He
first answers their question as to what would be the signs of His coming in vv. 3-35 before discussing when it
would occur. Since the time of His coming could be understood only in terms of signs, the sequence of His answer
is logical—what before when. After beginning His discussion of the signs in this section, He also answers their
question concerning when in this same section. In v. 15 Jesus basically says, “When you see such and such signs.”
In v. 33 He also says, “When you see” these signs. Yet having just told them in Part 1A of the chart above that they
could discern when He was coming based on certain signs, He then proceeds to tell them in Part 1B that they will
not be able to use signs to discern when He was coming. Thus, in Part B Jesus is talking about another aspect of
His coming. In light of the progressive revelation in Paul’s subsequent writings, we now know that the other aspect
of His coming that He was describing was the second phase of His coming. The claim by some dispensationalists
that Jesus cannot be describing the rapture or church age is thus refuted by the doctrine of imminency.

Phase determined by Signs
       To restate this matter again in terms of the chart in Illustration 123, in Part 1A (i.e., vv. 3-35), Jesus answers
the what and when of their question. He answers what signs would mark His return before He answers when He
will return because the only way to answer when He will return is by means of signs. Thus, Part 1A Revelation is
absolutely saturated with signs that indicate when Jesus will return. In sharp contrast, the exact opposite is true of
Part 1B Rapture (vv. 36-44). There is not one single, solitary sign anywhere in Part 1B that indicates when He will
return. In Part 1A the emphasis is that the time of His return will be known and recognized by the signs that are
seen (see esp. vv. 32-33). However, the polar opposite is true in Part 1B.


*
  See discussion of these two passages pertaining to Illustration 76. Election (eklego, ekloge, eklektos), 182.
†
  See Illustration 107. Annotated Text of Dan 9:24-27, 304.
‡
  Also see Unknown, 356.

  See Illustration 123. Modified Phase Chart of Mt. Olivet, 335.
Page 340                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
        The stress in Part 1B is that the time of His coming will be unknown. No signs will be available to indicate
His return in this section. Part 1A is dripping wet with signs of His coming, but Part 1B is bone dry; not even one
sign of His coming is provided. Thus, the obvious answer in Part 1B to the disciples’ question (in v. 3) is that there
will be no signs concerning the phase of His coming being referred to in Part 1B.
        Part 1A is like driving on an interstate that has sign after sign after sign telling you when you will reach your
destination. Part 1B is like a dirt road out in the country that does not have any signs anywhere indicating when
you will reach your destination. Only some of the local residents who live in the area even know the dirt road
exists, much less how long it is. Likewise, only one heavenly resident knows how long the road is in Part 1B—the
Father. Only the Father knows when you will reach the end of the road in Part 1B. And He did not put even one
sign on it.
        The fact that Jesus discusses the second phase of His return first does not indicate a posttribulational
rapture. To describe this phase first is not the same thing as affirming that it comes first. Rather, the Lord simply
describes the second phase first because that is the phase that will be indicated by signs and associated with the
desolation of the temple, which was foremost on their minds. This explains Part 1 of Illustration 123. Modified
Phase Chart of Mt. Olivet.

Answering Multiple Questions
        Concerning the relationship of Part 1 to Part 2, the second part of the phase chart indicates that in this
section Jesus is answering another question. The Lukan parallel in Lk 17:26-37 makes it clear that on this earlier
occasion, He also said that one would be taken and one would be left. In response the disciples had asked,
“Where?” Jesus’ response on that occasion was, “Where the body is, there also will the vultures be gathered” In
other words, on that occasion when asked where they would be taken and left, Jesus cryptically had indicated that
they would be taken and left to judgment. Likewise, when He presents this same material later in Mt 24:36-41, they
surely would recall that when He had presented this material before and His vulture answer then. His answer to
“where” had been, “Where the body is, there also will the vultures be gathered.” However, the disciples surely will
notice that this time, instead of answering their question in that manner, He answers it in Mt 24:42-44 with another
still somewhat cryptic comparison—of a thief in the night.
        They probably were wondering by this time why the Lord was comparing His coming to vultures and a
thief. Was He the vulture? Was He the thief? Was there not a more positive image that He could give of Himself in
regard to His coming? However, unlike the previous occasion in Lk 17, this time Jesus does not end His answer as
to where they would be taken with the inscrutable comparison. Instead, He gives four parables that serve as a
commentary on Mt 24:42-44 and thus on its parallel passage in Lk 17:37. Since these four parables are a
commentary on Mt 24:42-44, and consequently on Lk 17:37, these parables answer the disciples’ previous question
as to where they would be taken and left. Jesus’ coming judgment could be personified as vultures in its assured
nature and as a thief in its unexpected nature. Moreover, master, bridegroom, and king are the images used to
represent His personal identity. These are the images that He presents of Himself in the four explanatory parables.

Markings on Chart
        The parables in Part 2 of the chart are Jesus’ much fuller answer to His disciples’ previous where question in
Lk 17:37. In Part 2, Jesus describes the judgment of those taken and left. Those who are left will be dealt with at
the judgment that occurs at the next phase of His coming. Those who are taken are taken for the judgment that
occurs at this phase of His coming, that is, the Bema. As indicated in the chart, the parables dealing with the
judgment of those who are taken are marked with a superscript “T.” Correspondingly, the judgment of those who
are left is marked with a superscript “L.”
        In the first three parables, Jesus deals with the judgment of the elect, indicated in the chart by the use of an
asterisk (*). Thus, the asterisk in Part 2 indicates that in these first three parables Jesus is contrasting the judgment
of the faithful elect (i.e., believers of that time period) with the unfaithful elect (i.e., believers of that time period).
However, Jesus does not overlook the judgment of the nonelect (i.e., unbelievers of that time period). In the last
parable, instead of contrasting the fate of the faithful believers with the unfaithful believers, He contrasts the fate of
the faithful elect with the nonelect. For this reason, the last parable is not marked with an asterisk.

Sequential Parallelism with 1Pet 4:17-18
       Part 2 first describes the judgment associated with the rapture, then the judgment associated with the
revelation, and then it repeats this sequence—the judgment associated with the rapture is followed by the judgment
associated with revelation. The judgment of the rapture occurs first and deals with those taken. Then the judgment
Chapter 12. I Wish We’d All Been Ready?(Mt 24:36-44)                                                            Page 341
of the revelation occurs second and deals with those who are left. This sequence of judgment occurring first for
Christians is indicated in 1Pet 4:17-18, where Peter warns,

        For it is time for judgment to begin with the household of God; and if it begins with us first, what will
        be the outcome for those who do not obey the gospel of God? 18 And if it is with difficulty that the
        righteous is saved, what will become of the godless man and the sinner?*

        Commentators generally assume that the judgment referred to in 1Pet 4:17 is God’s temporal judgment, due
to the emphasis in this Petrine epistle on the temporal suffering. To prove their point, they refer to temporal testing
indicated in the very opening of the book in 1Pet 1:6-7. On the other hand, considering it an eschatological
judgment rather than a temporal judgment is much better in view of the eschatological promises Peter gives these
believers as a result of their victorious, temporal suffering in 1:6-7. On both sides of this passage concerning
temporal suffering, Peter promises overcomers the co-glorification salvation in 1:5,9—an eschatological salvation
that is earned.† The salvation in these verses is not justification by a passive response of faith; rather, salvation as a
result of living by faith is entailed. Notice how Peter uses the word judge in his epistle. In 1Pet 1:17, he warns
believers to watch their temporal conduct (i.e., their conduct on earth) in view of God’s future judgment: “And if
you address as Father the One who impartially judges according to each man’s work, conduct yourselves in fear
during the time of your stay upon earth.” Their temporal earthly performance is important because of their future
approaching eschatological judgment.
        The theme that God will judge each person (lost and saved) according to their works‡ in His future judgment
is a common NT theme.607 The judgment in 1Pet 4:5 is also futuristic: “They shall give account to Him who is
ready to judge the living and the dead.” The judgment in 1Pet 4:17 should be taken eschatologically as well: “For it
is time for judgment to begin with the household of God; and if it begins with us first, what will be the outcome
for those who do not obey the gospel of God?”
        A marked transition transpires from what is to what will be. The statement that it is time for this judgment to
begin is simply another way of stating the doctrine of imminency. This future judgment is imminent. Thus, the
passage is describing the imminent Bema, not a temporal judgment. Admittedly, commentators are correct in
identifying the difficulty in 1Pet 4:18 as referring to the temporal suffering believers are experiencing temporally:
“And if it is with difficulty that the righteous is saved, what will become of the godless man and the sinner?”
However, the salvation in this verse is a salvation that requires victorious suffering in the here and now. This
salvation is not free. Futuristic co-glorification salvation is in view. In consequence, on the basis of how Peter uses
the words judgment, salvation, and difficulty, the proper conclusion is that he is alerting believers to the fact that it
is time for the rapture and the corresponding Bema and that it is only with difficult, victorious suffering now that
Christians will experience misthological salvation then—at that future judgment.608 Jesus, like Peter, presents the
judgment of believers at the rapture followed by the judgment of unbelievers at the revelation.

                                                            Conclusion
       This passage of Scripture in Mt 26:36-44 begins with the declaration that no one except the Father knows
when Jesus will return. Even simplistic futurism admits that this statement in v. 36 applies to those living in the
present church age rather than in the future tribulation. For advocates of simplistic futurism to exclude the church
age from the Olivet Discourse is internally inconsistent. Jesus further specifies which group of believers will not
know the time of His return when He repeats to His disciples living in this present age, “You do not know which
day your Lord is coming” (24:42). Again, this lack of knowledge is only true of believers living in the church age.
Therefore, the intended address must be to believers living in the present church age. Jesus concludes this section
with yet another affirmation that His coming will be at an unexpected time (v. 44). This cannot be true of the
revelation. The passage must be dealing with the rapture and with those living in the church age.
       In surveying potential outlines, four possibilities at increasing stages of futuristic development were
demonstrated: simplistic, historical, imminent, and modified imminent futurism. Marrowistic misthology is proven
by any of the latter three options and not incompatible with the first one. However, proper eschatological
preference is for that latter view—modified imminent futurism. The coming of our Lord is imminent, even if not
immediate. Since He informs His disciples of His imminent return and tells them to be ready for it at any time, the

*
  Note the obvious implication of the principle of correlativity in this passage.
†
  See Inheritance of Salvation (1Pet 1:5) in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.

  Again note the obvious implication of the principle of correlativity in all such passages.
Page 342                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
simplistic and historical forms of futurism are ruled out. This leaves the imminent and modified imminent as the
remaining possibilities. Nevertheless, the rationale for the preference of the latter will have to be demonstrated
from the details of that parable when they are dealt with it subsequently.
                                         Chapter 13.
                                Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51)
                                                   Introduction
       This chapter will give the general reader a break from what might be perceived up to this point to be a rather
theoretical presentation. But the technical precision of the foregoing discussion was necessary to lay the foundation
for the accuracy of the following exposition. The major topics and objections to the Marrowistic position from this
passage of Scripture will be addressed. After reinforcing the foregoing comments on the time period involved in
this parable from the details therein, the misthological nature of the parable will briefly be demonstrated by a quick
review of the word portion (translated as place by the NAS below). Standard objections to NT misthology will
then be addressed pertaining to hypocrisy and love. Commonly, commentators assume that all hypocrites are lost
and that all Christians are loving. Therefore, for many the reflexive reaction to the parable below would be to think
that this unloving hypocrite is lost. Further, stock mentality dictates that serving the Lord out of a desire for
rewards is unloving and selfish. To top off superficial reflections, this parable says that this servant will weep, so
many automatically conclude that it certainly could not be describing a heavenly experience! By common consent,
the man or woman who treats his or her fellow believers in this manner will not go to heaven. However, one
problem that is immediately apparent with this reflexive reaction to the parable is that it makes one’s entrance into
heaven conditioned on how one treats other people. Salvation is no longer based on saving grace alone but on
transforming grace. From this perspective, grace that does not transform you into a wonderful, loving person has
failed to save you from hell. Within this chapter an alternative to this works-based soteriology will be presented,
and answers to the above objections will be provided.

                                                    Exposition
        What will God ultimately do with good-for-nothing children? Jesus answers this question forthrightly: “You
are the salt of the earth; but if the salt has become tasteless, how will it be made salty again? It is good for nothing
anymore, except to be thrown out and trampled under foot by men” (Mt 5:13). This passage from the Sermon on
the Mount describes what happens in the present time when a Christian becomes good for nothing. But what will
happen in the future?609 The answer to that question is found in Mt 24:45-51. In a television episode of Crime
Stoppers, a father had a good-for-nothing son. Unfortunately, the father was permissive with his son and failed to
treat his son as an accountable citizen. The son had grown up and broken the law and was hiding from the law in
his father’s house. His father lied to protect his son from the law. It resulted in the tragedy of the son killing his
father. God is not going to treat his children as that permissive father did. God will hold his children accountable as
citizens of His kingdom.

                                                         Text
       Who then is the faithful and sensible slave whom his master put in charge of his household to
       give them their food at the proper time? 46 Blessed is that slave whom his master finds so doing when
       he comes. 47 Truly I say to you, that he will put him in charge of all his possessions. 48 But if that evil
       slave says in his heart, “My master is not coming for a long time,” 49 and shall begin to beat his
       fellow slaves and eat and drink with drunkards; 50 the master of that slave will come on a day when he
       does not expect him and at an hour which he does not know, 51 and shall cut him in pieces and
       assign him a place with the hypocrites; weeping shall be there and the gnashing of teeth. (Mt 24:45-
       51)

                                                        Phase
       The rationale for understanding Mt 24:36-44 as dealing with the first phase of Jesus’ return—the rapture—
and thus with Christians was presented in the previous chapter. Among the various reasons given for adopting this
conclusion was the fact that in v. 36 the time is unknown and the passage progresses in clarity by saying that it is
not only unknown, it is also unexpected (24:42,44). The same is true in this passage (v. 50), so this passage should
be regarded as dealing with the same period of time. Yet in addition to these explicit indications of present time
and imminent coming, another subtle indication as to the time frame involved is provided in this current passage.
       In Mt 24:48, the slave does not expect his master for a long time. From the slave’s perspective, his master is
delaying his coming (NKJ). Jesus’ attitude is contrasted with that of the foolish servant. Jesus is demonstrating that
viewing His coming as delayed is very foolish in this parable. Instead, the wise thing to do is to view the time of
Page 344                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
His coming as unknown and unexpected, rather than delayed, within this pericope. Whether or not it is immediate,
it is most certainly imminent. Thus, the wise attitude is to view His coming as imminent rather than delayed. This
passage cannot be referring to the same time period as the Jewish section because in that time period His coming
truly is delayed! The Lord will delay His return until the end of the seven years. He will delay His coming until the
last day of the seventh year. In that time period, it would be foolish to expect Him until then. The reverse is true in
this time period now. In this time period today, it would be foolish not to expect Him at any time. And this is Jesus’
point. Do not consider His coming delayed in this present time period even if it is a long time off. For all we know,
it may be today. Therefore, this parable is dealing with the time period of the rapture.
        Knowing the proper time period should remove any doubt as to the meaning of the parable in Mt 24:45-51.
Since only Christians will be judged at the Bema following the rapture, this foolish slave must represent a foolish
Christian. This passage is a picture of what is going to happen to Christians at the rapture. Thus, it is a picture of
the Bema. It deals exclusively with Christians. The disciples probably did not understand the time frame Jesus had
in mind, so the Lord makes it very clear even to them, even at their level of understanding, that He is talking about
what happens to foolish believers. Thus, Keathley’s objection mentioned in the opening chapter of this book (that
the disciples did not have well developed eschatology) fails to take into account that even an immature eschatology
may be able to grasp the fundamental soteriological and misthological principles being represented parabolically.*
        In this parable, Jesus’ point is that the slave is put in charge of his master’s household and is then charged
by his master to be faithful in that responsibility so that when his master returns the slave may be put in charge of
all his master’s possessions. The Lord does not put the lost in charge of His house. Nor does the Lord promise the
lost that if they are faithful, He will put them in charge of all His possessions. This passage is talking about the
elect (i.e., believers) and giving them reason to endure, to be faithful. These multiple parables are designed to
encourage the elect (i.e., believers) to be faithful regardless of the time period in which they find themselves since
the parables deal with both time periods. This particular passage is dealing with the present time period.
        Not only does the Lord not put the nonelect (i.e., unbelievers) in charge of His house in the present, He will
not put the unfaithful elect in charge of His possessions in the future. All believers have gifts and should be
exercising them in the church, thus serving their brothers and sisters in Christ. But if believers abuse their brothers
and sisters in Christ, rather than serving them with the faithful exercise of their gifts, then such believers will not be
given even greater responsibilities in the millennial kingdom. If believers fail to handle their present tasks
responsibly, they will not be given future responsibilities eternally. Those who are unfaithful in a little thing will
not be put in charge of greater things. The result of unfaithfulness on the part of the elect is not only a failure to
receive future responsibilities; Jesus also teaches that there will be further discipline (i.e., punishment). In the
present time, God deals with us as with sons according to Heb 12:5-8. But in the future, God will judge us as
servants according to this parable. Before He can reward us as mature sons, God must judge to see if we actually
attained such maturity through faithful service. As a matter of fact, the point of both parables in Mt 24:42-51 is that
believers must be judged on the basis of their service. The unfaithful householder of vv. 42-44 is the unfaithful
servant of vv. 45-51. Two different images are used to present the same spiritual truth. Now, what will be the
results of that judgment if we have been unfaithful?
        The richest and most vivid part of the imagery is used to address this question in v. 51. What kind of
imagery does cut in pieces suggest? A similar passage in Lk 12:46-48 provides the answer. To cut in pieces is not
being used literally in Mt 24:51. This passage is a parable presenting its truth in the form of images. The image
being pictured by cutting to pieces is a flogging as is seen in Lk 12:46-48. The current writer saw his brother cut to
pieces as a result of a bike wreck. His brother was riding a bike without a shirt and jumped a three foot, dirt hill. In
doing so, he did half a flip, landed on his back in the gravel, and slid—with resulting multiple lacerations on his
back. When he managed to get up, there were strips of skin dangling here and there down his back. His back was
cut to pieces as a result of a foolish bike stunt.
        Jesus is using a metaphor to say that some Christians are going to find their backs cut to pieces as a result of
foolish service. This is His metaphorical way of saying that a negative evaluation of our service at His judgment
seat will result in more than a little slap on the wrist. It will be much more painful and serious than a minor
reprimand and result in much more than a case of the sniffles. It will resemble a lacerated back much more than it
will a slap on the wrist. The cutting to pieces is meant to be taken seriously but not literally. The metaphorical
nature of being cut in pieces or cut in two is confirmed by the imagery of the parable itself in that he is also
assigned a portion with the hypocrites. This imagery is more suitable to picturing a flogging. The fellow-servants
(i.e., angels, cp. Rev 22:9) inflicting this punishment are not parabolically pictured as killing the unfaithful servant.

*
    See Parables, 7.
Chapter 13. Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51)                                                                  Page 345
                                                      Portion
        The word translated as place in the NAS (Mt 24:51) is a very important word (meros), translated as portion
in the NKJ. It can be used to refer to an inheritance. For example, it is the same word that the younger son used in
Lk 15:12 when he asked his father to give him his inheritance. The lost, as well as carnal Christians and spiritual
Christians all have an inheritance. To summarize the discussion advanced thus far, natural men (i.e., the nonelect),
and carnal Christians (i.e., unfaithful elect), and spiritual Christians (i.e., the faithful elect) will all have their
payday.* In Rev 21:8, the natural man has his portion in hell. Hell will be his paycheck. The lost will get the same
payment that the devil gets. In Mt 24:51, Lk 12:46, Jn 13:8, and Rev 22:19, carnal Christians can lose their
inheritance (meros) with Jesus and receive one with the hypocrites instead. Having a portion in the tree of life in
Rev 22:19 is a reward for faithfulness as proven by the background for eating from the tree of life in Rev 2:7.
        Only believers who overcome (i.e., who endure to the end, who are faithful) will have the privilege of eating
from the tree and entering the city.610 The holy city represents a part of heaven, not all of heaven. Participation in
this part of heaven is forfeitable by the unfaithful. Instead of receiving the same paycheck that Jesus receives,
carnal believers will receive the payment that is given to the hypocrites. In Rev 20:6, spiritual believers will receive
the same portion (paycheck) that Jesus will receive—the privilege of reigning in heaven. Granted, carnal believers
will be in the heavenly kingdom with Jesus. They will be there with Him because entrance into the kingdom of
heaven is free; it is not a paycheck. But as Rev 20:4,6 points out, the privilege of ruling with Jesus in that kingdom
is the privilege of receiving the same paycheck as He does. It is the payment for overcoming.

                                                     Hypocrite
        The word hypocrite (hupokrites) should be easy enough to understand. The word means to pretend to be
something you are not, to say one thing and do another, to be one thing and live like you are something else. The
word was used to describe actors on stage. They put on an act. It means to act differently from what you really are.
For example, you could play the role of an animal or person. If you act like a pig, you are a hypocrite. You are
acting like something you are not. If a man acts like a woman, he is a hypocrite. He is acting like something he is
not. This is the historical background of the word hypocrite.
        The common assumption is that the slave is pretending to be a Christian. This interpretation is wrong. The
slave is not pretending to belong to his master; the slave is not pretending to have been put in charge of his
master’s house. The slave is not pretending to have fellow slaves. On the contrary, the slave really does belong to
his master. His master really has put him in charge of his household. Those whom this slave mistreats really are his
fellow slaves. He has the same identical relationship to the master as they do. As far as position goes, he is
genuinely his master’s slave. He genuinely holds the position of servant. But what he is in position and what he is
in practice are worlds apart. The same is true of many Christians. Their practice does not match their position.
They are hypocrites. This man was a servant, but he acted like he was not a servant. Likewise, many Christians are
the Lord’s servants but act as if they are not. Such Christians are saved but act like they are not saved.
        To be sure, the word hypocrite can be used to describe non-Christians. They can pretend they are Christians
when they are not. In such cases, their practice does not match their position. They do not have the position of
servant, yet they act like they do. Yet this type of hypocrisy is the exact opposite of what is being described in this
passage. His practice in this passage does not match his position for the opposite reason. He has the position but
not the practice. Lost people, on the other hand, inversely may have the practice but not the position. Lost
people may act like they are in Christ, but they are not in Christ. They are hypocrites since they act like they do
have this position. Saved people, on the other hand, may act like they are not in Christ even though they are in
Christ. They are hypocrites since they act like they do not have this position. In this parable, Jesus presents the
picture of a man who genuinely has the position but not the practice—a man who is saved positionally but who
fails to act like it practically. Christians who act like non-Christians are hypocrites.
        When the NT was written, it was recognized that genuine believers can be hypocrites. In Mt 7:5, Jesus said
that believers who ignore their own sin while judging their brother’s sin are guilty of hypocrisy. Indeed, this
parable in Mt 24:45-51 probably represents this very action. In Mt 24:49, we see that, although this slave is guilty
of sin, he beats his fellow slaves. Why did he beat them? He was probably looking for the speck in their service to
the master. He beat them for the speck in their service and ignored the log in his own service. When his master
returned, the master did exactly what He said he would do in Mt 7:1-5—he judged the worthless slave in the same
manner the worthless slave had judged his fellow slaves. This evil slave had begun to beat his fellow slaves, so his

*
    See Illustration 49. Three Portions, 108.
Page 346                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
master had him beaten in return. As Jesus said in 7:2, in the way you judge, you will be judged. In this parable,
Jesus illustrates that truth.
       Can genuine believers be hypocrites? Of course, they can. Jesus warned believers, who had God as their
Father, not to be hypocrites (Mt 6:2,5,16). Jesus’ half-brother, James, was concerned about hypocrisy among the
believers to whom he wrote (Jam 3:17). Paul likewise recognized the reality of hypocrisy among the regenerate
(Rom 12:9). Barnabas and Peter were genuine believers, yet Paul said that on one occasion both Barnabas and
Peter were being hypocrites (Gal 2:13). These regenerate hypocrites joined the non-regenerate hypocrites in their
hypocrisy, and Paul rebuked Peter to his face. Peter learned from that experience, and later he urged the genuine
believers not to be hypocrites (1Pet 2:1-2). Peter knew from his personal experience that genuine believers can be
hypocrites, and he wanted to spare these believers that experience.
       Peter had been warned by Jesus that it is possible for believers to be hypocrites and mistreat one another, as
seen below in Illustration 124. Parallels to Mt 24:45-51. The parallel in Lk 12:41-48 is particularly strong. The
introductory aspect of its context (Lk 12:35-40), like the Mt. Olivet Discourse, uses the imagery of lamps, a
wedding feast, an unexpected thief, and an unknown hour to urge believers today to be ready (i.e., to be faithful) in
view of the Lord’s imminent return in the rapture and the JSC which follows. From a dispensational perspective,
this could only be referring to the judgment of believers. The previous Matthean parable in Mt 18:21-35, like the
other two parables, also uses the imagery of an unworthy slave being unprepared for his master’s return to
represent believers who are not faithful.

                                                    Addressees
       That the warnings are intended for genuine believers is evident within each text. In Mt 18:21,35, it is
important to notice who asks the question in v. 21 that initiates the parable. It is Peter, a genuine believer. One
must also note to whom the warning of the parable is addressed in v. 35. It is addressed to you. Thus, it is
addressed to Peter, along with other believers. The intended application of this parable is to those who already are
saved, thus to the elect. This fact is also clearly indicated by the details of the parable. This parable deals with the
king of the kingdom and the king’s slaves. These slaves actually have the position of being slaves regardless of
Chapter 13. Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51)                                                                 Page 347
whether their practice indicates their true position. Positionally, they are servants of the king and kingdom (thus
servant = saved).* The same is true of the wicked slave. The wicked slave’s sins are forgiven (Mt 18:27).

                                         Four Types of Vertical Forgiveness
       All Christians have received judicial forgiveness of their sins. This judicial forgiveness is dependent solely
upon a response of faith, not upon a life of faithfulness, not upon confession of their sins, nor upon forgiving
others. It is a vertical forgiveness in that it deals with their relationship with God. But filial forgiveness is a
secondary vertical forgiveness that is conditioned upon various things, such as confession (1Jn 1:9).† As to the
relationship between the two, judicial forgiveness makes filial forgiveness possible, not automatic. God must first
become our Father before He can forgive us as our Father. God must first become our Father before He can grant
us Fatherly forgiveness.
       A brother can forgive his little niece if she accidently spills milk on the carpet while spending the night in
his house. Even though he has no trouble forgiving her, especially since she is his brother’s daughter, he is, in point
of fact, regardless of sentiment, forgiving her as his brother’s daughter, not as his own daughter. But suppose his
brother and his brother’s wife were killed in a car wreck, and out of love the remaining brother adopted his little
niece so that she could live with him and his family and be loved as one of his own children. If she then spilt milk
on the family carpet, she would still be forgiven. But now she is forgiven as a member of the family. The change in
legal status has made it possible for him to now forgive her, in point of fact, as one of his own children. Oh, to be
sure, he knew of her propensity to spill milk even before he adopted her. But he already had decided ahead of time
that he would forgive her whenever she spilt the milk. He is not going to disown the daughter of his dead brother,
whom he loved so much, even when his little girl spills the milk or drops a piece of meat on the floor. (Some
Christians have trouble with milk, let alone meat!) That little girl is already forgiven of any sin she could possibly
commit in terms of relationship. And that relationship is now the basis from which she is forgiven in terms of
fellowship any time she sins.
       Just so, our Father has adopted us for Jesus’ sake. Our adoption, based on Jesus’ death for us, makes our
Father’s love for us certain. Legally, our Father unconditionally forgives us for the sake of His beloved Son who
died for us: “He delivered us from the domain of darkness, and transferred us to the kingdom of His beloved Son,
in whom we have redemption, the forgiveness of sins” (Col 1:13-14). This was a permanent transfer, not a
temporary silo. Only God has the power to perform this transfer. But could the little girl not grow up and despise
her adoptive father, take him to court, and have the court nullify the adoption, even if her adoptive father loved her
and would never dream of disowning her? After all, there are Christians who have trampled underfoot the blood of
Christ by which they soteriologically were sanctified (Heb 10:29). Yes, a little girl could do that in our crazy,
worldly court system.
       Perhaps she got an offer from a rich, childless man in the community who wanted to adopt her. And she was
willing to cash in her adoptive father’s love for a new, richer dad. (Does Satan not offer, through an endless
barrage of materialistic commercials, to take us under his arms, supposedly as a loving father wanting us to have
the best of what the world has to offer?) Perhaps our courts would rule in her favor and decide that it was in her
best interest to live in a financially well-supported environment than with her current dad—a poor,
fundamentalistic preacher. She might complain to the courts about the outdated views and strict standards of her
fundamentalistic father, and the courts might lend a sympathetic ear. Never in her wildest dreams did she imagine
that what the new, sportier dad wanted was to enslave her (cf. Rom 6:16; 2Pet 2:19). But now the sad reality is that
he has seduced her into becoming his, and now she, like him, is enslaved to a perverted lust that will eventually kill
both of them.
       Are there no breaks that we biblically can apply to stop this Arminian insanity? Yes, there are. There is no
court system to which we can appeal that can override God! When your Father is the Supreme court, there is no
taking your Father to court. As Philip Evans has well illustrated:

               Someone might then make the challenge, “Your son could nullify his adoption and have himself
          legally severed from you.” This is true, but to do this he would have to go to the court system, an
          authority higher than I. Guess what? There is no greater authority than God. It is impossible for a
          child to “un-adopt” himself out of God’s family.611

    See Believers Are Called Slaves, 374.
†
    See “Filial Forgiveness” in Trichotomy.
Page 348                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
       Judicial forgiveness is the primary form of vertical forgiveness because judicial forgiveness is irreversible
and because judicial forgiveness makes the secondary form of vertical forgiveness (i.e., family forgiveness)
possible. Even those believers who rise to great heights and then plummet back through the various higher levels of
vertical forgiveness will be caught in the underlying safety net of judicial forgiveness and have their lives saved
from hell. Arminian arguments that we can ontologically commit spiritual suicide, or legally un-adopt ourselves, or
soteriologically transfer ourselves back into darkness fail when the facts are considered. The life we were given is
eternal life. We do not have the power to kill it. Nor do we have the power to undo the adoption by which we were
legally transferred into God’s family. Sin, Satan, and self are limited in the damage they can inflict. Nevertheless,
the damage that they can inflict is significant.
                                     Illustration 125. Four Planes of Forgiveness




        Jesus conditions this secondary vertical forgiveness (i.e., fellowship forgiveness) on horizontal forgiveness
in the two verses following the Model Prayer in Mt 6:9-15. Jesus teaches believers that whether we forgive others
horizontally here on earth does, in fact, determine whether our Father who is in heaven will forgive us vertically.
Thus, our horizontal forgiveness of one another is necessary for filial forgiveness and fellowship with our Father.
Horizontal forgiveness does not determine if God is our Father, but it is a condition for fellowship with our Father.
Evans illustrates: “As my son is growing up, if he is rebellious and hateful towards me, he will not be my friend,
but he will always remain my child….I would not disown him if he refused to do so [to be my friend].”612 It is a
sad commentary on Arminian theology, as Evans points out, that conditional security, in effect, pictures God’s love
as being inferior to the unconditional, relational, parental love that He has inspired in us. Sure, there is a friendship
love that is conditional from our Father. Still, it flows from the unconditional, soteriological love that He already
has granted us as our Judge. The conditional, temporal forgiveness that we experience as God’s children is
dependent on how we deal with others, particularly our spiritual brothers. A Fatherly forgiveness rather than a
judicial forgiveness is in view.

        Even though filial forgiveness is a form of vertical temporal forgiveness, the term temporal forgiveness
will be reserved for those occasions when God temporally decides to withhold punishment.* The former does not
guarantee the latter. Just because God grants filial forgiveness, it does not necessarily follow that He has or will
grant temporal forgiveness, as seen in the tragic case of David losing his child and not being able to remove the
sword from being upon his house even after he experienced filial forgiveness (2Sam 12:10-15). Not only is our
filial and temporal forgiveness dependent upon forgiving our fellow believers, our misthological forgiveness is
also dependent upon our obedience in forgiving our fellow believers.† If we do not forgive, then the misthological
consequences will be severe. We are not literal slaves, we are not given ten thousand literal talents, and we are not
literally handed over to literal torturers. The parable is using pictorial language. Nevertheless, the picture it
presents is that the consequences of poor service will be severe.
        James also describes this same truth didactically rather than parabolically in Jam 2:13.‡ He urges believers
to show mercy because judgment will be merciless to believers who show no mercy. Believers are not
automatically merciful as is seen by the need for the warning. The fact that James is talking about the judgment of
believers is stated again in Jam 3:1, where he warns that Christian teachers will receive a stricter judgment. He
makes it clear that some believers will experience stricter judgment. Also, compare his comments in Jam 5:9,12.
The people James is warning about the seriousness of judgment are not the lost but the saved, the brethren.
Believers are in danger of the merciless judgment in Jam 2:13. Although this judgment has its temporal dimension,
the primary and ultimate expression of this judgment is its eschatological dimension as is seen in Jam 5:8-9. The
judgment that believers will experience when the Lord comes again is entailed. Thus, this judgment takes place at
the time of the rapture and at the Judgment Seat of Christ. James understood Jesus’ parable; so should we.

                                           Not All Believers are Loving
       Now, back to the parable in Mt 24:45-51. After the slave lost his love, he next lost his self-control. All
Christians are sealed with the Spirit (Eph 1:13), but not all Christians are filled with the Spirit (Eph 5:18).
Therefore, not all Christians have the fruit of the Spirit, which is love and self-control (Gal 5:22-23). Believers who
are sealed by the Spirit can quench, grieve, and insult the Holy Spirit (1Thess 5:19; Eph 4:30; Heb 10:29). Grieving
the Spirit will not cause Him to leave since His sealing means that He is the down payment for the day of
redemption (cf. Eph 1:13-14; 4:30).§ Although grieving Him cannot prevent the eschatological fulfillment of
redemption, grieving Him will, nevertheless, bring very serious eschatological consequences, such as having one’s
inheritance with the other hypocritical believers who pretend to be serving the Lord when they actually were
serving only themselves.

                                                    Tears in Heaven
       The result of disobedience on the part of God’s children will be weeping and gnashing of teeth. When my
children were young, I saw my own little boy weep and gnash his teeth on occasions. Of course, the fact that he
wept and gnashed his teeth did not prove that he was not my son. It merely demonstrated that something happened
that he did not like. Some people may think that this passage cannot describe a believer since they think that there
will be no tears in heaven. Four possible answers might be made to this objection. (1) The weeping and gnashing of
teeth might not be literal since this is parabolic material. (2) The weeping and gnashing of teeth might be very
temporary since Jesus will wipe the tears away. (3) The wiping away of tears may indicate that the tears will be
limited to the millennium. (4) The wiping away of tears might be promised to faithful servants and not promised to
unfaithful servants, in which case it is reasonable to assume that those who have been unfaithful will weep. This
fourth position has the most to commend it.**

                                                Who Is Put In Charge
       The parable of Mt 24:45-51 is talking about believers. The Lord does not put unbelievers in charge of
believers. Oh, to be sure, some lost hypocrites take the position of pastor. They are lost but pretend to be saved. But
this parable is not about them. The intended application of this parable is for those whom the Lord makes
overseers of His flock. Hypocrites may fool people, but they do not fool the Lord. He only calls believers to this

position. Jesus’ intended application is concerning believers and the two contrasting fates that believers may
experience. This fact is also evidenced by the phase of His coming that Jesus is referring to in this parable in
Mt 24:45-51. The rapture is in view since His coming is imminent. The thief imagery in Lk 12:39 already has been
noted, plus the fact that this coming is unexpected in Lk 12:40,46. Thus, the parable is dealing with the judgment
that takes place as a result of the rapture. Since the rapture only involves believers, this parable is talking about the
judgment of believers.

Unbelieving Judas
        Those who prefer the soteriological interpretation may wish to counter the Marrowist position by pointing
out that Judas was appointed by the Lord to do His work. Thus, they might claim that the slave who was put in
charge could represent a lost person entrusted by the Lord. In support of this objection, let it be further noted that
not all of Jesus’ disciples were saved.613
       64
         But there are some of you who do not believe. For Jesus knew from the beginning who they were
       who did not believe, and who it was that would betray Him. 65 And He was saying, “For this reason I
       have said to you, that no one can come to Me, unless it has been granted him from the Father.” 66 As a
       result of this many of His disciples withdrew, and were not walking with Him anymore. (Jn 6:64-66)
