        Many withdrew from following Jesus; some of them were unbelievers. But Judas was among those
unbelievers who chose to stay with Jesus. Obviously, Jesus did not require His followers to be believers; rather, He
allowed them to follow in hopes that they would come to faith. A disciple was a pupil, a student, a learner. The
Lord’s evangelistic invitation for His followers to become believers was available even to Judas. By allowing all
those who are interested to follow Him, Jesus not only extended an evangelistic invitation to them, He also allows
us to see how to deal with false believers in Christian service. There were tares in Jesus’ ranks as He sought to
minister, and there are tares in our ranks as we seek to minister. The problem of false, counterfeit believers is a
reality we must face practically, theologically, and sometimes daily.
        On the other hand, both a fundamental similarity and difference is evident between the inclusion of Judas in
the Lord’s work then and that of false teachers now. The similarity is obvious in that just as Judas was permitted in
this group of followers so that Scripture could be fulfilled, so tares will be permitted into our numbers in
fulfillment of the many warnings of Scripture in effect today. What happened in Jesus’ ministry finds its
typological counterpart in ours. However, there is a major distinguishing characteristic between the type and
antitype, between what happened then and what is happening now. In order for tares, such as Judas, to be included
at all levels of His earthly ministry, Jesus actively had to permit this to occur. He had to choose someone whom He
knew would reject Him. But with the cessation of His physical ministry and physical presence, He no longer
Chapter 13. Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51)                                                                  Page 351
actively or physically has to choose someone who is lost to be in His service in order for them to slip into the
ranks. These false believers would not be able to fool Him, but they can fool the church. False converts do slip into
the church, and the Lord does permit it, but He does not ordain it. In the parable of the tares, Jesus alludes to these
principles.

Tares Sown By Enemy
     24
        He presented another parable to them, saying, “The kingdom of heaven may be compared to a man
     who sowed good seed in his field. 25 But while men were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed tares
     also among the wheat, and went away. 26 But when the wheat sprang up and bore grain, then the tares
     became evident also. 27 And the slaves of the landowner came and said to him, ‘Sir, did you not sow
     good seed in your field? How then does it have tares?’ 28 And he said to them, ‘An enemy has done
     this!’” (Mt 13:24-28)

       First, it must be stressed that the sower only sows good seed in his field. Correspondingly, Jesus is
indicating that He will only actively appoint genuine believers in the future mystery form* of His kingdom when
He is no longer present on earth during the church age. The Lord is doing more than simply teaching that the
kingdom will be delayed, He is imparting some vital kingdom information as to what will happen during that
delay. Secondly, while the sower and his men are sleeping, his enemy sows the tares. Likewise, Jesus and His
angelic forces passively will permit the devil to slip false believers into the Christian ranks. Still, Jesus refuses to
take any blame for actively having sown bad seed in the future, mystery form of His kingdom during the church
age. The sower categorically denies that the presence of the tares in the field is attributable to him. He most
emphatically did not put them there. True, he actively could have prevented it by hiring armed guards to keep a
constant watch over the field. But this would have been an abnormal security measure and is thus not chosen. Had
God chosen to do so, He could have positioned angels around the local church and had His angels kill anyone who
made a false profession of faith and thus exercised sovereign authority in preventing tares from entering His field.
Obviously, He has not chosen to exercise sovereign authority in this capacity. (Those who complain about
hypocrites in the church should think a little more carefully about the alternatives. The presence of tares in the field
provided no excuse for refusing to be wheat in the field.) At the same time, the Lord refuses to take responsibility
for the presence of the tares in His field, so we should not try to make Him responsible for the false professions in
our local assemblies. False converts may creep in, but the Lord does not bring them in, much less put them in
charge.
       In conclusion, the unfaithful servant in the Lord’s ministry during the church age represents someone
appointed by the Lord in the future mystery form of His kingdom. His Lord put him in charge. To claim that such a
servant is lost is to accuse the Lord of planting bad seed in His kingdom. It is to charge Him with doing something
that He has already indicated that He would not do. He will not sow bad seed (i.e., unbelievers) in His kingdom
during the church age. The presence of unregenerate hypocrites in the church is attributed to Satan, not to the Lord.
As to regenerate hypocrites, some of His seed will not produce the results they should, but such seeds are still
fundamentally not tares. Since the servant is put in charge by his Lord in the future church age, he must represent a
regenerate believer.

                                          Two Different Fates of One Slave
        To integrate the ongoing discussion in this chapter with that of the parable of the unfaithful servant and its
parallels in the chart,† Mt 24:45-51 is not talking about the fate of two different slaves. It is talking about two
different fates of one slave. This is made very clear in the parallel passage in Lk 12:41-48. Peter again puts forth a
question that sparks off the parable by asking in effect, “Lord are you warning us believers about being properly
dressed, having bright lamps, and being ready when you return in Lk 12:35-40?” Jesus’ answer shows that He is
indeed warning believers and especially believers to whom He gives positions of authority over other believers.
The Lord has gifted some believers as teachers and called them to serve as pastors. They will be judged very
strictly (cf. Jam 3:1).
        As to the fact that the passage is describing two different fates for the same slave rather than two different
fates for two different slaves, one carefully should notice the significance of the designation that slave in Mt 24:45.
It is the same slave that was put in charge in Mt 24:42 and the same slave described in Mt 24:43-44. Verses 43-44

*
    For mystery form of the kingdom, see Illustration 147. Forms of the Kingdom, 436.
†
    See Illustration 124. Parallels to Mt 24:45-51, 346.
Page 352                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
describe one possible fate for that slave. Verses 45ff describe a different fate for that slave. The passage is
presenting two different possible outcomes for one and the same slave. How many slaves are there? One. This is
not only indicated by the expression that slave but also by the use of the word begins in v. 45. He becomes evil
when he begins to do these things. Verse 45 is dealing with what that slave may begin to do. He begins to mistreat
his fellow slaves. This is not something that he does initially. He only does so after he loses his sense of
imminency and accountability. Initially, he was faithful and sensible. This is why the Lord put him in charge in the
first place. The reason the Lord put him in charge in v. 42 was not merely because he was His slave. To the
contrary, this particular slave had been tested and proven faithful and sensible, and as a result, his master put him
in charge of other slaves. The corresponding passage in 1Tim 3 (esp. v. 10) comes readily to mind. Elders and
deacons must first be tested and found to be faithful and sensible before they are given their positions. Yet just
because they are believers and are faithful before they are put in charge, this does not mean that they will continue
to be faithful after they are put in charge. Although they had passed the test described earlier in 1Tim 3, they may
fail it later.

                                        Misthological Suffering in Heaven
       These parables deal with this very possibility of believers becoming unfaithful. As a result, these believers
will experience severe misthological consequences. Phillips translates these passages in Mt 24:51 and Lk 12:47
very well. The expression, “cut him in pieces” is rendered as, “punish him severely,” and “receive many lashes” is
translated as, “be severely punished.”614 This translation accurately conveys the thought of the passage without
being excessively wooden. Although BDAG says that the word for cut (dichotomeo) could be used literally to refer
to dismembering a condemned person, it acknowledges that a metaphorical usage in Mt 24:51 and Lk 12:46
meaning “‘to punish with utmost severity’ has been suggested” by other lexicons. That Jesus is using a figure of
speech is evident since not even lost people are literally cut to pieces or dismembered. That the Lord is using the
word in a metaphorical sense rather than literal sense is made especially clear in Lk 12:46-48 where it is equated
with a flogging. Unfaithful believers will be punished misthologically.*

                                                           Unfaithful
        The NTME also accurately translates apistos as unfaithful in v. 46 rather than as unbeliever. This Greek
word means faithless, which in turn can mean without faith or without faithfulness depending on the context.
Therefore, whether apistos is translated as unbeliever or unfaithful depends on the linguistic context. In this
passage, it means unfaithful. The reason this slave is judged negatively is because he was unfaithful. The problem
was not that he did not believe in his master. That has nothing to do with the parable. The problem was not that he
did not believe his master would return. In Lk 12:45 Jesus makes it expressly clear that the slave did believe his
master would return. For these reasons, and the additional contextual indicators already mentioned, it must be
concluded that the majority of the translations are wrong in translating this word as unbeliever (at least in the
soteriological sense) in this particular context. Such a translation more likely reflects the theology of the translators
rather than the meaning of the word. In contrast, Arndt’s Lutheran commentary and Hendriksen’s Presbyterian
commentary are commendable in this aspect. Both commentators translate apistos as unfaithful.615 To their credit,
they did not allow their theology to cloud their judgment when translating the word on this occasion.
        The word apistos is the same word pistos, translated in Lk 12:42 as faithful, with a negative prefix a added
to it (called an alpha privative). In Lk 12:46 it has the negative prefix a which makes it mean unfaithful.† One
would think that since the translators correctly translated the word pistos as faithful in v. 42 that they would have
correctly translated apistos (i.e., unpistos) as unfaithful in v. 46, especially in view of the contrast in the context.
Sadly, most translations fail their English readers in this matter, however.616 Wilkin concurs:

       The last word in verse 46, apistos in Greek, is translated as “the unbelievers” in many versions (NKJ,
       KJV, NIV, NAS). However, it could also be translated “the unfaithful.” In fact, it is translated that
       way in the Revised Standard Version. That, in my estimation is a better translation. Support for this
       translation is found at the beginning of the parable: “Who then is the faithful and wise steward…?
       The issue from the start is faithfulness, not faith.617


*
  See Misthological Punishment (p. 672) for a concise discussion from an entire chapter devoted to defending the thesis that believers
can be punished. For a list of passages that teach the punishment of believers, see Illustration 230, 680.
†
  See Alpha Privative, 867.
Chapter 13. Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51)                                                                                     Page 353
        The translation of unfaithful is also consistent with the teaching of the NT that believers may be unfaithful
and thus suffer misthological punishment. In 1Cor 3:11-15, Paul explicitly teaches that some believers will
experience misthological suffering in heaven as a result of the JSC. “If any man’s work is burned up, he shall
suffer loss; but he himself shall be saved, yet so as through fire” (1Cor 3:15). Although the nature and duration of
this suffering is debated, the reality of this suffering should be accepted. It is biblical. As Alcorn states concerning
this verse: “Paul spoke of loss of reward as a great and terrible loss. The fact that we are still saved is only a
clarification, not a consolation.”618 In 2Cor 5:10, Paul also says that some believers will be recompensed in like
kind for the bad and good they do. In other words, if they do bad on earth, they will reap bad consequences in
heaven. He also indicated the same thing in Col 3:25: “For he who does wrong will receive the consequences of the
wrong which he has done, and that without partiality.” The didactical and parabolic material are in full agreement.
The parables are pictures of this misthological suffering that unfaithful believers will experience in heaven.* The
doctrine pictured by the outer darkness is not limited to three parables.
        Contrary to the stated preference herein for the translation of unfaithful in this context, Pagenkemper finds
this translation difficult to accept, noting that all the commentators he consulted concur in their preference for the
rendition of unbeliever and that this is the predominant usage in the NT.619 (Evidently, he had not consulted Arndt
or Hendriksen.) However, it is possible to adopt the translation of unbelievers but understand this term
misthologically. The NIBC does just that by defining them as unbelievers in terms of misthological unbelief:
“Unbelievers are those who did not take seriously the consequences of judgment (2Cor. 5:10; Rev. 3:11).”620 The
NIBC also proceeds to equate the beating with many stripes in the next verse as applicable to believers and cites
2Cor 5:10 in support. In other words, it is possible to take the passage as referring to genuine believers who do not
believe the Bema is a serious matter and who fail to prepare for it. Such soteriological believers are misthological
unbelievers. Certainly, one would not expect believers who take the Bema seriously to live in the manner described
in this passage. The soteriological believers who behave in this manner are most likely misthological unbelievers.
Their portion is with other soteriological believers who are misthological unbelievers. Faith in Christ will
soteriologically save Christians from hell, but a life that reflects a lack of belief in the seriousness of the Bema will
not save such believers from the outer darkness. Misthological faith is indeed very important, and misthological
disbelief is equally reprehensible. Those who believe in a Toothless Bema are misthological unbelievers. And some
of these misthological unbelievers have a tendency to berate those of their fellow servants who believe in a
punitive Bema.†
        The writer of Hebrews uses the feminine form of apistos (i.e., apistia) as a warning to believers about a
heart condition that they themselves could develop: “Take care, brethren, lest there should be in any one of you an
evil, unbelieving heart, in falling away from the living God” (Heb 3:12). And he warns of the misthological
consequences: “And so we see that they were not able to enter because of unbelief” (Heb 3:19). Soteriological
believers, who are misthological unbelievers (apeitheo), will not be able to enter the misthological rest of
Heb 3:18.621 Unbelieving believers do exist in Scripture. In fact, the Scripture uses apistia to describe one: “I do
believe; help my unbelief” (Mk 9:24).
        The term unbelieving believers may be used in a variety of ways. The term may describe someone who has
belief mixed with unbelief over a single issue (such as the healing of one’s son in the example above). Or it may be
used to refer to belief mixed with unbelief over separate issues (such as salvation from hell versus rewards in
heaven). Soteriological believers who are misthological disbelievers would be a case in point. The writer of

*
  See Misthological Punishment (p. 672) for a concise discussion from a entire chapter devoted to defending the thesis that believers

  Pro-Awards is a less pejorative term for the Toothless Bema. See PA (Pro-Awards) Arguments, 657. Nevertheless, at the very least,

Warning to Soteriologists, 959. Therefore, the pejorative term serves a useful purpose. In counter distinction, and as noted in my
introduction, my view of the Bema has teeth in it. So some in the opposing camp might want, in turn, to describe my position as the
Toothy Bema, though that will probably be too mild for their taste. My view of the Bema does not merely grin. Perhaps they will find
Fanged Bema a more useful term to describe their distaste for the Pro-Judgment or Punitive Bema model taken in the present book. If
such descriptive titles help, perhaps their view might be dubbed the Pat-on-the-Back Bema and mine the Slap-in-the-Face Bema. Yet,
to be more biblical, my view might be described better, in that case, as the Stripes-on-the-Back Bema (Lk 12:47-48). I am open to such
terms as being useful to convey the emotive force of the biblical text and am confident that my Stripes-on-the-Back view will be found
more biblical than their Pat-on-the-Back alternative. The Bible does not mince words and neither should we when it comes to
accurately portraying the power of the images used by the biblical writers to depict the solemn nature of the Bema for those who have
not prepared for it. Speak the truth in love, yes, but do not soften the biblical text beyond what was intended by the biblical writers. To
be sure, we do not want to add to the emotive force of the biblical text, yet taking away from the emotive force of the text is just as ill-
advised (Rev 22:18-19).
Page 354                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
Hebrews is dealing, in part, with this problem. Moreover, this misthological disbelief could lead to soteriological
disbelief (i.e., apostasy) “in falling away from the living God” (Heb 3:12). Even so, the person who formerly
believed (soteriologically) remains classified as a believer (soteriologically) even though he no longer
soteriologically believes. Such punctiliar appropriation results in a linear classification.* Having believed, such a
person remains classified as a believer. So here are three potential ways a Christian could be classified as an
unbelieving believer.622

                                                        Conclusion
        In considering the time period of the current parable, it was concluded from the details of the pericope that
the parable must be referring to the initial phase of Jesus’ coming (i.e., the rapture) since the Lord’s coming is
imminent and unexpected and the time is unknown. The disciples did not need to have a well-developed
eschatology in order to be able to adequately perceive these basic constituent aspects of His coming as being
described in this parable.
        That the person is a believer is proven by the facts: the Lord puts him in charge; the time period indicates
that the Bema judgment is in view; his portion may be understood misthologically; believers may be hypocrites in
their practice; the warning is addressed to believers; the king’s slaves evidently are used to represent the saved
(those whose sins have been forgiven); and Christians can be (or in this case can become) unloving. The parable
pictures an unfaithful, unloving believer who suffers a cutting to pieces, which is depicted as a flogging in a
parallel passage. It refers to suffering severe misthological consequences.
        The doctrine of rewards is used in the NT to encourage believers to love, so it is quite compatible with NT
teaching in general to understand this parable as having the same misthological function. Contrary to the popular
opinion that the desire for rewards reflects improper aspiration, rewards can be used as a motive purifier. Although
fuller discussion of the tears in heaven was relegated to a subsequent discussion,† it was evident in this preliminary
discussion that there are at least four plausible misthological responses that could be implemented in defense of a
misthological perspective. The counterargument based on the example of Judas being put in charge was likewise
not found persuasive as an argument to indicate that the Lord puts false believers in charge of His work today.
Further, the idea that Jesus puts false believers in charge of His work was refuted also by the parable of the tares.
There is no reason to believe that the Lord puts unbelievers in charge within His church. The Lord may permit it,
but He does not actively endorse it. Rather, the present parable shows the Lord putting faithful believers in charge,
who then may, in time, become unloving, unfaithful, and perhaps even unbelieving. These unfaithful believers will
be punished misthologically.




*
  See Singular Versus Plural Fruit, 621. Also see “Substantival Categorization” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis
from the Gospel of John.
†
  See Part 6. Misthological Context (Tears, 479).
                                          Chapter 14.
                              Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)
                                                   Introduction
       As previously noted, this parable is perhaps the most difficult one for dispensationalists to agree upon in
regard to the time frame in view. The author at one time held to the imminent view of the rapture in this parable but
subsequently modified his chronological charting of Olivet so that this section is now regarded as dealing with the
second phase of Christ’s coming rather than the first one. Doing so will by no means rule out an application to
present believers. Nevertheless, proper application should flow from proper interpretation, and it is to the
interpretation that the major part of this discussion will be devoted. This focus will help further resolve the riddle
that plagues dispensationalists as to who will repopulate the millennial kingdom. It will also pave the way for the
next parable in which the term outer darkness actually is implemented within the Olivet Discourse.

                                                         Text
       1
        Then the kingdom of heaven will be comparable to ten virgins, who took their lamps, and went out
       to meet the bridegroom. 2 And five of them were foolish, and five were prudent. 3 For when the foolish
       took their lamps, they took no oil with them, 4 but the prudent took oil in flasks along with their
       lamps. 5 Now while the bridegroom was delaying, they all got drowsy and began to sleep. 6 But at
       midnight there was a shout, “Behold, the bridegroom! Come out to meet him.” 7 Then all those
       virgins rose, and trimmed their lamps. 8 And the foolish said to the prudent, “Give us some of your
       oil, for our lamps are going out.” 9 But the prudent answered, saying, “No, there will not be enough
       for us and you too; go instead to the dealers and buy some for yourselves.” 10 And while they were
       going away to make the purchase, the bridegroom came, and those who were ready went in with him
       to the wedding feast; and the door was shut. 11 And later the other virgins also came, saying, “Lord,
       lord, open up for us.” 12 But he answered and said, “Truly I say to you, I do not know you.” 13 Be on
       the alert then, for you do not know the day nor the hour. (Mt 25:1-13)

                                                        Time

Tote
        The very first word of this parable, then (tote), seems to indicate that another time period is in view, that is,
the next time period. Gaebelein argues otherwise by saying that it simply means in “the same period of time,” thus
that the connection it demonstrates with the proceeding parable is to show that they both occurred in that same time
period.623 Chitwood likewise states that the then “shows that what is about to follow occurs during the same time as
that which preceded” (emphasis his).624 The reason they feel that they must restrict the meaning of then to mean in
that same time period is because they, like myself, both recognize that the preceding parable deals with the rapture.
If tote (the Greek word translated as then) means next, it means that the first parable deals with the first stage of
Jesus’ coming and the second parable deals with the next stage of His coming—the second stage.
        Admittedly, the use of the word then does not prove that the next phase of Jesus’ coming is being referred
to, since then can simply mean “at that time,” as BDAG points out. In fact, that is the way the NAS translates tote
in Mt 24:10. However, the Semitic range of this word is by no means limited to meaning at that time. Only seven
of the 158 times the NAS translates tote does it translate it as at that time. The NKJ simply translates it as then in
Mt 24:10, which is the way the NAS translates the word 149 times. Evidently, the NAS translators did not feel this
restricted meaning of at that time for tote was very common since they only used it seven times.
        BDAG also says that tote can “introduce that which follows in time.” In other words, it can be used to mean
next in that sequence of time. This common meaning would make sense in all sixteen occurrences of this word in
the Olivet Discourse and is demanded by the majority of those usages. Therefore, although Gaebelein is correct
that the word itself does not prove that the time of the revelation is in view, he overstates his case when he says,
“The use of the word ‘then’ proves the very opposite from what it is made to prove.”625 Not so. The word itself
does not prove anything. If anything, the frequency of usage, especially in this discourse, certainly would seem to
point to understanding tote in its common sense of next in sequence of time. In any case, tote could mean next in
sequence of eschatological judgments in Mt 25:1. The context must determine if this is indeed the case. Hodges
takes a more direct approach in arriving at the conclusion to which the present discussion is moving. He
understands tote as referring
Page 356                                                                                             The Outer Darkness


          back to the conclusion of the immediately preceding parable….It is then that the situation of the
          second parable exists….
               So the parable of the ten virgins awaits its fulfillment after Christ comes for the Church. It will
          take place during the Great Travail. (Italics his.)626

In other words, the then refers back to the new state of affairs that will be introduced by the conclusion of the
preceding parable. The rapture will introduce the tribulation. So this next parable, that of the virgins, is dealing
with the tribulation.

Delayed
       The next most important word in determining the time period is the word delaying in Mt 25:5. This delay
was encountered in the previous parable in Mt 24:48. The evil slave said, “My Lord delays His coming.” This is
the same Greek word for delay (chronizo) that the Lord uses in the next parable concerning the virgins (25:5).
Because the same Greek word is used in reference to time in both passages, it is perhaps understandable why many
dispensationalists jump to the conclusion that both passages describe the same time period, for both passages use
the same word. As noted previously, the present writer initially held that impression as well. This initial impression
could even be reinforced by pointing out that the time of the coming is unknown in Mt 25:13. Thus, one might
assume that this parable of the virgins also deals with the imminent rapture.
       Granted, an obvious connection exists between this parable and the preceding one. Yet the connection is not
that they describe the same time period but the same kind of person. The evil slave represents a carnal believer just
as do the foolish virgins. The first parable deals with the judgment of a foolish slave, the second parable with
foolish virgins. Both parables are dealing with the judgment of foolish believers. Moreover, both parables have
application to foolish believers, regardless of the time period in which they live. Still, proper interpretation and
identification of the time period requires a closer examination of the text.
       In the preceding parable, it was the evil slave who wrongly had the attitude that the coming of His Lord was
delayed (24:48). In contrast, in the next parable, Jesus Himself confirms that the coming of the bridegroom
actually will be delayed (25:5). Again, the same Greek word is used in both texts, but it is used differently. As
Hodges restates, “What the servant wrongly thinks his master is doing in parable 1, the bridegroom actually does in
parable 2. In parable 2, he does delay” (emphasis his).627

Unknown
       The most serious objection against regarding this parable as referring to a different time period from the
preceding parable is found in Mt 25:13, where it is said, “You do not know the day nor the hour.” The phase of the
coming in view appears to be imminent, just like it was in the previous parable, thus referring to the same period.
Sweigart’s arguments to this effect already have been duly noted. Also, Mt 25:13 seems to tie the time period of
this parable to the following parable of the talents in 25:14ff, which is dealing with the rapture. Further, the
parable of the virgins itself seems, at first glance, to indicate that the time of the Lord’s coming is unknown. If the
time of the coming is unknown and is truly imminent, it would indeed be referring to the first phase of Jesus’
coming, as do the preceding parable and the following parable.
       A standard counterargument is that the time of the Lord’s coming in the revelation is also unknown because
in Mt 24:22 the Lord tells us that the seven years of the tribulation will be shortened, supposedly making it
impossible to know the exact day or the hour of His return at the conclusion of the tribulation. Yet those who offer
this counterargument are often the very ones who appeal to the doctrine of imminency in defense of the doctrine of
the imminent rapture. In arguing that both phases are imminent, they weaken their own argument. Therefore, I will
not argue that the second phase is imminent. It is not. The revelation is not imminent for those living in that time
period. My agreement with Meisinger on this matter has been substantiated also by my own calculations.*
       The revelation is not truly imminent for the virgins in this passage. The virgins in this parable expect him to
come that night; they expected him to come before morning. The seven years already have been shortened to
2,520 days; they will not be lengthened by a few more days. He will come before the eighth year. The virgins
expected Him to come that night, and believers in the tribulation will expect Him to come at the conclusion of that
seventh year. In the preceding parable, Jesus clearly had said in Mt 24:44,50 that His coming would be unexpected
in that time period. Thus, He was referring to the first phase of His coming—the rapture. However, in the time

*
    See Imminent Future, 332; Unexpected, 338.
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                                  Page 357
period of this next parable, concerning the virgins, Jesus clearly depicts His coming as expected. The virgins go
out in Mt 25:1 to meet Him. They certainly are expecting Him to come!
        That these two parables are contrastive in relation to their time periods is also brought out even more
forcefully by Jesus’ narration when it is recalled who considered the coming as delayed in the previous parable.
The foolish Christian is the one who considers it delayed. The wise Christian considers it imminent. So in the
earlier parable, Jesus shows that the delay is a matter of perspective, but in the present parable it is no longer a
matter of perspective, it is a matter of fact. In the earlier parable, Jesus teaches us not to view His coming as
delayed, but in the present parable He teaches us to view it as delayed (cf. Mt 25:5). In this parable the Lord
explicitly says that He delays His coming. In the preceding parable, viewing His coming as delayed was unwise.
But in this next parable, the opposite is true; it is unwise not to be prepared for the delay.
        In defense of this modification of Sweigart’s imminent impression, let it again be restated that in one
parable it is foolish to expect delay, but in the next parable it is foolish not to expect delay. In the first parable, the
wise thing to do is to be prepared for His imminent return. In the second parable it is wise to be prepared for His
delay. Clearly, Jesus is contrasting two different stages of His coming. It was delayed in the eyes of the foolish
servant but not in the eyes of the wise servant. It may or may not be a long time in coming, but this indicates
imminency, not delay. The point of that section is that to consider the rapture delayed is foolish; we should rather
think of it as imminent. True, when we look backward, we think of the rapture as being delayed. But the Lord
wants us to look forward. In the forward view, it is not delayed, only imminent. The Lord wants us to see it as
imminent, not delayed in this present time. To see it otherwise is foolish/evil. The reverse is true in the present
section; it is unknown but not unexpected. They went out and were waiting on Him. They were expecting Him.

Double Delay
       It is important to note that in this second parable (Mt 25:1-13) a double delay occurs. Not only is there a
delay before He comes, but there is even a delay in-between the sign of His coming and the time He actually
comes. Therefore, this second parable must be referring to the same time period as Mt 24:1-35. There is a delay
before the midnight shout in Mt 25:6. So there is a delay while they slept. And there is also some delay after the
midnight cry. Thus, a second delay occurs after they awake and while they attempt to buy some more oil. This
shout cannot be the shout at the rapture or even at the revelation. The midnight shout does not occur
simultaneously with the coming, regardless of what stage of the coming is in view. The coming is delayed a little
while after the shout. So what shout is it? It must be something that indicates the Lord’s return but at the same time
separates the foolish from the wise. What has Jesus already described in this discourse that would do this? Clearly,
the abomination of desolation in Mt 24:15 will do so. And the author is indebted to Hodges for this identification.

Midnight Cry
        The midnight cry will occur at midtribulation and is hence called midnight. And it will point to the Lord’s
coming, but there will still be some time between it and His actual return. Further, it results in a tribulation that will
separate the wise from the foolish. In summary, this shout cannot be a shout that occurs at either the first or second
stage of Jesus’ coming because there is a delay after the shout. It is a shout which comes in the middle of the night,
which shows that the Lord’s coming is soon, which in turn will cause believers to go out to meet Him, and which
will separate the foolish from the wise. There is only one thing that Jesus has described in this context that would
fit this description. The midtribulation event (i.e., the midnight cry) is the abomination of desolation which occurs
midway through the tribulation (Mt 24:15). When believers see this sign, they are to flee out from Judea into the
mountains. This event will eventually separate the wise from the foolish.
        Counter suggestions as to the identity of the midnight cry by those who allocate this parable to the present
time period are not convincing. If it is the rapture (so Sweigart), then it would either be a partial rapture or there
would be no subsequent delay for those left behind—both of which are untenable. Chitwood seeks to resolve this
problem by identifying the cry with the current message for Christians to get ready for judgment. Accordingly, we
might call this the Bema cry. Granted, considering it a misthological cry is tempting, and Chitwood’s attempt to
move it to the beginning of the night by appealing to the prefect tense does give it more than a smattering of
respectability.628 But again this matter has been noted by commentators and reasonably explained as being a
sudden and dramatic cry that leaves a lingering impression in the minds of those who hear it. Moreover,
Chitwood’s appeal to the tense of the verb fails to deal adequately with the sense of the verse. Their immediate and
bustling response was delayed until this point during the night because the call did not occur until the middle of the
night (i.e., midnight).
Page 358                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                                    Application
       Therefore, in accordance with the modified outline of Olivet’s discourse offered herein as swinging back
and forth between both phases of Jesus’ coming, the appropriate conclusion is that Jesus’ point in Mt 25:13 is that,
although His coming is currently imminent, it is not immediate. This verse is a transitional verse between the two
parables and deals with two different phases of His coming, but at the same time it shows that the interpretation of
this futuristic passage has application to the present time. The application applies to believers in both periods.
Nonetheless, the you of v. 13 is addressed to believers in the current time period. The rapture is truly imminent for
them. Jesus implicitly limits the imminency of His coming in v. 13 to those living in the current period by using the
word you. He does not say that they (i.e., the virgins) do not know the day or hour. Current believers, as well as
believers in the next time period, are to realize that the nature of readiness rules out waiting until the last minute to
get ready. Readiness in the future is dependent upon readiness in one’s present time period.

       Jesus’ instruction in v. 13 is that His coming is imminent but not immediate. Imminent does not mean
immediate. Then, as now, we must be ready to handle the delay. Not knowing the day or hour does not rule out a
delay. Not knowing the day or hour does not rule out today, but neither does it rule out tomorrow. Both parables
deal with the delay but from two different perspectives. Nevertheless, they share a mutual application, which is that
current readiness is required for future readiness. Whether His coming is immediate, we would be extremely
unwise to delay our readiness. Although I may differ from some of my fellow misthologists, such as Sweigart and
Chitwood, concerning the timing and some of the technical details of the parable, I fully agree with them that there
is application to present-day believers.
       The chart provides an overview of the main eschatological details considered thus far by fellow futurists.
Rapture advocates believe the Lord’s coming in the parable of the virgins is unknown, unexpected, delayed, and
imminent. Revelation apologists, effectively counter by pointing out that the time of His coming is parabolically
known with relative certainty, certainly expected, doubly delayed, and impossible to regard as imminent. This
correct response effectively eliminates the left hand column of the chart from active consideration. The passage is
not dealing with the rapture, so an X has been placed in both cells of that column. Moving now to three
soteriological arguments, in the top right hand column of the chart under the revelation column (which places the
return after the tribulation), introduces three matters for contemplation in favor of regarding the unwise virgins as
unbelievers. These three suppositions will be introduced below and then offset by a combination of thirteen
soteriological and misthological reasons for regarding the virgins as regenerate believers who are dealt with when
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                                          Page 359
the Lord returns at the conclusion of the tribulation. Doing so will limit the options to the last quadrant marked
with a checkmark.

                                                            People
       Having identified the time period involved as the tribulation and corresponding revelation, it is now
necessary to identify the people involved. Does this shout separate unbelievers from believers or faithful believers
from unfaithful believers? In other words, are the foolish virgins lost or saved? Are they unbelievers or unfaithful
believers? The typical view is that the foolish virgins are unbelievers because they are not ready for His coming,
they are not allowed into the wedding feast, and the Lord says that He does not know them. But typical answers are
not necessarily correct answers, as will be shown in the following counterarguments to this typical soteriological
view.
       First, they are all virgins. This is not a term that one normally would consider as descriptive of unbelievers.
As a matter of fact, it is used of believers in both the present time period (2Cor 11:2) and the future time period
(Rev 14:4). Because virgin is used elsewhere in the NT as a designation for genuine believers for both time periods
and is never used elsewhere in the NT as a designation for unbelievers, it seems likely that it designates these
virgins as genuine believers in this passage also. In light of what will be happening during that time period, it is
probable that they are not only called virgins because of their regenerational purity but also because of their moral
purity. As deduced below, they are regenerate believers who have not worshipped the beast or taken the mark of
the beast.*
       Second, all ten went out in Mt 25:1. Unbelievers do not go out to meet the Lord. This parabolic detail
shows faith expressing itself in action in regard to Jesus’ coming. Perhaps some will argue that the midnight cry
and invitation in Mt 25:6 will separate believers from unbelievers and thus that the foolish virgins are lost; that is,
the abomination of desolation during the tribulation period will separate believers from unbelievers, and believers
in Jesus will respond to His warning by fleeing out of Judea, but unbelievers will stay put. But notice carefully that
taking this approach actually leads to the conclusion that the foolish virgins are saved, not lost. The foolish virgins
do not stay put. The foolish virgins, just like the wise virgins, respond to the warning by rising and trimming their
lamps. All these virgins demonstrate faith in Jesus by going out to meet Him in Mt 25:1. And the foolish virgins
respond just as sincerely as the wise virgins to the invitation to come out to meet Him in Mt 25:6. Thus, even the
argument that only believers will obey Jesus and flee when they hear the midnight cry is actually an argument that
the foolish virgins are saved since they respond in faith to the Lord’s warning about the abomination of desolation.
       Third, they all wait on Him to return. This is not an action that would be expected of unbelievers. It
indicates genuine faith. Fourth, they all fall asleep while they are waiting, until they hear the midnight cry. As
Hodges aptly remarks, “In the circumstances described in this parable, sleeping is sensible” (emphasis his).629
Since both the wise and foolish virgins sleep in this passage, it cannot be argued that sleep indicates that they are
not believers. They all rest until the abomination of desolation. This is a time of relative peace. The antichrist will
have made a peace treaty with the Jews in that period. But more than that, these Jewish believers can sleep because
they know that the bridegroom will not come until after the midnight shout, that is, until after the abomination of
desolation is seen in the temple. Their sleep demonstrates their faith that there will be a shout to warn them when
the time of His return is close at hand. Their sleep demonstrates faith in the Lord and in His warning concerning
the abomination of desolation. Fifth, when the shout comes, then they all arise and go out. This action also
indicates that they believe in the Lord and His warning. They hear the shout and go out just as they were instructed
in Mt 24:15-16. Their sleep and their going out signify faith in the Lord and His warning.
       Sixth, they all had lamps. Unbelievers do not have a lamp. They do not have the spiritual capacity to
experience the strength of the Holy Spirit. All believers have a lamp; they have a regenerate new nature and the
capacity to experience the Spirit’s power, but not all believers avail themselves of His power. Instead, many
believers quench or grieve the Spirit by whom they have been sealed. All believers have spiritual life due to
regeneration. But Jesus warns us in Mt 5:15 to be careful what we do with our lamp. The application is to be
careful, Christian, how you treat the Holy Spirit. If you only call upon Him in times of difficulty, you may find that
you do not have the power to shine or endure during that difficulty. Your regeneration guarantees that you have
spiritual life, but it does not guarantee spiritual growth (cf. 1Cor 3:1-3; Heb 5:12-14; and 1Pet 2:2). Some
Christians are carnal dwarfs. Spiritual life does not automatically produce spiritual growth or keep one’s love from
growing cold. These lamps represent regeneration, spiritual life. All ten virgins have experienced regeneration as

*
 See Mark of the Beast, 362. The virgins are overcomers who survive through the tribulation. They go out to meet the Bride. They are
not part of the Bride of Christ. The Bride is composed of overcomers who live during the church age.
Page 360                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
indicated by their lamps. The light from those lamps is to be distinguished from the lamps themselves. Loving and
good works that flow from a regenerate new nature are not to be confused with that new nature.
        Seventh, and even more importantly, they all had oil. The best translation of what the foolish virgins said is,
“Our lamps are going out.” In other words, “Our lamps are running out of oil.” Even if it were translated as, “Our
lamps have gone out,” it is still clear that they could not have gone out unless they had been burning initially and
thus had oil at the beginning of the night. The only way they could have gone out is to have been burning
previously. What distinguishes the foolish from the wise is not that one has oil and the other does not, but that one
has enough oil whereas the other does not. The wise virgins had extra oil. The foolish virgins had oil but did not
have any extra oil. Their light started to fade in the night.
        Obviously, oil is not a reference to the Holy Spirit (at least not in regard to regeneration). The Holy Spirit is
a person, not a substance of which you can have different degrees. You cannot have the Holy Spirit (or
regeneration) in various degrees, but you can be filled with the Spirit to various degrees. Some of these regenerate
believers were filled with the Spirit; some were not. What they lacked were reserves of spiritual oil. But what is
indicated by their lacking spiritual reserves? They lack spiritual stamina. Some things that cannot be borrowed. For
example, you cannot borrow someone’s fellowship with God. You hear people say, “I wish I had your faith and
courage.” Yet it is impossible to give it to them. You must develop your own faith and courage. You can borrow
someone’s lawn mower, but you cannot borrow his or her Christian maturity and strength of character. The oil
represents Christian strength, growth, fruit, energy, and maturity—spiritual muscle so to speak. Some believers
have spiritual reserves that they can draw upon; some do not.
        How does a believer obtain spiritual reservoirs? James said, “Consider it all joy, my brethren, when you
encounter various trials, knowing that the testing of your faith produces endurance” (Jam 1:2-3). Only those
believers who victoriously and joyfully draw upon the Lord’s strength in the midst of present difficulties will have
the strength to endure victoriously and joyfully when the big trials come. Doing well on the various tests now will
cause you to grow in spiritual maturity. You will produce the spiritual capacity that you need to endure. If you
want to endure in the end (Mt 24:13), you should endure till the end. As believers, we should be developing our
spiritual muscle. Believers are the ones who need to sing, “Give me oil in my lamp, keep me burning,” not
unbelievers. Believers need to develop their spiritual muscle, not unbelievers. Unbelievers need spiritual life before
they develop spiritual muscle. All these virgins had lamps and oil. They all had spiritual life and spiritual muscle.
But some of them had more oil, more spiritual muscle, than others.
        Eight, the oil they lacked was not regeneration since they were told to “go...buy” (Mt 25:9). This is not
talking about regeneration or salvation from hell because time and time again the Scripture tells us that salvation
from hell is free. Those who are trying to buy their way into heaven with baptism, prayers, or church attendance
are not going to make it. What the virgins lacked was not something that was free but something that was costly to
them personally. The biblical distinction between a gift and a reward compels Marrowists to identify these foolish
virgins as believers who had received the free gift of eternal life but who did not fully follow the Lord in
discipleship. They had been unwilling to pay the price. Wise virgins, on the other hand, are Marrowists who are
willing to buy the gold, white garments, and eye salve necessary to enjoy the marriage feast (Rev 3:18).
        Ninth, from the context, one should not be surprised to find that believers need to get ready for His coming.
The point of Jesus’ previous parable was that believers who already have eternal life need to get ready for the
Lord’s coming by faithful discipleship (Mt 24:44). That believers may not be ready is evident since, otherwise,
there would be no need to warn believers about the possibility of not being ready. In the preceding parable, Jesus
graphically described the failure of some believers to be ready. The point of the preceding parable was that Jesus is
coming, so get ready, believer. The point of this second parable is that tribulations are coming, so get ready
believer.
        Tenth, unbelievers will be excluded from the wedding feast of course since they will be excluded from the
millennial kingdom. Yet Jesus’ point in the Matthean wedding passages is that unfaithful believers, although
permitted into the kingdom, will be excluded from the feast.* We are familiar with the imagery of an open or
closed door representing an open or closed opportunity in Scripture.630 Such is the case here. This parable
illustrates the truth expressed in Mt 24:13. Only believers who endure will experience co-glorification salvation.
Those believers who do not endure will be excluded from this opportunity for millennial rulership. There are things
that cannot be obtained at the last minute. You cannot wait until the last minute to study for a comprehensive, time-
limited, closed-book examination. You cannot wait until the last minute to pay the estimated taxes you were
supposed to be paying all year. You will find that you have spent the money on other things. Prov 24:10 warns that

*
    See Feast, 555; The Lord’s Banquet, 561; Illustration 189. Table Exclusion from Mount Zion, 562.
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                                           Page 361
if you faint in the day of adversity, then your faith is small. We need to be doing everything we can to build up our
faith before adversity strikes. Believers trying to do just enough to get by will find that they do not have the
strength to stand when the rains of adversity fall and the winds of calamity come sweeping down upon them.
        Eleventh, to be sure, conditionalists will argue that Jesus’ statement that He did not know these foolish
virgins is very similar to what He had previously said in Mt 7:23, which in their opinion shows that the exclusion
in both passages is soteriological. Admittedly, in 7:23 when Jesus said that He did not know the person, He meant
that this person did not have eternal life. Also, Jesus said in Jn 17:3 that eternal life is knowing God. However, the
knowing in both of those verses is based on the Greek word ginosko. Why does Jesus use a totally different word
(oida) for know in Mt 25:12 than He does in Mt 7:23? Apparently, He uses a different word to make a different
point.* In 7:23 He is saying, “I do not have any association with you at all.” On the other hand, the word in 25:12
denotes acknowledging or honoring someone. In this parable Jesus is asserting that He does not honor them. He in
saying in effect: “I know who you are (one of the girls whom I asked to perform the entertainment at the wedding
by performing the torch dance), but I do not honor your request to join in the festivities and perform since you were
not ready.”
        Twelfth, it is also very interesting to note when these virgins are excluded from the feast. It is after the feast
already has begun! This beautifully parallels what Jesus already had taught them in Mt 22:11-13. The servant was
excluded from the feast after it already had begun! This is a strong indication that the virgins are saved.† The
separation of the sheep and goats occurs before the wedding feast begins. Thus, the nonelect already have been
removed before the feast begins. Therefore, since these virgins were not removed at that previous judgment, they
must be the elect—sheep.
        Thirteenth, the last and most conclusive point is in v. 13. Who is the you to whom the parable applies?
Genuine believers. These parables were spoken in private to Peter, James, John, and Andrew (see Mk 13:3). They
are the ones who are told to be on the alert. Since this warning is addressed to genuine believers, genuine believers
are the ones in danger of being foolish virgins.
