believers in the tribulation period—represented by the ten virgins). However, only believers who have been faithful
in endurance will be allowed entrance into the joy of the wedding feast.

                                              When, Where, Who, What
       As pictured in Illustration 129. The Wedding, the wedding is in heaven, and the feast is on earth. This
parable provides this information as well as other eschatological details. It tells us when the wedding feast will
occur, where the feast will occur, who will be allowed to attend the feast, and what it means to endure until the
end of the tribulation. The question as to when the feast will occur is settled by the fact that it occurs after the
revelation, and thus after He comes again. Concerning Mt 25:1-13, Pentecost is correct in concluding that it is
necessary

          to distinguish between the marriage of the Lamb and the marriage supper. The marriage of the Lamb
          is an event that has particular reference to the church and takes place in heaven. The marriage supper
          is an event that involves Israel and takes place on earth and has particular reference to Israel. The
          wedding supper, then, becomes the parabolic picture of the entire millennial age...Israel, at the second
          advent, will be waiting for the Bridegroom to come from the wedding ceremony and invite them to
          that supper, at which the Bridegroom will introduce His bride to His friends.632

       Stanton, likewise, stresses that both the Bema and the marriage “must occur in heaven after the Rapture but
before the return to earth.”633 Those tribulational believers who faithfully endure until the end of the tribulation will
be allowed to participate in the festivities of the feast. It already has been concluded from Mt 24:13,47 and
Mt 25:34 that this means they will receive the millennial salvation, which is the blessing of inheriting rulership in
the millennial kingdom. Thus, the wedding feast is a parabolic picture of the millennial reign with Jesus that will
be granted to the faithful elect.

                                                 Mark of the Beast
       The fact that enduring to the end (Mt 24:13) means more than simply being a believer who survives until the
end of the tribulation is demonstrated in this parable. Dillow’s coordination of this parable with the mark of the
beast is well stated. In 1993 the present author wrote Dillow asking him how he would integrate his position that
unfaithful believers live until the end of the tribulation with certain passages in Revelation concerning the Book of
Life and the worship and mark of the beast. For example, according to Revelation all those whose names are not
written in the Book of Life will worship the beast (Rev 13:8). Capital punishment will be the decreed penalty for
not worshiping the beast (Rev 13:5). Additionally, the right to buy and sell will be limited to those who receive the
mark of the beast (Rev 13:6).

Problem
        The problem for the thesis herein (that the foolish virgins represent unfaithful believers who survive the
tribulation) can be summarized by three questions: (1) Do unfaithful believers, that is, subcomers, receive the mark
of the beast? (2) If so, that is, if they do receive the mark, then how is it possible to affirm their eternal security
(Rev 14:9-11; 19:20)? (3) If not, that is, if they do not receive it, then how is it possible to deny their faithfulness
(Rev 13:16-17; 20:4), particularly since they will not be able to buy or sell as a result of refusing the mark?
        In response to these questions, the author summarized the traditional interpretation and then suggested an
alternative proposal that was in substantial agreement with an article Wilkin had written in 1991.634 In response,
Dillow wrote back, “The solution you proposed is the one which I share although we may differ in some of the
details.”635 Dillow went on to say that in response he would include the section The Mark of the Beast in the
revised version of his book, and he did so. Consequently, the analysis herein naturally will be in substantial

*
    See Part 1. Chapter 25. The Bride, 565.
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                                                   Page 363
agreement with Dillow’s proposal but “differ in some of the details.” Regrettably, Dillow inserted a detail that
would have been better left out: “One thing the carnal Christian fears is hell and he knows that if he accepts this
mark, it is proven that that he is unregenerate.”636 Corner rightly points out that this statement is out of harmony
with Dillow’s overall theology.637
       Therefore, I must present my difference with Dillow over this detail. First, carnal believers need not fear
hell. Second, although carnal believers certainly should fear taking the mark of the beast, their reason for fearing
the mark should not be hell. The implications of Dillow’s subsequent clarification suffice: “Since they are elect,
God will either work in their hearts or circumstances so that they avoid accepting the mark, or He will take them to
be with Him before they do so.”638 Although believers hypothetically could take the mark of the beast, they should
be able to reason that if they were to subcome to the desire to do so that God will kill them before they actually
could do so and that God would throw them into the outer darkness as a result.*

Typical FG Answer
        The typical dispensational answer to my opening questions could be argued in the following FG manner.
Unfaithful, unmarked believers are killed during the tribulation, with the result that only faithful believers survive
the tribulation. Thus, the salvation promised in Mt 24:13 is to faithful believers. Those believers who were going to
subcome to the temptation to worship the beast or to the desire to take his mark are killed by the plagues before
having an opportunity to do so. Consequently, not worshiping the beast is not required to be a believer, but it is
required to stay alive and be an overcomer. Believers who yield to the temptation in their hearts will be killed
before they have an opportunity to yield in action. Regarding this particular issue of taking the mark of the beast,
subcomers in attitude will die before becoming subcomers in action.
        Believers will not worship the beast, not because being saved prevents them from doing so, but because
premature death prevents them from doing so. There is a real danger to the elect who are led astray in their hearts
to worship the beast. They will die prematurely as carnal believers—as subcomers rather than as overcomers.
Therefore, the traditional FG view could be summarized as follows. No unfaithful believers survive the tribulation;
rather, they are killed before they subcome in action to either worshiping the beast or taking his mark. Not
receiving the mark and not worshiping the beast are not required to be a genuine believer, since believers can
subcome to either temptation in intent. But in yielding to either temptation in their hearts, they forfeit their lives in
the plagues of the tribulation before they have a chance to subcome in action.
        This view can call upon support from a variety of passages. For example, it may be claimed in Mt 24:36-41
that the wrath of the tribulation will come and take away all the unfaithful, whether they be believers or
unbelievers, in premature death eschatologically just as “the flood came and took them all away” originally
(Mt 24:39). Correspondingly, in Rom 11:26 when Paul says, “All Israel will be saved,” he should be understood as
referring to faithful Jews who are allowed to enter the millennial kingdom. Unfaithful Jews will not be allowed to
do so (Eze 20:38), being swept away by premature death in the flood of tribulational wrath.† This interpretation is
then able to provide a very attractive explanation as to why in the next parable (that of The Sheep and the Goats)
no unfaithful believers will be present at this judgment—because they were all killed by the tribulation. In the
current age, it would take extra ordinary activity (or passivity) on God’s part in causing (or allowing) events to
unfold so that absolutely all unfaithful believers would be swept away in premature death. Apparently, God would
have to allow worldwide persecution and cause premature death for all defectors. But such conditions will seem to
prevail during the tribulation. Therefore, those posing this interpretation would find it natural to suggest that this
future holocaust will be a time when only faithful believers will survive. If so, the reason that only faithful
believers are judged at The Sheep and the Goats judgment is because all unfaithful believers already will have been
dealt with by the judgment of the tribulational wrath and died a premature death.
        However, there are two problems with this view. Any text which seems to indicate that unfaithful believers
will live through the tribulation presents a problem (e.g., the present passage in Mt 25:1-13). Second, the
parallelism presents a problem. Some noncomers are killed during the tribulation, and some noncomers live
through it. Likewise, some overcomers are killed during the tribulation, and some overcomers live through it. Since
there will be both noncomers and overcomers who are killed during the tribulation and others in both groups who
live through it, one would expect the same to be true of subcomers. Is it not rather forced to argue that absolutely
all subcomers are killed during the tribulation?


*
    See endnote 1479.
†
    For our discussion of a relative all in Rom 11:26 as it applies to Eze 20:38, see All Israel in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 364                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
Unfaithful Survivors
       When the author has posed these objections to advocates of the typical FG dispensational answer outlined
above, some have acknowledged that it would be possible, in acquiesce to the modification being proposed herein,
for a few unfaithful believers to live until the end of the tribulation without violating their interpretation. If there
are hundreds of thousands of faithful believers who survive the tribulation and only a handful of unfaithful
believers who survive until the end of it, then it would still be permissible to use the word all proportionally in
saying that the flood of tribulational wrath “took them all away.” It must be understood as being a relative all after
all since there will be unbelievers who live until the end of the tribulation. In comparison to the billions swept
away, the analogy to Noah’s universal flood is still valid. This modification is, therefore, both reasonable and
necessary and still able to deal with the parable of the sheep and goats adequately.*
       Some subcomers (not all) are killed during the present time period. There is such a thing as sin unto death.
Christians can subcome to sin to such a degree during the present time that the Lord takes them home prematurely.
Some sins are so serious that the penalty is premature death. The same possibility also exists in the future period.
But not all carnal believers in the present are taken home prematurely; therefore, it is reasonable to assume that in
the future period some carnal believers are not taken home prematurely and thus live until the end of the
tribulation.
       This alternative interpretation does justice to Mt 25:1-13 and assumes that a parallel exists between the
present and the future. Just as there is a sin unto death for believers now, there will be a sin unto death for believers
then. Yet just as not all subcomers are taken home prematurely now, not all subcomers will be taken home
prematurely then. Some unfaithful, unmarked believers will be killed during the tribulation, but others will live till
the end of the tribulation. Anyone who worships the beast or takes his mark or does both will go to hell because
his/her name was never written in the Book of Life. Only noncomers will worship the beast or take his mark. As
for comers (i.e., believers), subcomers in intent will be killed before they become subcomers in action. This intent
to take the mark of the beast is a sin unto death for the carnal believer during the tribulation period. Since the
believers who subcome in intent (to either worshiping the beast or to taking his mark) are killed during the
tribulation, the only believers who survive the tribulation will be those who were faithful in these two areas. But
since believers who are faithful in these two areas will not be able to buy or sell and risk death, how is it possible to
deny their faithfulness in terms of being an overcomer? Can they be faithful in these two crucial areas and still fail
to be considered an overcomer? I believe so.

Cold Love
        Although it is decreed that the unmarked cannot buy or sell, both subcomers and overcomers (and even
some noncomers) will find a way to buy and sale without taking the mark. Refusing to be marked does not
automatically make a believer an overcomer who will reign with Christ. Reigning with Christ is conditioned on
three things in Rev 20:4 (not receiving the mark, not worshiping the beast, and martyrdom). It takes more than not
receiving the mark and not worshiping the beast to be an overcomer. Enduring to the end (Mt 24:13) means
more than not receiving the mark and not worshiping the beast. It also means not allowing your love to grow
cold (cp. Mt 24:12).
        Claeys correctly picks up on the association between cold love and enduring but unnecessarily equates cold
love with taking the mark of the beast so as to defend the typical FG dispensational conclusion that only faithful
believers will survive the tribulation. His basic rationale is that subcomers whose love grows cold will subcome to
the desire to take the mark of the beast and thus be killed by God before being allowed to do so.639 However, he
prematurely concludes: “This is the only way to explain that no believer will take the mark.”640
        Even given Claeys’ premise, it is not immediately apparent that all those believers alive when the Lord
returns will be considered overcomers. Claeys understands Zech 12:10 as indicating that “these Jews in and around
Jerusalem when the invasion of the armies of the nations occurs will believe in Christ just prior to his return”
(italics his).641 Obviously, in order to be able to believe in Christ, they will not have taken the mark of the beast
prior to becoming believers. Correspondingly, then, there will be unbelievers who, for whatever reason, survive
throughout the whole tribulation without taking the mark of the beast. Claeys considers these Jews (who convert at
the last possible moment and call out to the Lord for temporal salvation from the beast) to be the faithful remnant.
Granted, this conjecture is reasonable, but their faithfulness up unto that point in not taking the mark of the beast
will count for nothing in terms of inheriting the kingdom. The only faithfulness that counts towards rewards is
faithfulness that is exercised after one becomes a believer. Any national or typological refining that takes place in

*
    See Two Categories, 416.
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                                               Page 365
Mal 3:2 or Zech 13:8 before their personal conversion will not count toward individual rewards. Does this last
moment conversion followed by calling upon the Lord to save them from their earthly troubles suffice for ruling
with Christ in the millennial kingdom? Probably not. These last moment converts make what might be paralleled,
to a certain extent, to today’s death bed confession. Conversion at the end need not constitute enduring to the end
(Mt 24:23). This last minute conversion may not qualify them as overcomers who are qualified to enter the
kingdom. These new believers would add to the number of believers who enter the kingdom in flesh and blood
bodies.
        Granted these last moment Jewish conversions are not being described by the Lord in the parable of the
virgins since He evidently is dealing with Jews who are converted early during the tribulation and who are waiting
for His return during the course of the tribulation. Even so, this OT passage does give pause for thinking that not
all believers who live till the end of the tribulation will qualify for kingdom inheritance. Nor is it the only passage
to do so. Perhaps some of the Jewish rebels in Eze 20:38, who are purged from among them, are not allowed to
enter the Promised Land of Israel but are allowed to dwell elsewhere in the kingdom. The normal assumption is
that these Jewish rebels would have taken the mark of the beast. But if these Jewish unbelievers living in the
Jerusalem do not take the mark of the beast during the course of the tribulation, as is proven by their last moment
conversion, then why assume that all the Jewish unbelievers living throughout the rest of the world in Eze 20:38
have taken the mark of the beast? And if those unmarked unbelievers living in Jerusalem can believe at the last
moment, then why can unmarked unbelievers living elsewhere not believe at the last moment?* Or if some of them
have believed earlier, does it not sound like Mal 3:5 should be factored into consideration as describing
disqualification because of cold love, especially since the matters it describes could be associated with cold love.
The general assumption is that both the Jewish rebels and Jewish foolish virgins are unregenerate. But if the later
are regenerate, then one has grounds to suspect that the former, or at least some of them, may be regenerate also.
        Moreover, if Benware’s assessment of Zech 12:10 is accurate, or at least partially so, and it probably is, then
many of the unmarked unregenerate Jews will not believe and experience saving faith and regeneration “until the
second coming itself” when they see the Lord return.642 In this case, Claeys’ comment above about just prior is
reduced to not until. Although as a nation Israel will have repented, this particular group of Jews will not believe
until they see the Lord return. In fact, Claeys acknowledges that only unbelieving Jews will be left in Jerusalem at
this climatic finale, “at the very end of the Day of the Lord” and that they will not believe until “just before, and at
the time of, his return” (emphasis his).643
        Even if all unfaithful believers are killed off during the tribulation, this still does not prove that only faithful
believers are the only believers who will be alive at the end of the tribulation. There will be a number of new
believers who have done nothing to qualify as faithful believers. They will not have endured to the end for the
simple reason that they did not become believers until the very end—indeed at the last moment. So here is a group
of believers who only qualify to enter the kingdom in flesh and blood bodies and repopulate the kingdom. They
have done nothing to deserve rulership of the kingdom. Obviously, even on his own terms, and contrary to Claeys’
previous remarks, there is more than one way to explain that no believer will take the mark.
        Being an unmarked believer will not suffice to inherit the kingdom. More is necessary to be an overcomer
than simply to be an unmarked believer. These foolish virgins, who stayed virgins throughout the night were
unmarked Jewish believers.† They came to faith much earlier than these latter unmarked Jewish believers. But
being an unmarked Jewish believer was not enough to qualify either group for kingdom inheritance. Something
more than being an unmarked Jewish believer was necessary. Surely, Jesus intends for us to see this facet of the
parable. There is no need to pose that these virgins went off into the night to commit harlotry with the beast. They
stay virgins until the end. God does not kill them in the night because they are tempted to give up their spiritual
virginity. Something else, something obvious, is the issue. Claeys was on the right track when he factored in cold
love, but it is an error to equate cold love with giving in to the intent to take the mark of the beast.
        I wish overcoming were as simple as Claeys supposes: Just don’t rebel against God to the point of allowing
your love to grow so cold that you would take the mark of the beast. However, I suspect that more is required than
merely not rebelling against God to that extent. The same God who commands us to not take the mark of the beast
also commands us to love one another. And it is doubtful that He will suspend the implication of the latter just as
long as it does not transgress the boundaries of the former.

*
  See Separation Precedes Judgment, 413.
†
  If these foolish virgins represent unfaithful Jewish believers who live during the tribulational period (as is herein maintained), then
the most reasonable inference is that the unfaithful servant who is thrown into the outer darkness (Mt 25:30) also represents unfaithful
Jewish believers if he represents Jewish stewards living during the tribulational period. Either regenerate Jews are exclusively in view,
or ethnic Jews are being used typologically to picture those who are regenerate. See Jewish Slaves will be Entrusted, 375.
Page 366                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
        Giving in to the desire to take the mark of the beast would appear to be more closely aligned to apostasy
(giving up on God) than merely having a tepid love. Being lukewarm (Rev 3:16) or losing one’s first love
(Rev 2:4) is not to be equated with apostasy in the present age, and it probably cannot be equated with giving in to
the desire to go over to the enemy’s camp in the tribulation. Suppose, for example, that a believer is sold into
slavery during the tribulation because he or she refuses to take the mark of the beast. Would it not be possible for
that believer to wane in his or her love for her fellow believers or even for God under the grueling trials of such
slavery in the midst of the tribulation? Of course. Still, this does not necessarily mean that all such believers would
give in to the extent of thinking, “Ok, I will take the mark of the beast now.” Not likely. A more likely compromise
would be to think, “I’ll just gruel it out now that I am a slave. As long as I don’t take the mark of the beast, that is
all that the Lord requires of me. Loving my fellow slaves, much less my master, is not required for me to inherit
the kingdom.” Will such believers inherit the kingdom? No. Will such believers be killed because they have
subcomed to the desire to take the mark of the beast? No. They will not give into the desire to take the mark of the
beast and thus wrongly reason that they have done enough to qualify for the salvation promised to those who
endure. They will not overcome but neither will they be killed.
                                              Illustration 130. Cold Love of Believers




       In the above illustration, such unloving believers would be found in the (A) group of believers falling
outside the range of (B) those believers killed for desiring to take the mark of the beast. Thus, they could live
through the tribulation and yet fail to qualify for inheriting the kingdom. Although not taking the mark of the beast
will be hard, being an overcomer is even more difficult than not giving in to the desire to take the mark of the
beast. So if a copy of this book were to fall into the hands of someone who does not become a believer until after
the rapture, that person needs to be aware that not taking the mark of the beast is not enough to qualify for the
salvation from the darkness outside the feast being described by Jesus. They should read Mal 3:5 in conjunction
with Mt 24:12, not just in conjunction with passages from Revelation that discuss the mark of the beast. For now,
though, believers of today need to be aware that this interpretation has application to them. Believers today have
plenty of passages to contemplate as to what it means to be an overcomer, and none of them pertain to the mark of
the beast.*

Application
       For believers to overcome, then as now, they must demonstrate love (1Cor 13:3) in good works for others
(Jam 2:13-17), particularly for the Jewish missionaries (Mt 25:37-40). Even today, we see many believers who are
faithful enough to the Lord to avoid premature death (cf. 1Jn 5:16), but this does not mean they have met all the

*
  The unfaithful church-age believers are cast out of the Reward city because they already will be in it. Unfaithful tribulational
believers that live until the end of the tribulation will not be cast outside of the city; rather, they will be left standing outside of it.
Since they will not have died, they will not have entered the city before the judgment takes place. Perhaps it is not incidental that the
parable of the virgins corresponds to such misthopological expectations.
Chapter 14. Give Me Oil in My Lamp (Mt 25:1-13)                                                               Page 367
requirements to rule with Christ. Even today, we see believers who appear to be overcomers since they have toil,
perseverance, and endurance but who actually are subcomers since they have left their first love (Rev 2:2-7). Even
today, we see many believers who claim to love Christ, while refusing to love their brethren in Christ (1Jn 3:17;
Jam 2:16-17). Both now and in the future, we must not only be willing to be martyrs by laying down our lives for
Christ; we must also be willing “to lay down our lives for the brethren” (1Jn 3:16).

Proportion
        As to the proportion of unfaithful believers who will survive the tribulation, it is probably a small number,
but the interpretation proposed herein is not necessarily dependent upon this computation. The fact that five out of
ten virgins are unfaithful may suggest that a proportionally large number of unfaithful Jewish believers will survive
the tribulation. Yet this need not be the case. In the parable of the wedding feast in Mt 22:1-14, only one believer
present at the feast is found to be unfaithful. But certainly the portion of carnal believers (poorly dressed believers)
in the present church age is greater than the percentage suggested by the parable. It is probable that neither parable
was intended to teach mathematical percentages. There is little reason to believe that the percentage of unfaithful
Jewish believers who survive the tribulation will be vastly greater than the percentage of unfaithful Christians who
live during the church age! One would assume the opposite.
        The numerical contrast (of a singular individual being poorly dressed as opposed to half being poorly
prepared) simply fits the imagery of the respective parables. One reason for the numerical tension is to show the
absence of mathematical calculation. Most of those believers who are poorly prepared to endure the hardships of
the tribulation will probably be swept away in the wrath of the tribulation because they will, in all likelihood, tend
to subcome to the temptation to take the mark of the beast and thus be killed before being allowed to do so. It
makes sense to suppose that the vast majority of those believers who will have had the strength to resist the
temptation to submit to the beast in intent will have done so because they have plenty of oil; therefore, most
believers who live until the end of the tribulation will be found to be faithful believers—wise virgins.
Unfortunately, then as now, there will be believers, like those at Ephesus, who persevere and endure but who have
a cold love. These foolish virgins will be allowed into the millennial kingdom but not allowed to inhabit the
Promised Land (Eze 20:38). The reason that there are proportionally so many unfaithful believers in this parable is
because they are the focus of the parable. If you use a microscope to focus on a certain object, then that object
appears larger than life.* The number of unfaithful Jewish believers in this parable is larger than one would
anticipate because Jesus is focusing His microscopic perspective† on this particular group to illuminant certain OT
truths regarding unfaithful Jewish believers who survive the tribulation. These truths and this group would
otherwise be ignored.‡ Ethnic sons of the kingdom can be cast into the darkness outside the feast, even if they are
regenerate believers, if their love grows cold (cp. Mt 8:12).
        In summary, tribulational believers will not take the mark of the beast or worship him. Those believers who
intend to do so will be killed before they actually do so. But just because they do not receive the mark and do not
worship the beast does not necessarily mean that they are sufficiently faithful to be regarded as an overcomer. They
must also demonstrate loving good works in order to be worthy of this title. The most reasonable expectation is that
they will be few in number compared to those who are faithful, but this interpretation of this parable is not
dependent upon this inference. In any event, the most reasonable supposition is that there will be some noncomers,
subcomers, and overcomers who are killed during the tribulation; then again, there will be some noncomers,
subcomers, and overcomers who live through it. The foolish virgins represent (Jewish) believers who fail to
overcome during the tribulation but who, nevertheless, live rather than love until the end of the tribulation.

                                            Procreation in the Kingdom
       Millennial procreation and repopulation have been discussed already.§ The only minor problem with
Dillow’s proposal is that it appears (to some extent) to separate the children from their parents, since the children
will be in earthly bodies, but their parents will be in glorified bodies. Instead, it seems preferable to stipulate that
unfaithful believers who do not worship the beast or take his mark, and yet who live until the end of the tribulation,
will enter the millennial kingdom in their earthly/mortal bodies. They will not be transformed into their immortal
bodies at the beginning of the millennium, since there is no need for them to be transformed. They do not need

*
  See Illustration 142. Two Different Scopes, 417.
†
  See Two Categories, 416.
‡
  See Illustration 141. Sequence of Separation Complex, 414.

  See Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom, 60.
Page 368                                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
their immortal bodies at that time since they will not inherit the kingdom. They enter the kingdom, of course, but as
its subjects rather than as its rulers. The following proverb has misthological application: “A servant who acts
wisely will rule over a son who acts shamefully, and will share in the inheritance among brothers” (Prov 17:2). The
wise rule over the unwise. Shameful sons inhabit rather than inherit the kingdom. Therefore, they and their children
procreate during the millennium. In conclusion, the foolish virgins are best identified as unfaithful believers of the
tribulation who live till the end of the tribulation. Their unfaithfulness does not include subcoming in their hearts to
the worship or mark of the beast, but they do not have the spiritual stamina necessary to endure the tribulation
without letting their love grow cold (Mt 24:12). They are thus excluded from ruling in the kingdom. They and their
children become physical inhabitants of the millennial kingdom and its procreators.

                                                        Darkness Outside
        This parable pictures the five foolish virgins being left outside in the darkness. What is the darkness? It is
simply exclusion from the feast. It is not hell. The five wise virgins were likewise in the darkness before the feast
started. This does not mean that the wise virgins were in hell before being allowed into heaven. The darkness
simply pictures them as not participating in the joy of the feast. They could not enjoy the feast until the feast
started, of course. Likewise, the five foolish virgins who are left outside in the darkness (where the five wise
virgins previously were) are not being pictured as being left in hell.* They simply are depicted as being left out
from the joy of the feast. The darkness outside the feast represents exclusion from the festivities inside. And those
festivities represent rulership of the millennial kingdom.† The foolish virgins are excluded from the exercise of that
rulership. From other details, one may deduce that they enter the kingdom physically, but from the parable we find
that they do not enter it regally. The darkness represents regal exclusion. This observation is noted in anticipation
of the next chapter, where the actual term of darkness outside (otherwise called the outer darkness) will be
discussed in depth.

                                                              Conclusion
       In regards to time, the opening word of this parable—i.e., then—was found to be a probable indicator of
sequence rather than simultaneous time. This word advances the narration to the next point in time to be
considered. A transition is made from the discussion of the rapture to the revelation. Although those who find the
rapture in this section appeal to the fact that a delay is embedded within the passage, as seemingly indicating the
current delay as we await the rapture, the manner in which this delay is presented actually suggests otherwise.
       The coming of the Bridegroom in this parable is not truly imminent or unexpected. The midnight cry must
come first, and the Bridegroom is expected to arrive shortly thereafter. The dualistic nature of the delay further
prevents us from accepting the imminent futuristic view of this passage. The parable must be describing the second
phase of the Lord’s coming after the tribulation. Having narrowed down the eschatological options, this discussion
then proceeded to show Marrowism as the only viable soteriological and misthological candidate. The options were
narrowed down to Marrowism by offsetting the three non-Marrowistic counterproposals with a combination of
thirteen soteriological and misthological reasons to regard the foolish virgins as regenerate.
       From this identification, this parable was then used to help fill in the prophetic details regarding the events
at the conclusion of the tribulation. Namely, there will be believers who survive until the end of the tribulation
who, nevertheless, are not regarded as successfully having endured to the end of it. Even though they do not take
the mark of the beast or worship him, they will not be regarded as overcomers, probably due to a lack of love for
the brethren. It is reasonable to deduce that such believers will live until the end of the tribulation and enter the
kingdom in their physical bodies and thus be procreators in the kingdom rather than rulers of it. They will have
sufficient morality to enter the kingdom as procreators (since they did not worship the beast or take his mark) but
insufficient morality to enter the kingdom as co-rulers with Christ (since they were not able to maintain their first
love). We, therefore, have preliminary indications that the darkness in which they are left standing is to be
understood as allowing entrance into the millennial kingdom but exclusion from the joy associated with the bridal
ceremony and wedding feast.

                                        Chapter 15.
                         Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)
                                                   Introduction
       In the previous parable, it was concluded that those believers left standing outside in the darkness pictorially
represent unfaithful believers who live till to the end of the tribulation. This corresponds well with the
dispensational view and understanding of the wedding imagery employed in its historical context. The Lord will
return from heaven with His Bride to the marriage feast. Those believers who have served Him faithfully will join
Him joyously in the feast. In the present parable, we now at last come to the heart of the matter itself in that we will
deal with our first passage which uses the term outer darkness. This is not to say that material related to this term
has not been encountered until now. Far to the contrary, a synonymous form of it was just encountered in the
previous parable, in which the unwise virgins were left standing in the darkness outside. Also, in considering the
NT teaching on the out-resurrection, reason was found to believe that the out-resurrection is the positive inverse of
the outer darkness.
       The present book already has endeavored to clear the field of eschatological, soteriological, misthological,
hermeneutical, and contextual misunderstandings that might arise as briers and brush in hindering Marrowists from
planting their seed in good ground. The purpose of this present chapter is thus simply to plant the seed of the
kingdom message in its pristine simplicity. In the next chapter, that seed will be watered by finishing an
examination of the passage in its proceeding context (concerning the parable of the sheep and the goats).
       As to its preceding context (regarding the parable of the virgins), it was noted that Mt 25:13 is a transitional
verse between that parable and this one about the talents. Due to the transitional nature of this verse, it is included
in the quoted text below (but not in the headings since it already was dealt with under the heading for the parable of
the virgins). Once the rest of this extended context for the parable of the talents has been explored in the next
chapter, the other parables dealing with the outer darkness will receive interaction in the next section.

                                   Parable of the Talents (Mt 25:14-30)

                                                        Text
       13Be on the alert then, for you do not know the day nor the hour. 14For it is just like a man about to
       go on a journey, who called his own slaves, and entrusted his possessions to them. 15And to one he
       gave five talents, to another, two, and to another, one, each according to his own ability; and he went
       on his journey. 16Immediately the one who had received the five talents went and traded with them,
       and gained five more talents. 17In the same manner the one who had received the two talents gained
       two more. 18But he who received the one talent went away and dug in the ground, and hid his
       master’s money. 19Now after a long time the master of those slaves came and settled accounts with
       them. 20And the one who had received the five talents came up and brought five more talents, saying,
       “Master, you entrusted five talents to me; see, I have gained five more talents.” 21His master said to
       him, “Well done, good and faithful slave; you were faithful with a few things, I will put you in charge
       of many things, enter into the joy of your master.” 22The one also who had received the two talents
       came up and said, “Master, you entrusted to me two talents; see, I have gained two more talents.”
       23His master said to him, “Well done, good and faithful slave; you were faithful with a few things, I

       will put you in charge of many things; enter into the joy of your master.” 24And the one also who had
       received the one talent came up and said, “Master, I knew you to be a hard man, reaping where you
       did not sow, and gathering where you scattered no seed. 25 “And I was afraid, and went away and hid
       your talent in the ground; see, you have what is yours.” 26But his master answered and said to him,
       “You wicked, lazy slave, you knew that I reap where I did not sow, and gather where I scattered no
       seed. 27 “Then you ought to have put my money in the bank, and on my arrival I would have received
       my money back with interest. 28 “Therefore take away the talent from him, and give it to the one who
       has the ten talents.” 29For to everyone who has shall more be given, and he shall have an abundance;
       but from the one who does not have, even what he does have shall be taken away. 30And cast out the
       worthless slave into the outer darkness; in that place there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
       (Mt 25:13-30)
Page 370                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
When
        The parable of the talents is very similar to the first four Olivet parables. This parable deals with the same
time period as the first parable and presents the same truth in more detail. That the parable of the talents deals with
the current church age is indicated in the very opening verse, where Jesus says that we do not know when He will
return. To illustrate this principle, Jesus uses a parable about servants who do not know when their master will
return. This cannot be referring to those living during the tribulation. Those serving the Lord during the tribulation
will be able to calculate the time of His return to the very day.* The doctrine of imminence demands that we
understand the passage concerning the unknown time of His return as referring to the rapture.
        The Lord confirms this for us in Mt 25:19. The master is gone for a long time but may come back anytime.
His coming is imminent but not immediate. This only fits the description of the rapture. Amazingly, at the
beginning of their comments on the Olivet Discourse, Hindson and Borland state their agreement with Walvoord
that “the rapture is not revealed in this discourse at all, but is a later revelation, introduced by Christ in John 14.”644
Yet when commenting on this phrase in the Mt 25:19, they give an acknowledgement that results in flat
contradiction of this assessment:

                The phrase “after a long time” gives a veiled indication of the length of Christ’s departure to
         heaven during the present age. This is the only place in the Gospels where it is implied that Jesus
         will be gone for a “long time.” Notice in the parable that He goes on a long journey (back to
         heaven) and is gone for a long time before He returns (second coming [= rapture]). This does not
         eliminate the idea of an imminent return at any possible moment [thus rapture], but it does give a
         glimpse into the distant future when He will actually return at a time least expected [thus rapture].645

        After criticizing posttribulationalist G. Campbell Morgan for glossing over details within this discourse that
would distinguish the rapture from the revelation, dispensationalist Walvoord completely ignores the import of this
detail. Ironically, this detail provides a slam dunk in favor of the dispensational distinction between the rapture and
revelation.646 At least dispensationalists Hindson and Borland admit “the journey indicates the time between Jesus’
first coming [at the commencement of the present age] and His final return [at the conclusion of the present age],
during which He is in heaven.”647 Seemly, they cloak their reference to the rapture by referring to it as the
imminent second coming of the Lord at the conclusion of the present age when it would be least expected. Such
comments obviously necessitate that coming in view be that of the rapture. Why not simply admit that they are
talking about the rapture? Probably, because doing so would clash with their desire not to interpret the servant
thrown into the outer darkness as being a raptured believer. The Lord will deal with genuine believers, and only
with genuine believers, when He returns in His second coming at the conclusion of the church age (via the rapture).
Like MacArthur (MNTC), they simply ignore this fact. Their Lordship theology wrecks havoc on their
dispensational eschatology.648
        Granted, Morgan should have paid more attention to the details that would have distinguished the rapture
from the revelation within this discourse. However, he should have done so by noting that the Olivet Discourse
portrays both events and separates them in time. Following the example of Walvoord and other likeminded
dispensationalists, who squash the rapture and revelation together into one event within this discourse by treating
the whole discourse as if it were dealing exclusively with the revelation, is counterintuitive. As a dispensationalist,
I cannot share Morgan’s posttribulational assessment that being cast into the outer darkness relates to believers
passing through the tribulation. Nonetheless, I can appreciate that even as a posttribulationalist he has paid
sufficient attention to the details to take a misthological view of the outer darkness. Moreover, I can agree with him
when he says that the outer darkness is not Gehenna but to be “outside the Kingdom of responsibility.” “The
Kingdom does not merely mark a territory, but it marks the fact of authority, and the exercise of it.”649 Those
believers cast into the outer darkness are cast outside of the sphere of exercising kingdom responsibility, not
outside of the kingdom territory. Because this judgment is of church-age believers, as Morgan correctly perceives,
and because this judgment occurs at the rapture, as Hindson and Borland covertly concede, this judgment must be
misthological rather than soteriological.
        Rapture wins; LS theology loses. This passage is talking about a judgment that occurs at the rapture. Thus,
dispensationalists will have to concede, if they are logically consistent, that this judgment is the Judgment Seat of
Christ and exclusively deals with raptured believers at the conclusion of the church age. Thus, the servant thrown
into the outer darkness is a raptured believer. No dispensational doubt about it. No sign is given anywhere in the

*
    See Unexpected, 338; Unknown, 356.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                                        Page 371
parable to indicate the master’s return. Unlike the previous parable, which gave us a midnight shout, this parable
does not even give a midday whisper. Thus, the time period involved is the church age that will be concluded by
the imminent return of our Master in the rapture. One would immediately think that this means that any futurist
agreeing with Marrowists on the time period naturally would be forced to conclude that the parable must be dealing
with the judgment of believers. Alas, fellow dispensationalists do not always make for good misthologists. In the
previous chart, showing where some dispensationalists line up in regard to the time being depicted, Gaebelein was
shown to share our eschatological understanding.* Yet amazingly, although the rest of the authors in that part of the
chart concur with us concerning the misthological nature of the parable, he does not. Do Marrowists have a right to
charge him with inconsistency? Most emphatically!
        In his discussion of the outer darkness in this parable on the talents, Gaebelein acknowledges that its
misthological twin, the parable of the minas in Luke, “has more to do with rewards in the Kingdom.”650 Whereas
he does not want to enter into discussion of that passage in relation to its Matthean twin, we will deal with this
sister passage both within the present chapter and at its conclusion.† Gaebelein wants to turn the parable about the
unfaithful servant into a soteriological teaching to avoid teaching salvation by works! One is practically
dumbstruck with such soteriological inconsistency. To insist, as we do, that the servant was saved from eternal
damnation despite his performance is the way to counter those who teach salvation by performance. Gaebelein
blunders into teaching soteriological salvation by works by making that salvation dependent on works. Arguing
that the man was merely a professing believer may be good Calvinism but it is poor soteriology.
        How can the Lord be teaching truth pertaining to the rapture, as Gaebelein acknowledges, and yet merely be
dealing with professing believers? When the Lord returns in the rapture, it is to take genuine believers to the Bema
and judge them. For Gaebelein to say that the man was not a true believer is to leave us with the picture that the
Lord raptures unregenerate believers! Marrowists should be able to stop this discussion right here and say that our
point has been proven for dispensationalists who share our understanding of the time period involved.
        For example, although Phillips, in his Matthean commentary, rejects the misthological interpretation of the
outer darkness as dealing with believers on the other two occasions it occurs within Matthew, yet even he is forced
to acknowledge that this Olivet parable regarding the outer darkness is indeed dealing with believers because he is
compelled (by his dispensational understanding of the detailed indicators regarding the timing of this passage) to
regard it as dealing with the rapture. So how does Phillips attempt to reconcile the fact that this slave being thrown
into the outer darkness is dealing with rewards when he concluded that those cast into the outer darkness in the
previous parables were lost? He denies that the worthless slave is cast into the outer darkness! According to
Phillips, we are to suppose that this worthless slave is taken to the outer darkness so that he can look into it and see
the lost souls he might have reached had he been faithful. Such a fanciful interpretation is nothing less than an
attempt to tiptoe around the fact that Matthew uses the same identical expression for being cast into (eis to) outer
darkness on all three occasions. The slave is not brought to the outer darkness to stand on its brink and look down
inside it at those who have been cast into it. He himself is cast into it.
        If the passage is dealing with the rapture, it must be representing the Bema judgment of genuine believers,
as even Phillips has to admit. And if such is the case, then the point being advanced herein already has been
established—the passage is misthological rather than soteriological. The parable is dealing with rewards within
heaven, not entrance into heaven. Nevertheless, for the sake of those who do not hold my eschatological outline or
who need further demonstration that the passage is indeed referring to church-age believers, I will proceed by
asking, “Who do the slaves in general and the unwise slave in particular represent?” The fact that the passage is
contrasting what happens to faithful and unfaithful believers is indicated in numerous details. I will array my
assessment of the time period and the people involved by going over the details of the parable, one at a time.

Who

                                        Believers Need to Stay Alert
      First, the opening words of verse 13 are a command: “Stay on the alert.” The verb is a present imperative of
gregoreo. We already have encountered this verb a number of times in our journey to this point.‡ As a present
imperative, gregoreo probably can be best understood as meaning to continue to be on the alert. Jesus is not

*
  See Illustration 121. Pretribulational Positions for Mt. Olivet,334.
†
  For interaction with Benware who likewise inconsistently regards the unfaithful believer stripped of his mina to be a believer but the
unfaithful believer stripped of his talent to be an unbeliever, see Talents and Minas, 380.
‡
  See 1Thess 5:10,144; Doorkeeper, 178; Alert, 338.
Page 372                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
exhorting this group of people to come to a punctiliar saving faith that would save their spirits from eternal
damnation but to express that saving faith in linear servitude in such a way that it may save their souls from loss.*
In other words, the exhortation is a call to faithfulness, not an invitation to come to faith.
        To be sure, a lack of faith on the part of the servant who buries his talent in the Matthean parable and on the
part of the servant who hides his mina in the Lukan parable is evidenced by their behavior and confessed by their
own lips. These servants explicitly identify the reason they bury their talent as fear, which is the opposite of faith
(Mt 25:25; Lk 19:21). Such lack of faith does not mean, however, that such servants are unbelievers. Christians are
supposed to walk by faith, yet they may fail to do so. Some Christians walk in fear rather than by faith. If believers
do not walk by faith, they will suffer loss of rewards. Hebrews links the believer living by faith with the salvation
of the soul (Heb 10:38-39). The Greek word used of the faithful believers in these parables is pistos. This word can
also be used to describe someone who has faith. In these two contexts, pistos probably has both meanings—faith
and faithfulness—since pistos is contrasted with fear as well as equated with loyal service. The working/living faith
pictured by the Lord in these two parables is a rewards issue. To make working faith a soteriological issue would
be to teach salvation by works and to confuse one’s soteriology with one’s misthology. Misthological faith results
in a reward. As the Lord clarifies in the parable of the minas, wimpy faith only results in the (soteriological)
salvation of one’s life. Praise God that a timid faith can save us from hellfire. But it takes a serving faith to save us
from the outer darkness.
        The servant with timid faith believes a number of things. He believes that his master is coming back.
Additionally, he believes that it would be better to hide the talent rather than spend it, evidently because he
believes that his master will hold him accountable. Moreover, he even shows an obedience of faith in that he
accepts the entrustment.† So in both parables there are multiple indications of faith even on the part of those who
are unfaithful. Still, it is not a victorious or virtuous faith. Their faith is fearful rather than watchful.
        Jesus indicates that if we are watchful we can prevent the thief from coming in the night and breaking into
our house (Mt 24:42-43). Does this mean that we can prevent the rapture by looking for it? Hardly! Rather, if we
are diligently on guard, the event of the rapture and resulting Bema will not have a devastating impact on our
earthly lives. The results of the rapture will be exhilarating to those prepared for it but excruciating to those who
are not. One normally does not look forward to a thief coming and breaking into one’s house and taking everything
one has! It is understandable that not all Christians look forward to the rapture. Parabolically speaking, the Bema
rapture either will result in God taking everything you have or rewarding you with everything He has! To use a
Christmas illustration, one works to prevent thieves from breaking into one’s house, not to prevent Santa Claus
from doing so. He knows if you have been naughty or nice, so be good for the sake of the potential rewards.
         In the Lukan parallel, after talking to His disciples about the importance of laying up treasure in heaven
(Lk 12:33-34), Jesus immediately tells His disciples a parable, using this same verb in Lk 12:37, to show them the
importance of being on the alert. Jesus concludes with the warning about the thief. Peter asks Jesus for
clarification, and Jesus responds in 12:44 that whoever is watchful will be made ruler over everything that God
has! The positive implications of such a promise are mind staggering. But the negative results for those believers
who are not prepared are somber and sobering (Lk 12:46), as already seen in the Matthean parallel.‡
        As already demonstrated, in the Thessalonian passage (1Thess 5:6,10) Paul uses this verb gregoreo
(alert/watchful) to promise believers that they will live with the Lord via the rapture whether or not they have been
morally watchful. Nevertheless, the Thessalonian passage has teeth in it because, although our deliverance from the
tribulation is assured, our doing well at the Bema to follow is not guaranteed. In fact, Paul says that our salvation is
at stake. If we want this salvation, we will have to earn it by being morally watchful. Naturally, since salvation
from eternal damnation is not by works, this means that Paul is referring to misthological salvation. Having already
spent several chapters proving this point regarding Thessalonians, doing so will not be necessary here. Paul also
urges the believers at Corinth to: “Be on the alert, stand firm in the faith” (1Cor 16:13). Those told to be (or really
to stay) on alert are those who already have come to faith. It is a summons to stand firm in the faith they already
have. Nowhere in the NT is this verb, much less this command, used of the lost.
        Marrowists are not surprised to find Paul urging the Colossians to be watchful (Col 4:2), or Peter likewise
telling his congregation to be watchful (1Pet 5:8). But we would be highly surprised if Jesus were calling upon
those who do not believe in Him to continue watching for Him! Such an expectation would be logically
inconsistent. But we do not find any such inconsistency in the passage or in the NT. Believers, not unbelievers, are

Analysis. For distinction between salvation of the soul and spirit, see endnote 186 within the present work.

  See Obedience of Faith, 400.
