Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                          Page 373
exhorted to watchfulness so that they can be rulers in the coming kingdom.
       Being alert is a misthological theme for those who already are soteriologically saved. This Matthean passage
cannot be addressing the lost about soteriological issues since it is using an exhortation that is never used
soteriologically anywhere else in the NT but repeatedly is used misthologically. Jesus apocalyptically uses the
imperative in Rev 3:2-3 to command believers to become watchful, that is, Wake Up! Again, Jesus refers to His
coming as a thief in the night. And Jesus parenthetically clarifies exactly what He means later in the epistle:
“Behold, I am coming like a thief. Blessed is the one who stays awake and keeps his garments, lest he walk about
naked and men see his shame” (Rev 16:15). Keeping the garments you already have, as a believer, is
conditioned upon your keeping awake. The exhortation to stay on the alert in this parable about the outer darkness
is addressed to believers. Whether it is expressed parabolically, epistolary, or apocalyptically, believers are the
ones exhorted to be alert.

                                        Believers Addressed by Warning
        Second, as already noted, Mt 25:13 is a transitional verse between the parable of the virgins and the parable
of the talents. For that reason, I have included it in the text above (although not in the headings since we dealt with
this verse initially under the heading concerning the parable of the virgins). But my exegesis concerning the foolish
virgins, in conjunction with that offered here, proves that the intended application and warning of these two
parables is for those who genuinely are saved, since the you addressed in the warning is addressed to Peter, James,
John, and Andrew (cp. Mt 24:3 with Mk 13:3).

        3And as He was sitting on the Mount of Olives opposite the temple, Peter and James and John and
        Andrew were questioning Him privately, 4“Tell us, when will these things be, and what will be the
        sign when all these things are going to be fulfilled?” 5And Jesus began to say to them, “See to it that
        no one misleads you.” (Mk 13:3-5)

        3And as He was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to Him privately, saying, “Tell us,
        when will these things be, and what will be the sign of Your coming, and of the end of the age?”
        4And Jesus answered and said to them, “See to it that no one misleads you.…13Be on the alert then,

        for you do not know the day nor the hour.” (Mt 24:3-4; 25:13)

The warnings are addressed to His believing disciples (Peter, James, John, and Andrew), who are questioning Him
privately. Thus, it is inconceivable that the warning about being unworthy slaves is addressed to any other than
those who genuinely are saved.*

                                    Believers Today Do Not Know that Day
        Third, the believers living during the time of the tribulation will know the precise day that Jesus will return
with the mathematical certainty.† Although Mt 25:13 is a transitional verse with imperatival applicability to
believers living in the future to be prepared, the unknown timing of His coming is an interpretational limitation that
is only relevant to those living in the present church age.‡ The argument that the Lord will shorten the number of
days of the tribulation is a miscalculation of the meaning in Mt 24:22 and Mk 13:20. Constable concurs that these
days have been shortened prophetically to 1,260 days.651 Chitwood, likewise, wisely insists that the number of days
cannot be shortened from the 1,260 days, but he takes a different approach and asserts that the length of the days
themselves will be shortened on the basis of Rev 8:12 and Amos 8:9.652 Commentators on Revelation such as Epp
and Becker share this perspective, and Ryrie concedes that it is a valid interpretation.653 Regardless of whether the
expression means that the days are shortened prophetically or temporally, they will not be shortened numerically.
Even if the earth spins faster it will still spin the same number of days. The fact that the time of the Lord’s return is
unknown means that we can know with certainty that it is addressing believers living in the present time period.

                                             Believers Are His Own
        Fourth, to whom is Jesus referring when He identifies these three slaves as His own (Mt 25:14)? Does Jesus
refer to the lost or to the saved as His own? Surely Jesus’ description of believers as His own sheep in Jn 10:3-4,14

*
  See Illustration 136. Probabilities for the Unworthy Slave of Mt 25:13-30, 391.
†
  See Unexpected, 338; Unknown, 356.
‡
  See Application, 358.
Page 374                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
is the manner in which He identifies those who belong to Him by faith. He calls them His own. All three slaves are
equally His own. The slave who receives one talent is just as much His own as the other two. Again, this is
conclusive evidence that the unworthy slave is one of the elect—His own.

                                            Believers Are Called Slaves
       Fifth, whom do the Lord’s slaves (doulos) represent in the NT? Although it would be presumptuous merely
to assume that the term slave necessarily refers to someone who is saved, nevertheless it is in accord with
Marrowistic exegetical conclusions to note that whenever someone is affirmed to be a slave of the Lord in the NT
that the person’s status as one of the elect is also implicitly confirmed.* The NT never pictures the Lord’s slave as
someone who is lost. Our interpretation that the Lord is using slaves to picture saved believers in this parable is in
accord with NT usage. The implementation of this observation is not reading an epistolary usage back into the
gospels; rather, this interpretation finds that the epistolary usage may be traced back to the Lord Himself in that He
regards believers as His slaves and His slaves as believers. Those who attempt to neutralize the term slave so as to
use it indiscriminately, as referring jointly to both believers and unbelievers, will have to assume the burden of
proof. Let them prove that the slave is unsaved.

                                              Believers are Entrusted
       Sixth, to whom does the Lord entrust His work (in Mt 25:14)—to the lost or to the saved? Granted, there are
unsaved people who have taken positions of leadership in the churches. But that is the point; they have taken these
positions in the churches; these positions have not been given to them by the Lord. If a lost person has taken the
role of the pastor, it is not because the Lord has called him to that position. The point of this parable is not that
some people are in positions they should not be occupying. Rather, it is that some people who are in their proper
God-given positions are not doing their God-given duty. Does the Lord impart these talents to the lost and saved?
No. These are not natural talents, but spiritual talents to be used in His work. The Lord gives His spiritual talents
(such as spiritual gifts) only to those who genuinely are saved. With the receiving of such gifts comes the
responsibility to use them profitably. To what would the departure of the Master correspond in Mt 25:15? It
naturally would refer to the ascension at which time Jesus left believers in charge of His work. When the Lord
departed, He entrusted believers with the task of making disciples and gave each believer at least one spiritual gift
to use in that task. He did not entrust the lost with the Great Commission nor give unbelievers spiritual gifts to use
in His work. The unworthy slave must be one of the elect since he is so entrusted.

What is Entrusted?
       Pagenkemper counters this position by stressing the significance of what is taken away: “The failure to use
what was entrusted is viewed by the master as a grievous wrong, and so he severed his relationship with the servant
by removing the resources granted to him.”654 “Such an unfaithful servant will be severed from his relationship
with the master.” “Jesus’ kingdom parallels strongly suggest a rejection that is not simply that of a follower losing
out on an esteemed position in the kingdom, but a soteriological rejection from the eschatological kingdom.”655
       The reader is thus presented with two possibilities. The text either refers to a lost Jew who ultimately is
removed from his covenantal relationship with God, or it describes a carnal believer who ultimately is removed
from his position of service to God. In response to Pagenkemper, it may be asked, “Did Jesus intend to say that He
would be entrusting the lost Jews with the work of His kingdom when He returned to His Father?” If this is a
soteriological relationship, which is forfeited because of poor performance (as Pagenkemper maintains), then it is
difficult to see how he can avoid the accusation of advocating a performance-based soteriology. Further, it would
appear to be an Arminian soteriology in that the relationship (which was truly genuine during the Master’s
absence) is ultimately lost. That Pagenkemper’s Calvinism leads to Arminianism is not surprising. The pragmatic
equivalence of their soteriology concerning perseverance already has been shown.†
       On the other hand, if it is not a soteriological relationship which is forfeited, then Pagenkemper’s criticism
of the misthological position is groundless. Contrary to Pagenkemper, what is lost is not salvation from eternal
damnation but the opportunity to serve. Certainly those in hell lose any opportunity to serve God, but why presume
that the service or lack thereof depicted in this parable represents that of a severed soteriological relationship?
After all, if the service of the other two slaves represents that of genuine believers serving the Lord, then it would
be natural to take the lack of service represented by the third slave to picture the failure of genuine believers in
*
    The slaves in Mt 13:27 picture the elect—albeit probably elect angels.
†
    See Illustration 100. Acronymic Salvation of Pears and TULIP, 272.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                                       Page 375
serving God. This taking away of the talent would also coincide with the misthological teaching of the NT in which
it is possible to lose one’s crown (Rev 3:11), to lose one’s reward (2Jn 1:8), and to suffer loss of one’s reward
(1Cor 3:15). Further, in the twin parable of the minas, the taking away of the mina is contrasted (rather than
equated) with the forfeiture of life (Lk 19:24-26). In distinction to the enemies who lose their lives, the slave loses
his mina. Rewards are forfeitable, the gift of eternal life is not forfeitable.

Jewish Slaves were Entrusted
       Granted, the Jewish people (i.e., those related to God by physical birth under the old covenant in the past)
were the ones who originally “were entrusted with the oracles of God” (Rom 3:2). (Note the past tense.) Some
object that since not all Jews under the old covenant were saved (yet the Jewish race was entrusted with the oracles
of God), not all those entrusted in the present dispensation necessarily are regenerate either. Supposedly, mere
professing believers are entrusted with the gospel as part of the covenant community.
       In response to such an objection, note that in the new dispensation it is not professing believers but genuine
believers who are related to the Lord under the new covenant (which entails a circumcision of the heart rather than
of the flesh) to whom the Lord entrusts Himself and His work. The NT is replete with conceptual parallels, which
also have been rendered by the NAS as entrusted and teach that genuine believers are the ones entrusted with this
stewardship (1Cor 9:17) of the gospel ministry (Gal 2:7; 1Thess 2:4; 1Tim 1:11; 1Tim 6:20; 2Tim 1:14; Tit 1:3). In
fact, one does not have to wait until the present dispensation to find this transition. Jesus “was not entrusting
Himself” to new Jewish converts even during the earliest stages of His ministry (Jn 2:24). If Jesus intends to teach
an entrustment based on covenantal relationship in this Matthean parable (as Pagenkemper supposes), then the
Lord is teaching something contrary to His own practice (and Matthew is recording something contrary to NT
usage).* During His earthy ministry, Jesus was not even entrusting new, regenerate, Jewish converts with fuller
intimate revelations of Himself. To claim that these parables show that He was going to be entrusting unregenerate
Jews with the future stewardship of His kingdom message is ridiculous. Either Jesus does not practice what He
preaches, or Pagenkemper has misunderstood what Jesus teaches.
        The latter is the provable state of affairs. Jesus already had announced the transference of stewardship away
from the Jews earlier: “Therefore I say to you, the kingdom of God will be taken away from you, and be given to a
nation producing the fruit of it” (Mt 21:43). He now pictures that reality parabolically. Jesus is not depicting a
stewardship in the old economy (in the parable of the talent and other related parables). Rather, He is speaking
futuristically in anticipation of the stewardship in which believers in Him would find themselves in the new
dispensation. Paul and Barnabas ran headlong into the reality of this situation and “spoke out boldly and said, ‘It
was necessary that the word of God should be spoken to you [Jews] first; since you repudiate it, and judge
yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we are turning to the Gentiles’” (Acts 13:46).
       The Jews proved themselves to be unworthy stewards of the message of eternal life. This message has now
been given to the church. It is no longer the Jewish race who proclaims the message of God. A new race has been
chosen: “But you [believers] are [to be] a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for God's own
possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of Him who has called you out of darkness into His marvelous
light” (1Pet 2:9). The stewardship has been removed from Abraham’s physical descendants and given to his
spiritual descendants—to born-again believers—to those who are under the new covenant. The stewardship
correspondingly pictured in the parable of the talents is that of a regenerate, new-covenant believer.

Jewish Slaves will be Entrusted
       At a FGA conference in 2011, in his presentation Laying Up Treasures or Perhaps Not, Benware took the
position that these parabolic servants could not represent church-age believers because Jesus’ disciples would not
have known what He was talking about, since they did not know anything about the church at the time.† Thus, the
servants must be tribulational Jews. After all, ethnic Jews frequently are called God’s servant. The example cited
by Benware was Is 41:8, in which ethnic Jews are referred to as: “Israel, My servant.” I might also add at least
one more similar type reference in support of Benware’s contention: “Jacob, My servant” (Is 44:1). Also, on
behalf of Benware’s position, I would point out that Israel, as a servant, is criticized as being blind: “Who is blind
but My servant, or so deaf as My messenger whom I send? Who is so blind as he that is at peace with Me, or so

*
  See illustration of entrustment in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
†
  In counterpoint, I believe Jesus anticipated the interim nature of the kingdom in His parables. See Inductive Approach, 8. Therefore,
I will not pursue a rejoinder to Benware on this particular matter since those preliminary remarks advising against limiting our
understanding of Jesus’ parables to that of His original listeners have been provided previously.
Page 376                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
blind as the servant of the Lord?” (Is 42:19) Nevertheless, Israel was chosen by God as His servant and witness:
“You are My witnesses,’ declares the Lord, ‘And My servant whom I have chosen, in order that you may know and
believe Me, and understand that I am He” (Is 43:10). One might theorize, therefore, as Benware does, that at the
conclusion of the church age (when God resumes His work with Israel during the tribulation) lost Jews among
Israel might, in part, compose the body of servants. In other words, according to this proposal, although God does
not currently entrust His kingdom work to the lost in church, He will entrust His kingdom work to the lost among
Israel in the future during the tribulation when the Jews are entrusted with the gospel of the kingdom.

       Current and Future Witnesses
       By way of preliminary response to Benware’s position, however, I would reiterate that the Lord appoints
those as His witnesses who have received the Holy Spirit: “But you shall receive power when the Holy Spirit has
come upon you; and you shall be My witnesses both in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and even to the
remotest part of the earth” (Acts 1:8). I see no reason to suppose that He will change His modus operandi at the
conclusion of the church age, especially since He seals 144,000 Jews as His evangelists during the tribulation!
Nevertheless, for sake of argument, suppose that Benware is correct in his supposition that the Lord’s servant who
is being called into account in this parable is Israel at the end of the tribulation and that many Jews called into
account for their service at that time will be lost. Even so, his conclusion does not necessarily follow: that the
servant being thrown into the outer darkness represents a lost Jew. In fact, even if Benware’s premise is adopted,
his conclusion must be rejected.

        Israel My Redeemed Servant
        At the conference Benware called our attention to Is 41:8; in this book I call your attention to the context of
Benware’s proof text. Immediately after God refers to Israel as His servant in Is 41:8, He refers to Himself as
Israel’s Redeemer: “‘I will help you,’ declares the Lord, ‘And your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel’”
(Is 41:14). Despite Israel’s dismal performance, God reassures His servant, Israel, that He is his Redeemer. Indeed,
one should read chs. 41-43 of Isaiah in their entirety to get a full appreciation for how emphatically the context
affirms Israel’s redeemed status. A few highlights will suffice for present purposes. The Lord reassures that He is
Israel’s Redeemer: “Thus says the Lord your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel, ‘For your sake I have sent to
Babylon, and will bring them all down as fugitives’” (Is 43:14). Israel represents how God deals with His
redeemed slave. Certainly, more than potential redemption is in view.
        Just a few verses after chastising Israel as His blind servant (Is 42:19), the Lord emphasizes: “O Israel, ‘Do
not fear, for I have redeemed you; I have called you by name; you are Mine!” (Is 43:1) One could not possibly
ask for a clearer affirmation that Israel represents those who already have been redeemed. They are to return to
their Redeemer not in order to be redeemed or forgiven but because they already are redeemed and forgiven:
“Remember these things, O Jacob, and Israel, for you are My servant; I have formed you, you are My servant, O
Israel, you will not be forgotten by Me. I have wiped out your transgressions like a thick cloud, and your sins
like a heavy mist. Return to Me, for I have redeemed you” (Is 44:21-22). Yet again, their completed state in terms
of already being redeemed by their Redeemer is assured: “For the Lord has redeemed Jacob and in Israel He
shows forth His glory. Thus says the Lord, your Redeemer, and the one who formed you from the womb”
(Is 44:23-24). This redeemed servant, Israel, should break out singing, “I know my Redeemer lives!”

       Israel My Redeemed Son
       Israel is more than a redeemed slave/servant, however: “‘Do not fear, for I am with you; I will bring your
offspring from the east, and gather you from the west.’ I will say to the north, ‘Give them up!’ And to the south,
‘Do not hold them back.’ Bring My sons from afar, and My daughters from the ends of the earth” (Is 43:5-6).
Here, the sons and daughter of Israel are referred to as God’s sons and daughters. Israel is God’s redeemed slave-
child. Moreover, the sins of this slave-child are forgiven for God’s own sake: “I, even I, am the one who wipes out
your transgressions for My own sake; and I will not remember your sins” (Is 43:25).
       They belong to their Redeemer: “This one will say, ‘I am the Lord’s’; and that one will call on the name of
Jacob; and another will write on his hand, ‘Belonging to the Lord,’ and will name Israel’s name with honor. Thus
says the Lord, the King of Israel and his Redeemer, the Lord of hosts: ‘I am the first and I am the last, and there is
no God besides Me’” (Is 44:5-6). Did Benware carefully consider the full import of the context of Is 41:8? If so,
then how did he conclude that, if the servants in this parable represent Israel as God’s servant, the unfaithful
servant represents someone who is lost?
       In this OT context God pours out His heart in passionate love for His wayward servant/son Israel and offers
unconditional assurances to Israel. Despite the sinful disobedience of Israel, this servant/son is redeemed by his
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                          Page 377
Redeemer. Israel is God’s child who belongs to Him, who already has been redeemed and forgiven by Him, and
who will be gathered in safely to Him. Israel’s sins will be forgotten, but he himself will not be forgotten. This
servant/son is exhorted to return to his Redeemer, not in order to be redeemed but because he already is redeemed.
Remarkable! This OT context is a beautiful, typological picture of unconditional security for Israel as God’s
servant/son.
       If this is the context the Lord had in mind in Mt 25:30, then the servant does not represent a lost Jew but a
saved Jew—an unconditionally secure Jew who is thrown into the outer darkness. The outer darkness could not
possibly represent hell in such a case. The issue is not whether this servant is redeemed or belongs to God as His
child. Such matters are a given—given the OT context to which Benware directs us. Thus, in conjunction with the
OT background, and contrary to Benware, the issue is service, not redemption. If His servant Israel does not return
to Him, as enjoined in this OT context, then one would anticipate that the Lord must judge Israel’s service as being
unworthy of reward. Accordingly, this NT passage would be a picture of eternal security amidst misthological
accountability, given the background of the OT typology.

       Israel My Redeemed Punished Servant
       This conclusion should not come as any shock for those who regard this Matthean servant to represent how
God deals with His servant Israel. For this conclusion would have been derivable from the OT itself. If one will
consult the OT background, such a conclusion would have followed naturally: “‘And fear not, O Jacob My
servant,’ declares the Lord, and do not be dismayed, O Israel; for behold, I will save you from afar, and your
offspring from the land of their captivity. And Jacob shall return, and shall be quiet and at ease, and no one shall
make him afraid. ‘For I am with you,’ declares the Lord, to save you; for I will destroy completely all the nations
where I have scattered you, only I will not destroy you completely. But I will chasten you justly, and will by no
means leave you unpunished” (Jer 30:10-11; cp. 46:27-28). God’s chastisement (discipline) is linked with
punishment.* Israel, God’s unconditionally secure servant-son, will be saved but punished. As Claeys observes,

          Israel is portrayed in the Old Testament as a son of God who drifted far from his Father. As a result
          of presenting Israel as being in a family relationship with him, God calls Israel back into fellowship
          (a close relationship) with him throughout the Old Testament, the Gospels, and the book of Acts.
          That call back to fellowship with God is called repentance. (Emphasis his.)656

In an endnote to this statement, Claeys continues:

                 Since Israel is a son of God (or a backsliding daughter in Jer. 31:21-22), the nation is a
          picture of a believer in Christ (cf. John 1:12; Gal 4:7; 1 John 5:1), but one who has drifted far
          from God (such as the prodigal son of Luke 15). Like a believer in Christ, Israel has an eternal
          relationship with God (cf. Jer. 31:35-37.); but, like any good father, God desires a close
          relationship—fellowship—with his child. (Italics his.)657

        Marrowists recognize that the servant thrown into the outer darkness is unconditionally secure as to his
eternal destiny. The servant is saved from hell but punished in the outer darkness. Some Marrowists might regard
the servants as referring to tribulational Jewish believers, while other Marrowists regard them as church-age
believers. Even in the case of those who might regard these Jewish servants to be a mixture of regenerate and
unregenerate Jews (thus ethnic Jews), Marrowists still could contend that the Lord is portraying how He deals with
Israel as a picture of how He deals with believers. Typologically, therefore, at the very least, the Lord parabolically
is portraying how He deals with unfaithful Jewish believers. Regardless of the differences of opinion regarding
these particulars, in either case Marrowists acknowledge that the servant thrown into the outer darkness represents
a soteriologically secure servant-son who is punished for not behaving appropriately. Misbehavior does not prove
that the servant being thrown into the outer darkness is being dealt with as an unbeliever.

     Security in Slavery
     Thankfully, as a securitist, Benware affirms unconditional security. As such, I would remind Benware of his
own words: “Those of us who believe in the eternal security of the believer see a parallel between ourselves
and God’s covenant relationship with Israel.”658 Yes, securitists certainly see a parallel, and it is spelled out

*
    See Illustration 323. Discipline is Punishment, 899.
Page 378                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
above—in the very context of the passage to which Benware misdirected us, as supposedly proving that the Jewish
slave thrown into the outer darkness represents someone who is lost because this is allegedly how Jesus deals with
Jewish people in this OT context. Benware needs to revisit his securitistic roots and observe the unconditional
security being depicted in the context of the very passage to which he directed us. The nation of Israel
typologically represents a redeemed, unconditionally, eternally secure servant-child whom God will discipline and
even punish. How can one read this OT context* and then come to this NT passage and conclude that servant must
be lost because this represents how the Lord will deal with His Jewish servants in accordance to the manner
pictured by this OT background? Benware’s gravest mistake is not in regarding these servants as tribulational Jews
but in failing to recognize that unconditionally security applies to these Jewish servants. Israel (as God’s servant-
son) typologically represents an unconditionally secure believer in the very context of the proof text to which
Benware directs us. If Is 41:8 is indeed the background by which the Lord wishes His parable to be interpreted,
then the servant thrown into the outer darkness parabolically pictures unconditional security.

        Exodus Generation
        A word regarding typology is probably in order. For Israel to represent unconditional security typologically,
it need not be supposed that every single Jew is unconditionally secure. Far from it! For example, the Jewish
generation that exited out of Egypt is perceived correctly by securitists to picture unconditional security. For
example, Gleason provides multiple points in defending the redeemed status of the Exodus generation to support
his thesis: “Despite their unbelief and rebellion at Kadesh-barnea, the Exodus generation was a redeemed people
who had exercised faith.” “Because of the typological relationship between [the] readers [of Hebrews] and the
Israelites in the wilderness, the spiritual condition of the latter provides an interpretive key to understand the
spiritual condition of those warned in Hebrews 3–4.” In other words, because of the typological relationship
between NT believers and Israel, the redeemed status of the one infers the redeemed status of the other. Both
groups are redeemed. Moreover, their redeemed status was not at stake, even when they failed to enter the
promised rest: “Their redemption (i.e., salvation) from Egypt was not forfeited, for they were never allowed to
return to their former bondage under Pharaoh. Instead, God ‘carried’ them along in the wilderness ‘as a man carries
his son’ (Deut. 1:31).” What the writer of Hebrews is pointing out (Heb 3:11; 4:3,5), in alluding back to not
entering God’s rest in Ps 95:11, is that what is at stake is “forfeiting the right to worship before the presence of the
Lord in His holy sanctuary” (emphasis his). As Gleason notes, God’s resting place would be the Promised Land
and particularly Mount Zion (Ps 132:8,13-14; Is 11:10). Being able to worship God in the Promised Land and
Mount Zion are at stake for the believer.659 Or to restate Gleason’s splendid conclusions, by means of the
terminology used herein, misthological exclusion from the Promised Land and misthopological exclusion from the
City of Rest are at stake for the redeemed believer.† The Palmist and the writer of Hebrews are typologically
portraying the objective nature of this reality; whereas, Jesus parabolically is presenting its emotive and correlative
force, picturing it as weeping in the outer darkness. Yet this typological correlation does not necessarily mean that
every Jew who participated in that exodus was an unconditionally secure believer. For example, although the snake
on the pole typologically represented Christ, this does not mean that Christ is a snake! Neither typology nor
correlativity implies literal or historical equivalency.
        The Exodus generation was not allowed to go back to Egypt, even though they wanted to do so. The sea
closed behind them; the window of opportunity was shut. The passage through the Red Sea on dry ground was a
one-way trip.660 The Lord repeatedly reminded that generation of Jews that they previously were slaves in Egypt,

*
  Even aside from these texts and these considerations, Neff correctly finds it critically important that we recognize that Israel was a
redeemed nation, God’s redeemed people. For this is why they could live by keeping the law (Lev 18:5). See Neff, Live (pp. 77-81).
†
  Gleason also believes that the writer of Hebrews uses God’s rest in Gen 2:2 to include Adam’s rest in Gen 2:15, where God caused
(Hiphil) Adam to rest (nuach). Adam did not cultivate the ground until after he was expelled from the garden (Gen 3:23). For such
reasons, Gleason believes that Gen 2:15 should be translated as: God rested Adam in the garden to worship and obey Him. Granted,
worship is part of the rest in Psalms. But I would prefer to interpret tending (abad) the garden in 2:15 as a form of ruling it (cp.
Gen 1:26). Rulership is rest. Incidentally, how and where did God rest from His works in Gen 2:2? I would suggest that He rested by
sitting down (cp. Heb 1:3; 8:1; 10:12; 12:2) in His Heavenly Garden (atop the Emerald Eden) to rule. He rested from one form of
activity (i.e., creation) to assume another (i.e., rulership). Just as God rested by ruling from Heavenly Eden, Adam was to rest by
exercising rulership in the earthly Eden—the typological counterpart to the Heavenly Eden. As an aside, note that Adam was not
driven from Garden of Eden until after he was redeemed (via the blood of the slain animal). Typologically, it was as a redeemed son
that Adam was expelled from the garden, and, once expelled, he never was allowed to return, being eternally barred thereafter from
the eating of the tree of life (which he probably had been eating until that time) and thus from living forever, that is, from qualitatively
having the degree of eternal life associated with eating from the tree of life (Gen 3:31-24). The misthopological parallels will become
more obvious as we proceed. For example, see City of Rest, 551; Illustration 345. Three Possible Locations of the Emerald Eden, 922.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                            Page 379
but now they are redeemed (Dt 15:15; 24:18). Consequently, they are God’s servant. Regardless as to whether
every single Jew who left Israel was a believer, they all represented believers typologically. In like fashion, even
though every Jew who looked to the serpent on the pole may not have been a believer, each of them typologically
represents a redeemed believer. Collectively, those Jews represent believers, even if every single one of them was
not a believer individually. In the same way, Israel, as God’s servant, represents redeemed believers even if every
Jew is not a believer. When Israel is pictured as God’s servant, a redeemed servant is in view. If this typology is
the backdrop for Jesus’ parabolic picture, then how God deals with His redeemed servants is the subject matter.
       This imagery and typology applies to the NT believer as well. The NT calls us slaves of Christ (1Cor 7:22;
Eph 6:6), and rightly so, since He bought us (1Cor 6:20; 7:23). There is security in such slavery, not just
accountability. Regrettably, some otherwise fine writers think that if a believer stops believing, then that believer
no longer has eternal life. According to some such writers, the person does not lose eternal life but rejects it.
Supposedly, the individual has the option to reject the free gift of eternal life after receiving it. Logically, of course,
that presents a problem: “How can you reject a life that is eternal after you already have received it?” Even aside
from such problems, this perspective fails to take into account that the Lord refuses to let His servant go. Why?
Because this servant is His son. God told Pharaoh, “Israel is My son, My first-born. So I said to you, ‘Let My son
go, that he may serve Me’” (Ex 4:22-23). Believers, whether they are OT or NT believers, are servant-sons. God
will not let go of His servant-sons because they are His children.
       Can believers let go of God, even though He will not let go of them, so as to no longer be His servant-sons?
No. A slave does not have the right to tell His master, “I refuse to be your slave anymore.” The master owns the
slave and thus has a right to keep the slave—no matter if that slave does not want to be a slave any longer.
Likewise, slave-sons do not have the option to tell Christ, “I am returning your redemption payment; I am no
longer your slave.” Legally, as slaves, they do not have that right. One reason the Lord made us His slaves was so
that He could keep us unconditionally.

        Redemption is Non-Refundable
        That redemption was not paid to us, but for us. Redemption is not ours to return. Jesus likewise pictures
believers as secure sheep. The sheep’s safety is the shepherd’s responsibly (cp. Jn 10:28-29). We are sheep who
are kept safe in His hand because we do not have the right or power to squirm out of His hand. We could no more
tell Him that we are not His sheep anymore than a sheep could tell its shepherd that it is no longer his sheep. Once
His sheep always His sheep (OSAS). We do not have the right or ability to change that fact. Isaiah makes a similar
point in the context of Is 41:8. Whether or not we like it, remaining His redeemed slave is not an option, even when
being submitted to His punishment. For those who are redeemed, it must be affirmed that once a slave always a
slave (OSAS). Believers are His slaves. He has the right to keep us. However, He also has the right and
responsibility to punish us. The OT background regarding Israel as God’s servant acknowledges both aspects.
        Marrowists correctly perceive both aspects in the present parable regarding the servant thrown into the outer
darkness. The talent the slave returned to his master was not his redemption. The slave still remains his master’s
slave even after returning his master’s talent to him. The worthless slave remains his master’s slave just as much as
the faithful slaves remain his slaves. As believers we can rejoice in our slavery to the Lord because it assures us of
unconditional security. Benware failed to perceive the security pictured by this kind of slavery. Believers can sing,

                                    Redeemed, how I love to proclaim it!
                                    Redeemed by the blood of the Lamb;
                                    Redeemed through His infinite mercy,
                                    His child and forever I am.

With all sincerity, and without the least bit of resentment, if believers are familiar with the emphatic OT typology
pictured in Isaiah chs. 41-44 and its NT applicability, they also can sing,

                                    His slave, how I love to proclaim it!
                                    Redeemed by the blood of the Lamb;
                                    Redeemed through His infinite mercy,
                                    His slave and forever I am.

Let believers rejoice in their slavery because it assures them of unconditional security. I am thankful to be the
Lord’s slave and to realize that my security is completely out of my hands and completely in His capable hands.
Page 380                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
                                                             661
Even bridal slaves can sing joyfully of their slavery. There is security in being the Lord’s slave-sheep-son. In
terms of belonging to the Lord as His treasured possession at this soteric level, once a slave-sheep-son always a
slave-sheep-son (OSAS-OSAS-OSAS).* How powerful is such security? Just as powerful as the Master’s hand. To
take this slave out of his Master’s hand, the molester must reckon with the slave’s Master, not with the slave. A
slave is not responsible for his or her own safety. The Master squarely bears that responsibility.

       Talents and Minas
       After Benware’s presentation, one of the conference speakers asked me what I thought about Benware’s
presentation. This inquiring speaker was well aware that I take the opposing position and regard the slave thrown
into the outer darkness to be a believer, as attested in my books Breaking the Rocking Horse and Woolly Wolves
and Woolless Sheep, which I had on sale in the lobby. I remarked that there is little point in attacking the argument
of someone who already has shot himself in the foot. And I was not even referring to OT background above, which
is so detrimental to Benware’s comments! Instead, I was referring to the introduction Benware’s presentation.
Remarkably, Benware had begun his presentation with the parable of the minas and correctly concluded that the
servant stripped of his mina was a believer. Yet he assumed that the same conclusion would not be applicable for
the servant stripped of his talent!
       Benware’s book The Believer’s Payday was on sale also in the lobby. I had not read his book yet, but after
his presentation I was very intrigued to see how he explained his disjuncture. So I got a copy. Overall, it is a nice
introductory book on the topic of rewards; although, I would take exception to some of his positions, such as his
opinion that genuine believers never commit apostasy.662 However, there was a serious omission, at least from my
conference perception.

        Pray tell, since Benware never tells, either in his book or at the conference, “How can anyone seriously look
at these two passages and fail to ascertain that they are talking about the same basic event?” If one can conclude, as
Benware does, that the Lukan passage is talking about the judgment of believers, then what is to preclude one from
concluding that the twin Matthean passage also is talking about the judgment of believers. Beware of anyone who
interprets the parable of the minas and talents as talking about two entirely different events.
          At the conference Benware claimed that Jesus could not have been talking about a church-age believer in
Matthew because Jesus’ disciples would not have been familiar with church-age truths. Thus, he concluded that the
servant thrown into the outer darkness must have been a tribulational Jewish unbeliever. I anticipated that, at the
very least, Benware would try to be consistent and somehow argue that the servant stripped of his mina in Luke

believes that Luke is dealing with the Bema but, on the same page in which he concludes that the passage in Luke
is dealing with the Bema, Benware explicitly (and correctly) argues that this judgment takes place at the rapture:

          For anyone even roughly familiar with the dispensational framework in which Benware is writing,
Benware has acknowledged, in black and white, that the believer stripped of his mina is a raptured, church-age
believer being dealt with at the church-age judgment of the Bema! If Luke can present raptured, church-age
believers being dealt with at the church-age judgment in the parable of the minas, then what is to prevent Matthew
from doing the same in the parable of the talents? Furthermore, Matthew is the only gospel writer to even mention
the word church in his gospel! Moreover, Matthew even does so twice (Mt 16:18; 18:17), and both occasions occur
before the parable regarding the talent! By acknowledging at the conference that taking away of the mina is dealing
with the judgment of a church-age believer, Benware has demolished his own argument that the taking away of the
talent is dealing with Jewish unbelievers. His reasoning was that because the church was an unknown at the time
Jesus spoke this parable, the taking away of the talent must refer to a judgment after the Second Coming.
Amazingly, his own book obliterates his argument!* If Luke is describing the JSC, as Benware correctly perceives
in his book, then nothing precludes one from concluding that Matthew may be portraying the JSC as well. The
proper conclusion is that both parables are talking about the same event—the judgment of raptured believers at the
JSC. Those believers who have been entrusted by the Lord to do His work in His absence (which would be all
church-age believers and only church-age believers) are being called upon to give an account for their service.
          In his book, Benware matter-of-factly regards the worthless (poneros) slaved striped of his mina to be a
Christian (Lk 19:22). But the same terminology is used by Matthew (25:26) of the slave stripped of his talent. If
Luke is describing a worthless Christian being judged at the Bema, then surely Matthew is describing a worthless
(poneros) Christian judged at the Bema as well.664 Benware nullified his own defense in which he claimed that
Jesus could not have been speaking of a church-age judgment. To his credit, Benware acknowledges that in Luke
the worthless Christian’s sins are dealt with judicially at the Bema.665 More than an awards podium is involved, as
Benware perceptively perceives. Being thrown into the outer darkness is a negative reward. But Benware has
acknowledged that negative outcomes can be administered at the Bema. Although Benware’s book is
commendable in many ways, his position taken at the conference concerning the slave thrown into the outer
darkness is extremely questionable—indeed clearly objectionable. Matthew pretty much just adds an additional
detail about what happens to those servants stripped of their service. They are thrown into the outer darkness.

All Church-Age Believers are Entrusted
       An alternative objection might be made at this point, in response to my previous comments regarding Jesus
not entrusting Himself to new believers (Jn 2:24). Some might claim that if Jesus did not entrust new believers,
then He did not entrust all believers. Therefore, detractors might assert that the talent cannot represent the
regeneration of all believers. Granted, this is a straw-man argument at this point, as this is merely a hypothetical
objection, so there is little need to spend much time responding to it. Nevertheless, in following the NT practice of
dealing with perceived potential reactions of hypothetical objectors, a brief response is permissible.
       First, the talent does not represent regeneration. Therefore, what is lost is not regeneration. What is lost is
stewardship (which is a form of rulership). A misthological rather than soteriological matter is at stake. The talent
represents an entrusted stewardship for those who already have experienced regeneration. Second, the primary
application is not to new believers but to those who have been entrusted with this stewardship over a sufficient
*
  In fact, if one consults a harmony of the gospels, the parable of the minas occurs before the parable of the talents. Jesus already had
presented what Benware admits to be a church-age-judgment-parable regarding the minas before He presented this parable regarding
the talents. Those misthologists who correctly perceive that the parable of the minas is dealing with believers (much less church-age
believers) put themselves at an incredible disadvantage in trying to argue that the parable of the talents is not dealing with the same
motif.
Page 382                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
period of time so as to have been reasonably expected to produce a return. This steward does not picture someone
saved a day before the rapture being thrown into the outer darkness because he did not produce a major return
before the rapture. The parable focuses on the accountability of those who have had time to use their talents to
produce a return. This observation, however, is not an invitation to slothfulness on the part of new believers. New
believers can be powerful witnesses to their old friends. For example, Zaccheus is a picturesque example of a new
believer immediately setting out to earn major rewards.
       Nevertheless, the parabolic focus is on the responsibility incurred with time. The more time you have, the
greater the expectation of a return. Naturally, those believers who have been in the Lord’s service for ten years
would be expected to have produced more return than those who only had been believers for ten days.* In the
parallel passage already addressed, Jesus says, “Who then is the faithful and sensible slave whom his master put in
charge of his household to give them their food at the proper time?” (Mt 24:45) Mature believers have a
responsibility to immature believers (i.e., to members of the household) to help them mature rather than slap them
around. The slave put in charge of the other slaves is the one concerning whom that parable focuses its attention.
       The warning in the parable concerning the sensible steward in Mt 24:45 is first and foremost addressed to
those in places of leadership in the church. Pastors who fail to feed the immature flock with sound kingdom
doctrine and who then abuse those who attempt to do so certainly are going to have much for which to answer. Just
as 1Cor 3:11-15 has primary application to the pastor and only secondary application to the general church
membership, so the parable concerning the sensible steward has primary application to those entrusted with
positions of responsibility in the Lord’s house. That parable, which we dealt with previously,† shows an
entrustment according to maturity—not all were entrusted. (This would correspond to the phenomena we encounter
in Jn 2:24.) The present parable concerning the talents shows an entrustment according to ability—not all were
entrusted equally. The next parable that we will examine (that of the minas) at the close of this chapter shows
entrustment according to identity—all were entrusted equally. These parables form a composite picture of genuine
believers according to their identity, ability, and maturity in Christ. To assert that those so entrusted are not
genuine believers in Christ is absurd.

                   Believers can Fearfully Hide their Spiritual Gifts and New Nature
         Seventh, the unworthy slave hid his talent (Mt 25:18). This negative example also indicates the
genuineness of the relationship. After all, you cannot hide something you do not have. A saved person can keep his
devotion to Jesus secret. For example, the Gospel of John implicitly and explicitly refers to those who believed in
Jesus but who would not confess Him (cf. Jn 2:23-24; 12:42-43; 19:38).‡ The contexts of these passages demand
that the regeneration of these believers be accepted. Jn 19:38 is particularly interesting since the same verb (krupto)
used to describe Joseph of Arimathea is used to describe the unworthy slave who hid the talent. Joseph was a
hidden disciple, that is, he hid his devotion to Jesus. He was regenerate, but he hid his relationship to his Master.
Luke (11:33) uses the noun form of this Greek word, saying that no one who lights a lamp puts it in a hidden place
(kruptos). Compare this with the similar passage in Mt 5:14-16, where Jesus (after making this statement) said,
“Let your light shine.” The application is that you should not hide your light. If it were impossible for regenerate
believers to hide their light, then the exhortation would be pointless. Therefore, although it is possible for those
who are not really saved (i.e., for the unregenerate) to hide their devotion to Christ, this theoretical possibility is
not what concerned the NT writers, as is evident in the way they use this word to describe the danger of regenerate
believers hiding their light in terms of hiding their devotion to Christ. Thus, it is very probable that this is the same
concern in the parable of the talents.



*
  The parable of the laborers in the vineyard does not form an exception to the expectation that those believers who have been in the
Lord’s service for many years would be expected to have produced more return than those who had only been believers for several
days (Mt 20:1-16). Those who worked all day were expected to perform a day’s worth of work. Those who only worked one hour
were not expected to produce as much as those who worked all day. The reason those who worked less were rewarded as much is not
because they produced as much. Rather, because they believed more in the gracious nature of the rewarder, they were rewarded as
much congruently as those who served contractually.
       Whereas the other parables mentioned in the present discussion show God rewarding believers according to their identity,
ability, and maturity in Christ, the parable of the laborers shows Him rewarding them according to their opportunity. In this respect,
God is an equal opportunity employer. All believers have an opportunity to be kingdom rulers. Yet as seen in parables that go into
greater detail on that particular aspect of the reward, not all believers will rule equally.
†
  See Chapter 13. Weeping and Ruling (Mt 24:45-51), 343.
‡
  See “Carnal Believers in GJ” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                         Page 383
                                       Illustration 132. Some Christians Hide It




       This parable encourages us to make the most of our opportunities (Col 4:5). It challenges Christians not only
to sing but also to put into practice the children’s song: “Hide it under a bushel? No! I’m going to let it shine.”
Thus, the hand motions used for this song are useful to illustrate the point. In Mt 5:14-16 what is in danger of being
hidden is one’s regenerate nature, that is, what we are as believers. “You are the light of the world. A city set on a
hill cannot be hidden [krupto].…Let your light shine.” What Joseph of Arimathea hid was not merely his devotion
but his regeneration. The same should be concluded concerning the worthless slave. He hid the fact that he had
been entrusted with a regenerate nature.
       The probability that this aspect of the parable denotes the regenerate nature of the unworthy slave increases
to the point of certainty if it is acknowledged that what is hidden is not mere devotion but regeneration. The light
that we hide is not merely our devotion. Light is not merely something we do; it is something we are. As Paul
beautifully states in Eph 5:8-9, we are light, and thus we should walk in light by manifesting the fruit of the light in
what we do. Paul’s exhortation in that context makes it clear that Christians may fail to display their regenerate
nature in proper action. Proper fruit is not inevitable; it is possible for Christians to hide their light.
                                      Illustration 133. Some Christians Shine It




       Of course, a person has to have a light before he or she can let it shine. You have to have a talent before you
can use it. You have to be regenerate before you can demonstrate it to others. You have to be a believer before you
can be accountable as a believer for sharing the gospel of belief. Are you hiding your “little light” under a bushel or
in the ground as this unfaithful servant did? He had a talent; he knew it, and His master knew it, but no one else
knew it because he hid it.
       The Arminian may assert this means that the servant lost his regenerate nature when the talent was taken
away from him. Yet this response is false for at least two reasons. As discussed below, the timing of the loss makes
Page 384                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
                                     *
this an unfeasible deduction. Second, the talent does not represent regeneration itself per se; rather, the talent
represents the fact that regeneration has occurred. Spiritual gifts, for example, are distinguishable from the source
of those gifts—the Holy Spirit. Although the Holy Spirit is a gift, He is not one of the spiritual gifts which He
imparts. It is possible to have the Holy Spirit and yet hide the spiritual gifts which flow from your regenerate
nature, but it is not possible to hide the spiritual gifts which would otherwise flow from your regenerate nature
without first having a regenerate nature. What is lost is the opportunity to serve. At the very least, the opportunity
to use one’s gifts in the Lord’s service is lost. Quite likely, the spiritual gift itself is taken away, and as a result the
opportunity to use that gift no longer exists. The talent, therefore, would represent the spiritual gift and its entailing
responsibilities and opportunities to serve the Lord.
        Walvoord strings several speculations together in order to conclude that this servant not putting his money
in the bank demonstrates that he was an unbeliever like Judas. (1) Supposedly, the reason this servant did not put
the money in the bank was because he reasoned that if his master did not return, then he would be able to pocket
the money for himself. (2) This action demonstrates that the servant lacked saving faith like Judas (3) because
Judas likewise betrayed Jesus basically to cover his bets.
        In Walvoord’s reconstruction, “Judas had reasoned that if Jesus was indeed the Messiah, his betrayal would
not matter, and he would be ahead thirty pieces of silver. If Jesus was not the Messiah, he at least would have the
silver.”666 Really? Would Judas actually have imagined that Jesus would not be offended by the fact that he was
betraying Him if indeed it did turn out that Jesus was about to assign positions in His kingdom to His faithful
followers, as Judas would have had to suppose in such a case? This supposition (the third one in the above string)
is incredibly strained. Moreover, it ignores some rather significant differences. For starters, Jesus did not give the
30 pieces of silver to Judas. The servant, in contrast, was entrusted by his lord with the money. For the servant, the
money represents an entrustment by the Lord. For Judas the money represents a betrayal of the Lord.
Consequently, the second supposition in the above string is also highly suspect in that the antonymic relationship
regarding the money hardly encourages a synonymic portrayal of the characters. As to the first supposition in the
above string of Walvoord’s fictional reconstruction, it flies in the face of the reason actually supplied by Jesus in
the text. The servant hid his talent out of fear. The explanation as to why he hid the money is provided: “I was
afraid” (Mt 25:25).
        This servant simply was playing it safe in regard to keeping the money safe rather than trying to calculate
how he might keep the money for himself. France is true to the text in criticizing what he dubs a “safety-first
policy”:

          Banking as we know it had hardly begun in the Roman world of the first century…the practice of
          depositing money with the expectation of regular growth was not widespread. The “bankers” who
          might have accepted such a loan would not be a regulated commercial firm, but individual
          entrepreneurs, moneylenders, or money changers, whose honesty and competence might be
          questionable. In the circumstances, to bury money in the ground was probably the better way to
          keep it safe; the course of action demanded by the master may have been no less risky than the
          commercial ventures attempted by the other two slaves. But risk is at the heart of discipleship
          (10:39; 16:25-26); by playing safe the cautious slave has achieved nothing.667

       In a note to this material, France adds, “Loss of capital is clearly understood to be a real possibility.668
Ironically, if we are not willing to risk loss, then we risk loss. The servant’s do-nothing-wrong attitude was
interpreted by his master as a do-nothing attitude. One had better go down swinging with a coach like this rather
than just standing motionless at the plate. Perhaps there is some truth to the old adage that trying to do something
for the Lord, even if it is wrong, is better than doing nothing at all. To be sure, this perspective must be balanced
with the fact that the servant in Mt 18:23-35 who lost the talents that had been entrusted to him as a loan (daneion,
Mt 18:27) was thrown into debtor’s prison because he could not repay this debt. Perhaps he had made some bad
business decisions. Maybe he had risked loaning that money to others and had lost that capital as a result. Possibly,
it was his taking this risk that put him in such a bind. Loaning money is risky business. This servant who hid the
talent may have had good reason to be afraid. Nevertheless, inaction was the wrong course of action.†
       We must share the truth of the kingdom with others in hopes that depositing this truth in their lives will
produce a profit. Still, even if it does not and we consequently fail to reap the positive rewards that we could have

*
    See Believers’ Soteriological Status not Forfeitable at this Time, 389.
†
    For personal application of playing it safe with kingdom truth, see Exhortation, 393.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                        Page 385
if they had been fruitful with that knowledge, we must forgive them for their lack of fruitfulness lest the Lord not
forgive us for our lack of fruitfulness. We do not want to compound the lack of positive reward with the imposition
of negative rewards. We must not be bitter about our loss of positive reward and thus harshly treat those who are
failing to meet up to our expectations lest we be inflicted with negative rewards for failing to meet up to the Lord’s
expectations. Better to risk (and in the worst case scenario suffer loss of positive reward), than (A) to take no risk
or (B) to take a risk and deal harshly with those who put us at risk. For either of these latter two scenarios would
result in a negative reward: the debtor’s prison of the outer darkness.
        Walvoord is more than a little inconsistent when he correctly acknowledges that the servant who lost the ten
thousand talents with which he was entrusted was a believer669 and yet oddly asserts that the servant who hid the
one talent with which he was entrusted was an unbeliever. A more reasonable deduction is that just as the parable
of the ten thousand talents is used to show genuine believers (e.g., Peter) their need to keep forgiving, so the
parable of the single talent is intended so show genuine believers (i.e., Peter, James, and John) the need to take the
risk of serving.
                                         Illustration 134. Walvoord’s Rabbit




      Still, for sake of argument, let it be supposed that Walvoord is correct in both assumptions one and three.
Even so, assumption two does not necessarily follow. If Walvoord’s above interpretive string were rearranged to be
expressed syllogistically, it would look something like this:

       1. This servant did not serve Jesus in order to cover his bets.
       2. Judas betrayed Jesus in order to cover his bets.
       3. Therefore, this servant is lost because, like Judas, he was not sure that Jesus was the Christ.

       However, even if both the servant and Judas were hedging their bets, the common human propensity to
hedge one’s bets does not prove soteric equality. Both unbelievers and believers are prone to hedge their bets. Even
if both of Walvoord’s premises are granted, his conclusion does not logically follow. If a correlation exists between
the two actions, a correlative relation is much more intuitive than soteric identification. The major premise is not
only questionable because it flies in the face of the explanation provided by Jesus but also because it assumes that
the servant was placing soteric bets. But this need not be the case at all. Whereas Judas was placing soteric bets, the
servant was placing mistholic bets. The servant and Judas where not placing the same kinds of bets. Walvoord
asserts: “The one talent man did not believe that it was sure his lord was coming back. It is therefore clear that his
basic problem was that of being an unbeliever.”670 To the contrary, the only thing that is clear in Walvoord’s
statement is that Walvoord is engaging in eisegesis. The only reason he is able to pull this rabbit (of Judas soteric
equality) out of the hat is because he has first placed this rabbit in the hat. A far more reasonable proposal is that
the servant was not sure that his lord would respond negatively if he played safely with the entrustment. The
servant had reasonable grounds to believe that he would be sold or placed in debtor’s prison or given over to the
tortures until he repaid all that he owed if he lost the talent (Mt 18:25,30,34). Instead of being unsure that his lord
would return, the servant was sure that if his lord returned and he had lost the talent, then he would be in serious
trouble. This servant is not used to picture an unbeliever who is unsure that Jesus is the (returning) Christ. Rather,
Page 386                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
he is used to picture a believer who is afraid of the Judgment Seat of Christ. This servant believes his lord will
return, but he miscalculates on how to best prepare for that return.
       Judas struggling with whether Jesus was the Christ is not to be equated with a servant struggling with how
to be best prepared for the Judgment Seat of Christ. Just as Judas betrayed Christ as a result of his soteric failure to
deduce the true nature of Jesus as the Christ, so the unfaithful servant failed to serve Christ as a result of his
mistholic failure to deduce the true nature of the Judgment Seat of Christ. A soteric-mistholic correlation is
superior to a soteric-soteric equivocation. Jesus is not teaching that salvation from hell is conditioned on
performance. Even if Walvoord is correct in pulling a rabbit out of the hat in seeing a correlation between Judas
and the servant, he has failed to prove that the rabbit is in the hat or that the rabbit and hat are composed of the
same material. That Judas was a soteric unbeliever does not prove that the servant also was a soteric unbeliever. A
mistholic unbeliever—perhaps; a soteric unbeliever—not hardly. Frankly, I suspect that Walvoord’s attempt to pull
this rabbit out of this hat is completely immaterial to the discussion at hand. A shared human tendency is not
enough to establish intended correlativity, much less soteric equality. Far less speculative interpretations are at
hand. Walvoord should have paid more attention to what the servant failed to put into the bank (entrusted service)
and when he was expected to put it into the bank (during his master’s long absence).

                                          Believers Judged at this Time
        Eighth, as stated above, the time of this parable is concerned with the present (Mt 25:19). In this verse Jesus
purposefully provides a temporal marker, saying that His return will occur after a long time. This chronological
detail reinforces the initial observation made from the other temporal aspects* that the time period in view must be
His arrival at the end of the current church age. And the delay must be that of the church age. In the Olivet
Discourse, Jesus distinguishes between the judgment associated with the rapture and the judgment associated with
the revelation. The judgment in view is the Judgment Seat of Christ since it is the one associated with the rapture.
Only Christians are evaluated at the Judgment Seat of Christ (as can be seen in 1Cor 3:11-15 and from the fact that
only Christians are taken up at the rapture). Thus, if it is accepted that the time period involved is the church age,
then it must also be accepted that this judgment is the Bema that follows the rapture. This unworthy slave is a
genuine believer since only believers are dealt with at the Judgment Seat of Christ.671
                                             Illustration 135. Distinction in Judgments




*
    See the unknown day or hour of v. 13 discussed above and the time of the arrival in v. 27 to be considered below.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                                        Page 387
        Thus, in the Olivet Discourse Jesus distinguishes between judgment #1 (which deals with believers) and
judgment #2 (which deals with believers and unbelievers). Since He is dealing with the first judgment in this
particular parable, He must be dealing with the judgment of genuine believers. Granted, Keathley rejects this type
of argument as interpreting the parables through an eschatological grid that is dependent upon subsequent
revelation.672 However, the present writer is of the opinion that revelation is progressive and noncontradictory.
Consequently, subsequent texts that deal more clearly with the matter at hand may be used to aid in understanding
related texts. Nevertheless, for the sake of those who do not share this hermeneutical or eschatological persuasion,
let it be pointed out that the time period in question obviously was futuristic when Jesus spoke these words. Jesus is
not referring to physical Jews who were His servants in the past and who thus belonged to Him by virtue of their
past ethnic covenantal relationship with Him.* If one must insist on thinking of these servants as Jewish servants,
He is referring to futuristic Jews who would be His own in the future and who thus would have a soteriological
relationship with Him in that time period, which anticipates the Pauline concept of spiritual Jews (i.e., believers).†
        The Lord is not referring to elect Jews in general, much less to elect Jews during the tribulation period. This
parable depicts the reality announced by Mt 21:43. The opportunity to earn the kingship (basileia) of heaven has
been taken away from the Jewish people and given to those who produce the fruit of the kingdom. Rulership of that
kingdom is contingent upon fruit production. Even if basileia is translated spatially as kingdom rather than
experientially as kingship in Mt 21:43, being given a kingdom entails more than mere entrance into that kingdom.
The only way one can be given a kingdom is as a king. The production of these fruits is required for kingdom
rulership, not for kingdom entrance. Believers are being exhorted to produce fruits of the kingdom of God so that
they may inherit positions of rulership within that kingdom. Just as Jews in the past failed to obtain this rulership
they so desperately craved, so Christians in the present will fail to obtain it if they fail to produce the necessary
fruits. The potential rulership of God’s kingdom is taken away (airo) from God’s people, whether they be those
related to Him under the old covenant or the new covenant, if they do not produce the necessary fruits (Mt 21:43;
25:28-29). The parable of the outer darkness shows that the same thing that happened to the Jews in the past can
happen to believers in the future, if they do not produce the necessary fruits. Kingship (i.e., being given the
kingdom) is conditioned on the fruits one produces. Having this covenantal relationship with God, whether it is as
Jews or Christians, does not guarantee the production of such fruits.

                          Believers have Identical Relationships with their Lord
        Ninth, each of these three slaves has an identical relationship with his Master (Mt 25:20). Is this a judgment
to determine if they are genuine servants? No. It is a judgment to determine if they are faithful servants. All three
are judged on the same basis—works. This is not a judgment to see if they are believers but workers. This is not a
judgment to see if they are genuine believers but to see if they are faithful believers. The one who has his talent
taken away has the same identical relationship to his Master as the other two who are rewarded. In the case of each
of the three servants, the relationship is affirmed by the same words—his Master (Mt 25:21,23,26). The purpose of
this judgment is not to question their relationship but to question their workmanship. Since the nonelect do not
have the same relationship to the Lord that the elect do, this unworthy slave must be one of the elect since he has
an identical relationship to his master as the faithful servants. Similarly, one might argue that all three are saved
because all three are slaves. However, Keathley objects, saying,

             The first thing to recognize is that being a “slave” does not necessarily equal being “saved.”
        Some try to argue that since the word doulos (slave) is used of all three individuals, they must all be
        saved. If we use this logic, we must also conclude that the prodigal son and the older son were both
        saved because they were both sons. And we must conclude that the son who said he wouldn’t go to
        work but changed his mind, and the one who said he would work but didn’t were both saved since
        they were both sons.
             To argue that way shows a misunderstanding of parables. It wouldn’t be much of a parable if
        Jesus said there once was a son and a donkey… the son ran off and squandered the father’s money
        but the donkey stayed home and worked hard. Where’s the tension? How else is he going to tell the
        story?673
*
  See Jewish Slaves were Entrusted, 375.
†
  As demonstrated above, even if one insists on interpreting these slaves as futuristic ethnic Jews who are entrusted with the gospel of
the kingdom during the tribulation (even if individually they are unbelievers), one can equally insist, given the typological
background, that these Jewish servants are being dealt with parabolically, in a manner that would depict how God deals with Jews as
His unconditionally redeemed and secure servant-sons. See Jewish Slaves will be Entrusted, 375.

        Keathley’s appeal to hermeneutical consistency is well taken, as long as it is balanced with contextual and
typological sensitivity. Concerning the phrase sons of the kingdom in Mt 8:12, he states, “The phrase ‘sons of the
kingdom’ is a reference to ethnic Israel who considered themselves sons of God destined for the kingdom because
of their physical relationship to Abraham.”674 If this is the understanding of son he advocates in the present
passage, then some pertinent questions he must address. Did Jesus intend to say that He would entrust the ethnic
Jews (and thus lost Jews or perhaps even the lost in general) with the work of His kingdom when He returned to
His Father? Would it not be more reasonable to presume that Jesus would entrust the work of His kingdom to
believers rather than unbelievers?
        As to consistency, it is acknowledged that Hodges in Absolutely Free had said that the prodigal son could
represent either a lost person or a Christian.675 Upon subsequent reflection, Hodges came to the conclusion that the
prodigal son definitely represents a regenerate believer who has gone astray.676 He also goes on to state, “The NT
does not disclose any sense in which unregenerate people may be regarded as ‘sons of God.’”677 The applicability
of Hodges’ statement is not entirely clear, since the parable about the prodigal son does not use the phrase sons of
God. It would seem that Hodges is not limiting the strength of this confirmatory evidence to the exact phrase but
extending it to include texts where the word sons is understood as sons of God. If so, then Hodges’ statement might
extend theoretically to the two sons in Mt 21:28 and stipulate that the passage is talking about sons of God who
need to repent and get right with God. If so, then Keathley’s objections above are certainly open to question.
        On the other hand, even if the reference regarding sons in Mt 21:28 is to physical descendants of Abraham
rather than spiritual descendants (see GNTC), the contextual clues in Lk 15:11 are in Hodges’ favor that the latter
passage is referring to spiritual descendants (i.e., believers). The same would be true in the present passage
concerning the outer darkness. These slaves are saved. One need not take the simple English translation son as a
technical term for sons of God, much less for believers. The word must be interpreted in its context. And the
present context demands that these entrusted slaves of this future period, representing the church age, must
represent believers.* I thus concur with Huber instead of Keathley that slaves equal saved in this passage.678 Still,
even if one were to reject the perspective advocated herein for both the prodigal son and the sons called to work in
the vineyard in Mt 21:28 in favor of Keathley’s identifying them merely as ethic sons, one nevertheless would have
to contend with the typological probability that these ethnic sons are being used to illustrated how God deals with
Israel as His unconditionally secure servant-son.†
        Keathley’s question as to how else could Jesus have presented the tension is rather puzzling. Has Keathley
forgotten that Jesus contrasted sheep with goats, wheat with tares, and slaves with enemies (i.e., citizens) on
various occasions when He wanted to make a soteriological contrast? This is not to say that Jesus always used such
sharp contrasts in terms of nature or relationships when presenting soteriological truth. Indeed, He contrasted good
fish with bad fish—fish with fish. Then again, these contrasts of fish with fish and sons with sons and seed with
seed do not prove that such contrasts are always between the lost and saved. In the parable of the sower, three of
the contrasted soils picture soil in which belief is implicitly affirmed (in the Lukan version) and life was imparted
in the form of germinating seed. The parable of the prodigal son is best taken as tension between two believers.
Keathley’s presumption is that the only purpose of the tension would be to distinguish the lost from the saved.
However, the purpose just as easily could be to contrast the faithful believers with the unfaithful believers. Since
the stress in this parable is on the equality of the relationship and the nature of the service within that identical
relationship, misthologists are free to conclude that it affirms the reality of the relationship in its fullest sense.
        On a broader scale, one might bolster Keathley’s argument by noting that the distinction between the bad
fish and good fish is a contrast of the lost with the saved in general (Mt 13:47-50). Thus, this anti-misthological
argument could be summarized as follows:

          •    Fish ≠ saved.
          •    Sons ≠ saved.
          •    Slaves ≠ saved.
