       But again, the contextual dissimilarity should not be ignored. The bad fish are not put in charge of anything.
The opposite is true of the slaves.* Ethnic Jews are not the ones put in charge of the Lord’s interadvent work.
Although the sons in Mt 21:28-32 might describe physical descendants of Abraham, the same could not be true of
the slaves during the church age. Jesus’ past physical ministry was primarily to Jews, but His present spiritual
ministry is not characterized by this limitation. The parable is futuristic and pictures the upcoming church age and
is thus not to be taken ethnically. The theme of the parable is dealing with being entrusted with present and future
responsibilities as rewards in the kingdom, not merely entering the kingdom. In the context of this parable, it is
impossible to consider these slaves as representing the lost. They have the same relationship—that of entrusted
servants by their Master. What makes the entrustment genuine is not the integrity of their service but the integrity
of their Master. He did, in fact, entrust them, representing the fact that God indeed has regenerated us and placed us
in His service—whether or not we serve Him.
       In his endeavor to establish a link between the servant thrown into outer darkness in Mt 25:30 and the
unbelieving son who fails to enter the kingdom in Mt 21:28-32, Keathley overlooks a rather significant piece of
lexical evidence. Admittedly, ethnic progeny is probably intended in Mt 21:28-32. Unfortunately for Keathley,
however, the Greek text actually refers to children (teknon) rather than sons (huios) in Mt 21:28. Both of the
children in this parable have the same covenantal relationship. They are physical children (not sons) of Abraham
within a covenantal relationship with God through Abraham. Keathley’s equation of children with sons is open to
objection. When Jesus refers to the sons of the kingdom being cast into the outer darkness, He is talking about
soteriological sons, not ethnical Jews.† Also, in the parable of the prodigal son, Jesus is depicting soteric sons, not
ethnic Jews.679 Genuine sons of the kingdom, not Jewish children, are the ones thrown into the outer darkness.

                                 Believers have Received what was Offered
        Tenth, all three servants actually received what was offered. Belaboring this point is unnecessary since the
entrustment of the stewardship has been discussed above. Still, it should not go unnoticed that the slave was not
only offered the responsibility but actually received it. He appropriated what was offered to him. Those who want
to turn this into a soteriological issue must squarely face this fact. If what was offered was salvation, and the
responsibilities which go along with it, then the man received it. Arminianism is certainly superior to Calvinism on
this matter. Rather than do a Calvinistic dance around the passage and say that it concerns soteriological issues but
the man never experienced the soteriological reality, the Arminian can go with the natural reading of the text. The
man actually lost what he had received. You cannot lose something you never had. If salvation and its
corresponding opportunities and responsibilities are at stake, then the man lost his salvation. Arminianism is
simple, but then so is Marrowism. Neither of these systems has to try to import covenantal theology into the
passage in order to circumvent what is clearly stated. But whereas Arminianism argues that the parable
soteriologically denies eternal security, Marrowism uses this passage misthologically to defend eternal security.

                      Believers’ Soteriological Status not Forfeitable at this Time
        Eleventh, Arminians will disagree with my statement above that only rewards are forfeitable, but I would
point out that this talent is not taken away until this person stands before the Lord in judgment after his Master
arrives (Mt 25:27).680 The soteriology of neither Arminianism nor Calvinism can adequately explain the
chronology of this taking away—if the talent represents a soteriological relationship. In Calvinism the lost do not
have a saving relationship with the Lord to lose, so they have no soteriological talent to forfeit—either now or in
the future. To be sure, in Arminianism you may actually lose the eternal life that you now possess, but you lose it
now, not then. The timing of such a taking away proves too much for conditional security.
       Aside from the obvious misthological nature of this relationship represented by the talent, only the saved are
in a position to soteriologically lose something they already had. Those who were never saved, never had a
soteriological relationship to lose. Even if a soteriological relationship were forfeitable, the loss of eternal life
would have to occur beforehand. If you stand before the Lord in judgment and possess eternal life, your name will
be found in the Book of Life, and you will be allowed into heaven. The Lord does not examine the Books of Works
and then strip you of the gift of eternal life or erase your name from the Book of Life at that time if you do not
measure up. Not even Arminianism is that barbaric. The timing of the removal disqualifies Arminianism and
Calvinism as true hermeneutical contenders, leaving only Marrowism with a natural interpretation of the passage.
The timing of the removal (which occurs after the master’s arrival) presents a problem even in the soteriology of

*
    See Rationale for Division, 437.
†
    Or at the very least, He is talking about regenerate ethnic Jews. See Illustration 93. Five Types of Abrahamic Seed, 251.
Page 390                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
those who do not hold to dispensational eschatology. These servants had a servant-master relationship with their
master before being entrusted with the talent. The talent represents stewardship, not relationship. The slave thrown
into the outer darkness was a slave both before being entrusted with the talent and after being stripped of the talent.
Although his fellowship and stewardship most certainly changed, his relationship with his master did not change.
He was still a slave.

                                             Believers can Suffer Loss
        Twelfth, what does the servant lose out on when his talent is taken away? Joy (Mt 25:21,23,30) and ruling
authority over his master’s house (Mt 25:28). Believers certainly can suffer eschatological loss (1Cor 3:11-15).
And this must be the type of loss being described here. If what is lost is eternal salvation, as Arminianism poses,
then eternal salvation from hell is by works and is not eternal, a supposition which is false on both accounts.
Therefore, what is lost is not salvation from eternal damnation. If Christians do not take up their crosses and follow
Jesus in discipleship, they will lose their souls (i.e., the eternal value of their earthly lives), not the regeneration of
their spirits or their salvation from hell (Mt 16:24-27). Their earthly lives will not have any misthological value
relative to inheriting the kingdom. Believers who do not take advantage of their opportunity to serve the Lord now
will find that opportunity to serve Him taken away and given to others. The loss of the ability to serve is a punitive
response based on performance. Only servants can become kings. By failing to become kings, they lose the
capacity to show that they are a servant.
        We serve the Lord now as slaves in order that we may serve Him then as kings. Believers who refuse to
serve Lord Jesus now as slaves will find their opportunity to serve Him then as kings taken away and given to
others. Keathley counters, “He is punished for doing nothing with what he was given. This is more than ‘loss of
rewards.’”681 And he continues, “because the punishment for the unfaithful is so severe, I see them as all dealing
with salvation issues.”682 In contrast to Keathley, the present study has no qualms with considering this a
misthological punishment of believers and, therefore, refuses to regard the fact that the servant is punished as a
valid objection to the assertion that he is saved.*

                                             Believers can be Cast Out
         Thirteenth, is it so strange that Jesus talks about believers being cast out in Mt 25:30? Earlier, in Mt 5:13,
Jesus warned believers about being cast out as worthless salt. Indeed, a day or so after saying this again in
Mt 25:30 about worthless slaves, Jesus again warns genuine believers about the danger of being cast out in Jn 15:6
as worthless branches. In these passages, worthless believers are pictured as worthless—salt, branches, and
slaves—to be cast out. Nevertheless, it is possible for lost people to be cast out as well. The occurrence in Luke
13:28 marks the single time this word (ekballo) is used to describe the eschatological judgment that happens to the
unregenerate.683 The other times it is used of eschatological judgment, it is used to describe what happens to the
elect (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30).
        It might be argued that these people in Mt 25:30 cannot be believers because Jesus said that He would never
cast a believer out (Jn 6:37). But it must be asked, “What does the expression mean in that context?” In the context
of Jn 6:37, not being cast out is obviously a guarantee of eternal security, not a guarantee of eternal rewards. Being
cast out of the wedding feast in the kingdom is one thing; being cast out of the kingdom itself is quite another. In
effect, Jn 6:37 promises believers that they will not be cast out of the kingdom. It guarantees them that they will
not experience the soteriological casting out described by Lk 13:28. It does not guarantee them that they will not
experience the misthological casting out in Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30. The casting out in these Matthean passages has
nothing to do with eternal security. In contrast to Lk 13:28, none of the outer darkness passages specifies that it is
the kingdom itself from which they are cast.† Instead, it is some event or experience within the kingdom from
which they are excluded rather than from the kingdom itself. Being guaranteed that one will not be a soteriological
outcast does not guarantee that one will not be a misthological outcast.

                                   Believers are in the Outer Darkness
       Fourteenth, this term outer darkness is used exclusively by Matthew in his gospel and occurs three times
(Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30).‡ But what is Jesus’ normal designation for hell in Matthew? It is hell of fire, eternal fire,

three usages of outer darkness associate it with fire. The term outer darkness is used exclusively concerning Bema
judgment of believers in all three passages. Additionally, in the parable of the virgins, the five foolish virgins left
standing in the darkness outside are not pictured as being dragged off and thrown into a fire.

                                 Believers may Weep and Gnash Their Teeth
        Fifteen, the result of failing to serve is weeping (Mt 25:30). In the preceding context of 24:51 concerning
servanthood, weeping and gnashing of teeth also refer to the experience of an unfaithful believer. Although the
phrase weeping and gnashing of teeth can refer to the experience of the lost for failing to believe, it also can refer
to the experience of the saved for failing to serve.* Therefore, the expression itself weeping and gnashing of teeth
is biblically inconclusive as to whether or not the saved or lost are in view. The objection that there will be no tears
in heaven, because the Lord will wipe away those tears, is self-contradictory. Obviously, if there were no tears
there, then there would be no tears for Him to wipe away. Yet it would be a tragic mistake to trivialize the
emotional devastation caused by a negative review at the Bema by simply assuming that it will only last for a
moment. There are very strong reasons for believing that the tears will not be as temporary as is commonly
assumed. But as an entire section in the present work has been devoted to this topic, I will save that discussion for
then.† There is still more exegetical work to be done before addressing that issue in-depth.

Summary
       As summarized in the chart below, concerning the fifteen details described above, there are no reasons for
assuming that the unworthy slave is definitely lost. As a matter of fact, there is not even a single reason to assume
he is probably lost. There are only two reasons for thinking he might possibly be lost in the light of NT usage, but,
as always, the context is the determining factor.‡ And in this context, there are four reasons to believe he is
probably saved. And most importantly, there are nine reasons for concluding that the unworthy slave is definitely
saved. If we are going to allow the passage to determine our theology, it is impossible to conclude that this man
was lost.

Exposition
        What do the talents represent? They represent the abilities and corresponding responsibilities that the
regenerate have been given in order to serve the Lord, particularly in view of the mysteries of the kingdom we have
been granted. The resumption of Mt 13:12 in Mt 25:29 (cp. Mt 13:11; 10:27) strongly suggests this association.
France (NIC) references an article by Chenowweth that supports this contention. Bigalke uses this association to
support his contention that the talents are the gospel of the kingdom during the tribulation: “God entrusts the
preaching of the gospel of the kingdom particularly to the Jewish nation, but the saved Gentiles will also bear
responsibility.”684 Yes, the Jewish nation will be entrusted, particularly the Jewish nation at that time and
secondarily saved Gentiles (cp. Mt 24:14). However, this gospel-of-the-kingdom message is not put on ice until the
tribulation! The mystery of the kingdom is not merely that the kingdom is delayed. Preliminary responsibility of
the kingdom message has been entrusted to the church and is to be shared now.
        Is this message entrusted to the professing church as a whole, even to those who merely have heard the
message but not believed it? No! Granted, the church has many tares within it during the mystery stage of the
gospel of the kingdom. But the Lord is not going to hold the tares within the church accountable for having spread
the gospel! The grains of wheat (representing believers) are the ones held accountable to produce more wheat. The
Lord is not going to hold the tares accountable for producing wheat! The Lord will hold the tares accountable for
not believing the gospel they have heard, not for refusing to share the gospel they only have heard. Just as Bigalke
properly limits the responsibility of sharing this message to those Gentiles who not only hear this message but
believe it and who are saved by it, so the responsibility of sharing this message during the tribulation must be
limited to those Jews who not only hear it but who are saved by it. Even if Benware were right in indentifying the
stewards of the message in this parable as Jews during the tribulation, he is dead wrong to think that the steward
being thrown into the outer darkness represents a lost Jew. Even if he is right, he is wrong! Those stewards being
called on the carpet for sharing this message are those who have been saved from hell by this message. This
particular believer has been saved soteriologically but not saved misthologically. He believed the message of the
kingdom, which has the gospel of grace at its heart. Consequently, he was saved from hell by the heart of its
message. But he was not saved from the outer darkness because he refused to live and share in accordance with the
fuller scope of the message of the kingdom with which he was entrusted. Even Bigalke, who shares Benware’s
premise that the parable is dealing with the Jewish nation during the tribulation, acknowledges that the
accountability must be limited to those who are saved. Given Bigalke’s premise, I certainly would hope (and
anticipate) that, by logical extension, Bigalke would perceive that this means saved Jews! Otherwise, Bigalke
would have saved Gentiles being thrown into the outer darkness with lost Jews!
        Given the principle of correlativity, I certainly could grant the possibility of the lost and saved being cast
into the outer darkness, but not even I would grant that as a reasonable probability within this particular parable.*
Instead, if I were of that mindset, I would argue, as a number of other misthologists have done, that lost
(tribulational) Jews are thrown into the outer darkness in the other two parables pertaining to the outer darkness but
those thrown into the outer darkness in this passage are saved. † Thus, in this parable the picture is of one saved
from hell but not saved from the outer darkness. In the correlative sense, the casting of the lost into the outer
darkness would not be identical to the saved being cast into the outer darkness. Similarities do not prove equalities.
Do not equate the lost being thrown into the outer darkness with the saved being thrown into the outer darkness.
Note the similarities, yes, but do not transgress the principle of correlativity by equating the outer darkness of the
lost with the outer darkness of the saved. They are not identical. The outer darkness of the lost is the eternal black
darkness of the Lake of Fire. The saved are saved completely from this Lake of Fire. They will never put so much

*
  See Modern Interpreters, 453. I am not rejecting this correlation on the sheer grounds that such an argument would be making a
correlation within the same passage. Correlations can be made within the scope of a singular parable but not this particular parable.
The details of this parable argue too strongly that the soteriologically saved are exclusively in view. However, the possibility can be
entertained that the burning of the city (Mt 22:7) in the second outer darkness passage has dual applicability to the lost and the saved.
One can then expand this argument to a neoclassical misthological view of Preteristic Gehenna-Bema if one is of that school of
thought. (See Illustration 361. Neoclassical Preteristic Gehenna-Bema, 950.) In that case, one also could find the principle of
correlativity within a single Gehenna pericope. In other words, the principle of correlativity need not be developed exclusively by
correlating one passage with another passage. Sometimes this correlativity can exist within a singular passage.
†
  Although I do not share the perspective of some of my fellow misthologists in understanding the other two passages dealing with the
outer darkness as pertaining to the lost, I would, of course, share their applying the principle of correlativity regarding the outer
darkness to the lost. For example, weeping and gnashing of teeth is a correlative point of similarity between those cast into the fire and
the outer darkness. The correlative point of dissimilarity, though, is that they are not weeping and gnashing their teeth in the same
place. The fire is not the outer darkness. Weeping of saved ≅ weeping of lost. Weeping of saved ≠ weeping of lost. See Theory of
Correlativity, 911.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                        Page 393
as one toe in that lake. Sure, one can establish a correlation between being cast into the Lake of Fire
soteriologically and the outer darkness misthologically, but soteric-mistholic correlations cannot be made
equalities: soteric ≠ mistholic.

                                                      Exhortation
         As to Bigalke’s contention that the parable is dealing with the tribulation, even if this parable were dealing
with the Jewish nation during the tribulation, it still would have secondary applicability to saved Gentiles then and
preliminary applicability to saved Gentiles now. That includes me. And if you are a believer, it includes you. We
who have believed that message have experienced regeneration and have the responsibility to allow the light of our
regeneration to shine, not just in the way we live but in the things we teach, namely, the gospel of the kingdom. As
I add this note, I am preparing to attend a kingdom conference next weekend and have just spent two weeks of
vacation working on this manuscript trying to get it ready for a kingdom conference in nine months. The message
of the kingdom has not been delayed until the tribulation. Over the many years I have been working on this
kingdom manuscript, I have been asked many times when I would have it finished. I keep hoping it will be that
year, but it never is. I keep adding, tweaking, researching, and proofreading. At the last kingdom conference I
attended in October 2011, I was told that some have given up hope, and understandably so, on my finishing this
book. However, during that conference, while I was asleep in my motel room, I woke up at about five o’clock in
the morning, and the thought just struck me out of nowhere that it was so extremely odd that this servant hid his
talent because he believed that his master was an exacting man. The servant hid his talent because he was afraid
that he might mess up. What a dummy. What a fool. Then wham! As if the Lord had given me a slap in the face or
as if Nathan the prophet had stepped into the room (2Sam 12:7), the thought hit me, “You are the man!”
         I could not understand that man’s mentality, and yet I unknowingly had developed the same mentality. For
so many years I had been trying to make sure that I had all my theological and exegetical ducks in a row, partially,
and perhaps principally, because of Jam 3:1: “Let not many of you become teachers, my brethren, knowing that as
such we shall incur a stricter judgment.” To put your mistakes out where others could see is bad enough, but to put
them out where the Lord would judge them would be so much worse. Better to play it safe and keep researching
and correcting than to make that mistake—or so I thought until that moment. Out of fear of the Bema I had been
hiding my talent of the kingdom message that the Lord had given me about the Bema. The irony was like a slap in
the face. I had become the very man I was writing about and did not even know it! Like the old shaving
commercial about the cold, awaking, self-administered slap in the face, I could only say, after I got over the shock,
“Thanks, Lord, I need that.” Better to release this book with warts than to keep it buried in the ground of research.
Through the Lord’s grace, I am determined not to be the servant thrown into the outer darkness because I keep my
book shut.
         Having now shared my own personal application, let me now broaden it in hopes that it may help you avoid
that misthological darkness as well. The most surprising thing about this parable is not that some Christians are
pictured metaphorically as being cast out into the outer darkness. Rather, the surprise comes from noting that the
Christian in the greatest danger in this parable is not the ten-talent or five-talent Christian but the one-talent
Christian. Normally, it is the Christians who do not have as much ability or opportunity who sit back and let others
do the work. They say, “Let the pastor do it.” “Let those who are already deacons do it.” “Let so-and-so keep
teaching; I want to sit back and enjoy hearing the lesson.” “Let that person write the books. They have a national
ministry or seminary position to promote their publication. Why bother getting my book out when no one is going
to read it anyway.” “Why share the gospel with that person. They wouldn’t believe it anyway.”
         Such thoughts can be so very discouraging or seducing. Some believers want to sit back and enjoy doing
nothing. Their do-nothing attitude will qualify them for nothing but the outer darkness. Those who enjoy doing
nothing now will be given nothing to do throughout eternity. Whether it is apathy, fear, or discouragement that you
must overcome, get that talent out of the ground and share it. Those who take the risk and serve now, even though
it is as slaves, will be able to enjoy serving then as rulers. Something is wrong when Christians fail to develop their
potential. Jesus will judge everything we do, say, and think. However, He will also judge what we don’t do. Faith
without works is dead. Having a message but not sharing it is misthologically deadly. Faith in Jesus will save a
Christian from hell but not from the outer darkness. As Christians we must develop our potentiality and share the
message rather than waste the opportunity.
         This passage does not deny eternal security. In Jn 15:6, Jesus says that He will cast some believers out, but
in that same gospel He also says that He will never cast any believer out (Jn 6:37). The point is that, as a believer,
you will never be cast out in terms of relationship, but you can be cast out in terms of fellowship.685 Or as Stegall
and other securitists express it, believers may be cast out in terms of communion rather than union.686 This
Matthean parable demonstrates so well what Paul stated so emphatically in Eph 2:8—you are saved by grace. The
Page 394                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
unworthy slave did not serve his master in the manner his master had expected (and implicitly in this parable had
demanded), but the servant’s life was still spared. If entering into joy or being cast into the outer darkness in
Mt 25:14-30 refers to salvation from hell, then salvation from hell is by works. Such cannot be the case and is not
the case. The parable illustrates the blessed assurance of salvation from hell. The one-talent Christian knows he
belongs to his master even though he refuses to serve Him. Being his master’s slave and knowing that he is a
genuine slave is not dependent on his service. Neither salvation in terms of this relationship nor the assurance of
basic salvation is dependent upon performance.

                                                   Consolation
       Despite the above exhortation, however, some kingdom misthologists might be discouraged rather than
encouraged by it. Their thoughts might be, “How can you share the kingdom message when you have to
acknowledge that you might be wrong?” After all, I acknowledged my own hesitancy in releasing my book. A
word of explanation is in order. Let me provide the same consolation that the Lord provided me. The Lord not only
encourages us to take risks in this parable, He also provides considerable justification for doing so. The master in
the parable is the one who discerns the individual capabilities of each of His servants and entrusts them with their
respective number of talents. We can trust His discernment. France’s distinction and exhortation are well received:

         The “talents,” however, do not represent that individual ability but are allocated on the basis of it.
         They represent not the natural gifts and aptitudes which everyone had, but the specific privileges
         and opportunities of the kingdom of heaven and the responsibilities they entail. The parable thus
         teaches that each disciple has God-given gifts and opportunities to be of service to their Lord, and
         that these are not the same for everyone, but it is left to the reader to discern just what those gifts
         and opportunities are. What matters is that…each disciple should live and work in such a boldly
         enterprising way that the returning master will say, “Well done” (Emphasis his.)687

       France rightly cautions against playing it safe to the point of failing to be bold.* In fact, a kingdom writer can
be bold, even when refuting a scholar like France, who goes on to conclude: “There is thus a fundamental division
between good and bad disciples, between the saved and the lost….What utterly condemned this disciple, and made
him unready to meet his Lord at the parousia, was the fact that he had proved to be “useless” for the kingdom of
heaven….his performance did not match his profession” (italics his).688 For these reasons, France soteriologically
concludes that this servant did not belong to the kingdom. Such comments are standard among proveitists. If your
service proves to be useless, this will prove that you were a mere professor rather than possessor. Supposedly, you
never entered into the possession of eternal life. Allegedly, what this professor lost was the opportunity to serve in
the kingdom because he never possessed eternal life. This latter assessment might seem harmless, in and of itself,
but when read in the light of its proveitistic implications, it is a claim that the possession of eternal life necessitates
proveitistic performance. In this mindset, the possession of eternal life becomes conditioned on such performance.
In short, such theology conditions one’s security on one’s performance. Proveitistically, this slave had to perform
well or be thrown into hell. From proveitistic perspective, the servant was thrown into hell not merely because he
was lost but because his poor performance was considered incontrovertible proof that he never was saved. You
must prove your possession of eternal life by your performance; otherwise, you will be thrown into hell. You must
prove you are saved in order to be saved in the end. Proveitism is a very popular form of conditional security.
          Since the hallmark of kingdom teaching should be unconditional security, Marrowists can dispense with
France’s conditional security. The fundamental affirmation of Kingdom Theology 101 is that the outer darkness is
applicable to unconditionally secure believers. A gift is not a reward. Conditioning the possession of the gift of
eternal life on one’s performance fails to distinguish a gift from a reward and automatically disqualifies conditional
security as a valid possibility. By implicitly affirming unconditional security, France has removed himself from
further consideration at this stage of the discussion. Interaction with conditionalists is resumed elsewhere, both
herein and in my other writings, and need not further distract at this point. Those entrusted with kingdom truth
have been entrusted with, among other things, the doctrine of unconditional security. This is the fundamental
premise of Marrowism. In the following flowchart, therefore, this controlling affirmation will provide a place to
begin consideration of the various interpretive options for the parable.
          Someone will ask, “Have you ever stopped to consider the possibility that you might be wrong?”
“Frequently,” is my answer. In fact, having a mathematical background, I chart that potentiality in terms of

*
    See Believers can Fearfully Hide their Spiritual Gifts and New Nature,382.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                         Page 395
probabilities and possibilities. The above chart in Illustration 136 does so in terms of probabilities, the following
chart in Illustration 137 does so regarding possibilities. Ironically, as seen in both charts, seriously considering the
potentiality that I might have interpreted the parable fallaciously gives me sound cause to proclaim kingdom truth
boldly. When I indicated that my fear of Jam 3:1 was a factor preventing me from releasing this book until I had
time and opportunity to remove potential errors, I did not mean that I was afraid of being categorically or
fundamentally wrong regarding Marrowism. Far from it! I have considered various alternatives by those opposed
to Marrowism and found the logical implications of their positions to be untenable. Kingdom teachers need not be
paralyzed by irrational fears of failure. Although Marrowists may differ among themselves over some particulars,
they should teach confidently within their shared parameters. My concern was about missing some particulars, not
about choosing the Marrowistic perspective. One of the problems facing a misthologist is that there are a number
of valid options from which to choose within the Marrowistic hermeneutical tree for this passage. Therefore, being
certain that you have chosen the best option is sometimes difficult.
        In his chapter and book entitled, That’s Just Your Interpretation, Copan appropriately counters the
intellectual cop-out that attempts to reduce all interpretations to matter of personal opinion. Logically, “one
interpretation—or at least range of interpretations—better conforms to the truth than others.”689 Not only are moral
absolutes logically reasonable and certain interpretations preferable, but comparable certainty for certain
interpretations is absolutely reasonable. The chart in Illustration 136 shows the reasonable certainty of Marrowism.
The chart in Illustration 137, though, shows the absolute superiority of Marrowistic range of interpretations over its
contenders. Since those interpretations opposed to Marrowism lead to confusing a gift with a reward, these counter
interpretations are irrational. Once the irrational nature of such alternatives is correctly perceived, continuing to
entertain such alternatives as possible would be irrational. Thus, a point is reached where intellectual honesty
requires that the Marrowist acknowledge that interpretations opposed to Marrowism are pointless. There is no point
in entertaining them any further. At that point, intellectual honesty dictates that giving any further credence to the
possibility of the opposing range of interpretations would be intellectually dishonest. Such counter interpretations
are dead ends and thus are shown as dead ends on the chart.
                         Illustration 137. Possibilities for the Unworthy Slave of Mt 25:13-30
Page 396                                                                                            The Outer Darkness


        To review some of the primary hermeneutical options available, the first branching on the chart presents an
interpreter with the option to interpret the text from either a non-dispensational or dispensational perspective. Both
proveitistic and forfeitistic approaches to the text can be found outside the dispensational quarter, specifically in
Calvinism and Arminianism for example. Because all forms of conditional security lead to an accursed gospel of
performance-based soteriology, both proveitism and forfeitism are mapped as dark boxes that dead end on the
chart. Because proveitism is the form of conditional security generally found within the dispensational camp, all
interpretations resulting in conditional security under the dispensational branch are labeled simply as belonging to
the proveitist camp.
        On the left, under the non-dispensational side of the chart, one normally would expect to find some form of
conditional security. However, even on this side of the chart, it still would be possible to interpret the text as a
securitist. If the Lord is understood simply as dealing with unfaithful believers in terms of rewards (without the
dispensational distinctive of rapture as opposed to revelation), then this non-dispensational option leads directly to
Marrowism. The most natural conclusion would be that since the believer’s performance is limited to being dealt
with misthologically, believers must be unconditionally secure in terms of soteriology.
        Possibilities tend to be more complex on the dispensational side of the chart, owing in part to the more
detailed options associated with that eschatology. The stage of the second coming in view either may be the rapture
of believers (before the tribulation) or the revelation Christ (after the tribulation). Some dispensationalists interpret
the parable as dealing with the church age. Logical consistency for this branch on the chart, then, would lead to the
Bema and thus to Marrowism. This approach is my preference, denoted by the darker arrows tracing this path in
the chart: Rapture ⇒ Bema ⇒ Marrowism.
        Conversely, some dispensationalists acknowledge that the parable is dealing with church-age believers but
then insist that Jesus is not specifying either the Rapture or the Bema. To speak analogously, those adopting this
perspective argue that Jesus did not expect His disciples to be able to deduce: Rapture ⇒ Bema. Therefore, these
dispensationalists believe that it would be wrong to interpret the parable in this fashion. Jesus would be understood
as teaching more broadly, and thus the parable would be understood in terms of a general judgment in which the
lost and saved are judged simultaneously. That Jesus spoke comprehensively in such terms on other occasions
(e.g., Jn 5:28-29)* proves, in their minds, that He may have been doing so on this occasion. One cannot argue that
servant = saved anymore than fish = saved.† Just as Jesus separated the good fish from the bad fish and threw the
latter into hell, so He will separate the good disciples from the bad disciples and throw the bad disciples into hell.
Obviously, this perspective has a propensity to lead very quickly to proveitism and thus to conditional security.
Thus, it is charted as a dead end.
        To be sure, I interact with such objections thoroughly elsewhere and sometimes entertain the possibility of
being wrong even at this level, at least theoretically, if for nothing more than for the sake of those interactions. Yet
at the end of the hermeneutical day, such contemplations are not enough to cause ongoing questions as to the
accuracy of Marrowistic interpretations. Marrowism might be in error on some of the details of those interactions,
but the possibility of being categorically wrong is not even worthy of consideration in terms of the above
summation on the flow chart. The range of interpretations offered by Marrowism wins hands down. Thinking
otherwise would be irrational. The problem facing Marrowists is not in being certain that Marrowism is superior
but determining which Marrowistic branch is best within the Marrowistic range of interpretations. For example, a
kingdom writer should be bold, indeed very bold, in affirming the validity of the Marrowistic interpretation on the
branch of the hermeneutical tree that falls under rapture. This particular Marrowistic interpretation is the only valid
position under that branch. Conditionalists are climbing out on a very long limb that ends in an accursed,
proveitistic gospel. Bema is the superior option under rapture. If this passage is dealing with the judgment
associated with the rapture, then it certainly is dealing with the judgment of believers: Dispensationalism 101.
        Moving to far right on the chart under revelation, some dispensationalists think that Jesus is talking about
coming back at the revelation at the end of the tribulation. In this case, the foolish servant might represent a Jew or
he might represent either a Jew or Gentile: Jew/Gentile. If the faithful servants represent saved Jews and
inclusively represent saved Gentiles, then the possibility that the unfaithful servant represents unsaved Jews and
Gentiles is practically removed from consideration. For in that case one could not sustain the common
dispensational objection that Jesus is talking about the stewardship entrusted to the nation of Israel. Lost Gentiles
would be included in that stewardship, which is not a feasible option, so the presence of lost stewards cannot be

*
    See The Out-Resurrection in Jn 5:29, 102.
†
    See Believers have Identical Relationships with their Lord, 387; Rationale for Division, 437.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                          Page 397
defended by an assumption of a Jewish national inclusion of the lost. Theoretically, one still might argue that the
servant in question is lost, but such an argument would be self-defeating dead end in proveitism.
       The more popular dissenting option under this branch, therefore, is to limit the stewardship to ethnic Jews.
So only Jews would be under consideration. However, a misthological interpretation leading straight to Marrowism
is the most probable option in that case. For Jesus would be exclusively entrusting saved Jews with the gospel of
the kingdom, not unsaved Jews. Nevertheless, even if this Marrowistic perspective were rejected in favor of a
national entrustment (in which the gospel of the kingdom is entrusted to lost Jews inclusively), then the
Marrowistic position is still not disproven. In this case, the Jews nationally would be best understood typologically
as representing how God deals with believers. The phenomenon of national Israel typologically portraying
unconditional security is frequently affirmed by securitists. Notwithstanding, even if this perspective were rejected
on this occasion in favor of an exclusively soteriological understanding of Jesus’ intention in the parable, the
Marrowist still might contend that a correlative application is intended. In other words, even assuming that those
thrown into the outer darkness in all three parables represent lost Jews, the possibility still exists that Jesus intends
for believers to see how application might be made correlatively to themselves. The distinction between
interpretation and application allows for correlation. For example, in this case, if the parable of the minas is dealing
with a believer stripped of his mina, then a correlation exists between an unbeliever being stripped of his talent and
a believer stripped of his mina. Correlatively, the Marrowistic conclusion is affirmed even if the outer darkness is
interpreted soteriologically: Correlatively, the outer darkness is still applicable to unconditionally secure believers.

                                    The Parable of the Minas (Lk 19:1-27)

Introduction
        The Lukan parable concerning the minas/pounds will shed further light on its above Matthean sister passage
about the talents. As noted above, although Gaebelein could see rewards in the pounds, he had trouble seeing the
doctrine of rewards being represented in the talents. Benware likewise could perceive the misthological nature of
having the mina taken away, but he failed to acknowledge the misthological nature of having the talent taken
away.* Such inconsistencies were addressed above. One would think that since Gaebelein and Benware can
perceive the basic misthological nature of the parable of the minas, others would tend to do so as well. Alas,
however, many are so misthologically blind so as not to be able to discern the misthological nature of even this
parable.
        The first thing that a Lordship Salvationist would probably point to as an indication that Zaccheus was saved
was the fact that he gave his money to the poor. LS believes one has to give in order to receive. A person has to
give his or her life to Jesus in order to receive eternal life (supposedly as a gift) from Jesus. Now to be sure, they
will not say it in so many words, but nevertheless this is the logical outcome of their assertions: The exchange of
your life for eternal life is a barter, despite their claims otherwise. They would probably declare it more like this:
Zaccheus was saved by faith, but such faith has to express itself in good works in order to be true, genuine, saving
faith. Such a position would amount to nothing more than doubletalk— a denial that Zaccheus actually was saved
by simple faith. Such a claim by LS is a declaration that Zaccheus was saved by faith and works, since works are
required for the faith to be saving.
        It would be easy for those of the LS persuasion to assume that one must accept Jesus’ reign (i.e., His
Lordship) over one’s life in order to be saved on the assumed basis of Lk 19:14. After all, these people did not
want Jesus to reign over them, and they were killed. In contrast, FG believes that performance related submission
to the Lordship of Christ is required for rewards within heaven but not for entrance into heaven. Heaven is not a
reward; it is a gift. Proper interpretation of this passage will demonstrate the validity of the FG position with a
surprising degree of affirmation.

Text

          11And while they were listening to these things, He went on to tell a parable, because He was near
          Jerusalem, and they supposed that the kingdom of God was going to appear immediately. 12He said
          therefore, “A certain nobleman went to a distant country to receive a kingdom for himself, and then
          return.” 13And he called ten of his slaves, and gave them ten minas, and said to them, “Do business
          with this until I come back.” 14But his citizens hated him, and sent a delegation after him, saying, “We

       do not want this man to reign over us.” 15And it came about that when he returned, after receiving the
       kingdom, he ordered that these slaves, to whom he had given the money, be called to him in order
       that he might know what business they had done. 16And the first appeared, saying, “Master, your
       mina has made ten minas more.” 17And he said to him, “Well done, good slave, because you have
       been faithful in a very little thing, be in authority over ten cities.” 18And the second came, saying,
       “Your mina, master, has made five minas.” 19 And he said to him also, “And you are to be over five
       cities.” 20 And another came, saying, “Master, behold your mina, which I kept put away in a
       handkerchief; 21for I was afraid of you, because you are an exacting man; you take up what you did
       not lay down, and reap what you did not sow.” 22 He said to him, “By your own words I will judge
       you, you worthless slave. Did you know that I am an exacting man, taking up what I did not lay
       down, and reaping what I did not sow? 23”Then why did you not put the money in the bank, and
       having come, I would have collected it with interest?” 24 And he said to the bystanders, “Take the
       mina away from him, and give it to the one who has the ten minas.” 25 And they said to him,
       “Master, he has ten minas already.” 26 I tell you, that to everyone who has shall more be given, but
       from the one who does not have, even what he does have shall be taken away. 27 But these enemies of
       mine, who did not want me to reign over them, bring them here and slay them in my presence. (Lk
       19:11-27)

Brief Exegesis
       First, the occasion of the parable should be noted. Zaccheus received Jesus in Lk 19:6. This physical
reception probably indicates a spiritual reception as well. Jn 1:12 says that “as many as received Him to them He
gave the right to become children of God, even to those who believe in His name.” Zaccheus received Him. Before
this passage says anything about Zaccheus giving anybody anything, it first talks about him receiving something,
or better yet Someone. It is reasonable to suppose that Lk 19:6 is an outward picture of an inward reality. In
receiving Jesus gladly into his home, Zaccheus was receiving Jesus and His message gladly into his heart. He first
received Jesus before he gave for Jesus. Receiving precedes giving—such is the message of grace.
