      In Lk 19:9, it may be noted that Jesus did not say, “Today salvation has come to this house because he has
promised to give to the poor.” No. He was not saved because of something he promised to give—he did not buy his
way into heaven. He was not saved because he was willing to give something but because he had become
something.* Thus, Jesus responds, “Today salvation has come to this house, because he, too, is a son of
Abraham.” He had become a son of Abraham by receiving Jesus. Luke, Paul’s traveling companion, is the one
who recorded these words in the parable. Paul expressed this truth in Gal 3:7. “It is those who are of faith who are
*
  Alternatively, or perhaps even simultaneously, he was called such in anticipation of an inaugurated misthology. See endnote 679.
His saving faith, followed by repentance and a desire to follow Jesus, provided misthological grounds for Zaccheus to be considered a
seed of Abraham in the mistholic sense. See 2B in Illustration 93. Five Types of Abrahamic Seed, 251.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                                       Page 399
sons of Abraham.” Zaccheus became a son of Abraham by faith, not by giving. Jesus then tells this parable of the
minas to encourage Zaccheus to follow through on the promise he had made to give to the poor.
        Jesus again describes a slave owner who went on a journey in Lk 19:12. The same time period is also
involved here as was in Mt 25:14-30. After the ascension, believers were given the responsibility to work for Him,
but nonbelievers rejected Him. Many of the same arguments used above concerning the talents in Mt 25:14-30 as
to the salvation of all three of those slaves apply equally well here to these ten slaves. When the Lord returns in
Lk 19:15, He firsts deals with believers. His return in the rapture and judgment at the Bema will likewise occur
first.* Later, He will deal with unbelievers. He does not deal with both groups at the same time. This order is seen
here also. He first deals with His slaves (i.e., the saved) and then with His citizens (i.e., the lost) in this parable.
        In Lk 19:13, the Lord entrusts His work to believers, not to nonbelievers. All ten of His slaves have the
same identical relationship to their master. All the slaves correspondingly represent those who are saved. They are
entrusted with the same amount in this parable to represent entrustment on the basis of having the same identical
identity. The relationship of the slaves to the king is different from that of the citizens to the king. The citizens did
not want a relationship with this king, much less to serve him.
        The servants accepted their relationship with this king, although not all of them really were interested in
serving him. What determines whether one is saved from death in this passage is not whether one serves the king
but whether one completely rejects His claim to the throne of the kingdom. The parabolic throne in view is not the
throne of one’s heart or life. All believers have accepted Jesus’ claim that He is truly the king. Unbelievers have
rejected His claim (cf. Jn 18:37). What determines whether we are a believer or unbeliever is whether we accept
His claim. Jesus conditions our reception of eternal life on what we believe about His claim concerning His
identity and His corresponding ability to give eternal life to those who simply believe in Him for it (Jn 6:47;
8:24).690 This king has the right and ability to grant entrance into His kingdom. We acquiesce to that claim when
we trust Him for entrance into His kingdom. As the dying thief said, “Jesus, remember me when You come in
Your kingdom!" (Lk 23:42) His petition, as is ours, pertaining to requesting entrance into His kingdom is not,
“Jesus, remember our service.” Our salvation is not determined by whether we serve Jesus as King. The parable
itself makes this point very clear. The enemies are slain (cf. Lk 19:14,27); the worthless slave is not. The slave was
completely passive in regard to both the mina and the king’s claim to the throne. He did nothing to oppose the
king’s claim, and he did nothing to serve the king either. On the one hand, he had nothing to do with sending the
delegation to oppose the king, but on the other hand, he buried the mina rather than serve the king. Although his
actions were neutral, his attitude was apparently negative. Nevertheless, he was not treated like an enemy. His life
was spared.
        This servant’s life was spared because of his passive response to the king’s claim. This accords well with
Marrowism, in which saving faith is understood to be passive persuasion. The parable well illustrates that the man
was saved from death because of his passiveness. Rewards, in contrast, are dependent upon active performance. He
was not saved from the loss of the mina or loss at the Bema. It takes activity (i.e., works) to save one’s mina at the
Bema. The parallel is obvious. One of the slaves suffers loss of his mina, but he himself is saved from death (cf.
1Cor 3:15). In contrast, the citizens suffer the loss of their lives. The opposing citizens are slain, not the worthless
slave. There is quite a difference between losing your mina and losing your life. The saved have eternal life; they
do not lose their lives. Yet not all the saved are treated equally in heaven. Clearly, we are to conclude that what
happens to the slaves represents what happens to those who have eternal life. In contrast to the enemies, the
worthless slave is not slain, which illustrates eternal security and salvation by grace (Lk 19:7). The worthless slave
did not serve his master, yet his life was spared—an illustration of justification salvation by faith alone. But the
passage motivates us to serve in order to achieve co-glorification salvation by works.691
        The ten-mina slave in Lk 19:16 is faithful and hears the words, “Well done.” He also receives more
authority than the five-mina Christian (cf. Mt 5:28). The five-mina slave in Lk 19:18 is semi-faithful and does not
hear the words, “Well done.” Nevertheless, he also has opportunity to rule in heaven. The withholding of the words
well done from the second slave is not accidental. In all three occasions in the NT in which the words well done are
spoken, they are accompanied with the clarification that the servant being praised was faithful with the few things
or little things (Mt 25:21,23; Lk 19:17). This affirmation is missing in the encounter with the second slave in the
parable of the minas. Correspondingly, perseverance in stewardship entitles one to rulership, but it takes
meticulous (i.e., wholehearted) devotion to earn the commendation. In contrast, the slave in Lk 19:20-24 who only
returns the one mina hears censorship and experiences loss of opportunity to serve the King in any capacity. He

*
  Jesus disciples did not have to understand about the rapture and Bema, as such at this time, for Jesus to lay the foundation for such
teachings to be given in greater detail later.
Page 400                                                                                                  The Outer Darkness
loses the one mina he does have. We see these various types of believers in our churches every Sunday. Some
believers do everything they can. Others who do what they feel they have to do. Others who do nothing. A fourth
category is seen in Mt 24:48ff where some believers do worse than nothing. They do evil. In these parables there
are different degrees of faithfulness and different degrees of unfaithfulness. Correspondingly, different degrees of
rewards are pictured parabolically, based on different degrees of service:

         •    Some believers do everything.
         •    Some believers do something.
         •    Some believers do nothing.
         •    Some believers do evil.

        All faithful believers will be positively rewarded, but only the most faithful will be rewarded with crowns
and praise. All unfaithful believers will be punished, but even so there will be different degrees of punishment. The
Lord told this parable to encourage Zaccheus, a believer, to follow through on his commitment. Certainly our
congregations today need this same encouragement. Although their salvation from losing their soteriological life is
not at stake, their salvation from the loss of their talents and pounds is certainly at stake.

Reign Over Us

                                                    Waterhouse
        LS will not be satisfied with my assessment that objective recognition of the Lordship of Christ is called for
in this parable. They will want to press the point that subjective submission to the Lordship of Christ is also
demanded. Contrastively, some in the FG camp do not believe that subjective recognition of the objective Lordship
of Christ is necessary for salvation. So is an affirmation of objective Lordship the best FG can do?* No, it is not.
According to Waterhouse, “saving faith cannot exist with a total rebellion against Christ’s rule as Master.” This
would seem to be quite in harmony with Jesus’ picture of those who suffer damnation in this parable of the minas
as saying, “But his citizens hated him, and sent a delegation after him, saying, ‘We do not want this man to reign
over us’” (Lk 19:14). Would Waterhouse’s assessment not mean that in order to be saved you must want Christ to
reign over you as LS insists? After all, Jesus seals their fate on this basis: “But these enemies of mine, who did not
want me to reign over them, bring them here and slay them in my presence” (Lk 19:27).
        One would certainly be inclined to think that Waterhouse’s statement would be an endorsement of LS, but
this is certainly not Waterhouse’s intention, as he immediately follows up by clarifying, “However, this is not at all
the same as concluding that there must be efforts to obey Christ as Master or commitments which promise a
cessation from sin and a yielding to Christ’s authority.”692 To contemporary LS, this would sound like a Lordship
Salvation that is devoid of Lordship, a worthless commodity. Waterhouse’s statements do not necessarily fare any
better in the FG arena, though, since some in this camp would assert that any demand that requires a lost person to
submit to the Lordship of Christ necessarily negates the freeness of the offer.
        Seemingly, Waterhouse’s remarks are worthless at best, showing him to be either a soft Lordship
Salvationist or an inconsistent Free Grace Salvationist. Although this may be the case, his comments above and his
following summation are worthy of further consideration: “If a potential convert can trust in Christ, he has
recognized Christ’s authority to a sufficient degree; he has made all the commitments he needs to make” (emphasis
his).693 In his corresponding discussion in Bread Alone, Waterhouse rejects the contemporary form of LS in favor
of a biblical model. He again enunciates the same key points: “It is unlikely that saving faith can co-exist with an
attitude of total rebellion.” “One who trusts in Christ has already acknowledged His Lordship to a sufficient degree
and has obeyed to a sufficient degree to obtain salvation.”694 Although Waterhouse builds his argument on the
necessity of recognizing Christ’s deity (and this subjective necessity is not affirmed by all quarters of the FG
community), other contemplations should prevail even upon those in FG who do not share Waterhouse’s premise
regarding the necessity of recognizing Christ’s deity or who seek to disassociate submission with regeneration.

                                                Obedience of Faith
       First, it should be readily admitted that saving faith is considered an act of obedience from a fully-informed
biblical perspective. Conversely, lack of faith is considered disobedience: “He who believes in the Son has eternal
*
  See “Subjective Versus Objective Lordship” in Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity and “Objective and Subjective Lordship”
in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                           Page 401
life; but he who does not obey the Son shall not see life, but the wrath of God abides on him” (Jn 3:36).* This
Johannine chapter, which commences with describing regeneration as new birth, concludes by describing the faith
necessary for regeneration as submission to the Son. Saving faith is equated synonymously with obeying the Son.
John has no qualms affirming that faith is in fact commanded: “This is His commandment, that we believe in the
name of His Son Jesus Christ” (1Jn 3:23).
        Paul likewise describes faith as a form of obedience (Rom 1:5; 16:26). Quite likely, Peter is portraying the
same truth when he speaks of believers who have purified their souls by obedience to the truth (1Pet 1:22). In any
case, both Peter and Paul concur that obeying the gospel is a salvific requirement (2Thess 1:8; 1Pet 4:17).
Naturally, Peter’s announcement that the Spirit is given to those who obey God (Acts 5:32) inclines one to see
regeneration via means of submission in terms of saving faith in this Petrine ordo salutis: faith → regeneration.

                                                  FG Advocates
        Such conclusions already have been reached in FG literature. McCoy’s article Obedience Is Necessary To
Receive Eternal Life expresses this sentiment.695 Wilkin expresses the standard connection between Mt 7:21-23 and
Jn 3:36 and concludes, “A person who trusts in Christ alone obeys completely the will of the Father to believe in
Jesus Christ alone for eternal salvation.”696 And linking the Matthean and Johannine soteric requirement of doing
the Father’s will in Mt 7:21-23 with that of Jn 6:38-40 is, of course, standard FG fare. More pointedly, in his article
Obedience to the Faith, Wilkin commences by asking, “Must a person promise to obey God to have eternal
salvation?” He concludes by answering, “Obedience to the faith specifically refers to obeying the command to
believe the Gospel. If you’ve done that, you can be sure that you’ve exercised the obedience of faith” (Emphasis
his).697 Is this not what Waterhouse essentially has said above?
        Bing concurs with Morris in regarding the obedience of faith as “an epexegetic or appositional genitive in
which faith is the obedience called for….‘the gospel is seen as demanding the response of faith. Accordingly, the
way to obey is to believe.’”698 To be sure, Bing rightly denounces lexical equivocation: “The evidence presented
has suggested that the ‘obedience of faith’ spoken of in Rom 1:5 and 16:26 is obedience to the command to believe
the gospel. Therefore, these passages should not be used to support the Lordship position that faith itself is in
essence obedience” (emphasis mine).699 As to Acts 6:7, he acknowledges that Marshall may be correct: “Obedient
to the faith means obedient to the call for faith contained in the gospel” (emphasis his).700 And I certainly would
agree with his conclusion: “The lexical evidence and Bible passages do not support the Lordship definition of faith
as obedience, willingness to obey, or submission” (emphasis mine).701 Therefore, even though saving faith cannot
be defined as obedience or submission lexically, nevertheless it is a form of such obedience theologically.

                                                      Invitation
        The affirmation that saving faith is a form of submission to the Lordship of Christ is thus rightly confirmed
in FG literature. Submission to the Lordship of Christ is a logical requirement for regeneration. This is not to say
that this perspective is always stressed in FG literature. But for that matter, it is not always stressed in the Scripture
either. Having just concluded in ch. 3 of GJ that saving faith is obedience to the Son, John proceeds to show Jesus
offering the water of life to the Samaritan woman with no emphasis on the fact that faith is submission. Therefore,
it is quite unlikely that she would have even regarded faith as a form of submission.
        Certainly, it is not necessary for converts to be consciously aware of everything that transpires in the
moment of regeneration. They come under subjection to the headship and leadership (and therefore the Lordship)
of Christ because they become a member of His body (Eph 1:22; 5:22-24). Yet they are probably not even aware of
their new spiritual anatomy or lack of old-self autonomy.
        Converts may not even realize that “they are not their own” or that “they have been bought with a price”
(1Cor 6:19-20) and that they, therefore, have changed Masters by trusting in Christ as their Savior. They may have
changed Masters without even realizing it (because they changed owners). In his section rejecting PLS† (phony
Lordship Salvation), Bunge correctly affirms GLS (Genuine Lordship Salvation): “There really is no choice—a
sinner who accepts Him as his personal Saviour also accepts Him as his Lord….When that same sinner gets saved,
ownership changes. Now he is owned by the Lord Jesus because He bought him with a price.”702
        Surely most new converts are not aware that when they believed in Christ, they died in Christ. Yet Paul
affirms that they have indeed died in Christ, even if they are not aware of it (Rom 6:1-10). After driving this point
home, Paul exhorts them to consider themselves dead (Rom 6:11). Indeed, one may be dead and yet not realize it.

*
    See “Obey in Jn 3:36” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
†
    See Phony Lordship Salvationists, 403.
Page 402                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
Paul wants them to be consciously aware of what has happened so they can take the appropriate action. Ironically,
you are dead, so live like it!
        Similarly, it is quite possible that the past obedience to the faith that took place in Rom 6:17-18 took place at
their conversion without their conscious realization that their faith was a form of obedience. Much less did they
realize that it was an obedience that resulted in their dying with Christ or becoming slaves of a new Master.703 Paul
concludes these verses by informing these believers that at that past point in time they “became slaves of
righteousness.” Then in the next verse he makes a transition to the present: “So now present your members as
slaves to righteousness” (Rom 6:19). In the next chapter, he uses marriage to illustrate the same point. At the point
of conversion they changed masters (pictured as husbands) from the Law to Christ.
        Consequently, in view of GJ and FG literature as a whole, Jesus’ omission of the full revelation concerning
what would transpire in His dialogue with the woman at the well should not be regarded as a refutation of the fact
that in taking the water freely she additionally was changing masters. She would no longer be a slave of sin but of
righteousness. Much less did Jesus need to explain that He would become her new Husband! But His lack of
explanation and her lack of comprehension in no way negate the transformation or transition. In trusting in Jesus as
the Christ (i.e. the Messiah) for eternal life, the woman was submitting herself to God’s will to receive eternal life
by believing in Jesus. On that occasion, Jesus did not stress the fact that responding to His invitation was a form of
submission, and it is doubtful that she would have perceived it as such. However, what was implicit on this
occasion is made explicit in other junctures.

                                                        Coercion
        John concludes his description of the eternal state in Revelation with a similar invitation: “And the Spirit
and the bride say, ‘Come.’ And let the one who hears say, ‘Come.’ And let the one who is thirsty come; let the one
who wishes take the water of life without cost” (Rev 22:17). Once again the accentuation is on the freeness of the
invitation to drink. Still, let us not forget that John commenced his discussion of the eternal state with the Lake of
Fire (Rev 20:14-15). The offer is burn or drink. God does not force a person to drink, but if a person does not
drink, God has made it clear that He will throw that individual into the Lake of Fire. Free will is not nullified;
drinking is contingent on the person’s willingness to drink. Nevertheless, not obeying the summons to drink is
exceedingly unwise. Even if someone were to hold a gun to your head and command you to do something you did
not want to do, you are free to do otherwise. So is God holding a gun (namely hell to our head)? Maybe some
would want to construe it that way. More appropriately perhaps, God might be pictured as a fireman holding a
safety net and exhorting you to jump away from the burning building to safety. Or to bring water into the
illustration, suppose you are standing on the edge of a cliff with a raging forest fire all around you. Below you lies
the saving waters of a cool lake. God urges you to jump. He does not push you from the building or the cliff. But it
would be exceedingly foolish to think that one is free to ignore the invitation and not pay the consequences.

                                                 Royal Invitation
       Bing accepts Morris’ assessment: “The gospel is a message of good news, but it is also an invitation from
the King of kings. Rejection of the gospel accordingly is disobedience to a royal invitation.”704 Let us not think that
we are free to reject this royal invitation without paying dire consequences. Jesus conveys this parabolically in
Mt 22:1-7. The invitation to submit to the king’s will by coming to the banquet is not considered optional. Granted,
the king may not drag you to the banquet, but he may kill you if you resist his royal summons. Submission to the
king’s will by dressing appropriately is not required to save your life in the parable. The only submission necessary
to save your life is that you simply come. This would appear to be a reasonable picture of saving faith. God desires
full submission and appropriate dress in morally white garments, but the only response necessary to save your life
from the fire is that you simply come to saving faith.

                                                 Lukan Parallel
       The king in the Matthean parable kills those who refuse to come. Likewise, in Lk 19:27 Jesus pictures
Himself as a king giving the execution order: “But these enemies of mine, who did not want me to reign over them,
bring them here and slay them in my presence.” So how much must you want the Lord to reign over you in order to
be saved from the death penalty? Enough to serve Him? No. Jesus makes that clear in this Lukan parable as well.
The non-serving servant in this parable (who does not serve his master) only submits to his master’s will in one
area—he freely receives the mina from his master. The reception of the mina, not the mina itself, represents the
transaction that happens in regeneration. The mina itself, on the other hand, represents the corresponding
opportunities to serve as a result of having become regenerate. The only submission one must make to be entrusted
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                                      Page 403
(and thus be a servant) is to accept the free offer. One does not have to serve to be a servant in this parable. The
only submission seen in this parable by this servant is his receiving the mina. In view of the above texts concerning
the obedience of faith, this would picture someone who submits to the Lordship of Christ by believing in Him for
regeneration, but who refuses to do anything by way of service in his actions.

                                                 Automatic Lordship
        Those who believe in Christ for eternal life not only become regenerate, they automatically become
entrusted in various ways.* They become servants whether or not they serve and whether they are aware that they
have become entrusted servants. Whether they want to be servants or are aware of the transaction makes no
difference as to the reality that they have, in fact, become servants. The servant in the parable did not want to serve;
nonetheless, he was a servant. He is a picture of someone who has submitted to the Lordship of Christ in one area
and one area only; he has obeyed Christ’s command to believe in Him for eternal life. Nevertheless, he is
responsible to Christ in all areas of his life. Whether or not new converts (such as the woman at the well) are fully
aware of the ramifications of their trust in Christ, the fact remains that they are now entrusted by Christ as
regenerate servants and are accountable to Him as such. Christ has become their Lord in a new and exciting way
that He was not before. He has entrusted them with tremendous opportunities to which they otherwise were not
privy, and He will hold them accountable for how they perform in reference to those opportunities in view of their
new abilities. With great opportunity comes great responsibility. The invitation given by evangelists to the lost to
receive Christ as their Savior and Lord is really inappropriate in certain aspects. When people become believers,
Christ automatically becomes their Lord in a new way He was not before. They are given a relationship and
stewardship they previously did not have. God becomes their Father, and they have a responsibility to live as such
and share the gospel with others. They do not need to be told to make Christ their Lord. Quite frankly, He already
is. Information and exhortation would be more appropriate than a misleading invitation.

                                                     Importance
       In today’s theological climate, evangelists need to explain very clearly and carefully that submission of
one’s life/performance to Christ (or making Him Lord of one’s life/performance) is not required in order to receive
the free gift of eternal life. In fact, the ramifications of Christ’s Lordship do not need to be made in every
evangelistic encounter. So why bother? Why present an invitation pertaining to Lordship that is so susceptible to
being misunderstood?
       First, it is biblical to proclaim the Lordship of Christ. Second, it gives opportunity to affirm the dual nature
of Christ’s Lordship in conversion. Christ is not only objectively Lord; He is also subjectively Lord. Whether the
convert is consciously aware of it, the convert has submitted subjectively to the Lordship of Christ by believing.
Third, it refutes the LS notion that we must make Christ our Lord if we receive Him as our Savior. This is blatantly
false. The truth is that Christ makes Himself our Lord in new ways when we trust Him as our Savior. We do not
make Him Lord; He makes Himself our Lord by entrusting us as His servants. We are His servants even if we do
not serve because we have submitted to His reign over us by receiving the capacity from Him to serve Him. Fourth,
it shows that today’s so-called Lordship Salvation is not biblical Lordship Salvation.

                                      Phony Lordship Salvationists
        Those in the Christian community who teach that receiving the free gift of eternal life requires that you
submit your life to the Lordship of Christ are popularly, but improperly, known as Lordship Salvationists. They
label, and libel, those in the FG movement as being No-Lordship Salvationists (NLS). In reality, today’s Popular
Lordship Salvationists are Pseudo Lordship Salvationists. Those in the FG movement are actually the biblical
Lordship Salvationists. Hence, Grace Lordship Salvationists are the Genuine Lordship Salvationists (GLS).705
        Today’s LS refuses to submit to the Lordship of Christ in Mt 7:20-23. They submit their performance to
Christ without having ever submitted themselves to His will concerning eternal life. Jesus asks a rhetorical
question, “And why do you call Me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ and do not do what I say?” (Lk 6:46) Why should we call
today’s Lordship Salvationists Lordship Salvationists when they refuse to do what Christ says is necessary to

*
  Jesus only entrusts obedient believers with intimate fellowship and disclosures (Jn 2:23-25; 14:21-23; 1Jn 1:7). These misthological
entrustments are over and above His basic entrustment to all believers with a new relationship and the gospel of grace. The servants
who expanded their entrustment to five and ten talents before their master returned obviously had increased their entrustment in the
interadvent period. The servant entrusted with the single mina did not advance to greater entrustments during this time period but
stagnated at the basal entrustment.
Page 404                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
receive eternal life? Today’s Popular Lordship Salvationists are better called Pseudo Lordship Salvationists or
Phony Lordship Salvationists (PLS).
        Paul is concerned about labels: “Beware of the dogs, beware of the evil workers, beware of the false
circumcision; for we are the true circumcision, who worship in the Spirit of God and glory in Christ Jesus and
put no confidence in the flesh” (Phil 3:2-3). The legalists of Paul’s day advocated circumcision. Paul did not
hesitate to expose their counterfeit claim. Why should we? Paul turned the tables on these legalistic performatists*
by showing that those who compose the true circumcision are those who glory in Christ rather than in their fleshly
performance. Why not follow his example with modern day legalists?
        Jesus certainly does not soften His words on this matter. He blisters these Jewish legalists as those of the
synagogue of Satan, who say that they are Jews, and are not, but lie (Rev 3:9). If this is how Jesus feels about the
legalists of the past, why assume He feels any differently about the legalists of today? Today’s legalists claim to be
Lordship Salvationists, but they are not. They lie in labeling themselves as Lordship Salvationists. They lie in
libeling their opponents as No-Lordship Salvationists. They blaspheme the little FG movement. Will Jesus not also
respond to His GLS followers today just as He did then: “I know your tribulation and your poverty (but you are
rich), and the blasphemy by those who say they are Jews and are not, but are a synagogue of Satan” (Rev 2:9).
        In embracing FG theology, you automatically become a Genuine Lordship Salvationist. The only
submission to the Lordship of Christ that soteriologically brings salvation is the simple obedience of faith. Such
obedience results in Christ becoming your soteric Lord. He has bought you, sealed you, and entrusted you. You
might not even be aware of the transaction. But your lack of service or your lack of awareness does not change the
objective fact that He is your subjective Lord in this most fundamental area. You have submitted to His will in
receiving eternal life as a free gift and thereby have become His entrusted servant via faith, and He has become
your Lord in that He has entrusted you with a stewardship via regeneration. It is time that we call ourselves the
Genuine Lordship Salvationists and refer to the Satanic counterfeits as Phony Lordship Salvationists.
        Legalists call Christ their Lord but refuse to submit to His Lordship by refusing to trust in Him alone for
eternal life. They prefer to trust in their own performance. They do not want the Lord to reign over them. To do so
would mean that they would have to do what Christ says is necessary for eternal life and admit that it is not
conditioned on their performance. They refuse to do so. They will die in their sins as a result. The first and
foremost thing that is necessary to become a Lordship Salvationist in the context of Lk 19:27 is to submit to the
Lord’s will by simply accepting the mina from His hand. If you do that, then you cannot deny that you have
submitted to His Lordship over you to that extent. If you want the Lord to reign over you to the extent that you are
willing to freely receive eternal life from Him, then you have met the requirement of Lk 19:27.
        Accordingly, if you simply believe in Christ for eternal life, then you have submitted to the Lordship of
Christ to the degree necessary for Him to become your soteric Savior and mistholic Lord. Just as one can sign a
contract without reading all the fine print, and thereby unknowingly acquiesce to the unknown terms of that
agreement, one can trust in Christ for eternal life and experience a transformation and transition without reading
the entire Bible and without being aware of all that is taking place in receiving eternal life. You experience a
transition into a new Master-servant, Father-son, and Brother-brother relation in which you become Christ’s
servant and possession and brother, even apart from your conscious realization.
        Therefore, the PLS insistence that you must accept Christ as your Lord and Savior is suspect in that it is
frequently done with the unbiblical explanation that this means that you must make Christ Lord of your life. This is
false. You no more make Him your Lord than you make Him your Savior. You do not make Him save you do you?
Of course not! In the same manner, He makes Himself Lord of your life by right of purchase, entrustment, and
headship. As His purchased possession, you are under His protection.† However, as His possession you are under
moral obligation to glorify Him by the way you live (1Cor 6:19-20). Otherwise, you will not come into possession
of His kingdom. You will merely be there as a humiliated servant rather than an exalted ruler. Moreover, the PLS
insistence does an injustice to the fact that conscious realization of one’s subjection is not a biblical necessitation.
So if PLS wants to press the matter of subjective Lordship, let PLS press it. GLS affirms it.

                                              Enemies of Mine
      The Lord’s servants in the parable are those who receive the mina, whether or not they serve Him with the
mina. Some of the Lord’s servants will accept the life of the Spirit without walking in the Spirit and without

  Performatists might be useful as a less pejorative term for Legalistic Lordship Salvationists. Some in the PLS camp would

producing the fruit of the Spirit (Gal 5:22-25). They will hide their talent in the ground rather than invest it in the
Spirit (Mt 25:25-27). Now to be sure, licentious believers are enemies of God (Jam 4:4) in the misthological sense,
but not in the soteriological sense. Contrastively, these parabolic enemies are soteric enemies. This Lukan twin to
the Matthean parable of the talents is not describing the believer who hides his mina as an enemy of the Lord.
        In the parabolic literature of the NT, the master/servant relationship never uses the figure of the slave to
refer to the unsaved. The parabolic slave always refers symbolically to the elect—whether angelic or human. If a
parable deals with the unsaved, it conveys their fate through means of some other imagery than that of slaves. In
this case, it does so through the imagery of enemies. Identification of these parabolic enemies does not help the
PLS position. It destroys it. It was the legalists of Jesus’ day who hated Him. Jesus was a friend of sinners but an
enemy of the legalists. These parabolic enemies of Christ are the legalists who violently respond to the King and
His messengers.
        It will be objected that the legalists of today love Jesus. But do they? Do they love the Lord of the Gospels,
or is it the Lord of Legalism whom they love? The Lord of the Gospels does indeed say, “If you love Me, you will
keep My commandments” (Jn 14:15). Yet what does this entail? Is it that we first and foremost “love one another”
(Jn 15:12)? No. It is that we first become a member of the one another. You cannot serve the Lord with your talent
or mina until you are first given the talent or mina. Those who are in the flesh are powerless to please God
(Rom 8:8). The fundamental submission upon which we build our subsequent obedience is the admission that we
cannot save ourselves by our fleshly performance.
        PLS want the Lord of Legalism to reign over them, not the Lord of Grace. The Lord-of-Grace theology is
rejected by them. When the Lord of Grace sends out His servants with invitations to come, those rejecting His
invitation today vehemently respond that such messengers are advocates of nonlordship or no-lordship. In rejecting
the message of grace, these pseudo advocates of the Lordship of Christ have rejected the Lordship of the Lord of
Grace. They are not biblical Lordship Salvationists since they have rejected the Lord’s command pertaining to the
free offer of salvation. They are Legalistic Salvationists.
        So while, on the one hand, it might be true that through God’s enabling grace even unregenerate legalists
can experience an agape love for Jesus (in that they may be willing to die for Jesus), on the other hand it can be
argued that they do not love Jesus in that only those who have experienced new birth have the capacity to love the
Lord of Grace (1Jn 4:7). Not all those who are lovingly willing to die for Jesus are born of God and therefore
actually love the Lord of Grace.

                            The Parable of the Lost Talents (Mt 18:21-35)
       The parallelism between Mt 18:21-35 and Mt 24:45-51 has been noted already. The Marrowistic position is
that the wicked slave in the former parable and the evil slave in the latter parable both represent someone who is
saved. Obviously, we are not automatically jumping to the conclusion that slaves are saved just because they are
called slaves. Nonetheless, after one has done one’s exegetical homework, the proper deduction is that the term
slave is being used in both parables for someone who is saved.

Soteric Interpretation
       The soteriological interpretation, which originally was held by the present author, assumes that the
continuity of the parable indiscriminately uses the same word doulas (slave/servant) for the person in question
throughout the parable. As a result, he is called a slave both before and after his conversion. Therefore, the term
slave could be used to describe someone who is not yet a believer, since the individual in this story is commonly
thought to be an unsaved slave at the beginning of the parable. According to this popular perception, the
forgiveness in Mt 18:27 would be soteric forgiveness. Indeed, the parable can be interpreted in this manner without
necessarily causing any problems for FG theology. Jesus simply is using the word slave to describe someone who
experiences salvation but who subsequently fails to demonstrate the reality of that salvation in his life, and this
subsequent failure has misthological repercussions, but the misthological consequences are not as severe as the
original soteriological pronouncements in that his property, wife, and children are not sold. As a result of his initial
soteric forgiveness (picturing salvation by grace apart from works), the slave’s subsequent failure to demonstrate
his lord’s merciful nature is not dealt with as harshly as originally specified. Thus a soteric view that is compatible
with FG theology could be adopted theologically; nevertheless, any soteriological interpretation must be rejected
exegetically.

Mistholic Interpretation
        As Crawford has suggested, a straightforward exegesis of the passage strongly indicates that the slave
already was saved before his sins were forgiven in Mt18:27. The parable is not dealing with someone who
becomes a believer/slave but someone who already is a believer/slave. The debt incurred to him by his fellow slave
(picturing the debt between believing brethren) occurred before he was forgiven in v. 27. In other words, the debt
of a hundred denarii between these two slaves occurred while the wicked slave was incurring his debt of ten
thousand talents, not afterwards. The significance of this fact should not be ignored. This smaller debt which
pictures the debt between two believing brethren was incurred before the forgiveness pronounced in v. 27. Thus,
the forgiveness pictured in v. 27 is not the forgiveness that results in one becoming a believing brother. The wicked
slave already is a believing brother before he receives the forgiveness pictured in v. 27. The most reasonable
deduction from the sequence (and from the notification that what is being described is forgiveness among brethren)
is that the wicked slave already was saved before he was granted the forgiveness pictured in v. 27. The forgiveness
pictured in this verse must be the temporal forgiveness of an already saved slave. This verse is not depicting the
soteric forgiveness that we get when we first become believers/slaves but the forgiveness that we experience as
believers/slaves after we already have become believers/slaves. Our performance as believers, not as unbelievers,
is under review.
        The misthological forgiveness of our postconversional sins is conditioned, in part, on our dealings with our
fellow believing brethren. Jesus goes on to portray this reality by describing what happens to the slave in v. 34 after
his postconversional temporal forgiveness in v. 27. The wicked slave incurs his debt in v. 27 while he is a slave in
service to his master. Similarly, after we become believers, we incur a large sin debt (Mt 6:12) while we are
working in the Lord’s service. Nevertheless, as we confess our sins, the Lord forgives us (cp. 1Jn 1:9). By
confessing our sins, we can avoid the premature death that otherwise could have a devastating financial and
emotional impact on our wife and children. Nevertheless, our misthological forgiveness of those postconversional,
confessed sins is contingent on our forgiving our brothers and sisters in Christ. If we do not forgive them, then our
postconversional sins, which were forgiven temporally, will be taken into account misthologically at the Bema, and
we will have to pay the consequences personally. Thankfully, our family will not have to pay the consequences
along with us at that time. Therefore, not only do the slaves in this parable represent believers, the slaves in this
parable are believers from the beginning of the parable. There is no justification for regarding v. 27 as a picture of
justification salvation or for thinking that the slaves are a picture of the unsaved.*

Doulology
      Biblical doulology† should not only affirm that the slaves in these parables are saved but also note that the
word doulos (slave), when used of a servant of the Lord, always refers to the elect. While it may be that the Lord’s
servants in Mt 13:27 and 28 refer to angels, it would be elect angels—angels who serve the Lord. But when used of
human beings, the Lord’s slaves always refers to believers. The slave in Mt 10:24 for example, as one who is not
above His master, is urged to endure persecution in order to be saved in the end (Mt 10:22). Certainly, the one who
*
    See Four Types of Vertical Forgiveness, 347.
†
    Doulology is a coined term referring to the doctrine of slavery.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                         Page 407
needs to endure in order to be saved in the mistholic sense is already saved in the soteric sense. Jesus is not telling
unbelievers how to earn soteric salvation! Such slaves need to endure persecution because they are not above their
Master and in order to be exalted by their Master. When Jesus makes a similar statement in Jn 13:16, He may be
understood as excluding Judas from those who are truly His slaves, since the Lord excludes Judas from the
reference (Jn 13:18). And the Lord practically equates the slaves with the chosen/elect shortly thereafter (Jn 15:19-
20). Moreover, the heart of His statement in Jn 15:15a identifies those who are left, after Judas has left the room, as
those who are His slaves: “I call you slaves.” Who are the slaves? You are. The eleven remaining disciples are
defined as Jesus’ slaves. The corroborating evidence removes Judas from consideration. As has been demonstrated,
the servants in Mt 18:23 represent those who are already believing brethren. The parable is not describing lost
slaves who become saved slaves soterically. Rather, they are already saved soterically, but they may fail to be
saved misthological in the end.
        The slave who was entrusted during the delaying of a long time* in Mt 24:26-51 was initially sensible yet
also susceptible to becoming evil subsequently. Soteriologically speaking, since he was saved initially, he
remained saved subsequently. With deductive certainty, the securitist must affirm that this slave who became evil
during this delay was regenerate. Inductively, one likewise should conclude that the entrusted slave who performed
poorly during the long time (polus chronos) in Mt 25:19 and the virgins who fell asleep during the delaying
(chronizo) in Mt 25:5 represent the regenerate also, which is why they were entrusted with talents and torch dance.
        The Lord’s complaint that Jezebel “leads My bond-servants astray” (Rev 2:20) is most readily understood as
referring to leading those who are believers astray. In Rev 7:3, the bond-servants of the Lord who are sealed are the
144,000. While this may not be all believers, it would nevertheless be only believers. The only bond-servants the
NT knows anything about are the elect. The NAS shows a pronounced tendency to translate doulos as bond-servant
in the NT epistles when referring to believers. The only time it uses bond-servant in the gospels is in Lk 2:29,
when Simeon (a believer) refers to himself as the Lord’s bond-servant, “Let Thy bond-servant depart in peace.”
The NAS uses the similar term bondslave in Lk 1:38 and 48, where Mary and Elizabeth (also believers) refer to
themselves as the Lord’s bondslaves. Following the NAS example elsewhere, translating doulos as bond-servants
in these parabolic passages would help elucidate the issue. Jesus is talking about wicked and evil bond-servants
(i.e., believing servants). MacArthur spends several pages defending the thesis that believers are slaves since they
belong to Jesus.706 Unfortunately, MacArthur shows a propensity to forget his own admission when it is
inconvenient for his exegesis. For example, since Jesus had several slaves in the parables who did not serve Him,
the logical conclusion would be that a believer can belong to Jesus and yet fail to serve Him. Strangely, MacArthur
seems to draw the opposite conclusion. Further, Jesus’ slave who is thrown into the outer darkness would, by
MacArthur’s own definition of slave (as a person who belongs to someone), represent a person who belongs to
Jesus.

                                                               Conclusion
       In the previous chapter, and in the current one as well, it was shown that Mt 25:13 is a pivotal verse,
showing that misthological themes exist on both sides of this verse, which pertain to believers in two different time
periods with application to believers of both time periods, regardless of whether they are living in the present
church age or will be among those who live through the tribulation. Consequently, misthological books, such as
this one, should prove to be misthologically useful by way of application to those left behind to go through the
tribulation since similar promises apply to both groups. Nevertheless, the interpretation of the verse and of the
passage introduced by it in the parable of the talents is intended for those of us living in the church age.
       In this chapter, the time period in view was discussed briefly. Then the parable was examined and exegetical
comments were provided on key phrases and words. Several of these comments were based on time analysis. The
fact that the servants did not know when their Lord would return indicated that His return would be imminent
(25:13). The doctrine of imminence applies only to the rapture, so the parable likewise must be relegated to that
time period. This is confirmed by the fact that the master is described as being gone for a long time (25:19). The
significance of the timing of the events, however, is not limited to dispensational consideration. The fact that the
slaves are not dealt with until after the arrival of the master (25:27) would not be conclusive in and of itself outside
the dispensational framework of the rapture. But when coupled with the observation that the talent is not removed
until the master returns, it becomes a very persuasive argument that the talent does not denote a soteriological
concept—even outside the dispensational framework.


*
    Chronizo is translated in both capacities in this verse.
Page 408                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
         One might understand, to some extent, why covenantal theologians try to see a covenantal relationship, but
it is rather puzzling to see such arguments being advanced by those who are supposed to be dispensational in their
outlook. Nevertheless, the argument that Jesus is saying that all three servants have a covenantal relationship but
only the faithful servants have a saving relationship is nullified by the fact that the relationship is genuine until the
arrival of the Master. The passage cannot be describing the nonelect of the present or future.
         The above three arguments factor in time as a key component, but the remaining arguments do not. Jesus’
exhortation to stay on the alert (v. 13) for the return of their master is incomprehensible as a warning for those who
have not yet experienced regeneration. This verb is never used of the lost in the NT, and there is absolutely no
reason in this passage to counter the established NT usage which regards this verb as expressing a misthological
theme rather than a soteriological doubt.
         In using the word you (v. 13), Jesus contextually is addressing only genuine believers. This contextual
understanding is confirmed by the text itself. Jesus specifies that He is talking about His own (v. 14). The
relationship is further confirmed by Jesus’ self designation as their master (v. 20). The reality of their
soteriological relationship is moreover confirmed by the fact that they are entrusted (v. 14), an affirmation which is
never used of unbelievers in the NT. Jesus did not entrust unbelievers. The slave in question actually receives what
is entrusted to him (v. 24). He does not just leave the offer on the table. Thus, as was noted in Illustration 136.
Probabilities for the Unworthy Slave of Mt 25:13-30 (p. 391), a total of nine details in the passage demand that we
regard the passage as descriptive of true believers. An additional four items were marked on that chart supporting
the probability that the man in question was saved, but even these items can be sub-ranked.
         That the concern of the parable would be that unbelievers hid (v. 18) their devotion to Christ is highly
unlikely. Really, such a concern would be nonsensical. Moreover, there is strong reason to suspect that, although
the talent does not represent regeneration, the talent is a clear indication of the hidden regenerate nature. The
exegetical probability that this detail indicates the reality of regeneration is well-nigh certain. Hardly any less
certain is the intrinsic likelihood that what is taken away is the opportunity to serve in the Lord’s kingdom rather
than to live in the Lord’s kingdom. Parabolically speaking, the slave is not killed; he is not dragged outside the
kingdom. He spends the night on his master’s estate. Theologically speaking, the argument that what is taken away
is a covenantal relationship is implausible.
         Any legitimate reason as to why these two details should not be marked with absolute certainty (as
indicating that the slave was saved) is hardly conceivable. One might try to invent one, such as speculating that the
talent represents the opportunity to be saved. But this is a one-way street to teaching salvation by works. If such
were the case, then his opportunity to be saved was taken away because he did not respond properly in good works.
Salvation from damnation is ultimately determined by performance. The feebleness of such a response is readily
self-evident. What is taken away is the opportunity to serve rather than be saved. Nevertheless, for the sake of our
more imaginative soteriological critics, who may be able to conjure up another possibility to try to counter our
misthology, Marrowists can be content to leave these two items marked with extremely high probability rather than
absolute certainty. As to the third item marked as showing that they were saved, although some fellow
misthologists emphatically would argue that the black darkness in Jude 1:13 is a misthological concept, that
assessment is not shared herein and, therefore, the present work is content to acknowledge that the black darkness
may indeed be a soteriological description.* On the other hand, the expression outer darkness is not used
soteriologically anywhere else in the NT, so its occurrence in Mt 25:30 has been marked accordingly. As to the
designation of slave, the most reasonable hypothesis is that the man being so depicted is a bond-servant of the Lord
(and thus a believer) in harmony with the rest of the NT.
         This leaves two items that have been marked as not certainly or even probably indicating regeneration. The
slave was cast out and wept (v. 30). Again, perhaps contrary to some misthologists, the present writer is willing to
entertain the probability that such actions can be used soteriologically in the NT. At worst these details would be
considered inconclusive. Thus, they have been marked as representing either possibility.
         Similar points as those above were then briefly stated concerning the twin Lukan parable of the minas (or
pounds). The time of judgment must be the JSC. The unworthy slave suffers the loss of his entrustment, not loss of
his life. In contrast to the king’s enemies who rejected his title, the slave passively recognized his lord’s
sovereignty (thereby representing salvation by passive persuasion). But it takes active submission to such

*
  While the black darkness can be combined with the outer darkness in the principle of correlativity, they cannot be equated. The
arguments of those misthologists who would equate them are taken, herein, as falling short of establishing equivalence but useful in
demonstrating correlativity. Similar comments can be made regarding those misthologists would take the being cast out into outer
darkness and weeping as soteric in some passages but mistholic in others. Their arguments would support soteric-mistholic
correlativity. See Theory of Correlativity, 911.
Chapter 15. Slave in the Outer Darkness (Mt 25:14-30)                                                              Page 409
sovereignty to save oneself from loss of rewards. This parable illustrates the difference between the subjective and
objective Lordship of Christ.* Those believers who passively respond to His Lordship, by simply believing in Him
for eternal life (i.e., who are passively persuaded by His divine claims to give them eternal life), will find that their
lives are spared. Yet only those believers who advance beyond that to active submission to the Lordship of Christ,
by performing appropriate activity (i.e., works), will be saved from the loss of their mina (i.e., form the loss of
opportunity to serve). Keeping the mina is a Bema issue.
        Those believers who serve the Lord well will be well rewarded and hear the two most important
misthological words in the Bible: Well done. Believers who serve the Lord moderately may expect a moderate
commendation. Those who are indifferent in their service to the Lord can anticipate that the Lord will not be
indifferent to their lack of service for Him. They will be deprived eternally of any further opportunity to serve Him
in the capacities which He originally intended for them to serve. Rather than rule with Him, they will wail without
Him. Oh, yes, they will still be in the kingdom—somewhere—and thus with Him in the sense of being with Him in
the same kingdom. But, in another sense, they will be excluded from Him. As a result of their failure to serve Him,
they will not have as intimate an association as they could have had with Him.
        What that exclusion fully entails will be reserved for the subsequent discussion. For now note that in the
present Olivet context, simply being thrown into the outer darkness is not the worst thing that can happen to a
believer. To be sure, the indifferent slave (who was thrown into the outer darkness in 25:30) did in fact weep and
gnash his teeth. Yet the hostile slave (who was apparently thrown into the same misthological reality and
experienced the same misthological response) was flogged first (24:51). The most reasonable deduction, therefore,
would be that there will be degrees of punishment in the outer darkness. Even if the flogging is limited to the
Bema, the results of the Bema are eternal. That the consequences are eternal is a corollary of eternal rewards. Such
rewards may either be positive or negative. Because the Bema flogging relates to the dispensing of eternal negative
rewards, the results of the flogging are eternal, although the flogging itself is only temporary. Neither the flogging
nor Bema is eternal, but their results certainly are.
        Although this doctrine of misthological exclusion is misthologically negative, it is soteriologically
positive—exceedingly so. Unlike Arminianism and Calvinism, which condition salvation from eternal damnation
upon perseverance, Marrowism conditions misthological salvation upon perseverance. The biblical doctrine of
perseverance is very important to all three systems. However, only Marrowism affirms eternal security for those
who fail to persevere. A misthological understanding of the outer darkness is a defense for the Marrowistic
doctrine of eternal security.
        As to the certainty of the Marrowistic conclusion, the possibility of being wrong was considered. The
methodology used in this chapter to reach the level of certainty attained herein was consistent with the misthology
laid out in the introduction.† The parable of the talents was first examined inductively in that the details were
examined individually and collectively and assigned relative probabilities. The inductive probability of the
Marrowistic interpretation was found to be extremely high.‡ Yet owing to the nature of inductive inquiry, absolute
certainty was not obtained, nor was it the goal—at that level of the investigation. However, deductive logic was
then applied to the various hermeneutical branches composing the hermeneutical tree of probability, so as to
investigate the parameters of certainty for the overall possibilities. In each branch it was noted that those
interpretations opposing the Marrowistic conclusion dead end in either proveitism or forfeitism.§ Because both of
these latter systems of thought can be shown to lead to an irrational conclusion (in which the gift of eternal life is
treated as a forfeitable reward), the level of certainty in favor of the Marrowistic interpretation for each branch
must be considered 100%, which is consistent with deductive logic. Since this level of certainty is deducible for
each branch, the adductive conclusion is that the Marrowistic position is 100% certain. While being 100% certain
as to which Marrowistic branch is to be preferred over another Marrowistic branch may be beyond the scope of the
present inquiry (because inductive rather than deductive logic was used to determine which branch was preferable),
being less than 100% certain as to the preference of the overall Marrowistic interpretation was found to be
irrational. Intellectual honesty requires 100% certainty in favor of the Marrowistic range of interpretation. We can
be absolutely certain that the only way to pull a soteric rabbit out of the hat is by first putting it in the hat. No such
rabbits please. Exegesis is to be preferred over eisegesis.

                                               Chapter 16.
                                       Sheep and Goats (Mt 25:31-46)
                                                         Introduction
        The parable of the sheep and the goats is the last parable of the Mt. Olivet Discourse. The survey of that
discourse leading up to this point has shown that Jesus commences by describing the events associated with the
tribulation and both stages of His second coming. One stage comes at the end of the tribulation, the other at its
beginning. Jesus next gives parables that describe the judgments associated with both stages of His coming. Two
of the parables deal with the judgment which will occur at the beginning of the tribulation. Conversely, two of the
parables deal with the judgment which will occur at the end of the tribulation.*
       The two parables concerning the judgment that occurs at the beginning of the tribulation deal exclusively
with believers, pictured as faithful versus unfaithful slaves. The issue is not whether they belong to their Master but
whether they are faithful. One would expect this perspective since the rapture and JSC only deal with blood-bought
believers who actually belong to Jesus. In contrast, one would not expect the parables dealing with the judgment
that occurs at the end of the tribulation to deal exclusively with faithful versus unfaithful believers since
unbelievers will be dealt with also at that time.
       Not surprisingly, the Lord told two parables about this latter judgment at the end of the tribulation.
Naturally, the first parable that describes this latter judgment is the parable of the virgins and deals exclusively
with the saved—faithful versus unfaithful Jewish believers who live through the tribulation. The second parable
that describes this latter judgment is the parable of the sheep and goats. Contrastively, it deals with the lost and the
saved Gentiles who live through the tribulation.† This is the common dispensational understanding of the latter
passage, so dwelling at length on this aspect of the parable is unnecessary, particularly since I have a book devoted
to this parable. What is mistakenly assumed from this passage is that practice determines position, or stated
inversely, that position determines practice. However, this parable was not given to teach that good people go to
heaven or that bad people go to hell. This clarification will be the focus of attention in the present chapter. Since
the previous parables pictured unworthy and foolish slaves and virgins, it is reasonable to presume that the present
parable will not rule out their existence. We need not demonstrate their existence in the present passage. In order to
substantiate the points already made, it will suffice to demonstrate that their existence is not denied.

                                                                Text
        31
           But when the Son of Man comes in His glory, and all the angels with Him, then He will sit on His
        glorious throne. 32 And all the nations will be gathered before Him; and He will separate them from
        one another, as the shepherd separates the sheep from the goats; 33 and He will put the sheep on His
        right, and the goats on the left. 34 Then the King will say to those on His right, “Come, you who are
        blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world. 35 For
        I was hungry, and you gave Me something to eat; I was thirsty, and you gave Me drink; I was a
        stranger, and you invited Me in; 36 naked, and you clothed Me; I was sick, and you visited Me; I was
        in prison, and you came to Me.” 37 Then the righteous will answer Him, saying, “Lord, when did we
        see You hungry, and feed You, or thirsty, and give You drink? 38 And when did we see You a
        stranger, and invite You in, or naked, and clothe You? 39 And when did we see You sick, or in prison,
        and come to You?” 40 And the King will answer and say to them, “Truly I say to you, to the extent
        that you did it to one of these brothers of Mine, even the least of them, you did it to Me.” 41 Then He
        will also say to those on His left, “Depart from Me, accursed ones, into the eternal fire which has
        been prepared for the devil and his angels; 42 for I was hungry, and you gave Me nothing to eat; I was
        thirsty, and you gave Me nothing to drink; 43 I was a stranger, and you did not invite Me in; naked,
        and you did not clothe Me; sick, and in prison, and you did not visit Me.” 44 Then they themselves
        also will answer, saying, “Lord, when did we see You hungry, or thirsty, or a stranger, or naked, or
        sick, or in prison, and did not take care of You?” 45 Then He will answer them, saying, “Truly I say to
        you, to the extent that you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to Me.” 46 And
        these will go away into eternal punishment, but the righteous into eternal life.

 See Illustration 123. Modified Phase Chart of Mt. Olivet, 335.

  Jewish believers (represented by the virgins) who live through the tribulation are dealt with before the Gentiles (represented by the
sheep and goats) who live through the tribulation are judged: living Jews then living Gentiles are judged.
Page 412                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
                                                Events Precede Judgments
        The sequence of events within the parable of the sheep and goats needs to be compared between two
passages (cp. Mt 25:31 with Mt 24:29-31). The two passages of Scripture are discussing the same time frame.
After the tribulation is completed (24:29), Jesus comes in His glory (cp. 24:30 & 25:31). Then everyone is gathered
before Him. Next, He separates the elect from the nonelect (24:31), that is, the sheep from the goats (25:32). This
is the first order of business. The second order of business is to judge those who already have been gathered and
separated. In doing so, the Lord rewards the sheep (25:34-40) with the inheritance of the kingdom (25:34) and
eternal life (Mt 25:46). And He punishes the goats (25:41-46). The fact that He has come to earth at this time and
that they are to inherit the kingdom at this time shows that the millennial kingdom is ready to commence.
Therefore, this judgment occurs at the end of the tribulation and just before the start of the millennial kingdom.

       Some object that the soteriological indictment and punishment of the lost goats (in the form of eternal
punishment in the eternal fire) versus the misthological reward for the saved sheep (in the form of eternal life and
inheriting the kingdom) cannot refer to the beginning of the millennial kingdom but would have to refer to the
eternal state rather than an intermediate kingdom. This objection reflects an amillennial perspective. Feinberg, a
pretribulationalist, shows the futility of such an objection:
Chapter 16. Sheep & Goats (Mt 25:31-46)                                                                          Page 413


          First, as already mentioned, Matthew 25:31 clearly relates these events to 24:29-31, the Second
          Coming. Second, a period of confinement and judgment followed by final consignment in hell for the
          wicked is in keeping with Isaiah 24:21-24. Moreover, the intermediate state of the wicked is pictured
          as a time of torment (Luke 16:19-31) and therefore is justifiably called eternal punishment, albeit the
          first phase. Third, if the millennial kingdom is the first phrase [sic] of the eternal kingdom or reign of
          Christ (1 Cor. 15:21-28), then eternal life is not an inappropriate name for the reward of the
          righteous….Finally, even if “eternal life” and “eternal punishment” must refer to the final state of the
          righteous and wicked, that does not necessitate our disregard for the one chronological indicator.
          Often in prophetic literature there is the foreshortening of two events so that they appear to be
          temporally successive, but in fact are separated by many years. (Italics his.)707

       As Feinberg relates, the millennial recompense is but the introduction to the eternal state, and the two are
sometimes telescopically fused together.* The Judgment Seat of Christ occurs at the end of the church age and
deals with Christians. The Judgment of the Sheep & Goats takes place at the end of the tribulation but before the
millennium and deals with unbelievers and believers who survive the tribulation. The Great White Throne
Judgment takes place at the end of the millennium and deals with those who are born in the millennial kingdom.
This is standard dispensationalism, and I concur with the typical outline.

                                             Separation Precedes Judgment
       Before dealing with the character of the sheep and goats, two interesting facts that Jesus presents in this
parable should first be noted. First, the separation of the sheep from the goats precedes their judgment. The
separation is based on what they are (a sheep or a goat) and determines whether they enter the kingdom or the
eternal fire. Second, the judgment that comes after the separation is based on one thing—on what they do—not
what they are. This is exactly what one would expect from the Lord’s earlier comment in Mt 16:27. “For the Son
of Man is going to come in the glory of His Father with His angels; and will then recompense every man
according to his deeds.” Judgment is always based on deeds (i.e., works). However, it must not be concluded that
the determining factor as to whether they go to hell is their works. For this would teach that salvation from eternal
damnation is by works. This is an accursed gospel, and those who believe it will be declared to be accursed (cf.
Mt 25:41). The judgment is not to determine whether they enter the kingdom, but whether they inherit the
kingdom. Their entrance into the kingdom, in contrast, was determined by the separation which preceded the
judgment.
       From the OT background we learn that a separation evidently already had taken place in regard to Jesus’
brethren, the Jews, whom Jesus mentions in this Matthean context (25:40). Feinberg points out that this Matthean
separation of the sheep from the goats is actually the second of the two separations that take place after the
tribulation:

          While many unbelievers will be slain at Christ’s return, two judgments follow to root out all who
          remain. Ezekiel 20:37, 38 indicates that when Israel is established in the land at the return of
          their Messiah, there will be renewal of the covenant (v. 37) and purging of the rebels from the
          nation (v. 38). Thus, all wicked will be separated from Israel. All remaining Gentile unbelievers will
          be eliminated at the sheep-and-goat judgment (Matt 25:31-46). Therefore, no wicked will enter the
          kingdom. (Italics his.)708

       Following Christ’s return, after the Jews are gathered together to be judged, the Jewish rebels among them
will not be allowed to enter the Promised Land. Thus, the Pauline affirmation that all Israel† will be saved should
be understood as a relative all.709 However, it does not necessarily follow that these rebellious Jews are not allowed
into the kingdom itself or that the salvation at stake for these unfaithful or rebellious Jews is salvation from eternal
damnation. The context in Ezekiel is suggestive that the rebellious Jews will be saved soteriologically in that their
judgment is likened by Ezekiel unto the manner in which God dealt with the Jews who died in the wilderness and
who thus were not allowed into the Promised Land. God’s rebellious children (the Jews) died in the wilderness, but
they were not sent back to Egypt. Misthological salvation from a wilderness experience and pertaining to receiving

*
    See Millennial or Eternal Fire, 808.
†
    See “All Israel” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 414                                                                                                 The Outer Darkness
the misthological inheritance appear to be the issues at stake for these Jews rather than being thrown into an eternal
fire. The typology is suggestive that this picture is dealing with misthological exclusion from the Promised Land
itself rather than confinement in a subterranean imprisonment. The Promised Land is the land of Canaan, not the
entire planet.* Thus, being excluded from the Promised Land is not necessarily the same thing as being excluded
from the millennial kingdom since the latter will encompass the entire planet. Consequently, Constable’s remarks
may be a little closer to the mark:

            As the Lord had judged the fathers in the wilderness long ago, so He would judge the
       children of His people. He would discipline them to sanctify them (cf. Jer. 33:13). It was customary
       for shepherds to count their sheep as they passed under their staff that they held over the doorway of
       the sheepfold….
            The Lord would also bring His people under obligation to keep the terms of a covenant. This is
       evidently a reference to the New Covenant (cf. 36:25-38; Jer. 31:31-34). He would weed out the
       rebels and transgressors from among them and bring them out of the countries where they
       lived but would not bring them into the Promised Land. This probably refers to the Jews who will
       die during the Tribulation period (cf. Zech. 13:8; Rev. 12:15-17) and or when the Lord returns to the
       earth (cf. Matt. 25:31-46).710

       Those unfaithful Jewish believers who survive the tribulation will be allowed into the millennial kingdom
but excluded from the Promised Land itself within the kingdom. While entrance into the kingdom is free, this land
of promise within the kingdom is limited to those who meet the qualifications necessary to reside there. This would
indeed correspond very well with the Marrowistic understanding of the outer darkness regarding these Jewish
outcasts presented by Matthew earlier in his gospel (Mt 8:11-12).† To his credit, in his chart A Survey of the
Judgments, Betz lists seven judgments and places four of them as occurring at this point in time (i.e., after the
tribulation and before the millennium).711 The first of these post-tribulational judgments (the judgment of the beast
and false prophet in Rev 19:11-20) is not included in the chart below since that judgment does not entail the
separation of one group from another. Betz’s remaining intervening judgments are included with amendment and
addition:

        The evidence concerning this time frame leads one to anticipate two types of separations dealing with two
basic groups of people—Jews and Gentiles. (1) First, if there are any lost Jews who are alive at the end of the
tribulation, the Lord will separate these lost Jewish goats from the saved Jewish sheep who are alive at the end of
the tribulation. Betz affirms that this is indeed the case in his chart, and I will entertain the possibility as well.
(2) Second, the Lord misthologically will separate the good sheep from the black sheep, in regard to the living
Jewish believers. That is, Jewish believers who live until the end of the tribulation will be judged as to whether
they qualify to inherit the kingdom which they will be entering. Being morally pure in terms of not having taken

†
  See Part 1. Chapter 18. Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13), 429
‡
  See Illustration 130. Cold Love of Believers, 366.
