the mark of the beast is not enough to qualify as a kingdom ruler. (3) Third, the Lord likewise will misthologically
separate the resurrected good Jewish sheep from the black Jewish sheep.† This resurrection, followed by
separation, deals exclusively with Jewish believers from both the OT and tribulational time periods. The lost are
not resurrected until a thousand years later, so they are not in view.
        After dealing with the Jews, the Lord will then repeat this process in dealing with the Gentiles. That is, just
as before, the symmetry will again be that the soteriological separation of sheep from goats will be followed by
misthological separation of good sheep from black sheep. (1) First, the Lord will separate the lost Gentile goats
from the saved Gentile sheep. This separation of the Gentile nations will be in accordance with how they
responded to the gospel of grace—the soteriological component of the kingdom message which had been
proclaimed by the Lord’s Jewish brethren during the tribulation.‡ Those Gentiles who believe in the Jewish
Messiah for eternal life will be found to have that life and therefore allowed into the millennial kingdom. (2) Next,
the Lord misthologically will separate the good Gentile sheep who have lived through the tribulation from the
black Gentile sheep who lived through it. This will be in regard to Gentile believers and their response to the
gospel of the kingdom preached by the Jewish evangelists: “He who endures to the end will be saved” (Mt 24:13-
14).§ Those Gentiles who responded favorably to this message and to its Jewish messengers will be saved from
exclusion from the Promised Land and be allowed to inherit the kingdom. Those Gentile believers who are found
to be unfaithful will merely enter the millennial kingdom in non-glorified bodies rather than inherit the kingdom.
They and their children and the children of the lost will repopulate the planet, and these descendents will comprise
the nations that rebel at the end of the millennium.** (3) That the present Matthean passage only deals with the
good sheep does not mean that other details, such as the existence of black sheep, cannot be inferred. For example,
it is necessary to deduce, among other things, that there will be a resurrection of faithful Gentile believers so that
they can receive their promised inheritance. So it may be inferred that there will also be a resurrection of all
Gentile believers from both the OT and tribulational eras. As above, this resurrection, followed by separation, deals
exclusively with Gentile believers from both the OT and tribulational time periods. The lost are not resurrected
until a thousand years later, so they are not in view.

                                                         Inheritance
       The sheep inherit the kingdom in 25:34, which is an implicit affirmation of their identity as being the
faithful elect rather than elect in general.†† Many are called but few achieve post-temporal election.‡‡ Matthew
already has made it clear in his gospel that this inheritance is a reward for faithful believers. In Mt 5:5 he has
recorded that inheriting the earth is a reward for meekness. In the account of the rich ruler, he made it clear that
inheriting eternal life (cf. Mt 25:34,46) requires sacrifice (Mt 19:16,21,28-29). Granted, Calvinists may respond
that what you are is inevitably reflected in what you do. If you are a sheep, then you will not act like a goat. But of
course, there are some major problems with such a point of view.
       If the proveitistic contention actually were true that what you are is inevitably proven by what you do, then
good works are inevitable criteria which determine whether you are saved. According to Calvinism, you cannot be
a sheep without having good works, so you cannot be saved without having good works. To say that sheep in this
passage necessarily must have these evidences is to make such evidences a necessity that one must have in order to
be considered a sheep at the judgment and thus escape hell. In Calvinism salvation from eternal damnation
consequently is made contingent on your behavior as a sheep. The text says, “Come, you who are blessed of My
Father, inherit the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world. For I was hungry, and you gave
Me something to eat.” The explanatory for (gar) introducing verse 35 tells why the sheep are allowed to inherit the
kingdom in verse 34. Giving food is not the result of inheriting the kingdom; rather, it is the requirement for
inheriting it. And if it is assumed that inheriting the kingdom is synonymous with entering the kingdom, as

Calvinists claim, then giving food is a requirement for entering heaven. Viewing the works as inevitable makes
works a necessary requirement for salvation in this parable.*
       The second major problem with such a view is that it ignores the context. Jesus, in the foregoing parables,
has made it quite clear that some servants do not behave as servants should. Those servants and these sheep
represent believers. Thus, on the basis of the antecedent parables, we are to understand that some sheep do not
behave as sheep should—as in the case of the servants representing the sheep in the previous parables. All
believers do not act the way they should (some are quite foolish), as Jesus has just pointed out in the parable about
the foolish virgins, which is dealing with the same time period.
       As Kendall points out, the parables of the talents and virgins deal with believers saved through fire
(1Cor 3:15), so Jesus does not need to deal with such believers here. Jesus already has pictured unfaithful believers
in the darkness outside in both those parables. Moreover, the contrast in each of the Olivet parables is between the
rewarded and unrewarded, whether they are lost or saved is a secondary concern at best. Thus, this last parable
“gives not a distinction merely between the saved and the lost—it gives a distinction between the saved who have a
reward and the lost [who consequently do not have a reward].” “The king addresses not those who are saved [and
have no reward] but those who are saved and have an inheritance.”713 Jesus has no need to address unfaithful
believers in this parable because He uses the lost to paint the backdrop comprising those who are not rewarded.

                                                      Two Categories
        The question ingrained in the minds of most people, however, is why only two categories of people are
mentioned in this parable, not three. But we may ask, “Why not?” In the three preceding Olivet parables, only two
categories of people are mentioned in each parable. Why should the fourth parable be required to mention three
groups? In each of the three preceding parables, Jesus contrasted two groups of people, not three. He does so here
as well. Jesus already has dealt with unfaithful believers in the three preceding parables. Why should He be
required to do so again? Why must He use multiple groups to picture the unrewarded? He does not discuss goats
who worship the antichrist or who take the mark of the antichrist. Nevertheless, we can be certain that such goats
exist even though they are not mentioned. Likewise, mentioning carnal believers is unnecessary since He already
has indicated their presence in the preceding parables.
        In the context, Jesus has indicated that not only do unfaithful believers (sheep) exist, but they are not
excluded until later. In Mt 25:10-11, we saw that the foolish believers were excluded later (i.e., after the feast
already had started): “Those who were ready went in with him to the wedding feast; and the door was shut. And
later the other virgins also came.” The foolish virgins were excluded from the feast after it already had started, and
after those who were ready for it already had entered. We saw the same thing in Mt 22:11-12, where the king’s
friend was excluded from the feast after it already had started. The king first dealt with those who did not respond
to his invitation to come before he dealt with those who did respond to his invitation to come.
        In these parables, unfaithful believers are not dealt with until unbelievers are dealt with. The parable of the
sheep and goats deals with unbelievers. Since unfaithful believers are not dealt with at the same time as
unbelievers, why mention them at this time? The intent of these parables has been to contrast misthologically, not
to compare soteriologically. Thus, it is consistent to expect Jesus to contrast extremes and not compare good goats
with bad sheep. This contrast of extremes already has been charted and discussed in the antithetical interpretation
section.† One may also consult the earlier diagram concerning black sheep.‡ Further, the OT counterpart in
Dan 12:1-3 describes the eternal shame of these black sheep.§ Black sheep and white sheep both share the same
regenerate nature—they are both sheep. However, the intent of this Matthean comparison between the sheep and
goats is to contrast the nature, actions, and destiny of two groups that are ontologically distinct. A sheep is not a
goat. The intent is not to deny that there are three groups but to contrast the nature and actions of those whose
actions manifest their true nature. That there are those within both groups who mask their true nature is not dealt
with in this particular comparison.
        In contrasting the extremes, the Scripture does not necessarily deny the in-betweens. Potential middle
ground exists when classifying groups of people. Some passages, like the parable of the sower and Paul’s


*
  For a book dedicated to disproving proveitism as it relates to the parable of the sheep and goats, see Woolly Wolves and Woolless
Sheep. This book defends FG soteriology in relation to this parable. For a focus more on misthology, see my book Sheep and Goats.
That advanced discussion evaluates four misthological interpretations of this parable that are compatible with unconditional security.

  See Illustration 48. Antithetical Contrast of Polar Opposites, 106.
‡
  See Illustration 63. Sheep or Goat, 141.

  See Daniel 12:1-3, 533.
Chapter 16. Sheep & Goats (Mt 25:31-46)                                                                         Page 417
                                                                                       *
discussion in 1Cor 2:14-3:3, contrasts all three groups: lost, carnal, and spiritual. However, other passages only
contrast two groups. Some passages contrast spiritual Christians with carnal Christians. Some of those passages do
not even mention lost people, but that does not mean that lost people do not exist! We do not jump to the
conclusion that there are no lost people even though the three previous parables in the Mt. Olivet Discourse
contrast the judgment of only two groups: faithful and unfaithful believers. Likewise, this last parable of the sheep
and goats only contrasts two groups. Carnal Christians are not mentioned, but that does not mean they do not exist.
        Moreover, proportionally, very few unfaithful believers will probably survive until the end of the tribulation.
Therefore, in the particular situation being described and contrasted in this parable regarding Gentile survivors, it is
reasonable not to bother mentioning the few exceptions since relatively all the believers who survive until the end
of the tribulation will be faithful. This is particularly true since in the preceding parable (that of the virgins) it was
found that what unfaithful believers who do exist at the end of the tribulation will be dealt with after the feast
starts; at least that is when they experience the result of their judgment. That parable places the Jewish believers
who survive the tribulation under a microscope.† This parable of the sheep and goats, in contrast, looks at the
Gentile situation (at the end of the tribulation) through a telescope, and in providing this panoramic sweep of the
eschatological landscape, it does not focus on the miniscule number of unfaithful believers who survive.
        In this parable of the sheep and goats, Jesus zooms out so that He can include unbelievers in the picture. In
doing so, details regarding unfaithful believers are lost. Conversely, in the parable of the virgins, the Lord zooms in
so that the contrast between unfaithful and faithful Jewish believers is evident (so that the OT truth pertaining to
such believers might become apparent). Had He zoomed out in picturing the Jewish survivors in contrast to the
Gentile persecutors, then He would have painted the same picture as Paul and the OT when looking at this
landscape from a bird’s eye view, which is that of all Israel being saved (Rom 11:26).‡
        For someone like Zeller to take this phenomenon (in which only two opposing groups are mentioned in this
passage) as proof that faith must necessarily express itself in good works in order to save one from hell is to do a
grave injustice to the broader context of the Mt. Olivet Discourse, which contrasts faithful and unfaithful believers.
Judgment is always based on works; its preceding separation is based on faith. Zeller fails to note the difference
and inadvertently teaches a false gospel of salvation by works as a result. 714 It is foolish to expect the same results
when using a telescope as opposed to a microscope. A telescopic view of Gentile survivors is not going to give the
same picture as a microscopic view of Jewish believers.
                                             Illustration 142. Two Different Scopes




        In the telescopic view on the left, the original image is at the bottom. It is then seen through a fish-eye lens
using 400% magnification. In the microscopic view on the right, the original image is at the bottom, but is so small
that it only appears to be the size of a dot. But when seen through the fish-eye lens using 1000% magnification, it
appears that the black sheep is larger than the white sheep. Yet in reality that is not the case. In the original image,
the two sheep are the same size. The distortion comes from the nature of the lens.

*
  See Illustration 234. Misthological Range of Fruitfulness, 692.
†
  See Mark of the Beast, 362.
‡
  See “All Israel” in Salvation: A Categorical Analysis.
Page 418                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                           Illustration 143. All White Sheep




        In the previous Olivet parable dealing with believers who survive the tribulation (i.e., the parable of the
virgins), the microscopic focus was on the black sheep. In the present Olivet parable dealing with believers who
survive the tribulation, the telescopic focus is on the contrast between believers and unbelievers. Many people
assume that since the latter parable pictures all sheep as being saved that there are no black sheep. However, if one
were to read the present parable through the lens of the previous context, then one would be able to read between
the lines and see that the present parable is only describing all white sheep. As in the above illustration, the original
text, as understood in context, is drawn to scale in comparison to the same text as seen through the fish-eye lens of
the magnifying glass. This is not reading into the text something that is not there, but reading from the text what is
implicitly placed there by the context.

                                                    Conclusion
       The parable of the sheep and goats is a parable that teaches that both unbelievers and believers are judged on
the basis of works, not on the basis of faith. Separation precedes judgment. Simple faith is the basis for the
separation, not for the judgment. Two related, yet distinct, groups of questions may be asked in conclusion. First,
which group will your faith put you in when the rapture occurs? Those taken or those left? If your faith is in Christ
alone, then you will be taken at the Bema rapture.715 Second, after the Bema rapture, in which group will your
faithfulness put you? Will you be in the group that inherits the kingdom or in the group that merely enters the
kingdom? How we do at the separation does not guarantee how well we will do at the judgment. The proper
interpretation of this parable requires that we understand that these good sheep are faithful believers who are being
ushered forthwith into their millennial inheritance of the kingdom on the basis of their works. Their inheritance is a
misthological concept, not a soteriological one. Not all believers are faithful. But that is the subject matter of other
parables, not this one.

Page 420   The Outer Darkness
                                        Chapter 17.
                         Friend in the Outer Darkness (Mt 22:1-14)
                                                  Introduction
        The primary passage concerning the outer darkness (which is the parable of the talents) has now been
examined within its biblical context (that of the Mount Olivet Discourse) in the previous section. There are two
remaining occasions in which Matthew records this expression: the outer darkness. This chapter and the next one
will be devoted respectively to each of these occurrences. In conjunction with the belief that progressive revelation
generally may be expected to provide increasing clarity as it proceeds, the passages pertaining to the outer darkness
will be examined in reverse order in regard to their biblical sequence. Doing so has allowed the first impressions
drawn in this book concerning the outer darkness to be derived from what reasonably may be supposed to be the
clearest revelation concerning the outer darkness, which is the last parable to deal with it. Now the discussion
moves to the parable which may be reasonably presumed to provide the next clearest picture.
        These parables remind the author of a time when his oldest son, Jeremy, was a one-year-old and started
crawling up on the coffee table in the living room. The problem was that whenever Jeremy climbed up on the table,
he would fall off backwards and land on his head. Thankfully, the impact was softened by the carpeted floor;
nevertheless, it was a frightful experience for his parents. His mother, Dianne, tried spanking him to teach him
better. It did no good. He was persistent, or shall we say, stubborn. As a result, she decided to try something new.
Whenever he climbed up on the coffee table, she would take him off the table and put him in the playpen. Weeping
and gnashing of teeth promptly would follow, since Jeremy was quite aware that he had forfeited his rights to roam
the house freely. He was now limited to one corner of the house. Not only had he lost his freedom within the
house, he had also lost his right to toddle over to his parents whenever he wanted and get a hug and a kiss. To be
sure, he would still get an occasional kiss on the cheek or a pat on the head, but not nearly as many kisses while in
the playpen, and the hugs practically were forfeited. You cannot easily embrace a child in the playpen.
        Jeremy’s experience well demonstrates the spiritual truth being presented. Some Christians persist in
unfaithfulness. They do wrong, and God spanks them (disciplines them in this life), just as He promised to do in
Heb 12:6. Yet they persist in unfaithfulness over and over again in spite of God’s discipline. What is a parent to
do? What will God do? He will put such a child in the playpen (i.e., in restriction) when they reach heaven. Their
spiritual immaturity will be obvious to all. They will weep and gnash their teeth in heaven as they see God’s other
children allowed full rights of His house, while they are restricted to one corner of it.
        In the parable of the talents in Mt 25:14-30, we saw that some Christians are cast into the outer darkness.
They have the same identical relationship with God as do the rest of His children but not the same fellowship. In its
twin passage (the parable of the minas in Lk 19:1-27), eternal security was implicitly affirmed by the Lord. The
worthless servant lost his mina, not his life. The proper deduction is that unfaithful servants are thrown into the
outer darkness, not slain like God’s enemies. Unfaithful believers lose their freedom, not their lives. They have
eternal life which cannot be forfeited.
        As Christians (and therefore as God’s children) we should desire to have freedom of access within heaven,
not only to all of His house but also to His loving arms. As His children, we will want more than an occasional
kiss; we will want lots of kisses and hugs. Some Christians may not care much about such matters now, but we
may be assured that they will then. The passage of Scripture we are examining now will give further details about
the outer darkness and how to stay out of it. The outer darkness is not a place for the lost. As is seen in a number of
the details within the parable, the outer darkness is a place for believers—if they are unfaithful. As has been the
practice in the previous parables, these details will be examined and then allowed to speak for themselves.

                                                        Text
       1And Jesus answered and spoke to them again in parables, saying, 2“The kingdom of heaven may be
       compared to a king, who gave a wedding feast for his son. 3And he sent out his slaves to call those
       who had been invited to the wedding feast, and they were unwilling to come. 4Again he sent out other
       slaves saying, ‘Tell those who have been invited, “Behold, I have prepared my dinner; my oxen and
       my fattened livestock are all butchered and everything is ready; come to the wedding feast.”’ 5But
        they paid no attention and went their way, one to his own farm, another to his business, 6and the
       rest seized his slaves and mistreated them and killed them. 7But the king was enraged and sent his
       armies, and destroyed those murderers, and set their city on fire. 8Then he said to his slaves, ‘The
       wedding is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy. 9Go therefore to the main highways,
       and as many as you find there, invite to the wedding feast.’ 10And those slaves went out into the
Page 422                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       streets, and gathered together all they found, both evil and good; and the wedding hall was filled
       with dinner guests. 11But when the king came in to look over the dinner guests, he saw there a man
       not dressed in wedding clothes, 12and he said to him, ‘Friend, how did you come in here without
       wedding clothes?’ And he was speechless. 13Then the king said to the servants, ‘Bind him hand and
       foot, and cast him [out] into the outer darkness; in that place there shall be weeping and gnashing of
       teeth.’ 14For many are called, but few are chosen.” (Mt 22:1-14)

                                                Feast ≠ Kingdom
       The first detail to be considered is the feast itself. One of the major reasons so many people who believe in
eternal security have trouble believing that this parable is talking about the exclusion of a believer from the feast is
because they misunderstand what the feast represents. Does the feast represent the kingdom of heaven? If so, it
would appear that Jesus is saying that an unfaithful believer can be cast out of heaven (Mt 22:13). However, the
parable itself makes it clear enough that the feast is not to be equated with the kingdom of heaven but with only a
certain aspect of it. In this parable Jesus discusses a present aspect of the kingdom (its rejection and acceptance)
and a future aspect of the kingdom (participation in the feast).
       Naturally, the feast of this parable is not to be understood as this king’s kingdom. This is a parable about a
king who had a feast in the wedding hall of his palace that was in his kingdom. The feast was not his kingdom but
an experience within his kingdom. The feast represents a future aspect of the kingdom, but not the kingdom itself.
That the man was thrown out of the feast does not in and of itself prove that he was thrown out of the kingdom. His
being barred from a future experience in heaven does not necessarily prove that he was barred from heaven itself.
                                    Illustration 144. Unworthy Guest (Mt 22:1-14)




                                 Two Pairs of Symmetrical Responses
        Second, four groups in the parable are represented by the four responses. Some respond indifferently
(Mt 22:5; they pay no attention). Some respond violently to the gospel message (Mt 22:6-7; they kill and are
killed). The first two groups represent two types of negative responses to the gospel, that is, two types of
unbelievers (noncomers). Although the destruction of the second group is the one specifically mentioned, the
destruction of the first group is implied as well. They both perish in the flames as their city is burned. Since they
Chapter 17. Friend in the Outer Darkness (Mt 22:1-14)                                                                          Page 423
perish and are thus eternally separated from the king and his kingdom, their fate presumably represents those in the
Lake of Fire. I agree with those who identify the burning of the city as being Jesus’ first prophecy of the
destruction of Jerusalem in A.D. 70. This passage of Scripture is dealing with the present time period. Even so,
although the destruction of the city prophetically predicts the temporal destruction of Jerusalem, it also
typologically may represent the eternal destruction of these lost rebels as well.
        The next two groups represent two types of positive responses to the gospel, that is, two types of believers
(comers). Some believers respond with deep commitment to the gospel of the kingdom and prepare for the
kingdom (Mt 22:10). Other believers respond to the gospel of the kingdom with no commitment and just show up
in heaven without preparing for it (Mt 22:11). They have heard that the only requirement to enter the kingdom is
that they be born again through a simple response of faith and that is as far as their response goes. They come to
Jesus (the king of the kingdom) in a simple response of faith, not a life of faith.
        In response to the Calvinistic assumption that person who just shows up at the feast is merely a superficial
believer, it may be acknowledged that his faith is shallow; nevertheless, it is genuine. He responded to the
invitation to come just as genuinely as the others who came. According to the book of Revelation, being a comer
does not make one an overcomer. Some comers will be subcomers. In this present parable a symmetrical response
is made to the gospel of the kingdom. Some unbelievers respond indifferently while other unbelievers respond
intensely. Likewise, some believers respond indifferently while other believers respond intensely.

                                   Time of Rejection is After the Feast Starts
       Third, some detractors argue that the man’s presence at the feast does not show that he reached heaven since
the feast does not represent heaven. Granted, the feast does not represent heaven; it represents a particular aspect of
the kingdom. Still, it is important to note the time period of the kingdom being referred to—the future. The gospel
presently is being accepted and rejected. However, the parable starts off with the present and moves to the future.
The wedding feast takes place on earth after the separation of the saved from the lost, which is depicted by
separation of the sheep from the goats and the wheat from the tares. Due to the importance of this temporal point, it
is recommended that the illustration concerning the sequence of judgments pertaining to the sheep and goats be
kept firmly in mind.* This man is excluded after the second judgment in that illustration. Since this second
judgment (i.e., of the sheep and goats) will prevent those who have rejected the gospel from entering the future
kingdom, and since this man is cast out after the feast starts, he must have been saved because he is found at the
wedding feast in the millennial kingdom after the separation of the sheep and the goats. In other words, he must be
one of those bad sheep† referred to in that discussion. If he were not a sheep, he would not have been allowed into
the feast initially. If he were not a bad sheep, he would not have been expelled from the feast subsequently.
       Those who have rejected the gospel are not allowed entrance into heaven nor into the millennial kingdom on
earth. That this man is present at the feast must mean that he is allowed into the millennial kingdom and that he is a
genuine believer. In reply, Keathley counters: “If you go to Matt 22 and make a big deal about the fact that the guy
without wedding clothes made it into the banquet and was therefore saved, then those that argue that the virgins are
saved (to be consistent with their interpretation of Matt 22) have to reconcile the fact that here they didn’t get in.”
       In response, it should be carefully observed: Both this man and the five foolish virgins were excluded
from the wedding feast after it already had started! Keathley’s objection is invalid because both groups are
rejected after the dinner starts.‡ The dining commences before the casting is executed. This was also implicitly

*

†
  Bad sheep is being used broadly here to refer to believers who do not behave as they should (regardless of the particular time period
involved). Bad sheep of the church age as well as bad sheep of the tribulational period will be expelled/excluded from the feast after
the judgment of the sheep and goats and after the feast already has started. The friend thrown into the outer darkness represents a bad
sheep from the church age. Nevertheless, let it be pointed out for the sake of those who do not share the author’s perspective
concerning the time period involved that, even if this friend were regarded to be a Jew living during the tribulation, this Jew still
would picture a believer. Unfaithful tribulational Jewish believers will need to be separated from faithful tribulational Jewish
believers. (This statement is true even if no unfaithful Jewish believers survive the tribulation. They would still need to be resurrected
and judged before the feast starts.) Thus, in the broad sense, these unfaithful tribulational Jewish believers may be regarded as bad
sheep. These bad sheep will be thrown into the outer darkness. Even those interpreters who insist on regarding these servants as Jews
living during the tribulational period still must contend with the fact that redeemed Jews of that period would be the most natural
reference. When the Jewish people are pictured as God’s servants, they are pictured as His redeemed servants. If (contrary to the
evidence but in harmony with the theological perception of many dispensationalists) the intent of this parable is to portray how God
will deal with His Jewish servants, then redeemed Jewish servants are being depicted. See Israel My Redeemed Servant, 376.

Gathered Out ≠ Misthologically Cast Out, 435.
Page 424                                                                                                        The Outer Darkness
anticipated by Matthew’s first parable concerning the outer darkness where the reclining at table preceded the
casting from the table.* In both parables, the point is that those who are not adequately prepared are rejected after
the millennial celebration already has started. They are thus in the millennial kingdom. The difference between the
two parables is that in one parable the unfaithful group, represented by the poorly dressed wedding guest, depicts
unfaithful believers of the church age who are expelled.† The other parable uses foolish virgins, on the other hand,
to picture unfaithful believers of the tribulational period who are excluded. Both groups of unfaithful believers are
in the darkness outside. The foolish virgins represent bad sheep during the tribulation. The foolish friend represents
bad sheep during the current church age.

                              Place of Rejection is in the Millennial Kingdom
       Fourth, even if it were difficult to follow the time table, then a closer look at the place would still confirm
the same conclusion. Some may think that the marriage supper takes place in heaven after the JSC. Even if this
were correct, the man must be in heaven. He must have been raptured and passed through the JSC to be at that
supper in heaven. In short, the man must be a believer because he is at the feast in heaven. On the other hand,
others assert correctly that the wedding supper takes place on earth after the separation of the saved from the lost,
which is pictured by the separation of the sheep from the goats and the wheat from the tares. This judgment will
prevent those who have rejected the gospel from entering the future form of the kingdom. Thus, this man must
have been saved since he is found at the wedding feast in the millennial kingdom after the separation of the sheep
from the goats. The separation of the sheep and the goats is indicated by the destruction of those who refused to
come.‡ Death separated those who did not come to the feast from those who did come. Such separation of the lost
from the saved (whether it be temporal, typological, or eschatological) predates the judgment of the saved.

                                                     Palace ≠ Kingdom
        Fifth, the imagery of the parable itself suggests that the casting out refers to the king’s palace, not his
kingdom. It cannot be the millennial kingdom from which he is cast because the Great White Throne judgment
does not occur until after the feast ends, and he is ejected before the feast ends. It cannot be heaven from which he
is cast because the separation of the sheep and the goats occurs before the feast starts, and this man is rejected after
the feast starts. Correspondingly, the casting into refers to the darkness outside the palace rather than outside the
kingdom. That the darkness outside is not necessarily a literal darkness is evident from the fact that this is a parable
using metaphors. That it is not necessarily hell should be evident in that an earthly king cannot throw anyone into
hell. Further, there is no association of fire with the outer darkness.

                                       Garment = Imparted Righteousness
        Sixth, what is the wedding garment? If it is the imputed righteousness of Jesus, then it is possible to enter
the kingdom without it—if the feast at which he is present represents the kingdom, as is commonly supposed. It
would be much better to presume that (1) since it was evidently the man’s responsibility to make himself ready and
(2) since, as noted by Sapaugh, this (as well as the total imagery) corresponds very well with “the only other
eschatological wedding celebration in the NT where the clothing worn by the participants is mentioned” (Rev 19:7-
9), the clothing in both cases is to be identified as the practical righteousness of the saints. Sapaugh thus concludes:
“The wedding clothes of Matt 22:11 correspond to the clothes worn by the bride at the wedding of the Lamb in
Rev 19:8.”716 “The fine linen is the righteous acts of the saints” (Rev 19:8). Only those saints who overcome will
be considered worthy of this clothing (Rev 3:4-5). As Sapaugh further points out, Jeremias believes “that the
provision of appropriate clothing for the guests of the banquet by the king was not the custom of the time.”717 The
interpreters of the early church period understood the wedding garments as referring to practical righteousness.718
Appropriate clothing was the man’s responsibility, not the king’s responsibility, as even many contemporary

city prophetically predicts the temporal destruction of Jerusalem and typologically represents the eternal destruction of these lost
rebels as well. One might even allow that the burning also anticipates the Bema fire for those believers who rebel against the Lord.

                                        *
commentators would acknowledge. Just as the oil in the parable of the virgins was not something provided by the
bridegroom, so the clothing was not something provided by the king. The participants were responsible for buying
the oil or clothing that they needed.
        Pagenkemper admits that commentators are divided as to whether the wedding garment was provided by the
host. He seems to think that if they were provided, then that clinches his argument that the passage is dealing with
soteriological issues: “The implication of these verses is that the man feels he should be in the kingdom and
allowed to enjoy the banquet meal prepared for all who were invited and responded. Yet his lack of preparation
suggests that his ‘reality’ is out of accord with his profession to the right of entrance.”719
        Even if Pagenkemper’s proveitistic assessment of the man’s perspective is perceptive, jumping to the
conclusion that the man was merely a professing believer rather than a genuine believer is not prescriptive.† This
parabolic friend just as easily could represent a believer who felt that rewards were not worth the effort and that all
believers would be treated basically the same in heaven regardless of whether they dressed themselves in practical
righteousness. After reaching heaven (i.e., after the feast starts), he finds out that he is gravely mistaken. He should
have dressed himself in practical righteousness. Although practical righteousness and sanctification are provided to
the believer (i.e., made possible by the power of the Holy Spirit), this provision does not guarantee that all
believers will take advantage of the proffered opportunity. Even if the garments are provided, it still does not prove
that the garments refer to imputational righteousness. They may refer to imparted righteousness instead. Believers
are warned and exhorted to clothe themselves with Christ and Christian virtues (Rom 13:14; Eph 6:11,14; Col
3:12,14; 1Thess 5:8; 1Pet 5:5; Rev 3:4,17-18).720 Although imparted righteousness is available to all believers, it
does not necessarily follow that all believers will dress themselves in the practical expression of their faith.
        Whether the garment is provided by the host is a detail that Jesus did not consider decisive in the
understanding of the parable, as is evidenced by the fact that He did not supply that detail. Those who try to make
something decisive out of that detail certainly would seem to be building their case upon a matter that the parable
considers to be irrelevant. Amusingly, Keathley (who decries the use of details to interpret parables) appeals to this
missing detail in support of his own interpretation of the parable.‡ Amazingly, Keathley criticizes Hodges’
misthological interpretation by supplying his own speculative details:

       Hodges says, providing wedding garments for guests “seems not to have been the custom in those
       days.” But, unless Gower, who has no axe to grind, is just plain wrong, wedding clothes were often
       provided by wealthy hosts….Therefore, the wedding clothes provided by the host symbolize the
       righteousness of Christ provided by God for entrance to heaven—as opposed to our garments / merit
       which are not good enough to get us into heaven / banquet.721

        Keathley implies that Hodges’ statement is based on an “axe to grind.” However, there are those who, in
contrast to Hodges, take a soteriological interpretation of the passage but who nonetheless believe that the
garments were not provided. Take France for instance: “Each guest was responsible for his own clothing.
Augustine’s theologically-motivated suggestion that the host provided special garments is supported by no relevant
evidence.”722 France shares Keathley’s soteriological interpretation but rejects the notion that the garments were
provided. Moreover, France believes that Augustine was the one who had an axe to grind. Perhaps Keathley is
grinding his own axe as well since he evidently thinks that the soteriological interpretation is dependent upon the
garments being provided. However, the misthological interpretation has no need for any such axe, since it is not
dependent upon who provides the garments. It would seem rather precarious for Keathley to build his
soteriological rebuttal on a missing detail, and perhaps attribute his own axe-grinding motives to another, when
misthologists are quite happy to interpret the parable on the basis of the details that actually are provided.
Misthologists are free to agree with France that the garment refers to practical righteous, but misthologists insist
that this holy life style is necessary for rewards in heaven rather than for entrance into heaven.
        Axe or not, Keathley overstates his case concerning this garment passage when he claims, “No other
Scripture teaches that any member of the Church won’t take part in the marriage feast.”723 Not only is this
argument weak, it is in error. Since the banquet of Rev 19:7-9 is the only other passage in the NT that would
qualify as an explicit cross-reference that deals with the preparation of the garments in relation to the

quickly learn that they were in error. The misthological city and feast are reserved for those believers who meet the misthological
requirements. Mistaken perceptions about having a right to enter do not prove that soteriological issues are at stake.

eschatological wedding, Keathley’s argument could almost be considered an argument from silence at best.
Nevertheless, I will contend that such is not the case. Scripture is not silent on the matter. Rather, Keathley has
completely misunderstood the banquet imagery in the broader biblical context and has failed to hear what the
Scripture has to say on the issue.* A more developed form of the objection that Keathley is trying to pose would be
to claim that since all believers are members of the Bride no believer will be excluded from the feast. Others do in
fact make this objection to the mistholic position. Even then, as will be shown in a subsequent chapter, this
argument is, in fact, very counterproductive to the point such opponents are seeking to make to misthology.†

                             Misthological Worthiness = Misthological Glory
        Seventh, the lost do not have the potential of being worthy in Mt 22:8.‡ Two things are required to be
worthy: (1) responding to the invitation to come and (2) dressing properly (i.e., coming and overcoming). These
joint responses represent justification and sanctification. Matthew already has presented Jesus’ earlier teaching
concerning worthiness, which Jesus again mentions in Mt 22:8. This earlier teaching is well known: “7He who
loves father or mother more than Me is not worthy of Me; and he who loves son or daughter more than Me is not
worthy of Me. And he who does not take his cross and follow after Me is not worthy of Me” (Mt 10:37-38).
        Worthiness is based on what you love and the way you live; it is based on works. According to Rev 3:4-5,
you have to be more than a mere comer (believer) in order to be worthy; you must also be an overcomer. Worthless
believers will not make worthy rulers: “But you have a few people in Sardis who have not soiled their garments;
and they will walk with Me in white; for they are worthy. He who overcomes shall thus be clothed in white
garments” (Rev 3:4-5).
        Worthiness is based on the way you walk—the way you live. Those who already have responded to the
invitation to come (i.e., to believe) are urged by Paul to “walk in a manner worthy of the calling with which you
have been called” (Eph 4:1). Likewise, Paul urges the Thessalonian believers to “walk in a manner worthy of the
God who calls you into His own kingdom and glory” (1Thess 2:11-12). The way you walk as a believer (i.e., your
works) will determine if you are worthy of the Lord’s millennial glory—the glory of ruling in His millennial
kingdom. Paul is also insistent in his follow-up correspondence with the Thessalonians that your worthiness (as
believers) is based on the way you live.

       5This [perseverance when persecuted] is a plain indication of God’s righteous judgment so that you
       may be considered worthy of the kingdom of God, for which indeed you are suffering.…11To this
       end also we pray for you always that our God may count you worthy of your calling, and fulfill
       every desire for goodness and the work of faith with power…14And it was for this He called you
       through our gospel, that you may gain the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ. (2Thess 1:5,11; 2:14)

       In 2Thess 1:5, Paul is thus teaching that whether believers are considered worthy of His kingdom is
determined by whether they endure suffering. In 2Thess 1:11 Paul prays, not guarantees, that believers will be
counted worthy of their calling when the day of glory comes. In 2Thess 2:14 Paul says that the purpose for which
believers were called is to gain, that is, merit the glory of the Lord Jesus.§

                                                    Comer = Believer
       Eighth, who is called in Mt 22:14? Everyone, whether lost or saved, is called to the marriage feast. The lost
are represented as those who refuse to come. The invitation to come that was given by the resurrected Christ in
Rev 22:17 was often given by the Lord while He was on earth, as the Gospel of John attests. But many refused to
come to Jesus (i.e., believe in Jesus). Nonbelievers are noncomers. By refusing to come, they forfeit a place in the
kingdom. These parabolic city dwellers are killed and thus eternally separated from the king and his kingdom.
They are removed from the present form of the kingdom before its future form starts. The future form of the
kingdom is indicated by the commencement of the feast. Correspondingly, those who respond to the invitation to
come are believers who arrive in the future eschatological form of the kingdom during the feast. This man came to
the feast and thus represents a comer, a believer. Yet some of those who come to faith in Christ forfeit a place at
the banquet. They are called (invited) but not chosen.

*
  See Chapter 25. The Bride. For concise summation, see concluding part of that chapter beginning with Eph 5:28-33,587.

  See Chapter 25, 565.

  Review discussion of Misthological Worthiness, 73.

Chapter 17. Friend in the Outer Darkness (Mt 22:1-14)                                                                         Page 427
                                        Chosen = Misthologically Prepared
       Ninth, the chosen are those who, in addition to responding to the invitation to come (believe), also prepare
for the feast. As Sapaugh says, “The ones properly clothed are chosen to be at the banquet.”724 Huber well
summarizes that this does not teach a “special judgment after the millennium starts but simply the execution of the
Bema judgment already given.”725 A temporal call does not guarantee post-temporal election.
       The call/invitation is issued throughout the day to come to the feast. But the poorly dressed man is not
chosen to participate, even though he had been invited/called. The election/choosing (eklektos) is not only
distinguished from the call (kletos)—it follows the call. As has been demonstrated previously, this post-temporal
election is misthological, not soteriological.* Eklektos represents a misthological out-selection of those who had
positively responded to the soteriological invitation.

                                                           Speechless
       Tenth, in a discussion of this passage by Hodges and Wilkin, available at the GES web site, Wilkin states
that the fact that this man is speechless (phimoo) jumps out in contrast to the objections made by the lost in
Mt 7:22, where Jesus had made it clear that the lost will object to the sentence handed out to them: “Many will say
to Me on that day, ‘Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in Your name, and in Your name cast out demons, and in
Your name perform many miracles?’” Hodges concurs that “it is a very good point” and notes that, unlike
unbelievers, believers who are standing before God’s judgment will no longer have a sin nature.726 So
theologically, this man’s silence is indicative of the probability that he is saved and has a sinless nature which
prevents him from objecting. In fact, phimoo is also used of muzzling a oxen. This man is not muzzled by the
king’s question; rather, he is muzzled by his own nature from even making an excuse. Again, the contrast should
not be simply glossed over. The lost in the previous passage try to defend themselves on the basis of their actions.
They mistakenly think that they can appeal to meritorious actions for entrance. This man likewise could have
appealed to the fact that at least he came. But if coming represents coming to faith, then this is not a meritorious
action. As a believer, he realizes that he cannot appeal to this nonmeritorious action as a reason to participate in a
merited event. The feast is merited rulership.
        To be sure, it might be responded that the excluded virgins are not portrayed as silent (Mt 25:11). If they
also represent excluded believers, then why is one group silent and the other vocal? Does this mean we should not
pay attention to the little parabolic details? Not likely. It probably means that we should pay more attention to these
details. In the parable of the virgins, there is no weeping and gnashing of teeth. Their vocalized desire to enter the
banquet is expressed by their plea: “Lord, lord, open up for us.” They are not pictured as standing outside saying,
“Well, we really didn’t want to attend anyway.” To the contrary, they want to come inside. Their vocalization
shows their desire, just as the vocalized weeping of the those in the outer darkness shows their desire to enter. The
absence of a sin nature does not result in an absence of a desire to participate in the feast. Their joint vocalization
stands as a united condemnation upon those believers who say, “Well, I’m not really interested in rewards.” Such
short-sighted believers may very well be saying, “I don’t care,” now. But they will not be saying that then.†
       Moreover, it should not be thought that the king enters and just so happens to notice that one of the guests is
not properly clothed. On the contrary, this king comes in for the purpose of inspecting the guest: “The king came in
to look over (theaomai) the dinner guests.” This infinitive form of theaomai is used to show the purpose of the
king’s coming into the room—it was to inspect the guest. After this inspection, and after this guest is found lacking
the appropriate attire, the king then asks the man for an explanation as to why he is improperly clothed. The Bible
teaches that believers will give an account of themselves to the Lord at the Bema (Rom 14:10-12). Likewise,
believers who hide their talents or minas will be required to give an account and then be condemned on the basis of
the very excuse which they make (Mt 25:24-27; Lk 19:20-22). Nevertheless, after unfaithful believers have given
account and been evaluated and found not to measure up, they will have no further excuse or complaint which they
will wish to offer. By their own sinless nature, they will be silenced from complaining or making excuses, but they
will not be silenced from expressing regret. The virgins left in the darkness outside, as well as the poorly clothed
man thrown in the darkness outside, are silent when it comes to offering justification for their lack of preparation.

*
  See Misthological Sequence of Election, 298.
†
  Additionally, the virgins standing at the door outside may represent believers who still have their sin natures. Although this point is
contested by some misthologists, the foolish virgins are probably tribulational believers who have survived until the end of the
tribulation and who stand in flesh and blood bodies before the Lord in judgment. They will be excluded from the banquet and
subsequently live on the earth in flesh and blood bodies with the sin natures intact. They procreate in the millennial kingdom and give
birth to children with the sin natures intact. Many of these children will die during the millennium.
Page 428                                                                                                        The Outer Darkness
This is a stark contrast to those unbelievers whose sin nature compels them to offer works in defense of their
justification. While some believers may try to give account for their lack of works, unbelievers contrastively will
be trying to excuse themselves on account of their works.

                                                        Life is Spared
        In the parable of the minas, the life of the unworthy slave was likewise spared, in contrast to that of the
enemies who sent a negative delegation.* Likewise, in this parable of the feast, the king kills the city dwellers who
reject his invitation to come. Yet, as before, he spares the life of the unworthy friend who actually does come. Once
again, a picture of soteriological security is found amidst misthological loss (cp. 1Cor 3:15).

                                                          Conclusion
        That the ill-prepared wedding guest of Mt 22:12 is saved is proven by the fact that he responded to the
invitation to attend the banquet—he is at the banquet. He will be in the future kingdom and thus represents those
who have been born again (Jn 3:3,5). He is called friend. To be called friend in this parable probably identifies him
with the group that had been sent the original invitation, since it was to his friends that the king had sent his
original invitation.† Later, it was extended to people he did not even know. In the end, earthly pursuits did not
prevent this man from coming and being coolly acknowledged as a friend, but those earthly interests did prevent
him from preparing himself for the feast and from being acknowledged with a place at the feast. The quiddity made
by some is that friend (hetairos) is used negatively in Matthew. Yet I counter that this does not prove that it is used
soteriologically. That Jesus called Judas His friend sarcastically (Mt 26:50) does not prove that the landowner and
king could not refer to the laborers and wedding guest as His friend misthologically or reproachfully (Mt 20:13;
22:12). That the man thrown into the outer darkness is not an intimate friend (philos) only means that he was not an
obedient believer (Jn 15:14), not that he was an unbeliever.
        It might be asked, “How could the man without the wedding garment have been one of the friends who
initially responded indifferently when invited to the feast since those who refused to come were killed?” In
response it may be noted that the one who responded indifferently was a farmer, who presumably lived outside the
city in the country, and another was a businessman, who probably lived in the city (Mt 22:5). The city dweller who
responded indifferently would have perished with those who responded violently when the city was destroyed
(Mt 22:4). But the indifferent farmer would not have suffered the same fate (death and fire) that the indifferent
businessman suffered since the farmer was not in the city when it was burned. Both men were indifferent, but one
man is saved from the fire. This is an implicit picture of salvation by grace. He no more deserved to be saved than
the man who perished in the flames. The sparing of his life, as in the minas, is a soteriological picture of unmerited
grace.
        In terms of works, unworthy believers deserve hell just as much as unworthy unbelievers. Their lives may
be no different, equally marked by indifference to the Lordship of Christ. Nevertheless, unworthy believers do not
undergo the same fate as the lost. By grace they are spared the flames because salvation from hell is not based on
personal worthiness. Although this man was indeed saved from the fire, he was not saved from the outer darkness.
The outer darkness is distinguished from the flames. To equate the outer darkness with the fire runs counter to the
parable and fails to do justice to the reality of the man’s salvation from the flames, which Jesus intentionally
indicated in the parable by calling him friend and sparing his life.
        We are not only to invite the lost to come take of the water of life freely, we are to also invite them to
prepare themselves for the feast. The water is free; the feast is not. Both evangelists (who proclaim the message of
the water) and pastor-teachers (who expound the meat of the feast) can expect to encounter indifference and rough
treatment. Still, they cannot shirk their duty. We do not want to see the lost in hell, and we do not want to see
believers in the outer darkness. May our evangelistic zeal pour over into our didactical endeavors.




*
  See Brief Exegesis, 398.
†
  For those who wish to press this point, allowance will be made for the possibility that the friend represents a Jewish believer since
the original invitation was to Jews. Appendix 18. Jewish Friend and Jewish Son(s), 927.
                                        Chapter 18.
                           Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)
                                                  Introduction
       In the process of examining the outer darkness, foolish virgins and unworthy slaves and friends have been
encountered. An unworthy son will be dealt with next in the final passage on the outer darkness. Additionally, the
parable of the wheat and tares must be taken into consideration since it explicitly identifies those who are cast into
the darkness. Thus, the latter part of this chapter will deal inclusively with this related parable. As in the previous
section, the primary words and phrases will be examined to determine if the phrase outer darkness is being used
soteriologically or misthologically. As always, one must be cautioned against circular arguments when reading the
soteriological counterarguments raised against the misthological position.

                                                        Text
       5And when He had entered Capernaum, a centurion came to Him, entreating Him, 6and saying, “Lord,
       my servant is lying paralyzed at home, suffering great pain.” 7And He said to him, “I will come and
       heal him.” 8But the centurion answered and said, “Lord, I am not worthy for You to come under my
       roof, but just say the word, and my servant will be healed. 9“For I, too, am a man under authority,
       with soldiers under me; and I say to this one, ‘Go!’ and he goes, and to another, ‘Come!’ and he
       comes, and to my slave, ‘Do this!’ and he does it.” 10Now when Jesus heard this, He marveled, and
       said to those who were following, “Truly I say to you, I have not found such great faith with anyone
       in Israel. 11“And I say to you, that many shall come from east and west, and recline at the table with
       Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven; 12but the sons of the kingdom shall be
       cast out into the outer darkness; in that place there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.” 13And
       Jesus said to the centurion, “Go your way; let it be done to you as you have believed.” And the
       servant was healed that very hour. (Mt 8:5-13)

       38And the field is the world; and as for the good seed, these are the sons of the kingdom; and the
       tares are the sons of the evil one. (Mt 13:38)


                                  Sons Of The Kingdom Are Believers

Huber’s Contextual Sensitivity
      The first thing to be observed is that the presupposition that the sons of the kingdom refers to believers is
extremely strong due to its parallel text (Mt 13:38). Huber, a FG proponent, is fully justified in saying,

       Of great importance is the only other reference in the New Testament to the phrase “sons of the
       kingdom.” It is also found in the Gospel of Matthew. One would naturally think that this reference
       would shed a good deal of light on the usage in 8:12. The other reference is Matthew 13:38 where the
       “sons of the kingdom” are called the “good seed” in the parable of the tares! This is not to
       definitively say that the “sons of the kingdom” in Matthew 8 are “good seed,” each passage has its
       own context, but it certainly opens up a strong possibility for it.727

Keathley’s Inconsistency
       Still, is the phrase sons of the kingdom a technical idiom? Keathley’s definition of what constitutes a
technical term is acceptable: “A technical term is one the author uses a number of times, and so consistently that it
always means the same thing in all passages.”728 He accuses Huber of having a double standard in taking sons of
the kingdom as a technical idiom for believers (and thus supposedly not paying much attention to the context
because of this idiomatic assumption), since Huber, at the same time, asserts that having a stock-phrase mentality
in assuming that the outer darkness must refer to hell is faulty. So Keathley accuses Huber of a double standard in
claiming that outer darkness is not necessarily idiomatic but that the phrase sons of the kingdom is used
consistently to refer to believers. One may simply read Huber’s quote above to see that the charge made by
Keathley against Huber is unjust. Huber does not assume that the phrase sons of the kingdom is a technical idiom.
Additionally, the LS criticism of Huber manifests considerable inconsistency.
Page 430                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
        The criticism made by Keathley clashes with that made by Simpson. After appealing to the context
numerous times himself, Simpson criticizes those in FG for stating: “The context determines the meaning.”729
Simpson claims that since the same author is using the same phrase passed from death into life twice (Jn 5:24;
1Jn 3:14),* it must have the same meaning, evidently regardless of the context. Keathley accuses FG advocates of
not paying attention to the context in determining the meaning of a phrase, while Simpson accuses them of the
exact opposite! Critics of FG nullify their own position with offsetting criticism.
        Simpson uses this same stock-phrase mentality to criticize the FG contextual understanding of weeping and
gnashing of teeth in the outer darkness: “If an author uses a distinct phrase in multiple contexts, then that phrase
carries the same meaning each time it is used. How confusing it would have been for the disciples, if Jesus used
these terms, but only meant hell in half of the occasions in which He used them.”730 Simpson’s argument refutes
itself in that the disciples, along with others, were often confused by Jesus’ sayings. This was due in part to His
using words and phrases in different ways than anticipated or in a manner that could be understood in multiple
ways. Jesus uses the parabolic genre in particular to conceal His meaning cryptically.† So, on the one hand,
Simpson is criticizing FG for taking the context into consideration, and Keathley, on other hand, is criticizing FG
for not doing so. These LS criticisms are offsetting and cancel each other out.
        Simpson’s argument short circuits itself by its own internal inconsistency. If the fact that a phrase such as
the sons of the kingdom is used twice by the same author in the same book proves that it must be understood the
same way in both cases, then the sons of the kingdom who are thrown into the outer darkness must be the good
seed since they explicitly are identified as such in Mt 13:38. By the same token, those who weep and gnash their
teeth must be the good seed. Simpson’s line of reasoning refutes itself yet again with offsetting phrases. Although
this would be a shortcut to prove the FG position from Simpson’s own presupposition, I do not use this simplistic
equation in defense of the FG position because, as Simpson noted, we in FG prefer to examine the context, even of
identical phrases, before pronouncing identical phrases to be contextually equivalent.
        As to Keathley’s criticism that Huber takes sons of the kingdom as a technical idiom, this charge is
completely unfair, as is seen in the block quote of Huber above. Huber speaks in terms of contextual probability.
What Huber cautions against is the tendency of those who assume that outer darkness is an idiomatic equivalent
for hell and, in doing so, may fail to give the context the careful analysis it deserves. Huber believes that the
context must be factored into consideration. He is guilty as charged (by Simpson) of consulting the context;
innocent as charged (by Keathley) of not consulting the context. The only thing Huber is guilty of is consulting the
context; consequently, he is not guilty of stock-phrase mentality. Huber does not make a proof text of the phrase
independent of the context. Would that more exegetes would follow Huber’s example!
        In contrast to Huber, Pagenkemper explicitly states that the phrases into the outer darkness and weeping and
gnashing of teeth are both “used virtually as a technical idiom for the place where people are cast when rejected
from the kingdom. More precisely, they are cast into hell.”731 Keathley expresses no concern when his cohort,
Pagenkemper, considers the outer darkness and weeping and gnashing of teeth as technical idioms referring to hell.
Yet Keathley criticizes Huber for considering sons of the kingdom as a technical idiom. The charge is false. Huber
decries the use of stock-phrase mentality.732 Keathley’s ironic charge of a double standard should be applied to
himself and to his cohort Pagenkemper rather than to Huber.

Sons of Israel?
       As to the meaning of the phrase sons of the kingdom, the common soteriological assumption is that it means
sons of Israel. But if Jesus means sons of Israel, why did He not say so? In the parable of the wheat and tares, He
identifies the sons of the kingdom as wheat (good seed), thereby indicating that they are saved. They are not simply
to be identified as the sons of Israel (ethnic Jews). In that context it would seem that Jesus is teaching that sons of
the kingdom are not stumbling blocks, they do not commit lawlessness (Mt 13:41), and they are righteous in
deed/action (Mt 13:43). This summation presents a problem since Jesus elsewhere teaches that some believers are
wicked (poneros in Mt 18:32; 25:26). Some believers are stumbling blocks; they do commit lawlessness; and they
are indeed unrighteous. So how are we to interpret what Jesus means by sons of the kingdom when He
subsequently illustrates that some good seed behave wickedly? Even if sons of the kingdom thrown into the outer




*
    See endnote 1498.
†
    See Inductive Approach, 8.
Chapter. 18 Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)                                                                  Page 431
darkness refer to sons of Israel, regenerate Jews would be in view, or these ethnic Jews typologically would
represent how God deals with His redeemed sons misthologically.*

Unrighteous Sons
        Zeller rather conveniently forgets to mention these unrighteous believers when he misrepresents the
misthological position as claiming that righteous believers are thrown into the outer darkness. On the contrary,
unrighteous believers are the ones thrown into the outer darkness (cp. Eze 3:20; Heb 10:38). These positionally
righteous believers are being described in terms of their practical unrighteousness. Zeller thinks that since believers
are described in such glowing terms in Mt 13:43, all believers are righteous in the practical manner described in
that passage. He thus finds it ludicrous to suggest that any believer could be regarded as unrighteous and
consequently thrown into the outer darkness.733 To the contrary, to assume that all believers are being described as
the righteous in Mt 13:43 (or in Mt 25:37,46 for that matter) is a very gratuitous assumption.† Jesus does not have
to deal with unfaithful believers in the parable of the wheat and tares because He does not say everything in every
parable. He already had said that some of the sons of the kingdom would be cast into the outer darkness before He
reached the parable about the tares.
        Even before that teaching on unfaithful sons, the Lord had made it clear that all believers do not necessarily
let the light of their imputed righteousness shine forth in ethical expression. What justification is there for Zeller to
suppose that those believers who refuse to shine for the Son on earth will shine like the sun in heaven? When
Jesus’ teaching concerning these sons of the kingdom is seen in full, it is a demonstration of salvation by grace and
eternal security. Some sons are indeed unfaithful (poor demonstrators of faith) and are cast into the outer darkness,
not into the furnace. They will share a reaction similar to that expressed by those who are cast into the furnace
(Mt 13:42,50)—weeping and gnashing of teeth.

Weeping and Gnashing of Teeth
       As to the assumption that since both the wicked and worthless have a similar tearful reaction to their fate
they must therefore share the same fate, a simple observation should suffice: Subjective similarity does not prove
objective identity.‡ Gehenna of fire, eternal fire, and furnace of fire are Jesus’ normal designations for hell in
Matthew (Mt 5:22; 13:40,42,50; 18:8-9; 25:41). In both of the weeping-and-gnashing-of-teeth passages that clearly
refer to unbelievers, fire is explicitly mentioned (13:42,50). In contrast, in the weeping-and-gnashing-of-teeth
passages that apply to believers, fire is not mentioned of (8:12; 22:13; 24:51; 25:30).
       Pagenkemper correctly acknowledges, “Since this phrase [weeping and gnashing of teeth] does not appear
in this specific wording in either classical Greek or the Septuagint, the source of the suffering depicted by the
phrase must be discerned from its context.”734 He then proceeds to say, on the basis of his understanding of the
contexts in question, “Jesus used this phrase idiomatically, specifically when referring to the suffering experienced
by those rejected from the kingdom.”735 He subsequently begins the second part of his article by saying that this
phrase (along with six other elements examined in his first article) “signified not simply a rejection from some of
the privileges of the kingdom, but rather a complete rejection from the coming eschatological kingdom.”736 The
impression conveyed to the reader at the beginning of Pagenkemper’s second article is that this phrase weeping and
gnashing of teeth supports Pagenkemper’s interpretation. However, the reader should be aware of the circular
nature of Pagenkemper’s argument: The meaning of the phrase is determined by Pagenkemper’s interpretation, and
Pagenkemper’s interpretation is determined by the meaning of the phrase. Concealing the circular nature of his
argument was aided by breaking it into two articles.
       To be straightforward, Pagenkemper should acknowledge that since the context must determine the meaning
of the phrase, the phrase cannot determine the meaning of the context. Instead, he believes that it is a technical
idiom and that its idiosyncrasy must be determined by the context. The procedural nature of this part of his
approach might possibly be allowed. But for him to then turn around and say that the idiom determines the
meaning of the context (from which its idiosyncrasy was derived) is to run in a circle. Still, this idiosyncrasy is not
as bad as Keathley’s inconsistency in which he wrongly accuses Huber of using idiomatic arguments, when
Pagenkemper is the one who actually is doing so. Pagenkemper (upon whom Keathley is so dependent) is the one
who is making circular idiomatic statements. Yet Keathley ignores this shortcoming in Pagenkemper’s work and

*
  See Illustration 93. Five Types of Abrahamic Seed, 251; Israel My Redeemed Servant, 376; Israel My Redeemed Son, 376; Jewish
Friend and Jewish Son(s), 927; (Jewish) Friend, 936; Jewish Typological Son, 941.
†
  See Illustration 197. The Assumed All, 577.
