Page 432                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
unjustly attributes this shortcoming to Huber. More than Pagenkemper’s circular reasoning will be necessary to
conclude that just because these sons of the kingdom weep and gnash their teeth, they must be doing so in hell.
       As to the actual phraseology, weeping and gnashing of teeth is not used consistently for exclusion from the
kingdom itself. At times it is used for exclusion from the banquet within the kingdom instead (cf. Mt 22:13).
Considerable evidence is available for equating the banquet with some event or special privilege within the
kingdom rather than with the kingdom itself. One certainly would expect believers who see their soul-lives (in
terms of their life’s work) being destroyed in the Bema fires described by Paul to weep over the eternal loss they
are suffering in terms of rewards as a result of their wasted lives (1Cor 3:11-15).

Great Faith Versus Weak Faith
       Keathley quotes Mt 8:10-12 and then proceeds to state: “Here we see that being at the banquet equals being
in the kingdom / heaven. Not being at the banquet means one is not in the kingdom / heaven. This is undoubtedly a
reference to hell.”*737 He supports his statement with a table:738
                                       Illustration 145. Keathley’s Kingdom Banquet
                Gentile with faith                          Israel without faith
                Those from the east and the west (Gentiles) Son’s of the kingdom (Israel)
                In the kingdom                              Out of the kingdom—“outer darkness”
                Reason for being in the kingdom—faith       Reason for being excluded—lack of faith

       Somehow this chart is supposed to make Keathley’s comments “undoubtedly” persuasive. Yet an alternative
table that accords more closely with the actual details of the parable suggests otherwise. The details, for which
Keathley already has expressed very little interest, would have been very helpful in elucidating his understanding
of the parable.†
                                       Illustration 146. Matthew’s Kingdom Banquet
              Gentile with great faith                    Jews with weak faith
              Those from the east and the west (Gentiles) Son’s of the kingdom (believing Jews)
              At the banquet inside the kingdom           Outer darkness—excluded from the banquet
              Reason for inclusion—great faith            Reason for exclusion—weak faith

       What is being commended and illustrated is great faith on the part of the centurion and Abraham. Because
of his great faith, Abraham will recline at table in a rulership position in the kingdom rather than be cast into the
outer darkness. His simple faith had resulted in soteriological imputation and entrance into the kingdom. But his
great faith subsequently was imputed to him misthologically as misthological righteousness.‡ Pagenkemper’s
assumption that this faith is being juxtaposed with a lack of faith on the part of the sons of the kingdom is
unwarranted.739 Had Keathley taken an inductive approach (rather than jump to deductive conclusions) perhaps he
would have seen Pagenkemper’s leap in logic. Contextually and typologically, what is being contrasted is great
faith versus weak faith.§ Contrary to the implications of Pagenkemper’s assertions, it does not take great faith to
enter the kingdom. Simple faith is all that is necessary to become a child of God and of the kingdom.
       Great faith is required to dine with Jesus in the kingdom. Pagenkemper should have been more consistent in
his acknowledgement that they “will be rejected from enjoying the kingdom banquet….The banquet motif is made
clear by the presence of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob reclining.”740 What they are rejected from is the banquet in the
kingdom, not the kingdom itself. They cannot sit at the table with the heroes of the Jewish faith because they are
not heroes of faith.
       In this context, Jesus expresses delight to find faith based on His words rather than on His works. A faith
based on signs is not soteriologically defective, but it falls short of misthological approval. That soteriological faith
may be based on signs is clear enough from GJ, as is seen in the purpose statement of that gospel (Jn 20:30-31).

*
  For further interaction in the present work with Keathley’s claim that the banquet equals the kingdom, see Chapter 24 Whose Tears
in Rev 21:4
†
  See Deductive Approach, 7.
‡
  See Misthological Promise on Soteriological Foundation, 252.
§
  The broader context acknowledges that entrance is contingent on whether one believes (Mt 21:31-32). See Illustration 356.
Typological and Historical Jews, 942.
Chapter. 18 Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)                                                           Page 433
John writes his gospel in hopes that his readers will be convinced that Jesus is the Christ by the signs that he
records, and he shares various examples in his gospel of Jews who did believe in Christ because of His signs (e.g.,
Jn 2:11, 23; 7:31). However, Jesus also makes it evident that although such faith is saving faith, it is not
praiseworthy faith (Jn 4:48). In contrast to the Jews, not only were Gentiles able to believe despite the absence of
signs, even the Samaritans were able to believe on the basis of His words alone (Jn 4:41). Jesus pronounces a
special blessing on those who would believe despite the absence of seeing any miracles (Jn 20:29). The Scripture
teaches various degrees of faith. The sons of the kingdom who are excluded from the banquet are contrasted with
those who have great faith. The problem is that these rejected sons of the kingdom have a weak faith. By logical
extension, it may be stipulated on the basis of the other parables concerning the outer darkness that living by faith
is necessary to participate in the feast.*

Reclining then Casting
        The explicit dining-then-casting sequence demonstrated in Mt 22:11-13 (and also seen in the parable of the
virgins†) was implicitly anticipated by reclining-then-casting succession of Mt 8:11-12. First, many come from east
to west. Second, those who come then recline at table in the kingdom.‡ Third, some of those who come to the table
and who are designated as sons of the kingdom are then cast out. One must not suppose that the fact that the repose
takes place before the casting is coincidental. The Matthean detail that the lounging around the table takes place
before the casting away from the table is most significant indeed. Moreover, the fact that the order is attested to
multiple times in Matthew but inverted in Lk 13:28-29 naturally leads to the conclusion that two different
expulsions are in view. The Lukan expulsion before the feast starts is soteriological, but the Matthean expulsion
after the feast commences is misthological.§

                                                           Summary
       The misthological conclusion, accordingly, is that entrance into the kingdom is by simple faith. The reason
these sons of the kingdom are in the kingdom is because they are believers. Participation in the feast, however, is
based on great faith. The misthological greatness of a believer’s faith will not determine whether he or she enters
the kingdom, but it certainly will be a factor which determines if a believer may participate in the feast once that
believer has entered the kingdom. Therefore, these sons enter the eschatological kingdom but subsequently are
rejected from the feast rather than the kingdom. Naturally, our detractors will point out that this sequence of events
seems incompatible with state of affairs as seen in the parable concerning the wheat and the tares. Attention will
now be given to this objection.

                                           Wheat and Tares (Mt 13:24-50)

Introduction
       Pagenkemper and Keathley contend, on the basis of the soteriological contrasts between the lost and saved
in parables such as the wheat and tares and the sheep and goats, that the other parables dealing with the fate of two
different groups are likewise intending a soteriological contrast between the lost and saved. Indeed, a number of
passages contrast these two groups. To conclude that all contrasts must be limited to a distinction between the
same two groups would be unwise, however. As already noted concerning the contrast of extremes,** the fact that
Jesus can contrast unbelievers with believers on some occasions does not mean that He cannot contrast faithful
believers with unfaithful believers on other occasions and in other parables. In this current section, the importance
of paying close attention to the parabolic details will be further illustrated. At the same time, seeking to expound a
central meaning for the parable will not be found incompatible with paying close attention to the information
provided by the details of the parable.

Text
       24He presented another parable to them, saying, “The kingdom of heaven may be compared to a man
       who sowed good seed in his field. 25But while men were sleeping, his enemy came and sowed tares
       also among the wheat, and went away. 26But when the wheat sprang up and bore grain, then the tares
       became evident also. 27And the slaves of the landowner came and said to him, ‘Sir, did you not sow
       good seed in your field? How then does it have tares?’ 28And he said to them, ‘An enemy has done
       this!’ And the slaves said to him, ‘Do you want us, then, to go and gather them up?’ 29But he said,
       ‘No; lest while you are gathering up the tares, you may root up the wheat with them. 30‘Allow both to
       grow together until the harvest; and in the time of the harvest I will say to the reapers, “First gather
       up the tares and bind them in bundles to burn them up; but gather the wheat into my barn.”…
             36Then He left the multitudes, and went into the house. And His disciples came to Him, saying,

       “Explain to us the parable of the tares of the field.” 37And He answered and said, “The one who sows
       the good seed is the Son of Man, 38and the field is the world; and as for the good seed, these are the
       sons of the kingdom; and the tares are the sons of the evil one; 39and the enemy who sowed them is
       the devil, and the harvest is the end of the age; and the reapers are angels. 40Therefore just as the tares
       are gathered out and burned with fire, so shall it be at the end of the age. 41The Son of Man will
       send forth His angels, and they will gather out of His kingdom all stumbling blocks, and those who
       commit lawlessness, 42and will cast them into the furnace of fire; in that place there shall be weeping
       and gnashing of teeth. 43Then the righteous will shine forth as the son in the kingdom of their Father.
       He who has ears, let him hear.…
             47Again, the kingdom of heaven is like a dragnet cast into the sea, and gathering fish of every

       kind; 48and when it was filled, they drew it up on the beach; and they sat down, and gathered the good
       fish into containers, but the bad they threw away. 49So it will be at the end of the age; the angels
       shall come forth, and take out the wicked from among the righteous, 50and will cast them into the
       furnace of fire; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.” (Mt 13:24-30; 36-43; 47-50)

You Must Be in the Feast Before You Can be Cast Out of It
       In the previous discussion of being cast out (ekballo), ekballo was shown often to be used of believers being
outcast.* Nothing precludes us from concluding that believers are the ones who are cast out as worthless salt,
branches, servants in other parables, or even as sons here in Mt 8:12. To pursue this line of investigation from yet a
different angle, let it be asked, “From what are they cast out?”
       If it is the kingdom from which they are cast out, then how can their presence in the kingdom be explained?
For example, concerning the NT usage of ekballo, where were the demons before they were cast out of a person?
In the person. Where was the log and speck before being cast out of the eye? In the eye. Where were the money
changers before they were cast out of the temple? In the temple. Where were the sons of the kingdom before they
were cast out of the banquet? In the banquet hall. You have to be in something before you can be cast out of it.
They were cast out of the banquet after it already had started, as is the case in Mt 22:12-13. Their presence in the
banquet hall must be explained. The most natural interpretation is that they were allowed into the eschatological
form of the kingdom (denoted by the commencement of the banquet) before being excluded from the feast.†

Illegitimate Totality Equivalence
       This spatial observation concerning the location of the sons of the kingdom poses no problem for the
misthological view, even though the wicked are the ones cast out of the kingdom into the fire in Mt 13:41-42 (and
13:49-50). Marrowists can easily account for the presence of the wicked in the present kingdom and the presence
of unworthy sons in the future kingdom banquet by positing two different aspects of the kingdom.
       So just how can the tares (i.e., the sons of the evil one) be in the kingdom? Can detractors legitimately
confuse sons of the evil one with sons of the kingdom by posing that this is simply rejection imagery and by
assuming that the two groups are really one and the same since they both experience rejection? No. Such a
procedure would be guilty of illegitimate totality equivalence, which may be defined as the faulty presumption of
hermeneutical equivalence of seemingly related texts due to partially overlapping sections of certain centrally-
perceived elements to the exclusion of equally important incongruent details.‡ Stated more simply, illegitimate
*
  See Believers can be Cast Out, 390.
†
  Even more specifically, one might suggest that they were in the Heavenly City before being cast out.
‡
  Such a fallacy would be akin to confusing type with antitype in typology.
Chapter. 18 Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)                                                             Page 435
totality equivalence is the fallacy of comparing apples with oranges rather than apples with apples. Just because
two fruits have similar shapes and sizes does not mean that they are one and the same fruit An apple is not an
orange just because they are both round pieces of fruit. An emphasis on shared characteristics should not be made
to the exclusion of information provided by distinctive dissimilarities.
        Just as James Barr popularized the expression illegitimate totality transfer to describe the faulty lexical
procedure of importing a word’s full semantic range of meaning from multiple contexts into any given context, so I
am using the term illegitimate totality equivalence for the converse faulty hermeneutical contextual procedure of
using a parable’s misperceived central truth to equate it with the supposed central truth of another parable. This
failure comes about when one fails to give sufficient consideration to critical differences in divergent details within
that context. Facial resemblances of one person to another, for example, do not mean that both persons are one and
the same if distinguishing features are also noticeable. Totality equivalence is basically the opposite error of totality
transfer. In totality transfer, the total semantic range is imported into what the word means in any given context. In
totality equivalence, the multiple details (corresponding to the full semantic range of the former error) are
practically ignored in preference for equating two or more parables because they share one or more common
details. In this approach, one or more parallel characteristics are used to deny multiple oblique facets. In short,
totality transfer imports multiple meanings, while totality equivalence ignores multiple details for the sake of one
fundamental truth. Both hermeneutical extremes must be rejected.
        Certainly, a parable can have a central truth. However, the details must be consulted in determining that
central meaning. The central truth is to be derived from the details of the parable. For instance, the centrally-
derived truth of the parable of the tares is that unbelievers will be taken from the present form of the kingdom at
the end of the current age and thrown into the fire of hell. The parable of the worthless sons, in contrast, presents
the central truth that the believers in the future form of the kingdom will be excluded from the feast of that
kingdom. Failure to distinguish between different forms of the kingdom results in faulty soteriology and
misthology. Multiple forms of the kingdom therefore must be posited.

Soteriologically Gathered Out ≠ Misthologically Cast Out
       The necessity of expanding the understanding of the kingdom so that it is not just seen as a soteriological
concept is readily apparent. Otherwise, an Arminian simply would respond that these people entered the spiritual
kingdom through the spiritual birth but later forfeited their soteriological place in the spiritual kingdom. After all, a
person must be in the kingdom before he or she can be gathered out (sullego ek) of it. The same problem is
presented in Mt 22:14, where those who are killed are in the kingdom.
       Keathley fares no better with his Calvinistic approach. Like the Arminian above, Keathley equates the
kingdom with heaven: “Here we see that being at the banquet equals being in the kingdom / heaven. Not being
at the banquet means one is not in the kingdom / heaven. This is undoubtedly a reference to hell.”741 He then
goes on to conclude: “Therefore, partaking of the banquet is equal to being in the kingdom, and being kicked out
of the banquet means being kicked out of the kingdom.”742 In doing so, he has run full circle to come back to
the LS position he introduced at the beginning of his article:

             Lordship Salvation proponents will automatically assume that the man at the wedding feast
       thought he was saved because he thought he believed, but since he didn’t have any good works, he
       didn’t really believe, and so was kicked out of heaven and into hell. Some people use this passage
       to teach that you can lose your salvation.
             Free Grace proponents see this as a rewards passage and redefine the meaning of outer darkness
       because they mistakenly accept the assumption of their opponents that this is the millennial banquet
       and consequently accept the wrong conclusion that the man who shows up without the proper
       wedding garments is saved.743

       Keathley explicitly rejects the FG view that the passage is talking about loss of rewards and the Arminian
view that it is picturing loss of soteriological life. Instead, he argues that the man was never a believer. However, in
doing so, by logical extension, he has taken the Arminian view that soteriological entrance into heaven is at stake.
If that be the case, then the man already has successfully entered the soteriological sphere from which he is
subsequently excluded. Thus, Keathley is left with the Arminian position. Keathley also implicitly endorses the LS
view by equating the banquet with heaven and being cast out of the banquet as being kicked out of the
soteriological kingdom of heaven into hell. And he already had defined this as the LS view.
       But what is a lost man doing in heaven? Is God going to take unbelievers into heaven and then cast them out
afterwards? Or is this just another one of the “little details,” as Keathley calls them, that we are simply to ignore. If
Page 436                                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
so, Keathley would have done better to follow Pagenkemper’s lead and just reject this detail by merely passing it
off as rejection imagery. Pagenkemper’s rejection of the detail is unsatisfactory, but Keathley’s feeble attempt to
explain it is contradictory. The following excerpt from Keathley was quoted in its fuller context in the introductory
comments of this book.* The heart of this quote is as follows:

        Every detail doesn’t necessarily correspond to some eschatalogical event. Parables typically have one
        main idea that answers some question or problem given in the preceding context. So, little details
        like the one where the guy is at the banquet don’t necessarily mean that he made it into heaven
        and then was removed. This is just rejection imagery.744

       Apparently, Keathley is having trouble making up his mind as to whether the guests in the banquet made it
into heaven. Perhaps Keathley should be given the benefit of the doubt and be understood as just speaking loosely
and not intending to be taken literally. But this is precisely the problem. Even if Keathley is trying to speak broadly
rather than with technical accuracy (perhaps to enable his readers to sense the manner in which he evidently
believes that Matthew is presenting the passage), Keathley takes contradictory positions.
       How is one confidently and consistently to interpret the parable if not from the information it provides? Can
the interpreter really afford to brush aside details in order to make the parable fit his or her theology? No. It is
apparent that Keathley’s deductive approach is woefully inadequate to deal with the details of the parable. The
Marrowist approach, in contrast, allows one to interpret the details inductively and then adductively draw a
consistent interpretation within the deductive parameters of other doctrines such as eternal security. Rather than
ignore the details, they may be interweaved misthologically to show a logical consistency.

                  Present                                                          Future
                  Myster y                                                          il lennial

       The kingdom is already present in its mystery form.† In this present age, believers and unbelievers are mixed
together in this mystery form of the kingdom. Through public identification with Christ (through such means as
public profession of faith, baptism, and church attendance), professing believers enter the mystery form of the
kingdom, whether or not they have experienced saving faith. Believing in church membership for eternal life does
not result in the possession of eternal life, but it does result in membership within (and public identification with)
the church. On the other hand, when people believe in Christ alone for eternal life, they become genuine believers.

*
  See Deductive Approach, 7.
†
  The present form of the kingdom (in which believers and unbelievers live together) is the mystery form. When people believe, they
become new creatures; the old becomes something new (2Cor 5:17). Although they remain in the mystery form of the kingdom, they
are transformed from tares into wheat and are transferred into the mystical (spiritual) form of the kingdom. (The mystery form of the
kingdom is entered through professed spiritual birth, but the mystical/spiritual kingdom is entered through genuine spiritual birth.) In
the future, believers will enter the millennial form of the kingdom.
Chapter. 18 Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)                                                                        Page 437
Such believers are a part of the mystical form of the kingdom by organic identification with Christ in the new birth
experience and via baptism by the Spirit into Christ.
       These parables in Mt 13:41-42 and 22:1-7 are dealing inclusively with what happens to unbelievers at the
end of this current age and thus deal inclusively with the current form of the kingdom—the mystery form. More is
afoot in these parables than just teaching that the kingdom will be delayed. Information as to what happens during
that delay and at the conclusion of that day is also provided. But Mt 8:11-12 and 22:8-14 deal with what happens to
unfaithful believers exclusively at the beginning of the next form of the kingdom—its eschatological and thus
millennial form. Mt 22:1-14, therefore, deals with both forms. That unbelievers are gathered out of the mystery
form of the kingdom does not prove that believers are cast out of the millennial form of the kingdom.745
       The lost will experience their being cast out of the kingdom before the millennial kingdom starts; they will
never enter the future kingdom. The unfaithful saved will experience their being cast out of the banquet after the
millennial kingdom starts. Unfaithful believers will be in that future kingdom but cast out of the banquet after it
already has started. These unfaithful believers will be cast out of the banquet after they have first entered the future
kingdom. The fact that believers are excluded from the feast after it already has started is confirmed by the
sequence of events in the parables about the foolish virgins, unworthy friend, and worthless son. To ignore the
threefold repetition of this detail is to proceed at considerable hermeneutical risk of running counter to the main
point that Jesus is seeking to make in these parables, which is that it is those within the future kingdom who are
excluded from the feast are inside that kingdom.

Rationale for Division
        The parable of the wheat and tares divides people into two groups rather than three because (1) the focus is
on the fact that you are either lost or saved. You are by nature either a son of God or a son of the devil. You are
either going to heaven or hell. The focus is on contrasts not similarities. (2) Jesus already had taught that some sons
of the kingdom would be poor examples of faith. He did not need to repeat that teaching here. What Jesus
specifically has taught in one passage should not be considered negated when, in another passage, He speaks in
terms of generalities. (3) The separation of faithful sons from unfaithful sons does not occur at this time but later,
so it is natural that, since it is not time for this distinction, there is no need to mention it. The judgment in Mt
13:41-42 is to determine who is to enter the kingdom; the judgment in Mt 8:11-12 assumes that this already has
taken place. For the feast in the kingdom already has begun, and they are present.
        The following similarities and differences between the two accounts in Mt 8:5-13 and 13:41-42 may be
noted. Both parables are discussing the fate of the sons of the kingdom. They are sons of the kingdom because they
are sons of the king. These sons are regenerate believers who are gathered into the barn—that is, into the millennial
form of the kingdom. Although similar terminology is used in both parables, there are considerable differences in
how this terminology is applied. In the first parable, the sons are cast out and cast into. In the second parable, there
is also a gathering out and a casting into. However, in the first parable it is the sons who are cast out and into. In
the second parable, it is the tares, not the sons, who are cast out and into. In the first parable, the sons are cast into
the outer darkness. In the second parable, the tares are cast into the fire.
        These similarities coalesce with pronounced differences to illustrate the principle of correlativity. Being cast
out of the feast into the outer darkness is comparable with (≅), but not identical to (≠), being cast out of the
kingdom into the fire. To confuse the fire with the darkness is just as serious a broach of the principle of
correlativity as confusing the wheat with the tares. Just because tares resemble wheat does not excuse one for
treating the tares as wheat or the wheat as tares. Correlation does not prove equalization: outer darkness ≠ fire.
        Since the sons and the tares may represent two different groups, it should not be assumed that they
experience the same fate. On the contrary, the sons are gathered out of the field and put into the barn rather than
into the fire. Subsequently, they may be gathered out of the banquet and cast into the outer darkness. Consequently,
the outer darkness that the sons are put into is not the fire. A comparison of these two parables demonstrates that
the sons do not experience the same fate as the tares. The outer darkness into which the sons are cast is not the fire
of Gehenna. Ultraistic Grace* interpreters are mistaken in using this parable to say that believers can be
temporarily cast into metaphysical Gehenna. The parable teaches the opposite.
        For example, Faust states that, since unbelievers are cast into the outer darkness in Mt 8:11 and believers are
cast into the outer darkness in Mt 25:30, the literal darkness that unbelievers are cast into in 2Pet 2:4 must be the
same outer darkness into which unfaithful believers are cast. However, if those who are cast into the outer darkness
in Mt 8:11 are believers, then Faust’s equating the outer darkness with the literal darkness of 2Pet 2:4 collapses.

*
    Ultraistic Grace interpreters will be more fully defined in the discussion of the next chapter. See Ultraists, 457.
Page 438                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
The same is true of his assumption that Lk 12:46 is referring to believers being assigned a portion with
unregenerate unbelievers.746 If apistos means unfaithful rather than unbeliever in this verse (or if it refers to
misthological unbelief), then Faust’s argument is impeded considerably.* Alternatively, Faust is joined by other
misthologists in his assessment that the outer darkness is used of the lost in Mt 8:11 and of the saved in Mt 25:30.†
Yet these misthologists do not necessarily concur with his assessment that the literal darkness of the epistles is to
be identified with the metaphorical darkness applied parabolically to believers. One must remember, after all, that
the latter passage is parabolic whereas the former passage is not. In any event, even if the misthological perspective
that the outer darkness is used both soteriologically and misthologically is granted, this does not prove that the lost
and saved are thrown into the same metaphysical darkness. At most, a correlation rather than identification
between the metaphysical darkness and the metaphorical darkness may be supposed. In making an equality, Faust
is guilty of transgressing the bounds of the principle of correlativity.‡
        Both the wheat and the tares are gathered out of the field, as Mt 13:30 states. As a result, it would be
incorrect to think that what the tares are gathered out of in 13:41 is the millennial kingdom. The field is not the
millennial kingdom. If that were the case, then the wheat also would be gathered out of the millennial kingdom.
But this is obviously false. It must be kept in mind that Mt 22:1-10 is dealing with the present form of the kingdom,
in which wheat and tares grow together. This parable is not picturing the eschatological form of the kingdom. It
deals exclusively with the conclusion of the present form of the kingdom (which takes place at the revelation of
Christ from heaven). The sequence in Mt 13:30 should not be ignored. The tares are gathered first. Thus, the time
period in view is not the rapture but the revelation which commences the millennial kingdom. The field equals the
present mystery form of the kingdom; the barn equals the future form of the kingdom (i.e., the millennial
kingdom). These details are summarized pictorially in the illustration below.
                                         Illustration 148. Cast Out and Gathered Out

      Present=Field                                                       Future=Barn

        The account in Mt 8:5-13 is also dealing with the future form of the kingdom, not its present form. The
reclining at the table, which pictures the millennial reign, will be experienced in the future form of the kingdom of
heaven.§ The banquet thus refers to an experience in the future millennial form of the kingdom. All of the sons of
the kingdom (i.e., the wheat) will be gathered into this future millennial kingdom, as the parable of the wheat and
tares illustrates. They will be gathered into the barn of this future kingdom for one singular reason—they are sons

*
  See Misthological Suffering in Heaven, 352.
†
  See Modern Interpreters, 453.
‡
  See Theory of Correlativity, 911.
§
  See Feast, 555.
Chapter. 18 Sons in the Outer Darkness (Mt 8:5-13)                                                             Page 439
(i.e., wheat). How well the wheat performed or how poorly the tares performed are not factored into consideration.
Rather, the separation is based on the nature of one as opposed to the other.
        Similarly, as to the division of the good fish from the bad fish, it is purely speculative for France to assume
that dimension and disease were factors. I have eaten some very small fish, and I have never thrown away a fish
because it was diseased. On the other hand, on one occasion when my brother took me trout fishing, I was catching
quite a few fish. But when my brother came back to the spot where I was fishing and saw the fish I had caught, he
told me to throw my bag of fish away. Why? Because they were horny heads, not the type of fish we were going to
eat! It did not matter if any of the horny heads I had caught could swim better or looked bigger than some of the
trout he was catching. Neither size nor performance mattered. The sole criteria for his judgment was the nature of
the fish.
        Contextually, even if some of the tares grew larger or looked better than some of the wheat, that is not the
issue. No tares were taken into the barn. In like fashion, none of the bad fish were considered good even if they
were larger or looked better than some of the good fish. France is on firmer footing when he notes that “at least
twenty species of fish are found in the Lake of Galilee, most of which could be eaten.…The Levitical rule that only
fish ‘with fins and scales’ could be eaten (Lev 11:9-12) would have ruled out eel and possibly catfish (common in
Galilee).”747 Because tares are tares, you do not spare them. Because eels are eels, you do not eat them. The nature
of what is rejected or accepted, rather than its performance, is the singular criterion for the division. Nature rather
than performance is the singular factor. The nature would represent the new nature or lack thereof. Whether or not
one has been born again, not one’s performance, is the singular criterion for kingdom entrance (Jn 3:3-5).
        That separation is based on regeneration parallels the truth that Paul presented in Col 1:13. The only
requirement to enter this kingdom is new birth, which is brought about as a result of a simple response of faith.
However, Mt 8:5-13 is concerned with much more than a simple response of saving faith—simple faith. It is
concerned with a great faith. It takes a simple faith to enter the kingdom, but it takes a great faith to have the
privilege of reclining at the table in that kingdom. If the faith of believers is simple rather than great (i.e., if they
has failed to develop their simple saving faith into a victorious mature faith by living by faith), they still will enter
the barn. A believer (i.e., wheat) is not cast out of the barn, but a believer can be excluded from the table (i.e., the
feast). Mt 22:1-14 deals with entering the future kingdom; Mt 8:11-12 deals with what happens after you enter the
future kingdom.

                                                     Conclusion
       The association between the sons of the kingdom as used in both Mt 8:12 and 13:38 is contextually quite
strong. The phrase is used similarly, but not identically. In both contexts, the phrase must be describing believers
rather than mere pretenders. Neither parable is describing someone who merely professes to be a son. In both
parables the action taken concerning the sons of the kingdom takes place after the unbelievers already have been
dealt with. In Mt 8:11-12, the feast already has started before these sons are excluded. Consequently, unbelievers
cannot be in view since they would not have been permitted into the feast of the millennial kingdom. Unbelievers
are not allowed into the feast, so they cannot be the ones removed from the feast after it already has started. The
time frame in Mt 8:11-12, therefore, must be after the separation of the wheat from the tares. Although this
preliminary separation of unbelievers from believers implicitly is assumed in the passage regarding the outer
darkness, this separation is stated explicitly in the passage about the tares. Again, the same sequence of events is
seen in the second parable in that the tares are removed from the mystery form of the kingdom and then the
righteous are rewarded by shining brightly in the millennial form of the kingdom (Mt 13:43). The word then serves
as a temporal and sequential marker between the two groups and two forms of the kingdom. The sons will have to
be in the millennial form of the kingdom since they are present for the commencement of the feast. The tares have
to be in the mystery form of the kingdom while the wheat is growing. Since two different forms of the kingdom are
in view, two different forms of exclusion must be in mind as well. The sons are excluded misthologically from the
feast within the millennial kingdom, indicating that soteriological entrance into this form of the kingdom was not
earned. The tares are excluded before the millennial form of the kingdom is inaugurated.
       A comparison of these two parables refutes the soteriological claim of the Calvinists and the misthological
claim of the ultra misthologists that only faithful believers will be allowed into the kingdom. The sons in the first
parable are allowed into the feast and thus are to be distinguished from the tares which are not allowed into the
millennial kingdom. Unfaithful sons are allowed into the kingdom. Gathering out all the wicked in Mt 13:41 and
taking them out in Mt 13:49 cannot be referring to unfaithful sons, since these activities occur before the feast. The
relative all of Mt 13:41, pertaining to the removal of the wicked, and the assumed all of Mt 13:43 must be
understood as simply contrasting the fate of unbelievers with faithful believers due to the sequence of events.
       First, all the wicked were removed. Second, the unfaithful sons are removed. Third, the righteous will shine.
Page 440                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
Since the unfaithful sons are removed after all the wicked are removed, Jesus is only referring to those who are
wicked in nature and practice when He describes the removal of all the wicked. The Lord is not describing the
removal of the unfaithful sons (who are ontologically righteous by virtue of their wheat nature) in Mt 13:41 nor the
reward of the unfaithful sons in Mt 13:43. Unfaithful sons are dealt with after the wicked are removed but before
the righteous shine like the sun in exercising the rulership granted them at the feast. Unfaithful sons
soteriologically enter the millennial kingdom but subsequently are cast misthologically into the outer darkness.
       All those being contextually contrasted with the faithful believers are thrown into the fire. Because the
unfaithful sons are not being contrasted, they are not included in the all (i.e., the stumbling blocks) cast into hell.
Although carnal believers can be stumbling blocks, they are not part of the group being categorically contrasted.
The all, therefore, is not relevant to them. Contextually and sequentially, these texts argue against both Calvinists
and the ultraists. But further interaction and description of the ultraistic position will be reserved for the next
chapter.
