                                                Chapter 19.
                                   Historical Context of Outer Darkness
                                                         Introduction
        In the previous sections, the outer darkness was examined in its eschatological, soteriological, and biblical
contexts. Much work is still to be done, however. A fuller inquiry into the historical and misthological contexts
must also be undertaken. This section will provide an overview of fellow misthological interpreters from the past
as well as an introduction to contemporary misthological associates.
        The three basic soteriological positions concerning eternal security and perseverance (Arminianism,
Marrowism, and Calvinism) already have been described briefly.* A fuller description of the variations within
these views will now be necessary to better understand the manner in which the outer darkness and related issues
have been understood by others. Not surprisingly, many Arminians and Calvinists are strong advocates of LS in
that they believe that submission to the Lordship of Christ in terms of one’s performance is required to enter
heaven. Genuine full surrender to the Lordship of Christ necessarily involves the production of good works.
Consequently, LS must logically require good works for salvation from eternal damnation. In contrast, the FG
theology of Marrowism believes that the good works associated with submission to the Lordship of Christ are
required for rewards within heaven rather than for entrance into heaven. Not all Arminians, nor all Calvinists for
that matter, are full-fledged Lordship Salvationists, however.
        A distinction between initial and subsequent surrender to the Lordship of Christ is necessary to see the fuller
spectrum of theological perspective. Some Arminians take a FG view of saving faith in that they do not believe that
surrender to the Lordship of Christ regarding one’s performance is required at the initial point of experiencing
saving faith. (The Lutheran articulation of the nature of saving faith is particularly well stated at times, and the
Lutheran position might be considered Arminian to the extent that Lutherans do not affirm the preservation or
perseverance of the saints.) However, although some Arminians may not require performance-related submission
to the Lordship of Christ at the initial point of regeneration, many Arminians would at least require subsequent
submission in order to attain final salvation (or retain salvation) from hell. This is frequently referred to as a soft
Lordship view, in which subsequent rather than initial surrender is principally in view. But soft Lordship Salvation
is not limited to Arminians.
        On the other hand, some Calvinists distort the nature of saving faith by redefining it as commitment rather
than trust. They argue that new believers must surrender (commit) to the Lordship of Christ regarding their
performance in order for their faith to be saving faith. But then LS frequently admits that these genuine believers
can backslide (defect on their initial surrender) and remain saved. Therefore, these Calvinists require initial
submission but not subsequent submission (albeit they are being inconsistent with the Calvinistic doctrine of
perseverance). In summary of the Lordship camp, some Lordship Salvationists require initial and subsequent
surrender for soteric salvation; some only require subsequent surrender; some only require initial surrender. But
whether they are full-fledged, partial, or soft Lordship Salvationists, all forms of LS require performance-related
submission of some type, to some degree, at some time in a person’s life. LS advocates will argue that a believer
must or will surrender initially and/or continually. The type, degree, and time of surrender may vary from one LS
interpreter to another and from one passage to the next. In contrast, FG interpreters consider such surrender an
issue of misthology rather than soteriology.
                                        Illustration 149. Variations Concerning Lordship
                            type of           Arminian   Arminian    Free      Calvinistic   Calvinist
                           surrender                      Grace      Grace       Grace
                            initial                                                         
                          subsequent                                                        

        Assuming that all Calvinists are outside the FG camp would be an error, however. Some Calvinists are
Grace Salvationists. The negative statements made herein are not normally intended to be applied full-strength to
these Grace Calvinists. Rather, these criticisms are intended primarily for those Calvinists who must be excluded
from the FG Camp. Those Calvinists excluded herein from the FG umbrella are labeled by Dillow as Experimental
Predestinarians.748 In deference to this approach, such Calvinists might be called Puritans to refer to Calvinists
*
    See Three Basic Views of Election, 264.
Page 444                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
outside the FG camp who require an exceptionally high degree and frequency of initial and subsequent surrender or
works to validate one’s claim to have genuine faith. Yet enough Calvinism is present in Calvin’s theology to
strongly associate it with the theological system which later bore his name, so this type of distinction has not been
found necessary for present purposes. Hodges, in contradistinction, refuses to share the Calvinistic title with
Puritans:

           In deference, therefore, to the many Calvinists who hold a biblical theology of grace, (e.g., R. T.
      Kendall, M. Charles Bell, Charles C. Ryrie), we refuse to describe the writers we are talking about as
      Calvinists. Instead, it would be better to identify them with the theology that became prominent in
      Puritan thought and which was, in significant respects, a rejection of certain basic concepts of
      Reformation theology.…
           …And this is the fundamental issue in the debate today. Do we follow the Puritans…or do we
      concur with the great Reformers (Luther, Calvin, Melanchthon) that assurance is “of the essence” (an
      indispensable part of) saving faith?749

       Although I believe that assurance of one’s own eternal security is the essence of saving faith, I obviously
would not be considered a Calvinist. Therefore, I am not inclined to adopt this sharp delineation suggested by
Hodges. Even though many Calvinists shy away from being called Calvinists and although Hodges would prefer to
limit the term to those who hold a milder form of Calvinism, the present work will not hesitate to refer to those
who hold to the major tenets of TULIP as Calvinists. Some interpreters within the FG camp are Calvinists in the
classical sense (rather than the stronger derivative sense). Others in the FG camp, like the present author, reject
both classical and contemporary Calvinism. The primary purpose of this study is not to take issue with FG
Calvinists but with those Calvinists outside of the FG Camp. However, the Calvinistic tendencies in some grace
oriented writers, such as Walvoord, Ryrie, and even Dillow, have been found to result in hermeneutical
inconsistencies that prohibit limiting Calvinistic labeling exclusively to Calvinists outside of the FG camp.
Nevertheless, as indicated on the chart above, primary reference to Calvinists is intended for those outside the FG
sphere. The above references in the chart to Arminian Grace and Calvinistic Grace describe those outside the FG
camp who at times prefer an interpretation or position that is consistent with the FG camp.
       The biblical teaching concerning the outer darkness provides an excellent place to compare these basic
soteriological approaches and to set forth the major options concerning the outer darkness in terms of these camps.
The outer darkness has been examined in its eschatological and biblical contexts in the preceding sections. Now its
historical and pseudepigraphal context will be evaluated in the present section.

                                      Soteriological Interpretations

Calvinistic
       Irenaeus (ca. 130-ca. 200), an interpreter in the early church (who lived in the Ante-Nicene period), believed
that the wedding garment is good works and that the outer darkness is the punishment for those who never receive
the Holy Spirit:

      Still further did He also make it manifest, that we ought, after our calling, to be also adorned with
      works of righteousness, so that the Spirit of God may rest upon us; for this is the wedding
      garment….But those who have indeed been called to God’s supper, yet not received the Holy
      Spirit, because of their wicked conduct “shall be,” He declares, “cast into the outer darkness.”
      (1:517).750

Irenaeus continues,

      The children of the kingdom shall go into outer darkness…those who do believe in Him through
      the preaching of His apostles throughout the east and west shall recline with Abraham, Isaac, and
      Jacob, in the kingdom of heaven, partaking with them of the [heavenly] banquet. (1:518)

       Thus, he believes that the children of the kingdom who are cast into the outer darkness are unbelievers.
According to Irenaeus it takes two things to enter the kingdom and avoid the outer darkness: faith and works. If
you believe, and thereby receive the Holy Spirit, you will have good works and thus escape the outer darkness of
hell. This early Puritan perspective unfortunately teaches salvation by works. You cannot enter the kingdom
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                           Page 445
without the wedding garment, that is, without works of righteousness. The traditional Calvinistic perspective that
the outer darkness is a soteriological concept is the most popular one among Lordship Calvinists. In consulting
their commentaries, one will often find that those cast into the outer darkness are referred to as nominal,
unconverted, professing, or false Christians who are church members or leaders.

Arminian
       According to Clement of Alexandria (ca. 150-ca. 215), another interpreter of the Ante-Nicene period,
salvation (not being cast into the outer darkness) is dependent upon not falling into sin. Salvation from the penalty
of sin is based upon turning from the practice of sin. Practice determines salvation; salvation does not determine
practice: “We are bidden guard against what is to happen; as also that was said, ‘They that fall into sins shall be
cast into outer darkness’…So that from these things it is clear that the Lord, going the round of all the methods of
curative treatment, calls humanity to salvation” (2:232).
       His perspective is evidently Arminian. Likewise, concerning Lk 12:41-46, Tertullian (ca. 160-ca. 225),
another writer of this period, states that the steward who does not rule well within the churches and mistreats his
fellow servants will

      be severed, and have his portion with the unbeliever….What will be the end of the severed ones?
      Will it not be forfeiture of salvation, since their separation will be from those who attain salvation?
      What, again, will be the condition of the unbelievers? Will it not be damnation? Else, if these
      severed and unfaithful ones shall have nothing to suffer, there will, on the other hand, be nothing for
      the accepted and the believers to obtain. If, however, the accepted and the believers shall obtain
      salvation, it must needs be that the rejected and the unbelieving should incur the opposite issue, even
      the loss of salvation (3:398-399).

      “The wedding garment” may be regarded as the sanctity of the flesh (3:565).

      The body shall be slain in hell, and thrust out into that outer darkness which shall be the suitable
      torment of the eyes. He also who shall not be clothed at the marriage feast in the raiment of good
      works, will have to be “bound hand and foot” (3:571).

       According to Tertullian, the wedding garment is the sanctity of the flesh, which may indicate practical
sanctification expressed in good works. In any event, the outer darkness is equated with hell and apparently with
loss of salvation in his statement. Those believers who fail to have these good works will lose salvation and suffer
eternal damnation in the outer darkness.
       Another interpreter in the Ante-Nicene period likewise espouses the Arminian view, saying that we save
ourselves from the eternal punishment of the outer darkness by holding fast our confession in the face of
martyrdom:

      For we ought to pray that we may not enter into temptation; but if we be called to martyrdom, with
      constancy to confess His precious name, and if on this account we be punished, let us rejoice, as
      hastening to immortality.…But now, by confessing a good confession, we not only save ourselves,
      but we confirm those who are newly illuminated, and strengthen the faith of the catechumens. But if
      we remit any part of our confession, and deny godliness by the faintness of our persuasion, and the
      fear of a very short punishment, we not only deprive ourselves of everlasting glory, but we shall also
      become the causes of the perdition of others; and shall suffer double punishment….For if a person,
      by the denial of his own hope, which is Jesus the Son of God, should be delivered from a temporary
      death, and the next day…has a sudden catastrophe, and departs this life; is not he deprived of the
      things present, and loses those eternal? Or rather, he is within the verge of eternal punishment,
      “and goes into outer darkness.” (7:439; 5:1:6)

       The traditional Arminian interpretation of the outer darkness is that it is a soteriological concept that deals
with the fate of genuine believers whose faithfulness (submission to the Lordship of Christ) is not sufficient to save
them from hell. This interpretation is the most popular one in the Arminian camp.
Page 446                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
Free Grace
       The traditional position that the outer darkness is a strictly soteriological concept is also popular in the FG
Camp. For example, Chafer does not believe that the unfaithful servant who was thrown into the outer darkness in
Mt 25:30 was necessarily saved; rather, the unfaithful servant represents unconverted Jews.751 Hutson, in the same
volume in which he devotes a chapter to refuting Lordship Salvation, says that the outer darkness in Mt 22:13
describes the fate of the lost.752 To his credit, in his newer edition, Seymour has now expanded his chapter on
rewards to affirm that the unfaithful servant thrown into the outer darkness in Mt 25:30 deals with an unfaithful
believer who fails to inherit the kingdom. Yet Seymour still maintains that the outer darkness in Mt 8:12 refers to
the fate of lost Jews.753 Although the soteriological interpretation may not be the oldest FG interpretation, it is
probably the traditional one in terms of popularity, though an exclusively soteriological view of the outer darkness
seems to be on the decline in FG circles, as shown in the case of Seymour’s recent revision.*

Summation
        Traditionalists is the term that will be used herein to refer to those writers who believe the outer darkness is
strictly a soteriological concept. This category is composed of interpreters from all three camps: the Arminian, Free
Grace, and Calvinistic. It is the interpretation preferred by both Lordship Salvationists and Grace Salvationists.
Traditional interpreters typically have considered the outer darkness to be a metaphorical description of the fate of
the nonelect (i.e., noncomers). They do not believe that it refers to mere misthological exclusion from the wedding
feast, the kingdom, or Gehenna. Although the majority of biblical interpreters are in this traditional group, truth is
not necessarily determined by majority vote. Further investigation is prudent.

                                          Misthological Interpretations

General
       Not all writers from the various soteriological camps consider the outer darkness to be a soteriological
doctrine. There are interpreters from all three camps (Arminian, FG, and Calvinistic) who prefer a misthological
understanding of the outer darkness. Both LS and FG Salvationists have adopted this misthological position at
times. Misthological interpreters typically consider the outer darkness to be a metaphorical description of the fate
of the unfaithful elect (i.e., subcomers). Generally speaking, misthological interpreters believe that the outer
darkness is (for the most part) limited in duration to 1000 years, that the Lord will wipe away the tears of even the
unfaithful elect (subcomers), and that He will remove the unfaithful believers from the outer darkness at the
conclusion of the millennium. Some of these misthologists merely are content to affirm the general misthological
nature of the outer darkness. This prevalent perspective will be reviewed first. Afterward, those writers who are
more specific concerning the nature of the outer darkness will be grouped into three basic categories: conservative,
moderate, and ultraistic.

                                                       Origen
       In outlining the development of the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness, it will be necessary to
return to the Ante-Nicene period. Origen (ca. 185-ca. 254) wrote his commentaries when he “was over sixty years
of age, and therefore may be probably assigned to the period 246-248” (10:411). Origen is commonly regarded as
the father of universalism, but it would be more correct to associate him with speculative universalism at best,
since it is debatable that he actually advocated universalism. Claims and counter claims are nothing new about this
writer. Writing in 1848, Campbell expresses one possibility:

                It is true, Universalists endeavor to show the antiquity of their system by claiming Origen,
          Clemens Alexandrinus, and some of the early Christian fathers, as the asserters of their doctrine. But
          the testimony of Mr. Hosea Ballou, in his Ancient History of Universalism, proves, that Origen did
          not believe in the salvation of all men. His doctrine is, that the fires of hell are never extinguished,
          but that when souls in heaven sin, as he gratuitously supposes they will, they are to be sent to hell
          until they repent, and that on their repentance in hell, which he also gratuitously assumes, they are to
          be released and again received into heaven, still liable to the same changes as before; and that thus


*
    See Modern Interpreters, 453.
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                              Page 447
       heaven and hell will be forever transferring their population from one to the other. This is not modern
       Universalism.754

        Campbell finds universalism to be of rather recent origin: “Mr. Murray, who is styled by modern
Universalists the father of Universalism, came from England to this country in the month of September, 1770.”755
In any event, the assertion that Origen was the origin of universalism does not find universal accreditation. In fact,
writing more recently, in papers presented at the Fourth Edinburgh Conference in 1991, Norris presents evidence
that Origen’s doctrine of apokatastasis (the restoration of all things), understood by some as affirming the
universal salvation of all things (including the devil), was perhaps merely a speculative option that at most Origen
toyed with, but it was certainly not consistently or clearly maintained in Origen’s writings.756 Nevertheless, Norris
is able to assert, “There is no doubt that both Jerome and Rufinus agree that Origen rejected the salvation of the
devil as unbiblical, even insane.”757 Origen “insisted that the devil and his angels were subject to eternal
punishment.”758 Origen’s enemies were the ones who tried to draw inference otherwise. “Origen insists more than
once that Christian faith demands the eternal punishment of evil and the eternal reward of good.”759 Origen’s
statements to the contrary are speculative and ambiguous. He seems to reject the salvation of the devil and demons
but leaves the salvation of the damned up to the reader to decide. When it comes to the outer darkness, Norris
exclaims that Origen’s teaching here is likewise “a muddle,” with the explanation: “In his Commentary on John
Origen refuses to indicate whether those who have been ‘bound and cast into the outer darkness’ must remain in
that state forever or whether they might sometime be relieved of their punishment. According to his reading,
Scripture doesn’t say.”760
        Norris’ exasperation with Origen’s speculation and indecision is certainly understandable. Yet if we leave
Origen’s preoccupation with universalism at the door, as being nothing more than perhaps a conjectural venture
(after all, even universalists can be saved),761 perhaps a little more progress can be made in discerning Origen’s
preference in his discussion of the outer darkness in relation to the parable of the five talents. Origen begins his
discussion of this parable by saying, “The parable wishes to teach us by representing that even when forgiveness
has been granted by God to us of the sins in respect of which we have received remission, exaction will be
demanded even after the remission, unless we forgive the sins of those who have wronged us.” (10:497)
        This statement by Origen is true to the text. If believers do not forgive their brethren (i.e., their fellow
believers), then believers will suffer in the outer darkness for their sins; nevertheless, their sins are forgiven. This
observation by Origen is consistent with the misthological interpretation. This clarification, in and of itself, is not
sufficient evidence to conclude that Origen advocates a misthological interpretation of the outer darkness, however.
Admittedly, it is difficult to be certain what position he is advocating. He is not the epitome of clarity or
consistency. Nevertheless, the misthological interpretation seems to be the one he prefers.
        Justifying this understanding of Origen’s above quote concerning the outer darkness will require delving
more deeply into his writings. The quest should prove interesting (and perhaps even illuminating), so a brief
excursion will be undertaken. Origen begins his inquiry by raising the question as to whether the servants are
unbelievers or believers or both.762 He leaves the issue unsettled saying that they are “stewards of the Word”
(10:499). He then concludes this section by quoting 2Cor 5:10 (which deals with the judgment of believers) and
Mt 12:36 (which deals with the judgment of all men).
        Concerning the time of the judgment in Mt 18:24, he states that, in his opinion, the time indicates that it is
dealing with believers: “‘When he began to reckon,’ there was brought, at the beginning of his making a reckoning,
one who owed many talents” (10:500). His perception is accurate. He also commendably adds: “The sense of this
appears to me to be as follows: The season of beginning the judgment is with the house of God [1Pet 4:17], who
says, as also it is written in Ezekiel, to those who are appointed to attend to punishments, ‘Begin ye with My
saints’” (10:500). Origen’s misthological observation is excellent. The time of the judgment does, in fact, indicate
that it is dealing with believers. Unfortunately, Origen next goes off on one of his allegorizing tangents (for which
he is notorious), speculating that perhaps the wicked servant represents the antichrist or Satan “or neither of these”
(10:501). He leaves the matter unsettled.
        In returning to the text, he reaffirms that the faithful steward who receives ten talents represents someone
whom God has entrusted with His word and that the citizens who reject His rulership and who are subsequently
killed represent either Jewish or Gentile unbelievers (10:503). One would think that since Origen recognizes that
the faithful stewards represent faithful believers and the citizens represent unbelievers, he would conclude that the
unfaithful steward represents an unfaithful believer in contrast to the other two groups. Yet he stops short of stating
that the unfaithful steward, in contrast to the citizens (i.e., unbelievers), represents believers. And he does not go on
to say that the unfaithful steward, in contrast to the faithful steward (i.e., faithful believer), represents unfaithful
believers. He fails to acknowledge the obvious. However, he does state that the unfaithful steward was perhaps
Page 448                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
“one of those under the kingdom who had been entrusted with a great administration and had not dispensed it well”
(10:503). And then he concludes his discussion with an application that is consistent with the misthological
interpretation: “All of us who have obtained the forgiveness of our own sins, and have not forgiven our brethren,
are taught at once that we shall suffer the lot of him who was forgiven but did not forgive his fellow-servant”
(10:504).
       His application indicates that the interpretation he favors is the misthological one, in which the unfaithful
steward represents believers who have been forgiven. The potential suffering of believers is being described, if
they do not forgive others. Nevertheless, their sins have been forgiven. As a result, the timing of the judgment and
the repeated statements that the servant represents those who have been forgiven leads Origen to the opinion that
the unfaithful servant represents believers. But does he believe they lose their salvation?
       The fact that their sins evidently remain forgiven in his assessment makes an Arminian understanding of his
words difficult to accept. Thus, the outer darkness for him would not represent a loss of salvation. Also, he already
has described the first punishment as being potentially temporary, since he believes the unfaithful steward probably
would be able to pay off the debt if he was released (10:501). This would mean that he rejects the Calvinistic view
that the unfaithful servant is lost. Consequently, he apparently does not believe the punishment being described is
the eternal punishment of the lost for their unpayable sin debt. But if it is not the punishment of the lost nor of
those who lose their salvation, then it must be the punishment of those who are saved. This understanding would
accord reasonably well with his earlier comments concerning the nature of punishment:

      For if “we must all stand before the judgment-seat of Christ, that each one may receive the things
      done in the body, according to what he hath done whether good or bad,” [2Cor 5:10] let each one
      with all his power do what he can so that he may not receive punishment for more evil things done in
      the body, even if he is going to receive back for all the wrongs which he has done; but it should be
      our ambition to procure the reward for a greater number of good deeds, since “with what measure we
      mete, it shall be measured to us,” and, “according to the works of our own hands shall it happen unto
      us,” and not in infinite wise.” (10:493)

        Although believers will be punished for the evil they commit, their punishment is not infinite, and it can be
offset to a considerable extent by the good they do. It would be consistent with Origen’s earlier statement to say
that he leaves open the misthological possibility that the parable pictures an unfaithful believer who is to be
punished but who can offset that punishment by doing subsequent good. Rather than being sold, this unfaithful
believer could pay off the debt by subsequent faithfulness to void the punishment decreed. Maybe such believers
could lessen the tenure of their imprisonment if they promised to do good. In any case, Origen may have reasoned
that since the parable does not state that the unfaithful believer received life imprisonment, it may not be infinite.
        Another reason for doubting an Arminian understanding on the part of Origen concerning the unfaithful
steward is that Origen often tries to avoid the conclusion that genuine believers can go into the fire of hell
(Gehenna).

      For all bear the surname of “rock” who are the imitators of Christ, that is, of the spiritual rock which
      followed those who are being saved, that they may drink from it the spiritual draught. But these bear
      the surname of the rock just as Christ does. But also as members of Christ deriving their surname
      from Him they are called Christians….Now, if the gates of Hades prevail against any one, such
      an one cannot be a rock upon which Christ builds the church, nor the church built by Jesus upon the
      rock; for the rock is inaccessible to the serpent…but the church…is incapable of admitting the gates
      of Hades which prevail against every man who is outside the rock and the church.” (10:456-457)

Origen appears to take a Puritan approach here. Christians are members of Christ. They are the rock and imitate
Christ. If you are genuinely saved, you will believe the right thing and do the right thing.

      Each of the sins through which there is a way to Hades is a gate of Hades….But if any one wishes to
      put us to shame in regard to these things because of the great majority of those of the church who are
      thought to believe, it must be said to him not only “Many are called, but few chosen;” but
      also….“Strive to enter in the narrow door”….“Many, I say unto you, shall seek to enter in and shall
      not be able,”…this refers to those who boast that they are of the church, but live weakly and
      contrary to the word.…in the case of those against whom the gates of Hades will not prevail, those
      seeking to enter will be strong, being able to do all things, in Christ Jesus, who strengtheneth
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                            Page 449
       them.…And likewise already each of the heterodox and of those who have begotten and “knowledge
       which is falsely so called,” has built a gate of Hades. (10:457)

       In other words, if you claim to be a believer but do not live a life in accordance with that profession, you are
not a genuine believer. Genuine believers are orthodox in what they believe and do. They will live good lives and
thus enter the kingdom. This is excellent proveitistic example of a Puritan articulation of salvation by faith and
works. Believers will persevere in good works. Origen then compliments his discussion of the gates of Hades with
a discussion of the gates of Zion.

       Now the gates of Zion may be conceived as opposed to the gates of death, so that there is one gate of
       death, dissoluteness, but a gate of Zion, self-control; and so a gate of death, unrighteousness, but a
       gate of Zion, righteousness, which the prophet shows forth saying, “This is the gate of the Lord, the
       righteous shall enter it.” (10:457)

       According to Origen, practical righteousness is required to enter the gates of Zion.763 Yet Origen is of the
opinion that all genuine believers have enough practical righteousness to enter Zion. For him, it is a soteriological
concept. Practical righteousness is required to be saved, to enter the kingdom. As a result, “let us take heed in
regard to each sin, as if we are were descending into some gate of death if we sin” (10:458). Thus, if we see
ourselves slipping into sin, we are to consider it as leading us to hell and thus turn from it. Consequently, we
cannot know that we are genuine believers when we slip, and we cannot know that we are genuine believers when
we do not slip since we might slip, which is again excellent Puritan theology concerning assurance of salvation.
You cannot be sure that you are a genuine believer; you might go to hell. This is apparently his position concerning
those who slip or stumble.764 Those believers (little ones) who stumble never were saved to start with; they are not
genuine believers. This understanding of Origen’s position is confirmed by his subsequent exposition:

       But if there is woe unto men everywhere on the earth, because of occasions of stumbling to those
       who are laid hold of by them; but the disciples are not of the world…as the Master is not of this
       world [Jn 17:16]; to no one of the disciples of Jesus does the “woe because of occasions of
       stumbling” apply, since “great peace have they who love the law of God, and there is to them no
       occasion of stumbling” [Ps 119:165]. But if any one seems to be called a disciple, but yet is of the
       world, because of his loving the world, and the things therein…to him, as being really of this world,
       shall come that which happens to the world, the “woe, because of occasions of stumbling.” But let
       him who wishes to avoid this woe not be a lover of life….For as none of the “woes” happen to any of
       the disciples of Christ, so does not this “woe, because of stumbling;” for supposing, that thousands of
       occasions should arise, they shall not touch those who are no longer of the world. But if any one,
       because of his faith wanting ballast, and the instability of his submission in regard to the Word of
       God, is capable of being caused to stumble, let him know that he is not called by Jesus His disciple.
       (10:487-488)

       In other words, if you are really a genuine believer, you will not stumble and will not be condemned along
with the world. As demonstrated in this context, Origen uses disciple to mean genuine believer. Genuine
disciples/believers are not of this world. Those who seem to be disciples but who do not demonstrate it in their
affection for Jesus and their submission to Jesus are not really disciples. Their faith is found wanting: it is not
saving faith. They will suffer the woes—the same fate that the world will experience. They do not lose their
salvation as in the Arminian scheme; they were never saved to start with, as in the Puritan position.
       In returning to his theme of stumbling little ones, Origen deals with possible objections to eternal security
by quoting Mt 18:6,14. The first verse says that little ones can stumble; the second verse says that they cannot
perish. He then states that he “who is now little, could not be made to stumble or perish” (10:492). Although
Origen does not solve the dilemma, it would seem reasonable to conjecture, on the basis of his previous discussion,
that believers who stumble are not “now little.” He has already divided the little into two classes: genuine believers
and false believers. The promise of not perishing applies only to those who are genuine believers. He assumes that
their preservation proves their perseverance—a standard presumption in the Puritan position. But this poses a
problem. Even genuine believers sin: “It is impossible that a man should be found altogether sinless, and who,
without sin, has attained to virtue” (10:488-489). How is it possible to sin and yet not stumble?
       Origen plays with the idea that genuine believers do not commit the greater sins versus the opinion that
there is no difference in degree of sin. The position he adopts is that there is a difference in degree of sin,
Page 450                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
maintaining that those who object to distinguishing between greater and lesser sins as introducing “extraneous”
notions into the Bible so that “every sin…distinguishes between the brother and him who is called the brother” are
being “very harsh” (10:492). In other words, his perspective is that the big sins might determine who is really
saved, who is really a brother, but the little sins do not. He then leaves the matter “in the air,” so to speak, saying
that we cannot pass judgment but should wait and let the Lord do so when He returns (10:493). This is typical
Puritan relativism. You can be sure of eternal security; you just cannot be sure that it applies to you!
       In the midst of this discussion, however, Origen states that the brother in question, who is sinning but not
stumbling, will not altogether be gained or perish as a result of church discipline but suffer something. “Therefore
he is not altogether gained, nor will he altogether perish. But what at all he will suffer…we dare not declare”
(10:493). He then proceeds to quote 2Cor 5:10, which has been quoted above with his context.
       Origen takes a primitive Puritan position that is open to and leads to a misthological interpretation of the
punishment of the unfaithful steward. His Puritan bent is shown in his understanding that genuine believers cannot
perish and necessarily will manifest relative faithfulness. Still, he is open to a FG position as well. If that relative
faithfulness is not great enough, such a believer will not perish, but he will experience some kind of suffering. That
the unfaithful steward in the parable of the talents represents a genuine believer is brought out by the facts that
(1) his sins are forgiven, (2) the punishment is finite, (3) the time of the judgment accords with the judgment of
believers, and (4) the possibility of believers sinning without stumbling (from salvation) is entertained. In other
words, the unfaithful servant does not represent someone who loses his salvation since his sins remain forgiven; the
punishment is finite and potentially temporary, and the gates of Hades cannot prevail against him as a believer.
Additionally, the fact that believers may sin but not stumble (perish) confirms the fact that salvation is not lost.
       Unfortunately, Origen’s misthology is contaminated by Puritan soteriology, making it impossible for the
unfaithful servant to know whether he is lost or saved until he reaches judgment. The most reasonable conclusion
of Origen’s position is that the unfaithful steward who lost the talents and who was handed over to the jailer was an
eternally-secure believer who was unfaithful and unmerciful. Since Origen’s discussion of the parable of the
unfaithful steward who hid the single talent is embedded in his discussion of the unmerciful servant, it should be
interpreted in a similar manner. For Origen, the outer darkness in the passage concerning the unfaithful steward is
the misthological punishment of an eternally-secure unfaithful genuine believer.

                                                  Saint Jerome
       Moving now to the Nicene period and Post-Nicene period, in the writings of Saint Jerome (ca. 342-ca. 420)
in the latter part of the fourth century, we find what seems to be a soteriological interpretation of the passage
concerning the outer darkness in the parable of the marriage feast, in which he equates it with Gehenna:

       He who has not a wedding garment, and has not kept that command, “Let your garments be always
       white,” is bound hand and foot that he may not recline at the banquet, or sit on a throne, or stand at
       the right hand of God; he is sent to Gehenna, where there is weeping and gnashing of teeth (6:441).765

On the one hand, this punishment seems to be eternal:

       I adjure and require everyone who shall either read or copy these books of mine…by the eternal fire
       which is “prepared for the devil and his angels;” as he hopes not to inherit eternally that place where
       “there is weeping and gnashing of teeth,” and where “their worm dieth not and the fire is not
       quenched,” let him add nothing (6:169).

       On the other hand, Jerome does seem to entertain an ultraistic interpretation of the outer darkness: “You will
be cast into prison; into that outer darkness which surrounds us with greater horror as it severs us from Christ the
one true light. And you shall by no means come out thence till you have paid the uttermost farthing, that is, till you
have expiated your most trifling sins” (6:265).
       He evidently believes that it is possible for a believer eventually to be released from the outer darkness and
thus from Gehenna. If so, then he advocates a ultraistic misthological interpretation of the outer darkness and
Gehenna. More will be said concerning the ultraistic position later. For now it is sufficient to note that he definitely
interprets the outer darkness in the parable of the unfaithful servant as being a misthological concept. In a well-
written extended section concerning the different degrees of rewards in heaven, he commendably observes:

       If we are all to be equal in heaven, in vain do we humble ourselves here that we may be greater
       there.…He who loves little, and has little forgiven, he will of course be of inferior rank.…Just as in
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                                Page 451
       another Gospel it is written that a nobleman…called the servants….But the one who had received a
       talent, or a pound, buried it in the ground, or tied it up in a napkin, and kept it until his master’s return
       (6:412).

       According to Jerome, the parable about the unfaithful servant being thrown into the outer darkness is
dealing with rewards in heaven (i.e., rank in heaven), just as in other similar passages. Jerome continues:

       Our first thought is that if, according to the modern Zeno, the righteous do not toil in hope of reward,
       but to avoid the loss of what they already have, he who buried his pound or talent that he might not
       lose it, did no wrong, and the caution of him who kept his money is worthy of more praise than the
       fruitless toil of those who wore themselves out and yet received no reward for their labor (6:412-
       413).

       The reason the unfaithful servant did wrong was because he was not supposed to merely try to keep what he
had but to use it to earn rewards. The issue is not trying to keep salvation but trying to earn rewards. Jerome’s
discussion of sheep versus goats further illustrates that he is not equating the servant who was cast into the outer
darkness with the goats:

       Six cities of refuge are mentioned in the law, provided for fugitives who were involuntary homicides,
       and the cities themselves belonged to the priests. I should like to ask whether you would put those
       fugitives among your goats, or among our sheep. If they were goats, they would be slain like other
       homicides, and would not enter the cities of God’s ministers. If you say they were sheep, they will
       not possibly be such sheep as can enjoy full liberty and feed without fear of wolves. And it will be
       plain to you that sheep indeed they are, but wandering sheep (6:413).

      Such believers are sheep. They are not treated like goats, but they do not have the full liberty that the other
sheep do. Inferior sheep are not treated like other sheep.

       The Gibonites met the children of Israel, and although other nations were slaughtered, they were kept
       for hewers of wood and drawers of water. And of such value were they in God’s eyes, that the family
       of Saul was destroyed for the wrong done to them. Where would you put them [the Gibonites]?
       Among the goats? But they were not slain, and they were avenged by the determination of God.
       Among the sheep? But holy Scripture says they were not of the same merit as the Israelites. You see
       then that they do indeed stand on the right hand, but are of a far inferior grade (6:413).

Jerome uses Jonathan to make the same point:

       Jonathan came between [in terms of rank] David, the holy man, and Saul, the worst of kings, and we
       can neither place him among the kids because he was worthy of a prophet’s love, nor amongst the
       rams lest we make him equal to David, and particularly when we know that he [Jonathan] was slain.
       He will, therefore, be among the sheep, but low down. And just as in the case of David and
       Jonathan, you will be bound to recognize differences between sheep and sheep (6:413).

      The difference between the faithful and unfaithful servants is not that of sheep versus goats. It is a difference
of good sheep versus bad sheep. The sheep of inferior quality are not treated like goats. Jerome then returns to the
servant imagery:

       “That servant, which knew his lord’s will, and made not ready, nor did according to his will, shall be
       beaten with many stripes; but he that knew not, and did things worthy of stripes, shall be beaten with
       few stripes. And to whomsoever much is given, of him shall much be required: and to whom they
       commit much, of him will they ask the more.” Lo! more or less is committed to different servants,
       and according to the nature of the trust, as well as of the sin, is the number of stripes inflicted
       (6:413).

      The servant who was entrusted with less (i.e., one talent) sinned in not using it to earn rewards. His
punishment in the outer darkness is equivalent to being inflicted with stripes; it is not equivalent to being killed like
Page 452                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
enemies or goats. The punishment of the unfaithful servant (who was thrown into the outer darkness) is a
misthological rather than soteriological punishment according to Saint Jerome.
        This assessment is in concurrence with proponents of OSAS who assert that despite shortcomings in
Jerome’s theology, he was nevertheless a defender of OSAS. This is in contrast to Wilkin, who shares Torrance’s
opinion: “The apostolic fathers taught that in order to retain salvation from eternal judgment one had to feel
sorry for and confess his post-baptismal sins to a priest and then do whatever acts of penance were prescribed by
the priest.”766 My hesitancy in uncritically accepting Torrance’s conclusion is due to Torrance’s insensitivity to the
possibility of misthological ultraism. He therefore appears to have conceded too easily to the NOSAS camp that the
apostolic fathers abandoned the doctrine of eternal security. This is to be expected, though, from someone so
misthologically inept as Torrance, who claims that rewards are not based on merit or achievement and are not to be
sought by Jesus’ disciples.767 Had Wilkin been more alarmed by Torrance’s misthological shortcomings, perhaps
Wilkin would not have so quickly given wholesale endorsement to Torrance’s conclusions.
        At least two basic options appear to be available to eternalists pertaining to the apostolic father. First, it
could be argued that all the apostolic fathers had abandoned the gospel, as Wilkin and Torrance maintain. It is a
common accusation by Arminians that incipient eternal security was invented by Augustine as a mutation of
Gnosticism.768 Of course, OSAS may counter that the apostolic fathers overreacted to a perverted licentious form
of OSAS found within immoral forms of Gnosticism. Or one may take a misthological ultraistic defense of OSAS
and affirm that at least some of the apostolic fathers believed in eternal security. The following quote from Le Goff
is cited by various writers (such as Engwer and Campbell) as an apostolic defense of eternal security:

           Saint Jerome, though an enemy of Origen, was, when it came to salvation, more of an Origenist
      than Ambrose. He believed that all sinners, all mortal beings, with the exception of Satan, atheists,
      and the ungodly, would be saved: “Just as we believe that the torments of the Devil, of all the deniers
      of God, of the ungodly who have said in their hearts, “there is no God,” will be eternal, so too do we
      believe that the judgment of Christian sinners, whose works will be tried and purged in fire will
      be moderate and mixed with clemency.” Furthermore, “He who with all his spirit has placed
      his faith in Christ, even if he die[s] in sin, shall by his faith live forever.”769

The following quote by Kelly, the Anglican historian, is likewise cited by Engwer in defense of OSAS: “Jerome
develops the same distinction, stating that, while the Devil and the impious who have denied God will be tortured
without remission, those who have trusted in Christ, even if they have sinned and fallen away, will eventually
be saved.”770 Campbell likewise supplements this quote with an additional one from Schaff’s well-known work on
church history: “It was the common opinion of the Greek Fathers, that the fire of the day of judgment would cause
severe suffering to some of those who would be finally saved, and that this might be mitigated by a severe
repentance, and in some degree by suffering here, and by the prayers of others.”771
       Arminians and FG misthological conservatives, among others, possibly have been a bit hasty in their
assessment that OSAS was not advocated by any of the apostolic fathers. Lest it be thought that Jerome is the
singular exception, it should be noted that Engwer provides quotes from Le Goff and Kelly, in which Ambrosiaster
is regarded as another example of apostolic eternal security:

      Like Hilary and Ambrose, Ambrosiaster distinguishes three categories: [1] the saints and the
      righteous, who will go directly to heaven at the time of the resurrection; [2] the ungodly, apostates,
      infidels, and atheists, who will go directly into the fiery torments of Hell; and [3] the ordinary
      Christians, who, though sinners, will first pay their debt and for a time be purified by fire but
      then go to Paradise because they had the faith. Commenting on Paul, Ambrosiaster writes: “He
      [Paul] said: ‘yet so as by fire,’ because this salvation exists not without pain; for he did not say, ‘he
      shall be saved by fire,’ but when he says, ‘yet so as by fire,’ he wants to show that this salvation is to
      come, but that he must suffer the pains of fire; so that, purged by fire, he may be saved and not, like
      the infidels [perfidi], tormented forever by eternal fire; if for a portion of his works he has some
      value, it is because he believed in Christ.’”772

       Faust also cites this quote from Ambrosiaster above. Correspondingly, I must disagree with Vance, who
says that Faust’s book, “is at best a curiosity.”773 On the contrary, Faust’s discussion would appear to be based in
large part upon historical reality: “Jerome (and many other early, professing Christians) taught that some Christians
would be temporarily punished in fire, yet saved at last. Augustine, on the other hand, resisted this idea, and taught
that any man that committed gross sins would burn eternally.”774
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                             Page 453
        While not all church fathers would agree with Faust, and while none may agree with him on every little
detail, Faust makes no small contribution to FG soteriology in supplanting Augustine as the originator of apostolic
eternal security with earlier church fathers. And even though Thomas Oden might have gone to the opposite
extreme from Torrance and overstated his case in his Justification Reader (in finding a Protestant understating of
the term Sola Fide throughout the fathers) and although NOSAS apologists certainly seek to counter, it is
nevertheless not without significance that Ambrosiaster, the great patristic Pauline Latin commentator (who also
provided the first real exegesis of 1Cor 3:10-15), in the same commentary as noted above regarding 1Cor 3:15,
previously had stated concerning 1Cor 1:4, “God has decreed that a person who believes in Christ can be saved
without works. By faith alone he receives the forgiveness of sins.” And on 1Cor 1:2, he notes that Paul “censures
them for many things, but in spite of that he still says that they have been sanctified.”775 Such statements are in
harmony with numerous affirmations that Ambrosiaster made in his commentary on Romans.
        Therefore, I appreciate the contribution of securitists such as Faust, Campbell, and Engwer who call
attention to these early patristic affirmations of justification by faith alone, even in the case of those believers
whose lives were open to censure because the disjunction between their faith and practice was so extensive so as to
indicate that their sanctification was to be understood more in terms of their position rather than their practice.
Some early church fathers (to a considerable degree at least) acknowledged that some believers were justified by
faith alone, even apart from works, since their works would have suggested otherwise. Although the consistency of
some of these fathers might be open to question in some of their articulations, nonetheless they qualify their
questionable comments elsewhere by acknowledging that unfaithful believers nevertheless will still be saved—yet
so as through fire.

                                              Modern Interpreters
      Turning to more recent interpreters, Warren Wiersbe, a popular commentator, concurs concerning the
general misthological nature of the outer darkness:

      Some feel that this unprofitable servant was not a true believer. But it seems that he was a true
      servant, even though he proved to be unprofitable. The “outer darkness” of Matthew 25:30 need not
      refer to hell, even though that is often the case in the Gospels (Matt. 8:12; 22:13).…he lost his
      opportunity for service, and he gained no praise or reward. To me, that is outer darkness. (Emphasis
      his.)776

      Wiersbe is not alone in rendering a split decision regarding the outer darkness. In his popular study Bible,
Spiros Zodhiates, for example, likewise interprets the first two usages of the term to be soteriological, but, like
Wiersbe, he takes the last passage to be misthological:

      In the first two instances, “outer darkness” refers to the place of suffering for the unbelievers
      contrasted to the light where the believers dwell (see 1 Jn. 1:5-7). Unbelievers will be thrown into
      the furnace of fire, whereas believers will shine as the sun in the kingdom of the Father
      (Mt. 13:42,43). “The outer darkness” in Mt. 8:12 and Mt. 22:13 is Gehenna, the place of burning
      (Mt. 5:22,29,30; 10:28; 18:9). But the “outer darkness” of Mt. 25:30 does not mean Gehenna. It is
      applied not to unbelievers or hypocrites but to the believers who neglected the exercise of their God-
      given talents….
        The expression “outer darkness” in Mt. 25:30 occurs at the end of the parable of the talents, a
      parable to show the necessity of serving Christ faithfully according to His investments in us.
      Therefore, in this instance, “the outer darkness” must mean a place of far less rewards for the
      servants who proved themselves less diligent than those who used and exercised their talents to the
      fullest. The expression must refer to the degrees of the enjoyment of heaven rather than referring to
      hell. This teaching of varied rewards is part and parcel of the inherent doctrine in the N.T. that
      neither heaven nor hell is going to be of equal degree for all because this would annul the justice of
      God. Entrance into heaven is through the acceptance of Christ’s sacrifice for our justification. But
      our rewards in heaven will depend on what we have done for Christ….The neglect of the Christian’s
      responsibilities and faithfulness to his task as a Christian in the world is considered of such
      paramount importance that the same simile is used by the Lord, “the outer darkness,” to indicate the
      punishment of the unbeliever for his rejection of God’s salvation. In the case of the non-believer, it
      will be positive punishment, fire and burning (Mt. 13:30; Jn. 15:6); in the case of the believer, it will
      be weeping which is the expression of sorrow over not having used his God-given opportunities.
Page 454                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
       The gnashing of teeth indicates anger at oneself for missing such marvelous opportunities that the
       believer had on earth. The same emotional attitude will be expressed by the unbeliever ….Gnashing
       of teeth, in the case of the unbeliever, refers to being angry at oneself because he did not decide to
       go through the narrow gate. (Emphasis his.) 777

         The present work will not necessarily always distinguish those writers who hold one of the outer darkness
passages as misthological from those who hold all three passages to be misthological. Sufficient misthological
proficiency so as to at least acknowledge that one of the three passages is misthological will suffice for that writer
to be esteemed as being worthy of the title misthologist.* Thus, a misthologist is defined as an advocate of
unconditional security who affirms that the term outer darkness, as used by Matthew, is applicable to believers as a
reward concept. Theoretically, this title would be limited to those in the FG camp. Yet in the real world, in which
theology is done, some writers that technically would be considered outside the FG camp (even to the extent of
being weak advocates of conditional security) also take what would be considered a misthological view of the
outer darkness. Therefore, pointing out the inconsistencies, at times, of those misthologists (if the term be used
broadly to include such writers) will be necessary. Some of the disagreements found among misthologists,
therefore, will be attributable to allowing such inconsistent writers into the fraternity of misthologists, even though
they are deficient on such an elementary doctrine as unconditional security. For the most part, however,
misthologists will be found to be staunch advocates of unconditional security and FG theology.
         The statement by Zodhiates gives occasion to point out that he correctly perceives a correlation between
believers and unbelievers gnashing their teeth. Both unbelievers and believers will be angry at themselves for
failing to avail themselves of the opportunities provided by the Lord. Just as there will be degrees of punishment in
hell, there will be degrees of reward in heaven. The principle of correlativity between the soteriological and
misthological dimensions is more pronounced than most realize. To Zodhiates’ credit, he stresses that the weeping
and gnashing applies dualistically to both unbelievers and believers. The correlation between the two is very
pronounced. Moreover, Zodhiates moves beyond the present writer, in one respect, in acknowledging that the outer
darkness itself is directly applicable to both unbelievers and believers alike. As a fellow practitioner of the
principle of correlation, the present writer can appreciate and respect this dual position, although he would express
it a little differently.†
         The implications of the shared perspective between the present writer and those, like Zodhiates, who allow
shared applicability of the truth conveyed by the outer darkness to both unbelievers and believers are more
impressive than one initially might perceive. Although the present work will reject their taking some of the outer
darkness passages soteriologically, the affirmation of dual applicability is still maintained. Consequently, the unity
between their writings and the present writing regarding the duality will outweigh the disunity regarding
exclusivity. Therefore, it is not without a considerable measure of appreciation for this shared view of mutual
applicability that the present book will, nevertheless, insist that the term outer darkness is applied exclusively to
believers in terms of direct applicability. Let the implications of Zodhiates’ correlation not be glossed over,
however, by those misthologists who share the present writer’s view of misthological exclusivity. Despite my
differences with Zodhiates on the particulars, we both affirm the principle of correlativity, and that principle is
more important than our differences.
         Pursuant with that shared principle of correlativity, it may be deduced that even if the present writer is
mistaken in taking all three passages pertaining to the outer darkness as being misthological, this would not be
sufficient justification to discredit the thesis of this book. One would have to demonstrate that none of these three
passages is misthological. If, for example, Zodhiates and other such likeminded misthologists are correct in taking
a split perspective on the outer darkness, so as to interpret it as pertaining to unbelievers in some passages and to
believers in only one passage, then even that limited misthological perception is more than enough to confirm the
thesis being developed herein. Indeed, even if one were able to discount this limited concession to misthology, the
underlying thesis of this book still would not be disproven. The thesis of this book is not built upon parabolic
material but rather uses parabolic statements regarding the outer darkness to express a misthological

to misthological themes so that salvation from the outer darkness depicts conditional misthological security. For the technically astute,
notice that misthologist was not so narrowly defined so as to insist that the outer darkness pertains only to misthological themes. That
some misthologists, contrary to the present author, will interpret some of the outer darkness passages soteriologically is allowed within
the definition.
