Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                                            Page 455
correspondence that is rooted in didactic material. Namely, the outer darkness is but a picture of the outworking of
other statements in the Scripture regarding loss of rewards. If one truly understands what rewards are at stake, one
would have to acknowledge that the reality painted by the parabolic outer darkness is the natural corollary. Even if
none of the three passages regarding the outer darkness pertains directly to the loss of rewards, one still could
deduce that, on the basis of the principle of correlativity, the soteriological truths pertaining to this soteriological
exclusion find a counterpart in the misthological exclusion of believers as deduced from didactical material.
        So that this important point may not be glossed over, let it be stated crassly. Even if I am wrong in my
assessment that all three passages regarding the outer darkness are misthological, then the strong probability still
exists that I am right in at least taking one such passage misthologically. And one passage is all that is necessary to
prove my major point of contention, as is demonstrated by Zodhiates.* Then again, even if it could be proven that I
am wrong on all three passages, my major point is still not disproven. A correlation between the lost being cast into
the outer darkness and the saved being deprived of rewards is still demonstrable.† In other words, even if I am
wrong (regarding the particulars), I am right (regarding the principle): Even if I am wrong, I am right. One would
have to disprove a tremendous amount of factual data to disprove the underlying thesis of this book. A soteric-
mistholic correlation exists between the lost being submitted to the darkness and unfaithful believers being dealt
with at the Bema.
        Proceeding, then, with such current writers who adopt a misthological perspective of the outer darkness and
accepting their support, even if derived from only one passage regarding the outer darkness, Ellison adopts a
misthological understanding of both the parable of the foolish virgins and the unfaithful servant:

        This is no story of eternal destiny decided by the Coming. The foolish have lost something but need
        not be lost themselves.…
        …There is no suggestion of the eternal fate of the third servant; like the foolish maidens he has lost
        something.…no special kind of darkness is meant—the reckoning takes place after nightfall.…If we
        wish to continue the story, we shall find that the morning will come, and the slave is still his master’s
        slave, only he has irreparably lost something. The often heard remark that no Christian could speak or
        think as the servant does in v. 24 [i.e., Mt 25:24] comes from living in a monastery without walls.778

       Bruce is likewise open to the possibility that the outer darkness refers to loss of rewards rather than loss of
salvation and cites Olshausen in support of this position.779 (Olshausen will be presented in the moderate section
below.) The NIBC with its corresponding Nelson Study Bible (which basically incorporates the NIBC notes) may
be the closest thing to a FG study Bible currently available. That the outer darkness is a rewards issue is affirmed
therein.

Conservatives
       Alford (an Arminian), writing in 1863, appears to take a less ultraistic position than that of Olshausen (an
Arminian who wrote 33 years earlier). For Alford, the outer darkness refers to the exclusion of unfaithful believers
from the marriage supper but apparently not from the kingdom. Alford recognizes that the judgment expressed in
the parable of the talents in Mt 25:1-30 is the premillennial judgment of all Christians and deals with their reward
in the millennial kingdom.780 He also correctly notes that being cast into the outer darkness means to be cast
“outside the lighted chamber of the feast.”781 Yet he does not go on to equate it with damnation, nor even with
being cast out of the kingdom. His position is in harmony with the context and is superior to the other typical
interpreters of his day, who believed that unfaithful believers are cast outside the kingdom.782 His position is noted
by Glasson: “Dean Alford in his great commentary on the Greek Testament maintains that in Mt. 25, the judgment
of believers is illustrated by the parable of the talents, and this is an entirely different occasion from the judgment
of Gentiles (non-Christians) later in the chapter” (emphasis his).783

*
  As noted herein, other misthologists (such as Chumney, Faust, Kendall, Phillips, Lutzer, Seymour, and Wiersbe) entertain a split
decision regarding the outer darkness, perhaps taking only one passage as misthological. One is enough, however.
†
  For example, Benware believes that the outer darkness is strictly soteriological. For sake of argument, assume that on all three
passages he is right and I am wrong. I still could make much the same argument as made herein using the parable of the minas which
he concedes is misthological. See Talents and Minas, 380. Then again, assume that both of us are wrong and that not even this passage
is misthological. In that case, other passages still could be brought into play to demonstrate the major points. Even weak treatments of
the Bema contain enough useful material to derive the major points. In particular, Rev 22:19 points toward misthopology. That one
verse, in and of itself, in conjunction with other standard Bema material, suffices for a misthological correlation with the outer
darkness, even if the outer darkness were an exclusively soteriological expression.
Page 456                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       Conservatives is the term that will be used to describe interpreters (such as Alford) who believe that the
outer darkness refers to believers being cast out of the marriage feast but not out of the kingdom. Many of these
misthological conservatives prefer an experiential rather than spatial description of the outer darkness. They are
designated as conservative because their position is closer to the traditional interpretation than the remaining two
interpretations considered below. Conservative writers include Alford, Carmical, Dillow, Evans, Hodges, Huber,
Lutzer, Sapaugh, Stanley, and Wilkin.784 To specify an author’s soteriological position, as well as his or her
misthological position, an interpreter such as Alford could be called a conservative Arminian; whereas an
interpreter such as Huber would be considered a conservative Marrowist, since Huber belongs to the FG camp.
Huber’s work deserves special note since it is dedicated to this conservative understanding of the outer darkness
concerning all three Matthean texts. Further, Hodges adopted his conservative misthological understanding of the
outer darkness concerning all three texts as a result of Huber’s work.785

Moderates
       In 1830, in his first German edition of his commentary, Olshausen expressed himself very clearly in his
discussion of the parable of the talents in Mt 25:14-30, in which he concluded that Mt 25:30 is describing believers
who are cast into the outer darkness outside the kingdom but not into the fire: “And cast out the worthless slave
into the outer darkness; in that place there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth” (Mt 25:30). This position was
maintained in the three subsequent German editions and appeared in English in 1857 in the American edition:

      The immediate reference is not to eternal condemnation, but to exclusion from the “kingdom,” into
      which the faithful enter. The degree of guilt in the case of the unfaithful, determines the possibility of
      their being awakened to repentance. The kingdom, finally, is viewed as a region of light, encircled by
      darkness. And in reference to this point, the metaphorical language of Scripture is very exact in the
      choice of expressions. Concerning the children of light who are unfaithful to their vocation, it is
      said that they are cast into the darkness; but, respecting the children of darkness, we are told that
      they are consigned to the pu'r aijwvnion [pur aionios], everlasting fire; so that each finds his
      punishment in the opposite element.786

        Olshausen concludes that the outer darkness is a place outside the kingdom into which unfaithful children of
light are cast. In his opinion, entrance into the eschatological kingdom during the feast is a misthological aspect of
the kingdom that is determined by faithfulness. Eternal condemnation, in contrast, is determined by faith. Believers
and unbelievers are punished in opposite elements. Thus, believers (i.e., children of light) are punished in darkness,
not in fire. Unbelievers (i.e., children of darkness) are punished in fire. In his next paragraph, Olshausen makes a
similar deduction concerning Luke’s parable of the minas.
        As Olshausen observes, the servant (slave) who does nothing, and thus who performs no good works, is a
member of Christ’s body, not merely a church member who professes such union. His punishment is to be
distinguished from the punishment experienced by the lost, who are represented by the citizens (enemies).

      Whilst the one servant represents an inactive member of the body of Christ, the Church, who failed to
      perform his duty, these citizens are open rebels, and hence their lord orders them to be killed. It is
      evident that this penal proceeding is essentially distinguished from the reproof administered to the
      one servant.787

       Olshausen’s analysis of these two parables suffices to show that he distinguishes between the soteriological
and misthological aspects in Matthew’s last parable concerning the outer darkness, correctly perceiving that
unfaithful believers are not punished in the fire, but in the outer darkness.788 Thus, Olshausen believes that
unfaithful believers are cast out of the kingdom but not cast into the fire of Gehenna. That Olshausen identifies the
fire with Gehenna may be seen in his discussion of Mt 18: eternal fire (v.8), Gehenna fire (v. 9).

      8And if your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it from you; it is better for
      you to enter life crippled or lame, than having two hands or two feet, to be cast into the eternal fire.
      9And if your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out, and throw it from you. It is better for you to

      enter life with one eye, than having two eyes, to be cast into the fiery hell [Gehenna fire]. (Mt 18:8-
      9)
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                                  Page 457
        And if your hand causes you to stumble, cut it off; it is better for you to enter life crippled, than
       43

       having your two hands, to go into hell [Gehenna], into the unquenchable fire. (Mk 9:43)

        As Olshausen says, “The simple pu'r aijwvnion, everlasting fire, of Matthew is in Mark paraphrased by
gevenna [Gehenna]…they depict the ajpwvleia [apoleia], perdition.”789 Gehenna is the eternal fire of perdition.
Olshausen’s position may be summarized as saying that unfaithful believers will be cast into the outer darkness
(i.e., excluded from the kingdom), but they will not experience Gehenna or eternal condemnation.
        Moderates is the term used herein to describe interpreters such as Olshausen who are one step further
removed from the traditionalists than conservatives. Classical moderates take the position that the outer darkness
refers to believers being excluded from the millennial kingdom.* Such moderates include Olshausen, Neighbour,
Haldeman, Patterson, Morey, and Dyer. Most of these writers appear to take a moderate Grace position.790
Olshausen, however, is moderate Arminian. Dyer is a moderate Lordship Salvationist (apparently of the Calvinistic
persuasion). He believes that only initial rather than continual surrender is soteriologically necessary. Subsequent
surrender is a misthological necessity. Those believers who do not follow through with their surrender will be cast
into the outer darkness.

Ultraists
       In 1853, twenty-three years after Olshausen’s first German edition but four years before Olshausen’s
American edition, Govett (a Grace interpreter) published a similar position in English. For both writers, the outer
darkness denotes the exclusion of unfaithful believers from the kingdom, and they both conclude that these
unfaithful believers will not experience the Lake of Fire. However, Govett is more ultraistic than Olshausen in that
Govett argues that some believers will be cast into the fire of Gehenna for a thousand years.791
       Ultraists is the term used herein to describe interpreters such as Govett, since they are the furthest removed
from the traditionalists. Like moderates, ultraists believe that some believers will be excluded from the millennial
kingdom in a place called the outer darkness. However, in contrast to moderates, ultraists believe that some
believers will spend the millennium in Gehenna before being allowed into the eternal kingdom afterward. Yet, they
do not all necessarily equate the outer darkness with Gehenna or Gehenna with the Lake of Fire. Ultraists include
Govett, Pember, Panton, Lang (?), Nee, Lee, Craig, Whipple, Finley, Faust, and possibly Saint Jerome.792 Panton
published Dawn Magazine from 1925 through 1955, so this publication may be consulted for additional authors
advocating the ultraistic position.
       Faust has devoted several chapters to the survey of those who are open to a misthological view. The present
author wrote this brief historical overview above on the early interpreters years before seeing Faust’s material and
has not sought to interact with Faust’s present work on the historical aspect; consequently, the reader can compare
the two separate reviews. There is more work to be done here by those who have an interest in the history of
interpretation than originally may have been perceived.

Summary
       In summary of the misthological position, conservatives believe the outer darkness is an experience inside
the kingdom, moderates that it is a place outside the kingdom, and ultraists that it is a place outside the kingdom
and that some believers will also spend some time metaphysically inside Gehenna.793
                                 Illustration 150. Interpretations of the Outer Darkness

                                                Outside Outside Inside
                                                 Feast Kingdom Gehenna
                            Traditionalists                     
                            Conservatives                       
                            Classical Moderates                 
                            Ultraists                           

        To restate this summarization in terms of the chart, traditionalists do not believe that the outer darkness
refers to eternally-secure, unfaithful believers being misthologically cast out of the feast or out of the kingdom or
*
 For a distinction between progressive and classical moderates see Progressive Moderates (PM), 568; Classical Moderates (CM),
568; Outer Darkness Summation, 731. Apparently, Chitwood and Wilson are closer to PM than to CM.
Page 458                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
into Gehenna. For them the outer darkness is a soteriological concept that depicts eternal torment in hell. However,
the remaining three groups adopt a misthological rather than soteriological understanding of the outer darkness.
Conservatives believe that the outer darkness refers to being misthologically cast out of the feast, but not out of the
kingdom nor into Gehenna. Classical moderates believe that the outer darkness refers to being misthologically cast
out of the feast and out of the kingdom, but not into Gehenna. Ultraists believe that the outer darkness refers to
being misthologically cast out of the feast and out of the kingdom and that some of the most unfaithful believers
are temporarily cast into Gehenna.
       Ultraists tend not to like the ultra designation and would object to being listed at the end of the chart,
preferring to describe themselves as moderates. Faust, for example, in responding to Zeller’s mistaken assessment
of his Faustian position, clarifies:

       Zeller personally embraces the “extreme view” that an unfaithful Christian will experience NO
       chastisement or pain on the day [of] reckoning. This is in contrast to the “extreme view” on the other
       side, which claims that it is possible for true Christians to be punished with eternal torment (losing
       eternal salvation). In light of these two “extremes,” the doctrine that unfaithful Christians (who do not
       repent in time) will be chastised at the Judgment Seat of Christ and banished during the Millennium,
       represents the MODERATE VIEW. It is able to combine the partial truth on both sides of the
       controversy. (Emphasis his.) 794

        Soteriologically, Faust’s preference in terminology is justifiable. When one considers that traditionalists
consign non-persevering believers to hell for eternity, the ultraistic misthological view of Gehenna, which teaches
that such believers literally will burn only for a thousand years, is much milder by comparison. Since the FG
position unconditionally guarantees eternal security to believers and since the ultra-misthological view is part of
that camp, the ultra-misthological view is admittedly a moderating soteriological view. However, Zeller’s
criticisms are soteriologically defective in combining soteriology and misthology by failing to distinguish
perseverance as a strictly misthological necessity. Therefore, when the range of views within the FG camp are
compared to one another misthologically (from which Zeller’s views would be excluded due to his soteriological
deficiency), the ultraistic position is truly seen to be at the extreme end of a purely misthological spectrum.
                              Illustration 151. What is a Classic Moderate Misthologist?
Chapter. 19. Historical Context of Outer Darkness                                                                            Page 459


       To restate in terms of the modified illustration above, ultraists are soteriological moderates and are pictured
as such in terms of the horizontal soteriological axis. A dip in the lake is not nearly as bad as spending eternity
there. The misthological claim that unfaithful believers spend 1000 years burning in Gehenna (or perhaps even the
Lake of Fire) is not nearly so terrifying as the Arminian and Calvinistic claims that they spend eternity burning in
the Lake of Fire. Zeller’s views lie somewhere off the vertical Marrowistic vertical axis. His views would be
located somewhere on the soteric horizontal axis (toward the Calvinistic direction) since his views are
soteriologically divergent from the Marrowistic affirmation of unconditional soteric security.

                                                            Conclusion
       The traditional group is composed of interpreters from all three camps—the Arminian, Free Grace, and
Calvinistic camps—and is the interpretation preferred by the majority in both the Lordship and FG camps.
However, the misthological interpretation, although preferred by the minority of interpreters, finds advocates in
each of the above-mentioned camps as well. Since there are Arminians, Calvinists, Lordship Salvationists, and
Free Grace Salvationists who advocate the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness, it appears that an
interpreter’s soteriology does not necessarily predetermine whether that interpreter will take a soteriological or
misthological view of the outer darkness. Nor does it rigidly determine the interpreter’s misthological preference.
       Nevertheless, the misthological view is more popular in the FG camp than in the LS camp, and for good
reason. It is much more consistent with FG theology to say that those believers who are cast into the outer darkness
should have performed much better than they did. To declare that all believers who do not go to hell must or will
live holy lives, as the Arminians and Calvinists do, resurfaces the problem of soteriological relativity in the
Arminian and Calvinistic camps. According to these schools of thought, believers must or will live relatively holy
lives. How holy? It depends on who is drawing the line and which passage is being discussed. A LS interpreter
may give the impression that a very high degree of morality is required when interpreting one passage of Scripture
and then give the impression that a very low degree of morality is acceptable when interpreting another passage. In
such cases, either the standard keeps changing (which means that God cannot make up His mind), or the interpreter
is being inconsistent. In terms of the morality and faithfulness required for salvation from eternal damnation, does
God require that believers merely slow down for a speed bump, or does He have higher requirements (which could
be pictured as jumping over a high jump or would it be more like a pole vault)? Or does He require absolute
perfection that can be imputed to believers only as a gift by grace? Those in the FG camp prefer the latter option.
       Far greater potential exists in the FG camp (than in the Arminian or Calvinistic camps) for soteriological
agreement that how holy one lives is soteriologically irrelevant. In FG theology, living a holy life does not
determine whether one is going to heaven. One should live a holy life, not in order to enter heaven, but in order to
gain rewards in heaven. Those within the FG camp are also in a much better position to state consistently that a
higher degree of practical righteousness is required to achieve the fullest potential of rewards and escape from the
outer darkness. Nevertheless, interpreters from the other camps are attracted to a misthological view of the outer
darkness, even though doing so poses problems of consistency with their soteriological positions.
       Consider the plight of Dyer, the moderate Lordship Salvationist cited above, who believes that initial
surrender is soteriologically necessary and that subsequent surrender is a misthological necessity.* Does it not seem
rather contradictory to say that initial surrender pertaining to one’s performance is required to escape hell but
subsequent surrender is not? Would it not be much more consistent to make such surrender the requirement for the
same issue rather than for two different things? FG theology is consistent: Surrender is a misthological
requirement, not a soteriological one. Discipleship is required to escape the outer darkness; it is not required to
escape hell.
       This same observation can be applied to those interpreters who believe that both initial and subsequent
surrender are soteriological necessities. Since genuine performance-related surrender entails works, those who
make such surrender a soteriological requirement make good works a requirement to reach heaven. They only
compound their inconsistency when they then acknowledge that surrender and its resultant good works are required
for rewards in heaven. By making such surrender a soteriological and misthological necessity, they fail to
distinguish between the two concepts and make surrender (and thus works) a requirement for both salvation and
rewards. Salvation from eternal damnation becomes a reward in perverted forms of the gospel.
       There is no need to be in the dark about the outer darkness. These passages concerning the outer darkness
have given misthologists an opportunity to make a clear and consistent distinction between salvation by grace and

*
    The Misslers could be cited also as an example of moderate Lordship Salvationists affirming a misthological outer darkness.
Page 460                                                                                                     The Outer Darkness
salvation by works. Rewards, both positive and negative, are always based on works, but salvation from eternal
damnation is never based on works.795
       Numerous indications within the parables concerning the outer darkness demonstrate that those being cast
into the outer darkness are genuine believers. They are identified as the sons of the kingdom (thus wheat) who have
the same relationship with the Lord as do those who are rewarded in the eschatological kingdom. They are
contrasted with the lost citizens who lose their lives (and who thereby are excluded from the eschatological
kingdom). Those cast into the outer darkness lose their privileges, not their lives. The temporal indicators of the
parables give sufficient grounds for concluding that those cast into the outer darkness experience their expulsion
after having first been raptured, judged, and allowed into the millennial kingdom. Further, it unduly strains the
imagery of the parables to think that the punishment being pictured is exile from the kingdom rather than mere
exclusion from the banquet within the kingdom. Therefore, the identifications, contrasts, temporal indicators, and
imagery given within the parables make it necessary to completely reject the traditional Arminian and Puritan
interpretations. The most natural interpretation is that Jesus is describing the judgment of genuine believers who
have been unfaithful and who consequently suffer loss within the kingdom rather than removal from the kingdom.
       The temporal indicators and imagery also throw the classical moderate and ultraistic FG interpretations into
serious question. The fate of these unfaithful believers is not exclusion from the kingdom nor burn time in
Gehenna. Since these unfaithful believers are not punished in Gehenna or outside the kingdom, is it realistic to
maintain that other unfaithful believers suffer such a fate? Proper interpretation of the outer darkness makes the
classical moderate and ultraistic FG positions very difficult to accept and certainly places the burden of proof on
those advocating these positions when dealing with passages describing entrance into the kingdom and
confinement in Gehenna. One would tend to think that since the unfaithful believers in these parables are allowed
into the kingdom rather than punished in Gehenna, other passages dealing with unfaithful believers would likewise
present them as being punished inside the kingdom rather than outside of it.
       As a result, of the interpretive options surveyed thus far, the conservative FG interpretation of the outer
darkness is the one which accords most fully with the major tenets derived directly from the texts pertaining to the
outer darkness, and it is also the one which is made most likely in dealing with other passages concerning the fate
of unfaithful believers. The message of the outer darkness is that unfaithful believers do exist, they will be judged,
they will suffer loss in the kingdom (not outside of it), but they will not be cast into Gehenna.
       This adherence to the conservative understanding of the outer darkness does not mean that conservative
assumptions concerning the implications of the outer darkness are always preferable, however. Sometimes
moderates and ultraists have a better grasp of the implications of the outer darkness in relation to other
interconnected misthological concepts than do conservatives. Wholesale endorsement or rejection of these
competing misthological approaches would not be prudent. Adopting the strengths of each methodology and
forming a consistent misthology is preferable.* But before doing so, however, in the next chapter I will respond to
the soteriological claim by traditionalists that the intertestamental period rules out a misthological understanding of
the outer darkness.




*
 When further implications are factored into consideration, the preference herein will be for a conservative-moderate position. See
Progressive Moderates (PM), 568.
                                       Chapter 20.
                        Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness
                                                   Introduction
        The counterargument has been posed by some within the traditional camp that an analysis of extra biblical
material is detrimental to a misthological understanding of the outer darkness. In response, this chapter will go
back in time, beyond the history of interpretation as represented by the church described in the previous chapter, to
the intertestamental time period in order to evaluate the claim that this body of intertestamental literature reinforces
the traditional soteriological view of the outer darkness, especially as to whether the influence would have been so
great as to be a controlling factor in the NT usage.
        Discussions of apocalypticism deal foremost with Daniel, 1 & 2 Enoch, 4 Ezra, 2 & 3 Apocalypse of
Baruch, the Apocalypse of Abraham, and Revelation.796 Since the focus of this chapter is the apocalyptic literature
of the intertestamental period, it will examine the writings of this genre that were composed in between the
completion of the Old Testament and the New Testament: 1 Enoch and 2 Enoch.797 These two works are saturated
with the doctrine of eternal rewards and consequently may form an important stepping stone between the Old and
New Testaments. In accordance with the usage thus far employed, misthology and its derivatives are used herein to
refer almost exclusively to the doctrine of eschatological (i.e., misthological) rewards, whether they are received in
the intermediate or eternal state. The focus of these apocalyptic writings and this current study is not that of
immediate retribution (temporal misthology).
        The writers of 1 & 2 Enoch acknowledge that it is possible for the wicked to prosper and go unpunished in
this life. In moving from the primarily temporal misthology of the Old Testament to a misthology which is
eschatological and personal, these noncanonical writings assume that good people are eschatologically rewarded in
one sphere of reality while bad people are punished in a completely different sphere of eschatological reality. Or in
laymen terms, the intertestamental presupposition is that good people go to heaven and bad people go to hell.
        The soteriological shortcomings of this misthology are apparent. The NT advances far beyond this
noncanonical soteriology by advancing beyond the misthological foundation of this intertestamental genre.
Consequently, one byproduct of this research will be the demonstration that the soteriological superiority of the NT
over these pseudepigraphal works is due largely to the advanced misthology of the NT. However, the primary
reason for this study is to examine the background for the outer darkness. Both 1 and 2 Enoch have numerous
references to the darkness as an eschatological punishment, and 1 Enoch provides a possible backdrop for
Matthew’s outer darkness.

Dating
       Concerning the apocalyptic literature mentioned above, Daniel is excluded from consideration since it is
part of the OT and thus does not belong to the intertestamental period. Likewise, Revelation is excluded since it
belongs to the NT period. The other writings (4 Ezra, 2 & 3 Apocalypse of Baruch, the Apocalypse of Abraham)
also belong to the NT period or later and thus are also excluded from this intertestamental study.798
       In regard to 1 & 2 Enoch, Milik’s controversial dating of the Similitudes of Enoch and 2 Enoch as late
Christian compositions rests primarily on an argument from silence (i.e., their absence from the Qumran literature).
The most substantial arguments for both of these noncanonical books still point to a pre-Christian composition.799
Suter acknowledges that Milik’s argument from silence is the keystone of Milik’s dating and that it is very
problematic.800 Although Isaac also recognizes that Milik’s dating is “not supported by any solid evidence,” he
accepts Milik’s grouping of 1 Enoch into five books, using it within his own translation and giving it in his
introduction:

           1.   The Book of Watchers (1-36)
           2.   The Book of Similitudes (37-71)
           3.   The Book of Astronomical Writings (72-82)
           4.   The Book of Dream Visions (83-90)
           5.   The Book of the Epistle of Enoch (91-107).801

       The consensus of the Pseudepigrapha Seminar is that the Book of Similitudes dates from the first century
A.D., whereas previously it was dated as first century B.C. It is sufficient for present purposes to conclude that
“1 Enoch is a collection of apocalyptic traditions and writings of diverse genre and date, composed during the last
three centuries B.C.E. and accumulated in stages.”802 Although scholars cannot agree on the dating of the books or
Page 462                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                        803
even their subsections, we may be content with the dating of 1 Enoch (also known as Ethiopic Enoch) as an
intertestamental writing. Consequently, “there is little doubt that 1 Enoch was influential in molding New
Testament doctrines concerning the…final judgment.”804
       The historical significance of 2 Enoch (Slavonic Enoch) is smaller since the disagreement concerning its
date is greater. Although Andersen concedes this limitation, he is inclined to date it “early rather than late,” as a
Jewish, pre-Christian writing.805 Its simple soteriology reflects its simple misthology: “A blessed afterlife is strictly
a reward for right ethical behavior.”806 The procedure in the current book will be to examine the works as a whole
and compare them to each other and the NT rather than attempt to break the documents up into their constituent
sources and then try to compare these hypothetical parts with each other.807

                                                      1 Enoch

Soteriological Works
        The most important observation to be made about these documents is that their soteriology and misthology
completely overlap. They teach salvation by works and rewards by works: Salvation is their reward, and their
reward is salvation. 1 Enoch is typical of this legalistic genre. The deeds of the people will be weighed in the
balance, and this weighing of deeds will determine who is a sinner and who is righteous (1En 41:1-2; cf. 61:8).
They are “righteous because they have hated and despised this world of oppression (together with) all its ways of
life and its habits” (48:7). In contrast to sinners (oppressors), the righteous have “no record of oppression” written
against them (81:4). They are the “upright” (81:4) who “do right” (81:9).
        Enoch’s paraenesis to others is to “repent and forsake” their deeds (50:2), since the unrepentant will perish
(50:4). The paraenesis for his righteous children is not to walk in evil lest they too be destroyed; they are to “walk
in the way of peace so that [they] shall have life and be worthy!” They must “hold fast” his words (94:1-5). These
ethical exhortations are addressed by Enoch to his children so that they might “walk in the way of righteousness,”
rather than in wickedness and injustice and so perish (91:19). Those who “walk in the path of his righteousness and
[do] not become wicked…shall be saved” (99:10). They will “inherit the earth” (5:7) and “inherit eternal life”
(40:9). They will have access to the “fragrant tree” and “its fruit for life” (25:4-5). They will wear “garments of
life” (62:16) and sit upon his throne of honor (108:13).
        When Enoch warns the sinners that their creator will throw them down on their own righteousness and show
them no mercy (94:10), it is tempting to read NT or even OT theology (e.g., Is 64:6) into this statement and make it
mean that no one can be saved on the basis of his or her own righteousness. Not so! As has just been indicated,
from the perspective of 1 Enoch, self-righteousness is the very thing that will tip the scales in favor of the righteous
and save them from damnation. The punishment of the wicked is due to the fact that they do not have enough self-
righteousness to save them whereas the righteous do. Wicked sinners are often identified as rich oppressors, but
these lost sinners may simply be those “who do evil” or “who err” or defile their bodies (108:6-7).

Faith
        This joint doctrine of salvation-rewards by works does not fail to include faith as an essential element in
1 Enoch (41:5; 43:3-5; 58:5; 61:4,11; 63:5-8; 67:8,10,13; 69:25; 94:8; 104:13). But these references to faith are
extremely infrequent in comparison to the dominant emphasis on works. Furthermore, all but two references (94:8;
104:13) are limited to the Book of Similitudes (chs. 37-71). If the Book of Similitudes is from the late first century,
as has been assumed, then it might be expected to be influenced by the NT or Christian tradition. In other words,
the faith that turned the world upside down may have influenced this document’s inclusion of faith.
        On the other hand, there is no reason to suspect Christian influence in many of the references, and in none of
the instances is it certain. Therefore, their genuineness, as an expression of Judaic thought of the first century, will
be given the benefit of the doubt. As a result, it may be assumed that one of the many requirements to be holy is to
“believe in the name of the Lord of the Spirits” (43:4). Another reason for considering this phrase to be genuine is
due to the existence of parallels where it is said that they “cling to the Lord of Spirits,” “lean upon the name of the
Lord of Spirits,” and appeal to His name (46:8; 45:3; 61:3). To cling to Him, lean upon Him, appeal to Him, and
believe in Him are probably just different ways of saying the same thing: they rely on Him; they trust Him. Thus,
the warning against apostasy in 81:8 may include a warning against denying His name by ceasing to believe in His
name. Warnings against denying His name (41:2; 45:2; 46:7; 48:10; 67:8) have similar metaphorical parallels
(46:5-6; 60:6; 67:11) and provide contrasts to the metaphorical exhortations to believe in His name. The overall
impression created by the metaphors, parallels, and contrasts is that although the emphasis on believing is rather
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                        Page 463
minor compared to the emphasis on ethical behavior, nevertheless, the emphasis on belief is well-integrated into
the text and is not due to Christian redaction, much less to Christian interpolation.
        As a result, 63:5-8 becomes rather remarkable as a potentially genuine expression of the Jewish apocalyptic
traditions that were current in the century in which Jesus taught:

            Would that someone had given us a chance so that we should glorify, praise, and have
       faith…darkness has become our habitation forever and ever; because we have formerly neither had
       faith nor glorified the name of the Lord of the Spirits….We had put our hope upon [cf. 94:8] the
       scepters of our empires. Now…he is not saving us; and we have no chance to become believers.
       [1En 63:5-8; lit. “to believe,” cf. 67:8]

        These tormented sinners now know that they should have believed—that is, they should have put their hope
upon and trusted in the Lord of Spirits. However, after death it is too late to believe, that is, to put their hopes upon
or to trust in the Lord of Spirits for salvation. Such soteriological expressions of faith would be on a par with some
of those in the NT if it were not for the wider context. According to 1 Enoch, faith is necessary, but it is not
sufficient. Faith must result in good works in order to be saving faith. Ultimately, the righteous are those who
persevere in faith and works. This theology, in which salvation ultimately depends on faith and works or faith that
works, is the theology of many NT interpreters in the LS camp. But it is not the theology of the NT. On the
contrary, LS is the theology of 1 Enoch!

Enoch’s Darkness

                                            Matthew’s Outer Darkness
       The failure of NT interpreters to distinguish between the theology of 1 Enoch and the theology of the NT is
perhaps best illustrated in their treatment of the outer darkness in Matthew. It is of little surprise that
Pagenkemper’s rebuttal of the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness is based, in part, on the
intertestamental literature.808 The common assumption is that the outer darkness may be simply equated with the
soteriological darkness of 1 Enoch. For example, Sim argues that the background for the outer darkness in
Mt 22:13 is found in 1 Enoch 10:4. He acknowledges that the two passages “are not similar in wording.”809 But on
the basis of the structure, he agrees with Rubinkiewiez that Mt 22:13 is a citation of 1 En 10:4.810 Both texts agree
word for word in the phrase: “Him into the darkness.” Matthew, however, adds outer to this phrase. Repeatedly,
Sim glosses over the significance of this addition. The addition of this Matthean description outer is surely very
important, being repeated three times: in texts dealing with “the children of the kingdom” (Mt 8:12), the king’s
friend (Mt 22:13), and his own servants in the kingdom (Mt 25:30). Yet the significance of these texts and this
addition is lost on Sim, as is clearly seen as he proceeds to try to answer his own question, “How are we to account
for the many differences between the Gospel verse and its parallel”?811
       The last difference he notes is the most interesting. 1 Enoch uses ballo for cast while Matthew uses ekballo
(cast out). If Matthew is indeed citing 1 Enoch, why does he not use the same form of the word? Is it merely to be
emphatic? No. Sim himself shows that there must be more to it than mere emphasis. Matthew’s usage of these two
words throughout his Gospel reflects his theology.

             These words are not synonymous for Matthew; each has a specific usage. Bavllw [ballo] is
       always used to describe the casting of the wicked into the eternal fire [3:10; 5:29-30; 7:19; 13:42,50;
       18:8-9], while ejkbavllw [ekballo] always describes their (prior) exclusion from the eschatological
       kingdom. In Matthew’s view of the eschatological fate of the wicked, the offenders are first cast out
       (ejkbavllw) of the kingdom of God and then thrown (Bavllw) into the fire of Gehenna. Since
       Mt. 22:13a deals solely with their expulsion from the kingdom and not with their ensuing
       punishment, Matthew’s use of ejkbavllw rather than Bavllw…is perfectly understandable.812

       Sim’s own analysis demonstrates that the word Matthew uses for cast (ekballo) in the expression, “cast into
the outer darkness,” is never used by Matthew to denote being cast into fire, hell, or Gehenna. By Sim’s own
admission, ekballo deals with the eschatological kingdom rather than an eschatological fire. Sim’s statement
that they experience a double casting is totally unwarranted and unsupported.813 He assumes that they are cast out
of the kingdom (although the imagery indicates that it is not the kingdom itself from which they are expelled), and
Sim imagines that they are subsequently cast into Gehenna. His position is that of one assumption built upon
another. A far better solution would be to acknowledge that the two different words for casting are used in two
Page 464                                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
different ways because they are describing two different groups of people. Sim’s own findings would suggest this
conclusion since he believes that the ekballo, which is used consistently in the outer darkness passages, is not
synonymous with ballo. Thus, ekballo is not used in reference to eternal damnation. The conclusion that would
most naturally suggest itself as worthy of investigation is that those who are cast into the outer darkness do not
undergo eternal damnation. Unfortunately, Sim is so blinded by tradition that he does not see the obvious, as is
demonstrated by the fact that he fails to pursue or even consider this logical possibility.
        If Sim is correct that “bavllw [ballo] is always used to describe the casting of the wicked into the eternal
fire,” then it could be concluded that ballo is used soteriologically to describe the judgment of the lost, and ekballo
is used misthologically to describe the judgment of the saved. The words used to describe their casting and the
darkness into which they are cast are different because two different types of darkness are being described.
        Although Sim’s assumption that ekballo is always used soteriologically in eschatological contexts is
generally correct, there is one exception (Mt 5:25) that makes a more detailed investigation necessary. For the sake
of completeness, Luke’s use of ballo and ekballo also should be taken into consideration.
                                 Illustration 152. Eschatological Usage of Ballo and Ekballo
                                                                   Matthew
                                                           ballo                                  ekballo
                      soteriological     3:10; 5:29-30; 7:19; 13:42,48,50, 18:8-9                    
                      misthological      5:25                                               8:12; 22:13; 25:30

                                                                          Luke
                                                              Ballo                              ekballo
                      soteriological     3:9                                                13:28
                      misthological      12:58                                                       

       Mt 5:25-26; 18:34-35; and Lk 12:58-59 deal with the same truth. As believers, we already have
soteriological forgiveness of all our sins. The general perception is that this is the type of forgiveness that Jesus
pictures in Mt 18:27 where “the lord of that slave felt compassion and released him and forgave him the debt.” As
a result of this forgiveness, the slave was spared the punishment that had been decreed: “But since he did not have
the means to repay, his lord commanded him to be sold, along with his wife and children and all that he had, and
repayment to be made” (Mt 18:25). As for those who prefer to think of the initial forgiveness as soteriological,
Marrowists can be accommodating by picturing this forgiveness as being saved from the Lake of Fire by grace. As
a result of this gracious forgiveness, the slave’s subsequent failure to demonstrate his lord’s merciful nature is not
dealt with in the manner originally specified in that his property, wife, and children are not sold. Yet, as the slave
soon discovers, this original forgiveness did not entitle him to act in a reprehensible fashion.
       Our misthological forgiveness of our postconversion sins depends on our dealings with others, especially
with our fellow believers, referred to as my brother (Mt 18:21; cp. 6:12). Jesus goes on to portray this reality by
describing what happens to the slave after his initial forgiveness.

        “And his lord, moved with anger, handed [paradidomi] him over to the torturers [jailers] until he
        should repay all that was owed him. So shall My heavenly Father also do to you [Peter, etc., 18:21] if
        each of you does not forgive his brother from your heart” (Mt 18:34-35).

       The Lord has “forgiven us all our transgressions” (Col 2:13), the entire debt (Mt 18:27), both preconversion
and postconversion sins. Nevertheless, our postconversion sins still will be judged misthologically at the Judgment
Seat of Christ. The issue is no longer the Lake of Fire. The slave’s debt was dealt with in an entirely different
manner after his soteriological forgiveness pictured in 18:27.* He, his wife, children, and property were not sold.
Rather, he was only jailed—a picture of misthological punishment, not soteriological punishment. Notwithstanding
the lesser nature of this punishment, it is still not to be taken lightly.


*
 The possibility of a soteric interpretation of Mt 18:37 is being entertained at this point to demonstrate potential conformity with the
popular expectation that such is the case and to show that my preference for misthological forgiveness is not incompatible with such a
view. Nevertheless, my exegetical preference is to regard v. 27 as a picture of temporal forgiveness. See The Parable of the Lost
Talents (Mt 18:21-35), 405.
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                         Page 465
          Make friends quickly with your opponent at law while you are with him on the way, in order that
          your opponent may not deliver you to the judge, and the judge to the officer, and you be thrown
          [ballo] into prison. Truly I say to you, you shall not come out of there, until you have paid up the last
          cent. (Mt 5:25-26)

          For while you are going with your opponent to appear before the magistrate, on your way there make
          an effort to settle with him, in order that he may not drag you before the judge, and the judge turn you
          over to the constable, and the constable throw [ballo] you into prison. I say to you, you shall not get
          out of there until you have paid the very last cent. (Lk 12:58-59).

       Matthew’s use of ballo in 5:25 parallels his use of ekballo in all three passages concerning the outer
darkness. What is being pictured is not loss of life or exclusion from the king’s kingdom. It is an impoverished
experience within the eschatological kingdom. Believers already have been graciously forgiven of all their sins:
preconversion and postconversion, omission and commission. Yet what they do or fail to do after the forgiveness
granted them at conversion still will be judged, but these sins will not be dealt with in the same way as those sins of
the unconverted since believers have been forgiven in terms of the Lake of Fire. The Lord cannot go back on the
type and scope of the forgiveness that already has been granted.
       Although Matthew and Luke use the same word ekballo, they use it in two different ways. Luke uses it
synonymously with ballo to refer to soteriological exclusion from the kingdom in the fire (Lk 3:9; 13:28). Luke
also uses ballo misthologically (Lk 12:58), but he does not use ekballo in this misthological sense. Matthew,
likewise, uses ballo misthologically (Mt 5:25) and soteriologically (Mt 3:10; 5:29-30; 7:19; 13:42,48,50; 18:8-9).
But Matthew uses ekballo synonymously with ballo to refer to misthological imprisonment within the kingdom
(Mt 5:25; 22:13). Neither writer uses ballo to distinguish between soteriological and misthological punishment.
Luke only uses ekballo once eschatologically (Lk 13:28):

          There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth there when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and
          all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but yourselves being cast out.

       Luke uses ekballo soteriologically in reference to the removal of unbelievers from the present mystery form
of the kingdom when it is transformed into its future eschatological form, the millennial kingdom.* Luke’s choice
of ekballo in this verse does not parallel Matthew’s eschatological usage of this verb. Instead, Luke’s usage
parallels his own predominant habit of using ekballo to describe the casting out of demons (Lk 9:40,49; 11:14-15,
18-20; 13:32).

          And I begged Your disciples to cast it out, and they could not (Lk 9:40).

          And John answered and said, “Master, we saw someone casting out demons in Your name; and we
          tried to hinder him because he does not follow along with us” (Lk 9:49).

          And He was casting out a demon, and it was dumb; and it came about that when the demon had gone
          out, the dumb man spoke; and the multitudes marveled. 15But some of them said, “He casts out
          demons by Beelzebul, the ruler of the demons” (Lk 11:14-15).

          And if Satan also is divided against himself, how shall his kingdom stand? For you say that I cast out
          demons by Beelzebul. 19And if I by Beelzebul cast out demons, by whom do your sons cast them
          out? Consequently they shall be your judges. 20But if I cast out demons by the finger of God, then
          the kingdom of God has come upon you (Lk 11:18-20).

          And He said to them, “Go and tell that fox, ‘Behold, I cast out demons and perform cures today and
          tomorrow, and the third day I reach My goal.’” (Lk 13:32).

       In reading Lk 13:28 in conjunction with its context (Lk 13:32), it is seen that Jesus casts unbelievers out of
the kingdom just as He casts demons out of a person. No matter how good people think they are(Lk 13:26-27), they

*
    See Illustration 147. Forms of the Kingdom, 436.
Page 466                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
will experience the same fate as the demons if they are trusting in that goodness as a reason God should let them
into heaven (Lk 13:25). Just as the commencement of the present form of the kingdom was marked by the casting
out of demons from the people in which they then lived (Lk 11:20), so the commencement of the future form of the
kingdom will be marked by the casting out of unbelievers from the present form of the kingdom in which they now
live (Lk 13:28).814

           And He was passing through from one city and village to another, teaching, and proceeding on His
          22

          way to Jerusalem. 23And someone said to Him, “Lord, are there just a few who are being saved?”
          And He said to them, 24“Strive to enter by the narrow door; for many, I tell you, will seek to enter
          and will not be able. 25Once the head of the house gets up and shuts the door, and you begin to stand
          outside and knock on the door, saying, ‘Lord, open up to us!’ then He will answer and say to you, ‘I
          do not know where you are from.’ 26Then you will begin to say, ‘We ate and drank in Your presence,
          and You taught in our streets’; 27and He will say, ‘I tell you, I do not know where you are from;
          DEPART FROM ME, ALL YOU EVILDOERS.’ 28There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth there when
          you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but yourselves
          being cast out [ekballo]. 29And they will come from east and west, and from north and south, and
          will recline at the table in the kingdom of God. 30And behold, some are last who will be first and
          some are first who will be last.”
               31Just at that time some Pharisees came up, saying to Him, “Go away and depart from here, for

          Herod wants to kill You.” 32And He said to them, “Go and tell that fox, ‘Behold, I cast out [ekballo]
          demons and perform cures today and tomorrow, and the third day I reach My goal’” (Lk 13:22-32).

       In response to the soteriological question concerning who is being saved in v. 23, Jesus gives a
soteriological answer in vv. 24-28. To be saved means to enter the future kingdom, and to enter the future
kingdom means to be saved. Those who are saved are those who enter the kingdom. Basic entrance into the
kingdom is a soteriological issue, not a misthological one. (This observation argues in favor of the conservative FG
view of the outer darkness rather than either the classical moderate or the ultraistic view.) Being cast out of the
kingdom is likewise a soteriological issue rather than a misthological one. No believer is cast out of the kingdom
since every believer is soteriologically secure. Marrowists therefore may agree with Keathley,

          This passage is obviously about salvation because it is part of the answer to the question asked in
          Luke 13:23, “Lord are there just a few who are being saved?” Those who enter by the narrow gate are
          saved and are pictured eating at the banquet with Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. Those who are not saved
          will be weeping and gnashing their teeth at being “cast out.”815

But then Keathley immediately goes on to assert,

          Here we have a direct parallel with the imagery of Matthew 8:12 and the Matthew 22 passage.
          Although the term “outer darkness” is not used, the phrase “cast out” carries the same connotation.816

        Although Keathley has requested that we ignore the details of the parable,* it would seem more prudent to at
least point out just a few. To be fair, if Keathley is going to use the details to note the similarities of the two
parables, then it would be wise, on the same basis, to note the dissimilarities of those parables as well. First, it
should be noted that in Mt 8:5-13 it is the sons of the kingdom who are cast out. In Lk 13:22-32 it is those who
think they are saved but in reality are not saved who are cast out. This does not necessarily indicate that the same
group of people is in view. That one group is not really saved does not prove that those in the other parable are not
really sons. Second, Matthew does not specify what they were cast out of—it could be the kingdom or the banquet.
We already have considered reasons for not equating the kingdom with the banquet and for concluding that it was
the banquet rather than the kingdom from which the sons were cast. Third, one should consider what form of the
kingdom they were cast out from. It is the present mystery form, not the future millennial form of the kingdom
from which those in Luke are cast. Thus, they are cast out before the eschatological banquet starts. Further, in
Matthew the order is the reverse of what it is in Luke. In the Matthean account, the reclining at table is mentioned
beforehand and presumably precedes the casting out. It is not necessary to suppose that the difference in order is

*
    See Deductive Approach, 7.
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                                  Page 467
accidental or incidental; rather, it is definitely intentional. Matthew emphatically confirms this order in his next
parable on the outer darkness. The man is explicitly reported to be cast out after the feast starts in Mt 22:11-13.*
        Furthermore, Luke even sequentially appears to add a misthological warning concerning eschatological
kingdom status relative to the seating order at the banquet itself. The numbers being saved are fewer than the
disciples think. Many of the present workers in the mystery form of the kingdom will be found to be workers of
unrighteousness who trusted in their works for kingdom entrance and who, therefore, are denied eschatological
entrance into the kingdom and thus are expelled from the present form of the kingdom when this temporal
transition to the future form of the kingdom takes place. Yet even those for whom the entrance into the future
kingdom is opened will subsequently find themselves arranged from first to last (in relation feast) after they enter
that future kingdom. Sequence is significant.
                                   Illustration 153. Sequence and Significance of Casting

                    Lk 13:22-32                                                          Mt 8:5-13
      Lost Cast Out                              Then Banquet                                  Then Sons Cast Out
         No Place                           First versus Last Place                                  Least Place

        In the above chart, the lost are cast out of the kingdom before the banquet commences (Lk 13:28). They will
have no place at the banquet. After they are cast out of the kingdom, the banquet starts within the kingdom
(Lk 13:29). This Lukan sequence of casting preceding reclining prohibits one from equating the casting here with
that in Matthew where the sequence is reclining preceding casting. Luke deals with the soteriological exclusion
from the kingdom before the banquet starts; Matthew is relating information concerning the misthological
exclusion after the banquet starts. Among those who remain in the kingdom, there will be a ranking ranging from
first to last place in terms of their table status, but first to least place in regards to their kingdom status.† In this
kingdom ranking, which takes place after the banquet starts, the sons of the kingdom who have exhibited the most
faith will be given a place at the head of the table; those believers who have demonstrated a moderate amount of
faith will be given a seat at the lower end of the table;‡ those believers who have displayed the least amount of faith
will be given no place at the table. Those believers who are found to be unworthy of the banquet will be cast out of
the banquet into the darkness outside.
                                               Illustration 154. Two Exclusions




      Luke ties the first and last place together with the eschatological form of the kingdom relative to the table in
Lk 13:29-30. Matthew also does practically the same thing in 19:28-30, with misthological ranking/ruling in the
millennial kingdom (relative to those who will be considered faithful workers). In comparison with Mt 5:19-20,
one may summarize the significance concerning the timing of the casting by saying that the lost are cast out of the

*
  See Time of Rejection is After the Feast Starts, 423. Correlativity would be more reasonable than Keathley’s equality.
†
  See Illustration 231. Last is not Least, 683.
‡
  Midcomers is a coined term for those semi-faithful believers who have demonstrated a moderate amount of faith and faithfulness so
that they are qualified only to sit at the lower end of the table.
Page 468                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
mystery form of the kingdom before the millennial banquet begins. The lost will have no place in that kingdom.
They will be excluded from the kingdom itself and therefore have no place in it. Next, after the millennial kingdom
has commenced, the first order of business will be to deal with seating arrangements. Those who have dressed
themselves in white garments will be given places of honor at the table ranging from first to last. Those who have
failed to dress themselves properly will be excluded from the table and have no place at the table, but at least they
will be in the kingdom, although they have least place in the kingdom. The distinction between first, last, and least
place is thus a misthological contrast.*
        This further narrowing of the scope of salvation is seen in that Jesus adds an additional teaching introduced
by the word and (kai) in Lk 13:29. Having responded to their remark that just a few are saved (and thus will be in
the kingdom), Jesus reminds them that not all who are saved (i.e., not all who will be in the kingdom) will have
first place in it. Not only are there just a few who are being saved (and who will thus enter the eschatological
kingdom), but there are also just a few who are saved who will have first place in it (and recline at the table, much
less be at the head of the table, in the eschatological kingdom). Correspondingly, Lk 13:29-30 adds a misthological
dimension to the discussion. It is Jesus’ way of saying that we should not be content with merely entering the
kingdom, but rather we should strive to have first place in the kingdom. Do not be satisfied with being in the
kingdom. Seek first place (i.e., a place at the head of the table in the kingdom).
        Ekballo is the standard word for casting out demons in Matthew’s gospel as well as in Luke’s gospel, but
Matthew does not even remotely equate demonic expulsion with being cast out (ekballo) into the outer darkness in
Mt 22:13 or 25:30. Ekballo is used in the general proximity of the outer darkness of Mt 8:12, but it is not
associated with this usage regarding demonic expulsion. In Mt 7:22, on the other hand, ekballo is found on the lips
of those who are denied entrance into the kingdom despite their casting out demons.

          21Not everyone who says to Me, “Lord, Lord,” will enter the kingdom of heaven; but he who does
          the will of My Father who is in heaven. 22Many will say to Me on that day, “Lord, Lord, did we not
          prophesy in Your name, and in Your name cast out demons, and in Your name perform many
          miracles?” 23And then I will declare to them, “I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice
          lawlessness” (Mt 7:21-23).

        This Matthean passage is parallel to Lk 13:23-27. Entrance into the kingdom is a soteriological issue. All
who are saved will enter the kingdom. Entrance into the kingdom is not based on works but upon meeting the
Father’s requirement for entrance—to believe.817 Whereas Luke associates this denied entrance into the future
eschatological kingdom (Lk 13:23-27) with being cast out of the present mystery form of the kingdom (Lk 13:28),
Matthew does not. Matthew’s discussion of being cast out in Mt 8:12 is not linked with the casting out of demons
in Mt 7:22 nor with the denial of Mt 7:23. On the contrary, he records these teachings as happening on two
different occasions. The teaching in chapter 7 is part of the Sermon on the Mount; the teaching in chapter 8 is given
after Jesus comes down from the mountain. Matthew’s use of ekballo in the soteriological passage of 7:21-23 has
nothing to do with his misthological usage of ekballo in 8:12. In the former passage it is used of demons who are
cast out in the present time period; it is not used of casting out that occurs in an eschatological time period. In
contrast, in Mt 8:12 it is used of eschatological expulsion.
        Likewise, the account of casting out demons in Mt 8:16 is given at a different time and place than when
Mt 8:12 is spoken. There is no reason to assume a word play here. In contrast, Jesus’ words about casting out are
spoken on the same occasion in Lk 13:28,32. Luke stresses that these words are spoken at the same time and place:
“Just at that time” (Lk 13:31). Therefore, Luke is likely indicating that on this particular occasion Jesus uses a
word play to point to the parallel between unbelievers being cast out then and demons being cast out now.
        Matthew and Luke’s eschatological usage of ballo is similar. They both use it soteriologically and
misthologically. And although both use ekballo in reference to demonic expulsion, they use it differently when
they use it eschatologically. Matthew uses ekballo to refer to the misthological aspect of Jesus’ teaching; Luke uses
it to refer to the soteriological parallel of demonic expulsion. That Jesus uses ekballo in various ways is well
attested to by John. In Jn 6:37, Jesus says that He will not cast out anyone who comes to Him, but in Jn 10:4 He
says that He will put forth those who come to Him. The word Jesus uses in both verses is ekballo. Obviously, there
is a sense in which believers can be cast out and another sense in which they cannot be cast out—if ekballo is
translated as cast out in both verses. Believers, demons, and unbelievers are used as the object of being cast out
(ekballo). The context determines who is cast out and from what they are cast out.

*
    See Illustration 232. Kingdom Ranking, 684.
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                        Page 469
        The questions are not, “Does Jesus use ekballo in various ways?” or “Does He use it of believers?” He
certainly does both. The point is that sensitivity must be shown to each gospel writer’s context in order to discern
the particular emphasis of Jesus’ teaching that is being set forth by each respective writer. Matthew focuses our
attention on that part of Jesus’ teaching in which Jesus uses ekballo to refer to the misthological experience of
those who are saved. In Matthew’s eschatological usage of these verbs, ekballo is always used to describe the
misthological judgment of the saved, never to describe the soteriological judgment of the lost. Matthew generally
uses ballo in reference to the soteriological judgment of the lost.
        Luke, however, does not have Matthew’s emphasis on the soteriological usage of ballo nor his sharp
contrast with the misthological usage of ekballo. Their emphasis, contrasts, and usages are different but not in
conflict. Jesus uses both emphases in His teaching and uses these verbs in the manner presented by both writers.
Nevertheless, the writers focus the attention of their readers on particular emphases and usages rather than every
emphasis and usage. Matthew’s eschatological usage of ekballo ≠ Luke’s eschatological usage of ekballo. The
darkness outside the feast is for believers; the darkness outside the kingdom is for unbelievers.
        Therefore, multiple contextual contrasts indicate that the expulsion experienced by the workers of
unrighteousness in Lk 13:28 is not the same as that experienced by the children of the kingdom in Mt 8:12: (1) the
sequence of reclining in relation to casting is inverted;* (2) the expulsion is an explanation of absence of faith on
the part of those who are not being saved in Luke whereas the Matthean focus is on the degree of faith on the part
of those dining; (3) there is an eschatological differentiation between how both writers implement the verb cast out.
Therefore, for sequential, contextual, and lexical reasons, the workers of unrighteousness in Luke should not be
equated with the children of the kingdom in Matthew.818 Although the same word (i.e., ekballo) is used to describe
their fate, they do not share the same fate. The distinction in their fates must be affirmed from the contexts.†
        Likewise, concerning the relationship between Matthew and 1 Enoch, Matthew’s outer darkness is not to be
equated with the darkness and fire of 1 Enoch; the context of both writings makes this differentiation necessary. In
conclusion concerning the Matthean usage, it must be stressed that the context of Matthew’s outer darkness forbids
it being identified with Enoch’s darkness. Matthew’s outer darkness is strictly misthological, whereas Enoch’s
darkness is a combination of soteriology and misthology. The darkness being referred to in these two works is not
identical.

                                               Jude’s Darkness
      Quite the opposite is true in the book of Jude. Both 1 Enoch and Jude are referring to the same darkness.
The judgment referred to in Jude 1:14-15 is the same as 1En 1:9.

          14And about these also Enoch, in the seventh generation from Adam, prophesied, saying, “Behold, the
          Lord came with many thousands of His holy ones, 15to execute judgment upon all, and to convict all
          the ungodly of all their ungodly deeds which they have done in an ungodly way, and of all the harsh
          things which ungodly sinners have spoken against Him” (Jude 1:14-15).

          Behold, he will arrive with ten million of the holy ones in order to execute judgment upon all. He will
          destroy the wicked ones and censure all flesh on account of everything that they have done, that
          which sinners and the wicked ones committed against him (1En 1:9).

The relationship between these two passages is well stated by Hiebert:

          The apocryphal Book of Enoch, compiled during the first century B.C. from some apocryphal works
          belonging to the last two centuries B.C., exerted a strong and widespread influence on Jewish and
          early Christian literature…
               When Jude wrote, “Enoch…prophesied saying”…he clearly accepted it as a historical fact…it is
          found in the Book of Enoch (1:9) with some variations…the quotation was drawn from the Book of
          Enoch. But this does not mean that Jude accepted the Book of Enoch as inspired or that he approved
          of all its contents. It simply means that under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit he accepted the
          statement as true.819


*
    For discussion of reclining, see Table Exclusion, 563.
†
    See Reclining then Casting, 433.
Page 470                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
The biblical writers did not consider all their oral and written sources to be inspired. Many of their sources, such as
1 Enoch, contained “some truth and a good deal of error.”820 But writing under inspiration, the biblical writers only
accepted as true that part of their sources that was actually true. Or as the old adage goes, all that is in the Bible is
true, but not all truth is in the Bible. There are many truths in worldly texts. A math book, for example, contains
truths not found in the Bible. Both Jude and Enoch are referring to the eternal punishment of the wicked in
darkness (Jude 1:6,13).821 And both writers make a truthful statement about that punishment. Hiebert is correct that
Jude is referring to the unregenerate wicked in vv. 12-13.

        And angels who did not keep their own domain, but abandoned their proper abode, He has kept in
        eternal bonds under darkness for the judgment of the great day. (Jude 1:6)

        These men are those who are hidden reefs in your love feasts when they feast with you without fear,
        caring for themselves; clouds without water, carried along by winds; autumn trees without fruit,
        doubly dead, uprooted; 13wild waves of the sea, casting up their own shame like foam; wandering
        stars, for whom the black darkness has been reserved forever. (Jude 1:12-13)

        Hiebert is also very perceptive when he argues that these unregenerate wicked are described as hidden rocks
or reefs beneath the surface of the water and pose a genuine threat that morally may shipwreck genuine
believers.822 Using the same analogy of being shipwrecked, Paul similarly writes concerning believers who have
had their faith destroyed (1Tim 1:19; 2Tim 2:18).823 The NT writers recognize the fact that regenerate believers
can become shipwrecked in terms of both their faith and faithfulness. Believers can participate in the evil deeds of
the unregenerate wicked (Eph 5:11). As a result of doing so, these believers become what might be called the
regenerate wicked. The wicked dead, whether regenerate or unregenerate, will both be judged according to their
works. Still, the beauty of the NT is that these wicked believers (Mt 25:26) will not be cast into the same darkness
as unbelievers.
        Some similarities between the fates of wicked believers and unbelievers may be granted, but such
similarities do not prove identical fates.* Matthew and the rest of the NT writers realize that the gift of eternal life
is received by a response of simple faith (Mt 21:32). Yet they also teach with equal clarity that this simple act of
saving faith may fail to result in faithfulness. However, whereas 1 Enoch would consign unfaithful believers to the
judgment of literal darkness and eternal fire, the NT does not. In contrast, the NT speaks metaphorically of such
believers experiencing misthological fire (Mk 9:49; Jn 15:6; 1Cor 3:15; Heb 6:7-8; Jam 5:3; Jude 1:23) and
misthological darkness (Mt 8:12; 22:13; 25:30). Believers will come into misthological judgment but not
soteriological judgment (Jn 5:24). They will never come into a judgment where the issue is the Lake of Fire versus
the kingdom of heaven. They may be cast out misthologically (Jn 15:6), but they will never be cast out
soteriologically (Jn 6:37). They can be cast out of the banquet; they cannot be cast out of the kingdom.
        The darkness to which Jude refers is the literal darkness of 1 Enoch. Osburn believes that the passage to
which Jude refers in 1:12-13 is 1En 67:5-7.824 But his argument is unconvincing. As can be seen below in
Illustration 155. Confinement in Darkness and Fire in 1 Enoch, 1En 67 does not contain a reference to darkness.
As for other top contenders, 1En 10:4 is the only passage that speaks of angels being confined to darkness and fire.
Further, this judgment in 1En 10:4 is preliminary to the great day of judgment just as it is in Jude 1:6.
        4
         And secondly the Lord said to Raphael, “Bind Azaz’el hand and foot (and) throw him into the
        darkness!” And he made a hole in the desert…and cast him there; 5he threw on top of him rugged
        and sharp rocks. And he covered his face in order that he might not see light; 6and in order that he
        may be sent into the fire on the great day of judgment. (1En 10:4-6)

The only other passage that speaks of all three—darkness, confinement, and fire—is 1En 103:7. Perhaps, this
passage is foremost on Jude’s mind as he writes about the darkness in verse 13.
        4
         Woe unto you sinners who are dead!…7they shall experience evil and great tribulation—in
        darkness, nets, and burning flame. 8Your souls shall enter into the great judgment. (1En 103:4-8)

run roughshod over the principle of correlativity, failing even to notice its existence.
