       On the other hand, in 1En 88:3 the darkness is connected with the sexual abuses of fallen stars, which may
parallel their licentiousness (Jude 1:4) and their description as stars (Jude 1:13). Then again, their being described
as receiving the error of Balaam as their reward in Jude 1:11 may allude to 1En 108 where “the spirits of the ones
who err” (v. 7) are “taken into darkness” (v. 14). Rather than limit Jude’s references to any one specific passage,
the safest conclusion is that Jude had the general impression created by a number of passages in mind. Nonetheless,
the passage to which Jude most directly alludes to in Jude 1:6 is 1En 10:4-6.

                                        Background for Outer Darkness
       Matthew, however, is not referring to literal darkness. His concept of the outer darkness is developed and
explained more so in a parabolic rather than didactical fashion and thus presents a metaphorical rather than literal
darkness. And in contrast to Jude, Matthew does not directly equate his darkness with the darkness of 1 Enoch.
Nonetheless, it would seem likely that the Enoch material does provide an indirect background for Jesus’
statements in Matthew’s gospel concerning the outer darkness. In both Enoch and Matthew, more than being a
believer is required to be saved from the darkness. Both faith and faithfulness are necessary. In both writings, a
person’s works determines whether that individual will be thrown into the fire and into the darkness. In the
writings of both, a person’s works can condemn him or her to be thrown into the fire. (According to the NT, our
works condemn us to hell rather than justify us for heaven.)
       Sim argues that the agreements between Mt 22:13 and 1En 10:4 cannot be attributed to coincidence or “a
common (apocalyptic) motif, since the idea of God commanding an angel (or angels) to bind someone by the hands
and feet and cast that individual into the darkness is found in no other extant work of that time.”825 Sim also points
Page 472                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
out that the second closest parallel is also found in 1 Enoch (cf. 1En 88:1). As can be seen above in Illustration
155, a number of other passages in 1 Enoch refer to either wicked angels or humans being confined or imprisoned
in the darkness. Therefore, in spite of the fact that Sim was mistaken in considering Matthew’s outer darkness as a
soteriological theme, he is correct that a connection exists between the two. Enoch’s soteriological darkness indeed
does provide a backdrop for Jesus’ misthological darkness. Jesus’ hearers were probably familiar with Enoch’s
demands that it takes more than being his child to escape the darkness. In chapter 91 Enoch summons “his son”
Methuselah and his other children (all Methuselah’s brothers) and warns all of his children:

       Children of righteousness…‘Hear, all you children of Enoch, the talk of your father…for I exhort
       you, (my) beloved, and say to you: Love uprighteousness….Now listen to me, my children, and walk
       in the way of righteousness, and do not walk in the way of wickedness, for all those who walk in the
       ways of injustice shall perish.

       The reason for this warning is because those who walk in this manner will “be thrown into the judgment of
fire and perish in wrath and in the force of the eternal judgment” (1En 91:9). It is his children, the children of
righteousness, that will be cast into darkness if they fail to believe and work (1En 94:1,3,9). Jesus and his hearers
were familiar with this tradition, which taught that it takes more than being a son of Enoch (i.e., a son of
righteousness) to be saved from the eternal fire of hell. Thus, the Enochian imagery provides a backdrop for the NT
claim that it takes more than being a son of Abraham to be saved from hell. At the same time, although the two
teachings are similar, they are not identical. According to Enoch, it takes both faith and works to be saved from
perishing in the fire of hell. According to the NT, however, it only takes faith (Jn 3:16). NT soteriology does not
require faith and works or faith that works; it demands faith without works. The idea that salvation is based on faith
without works is totally foreign to Enoch. The superiority of the New Testament’s soteriology is due largely to the
fact that it distinguishes between the soteriological salvation received by faith alone and the misthological salvation
achieved by works.826 Salvation by faith will save NT believers from the soteriological fire and darkness, but it will
not save them from the misthological fire and darkness.

                                                   Faith-Works
       When James speaks of the inability of faith without works to save, he is recognizing the distinction between
soteriological justification and misthological justification. Misthological justification and misthological salvation
are based on works (Jam 2:24). Just as in 1 Enoch, faith will not save the fallen angels from the fire, so also it will
not save fallen angels in Jam 2:19. Judgment is always based on works. The works of wicked angels will condemn
rather than justify them in the day of their judgment.827 Likewise, the judgment of believers will be based on
works. The works of wicked believers will misthologically condemn rather justify them on the day of their
judgment. The primary difference between Enoch and James is that, in the former, the judgment is used
soteriologically in reference to the placement of the wicked in the fire; whereas, in the latter, the judgment is used
misthologically concerning their location inside the kingdom. In other words, James does not cast unfaithful
believers into hell.
       This advanced NT misthology makes possible a doctrine of salvation (from the Lake of Fire) by grace
through faith. As to the human response required for soteriological salvation, the NT towers above Enoch for this
very reason. The fact that unfaithful NT believers will be saved from the Lake of Fire proves that salvation from
the Lake of Fire is based totally upon faith without works. The NT demolishes the simplistic notion advanced in
Enoch that good people go to paradise, and bad people go to hell. In the NT, going to hell is no longer dependent
upon whether you are good. Instead, it is based exclusively upon whether you are a believer.
       The same argument holds true for the outer darkness. Just as being a child of Enoch will not save you from
the darkness, being a child of the kingdom will not save you from the outer darkness (Mt 8:12). Just as the children
of righteousness must practice ethical righteousness in order to escape the darkness, so too in Mt 22:12-13 the
king’s friend must clothe himself in proper clothing (i.e., ethical righteousness) in order to escape the outer
darkness. Just as it takes faithfulness to escape the darkness in Enoch, so it also takes faithfulness to escape the
outer darkness in Mt 25:30. As before, the difference between the two writings is that Enoch only can teach a
salvation by works (i.e., by faith that works or faith-works). Matthew, on the other hand, can teach a salvation by
grace and a judgment by works because he acknowledges two judgments with two different eschatological spheres
of reality. That the king’s friend was permitted to continue to live in the kingdom rather than be killed like the
king’s enemies in Mt 22:7 (cf. Lk 19:27) demonstrates salvation by grace: His life was spared, and he remained in
the kingdom. So too, unfaithful believers will not lose their eternal life or be cast out of the kingdom. It is not
simply that they are not cast into the same thing; they are not cast out of the same thing (Jn 6:37). They are not
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                         Page 473
cast out of the kingdom, much less into the Lake of Fire. The ultraistic misperception of the outer darkness has
been noted previously. It misconstrues the picture painted in the parable because the misthological contrast
between those who are first versus least place in the kingdom still places them “in the kingdom” (Mt 5:19), not
outside of it. The fact that the king’s worthless friend was cast out of the kingdom’s banquet hall demonstrates
judgment by works; nevertheless, this worthless friend was “least in the kingdom” (Mt 5:19). At least he was in the
kingdom—grace. But he was least in the kingdom—works. At least the least will be in the kingdom. The lost will
have no soteriological entrance into the kingdom (Mt 5:20), yet the least in the kingdom will nevertheless be in the
kingdom, albeit as least place in misthological contrast to first place (Mt 5:19).

                                                    Other Rewards
        As already noted in 1 Enoch, the righteous are told that they will inherit the earth, have access to the fragrant
tree with its fruit of life, be given garments of life, and sit on His throne.828 The fact that only the righteous will be
given such garments may serve as a partial background for Jesus’ parable in Mt 22:11-12, where the guest did not
have the appropriate garment. He did not have it because he was not ethically righteous. Such a position would
accord well with Rev 3:4-5 and may show that Sim is giving a false dichotomy concerning the garment. In
Rev 3:4-5 the garment imagery is used to show both the requirement of ethical righteousness and the reward for
ethical righteousness. Whether the wedding guests were to provide their own wedding garments or have garments
provided for them is really a moot point. In light of the fuller revelation, the wedding garment represents both the
requirement of practical righteousness and the reward for practical righteousness, resulting in misthological
participation in the wedding feast.
        The white garments are something we purchase from the Lord (Rev 3:18). Oh, yes, the Lord is pictured as
providing these white garments for us—as a merchant. If we want them, we will have to buy them from Him. The
divine Merchant will sell them to us for a price—the price of an obedient life. Ethical appropriation is the
necessary means to experience imparted righteousness. This imparted righteousness is in turn the required means to
achieve misthological righteousness. Those who persevere in preserving the whiteness of their garments temporally
(Rev 3:4) will be given white garments eschatologically (Rev 3:5; 6:11). They themselves will have to keep their
garments white by washing their garments in the blood of the Lamb (Rev 7:9,13-14). They themselves will have to
do the washing so that they can clothe themselves accordingly. That such imparted righteousness is provided to
every believer as Christ’s betrothed Bride (2Cor 11:2-3) does not mean that every believer, as the betrothed Bride
of Christ, will clothe herself in such garments and thus be able to participate in the marriage ceremony (Rev 19:8).
The garments demonstrate that practical righteousness is required for misthological participation. Practical
righteousness, whether temporal or misthological, is thus represented by the wedding garments. The distinction as
to whether these garments are given to us misthologically or obtained by us temporally for a misthological benefit
is inconsequential. Regardless as to whether these garments are misthologically imputed or imparted, they are
misthological.
        The NT picks up on each of these Enochian themes: inheriting the earth, having access to the fragrant tree
with its fruit of life, being given garments of life, and sitting on His throne. But whereas in 1 Enoch they are
soteriological-misthological themes, in the NT they are strictly misthological. In Enoch these benefits jointly
represent salvation and judgment by faith and works. By loosing these concepts from their soteriological moorings,
the NT teaches a salvation by faith versus a judgment by works. In the NT not all believers will obtain this
misthological inheritance, nor have access to the tree of life or its fruit, nor be clothed in white garments, nor sit on
His throne.
        That the inheritance, tree, fruit, garments, and throne are promised misthologically to overcomers (rather
than soteriologically to all believers) is a popular position in the FG camp. The reason Christians are encouraged to
serve the Lord with hardy work is because the inheritance is a potential reward (Col 3:23-25). The fruit of the tree
of life is promised to overcomers (Rev 2:7). Believers can lose the tree of life as their inheritance (Rev 22:19). Of
course, the intended application of the warning must be to believers since unbelievers do not have a part (meros) in
the tree of life to lose. One cannot lose something one does not have; one must at least potentially have it.
Believers, not unbelievers, are the potential heirs to the kingdom. The white garments are not free but only given to
overcomers on the basis of the worthiness of their walk (Rev 3:4-5,18). Jesus’ overcoming consisted of a life of
faith and faithfulness rather than a simple act of faith. Those believers who overcome in the same manner as Jesus
did will sit with Him on His throne. Consequently, not all believers will sit with Him on His throne (Rev 3:21).
Only those believers who endure with Him will rule with Him (2Tim 2:12).
        These rewards are only given to faithful believers on the basis of their works. These benefits do not, in and
of themselves, demonstrate salvation by grace. However, the fact that unfaithful believers who do not receive them
are not cast into hell does demonstrate salvation by grace. This dimension is missing from 1 Enoch. By the same
Page 474                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
token, the fact that the NT takes these themes and misthologically applies them to believers further confirms the
conclusion that the NT has done the same thing with the outer darkness. In stark contrast, those NT interpreters
who fail to acknowledge that unfaithful believers do not receive these rewards are guilty of lowering the NT to the
soteriological level of 1 Enoch with its salvation by faith-works. Salvation by faith-works from eternal damnation
is not the gospel according to Jesus; rather, it is the gospel according to 1 Enoch.

                                                     2 Enoch

Works
       In 1 Enoch, salvation from hell is based on faith-works. In 2 Enoch, soteriology is based exclusively on
works. Sinners are described in 10:4-5 in standard ethical terms (cf. 59:5). What reward (punishment) people
receive is determined by how they do when they are weighed in the scales (44:5). The warnings and promises are
again given by Enoch to his children (50:2; 53; 61:1; 66:1). Some of the more specific eschatological rewards that
are promised are an inheritance (50:2; 54:1; 66:6), glory (43:3), and rest and dinner in the palace (42:3-5). This last
reward is particularly interesting in view of its potential parallel to Mt 8:11-12 and Mt 22:1-13.

Background for Palace Exclusion

            When the last [righteous] one arrives, he [the Lord] will bring out Adam, together with the
       ancestors; and he will bring them in there…just as a person invites his best friends to have dinner
       with him…and they talk together in front of that man’s palace, waiting with joyful anticipation to
       have dinner. (2En 42:5)

       In contrast to the works-righteousness writings of Enoch, however, the Lord gives a surprising ending.
Those who are not ethically worthy to participate in the feast will be brought out (cast out) of the feast. To go
outside and to be outside of the banquet do not mean to go out of paradise or to be outside of paradise; it simply
means to go out of the palace (i.e., to be outside in front of the palace but still in paradise). Therefore, if some of
the king’s friends are cast out of the palace, it should be taken to mean that they are removed out of the feast
through the front door of the palace, not out of the kingdom.
                                Illustration 156. Darkness Outside the King’s Palace
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                        Page 475


       The Lord gives a shock to the stock Enochian backdrop. Jesus counters the works-righteousness associated
with the darkness in the Enochian material by disassociating the darkness outside the palace with the fires of hell.
After all, even in Enochian material, one cannot equate being outside the palace with being in the Enochian fire!
Moreover, if this dinner is understood as taking place at night (a reasonable presumption), then those standing
outside the palace waiting for dinner are standing in the darkness outside the palace—in joyful anticipation of the
dinner to be eaten inside—even in the Enochian writings! The fuller online context reads as follows:

             And I saw the key-holders and the guards of the gates of hell standing, as large as serpents, with
      their faces like lamps that have been extinguished, and their eyes aflame, and their teeth naked down
      to their breasts. And I said to their faces, “It would have been better if I had not seen you, nor heard
      about your activities, nor that any member of my tribe had been brought to you. To what a small
      extent they have sinned in this life, but in the eternal life they will suffer forever.”
             And I ascended to the east, into the paradise of Edem [sic], where rest is prepared for the
      righteous. And it is open as far as the 3rd heaven; but it is closed off from this world. And the guards
      are appointed at the very large gates of the east of the sun, angels of flame, singing victory songs,
      never silent, rejoicing at the arrival of the righteous. When the last one arrives, he will bring out
      Adam, together with the ancestors; and he will bring them in there, so that they may be filled with joy;
      just as a person invites his best friends to have dinner with him and they arrive with joy, and they talk
      together in front of that man’s palace, waiting with joyful anticipation to have dinner with delightful
      enjoyments and riches that cannot be measured, and joy and happiness in eternal light and life
      (2En 42:1-5)829

       Two different sets of gates are present in this Enochian text: one gate for hell and another gate for paradise.
Enoch ascends from the gates of hell to the gates of paradise. The gates of paradise are closed off from the gates of
hell and separated by his lengthy ascension. Enoch pictures the place outside the palace to be a place of joyful
anticipation of the dinner. Logically, to be cast back into this place after the dinner has started (which is the case in
Matthew’s gospel) would not picture being cast into fire. Those in this place outside the front of the palace before
the dinner were not in fire, and those in this identical place after dinner are not in fire. The darkness outside the
front of the palace is not a place of fire.
       With a stroke of genius, Jesus adds the outer darkness as a buffer zone between the outside of the palace
and the darkness of hell. What Enoch left open to question, Jesus settles beyond question: This buffer zone is
inside of paradise, far removed from the gates of hell. To be in the darkness outside the palace is to be within the
gates of paradise. To get to the Enochian hell, one would have to stroll across the dark grounds outside the palace,
exit the gates of paradise, descend back down to the realm of hell, and enter the gates of hell. None of these things
happens to those cast into the Matthean outer darkness. Being cast into the biblical outer darkness is to be cast
outside of the king’s palace, not outside of the king’s kingdom. In contrast to the Enochian writings, the darkness
outside the palace is not to be equated with the flames of hell but with being outside the palace—as even
unwittingly allowed by Enochian writings!
       Enochian material cannot be credited with perceiving that the darkness outside the Enochian palace would
not be equated with the darkness inside the Enochian hell. The Enochian material is blind to the deficiency of its
own imagery. The genius displayed by Matthew’s writings (in picking up on the Enochian discrepancy between the
darkness in hell versus the darkness outside the palace) must be attributed to Jesus Himself.
       In placing unfaithful believers in the darkness outside the palace rather than in the darkness of hell, Jesus
towers above the works-righteousness found in Enochian writings. Those costly-free interpreters who try to reduce
the outer darkness to the darkness of hell are robbing Jesus of the credit He rightfully deserves for rejecting works-
righteousness with His treatment of the outer darkness. Jesus purposefully places those in the outer darkness within
paradise. At most, Enochian material does so accidently.

Vice List
       Unfortunately, there are those, even within the FG camp, who would follow the wayward theology of those
who seek to limit the NT soteriology to that of intertestamental background by making the outer darkness and the
inheritance of the kingdom strictly soteriological themes. Lopez, for example, is led astray by Brown into arguing
Page 476                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
that the inheritance of the kingdom is not a reward in the NT because it is soteriological in 2 Enoch.* I must insist,
to the contrary, that since the NT can make a distinction between an active and passive inheritance (i.e., between a
reward and a gift), Paul can use the vice list of 1Cor 6:9-11 misthologically. Lopez calls attention to the vice list of
2En 10:4-6 as a parallel to the Pauline vice list in 1Cor 6. After describing the fiery darkness in 2En 10:1-3, Enoch
proceeds to describe its lost inhabitants in terms of their vices:

          And those men said to me, “This place, Enoch, has been prepared for those who do not glorify God,
          who practice on the earth the sin which is against nature, which is child corruption in the anus in the
          manner of Sodom, of witchcraft, enchantments, divinations, trafficking with demons, who boast
          about their evil deeds—stealing, lying, insulting, coveting, resentment, fornication, murder—and who
          steal the souls of men secretly, seizing the poor by the throat, taking away their possessions,
          enriching themselves from the possessions of others, defrauding them; who, when they are able to
          provide substance, bring about the death of the hungry by starvation; and, when they are able to
          provide clothing, take away the last garment of the naked; who do not acknowledge their Creator, but
          bow down to idols which have no souls, which can neither see or hear, vain gods; constructing
          images, and bowing down to vile things made by hands—for all these this place has been prepared
          as an eternal reward. (2En 10:4-6)

Vice List Reward
        Strangely, Lopez does not mention the fact that his key text may be translated as saying that the vice list
results in a reward! Moreover, in the preceding chapter, which is only one verse in length, Enoch concluded, “For
them [i.e., for those who live righteously] this place [Paradise] has been prepared as an eternal inheritance”
(2En 9:1). The performance-based inheritance of the righteous is set forth in synonymous juxtaposition with the
performance-based reward of the unrighteous. The inheritance is a reward! Yet Lopez endeavors to use this text to
assert that the inheritance is not a reward!
        Perhaps, Lopez overlooked this equation of the inheritance with reward due to the fact that some translators
render 2En 10:6, this place has been prepared as an eternal reward, just like they would 2En 9:1, that is, this place
has been prepared as an eternal inheritance. Some translators translate both verses as referring to inheritance. But
translating both verses as inheritance is a questionable procedure, and Andersen rejects it, noting that the Slavonic
word dostoanie is used in 10:6, but a different word, naslede, is used in 9:1. Nevertheless, as Andersen points out:
“Both words are used in the Gospels to translate kleronomia [inheritance].”830

Active versus Passive Inheritance
       In any event, because of the basic genre of the book of 2 Enoch, Lopez should have been more sensitive to
the danger in equating Enoch’s active inheritance with a NT passive inheritance. Anderson sums up the soteriology
of 2 Enoch by accentuating, “A blessed afterlife is strictly a reward for right ethical behavior.”831 Even Lopez
acknowledges, “Rabbinic teaching adopted a salvation-by-works view through ritual observance and personal
character as the only means of sharing in the world to come.”832 As Lopez also notes, “Numerous writers notice
distinctions between a passive inheritance based solely on faith and an active inheritance based on obedience.”833
Since he admits the accuracy of this differentiation, and since this distinction is not present in 2 Enoch, this
inheritance-by-works in 2 Enoch, although soteriological in 2 Enoch, must nevertheless be regarded as an active
inheritance. Consequently, it is with considerable justification that the misthological advocate might anticipate that
such an inheritance might very well be regarded as active in the NT as well.
       Contrary to Lopez’s claim, the burden of proof is on those who seek to limit the inheritance of the kingdom
to a passive inheritance in the NT. Granted, the inheritance is soteriological in 2 Enoch, but that is only because
2 Enoch does not have a second, distinct misthological category. The inheritance is an earned reward in 2 Enoch.
The inheritance is not a soteriological gift in 2 Enoch. Therefore, Lopez’s approach in using 2 Enoch to argue that
the inheritance must be a gift in the NT must be met with suspicion. On the other hand, one should not be surprised
to find both the soteriological and misthological aspects affirmed and delineated in the NT, since the NT
distinguishes its soteriology from its misthology. Whereas these motifs are integrated in 2 Enoch, they are
differentiated in the NT.



*
    See endnote 196.
Chapter. 20. Intertestamental Context of Outer Darkness                                                                        Page 477
NT Differentiation
        The inheritance as a reward motif is adapted and enriched in the NT, as are the other intertestamental
teachings concerning: glory, rest, and dinner. Additionally, the Enochian elaboration of darkness, confinement, and
fire find restrained expression in the NT. Here is where the soteriological distinction might be seen more clearly in
the NT.
                               Illustration 157. Confinement in Darkness and Fire in 2 Enoch
                                                              2 Enoch

       The comments made concerning these topics in 1 Enoch will suffice for these references from 2 Enoch as
well. In the NT, these motifs are no longer soteriological promises to those who work for their salvation from hell;
instead, an added dimension is found in the NT, where such descriptions may become strictly misthological
promises to those who work for their reward. The provision of reward for clothing and feeding the needy (2En
42:8; 63:1), for helping the orphan and widow (2En 42:9), for giving alms (2En 51:3), and for taking up the yoke
(2En 48:9) all find beautiful expression in the NT. These themes are like lumps of coal taken from the drab
theology of 2 Enoch and made into exquisite diamonds in the NT.
       This misthological advance in thought in the NT again shows a soteriological advance as well. According to
2 Enoch, “many shelters have been prepared for people, good ones for the good, but bad ones for the bad” (61:2).
In other words, bad people go to the bad place; good people go to the good place. Both the good and the bad have
individual housing in their own respective places. Jesus also teaches something very similar in Jn 14:2. The
difference is that within Jesus’ kingdom there will be places for both bad believers and good believers. In Enoch’s
perspective, good people go to paradise; bad people go to hell. Not so with Jesus. It is true that on occasions Jesus
does express His theology in these simple terms by contrasting the fate of the good with the bad in terms of heaven
versus hell, as in the sheep versus the goats. Good works distinguish the good sheep from the bad goats (Mt 25:31-
46). They do not distinguish bad sheep from good goats, however.* The parable is concerned with the former
comparison rather than the latter. Yet, on other occasions, Jesus goes into greater detail to show that bad people
will also be in His kingdom, who are saved from the fire of hell. This added dimension is missing from these
apocryphal works.

                                                          Conclusion
       Although 1 Enoch teaches salvation by faith and works, in contrast to 2 Enoch (which teaches salvation by
works), it would be wrong to assume that this means that 1 Enoch teaches salvation by faith. Paul would not accept
such a superficial conclusion. In the NT, salvation by works is not merely contrasted with salvation by faith and
works; it is contrasted with salvation by faith alone (i.e., faith without works). Paul was not upset with the
Judaizers in Galatia because they wanted to replace faith with works but because they wanted to add works to faith.
Paul was not simply rejecting a salvation by works; he was rejecting a salvation by faith and works. A synergistic
soteriology is simply unacceptable. The NT advanced far beyond the intertestamental apocalyptic literature by
teaching salvation by grace through faith alone without any works whatsoever. Unfortunately, many of the New
Testament’s interpreters, such as Pagenkemper, have not yet made this advance. By advocating salvation by faith
and works (= salvation by faith that works) many of today’s scholars are playing the part of contemporary
Judaizers.

*
 For brief review, see Illustration 63. Sheep or Goat, 141; Illustration 64. Black Sheep, 142. For fuller review, see Chapter 16. Sheep
and Goats (Mt 25:31-46), 411.
Page 478                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
        The writers of the NT use the intertestamental apocalyptic literature and traditions in various ways.
Sometimes, as in the case of Jude, they simply adapt it with little modification, using the images in much the same
sense. For both Jude and 1 Enoch, the darkness is literal and soteriological. More often, however, the writers of the
NT demonstrate a great advance over in their theological use of these intertestamental themes. For both Matthew
and 1 Enoch, the requirements to be saved from the darkness are faith and faithfulness. However, Matthew
distinguishes his outer darkness as being exclusively metaphorical and misthological. (Matthew’s outer darkness is
a metaphorical equivalent to Paul’s metaphorical fire in 1Cor 3:15.) In like manner, the tree of life and its fruit, the
garments, and the throne are moved by the author of the NT Apocalypse from the intertestamental soteriological
category to an exclusively misthological category. Yet the requirements remain the same—faith and works.
        Although the requirements remain the same, the prize is distinguished from its soteriological surroundings.
In the NT era it became possible to have faith without works and still be saved from hell (cf. 1Cor 3:15). This
distinction salvaged the soteriological perspective of justification by faith from the jaws of the intertestamental
period. This precious truth of justification by faith alone that had been assumed in the pages of the OT and carried
on by oral tradition had been lost in the intertestamental period. It was this theological advance over the
intertestamental writings, initiated by Jesus in the NT era, which recaptured the OT soteriology of salvation by
grace through faith apart from works from the legalistic jaws of the intertestamental period. Believers who failed to
demonstrate faithfulness in a life of good works were no longer to be considered punishable in the same place as
unbelievers, as intertestamental writings had taught. Gehenna was now to be considered as a place for the lost (i.e.,
unbelievers) and the kingdom of heaven for the saved (i.e., believers). Thus, salvation from hell was now to be
determined by whether a person was a believer.
        Notwithstanding this teaching of eternal security apart from works, the NT did not come to condone wicked
behavior on the part of believers. Instead, the motivation for godly behavior on the part of believers was moved
from an intertestamental threat of loss of salvation to a NT threat of loss of reward.* The NT warnings do not
threaten those with faith without works with exclusion from the kingdom. Rather, the NT urges believers to work
on the basis of exclusions, limitations, and distinctions that will be made within the kingdom. Being in least place
in the kingdom, not having a right to the tree of life and its fruit in the kingdom, being denied the opportunity to
rule in the kingdom, and not being allowed to celebrate as intimately with the Lord in the kingdom (as other
believers who are faithful) are so dreadful in their scope that such an impoverished experience within the kingdom
of heaven is presented metaphorically as being cast outside the palace of the kingdom and away from the supper
table. Those believers who do not heed the biblical injunction to keep themselves from sin will be kept from the
table in the kingdom. They will be in the kingdom, but this elucidation serves more as a clarification than
consolation. This soteriological clarification does little to serve as a misthological consolation. It may have some
value as a soteriological solacement, but it would have none as a misthological easement. The outer darkness is not
to be taken lightly just because it describes a loss of reward for those who will nevertheless dwell in the kingdom.




*
  This NT advancement was actually a movement back to the OT misthopology. Nevertheless, in terms of its clarity, it was also
advancement, just as one would anticipate within progressive revelation. NT misthology is, to a considerable extent, a clarification and
amplification of OT misthopology. For myself personally, I came to this discovery the roundabout way. As I traced out the
implications of the outer darkness, I discovered its misthopological implications. Only later did I realize that had I been more alert to
the OT misthopology, I naturally would have perceived the misthopological implications of the outer darkness. The NT is making
explicit what the OT already has made implicit. Yet, in the case of misthopology at least, the OT speaks with a surprising degree of
clarity. However, I did not perceive this misthopology in the OT until after the fact, until after first clearly seeing it in the NT. From
my experience regarding this area of study, I can confirm that the OT is in the NT revealed, and the NT is in the OT concealed. See
Like a Tree Planted by the Water.

                                                             Chapter 21.
                                                               Litotes
                                                               Introduction
        Having laid an eschatological foundation and then built a misthological understanding upon it, and having
covered elementary questions concerning some of the negative aspects of misthology, this book is now ready to
inquire further into some details that require more penetrating insight in connection with the misthological
implications of the outer darkness and address more provocative questions. This section will be dedicated to some
of these more challenging misthological questions that surface in the discussion of the outer darkness: Does a
misthological view of the outer darkness indicate a misthological view of the Bride of Christ? What response
should be made to ultraistic FG interpreters who advocate taking the outer darkness and/or other passages to mean
that some believers will spend a limited amount of time in Gehenna? Is it possible for believers to be hurt, at least
temporarily, by the second death in the Lake of Fire? Does the wiping away of tears associated with the eternal
state in the last two chapters of Revelation imply that rewards are only millennial in scope rather than eternal?

What About the Tears?
       Probably, the most common objection that one encounters at the popular level when presenting a
misthological understanding of the outer darkness is in connection with the biblical promise that our tears will be
wiped away. Since all our tears will be wiped away, those who weep in the outer darkness cannot be saved—so it
is assumed. In order to investigate John’s statement about all of our tears being wiped away and the possible
implications this statement may have on negative rewards (such as the outer darkness and the identity of the
overcomers in the book of Revelation), it is first necessary to be familiar with the Johannine literary expression
being employed, called litotes.

English Definition
        John often uses litotes in his writings.* Litotes are a normal part of everyday speech. Webster defines a
litotes as an “understatement for effect, in which something is expressed by a negation of the contrary (Ex.: not a
few regrets).”834 Thus, it is an understatement formed by the negation of the contrary. The litotes not a few regrets
is a negation formed by the addition of the word not to create an understatement which means the exact opposite—
many regrets. Some everyday examples of litotes would be: “Michael Jordan was not a bad basketball player.”
“That coat is not cheap.” “This is no small problem.” “That test was no breeze.” “He is not a Scrooge.”

Greek Definition
       The English word litotes is simply the transliteration of the Greek word litotes. Grammatically, it refers to a
figure of speech in which an assertion is made by means of understatement or negation. Like English speakers
today, the Greeks also frequently used this figure of speech. Robertson summarizes in his Grammar of the Greek
New Testament that litotes are also “common enough” in the NT.835 Of course, there are a number of ways of
making a negation in Greek, just as there are in English: no, not, by no means, certainly not, absolutely not, or the
popular and vernacular expression—ain’t no way! Of course, the last example is poor grammar in English because
it involves a double negative. In Greek grammar, though, this double negation is the proper way to emphasize the
negative. In the following chart (Illustration 158. Johannine Litotes), not represents the simple Greek negative, and
never represents the double (emphatic) Greek negative. Boyer says,

               The most emphatic way to say that something shall not happen in the future is to use ouv mh, with
          the subjunctive mood.…I prefer to think of it as a form of litotes; i.e., the second negative (mh,)
          negates the subjunctive verb and together they express a doubtful idea; the first negative (ouv) negates
          the doubtful clause introduced by mh,. As a whole the clause communicates that “there is no doubt
          about it; it is not an uncertain matter.”836




*
    Litotetic will also be used herein as coined adjectival equivalent for litotes. It and similar derivatives will be used herein.
Page 482                                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
Functional Litotes
        Bullinger gives some samples of litotes in the OT and NT in his discussion of meiosis. (Both of these
synonyms are transliterated Greek words.) He defines it as “a belittling of one thing to magnify another.” He
continues to explain, “One thing is lowered in order to magnify and intensify something else by way of contrast. It
is used for the purpose of emphasis; to call our attention, not to the smallness of the thing thus lessened, but to the
importance of that which is put in contrast with it.”837
        As to the contrast, the thing that obviously is contrasted with not being hurt by the second death in Rev 2:11
is receiving the crown of life in 2:10. Similarly, the contrast between having one’s name erased is to have it
confessed in Rev 3:5. In Bullinger’s very limited list of examples, the only two Johannine examples he provides
are Jn 15:20 and 1Jn 3:17. Grammatically, these two examples are interesting in their own right.
        In Jn 15:20 Jesus says, “If they kept My word, they will keep yours also.” However, the implication of the
context is that they have not kept My word, and they will not keep yours. Quite to the contrary, they will persecute
you. The negation is merely implied, not stated. Likewise, when John asks, “How does the love of God abide” in a
believer who does not help his fellow believer? (1Jn 3:17), the unstated implication is that it does not
experientially abide in such a believer. These two examples by Bullinger serve to illustrate the fact that a
litotes/meiosis does not technically have to state the negation. To imply the negation is sufficient contextually. This
makes sense since he says, “In Meiosis there is an omission therefore, not of words, but of sense.”838
        In order to achieve greater specificity concerning the form of litotes employed, I could call those litotes that
formally state the negation formal litotes, whereas informal litotes that merely imply the negation could be called
functional litotes.* Burton defines litotes as, “Deliberate understatement, especially when expressing a thought by
denying its opposite.” And he defines meiosis as, “Reference to something with a name disproportionately lesser
than its nature (a kind of litotes).”839 Thus, I am using the terminology formal litotes to refer to those constructions
which explicitly state the negation and functional litotes for those constructions which do not. In the chart below,
Jn 15:20b, 1Jn 3:17, Rev 3:10, 7:17, and 21:4 (concerning the tears) are litotes in function rather than in form and
are denoted as such by the bold italic font. They are litotes in essence since they state the opposite by negation of
the negative idea or concept. They might thus be appropriately called conceptual litotes.†

Positive and Negative Litotes
      Litotes may be further categorized as either positive or negative depending upon whether the response,
promise, or warning is positive or negative. Therefore, a more precise definition is to define a litotes as a positive
Page 484                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
or negative affirmation made by the explicit or implicit denial of its opposite. It is very important to realize that the
inverse of a litotes is not always true, and even in those cases where the inverse may be true, the truth of the
inverse is not the point. The affirmation implied by the understatement is always the point. In other words, the
denial of the opposite does not necessarily mean that the opposite can happen. The opposite is not the point. The
intention of the litotes is to convey the affirmation created by the understatement.

Inversion of Litotes is Perversion
        For example, to say that overcomers will not be hurt by the second death (Rev 2:11) does not necessarily
mean that subcomers literally will be hurt by the second death, which is identified as the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14).
Understandably, being hurt by the second death traditionally is understood soteriologically, but turning the
negation of this expression into a threat of being hurt soteriologically if one does not overcome wrongly results in
teaching that (1) salvation from everlasting damnation is dependent upon more than just believing, that
(2) punctiliar faith and its resulting regeneration are not enough to enter heaven, and that (3) salvation from eternal
damnation is ultimately dependent upon overcoming. Turning this negation into a soteriological threat makes
soteriological salvation dependent upon performance—an accursed gospel. However, teaching an accursed gospel
is unnecessary if one will treat this figure of speech for what it is—a litotes.
        The point of this particular litotes is that the believer who overcomes will have a radical, eternal experience
of life that is the exact opposite of eternal death. This reward of life is eternal, and this misthological affirmation is
the point. The purpose of this litotes is not to say that believers who subcome can be hurt soteriologically by the
second death. Soteriologically, this is an impossibility. Yet another possibility is readily at hand. Rather than have
an eternal experience of death (separation from God), overcomers will have an eternal experience of life (intimate
union with God). Their experience of life will surpass that of subcomers. All believers have spiritual life eternally.
But only overcomers will have abundant life eternally. No believer literally can be hurt by the second death (since
the second death is a soteriological issue). However, subcomers can fail to have a radically different experience
from noncomers who are indeed hurt by it.841 Subcomers may have a correlative subjective response in the
misthological outer darkness of heaven, in that they may weep and gnash their teeth in a manner similar to the lost,
yet they cannot be subjected to the objective, soteriological, internal darkness of hell that the lost will experience.
        Hodges argues that not being hurt by the second death is a litotes promised only to overcomers in 2:11, but
more importantly, he also correctly limits the promise in 20:6 to overcomers.842 Faust is extremely skeptical of the
litotetic approach, demanding a “high degree of evidence to interpret” this warning as “only a figure of speech,”
challenging those who hold this position to “show that any of the other similar promises to these Seven Churches
are not conditioned upon ‘overcoming.’”843 When the present writer first read this Hodgian interpretation back in
1985, he, like Faust, initially thought it was too good to be true. Yet, rather than being content with this initial
skepticism, the present writer researched the hermeneutical plausibility over the years. As a result of examining the
evidence, this chapter is offered as the “high degree of evidence” that Faust requested to substantiate Hodges’
approach.
        One has cause to wonder if Faust understands the true nature of this figure of speech since he challenges
those who hold this interpretation to show that it is not conditioned on overcoming. This challenge either misstates
or misunderstands what is being said by those who prefer the litotetic interpretation. The promise made by
mistholic litotes is conditioned on overcoming. Litotetic interpreters, following the Hodgian interpretation, limit
the promise to overcomers. Hodges made this limitation years ago, and the present work confirms it. The litotetic
promise of not being under the power of the second death is limited to overcomers. It does not apply to subcomers,
at least not directly.
        This litotetic affirmation should not be taken to mean that there is a literal sense in which subcomers are
inversely under the power of the second death. Moreover, if believers are cast into the Lake of Fire at the Bema,
but Gehenna is not the Lake of Fire, then how does Faust manage to get unfaithful believers into both fires? It
appears that he attempts to do this by locating the Lake of Fire at the Bema in outer space, having them experience
death there, and then having the angels gather them out of the millennial kingdom (which was supposed to be on
earth was it not?) and casting them into Gehenna in the center of the earth! Not only are there spatial logistics for
Faust to overcome, he must also explain how believers can be raised and killed at the Bema after the rapture. Then
one would presume that these believers must be raised and killed again so that they can experience the second
phase of this ultraistic judgment and be thrown soul and body into Gehenna at the beginning of the millennium.
Not only must Faust circumvent the fact that the Bible teaches that we die once (Heb 9:27), Faust apparently must
postulate that carnal believers die two or three times! Moreover, their resurrected bodies must be killed. The
ultraistic gymnastics used to respond to such logistics seem far more speculative than a litotetic interpretation
based on a solid, grammatical hermeneutics.
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                                          Page 485
        The promise of 20:6 that the second death would have no power over overcomers should be understood as a
litotes and not thrown into reverse so as to assume that subcomers will be hurt by the second death so as to be cast
into the Lake of Fire. Rather than experience any type of separation from God (either in hell or in the outer
darkness) overcomers will be united intimately with the Lord in priesthood and in rulership. Revelation uses a
variety of ways to picture the overcomers’ abundant life.* They alone are given crowns of life (2:10), access to the
tree of life in the city (2:7; 22:14,19,), a promise concerning not having their name erased from the Book of Life
(3:5), and access to the water of life from inside the city (7:17; 22:1-2).†
        Although more will be said concerning Rev 3:5 below, summarization is provided here concerning the
inversion of litotes: The point of this verse is that overcomers will have a radically different experience from that
of having their names erased. This does not mean that their name actually could be erased, however. A believer’s
name cannot be erased from this particular book. This is impossible. The verse is a promise to overcomers, not a
threat to subcomers. The verse has no application to subcomers.
        When Jesus promises that overcomers will not go through the tribulation (Rev 3:10), this does not mean that
subcomers will go through it. Unlike Faust, I have no affinity for the partial rapture position. A partial rapture is
ruled out by 1Thess 5:9-10 and other considerations. The affirmation is the point, not its opposite. This is a promise
to overcomers, not a threat to subcomers. Subcomers are not addressed by the litotes. By promising that
overcomers of the church age will not go through the tribulation, Jesus is stating an impossibility. For any believer
of the church age to go through the tribulation is impossible. Jesus’ point is that overcomers will be rewarded with
ruling rather than suffering. Therefore, litotes often can be detected by an obvious understatement. Further, if the
statement is a denial of an impossibility, then certainly one should assume that a litotes is being used.
                                            Illustration 159. Inversion is Perversion
                           FORWARD                                                               REVERSE
Jn 6:37 The one who comes to me I will certainly not cast out          The one who does not come to me I will certainly cast out
Jn 6:39 Of all that He has given Me I lose nothing                     Of all that He has not given Me I lose it
Rev 2:11 He who overcomes will not be hurt by the Lake of Fire         He who does not overcome will be hurt by the Lake of Fire
Rev 3:5 He who overcomes I will not erase His name                     He who does not overcome I will erase His name

       While driving down a one-way super highway, throwing your car into reverse would be unwise. Lang
cautions: “It is not safe to reverse divine statements, as is done by inferring here that a believer who does not
overcome will be hurt of the second death” (emphasis his).844 Litotes are to be understood as moving in one
direction, within the flow of the context. Otherwise, we risk destroying the intended meaning of the litotes if we
throw them into reverse. For example, Jn 6:37 cannot be thrown into reverse and made to say that the one who
does not come to Jesus is cast out (ekballo).‡ One would have to come to Jesus first before being cast out is even a
possibility.§ An object has to be in a container before it can be cast out of the container. Unbelievers were never in
Christ to be cast out of Christ. Or as Barker exclaims: “Are we to understand by this statement that Jesus is
implying that He will cast out some who come to Him? Certainly not!”845 When Jesus says that He does not lose
(apollumi) comers (Jn 6:39), this does not mean that He loses noncomers. Unbelievers were not given to Him by
the Father. The litotes are not dealing with unbelievers. The affirmation is the point, not its opposite.** Just as the
soteriological litotes in Jn 6:39 is not intended for unbelievers, the misthological litotes of Rev 2:11 is not intended
as a threat for unfaithful believers. Litotes should not be thrown into reverse or made to stand on their head.
Logically, inversion is a fallacy.846

*
  Obviously, subcomers will experience mistholic separation when they are cast into the outer darkness. Therefore, one rightly might
interject that a correlation exists being between the lost being hurt by the second death and subcomers being hurt by the second death.
The present study allows the correlation but not equalization. For a believer to be hurt correlatively by the second death cannot be
made equal to being cast into the Lake of Fire. See endnote 1644.
†
  See Limited Accessibility, 549.
‡
  Nevertheless, believers can be cast out (ballo) misthologically even in this gospel (Jn 15:6). Therefore, a correlation exists between
being cast out soterically and misthologically. As always though, correlativity ≠ equality.
§
  See You Must Be in the Feast Before You Can be Cast Out of It, 434.
**
   Notwithstanding the accuracy of this argument as it applies to conditionalists and ultraists, some wrongly have insisted that
apollumi does not have misthological applicability. Far to the contrary, believers misthologically can lose themselves (Lk 9:25) and
their lives (Jn 12:25). Some might try to counter that although believers might lose the items in question, the Lord Himself never
would. Although I am inclined to agree with this assessment, even regarding the problematic Judas exception clause in Jn 17:12 (see
Race of Grace), asserting that the Lord never uses apollumi misthologically is in error. Moreover, the Lord possibly might
destroy/apollumi believers misthologically (cf. Jam 4:12). See endnote 265.
Page 486                                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
                                             Illustration 160. Contrapositive of Negation

       • If wood is petrified, then it will not bend (P ⇒ Q). True.
       • If wood bends, then it is not petrified (Q ⇒ P). True.
       • If wood is not petrified, then it will bend ( P ⇒ Q). False.
        The third statement is false and does not logically follow from the first two. Just because the wood is not
petrified, does not mean that it can bend. The wood may be charcoaled instead, and charcoaled wood will not bend
either. But this latter possibility was not considered (and neither affirmed or denied) by the first statement. In like
manner, we cannot logically conclude that just because a person is not an overcomer that he or she can be hurt by
the second death. Doing so would be a logical and biblical fallacy.
        When presenting this material before a group of listeners at a GES conference, an objection was raised
afterward that the present author was turning Jesus’ negative warning into a positive promise. Actually, this
objection reveals the fact that the objector was the one who had turned the statement into something it was not. As
seen in the above chart, Jesus is indeed making a positive promise. Those who reverse it have perverted it by
turning the positive promise into a negative warning.

                                                   The Believer’s Security

Litotetic Security
       Lenski acknowledges that will not cast out in Jn 6:37 is “a strong litotes,”847 but then he tries to water it
down only to mean that Jesus simply will receive the believer. Unfortunately, his forfeitistic theology, with its
denial of eternal security, prevents him from being able to grant the litotes its true contextual significance.
Hendriksen, a Calvinist, exposes this Arminian weakness by pointing out that the heart of this passage (6:35-40)
has four litotes. Unfortunately, Hendriksen allows the weakened meaning of will not cast out in 6:37 simply to
mean welcome.* Still, at least Hendriksen fully acknowledges the force of the other three litotes.
       The first two litotes in this passage are found in 6:35—will not hunger and will not thirst. Hendriksen
correctly states that this means that the positive result obtained by eating and drinking is “complete and
enduring.”848 This eating and drinking is a once-for-all appropriation by a singular response of faith. The last litotes
in the passage is will not lose in 6:39. Hendriksen believes that this litotes is even stronger than the litotes in 6:37.
Whereas the litotes in 6:37 means that Jesus will certainly “welcome” the believer, the litotes in 6:39 means that
He will “guard” the believer to the very end. The idea here is that believers are “kept and guarded to the very
end” (emphasis his).849

Preservation
        Hendriksen’s discussion is very commendable and exposes a defect in the Arminian argument.
Unfortunately, it also demonstrates one of the weaknesses of the Calvinistic camp. Hendriksen’s discussion is
flawed because, having demonstrated eternal security from the passage, he assumes that he has proven the
perseverance of the saints without a shred of anything approaching solid evidence. He assumes that the
preservation of the saints proves the perseverance of the saints.850 But such proof would be convincing only to
Arminians and Calvinists, who jointly presuppose that it would be impossible to have preservation without having
perseverance. They believe preservation and perseverance go hand-in-hand. Perseverance is the necessary means
for preservation in Arminianism and Calvinism. Marrowism, in contrast, does not condition preservation on
perseverance and thus would find his assumed perseverance to be groundless. The passage does not teach the
perseverance of the saints; it teaches the perseverance of the Savior. The Savior is the one who guards the believer
in this passage; we do not guard ourselves. The context has some very strong litotes that affirm the preservation
(rather than perseverance) of the saints. John illustrates eternal security by litotes, by negating the opposite of
eternal security. His approach is logically sound. John records Jesus as using the strongest possible language to
assure the believer that the life Jesus offers is eternal.
        Jesus states this security both by positive affirmations (by repeatedly calling it eternal life) and by negative
affirmations (litotes). In other words, anyone who believes in Jesus is guaranteed by Jesus that it is impossible for


*
    For lexical, syntactical, and logical rebuttal of this erroneous translation, see The Race of Grace and Drawing and Appointment.
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                           Page 487
                                                                                     *
him or her to ever go to hell. Whoever ever believes in Him will never ever perish. A believer has to go to heaven.
By denying that a believer can go to hell, Jesus guarantees that the believer must go to heaven. Jesus is the one who
makes the promise, not the believer. Our salvation depends upon His promise to us, not our promise to Him. Our
salvation depends upon His faithfulness to us, not upon our faithfulness to Him. If you were to believe in Jesus and
subsequently ever to be soteriologically thirsty or hungry or condemned to hell, then Jesus has lied.

Squirm Out
        The Arminian attempt to deny this fact by turning to Jn 10:28-29 and saying that we can squirm or jump out
of Jesus’ hand shatters worse than humpty dumpty upon the force of these litotes. If we can perish as a result of
squirming out of Jesus’ hand, then not only have we proven ourselves stronger than God, we also have succeeded
in making God a liar because He said that we cannot perish.851 To paraphrase Paul in Rom 3:4, “May it never be!
Rather, let God be found true though every Arminian be found a liar.” This is a harsh paraphrase, but John himself
said practically the same thing in 1Jn 5:10-13, when he said that the one who does not believe God has made Him a
liar, and what is more, John is talking about those who do not believe that the life God has given to the believer is
eternal. John would not be impressed with the Arminian attempt to evade his statement by claiming that God gives
us eternal life, but He does not give it to us eternally or that He only gives it to us as we continue to believe. To be
sure, the promise is made to believers, and the present tense verb for believe is used substantively to identify them
as such. However, the reason they continue to have life in 1Jn 5:12 is not because they continue to believe but
because God already has given this life to them as a completed aoristic action in the past (1Jn 5:11).

Ou Me
       Yet Lavender attempts to evade the assurance of eternal security found in a verse like Jn 3:16 by asserting:
“The condition here is that the one believing will not perish if believing continues. If John had wished to show that
the believer could in no wise perish, he would have used the construction ouv mh. [ou me].”852 Yet, contrary to
Lavender’s expectations, this is the very construction that is found in Jn 6:35,37 and 10:28 in John’s affirmation of
eternal security! Lavender says that me apollumi (may not perish) in Jn 3:16 is conditioned on continuous faith
since John does not say ou me apollumi (will certainly not perish). However, ou me apollumi is the very expression
John uses in Jn 10:28! To use Lavender’s words, the believer can “in no wise perish.” Lavender’s argument self-
destructs with the chart that he himself supplies a few pages later.853 In conjunction with the admission that
Lavender himself makes concerning ou me, I simply will respond in terms of my above illustration with a
contraposition of a negation:
                                     Illustration 161. Contraposition of Negation

       • If a person ever believes, then that person will never perish (P ⇒ Q). True.
       • If a person ever perishes, then that person never believed (Q ⇒ P). True.
        To reinforce the above contrapositions, let it be noted that ou me frequently is translated as never, especially
in Jn 10:28. In fact, BDAG suggests this translation for both Jn 8:52 and 10:28. The interesting thing about Jn 8:52
is that the condition is expressed by an aorist subjunctive: “If anyone keeps [punctiliar] My word, he shall never
[ou me] taste of death.” Those who at any time ever keep Jesus’ word by believing in Him for eternal life are
promised that they will never taste of death. By Lavender’s own admission, once you have met the condition, the
ou me result becomes unconditional and irreversible. The result is linear—never perish. The condition is
punctiliar—ever believe (i.e., at any point in time).
      Although pointing out Lavender’s inconsistency above destroys his argument, I do not want to overstate my
counterargument by giving the false impression that the mere presence of ou me proves punctiliar contingency.
Fidelity to the Scripture is more important than winning an argument. To be sure, once the condition has been met,
the ou me result becomes unconditional and irreversible. The question, however, raised by the astute Arminian is,
“When have you met the condition?” If it is a linear condition, then you are still in process of meeting it.

    See John in Living Color.
