                                   We have become partakers                  If we hold fast

       An irreversible linear consequence (i.e., £) that can never happen does not necessarily demand a punctiliar
contingency (i.e., z) as it does in row one (z£). An irreversible result can in fact be based on linear contingency
as in row 2 (££) or row three (£z).† From a similar point of view, it might be stated that a result which is
(partially) irreversible can be based on ongoing parallel contingency as in row 4 (£                      ●▬
                                                                                       £) or as in row 5 ( £). A clear
case of this phenomenon using ou me occurs when Peter says, “As long as you practice these things, you will never
stumble” (2Pet 1:10). The emphatic guarantee that these believers never will stumble is conditioned linearly on
their practicing these things and may be nullified if they cease such practice. God promises that we never will
stumble as long as we practice His word. This phrase as long as is added by the NAS to bring out the sense of the
anarthrous present participle, and I do not object to this rendering in this context. God will not allow us to stumble,
much less cause us to stumble, as long as we practice His word. In this promise, God irreversibly has obligated
Himself to us with ou me. Since the realization of this promise is exclusively contingent upon our linear practice, it
is unilaterally contingent on our performance. The ou me rules out ongoing bilateral contingency. We do not have
to worry about God keeping His part of the promise if we will just fulfill our part of the condition necessary to
experience the benefit. But since our experience of this benefit can come and go, it cannot be truly said that
the benefit is completely irreversible. So an Arminian could argue that the syntax in Jn 10:27-28 allows for the
possibility that Jesus means, “As long as they follow, they will never perish,” arguing that the present tense of
follow suggests linear action. If this were indeed the case, then it would be an example of parallel linear
contingency (i.e., ££).

                                       Illustration 163. Irreversibility and Contingency

                Irreversibility                       Contingency
    1.Bilateral—neither party can reverse Nonlateral—contingent on neither party
    2.Unilateral—one party can reverse    Unilateral—contingent on one party
    3.Nonlateral—both parties can reverse Bilateral—contingent on both parties

Bilaterally Irreversible
       If the benefit is truly irreversible, or what I am calling bilaterally irreversible, then there cannot be any
remaining unfulfilled contingencies. Any contingency in question already must have been fulfilled completely,
either punctiliarly or linearly. The inverse relationship in terminology between irreversibility and contingency is
such that if the result is bilaterally irreversible, then it is nonlaterally contingent.‡ Since neither party can reverse
the result, the result is no longer contingent.

*
  Although Mk 13:13 and Heb 3:6,14 are not litotetic and do not use ou me, for the sake of completeness they are included in the chart
to provide other forms of contingency discussed in the present book.
†
  See “Conditional and Unconditional Promises” in Sealed and Secure.
‡
  The term nonlateral is being used in distinction to bilateral and unilateral to designate a consequence which has no remaining
conditions. In football, the quarterback can call for an offensive play known as the option. In doing so, he can run around the end and
have the option of making a lateral pass to a receiver running beside him. The ou me in an OSAS passage is like a defensive end who
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                                               Page 489
       Truly irreversible results are possible of being conferred from one person to another. Suppose someone who
has an incurable deadly disease were to transmit this disease to someone else sexually. After the transmission takes
place, there is nothing that either one of them can do that will undo the damage. Once the fatal disease has been
transmitted, the result is certain. The claim of OSAS, as pictured in option one above, is that the impartation of
eternal life is bilaterally irreversible and therefore the retention of eternal life is no longer contingent. The life
imparted by God in regeneration is eternal; therefore, the recipient of such life cannot die in the sense of losing the
benefit imparted in regeneration.

Unilateral Irreversibility
       On the other hand, if the impartation of eternal life simply were unilaterally irreversible (i.e., undoable by
God), then the believer (as the recipient) could undo the impartation. The retention of regeneration would be
unilaterally contingent on the recipient keeping the gift of eternal life. NOSAS prefers this (the second) option.
Eternal life is yours as long as you follow Christ. God will not change His mind on giving you eternal life as long
as you believe.

Nonlaterally Irreversible
        A harsher form of NOSAS would claim that the impartation of eternal life is nonlaterally irreversible. That
is, the impartation is reversible by either party. Not only could the recipient lose the gift of eternal life. God might
go back on His promise and take it from the recipient. In such a scenario, the retention of regeneration would be
bilaterally conditioned on the recipient keeping it and God not taking it. Engaging this form of NOSAS is
unnecessary since doing so would be basically attacking a strawman. The more astute NOSAS advocates tend to be
perceptive enough to realize that option three is not a theological possibility. In light of the context of the present
passage (Jn 10:28-29) and the conceptual parallel in a passage such as Rom 8:38-39, informed Arminians generally
will admit that God securely holds on to believers so that the only way believers possibly might escape this
security (within their system) would be to cease to be a believer (i.e., cease to be a sheep in this context) and
thereby squirm out of God’s hand by their own doing. So dealing with this option is unnecessary. Besides, proving
option one dispels both NOSAS options two and three.

                                                 OSAS Response
       In my humble attempt not to overstate the OSAS case by mounting a better NOSAS counterargument above
than that offered by Lavender, I do not wish to understate the OSAS response either. In the examples provided by
the scriptural citations above in Illustration 162. Contingency and Consequence, linear contingency results in a
reward, not a gift. Perseverance results in a reward, not a gift. Moreover, the nature of the gift and the timing of its
impartation make linear contingency impossible.

 Rewarded Contingency
       The sequentially linear result of not stumbling temporally in 2Pet 1:10 results in a sequentially linear result
of a misthologically abundant entrance in 2Pet 1:11. Not stumbling is itself a temporal reward. If, owing to its OT
background, Heb 13:5 is taken as referring to God not withdrawing from us temporally, then it also is presenting a
temporal reward.* Temporally overcoming is rewarded subsequently with an honored name in Rev 3:5. One would
likewise expect that if Jn 10:28 actually were stipulating linear contingency, then it would also present a
misthological result. Jesus promises misthological honor to those who follow Him in ongoing discipleship
(Jn 12:26). Since the soteriological nature of 10:28 is readily agreed upon, the punctiliar nature of the contingency
should be as well because one is given eternal life the moment one comes to faith, not after a life of faithfulness.
Follow in the context of 10:28 simply means to follow the Lord in saving faith (i.e., follow = believe).†




takes out the optional receiver, leaving no possibility of a lateral pass. The quarterback is stuck with the ball and must run with it
himself. Nonlateral is thus useful for describing contingency, but it is not practical for describing irreversibility. A nonlateral
irreversibility would be negation of the irreversibility so that it is actually reversible by either party. Similarly, in math the product of
two negatives is a positive.
*
  See endnote 1115 for an alternative interpretation.
†
  See “Follow in Jn 10:27” in the author’s Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John. For other
possibilities, see The Race of Grace.
Page 490                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
Irreversible Transition
        As human beings we can transmit death irreversibly, but we cannot transmit life irreversibly. God, on the
other hand, can transmit life irreversibly. The disagreement between OSAS and NOSAS is whether the Lord’s
transmission of eternal life is truly irreversible. If it is truly irreversible, then it is no longer contingent, even
unilaterally, after the transmission takes place. Although life itself may be said to be dynamic, an irreversible
transition from death to life would be static. The transition itself would be a one-way, over-and-done-with, never-
to-be-repeated event. The internalization and transition regarding the impartation of eternal life already have been
completed irreversibly according to cross references such as Jn 4:14 and 5:24. Therefore, my argument for OSAS
is based on much more than a simplistic appeal to the syntax. The nature, timing, and scope of the consequence (in
conjunction with similar contemplations regarding the condition) have been taken into consideration as well.
        The question is not, “Does the phrase ou me necessarily demonstrate complete irreversibility independent of
the context?” It does not. In and of itself ou me merely rules out bilateral contingency. Rather, the question is,
“Can ou me be used in conjunction with other factors to signify complete irreversibility?” Certainly. The litotetic
texts regarding the impartation of eternal life provide one such example. The sheer nature of the gift in Jn 10:28
rules out soteric reversibility since Jesus promises: “I give eternal life to them, and forever they will never ever
perish; and no one will snatch them out of My hand” (TM). It is eternal life. The contextual stress is on the
irreversible nature of this transaction since the one who receives such life will never perish nor be taken out of
Jesus’ hand. One is not left the option of simply affirming the soteric quality of eternal life and denying its
quantity.*
        Second, the fact that the one to whom Jesus gives (didomi) such life will never perish stresses the security of
the recipient. The stress is not on a unilateral retention of the gift, but a unilateral impartation which results in a
nonlateral retention. In other words, the emphasis of the text is that the one who is given the gift is kept in Jesus’
hand, not that the one who keeps the gift is kept: given-kept, not keeps-kept.
        If the retention of eternal life is bilaterally irreversible, as indicated by the context, then retention must be
based on punctiliar contingency since the retention in such a case such as this must be conditioned only on the
punctiliar impartation. The promise—if you believe you will not perish—is unilaterally conditional when made but
becomes bilaterally irreversible when the condition has been met. The condition is met at the point of saving faith.
        To clarify my concession made above with the observation being made here, the impartation of eternal life
is unilateral in that if you simply believe, God will give you eternal life. The retention of eternal life is bilaterally
irreversible in that even if you subsequently disbelieve, God cannot take eternal life away from you. As for your
part, you cannot dissolve eternal life. You cannot kill it. You cannot give it away. And you cannot give it back.

                                             The Believer’s Name in Rev 3:5
       John’s readership would be very familiar with his use of litotes to affirm the doctrine of eternal security.
Due to their familiarity with this doctrine and with John’s use of litotes, they would have little trouble
understanding Rev 3:5. “He who overcomes shall thus be clothed in white garments; and I will not erase his name
from the book of life, and I will confess his name before My Father, and before His angels.” Surveying four
principal interpretations of the verse will suffice to demonstrate the compatibility of this positive promise with
unconditional soteriological security.
                                          Illustration 164. Four Interpretations of Rev 3:5

 Unbelievers            whose names are                  blotted out   and who lose the       Gift      of eternal life.
       Believers        whose names are                  blotted out   and who lose the       Gift      of eternal life.
       Believers        whose names are                  blotted out   and who lose the      reward     of eternal life.
       Believers        whose names are           not blotted out      and who gain the      reward     of eternal life.

 Unbelievers who were Never Really Saved
      The first interpretation represented on the chart is a Calvinistic one that considers the reference to be to
unbelievers whose names are blotted out of the book and who thus lose, forfeit, or fail to get the gift of eternal life
when they stand before the Lord in judgment. The problem with this interpretation is that it assumes that

*
    See Illustration 258. Quality versus Quantity, 725.
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                           Page 491
unbelievers’ names were ever written in the Book of Life, even though they never had eternal life. But if the Book
of Life is a record of those who have spiritual life, then it cannot have the name of unbelievers. How can
unbelievers lose something they never had? The problem still remains even if it is argued that at the time of death,
their name is erased to show that they never had life. The book is a record of those who have been purchased by the
blood of Jesus.
        Paul affirms that the names of his fellow workers are in the Book of Life (Phil 4:3). This would be a
pointless statement if everyone’s names (lost and saved) are recorded there. Likewise, when Jesus tells believers to
rejoice because their names are recorded in heaven (Lk 10:20), He is not telling them to do something ridiculous. It
would be foolish to rejoice that your name is recorded in the Book of Life if this book is merely a record of
everyone’s name, lost and saved, as the first interpretation assumes. It would almost be equally foolish to rejoice
that your name is recorded there as a believer if it could be erased as the second interpretation assumes.
        From Rev 5:9 one also gets the impression that this book is the record of those who have been redeemed
(agorazo): “And they sang a new song, saying, ‘Worthy art Thou to take the book, and to break its seals; for Thou
wast slain, and didst purchase [redeem] for God with Thy blood men from every tribe and tongue and people and
nation.’” Although Rev 5:9 is probably referring to the book of destiny (the scroll containing the rest of the book of
Revelation), rather than directly to the Book of Life, the opening of the Book of Life in 20:15 may very well be a
part of that scroll. In which case, the Book of Life is part of the book of destiny. The book of destiny is not only
concerned with the fate of the lost. It is also concerned with the fate of the redeemed and reveals their fate and
eternal state by picturing their names in the Book of Life (Rev 13:8; 17:8; 20:15). In any case, since the book of
destiny is associated with the names of the redeemed in 5:9, surely the Book of Life is even more so and restricted
to the redeemed since the Book of Life is a record of those who have spiritual life and who are thus delivered from
the spiritual death of Rev 20:15.
        Also, multiple confirmations within Revelation demonstrate that those whose names are not in the Book of
Life were never recorded there. “And all who dwell on the earth will worship him, everyone whose name has not
been written from the foundation of the world in the book of life of the Lamb who has been slain” (Rev 13:8).
“Those who dwell on the earth will wonder, whose name has not been written in the book of life from the
foundation of the world” (Rev 17:8). The lost are those whose names were not written from the foundation of the
world, not those whose names are erased. The names of those who never trust Jesus as their Savior are never
recorded there. If your name is not there, it was never there. The situation is similar to Mt 7:23 where Jesus says
that He “never knew” those unbelievers who claim to have belonged to Him. Their names were never recorded.
Permanence permeates the whole concept of having or not having one’s name recorded from the foundation of the
world. Conversely, those who have their name in the Book of Life have had it there from eternity and for eternity.
It represents those who possess eternal life. The situation is not that Jesus used to know them or that their name
used to be recorded. What has been written formerly has been written permanently.
        The next objection to this Calvinistic interpretation is even more serious and can be best expressed by
answering a few simple questions from the perspective of this interpretation. What happens to you if your name is
erased? You go to hell. “And if anyone’s name was not found written in the book of life, he was thrown into the
lake of fire” (Rev 20:15). What determines whether your name is erased according to this interpretation? Whether
or not you overcome is the obvious answer: “He who overcomes shall thus be clothed in white garments; and I will
not erase his name from the book of life” (Rev 3:5). However, overcoming in Revelation chs. 2-3 means more than
just simply believing. Although some mistakenly think that all believers are overcomers in the sense described in
Rev 2-3, it must be acknowledged that in these chapters overcoming contextually means more than just simply
believing. Even those who believe that all believers are overcomers in Revelation have to concede that overcoming
means more than just responding in passive faith to the gospel. Contextually, they are forced to admit that it is an
active response that involves works. But if whether one ends up in hell is determined ultimately by whether one
actively overcomes, then salvation from hell is not by simple faith alone but is based on a synergistic requirement.
This accursed soteriology must be rejected. Whether we go to hell is not determined by whether we overcome in
terms of our performance. This Calvinistic performance-based soteriology is hermeneutically defective in that it
ultimately teaches that salvation from hell is by works. The argument that all genuine believers will overcome also
runs into the immediate problem that these warnings and exhortations to overcome were intended for genuine
believers. Therefore, the first interpretation on the chart, the Calvinistic interpretation, must be rejected because it
teaches salvation by works.854

 Believers who lose Salvation
      The second interpretation, the Arminian position that believers’ names can be erased, must be rejected for
the same reasons outlined above concerning interpretation number one. The Book of Life, as used in Revelation,
Page 492                                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
refers to the names of those who have spiritual life; this is, it refers to the redeemed. Their names are there
permanently and will never be erased. The Book of Life is a grace concept that is used to teach a reward concept in
this passage. The presence of our names in the Book of Life is a picture of salvation by grace. We do not deserve to
have our names written there. We deserve the Lake of Fire. Since the presence of our names is not based on what
we do but what we believe, our failure to overcome cannot be the basis for our names being removed. By saying
that He will do the opposite of nullifying the grace concept (represented in the presence of the name), Jesus uses a
litotes to advance to the doctrine of rewards. The doctrine of rewards is founded upon the doctrine of grace. Before
we can earn rewards within heaven, we must first experience the grace that will take us into heaven.
        Since overcoming contextually means more than simply to believe, this passage cannot be interpreted
soteriologically as making our salvation from the Lake of Fire dependent upon our overcoming. These first two
interpretations must both be categorically rejected because they result in an accursed gospel.
                                                Illustration 165. Not Erased = Litotes




 Believers who lose Rewards
       Although the passage is not talking about soteriological deliverance from the Lake of Fire, two
interpretations still remain, both of which correctly understand that the issue is rewards.* Fuller argues that the
name represents a believer’s reputation rather than a litotes. Believers may lose their good reputation (cf. Rev 3:1)
and the rewards associated with it in heaven. Thus, a believer’s name (in the sense of good reputation) may be
blotted out, with the result that the believer will lose rewards in heaven, but he or she will not be cast into the Lake
of Fire. Fuller’s interaction with the text is commendable in a variety of areas. He understands that making the term
overcomer apply to all believers


*
  There are actually at least two other ultraistic interpretations as well. See Preliminary Remarks on Book of Life, 69. However, one
was dismissed initially, and the other one is similar to the third interpretation discussed here. The ultraistic version of this third option
is beset with even more difficulties than the one under present discussion and hence is not dealt with in this section.
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                           Page 493
       is not exegetically sound in Revelation, and it virtually eliminates each of the letter’s respective
       motivations to remain faithful as well as the very need to urge faithfulness. A command that everyone
       keeps is superfluous, and a reward that everyone receives for a virtue that everyone has is nonsense.
       Surely the burden of proof is on the shoulders of those who would argue that the warnings are not
       genuinely addressed to true believers as they seem to be and that the promises are genuinely
       addressed to all believers (as they do not seem to be). Hence the “overcomer” is the individual
       Christian who enjoys special benefits in eternity for refusing to give up his faith in spite of
       persecution during life on earth.855

Also, Fuller correctly understands that the verse is dealing with rewards:

       When the context of Rev 3:5 is honored, it is best understood not in soteriological terms….It
       promises a unique and honorable eternal identity. The unfaithful Christian, conversely, will find that
       even as he on earth was ashamed of Christ’s onoma [name], Christ will in heaven be ashamed of his
       (Matt 10:33; 2Tim 2:12). It is a promise and threat.856

       Clarification might be increased slightly by pointing out that 3:5 itself is a misthological promise rather than
a threat; nevertheless, the conceptual parallels in Mt 10:33 and 2Tim 2:12 do contain the negative flipside of what
happens to the names of believers who do not overcome. To Fuller’s credit, he also rejects the first interpretation,
which is that of Walvoord, by pointing out that Walvoord’s position “contradicts Rev 13:8; 17:8, which indicate
that the names are or are not written ‘from the foundation of the world.’ The names are either permanently present
or absent, according to two very clear statements.”857 Fuller’s observation also renders interpretation number two
unlikely, as pointed out above. However, Fuller’s own argument makes his own interpretation (number three)
unlikely as well. The names are not blotted out. They are there permanently. One need not abandon interpreting the
passage litotetically in order to interpret it correlatively.

 Believers who gain Rewards
        This brings us to the fourth interpretation, which is that it is impossible for anyone’s name to be erased from
the Book of Life, as it is pictured in the book of Revelation.858 Jesus is denying an impossibility and as such should
be understood as presenting a litotes. This position is contextually conformed by the presence of other litotes in the
immediate context (Rev 2:11; 3:8,10,12). As noted above in Illustration 158. Johannine Litotes, it is best to agree
with such diverse interpreters like Lenski, Lloyd-Jones, Benedict, Dillow, Hodges, and Wilkin that a litotes is
being used here in Rev 3:5 as well. The presence of a litotes in 3:5 has been confirmed by interpreters from all
three soteriological persuasions: Arminianism, Marrowism, and Calvinism.
        Lloyd-Jones is a Calvinistic interpreter who gives an excellent defense of the interpretation that Rev 3:5 is a
litotes. His argument is based primarily on a comparison of Rev 13:8 and 17:8 with Eph 1:4 and the conclusion that
the names must have been recorded on the basis of God’s foreknowledge. Since the book represents what God
foreknows, if a name is erased, then God is mistaken in His foreknowledge—which is impossible. Consequently, it
is impossible for a name to be erased. Unfortunately, Lloyd-Jones uses this litotetic affirmation in his defense of
the Calvinistic doctrine of perseverance. He says that “the opponents of the doctrine of perseverance emphasize the
negative statement, ‘I will not erase his name out of the book of life.’ That implies, they argue, that there are others
whose names will be blotted out of the book of life.”859 However, not all opponents of the Calvinistic doctrine of
perseverance believe that the verse implies the negative erasing. There are exceptions to this rule of thumb.
Marrowists do not necessarily believe a threat of erasing is in view. And they are not the only exceptions.
        Lenski, a Lutheran, may be considered a representative of the Arminian camp in that he rejects the doctrine
of perseverance and does not believe in eternal security. Yet, like Lloyd-Jones, Lenski affirms that 3:5 is a
litotes.860 Overcomers will never have their names erased. The difference is that Lloyd-Jones interprets the verse
from the Calvinistic grid that assumes that all believers are overcomers and that the issue is the distinction between
genuine and professing believers. Lenski, on the other hand, does not believe that all genuine believers will
overcome. Instead, he believes that genuine believers may lose eternal life. For example, Lenski says concerning
Rev 2:10 and 3:11 that “to lose the crown is to lose ‘the life’ (2:10), eternal salvation, our share in the
kingdom…plunging us back into death where there is no crown.”861 Thus, from Lenski’s perspective, retaining
eternal life is based on one’s continuance in faith. The same is true in Reformed Arminianism. Although Walvoord
tries to avoid this Arminian conclusion by countering with his Calvinistic doctrine of perseverance, in reality he
holds the same position. Concerning 2:10 Walvoord states that by “being faithful unto death, they would be all the
more sure that they would receive the crown of life. This is not to be understood as a crown or a reward attending
Page 494                                                                                               The Outer Darkness
                                                                          862
eternal life, but rather that their crown would be life eternal itself.” For both Lenski and Walvoord, what is at
stake is eternal life itself, and it is dependent upon holding fast, upon overcoming, upon faithfulness, and thus upon
works.
        In reality, both Arminians and Calvinists agree that salvation from hell is by works; they simply disagree on
how to articulate it. For Arminians, salvation from hell is a reward that may be lost by those who fail to persevere
in faith and/or faithfulness. For Calvinists, it is a reward that will not be lost because all believers will persevere.
For both groups, it is a reward that necessitates perseverance for its attainment. By making the final realization of
eternal life a joint soteriological and misthological concept, in the end both Lenski and Walvoord effectively
nullify the possibility of regarding eternal life as a gift. The litotetic proposal is far superior in that it allows one to
maintain the NT distinction between gift and reward. Entrance into heaven is free. The most natural Marrowistic
interpretation is the litotetic affirmation.
        Lloyd-Jones is correct, however, concerning the implications of 13:8; 17:8, and God’s foreknowledge. The
presence of the names from eternity past reflects God’s foreknowledge and thus the immutability of the names—
they cannot be removed. The promise is a litotes. Lenski has the stronger argument concerning the meaning of
what it means to be an overcomer in the book of Revelation and in concluding that not all believers will overcome.
Taking the strengths of both positions together would yield the conclusion that the promise is a litotes limited to
those believers who experientially overcome.
        The other interpreters mentioned above, who believe that 3:5 is a litotes, are from the FG camp and have the
best of both arguments. They agree with the Calvinists that the implication of 13:8 and 17:8 and God’s
foreknowledge is that the believer cannot lose eternal life. At the same time, they also agree with the Arminians
that believers may fail to persevere. Marrowism has the best that both Arminianism and Calvinism have to offer
without their inherent weaknesses. Rather than having erased names (which is impossible anyway), overcomers
will have confessed names, as the verse itself goes on to say: “He who overcomes will thus be clothed in white
garments, and [kai] I will not erase his name from the Book of Life; instead [kai], I will confess his name before
My Father and before His angels” (Rev 3:5; TM).
        Dana complains that the translations of kai have been too limited in the past and suggests adversative
translations such as however and but, allowing the context to determine the best possible translation.863 Wallace
calls this use of the adversative the contrastive conjunctive and adds rather, yet, and though as possible
translations.864 A number of translations have adopted the contrastive translation of but for the second kai. But this
seems a little mild for the context. A better translation that conveys the power of this contrast is instead. Instead of
erasing an overcomer’s name, Jesus promises to confess it. As a matter of fact, this contrast might even be
considered emphatic and rendered indeed. It is an emphatic contrast. The names of these believers will be honored.
Overcomers will receive a new name (Rev 2:17; 3:12), the name of God, and the name of New Jerusalem (3:12).
The best the world can do to honor a great actor’s name is to put it up in lights. The Lord will do much better for
His overcomers! If one must understand the passage as implying a threat, then let it be the threat of not having
one’s name confessed rather than erased. This is the proper correlation between eraser and confessor.

                                                     Conclusion
       This rather elementary overview of Johannine litotes has been confined primarily to the litotes that already
have been noted by others. Some of these litotes concern eternal rewards in the eternal state. However, additional
undocumented Johannine litotes concerning rewards in the eternal state merit attention also. Before proceeding to
this more advanced interaction with litotes, it is worthwhile to note in passing that all positive litotes in the Gospel
of John apply to all believers. In contrast, none of the positive litotes in Revelation made to believers apply to
all believers; they only apply to overcomers. The significance of this limitation in Revelation will be more
apparent in the remaining chapters of this section.
       Many will object by asserting that everybody will be happy in heaven. Such sentiment only begs the
question, “Will everyone be equally happy in heaven?” Certainly not. Some will be happier than others. Will
everyone maintain whatever their personal degree of happiness is without fluctuation? Apparently not. Believers
will not be emotionally frozen at one constant temperament. Can sorrow and happiness coexist? Apparently so.
Paul teaches that spiritual believers on earth can simultaneously experience both joy and sorrow (2Cor 6:10). There
seems to be little compelling reason to think that it is that different for glorified believers in heaven. After all, even
God who inhabits heaven can experience sorrow: “And the Lord was sorry that He had made man on the earth, and
He was grieved in His heart” (Gen 6:6). If God can be grieved in His heart while living in heaven, what is to
preclude believers from at least experiencing occasional grief or simultaneous sorrow in their hearts while living in
heaven. If God expresses sorrow at the JSC over the way we have lived on earth, who are we to think that we will
be rejoicing over it?
Chapter 21. Litotes                                                                                        Page 495
       Unfaithful believers will be happy that they are in heaven, but simultaneously they will be sorry for the way
they have lived on earth, especially when they are excluded from rulership of the earth. At the JSC those who have
been found unfaithful at the Bema will not break out singing the hymn: “Everybody will be happy over there.”
While there may be some truth to that song, those weeping and gnashing their teeth will not be participating in that
song, at least not while they are weeping and gnashing their teeth. Of course, they will be happy to some extent
sometime. However, the elation intended by that song would be better expressed if the words were changed to:
“Overcomers will be happy over there, over there.” The Lord’s intent is not to picture subcomers as being happy
in the outer darkness. Whatever degree of happiness subcoming believers have in heaven will (at times) be
overshadowed by the simultaneous and overpowering sorrow they experience there.
Page 496   The Outer Darkness
                                            Chapter 22.
                                      Who are the Overcomers?
                                                   Introduction
        Throughout this present book it has been assumed that not all believers are overcomers in the sense
described in the book of Revelation and thus that the promises to these overcomers do not apply to all believers.
Notwithstanding the preliminary reasons already cited,* in view of the argument above in the previous chapter (that
the litotes in Revelation apply only to overcomers but not to all believers), further substantiation of this position is
prudent. The various soteriological camps will be surveyed and further clarified. In the process, the confusion
resulting from taking overcomer to be a soteriological theme in this eschatological epistle will become redundantly
and painfully apparent. A litotetic Marrowistic exegesis, on the other hand, can easily break through these weak
soteriological entrenchments and reestablish hermeneutical order.

                                              Theological Camps

Arminian
      Arminian interpreters are completely free within their theological tradition to affirm that those believers who
subcome are regenerate. The contribution to the discussion by Arminian interpreters is limited, however, by their
departure from classic Arminianism in insisting that what is at stake for the subcomer is eternal damnation. That
Arminius himself would affirm NOSAS is doubtful, despite the prevalence of his contemporary followers in doing
so. My belief in OSAS, as affirmed by John in his gospel account, leads me to join Arminius in questioning
contemporary Arminians who affirm that believers can be subjected to such torment.
      Granted, Corner, a contemporary Arminian, will object to my statement about Arminius, just as he does to
Hunt and Vance, my fellow non-Calvinists. To prove his point, Corner gives this quote from Arminius: “If David
had died in the very moment in which he had sinned against Uriah by adultery and murder, he would have been
condemned to eternal death” (bold italic mine, simple bold Corner’s).865 Corner then makes this assertion:

          Dave Hunt and Laurence Vance both try to portray James Arminius in their writings as
          someone who was not definite about a one-time believer losing his salvation, but the above
          quote about King David when in adultery and murder could not be more clear as to show what
          Arminius believed about loss of salvation. (Bold his, italic mine.)

        Actually, it could be a lot clearer. In Corner’s own citations, Arminius is only saying, “If David had....”
Corner put the emphasis on the second half of the statement, but if the emphasis is placed on the first half of the
sentence, as done above with the bold italic, then it leaves one to question if Corner has considered the difference
between potentially losing regeneration versus actually losing it. Even Calvinists such as Pink will affirm that the
elect potentially could lose regeneration if they do not persevere. What Pink would deny is that this potentiality
becomes a reality. This same weakness is also evident in Corner’s other quote of Arminius on that same page, “If it
[were to] happen that this member grows slothful...becomes half-death; and so at length..dies altogether,
[then he] ceases to be a member [of Christ]” (bold his, italic mine).866 If it were to happen cannot be assumed to
mean that it does happen. The question is, “From Arminius’ perspective, does it happen?”
        One might just consider this an oversight on Corner’s part. Still, this is difficult to do since he is trying to
portray non-Arminians as being the only ones who raise this question. The truth of the matter, though, is that some
Arminians would voice the same evaluation as do Hunt and Vance. In his opening chapter, Picirilli, an Arminian,
states: “Arminius was cautious.” Picirilli then provides the same standard quote from Arminius that is provided by
Vance and Hunt, in which Arminius affirms: “I never taught that a true believer can either totally or finally fall
away from the faith and perish, yet I will not conceal that there are passages of Scripture which seem to me to wear
this aspect” (emphasis his).867 Picirilli then documents this quote in its full context on the first page of his ch. 12
and then goes on to say that these matters are “debated by Arminians within their own ranks.”868
        Corner is being less than candid with his readers. But to be fair to my readers, let me point out that Picirilli
does go on to express a sentiment that seems to approximate the point Corner is trying to make. In Picirilli’s
opinion, Arminius “apparently agreed with Augustine, that the regenerate who apostatize are non-elect.”869 If this

*
    See Purpose and Recipients, 34.
Page 498                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
is the correct view of Arminius’ theology (and it will be left to his followers to duke it out for themselves as to
whether or not it is), then only non-elect believers can lose regeneration within classical Arminianism. In any
event, it would appear to be inconsistent to base election on perseverance and then turn around and base
perseverance on election. I will leave Arminius to the fate of his inconsistency or ambiguity, as the case may be.

Grace Calvinists
       In contrast, Calvinistic interpreters would find it very difficult to affirm that those who subcome are true
believers due to the Calvinistic doctrine of perseverance. For example, Ryrie is a Grace Calvinist. As such, he
acknowledges that those being addressed in chs. 2-3 of Revelation who are in need of repentance in the churches
are Christians (i.e., regenerate believers).870 The reason Ryrie can make this affirmation is because he defines
perseverance in terms of preservation. However, he acknowledges that others within this Calvinistic camp would
rule out the possibility of subcomers being believers: “Some who approach this doctrine from the emphasis of
perseverance deny the possibility of a believer being carnal.”871 For an analysis which affirms that the regenerate
can indeed be carnal, one may consult Wilkin’s thesis concerning perseverance.872
       Unfortunately, Ryrie is terribly inconsistent in his statements concerning the identity of the overcomers. In
the notes of his study Bible, he states concerning Rev 2:7 that overcomers refers to “all true Christians (cf.
1 John 5:5).”873 Even if his assessment were accurate (and I am not inclined to think that it is for v. 5), how does
one reconcile this with his statement above that the exhortations to repent are addressed to Christians? If those who
are subcoming are the ones being exhorted to repent, then they are not overcoming. Yet if they are not overcomers,
then according to his study Bible they are not Christians. His logic leads to the conclusion that those being
exhorted to repent are not genuine Christians. However, this is in conflict with what he said in his book Salvation,
in which he states that the exhortations to repent are addressed to believers. Ryrie’s definition of overcomer in his
Theology is well stated:

       Every believer, whether new or mature, has victory simply because he is a believer….this
       overcoming is not something that is subsequent to salvation…
            Effecting that victory will involve habits, defenses, activities, but it is our faith in Jesus that
       makes us believers and thus overcomers.874

        Perhaps this definition of overcomer is feasible in 1Jn 5:4. The problem is that Ryrie imports this meaning
into Rev 2-3, despite the obvious conflict between his definition and the context of chs. 2-3. According to his
definition, even new believers are overcomers. Yet new believers are baby Christians; they are immature; they are
carnal. The implication of his definition, then, is that carnal believers are overcomers. This may be true in 1Jn 5:4,
but it certainly is not true in Rev 2-3 (and not necessarily true in 1Jn 5:5). Furthermore, the impression one receives
from his definition is that all believers are overcomers whether or not they experience victory. According to his
definition, the designation overcomer is based on what you have believed in the past, not on what you believe or do
in the present. Again, this is true of what the term means in 1Jn 5:4, but it fails to do justice to the context of Rev 2-
3. Moreover, it probably fails to adequately explain the context of 1Jn 5:4—if 1Jn 5:5 is referring to experiential
overcoming. In 1Jn 5:5, present faith puts a believer in a position where that believer can overcome experientially.
In that capacity, the fact that all overcomers are believers does not prove that all believers are overcomers. John’s
statement in 1Jn 5:5 not only lays the foundation for the experiential overcoming found in Rev 2-3, but a proper
understanding of 1Jn 5:5 is informed by the latter text. In the latter context, what a believer does determines
whether he or she will be regarded as an overcomer. Not even persevering in faith is enough to qualify the believer
as an overcomer in Rev 2-3, so how can merely being a believer qualify one as an overcomer?
        As expected, Ryrie’s position crashes upon the rocks of realism when it reaches the shores of his
commentary on Revelation. When his Calvinistic soteriology meets the exegetical highway, the skid marks indicate
that a crash has occurred. Concerning Rev 2:11, he again takes the position that all believers are overcomers: “The
promise to the believer-overcomer is that he or she shall not have a part in the second death, which is the lake of
fire (20:14; 21:8). In other words, the believer will share in the resurrection, not in the torment that awaits the
unbeliever.”875
        However, Ryrie then proceeds to limit the promise for overcomers to those believers who are faithful, in his
comments on Rev 2:26-28: “The faithful are promised association with Christ in His millennial reign.”876 In doing
so, Ryrie has now limited the reference to overcomers as a designation to faithful believers. Next, he proceeds in
his comments on Rev 3:5-6 to equate overcomers with “the true believing remnant in the church.”877 Thus,
overcomers are regarded as true believers, and those who fail to repent and overcome by being faithful are
regarded, by Ryrie, as false believers who will go to the Lake of Fire. The net result is that Ryrie is teaching that
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                            Page 499
salvation from the Lake of Fire is dependent upon a believer’s faithfulness. Faith is not enough. Salvation from hell
is dependent upon a believer’s works. In fact, in his Ryrie Study Bible, he provides an infamous footnote to Jam
2:24: “Unproductive faith cannot save, because it is not genuine faith. Faith and works are like a two-coupon ticket
to heaven. The coupon of works is not good for passage, and the coupon of faith is not valid if detached from
works.”878 In the final analysis, Ryrie conditions entrance into heaven on the evidence of one’s works. Ryrie’s FG
soteriology has been eclipsed by his Calvinistic presuppositions. Ryrie is very inconsistent in his FG affirmations.*
                                 Illustration 166. Inconsistent Frontloaders and Backloaders

      Category:                   1             2                 3                 4          5      6             7
Frontloader                      LS          FG/LS              FG/LS             FG/LS      FG      FG            FG
Backloader                       LS            LS               FG/LS              FG         LS    FG/LS          FG
Conclusion                       LS           ILS                ILS               ILS       ILS     IFG           FG

        FG theology is a moving target. Someone considered a leading defender of FG in years past may not be so
considered by today’s standards. Granted, it might not be completely fair to apply today’s standards to FG
proponents of the past. For example, although Martin Luther was a leading FG proponent in his day, his failure to
affirm the eternal security of the believer would be considered a major theological inconsistency by modern FG
advocates. Nevertheless, he generally would be considered a stellar (albeit inconsistent) defender of FG doctrine in
his day by many FG advocates in our day. Correspondingly, some FG advocates, such as Ryrie and Walvoord, find
themselves in a transitional period in which FG is rapidly being developed with greater precision and clarity as
contemporary FG advocates must contend with those who are trying to beat a LS path back to the soteriology of
Catholicism. When a doctrine comes under attack, it is further refined and defined. FG theology is, therefore, being
intensely scrutinized and finely honed.
        For example, as Ryrie himself acknowledges in his discussion of inerrancy, “To affirm clearly one’s belief
in the inspiration of the Bible demands many words today. That was not always so. Formerly, it was enough to say,
‘I believe in the inspiration of the Bible.’”879 As he goes on to explain, today “it has become necessary to say, “I
believe in the verbal, plenary, infallible, and unlimited inerrancy of the Bible.”880 Ryrie kept pace with his
discussion of inspiration, but he is lagging behind in the ramifications of his soteriology. The discussion in the FG
camp has moved on to show that the soteriological identification of all believers as overcomers in Rev 2-3 is a
view compatible with LS, not FG. Ryrie is not the only FG writer dragging his feet in making the inevitable
misthological identification of believers in this passage, but hopefully logical consistency will be persuasive
eventually.

                                                 Five Types of LS
       The above chart in Illustration 166 seeks to give objective criteria for subjective impressions whereby
various writers may be gauged in the soteriological spectrum. In Dillow’s opening chapter, he discusses the
problem of frontloading and backloading the gospel.881 An amplification of the GES motto in these terms is very
helpful. Salvation (from eternal damnation) is by (punctiliar) faith alone in Christ alone. The distinctive
characteristic of FG is to not add works as an exegetical requirement for salvation from eternal damnation on either
the front or backend of the gospel.
        To frontload the gospel with demands of good works at the beginning of the Christian experience clearly
adds works as a requirement for salvation at the point of regeneration. It would be extremely difficult for a person
hearing such a gospel to respond with simple faith in Christ alone for eternal life. They are told that eternal life is a
free gift but in order to receive it they must turn from their sins, be baptized, and make Jesus Lord of their lives,
etc. As a result, they are prevented, by such a perverted form of the gospel, from believing that eternal life is really
a free gift.
       On the other hand, someone who backloads the gospel by saying that good works are the inevitable results
of regeneration logically makes such works necessary for glorification. You cannot reach heaven without these
good works. If people were logically consistent, they could not believe that they could reach heaven without good

*
 FG = Free Grace Salvation or Free Grace Salvationist(s). It is used in distinction to LS.
LS = Lordship Salvation or Lordship Salvationist(s).
ILS = Inconsistent LS.
IFG = Inconsistent FG.
Page 500                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
works according to such theology. However, people fluctuate in terms of logical consistency, and some might
actually find it easier to believe that entrance into heaven is conditioned only upon faith when hearing this more
subtle form of perversion. In other words, since this perversion of the gospel is more pernicious, it might be easier
for some of those hearing this form of the gospel to slip through Satan’s fingers and actually believe the saving
component of the gospel. Although this form of the gospel is certainly poisoned, it may not prove equally fatal to
everyone who hears it. Not all forms of poison are equally fatal. Therefore, categories 1-5 are perversions of the
gospel ranked by degree of distortion, with category number one being the deadliest.

Typical LS Inconsistency
        Of course, all levels of Lordship Salvation are inconsistent since they maintain that salvation is by grace
apart from works and that works must be a part of that salvation. What is meant by acknowledging that level one of
LS is consistent is that this level of LS maintains that performance-related submission to the Lordship is required
both initially at the point of conversion and subsequently as a matter of discipleship, and that those espousing this
view use the typical LS verses in defending LS. These types of Lordship Salvation are being comparatively
consistent with their theology.
        Nevertheless, even among level-one LS, there are variations. Some LS pastors tend to preach salvation by
grace during the first part of their sermons and then switch to salvation by works during the last part of their
sermons. Others are content to preach a sermon of salvation by grace and then give an invitation indicating that one
is saved by works. For example, the alter call that implies that in order to truly be saved from hell one must walk
down the church isle and publicly confess Christ is a standard LS ploy to get unbelievers to go forward publicly.
Frequently, one will encounter LS pastors who preach salvation by grace for weeks, or sometimes even months,
and who then switch to salvation by works for another period of weeks or months. The author has been a member
in numerous LS churches and sat under pastors who fit each of these profiles. To say that a pastor is a consistent
LS is actually a misnomer since there is no such thing as consistent LS. Nevertheless, relatively speaking, the term
consistent LS may be used to describe those pastors who are consistent in their use of LS theology regarding
standard LS proof texts pertaining to both the initial and ongoing qualifications necessary to be considered a
genuine believer within their system.
        The second level of LS in Illustration 166 refers to someone who is inconsistent regarding the initial LS
requirements. Examples of this watered down LS would include those who claim that at the point of conversion
there must only be a temporary willingness to surrender to the Lordship in certain areas or a temporary willingness
to forsake certain sins. However, as noted on the chart, some LS who take this less offensive (yet deadly882) posture
concerning the initial requirements will then maintain that subsequent to regeneration there must be a radical
change of life that manifests itself in good works; otherwise, the conversion was not genuine. Practical
sanctification validates justification and is necessary for glorification. They use the standard LS proof texts to
argue that one cannot get into heaven apart from a life of good works.
        Category three represents the form of LS that mixes FG and LS perspectives concerning both initial and
subsequent requirements. Level four depicts those in LS who take mixed views regarding initial requirements but
FG views thereafter. For example, take the type of Baptist who strangely holds that one must submit to the
Lordship of Christ in order to become saved but does not require baptism to reach heaven. Certainly, this would be
a logical and theological inconsistency. Submission to the Lordship of Christ requires submission to Christian
baptism. This same Baptist might also acknowledge that such believers might subsequently live a life of
unfaithfulness, never follow through in discipleship, and wind up in the outer darkness as a result; nevertheless,
this Baptist might admit that such believers would still be saved from hell. This LS perspective concerning initial
surrender would be consistent with FG theology concerning the possibility of subsequent failure.
        The last level of LS pictured above is level five in which someone teaches that we are saved by faith alone
in Christ alone, but faith that saves is not alone.883 In other words, they adopt the FG perspective concerning the
initial requirement but then take the soft LS view in saying that regeneration must produce the anticipated change
in behavior. In this proveitistic view, fruit proves root. If your life does not visibly manifest good fruit, then you do
not have the root of regeneration. Once again, it would be impossible to enter heaven without the fruit, that is,
without the good works. Salvation from hell, ultimately, is jointly dependent upon regeneration and the subsequent
quality and quantity of one’s practical sanctification in Calvinism. Zeller would be an example of this approach. He
tries to follow Ryrie’s lead (described below), but Zeller is more of a category five writer than a category six, since
Zeller clearly rejects FG on the backend in seeking a mediating position between LS and FG. Admittedly, Zeller
rejects the frontal LS assault on the gospel but then swings the backdoor wide open to LS, in seeking to counter FG
theology concerning the results of regeneration and the requirements for ultimate entrance into heaven. Zeller is a
well-camouflaged LS.884
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                          Page 501
Fifth Degree LS Mathematics
        Zeller defends the fifth degree LS view by citing the following formulas by Kober as clarifying his view, as
if it were the correct view, supposedly superior to the incorrect view:

        Correct View: Grace + Faith = Salvation + Works
        Incorrect View: Grace + Faith + Works = Salvation885

        As will be shown subsequently, this fifth-degree LS mathematics is really no better than first-degree LS.*
According to both schemes, works are required to enter heaven and thus to be saved from hell. The salvation being
referenced above in Zeller’s equation is justification salvation (J) followed by postconversion works (W). He is not
referring to works that one performs after entering heaven but to works that one performs after experiencing saving
faith. Such faith must produce good works to save ultimately from hell according to Zeller’s mathematical
representation. Hence, Zeller in effect claims that J + W = S (salvation from hell). This is identical to full-fledged
LS claims made by MacArthur. According to both LS perspectives, after God has saved the believer from hell by
an act of forensic justification, the believer must produce good works in practical sanctification or he or she will go
to hell. In the final analysis, one cannot be saved from hell without good works, regardless of which degree of LS
is adopted. Soteriological salvation is dependent on both justification and sanctification. In effect, LS frequently
denies W + F = S but nevertheless affirms F + W = S. They backload saving faith with the necessity of
postconversional works in order to be saved from hell. They flip the order but not the requirement. From their
perspective good works are still necessary to reach heaven.

                                                Two Types of FG
        Turning now to FG writers, Ryrie is a category six writer (IFG in Illustration 166), who does an excellent
job on the front end, and he quite frequently does just as well on the backend. However, Ryrie’s identification of
the overcomers as all believers in Revelation is a backend LS argument in which he stumbles into the LS camp.
Consequently, he is inconsistent in his FG theology. As will be clarified subsequently, consistent FG theology
expects good works in the lives of those who have experienced regeneration. But unlike LS, FG does not demand
good works for authentication of justification and thus does not make entrance into heaven dependent upon
postconversional performance.† Good works are a practical expectation, not an absolute or theological obligation.‡
Believers are exhorted to overcome, yet many of them will fail to fulfill this expectation. Ryrie fails to
acknowledge this fact consistently, which results in a considerable inconsistency within his soteriology.
        Category seven refers to those FG writers who clearly are distinguished from the LS camp on both the front
end and backend issues. This does not mean that FG advocates always agree on every soteriological passage! Far
to the contrary, part of the richness and diversification within the FG movement is due to the fact that there are
frequently multiple interpretations that would be consistent with the FG position. Yet genuine diversification
should not be used as a cloak for interpretations which are definitively inferior. The present work is offered in the
hope, for example, that those in the FG camp who take a soteriological view of the outer darkness will come to see
that taking such a position makes them inconsistent with their FG perception. The outer darkness is a reward issue.
Hopefully, they will then move from a category six to a category seven by adopting the misthological interpretation
on this and similar topics. Indeed, perhaps future generations of FG advocates likewise may consider the FG
leaders today who take a soteriological view of the Bride to actually be category six FG advocates. In future
generations, bridal misthology may be perceived to be necessary to be consistent with FG theology. Even so, for
now, continuation of the discussion of the overcomer in the current theological climate suffices.

Calvinists
       The contribution of Calvinistic interpreters to the identification of the overcomer is diminished by their
denial that the subcomers are regenerate. For a rigorous rejection of the FG position, one may consult Rosscup,
who is in favor of the Calvinistic position that all believers overcome and persevere.886 Although the present writer
does not share Rosscup’s point of view, he nevertheless acknowledges that Rosscup’s criticism of Benedict’s FG
interpretation of Rev 2:11 is justified to an extent. Benedict suggests that there is a sense in which regenerate
subcomers can be hurt indirectly through others by the second death, although subcomers are eternally secure.

*
  See LS Mathematics, 617.
†
  See endnote 499.
‡
  See Theory of Misthological Relativity, 687.
Page 502                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
Rosscup responds that to be hurt by the second death is to be inflicted injury “directly, fully, eternally” (emphasis
his).887 Respectfully, the present work finds the probability of Benedict’s proposal that John intends to entertain the
idea of being hurt indirectly by the second death through others to be rather unlikely.* However, this admission by
the present FG writer does not mean that Rosscup’s Calvinistic interpretation must then be accepted by default. On
the contrary, a superior FG interpretation of the verse (taken by Hodges, Wilkin, and Dillow) is simply to treat it as
a litotes. These and other Grace authors cited below may be consulted for comparison with Rosscup’s specific
arguments.
        Moreover, the rejection herein of Benedict’s theory of indirectivity (as he has presented it) does not
necessitate agreement with Rosscup’s response.† The theory of correlativity proposed herein acknowledges that
John does not mean to insinuate that unfaithful believers are hurt directly by the second death. Does this mean that
theory of correlativity reduces to Benedict’s theory of indirectivity? Not really. The theory of correlativity has its
roots in typology. In typology the serpent on the pole represents Jesus on the cross (Jn 3:14). So would one say that
the serpent is Jesus indirectly? I hope not. Typologists are more refined and accurate in their statements. When the
misthological promise of not being hurt by the second death is read in conjunction with the second death having no
misthological power over the one not hurt misthologically by this death, then the affirmation may be allowed that
unfaithful believers are hurt by the second death in the sense of being correlatively, fully, and eternally inflicted
with the injury pictured by that death (Rev 2:11; Rev 20:6).‡ There is a direct correlation (not identification!)
between being the two.§ To be hurt by this death is to die. Unfaithful believers fully experience misthological
death, not mere misthological sickness. For both unbelievers and unfaithful believers, the results are eternal.
Benedict’s theory of indirectivity is too tame; the theory of correlativity, in contrast, is not a tame lion. It has teeth
and can use them quite effectively to devour the arguments of conditionalists. Yet one need not sic this lion upon
Rosscup to find sufficient justification for rejecting his conclusions.
        By way of general response, two glaring inconsistencies in Rosscup’s work may be pointed out. First, he
believes that “all of the genuinely saved will turn out to be overcomers and receive the reward Christ promises
them.”888 The assumption that all believers will receive such rewards is refuted by passages such as 1Cor 3:15,
which indicate that all believers will not be rewarded in this manner. Second, Rosscup supposes: “The truly saved
ones are the brand of people who, when they sin, confess, seek God’s forgiveness and cleansing, and desire to live
in the light with God (1 John 1:5-9). If they are negligent here, God may take them home to heaven early
(1 Cor 11:30-32).”889 He then allows, however, that there are “those who really are saved but living in backslidden
slackness.”890 To say that negligent believers who live in a backslidden condition until they die are, in fact,
overcomers (in the way that John uses that term in Rev 2-3) is to lower John’s practical exhortations to overcome
from a pole-vault to a speed bump! Zeller cites Rosscup’s article as being an excellent articulation of his own
position and concludes, “Every saved person, regardless of his degree or level of faithfulness in this life, can claim
the promises” made to overcomers in Revelation.891 Yet Rosscup’s argument is tantamount to saying that all
genuine believers overcome except for all those genuine believers who do not overcome. But John is not engaging
in such tautological rhetoric. In effect Zeller is saying that no matter how little faithfulness a believer manifests,
such faithfulness affirms that the believer is a genuine overcomer. Yet who reading Revelation chs. 2-3 would ever
get the idea that halfhearted faithfulness will qualify one to be considered an overcomer?
        At least Rosscup does achieve consistency in identifying the overcomers as all genuine believers and the
rewards as given to all genuine believers. Even so, this means that his interpretation must be rejected completely
because of his misidentification. Overcomers must be identified exegetically as faithful believers. Nonetheless, the
fact that Rosscup is at least theoretically consistent is appreciated in light of the fact that some other interpreters
fail in even this basic regard. For example, Epp correctly says concerning Rev 2:4, “Some of us would try to apply
these conditions to the liberals in the church, but Christ was speaking of the orthodox, the fundamental, the Bible-
believing Christians.”892 Yet elsewhere Epp fails to consistently affirm that the application of the warning to the

Preteristic Gehenna-Bema. Nevertheless, even in this case, the principle of indirectivity is not to be equated with the principle of
