churches is to believers. Even more surprisingly, William Ross (evidently FG) acknowledges Epp’s inconsistency
and then defends it by taking the same position!

       Epp suggests that all of the rewards in Revelation 2 and 3 apply solely to overcomers. Some are
       received by reason of faith in Christ. Others are received by reason of faithfulness to Christ.
            In this thesis the position is taken that the rewards in these chapters are for faithful believers. As
       will be seen in the development of these rewards, this does not necessarily limit them in all instances
       solely to faithful believers.893

        What makes Ross’ position even more astonishing is that he takes it after having correctly acknowledged
that Revelation “does not allow for a distinction between overcoming and non-overcoming rewards.…in each
instance the reward is associated with faithfulness or some positive response on the part of the believer.”894
Although Ross is to be commended for acknowledging that not all genuine believers are overcomers in Revelation
and for correctly noting that certain rewards are only promised to these overcomers (e.g., he acknowledges that
Rev 3:5 is a litotes), the value of his thesis is diminished by his rejection of the fact that all the rewards are
rewards. He does not recognize that the rewards are promised only to those genuine believers who are faithful, that
is, to overcomers. All the rewards are conditional, none of them are gifts given in response to a simple act of
saving faith. However, inconsistency concerning this matter is not limited to certain FG interpreters. Barnhouse
can be considered an example of inconsistency from the Calvinistic camp.895 He may be compared with Ross.
        The point in Ross’ thesis where his inconsistency is most keenly felt is his discussion of the tree of life. He
says that in Rev 2:7 and 22:14 all believers will have a right to eat from it.896 Yet it is at this very point where
Barnhouse, who is equally inconsistent on other matters (if not more so) makes his strongest point: “Eating of the
tree of life is a reward that shall be given to the overcomer in addition to his salvation.…he receives [it] over and
above his entrance into eternal life, a place in the Heavens in the midst of the paradise of God.”897 Likewise,
concerning the crown of life, Barnhouse says, “This is not a promise of life but the crown of life. Life is not a
reward for faithfulness. Life is a gift of grace. The crown belongs not to all, but only to that select few.”898
Nevertheless, Barnhouse is inconsistent concerning a number of the other rewards, saying that they are given to the
true believer (rather than the faithful believer). Rosscup justifiably points out Barnhouse’s inconsistency in saying
that the rewards are “for only some of the saved,” while other rewards are for “all the saved” in Rev 2-3 (emphasis
his).899 Evidently, by the time Barnhouse reaches the end of his commentary, he has forgotten what he had said at
the beginning. Concerning Rev 2:7 he said that the tree of life is a right for only some believers, but concerning
Rev 22:14 he says, “All the saints may partake of this tree.”900
        Richardson’s inconsistency is of a different nature.901 Richardson devotes a large section of his thesis to
arguing that the overcoming in Rev 2-3 refers to experiential overcoming rather that positional overcoming and
that not all genuine believers will overcome experientially concerning the matters described in those chapters of
Revelation. He even concludes the section by approvingly quoting Lang’s ultraistic misthological opinion that
carnal Christians might suffer temporarily rather than eternally in the Lake of Fire.902 Yet for some strange reason,
Richardson had said earlier in his thesis that genuine believers “will experience a habitual victory…a habitual,
experiential overcoming.”903 Richardson’s earlier statements must be rejected due to his subsequent arguments.
One who is truly saved may be carnal; that is, a genuine believer may fail to overcome and subcome instead.
        For a defense of eternal security that has difficulty affirming the reality of regenerate subcomers, one may
consult Gromacki.904 On the one hand, he correctly bases security on preservation.905 He identifies Lot as a
“saved…carnal believer.”906 He identifies “a genuine backslider” as a genuine believer “who has retreated to a
stagnant life full of carnality.”907 Gromacki also affirms the salvation of OT Saul—a man who persevered in
unholiness, seeking to take the life of David until he finally took his own life in suicide!908 He affirms the
possibility that Simon Magus was saved although he had no portion or inheritance (Acts 8:21). On the other hand,
however, Gromacki does display some of the typical Calvinistic weaknesses of perseverance. He strangely asserts,
“A man is not saved by faith and works; he is saved by faith that works.”909 This statement is soteriologically
defective and reveals a lack of understanding concerning the temporal and misthological nature of salvation in Jam
2:26. Gromacki also mistakenly believes that “the genuine Christian will never waver from this doctrinal position,
or deny it.”910 And he shares the common misperception that “no genuine Christian ever defects from the doctrinal
fundamentals of the faith.”911 Gromacki is thus another example of IFG.

Grace Salvationists
      The mixture of FG theology with Calvinism certainly has the potential to result in a mixed up theology, but
perhaps not always. Kendall may be a refreshing exception.912 In contrast to Gromacki, Stanley argues that
Page 504                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
                                                                                   913
genuine believers will remain saved even if they completely abandon the faith.         This is pristine FG theology.
There is no need to deny the scriptural reality of regenerate subcomers in affirming the doctrine of eternal security.
        Accordingly, interaction will be more fruitful with those interpreters of Revelation like Betz, Benedict,
Chitwood, Dillow, Hodges, Keathley III, Philips, Vacendak, and Wilkin who acknowledge that what is at stake for
subcomers is not literally being cast into the Lake of Fire.914 Unfortunately, many of the better commentaries from
this perspective are those by the partial rapturists: Govett, Lang, and Roadhouse. These commentaries are often
superior to other commentators in this particular matter, even though they incorrectly relate some of the promises
to participation in the rapture.

                                          Partial Rapture in Rev 3:10
       Perhaps the strongest counterargument to viewing unfaithful believers as subcomers is based on Rev 3:10.
Antagonists claim that this verse promises the rapture only to overcomers. If carnal believers are excluded from
this promise, then the general assumption is that one must advocate either a partial rapture understanding or the
Calvinistic position that those who fail to overcome are not regarded as genuine believers. Consequently,
Calvinists, like Wong, who believe in a full rapture, think this verse proves their case: “The promise to the
overcomer in 3:10 and 3:12, then, must inevitably be for all believers (i.e., church saints). To see it as a privilege
for only a special class among the saved is tantamount to arguing for a partial rapture, which Scripture nowhere
teaches.”915
       The logic of Wong’s argument is self apparent. If any promise made to overcomers must be applied to all
believers, then all believers must be overcomers. So if all believers will be raptured, and if 3:10 promises the
rapture only to overcomers, then all believers must be overcomers—at least this is the logical assumption. The
straightforward logic of Wong’s approach is commendable. Nevertheless, this type of argumentation is a two-
edged sword that cuts both ways. If any promise made to overcomers cannot apply to all believers, then all
believers cannot be overcomers. In fact, more texts and clearer texts demonstrate that the rewards are limited to
faithful believers. Wong’s argument is based on the opacity of two texts. The misthological argument is based on
the clarity of multiple texts. Interpreting Wong’s two unclear texts in light of several clearer texts is best.
       In his review of Wong’s article, Wilkin counters with an article by Niemelä in which an alternative
punctuation of the text is suggested.916 Accordingly, a translation such as the following might be preferred.
          9
            Behold, I will cause those of the synagogue of Satan, who say that they are Jews, and are not, but
          lie—I will make them to come and bow down at your feet, and to know that I have loved you,
          10
             because you have kept the word of My perseverance. I also will keep you from the hour of testing
          that is about to come upon the whole world, to test those who dwell upon the earth. (Rev 3:9-10; TM)

Johannine Love
       The punctuation by Wilkin and Niemelä is accepted herein, which in effect refutes both Wong and the
partial rapture position. The explicit promise to overcomers (i.e., to those who persevere) within the text is a
special acknowledgement of an exceptional measure of Christ’s love for them. The Lord is promising these faithful
believers that He publicly will demonstrate His love for them because they kept His word. As already noted, love
may be a reward.* Jesus also taught that the Father loved Him in a special way because of His obedience: “For this
reason the Father loves Me, because I lay down My life that I may take it again”(Jn 10:17). According to Jesus
the Father loves Him because He obeys His Father’s will. This does not mean that this is the only reason the Father
loves His Son, but this is one reason. As a result of His sacrifice, Jesus enjoys His Father’s love in a special way
that would have been impossible apart from that sacrifice. For example, Jesus’ sacrifice makes it possible for the
Father to express His love for His Son by giving redeemed humanity to His Son.
       Likewise, in Rev 3:9-10 Jesus promises overcomers that He will love them because they keep His word.
Their sacrifice will make it possible for Him to grant them the joy of ruling with Him, which is an expression of
His love for them that they otherwise would not have had. This promised expression of love does not apply to
disobedient believers who are unwilling to make the sacrifice necessary to be an overcomer. Certainly, God loves
all His children universally. Their obedience is not the only reason He loves them. Nevertheless, this special
expression of His love being described in Revelation will be reserved for those particular believers who obey Him.
God does not love all His children equally—at least not misthologically. The text here in Revelation is best read as
Jesus saying in effect, I will love you because you kept My word.
*
    See Love as Reward for Love, 736.
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                           Page 505
        This Johannine teaching concerning the nature of Jesus’ love should occasion no surprise. As already
pointed out, John records that Jesus, at times, conditions His love for us upon our love for Him (Jn 14:21-23). John
also records that Jesus conditions His friendship with us upon our obedience to Him (Jn 15:14; cp. Jam 4:4). In
fact, John identifies himself in his gospel as the disciple whom Jesus loved (Jn 13:23; 19:26; 20:2; 21:7,20). Would
this not indicate that the apostle John enjoyed a special intimacy with the Lord that surpassed that of the other
disciples? This special intimacy with the Lord, however, is not limited to those who, like John, follow the Lord in
fulltime Christian ministry, as John himself indicates in his gospel by also referring to Lazarus as the one whom
Jesus loved (Jn 11:3). John emphasizes that Lazarus was the special object of Jesus’ love by the repeated reference:
“Now Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus” (Jn 11:5).
        Jesus loved Lazarus and his sisters to an exceptional degree; otherwise, the statement is meaningless. The
laity, as is proven by the example of these lay believers, can enjoy the same special intimacy with the Lord as that
experienced by His most beloved, fulltime workers. Those who stay home and support those who follow the Lord
in fulltime Christian work can enjoy the same quality of intimacy with the Lord as do His most beloved
missionaries. There is security in knowing that the Lord loves everyone, lost and saved, regardless of the way they
live (Jn 3:16). The Lord can even feel a special love for specific lost individuals on occasion (Mk 10:21). And it is
certainly comforting to know that God loves His children even when they are disobeying Him; although, they
might not particularly enjoy the manner in which that love is expressed (Heb 12:6-8). Still, it is also encouraging to
know that when we walk with the Lord in the daily light of His word that we can have the joy of special intimacy
with Him as the reward that He sheds on our way. As Wilkin and Niemelä rightly deduce from the grammar and
theology of Rev 3:9-10, special intimacy throughout eternity is available for those believers who are willing to
endure temporally.

Contextual Limitation
       Wilkin and Niemelä are also correct that the promise to keep believers from the hour of testing is not
grammatically dependent upon believers keeping Jesus’ word. Moreover, proper punctuation of the text could
provide a reminder that the length of their endurance will not include the tribulation, and thus the Lord’s coming is
indeed imminent and will come swiftly. Niemelä is able to demonstrate grammatically that the promise is not
explicitly limited to overcomers. However, Niemelä’s theological assessment of the verse is not nearly as
persuasive: “The promise to the overcomer in Philadelphia is in Revelation 3:12, not in 3:10. Thus, Christ does not
set 3:10b forth as a reward to the overcomer. If deliverance from the hour were a reward for faithfulness, it would
have been in verse 12.”917
       Niemelä is to be applauded for seeking to circumvent the false soteriology of Calvinistic perseverance in
this verse. (He does so by making this promise applicable to all believers, even carnal believers who do not
persevere.) His discussion and chart concerning general versus special application is very helpful also. Further, his
argument that the Lord is promising all believers deliverance from the experience of the tribulation either by death
or rapture is consistent with his premise. Still, there is a better approach that does not have to resort to denying the
misthological nature of the promise in renouncing Calvinism and yet which simultaneously affirms a full rapture.
       Since each of the other verses addressed to the Philadelphian church is misthological, the immediate context
suggests that this verse is to be understood in the same manner. In the broader context also, the letters to the seven
churches are filled with misthological promises—both positive and negative—based on the response of the readers.
By interposing a general promise to all believers regardless of the way they live, Niemelä has run counter to the
misthological genre of the immediate and broad context. In attempting to deny the misthological nature of this
verse merely on the basis of grammar, Niemelä is running counter not only to the grain of this particular passage
but also against the flow of the addresses to each of the seven churches. The promise to keep believers from the
hour of testing is limited contextually to overcomers, who are addressed by the word you. Due to the context, I
find it necessary to agree with Wong rather than Wilkin or Niemelä that the text limits the promise of this
deliverance to overcomers. Granting Wong this concession, however, in no way requires agreement with either him
or partial rapturists concerning the nature of this promise.
       This promise simply may be considered a litotes. During the time when the world is being tested, these
faithful believers will be receiving their crowns instead of experiencing the tribulation. Judgment begins with us
(the house of God), but when it moves to the world, we will be removed to heaven to receive our crowns. Thus,
the Lord is promising these overcomers that He will crown them rather than test them. Testing during that period is
Page 506                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
contrasted with being crowned during that period. When it comes time for the world to be tested, it will be time for
overcomers to be crowned. Contextually, this verse is best considered a conceptual litotes.*

Exhortations
       A number of interpreters assume that since all believers are overcomers within 1 John, the exhortations to
overcome in Rev 2-3, contrastively, must be addressed to unbelievers. Yet even a casual consideration of the nature
of NT exhortations would caution us from jumping to such a hasty conclusion. Exhortations in the NT are
frequently based on what God has done, is doing, or will do. Many of these implicit and explicit exhortations fall
within the first category; that is, they are addressed to believers to be or do something based on what God already
has made them or done for them.
