Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                        Page 507
    You are holy, so be holy (1Pet 2:9-12).
    Since you are gifted, serve one another (1Pet 4:10).
    Since God has demonstrated His love for you, love one another (1Jn 4:10-11).
    Let him who is righteous be righteous (Rev 22:11).
    Let him who is holy be holy (Rev 22:11).

        All of these exhortations are to be what you are. They are all addressed to genuine believers. Jesus and
Paul both exhort believers that since they already are light they should be light in the world in which they live
(Mt 5:14-16; Eph 5:8). Since Jesus and Paul can exhort those who are light to be light, why can John not urge
those who are overcomers to overcome?
        The statement is the basis of the exhortation. A statement of who you are as a believer is followed by an
exhortation to be what you are. This would be consistent with my findings concerning overcoming in 1 John and
Revelation. In 1 John the readers were told that they are overcomers. Within the book of Revelation, this
statement is then followed by the exhortation for the readers to overcome. The statement of who you are is the
basis for how you should act.
        Wong, however, uses reverse logic. He argues that the exhortation to overcome is the means by which to
determine whether you are a believer. If you overcome, then you are a believer. If you do not overcome, then you
are not a believer. Overcome because if you do not overcome, then you are not a believer. This reverse logic is
wrong because it treats the exhortation as a promise and premise.
        To illustrate, suppose Wong’s reverse logic was applied to other exhortations (like #44 in the above
illustration). One would then be free to change the exhortation into the premise: “Love one another because if you
do not love one another, then God does not love you.” The requirement to have God love you is to love one
another. He loves us because we first loved one another! Wong’s reversal would make our derivative love the
original love. This is to be distinguished from the derivative sense in which believers may be rewarded with love.
Using the Wong approach, one interchangeably could claim that God loves us because we first loved Him. Further,
the context specifies that the love being referred to is Jesus’ propitiatory death on the cross for us. In that case,
using his reverse logic, Wong would be justified in saying, “Love one another because if you do not love one
another, then Jesus did not die for you.” Now Calvinists who advocate limited atonement may not recoil from such
theology, but hopefully the rest of us certainly will. Yet even limited-atonement advocates will find that their
limited atonement is no longer based on whether they are a believer (or even one of the elect); it is now based on
whether they love, and more specifically, in the light of John’s context, upon whether they demonstrate that love
by good works for others (1Jn 3:18). In other words, what ultimately determines whether you go to heaven is your
good works in this reversed approach. You are saved by works. This is the logical conclusion of Wong’s reverse
logic.
        Likewise, from #41 one would conclude that if you do not love one another, then you are not born again.
You must love one another so that you can be born again and so that Jesus will have died for you. Admittedly, this
sentence is theological nonsense, but the reason it is nonsense is because it accurately represents the nonsense of
the reverse logic that it represents. Will one also stand #28 on its head and say that you better triumph over them
because if you do not, then Christ has not triumphed over them? Or how about twisting #23 around backwards and
concluding that if you grieve the Holy Spirit by whom you were sealed, then you were never sealed to start with?
But how can you grieve Him by whom you were sealed if doing so proves you were never sealed? The exhortation
becomes a meaningless impossibility. Wong’s inversion is a perversion.
        As previously point out, Jesus and Paul exhort those who are light to be light—that is, to be what they are.
However, what happens if Wong’s logic is used? One would conclude that we must be light so that we may
become light. In other words, be something you are not in order to become what you want to be. Thus, Jesus and
Paul are exhorting us to be hypocrites and advocating hypocrisy as the means to spirituality. Something is wrong
with Wong’s logic. A number of the exhortations concern forgiveness (#3,#5,#24). Will we conclude that if we do
not forgive, then we were never forgiven to begin with? Is God’s soteriological forgiveness the basis for our love,
or is our love the basis for His soteriological forgiveness? Correct order and logic make a big difference. The
exhortation (You are a believer so overcome) is quite different from the reverse (Overcome so you will be a
believer). You have won a million dollars so buy the house of your dreams is quite different from: Buy the house of
your dreams, and you will win a million dollars! In like manner, to say that you are forgiven so forgive is quite
different from demanding that you forgive so that you will be forgiven.
        There are various types of forgiveness, such as soteriological, temporal, and misthological. The word
forgiveness is used in different senses depending on the context. In one context, all believers are forgiven. In
Page 508                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
another context, John teaches that only those believers who confess their sins are forgiven (1Jn 1:6-9). That the
word applies to all believers in some contexts does not prove that it applies to all believers in every context.
        Because we are forgiven soteriologically, we should forgive. This is not the same as saying, “If you forgive,
you will experience soteriological forgiveness.” This conclusion is based on plain statements of Scripture, not on
reverse logic. Misthological forgiveness is conditioned upon forgiving one another. In contrast, soteriological
forgiveness is based on faith, not on forgiving others. When we pray, “Forgive us our debts, as we also have
forgiven our debtors” (Mt 6:12), we do so because God is our Father, not in order for God to become our Father.
We do not mean, “Let us into heaven because we have forgiven others.” We already are God’s children and have
been forgiven completely in terms of relationship. What believers are acknowledging in this prayer is that their
fellowship forgiveness is dependent upon their forgiving others. Soteriological forgiveness is conditioned on faith.
Temporal fellowship forgiveness is dependent upon faithfulness.
        The model prayer is embedded in the Sermon on the Mount’s discussion of rewards. So why did Jesus
digress from a discussion of rewards to teach His disciples how to pray? This question shows a mistaken
perception concerning prayer in general and this prayer in particular. Jesus had just linked answered prayers to
rewards: “When you have shut your door, pray to your Father who is in the secret place; and your Father who sees
in secret will reward you openly” (Mt 6:6; NKJ). He then continues with teaching His disciples how to pray, and
in doing so points out that our forgiveness is conditioned on our forgiving others (Mt 6:12,14-15). In the next
breath, He discusses how to get rewards while fasting (Mt 6:16ff). The misthological dimension of this temporal
forgiveness is hard to miss.
        Are all believers overcomers? Certainly. However, just because a believer positionally and ontologically has
overcome the world in a response of faith (1Jn 5:1-4) does not mean that he or she will practically overcome the
world by a life of faith (1Jn 5:5; Rev 2-3). All overcomers are believers, and all believers are overcomers. Still, this
does not mean that all believers are overcomers in the fullest sense of the word. Some believers will fail to
overcome experientially. The only sense in which these unfaithful believers will overcome, strictly speaking, is in
a positional and ontological sense. Other believers will advance to maturity and also overcome experientially.
These believers who are overcomers in the fullest sense of the word are a subset of those who are overcomers in
the general sense of the word. All overcomers are believers, but not all believers are overcomers—in the sense in
which this word is employed in Revelation. That all believers overcome in one sense of the word does not mean
that all believes are overcomers in every sense of the word.
                                    Illustration 168. Venn Diagram of Overcomers
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                           Page 509
                                           Two Senses of Cast Out
       That John uses words to denote different things in different contexts has been pointed out already,
concerning his statement about being cast out (ekballo). In some contexts unfaithful believers are cast out
(Jn 15:6). In other contexts, no believer can be cast out (Jn 6:37). The same is true of the word abide (meno). In
some passages all believers are abiders (Jn 6:56). In other passages, only faithful believers are abiders (Jn 15:4-6).
The basic dictionary meaning of the word abide is to stay or remain.

                                              Two Senses of Abide
       Abide is used in different ways determined by the context. Most of the time it refers to the present
experience of eternal life in fellowship with the Lord. It can, however, refer to the present possession of eternal life
regardless of experience. Union is static; communion is dynamic. Jesus came that we might possess and experience
life (Jn 10:10). Possession does not guarantee experience; experience is not required for possession. In short,
sometimes to abide means to remain in fellowship. Sometimes it means to remain in relationship. In Jn 6:56 the
only requirement for abiding in the sense of remaining in eternal union with Jesus, is a single response of faith.
This verse is teaching that as believers we have eternal life as a present permanent possession regardless of whether
we live for Jesus or continue to believe in Jesus.
       On the other hand, in Jn 15:4-6 abide refers to ongoing fellowship, which in turn is conditioned on ongoing
obedience to His word. Jesus already had promised His disciples that they would abide in Him eternally in 6:56.
Subsequently, He exhorts them to abide in Him experientially in 15:4-6. This is another way of exhorting them to
be what they are: You are abiders so abide. The same is true of the word overcome. You are an overcomer so
overcome. You have to be an overcomer in the primary sense of the word before you can be exhorted to overcome
in the fullest sense of the word. That the believers in Rev 2-3 are being exhorted to overcome in the secondary
sense of the word indicates that they already have become overcomers in the primary sense of the word. They were
consequently genuine believers.
       One might also note that in GJ the Scripture repeatedly says that Jesus can do nothing on His own
(Jn 5:19,30; 7:17,28; 8:28, 42; 12:49; 14:40). Notwithstanding, in the midst of these repeated denials that He can
do nothing on His own, Jesus explicitly claims to do something on His own (Jn 10:18). He will lay down His life
on His own, meaning that it is not something the Father will force Him to do. Jesus will do it of His own volition.
Sensitivity must be given to the context to realize that just because a phrase is applied to Jesus in one sense in
certain contexts does not mean that it must be so applied in all contexts. The same is true of the word overcome.
Just because believers overcome in one sense of the word in one context does not establish that believers overcome
in every sense of the word in all contexts.

Promises
       Since Jesus promises faithful believers that they will be kept from the hour of testing in one context
(Rev 3:9-10) but promises in other contexts that no believer will have to go through the tribulation, one is
prevented from throwing this exhortation into reverse and claiming that those believers who do not persevere will
be excluded from the rapture. Exhortatory reversion is hermeneutical perversion on this occasion. Since the
exhortations cannot be thrown into reverse, does it follow that it is an empty promise? Is Jesus just promising these
overcomers that they will experience the rapture, when in fact they will experience the rapture regardless of
whether they overcome? Not at all. He is not making an empty hortatory promise to the believers in order to try to
encourage them to overcome. As demonstrated in the previous chapter, litotes should not be thrown in reverse. AS
shown in the present chapter, exhortations should not be thrown in reverse either. Reversion is both a litotetical
and persuasional perversion. As noted above, the exhortation in Rev 3:10 is simply a functional litotes. By
implicitly promising these overcomers that they would not have to suffer through the tribulation, Jesus is implying
that they will be doing the exact opposite. Instead of suffering during that time, they will be rejoicing.

                                              The Tree is not Free
       John could expect his readers to pick up on the intended meaning of the litotes from the nature of the other
promises to overcomers. The two-sided nature of Wong’s argument has been pointed out and refuted with the
converse of his argument. If any promise is made to overcomers that cannot apply to all believers, then all
believers are not overcomers. Likewise, if these promises are only applicable to faithful believers, then not all
genuine believers are faithful believers. It would have to be concluded that carnal believers are excluded from the
promises. A brief investigation of the nature of some of the promises will be helpful in demonstrating that a litotes
Page 510                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
is intended to make the promise exclusively applicable to faithful believers. The first promise made to overcomers
is that they will be able to eat of the tree of life.

       To him who overcomes, I will reward [didomi] him to eat of the tree of life, which is in the Paradise
       of God. (Rev 2:7; TM)

       Behold, I am coming quickly, and My reward [misthos] is with Me, to reward [apodidomi] every
       man according to what he has done…Blessed are those who wash their robes that they may have the
       right to the tree of life, and may enter by the gates into the city. (Rev 22:12,14; TM)

       If anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God will take away his portion
       from the tree of life and from the holy city. (Rev 22:19; TM; CT; MT)

       The verb for reward in 2:7 is didomi—to give. It can mean to pay, to give payment, to render in response to
merit (e.g., Mt 20:4; 26:15; Lk 22:5; Rev 2:7,10,17,23,26,28; 3:21; 6:11; 11:18; 20:4).* Rev 11:18 is a close
parallel, where it says that it is time for God to give/pay His servants their reward. The word can also be used in
reference to giving a gift (e.g., Jn 4:10; Acts 11:17; Eph 4:8; Rev 21:6). Whether it means to give as a gift or as a
payment is determined by the context. In the immediate context, the right to the tree of life is given to those who
work for it (2:5). Consequently, a merited payment is intended. In the broader context of 22:12-14, it is a reward
(misthos), which is rewarded (apodidomi) to those who wash their robes in practical sanctification (cp. 1Jn 1:9;
Rev 7:14; 19:8). The parallel verb, which is used synonymously for didomi in the broader context, is apodidomi—a
word that the Greek lexicons (e.g., BDAG, FB) note as being translatable as reward. Apodidomi more clearly
specifies that the transaction is due to merit—that what is being given is not a gift, but earned.
       Both the CT and MT concur over and against the TR† that what is forfeitable in Rev 22:19 is the tree of life,
not the Book of Life: “If anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away his
part from the tree of life.”919 A believer can lose his or her portion/inheritance (meros) from the tree of life. This is
consistent with the NT and Johannine teaching concerning the believer’s portion.‡ Obviously, one cannot lose
something one does not have. This book of prophecy was addressed to and given to believers. The warning against
tampering with the message of the book is thus likewise intended for believers. Genuine believers are in danger of
losing their right to this tree; unbelievers have no right to this tree to lose. Conversely, the promise is limited to
those believers who are faithful to the word, who live righteously (in the broad context), and who work for it (in
the immediate context). This reward is paid only to faithful believers, not given as a gift to all believers. Wong is
wrong in his assessment that the promises to overcomers are guaranteed to all genuine believers.

                                           The Crown of Life is not Free
        Wong’s argument requires him to take the position that all believers will receive the crown of life, since it is
likewise promised to overcomers (Rev 2:10). For this reason, he simplistically and soteriologically equates the
crown of life with eternal life. According to this rationale, since eternal life is a free gift to all believers, all
believers may be pictured as having the crown of life. But this approach fails to do justice to the fact that believers
already have the free gift of eternal life. They do not have to wait until they get to heaven to receive it. On the
contrary, present possession of eternal life guarantees our future entrance into heaven, not our future acquisition of
eternal life. Future acquisition of eternal life is merited only by faithful believers (Mk 10:28-30; Rom 2:5-7; 5:15-
21; 6:22; Gal 6:7-9; 1Tim 6:12,18-19; Tit 1:2; 3:7).
        That all believers already have eternal life at its rudimentary level in no way proves that all believers will
have it at its most prestigious level. That a person has graduated from elementary school in no way guarantees that
he or she will receive a diploma from a university. Having education at one level does not guarantee the attainment
of education in its most advanced form in the future. That all believers already have eternal life while on earth, and
as a result will continue to have this life in heaven, in no way guarantees that all believers will experience that life
at its maximum capacity. Jesus came that believers might not only have eternal life as a free gift but that they might
experience it abundantly as victorious believers (Jn 10:10). The variation among believers in their present
experience of the spiritual life is but a pale foreshadowing of the exponentially experiential differentiation that will

*
  See “Didomi (give/reward)” in Soteric and Mistholic Faith.
†
  CT = Critical Text. MT = Majority Text. TR = Textus Receptus.
‡
  See Chapter 3. The Portion of the First Resurrection.
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                           Page 511
be made among believers at the Bema. The thought that all believers will receive crowns is denounced by texts
such as 1Cor 3:11-15. This passage depicts believers as being saved but so as through fire. Just as salvation can be
experienced at different levels by believers at the Bema, so can eternal life be experienced to different degrees by
believers both temporally and misthologically. The superlative experience of eternal life by faithful believers is
described as being rewarded with the crown of life or the tree of life.
        It is widely acknowledged that the crowns are earned by faithful believers. Wong’s theological perception,
that all believers are faithful, is nothing more than a Calvinistic imposition upon John’s composition. Even worse,
Wong’s soteriology results in an accursed gospel. The text explicitly conditions the crown upon faithfulness. “Be
faithful until death, and I will reward you with the crown of life” (Rev 2:10; TM). The Greek word for reward is
again didomi, which is dependent upon the context as to whether it means to grant as a gift or payment. In this
context it is conditioned upon faithfulness and thus is merited and consequently is used synonymously with
apodidomi (reward). If this is a soteriological promise, as Wong makes it out to be, then our salvation from hell is
a reward dependent upon our faithfulness until death—our perseverance. Wong’s Calvinistic presumption is
refuted by the sequence of events within the text. John does not say that those who are given the crown will
persevere; rather, he says that those who persevere will be given the crown. As in Mk 13:13, perseverance is the
requirement not the result—contrary to what some Calvinists would lead us to believe. Wong’s attempt to equate
the crown of life with the free gift of eternal life fares no better than that of Lenski and Walvoord discussed earlier
in this chapter.
        In response to the objection that Rev 3:11 warns overcomers about the possibility of losing their crown,
Wong remarks, “It is a general reward Christ will give to every saved person. And so the truly saved will not lose
it.”920 There are several basic problems with Wong’s premise. First, gifts, not rewards, are given to every believer.
Second, rewards are indeed forfeitable—at least until all contingencies have been met (e.g., 1Cor 9:27). Third,
rewards are always based on works (Mt 16:27; 1Cor 3:13-15; 2Cor 11:15; Rev 2:23; 18:6; 20:12-13; 22:12). If
Wong insists that the crown of life simply consists of eternal life, then he wrongly conditions the free gift of eternal
life on our works and indicates that eternal life is forfeitable at a soteriological level.
        Even aside from such basic soteriological and misthological errors, Wong’s position fails to do justice to the
immediate contexts on two counts. First, the warning is directed to the believers in Philadelphia. As is well known,
this church is one of the two churches in the book of Revelation that received a commendation without any
condemnation. Jesus spoke nothing but praise for this church. The warning about not losing the crown is addressed
to overcomers in this church. Lost people have no crown to lose. False believers have no crown to lose. The
warning is not addressed to the lost but to genuine believers. If Wong were consistent (which he is not), then he
would have to admit that genuine believers are being threatened with the loss of eternal life according to his
premise.
        Conversely, if the warning is addressed to those who are overcomers, but who potentially could become
subcomers, then the warning is coherent and consistent with Rev 22:19. Believers are warned that they will lose the
rewards to which they otherwise would be entitled if they fail to overcome. In both cases, the warnings concerning
the tree of life and the crown of life are to potential subcomers—to genuine believers who have the potential to
overcome or subcome. These warnings are not addressed to those who have not yet come to faith in Christ. In
trying to side step this conclusion, Wong equates the unfaithful with the unsaved. His logic wrongly makes
faithfulness a requirement to be saved from hell. Further, he evidently unwittingly redefines overcomers as mere
professing Christians rather than genuine Christians.
        On the one hand, Wong wants (1) to argue that the nature of the rewards compels us to apply them to all
genuine believers, and (2) to indicate that since they are promised to all genuine believers, overcomers must
represent all genuine believers. Yet it is readily apparent from the text that the rewards apply only to faithful
believers, so, the logical extension of his argument is that all genuine believers will be faithful. The fallacy of his
assumption that all believers will be faithful has been demonstrated by showing that Rev 2:6 and 3:5,10 can be
understood as litotes. Accordingly, there is no compelling reason to apply them to all believers.
        Still, for the sake of argument, assume for the moment that Wong is correct in thinking that the promises
demonstrate that the overcomers represent all genuine believers. In that case, what is to be made of the reversal that
Wong takes when discussing the warning of 3:11? “Hold fast what you have, in order that no one take your
crown.” This warning is addressed to overcomers in the church at Philadelphia. Wong wants us to believe that the
warnings are addressed to a mixture of real believers, carnal believers, and false believers. 921 Evidently, Wong has
spotted a mixture in the Philadelphian church that Jesus has failed to notice or at least failed to mention. In any
case, in applying the warning to professing believers (i.e., false believers), Wong is being inconsistent with his
methodology.
Page 512                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
        Contextually, the warning is to overcomers. If soteriological promises to overcomers prove that overcomers
must represent all genuine believers, then soteriological warnings to overcomers would prove the opposite
according to such logic. The warnings would have the opposite import as the promises and thus indicate that
overcomers merely represent professing believers. On the one hand, Wong’s logic limits the promises concerning
being overcomers to genuine believers. On the other hand, when discussing the warnings, he broadens the concept
of overcomers to include carnal and false believers. His logic refutes itself.
        The most tragic shortcoming of his combining this caution into a joint, one-dimensional soteriological-
misthological warning is that it makes it an admonition to believers to escape hell by enduing. If they do not
endure, they will prove that they were false believers. Their salvation and assurance of salvation is based on their
proveitistic endurance. Those carnal believers who are living like they are unsaved and who need to repent of their
sinful works are wrongly told that the way to achieve assurance of salvation is to work for it. Turning from their
sins and persevering so that they can be sure that they really are regenerate pragmatically becomes the means to
really be saved. Salvation from hell is made a reward that carnal believers earn by holding fast to what they have.
False believers are exhorted to do the same thing but to add faith to the list as one of the requirements. One is left
puzzled as to how false believers can be exhorted to hold fast to eternal life when they do not have it. Evidently,
this does not matter to Wong since ultimately, in Wong’s scheme of things, salvation for the lost and saved is by
faith and works anyway. Arminian theology is far superior to this Calvinistic mire.
        An Arminian simply could remark that the crown is eternal life and those believers who fail to hold on to it
will lose it. After all, you have to have it before you can be warned not to lose it. Indeed, this is the very point
Shank is making when he quotes others as supposing that the crown of life is a genitive of apposition or definition
so that the crown of life is eternal life itself. His argument is that eternal life is received initially as a gift but is
retained as a reward. In this sense, it is both a gift and a reward.922 Shank is correct that eternal life is both a gift
and a reward, but he is wrong in thinking that the retention of regeneration is a reward. Conditionalists wrongly
submit the gift of eternal life to a hermeneutical process by which to cause it to undergo a metamorphosis from a
gift into a reward so that the final realization of this gift is a reward.*

                                             Illustration 169. Metamorphological Life




           •    NOSAS equates the future reward of eternal life with entrance into heaven.
           •    OSAS equates the future reward of eternal life with rewards in heaven.

       As Shank and others note, this crown of life is also referred to in Jam 1:12, where it is promised to those
who love the Lord. But it should be noted that it is a future acquisition, not a present possession. Paul also teaches
that the crown of righteousness is a payment (apodidomi) that he will receive on that day (2Tim 4:8). This crown
of righteousness is for those who love the Lord’s appearing. This futuristic crown for loving is thus parallel with
that of Jam 1:12. (Because the crown of life and the crown of righteousness are both conditioned on loving the
Lord, it is inconsistent for Corner to say that all believers will possess the former but only some believers will
possess the latter.923) The futuristic nature of the actual acquisition is stressed by Paul: “In the future there is laid
up for me the crown of righteousness.” It is currently laid up. The realization of this potential acquisition is
dependent upon his loving endurance for the Lord in finishing the race set before him.


*
    For more biblically astute models, see my diagrams in endnote 1277. Two axis are better than one.
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                                Page 513
       This biblical picture explains how believers can lose the crown of life. We do not have it yet, but by
pressing on in the race, so as to not be disqualified for the prize set before us, we will obtain that crown. The Lord
is promising that it is as good as ours if we will just hold on. Still, the fact that we have not yet actually received it
means that it cannot be the gift of eternal life. We already have received eternal life as a gift. We have not yet
received it as a reward. Therefore, it is the future realization of this life as a reward that is at stake, not our retention
of the gift. We are looking at payday in this passage. The Calminian payday has God saying, “As a reward for your
hard work, you get to keep your gift.” Although Shank’s exegesis is to be preferred over Wong, it is equally wrong
in confusing the concept of gift with reward and inevitably teachings a false gospel that conditions the gift on
performance.
       Jesus provides a warning in Rev 3:11 that makes it very clear that He is talking about something that
believers currently are qualified to receive as a result of their faithfulness but that can be forfeited if they fail to
continue in that faithfulness. John already has used litotes to make it abundantly clear in his gospel that eternal life
cannot be forfeited, so he cannot be making a simplistic reference to losing eternal life at the soteriological level. In
other words, since John is describing something that can be forfeited, he is making it easy for his readers to pick up
on the fact that he is not describing the free gift of eternal life. Verse 11 is John’s way of reminding the reader that
Jesus is not talking about the gift of eternal life—He is not talking soteriologically at all. He is speaking in terms of
pure misthology.
       The promise of the crown cannot be made to all believers since it contextually is limited to those believers
who are faithful and to those who currently are qualified on the basis of that faithfulness to receive the crown if
they persevere in that faithfulness. Its forfeitable nature precludes one from concluding that all believers are
overcomers. As already stated, if there is any one promise made to overcomers that cannot apply to all believers,
then all believers cannot be overcomers. If these promises are only applicable to faithful believers, then not all
genuine believers are faithful believers. If believers who presently are overcomers become subcomers, then they
will lose their right to this reward but not their soteriological salvation. Hence, subcomers genuinely are saved but
misthologically are excluded from the rewards promised to overcomers. Not all genuine believers are overcomers.

                                         The Throne is not Free
       Wong continues with his insistence that all believers are overcomers in his treatment of the throne in
Rev 3:21: “To him who overcomes I will reward to sit with Me on My throne, as I also overcame and sat down
with My Father on His throne” (TM). The Greek word for reward is again didomi, which is again dependent upon
the context for its meaning. And Wong acknowledges that the throne is a reward.

                The promise of Revelation 3:21 is a reward for all believers. For in 20:4-6 all who belong to the
          first resurrection are depicted as sitting on thrones….This leaves no ground for a third category (i.e.,
          a group of nonovercoming, defeated believers)….In addition, since all the redeemed reign even in
          this life (Rom. 5:17), it is reasonable that they will reign in the next (1 Cor. 6:2; 2 Tim. 2:12; Rev
          22:5). Also all the justified are more than conquerors through Jesus (Rom. 8:37).924

       Many of the comments above pertaining to the crown are equally applicable to the throne. Wong’s
assessment that all believers sit on the thrones in Rev 20:4-6 has been refuted already in the discussion of that
passage.* His argument from Rom 5:17 is difficult to access for the simple reason that it is difficult to be dogmatic
about the interpretation of that verse.
       Some believe that the reign of life being referred to in this verse is the present experience of abundant life.
Indeed, Dillow suggests this interpretation.925 If this is the case, the future tense of the verb will reign is a logical
future and may be understood temporally.926 Logically, abundant life is the potential experience of anyone who
has received eternal life. One generally would expect those who have received the free gift of eternal life to
progress to experiencing it in the form of the abundant life. Even if Wong is correct that it refers to the believer’s
present experience, it does not necessarily follow that the verse is teaching that all believers are experiencing the
abundant life. What should be is not necessarily what will be. The exhortations in the book of Romans demonstrate
that the abundant life is available to all believers, but it is not the inevitable experience of all believers.
       On the other hand, Dillow also notes that many commentators believe that Rom 5:17 refers to sharing
Christ’s messianic rule in the millennial kingdom (as shown in parallel texts such as Rom 8:17 and 2Tim 2:12).927


*
    See Rulership, p. 45.
Page 514                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
In this case, it is an absolute future and refers to the hereafter. From the broader context, this interpretation may
be the preferred since Paul teaches that God

          will reward every man according to his works. 7 He will reward eternal life to those who seek for
          glory and honor and immortality by perseverance in good work. (Rom 2:6-7; TM).

       Of course, as Paul goes on to demonstrate, it is impossible for unjustified sinners to please God by their
works. However, believers have been justified and consequently can live lives that are pleasing to God. They can
seek for glory and honor by doing good works, and as the text goes on to state, “Glory and honor and peace will be
rewarded to everyone who works what is good” (Rom 2:10; TM). Believers can qualify for eternal life as a future
reward in the form of glory and honor, if they do the good works that are necessary.

          For if by the transgression of the one, death reigned through the one, much more those who receive
          the abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life through the One, Jesus
          Christ….21 that, as sin reigned in death, even so grace might reign through righteousness to eternal
          life through Jesus Christ our Lord (Rom 5:17,21).

       That the abundant life is the potential experience of all believers does not prove that it is the inevitable or
unconditional experience of any believer. It is limited to believers and available to all believers, but it is not
automatic. We are supposed to reign in life now and in the future, and Paul may have both temporal and eternal
misthological aspects of that abundant experience of life in mind. There is no excuse for believers not to progress
to the abundant life. God has imputed His righteousness to us, giving us legal claim to His blessing. His imputed
righteousness makes His imparted righteousness available through our Lord Jesus who indwells us. However, the
availability of this abundant experience of God’s grace to all believers in the form of abundant life does not
establish that believers automatically will enjoy it.
       The sad reality is that many Christians have an experience that could be best described as one of death, as
Paul goes on to describe in the book of Romans (6:16,21,23; 7:10,13,24; 8:6,13). Carnal Christians are carnally
minded and thus dead (8:6), and Paul warns these believers that if they live in a carnal manner they will die
(8:13).928 He also reminds these believers in Rome that co-heirship and co-glory with Jesus are conditioned on co-
suffering with Him (8:17). Wong’s assumption that Rom 5:17 teaches that all believers temporally rule with Christ
in the here-and-now is clearly questionable. His argument that all believers will rule eschatologically with Him in
the future is thoroughly objectionable.
       Wong’s assumption that 1Cor 6:2 teaches that all believers will rule with Christ is just that—an assumption.
The text actually says, “Do you not know that the saints will rule the world?” Wong evidently assumes that the
saints refers to all saints. Yet this is not what the text says. At most, it might be said that all saints categorically
are qualified potentially. However, the actual realization is that many of them misthologically will be disqualified
characteristically. In any event, not all saints are qualified to exercise judgment in the church, much less
misthologically qualified to judge the world.* Even an appeal to Rev 22:3-5 as proving that all saints will rule
would be in error because the text actually says that the Lord’s servants will reign forever. The text does not say,
“All His servants.” Would one understand Rev 2:20 to mean that in seducing God’s servants in the church at
Thyatira, Jezebel had lead all the believers astray in that church? Obviously, not. Some of the believers in this
church at Thyatira were being led astray, but others were keeping their garments white. The word servants does not
necessarily refer to all believers.†
       Wong’s citation of 2Tim 2:12 is rather surprising: “If we endure, we shall also reign with Him.” The text
does not say, “If we are believers, we shall also reign with Him.” Wong must presume that all believers will endure
in order to derive support from this text. Yet this presumption is the very thing he is supposed to be proving. This is
circular reasoning. Moreover, 2Tim 2:12 is evidently contrasting two different possible outcomes for believers.
The latter part of the verse says, “If we deny Him, He will also deny us.” The we refers to the same group of people
in both the first half and second half of the verse. It refers to believers. For example, the first part of the verse does
not mean, “If we unbelievers endure, then we unbelievers will also reign with Him.” Rather, it is understood to
mean, “If we believers endure, then we believers will also reign with Him.” Likewise, the second part of this verse


*
    See Illustration 53. Unrighteous will not Inherit, 121.
†
    See Illustration 197. The Assumed All, 577.
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                                  Page 515
means, “If we believers deny Him, then He will deny us believers.” The verse is describing the Lord’s
misthological denial of believers rather than His soteriological denial of unbelievers.929
        There is another text in Rev 2-3 that quite clearly defines just who the overcomers are and conditions their
rulership with Christ upon their faithfulness to Christ. “And he who overcomes, that is, he who keeps My works
until the end, I will reward Him with authority over the nations. And he will rule them with a rod of iron”
(Rev 2:26-27a; TM). Who are the overcomers? They are the ones who keep Christ’s works till the end. Concerning
the warning in Rev 3:11, Wong already has been forced to admit that “some believers, who are ensnared in sin and
living like the unsaved are challenged to repent,” and he proceeds to call this: “repentance from carnal living.”930
The logical conclusion of such a concession should be that such believers are carnal believers who are not keeping
Christ’s works. They cannot be regarded as overcomers. All believers are not overcomers. Straightforward
interaction with the text and frank admission as to the implications of his own concessions should have led Wong
to the right conclusion.
                           Illustration 170. Johannine Definition of Overcomer in Revelation

                        Rev 2:26                             Rev 3:21
    And he who overcomes (that is, he who keeps To him who overcomes I will
    My works until the end) I will reward Him with reward to sit with Me on My
    authority over the nations.                    throne.

Epexegetical
        As to the translation above, BDAG (1.c) notes, kai is “often explicative; that is, a word or clause is
connected by means of kai, with another word or clause, for the purpose of explaining what goes before it and so,
that is, namely” (bold added). Carson agrees that this is the case in this verse, stating that kai ho nikon kai ho teron
in Rev 2:26

       does not in context refer to two people, one who conquers and another who keeps God’s word.
       Rather, it appears to be a slightly cumbersome idiom to invest this obedient conqueror with a weighty
       label. The point once again is that it is a fallacy to accept the Granville Sharp rule in its
       oversimplified form.931

        Thus, the epexegetical (i.e., explanatory) use of kai is indicated by the context.* Kai may also be used in
Greek literature to introduce an author’s parenthetical remark. John introduces a parenthetical explanation in 2:26
to define what he means by the word overcomer. In terms of modern punctuation and abbreviations, the verse is
saying, “And he who overcomes (i.e., he who keeps My works until the end) I will reward Him with authority over
the nations” (TM). So whether one wants to refer to this occurrence as an epexegetical or parenthetical statement,
the bottom line is still the same. The overcomer is someone who keeps Christ’s works until the end. A comparison
of Rev 2:26 with 3:21 demonstrates that rulership is conditioned on one thing—overcoming.† Keeping Christ’s
works is not an optional or additional component of what it means to be an overcomer in Revelation. This is the
core meaning of what it means to be an overcomer. As is apparent from both the exhortations and the warnings, not
all believers keep Christ’s word; thus, not all believers are overcomers in this sense of the word. The promises do
not apply to those believers who fail to keep Christ’s word; they do not apply to misthological failures.

Synchronical
       Despite my contextual preference for the epexegetical explanation, misthological exegetical options are by
no means limited to this syntactical identification. The phrase ho nikon kai ho teron is simply the joining of two
articular participles by kai. It should not be overlooked that both articles are singular. The similar phrase used in
Rev 1:3 where John pronounces a blessing on the one who reads (sg.) and those who hear (pl.) is not a syntactical
parallel. In that verse, Jesus is addressing two different groups of people: one singular, one plural. That is not true


*
 For another occasion in which John uses the epexegetical kai, see endnote 616.
†
 For another comparison in Revelation which requires that overcomer be defined as faithful believer, see Illustration 22. Triad
Description of Overcoming Rulers, 51.
Page 516                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
in Rev 2:26. The closest parallels in the NT of two articular participles (of the same number) being joined by kai
are:

       •    Many were coming and going (Mk 6:31; TM).
       •    Those preceding and proceeding were shouting (Mk 11:9; TM).
       •    He cast out those buying and selling in the temple (Mk 11:15; TM).

        Granted, one might conjecture that in each of these cases two different (albeit closely related) groups are in
view. Nevertheless, the fact that two different groups are involved is not stressed. One interconnected group
performing two actions apparently is being described. For example, Mk 6:31 literally reads, “Those coming and
those going were many” (DBY). The word those is repeated by DBY. Yet all other English translations consulted
render the phrase as referring to one massive group of people who were coming and going. This popular
translational precedence of a single those as referring to one group is followed in my translations of the parallel
phrases above.
        As to Rev 2:26 itself, it may accordingly be translated as: “The one who overcomes and keeps My works
until the end, I will give to him authority over the nations” (TM). Unlike the above parallels, this phrase cannot
even hypothetically be referring to two separate people: one who overcomes as opposed to one who keeps My
works. Although these two constituent components are not united under one singular article, both substantives are
united under one singular personal pronoun: him (autos sg.). A smoother translation would be, “I will give
authority over the nations to him—the one who overcomes and keeps My works until the end.” Kai need not
necessarily be rendered epexegetically to show that the overcomer and keeper are not two different people. The
promise is made to the individual who is both an overcomer and keeper. The keeper is not another group or person.
        At most it may be asserted that keeping is a separate but interconnected action with overcoming. The one
granted ruling authority is the one who synchronously performs these two actions. Does this approach nullify my
epexegetical argument? No. The ruler is the one who performs both interdependent actions: overcoming and
keeping. Overcoming evil and obeying Christ is the only way to become a ruler. Overcoming states the regal
requirement in relation to the world; keeping states the same misthological requirement in relation to Christ.
        One does not overcome Christ in order to become an overcomer. Surely these constructions are to be
understood as verbalizing the singular requirement in relation to two different objects. These two expressions are
the positive and negative flipsides of the same misthological coin. Even if overcoming and keeping are presenting
two different actions, they are actions being undertaken by one-and-the-same person in order to become a ruler.
Both actions are part of the same misthological requirement and are required simultaneously. It is just that the dual
aspects of that singular requirement, as expressed toward Christ and the world, are being articulated. One phrase
expresses the requirement negatively; the other expresses the same requirement positively. The one who
overcomes the world is the one who keeps Christ’s word. The overcomer is the keeper. This is the same conclusion
reached derived from the epexegetical analysis. The two arguments are not mutually exclusive but reinforce each
other. The synchronical syntax leads to the epexegetical conclusion.

                                               The Pillar is not Free
       Wong believes that the promise concerning the overcomers being a pillar must be applied to all believers,
and thus that all believers are overcomers. He notes that the passage may be understood misthologically and thus
taken to refer to the “overcomer’s prominent position in eternity.” However, he prefers to take it soteriologically
as “a symbol of the overcomer’s absolute permanence or security in his eternal home.”932 If it is simply a
soteriological picture of eternal security, then indeed Wong would be correct, since eternal security applies to all
believers and is not conditioned upon one’s faithfulness. However, the text suggests conditional rather than
unconditional prominence:

       He who overcomes, I will make him a pillar in the temple of My God, and he will not go out from it
       anymore; and I will write upon him the name of My God, and the name of the city of My God, the
       new Jerusalem, which comes down out of heaven from My God, and My new name. (Rev 3:12)

       There are two immediate problems with Wong’s soteriological interpretation of this verse. First, the
exhortation to hold fast in v. 11 lest you lose your crown has just indicated in the preceding verse that what you get
as a result of holding fast is a crown. The crown cannot refer soteriologically to eternal life since eternal security is
not conditioned upon holding fast. Crown in v. 11 must mean a prominent position in the kingdom. Verse 12
appears to be a continuation of that theme. The overcomer is one who holds fast, and the prominent position is
Chapter 22. Who are the Overcomers?                                                                              Page 517
described again in different terms. Second, John has defined overcomer in 2:26 to be someone who keeps Christ’s
works until the end. Eternal security is not conditioned upon keeping Christ works until the end, thus the passage
cannot be describing eternal security, at least not soteriologically.
       The problem is that Wong has presented a false dichotomy in assuming that the promise pertaining to the
pillar must be understood as denoting either prominence or permanence. It is not either-or; it is both-and. The
promise to faithful believers is that they will receive both permanence and prominence. They will be given
prominence permanently. As believers, they have eternal security soteriologically. As faithful believers, they will
have eternal security misthologically. This is simply another way of saying that rewards are eternal. These rewards
will not fade away with the passage of time. As John had noted earlier in his gospel, if anyone serves Jesus, then
God will honor him (Jn 12:26). The point being stressed in 3:12 is the permanence of that prominence.

                                                     Conclusion
        The examination within this chapter concerning what it means to be an overcomer within the book of
Revelation encountered various levels and types of LS and FG swirling around in a state of contaminated
confusion, almost making a cesspool of chapters 2 and 3 of Revelation. Unlike the water of life flowing pure and
free at the conclusion of the epistle, this hermeneutical water in chs. 2 and 3 was found unsafe to drink, due to the
polluted tributaries from Arminianism and Calvinism which flowed into it, making it bad for one’s soteriological
health. Thankfully, this bitter state of affairs was not without easy remedy. Like Moses at Marah (in Ex 15:23-25),
these waters can be made safe and sweet to drink by the use of a tree.
        A simple distinction allowed these passages to be restored to the pure state in which John originally
recorded them. For John, the water of life is free; the tree of life is not. The water of life is offered freely to all who
will drink it. The tree of life is offered conditionally to all believers who will work for it. The Marrowistic
distinction between a gift and a reward made these contemporary waters of Marah fit to drink. One does not choke
on fruit while trying to drink from the stream. Whereas Arminianism and Calvinism want to drop their meritorious
fruit into the stream and churn them together to make them one and the same, Marrowism allows the reader to
enjoy both drinking and eating from John’s epistle without choking to death by trying to do both in the same
swallow.
        Ryrie’s attempt at merging Calvinism with FG theology might work theoretically, but it fails miserably
exegetically. His attempt to combine an exegetical LS understanding of what it means to be an overcomer in
Revelation with FG theology was clearly faulty in that it makes the gift a reward and the reward a gift. Other
writers, such as Zeller, Rosscup, Ross, Epp, Barnhouse, and Richardson, were then consulted for their input and
found, at times, to be as wrong as Wong in failing to distinguish a gift from a reward.
        Even among those Marrowistic writers who could correctly discern a gift from a reward, differences of
opinion were to be found—some preferring a partial rapture, with others acknowledging a full rapture. The claim
that Marrowism necessarily results in understanding Rev 3:10 as referring to a partial rapture was found to be false.
The litotetic approach, while found among interpreters from all camps, was defended as most suitable to the
Marrowistic hermeneutic. The dualistic manner in which John uses the same words to form both assurances and
promises were found to be fully compatible with his grammatical propensity to use litotetic promises and
assurances. Just as he might use words such as ekballo (cast out) and meno (abide) to assure all believers that they
abide in Christ permanently and would never be cast out soteriologically (while urging them to abide experientially
so that they might not be thrown out misthologically), so John also uses litotes to anchor believers soteriologically
(while at the same time compelling them to sail for the horizon misthologically).
        “Be what you are!” was found to be the cry from John’s lips. You are overcomers so overcome. Explicit
promises of rewards, as well as implicit litotetic promises of awards, were enjoined to punctuate his statements
with exclamation marks. It is no more incompatible for John to say that you have an anchor so sail than it is for
mariners to insist that their sailboats need to have anchors as well as sails. The soteriological anchor makes it safe
to take to the winds with misthological sails.
        To continue the maritime analogy, it is time for believers to unfurl their sails and stop worrying about the
soteriological rocks of hell. Treasure is out there and booty to spare (thrones and crowns, trees and pillars) for
those Christians willing to unmask their true identity and sail out as privateers into the deep water and wage war
with the enemy warships. Unlashing their misthological sails from their soteriological masts will enable believers
to fight the good fight of faith and win it. One does not necessarily need to be a Sir John Hawkins or Sir Francis
Drake to smell the opportunity. We need to wage battle against the satanic forces that seek to enslave the lives of
those in the chains of synergistic soteriology or hedonistic priorities.
Page 518   The Outer Darkness
                                             Chapter 23.
                                Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards
                                                    Introduction
       Introductory questions concerning the tears were presented at the beginning of this section.* When people
object to the doctrine of eternal rewards in general and to negative misthology in particular, they quite frequently
do so on the basis that the Bible promises that God will wipe away our tears so that no more sorrow will exist in
heaven (Rev 21:4). Their logic, or lack thereof, runs something like this syllogistic reasoning:
                                          Illustration 171. Weeping Syllogism
              1. Those in the outer darkness weep.
              2. There will be no weeping in heaven.
              3. Therefore, those in the outer darkness are not in heaven.

        From there, they are but a short hop, skip, and a jump away from concluding that the outer darkness is a
soteriological issue and that the outer darkness is equitable with eternal damnation. However, two important
preliminary questions need to be asked concerning this verse. The first question is, “When are the tears wiped
away?” The second is, “Whose tears are wiped away?” The first question will be addressed in this chapter and the
second one in the next. In answering these questions, I will have to part company with some of my misthological
friends—both conservative and ultraistic.
        In this chapter I will present evidence that the tears are wiped away at the conclusion of the millennium—a
point conceded by some misthologists. Yet counter to some misthologists, particularly of the ultraistic persuasion,
it will also be demonstrated that rewards do not cease at the conclusion of the millennium. Subsequently, I will
deal briefly with the second most common objection to the significance of the outer darkness: the notion that
rewards do not matter anyway since we cast our rewards at Jesus’ feet.

                                     When are the Tears Wiped Away?
      Before actually undertaking a serious response to the above reaction to outer darkness misthology, the
absurdity of the above tripartite deduction should first be noted by asking, “If there are no tears in heaven, then
how can the Lord wipe them away?” A syllogistic rejoinder could then readily be made:
                                            Illustration 172. Tears Syllogism
              1. Jesus will only wipe away the tears of those in heaven.
              2. Only those in the outer darkness of heaven will have tears.
              3. Therefore, Jesus will only wipe away the tears of those in the outer darkness of heaven.

        So which is it? Does the promise of wiping away tears apply to believers or unbelievers—to those in heaven
or in hell? Obviously, it must be the tears of believers in heaven. Jesus is not going to wipe away the tears of those
in hell. So the Weeping Syllogism is false, and the objection that those in the outer darkness cannot be in heaven is
invalid. Does this mean that the second syllogism is faultless? No. The Tears Syllogism is faulty because the
promise of wiping away tears is not limited to those in the outer darkness. In fact, it is questionable that it even
applies to them at all after all.
        If the only tears in heaven are those in the outer darkness, then the second syllogism stands, and I have
proven my position that the outer darkness is in heaven. Notwithstanding, I will argue that the second syllogism is
false and that my position is still proven. In other words, if one were to agree with the Tears Syllogism, then one
would be forced to agree with the misthological positioning of the outer darkness in heaven. Yet even if one
disagrees with the Tears Syllogism, it can still be demonstrated that the outer darkness is in heaven.
        By giving a more thorough consideration to the timing of the removal of the tears, I will pursue the latter
course of action. Dillow correctly states that this wiping away of tears does not occur until after the millennium.
Although it is conceivable that the weeping lasts for the whole 1000 years, Dillow attempts to tone down the
significance of this observation in his section on The Duration of the Remorse.933 However, his arguments are
completely unimpressive.

*
    See What About the Tears? 481.
Page 520                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
        The fact that every knee will bow does not mean that everyone will be restored or that the Lord will rejoice
in a “tardy repentance” that is delayed until that time. Satan, his demons, and the lost will confess at that time, but
this does not mean that the Lord will rejoice over their tardy repentance. Although the Lord died for the lost, He
will not rejoice in their tardy repentance. Dillow’s appeal to Rom 8:33-39 is also far from convincing. Are we to
assume that Rom 8:33-39 does not apply to the 1000 years of the millennium? Are we to conclude that believers
can be separated completely from the love of Christ and fellowship with the Lord for 1000 years before Rom 8:33-
39 applies? Not hardly. Unfaithful believers will never be separated completely from the love of Christ. They will
always have some diminutive fellowship with Him. But they will never experience the same depth of love and
fellowship with the Lord that the faithful believers enjoy. If temporal fellowship with the Lord is conditioned upon
how believers walk, and it is, then no legitimate reason precludes one from concluding that eschatological
fellowship cannot be conditioned on how they have walked also.
        Dillow is not the only FG writer who acknowledges that believers are cast into the outer darkness and who
then uses Rev 21:4 to tone down the weeping there. For example, Hodges surmises, “They will weep and gnash
their teeth. Not forever, of course. Indeed, perhaps only for a short time. For ultimately God will wipe away every
tear from their eyes (Rev 21:4).”934 Similarly, Stanley concludes that believers are thrown into the outer darkness
and weep there, but he also tries to minimize the impact of this description by saying: “We do not know how long
this time of rejoicing and sorrow will last. Those whose works are burned will not weep and gnash their teeth for
eternity. At some point we know God will comfort those who have suffered loss (see Rev. 21:4).”935

                                                When and Who
       Chitwood is more straightforward and does not shy away from stating that the wiping away of tears in
Rev 21:4 occurs at the end of the millennium. In contrast, why do some highly esteemed FG writers tend to say
that the tears are wiped away after a short or undisclosed or unknown period of time? The text is not ambiguous.
The tears in Rev 21:4 are not wiped away until the end of the millennium, which will literally last a thousand years.
Chitwood is to be commended for not dodging this conclusion or toning it down. Unfortunately, he then tries to
nullify the eternal nature of rewards by claiming,

             The results of such a forfeiture though cannot exist beyond the millennium. All tears will be
       wiped away at the end of the millennium (Rev. 21:4 [the reference to all tears being wiped away
       prior to the millennium in Rev. 7:17 is only for a select group of individuals realizing an
       inheritance in the kingdom]), and conditions relating to the forfeiture or nonforfeiture of one’s
       birthright cannot really apply beyond this point in time.
             The wiping away of all tears at the end of the millennium would pretend equality within a realm
       where equality had not previously existed. It would clearly appear that during the eternal ages
       distinctions among Christians such as those set forth in the overcomers’ promises or conditions set
       forth in Scriptures dealing with the forfeiture or nonforfeiture of one’s birthright will no longer
       exist.”936 (The bracketed insert is his; the emphasis is mine.)

                                             Rewards are Eternal
       Faust likewise states, “After the millennium, the banished Christians will be restored to endless bliss.”937
The attempts of such misthologists to tone down the eternal nature of rewards must be rejected in consideration of
the words that the NT uses to describe our rewards and in light of other factors as well. Rewards and distinctions
between overcomers and subcomers are not limited to the millennium. Yet if rewards are eternal, then what is the
significance of the tears being wiped away at the end of the millennium? This question and other considerations
will be dealt with as we delve into the eternal nature of rewards.

Aionios
        The NT Greek lexicons (FB, TY, L-N, and BDAG) define the adjective aionios as meaning eternal. Within
the space of three consecutive verses, Paul contrasts the eternal nature of the misthological glory, for which we
wait (2Cor 4:17), with what is temporal (2Cor 4:18), and he couples this eternal glory with the eternality of our
heavenly dwelling (2Cor 5:1). Paul and Peter use this adjective to assure that the glory with which we will be
rewarded will be eternal (2Tim 2:10; 1Pet 5:10). Peter also goes on to affirm that the abundant misthological
entrance that we may earn is into the eternal kingdom (2Pet 2:11). The richness of that misthological entrance does
not end with the millennial kingdom. If the unfaithful rule after the millennium, then the rule ceases to be a reward
at that time, which cannot be the case since Peter and Paul teach that our reward will be eternal (aionios).
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                Page 521
       The writer of Hebrews repeatedly uses aionios to refer to that which is eternal in nature. The millennial
salvation is eternal salvation (Heb 5:9). He is referring to its duration. He is not using this expression eternal
salvation as contemporary writers do to refer to salvation from hell. He is using it in reference to inheriting the
kingdom, not in reference to entering the kingdom.938 This salvation, which is to be inherited and is thus
misthological (Heb 1:14), is an eternal inheritance (Heb 9:15). The writer of Hebrews contrasts the passing
pleasures of sin with the permanence of the reward (Heb 11:24-26) by pointing out that the kingdom we are to
inherit cannot be shaken and will remain (Heb 12:27-28). Millennial salvation is misthological and eternal. This
misthological salvation is not limited to the millennium. The millennial kingdom is but the introductory phase to
the eternal kingdom. The results of the judgment are eternal (Heb 6:2). Our redemption is eternal (Heb 9:12). The
Holy Spirit is eternal (Heb 9:14). This repeated use of aionios by the writer of Hebrews, along with his contrasts
and other affirmations, demonstrates that our misthological salvation and our misthological inheritance are just as
eternal as: the Holy Spirit, God’s soteriological judgment, and our soteriological redemption. Nothing can be any
more permanent! Our misthological salvation and inheritance are everlasting rather than merely age-lasting.

Aion
        Admittedly, the noun aion can be used to refer to this present age, the future millennial age, or eternity. Still,
the latter meaning is most common and is the only part of its semantic range transmitted to its adjectival form—
aionios. In Rev 22:5, aion cannot refer to the present age or the millennial age, for the time period being referred to
is after the millennium. The time period in view is the eternal state; consequently, the context confirms the explicit
claim by the text itself that they will rule forever and ever, just as Rev 11:15 says that He will rule forever and
ever (aion). The writer of Hebrews (Heb 1:8) said that the Son’s throne would be forever, which is the same thing
that the angel said in Lk 1:33. What does this Greek word aion mean in reference to this rulership? The angel gives
a very good definition in Lk 1:33. It means, “Will have no end.” This is the same form of the word that is found in
Rev 22:5, concerning the reign of the faithful elect. Their reign will have no end. “But the saints of the Highest
One will receive the kingdom and possess the kingdom forever, for all ages to come” (Dan 7:18). The OT has no
anticipation of a 1000 year limitation.

Aion and Aionios
        The nominal and adjectival forms of this Greek word can be used interchangeably to refer to eternity. For
example, in Jn 4:14 both forms of the word are used to say that those who have eternal life will never thirst. Never
means forever, for eternity. Peter likewise says that Jesus’ kingdom is eternal (2Pet 1:11). Compare His eternal
dominion in 1Pet 5:11 (aion) with our reward of eternal glory in 1Pet 5:10 (aionios). This demonstration of the
meaning of aionios counters Whipple’s position concerning the nature of this word and substantially weakens his
ultraistic argument that believers can be cast into the fires of Gehenna in Mt 18:8-9.939

       And if your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it from you; it is better for
       you to enter life crippled or lame, than having two hands or two feet, to be cast into the eternal
       [aionios] fire. 9 And if your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out, and throw it from you. It is better
       for you to enter life with one eye, than having two eyes, to be cast into the fiery hell [Gehenna].
       (Mt 18:8-9)

       Whipple argues that aionios means “age-lasting” rather than “everlasting.” Admittedly, an OT Greek
lexicon, L&S, provides definitions of aionios that are inclusive of this meaning. The Greek Dictionary for the NAS
also defines it as meaning agelong or eternal. But the NAS never translates it as agelong in the NT, only as
eternal, eternity, and forever. As L&S indicates concerning aionios and as NIDNTT explicitly states concerning
aion: “In Plato the term [aion] is developed so as to represent a timeless, immeasurable and transcendent super-
time…and from it the Mysteries of Aion, the god of eternity could be celebrated in Alexandria.”940 As clearly seen
in the definitions provided by NIDNTT, aion is defined in terms of eternity or age-long, but aionios is limited to
eternity. So on the basis of these lexicons, one is still left to conclude that the NT meaning for aionios is eternal.
Also, let it be noted that an alternative OT Greek lexicon, LEH, defines it exclusively in terms of eternal rather
than agelong.
       Whipple maintains his position that aionios in Mt 18:8-9 refers to the millennial age in his follow-up book
on Matthew.941 But what is bewildering about Whipple’s continued insistence on limiting aionios to the 1000 years
of the millennial reign is the fact that in this second book he states: “The rewards that Peter wrote about for the
church are not those of the millennial kingdom, but the ‘everlasting [aionios] kingdom’ (2 Pet. 1:11).”942 Yet the
same form of aionios is used by Matthew and Peter in both passages. The fire is just as eternal as the everlasting
Page 522                                                                                                       The Outer Darkness
kingdom. Whipple short-circuits his own argument, apparently without realizing it. He repeatedly states that
rewards are eternal but fails to demonstrate why a believer’s punishment in Gehenna is temporary in light
of the eternal nature of the believer’s misthological punishment.943 He is correct that misthological reward of
the kingdom is eternal and consequently incorrect that the punishment of the fire is not eternal.
        Although the noun aion is used to refer to a segment of time (i.e., age) or to eternity, its adjectival form
aionios is not used in this capacity in the NT. The adjective falls short of having the same breath of meaning
possessed by the noun; the adjective simply means eternal. Believers are not temporarily punished in Gehenna
since punishment in Gehenna is not temporary. The use of aionios in this Matthean passage would lead the reader
of Matthew’s gospel to believe that this punishment is eternal. Naturally, to be punished in Gehenna would indicate
eternal punishment. Since its flames are eternal, its punishment is most naturally taken as eternal.* However, this
cannot be the eternal punishment of believers due to the doctrine of eternal security. Misthological punishment is in
the kingdom, not in the fire of Gehenna nor in the Lake of Fire. Eternal security does not begin in the eternal state;
it does not merely mean security in the eternal state; eternal security begins the moment we receive the gift of
eternal life. The doctrine of eternal security, seemingly, would banish the ultraistic misthological interpretation of
this passage from consideration due to the eternal nature of the punishment in those soteriological flames.
        These soteriological flames are equivalent to the soteriological darkness of Jude 1:13, which describes the
apostates of that passage as, “Wild waves of the sea, foaming out their own shame; wandering stars, for whom the
blackness of darkness hath been reserved forever [aion].” Aion is typically translated as forever, for eternity, or for
everlasting in this passage. However, let us entertain Whipple’s argument that aion means millennial age in Jude
1:13 concerning genuine believers who have committed apostasy “for whom the black darkness has been reserved
for the millennial age.” (TM).944 After all, aion is used in the singular in this verse, and if it means age, it is
referring to one age, not ages.
        Yet the very same form of the word aion is found in Jn 10:28: “And I give eternal [aionios] life to them, and
they shall never [aion] perish; and no one shall snatch them out of My hand.” Thus, using Whipple’s definition,
this verse could be retranslated as saying, “And I give millennial [aionios] life to them, and they will not perish in
the millennial age [singular]; and no one shall snatch them out of My hand” (TM). Even by Whipple’s definition,
Jn 10:28 is saying that no believer will ever perish in the millennial age. The verse is talking about all believers,
since in that context the picture of Jesus’ sheep as those who follow Him is simply a picture of those who trust Him
for eternal life. Those who believe His message and thus appropriate His free gift of eternal life are His sheep. It is
a parabolic picture of the didactical material presented earlier in Jn 5:24.†
        The promise that they will not perish is not limited to the millennium and is not limited to faithful believers.
This same construction is used in the promises He made to all believers in Jn 6:51,58. As a result of eating (i.e.,
appropriating), they will live forever. Jesus is not merely promising millennial life or millennial salvation. Whipple
cannot use Jude 1:13 to claim that believers can spend an aion in Gehenna since Jesus promises believers life
during that aion. Thus, they will not perish in that aion period of time. Jesus is promising eternal life and eternal
soteriological salvation. A comparison of Jude 1:13 with Jn 10:28 demonstrates that unbelievers and believers do
not share the same fate during the aion. Whipple’s definition leads to self-contradiction and is therefore false.
        At a kingdom conference which the author attended, Whipple evidently tried to evade this objection by
appealing to the verbal tense. In his discussion of Jude 1:13, he appealed to the tense of the Greek verb for believe
in Jn 11:25-26 as denoting continuous action since it is a present participle. His defense was that only those who
persevere in faith will not die in that kingdom age. He thus tried to limit this Johannine promise to overcomers and
to make it a misthological promise rather than a soteriological one. In his defense, let it be noted that this appeal to
the Greek tense as denoting ongoing action is extremely common. If the Greek tense conditions our salvation from
misthological death‡ on continuous faith, then his interpretation is far more attractive than that of the Calvinists and
Arminians who use the same tense argument to condition our soteric salvation on continuous faith.
        However, I thoroughly reject this popular tense argument in soteric contexts. I contend that Jesus promises
that those who believe in Him with a punctiliar faith will never die. Thus, no believer will ever die in the sense
indicated in this passage. If the linear tense argument is false (and it is), then Whipple’s argument backfires upon
itself. The tense shows that no believer will die after being raised from the dead or after the rapture. My
counterargument regarding the tense§ rules out believers being resurrected and then being killed or experiencing
the second death and being sent to Gehenna. This passage in Jn 11:25-26 and its metaphorical counterpart in Jn
