10:28 are soteriological promises to all believers that they will never perish or die. Thus, believers cannot literally
be sawn in two, killed, or physically destroyed.
        Faust seeks to counter by pointing out, “It is true that all Christians presently possess ‘eternal life’ as a free
gift (John 6:47). However, unless the Christian is raptured without dying, physical death must intervene
before he or she experiences true, continual life” (italics his, bold mine). From this deduction he goes on to
conclude, “Therefore, it will not be until after the millennium that all Christians experience absolute “eternal life”
(italics his, bold mine). He correctly notes that eternal life may be a reward but deduces on the basis of his
misthology: “The only way ‘eternal life’ can be set before the saints as a conditional reward would be if there is
another, special time when some saints will begin this experience earlier than the larger group” (italics his, bold
mine).945
        Apparently, Faust has overlooked a significant text and misconstrued his timeframes as a result. In Jn 11:26,
Jesus assures Martha that those believers who live until He returns will never die (cp. Jn 8:51-52). As Faust
indicated, in their case physical death will not intervene. However, this is a significant exception. Those carnal
believers who are alive at the rapture will be caught up to be with the Lord forever and are assured that they will
never die. It would be impossible for them to be killed at the Bema. Faust’s entire argument for the bema-death of
carnal believers short-circuits on the grounds of Jn 11:26.
        All believers already have eternal life as an absolute quantitative possession.† On the basis of Christ’s
promise, it must be concluded that the possession of this life will prevent those believers who are alive when Christ
returns from ever experiencing physical death. Faust is mistaken in attempting to delay the quantitative possession
of eternal life until after the millennium. Believers will never die spiritually, and those who are alive when He
returns will never die physically. The conditional dimension of eternal life for the believer is not to be found in its
quantitative attribute, but in its qualitative aspect.
        Those believers who serve the Lord faithfully will experience this life abundantly, that is, in a fuller measure
than those who do not. The Greek word for abundant in Jn 10:10 is perissos. In this verse, Jesus discusses
possession in terms of a fuller experience, which means to have more of eternal life in terms of amount rather than
duration. Elevation rather than duration is in question. Faithful believers will experience eternal life at a higher
degree of satisfaction than those unfaithful believers consigned to the outer darkness. Yet both faithful and
unfaithful believers currently have eternal life and are promised that as a result they will not die if they are alive
when the Lord returns.
        The answer as to what Jesus is promising is not to be found in limiting the misthological fullness of this life
to the earlier period of a mere thousand years, as Faust attempts to do. On the contrary, the misthological
qualitative dimension of eternal life in the form of abundant life begins now, excites our imagination in the
millennium, and is amplified beyond description in the eternity future. How could Jesus meaningfully have
communicated to those living in that geocentric time period that abundant life could expand to encompass ruling
galaxies? Many believers even living in our own current heliocentric time period have not yet even grasped the
logical necessity of that conclusion! Abundant life does not stop at the millennium.
        Aside from the timetable miscalculation, the ultraistic interpretation of Gehenna is refuted by the fact that
believers are not subject to the death after the rapture. It is sorely tempting at this point simply to accept Unger’s
traditional assessment that Gehenna does not refer to temporary suffering during the intermediate state but to
eternal suffering during the eternal state and is thus equivalent to the Lake of Fire.946 But there are also problems
with the traditional view that need to be addressed in the appendices of this book, and to the credit of ultraistic
friends, such problems are receiving closer scrutiny in misthological circles. Indeed, the present writer would
concur that carnal believers can experience misthological death. Yet, since Gehenna is a place of suffering for the
“whole body” (Mt 5:29; 10:28), this misthological death must be experienced after a bodily resurrection if it refers
to a direct eschatological punishment. I will, therefore, agree with Unger at least to the extent of saying that using
Gehenna as a simple description of the intermediate state is ruled out.‡ Additionally, since I do not accept the
ultraistic premise that believers are raised to be killed, I also reject their argument that Gehenna is a millennial
possibility for believers.
        The ultraistic position furthermore is refuted by my analysis of the eternality of the misthological reality.
The eternal aspect of its suffering is not only supported by the use of aionios in Mt 18:8-9 but is also confirmed by
its description in Mk 9:43-48, as a place where the fire is unquenchable (eternal) and filled with worms that do not

  Preterists and annihilationists, and perhaps some even within our own camp would pose a temporal Gehenna. These complexities

die (eternal torment). This region of fire and legion of worms can never be escaped. Unfaithful believers can be
punished in the outer darkness, but they cannot spend any metaphysical time in literal Gehenna, not one moment
ever.

Aionic Rulership
       To reiterate the above discussion concerning aion and aionios, I am employing a coined adjectival form
aionic to refer to these terms interchangeably below. Whereas in the discussion above, I was content to deal
primarily with the NT, it should not be thought that this position concerning the eternality of rewards, both positive
and negative, is limited to NT affirmation. On the contrary, the eternal nature of rewards is also corroborated by the
OT, as will now be demonstrated.

                              Forever and Ever (Eis ton Aiona tou Aionos)
       The phrase, forever and ever, in Heb 1:8 is literally for the age (aion sg.) of the age (aion sg.): eis ton aiona
tou aionos. The kingdom with which the Lord Jesus is to be rewarded will last forever and ever. The singular form
of aion is thus used idiomatically to affirm the eternality of Christ’s kingdom. The same phrase is used to affirm
eternal Kingship in the LXX: “The Lord is King forever and ever” (Ps 9:37). “Thy throne, O God, is forever and
ever” (Ps 45:6). The Davidic throne is synchronistically parallel to this expression for eternity: “So I will establish
his descendants forever and ever, and his throne as the days of heaven” (Ps 89:29) and forever like the moon
(89:36-37). Simply and repeatedly, it is said to be forever (Ez 37:25). Those who use their insight to lead others to
live righteously will shine brightly “like the stars forever and ever” (Dan 12:3). This glorious distinction,
introduced by the millennial age, is eternal in its duration.

                              Forever and Ever (Eis tous Aionas ton Aionon)
       The related phrase, forever and ever, in Rev 22:5 is literally for the ages (aion pl.) of the ages (aion pl.): eis
tous aionas ton aionon. Here we are told that God’s servants will “reign forever and ever.” This is the same phrase
used in Rev 20:10 concerning the eternal torment of the beast, devil, and the false prophet in the Lake of Fire.
God’s faithful servants will rule in the kingdom of heaven just as long as these rebels against God suffer in the
Lake of Fire—for eternity. These concepts stand or fall together.
       Eternal dominion is ascribed to Christ with this phrase (1Pet 4:11; Rev 1:6; 5:13; 11:15). Daniel (7:18)
likewise uses a form of this phrase to affirm the eternal nature of the reward: “But the saints of the Most High shall
receive the kingdom, and possess the kingdom forever [aion, sg.], even forever [aion sg.] and ever [aion pl.]. Thus,
the combination of singular and plural in the phrase, aionos ton aionon, can be used in the same fashion as the
plural with plural: aionas ton aionon. Singularity is used of eternity, and the nominal may be eternal.

                                             Everlasting (Ton Aionon)
       Likewise, in Ps 145:13 we again find: “Thy kingdom is an everlasting kingdom, and Thy dominion endures
throughout all generations.” Everlasting is literally of all the ages (aion pl.). Luke expresses it this way: “He will
reign over the house of Jacob forever; and His kingdom will have no end” (Lk 1:33). The plural nominal form is
used to affirm an aionic rulership that is to last throughout eternity future.

                                           Forevermore (Eis ton Aiona)
       Micah (4:7) notes the permanency of His majesty: “And the Lord will reign over them in Mount Zion from
now on and forever [eis ton aiona, sg.].” Isaiah affirms the eternal perpetuity of the generations and rulership:
“There will be no end to the increase of His government or of peace, on the throne of David and over his kingdom,
to establish it and to uphold it with justice and righteousness from then on and forevermore” (Is 9:7). Davidic
material concurs by using this phrase to say: “The Lord will reign forever!” (Ps 146:10; cp. Ex 15:18). The Davidic
throne is to be forever (2Sam 7:13,16; 2Chron 13:5). The inheritance is to be forever (Ex 32:13; Ps 37:18).
       Danielic texts use the singular interchangeably with the plural (Dan 2:44): “In the days of those kings the
God of heaven will set up a kingdom which will never [eis tous aionas, pl.] be destroyed, and that kingdom will
not be left for another people; it will crush and put an end to all these kingdoms, but it will itself endure forever [eis
ton aiona, sg.].” “His kingdom is an everlasting [sg.] kingdom, and His dominion is from generation to generation”
(Dan 4:3). Although the nominal singular form of aion is used, it refers to eternity future. When the Hebrew text in
Dan 6:26 is consulted, synonymous usage is found as well: “He is the living God and enduring forever [alam], and
His kingdom is one which will not be destroyed, and His dominion will be forever [soph].”
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                             Page 525
                                                    Aionios
       The Lord’s “dominion is an everlasting [aionios] dominion which will not pass away; and His kingdom is
one which will not be destroyed” (Dan 7:14). This kingdom, which is to be given to His saints, is eternal: “Then
the sovereignty, the dominion, and the greatness of all the kingdoms under the whole heaven will be given to the
people of the saints of the Highest One; His kingdom will be an everlasting [aionios] kingdom, and all the
dominions will serve and obey Him” (Dan 7:27). The Danielic fifth and final kingdom is that which is
introduced by the millennium and which continues throughout eternity. There is not a separate sixth
kingdom for the eternal age. The millennial kingdom is a transitional inauguration to the eternal regality of
both the Lord and His faithful saints. This reward—this rulership—is eternal.

Ever, Never, and Forever
        The fact that both the positive and negative results of judgment are eternal is demonstrated in a variety of
ways. In contrast to the destruction that unfaithful believers will receive in Gal 6:8, faithful believers reap eternal
life, not mere millennial life. Isaiah says they will inherit the land forever (Is 60:21). The duration of the
inheritance should be contrasted with that of the non-inheritance. Dillow translates Heb 3:11 and Ps 95:11 as
saying that they will never enter My Rest.947 Does never not mean forever? BDAG (ei, 4) likewise calls this gram-
matical construction a “marker of strong or solemn assertion,” in this case, a negation that should be translated
strongly as “they shall certainly not enter.” On the next page, Dillow translates the saying concerning the unfaithful
elect in Num 14:23 as, “Not one of them will ever see the land.”948 This is an emphatic negation in the Greek text.
The unfaithful elect will never ever enter the rest. Not only are the inheritance and rest eternal, the disinheritance
and unrest are also eternal. Both the positive and negative aspects of the judgment are eternal. Those who are cast
into the outer darkness are there eternally, at least in terms of the misthological consequences being represented by
exclusion from the misthological inheritance and rest.
        Does this mean unfaithful believers are excluded eternally from any and all fellowship with the King? No.
The parables do not picture the unfaithful believers as being killed. They continue to live. At the same time, the
parables do not picture them as being allowed into the palace at the end of the wedding feast. To conjecture that
they are ever allowed into the palace after being cast outside of it is presumptuous. A better picture is to
acknowledge that, although they stay out of the palace, the King does not stay in the palace. The whole kingdom is
His, and, in the course of His affairs, He will travel throughout the kingdom. Although the unfaithful are locked out
of the palace, the King is not locked in the palace. The unfaithful still can have limited contact and fellowship with
the King when He comes out of the palace.
        On the one hand, misthological assumptions that the next morning he wipes away their tears and tells the
unfaithful that it will be business as usual are equally unconvincing. Far to the contrary, like those who fell in the
wilderness, they never enter the rest for all eternity, just as the writer of Hebrews points out. We may think of them
as barred from the palace, not banished from the kingdom. There is no compelling reason to limit the negative
experience of the outer darkness to 1000 years. On the other hand, there is no reason to assume that the king comes
out of the palace the next morning and kills those who were cast into the outer darkness. Such soteriological
assumptions are unwarranted. Those barred from this misthological rest are barred for the rest of their lives.

Reception of the Unshakable Kingdom
       Those who died in the wilderness (and who consequently never entered the land) never received the
inheritance, just as Esau never received it. The writer of Hebrews mentions that Esau did receive a limited blessing,
“By faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, even regarding things to come” (Heb 11:20). But the blessing Esau
received there does not nullify the fact that the rejection he experienced in Heb 12:16-17 was eternal.
       15
         See to it that no one comes short of the grace of God; that no root of bitterness springing up causes
       trouble, and by it many be defiled; 16 that there be no immoral or godless person like Esau, who sold
       his own birthright for a single meal. 17 For you know that even afterwards, when he desired to
       inherit the blessing, he was rejected, for he found no place for repentance, though he sought for it
       with tears. (Heb 12:15-17)

       Further, the writer of Hebrews goes on to say in Heb 12:25-29 that the kingdom we will receive (i.e., rule)
will be unshakable and remain. BDAG (1.a) cites Lk 19:12,15 as examples where receiving a kingdom (basileia) is
equivalent to receiving a kingship. Receiving a kingdom can certainly mean more than entering a kingdom; it can
be used to describe receiving the right to exercise rulership over that kingdom. Although this expression of
Page 526                                                                                                    The Outer Darkness
receiving a kingdom appears capable of being used soteriologically to denote mere entrance into the kingdom
(which appears to be the case in Mk 10:15; Lk 18:17), it can also be used misthologically to denote rulership of the
kingdom received.
        The soteriological expressions for receiving the kingdom in Mk 10:15 and Lk 18:17 both use (dechomai) for
receive.* The misthological receiving of the kingdom uses lambano in Lk 19:12,15 and its compound paralambano
in Heb 12:28. The background for this passage in the LXX also uses paralambano: “But the saints of the Highest
One will receive the kingdom and possess the kingdom forever, for all ages to come” (Dan 7:18). This is the same
compound that was used a little earlier in the LXX to describe Darius assuming rulership: “So Darius the Mede
received the kingdom at about the age of sixty-two” (Dan 5:31). Soteriological reception of the kingdom might
possibly be distinguished lexically from the misthological acquisition of it. Nevertheless, to receive the kingdom
most naturally means to take possession of it: “Judgment was passed in favor of the saints of the Highest One, and
the time arrived when the saints took possession of the kingdom” (Dan 7:22; cp. 7:18). The entire context of Heb
12:28 substantiates the misthological understanding of this acquisition of the kingdom as referring to earned
rulership since it is conditioned upon believers offering an acceptable service to God. This kingship is rulership
that believers take possession of through service to God.
        What is at stake is not a mere millennial kingdom but a kingdom that cannot be shaken. The inheritance that
we are to receive (i.e., the kingdom that we are to receive) cannot be shaken. According to Hodges the subject
matter pertains to “the ultimate remaking of the heavens and earth which will follow the millennial kingdom.”949
This verse in Hebrews is describing rulership in the eternal state after the millennial age and is therefore a
conceptual parallel to Rev 22:5. The clear implication of Heb 12:28 is that rulership during the eternal state can be
forfeited in the present if we do not live for the Lord. The rulership that is won or forfeited is won or lost for
eternity. An eternal distinction will exist between overcomers and subcomers, between rulers and non-rulers.950
The fact that our service in Heb 12:28 is to be rendered out of gratitude should pose no problem to the acceptance
of this conclusion.951 Our gratitude should not be limited to what the Lord unconditionally has done for us (in
giving us unconditional security); it should also include what He conditionally will do for us (in offering us
conditional rewards). The way to show gratitude for the opportunity of receiving such a stupendous reward is to
pay the price necessary to receive such a reward. The Lord has given us a great opportunity; let us show gratitude
by taking advantage of it.

Rest
        Dillow’s discussion about the rest in his fifth chapter not only points out the length of the rest, it also sheds
light on the nature of the rest. By appealing to passages such as Num 14:21-23; Dt 3:18-20; 12:8-10; and Josh 1:13,
he is able to argue convincingly that the rest is a place, specifically the land of Canaan. He also identifies “the city
Zion, the central city of Canaan,” as the resting place on the basis of Ps 132:13-14.952 Further, he also points out
that although the rest is a place (the land and city), it is also an experience of rulership over the kingdom.
        On the other hand, Dillow and others are apparently inconsistent in claiming that all the elect will enter into
the place of rest, but only the faithful elect will enter into the experience of rest. It would be much more consistent
to affirm that the unfaithful elect will never enter this rest at all—either spatially or experientially. After all, Dillow
correctly identified the rest as both a place and an experience. Therefore, it should be concluded that unfaithful
believers will never enter into the place or experience of rest (rulership). Subcomers will never enter the land, the
city, or rule in the kingdom. The outer darkness appears to be a picture of this doctrinal fact. The outer darkness is
both a place and an experience. As the rest is both spatial and experiential, so is the lack of rest—the outer
darkness. The outer darkness is best defined as the spatial experience of being within the kingdom but never
ever being allowed to enter the capital city, nor the land of Canaan, and never ever being allowed to exercise
rulership over any part of the kingdom during the millennial or eternal epochs.

Aphthartos, Amarantos, and Amarantinos
      Further demonstration pertaining to the eternity of our recompense is found in Paul’s statement that our
wreath would be imperishable (aphthartos; 1Cor 9:25). Peter likewise said that our inheritance would be
imperishable (aphthartos) and not fade away (amarantos; 1Pet 1:4) and that our crown would not fade away
(amarantinos; 1Pet 5:4). Our crown and inheritance is just as imperishable (aphthartos) as our new birth and the
word of God that produces that birth (1Pet 1:23). Our rewards are imperishable and unfading. If the distinctions

*
  Soteriologically believing the kingdom message is probably in view. Alternatively, misthologically believing the kingdom message
may be in view. See Children Represent Merited and Unmerited Entrance, 639.
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                         Page 527
between the faithful and unfaithful are obliterated at the end of the 1000 years, then the rewards cease to be
rewards at that time, which cannot be the case. Whether Jesus is our Savior will have everlasting consequences:
heaven versus hell. Whether Jesus is our Lord will also have everlasting consequences: rest versus unrest.

Payment
       Nee correctly understands the parable of the unmerciful servant in Mt 18:21-35 as describing the
misthological punishment of unmerciful believers at the Bema.953 According to Nee, such a believer is punished by
being put into prison and handed over to the tortures. It pictures the same spatial and experiential suffering as
portrayed by the outer darkness. (However, it does not envisage Gehenna as Nee believes.) Nee also does
exceptionally well to further note that such believers “will have to remain there until they pay off all their debts. Of
course, there is no way to pay off all the debts.”954 The logical conclusion of Nee’s statement is that they will
have to remain there forever. Yet Nee attempts to avoid this ratiocination by arguing that some day they will
mature and learn to be merciful and be released at that time.955 In doing so, he contradicts himself by saying that
some believers “will be temporarily put into the fire [of Gehenna]. They will come out only after they have paid
all their debts.”956 On the contrary, Sauer computes this as being an eternal debt since it is impossible to pay it off
even with an infinite amount of time to do so.

       One talent consisted of 6,000 denarii. This means that 10,000 talents were equal to 60 million
       denarii….the daily wage for a worker in the harvest amounted to one denarius, i.e., not quite a
       shilling (Matt. 20:2-10, 13)….He would have to work 164,000 years without holidays, without any
       Sundays or other furlough. And even then he would have worked off only the capital amount without
       having paid the interest, simple or compounded, which of course would have to be reckoned up and
       added….So that the more he worked to decrease his debt, the more his debt would have increased
       from day to day. (Emphasis his.)957

       Nee correctly believes (1) that such believers have to remain there until they pay their debt and (2) that they
can never repay it. Therefore, he should have concluded (3) that they will never be released. In attempting to avoid
this logical culmination of his own observation, Nee refutes his own argument. His error is in denying that the
punishment is eternal. This punishment cannot be limited to the thousand years of the millennium. Consequently, it
cannot be a misthological Gehenna for the redeemed.

Tree and City Inclusion
        Lee falls into the same type of error when he says that carnal believers are thrown into the outer darkness
and punished there until they become ripe and mature.958 As a result, he concludes on the basis of Rev 22:3-5 that
carnal believers will be included in the New Jerusalem, eat of the tree of life, and rule forever. His premise is faulty
since in Mt 13:30 all the wheat is gathered into the same place (the millennial kingdom) at the same time (the
revelation). The time of the harvest and gathering of the wheat is not dependent upon the maturity of each
individual piece of grain. As the parable of the sower illustrates, some of the wheat never brings forth fruit to
maturity (Lk 8:14).*
        In the thorny soil, life and growth are found but no mature fruit. As McCoy notes from Tenney, the fact that
they bear no mature fruit does not mean that they bear no fruit to any degree, but the fruit will be puny and runty,
scanty in amount and stunted in development.959 It is not until one reaches the good soil that all three are found:
life, growth, and mature fruit. This type of Christian sinks his or her roots deep and grows straight and experiences
an abundant result. This believer will be well rewarded in contrast to the other two believers who suffer various
degrees of loss of reward. At least the middle Christian did bear some fruit. Lee’s attempt to transform the outer
darkness into a Protestant purgatory fails to do justice to the Lord’s teaching that if maturity is to be reached, it
must be reached now. The outer darkness is punitory, not preparatory or purgatory. Lee’s conclusion is also
faulty since Rev 22:14,19 shows that the tree and city are rewards (cf. Rev 22:12) in the eternal kingdom. Thus, the
servants who partake of the benefits in Rev 22:3-5 are faithful, rewarded servants. And the rewards they receive are
eternal, not merely millennial. Fruit is extremely and eternally important.†

Misthologically Seeing God
       Surprisingly, even Dillow makes a similar mistake concerning the eternal duration of rewards in Rev 22:3-
5.960 Earlier, Dillow had given a superb analysis of Rev 21:7 (which says that overcomers would inherit the things
promised) and 22:14 (which says that those who wash their robes will have a right to the tree of life and enter by
the gates into the city). Concerning these passages, he appropriately argues that only overcomers will rule in the
New Jerusalem.961 Deductively, one would conclude that only overcomers will rule in the eternal state and in the
eternal kingdom. Further, Dillow’s distinction between the millennial kingdom and the eternal kingdom/state
concerning the promise in Rev 22:5 of eternal rulership indicates that he correctly perceives that Rev 22 (esp.
22:14) is dealing with the eternal state.962 He also acknowledges that not only is Rev 22:14 conditional, but “the
context of Rev 22 is similarly conditional.”963 In spite of these splendid observations, he oddly concludes that Rev
22:5 is an uncon-ditional promise that all believers (subcomers included) will rule in the eternal kingdom.
However, his own analysis points to the opposite conclusion. As GNTC rightly observes, Rev 22:5 is a conditional
promise realized only by those believers who overcome.* The book of Revelation does not teach that all believers
will rule, and it does not teach that all believers are overcomers. If all believers rule during the eternal state, then
the promise in Rev 21:7 applies to all believers, and all believers are overcomers. If that were the case, then Wong
is right, and Dillow is wrong. Dillow’s argument short-circuits itself. Rather, it should be concluded that in the
eternal state:

        •    All believers do not inherit these things (Rev 21:7).
        •    All believers do not rule—in the New Jerusalem nor in the eternal kingdom (Rev 22:5).
        •    All believers do not eat of the tree (Rev 22:14,19).
        •    All believers do not enter the city (Rev 22:14,19).

         Dillow did very well on points 1 and 3, but he fumbled the ball on points 2 and 4. All believers do not rule
the eternal kingdom, and all believers are not residents of the New Jerusalem. Just as it was concluded that the tree
is not free,† so it must be concluded that the city is not free either. The same arguments would apply to both. It was
fitting for Dillow to cite from Lang’s book, Firstborn Sons, in support of his position that in Rev 21:6-8 there are
“three classes of people being compared” in the eternal state: children of God (immature heirs who receive a
limited inheritance), sons of God (mature heirs who receive a full inheritance), and the lost.964 In spite of this
observation, Dillow apparently believes that the related passage in Rev 22:3-5 shows that in the eternal state even
subcomers will see His face, have His name on their foreheads, and rule forever.
         However, Mt 5:8 clearly indicates that seeing God is restricted misthologically to only certain believers.
Additionally, Heb 12:14 also indicates that seeing God is an experience that can be limited to believers who
persevere in practical sanctification to the point that they share His holiness experientially and produce
righteousness visibly (Heb 12:10-11). Jesus also teaches conditional manifestation in Jn 14:21. That seeing God in
Rev 22:4 is a reward given only to the overcomer is indicated by Lang who (concerning this very passage) gives a
historical and biblical parallel concerning the seven nobles in Est 1:14, who “saw the king’s face” (KJ). They had
“conspired to overthrow the usurper Smerdis [and] agreed that part of their reward should be the right of
unrestricted access to the king….Thus, to ‘see the king’s face’ meant freedom of access to his immediate presence
at all times, a high privilege not available to others.”965
         This is all the more remarkable in that Queen Esther, whom the king dearly loved (Est 2:17), feared for her
life when it became necessary for her to come before the king uninvited: “All the king’s servants and the people of
the king’s provinces know that for any man or woman who comes to the king to the inner court who is not
summoned, he has but one law, that he be put to death, unless the king holds out to him the golden scepter so that
he may live. And I have not been summoned to come to the king for these thirty days” (Est 4:11). This privilege of
immediate access at all times to see the king was a right not even granted to his beloved queen, and yet it was
granted as a reward to these men! This is the reward being offered to faithful believers. In further contrast to
Dillow, who thinks that the privileges in Rev 22:4 are a gift, Lang asks, “How shall a Christian sincerely expect

grounds for ignoring the implications of Rev 22:19. Subcomers will not have access to either the tree of life or the Reward City.

that name to be placed at last on his forehead if he does not bear it now morally, by living before men a life of

Misthological Name
       In support of Lang’s rhetorical question, it may be responded that Rev 3:12 clearly says that only
overcomers will have God’s name written upon them. This verse is particularly interesting because it says that
overcomers will be made a pillar in the temple “and not go out from it anymore.” This appears to be a promise that
the overcomers’ reward will be forevermore.* It will be eternal and thus not be obliterated at the end of the
millennium. This conclusion is strongly supported by the next part of the verse, which says that the name written
on the overcomer will not only be the name of God but also “the name of the city of My God, the New
Jerusalem, which comes down out of heaven from My God, and My new name.” This promise to the overcomers
concerning the names written on them are associated with the New Jerusalem and the eternal age, not the Heavenly
Jerusalem and the millennium age. This eternal reward of having the name of God during the eternal state is
promised to overcomers, not subcomers.

Rulership
       Concerning rulership in Rev 22:5, John repeatedly makes it clear that the rulers are overcomers, not
subcomers (e.g., Rev 2:10,26-27; 3:21; 20:4,6). Lang likewise states concerning Rev 22:5, “Let each who aspires
to reign with the Son of man in His kingdom walk now in His steps.”967 Granted, Dillow is free to agree with Lang
that Rev 21:7 describes overcomers in the eternal state and then disagree with Lang that Rev 22:3-5 describes
overcomers in the eternal state. Yet Dillow should justify his disagreement since it appears to be a completely
unjustified flip-flop. To be consistent, it is best to agree with Lang that both Rev 21:7 and 22:3-5 describe the
blessings given to overcomers in the eternal state. That the expression, “His servants,” in Rev 22:3-5 does not
necessarily mean “all His servants” should be obvious enough from Dillow’s own analysis.†
       In Rev 2:20, His servants are lead astray. As was noted in the interaction with Wong herein, jumping to the
conclusion that this means that all His servants are lead astray is misleading.‡ Not all comers are subcomers.
Likewise, when we read in Rev 11:18, that the time has come for God to reward His servants, we should not
automatically conclude that this means all His servants. Surely those servants who are lead astray are not to be
rewarded in a positive manner. “The saints” does not mean “all the saints” in Rev 11:18, which is a distinction that
Dillow has well noted concerning other passages of Scripture. Since the rewarded servants in Rev 11:18 do not
refer to all the servants, why jump to the conclusion that the rewarded servants in Rev 22:3-5 refer to all the
servants? It must be concluded that Dillow is as equally wrong as Wong concerning Rev 22:5.

Eternal Distinctions
       It could be countered that Rev 11:18 is anticipating the millennial state, but Rev 22:3-5 is dealing with the
eternal state. This is true, but what does it prove? The millennial distinction between overcomers and subcomers is
still maintained in the eternal state, and overcomers are the ones rewarded in the eternal state. Dillow himself
acknowledges this concerning Rev 21:7. The New Earth and New Jerusalem have just been described by John in
Rev 21:1-2, as well as in some promises in Rev 21:3-6. Then John proceeds to say in Rev 21:7 that it is the
overcomer who will inherit these promises.968 Those who inherit, rule, and are blessed in the eternal state
(Rev 21:7; 22:3-5,14) are those who overcome and wash their robes. Practically speaking, not all believers will
overcome; otherwise, there would be no need to exhort them to overcome. Exegetically speaking, the book of
Revelation already has made it clear that not all the saints overcome. Some are led astray. Thus, when Rev 21:6
and 22:17 are contrasted with Rev 21:7 and 22:14,19, the implication is that some comers will be subcomers in
Rev 21:6 and 22:14,17,19.

        •    It may be anticipated that some of those who take the free offer of the water of life in 21:6 will
             fail to pay the price necessary to become an overcomer in 21:7.
        •    Only those who wash their robes in practical sanctification will be entitled misthologically to the
             tree of life and the city in 22:14.

        •    It may be anticipated that some of those who take the free offer of the water of life in 22:17 will
             lose their misthological portion in the tree of life and holy city in 22:19.

       In short, it is possible to take Rev 22:19 as an implicit indication that some of those who respond to the free
soteriological offers of Rev 21:6 and 22:17 will fail to qualify for the misthological offers of 21:7 and 22:19. The
water of life is offered freely to all, and only those who have responded positively to that offer can said to be
genuinely addressed by the warning of 22:19 concerning the danger of losing their misthological right to partake of
the tree of life and the holy city. The lost have no such rights to lose.

Eternal Rewards in the New Jerusalem

                                              Tree and City Exclusion
         The tree of life and the city of Rev 22:14,19 are implicitly denoted as rewards in 22:12. This misthological
description of the tree and city follows the discussion of the tree in the New Jerusalem in Rev 21:2 and 22:2.969
“And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven from God, made ready as a bride adorned for
her husband” (Rev 21:2). What is at stake in Rev 22:14,19 is not merely exclusion from the tree and the Heavenly
Jerusalem during the millennium. What is at stake is rewards concerning the Heavenly Jerusalem after it has come
down out of heaven. Thus, what is at risk are the rewards concerning the New Jerusalem and the eternal state.
Indeed, Lang seems to have anticipated this very conclusion. In regard to the question, Is the vision of the Holy
City in chs. 21 and 22 “millennial, eternal, or both?” he responds, “Certainly it is eternal....But is also millennial,
because the marriage of the Lamb takes place just before He comes forth to set up His kingdom on earth” (Rev
19:6-8). I would prefer to say that it refers to inaugurated eternity, but that minor point aside, I definitely agree
with Lang’s statement that this reward list is limited, both during the millennium and throughout eternity, “for that
limited portion of the saved known to Scripture as ‘the church of the firstborn ones who are enrolled in
heaven’…there attaining thereto is the reward that grace will give for the sufferings which grace enabled them to
bear unto the end.” Moreover, I would agree with his calling this reward “the heavenly portion.” The “eternal
kingdom” will be “RICHLY supplied” to those who overcome (emphasis his). The saved not comprising this
rewarded company “will live on earth, not in the regions above, in heaven” (i.e., the Heavenly City)—as he
maintains—both during the millennium and throughout eternity.970 For the most part, I simply am tracing out the
logical implications of Lang’s statements with increased clarity and consistency.
         For example, Wilkin is certainly correct to conclude that Rev 22:14-17 is dealing with the New Jerusalem
and the eternal state.971 The misthological threat in Rev 22:19 is also dealing with the tree and New Jerusalem in
the eternal kingdom. Lang correctly perceives that they lose their portion in the city and tree both millennially and
eternally.972 Millennial exclusion becomes eternal exclusion from the tree and the New Jerusalem! Nevertheless,
Wilkin stops short of making this connection, but it is the logical extension of his argument. He is inconsistent in
concluding that all believers will enter the city. Whipple tentatively takes a similar position: “Finally, all the saved,
i.e., all those whose names are written in the Lamb’s Book of Life (Rev. 21:27), will have the right to enter the
city, though they probably will not be permitted to live there.”973 Correspondingly, at most the subcomers will
enter the city through some other means than the gates. They certainly will not inherit or inhabit the city.
         This approach is attractive but not entirely persuasive. The presence of one’s name in the Book of Life
guarantees that one will not be thrown into hell (Rev 20:15) and that one will live somewhere in the kingdom of
heaven. According to Rev 21:27, only those who have their names written in the Book of Life will enter the
Heavenly City on earth: “And nothing unclean and no one who practices abomination and lying, shall ever come
into it, but only (ei me) those whose names are written in the Lamb’s book of life.” Even so, this does not prove
that all those who have their name written in the Book of Life will enter the city. In this verse, the direct contrast
may be simply between the lost and saved, not between subcomers and overcomers. The lost will never enter the
city; only the saved will enter it.*
         Yet this need not necessarily mean that all the saved will enter it: that only A can do B does not mean that all
A will do B. Or to restate in terms of another plausible translation of ei me: that no one except the saved will enter
does not mean that all the saved will enter. All names of the saved are written, and only the saved will be allowed
to enter. But not all the saved will be able to enter. Everyone will want to enter, but only those who have met all

*
 For my principle discussions of misthopology, see Tree and City Inclusion, 527; Misthologically Seeing God, 528; Tree and City
Exclusion, 530; Rev 21:2—City, 542; Part, 548; Limited Accessibility, 549; Portion in the City, 551; City of Rest, 551; Gates of Honor
and Limitation, 551; Limited Entrance, 570; Reward City, 603; Bridal City, 604.
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                   Page 531
requirements to do so will be able to do so. Other requirements, such as overcoming, are not specified in this verse
since the polar contrast is not with subcomers. The expression, ei me, is “a marker of contrast by designating an
exception” (L-N 89.131).* It should not be necessarily assumed that in this contrast all the saved have entrance.†
        As an example of the ei me not necessarily meaning all without restriction (nor all without exception for
that matter), note that the OT restricts the eating of the showbread to the priests: “It shall be for Aaron and his sons,
and they shall eat it in a holy place; for it is most holy to him from the Lord’s offerings by fire, his portion forever”
(Lev 24:9). They were the only ones who were supposed to eat this bread. Yet Jesus notes that there were
exceptions to this restriction: “Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, he and those who were with
him: how he entered the house of God and ate the showbread which was not lawful for him to eat, nor for those
who were with him, but only [ei me] for the priests?” (Mt 12:3-4; NKJ) At a minimum, Jesus’ point is that since
the OT did not condemn David and his men, His opponents should not condemn Him or His disciples either. They
are exceptions to the ei me rule.
        Theoretically speaking at least, if people born without a sin nature in eternity future do not receive the gift of
eternal life and therefore do not have their names in the Book of Life, they nevertheless will be inhabitants of the
eternal kingdom and be allowed to visit inside the capital city—New Jerusalem. They would be exceptions to the ei
me clause. The emphatic negation (ou me) in Rev 21:27 would not apply to them since they will be sinless, in
contrast to the lost who retain their sin nature throughout eternity and who are designated as liars in the eternal
state.‡ Alternatively, they may have eternal life and have their names in the Book of Life. In that case, their being
allowed to enter does not prove that subcomers will be allowed to enter.
        The objection will still be made that the above scenario does not demonstrate that any of those whose names
are in the Book of Life will be excluded. Such an objection would fail to note the context of the Levitical statement
above, which stipulates: “No man, of the descendants of Aaron, who is a leper or who has a discharge, may eat of
the holy gifts until he is clean” (Lev 22:4). Although Aaron’s sons were qualified to eat, by virtue of being his
sons, they could be disqualified from eating because of ceremonial uncleanness. To speak in terms of this analogy,
any believer who is soteriologically clean because he or she is a child of God, and thus qualified to enter the city on
that basis, may be disqualified from entering if he or she is misthologically unclean. Misthological lepers will not
enter the city in eternity. This grammatical parallel shows that further restrictions may disqualify those normally
qualified by the ei me exception clause. Thus, by virtue of this grammatical parallel, even if a believer would
normally not be excluded because of the presence of his or her name in the Book of Life, the believer may still be
excluded because of extenuating circumstances specified elsewhere.

                                    Multiple Meanings of the Book of Life
        The Book of Life is used apparently in four different ways in Scripture. (1) Book of earthly citizenship: it
may refer to citizenship on earth (secular usage). (2) Book of earthly life: it may refer to life on earth (Ex 32:32-33;
Ps 69:28). (3) Book of millennial life: it may refer to life in the millennial Jerusalem (Is 4:3-4; cf. Rev 3:12);
Heb 12:23. (4) Book of heavenly life: it may refer to life in heaven (Dan 12:1-2; Lk 10:20; Phil 3:20; 4:3; Rev 3:5;
13:8; 17:8; 20:12-15; 21:27).
        The Book of Life is a record of citizenship in an earthly city or nation, or in the millennial city of Jerusalem
or heaven. Evidently, the Book of Life was used in the secular world to denote citizenship. One’s name could be
blotted out of this book of birth, and one could lose one’s citizenship. It was also used in the OT as a metaphor to
denote those who had physical life, and of one’s name being erased upon death. This metaphor was later used in
the OT for those whose names are recorded as citizens of the millennial Jerusalem. Finally, it was used to describe
those who possess eternal life and thus have citizenship in heaven.
        There were similarities and differences in the four types of usage. It would also seem that citizenship in the
millennial Jerusalem was a reward. All believers have their name in the Book of Life in the fourth sense, but only
overcomers have it recorded in the third sense. Concerning Rev 21:27, it is possible to take it in the fourth sense
with a third sense result: “And nothing unclean and no one who practices abomination and lying, shall ever come
into it [the city], but only those whose names are written in the Lamb’s book of life.” As noted above, only ≠ all.
The fact that only those who are citizens of heaven will be allowed into the New Jerusalem does not mean that all
citizens of heaven will be allowed into it. Citizenship in heaven is only one of the requirements. Yet it is the

  See Illustration 197. The Assumed All, 577.
