   Speaking less theoretically, the soteric-mistholic misthopology in Rev 21:7-8,27 and 22:14-15 applies via the principle of
correlativity to subcomers so that they are understood as also being excluded misthologically.
Page 532                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
requirement which excludes the lost. That it excludes all the lost does not mean that it includes all the saved,
however. That only the saved enter does not mean that all the saved can enter.

                                                 Special Entrance
       That overcomers will have a special entrance by the gates into the city in Rev 22:14 does not indicate that
subcomers will have a common entrance. The New Earth will be populated by overcomers, subcomers, and general
inhabitants of the New Earth. The New Earth is not ethereal. It is not a Non-Earth. These general inhabitants will
procreate, and they and their descendants will have the general entrance into the New Jerusalem. Subcomers will
have no entrance. In contrast to the general population who inhabit the New Earth, overcomers will have an
entrance that denotes their honor as those who inherit the New Earth (cf. Mt 5:3). To summarize in simplified
terms, Rev 22:14 describes overcomers as inside the New Jerusalem; Rev 22:15 describes noncomers as outside
the eternal kingdom; and Rev 22:19 describes subcomers as outside the New Jerusalem—and such will be the
eternal state of affairs. A correlation may be seen to exist between the noncomers and subcomers being outside.
       The naive assumption that those outside the city in Rev 22:15 must be identified with those in the outer
darkness, and consequently as the lost, is groundless. The concession is made herein that those who are outside in
Rev 22:15 are lost. However, the fact that this particular group of outsiders is lost does not prove that all outside
inhabitants are lost. According to Rev 21:23-27, multiple groups will be outside the city. The surrounding nations
will walk by the city’s light, and the kings of those nations will bring the tribute from those nations in order to
have a kingly entrance into the city through its gates (see 21:26; Hodgian MT). The translation, “Outside are the
dogs,” might give the false impression that all those outside in 22:15 are dogs. This understanding is objectionable
on the basis of the broader context, in which it is apparent that regenerate kings and nations are outside as well.
Granted, the translations which supply the word outside (exo) first in their rendition accurately convey the Greek
word order and the potential emphasis, but such translations may falsely convey the additional impression that the
emphasis is stressed to the point of exclusion. Even the Discovery Bible rates this order as having minor rather than
major emphasis.974 It would perhaps be better to translate the phrase as, “The dogs are outside.” They are outside;
they are excluded, but this does not mean that all those who are outside are excluded. The kings come into the city
from the outside. Inhabitants of the nations presumably enter from outside as well; although, they may not have the
royal welcome to which the kings are entitled. Those in the outer darkness may indeed have accessibility to the
nations and even dwell in the various nations, but they will not have access to the capital city itself. Indeed,
correlatively speaking, John probably intends for us to perceive that those unfaithful servants in the darkness
outside the wedding feast have something in common with the dogs outside the city. Characteristically black sheep
are correlatively outside with the categorically black dogs.*
                                                  Illustration 173. Outside the City




       The outer darkness is best conceived of as a metaphorical description of the eternal unrest and punishment
that subcomers experience by being excluded from (1) the land of Canaan—the Heavenly Jerusalem—during the
millennium, (2) the New Jerusalem for eternity, and (3) the rule of the millennial and eternal kingdom. The form
and location of the outer darkness may change, but just as Jerusalem will be eternal in one form or location

*
    See Illustration 337. Dogs and Sheep Outside the City, 914.
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                              Page 533
or another, so the exclusion from the New Jerusalem will be eternal also. The black darkness of the outer
darkness is eternal. it is tempting to agree with Chitwood and Whipple that Jude 1:13 describes the outer
darkness.975 In that case, I would argue that these regenerate apostates are “wandering stars for whom the black
darkness has been reserved forever” and thus would claim direct support for my conclusion that the outer darkness
is eternal. But the context suggests a correlation instead, and thus indirectly supports my thesis.*

Jude 1:13
        There are sound reasons for considering these particular apostates described by Peter and (thus by Jude) as
destined for the “blackness of darkness” (2Pet 2:17; Jude 1:13) as unregenerate.† The darkness in Jude 1:13 is
literal and soteriological. In contrast, the Matthean outer darkness is metaphorical and misthological. My
conclusion that the outer darkness is eternal is not based on an appeal to Jude 1:13. In similar fashion, it should be
concluded that when the dogs are described outside the city (Rev 22:15), they are to be understood as being in hell,
completely outside the kingdom. This group was, likewise, described in Rev 21:27 as not being able to enter it
because of their eschatological and eternal status as sinners with the result that they burn in hell (Rev 21:8). This
exclusion is soteriological rather than misthological, as denoted by the implication that their names are not in the
Book of Life in this earlier reference. Unlike subcomers, who are excluded because of their past sins in their
temporal state, this lost group is excluded because of their present sins in their eternal state. The lost sinners will
remain sinners throughout eternity and be classified as such.

Daniel 12:1-3
        Although it was conceded, in concord with Wilkin’s position, that Jude 1:13 does not refer to the eternal
state, it is quite interesting that Wilkin’s position on Dan 12:2 is also quite in harmony with my conclusion that the
misthological reality depicted by the outer darkness is eternal.
                1
                 Now at that time [“the end of time,”11:40, just before the end of the tribulation] Michael, the
          great prince who stands guard over the sons of your people [the Jews], will arise. And there will be a
          time of distress such as never occurred since there was a nation until that time; and at that time your
          people [the Jews], everyone who is found written in the book [of life], will be rescued. 2 And many
          of those who sleep in the dust of the ground will awake, some to everlasting life, but others to
          disgrace and everlasting shame. 3 And those who have insight will shine brightly like the brightness
          of the expanse of heaven, and those who instruct the many in righteousness, will shine like the stars
          forever and ever. (Dan 12:1-3; TM)

        Simple Soteriology
        There are three basic options for interpreting this Danielic passage. The non-dispensationalist would say that
it refers to the general resurrection of believers and unbelievers at the end of time to stand before the Great White
Throne Judgment of Rev 20:11-15. Thus, the text is simply dealing with a soteriological judgment. My preference
for a dispensational framework that would see distinct resurrections has been presented already in the first part of
the present work. Nevertheless, my discussion here will reinforce that position taken earlier. Postmillennialists and
amillennialists both criticize premillennialism as being a one-text eschatology. Their joint contention is that
premillennialism only has one text, Rev 20:4-6, which explicitly teaches two distinct resurrections at two different
times. I would suggest that the present Danielic text implicitly substantiates the premillennial position as well.

       Telescopic Soteriology
       The dispensationalist typically would respond to the general resurrection theory in this Danielic passage by
saying that this resurrection of believers together with unbelievers is simply a telescopic portrayal in which the
resurrection of the believers at the beginning of the millennium is lumped together with that of the unbelievers at
the end of the millennium. It is a summary statement that both groups will be raised after the tribulation. It does not
establish that both are raised at the same time. I have no quarrel with telescopic eschatology, of course, and indeed
use the telescopic argument myself in various contexts. However, this particular text does not require a
soteriological interpretation but rather points to a third alternative. Consequently, this passage does not disprove
the premillennial position, it actually strengthens it.
*
    For plausible correlation of these soteriological passages with misthological truths, see Theory of Correlativity, 911.
†
    See 2Pet 2:18-22, 854.
Page 534                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
     Simple Misthology
     The dispensational interpretation that Wilkin prefers is to see this text as describing a misthological
judgment dealing exclusively with believers before the millennium.

            Note that “many” will awake. Why doesn’t it say “all”? The reason is that Daniel is thinking of
       the resurrection of the righteous before the Millennium. Unbelievers will be resurrected after the
       Millennium (Rev 20:13).
            Thus Daniel speaks of two types of resurrection that OT believers will experience. Some will be
       resurrected to “everlasting life,” which is a reference to abundant eternal life. We find the same
       concept in Matt 19:29, Gal 6:8, and Heb 11:36. Whenever eternal life is spoken of as a possible
       future experience, the reward of abundant eternal life is in view. Even in the OT.
            But some believers will experience shame when resurrected. Of course this is a New Testament
       teaching as well: “Little children, abide in Him, that when He appears, we may have confidence and
       not be ashamed before Him at His coming” (1 John 2:28). See also Mark 8:38.
            Now admittedly Daniel does speak of “everlasting contempt” which is literally “everlasting
       abhorrence.” But this is parallel to shame. It simply means that forever this person will live with the
       consequences of their unwise life. “Those who are wise shall shine like the brightness of the
       firmament…forever and ever” (Dan 12:3). The implication is that those who are unwise shall not
       “shine” forever in their service for Christ.976

        In other words, Daniel says that many rather than all “of those who sleep” will be raised because he is not
talking about a general resurrection of all people (many ≠ all). Some of the dead (i.e., the unsaved dead) will not be
raised until the end of the millennium a thousand years later. Peterson acknowledges that many rather than all is the
most common meaning of this word and yet seeks to maintain the traditional interpretation by asserting that God
will only raise some—friends and foes—basically martyrs and those who martyr them.977 While Peterson’s
affirmation that this is only a resurrection of part rather than the whole is appreciated, it is unlikely that God will
only raise part of the unbelievers at this time. The resurrection of the lost is better understood as occurring at the
end of the millennium. God will not raise any of the lost before the millennium. There is no need to raise the lost
before the millennium since they will not have any entrance into the millennial kingdom. It is much more natural to
suppose that the part (i.e., the many) God will raise at this time described by Daniel will be those who are
believers. All believers will need to be raised before the millennium for their participation in the millennial
kingdom. There is no need to raise unbelievers at this time. As already demonstrated in the Johannine aside in
Rev 20:4-5, the martyrs are raised at the beginning of the millennium, but “the rest of the dead were not resurrected
until after the millennium” (TM).
        Secondly, those raised in Dan 12:2 appear to be those who have their names written in the Book of Life in
verse 1. Those Jews living at the end of the tribulation who have their name in the Book of Life will be rescued,
while those Jews who are dead at the end of the tribulation who have their name in the Book of Life will be raised.
Thus, those Jews who have their names written in the Book of Life are either rescued or raised at this time. This is
a resurrection of only those who, at the end of the tribulation, have their names in the Book of Life.
        Thirdly, those being raised are described as those who sleep. This imagery is certainly capable of describing
dead believers (cp. Is 26:19). And although the NT uses a different word for sleep in reference to NT believers of
the church age being asleep in Christ (in order to limit that reference to believers, cf. 1Thess 4:16), there seems to
be no insurmountable reason for not limiting those asleep in the ground to believers—in this particular context.
The context, rather than the phrase itself, supplies the limitation. In other words, the context would limit those who
sleep in the ground (with their names in the Book of Life who are resurrected at this time) to be understood as
believers at the conclusion of the tribulational period.
        Fourthly, the LXX word for shame (aischune) is the same word that Jesus uses concerning believers
experiencing shame at His judgment (Rev 3:18). And, as Wilkin points out, the verbal form (aischuno) is used of
believers being ashamed when the Lord returns in 1Jn 2:28, and a compound of it is used of their being put to
shame in Mk 8:38. As for disgrace (oneidismos), Paul says believers may fall into disgrace (1Tim 3:7).
        Overall, there is no compelling reason to believe that the second part of Dan 12:2 is not describing believers.
Instead, there are significant eschatological and misthological grounds for concluding that those resurrected to
everlasting shame are believers. Contextual considerations lean in favor of this conclusion as well. Therefore, it is
best to conclude that the rewards being described in this verse are for faithful and unfaithful believers. The
negative rewards are just as permanent as the positive rewards. The shame for the unfaithful believer will be just as
eternal as the shine for the faithful believer. In comparison, the shameful believers will have a darkened
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                               Page 535
misthological experience throughout eternity future. Likewise, David warns, “As for you, my son Solomon, know
the God of your father, and serve Him with a whole heart and a willing mind; for the Lord searches all hearts, and
understands every intent of the thoughts. If you seek Him, He will let you find Him; but if you forsake Him, He
will reject you forever” (1Chron 28:9). King Solomon will be rejected permanently from being king in the
millennial and eternal kingdom because he forsook the Lord.
                                       Illustration 174. Danielic Misthological Resurrection




       The premillennial judgment being described in Dan 12:1-3, in which only some are raised, is part of a
complex of judgments taking place at the time of the Sheep and Goats Judgment described in Mt 25:31-46.* The
Danielic aspect is limited to what happens to (Jewish) believers at this judgment. This is a premillennial
resurrection of believers so that they can be judged to determine what their status will be in the millennial
kingdom. This text counters the postmillennial and amillennial claim that there is only one resurrection—a general
resurrection of the lost and saved. Not so. This is a resurrection of only some of those who are dead; evidently the
resurrection of the rest is to follow later, just as John clarifies: “The rest of the dead did not come to life until the
thousand years were completed” (Rev 20:5). This Danielic counterpart also refutes those who wish to point at the
soteriological division between good sheep and bad goats in the Matthean passage as proving that there are no bad
sheep at this judgment. Whereas Matthew is dealing with all the [living] nations at this judgment (Mt 25:32),
Daniel is focusing on the believers at this judgment, specifically Jewish believers. A Jewish Bema is in view. The
two accounts coalesce to complement one another and show that there will be black sheep being judged at this
time. The premillennial misthological interpretation should thus be accepted. However, in subsequent discussion, a
modification will be appended in which the more precise preference will be for a telescopic misthological
understanding over a simple misthological view.†

Permanent, not Purgatory
       The purpose of the future punishment is for present maturity. God has told us that this Bema punishment for
believers will be severe and permanent in order to give us sufficient motivation to become mature and merciful
now. Our works of mercy must be done now. The outer darkness is not purgatory. It does not purify us, sanctify us,
or cause us to mature. This purity, practical sanctification, and maturity must be obtained now in the present before
death in order to be kings in eternity.
       Purgatory is a temporary punishment that allegedly purifies believers so that they can enter the kingdom.
With Nee, I must denounce the doctrine of purgatory.978 But Nee and Lee’s perception of the outer darkness
appears to be the same thing as purgatory in these three essential elements. In contrast, I do not conceive the outer
darkness as being temporary, purifying, or qualifying for anything. The outer darkness is permanent. Its purpose is
to purify us before our death, not after our death. It does not qualify us for entrance into the kingdom or kingship

*
    See Illustration 141. Sequence of Separation Complex, 414.
†
    Daniel telescopically sees the millennial and eternal misthological results simultaneously pictured together. See Daniel 12:2, 812.
Page 536                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
after we are cast into it. The outer darkness has nothing to do with entrance into the kingdom and completely
disqualifies us from ever inheriting that kingdom or kingship. That tears are wiped away at the conclusion of the
millennium does not prove that rewards or lack thereof cease at that time as well.

Casting Crowns
       Although the assumption that no tears exist in heaven is probably the basis for the most common objection
to the importance of eternal rewards, the close second would be that believers do not keep the crowns. We cast
them before the throne. So some think: “What difference does it make if we get a get a crown since we are just
going to throw it away anyway?” This perception that rewards do not really matter throws the analogy of faith into
reverse and attempts to deny the clear teaching of Scripture on the basis of an ambiguous verse in Rev 4:10. In
response to such an absurd denial of the doctrine of rewards, one should step back and ask, “Do we truly ever lose
anything that we give to Jesus? Is not the consistent teaching of Scripture that anything we give to Jesus we will
save and receive back a hundred fold?” Second, does it really make sense for Jesus to exhort us to keep our crowns
in Rev 3:11 only to tell us in the next chapter that we will not keep them? Might there not be a more probable
interpretation?
       Moreover, the identification of the twenty-four elders is debatable; even much less certain is the significance
of their action. Assuming that they do represent rewarded believers, as seems probable,* then various
interpretations of their action are compatible with the eternal nature of our reward. Their casting their crowns could
be a picture of the Spirit-filled life and the Spirit’s enablement. What we accomplish in this life and the rewards we
correspondingly obtain are attributed to His enablement and pictured as such by our casting our crowns before
Jesus’ feet. What is pictured is our acknowledgement that we have earned our eternal rewards by His enablement.
Such a position is not incompatible with the eternal nature of our rewards. Still, a better interpretation is suggested
by historical precedence and Rev 11:16. Lang’s historical illustration is outstanding and even weakens his own
assessment that the elders are angels:

          In A.D. 63 Tiridates, king of Armenia...agreed to renounce his crown to the [Roman] emperor Nero,
          on the understanding that he should receive it back as the emperor’s feudatory….Having thus
          divested himself of regal power and rank, it remained for Tiridates to undertake a journey to Rome, in
          order to receive from the hand of the emperor the crown of Armenia, together with all the rights and
          securities the Roman people and Senate could confer.979
                                         Illustration 175. The Boomerang Crown




       Tiridates renounced his crown in order to receive it back again as the crown of Armenia. In other words, he
gave up his own crown in order to receive it back from the hand of the emperor. The action in Rev 4:10 could be a
picture of this type of event or of the similar spiritual truth that the person who saves his life will lose it, and he
who losses his life for Jesus’ sake will save it (Mk 8:35). If you do not give it to Jesus, you will find it taken from
you (Mt 25:28). If you give it to Jesus, you will find it given back to you (Mk 10:29-30).

*
    See Twenty-four Elders, 36.
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                                Page 537
Retaining Thrones
        In any case, Rev 11:16 says that the elders still have their thrones even after casting their crowns before the
emperor’s thrown in Rev 4:10. The twenty-four elders constantly leave their seats on their respective thrones to fall
in worship before the emperor’s throne (Rev 4:4,10; 5:8; 11:16; 19:4). They obviously return to their own thrones
after each occasion, or they would not be able to fall down before Him on the next occasion. Since falling down
before Him and worshiping Him are not onetime events, it may be reasonably inferred that the same is true of
casting their crowns before Him. In any event, they do not lose their thrones nor their ruling power as indicated by
their continuing to have thrones. They do not cast their thrones at His feet! They still have those thrones in ch. 11,
after casting their crowns in ch. 4. Submitting themselves, their thrones, and their crowns to Him in worship does
not result in the loss of themselves, their thrones, or their crowns.
        They probably cast their crowns before His feet on special occasions, which of course means they do not
lose their crowns. As a matter of fact, the Greek text suggests this very possibility. They cast their crowns when
(4:9) the living creatures give glory. According to BDAG, the word translated as when (hotan) could just as well be
translated as whenever, as often as, every time that to signify repeated action. In fact this lexicon says that it is used
to indicate repeated action “in many instances.” The NAS certainly renders hotan as whenever in multiple
instances: Mt 6:16; 10:23; Mk 3:11; 11:19,25; 14:7; Jn 7:27; 8:44; 16:21; 2Cor 10:6. BDAG (1.b.a) considers
Rev 4:9 itself to be one of these instances. Several translations likewise render 4:9 as whenever (NKJ; NAB; NLT)
or every time (NJB). In conjunction with the latter translation and in accordance with the BDAG rendition, it is best
to take it as denoting repeated action:
          9
           And every time the living creatures give glory and honor and thanks to Him who sits on the throne,
          to Him who lives forever and ever, 10the twenty-four elders will fall down before Him who sits on the
          throne, and will worship Him who lives forever and ever, and will cast their crowns before the
          throne. (Rev 4:9-10; TM)

       A repeated action is my preferred understanding of the text. On the other hand, my position is not dependent
upon the action being repeated. The submission and recognition that vassal kings (or servant kings) pay to a
suzerain (or great king) in this manner need not be done repeatedly. A similar comparison can be made concerning
Christ. His onetime deliverance of the kingdom up to the Father in 1Cor 15:24-25 does not demonstrate that He
will cease to rule or lose the kingdom! When Christ hands the kingdom over to the Father, this does not mean that
Christ will cease to rule. It means that the nature of that rule changes to a co-rulership with His Father (Rev 22:1).
Casting our crowns before Him may likewise denote the co-rulership we will share with Him (Rev 3:21). Other
passages of Scripture show that in giving up the kingdom, the Lord does not lose it. The Lord did not cease to be
Lord! For example, Rev 22:3 shows that the Lamb will still be on the throne in the eternal state. The delivering
over of His rule to the Father does not mean that His rule will cease but that it will change its character.980
Correspondingly, the casting of our crowns before the throne does not mean that we lose the crowns. We no more
lose our crowns or rulership than Jesus loses His throne or His Lordship! Handing over does not mean giving up. It
means to turn over to Him in order to share with Him. Jesus rules forever (Rev 5:13), and so do we (Dan 7:18;
12:3). Otherwise, He would cease to be King of kings and Lord of lords (Rev 17:14; 19:16). For Him to remain
Sovereign King over vassal kings, the vassal kings must continue to function as kings. The casting of the elders’
crowns before Jesus in Rev 4:10 cannot denote abandoning ruling servitude to Jesus since they sing about
experiencing a future rule over the earth in Rev 5:10.* Rulership and rewards are eternal, not merely millennial.
Overcomers rule forever (Rev 22:5; cp. 2Chron 13:5).

Finest Hour
       A misthologist whom I hold in very high regard frequently exhorts believers not to miss out on millennial
rulership because this would be their “finest hour.” Respectively, I disagree. When we have been in heaven for a
billion years, we will not be making reminiscing remarks about the millennial kingdom as the good old days. I
cringe at the thought of picturing an overcomer remarking with a sigh, “I remember in the good old days when
being the Bride of Christ really meant something special, but nowadays everybody is treated alike.” To the
contrary, the best will always be yet to come if you are an overcomer. The millennial kingdom might be likened to
a honeymoon, but eternal matrimony cannot be likened to monotony. If you are an overcomer, your finest hour


*
    See Illustration 24. Textual Options for Rev 5:8-10, 54.
Page 538                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
always lies in the future. John’s stress on the thousand years in Rev 20 is not his way of saying that the honeymoon
is over when he reaches the eternal state in Rev 21-22. Rather, the eternal state is the misthological finale.
       As Baughman recognizes, “The general teaching of Scripture is that the kingdom is eternal, that it lasts
forever. It is not until chapter 20 of Revelation that the thousand-year interval is marked off. Important events
happen at that time, but they are not the end of the kingdom.” “Revelation 20:6 does not mean that tribulation
saints will only reign a thousand years, but that they will reign with Him during this first thousand years”
(emphasis his). He adopts the KJV translation of zao as lived in this verse and notes that the same tense is used of
reigned so that they lived and reigned would be understood as being simultaneous. They no more cease reigning at
the end of the thousand years than they cease living. An ingressive aorist would make sense, they began living and
reigning. The notion of either action ceasing is foreign to the thought of the verse. Baughman notes that
premillennialists usually “overemphasize the millennium” and supplies corrective charts of kingdom emphasis.981
                                        Illustration 176. Kingdom Emphasis




       Following Baughman’s example, I would note that John’s purpose is not to impose a thousand year
limitation on the OT anticipation of an eternal kingdom. Although a transition occurs, a termination does not. The
kingdom continues to get bigger and better for the overcomer. As time progresses the quality of life that
overcomers experience increases. Sadly, many kingdom teachers have diminished the importance of not missing
out on kingdom rulership by mistakenly limiting this rulership to a thousand years—a mere drop in the
eschatological bucket. Christ has some very negative things to say about Christians who lose their first love for
Him. Surely, if we keep our first love for Him, we can be certain that He will not lose His first love for us! He will
not love His Wife less than His Bride. The expressions of His love for her will continue to expand as His kingdom
continues to increase.

                                                   Conclusion
        The purpose of this chapter was to answer the question, “When are the tears in Rev 21:4 wiped away?” As a
preliminary response, the counter question was asked, “Where are the tears wiped away?” Assuming that they are
wiped away in heaven, there must be tears in heaven. Therefore, it would be illogical to use this verse as proof that
those who weep in the outer darkness could not be in heaven. Secondarily, it was noted that those tears are not
wiped away until the end of the millennium. Thus, the objection that the outer darkness cannot depict heavenly
reality is refuted by the fact that the passage in question would allow for 1000 years of weeping.
        Appreciatively, ultraistic interpreters are more consistent in their recognition that the tears are not wiped
away until the end of the millennium. Unfortunately, some ultraists attempt to use this occasion to argue for the
cessation of rewards. In the present writer’s mind, the far most serious objection to this form of ultraism is that it
limits Marrowism to one millennium. After 1000 years, the distinction between a reward and gift evaporates in this
form of ultraism. In response, the eternal nature of rewards was affirmed by an overview of the adjective for
eternal (aionios). Attempts to evade the eternality of the misthological reality were lexically inconsistent and
verbally inadequate. The adjectival form appears lexically restricted in the NT to a subset of the semantic range of
its noun so that it only refers to things that are eternal. The ultraistic appeal to the present tense of the verb as
Chapter 23. Millennial Tears and Eternal Rewards                                                               Page 539
denoting linear faith is based on a popular but refutable notion that linear faith is required by an articular present
participle.
        The everlasting misthological exclusion pictured by the outer darkness is also confirmed by the strong
emphatic Greek negation. Such believers will never ever enter God’s rest. Typology concerning Esau from the
book of Hebrews further substantiates this misthological understanding of the significance of rest in the epistle as
well so that both Esau and the rest are understood to portray the permanence of this exclusion and thus
substantiating the definition of the outer darkness made herein. The misthological reality introduced by the
millennium will be carried over into and projected infinitely throughout eternity future. Since the positive rewards
are imperishable and unfading, the parallel impoverishment resulting from not having these rewards must last just
as long. Unfaithful believers will not be rewarded with these possessions at the end of the millennium, and faithful
believers will not be stripped of their rewards at that time. Consequently, the distinction within heaven between
have’s and the have-not’s must remain throughout the never-ending ages. The city and certain privileges pertaining
to it are to be limited to overcomers, not only in the millennial age, but also in the eternal state.982
        Those believers who are stripped of their talents and thrown into the outer darkness will have an
impoverished experience throughout eternity. Yet even some misthologists have fallen into the fallacy of thinking
that all believers within heaven will have their cup of happiness filled to capacity, just that unfaithful believers will
have a smaller cup. Let such misthologists visit the unfaithful believer who has been cast into the debtor’s prison
for all eternity and ask him if his cup is full! If the felicity of such believers is filled to capacity, as is commonly
supposed, then why are they weeping and gnashing their teeth? The cup fallacy has no place in kingdom
misthology.
        In emphatic conclusion, the outer darkness may be defined as the parabolic representation of the
didactical reality that unfaithful believers will undergo in the permanent punitory (rather than preparatory
or purgatorial) spatial experience of being in the millennial and eternal kingdom but never ever being
allowed to enter the capital city, or the land of Canaan throughout eternity future, with the result that those
submitted to this banishment will never ever be allowed to exercise rulership (or participate in any other
misthological functions, roles, or privileges pertaining thereto) over any part, sphere, or aspect of the
millennial or eternal kingdom during the millennial age or for any part of eternity future, forever.
Page 540   The Outer Darkness
                                           Chapter 24.
                                      Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?
                                                  Introduction
        In preparation for the treatment of tears in Rev 21:4, Chapter 21 was dedicated to a discussion of litotes and
the most widely-recognized litotes in Revelation, with the understanding that the applicability of these positive
litotes to believers in Revelation is limited to overcomers. Then Chapter 22 was devoted to defending the
presupposition that overcomers do not refer to all believers. Subsequently, Chapter 23 responded to the question of
when the tears will be wiped away. That the tears in Rev 21:4 are not wiped away until the end of the millennium
was pointed out. More notably, the wiping away of the tears in 7:17 prior to the millennium applies only to
overcomers. Consequently, the wiping away of tears cannot mean the wiping away of rewards or the wiping away
of distinctions between subcomers and overcomers. The rewards are eternal. But if the rewards and corresponding
loss of rewards are eternal, then the question that naturally comes to mind is, “Why are the tears not eternal?”
Perhaps, the possibility that the tears might be eternal should be considered.
        Instead of trying to question the undeniable eternal nature of rewards, Chitwood should have focused on the
astute observation he made concerning the earlier reference in Revelation to the wiping away of tears: “The
reference to all tears being wiped away prior to the millennium in Rev. 7:17 is only for a select group of
individuals realizing an inheritance in the kingdom.”983 The most important question is not as everyone assumes,
“When are the tears wiped away?” The real point of inquiry is, “Whose tears are wiped away?”
        The first question has been answered in the previous chapter, enabling the second question now to be
considered more fully. Chitwood’s insight into Rev 7:17, provided previously in a lengthy block quote, is
impressive.* The previous promise of wiping away the tears in Rev 7:17 is promised only to faithful believers
inheriting the kingdom. Chitwood’s acknowledgment of this fact should have alerted him to the possibility that the
same may be true in Rev 21:4. Instead, he joins in the universal assumption that this latter promise of wiping away
tears applies to all believers.
        In Keathley’s rejection of the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness, he likewise appeals to this
common sentiment:

               Another question is the meaning of the banquet imagery. Banquet imagery almost always refers
         to the kingdom / heaven (cf. Isa 62:4-5, Jer 2:2, 31:2, Eze 16:32 and Hos 2:2, Isa 25:6; 65:8-16 and
         Ps 22:26-29). Especially compare Isaiah 25:6-9 where it talks about God preparing a lavish banquet
         for all peoples and “wiping tears away from all faces.”…
               …Moreover, they contradict the very nature of the joy we are to experience in heaven. In fact,
         how do we reconcile the fact that God will “wipe away every tear” (Rev 21:4; Isa 25:6) with the idea
         that there will be “weeping and gnashing of teeth” in heaven.984

       Keathley’s challenge that misthologists reconcile the wiping with the weeping is justified. On the basis of
what has been seen so far, the reader might respond that those in the outer darkness weep for the thousand years of
the millennium and then have their tears wiped away. Indeed, some misthological interpreters of the outer darkness
believe this is the case. On the other hand, this explanation leaves one puzzled as to how the tears can be wiped
away when the loss of rewards that prompted the tears is not wiped away. Further, why wait till the end of the
millennium to wipe them away? What is it about the end of the millennium that removes this misthological grief,
since the end of the millennium does not end the other negative misthological consequences? The present state of
affairs in the misthological camp has left such questions largely unanswered. The time has come that they be
addressed.

                                                      Litotes
       This following advanced section on selected eschatological litotes in Revelation is intended to move the
Marrowistic discussion of Johannine litotes to an acknowledgment that the wiping away of tears in Rev 21:4
likewise must be understood from the context as a litotes promised only to overcomers. The context is crucial.

                1
                  And I saw a new heaven and a new earth; for the first heaven and the first earth passed away,
          and there is no longer any sea. 2 And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of
          heaven from God, made ready as a bride adorned for her husband. 3 And I heard a loud voice from the
          throne, saying, “Behold, the tabernacle of God is among men, and He shall dwell among them, and
          they shall be His people, and God Himself shall be among them, 4 and He shall wipe away every

          brimstone, which is the second death.” (Rev 21:1-8)

Rev 21:1—Sequence
        The NAS has changed the and (kai) that begins the passage in verse 1 to a then in its newer edition. The
newer translation is better since it brings out the sequence of events. This passage in ch. 21 is describing what
happens after the Great White Throne Judgment in ch. 20, which in turn occurs at the conclusion of the millennial
age. The events in ch. 21 happen next in sequence of time and refer to the eternal state. The progression of events
is: millennium, followed by Great White Throne in ch. 20, then the revelation of the new heaven, New Earth, and
New Jerusalem in ch. 21.

Rev 21:2—City
         After describing the new heaven and New Earth, John describes the city (i.e., the New Jerusalem) as
Christ’s Bride. The verse is presenting two reward concepts—the city and the Bride—merged together into one
bridal city.* The Groom will wipe away the tears of His Bride (i.e., the faithful elect) who dwells in the city. This
identification of the Bride as being composed of only faithful believers is not very popular, but, as will be shown in
the next chapter, consistency requires that the Bride be limited to those believers who have been faithful. For now,
however, attention may be called to the misthological nature of the city, which has been pointed out repeatedly,
particularly in the previous chapter.
        One of the arguments advanced by those who reject the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness is
that all believers will have access to the city. Therefore, in their minds the outer darkness cannot depict exclusion
from the city. Although those in the misthological camp do not necessarily equate the outer darkness with
exclusion from the city, misthological consistency would lead to this as the most plausible conclusion.† Indeed, the
misthopology of the OT lays the foundation for the misthology of the NT regarding the outer darkness. The NT
doctrine of the outer darkness is a picturesque expression of the misthopological exclusion already anticipated in
the OT, particularly in Psalms and Isaiah.

Jerusalem is a satellite city located in space, perhaps to the far north of this planet. During the millennium, this
satellite city will come to this planet and be stationed in orbit above the Earthly Jerusalem.* At the conclusion of
the millennium, some dispensationalists believe that the Heavenly Jerusalem will descend to the New Earth and

       While I was preaching through this material, I developed three-dimensional representations to share with the
congregation. Printing it on paper has the advantage of being easier to cut and fold, easy enough in fact for the
children of the church to undertake. It also has the advantage of being very visible if you wish to add labels. The
above cutout has been drawn to scale to use in conjunction with a basketball to represent the size of the earth. In
such comparisons, a tennis ball would correspond to the size of the moon. So one could simply pass out copies of
the above illustration to children of the church, and they could make their own scaled models that could be
compared to their basketballs and tennis balls at home.

       I also printed these scaled models on transparencies since the city is described by John as looking like
crystal-clear jasper (Rev 21:11). Evidently, it has a golden hue to it since John goes on to add: “And the city was
pure gold, like clear glass” (Rev 21:18).

       Drawing this city to scale is not difficult, particularly on a computer. Yet one might accomplish the same

                                          Illustration 181. Zone of Darkness




        I drew the city to scale for my sons’ globe and shined a flashlight on it. Since day and night will continue for
the rest of the planet, it is easy to picture Antarctica as being a literal Zone of Darkness in comparison. This is the
manner in which Carmical describes the outer darkness in his fictional account.* His account is probably far more
literally accurate than many imagine. Although I would not restrict the outer darkness to this zone, the worst
offenders may very well be confined literally to the darkest part of the globe at Antarctica.

    See Spatial and Internal, 569.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                       Page 547
       I could only smile when my youngest son, Jonathan, asked how big this heavenly city would be in
comparison to New York City. Comparing its base to the surface area of the entire United States would be more
appropriate. This scaled model will help children better visualize the size of the city. The speculation that the New
Earth will be significantly enlarged to accommodate such a large city on its surface should probably be rejected.
An enlargement of the planetary sphere would in turn bring an increase in the gravitational field. This would be no
problem for those in glorified bodies, but those who comprise the nations, and who are thus in physical bodies,
would be burdened by the increased gravity. (Certainly the planet would stay within inhabitable range.) The change
in the planetary surface will accommodate the New Jerusalem without any substantial change in the planetary size.
                                            Illustration 183. Golden City




        The New Earth will have no sea (Rev 21:1), so there is a change in the planetary surface that will allow the
city to descend to the projected location without resting on any water. So the above picture would be that of the
satellite city during the millennium. For this picture, I printed the city on a transparency with a golden hue.
Jonathan is holding it above the earth. However, the distance which the city will be above the earth is speculative.
Stationary satellites, such as those used for communications, broadcast, and weather, are about 22,000 miles above
the earth, which is less than the circumference of the earth. Perhaps that would be an appropriate distance.
However, the city will presumably have a gravitational field, so the city may be further out in space, like the moon.
For comparison, the moon is also pictured by the tennis ball.
Page 548                                                                                                The Outer Darkness
                                            Illustration 184. City in Biosphere




        Apparently, the throne of God will be at the top of the city, from which the river of life proceeds and flows
down the side of the city to the New Earth (cf. Rev 22:1). The city is called Mount Zion in Scripture and will
resemble the shape of a large mountain with rivers of life flowing down its sloped sides. Since the low flying
satellites such as space shuttles and space stations fly at an altitude of only 100-300 miles, it is apparent that most
of the surface area of the city would project far into outer space and would be uninhabitable by creatures living in
natural bodies. Nevertheless, it appears that the entire surface area of the city is inhabitable after all (Is 65:25).
Given that the water is not frozen solid but flows down these slopes and that plants such as the tree of life grow on
these slopes, it must be deduced that the city is encapsulated in a biosphere which supports life. This would have to
be true of the city both in its satellite orbit and when it rests on the New Earth.

                                                           Part
        The first thing to be noted about the size of the city in relation to the planet is that the city is smaller than the
planet. Just as the Promised Land (i.e., the land of Canaan) did not cover the whole world, so the Promised City
does not engulf the New Earth when it comes down to rest on the New Earth and subsume the Promised Land. The
Promised Land will become the Promised City (or a dimple in the base of the city). There will be ample room for
the kings and nations outside the city. “And the nations will walk by its light, and the kings of the earth will bring
the glory and the honor of the nations into it” (Rev 21:24; MT; TM). There will be many cities in the millennial
kingdom, while the Heavenly Jerusalem is suspended above the earth (Lk 19:17-19). There will also be many cities
on the New Earth, even if the Heavenly City descends to the planetary surface after the millennial introduction.
The kings of the earth and the nations which dwell on the earth in the eternal state will live in those cities. The New
Jerusalem will be the capital city, not the only city. The New Jerusalem is part of heaven, not all of heaven. To be
excluded from the New Jerusalem and cast into the outer darkness need not mean any more than being spatially
restricted from entering the capital. Those in the outer darkness may find their dwelling places elsewhere on the
New Earth. Exclusion from the city is not to be equated simplistically with inclusion in hell.
        Alcorn has a page in his book defending a literal understanding of the size of the city and then devotes an
entire appendix to substantiating this point.987 Suffice it to say here that the emphasis in Rev 21:17 (upon the fact
that these are human as well as angelic measurements) makes it necessary to affirm the literalicity of the city and
its dimensions. Even if the numeric figures are symbolic figures, there is no reason to suppose that something that
is literal (such as a throne, wedding ring, 911, July 4th, Alamo, or Waterloo) cannot have a symbolic meaning as
well.
        The Lake of Fire could be pictured in the distance (in the bottom corner of the picture for example). At the
time of the Great White Throne Judgment, the earth and sea will yield their dead (Rev 20:13). Those who have
been released from their subterranean imprisonment will be resurrected and sentenced to torment in the
extraterrestrial imprisonment of the Lake of Fire. They are definitely outside the city as stated in Rev 22:15. They
might be pictured as being outside but looking in; that is, it is conceivable that those who suffer in the black flames
of hell may be able to see the brilliant light of the city from the distant planet. This need not necessarily mean that
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                             Page 549
the inhabitants of the New Earth will in turn be able to see those black flames in the distant sky. Stars are only
visible at night because of the light they emit. Black flames would make no such emission, especially if such
flames were at the center of an inescapable black hole (from which not even light can escape) or in a
hypersphereical dimension. Whatever the final nature of the case may prove to be, there is no reason to reject the
clear testimony of Scripture concerning the outer darkness on the basis of speculations that everyone outside the
city must be lost. This simply is not the case, as Revelation itself demonstrates.* Those excluded from the New
Jerusalem may be excluded from part of heaven without being excluded from all of heaven. The New Earth is an
inhabitable part of heaven to which those in the outer darkness may be consigned.

                                               Limited Accessibility
       Pertaining to the related texts displayed previously,† it may be surmised that access to the tree of life is
limited to overcomers (Rev 2:7), that is, to those who wash their robes in practical sanctification (Rev 22:12,14).
The tree of life is in the city (Rev 22:2). Subcomers will lose their inheritance rights to this tree and to the city
(Rev 22:19). Loss of these rewards would suggest loss of access to the city itself.‡ Accessibility to the very springs
themselves (from which the water of life originates within the city) appears to be limited to overcomers (Rev 7:17;
22:1-2). But the water of life itself (from these springs) may be experienced freely by those outside the city.

        Then he showed me a river of the water of life, clear as crystal, coming from the throne of God and of
        the Lamb. 2 In the middle of its street, the tree of life ran along on both sides of the river, bearing
        twelve kinds of fruit, yielding a different kind each month; and the leaves of the tree were for the
        healing of the nations. (Rev 22:1-2; TM)
                                                 Illustration 185. The Tree of Life




        Just as the leaves of the tree of life, which grow inside the city, may be shared with those who live in the
nations outside the city, so the water of life may be freely accessed outside the city. For the water flows down the
middle of the streets, through the twelve gates, to the nations outside of the city. Some suggest that the tree of life
is a forest of trees; others believe the river is in the middle of the tree; others think that the tree is in the middle of
the river; others picture the tree along the banks of the river (cp. Eze 47:12). The mental picture the present writer
has is that of a single tree taken from the Garden of Eden thousands of years ago and transplanted at the top of the
Heavenly Jerusalem. Evidently, Alcorn shares this perspective as well:

             The same physical tree of life that was in the Garden of Eden will one day be in the New
        Jerusalem on the New Earth (Revelation 22:2). Now it is (present tense) in the intermediate Heaven.
        Shouldn’t we assume it has the same physical properties it has in the Garden of Eden and will have in
        the New Jerusalem?...

He continues in more depth subsequently:

            The river flows down the city’s main street. Likely it has countless tributaries flowing
       throughout the rest of the city….

        This tree has now grown progressively for thousands of years. It has a massive root structure that sinks deep
into the rich soil along the banks of the river of the water of life, where the tree continues to grow and spread. It has
formed groves and parks, as well as lining the main roads. In addition to being on the outside slopes of the city
walls, the tree and the water of life probably pervade the inside of the city as well. The city would be a virtual
green house. If we can have trees in our malls and waterfalls in our hotels, just imagine the creative ingenuity that
might go into channeling the river of life and growing the tree of life inside a city lit by the glory of God. There
could easily be lakes inside that massive city and waterfalls greater than Niagara.
        Tatford suggests that the tree of life is “like an immense banyan tree, sending down fibers to become huge
trunks.”990 Yet, since the tree grows along the banks of the river, one might conceive of a root structure similar to
the bald cypress that grows at the edges of streams with exposed roots. The text inspires the imagination, and the
image pictured herein is that of a banyan tree with bald cypress characteristics—that is, a banyan tree with aquatic
roots rather than aerial roots. Its aquatic roots send up fibers to become huge trunks and thus spread along the
banks of the river, reproducing itself so that this single tree has now spread by the end of the millennial age (which
is the time period in which John sees it) to run along the entire bank of the river of the water of life. In such a case,
the fruit of the tree could be seedless since the tree is propagated by its roots rather than by seeds. Possibly, a single
massive tree interconnected by a single root structure that has spread along all banks of the river is envisioned.
                                 Illustration 186. The Tree of Life by the River of Life




       The river and tree both have one point of origin—the throne of God at the top of the city, which is 1,500
miles high. The river is longer than this length, deriving its additional duration from its own curvature as a river
plus the slope of the city walls (Rev 21:16). If Lenski is correct, the river flows through twelve streets and out of
the city through the twelve major gates.991 If the tree is limited to just the dual banks of one river, and the
additional length it would have from sloped walls and curvature is ignored, then the tree line would measure 1,500
x 2 = 3,000 miles for a single branch of this river. This figure must be multiplied times the number of streets
through which it flows so that the total is 36,000 miles of tree line when all main branches of the river are taken
into consideration. This minimum figure fails to include slope and curvature of the river.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                                   Page 551
       If the tree does, in fact, cover the slopes of the walls, with parks running along the tributaries, and has
numerous other outlets through the sloped city walls and grows inside the city (as is probable), then the figure for
the cavernous tree far exceeds the calculations above. Moreover, a tree that expansive in nature, and which drinks
from the water of life, could produce a tremendous amount of fruit. Its leaves are exported for the healing of the
nations outside the city (cp. Rev 22:2). These nations are composed of people who enter the eternal state in flesh
and blood bodies at the conclusion of the millennium and who then procreate subsequent generations of sinless
humanity in physical bodies. The population produced by this eternal procreation will still be subject to physical
needs.* Of course, to be outside the city does not necessarily mean to be inside hell.

                                                 Portion in the City
        Intimate association with the city is limited to overcomers since this promise by Jesus is limited to the
overcomer: “I will write upon him the name of My God, and the name of the city of My God, the new Jerusalem,
which comes down out of heaven from My God” (Rev 3:12). For these contextual reasons, one would tend to think
that portion or part (meros) in Rev 22:19 means the right to participate misthologically in: “If anyone takes away
from the words of the book of this prophecy, God will take away his right to participate misthologically in the tree
of life and the holy city” (Rev 22:19; CT; MT; TM). The city and tree of 22:14 are to be included in the reward of
22:12. The servants who partake of these benefits in the manner described in the passage are faithful, rewarded
servants. Subcomers will be excluded. The nations will be included to a limited extent. They will be able to enter
the city and use the leaves of the tree.† Yet the right to inhabit the city and eat the fruit of the tree would be limited
to overcomers.

                                                   City of Rest
       Previously, it was pointed out that Dillow acknowledges that the city of Zion is part of God’s eternal rest.‡
“For the Lord has chosen Zion; He has desired it for His habitation. This is My resting place forever; here I will
dwell” (Ps 132:13-14). The parallel to Rev 21:3a is obvious. Zion, God’s rest in the eternal state, is the New
Jerusalem. As has been determined, subcomers will never enter God’s rest.§ Consequently, subcomers will never
enter God’s rest, which is Zion, the New Jerusalem. Tanner rightly references Is 11:10 in associating the
misthological rest we are trying to achieve with the inheritance of the Messianic kingdom.992 This resting place is
contextually associated with His holy mountain (Is 11:9) and even with being an inhabitant of Zion (Is 12:6, cp.
Is 4:3-5). This reward city is the misthological mountain home of those who qualify to live there.**
       Whatever the wiping away of tears means, it does not suggest that God will allow subcomers to enter New
Jerusalem at the conclusion of the millennium. It would seem that, since all believers go to be with the Lord when
they die, subcomers are presently in the Heavenly Jerusalem. However, at the beginning of the millennium, when
the Heavenly City takes its satellite position in orbit above the earthly Jerusalem (see Illustration 177. Heavenly
Jerusalem), and the effects of the Bema are carried out, the subcomers will be expelled and permanently exiled
from the city as it becomes the location of exercising the millennial rest (i.e., the millennial rule) and subsequently
becomes the eternal rest. This expulsion corresponds very well with the sequence and timing of events that Jesus
parabolically describes by the improperly-dressed man being thrown out of the banquet hall immediately after the
wedding feast started.†† Subcomers will be in the banquet hall (and thus in the city) until the banquet starts; then
they will be expelled from the banquet (and thus from the city).

                                        Gates of Honor and Limitation
       The above analysis provides a possible purpose for the great and high, four-sided wall that surrounds the
city and for the angelic guard at each gate (Rev 21:12). One suggestion made by commentators is that the angels
are there as an honor guard. This is reasonable, especially in view of 22:14, which denotes entrance by the gates as
a special reward to overcomers (i.e., those who wash their robes in practical sanctification). That the angels are at
the gate to honor those who are worthy to enter the city in this manner is a reasonable conjecture. Of course, with
