only three gates on each of the four sides, and with each side of the wall running 1,500 miles, this computes to one
gate every 500 miles. Evidently, it is to be understood from these dimensions and from the honor afforded to those
who enter by the gates that the gates are not the only literal means of entry into such a massive city, and probably
not even the major avenue of entry. A city of this size could easily accommodate aerial entry and entry by subways
and other highways. The wall is only seventy-two yards high (Rev 21:17), which is no obstacle to aerial entry for a
city that is 1,500 miles high!
        The angelic guard may be at the gates to serve as a reminder that this type of entry is indeed a reward and
honor limited to overcomers. If there are different degrees of punishment in the outer darkness, which is a logical
inference, then some subcomers might be allowed to live outside of the city walls and thus in the outer parameter
of the city. The outer darkness might include the outer parameter of the city—just outside the city walls. Perhaps
subcomers who live further away from the city (and thus deeper in the outer darkness as it were) will be permitted
to visit the outer parameter on occasions as well. If so, they will have a visual reminder that they are not only
excluded from the city, but from entry through those gates as well. If such is the case, then subcomers may be
pictured standing outside the gates (each made of a single pearl, 21:21) and looking in through the gates.
        This means that those subcomers who live during the church age (and who have now gone on to be with the
Lord) are now with Him in this satellite city. At the rapture, they will participate in the resurrection and receive
glorified bodies. They will then be judged at the JSC. The results of the Bema, at least in terms of expulsion from
the festive city, will not occur until after the millennium starts and the city becomes the satellite capital city of the
earth during the millennial age. At this time subcomers will be cast outside the city, which they will have inhabited
up until this point in time. They will be banished from the Heavenly City when it becomes the satellite city during
the millennial reign and left on the outside looking in as it comes to rest on the earth during the eternal state.
                                         Illustration 187. Outside Looking In




Rev 21:3—Tabernacle
      The next verse of this context alludes to a rewards motif previously mentioned by John as describing God
dwelling among humanity in His tabernacle. The experience was described earlier by John in Rev 7:14-15 as a
reward for those who wash their robes in practical sanctification:
         14
           These are the ones who come out of the great tribulation, and they have washed their robes and
         made them white in the blood of the Lamb. 15 For this reason, they are before the throne of God; and
         they serve Him day and night in His temple; and He who sits on the throne shall spread His
         tabernacle over them. (Rev 7:14-15)

Being with God in His tabernacle is associated with sharing His presence around His throne. Subcomers are not
included in this specific aspect of God’s dwelling among people. Unfaithful believers will dwell with God in His
kingdom, not in the tabernacle of His throne room. To be clothed with white robes, one must actively do the
washing for oneself.* Just as the Bride must clothe herself with white garments (Rev 19:8),† so overcomers must

*
    See Other Rewards, 473.
†
    See Garments, 565.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                            Page 553
wash their own clothing. The Lamb will not do the washing for them. In fact, the only other time this phrase blood
of the Lamb occurs, it is described as one of the components necessary to be an overcomer (Rev 12:11).* Being
clothed in white garments is seen repeatedly as something one achieves as a result of overcoming (Rev 3:4-5,18)
and is associated with rulership (Rev 4:4). Consequently, the reason those in 7:9 are clothed in white robes is
because they themselves have made their own garments white through (dia) the blood of the Lamb in conjunction
with (kai dia) their own sacrifice. The blood of the Lamb and the blood of their own sacrificed lives are the dual
instrumental means by which they overcome (Rev 12:11). They have done their own washing in 7:14, in fulfilling
the requirements necessary to be regarded an overcomer. And 12:11 specifies that this entails cleansing their
garments by the blood of the Lamb and by the blood of their own sacrifice.

Rev 21:4—No Tears
        Petterson asks, “Does John’s vision teach the absolute banishment of death and pain? Obviously not,
because four verses later the wicked are said to go into the lake of fire (Rev. 21:8).”993 Peterson’s assessment is
correct, insofar as it goes, in refuting universalism by pointing out that this is a relative wiping limited by the
context to one group of people. Although Peterson naturally would assume from his Calvinistic premise that this
applies to all believers, the verse itself limits the promise to a particular group of believers: “He shall wipe away
every tear from their eyes.” The preceding verses in 21:1-3 leave no doubt as to the identity of the individuals who
are to experience this wonderful benefit. They are the bridal saints who inhabit the bridal city. As Chitwood
acknowledged, “The reference to all tears being wiped away prior to the millennium in Rev. 7:17 is only for a
select group of individuals realizing an inheritance in the kingdom.”994 The proper conclusion, therefore, is that the
wiping away of tears is a reward promised to overcomers, not to subcomers.
       This promise in 21:4 is composed of numerous litotes: no tears, no death, no mourning, no crying, and no
pain. No tears means supreme joy. No death means a superlative experience of life, which is used repeatedly as a
reward concept in Revelation.995 Like the preceding verse, verse 4 also brings back the imagery of ch. 7, which
made implicit promises to overcomers who wash their robes in practical sanctification (Rev 7:14). In addition to
the tabernacle experience around God’s throne mentioned above, overcomers are also promised that their tears will
be wiped away as a reward for washing their robes. Further, in this initial context, the wiping away of tears is also
understood as a litotes from a context of litotes (no hunger, no thirst, no hot sun—7:16). Since the wiping away of
tears was limited to overcomers previously in ch. 7, since it is associated with apparent litotes, since it may be
understood misthologically in the present context of ch. 21, since it is for the bridal inhabitants of the city, and
since it refers to more than just the removal of sorrow, the wiping away of tears should also be taken as a litotes in
21:4, promising supreme joy to its recipients.

Rev 21:6—Litotes
        The next promise is to give the water from the springs of the water of life without cost. It thus applies to all
believers (21:6). Even so, it is one thing to be able to drink water flowing from the spring to the outside of the city,
and it is quite another to be lead personally to and have access to the spring itself inside the city, which is the case
in Rev 7:17, where Johns says, “For the Lamb in the center of the throne shall be their shepherd, and shall guide
them to springs of the water of life; and God shall wipe every tear from their eyes.” The springs are at the throne,
which in turn is at the top of the city, Mt. Zion, the New Jerusalem. Those believers who wash their robes will have
this special access to the very source of the living water and have their own watery eyes dried by God.
        This spring of water produces a river (Rev 22:1-2), so it flows through the gates in the walls to the outside
of the city, and the water of life is free outside the city walls (cf. 22:17). The water will be freely available outside
the city to anyone within the kingdom. Kingdom residents may come and drink the water at that location. One
might even picture subcomers being allowed to come drink freely outside the walls. Anyone within the kingdom
will freely be able to drink that spring water, but only those who are faithful will have access to the spring itself,
inside the city, and thus drink the water at its very source. The tree of life will be located in the city by the water
(Rev 22:2). Since it is possible to lose one’s right to the tree of life within the city (Rev 22:19), it is reasonable to
conclude that it is equally possible to lose one’s right to direct access to the spring itself inside the city. Since even
in our day and age it is possible to obtain exported spring water from Europe, it is reasonable to infer that spring
water might also be exported (or teleported) from the New Jerusalem as well. Just as one can drink European
spring water without ever setting foot inside Europe, so it is reasonable to postulate that even those who have not
visited the capital city will be able to drink water exported from that city. After all, the leaves are evidently

*
    See Illustration 22. Triad Description of Overcoming Rulers, 51.
Page 554                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
exported for the healing of the nations. Why not assume that the water is likewise shared with those outside the
city, especially since it freely flows outside the city? In any case, it may be deduced that subcomers will have to
drink the water of life outside the city without being able to set foot inside the city from which the water originates
during the millennial and eternal states.
        All believers will have some type of association with the Book of Life (Rev 13:8; 17:8; 20:15) and with the
water of life (Rev 21:6; 22:17; Jn 4:10). However, only overcomers will have the unique association with the Book
of Life described in Rev 3:5 and with the water of life depicted in 7:17 and 22:1-2. Both the tree of life and the
water of life are located in the middle of the city at the throne of God. The water of life flows forth from there
through the city, through the walls of the city, and outside into the land beyond. Those in the kingdom (but outside
of the city) will have free access to the water which flows outside the walls of the city. Yet access to the springs
from which the water originates (7:17) will be limited to overcomers. Subcomers can drink the water of life from
the river of life outside the city; overcomers can drink it directly from the springs inside the city at the throne.

Rev 21:7—Overcomers’ Inheritance
        The very next verse in the passage explicitly states that these things are only inherited by the overcomer.
Only overcomers will inherit the water of life (Rev 21:6-7). It is one thing to inherit the water and quite another
merely to drink it, which is analogous to inherit versus enter the kingdom. Subcomers will be able merely to drink
the water of life. They will drink it, but not be led to it. This promise of being led to the springs themselves is
limited to overcomers (7:17). Only overcomers will inherit the litotes promised in these passages. Only overcomers
are promised the litotes of having their tears wiped away. In this passage misthological sonship is also conditioned
upon overcoming and is rewarded with the joy of a full inheritance.*

                                             Potential Weakness
      Much of the above material is derivable from the exegetical analysis already provided herein, or from that
implemented above, or from standard dispensational sources combined with a little imagination and some
deductive reasoning. Still, for many readers, much of what has been just shared may seem rather new, so
responding to potential objections will be prudent. Most importantly, having given this brief overview of the
heavenly terrain and the context of the promise regarding removing our tears, Keathley’s objection (based on the
OT background in Isaiah) may now be evaluated.

Is 25:8

                                       Failure to Address the Problem

All Faces
       The most obvious weakness with the above position being advocated herein is derived from Is 25:8: “He
shall wipe away every tear from every face.” This passage is a background passage for the second outer darkness
context (Mt 22:1-14). The language of Is 25:8 is universal. It refers to all peoples, all nations, all tears, and all
faces. The description of the tribulation in Is 24 is followed by the description of the millennium in Is 25. In this
millennial chapter, Is 25:6 describes the feast of the wedding banquet which begins the millennium, and Is 25:7-8
describes the removal of death and tears at the close of the millennium. As Martin says, these events are
“telescoped” together.996
       Unfortunately, a potential weakness in the misthological interpretation of the outer darkness has not been
dealt with adequately by misthological interpreters in the past. Therefore, the objection raised by Keathley at the
beginning of this chapter is not without seeming justification. In fact, the present author already had anticipated,
researched, and written most of this material long before he read Keathley’s comments. Nevertheless, he would
consider Keathley’s comment astute in having pinpointed such an obvious problem, which has yet to be addressed
adequately in print by misthologists. The question posed in this present study is really rather simple: “If the
banquet and wiping away of tears is promised to all believers, then how can the exclusion from the banquet and the
consequential shedding of tears be applied to any believers?”




*
    See Sons of God, 77.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                                  Page 555
Feast
        In 1978, Michael Huber wrote his master’s thesis at Dallas Theological Seminary entitled, The Concept of
the “Outer Darkness” in the Gospel of Matthew.997 In his thesis, he mentions Is 25:6 several times.998 He correctly
argues that the three outer darkness passages refer to the experience of unfaithful believers and that thus some
believers will be excluded from the feast. Yet he does not deal with the fact that Is 25:6 says that the feast will be
for all people, not just faithful believers. In 1991, Gregory Sapaugh also wrote his master’s thesis at Dallas entitled
An Interpretation of Matthew 22:1-14999 in which he makes a very significant observation: “That the messianic
reign is likened unto a feast or banquet is seen in Isaiah 25:6-9; 65:8-16; and Psalm 22:26-29. The Isaiah 25
passage brings out the glory of the occasion.”1000 He then quotes Is 25:6-9 in full. The OT background pictures the
messianic reign as a feast. Sapaugh also points out that in the NT

        the idea of reigning with Christ seems to be related to dining with Him. In Luke 22:28-30, Jesus
        spoke to His disciples and said: ‘But you are those who remained with Me in My trials. I also will
        confer to you, just as My Father conferred to Me, a kingdom, in order that you might eat and drink at
        My table, in My kingdom, and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.’ Therefore, to be at
        the wedding banquet, to eat and drink at His table, is to reign with Christ.1001

       Sapaugh further argues that not all believers will be able to participate in the wedding feast. And he is
certainly correct in that not all believers will rule with Christ. Yet he does not reconcile his interpretation with the
background passage in Is 25:6, which says the feast will be for all people.
        6
          And the Lord of hosts will prepare a lavish banquet for all peoples on this mountain; a banquet of
        aged wine, choice pieces with marrow, and refined, aged wine.7 And on this mountain He will
        swallow up the covering which is over all peoples, even the veil which is stretched over all nations.
        8
          He will swallow up death for all time, and the Lord God will wipe tears away from all faces, and
        He will remove the reproach of His people from all the earth; for the Lord has spoken. (Is 25:6-8)

                                       Wiping Away Tears of Physical Death
        Martin attempts to avoid the conclusion that Is 25:6 applies to all people in the millennial kingdom, since
this would mean that everyone living in the millennial kingdom will be saved, which is impossible from a
dispensational perspective—since the rebellion that occurs in the battle of Gog and Magog is at the conclusion of
the millennium. Death will still occur during the millennial age and at the conclusion of it.* Martin’s solution is to
limit all people in v. 6 to mean “people in all areas of the world.”1002 Although the present work does allow a
relative rather than universal all (if context so warrants it), Martin’s articulation of what this relative all means in
this particular context appears very doubtful and unnecessary, but his linkage of the wiping away of tears in Is 25:8
with the removal of death in Is 25:7 is warranted.1003 The promise is connected contextually with tears associated
with death. Therefore, this promise will be realized partially at the rapture and partially at the revelation, but only
realized fully at the end of the millennium, when death is fully and finally obliterated for all people.
        For this reason, it is best to understand Paul’s affirmation that “death is swallowed up in victory” at the time
of the rapture in 1Cor 15:54 as not applying fully or equally to all those entering the millennial kingdom. Rather, as
Paul himself notes, it is limited to those experiencing the transformation into glorified bodies. Moreover, this
victory over death need not be taken as being experienced equally by all those who experience the transformation.
In this context, the full form of the Pauline victory appears to be given misthologically (1Cor 15:57-58) to those
who inherit the kingdom (1Cor 15:50).†

                                      Wiping is Universal and Limited
       My proposal is that the feast is intended for all but only realized by some. The wiping away of tears is
experienced partially by all (no tears over literal death), but only realized fully as a litotes by the faithful (no
tears over misthological death).‡ Thus, the feast and wiping are potentially available to all in the kingdom,
but only realized to various degrees by some within the kingdom. This would be analogous to an unlimited

*

and Mistholic Faith.
‡
  See “Misthological Death” in Believe: An Aspectual and Metaphorical Analysis from the Gospel of John.
Page 556                                                                                             The Outer Darkness
atonement which makes the salvation of all possible but is limited in effect to those who respond to the
gospel. The lack of specificity in the passage is not unique. Even in the NT some eschatological passages seem to
indicate that there is only one resurrection (e.g., Jn 5:28-29) and no carnal believers (e.g., the sheep versus the
goats). It is permissible on some occasions to speak in general terms and make summary statements and to fill in
the details on other occasions.

                                       Misthological Time of Fulfillment
        The validity of Martin’s association of the wiping away of tears with literal death in the universal scope of
Isaiah’s promise has been noted. This aspect is acknowledged by the above proposal in that the wiping away of
tears associated with literal death will be experienced by all believers. However, the time of this fulfillment
proves its misthological nature in Rev 7:17 and 21:4. For those believers living during the church age, the
wiping away of tears promised in Is 25:8 will be experienced at the rapture, just as Paul confirms. Paul quotes from
this very verse, saying that it will be fulfilled at the time of the rapture for believers who live in the present time
period. “But when this perishable will have put on the imperishable, and this mortal will have put on immortality,
then will come about the saying that is written, “Death is swallowed up in victory” (1Cor 15:54).
        No more tears will be associated with literal death for believers in the present time period after the rapture.
For subsequent believers, the promise about tears being removed in Is 25:8 (due to death being swallowed up) will
be fulfilled subsequently. For faithful tribulational believers, it will be fulfilled at the end of the tribulation. For
believers who enter the millennial kingdom in physical bodies and other believers who live till the end of the
millennium, this promise in Is 25:8 will be fulfilled at the end of the millennium.
        Assuming that what Paul writes in 1Cor 15:54 is intended to be applicable to all transformed believers, it
should be remembered that the promise of Is 25:8 will be fulfilled for present believers long before the end of the
millennium. As a matter of fact, it will be fulfilled before the beginning of the millennium. Even more to the point,
it will be fulfilled before the Judgment Seat of Christ occurs! According to Paul, Is 25:8 is fulfilled for present day
believers “when” this perishable body puts on its imperishable body. In other words, Is 25:8 is fulfilled for the
believers of this time period at the moment of the rapture, since it is at this point they receive their resurrected
glorified bodies and experience complete and final victory over literal death. Thus, this limited aspect of Is 25:8
is fulfilled before the Bema. Therefore, this aspect of the fulfillment has absolutely nothing to do with having
our tears wiped away after the Bema. This limited application of Is 25:8 is not a promise to wipe away the
tears of those cast into the outer darkness.
        The wiping away of tears in Is 25:8 is associated with death, not with the Bema. The Bride of Christ does
not have to wait until the end of the millennium to have her tears dried away. For one thing, Is 25:8 will be fulfilled
for her at the beginning of the millennium. She will also experience the joy of ruling with Him throughout the
millennium. Since the Bride will have her tears wiped away long before the end of the millennium, and since the
promise in Rev 21:4 occurs at the end of the millennium, the promise in Rev 21:4 is subsequent to and rises higher
than the limited application of Is 25:8.

• If 1Cor 15:54 applies Is 25:8 to all raptured believers, the tears of Is 25:8 are wiped away before the Bema for
  church-age believers.
• Accordingly, the fulfillment of Rev 21:4 is 1000 years after the fulfillment of Is 25:8 for the bridal church-age
  believers.
• The fulfillment of Rev 7:17 commences for tribulational believers before they experience the fulfillment of
  Is 25:8.

        Although it was previously affirmed that Dillow was correct in placing the wiping away of tears after the
millennium, now it may be further noted that he associates the removal of tears for the faithful with the JSC and
thus with the beginning of the millennium.1004 When I initially acknowledged that he and others were correct for
placing the wiping away of the tears at that location, I was speaking textually and spatially rather than
chronologically. The text does place the wiping away of tears at that time. Dillow is to be commended for
acknowledging this apparent exegetical location, yet evidently he intuitively realizes it should not be left there. He
does not provide a rationale, so I do so for him.
        Only a superficial exegesis would place the wiping away of tears at the conclusion of the millennium. A
more complete exegesis would realize that this promise at the end of the millennium is a litotes that must
chronologically be inaugurated before the millennium. Since the Bride’s tears are removed long before the end of
the millennium, and since Rev 21:4 pictures the joy of the faithful who compose the Bride, the purpose of this
verse is not to show that the Bride’s tears are not wiped away until the end of the millennium. Instead, this verse
shows that her unique joy is not limited to the honeymoon of the millennium. It refers to her eternal joy in the
eternal state. Rev 21:4 is John’s way of saying that the Bridegroom and Bride live happily ever after. Dillow’s
intuition was better than his exposition on this particular point. The Lord wipes away the tears of His faithful Bride
with a misthological handkerchief at the JSC. There will be no such handkerchief for those who have been
unfaithful.
        The promise in Rev 21:4 is a promise of wiping away the tears associated with metaphorical death, and (as
such) this wiping will be experienced only by faithful believers. Not only will they not experience soteriological
death; they will not experience misthological death. Not only will their spirits not die, their souls will not die either.
Instead of losing their souls, they will gain their soul-lives. This aspect of the wiping away of tears is in view in
both Rev 7:17 and Rev 21:4. The wiping away of tears in these two passages is a litotes that means supreme joy. In
addition to the context demanding this interpretation, the fact that this is a litotes that means supreme joy was
indicated in Lk 6:21: “Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.” The fact that it is a reward limited to
faithful believers is indicated in both Mt 5:4 and Lk 6:21. In other words, it is another way of saying what
Mt 25:21,23 already has anticipated, “Enter into the joy of your master.”
        Pagenkemper acknowledges: “In the Talents the phrase ‘enter into the joy of your master’ (Matt. 25:21, 23)
is viewed by many writers as suggestive of an invitation to a banquet (many connect this directly with the
eschatological banquet.)”1005 Pagenkemper would have been far more consistent if he had followed through with
this observation and noted that in these two verses those being told to enter into their Master’s joy are the two
servants who are faithful. The faithful servants are immediately granted rulership after being invited to enter this
joy. Being put in charge of the millennial cities is equated with entering into their master’s joy, which alludes to the
wedding banquet. The banquet is a reward for faithful service and denotes rulership in the millennial kingdom.
Contrary to Pagenkemper, the banquet does not represent a soteriological gift. Whereas Mt 25:21,23 refers to
millennial joy for the faithful, Rev 21:4 refers to eternal joy for the faithful. Since rewards are eternal, the joy or
sorrow produced by rewards would also be eternal.

                                 Misthological Support of OT Background
        Whereas Paul may be focusing on a limited application of Is 25:8 in 1Cor 15:54, by making it applicable to
all transformed believers, in Revelation John gives the fuller intended application of the verse from its OT
background by litotetically limiting its full applicability to overcomers. By limiting its scope only to embrace
overcomers, John deepens its perspective. In Is 30:19, it is those who dwell in Zion who will weep no more. The
promise is for city dwellers, not kingdom inhabitants. Is 35:10 promises eternal joy, no sorrows, for those in Zion
(cf. Is 51:11). Contextually, Is 57:18 promises comfort for those who respond to His chastisement, not for those
who continue to walk in wickedness (cf. Is 57:20-21; 59:20). The promise is for those who take refuge in the Lord
and who thus will inherit the land and possess His holy mountain, that is, Mount Zion (Is 57:13). The NAS
expresses it this way: “He who takes refuge in Me will inherit the land and will possess My holy mountain.”
Conversely, the NKJ transposes the word order: “He who puts his trust in Me shall possess the land, and shall
inherit My holy mountain.” It makes little difference. As noted previously, the two words are synonymous and
Page 558                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                                  *
therefore may be translated interchangeably. Those who inherit the land will be the ones who possess the city.
Overcomers (i.e. bridal saints) will possess dwelling places in the bridal city (Jn 14:2-3). Subcomers will not.
        The Lord promises to revive those who are contrite and poor in spirit (i.e., those who have a contrite and
lowly spirit). Compare the misthological nature of this promise in Mt 5:4. Is 60:20 depicts no mourning in the
glorified Zion. Its inhabitants not only dwell in the land, they possess it (Is 60:21). No more mourning is a promise
for those who possess the land. Inheriting and possessing the land are misthological concepts that correspondingly
are limited to overcomers. Is 61:2 says that the Lord will “comfort all who mourn.” Does this mean that He will
comfort everyone, even those in hell? Hardly! The context rules out those who are confined to hell. It also rules out
comfort for those who are confined to the outer darkness, since the very next verse defines the comfort as “the oil
of gladness” and limits the comfort to “those who mourn in Zion” (Is 61:3; cp. Lk 6:25). Their comfort consists of
wearing a garland on their head as a “crown” (Is 61:3 NIV; cf. 51:10), being praised (Is 61:3), being called priests
(Is 61:6), having a double portion (Is 61:7). These things are rewards for the faithful believers, not gifts for all
believers, as 61:8 goes on to explain: “For I, the Lord, love justice; I hate robbery and iniquity. In my faithfulness I
will reward them” (NIV). This comforting removal of mourning is a reward, just as it is in Mt 5:4. Jeremiah also
says that the cessation of weeping is due to rewarded work (Jer 31:16). It is a reward experienced by those in Zion
(Jer 31:12-13).
        The litotetical aspect of removing the tears is seen in that it is equated with “everlasting joy” (Is 61:7). This
blessing is for those who will clothe themselves in practical righteousness like a bride (Is 61:10). Those who are
righteous in this passage are “those who are living by God’s standards.”1006 Their righteousness will be seen by
others (Is 62:1-2). Thus, imparted practical righteousness rather than imputed legal righteousness is intended. They
will have a “new name” (Is 62:2; cf. 62:10). They will be God’s crown and royal diadem (Is 62:3); that is, they will
be His rulers; they will rule His kingdom; they will be an expression of His rulership. They will be God’s Bride
(Is 62:5). All these items are rewards and recompenses, not gifts (Is 62:11). They are for those who dwell in the
city, that is, in Zion (Is 62:12). Accordingly, Is 65:19 does not rule out weeping in the new heavens and New Earth
of Is 65:17. Rather, it rules out weeping in the New Jerusalem of Is 65:19.
        Unfaithful believers will live in the new heavens and New Earth, but they will not dwell in Mount Zion
during the millennium or eternity. They will be excluded from the Heavenly Jerusalem (Mount Zion during the
millennium) and from the New Jerusalem (Mount Zion during eternity). They will be in the kingdom but outside
the city. In summary of the background from the book of Isaiah, the banquet and wiping away of tears for all
people in Mount Zion (in Is 25:6-8) is for all people potentially, but it will not be for all people experientially. The
wicked will be excluded, whether they are lost or saved. In fact, the writer of Hebrews uses the background
associated with Is 26:11 to warn believers that they are in danger of God’s fiery wrath (Heb 10:27).† In that day,
this mountain city (Is 25:6,10; 26:1-5) will open its gates only to the righteous, that is, to the “one who remains
faithful” (Is 26:2). Believers who were not faithful will be outside of the mountain city of Mount Zion, excluded by
its gates. To say that those who are faithful will be rewarded with having no tears is a litotes for having eternal joy,
inheriting (i.e., possessing/owning) the land, possessing the mountain city, wearing crowns, being praised, being
called priests, having a double portion, having a new name, being rulers, and being God’s Bride.‡

                                      Misthological Support from NT
       It is not unusual for commentators to perceive a limited aspect of this truth concerning Mt 5:4. “Blessed are
those who mourn, for they shall be comforted.” This blessing of being comforted is a reward promised only to
those who mourn, not to everyone or every believer. Hendriksen, for example, writes:

            People mourn for many reasons: sickness, pain, bereavement, material loss, wounded pride, etc.
       In the present context, however, a basically different kind of mourning is in view. It is the mourning
       of those who recognize their spiritual bankruptcy (first beatitude) and are—or are presently going to
       be —hungering and thirsting for righteousness (fourth beatitude), that is emphasized.…
            …Their mourning therefore is God-centered, not man-centered.…It grieves them that God, their
       own God whom they love, is being dishonored. Cf. Ps. 139:136. This type of grief “to the glory of
       God” is also strikingly expressed in Ps. 119:136, “Streams of water run down my eyes because they
       do not observe thy law.” See also Ezra 10:6.…

  See Blessed, 45.
†
  See Misthological Wrath, 676.

Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                          Page 559
             At times the comfort consists in this, that the affliction itself is removed….Often, however, the
       affliction remains for a while but a weight of glory outbalances the grief (II Cor. 4:17). (Emphasis
       his.)1007

These passages promise no tears (and all that is represented by this litotes) to those believers whose zeal for
practical righteousness in their own lives (cf. Mt 5:6) causes them to grieve over sin, not only in their own lives but
also in the lives of others. All sin grieves them because it grieves the God whom they love and whose Bride they
are intended to be.

Church of First-Born
       The city of Mount Zion is to be the habitation of the “church of the firstborn” (Heb 12:22-23). Concerning
this passage, Dillow states:

       To come to the “church of the firstborn” means to be called to the privilege of being a firstborn son.
       All Christians are called to be part of that assembly and by birth have a right to be there. However,
       they may forfeit that right and never achieve their calling. That is the thrust of all the warnings of the
       book of Hebrews.1008 (Emphasis added.)

        Dillow’s summation is excellent and is another way of saying that all Christians are invited to become
firstborn sons and have a right to come to Mount Zion. Dillow acknowledges that this right may be forfeited. These
things are theirs potentially but may fail to become theirs experientially. The logical implication of Dillow’s words
should be that those who are unfaithful will not only experientially fail to achieve firstborn status, they will also
fail to have a right to be at Mount Zion. Although Dillow develops the first implication very well, he fails to follow
through adequately on the second one. Those believers who are excluded from firstborn status are also excluded
from Mount Zion and all the promises that pertain to it. As a result, the litotes promised to those in Mount Zion (to
have all their tears wiped away) does not apply to unfaithful believers since they will be excluded from Mount
Zion. They have lost their right to expect Rev 21:4 to apply to them. These beautiful verses from Revelation and
their promises regarding the removal of tears are limited to those believers within Revelation who are overcomers.

Summary
        In this chapter, answers have been sought for multiple riddles. First, why are the tears not eternal if the
rewards are eternal? The proper conclusion is that the tears are indeed eternal if shed by unfaithful believers. The
tears of faithful believers are wiped away by positive rewards at the Bema. The tears of the unfaithful believers are
inflicted, rather than wiped away, by negative rewards imposed at the Bema.
        Second, why is the wiping away of tears in Rev 7:17 only promised to overcomers prior to the millennium
but the wiping away of tears in Rev 21:4 applied to all believers at the conclusion of the millennium? The answer
is that it is not applied to all believers at the end of the millennium. The litotetic nature of 7:17 is rather easily
demonstrated. Dillow’s solution was to apply the wiping away of tears misthologically to faithful believers at the
Bema and graciously to punished believers at the conclusion of the millennium. The simplicity of this approach is
indeed attractive but unfortunately also renders it inadequate.
        For starters, the litotetic nature of 7:17 limits this promise to overcomers. Why would a reward promised
only to overcomers prior to the Bema be extended to all believers at the conclusion of the millennium? Such a
proposal would blur the Marrowistic distinctions between a gift and a reward. What was once a reward is somehow
turned into a gift in this approach. Also, Dillow’s solution is rendered unlikely by the eternality of misthology and
the permanent distinctions pertaining thereto. Rewards, and lack thereof, are eternal. Not only is Dillow’s
interpretation unlikely, it is unnecessary. The context of 21:4 is quite capable of supporting a litotetic
interpretation, thereby allowing both passages to be interpreted harmoniously. Lastly, Dillow’s approach poses
another impossibility. In 7:17 the Lord has something to wipe away our tears with—a misthological handkerchief.
No such misthological handkerchief is available to those who have been unfaithful, no matter how long they wait.
Rewards are based on what we do now. If we fail to earn those rewards now, there will be nothing left with which
to wipe away our misthological tears then.
        The third riddle is the one posed by Keathley. Why does the wiping away of tears in the OT banquet
imagery not apply to all believers? Obviously, an absolute universal all is not intended in the OT. Keathley is not
trying to advocate universalism. As a result, it must be admitted that Isaiah is employing a relative all. All faces of
a certain group of people will experience this wonderful benefit.
Page 560                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
        For summary purposes, misthologists could be content to say that only those, and all those, who are allowed
to enjoy the banquet will have their tears wiped away at the banquet. That is, the promise of wiping away of one’s
tears applies only to overcomers. Certainly, it should not be very difficult to perceive the basic continuity a
misthological understanding of the outer darkness would have with a misthological wiping away of tears at a
misthological banquet. Those in the outer darkness are excluded from the banquet and thus from the promise of
having their tears wiped away. The OT context certainly supports such a proposal. The joy of Mount Zion is
limited to Mount Zion. Those in the outer darkness are excluded misthologically from Mount Zion and therefore
from the promises. They will be in the kingdom but not in this particular city of the kingdom. If this is the case,
then the removal of death and tears in Is 25:8 is limited litotetically to overcomers.
        However, in due regard for the generally-assumed Pauline application of this promise pertaining to the
swallowing up of death to all believers via the rapture, a slightly more sophisticated understanding of this teaching
was posed to accommodate all the data surveyed, so that a partial versus full realization of the promise was
entertained as plausible. If this general perception of a Pauline application of the Isaiah text to all believers is
correct, then the full rapture will result in partial realization of Is 25:8 insofar as some limited aspect of this verse
may be applied unconditionally to all believers in that they will not die physically. The subsequent Bema will
result in full contextual realization of the misthological aspect of the promise for faithful believers.
        So does Is 25:8 apply to all believers? Yes, if Paul is giving the text such application. Believing this
potentially to be the case, I have outlined an approach above that might be called a partial-relative realization. On
the other hand, some Ultraists may be inclined to take 1Cor 15:54 as a relative promise that is only applicable to
overcomers. This would result in a slightly simpler approach in that they would only be posing a simple-relative
realization. The promises in both texts would simply be relevant only for overcomers.
        Although I have not taken this alternate route, I was able to approximate the same conclusion as the simple-
relative realization, since I understand Paul as saying that the victory over death which he envisions entails both a
moral and immortal transformation so that one may be granted the misthological inheritance of the kingdom.* This
being the case, one might insist that Is 25:8 does not apply to unfaithful believers at all. Isaiah does not intend for
these promises to be applied indiscriminately to all people inhabiting the millennial kingdom. Let it be noted
empathically that Isaiah intends to limit these promises to “all peoples on this mountain” (Is 25:6)! In the next
verse he reiterates that God will perform these actions on this mountain (Is 25:7). Now although the actions
performed in v. 7 may benefit all peoples throughout the kingdom, the banquet itself is limited by Isaiah himself in
v. 6 to the mountain inhabitants. The all is contextually relative and only applies to those who are faithful (Is 26:2).
Both Isaiah and Paul intend for this promise to be understood in this manner. Death will be swallowed up
litotetically in victory only by overcomers. Neither Isaiah nor Paul is limiting his vision to the simple removal of
death but eschatologically envisioning the superlative misthological experience of abundant life for the faithful.
Does Is 25:8 apply to all believers? No. By way of interpretation, the all must be limited to believers on this
mountain. Isaiah himself says so. Although Paul makes a delimited application to believers in general, this
circumscription is subsidiary to the main point being made.
        Regardless of which route is chosen, partial-relative or simple-relative, the all is relative. The NT
misthological conceptual support for understanding this joy and removal of tears in a manner consistent with an
exclusive misthological realization is demonstrable. Since the promise to remove tears is limited to overcomers,
does this mean that physical death will continue to exist in the eternal state for subcomers and for those who enter
the eternal kingdom in flesh and blood bodies? No. At the conclusion of the millennial kingdom, death will be
thrown into the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14). Physical death will be done away with for those not experiencing the
second death in the Lake of Fire. There will be no death for the nations comprising the eternal kingdom in flesh
and blood bodies. Does this mean that there will be no tears or sickness in the eternal kingdom? No. As Govett
acknowledges, the leaves of the tree of life will be for the healing of the nations in the eternal kingdom
(Rev 22:2).1009 Since the pain of sickness will still exist, the pain ruled out in Rev 21:4 is not the absolute removal
of all pain for all those in the eternal kingdom.
        Consequently, the promise in that verse regarding no pain is best taken litotetically rather than absolutely.
Pain will still exist, but there will be no pain for the overcomers. As for the nations who experience pain, the tears
that they experience from injury or sickness will be wiped away, so to speak, by the leaves of the tree. Tears still
will be experienced from time to time by those in flesh and blood bodies. Surely, little children who fall and scrap
their knees will still cry. They will not be told to keep a stiff upper lip. Subcomers who are consigned to the outer
darkness may be expected to shed tears from time to time as well; although, they will be grateful not to be in hell.

*
    See Procreation in the Millennial Kingdom, 60.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                      Page 561
Chitwood believes that Rev 21:4 rules out the possibility of misthological death in the eternal state. To the
contrary, misthological death still will be present. The promise of no death of any kind for the overcomer does not
mean that the nonovercomer will not experience any kind of death.
       Chitwood’s deduction appears self-defeating: “There can be no such thing as Christians being hurt of the
second death beyond the Millennium, for Rev. 21:4 plainly declares that there will be no more death during this
time.” Yet, on the next page, he remarks about Rev 21:8, which follows shortly thereafter: “The second death for
the nonovercomer is having a “part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone” (emphasis his).1010 His
perspective is that these two verses taken together indicate that subcomers can be hurt only metaphorically by the
second death during the millennium. A more intuitive approach would acknowledge that if Rev 21:4 is talking
about the eternal state, then so is Rev 21:8. Litotetically, verse 4 is promising that no death will exist for the
overcomer during the eternal state, while verse 8 misthologically is warning that misthological death will continue
to exist for the subcomer. Chitwood’s assertion that subcomers can be hurt misthological (in a metaphorically
sense) by the second death during the millennium is perhaps permissible (Rev 2:11; 20:6). However, given his
misthological interpretation of Rev 21:8 as dealing with subcomers, the proper conclusion, in that case, would be
that they will be hurt misthologically by the second death throughout the eternal state as well. Conceptually, I
would have no objection to such a conclusion. The outer darkness is eternal. Therefore, the misthological death
pictured metaphorically by that darkness is eternal. Correlatively, I reach that conclusion even regarding Rev 21:8.
       My major disappointment with Chitwood’s position is not that he applies Rev 21:8 to believers but that he
limits the application to the millennium. My minor point of disagreement is that he applies the verse
metaphorically whereas I would apply it correlatively. We both apply it misthologically. In my assessment, the
second death is experienced literally by unbelievers for all eternity and will be experienced correlatively by
subcomers for all eternity. Rewards are eternal.* That some Gehenna misthologists attempt to circumvent the
eternal nature of rewards is understandable. For they cannot have subcomers being submitted to literal Gehenna for
eternity. FG soteriology would forbid such a possibility. However, neither Chitwood nor I are Gehenna
misthologists in that both of us would only allow metaphorical applicability (in Chitwood’s case) or correlative
applicability (in my case) of metaphysical Gehenna to subcomers. We both hold to a progressive moderate
misthology in that regard. Therefore, Chitwood is not laboring under any compulsion to limit his misthological
application to the millennium. Regardless as to whether our fellow moderate misthologists may prefer Chitwood’s
metaphorical approach or my correlative approach, the plausibility of the eternal misthological applicability of
Rev 21:8 should be given due consideration. That this verse has eternal metaphorical applicability is the most
natural interpretation of Rev 21:8 given Chitwood’s approach or the most natural correlation given mine.
Regardless, the metaphorical application of the principle of correlativity to unfaithful believers is eternal.

The Lord’s Banquet
       The banquet prophesied by Isaiah is anticipated by Jesus in that the Lord’s Supper prefigures this messianic
feast. Those who are unclean, like Judas, will be excluded. Jesus immediately sent Judas from the room after He
gave him the dipped morsel from the Passover meal, so Judas was not there for the Lord’s Supper which followed
(cp. Mt 26:21-26; Jn 13:21-30).1011 In like manner, unbelievers will be cast into the pit of Gehenna (Is 24:22)
before the millennial reign from Mount Zion starts (Is 24:23) and the messianic mountain feast begins (Is 25:6).

                                                        Wash
       Even earlier, however, before Judas was sent from the room, Jesus already had made it clear that
participation in the meal was conditioned on being clean. Jesus warned Peter that if he would not submit to the foot
washing, then even Peter would have no portion (meros) with Him. Had Peter not submitted to the foot washing,
then certainly he would not have been permitted to participate in the Lord’s Supper which followed. Surely, he
would have been dismissed from the room. Consequently, three types of people are represented at the Passover
meal in Jn 13:10, where Jesus informed Peter, “He who has bathed [louo] needs only to wash [nipto] his feet, but is
completely clean; and you are clean, but not all of you [are clean].”
       (1) Judas was unclean. Unbelievers have not experienced the bath (loutron) of regeneration (Tit 3:5) and are
therefore unclean. (2) On the other hand, some believers have had a bath, and are thus clean, but have not yet
submitted to the subsequent cleansing pictured by the foot washing and described by 1Jn 1:9. Those believers with
dirt on their feet (i.e., with unconfessed sin) will be disqualified from having a portion (meros) with Jesus in the


*
    See Rewards are Eternal, 520.
Page 562                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                    *
Lord’s Supper. (3) Those believers who are completely clean are believers who have had both a bath and
subsequent washing. Participation in the Lord’s Supper is conditioned on having both a bath and cleansed feet.

                                             Personal Worthiness
      Paul likewise urges believers to live their lives in a manner that is worthy (axios) of the kingdom, and he
uses an antonym to warn believers that they must not partake of the Lord’s Supper in an unworthy (anaxios)
manner (1Cor 11:27). From its inauguration in the Upper Room, the Lord’s Supper was to be limited to believers
who were morally pure. Believers should not participate in the Lord’s Supper with unconfessed sin in their lives
because the Supper is understood to be conditioned on moral purity as represented by the foot washing. Jesus has
His eyes focused on the future implications of the Supper:
          16
            For I say to you, I shall never again eat it until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God. 17 And when
          He had taken a cup and given thanks, He said, “Take this and share it among yourselves; 18 for I say
          to you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine from now on until the kingdom of God comes.”
          (Lk 22:16-18)

        The Supper foreshadows a future event in the messianic kingdom that has not yet been fulfilled in the
present. To be sure, one aspect of the Supper is to be a memorial, as Matthew points out, for what already has taken
place: “For this is My blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many for forgiveness of sins” (Mt 26:28).
Jesus’ blood already has been shed and our sins forgiven. This is past. However, Matthew also proceeds in the very
next verse to indicate the prophetic dimension of the Supper: “But I say to you, I will not drink of this fruit of the
vine from now on until that day when I drink it new with you in My Father’s kingdom” (Mt 26:29). Participation in
this Supper requires a sober looking back at one’s past judicial cleansing in remembrance of Jesus’ death
(Lk 22:19; 1Cor 11:24-26). More than just this past judicial bath of justification is required, however. Looking
forward to one’s participation in the future dimensions of the Supper as a reward for one’s present sanctification;
thus, daily purification is envisioned also. As Jesus alludes and as Constable elucidates, the Lord’s Supper
prefigured the messianic banquet:

               As the first Passover looked forward to deliverance and settlement in the Promised Land, so the
          Lord’s Supper looked forward to deliverance and settlement in the promised kingdom. Disciples are
          to observe the Lord’s Supper only until He returns (1 Cor. 11:26). Then we will enjoy the messianic
          banquet together (Isa. 25:6; cf. Matt. 8:11).1012
                                    Illustration 189. Table Exclusion from Mount Zion




*
    See Portion in Jn 13:8, 110.
Chapter 24. Whose Tears in Rev 21:4?                                                                        Page 563


        Constable is correct to connect the Lord’s Supper with the messianic banquet. As Isaiah foretold, this
banquet would be celebrated on Mount Zion (Is 25:6-7), referred to as the city of Heavenly Jerusalem in the NT
(Heb 12:22). Unbelievers would be excluded, being tossed into the pit (Is 24:22), which the NT refers to as
Gehenna. However, access to the city, and thus to the banquet, would be limited to the faithful believers (Is 26:2).
Jesus already had indicated earlier in His ministry that not all sons of the kingdom would be qualified for
participation in this messianic alimentation. Some of them would be cast in the darkness outside the banquet. They
would be cast away from the table rather than out of the kingdom (Mt 8:11-12).
        Had Peter not submitted to the foot washing, he too would have been cast out of the room and excluded
from the Lord’s Supper. After the Supper, Jesus reminds His disciples that dining at His table in the kingdom
would be equated with ruling the kingdom. These diners would be the kingdom rulers (Lk 22:30). Those granted
this privilege would be those believers who faithfully stood by Jesus in His trials (Lk 22:28). Peter was in danger
of table exclusion if he failed to submit to the foot lavation. Just as dining at this table represents ruling in the
kingdom (Lk 22:30), being excluded from this table would signify being excluded from the kingdom rulership,
rather than from the kingdom itself. Those who recline to eat will sit (kathemai) on thrones to rule: “And you are
those who have stood by Me in My trials; and just as My Father has granted Me a kingdom, I grant you that you
may eat and drink at My table [trapeza] in My kingdom, and you will sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of
Israel” (Lk 22:28-30).

                                                    Table Exclusion
        Nevertheless, some have questioned taking the reference in Mt 8:11-12 as referring to table exclusion rather
than kingdom exclusion because the word table is not explicitly stated in the Greek text. Nor is the word table
found in the KJV translation of this previous passage. Yet it must be noted that the KJV fails to alert its readers to
the fact that two different Greek words are being used for wash in Jn 13:10. Nipto is a Greek verb that refers to
washing part of one’s body, such as one’s feet, hands, or face (Mt 6:17; 15:2; Jn 13:10). This verb, therefore, may
be used in contrast to louo, which denotes washing one’s entire body by bathing.
        In a similar manner, it should be clarified that some Greek verbs mean to recline or lean rather than to
simply sit. Anakeimai is one such verb. The KJV appropriately translates this verb as leaning in Jn 13:23 and being
at the table in Jn 13:28. Yet it fails to do so in the Upper Room passage in Lk 22:27. Here, unfortunately, the KJV
simply translates it as sitteth at meat. The NKJ is closer since it translates anakeimai as sits at the table. To its
credit, it specifies that the meal was eaten at the table. The verb itself implies this, and the context explicitly
acknowledges that the meal is at a table just three verses later (Lk 22:30). The word table (trapeza) is explicitly
used in that verse. Unfortunately, both the KJV and NKJ are inaccurate when they picture them as sitting there.
This picture of sitting is more of a Da Vinci device than a picture of reality. The Da Vinci Code is a fiction based
on a historically inaccurate painting. Those participating in the Lord’s Supper actually reclined on cushions at the
table; there were no chairs.1013 This is why John was able to lean back on Jesus’ chest at the meal (Jn 13:25).
        Anaklino is a synonym for anakeimai. It is used in Lk 12:37 for recline at the table (NAS). Alas, the KJV
simply translates this as sit. Yet in Lk 2:7 the KJV translates anaklino as laid since sit obviously would be a bad
translation. Mary did not sit Jesus in a highchair but laid Him in a manger! Likewise, it should be concluded that
Luke 13:29 is referring to misthological rulership, pictured by anaklino as reclining at table: “And they will come
from east and west, and from north and south, and will recline at the table in the kingdom of God.” On the other
hand, the previous verse in Lk 13:28 talks about another type of exclusion: “There will be weeping and gnashing of
teeth there when you see Abraham and Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, but yourselves
being cast out.” Unbelievers will be cast out of the kingdom, but faithful believers will recline at table in the
kingdom. Luke contrasts unbelievers with faithful believers in this passage.
        Matthew, though, uses anaklino to contrast faithful and unfaithful believers: “And I say to you, that many
shall come from east and west, and recline at the table with Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, in the kingdom of
heaven, but the sons of the kingdom shall be cast out into the outer darkness; in that place there shall be weeping
and gnashing of teeth” (Mt 8:11-12). Unlike the similar account in Luke, where the outcasts are cast out of the
kingdom, in Matthew the outcasts are cast away from the table. Or to restate the situation without the word table,
in Mathew they are cast away from the reclining (anaklino) experience, but in Luke they are cast out of the
kingdom. So unless one equates the kingdom (basileia) in Lk 13:28 with the reclining experience (i.e., the ruling
experience of misthological kingship), one is left with taking Lk 13:28 as referring soteriologically to spatial
Page 564                                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
exclusion. Although the former would be quite compatible with misthology, the latter is misthologically
preferable.*
       Since the verb anaklino means to recline and typically is used of reclining to eat a meal, the verb should be
taken as having this normative meaning in Mt 8:11. Since the verse is alluding to the future banquet prophesized by
Isaiah, the verb should be understood as reclining to eat a meal. Since Jesus picks up on this banquet theme and
uses the Lord’s Supper to prefigure it, Jesus should be understood as picturing reclining to eat a meal. The regal
nature of this meal is implicit in the OT and explicit in the NT. Because only those believers who are morally pure
in terms of their faithfulness are allowed to participate in the table fellowship and corresponding royal rule in
Is 25:6-7, the promise of having one’s tears victoriously wiped away in the manner being described in Is 25:8 must
be limited to overcomers.

                                                         Conclusion
        There is ample reason to suspect that the promise in Is 25:8 regarding the removal of tears and death is a
litotes limited in intended application to faithful believers. A reasonable supposition is that Paul’s application in
1Cor 15:54 is primarily dealing with overcomers as well. Although it is true that no transformed believer will die,
this corollary need not necessarily be considered the proposition that Paul is seeking to prove in this context. His
overall argument is that transformed overcomers will need to be literally immortal in order to inherit the kingdom
misthologically (1Cor 15:50) and be given the litotetic victory over death (1Cor 15:57). Paul and Isaiah appear to
be making the same misthological point. In Rev 21:4, John certainly is making this affirmation: These promises are
litotes limited in intended application to overcomers.
        The fact that subcomers will not die any more as a result of their transformation is not the principal point
being made. Nevertheless, this subsidiary affirmation may be inferred from 1Cor 15:54.† From the combination of
the information being provided by Isaiah, Paul, and John, one is able to make this summary statement: If (as a
result of your regeneration) you have undergone (A) a moral transformation and (B) an eschatological
transformation, then you will (C) be immortal, (D) inherit the kingdom, and (E) have your tears wiped away (A &
B ⇒ C & D & E).
        Since overcomers will need to experience literal victory over death (via their transformation) in order to
experience their superlative experience over death (via their rewards such as having their tears litotetically wiped
away), it may be inferred that subcomers also will experience literal victory over death since they will share the
overcomer’s transformation into glorified bodies. So if (as a result of your regeneration) you only have undergone
(B) an eschatological transformation, and thus have bypassed (A) the moral transformation of practical
sanctification, then you will simply (C) be immortal (B ⇒ C). Subcomers will not share in the litotetic removal of
death or tears, nor in the regal dining/ruling experience with Jesus.1014
        Just as literal sickness still will exist in the eternal state, so will literal crying and pain. The fact that these
experiences will no longer exist for overcomers does not mean that they will cease to exist for those who are not
overcomers. Death will no longer literally exist in the eternal kingdom. No tears over literal death will exist.
However, misthological death will continue to exist. Misthologists are fully aware that subcomers will lose their
souls at the Bema. The loss of one’s soul life certainly can be considered a form of misthological death. Those in
the outer darkness misthologically will have lost their souls/lives for all eternity. That is a wound that time cannot
heal. Tears over their misthological death can be expected from time to time by those suffering this misthological
fate.

 See Illustration 274. Statistical Basis for Kingdom/Kingship, 765.

 Compare the subsidiary nature in which it may be inferred that all resurrected believers will be unmarried in Lk 20:36. See
Misthological Worthiness, 73. The overall Lukan text is limited misthologically to those who are worthy of the resurrection, yet this

                                                        Chapter 25.
                                                         The Bride
                                                           Introduction
        Understandably, objections to the misthological understanding of the outer darkness may be due in part to
the typical understanding of the identity of the Bride of Christ. After all, if all believers compose the Bride, then
how can some of them be excluded from their own wedding banquet? The present work has assumed that the Bride
will not be composed of all believers. Preliminary reasons for this conclusion were derived from multiple avenues.
For example, only the faithful have the white garments, which appear to represent the wedding garments. If only
the faithful have wedding garments, then one would presume that only faithful believers make up the Bride. Only
faithful believers are allowed to the wedding feast. One would assume that those excluded from the wedding feast
are excluded from the wedding and cannot possibly be the Bride. The bridal imagery of Isaiah is applied to those
who clothe themselves in the practical righteousness that God offers (Is 61:10). A more thorough consideration
will be given in this present chapter concerning the nature and ramifications of the wedding garment to further
substantiate the conclusion that bridal arguments are no grounds for rejecting the misthological interpretation of the
outer darkness. The misthological options will be surveyed; then the most difficult text used to counter the bridal
position will be examined—Ephesians chapter five.

                                                            Garments
       The oil necessary to enter the wedding in Mt 25:9-10 is bought. The white garments are also bought
according to Rev 3:18. (The same Greek verb for buy is used in both verses—agorazo.) In Rev 3:18-21, the
believers are exhorted to buy the white clothing, open the door to Jesus, and overcome. The parallelism within the
verse would suggest that those who overcome are those who open the door by buying the offered items. They are
rewarded with white garments, which qualify them to eat and rule with Jesus.
                                      Illustration 190. The Internal Parallelism of Rev 3:18-21
                                               v. 18                          v. 20                   v. 21
            invitation:                        buy                          open door               overcome
              reward:                     white garments                     eat with               rule with

        The fact that believers are being addressed in Rev 3:18-21 is seen in that the exhortation addresses the
church, calls for works instead of faith, and warns of paternal discipline. As previously noted,* the word used for
disciple (paideuo) in Rev 3:19 is the word used in Heb 12:6-11 to prove sonship. It is used of God disciplining His
own children, not of God’s disciplining the devil’s children. The fact that believers are urged to open the door to
Jesus should not sound strange since in Eph 3:14-17 Paul prays that believers, who already were sealed with the
Spirit, would learn to experience the strength of being filled with the Spirit so that Christ may dwell in their hearts.
Paul wants these Spirit-sealed Christians to become Spirit-filled Christians. Only in this way will Christ be able to
dwell in their hearts in the manner in which Paul envisions. He wants these believers to have a special intimacy
with Christ, which he pictures as Christ dwelling in their hearts. Not all believers have this special dwelling—that
is, this special intimacy with Christ. Otherwise, there would be no need for Paul to pray that Christ would dwell in
the hearts of those who already are believers. This truth is expressed also by John (Jn 14:21-23). In these verses,
this special abiding experience with Jesus is dependent upon lovingly obeying Jesus. It is dependent upon works—
practical sanctification. Christians need to open the door of their hearts, so to speak, to Jesus so that they can
experience intimate dining with Jesus.
        Being dressed in these white garments is to be dressed in the imparted righteousness of readiness and
sanctification (cf. Lk 12:35), not merely the imputed righteousness of justification. The injunction to buy such
clothing is addressed to Christians as something they need to do. If Christians buy the clothing, open the door, and
overcome, they will be clothed with white garments, eat with Jesus, and rule with Jesus. As in Lk 22:28-30, eating
with Jesus is associated with ruling with Jesus. More significantly, for the present discussion, the white garments
are something Christians buy for themselves, and something with which they clothe themselves. The picture is not
that of the Lord clothing the believers, but of the believers clothing themselves.

    See Purpose and Recipients, 34.
