        Earlier in the context, in Rev 3:5 to be specific, the promise to overcomers was that they would be clothed in
white garments. To the English reader, this might appear to be saying that those being clothed are passive, but such
is not the case, however. The verb is in middle voice, or more specifically according to Wallace, it is a causative
middle: “The one who overcomes will cause himself to be clothed in white clothing.” And the direct middle is
used in Rev 3:18 meaning, “You clothe yourself.” Similarly, the reflexive active is employed in Rev 19:7 to say,
“His bride has prepared herself.”1015 (Terminology and emphases by Wallace.) These faithful believers who
overcome are the ones who are worthy to walk with the Lord in white; believers who subcome are not worthy. In
Rev 3:5, overcomers are promised white garments. In Rev 3:21, overcomers are promised they will rule with
Christ. To be promised white garments is equivalent, contextually, to being promised rulership in the kingdom. Not
only is the equivalence seen between wearing white garments and ruling, when comparing Rev 3:5 with Rev 3:21,
it is also evident in comparing Rev 3:18 with Rev 3:21. Those who are deemed worthy to wear white are those
believers who overcome. As a reward, they are granted rulership.
        Those who clothe themselves in white in Rev 3:18 are the overcomers who buy the clothing for themselves.
The clothing is provided, but it is not provided free of charge. It must be purchased by an overcoming lifestyle. The
same imagery is used in Rev 19:7. The Bride clothes herself in fine, bright, clean linen, which is equivalent to the
white garments. As expected, these garments are identified as her righteous works: “The marriage of the Lamb has
come and His bride has made herself ready. And it was given to her to clothe herself in fine linen, bright and clean;
for the fine linen is the righteous works of the saints” (Rev 19:7-8).
         Believers make themselves ready by dressing themselves in righteous works. This fine linen is not imputed
righteousness; it is imparted righteousness. Granted, only those who have imputed righteousness can progress to
the practical righteousness that is pictured by John. Still, this practical righteousness is not to be identified with
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                                   Page 567
righteousness that is freely given. It is composed of righteous works. As believers, if we want this type of
righteousness, then we must work for it. We are responsible to clothe ourselves with readiness, as Jesus
imperatively commands: “Be dressed in readiness, and keep your lamps alight” (Lk 12:35). If we want to be ready
for participation in the wedding, then we must clothe ourselves appropriately with works of righteousness. This
leads to an inescapable conclusion concerning the Bride. The Bride is composed of overcomers, not subcomers.
The major arguments used herein concerning the identity of the Bride are expressed in the syllogisms below. All
believers are betrothed to Christ (2Cor 11:2) and are in a position to become the Bride of Christ, but only
overcomers in practice will be qualified, on the basis of that practice, to proceed with the ceremony required to
become the actual Bride of Christ and consummate the marriage—they must put on the bridal dress of practical
sanctification.
                                             Illustration 192. The Identity of the Bride
          Syllogism 1
          Major Premise:        The Bride is clothed with white garments (Rev 19:7-8).
          Minor Premise:        Only overcomers are clothed with the white garments (Rev 3:4-5,18;16:15).
          Conclusion:           Therefore, the Bride is composed only of overcomers.

          Syllogism 2
          Major Premise:        The Bride is associated intimately with the city (Rev 21:2,9-10).
          Minor Premise:        Only overcomers are associated intimately with the city (Rev 3:12).
          Conclusion:           Therefore, the Bride is composed only of overcomers.

          Syllogism 3
          Major Premise:        The Bride is not excluded from the marriage feast.
          Minor Premise:        Subcomers are excluded from the marriage feast.
          Conclusion:           Therefore, the Bride is not composed of subcomers.

                                                         Interpretations
       Previous descriptions of misthological conservatives, moderates (i.e., classic moderates), and ultraists were
concerned primarily with the nature of the outer darkness itself.* Further refinement of the classifications will
permit increased precision in terminology, making greater detail possible in connection with the Bride of Christ
and related matters. Again, it must be kept in mind that the chart below is given for a quick reference and is a
generalization that paints the broad picture. Exceptions within each classification are possible as one examines the
writings of various authors within each camp.
                                         Illustration 193. Hermeneutical Spectrum Chart
                   1. Outer darkness             2. Rapture     3. Bride   4. Inherit        5. Entrance   6. Gehenna   7. Church
          1000 inside outside spatial partial full part all                    =    kingdom land city
                                                                           entrance
 T
 C
PM
CM
 U

              = general agreement;       = majority position;     = minority position;     = limited agreement
        T = Traditionalists; C = Conservatives; PM = Progressive Moderates; CM = Classical Moderates; U = Ultraists

Traditionalists (T)
       Traditionalists are those who in general believe that (1) the outer darkness is a soteriological concept rather
than a misthological one. The outer darkness is thought to be eternal rather than millennial and is thus not limited
to 1000 years. It is outside the kingdom and refers to spatial confinement in Gehenna/hell. (2) The rapture,

*
    See Misthological Interpretations, 446; Conservatives, 455; Moderates, 456; Ultraists, 457.
Page 568                                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
whenever it occurs, is full rather than partial. (3) The Bride is composed of all faithful believers. From the Puritan
perspective, this means that the Bride is made up of all genuine believers. From the Arminian point of view, this
means that all believers who endure in faith and faithfulness will compose the Bride. From both perspectives, those
believers who fail will go to hell. Thus, the Bride is a soteriological issue. (4) There is no difference between
inheriting and entering the kingdom. (5) Entrance into the kingdom, the land, and the city is based on grace. Thus,
entrance is not earned, even though only those who endure will be granted this supposedly free entrance.
(6) Gehenna is a place of eternal torment for unbelievers or false believers. And (7) the church is composed of all
NT believers.
       The next four rows on the chart depart from this exclusively soteriological view concerning one or more of
these seven areas to adopt a misthological perspective for that particular element. The misthological interpretations
are sub-grouped in the chart as conservative, progressive moderate, classical moderate, and ultraistic. This is not to
say that all authors can be compartmentalized neatly. Any given author may take positions from the various
categories. In general, many FG writers acknowledge that the outer darkness is a misthological result of the
Judgment Seat of Christ and thus applies (either exclusively or inclusively) to believers who are eternally secure.
However, they disagree among themselves as to the nature and duration of those misthological consequences, the
nature of the rapture, the composition of the Bride and the church, whether there is any distinction between
inheriting and entering the kingdom, and whether believers will spend time in Gehenna.

Conservatives (C)
       Of the various misthological views, conservatives are most closely aligned with the traditional
dispensational view. Conservative misthologists believe that (1) the outer darkness is a misthological concept,
though some of them seem to limit at least certain aspects of it to 1000 years. The outer darkness is inside the
kingdom and is experiential rather than spatial. (2) The rapture is full. (3) The Bride is composed of all believers.
(4) There is a difference between inheriting and entering the kingdom. Although not all conservative misthological
interpreters concur on this point, it is the general consensus. (5) Abundant entrance through the gates of the city is a
reward, but entrance into the city itself is available to all believers, including subcomers. (6) Gehenna is a place of
eternal torment for unbelievers. It is not a misthological concept. And (7) the church is composed of all NT
believers. Since conservative FG misthologists believe that the Bride is composed of all church-age believers, they
are consistent in affirming that the church is composed of both overcomers and subcomers.

Progressive Moderates (PM)
       When the broader misthological spectrum is taken into consideration, conservative moderates, (i.e.,
progressive moderates) may be regarded as the true moderates.* Progressive moderates believe that (1) the outer
darkness is a misthological concept, is inside the kingdom, and is spatial.† (2) The rapture is full. (3) The Bride
will be composed of only faithful believers. (4) There is a difference between inheriting and entering the
kingdom.‡ (5) Although all believers will enter the kingdom, entrance into the land and city are rewards limited
to overcomers. (6) Gehenna is a place of eternal torment for unbelievers.§ And (7) the church will be composed
only of faithful NT believers.

Classical Moderates (CM)
       Classical moderates believe that (1) the outer darkness is a misthological millennial concept, is outside the
kingdom, and is spatial. (2) The rapture is full. (3) The Bride is composed of only faithful believers. (4) There is a
difference between inheriting and entering the kingdom. (5) Gehenna is a place of eternal torment for unbelievers.


*
  See Outer Darkness Summation, 731.
†
  More precisely, PM asserts that the outer darkness is a metaphorical depiction of a spatial restriction. Thus, although the outer
darkness itself is metaphorical, the truth it pictures has spatial implications.
‡
  Some within PM (Progressive Moderation), such as Chitwood, would assert that the typical entrance texts are dealing with inheriting
the kingdom. Thus, they would not make a differentiation between inheriting and entering the kingdom in those passages.
Nevertheless, since they acknowledge that even those believers who fail to enter the kingdom in that misthological sense are still
within the kingdom, logically it must be inferred that they allow a distinction between soteriologically entering the kingdom and
misthologically inheriting the kingdom. After all, the only way to be soteriologically within the kingdom is to enter it soteriologically.
§
  PM does not necessarily deny that Gehenna may be applied metaphorically or correlatively to unfaithful believers. However, PM
rejects the view that unfaithful believers will be cast literally into metaphysical Gehenna. The literal metaphysical applicability of
Gehenna and/or the Lake of Fire is reserved for the lost.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                                         Page 569
And (6) the church will be composed only of faithful NT believers. When misthology is narrowly focused on
kingdom exclusion, this classical moderation may be regarded as a moderate view.*

Ultraists (U)
        Ultraists believe that (1) the outer darkness is a misthological concept, is outside the kingdom, and is
spatial. (2) Older writers from this point of view believed in a partial rapture, but more recent advocates may tend
to acknowledge a full rapture. (3) The Bride is composed of only faithful believers. (4) There is no difference
between inheriting and entering the kingdom. (5) Gehenna is a place of millennial torment for believers. In
ascribing the literal fires of Gehenna a misthological value, these interpreters take misthology to a rather extreme
position and for this reason are designated ultraists. And (6) the church will be composed only of faithful NT
believers.

Summation of Classifications
        Admittedly, from a certain point of view, the present work might be considered even more misthologically
extreme than the ultraistic position since the present work does not necessarily reduce the severity of the objective
misthological consequences over a period of time but rather attempts to be consistent in the application of
misthological principles to eternity future. This is mentioned in hopes that it will be understood that the term
ultraistic is not intended to be a derogatory remark against those who hold the position herein bearing that title.
        Using these simplistic definitions, it may be summarized that traditionalists generally believe the outer
darkness is soteriological and external, and that the inheritance is the same as the entrance. In contrast to
traditionalists, conservatives generally believe that the outer darkness is misthological and internal, and that the
inheritance is not equated with entrance. In contrast to conservatives, conservative moderates (i.e., progressive
moderates) generally believe that the outer darkness is spatial and the Bride is only composed of the faithful. In
contrast to conservative-moderates, classical moderates generally believe the outer darkness is external, the
inheritance is equivalent to entrance, and the church is composed of the faithful. In contrast to moderates, ultraists
generally believe that Gehenna is a place of millennial torment for the unfaithful.
        That not everyone falls into these neat little categories has been admitted already. The present writer does
not even completely fit any of his self-imposed categories above. Moreover, other variations not charted as well,
such as the conservative-ultraistic, neoclassical, or neo-ultraistic positions. Nevertheless, the categorization is a
helpful conceptualization of the big picture concerning the variations.1016

Spatial and Internal
        Conservatives and conservative-moderates believe that the outer darkness is an experience inside the
kingdom. Classical moderates and ultraists tend to believe that the outer darkness is a place outside the kingdom.
The position adopted herein is that the outer darkness is spatial, but this spatial limitation is to be understood
primarily in terms of what they are excluded from rather than what they are put into. All subcomers have spatial
limitations placed upon them in that they are not allowed into the land of Canaan nor into the New Jerusalem. The
spatial restrictions are probably much greater for some believers than for others. There will be degrees of
punishment expressed in terms of remoteness from the capital city in the outer darkness. Just as it is generally
acknowledged that there will be different degrees of punishment for unbelievers and different degrees of rewards
for overcomers, it is reasonable to postulate variations among positive and negative rewards administered to those
in the outer darkness. Indeed, some of those who rank the lowest in the outer darkness may experience rather
severe spatial restrictions, similar to what Carmical has described fictionally as the “Zone of Darkness” at the
South Pole.1017
        Although no subcomer will be allowed to rule in the kingdom, many subcomers probably will be able to
travel inside the kingdom but be excluded from the land of Canaan itself during the millennium and from the New
Jerusalem throughout eternity. Since they are outside the land and city and not allowed to rule, they are therefore in
the outer darkness spatially and experientially. If they are in the Heavenly Jerusalem before the Bema occurs, they
may be excluded (cast out) of it after the Bema (i.e., before the wedding ceremony commences on earth) and be
confined to live on earth outside the land of Canaan during the millennium. In other words, when the Heavenly
City lands on earth at the conclusion of the millennium and engulfs the land of Canaan, becoming the Promised


*
    See Illustration 150. Interpretations of the Outer Darkness, 457; Illustration 151. What is a Classic Moderate Misthologist? 458.
Page 570                                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
             *
Land itself, perhaps subcomers will be allowed to stand outside the city and look into their former habitation. This
conjecture is certainly not beyond the scope of possibility. Those who say that it is impossible for the outer
darkness to have literal or eternal consequences should give the matter further thought. Just as the king’s friend
was cast out of the feast after it already had started, so subcomers may be expelled from the Holy City to live on
Earth after the wedding starts.
        The spatial nature of the outer darkness would seem to be rather strongly affirmed by the parabolic detail
repeated all seven times where the phrase about weeping and gnashing teeth is used: “There [ekei], there will be
weeping and gnashing of teeth” (Mt 8:12; 13:42,50; 22:13; 24:51; 25:30; Lk 13:28) If Jesus simply had meant that
there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth (as the NKJ translates it), it is strange that He prefixed this experiential
there with a spatial there. This does not come across in translations such as the KJV and NKJ. The NAS does a
good job of bringing it out, however, typically by translating it each time as in that place there will be weeping and
gnashing of teeth or as it does in Lk 13:28 with both: there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth there. Even
conservatives acknowledge that when this identical phrase is used of the lost being cast into the furnace of fire, a
literal place with spatial restrictions is in view. The outer darkness should likewise be regarded as having spatial
restrictions and thus be accurately described as a place.

Full Rapture, Partial Bride
       In general, FG interpreters today believe in a full rapture. Conservative FG interpreters believe that the
Bride is composed of all believers. Other FG interpreters believe the Bride is composed of only the faithful elect.
All believers in the context of this discussion does not refer to the elect of all ages. For example, the chart does not
indicate that conservatives believe that tribulational believers will compose the Bride of Christ. They probably
would speak of the tribulational believers as being the bridal companions or guests in distinction to the believers of
the church age who actually compose the Bride. Thus, all on the chart means all believers of the church age.

Limited Entrance
        Concerning entrance into the kingdom, conservative interpreters distinguish between inheriting and
entering the kingdom. Ultraistic interpreters do not make this distinction. Ultraists may distinguish between being
an heir of God and a joint-heir with Christ, but ultraists generally do not distinguish between inheriting and
entering the kingdom.1018 They thus appeal to the inheritance passages to say that subcomers do not have any part
in the kingdom. Within ultraism, subcomers are not believed to enter the kingdom.
        On the one hand, the present author agrees with the conservatives that there is a distinction between
inheriting and entering the kingdom and that all believers will enter the millennial kingdom. On the other hand,
ultraistic exclusionists are correct, to a limited degree, in that not all aspects of the entrance are free. Subcomers
will be excluded from the land and the capital city. There will be numerous cities within the millennial kingdom.
For example, some overcomers will be put in charge over (i.e., rule over) ten cities in the millennial kingdom.
Conservatives may concede that subcomers will neither have residence in the New Jerusalem nor enter by the gates
into the city—since this type of entrance denotes honor. Even conservatives postulate that subcomers may have to
enter the New Jerusalem by the subway, for example, rather than by the gates. Thus, such conservatives appear to
believe in some possible type of spatial limitations for subcomers.
        Nevertheless, the position advocated herein is that subcomers will not enter the Heavenly Jerusalem during
the millennium in any capacity, nor will they be able to enter the New Jerusalem after the millennium. Subcomers
never enter the land of Canaan or Jerusalem during or after the millennium. However, Dillow’s conservative
interpretation is probably correct that entrance by the gates into the city does, in fact, denote a special entrance in
Rev 22:14.1019 In contradistinction to Dillow, though, the position taken herein is that after their expulsion
subcomers will never be allowed into the land of Canaan or city of Jerusalem, but their descendants will be allowed
into the land and city. This allows one to agree with Dillow that entrance by the gates may denote special honor.
These descendants will not have the special entrance denoted by entering through the gates into the city.†
        Nor is this the only manner in which entrance may be a reward. In general, entrance into the kingdom is free
and is distinguishable from inheritance of the kingdom. Nonetheless, this general rule of thumb is not intended to
be taken as an absolute tenet. Unfaithful believers will never enter certain places in the kingdom (e.g., the land of

*
  Although the common perception of New Jerusalem descending and landing upon New Earth during the eternal state is tentatively
adopted in the present volume, the second volume adopts the alternate perspective in which it is thought to remain in a stationary orbit
above the New Earth.
†
  See Gate Entrance, 653.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                         Page 571
Canaan and the New Jerusalem). Further, it is possible to view entrance into the kingdom (if one mistranslates it as
such) as a reward in certain contexts. According to one such biblical text, they were “strengthening the souls of the
disciples, encouraging them to continue in the faith, and saying, ‘Through many tribulations we must enter the
kingdom of God’” (Acts 14:22). Believers must endure tribulations and continue in the faith if they hope to enter
the kingdom in this verse. Thus, it is necessary to disagree with Dillow concerning this passage.1020 Contrary to his
assessment, enter appears equivalent to inherit in Acts 14:22. Nonetheless, this admission does not interpret
Acts 14:22 as referring to the kingdom as a place but to the kingdom as an experience, or more specifically, to an
experience within the kingdom.

                                             Misthological Entrance
       Witness Lee correctly notes that Jn 3:5 describes a soteriological entrance into the kingdom of God: “Jesus
answered, ‘Truly, truly, I say to you, unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter into the kingdom of
God.’” Yet he also takes Acts 14:22 as denoting a misthological entrance into the kingdom of God that is
equivalent to inheriting the kingdom.1021 However, in doing so he nullifies his distinction between the kingdom of
God and the kingdom of heaven.1022 What determines if the entrance is soteriological or misthological is not,
counter wise to Lee, whether it is described as entrance into the kingdom of God versus entrance into the kingdom
of heaven. On the contrary, the context and the meaning of the word kingdom (basileia) itself must be relied upon
to understand the two different types of entrances. Ramey, who takes a conservative misthological view of the
outer darkness, likewise finds the kingdom of heaven to be synonymous with the kingdom of God.1023
                              Illustration 194. The Kingdom of God = The Kingdom of Heaven
                                 Kingdom of Heaven                      Kingdom of God
                        1.    Mt 4:17                             Mk 1:15
                        2.    Mt 5:3                                                   Lk 6:20
                        3.    Mt 11:11                                                 Lk 7:28
                        4.    Mt 13:11                          Mk 4:11                Lk 8:10
                        5.    Mt 13:31                          Mk 4:30
                        6.    Mt 19:14                          Mk 10:1                Lk 18:16
                        7.    Mt 19:23                Mt 19:24; Mk 10:23               Lk 18:24

       The distinction between spatial and experiential entrances in the kingdom is not based on whether that
kingdom is described as being the kingdom of heaven versus the kingdom of God but on the nature of the Greek
word for kingdom. This distinction is difficult for the English reader to perceive since the translations generally
translate the Greek word basileia spatially as kingdom when, according to the BDAG, basileia can also be
translated experientially as kingship, rule, or reign. In fact, as was previously pointed out, this regal meaning is the
primary meaning.* Will all believers enter the basileia? Yes and no. All believers will enter the basileia in the
sense of enter the kingdom (a territorial entrance), but not all believers will enter the basileia in the sense of enter
the kingship. According to Acts 14:22, endurance is required for entrance into the kingdom. Although Paul does
say that we already have been transferred into the kingdom in Col 1:13, he is speaking there of an entrance into the
kingdom that already has been accomplished. Paul never speaks of entering the future form of kingdom on the
basis of faith. The future entrance into the kingdom of Acts 14:22 is based on works. Paul clearly equates the
nominal form of the kingdom with the verbal form of kingdom in 1Cor 15:24-25. The nominal form can have the
same meaning as the verbal form—rule. Kingdom can equal kingship. The implication is that future entrance into
His kingdom is associated with entrance into His future rule of earth. To enter into His kingdom in the future can
be equated with entering into His experience of ruling.
       Not all Christians will have that type of entrance into the kingdom. While Christians today principally think
of the kingdom as a place, Paul principally thinks of it as an experience. Those who endure will enter into the
kingdom (i.e., into experience of the king)—they will rule. The kingdom is the rule of the king—rulership. Only
overcomers will enter into His kingdom/rule in the sense of sharing in His kingdom/rule. Or to use the terminology
of Hebrews, overcomers will be partakers of His misthological rest; they will share this experience with Him.
Overcomers will not merely enter a place called His kingdom; they will also enter into His place = position =

*
    See Present—Future, 54.
Page 572                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
experience in the kingdom. They will enter positions of authority on thrones as kings. Their entrance into the
kingdom as kings will be markedly different from that of subcomers who enter the kingdom as its subjects. Since
kingdom is the noun form of the Greek verb rule, perhaps a better English equivalent for kingdom would be rule
since we can use rule as both a noun and verb in English. Endurance is necessary to enter His rule according to
Paul in Acts 14:22, and according to the writer of Hebrews, endurance is necessary to enter His rest. Both writers
are referring to the same experience of rulership. This regal experience cannot be entered into apart from
endurance.
       Paul’s meaning of enter the kingdom in Acts 14:22 is experiential—through many tribulations we must
enter into the kingship.1024 Only overcomers will enter into this rulership.* All believers will enter the kingdom,
but not all believers will enter the kingship. All believers will enter the rule, but not all believers will enter the
rulership. The same Greek word basileia is used to describe both entrances. Thus, in one sense all believers will
enter the kingdom (territory), but in another sense only some believers will enter the kingdom (kingship). In
addition to Pauline passages about inheriting the kingship (1Cor 6:9-10; 15:50; Gal 5:21; Eph 5:5; cp. Jam 2:5),
Paul also uses several other words in connection with the kingship—Acts 14:22 (enter the kingship); 1Thess 2:12
(worthy of the kingship); 2Thess 1:5 (worthy of the kingship); 2Tim 4:1 (exhorted in view of the judgment
associated with His kingship), 2Tim 4:18 (will be saved for His kingship). Salvation is not merely from hell; it is
for the kingship. Jesus also uses the noun basileia to denote the kingship of believers as well (Mt 5:3,10; 25:34;
Lk 6:20; 9:62; 12:32; 22:29). None of us are fit for the kingdom/basileia in terms of being fit for basic
soteriological entrance into the kingdom/basileia, but we can be fit for the kingdom/basileia in terms of being fit
for misthological entrance into the rulership/basileia.

                                           Spatial versus Experiential
       Therefore, to enter the kingdom in Acts 14:22 means to inherit the kingdom. There is no difference between
inheriting the kingdom and entering the kingdom in Acts 14:22, because the verse is talking about entering the
kingship (i.e., the rulership of the kingdom). The gospel writers, however, use the expression enter the kingdom to
denote entrance into a territory. As a result, when they use the expression enter the kingdom, it does not mean the
same thing as to inherit the kingdom. They use the expression enter into the kingdom in a manner similar to how
Paul uses the phrase transfer into His kingdom in Col 1:13. This transfer is positional, not experiential. All
believers already have been transferred positionally into His present, mystical (spiritual) kingdom.
       Ultraists do not necessarily deny the mystical, present form of the kingdom.1025 Also, they do not necessarily
deny that all believers enter into the present form of the kingdom.1026 Most importantly, they do not deny that all
believers enter into the eternal kingdom. What they do deny is that subcomers enter into the millennial kingdom.
Consequently, the chart (Illustration 193. Hermeneutical Spectrum Chart) indicates whether the interpreter
believes that entrance into the millennial manifestation of the kingdom is a reward for faithful believers. It does
not indicate that the interpreter believes that entrance into the present or eternal manifestation of the kingdom is a
reward. As to where unfaithful believers are located during the millennial manifestation of the kingdom, Panton
suggests four different possible locations where various believers who are excluded will be:1027

          1.   on the outside looking in, like Moses in a Mt. Pisgah typology;
          2.   Paradise in Hades;1028
          3.   the outer darkness;
          4.   the fire of Gehenna.1029

Gehenna
       Ultraists believe that some subcomers are thrown into Gehenna for 1000 years. Some of these interpreters
identify the outer darkness as Gehenna. The counter position taken in this book is that all believers already have
been transferred positionally into His (present) kingdom (Col 1:13) and will have a position/place in His
(millennial and eternal) kingdom.

Church
       In regard to the last category on the chart, some misthological interpreters believe that only overcomers will
ultimately compose the glorified church—to be in Christ does not necessarily put you in His glorified church. Even

*
    See Appendix 2. Kingdom and Kingship Entrance, 749; Acts 14:22, 849.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                            Page 573
conservatives appear to agree with this statement to a limited extent. The church of the first-born in Heb 12:23 is
not composed of subcomers. There are no subcomers in the church of the first-born. However, the chart does not
indicate this very limited agreement between conservatives and ultraists concerning the church. The question is not
really whether the church of the first-born refers exclusively to overcomers. Apparently, this fact is generally
accepted among misthological interpreters. The question is whether the church triumphant refers exclusively to
overcomers, and the chart represents the answer to this question.

                                           Conservative Appraisal of the Bride
        Hodges, Wilkin, and Dillow are among the primer representatives of the conservative view. Of course, the
designations of conservative versus ultraist are simply designations being implemented herein to give a frame of
reference for the major interpretations. All conservatives do not agree with each other on every detail, nor do all
ultraists. For example, the author’s own position is very radical in some areas but conservative in other aspects. In
a personal correspondence with Hodges in 1992, the present writer asked Hodges to summarize what he considered
to be weaknesses in the misthological understanding concerning the nature of the Bride.1030 The present writer
basically submitted the first and third syllogisms above* in favor of a misthological identification of the Bride, with
the statement that Eph 5:26 and 2Thess 2:13 would be best taken as references to sanctification salvation—that is,
progressive sanctification. Hodges disagreed with the analysis and gave an insightful response:

                 I do not believe one can build doctrine on symbolic material. Instead, symbolic material must
          be understood in terms of some explicitly taught truth. For example, co-heirship as a doctrine in no
          way depends on passages like Mt. 22:1-14. I thus demur at all strictly doctrinal materials drawn from
          symbolism alone. For example in your syllogisms, two possible objections emerge:
                The white garments of the church and of the overcomers are not necessarily identical since in
          one case a corporate concept is involved, and in the other an individual one. The white garment in
          ancient times signaled distinction and privilege. Such belong to individuals in one sense and to the
          Church as a whole in another.
                The marriage feast is equally an apt symbol for a time of joy and exultation. Must its every
          occurrence refer to exactly the same thing? As Rev. 17:9,10 show, even in the same passage a symbol
          can mean two things!
                In my judgment, in Eph. 5:26, it is improbable that “sanctification” and “having cleansed” refer
          to progressive sanctification. Both are aorists with no suggestion of process (though that is not ruled
          out by the aorists), so that a reference to the decisive events of 1 Cor. 6:11 seems much more natural.
                In my opinion, 2 Thess. 2:13 refers to the truth enunciated somewhat differently in Gal. 1:15.
          The “salvation” here is naturally taken to refer to exactly the same thing as it does in 1 Thess. 5:8-
          10—i.e., deliverance from the wrath of the day of the Lord. The fact that “sanctification” proceeds
          “belief of the truth” in [2 Thess] 2:13 puts this passage in the same category as 1 Peter 1:2 as well.1031
                Surely in Ephesians the church is identified as the body of Christ, but all believers are baptized
          into that [body] (1 Cor. 12:13). Indeed anyone who does not have the Spirit is not even a Christian
          (Rom. 8:9). In my judgment, the Lang-Govett school are guilty of an unprovable over-refinement in
          this area of doctrine. All symbolic texts can be construed conformably to clearly taught doctrine,
          unless premises are adopted that certain symbols must always mean this or that. In the absence of
          explicit teaching no case can stand, since the fluidity of figurative texts—even in Scripture—is easy
          to show. (Emphasis his.) 1032

       Hodges’ gracious response is deeply appreciated and gives concrete evidence that some of the keenest
minds in the FG camp are in full agreement with the standard theological position concerning the soteriological
identity of the Bride. Hodges is prudent to call for consideration of the context represented by the syllogisms.1033
The fact that unfaithful believers are thrown into the outer darkness does not in and of itself prove that the Bride is
composed only of overcomers. As interaction between FG interpreters hopefully increases, the conservatives will
certainly bring forth additional arguments for identifying the entire church as the Bride of Christ. Hopefully, the
present work will stimulate this discussion. But for now, my interaction will be primarily with the comments that
Hodges has made as I present the remainder of my case for bridal misthology—misthologically limiting the
realization of the eschatological Bride to experiential overcomers.

*
    See Illustration 192. The Identity of the Bride, 567.
Page 574                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
Symbolic and Parabolic Versus Doctrinal Material
        Hodges’ warning that doctrinal material should not be developed from symbolic material alone is sound
advice but must be tempered with the fact that Jesus taught in parables. “And He was teaching (didasko) them
many things in parables (parabole), and was saying to them in His teaching (didache)” (Mk 4:2). Jesus’
parabolic symbolism is didactic and thus conveys doctrine. In other words, Jesus taught in parables, so parables are
didactic. The negative Bema images and implications from Jesus’ parables should be kept in mind when reading
the related doctrinal material of the epistles. The parables and teaching of Jesus in the gospels form the background
for much of the doctrinal material of the epistles. The writers of the epistles knew that these negative images
metaphorically described the fate of unfaithful believers, so it is of no surprise that their writings likewise
doctrinally describe the fate of unfaithful believers in a negative manner and presume the broader implications of
their fate.
        Also, inductions based on the details of a parable naturally lead to deductions concerning the implications of
that parable. Further, the example Hodges gives concerning co-heirship illustrates the fact that it is necessary on
the basis of doctrinal material to divide believers misthologically into two different groups, with one group being
the subgroup of the other. One group is taken from the other group. Co-heirs are taken out of the larger group—
heirs. All believers are heirs, but not all believers are co-heirs. Yet co-heirs do not cease to be heirs just because
they become co-heirs. Or to state in Dillow’s terminology, all believers are heirs of God, but not all believers are
heirs of the kingdom. Heirs of the kingdom do not cease to be heirs of God. Likewise, my argument that the Bride
is taken out of the body of believers does not mean that the Bride ceases to be a part of that body. This observation
greatly weakens Hodges’ appeal to the body in Eph 5 in his attempt to identify the Bride as all of the body rather
than part of the body.

       Co-heirship is only one of many misthological doctrines that demonstrate that believers will be divided into
two different groups (one the subgroup of the other). One group is designated as children of God; the other as sons
indeed. Being a son indeed does not mean that one ceases to be a son in the more general sense. All believers will
participate in the resurrection for believers, but only some of those who participate in this general resurrection will
be chosen to participate in the out-resurrection. Those who participate in the out-resurrection are chosen out of
those who participate in the general resurrection. Participation in the out-resurrection does not mean that one
ceases to be a part of the group that experienced the general resurrection. Likewise, being a part of the separate
bridal body does not mean that we cease to be a part of Christ’s body.
        All believers enter the kingdom, but only some of those believers enter the rest. Being part of the body of
believers who enter the rest does not mean that one ceases to be part of the body of believers who enter the
kingdom. Becoming an overcomer in practice does not mean that one ceases to be an overcomer in position.
Overcomers in practice are a subset of those who are positional overcomers. God loves all His children
unconditionally. Yet those children who obey Him are also loved in an additional, conditional manner. Being loved
as an obedient child does not replace simply being loved as a child. It adds to that love rather than replaces it.
Misthological doctrinal material divides believers into two broad distinct groups, in which one group is taken out
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                         Page 575
of the other, but the subgroup does not cease to be a part of the main group. It is apparent from Hodges’ writings
that he would be in agreement with these subcategories on multiple other occasions, so I question whether
conservatives can be hermeneutically consistent in rejecting the bridal subcategorization.
       The identification of the Bride as a distinct body of believers taken out of the general body of believers
(while remaining a part of that general body) is homogeneous with doctrinal material and is thus not restricted to
symbolism. In point of fact, Dillow says that all believes are members of Christ’s mystical body but not all are
members of His visible body.1034 Granted, Dillow is not using the text eschatologically, but the point still remains
that Christ’s visible body is distinct from His invisible body, but His visible body is still a part of His invisible
body. Likewise, the Bride may be distinguished from His general body but still be considered a part of His general
body.

Corporate Versus Individual
       In response to Hodges’ comment about the corporate concept, it may be noted that the fact that a corporate
concept is involved in some passages (such as Rev 19:7-9, while an individual concept is involved in passages such
as Rev 3:4-5,18) does not establish that the white garments are not identical. Individual and corporate truths can be
indistinguishable. For example, many things that are positionally true of the corporate church are also true of
individuals within that corporation. Take imputational righteousness as a case in point. Individual members are
positionally righteous and so is the corporation they compose—the church. Thus, it is certainly not without biblical
precedence to say that what is true of the individual in many cases is also true of the corporation. In other words,
just as individual overcomers may be clothed in misthological white garments, so may be the bridal corporation
they compose.

Symbol’s Reference
        Although it is certainly true that a symbol does not always refer to the same thing in every passage, the
example given by Hodges in Rev 17:9-10 is not very helpful as a counter example. The text itself makes it very
clear that the seven heads are two different things in those two verses. But that is not the case in Rev 19:7-9.
Should we not interpret symbols in terms of previous references to those symbols unless there is strong evidence to
the contrary? John lays a foundation for our understanding of what the white garments are in Rev 3:4-5,18. These
exhortations are addressed to the corporate church and prove that not all within that particular corporation will
have these white garments. Much later in the book, in Rev 16:15, another exhortation is made concerning the white
garments, and it is very similar to the one made earlier in Rev 3:18. We then reach the climax in Rev 19:7-9 with
the expectation that these white garments are truly valuable, that they represent practical rather than positional
righteousness, and that they are only worn by some within the church. With these expectations, we reach Rev 19:7-
9 and find that the white garments are the bridal dress—a dress we ourselves make since it is composed of our
righteous works and thus represents practical righteousness. This dress determines whether we have made
ourselves ready. According to Lenham, the production of this garment took a lot of work on the part of the Bride:
“In the days when this was written, the bride literally made her wedding garment, putting many hours of hard work
into it. All Christians do not work for Christ, therefore all will not be the bride.”1035 The natural conclusion is that
the same garment is being described, and since it is worn only by overcomers within the church, the Bride is
composed only of those within the church who overcome. It all fits perfectly.
        Conservative interpreters, though, would seemingly have one believe that all within the church will wear
this dress. If that be the case, then what happens to all those earlier exhortations to overcome and thus keep our
garments white? Do they evaporate? Do we reach the climax only to be told that it really does not matter if we
overcome and keep our garments white since even subcomers are going to have white garments? Such a position
not only runs counter to the previous exhortations, it also encounters the difficulty expressed by the text itself in
having to argue that all the saints have clothed themselves with acts of practical righteousness. This is simply not
true, as Revelation chapters two and three demonstrate.
        In an attempt to avoid such an untenable position and yet maintain the conservative position concerning the
Bride, Dillow suggests “that the wedding garment…adorns the bride as a whole and not each individual saint
of which she is composed. Each saint makes various contributions (righteous acts) to the bride’s wedding garment,
and some may or may not make any at all.”1036 In an attempt to picture the Bride as composed of the entire church,
Dillow gives a picture that leads to the logical conclusion that the Bride will be half-naked! Considering the
proportion of carnal believers to spiritual believers, her bridal dress may look more like a white, string bikini!1037
“Bikini Believers at the Bema” might be a misthological possibility, as Radmacher’s sermon title suggests.1038 But
the notion of a bikini Bride is not biblically conceivable. If the wedding garment is to adorn the entire Bride but not
all of her members, as Dillow imagines, then her wedding dress is going to be mighty shabby indeed. John makes it
Page 576                                                                                        The Outer Darkness
clear in Rev 16:15 that only overcomers will keep their garments and that subcomers will lose their garments and
thus be shamefully naked—no bikini. In light of this passage and chapters two and three of Revelation, it would be
much better to simply accept the fact that the Bride is composed of only overcomers and thus has a beautiful dress
with all her members beautifully covered.
                                   Illustration 196. Conservative Bride of Christ




Bride ≠ All
       Dillow’s discussion of The Implied “All” is summarized and contrasted in the table below.1039 (Eph 5:27
and Rev 2:20; 11:18; 22:3 have been added to Dillow’s references.*) His discussion concerning the Bride is also
found in this otherwise excellent section. Dillow does well in his analysis of every verse in this section except
Rev 19:8, where he was inconsistent. If he had just applied the same statement to Rev 19:8 that he applied to
Heb 3:6, he would have achieved consistency by enunciating the same affirmation concerning the Bride: “Being
part of Christ’s bride is not automatic to all Christians. It is the intent, the ideal, but it is actual only in the
lives of those faithful Christians who persevere in holiness.”1040 This would have been an excellent observation,
if Dillow had also made it concerning the Bride. Yet Dillow could not make this statement concerning the Bride
because he holds to the view that the Bride is composed of all the saints. As stated above, he attempts to harmonize
*
    See Rulership, 529.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                            Page 577
this view with his discussion by claiming that the wedding garment adorns the entire Bride but not each individual
saint, since individual clothing is based on individual works of righteousness, and some may have none.
Accordingly, some saints may not make any contribution to the wedding garment and thus be unclothed. Dillow is
thus saying that the Bride as a whole will be composed of all saints—clothed and unclothed.

        In addition to picturing a practically naked Bride, Dillow’s argument fails to achieve consistency. For such
an interpretation to be convincing, apparently one would have to acknowledge that the wedding garment adorns the
Bride as a whole, and each member of which she is composed, and each saint makes contribution to the garment.
The result would then seem to be that all of the saints have clothed themselves appropriately. But this, in turn,
would contradict the warnings and exhortations in Revelation and Matthew. It would also contradict Pauline
theology since Paul indicates that not all believers will necessarily clothe themselves in the appropriate manner.
        As a result, conservative FG interpreters are on the horns of a dilemma concerning the Bride. They must
either sacrifice internal consistency within Rev 19:8 or external consistency with the warnings and exhortations.
However, there is no reason to sacrifice the consistency of Scripture on the matter. If one simply will acknowledge
(as Dillow has done elsewhere) that the actual must be distinguished from the ideal, then harmony is easily
demonstrated. Although it is the intent and ideal for the Bride to be composed of all the saints, such is not actually
the case—just as it is the intent and ideal for all believers to live victorious Spirit-filled lives, yet many do not.
Paul’s desire in 2Cor 11:2-3 is to present these believers as pure virgins, and yet he acknowledges that they may
lose their purity. How tragic it will be for betrothed believers who lose their virginity through indulgence in
worldly affairs. They will sacrifice the marital bliss that is intended for them. They will miss out on the special
intimacy of knowing Jesus in such a way that can only come to those who experience the fellowship of His
sufferings. This fellowship and friendship in the form of bridal intimacy cannot be obtained by those believers who
commit adultery in a love affair with the world.
         The part of Hodges’ letter dealing with 2Thess 2:13 already has been discussed in detail.* Hodges is correct
that it presents the same truth as 1Thess 5:9. But what is the exact meaning of that truth? In contrast to Hodges, the
position taken herein is that the word salvation in these passages is describing co-glorification salvation rather than
tribulational salvation. Salvation in terms of rulership in the millennial kingdom is at stake. Admittedly, Hodges is
correct to assert that the tribulational deliverance for all believers is affirmed. However, this is not how the
passages use the word salvation itself. I also agree with Hodges that 2Thess 2:13 is in the same category as
1Pet 1:2 but disagree as to the identification of that category. The sanctification in 2Thess 2:13 and 1Pet 1:2 is
*
    See Election in 1Thess 5:9 and 2Thess 2:13, 293.
Page 578                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
progressive sanctification rather than positional sanctification. Dillow’s discussion concerning these two verses and
Eph 1:4 was found superior. Eph 1:4 is referring to progressive sanctification. Thus, it presents a very strong
argument for considering the sanctification in Eph 5:26 as progressive sanctification, since the same expression
occurs in Eph 5:27. Not only is Eph 5:26 a reference to practical sanctification, it is likely that the water referred to
in Eph 5:26 is baptismal water required for practical sanctification.

Body
      As to the Pauline imagery concerning the body and the Bride, the principal text is Eph 5:23-33. The
conservative view is that the Bride is composed of the entire body (i.e., the entire church). Lang’s chapter, The
Body, represents his response to the conservative view.1041 He says that two general features must be kept in mind
when studying the Pauline use of the human body to illustrate communion with Christ:

                (a) Though worked out in much detail, [the figure body] is not primary or dominant in Paul’s
          letters. He uses the figures ‘temple,’ ‘betrothed virgin,’ and ‘bride’ both before, in connection [sic]
          with, and after that of ‘body.’ By some writers this balance has not been preserved and the figure
          ‘body’ has been over stressed.
                (b) The figure is not employed by the apostle to teach ecclesiastical or prophetical truth. Its use
          is confined to the present and practical relationship between Christ and His people.…It is misleading
          to argue from this figure about the constitution and discipline of the church or its future prospects at
          the coming of Christ.…Nor is there warrant for transferring the figure to heaven or the hereafter; its
          Pauline use concerns the present relationship between the Head and the members and His use of them
          in His affairs.1042

       Lang also subsequently goes on to deal with 1Cor 12:13 and to argue that not all believers are members of
Christ’s body. Yet I find it necessary to agree with Hodges rather than to accept Lang’s subsequent point
concerning the identity of the body in 1Cor 12:13. All members have been baptized by the Holy Spirit into the
body of Christ and are members of the body. As Hodges states, the body of Christ is composed of all believers.1043
Lenham, on the other hand, acknowledges that all members are members of Christ’s body, but then proceeds to
argue that the Bride is not synonymous with Christ’s body. Thus, no conflict needs to be supposed in limiting the
Bride to overcomers, while carnal believers are confined to the outer darkness.1044 In any event, a diversity of
opinion among bridal misthologists exists concerning the relationship of the Bride to the body.

                                                 Eschatological Bride
       Regarding Lang’s initial point, however, if Lang is correct that the figure of body only deals with the
present relationship between Christ and the church and does not deal with the eschatological relationship between
Christ and the church, then the conservative position has been well answered. Although Lang’s position concerning
the identity of the Bride is superior, his defense of that position is not particularly convincing.
       The identification of the Bride with the entire church rests principally upon Eph 5:25-27. The key doctrinal
point in understanding this passage is the nature of sanctification in Eph 5:26. Gromacki takes the view that it is
permanent sanctification (cf. 1Jn 3:2).1045 Hodges believes that it refers to positional sanctification and appeals to
1Cor 6:11 (cf. Tit 3:5). If the verse is referring to either positional or permanent sanctification, then (at least here in
Paul’s writing) the Bride is to be identified with the entire church. If that were the case, then it could be responded
that Paul and John are using the bridal imagery differently. Yet it appears best to understand Eph 5:26 as referring
to practical (i.e., progressive) sanctification. Regarding it as a reference to practical sanctification would be
consistent with the above interpretation of Eph 1:4 and 5:27 (as dealing with practical sanctification) and with
viewing the washing in Eph 5:26 (as a reference to water baptism—which is required for practical sanctification).
       Most importantly, the presentation in Eph 5:27 of believers as holy and blameless is futuristic and dependent
upon their walk, and thus dependent upon practical holiness. Commendably, Bond (GNTC) acknowledges that
Paul may be speaking of the JSC and the conditional necessity of practical righteousness in order to be presented in
this manner in view of Col 1:21-23. This is the goal, not guaranteed result. Bond also appropriately interprets Eph
5:26 as dealing with practical sanctification. Perhaps even conservative misthologists are waking up to the
possibility of bridal misthology. In any event, the following illustration of this phrase holy and blameless and its
related texts will be explained both in the ensuing discussion which immediately follows and the overview.*

*
    See Eph 5:27, 585.
Page 579




                        Illustration 198. Holy and Blameless
Chapter 25. The Bride
Page 580                                                                                            The Outer Darkness
                                   Eschatological Presentation of the Bride
        In Col 1:18-23, Paul again speaks in terms of Christ being the head of His body (Col 1:18), just as he does
in Eph 5:23. Then Paul proceeds to talk about a futuristic presentation of this body to Christ as holy and blameless
in Col 1:22, just as he does in Eph 5:27. But in Col 1:23 Paul makes it very clear that the requirement for being
presented in this manner is practical holiness.* We will be presented in this way if, and only if, we are faithful.
Thus, the presentation in this manner is limited to the faithful elect. The unfaithful elect will not be presented in
this manner. Consequently, it is best to interpret the unclear symbolism in Eph 5 in light of the clear
doctrinal statements in Col 1 with the result that only those who are faithful will be presented in the future
as the Bride of Christ. As Lang says, “The church does not become the ‘bride’ prior to the rapture. It is only at the
time of the wedding itself that a betrothed maiden becomes a bride.”1046
        Christ’s desire, as Paul records it in Eph 5:27, is the same as Paul’s own desire in 2Cor 11:2, which is to
present the betrothed virgin to Christ as holy, blameless, and pure. However, as Paul indicates in 2Cor 11:3, there
is a danger that he may not be able to do so; it depends upon their faithfulness. Paul uses the same Greek verb
paristemi for the presentation in all three verses (Eph 5:27; Col 1:22; 2Cor 11:2).
        Paul only uses paristemi once more in the book of Colossians, and he uses it in this very context (Col 1:28).
In this verse he also uses it to refer to an eschatological presentation that requires diligent labor in the present time
period. In the book of 2 Corinthians, he also uses the verb on one other occasion—that is, in 2Cor 4:14. Again, it
refers to an eschatological presentation. All believers will be presented to the Lord, as Paul says in Rom 14:10,
where he uses this verb to say that all believers will be presented at the JSC. Yet not all believers will be presented
as holy, blameless, and pure. We must all stand before God at the JSC, but we will not all stand misthologically
holy, blameless, and pure before Him there. To be able to stand before God misthologically approved, we must be
experientially pure. Otherwise, we will not have the strength to stand when presented before the Lord (Lk 21:36)
but will shrink away in shame (1Jn 2:28).
        For this reason, Paul urges the Corinthians in 2Cor 4:16-17 not to lose heart but to be faithful in the midst of
their afflictions so that they may receive “an eternal weight of glory” as a result of the presentation that he
mentioned in 2Cor 4:14. He states that this reward of glory will be eternal in both v. 17 and v. 18. Thus, the results
of this presentation are not limited to the millennium. The presentation is eschatological, misthological, and
eternal. The same is true concerning Paul’s use of paristemi in 2Tim 2:15, where he urges Timothy: “Be diligent to
present yourself approved to God as a workman who does not need to be ashamed, handling accurately the word of
truth.” Paul then goes on to say that this misthological approval, in terms of honor versus dishonor, is dependent
upon Timothy’s cleansing himself in practical sanctification (2Tim 2:20-21). Therefore, the reason I must disagree
with Lang’s position concerning Paul’s use of the bridal/body imagery in Eph 5 is because the presentation is
indeed eschatological—it concerns the future. Similarly, the reason it is necessary to disagree with Hodges’
position, concerning Paul’s use of the bridal/body imagery in Eph 5, is because the presentation is misthological—
it is associated with rewards.

                                                    Bridal Body
        Granted, Hodges is accurate when he says, “In Ephesians the church is identified as the body of Christ, but
all believers are baptized into that [body] (1 Cor. 12:13).” But this oversimplification of the Pauline imagery is the
key to the problem. In 1Cor 12:12-31, Paul uses the imagery of believers composing the actual members of
Christ’s body—that is, His feet, hands, ears, and eyes. In Col 2:19, Paul uses the imagery of believers forming the
joints and ligaments of Christ’s body. Paul is also thinking in terms of this same imagery in Eph 1:23; 2:16; and
4:4,12,16, as is demonstrated by his reference to believers being the ligaments of Christ’s body (4:16). Howbeit,
when Paul reaches Eph 5:22-33, he adds an additional dimension to the manner in which we are Christ’s body. One
cannot marry one’s own body. One cannot marry one’s hand or eye. There must be another dimension to Paul’s
thought.

Two Bodies
        Paul’s previous references to the body are reminiscent of Adam’s body. His body had feet, hands, ears, eyes,
joints, and ligaments. But this was not the only dimension of Adam’s body; Eve was also Adam’s body—his bridal
body. Paul is extremely clear about this matter in 1Cor 6:15-16, where he makes being one flesh sexually with
another person equivalent to being one body with that person. This Pauline concept of one flesh being one body
must be kept in mind when studying Eph 5. In Eph 5:23,30, when Paul says that we are Christ’s body, he is
*
    See Misthological Sinlessness, 772. Also see “Conditional Blamelessness” in Trichotomy.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                        Page 581
intending for us to understand the dual sense in which this is true. We are members of Christ’s body corresponding
to Adam, and we are members of His bridal body corresponding to Eve. For the sake of simplicity, the distinction
between the dual aspects in which we are Christ’s body will be referred to as His federal and bridal body.
                                         Illustration 199. Two Bodies in One




       All believers are members of Christ’s federal body. However, what is the exact relationship of His federal
body to His bridal body in regards to the church? Is the church composed of both bodies? Wilson has well said
concerning the body,

       Christ has two spiritual bodies. Body number one is made up of all of the Christians. Body number
       two is His bride, which—though taken out of His body—nonetheless is also His body.…
            Possibly the key to understanding the body and the bride of Christ is to be found in the fact that
       the body of Christ is composed of all of the Christians of the New Testament; whereas the bride of
       Christ is made up of the obedient, faithful, fruitful, sanctified Christians from among those who
       constitute the body. Therefore, in a real, literal, Scriptural sense, the church of Christ is both body
       and bride of Christ.1047

Nevertheless, Wilson’s understanding of the relationship of the body to the church leaves something to be desired
when he says,

       The church is His body (Eph. 5:23, 30-32)—more specifically members of His body—so that it does
       not say that the church is the complete body of Christ but only a part of the body. The church is that
       part of the body of Christ which is called out and separated from the body and constitutes the body of
       Christ. Instead of the church being called out of the world, she is called out of the family of God. One
       common error in teaching is that every Christian from Pentecost to the Rapture is a member of the
       church and constitutes the bride of Christ. The truth of the matter is, the church constitutes a very
       small portion of the saved between Pentecost and the Rapture.1048

       Wilson’s comments on two matters must be rejected. (1) Contrary to Wilson, the church presently is
composed of all believers, not just part of them in this present time period between Pentecost and the rapture.
(2) Further, the church is not only called out of the family of God; it is also called out of the world. A problem with
the views advanced by both Hodges and Wilson is that they seem to treat the passage one-dimensionally. Hodges
appears to make no real distinction between the federal body and bridal body, which results in a one-dimensional
view. Wilson, on the other hand, makes a distinction between the federal and bridal body but then views Eph 5:22-
Page 582                                                                                              The Outer Darkness
33 exclusively in terms of the bridal body, which also results in a one-dimensional view. Govett’s statement is
better: “Christ’s present love for the Church as His Body, shall take the final form of love for the Church as His
Bride.”1049 Even so, his affirmation leaves the question unanswered as to whether the federal and bridal bodies are
currently distinct, and it also fails to deal with the related question as to whether the federal body still will be
considered the church in the future. Whipple achieves greater specificity when he says:

          Contrary to that which teachers have taught previously, the body of Christ and the church are not the
          same throughout eternity. But rather, the church is taken out of the body of Christ at the Judgment
          Seat of Christ, forming two bodies. This in no way corrupts the scriptural teaching that the body is
          one, as taught in Ephesians 4:4. For both bodies are still the one invisible body of Christ in this
          present time, is [Sic] but one body and is [Sic] called the church. However, at the Judgment Seat of
          Christ, this body will become two visible bodies, when God calls-out (GR. ‘eklektos”) of this body,
          the church. The very word ‘church’ itself means an out-calling (Gr. ‘ekklesia’), or those who have
          been called out of the called.…Therefore, as Adam had two bodies, (Gen. 5:2), so will Christ have
          two bodies, one called out, or taken out of the other. The first body of Christ is made up of all the
          saved who were judicially placed in Christ on the cross through faith. The second body of Christ, will
          be made up from a portion of the first, and called out at the Judgment Seat of Christ. At this stage, the
          name of this second body is the “called-out ones,” i.e. the church (Gr. ‘ekklesia’), or the “bride of
          Christ.” (Emphasis his.)1050

       Whipple’s above comment concerning the identity of the Bride and church should be accepted for a variety
of reasons. First, the use of the bridal garments in Revelation identifies overcomers as the Bride. As Roadhouse
says, “The personnel of the Bride, throughout Revelation, is limited to the Overcomers.”1051 “The uniform usage in
this book [Revelation] is that the ‘fine linen’, when pertaining to a believer, is that of the Overcomer saint. It is
personal righteousness” (both emphases his).1052 Second, the position that only overcomers join in the wedding
celebration is supported by the Matthean texts. Third, the intimate association of overcomers with the city and the
intimate association of the Bride with the city indicate that the Bride is composed exclusively of overcomers.
                                           Illustration 200. The Post-Temporal Church

        Fourth, the parallelism of ekklesia with eklektos should not be ignored. Both mean the out-called, that is,
called out of the called. These two words seem to indicate that all the elect currently compose the church, but only
the faithful elect ultimately will compose the church. The noun for church is ekklesia, which is the word called plus
the Greek prefix ek meaning out. As has been demonstrated already, pre-temporal election does not guarantee post-
temporal election.* Many are called, but few are chosen (i.e., few are out-called, i.e., few are called out of those
called). Being a member of the pre-temporal and temporal out-calling (ekklesia and eklektos) does not guarantee

*
    See Part 1. Chapter 7. Election and Predestination.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                          Page 583
being part of the post-temporal out-calling. Thus, although all believers are currently part of the church in this
temporal time period, they will not all be part of it in the post-temporal period.
        Fifth, the parallelism of ekklesia, out-called, with the out-resurrection also reinforces the idea that the
church ultimately will be a subset of believers. All believers are members of the church and will experience the
resurrection at the rapture, but not all believers will qualify for the out-resurrection and the out-calling that follows
the rapture.
        Sixth, the restricted meaning of church of the firstborn in Heb 12:23 demonstrates that the word church can
indeed be used misthologically to refer to only some believers—that is, the faithful. Seventh, the futuristic
restricted meaning of church in Eph 5:26 also argues for understanding the church as referring to overcomers.
Eighth, the dual manner in which we are Christ’s body corresponds to the typological manner in which Eve was
composed of part of Adam’s body but not all of his body.

Body Typology
        This union between Adam and Eve is the original type in reference to what it means to be Christ’s body.
Adam’s body was formed out of the world’s dust, yet his body did not cease to be dust as is pointed out in the
expression dust to dust. Christ’s body was also formed out of world’s humanity but did not cease to be human. We
are still human beings even though we compose His federal body. Similarly, the church was first formed out of the
world as a federal body, which corresponds to the formation of Adam’s body out of dust. Next, the bridal body of
the church will be composed out of the federal body of the church, just as Eve’s body was formed out of Adam’s
body.
                                          Illustration 201. Topological Bodies
