       After Adam’s body was formed out of the world’s dust, Adam’s bride was taken from Adam’s body (i.e.,
from only part of his body), but she was still his body. Although she was a separate body, she did not cease to be
his body. It must be remembered that Adam and Eve were two distinct beings yet one flesh—that is, one body. The
bride was taken from Adam’s body and yet remained his body. In similar fashion, the first phase of the formation
of Christ’s Bride was the formation of His own body out of the world—the federal body (which corresponds to
Adam’s body being formed out of the earth). Christ’s federal body, the church, is currently composed of all
believers. The next stage in the formation of Christ’s Bride will be the formation of the bridal body itself by taking
members out of the first body, just as Eve was taken out of Adam’s body. Therefore, the church ultimately will be
composed of those not only taken out of the world but also subsequently taken out of that body of believers to form
the Bride, just as Eve was ultimately composed of the dust not taken directly from the world; rather, her body was
formed subsequently out of the dust that was used to compose Adam’s body.
Page 584                                                                                          The Outer Darkness
       God prepared a body (Adam/church) before He could prepare a bride for that body (Eve/bride) from the
original body. Why did God not make Adam and Eve at the same time? Evidently, one reason the Lord did not
make them synchronously was to use them typologically to foreshadow the relationship between Christ and the
church. The aspect of this typology that gets the most attention today is the area of submission. According to Paul,
women are to be submissive to their husbands due to the creation order and due to their typological representation
of the church (Eph 5:22-24; 1Tim 2:13). Yet the significance of this typological representation is not exhausted by
the topic of submission. It also represents sequential subcategorization.
       This original bridal typology is also represented in other types. As Chitwood points out concerning
Rebekah, “The bride for Isaac was to be taken only from the family of Abraham, as the bride for Christ is to be
taken only from the family of God.…Abraham made his servant swear…that the bride which he obtained for Isaac
would be taken only from the family in the far country” (Gen 24:3-9; emphasis his).1053 A bride is taken from her
family to marry her husband. The groom does not marry the bride’s family; he marries a woman from that family.
In relation to Christ’s Bride, this means that the Bride’s family are her fellow believers. Christ does not marry the
Bride’s family (composed of all believers), but only the Bride herself (composed of faithful believers taken from
within that family of believers—the Bride’s brothers and sisters). Having looked at the imagery and some of the
key concepts in Eph 5:23-33, a verse-by-verse overview is now in order.

                                           Overview of Eph 5:22-33

Eph 5:22-24
      Wives, be subject to your own husbands, as to the Lord. 23For the husband is the head of the wife, as
      Christ also is the head of the church, He Himself being the Savior of the body. 24But as the church is
      subject to Christ, so also the wives ought to be to their husbands in everything.

        Christ is currently the organic head of His federal body the church. The church is subject to its federal head
(as in Col 1:18). As Adam was the head of his body, so Christ is the head of His body. However, Adam was the not
only the head of his own personal body; he was also head of his bridal body, Eve. The reason is simple enough.
Adam was the head of his body, and Eve did not cease to be Adam’s body. As his wife, Eve was still one flesh
(i.e., one body) with Adam. Consequently, Adam was the head of Eve’s body because he was the head of his body.
Being head of his body made him head of her body since they were one body. Verse 24 shows the premarital
subjection of the church as the federal body and intended Bride.

Eph 5:25
      Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ also loved the church and gave Himself up for her.

       Eve was formed out of Adam’s body, but she remained his body, and she was loved as his body. So also
Christ loves the church (i.e., His bridal body), which is formed out of His federal body. Verse 25 shows the
premarital sacrifice of Christ for His intended Bride.

Eph 5:26
      That He might sanctify her, having cleansed her by the washing of water with the word.

       For the reasons already presented in this chapter, it is necessary to agree with Walvoord rather than with
Hodges that the sanctification in view is practical sanctification. This sanctification is associated with Christ’s
present work in us, rather than with the positional sanctification associated with our justification. Premarital
sanctification is in view. Walvoord does well in his connection of this passage with that of Revelation. The
reference to the fine linen of the Bride in Rev 19:8

      seems to be not to justification by faith but rather to the righteousness wrought in the lives of the
      saints who comprise the wife of the Lamb.…In Ephesians 5:26-27 Christ is said to be carrying on a
      present work with His church…with a view to the future presentation in glory…The present work of
      sanctification of the church must be distinguished from justification.…The righteousness thus
      wrought in the life of the believer is pictured here as the fine linen which adorns the wife of the
      Lamb.…The fine linen may, in some sense, be a part of the reward given at the judgment seat of
      Christ to those who have served the Lord, here seen collectively in the wife of the Lamb.1054
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                         Page 585
        Although the aorist tense is used for sanctify (hagiazo) and cleansed (katharizo), as Hodges points out, this
premarital sanctification is represented as a bridal bath. Nevertheless, the fact that Paul uses loutron (bath) to
picture the washing of regeneration in Tit 3:5 by no means proves that he is using it to refer to regeneration here in
Eph 5:26, when he refers to it as a washing of water. Paul is simply talking about a bridal bath, and loutron is the
word for bath. As to the fact that Paul uses the aorist tense to describe it, note that the aorist tense also is used to
describe water baptism in Mk 16:16.1055 The prenuptial washing of practical sanctification is pictured by water
baptism and is misthologically necessary for the consummation of the marriage. Since this sanctification is
accomplished pictorially through water baptism, the aorist tense is referring to practical rather than positional
sanctification.
        Pauline usage itself (of the aorist tense in regard to these two verbs) could suggest practical sanctification.
He uses the aorist optative for sanctify in hopes of misthological blamelessness: “Now may the God of peace
Himself sanctify you completely; and may your whole spirit, soul, and body be preserved blameless at the coming
of our Lord Jesus Christ.” (1Thess 5:23). Concerning a promise of misthological sonship (2Cor 6:18), Paul uses the
aorist subjunctive in the next verse to exhort: “Therefore, having these promises, beloved, let us cleanse
[katharizo] ourselves from all defilement of flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God” (2Cor 7:1).
        The use of the aorist subjunctive in a similar passage by Paul may also be noted: “Therefore, if a man
cleanses [ekkathairo] himself from these things, he will be a vessel for honor, sanctified, useful to the Master,
prepared for every good work” (2Tim 2:21). The aorist imperative is used of practical sanctification in 2Cor 5:7,
“Clean out [ekkathairo] the old leaven, that you may be a new lump.”
        The only other use of this verb (katharizo) by Paul, aside from 2Cor 7:1 and Eph 5:26, is likewise an aorist
subjunctive: “Who gave Himself for us, that He might redeem us from every lawless deed and purify for Himself a
people for His own possession, zealous for good deeds” (Tit 2:14). We have been redeemed from sin and cleansed
for good works. Certainly, we have grounds for suspecting that this cleansing for good works refers to practical
sanctification. We are not only saved from something negative; we are saved for something positive.
        Indeed, it is difficult not to think of the intriguing viticultural imagery explained by Derickson and
Radmacher concerning a seemingly related passage: “Every branch that bears fruit, He cleanses [kathairo] it, so
that it may bear more fruit” (Jn 15:2; TM). Like Paul in Eph 5:26, John attributes this cleansing to the
instrumentality of the word (Jn 15:3). The cleaning (or purging, KJV) was in the spring (Jn 15:2), but the pruning,
on the other hand, was not done until later in the fall (Jn 15:6).
        Derickson and Radmacher mount a convincing argument that kathairo in Jn 15:2 must refer to the Lord’s
spring cleaning and is connected with being completely clean (katharos) in Jn 13:10. Indeed, they cite Eph 5:25-27
as also teaching this truth and then explain the full significance of this cleansing: “The cleansing to which Jesus
alludes should not be seen as the believer’s cleansing from the penalty of sin that occurs at the time of the new
birth (cf. John 13:10). This is not justification truth. Rather, this cleansing is a sanctification truth.”1056
        The sanctification washing denoted by nipto in Jn 13:8,10 also uses the punctiliar aorist. Jesus told Peter: “If
I do not wash you, you have no part [meros] with Me.” Wash in Jn 13:8 is an aorist subjective as is sanctify in
Eph 5:26. Given the post-regenerational nature of the washing on the one hand, the sanctifying nature of the
washing on the other hand, the use the of same verbal tense, and that the condition is explicit in the former and
implicit in the latter, it is deduced that those believers who do not submit themselves to this post-regenerational
washing of practical sanctification will not be a part of the Bride of Christ.

Eph 5:27
      That He might present to Himself the church in all her glory, having no spot or wrinkle or any such
      thing; but that she should be holy and blameless.

       Although this presenting (paristemi) discussed above is the intended goal for all believers, it will only be
realized for some believers—those who experience the glory of ruling with Christ, that is, co-glorification
salvation. Just as all believers do not necessarily respond to the cleansing of the word in Jn 15:2-3, to go on to
become fruitful believers or completely clean (Jn 13:10), so all believers do not necessarily submit themselves to
the Lord’s cleansing word in Pauline theology. Those believers who submit to practical sanctification will be pure
and spotless, and thus holy and blameless. The fact that this holiness is experiential rather than positional is
demonstrated by the word with which it is paired—blameless. The combination of these two words in the phrase
holy and blameless occurs only three times in the NT.*

*
    See Illustration 198. Holy and Blameless, 579.
Page 586                                                                                           The Outer Darkness
       This combination of holy (hagios) and blameless (amomos) occurs in Eph 1:4; 5:27; and in its parallel
passage in Col 1:22. The similar occurrence in 1Thess 3:12-13 is a conceptual parallel. The experiential nature of
the references in Eph 1:4 and 5:27 are debatable. However, the parallel in Col 1:22 is very clearly referring to
experiential holiness that is contingent upon our practice, as Col 1:23 makes clear. Hodges gives an excellent
discussion of this verse and word,

       Words like “holy,” “blameless,” and “above reproach” do not require the sense of “sinless” or
       “absolutely perfect.” Men can be described in all these ways who are not completely sinless.…A
       comparison of Colossians 1:22 with 1:28 is also helpful.…This statement [in 1:28] is connected by
       the presence of the special word “present.” But here Paul employs the word “perfect” which is the
       normal Greek word for mature….Obviously this word also does not have to suggest sinless
       perfection. It is natural, therefore, to see 1:22 and 1:28 as slightly different forms of the same idea.
       The aim of Christ’s reconciling work at the cross is the aim Paul serves by his teaching ministry. He
       seeks to bring men to that matured experience of holiness which will enable them to be presented
       acceptably to God….He is saying, then, that the Colossians will never reach maturity in holiness if
       they listen to the wrong voices. In that event, they could not be presented to God in a spiritual
       state which truly fulfilled the aims of the cross. Their lives would be open to His censure.1057

       Hodges has well articulated the meaning of being presented blamelessly to Christ in Col 1:22, where he
accurately states that not all Christians will be presented in this manner. Consequently, if all believers are not
presented blamelessly in Col 1:22, why assume the opposite in Eph 5:27? Why assume that all believers are
presented blamelessly in Eph 5:27, when only some believers will be so presented in Col 1:22? The Greek word
translated as blameless is amomos. In addition to its three occurrences with holiness in Eph 1:4, 5:27, Col 1:22, the
only other time it occurs in Paul’s writings is in Phil 2:15. The NKJ translates this as:

       Do all things without complaining and disputing, that you may become blameless [amemptos] and
       harmless [akeraios], children of God without fault [amomos] in the midst of a crooked and perverse
       generation, among whom you shine as lights in the world, holding fast the word of life, so that I may
       rejoice in the day of Christ that I have not run in vain or labored in vain. (Phil 2:14-16)

        In this passage, being blameless is based on what we do; it refers to practical holiness. It is associated with
letting our light shine and holding fast to the word. Blamelessness is not guaranteed. Like John, Paul looks forward
to receiving a full reward in the Day of Christ—if his converts hold fast and become all that they can be in the
army of Christ (2Jn 1:8). This potential blamelessness “in the day of Christ” was also used by Paul earlier in this
epistle to urge believers: “Approve the things that are excellent, in order that you may be found pure and blameless
[aproskopos] in the day of Christ” (Phil 1:10; TM). By godly behavior (cp. Phil 1:11), they are urged to become
experientially blameless now, in anticipation of the Day of Christ, so that when that day arrives they may be found
misthologically blameless at the Bema. They are to become blameless by allowing God to perfect His work in
them “until the day of Christ” (Phil 1:6) so that they may be found blameless “in the day of Christ” (Phil 1:10;
2:16).1058 This word amemptos, translated as blameless in 2:15 and associated with amomos (which is also
translatable as blameless), is used by Paul in 1Thess 3:13 in connection with holiness, where the NKJ again
translates it as blameless: “And may the Lord make you increase and abound in love to one another and to all, just
as we do to you, so that He may establish your hearts blameless [amemptos] in holiness before our God and Father
at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ with all His saints” (1Thess 3:12-13; NKJ).
        This blamelessness and holiness is eschatological and is dependent upon loving one another. Peter likewise
urges believers to be eschatologically blameless in 2Pet 3:14. The word translated as harmless [akeraios] in
Phil 2:15 is also used by Paul in Rom 16:19 to refer to experiential purity.
        Paul’s use of blameless (amomos) to refer to practical holiness is in harmony with the usage by the other NT
writers as well. John uses this word in Rev 14:4-5 to describe those who keep themselves chaste and do not lie—
experiential holiness. Jude employs it to refer to being eschatologically blameless (Jude 1:24). Even Wilkin, a
misthologically conservative interpreter, acknowledges that the blamelessness in Jude 1:24 is conditional and refers
“to an experience which is not sinless but which is yet pleasing to God since it reflects faithfulness to Him.”1059
Doskocil (GNTC) concurs. The same idea is probably reflected in Heb 9:28, concerning which even Hodges
himself states:
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                        Page 587
       The author implied that ‘those who are waiting for Him’ constitute a smaller circle than those whom
       His death has benefited. They are as all his previous exhortations reveal, the ones who ‘hold firmly
       till the end the confidence we had at first’ (3:14). The ‘salvation’ He will bring them at His second
       coming will be the ‘eternal inheritance’ of which they are heirs.1060

       Those who experience this blameless co-glorification salvation without reference to sin are a “smaller
circle” than those who have been benefited by justification. Likewise, it should be concluded that the smaller circle
of believers (i.e., overcomers) who compose this group is the same group that composes the Bride. The Bride is
composed of this smaller circle of believers—the Bride is a subgroup of believers.
       The word translated beyond reproach (anegkletos) in Col 1:22 reflects the same idea and is also found in
1Tim 3:10 and Tit 1:6-7. As believers we should be and can be blameless, but we may not be. Paul also uses the
word aproskopos in Phil 1:10, where he prays that believers will be blameless in the Day of Christ. Accordingly,
this eschatological blamelessness is dependent upon their love.

Eph 5:28-33
      So husbands ought also to love their own wives as their own bodies. He who loves his own wife
      loves himself; 29for no one ever hated his own flesh, but nourishes and cherishes it, just as Christ also
      does the church, 30because we are members of His body. 31For this cause a man shall leave his father
      and mother, and shall cleave to his wife; and the two shall become one flesh. 32This mystery is great;
      but I am speaking with reference to Christ and the church. 33Nevertheless let each individual among
      you also love his own wife even as himself; and let the wife see to it that she respect her husband.

        Christ loves His bridal body—the church. Although we are currently waiting to be presented to Him and
have not yet been consummated as His Bride, nevertheless, we already are legally married to Him. We already are
betrothed to Christ. A man may go to great lengths on behalf of the bride to whom he is betrothed. Joseph certainly
did on Mary’s behalf. All genuine members of the church are currently members of His federal body, and Christ
loves us as such. However, these members of His body do not cease to be His body just because some of them
form the Bride (cf. Eph 5:30). These members of His bridal body are still one flesh (i.e., one body) with those who
compose His federal body. Adam’s rib did not cease to be one flesh with him, even though it was separated from
the other members of his body. The reason his rib did not cease to be a part of his body is because it was given
back to him in the form of his bridal body, Eve. The two bodies were one flesh. Jointly, the man and woman were
called Adam (Gen 1:26-28). Eve was created to be a co-ruler with her husband. But how can the Bride be
composed of non-rulers when her typological counterpart was created to co-rule? I do not believe that it can.
Christ’s co-ruling body cannot be composed of non-ruling saints.
        Paul does not explicitly mention the clothing of the Bride in this passage. Nonetheless, the clothing is
merely symbolic of moral purity that Paul does mention in Eph 5:27. Additionally, Paul refers to clothing in Eph
4:24, where he urges the believers to be clothed with the new self in righteousness and holiness. Sapaugh notes this
fact as well when he says concerning Mt 22:11,

       The banquet of Rev 19:7-9 is also the only other eschatological wedding celebration in the NT where
       the clothing worn by the participants is mentioned. The wedding clothes of Matt 22:11 correspond to
       the clothes worn by the bride at the wedding of the Lamb in Rev 19:8. She is said to be clothed in
       “fine linen, clean and bright” (NKJ). Further, this fine linen is described as the “righteous acts of the
       saints” (NKJ). This is in definite contrast to the man without the garment in Matt 22:13, who did not
       make himself ready.…
            The most reasonable conclusion is that the wedding garment is a figure for righteous living.
       (Emphasis his.)1061

Then in a footnote to this material, he adds,

       In the Pauline system, the wedding garment of good works is expressed in a passage like Eph 4:22-
       24. There Paul exhorts the Ephesian believers to put off the corrupt old man, be renewed, and “put on
       the new man, which was created according to God in righteousness and true holiness” (v 24). The
       Greek verb for “put on” is endyo [enduo], which is the same word here in v 11 (“clothed”).
       (Emphasis his.)1062
Page 588                                                                                      The Outer Darkness
Therefore, Paul does urge believers to clothe themselves in a manner that is consistent with the misthological
imagery used concerning the wedding garments. Paul also uses this same verb (enduo) in 1Thess 5:8-9, where he
urges believers to clothe themselves with faith, hope, and love in order that they may obtain co-glorification
salvation. Only those believers who so clothe themselves will obtain these special benefits.
                                          Illustration 202. Biblical Bride




Conclusion
       In conclusion to this discussion of the marriage supper and its participants, FG interpreters typically
understand the outer darkness as being a place and/or experience for unfaithful believers. Some of these
interpreters are considerably more extreme than others. Hodges, Dillow, and Wilkin represent the conservative
view, which is more traditional in its understanding of the kingdom, tears, Bride, Gehenna, and the church. Other
FG interpreters, such as the present writer, prefer a more misthologically consistent view in which all the
participants in the wedding are limited to overcomers. If the participants must be clothed appropriately, then
certainly the Bride must also be clothed appropriately. Thus, the Bride is composed only of overcomers. The
biblical Bride of Christ is clothed in a white wedding dress, not in a bikini. My conclusion that the Bride is a
misthological concept is (1) consistent with the wedding imagery in Matthew; (2) is implied by the bridal imagery
in Pauline thought; (3) is indicated by the Pauline doctrines regarding clothing, presentation, and blamelessness;
and (3) is demanded by the wedding imagery in Revelation. Therefore, the misthological bridal position has been
adopted herein.
Chapter 25. The Bride                                                                                                     Page 589
                                              Illustration 203. Bridal Misthology




                                                                                                                Calvinist
                                                      In
                                                        Kingdom




       The above illustration pictorially restates an earlier illustration,* depicting the horizontal soteriological axis
intersecting a vertical misthological axis. Between the polar soteriological opposites of Arminianism and
Calvinism lies the Marrowistic affirmation of unconditional eternal security for the regenerate believer. Various
misthological divergences are discernible though, even within the Marrowian camp. At the conservative end of the
misthological spectrum, there are FG misthologists who consider the outer darkness to be a misthological rather
than soteriological motif. These misthological skotologists† would affirm a metaphorical depiction of believers
being cast into darkness.


*
   For demonstration of the connection between the passages of Scripture being discussed with each other and Eph 5:27, see
Illustration 151. What is a Classic Moderate Misthologist?, 458.
†
  Skotology is a coined term derived from the Greek word skotos (darkness) and is used to refer to the study of darkness in the NT. A
misthological skotologist correspondingly would be one who finds darkness being misthologically applied punitively to believers in
the outer darkness context.
Page 590                                                                                         The Outer Darkness
       Some misthologists are more aggressive (or should I say consistent) in their misthology and likewise
consider the Bride of Christ to be a misthological theme as well. This approaches a more moderate misthological
view. Thus, bridal misthology would be regarded as a conservative-moderate (i.e., progressive-moderate) position.
Moving a little further down the vertical misthological axis, one comes to what I technically have defined as the
classical moderate position—the misthological spatial exclusion from the kingdom. Such misthological
exclusionists would contend that unfaithful believers might fail to enter the millennial kingdom at all.
       The woman pictured as crying in the outer darkness in the above diagram summarizes the probable sequence
of events. As Chumney relates, those who weep and gnash their teeth at the Bema will do so “when they realize
they will not be [a part of] the Bride of Christ” and are “cast into ‘the outer darkness.”1063 Since he believes that
Lk 13:27-28 describes carnal Christians, he is thereby advocating a moderate view in which unfaithful believers
are not only excluded from the bridal suite but from the kingdom as well.
       Moving to the lower end of the misthological spectrum, we come to the ultraists. This is a rather extreme
misthological position in which it is claimed that unfaithful believers are not only excluded from the kingdom, they
are also thrown into the literal fires of metaphysical Gehenna. Those in this camp would tend to be ultra
skotologists—taking even the darkness in Jude 1:13 to be a literal misthological fate for believers during the
millennium.
       As noted above, the position adopted herein is that the outer darkness is a misthological concept.
Correspondingly, it would be inconsistent to affirm that all believers will compose the Bride since those in the
outer darkness are excluded from the wedding. However, those cast into the outer darkness were not cast outside of
the kingdom, so the affirmation of the misthological nature of the outer darkness does not necessarily lead one to
believe that subcomers are excluded from the kingdom. Nevertheless, it is possible to accommodate the classical
moderate view concerning kingdom exclusion to a limited extent, when that kingdom is viewed dynamically as an
experience rather than spatially as a mere place. Notwithstanding, I have not made concession to the ultraist
concerning the literal fires of Gehenna.
       For my part, I might be described as a kingdom exclusionist in the experiential sense of the word but not in
the spatial sense of the word. Unfaithful believers will be excluded from the kingship but not from the kingdom.
They will be subjects of the kingdom rather than the queens of the kingdom. The bridal queen will be composed
only of faithful believers. Nonetheless, normally I would not refer to myself as a kingdom exclusionist but as a
kingship exclusionist.
